title: Bloggingheads: Battleship Hillary
description:
Journalists Michael Tomasky (l), of Guardian America, and Byron York (r), of the National Review, on whether Hillary Clinton's rivals can find a vulnerability.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: New McCain Ad: Guts
description: Senator John McCain has a new ad out in New Hampshire, portraying him as a corruption-busting, responsible fiscal steward. But it also contains perhaps one of the closest brushes with commercial confrontation, flashing pictures of two Republican opponents, former Massachusetts Governor Mitt Romney, former New York Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, alongside those of two Democratic opponents, Senator Hillary Clinton of New York and former Senator John Edwards of North Carolina, as an announcer says, All of the candidates say theyll stop wasteful spendingone man has actually done it, and as the spot switches to a shot of Mr. McCain sitting at a desk.

title: Writers Break Off Contract Talks
description: Reuters reports:

title: 10-Year-Old With Matches Started a California Wildfire
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 31  A 10-year-old boy admitted that he accidentally started one of the largest of last weeks Southern California wildfires while playing with matches, enforcement officials say.

title: Child Health Care Bill Advances in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  The Senate moved on Wednesday to take up a bill providing health insurance for 10 million children, just hours after President Bush said he would veto the legislation because it called for a massive tax increase.

title: Green Grocers (and Bakeries)
description: Most people probably would not associate having a sweet tooth with saving the planet. But the owners of the Little Cupcake Bake Shop would respectfully like you to know that they are part of the solution.

title: Striving Hard to Recover From a September Morning
description: Memory tends to blur sharp edges. But Sept. 11, 2001, remains a jagged obsidian crag thrusting through the veil that usually descends on the recent past. It is still hard to know how to deal with a single event that looms so large and yet was so isolated. The musical Crossing Brooklyn, by Jenny Giering and Laura Harrington, which opened on Sunday at the Connelly Theater, takes on the subject and stirs in the process a lot of memories for anyone who was in New York on that day. But the show remains an uneasy synthesis in which real life keeps tearing at the illusion that art strives to uphold.

title: Actor Is Sentenced
description: Lane Garrison, 27, who played David Apolskis, a k a Tweener, in the Fox television series Prison Break, was sentenced yesterday in Los Angeles to three years and four months in prison, The Associated Press reported. In May he pleaded guilty to vehicular manslaughter without gross negligence, driving under the influence of alcohol and providing alcohol to a minor. In December he was driving when he lost control and crashed into a tree, killing Vahagn Setian, a 17-year-old high school student, and injuring two other passengers, 15-year-old girls. Mr. Garrison could have been sentenced to seven years.

title: Girardi Introduced as Yankees Manager
description: Joe Girardi said today that the Yankees may not be ready to win a World Series yet, because the team does not have all the pieces it needs. But he said that is the ultimate goal.

title: Tough Young-Offender Law Is Set Back in Rhode Island
description: BOSTON, Oct. 31  The Rhode Island legislature has voted to repeal a four-month-old law under which 17-year-old offenders were treated as adults in the criminal justice system.

title: Fresh-Faced Eco-Consumers
description: FOR many customers in the Whole Foods Market on the Lower East Side last Friday night, just spotting the word organic on recycled packaging would have been reason enough to grab a bottle of moisturizer. But not Erin Schrode, 16, a founder of Teens for Safe Cosmetics, a nonprofit in Marin County, Calif. She was there to play host to a rally-cum-marketing-event she had organized with her mother, Judi Shils, the groups executive director.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q. How do I choose a deep color for my bedroom that will look dramatic, not depressing?

title: Merck Buys License to Sell New Vaccine for Hepatitis
description: Merck has licensed the exclusive worldwide rights to sell a new, potentially more powerful vaccine against hepatitis B from Dynavax Technologies Corporation, a biotechnology company that is exploiting new findings about how the immune system works.

title: Nominees Stand May Avoid Tangle of Torture Cases
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  In adamantly refusing to declare waterboarding illegal, Michael B. Mukasey, the nominee for attorney general, is steering clear of a potential legal quagmire for the Bush administration: criminal prosecution or lawsuits against Central Intelligence Agency officers who used the harsh interrogation practice and those who authorized it, legal experts said Wednesday.

title: The Yes, No and Maybe on Drivers Licenses
description: In the Democratic debate on Tuesday night, Tim Russert, the moderator, tried to pin down Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on letting illegal immigrants obtain drivers licenses:

title: Staph at the Gym? Not if Youre Careful
description: THE news has been scary: a virulent strain of methicillin-resistant staphylococcus aureus, or MRSA, a staph bacterium usually associated with hospitals and nursing homes, has been surfacing in other settings. In the last month, schools across the country have reported outbreaks, some of them deadly.

title: Paul W. Tibbets Jr., Pilot of Enola Gay, Dies at 92
description: Brig. Gen. Paul W. Tibbets Jr., the commander and pilot of the Enola Gay, the B-29 Superfortress that dropped the atomic bomb on Hiroshima in the final days of World War II, died today at his home in Columbus, Ohio. He was 92.

title: The F.C.C. and Cable Companies
description: To the Editor:

title: Torre Is Close to Finalizing Contract With Dodgers
description: When the Yankees made a trade with the Los Angeles Dodgers on July 31, the Dodgers had a slightly better record. But the Yankees stormed through the rest of their regular season, and the Dodgers limped to an 82-80 finish.

title: Russia Sets Limits on Foreign Vote Monitors
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 31  The system of international monitoring intended to ensure clean elections in the states of the former Soviet Union appeared near collapse on Wednesday after Russia formally declared that it would sharply cut the number of observers for it parliamentary elections in December. Officials in charge of the monitoring mission refused to agree to the change.

title: Aleksandr Feklisov, Spy Tied to Rosenbergs, Dies at 93
description: Col. Aleksandr Feklisov, a Soviet spy whose long career included directing the intelligence-gathering of Julius Rosenberg, who was convicted of espionage and executed in 1953, and acting as an intermediary between the White House and the Kremlin during the 1962 Cuban missile crisis, has died. He was 93.

title: Browne Sanders Is an Inspiration After Winning a Lawsuit
description: Since winning her sexual-harassment lawsuit against the men who run the Knicks, Anucha Browne Sanders has talked to Anita Hill, been feted by Billie Jean King and galvanized women who are not famous but whose workplace horror stories are familiar.

title: Victims Wife Says City Is Improperly Withholding Girl
description: The lawyer for a woman whose estranged husband was shot dead on a Queens playground on Sunday argued yesterday that the city was improperly keeping her 4-year-old daughter from her.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article yesterday about a fatal fire in Queens that killed Renee Chong, a New York City correction officer, and her two young sons misstated the year that she was promoted to captain. It was 2000, not 1988. (She joined the Correction Department in 1988.)

title: A Rate Cut by the Fed, but a Sense It Stops Here
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  The Federal Reserve gave investors what they wanted on Wednesday, lowering short-term rates for the second time in two months. But it pointedly warned Wall Street not to assume that more reductions were ahead.

title: A Concussion Could End Coless Streaks
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Oct. 31  The gap between Laveranues Coles and Terrence McGee closed almost instantly. Coles turned back toward the football, away from the defender, and cradled his only catch of the game last Sunday. A split-second passed, McGee gathered momentum, and ... BOOM.

title: Surge Will Be Brief, Economists Say
description: The economy expanded faster than expected in the third quarter, led by a surge in consumer spending and export sales, the government reported yesterday. But economists said the good news would not last.

title: Tip of the Week: Check Spelling Automatically
description: Do you often forget to proofread your outgoing Outlook messages? Recent versions of the commonly used Microsoft program include an option to check the spelling automatically in a message before you send it. Just go to the Tools menu to Options, then click on the Spelling tab. Put a check in the box next to Always check spelling before sending and click the O.K. button.

title: Lazard Says It Doubled Earnings in Quarter
description: Lazard, the investment bank run by Bruce Wasserstein, more than doubled its profits for the third quarter this year, buoyed by sharp gains in its fees for advising on deals.

title: Playing Sudans Game
description: After four years of genocidal massacres that have killed more than 200,000 people, the Darfur region of Sudan desperately needs a peace agreement and a robust multinational force to carry it out. Regrettably, this weeks internationally sponsored peace conference in Libya is doing little to meet those urgent needs.

title: Ex-Prosecutor Acquitted of Misconduct in 9/11 Case
description: DETROIT, Oct. 31  A former federal prosecutor was found not guilty on Wednesday of charges that he illegally withheld evidence from defense lawyers in the first major terrorism case that the Justice Department brought after the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A dance review yesterday about Ice Theater of New York, at the Sky Rink at Chelsea Piers, misstated the title of David Liu, who choreographed a competition routine. He is the companys co-artistic director, not artistic director. (Moira North, who founded the company, is the artistic director.)

title: Analyst Raises Doubts About Citigroup Dividend
description: A longtime banking analyst said late last night that Citigroup may be forced to cut its dividend or sell assets to stave off what she said was a $30 billion capital shortfall, moves that could pull down its shareholder returns for several years.

title: New Details Are Released in Death of Gotbaum
description: When Noah Gotbaum was told that his wife, Carol, had died in police custody at the Phoenix airport on Sept. 28, he responded with anger.

title: Panel Criticizes Army Contracting for Troops
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  An independent panel has sharply criticized the Army for failing to train enough experienced contracting officers, deploy them quickly to war zones like Iraq and Afghanistan and ensure they manage billions of dollars in contracts to supply American troops in the field, according to officials briefed on the panels findings.

title: Two Hard Drives Double Your Fun
description: Q. I saw a new laptop for sale with two hard drives  why is that? What is the advantage?

title: Seasonal Stress Test Is Starting for Knicks
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Oct. 31  The next-to-last practice of a historically awful off-season was winding down early Wednesday afternoon, and Coach Isiah Thomas stood at midcourt, sharing a ferocious belly laugh with Jamal Crawford as the Knicks slowly dispersed. The snapshot, brief as it was, belied the immense stresses bearing down on Thomas and his franchise.

title: Mexico: Floods Batter Tabasco State
description: Four days of steady rain in the Gulf Coast state of Tabasco has caused rivers to overflow their banks, leaving vast areas of the state capital, Villahermosa, underwater. Newspaper photos showed cars underwater and parts of the city turned into a vast lake, and Gov. Andrs Granier appealed to residents of the citys central district to leave their homes. He said that as many as 400,000 people around the state had been affected by the flooding and that river levels were continuing to rise. Some 20,000 people have been moved to shelters.

title: Ex-Prosecutor Innocent of Withholding Evidence
description: DETROIT, Oct. 31  A former federal prosecutor today was found not guilty of charges that he illegally withheld evidence from defense lawyers in the first major terrorism case brought by the department after the Sept. 11 terror attacks.

title: Burmese Monks March Again Ahead of Visit by U.N. Envoy
description: BANGKOK, Thursday, Nov. 1  A small group of Buddhist monks held a protest march in Myanmar on Wednesday in the first significant public show of defiance since troops crushed a pro-democracy uprising a month ago.

title: Biologists for Agency Endorse Dams Plan
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31  Federal fisheries officials in Seattle on Wednesday endorsed, with minor modifications, a plan for the governments continued operation of the hydroelectric dams on the Columbia and Snake Rivers. They said it did not jeopardize the survival of 13 stocks of salmon and steelhead that the government must protect under the Endangered Species Act.

title: F.T.C. to Review Online Ads and Privacy
description: Whitney Chianese was exchanging e-mail messages with her mother a few weeks ago, discussing the recent death of her grandmother, when advertisements for health care products began popping up on her computer screen.

title: Corrections
description: Editors' Note

title: Foreign Service Officers Resist Mandatory Iraq Postings
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  Career Foreign Service officers at the State Department reacted angrily at a town hall meeting on Wednesday to the possibility that they might be forced to go to Iraq, putting senior Bush administration officials on the defensive.

title: A Washington Monument: Her Life and Bold Times
description: Stacy A. Corderys Alice is by no means the first biography of Americas most famous, rambunctious and press-baiting first daughter. But its the first such book in 20 years. And according to Ms. Cordery it is the first full biography of Alice Roosevelt Longworth based on her personal papers.

title: Everybody vs. Hillary
description: Hillary Clinton stood on a stage for two hours Tuesday night, being yelled at by six men. Now this is what they mean by pressure. The most important job in the world is at stake and every single one of the other candidates walked into the presidential debate gunning for her. They began piling on from the first question. She took it all and came out the other end in one piece. Shes one tough woman. Kudos.

title: A Quake in the Bay Area Raises Concerns
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31  An earthquake rattled the Bay Area on Tuesday night, and in many ways it was just a pre-Halloween scare that did little damage, injured no one and barely merited a break-in to prime time broadcasting.

title: Wrights Late Scoring Spree Helps Get Nets Party Started
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 31  Antoine Wright spent countless hours in a Las Vegas gym this summer working on his game. Still, the Nets decided last week to pass on his fourth-year option, meaning he will become a free agent after this season.

title: How Do You Ski if There Is No Snow?
description: PARIS  Global warmings foes rarely cite ski resorts and golf courses among its victims.

title: Fool's Errand? Send Me.
description: As he was preparing to write his business column for PLAY Magazine, about the escalation of spending by college football programs (Skybox U), Joe Nocera found himself admiring those who were fighting the fight against the spiraling costs that Nocera says have made football too dominant in university life. Theyre clinging to an idealistic notion of sports, and Im fundamentally in favor of that, Nocera told me. I do think in American life that college sports should be downplayed. Still, its a little too Don Quixote-ish, and just unrealistic.

title: The Philharmonics Asian Itinerary
description: The New York Philharmonic yesterday announced the stops on its Asian tour from Feb. 11 through 24: Taipei and Kaohsiung on Taiwan and Hong Kong, Beijing and Shanghai in China. The orchestra is still considering an extension of its tour to North Korea. Lorin Maazel, the music director, will conduct works by Barber, Beethoven, Brahms, Dvorak, Elgar, Mendelssohn, Mozart, Rossini and Tchaikovsky. On Feb. 18 in Hong Kong, Xian Zhang, associate conductor, will share the podium with Mr. Maazel, leading works by Mozart and Richard Strauss.
Manhattan

title: All Dressed Up
description: AT J. Roaman, a home furnishings store in East Hampton, N.Y., a painted white iron bed wears a giant charm bracelet over its left head post. The bracelet isnt there because the bed wants for visual interest; its already enveloped in a brightly colored quilt by Lisa Corti, a Milanese designer, and topped with four pillows, five throw pillows and a bolster. The reason for the jewelry, according to Judi Roaman, a former fashion retailer who opened the store in May, is that furniture, like any carefully curated outfit, should express its owners personality. Accessories make the bed into who you want her to be, she explained.

title: Analyst Says Citigroup Needs to Cut Its Dividend
description: A long-time banking analyst said last night that Citigroup would need to cut its dividend or sell assets to stave off what she said was a $30 billion capital shortfall, moves that could pull down its earnings for several years.

title: Her Life Coach Comes From Another Lifetime
description: Barbara, the heroine of Spain, a new play by Jim Knable at the Lucille Lortel Theater, has an unusual pest problem. Shes got a conquistador infestation in her living room. A real, live Spanish adventurer from the 16th century has plopped himself down on her couch  battered armor, blood-spattered sword and all  and he wont take his grimy boots off the coffee table. Whom do you call in this kind of urban emergency? 311?

title: Saudi Arabias King Hits a Few Bumps in His Visit to Britain
description: LONDON, Oct. 31  First, King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia chastised his host, the British government, for not doing enough to combat terrorism. Then the acting leader of Britains Liberal Democrat Party announced that he was boycotting ceremonial events for Abdullah to protest his countrys human rights policy. Then the mayor of London criticized British officials for bending over backwards, desperate to win arms deals with the Saudis.

title: Survivor of Steam Blast, in Pain, Relives Escape
description: By the time he woke up, the summer had passed. Days and weeks he couldnt remember had been crossed off the calendar hanging on the wall of his hospital room.

title: Sam Dana, 104, Oldest Former N.F.L. Player, Is Dead
description: Sam Dana, the oldest former National Football League player, who emerged as a celebrity of sorts four years ago when he was found to be alive  contrary to reports in the football record book  died Monday in Kenmore, N.Y., outside Buffalo. He was 104.

title: Renewal in Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Stories of Arabian Nights and a Dystopian New York
description: The mother of all storytellers, Scheherazade is the central character in 1001 but she doesnt stay Scheherazade for long. In Jason Grotes kaleidoscopic reinvention of the 1001 Nights tales, she morphs into Dahna, a contemporary Palestinian graduate student in New York, just as Scheherazades husband, the wife-killing Shahriyar, becomes Dahnas Jewish boyfriend, Alan, and her sister Dunyazade becomes Dahnas sister, Lubna. Moving fluently back and forth from the Arabian Nights of legend (complete with jeweled turbans and scimitars) to New York in a dusty, apocalyptic near-future, these stories within stories come to include Flaubert during his wild-oats days in Egypt and even a cameo appearance by Jorge Luis Borges, the master of labyrinthine fictions.

title: The Cause Was Admirable, and So Was Declarers Play
description: The Carol J. Rostad Memorial Bridge Tournament, played Oct. 20, was won by a husband-and-wife partnership, Christal Henner-Welland and Roy Welland. They did well on the diagramed deal. The auction was predictable. Since Roy Welland (South) had seven points, he was right to act over Easts takeout double, and one no-trump was the only option. West would have liked to bid with his seven-count, but his only four-card suit had been bid by his left-hand opponent, and to have made a penalty double would have been aggressive.

title: Bomb Kills 8 on Bus in a Central Russian City
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 31  A bomb exploded on a bus during the morning rush in a central Russian city on Wednesday, killing at least 8 people and wounding about 50 in what may have been a terrorist attack, local officials said.

title: Haunted Inn Draws Horde of Believers
description: NEW LONDON, Conn.

title: Ex-F.B.I. Agents Trial Fizzles, as Does Witness
description: Prosecutors said they would drop the murder case against a retired Federal Bureau of Investigation supervisor, a law enforcement official said yesterday, after a reporter upended the trial with taped interviews showing that their main witness, a gangsters mistress, had changed her account and damaged her credibility.

title: Biden-Giuliani Smackdown Enlivens Campaign Trail
description: In addition to the headline-grabbing Edwards-Obama-Dodd tag-team match with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, the Democratic debate Tuesday night in Philadelphia had a pretty lively undercard: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. vs. Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: An Unanswered Question: Who Follows Mubarak?
description: CAIRO, Oct. 31  An old joke here goes something like this: President Hosni Mubarak is on his deathbed when an aide comes to his side and says, Mr. President, arent you going to give a farewell speech to the people? The president opens his eyes and replies: Really? Why? Where are the people going?

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Replacement Trees

title: Looking for Details on College Loans
description: Pursuing an initial inquiry into abuses in the student-loan industry, the Education Department said it had sent letters to 55 colleges and 23 lenders, asking for details of the colleges relationships with lenders. The 55 are winnowed down from an initial round of 921 colleges that were questioned last spring and process many federally backed loans. At 48 of the colleges, a single lender holds 95 percent of the loans. Additionally, the department is publishing final rules today in The Federal Register that first proposed in June, barring gifts from lenders to universities, including travel and other perks.

title: Little Progress in Hollywood as Contract Expires
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 31  With the clock running out on the contract between Hollywoods writers and producers Wednesday, negotiators made little progress toward a new deal, and both sides prepared for a strike that could begin as early as Friday.

title: Ballet Theaters Season
description: Besides the world premiere on June 3 of a work choreographed by Twyla Tharp to a score by the film composer Danny Elfman, the American Ballet Theater will present a revival of Harald Landers tudes and Ronald Hynds Merry Widow, as well as six other full-length ballets: Le Corsaire, Swan Lake, Don Quixote, The Sleeping Beauty, La Bayadre and Giselle. The Orange County Performing Artscenter, which co-commissioned Ms. Tharps untitled dance, will present its West Coast premiere on Aug. 6. The American Ballet Theater season will begin with a gala on May 19 and continue through July 12.

title: Washoe, a Chimp of Many Words, Dies at 42
description: She spent her early years playing in the backyard of a small house in Reno, Nev., learning American Sign Language from the scientists who adopted her, and by age 5 she had mastered enough signs to capture the worlds attention and set off a debate over nonhuman primates ability to learn human language that continues to this day.

title: A Faster Generation of Wireless Routers, Operating on 2 Levels
description: The convenience of Wi-Fi wireless networking has created a thirst for faster home networks. Of course, device makers are happy to oblige. The latest routers are able to work in two parts of the wireless spectrum at once to increase speed and range.

title: Cash Flurry Halts Traffic on L.I. Road
description: Two Suffolk County auxiliary police officers driving on patrol in Stony Brook, N.Y., came upon a bewitching sight yesterday morning.

title: Adultery, Blood, Guts and Samurai
description: What happens when you cross Kabuki and punk rock? In Drum of the Waves of Horikawa, a co-production of the Theater of a Two-Headed Calf and the Here Arts Center, you get something loud (duh), lively and exploratory, but you also get a confused mishmash.

title: Swastika Painted on Columbia Professors Door
description: A swastika was found spray-painted on a Jewish professors office door yesterday morning at Teachers College at Columbia University, the second time in less than a month that one of the colleges professors has been the target of bias.

title: Bounty Show Is Suspended
description: The cable channel A&E has suspended production on the popular show Dog the Bounty Hunter after the shows star, Duane Dog Chapman, was said to have been overheard expressing racist insults in two recorded phone calls.

title: Immigration Is Fodder for Clinton Rivals
description: It was a moment that crystallized Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons struggles in Tuesday nights debate. Questioned about a plan to grant drivers licenses to illegal immigrants, Mrs. Clinton at first seemed to defend it, then suggested she was against it, until finally, pressed for a direct answer, she accused the moderator, Tim Russert, of playing gotcha.

title: Documentarian Greenspan Ready for Beijing Olympics
description: Bud Greenspan is looking toward the Beijing Summer Games next year to create another documentary that chronicles the inspiring side of the Olympics. He has been writing, producing and directing these films for so long that the moniker Olympic documentarian sticks to him like the glasses that are always perched on his bald dome.

title: Richardson: Ill Never Mislead You
description: This advertisement for Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico, a Democrat, began running this week in Iowa.

title: A New Jersey Crime Storys Hollywood Ending
description: WEST CALDWELL, N.J., Oct. 31  It was the early 1970s, and every week nearly four dozen American soldiers were returning home from Vietnam in flag-draped coffins. Frank Lucas, who ruled a crime empire in Newark and Harlem, had a plan: smuggle the purest Asian heroin he could find into New York, stashed inside those coffins.

title: Pumpkin Lights the Way
description: With a special appearance by Charlie Brown and an unexpected exit on Dancing With the Stars, ABC earned the most viewers over all on Tuesday. Nielsens estimated that the autumn perennial Its the Great Pumpkin, Charlie Brown drew 11.4 million viewers at 8 p.m., almost 5 million more than last week, when Cavemen and Carpoolers were programmed in the time slot. This wasenough to put ABC on top in the hour among adults 18 to 49. At 9, ABCs Dancing With the Stars attracted the nights largest audience (18.6 million), but the shows studio audience booed the announcement that Sabrina Bryan would be sent home. The runner-up with 17.2 million viewers, Foxs House at 9, delivered the nights top ratings in the 18-to-49 group. CBS ranked third over all behind both Fox and ABC, leading the 8 p.m. hour in total viewers with NCIS (16.3 million). NBC was fourth, struggling early with Singing Bee at 8 (5.8 million) followed by a 90-minute Biggest Loser at 8:30 (6.3 million). At 10 NBCs rerun of Law & Order: Special Victims Unit (8.7 million) finished second to ABCs Boston Legal (11.8 million) but ahead of CBSs Cane (8.1 million).

title: On the Farm, a Rat Race in Sheeps Clothing
description: Warnerville, N.Y.

title: Looks It Not Like the King? Well, More Like Burton
description: Now you see him; now you dont. And, oh, the frustration of it.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about a fire in a North Carolina beach house in which seven college students died misidentified the contributing reporter from Columbia, S.C., where six victims attended the University of South Carolina. She is Katie Jones, not Jackie Alexander.

title: A $500,000 Prize Motivates a Fast Turnaround
description: A marathon may be a physical punishment, but some runners seem to be gluttons. A few have tried to run one each week. Last year, one man ran 50 in 50 states in 50 days.

title: A Little Hope for Amtrak
description: Anyone who has ridden Amtrak lately, especially anyone familiar with rail travel in Europe or Japan, should be able to see that it needs help. Congress is considering a bill to significantly increase funding for the nations only passenger railroad. The bill would be a welcome step, but even if it passes, Amtrak  badly underfunded compared with air and auto travel  could use a lot more support.

title: Wal-Mart Wants to Carry Its Christmas Ads Beyond Price
description: THE possibility that consumers will hesitate to spend for the holidays is worrying retailers as the Christmas shopping season gets under way. Wal-Mart, the nations No. 1 merchant, is starting its big holiday advertising campaign today with an upbeat appeal that seeks to elevate saving money from a necessity to a virtue.

title: Afghanistan at the Brink
description: KABUL, Afghanistan

title: Census Reveals Fear Over Neighborhoods
description: Nearly half the nations children live in places where their parents fear that neighbors may be a bad influence, and one-third or more of black and Hispanic children are generally kept inside their homes because their neighborhoods are considered too dangerous.

title: Key Senators Raise Doubts on Eavesdropping Immunity
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  The leaders of the Senate Judiciary Committee said Wednesday that they had serious concerns about a plan for legal immunity to phone carriers that participated in the National Security Agency domestic eavesdropping program after the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Giants Defense Waits for a Midseason Test
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 31  Steve Spagnuolo can laugh about it now. It was the furthest thing from funny a few weeks ago.

title: By Rail or Road, Travel Costs Rising in New York Region
description: The agencies that operate the buses, trains, tunnels and bridges that spill commuters into Manhattan are in the midst of one of the biggest and most sustained rounds of fare and toll increases in decades.

title: White House Moves to Save Mukasey Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  President Bush went on the offensive today to salvage the nomination of Michael B. Mukasey to be attorney general, declaring that Mr. Mukasey is being mistreated by some senators and that his service is urgently needed while the nation is at war.

title: Veteran Bush Aide Resigns as Envoy to Return to Texas
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  Karen P. Hughes, the close aide whom President Bush brought back for a second stint in his administration, most recently to woo the hearts and minds of the Muslim world, announced her resignation on Wednesday.

title: Bush Names North Dakotan to Head Agriculture Dept.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  President Bush announced Wednesday that he had selected Edward T. Schafer, a former two-term Republican governor of North Dakota, to head the Department of Agriculture.

title: Under the Table, a Walking, Talking Robot
description: Disc-shaped floor cleaners, playful dinosaurs, bouncy mechanical dogs. Personal robots have been popping up in all these forms and more. On the small end of the scale comes the Tomy i-Sobot, a mechanical figure that is 6.5 inches tall and can walk around the floor or tabletop on two motorized legs.

title: Stocks Fall on Exxon Earnings and Citi Woes
description: A bad day on Wall Street got even rougher late in the session today as the Dow Jones industrials closed down more than 360 points, a sell-off set in motion by a weak earnings report from the oil giant Exxon Mobil and concern that Citigroups woes may be worsening.

title: Inflation Rises, and Confidence Falls
description: European inflation accelerated in October more than economists forecast, while confidence in the economy declined, underlining the European Central Banks quandary over whether to raise interest rates. The inflation rate in the 13-nation euro area rose to a two-year high of 2.6 percent, from 2.1 percent in September, the European Unions statistics office in Luxembourg said. That was above the 2.3 percent expected by economists. An index of executive and consumer sentiment fell to a 19-month low of 105.9 in October, according to a separate report.

title: Home & Garden Calendar
description: Design and Society

title: Dream Houses and Wishful Thinkers
description: I DONT own a home. I live under tenuous circumstances in a dilapidated rental apartment in Brooklyn. I still decorate with art from friends, furniture plucked from the street, and piles of books in precarious Dr. Seuss-like stacks.

title: Drivers Can Drive You Crazy
description: Q. I keep getting an error message that includes the statement, The ialmrnt5 display driver has stopped working normally, and my Windows XP computer has to be restarted in order to work. What is causing this?

title: Charges Dropped in F.B.I. Murder Case
description: Roy Lindley DeVecchio, the retired Federal Bureau of Investigation supervisor charged with murder, walked out of court a free man this morning after prosecutors dropped all charges against him in the wake of new evidence that the governments main witness changed her account and may face perjury charges.

title: How to Try a Terrorist
description: Seattle

title: House Close to Dismantling 1872 Statute on Mining
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  The House is expected Thursday to take a major step toward dismantling the last significant law remaining from efforts to settle the American Wild West, an 1872 mining statute that has allowed vast treasures of gold and other minerals to be carted off federal lands without any royalties paid to the government.

title: Canada: Merger of Energy Trusts
description: Penn West Energy Trust, a Canadian energy trust, agreed to acquire Canetic Resources Trust for about 3.6 billion Canadian dollars ($3.8 billion) to cushion the impact of a new tax. The combined trust would have tax pools, or accrued credits used to reduce tax payments, valued at about 5.5 billion Canadian dollars at the end of 2007, according to the statement. Canetics unit holders would receive 0.515 of a Penn West unit and a distribution of 9 cents a Canetic unit before the closing, according to the companies. That values the offer at 15.84 Canadian dollars for each Canetic unit, 7.1 percent above the closing price on Tuesday. Both companies are based in Calgary.

title: Croatian Rocker Draws Anti-Nazi Protests
description: Two concerts by a Croatian rocker scheduled for a Midtown Manhattan church center have ignited protests from Jewish and Serbian groups incensed by shows that they say glorify a puppet Croatian government that collaborated with the Nazis, The Associated Press reported. The focus of fury is Marko Perkovic, who goes by the stage name Thompson (as in the submachine gun) and whose folk-inspired heavy-metal music has drawn crowds in Europe. He has been criticized for a song that uses a slogan employed by the puppet Ustasha regime in World War II, and critics say some of his fans have given the Nazi salute and worn black T-shirts and caps styled after the uniforms of the puppet regime. Mark Weitzman, a spokesman for the Simon Wiesenthal Center, dedicated to fighting anti-Semitism, said that while some of Mr. Perkovics songs have a positive message of patriotism and peace, there is also an element that appears to glorify the regime that collaborated with the Nazis in World War II and that was responsible for thousands and thousands of deaths of Jews, Serbs and other Croats. Similar criticism came from Nenad Milinkovic, president of the board of a Serbian-American church in Manhattan. Mr. Perkovic, 42, said his performances had been misinterpreted. Im a musician, not a politician, he said in June after a concert for 50,000 fans in Zagreb, the Croatian capital. At my concerts I sing about love, God and the homeland  only about that and nothing else. Mr. Weitzman urged Cardinal Edward M. Egan, the Roman Catholic archbishop of New York, to cancel the concerts, at a cultural center operated by the Croatian Church of St. Cyril & Methodius, at 10th Avenue and 41st Street. Joseph Zwilling, a spokesman for the archdiocese, said church officials were investigating but had found nothing to substantiate the accusations. Mr. Perkovics tour is to take him to Toronto; Cleveland; Chicago; Los Angeles; Vancouver, British Columbia; and San Jose, Calif.

title: Repairing Solar Array Is New Focus of Spacewalk
description: Faced with two major problems on the International Space Station, NASA station managers shifted gears yesterday to an audacious effort to save a torn solar array.

title: G.P.S. Isolation
description: To the Editor:

title: Lebanon: Claim Hezbollah Has Rearmed
description: In a report to the United Nations Security Council, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon expressed great concern over information supplied him by Israel that Hezbollah had rearmed to a level higher than before the 2006 Israeli-Hezbollah war in Lebanon. Mr. Ban cited Israeli reports that Hezbollah, the radical Shiite group in southern Lebanon, had installed long-range rockets, shore-to-sea missiles and an air defense unit. He also criticized Israel for continuing to withhold information on the location of an estimated one million unexploded cluster bombs left in southern Lebanon.

title: TV Anytime or Place: The Sequel
description: O.K., its happened: were officially old.

title: Putting It Like a True Parisian
description: THE passage of time may mellow some people, but it does little to alter their sense of style. Consider these self-assured Parisians, captured basking outdoors on a recent autumn afternoon. Sure, most have abandoned the brashness of youth for a more reticent look. But each is assertive just the same, spiking a muted ensemble of ivory, taupe or gray with recklessly high-contrast touches: a scarlet muffler, a saucy fedora or a genteel cardigan in an incongruously girlie shade of pink.

title: Houston Law Firm Sues Kerik for $200,000 in Legal Fees
description: Bernard B. Kerik, the former police commissioner of New York who pleaded guilty last year to state misdemeanor charges and will probably face federal indictment this month, was sued last week by his former lawyers for more than $200,000.

title: Is This It for the It Bag?
description: EVERYONES talking about the bubble, and when it will burst.

title: Torture and the Attorneys General
description: Consider how President Bush has degraded the office of attorney general.

title: Cameron Suspended for Violating Stimulant Policy
description: Mike Cameron yesterday became the second player suspended by Major League Baseball for violating the organizations policy on stimulants.

title: Americas Lagging Health Care System
description: Americans are increasingly frustrated about the subpar performance of this countrys fragmented health care system, and with good reason. A new survey of patients in seven industrialized nations underscores just how badly sick Americans fare compared with patients in other nations. One-third of the American respondents felt their system is so dysfunctional that it needs to be rebuilt completely  the highest rate in any country surveyed. The system was given poor scores both by low-income, uninsured patients and by many higher-income patients.

title: The Me in Team
description: Kobe Bryant and Alex Rodriguez, arguably the two best players in their respective sports, have made moves recently to change teams. Do you see any similarities in their situations, and would you want either one on your favorite team?

title: Circuits: Slick Moves From a Smartphone
description: IPhone who? The new HTC Touch smartphone is borrowing the iPhones vaunted gesture-based interface  changing functions on-screen with the flick of a finger  and bringing it to the familiar confines of Windows Mobile. The Touch, not to be confused with the iPod Touch, is a slim smartphone with a large touch screen. It runs on Sprints broadband-speed wireless network.

title: Union Gives Endorsement to Clinton
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton received the endorsement yesterday of one of the nations largest and most politically active labor unions, the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, which has 1.4 million members.

title: Chrysler to Cut Jobs and Drop Models
description: DETROIT, Nov. 1  Chrysler LLC said today that it would cut up to 10,000 more hourly jobs, eliminate 1,000 salaried positions, and discontinue shifts at five assembly plants in the United States and Canada, in the first major steps under its new private owners.

title: Next Week, and Beyond
description: PLAY Magazine's next issue will be published on March 2, 2008, just in time for baseball, March Madness, and much, much more. Until then, stay up to date with PLAYs unique brand of opinion and observation on the world of sports with our weekly e-mail newsletter. Next week, Will Leitch returns to once again look askance at the top stories in sport.

title: Clinton Returns to Her Alma Mater
description: Wellesley, Mass., Nov. 1Hillary Clinton reached out to young women voters in an emotional return today to her alma mater, Wellesley College, where she said that in so many ways, this all-womens college prepared me to compete in the all-boys club of presidential politics.

title: Real Estate Agent Found Slain in 5th Ave. Home
description: A woman who helped pioneer the punk music scene, influenced the careers of Madonna and the Ramones and went on to become known as a real estate agent to the stars was found bludgeoned to death Tuesday night in her apartment at 965 Fifth Avenue, the police said yesterday.

title: A Writer Who Always Sees History in the Present Tense
description: BERLIN  From Spain recently came news of a proposal by the government to erase all physical signs of the Franco dictatorship, as if by getting rid of the plaques and statues and street names from the old regime the country could rectify and obliterate a past it has preferred not to linger over. Meanwhile Polish voters just threw out a conservative government that wanted to drag up the past by holding job seekers accountable for their dealings under the Communists.

title: Investors Divided on the Feds Rate Cut
description: For stock investors, the Federal Reserve delivered just the right tonic yesterday.

title: Suit Accuses Court Panel of Cover-Up
description: A former lawyer for the state court system, fired in June from her job investigating lawyers charged with misconduct, has charged in a federal lawsuit that supervisors whitewashed some cases for personal or political reasons.

title: Motive Sought in Womans Murder
description: A woman who helped pioneer the punk music scene, influenced the careers of Madonna and the Ramones and went on to become known as a real estate agent to the stars was found bludgeoned to death Tuesday night in her apartment at 965 Fifth Avenue, the police said Wednesday.

title: 7 Are Acquitted in Madrid Bombings
description: MADRID, Oct. 31  The National Court on Wednesday convicted three men of murdering 191 people and wounding more than 1,800 in the 2004 Madrid bombings. But three other men, who were accused of being the organizers, were found not guilty of direct involvement in the attacks, the most deadly carried out by Islamic radicals on European soil.

title: Democrats and Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Garments and 1 Photo at a Time
description: THE fitting room, to those who equate shopping to a religious experience, is a confessional. It is where sins of the flesh are laid bare and penance is made, all too often behind a curtain that doesnt quite close all the way.

title: Energy Expert Sees Hazard in Costly Oil
description: LONDON, Oct. 31  The rapidly growing appetite for fossil fuels in China and India is likely to help keep oil prices high for the foreseeable future, threatening a global economic slowdown, a top energy expert said on Wednesday.

title: Where Art Meets Fashion Meets Celebrity Meets Hype
description: SLUMPED in a rolling chair behind the information desk at the Guggenheim Museum, clutching about him a vast fringed leather coat from Prada, Andr Leon Talley, the Vogue editor at large, emitted a theatrical moan. Where, where, where is Cate Blanchett? said Mr. Talley, elongating the actresss name, not altogether sotto voce, until it became a trans-European bleat, a cry of pain.

title: Health Care for Bridges: A Search for Diagnostic Tools
description: COLTON, N.Y., Oct. 30  The bridge that carries Route 56 over the Raquette River here is so ordinary that it has no name, only a number, 1027260. But for now it is a bridge like no other, studded with instruments like a cardiac patient, giving up secrets that may explain how to keep others from falling.

title: Great Hera! Amazon Trades Her Lasso for Stage Mike
description: As befits the singer best known for playing Wonder Woman, the larger the song, the more lived-in the performance. For Lynda Carter, who made her New York cabaret debut on Tuesday evening at Feinsteins at Loews Regency, that meant taking on Johnny Mercer and Harold Arlens hydra-headed Blues in the Night and wrestling it to the ground.

title: Circuits: A Computer That Works With Google, Not Microsoft
description: Advocates of Linux, the free open-source operating system, like to say that buying a standard-issue computer involves a Microsoft Tax, because you have no choice but to pay for Windows. New versions of Linux and inexpensive hardware like the new Everex gPC TC2502 make that tax avoidable.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Donald Runnicles to Lead Deutsche Oper

title: Salazars (Running) Shoes Still Not Filled
description: It might seem hard to believe, but to find a long-distance runner in America with a household name you have to look back to the early 1980s and Alberto Salazar, the charismatic, three-time winner of the New York City Marathon. Some American runners have performed well since then, but as John Brant, who profiled Salazar in this months PLAY, said earlier this week, The combination of mystique and glamour and drama just hasnt been there.

title: Minaya to Talk to Wright About Rodriguez Interest
description: The conference call was scheduled so that Omar Minaya, the Mets general manager, could announce that Moises Alou and Damion Easley would return to the team. But it also provided the opportunity, when asked about the Mets potential interest in Alex Rodriguez, for perhaps his biggest chuckle of the afternoon.

title: Personal Income and Spending Up in September
description: Personal income and spending continued to grow in September, a government report showed today, suggesting strength in the economy even as analysts fear widespread troubles in the next few months.

title: A Place for Reflection
description: NOT all mirrors are strictly utilitarian, Some have elaborate frames that allow them to function as wall art, while the reflective surface adds an extra dimension to a room. Of course, many decorative mirrors are also useful, particularly in an entrance hall for fixing lipstick or adjusting a necktie on the way out the door.

title: Donald Runnicles to Lead Deutsche Oper
description: Donald Runnicles, right, was chosen yesterday to become the music director of the Deutsche Oper in 2009, The Associated Press reported. Berlins state secretary of culture, Andr Schmitz, said, This appointment is a clear signal of encouragement and awakening for the Deutsche Oper. Mr. Runnicles, the music director of the San Francisco Opera, will join the German company under a five-year contract beginning on Aug. 1, 2009, according to a statement from the Berlin city government, which administers the opera company and two others in the city. He will succeed the Italian conductor Renato Palumbo, who took over the Deutsche Oper last year after Christian Thielemann quit in a dispute with Berlin authorities over financing. Mr. Runnicless tenure in San Francisco will end in 2009, when he will also become the chief conductor of the BBC Scottish Orchestra.

title: Missing Compassion
description: To the Editor:

title: Working-Class Enclave Hopes to Survive in Affluent District
description: GREAT NECK, N.Y.

title: MTV Europe Awards
description: Justin Timberlake will be in the spotlight tonight when the MTV Europe Music Awards, with Snoop Dogg as host, are handed out in Munich, Reuters reported. Named best pop act and best male last year in Copenhagen, Mr. Timberlake, with a leading four nominations, will be pursued by a field, with three nominations each, that includes Amy Winehouse, Avril Lavigne, Beyonc, Fall Out Boy, Linkin Park, My Chemical Romance, Nelly Furtado and Rihanna.

title: Lines, Shapes and Subjects, Lost and Found, That Link the Centuries
description: Its tough to compete with the old masters. Thats one lesson to be gleaned from Drawing Connections, an exhibition at the Morgan Library & Museum in which four contemporary artists display their own works on paper alongside pieces theyve selected from the museums impressive drawing collection. The results do not work to the advantage of the living artists  Georg Baselitz, Ellsworth Kelly, Giuseppe Penone and Dorothea Rockburne  at least not if you judge by the standards of traditional draftsmanship.

title: Text of the Feds Statement on Cutting Interest Rates
description: Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Feds monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, decided to lower interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point:

title: Court Takes Second Look at Enemy Combatant Case
description: RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 31  It seemed like a foregone conclusion that the full United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit would be receptive to the Bush administrations contention that it has the authority to detain people it calls enemy combatants.

title: Wise Laureates (but Not Always)
description: To the Editor:

title: In Rape Case, a French Youth Takes On Dubai
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates, Oct. 31  Alexandre Robert, a French 15-year-old, was having a fine summer in this tourist paradise on the Persian Gulf. It was Bastille Day and he and a classmate had escaped the July heat at the beach for an air-conditioned arcade.

title: Is There Room at the Top for Black Executives?
description: The executives are a study in contrasts. One is a brash risk-taker who bootstrapped his way from an Alabama cotton farm to one of Wall Streets largest brokerage firms. The other made his mark as a consensus builder who leveraged ties to one of Americas most powerful families to eventually lead the worlds largest media company.

title: Putting the New Orleans in the New Orleans Hornets
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 31  The Hornets returned here full time from Oklahoma City on Halloween, only this time costumed fans provided a ghostly presence instead of the team, which has essentially been an apparition in this ruptured city since Hurricane Katrina.

title: Personal Happiness and the Public Sphere
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A classical music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday about the Orchestra of St. Lukes at Carnegie Hall, using information provided by the orchestra, misstated the age of Jay Greenberg, a young composer whose Violin Concerto was played. As a review on Tuesday about the concert noted, he is 15, not 16.

title: Autumns Rituals Beckon Softly
description: LIKE all gardeners, city folks have their own fall rituals. This year, though, those rituals have been delayed by the unusually warm weather.

title: National Briefing: Immigration: Raids Traumatized Children, Report Says
description: Hundreds of young American children suffered hardship and psychological trauma after immigration raids in the last year in which their parents were detained or deported, according to a report by the National Council of La Raza and the Urban Institute. Of 500 children directly affected in three factory raids examined in the report in which 900 adult immigrants were arrested, a large majority were United States citizens younger than 10. With one or both parents deported, the children had reduced economic support, and many remained in the care of relatives who feared contact with the authorities, the study said. Although the children were citizens, few families sought public assistance for them, the study found.

title: Safety Data Is Forthcoming, NASA Chief Tells House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  The NASA administrator told a Congressional panel on Wednesday that his agency would soon release data from tens of thousands of interviews with pilots about safety issues, information that NASA previously said could damage the airline industry.

title: The Feminine Critique
description: DONT get angry. But do take charge. Be nice. But not too nice. Speak up. But dont seem like you talk too much. Never, ever dress sexy. Make sure to inspire your colleagues  unless you work in Norway, in which case, focus on delegating instead.

title: U.S., Stymied 21 Years, Drops Bid to Deport 2 Palestinians
description: The government has reached a settlement in a landmark deportation case, ending an effort of nearly 21 years to expel two Palestinians accused of aiding a militant branch of the Palestine Liberation Organization. The men will be allowed to apply for United States citizenship in three years.

title: Carrie Underwood No. 1
description: With relatively strong sales, Carrie Underwood, above, leads a crop of new albums on the Billboard chart. Carnival Ride (Arista), her second release, sold 527,000 copies in the United States, according to Nielsen SoundScan, one of the better opening-week showings in 2007 and the best for a female artist in three years. Robert Plant and Alison Krausss new Raising Sand (Rounder) sold 112,000 copies to reach No. 2. Gary Allans Living Hard (MCA Nashville) bows at No. 3 with 69,000 sales, just a few hundred more than Serj Tankian of System of a Downs first solo record, Elect the Dead (Reprise). Coheed and Cambria, a New York rock group, reached No. 6 with its new No World for Tomorrow (Columbia) and the South African band Seether opened at No. 9 with Finding Beauty in Negative Spaces (Wind-Up).

title: Rule Jostles Runners Who Race to Their Own Tune
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  At the peak of the marathon season, with one of the years biggest races set for Sunday in New York, a worry has emerged among some runners, and it has nothing to do with hitting the wall at Mile 20: Will Beyonc be there to push them to the finish? Will they be able to call upon Bon Jovi for support when there is no one else to turn to?

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A map in Business Day on Oct. 20 with an article about coal-burning power plants in the United States reversed the symbols indicating proposed power plants and plants under construction. There are 7 coal-burning power plants under construction in the United States, and 47 proposed new plants  not the other way around.

title: $75 Billion Fund Is Seen as Stopgap
description: Nearly three weeks after the countrys biggest banks announced a $75 billion fund to help stabilize the credit markets, the reality is sinking in that the plan will provide hospice care to troubled investment funds, not resuscitate them.

title: Gang Member Is Convicted Under Terror Law
description: In the weeks after Sept. 11, 2001, 36 states enacted laws that would guarantee harsher sentences in terrorism cases. Gov. George E. Pataki signed New Yorks law within six days of the attack. Like the others, it was aimed at international terrorism organizations like Al Qaeda.

title: Locked vs. Unlocked: Opening Up Choice
description: NOKIA, the worlds largest maker of cellphones, has been running ads that read, Open to Anything and Unlock your potential.

title: Economic Balancing Act for Argentinas Next Leader
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 31  The landslide victory of Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner, the wife of Nstor Kirchner, Argentinas current president, seemed to signal that the Peronist party was back and stronger than ever. But the way she won the presidency and the economic challenges she faces will prove a stiff test of her abilities to keep the couple in power.

title: Mr. Jeans Meets Mr. Pants
description: YOU might make some assumptions about Jonathan Rojewski when you hear about his life. A former finance guy, that modern catchall for someone who plays with numbers and wears a suit, Mr. Rojewski, 34, left the world of portfolio management in 2006 and walked into 2007 as the president and a founder of Tanteo Spirits, a premium line of tequila coming out next spring.

title: A French Star Reinvents a New York Classic
description: WHEN Jacques Grange paid his first visit in early September to Galerie Mark, a Manhattan real estate sales office masquerading as an art-and-design gallery, his perennial look of wry amusement was tinged with anxiety.

title: Looking Back at the Mountain
description: Memory can be an odd thing. Nearly four months after Tom Bissell climbed Mount Kilimanjaro, suffering through pounding headaches from altitude sickness, the pain is almost forgotten. The memories that remain, Bissell said this week, are of the good stuff: the camaraderie, the great treatment by the 39 porters and four guides who helped his group, and the amazing views. Any way you cut it, he said, it was breathtakingly beautiful.

title: Jeweler Admits Lying Over Sale
description: A Manhattan jeweler known as the Harry Winston of the hip-hop world who was accused of laundering money for a Detroit-based cocaine ring pleaded guilty yesterday to reduced charges.

title: Figaro Gets a Gaudy Russian Tattoo
description: Classical music is supposedly in a period when national traditions and performance styles are losing their distinctions in an increasingly homogenized musical world. Dont tell that to the Russian conductor Yuri Temirkanov and the players of the St. Petersburg Philharmonic Orchestra.

title: Lottery Numbers
Im Sorry but Youre Spinning on My Machine
description: IF bike 28 is not available, Susan Koeppens entire spinning routine is ruined. If any of the mats in Eva Barashs yoga class are crooked, she cannot continue teaching. And if Pamela Drucker does not find a treadmill on the fourth floor of her gym, then her exercise regimen is pretty well shot.

title: Iraq Asks for Irans Help in Calming Kurdish Crisis
description: BAGHDAD, Oct. 31  Iraqi officials asked for Irans help on Wednesday in negotiating a diplomatic solution to the standoff with Turkey over Kurdish guerrillas who have been using northern Iraq as a base to stage raids on Turkish troops across the border.

title: A Wi-Fi Gadget for Music and Photos, All Wrapped in Leather
description: With todays ever-faster processors of increasing complexity, its good to know that some gadget designers still remember how to have fun. Chumby is a powerful little device with Wi-Fi, a 3.5-inch screen and an interface that you can customize. If you are wondering where the fun lies, it is also covered in leather and has something called a squeeze sensor.

title: Britain: Brewer Steps Up Defense
description: Scottish & Newcastle, fighting a takeover bid from Carlsberg, started arbitration aimed at forcing Carlsberg to give up its stake in a joint venture the companies share in Russia. Scottish & Newcastle said it would ask a Swedish tribunal to confirm breaches by Carlsberg in the ownership agreement for the Russian venture, Baltic Beverages Holdings. Carlsberg, based in Copenhagen, called the move a distraction and said it could take more than a year for the arbitration process to complete.

title: Editors Note
description: An illustration on Sept. 5 with a front-page article about the role the turmoil of the 1960s played in shaping Hillary Rodham Clintons political philosophy showed part of a letter of recommendation that a professor at Wellesley College wrote for her when she applied to Yale Law School.

title: Afghan Force and NATO Battle Taliban in South
description: ARGHANDAB, Afghanistan, Oct. 31  Afghan and NATO forces fought hundreds of Taliban fighters 15 miles outside Kandahar in southern Afghanistan for a second day on Wednesday, according to Afghan and Western officials. A local police commander said 250 Taliban fighters had been surrounded and 50 of them killed just north of the city, but Western military officials said they could not confirm the claims.

title: Corrections: Keeping the Gauge Off E
description: The Personal Best column last Thursday, about strategies for marathoners, misidentified the location of the Hansons-Brooks Distance Project, a group of runners with 13 marathoners competing in the Olympic trials in New York on Nov. 3. It is Rochester, Mich., not Rochester, Minn.

title: Democrats Debate: A Focus on Clinton
description: To the Editor:

title: Bushs Note to Congress: Were at War
description: President Bush took another opportunity to bash the Democrat- controlled Congress today in a speech he delivered on global terrorism, saying that some members are behaving as if America is not at war.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article and picture caption on Friday about an audit by the New York City comptrollers office saying that the Department of Parks and Recreation wasted millions on a golf course project planned for a former landfill in the Bronx misidentified the source of the unpleasant odor at the site. It is hydrogen sulfide and other sulfide gases, not methane. (Methane, another landfill gas, is odorless.)

title: John Woodruff, an Olympian, Dies at 92
description: John Woodruff, whose halting, come-from-behind victory in the 800-meter run in the 1936 Berlin Olympics astonished the sports world and, along with the gold-medal success of Jesse Owens and other black athletes, helped embarrass Adolf Hitler, died Tuesday in Fountain Hills, Ariz. He was 92.

title: Blackwater Mounts a Defense With Top Talent
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  Blackwater Worldwide, its reputation in tatters and its lucrative government contracts in jeopardy, is mounting an aggressive legal, political and public relations counterstrike.

title: Swinging Into Comedy (and Along With Sinatra)
description: Is there another dance in which the peripheries of the stage are more fun than in Twyla Tharps Bakers Dozen? In this elegantly comic jazz ballroom fantasy to music by Willie (The Lion) Smith, which joined American Ballet Theaters repertory on Tuesday night at City Center, people hurtle or shimmy onto the stage and yet are often content to stay a yard or so from the wings, strutting their stuff.

title: Panel Faults Armys Wartime Contracting
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  An independent panel has sharply criticized the Army for failing to train enough experienced contracting officers, deploy them quickly to war zones like Iraq and Afghanistan and ensure that they properly manage billions of dollars in contracts to supply American troops in the field, according to officials briefed on its findings.

title: More Jobs to Be Cut at Alcatel After Loss
description: Alcatel-Lucent, the troubled telecommunications equipment maker, said yesterday that it would cut 4,000 more jobs to reduce costs and announced the departure of its chief financial officer in the wake of its third consecutive quarterly loss.

title: Natural, Organic Beauty
description: FOR Flavia Kawaja, an interior designer in Manhattan, a trip to the beauty department at Whole Foods Market comes not with a shopping list but with a mental list of what synthetic ingredients to avoid.

title: Plan to Use Cellphones as a Reward for Good Schoolwork Begins to Emerge
description: In New York City public schools, cellphones are considered contraband. But free cellphone airtime could be a reward for high-performing students if the city adopts the newest idea from the Education Departments chief equality officer.

title: Veto Likely for a Bill Favoring Workers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (Bloomberg News)  The House of Representatives voted Wednesday for the largest expansion ever of a program to help workers hurt by imports or overseas competition, setting up a fight with President Bush, who has threatened to veto the measure.

title: Greece: Claims of Refugee Abuse
description: The merchant marine minister, George Voulgarakis, ordered an investigation into accusations that the countrys coast guard had systematically mistreated people trying to enter the country illegally and that it had tried to sink boats carrying them. The claims were made this week by the German-based refugee rights group Pro Asyl. Greece detains an estimated 50,000 illegal entrants each year.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Waiting for Revelations on the Slope of Enlightenment
description: At a certain point during an Elisa Monte Dance concert one piece begins to blur into the next. On Tuesday this moment came much closer to the beginning of the two-hour show than the end of it.

title: Selig Allows Dodgers to Bypass Hiring Rules
description: The legacy of Jackie Robinson lives on.

title: For Sale: Odds and Ends of a Life in the Theater
description: Last week Tom OHorgan did something he never thought hed do. He left New York.

title: Ruling Blocks Tribal Casino in Hamptons
description: Blocking a crusade by the Shinnecock Indian Nation for a casino on tribal land in Hampton Bays, a federal judge has ruled that the tribe had lost aboriginal title to the land during Colonial times, and therefore must follow town zoning and building regulations, which forbid casinos.

title: The Keys to Higher Learning
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: No Daily Show? How a Writers Strike Would Affect Online Video
description: Negotiations between the writers union and Hollywood producers broke off Wednesday night as the current contract expired. And both sides prepared for a strike that could start as early as Friday, The New York Times reports.

title: Googles OpenSocial Is Not a Facebook Killer
description: For the last year, Sergey Brin has been campaigning at Google with the slogan features not products in an attempt to reduce the sprawl of the companys eccentric creativity.

title: Martin Puryear
description: A retrospective of the sculptor's work opens on Nov. 4 at the Museum of Modern Art and continues through Jan. 14.

title: Water: H2O=Life
description: A new exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History.

title: Recovering From the Steamroller
description: Can a single loss ever be so damaging that it carries over into the rest of a season, and even into other seasons?

title: GCA of Japan to Acquire Savvian, a Mergers Adviser
description: GCA, a Japanese mergers and acquisitions advisory firm, said on Thursday it would acquire Savvian, a mergers and acquisitions specialist in the United States, for $780 million in stock.

title: Chinese Insurance Agency Has Strong Nasdaq Debut
description: In its Nasdaq trading start Wednesday, CNinsure, a Chinese insurance agency and brokerage, was up as much as 79.6 percent to a high of $28.74 early in the session but hovered around or just above the $25 mark for most of the day. It closed 58 percent above its I.P.O. price at $25.29.

title: Shasta Closes $250 Million Fund
description: Silicon Valleys Shasta Ventures has closed a $250 million venture capital fund to focus on early-stage technology companies.

title: Harmony Tunes Into $28 Million in New Funding
description: Harmony Information Systems has raised $28 million in venture capital. The company, which sells a product that automates paper-based systems mostly for state and local health and human services agencies, previously announced its intent to aggressively expand following its merger this week with Synergy Software Technologies.

title: Clorox to Acquire Burts Bees for $925 Million
description: In a move to capitalize on the growing popularity of natural products, Clorox has unveiled a plan to buy Burts Bees for $925 million.

title: Penn West to Buy Canetic for $3.8 Billion
description: Penn West Energy Trust is to acquire Canetic Resources Trust for $3.8 billion to form an energy giant owning gas pools, oil sands, coal-bed methane, shale gas and enhanced oil-recovery projects.

title: $75 Billion SIV Is Seen as Stopgap
description: Nearly three weeks after the countrys biggest banks announced a $75 billion fund to help stabilize the credit markets, the reality is sinking in that the plan will provide hospice care to troubled investment funds, not resuscitate them.

title: Citi to Buy Rest of Nikko for $4.6 Billion
description: Citigroup has signed an agreement to acquire all of Nikko Cordial, Japans third-largest brokerage, paying about $4.6 billion for the 32 percent it does not already own.

title: China Plans to Open a Market in Stock Futures
description: In an effort to develop a stock futures market that will give investors more options and help them hedge risk, China is planning to introduce stock index futures soon and is ready to approve new quotas for foreign investors in the countrys red hot stock markets.

title: Merrill Lynch Sues Over Racist E-Mails
description: Merrill Lynch is subpoenaing an Internet service provider and Microsoft to identify the sender of explicit racial remarks in e-mail messages to black investment bankers within the company, a spokesman for the investment bank said.

title: More Jobs to Be Cut at Alcatel After Loss
description: Alcatel-Lucent, the troubled telecommunications equipment maker formed from a merger last year, said Wednesday that it would cut 4,000 more jobs to reduce costs and announced the departure of its chief financial officer in the wake of its third consecutive quarterly loss.

title: Despite L.S.E. Ties, Lehman Climbs Aboard Boat System
description: Lehman Brothers, the London Stock Exchanges closest adviser, has joined Boat, a rival trade reporting system that went live Thursday morning.

title: China Railway May Raise $4 Billion in Offering
description: Chinas largest construction company, the China Railway Engineering Group, could raise as much as $4 billion from Shanghai and Hong Kong share sales by next month, Bloomberg News reported citing unnamed sources.

title: Citigroup Buys Hedge Fund Carlton Hill
description: Citigroups alternative investments unit has agreed to buy Carlton Hill Global Capital, a hedge fund specializing in credit derivatives. Carlton Hill was founded last year by two Morgan Stanley alumni, James OBrien and Jonathan Dorfman.

title: Il Sole I.P.O. to Raise 300 Million Euros
description: Il Sole-24 Ore, the publisher of Italys largest financial daily newspaper, is looking to raise about 300 million euros ($433 million) in an initial share offering this month, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Mundra I.P.O. Sells Out in 30 Minutes
description: The first initial public offering by an Indian port gathered bids for almost triple the number of shares on offer in a 17.7 billion rupee ($450 million) sale, Bloomberg News reported.

title: McCain Falls Behind in Wall Street Support
description: Arizona Senator John McCain is getting less financial support from hedge funds, private equity firms, pharmaceutical and oil companies, and other controversial business sectors on his presidential bid than former New York Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and New York Senator Hillary Clinton, The Phoenix Business Journal reported.

title: Evercores Adjusted Profits Rose in 3rd Quarter
description: Evercore Partners, the boutique investment bank, said Thursday that its adjusted pro forma net income was $9.8 million in the quarter ended Sept. 30, up from $8.8 million a year earlier.

title: How to Spiff Up Your Rsum
description: I have invited Susan Strayer to do a guest post on why the rsum above is a recruiters dream. As the corporate director of talent management for the Ritz-Carlton Hotel company and private career coach, Ms. Strayer has reviewed thousands of rsums. She is also the author of The Right Job, Right Now, which was published earlier this year. But before we get started, I have a caveat. I think we are getting to the point where many people (especially entrepreneurial types) wont be using traditional rsums. Instead, they will rely on narrative bios, personal Web sites, or preformatted rsums posted on social networking sites like LinkedIn. But until that time, its wise to have a traditional rsum handy.

title: Cold Cut-Ups
description: Now thats putting the ham in a baloney sandwich. More sandwich art found here.

title: How a Murder Case Abruptly Collapsed
description: Brooklyn prosecutors said they would drop the murder case against a retired F.B.I. supervisor, Roy Lindley DeVecchio, after tapes discredited the main witness, a gangsters mistress. The tapes came to light in a report in The Village Voice by the reporter Tom Robbins that showed that the main witness, Linda Schiro, had changed her account and damaged her credibility.

title: Black Executives Ask: Is There Room at the Top?
description: The executives are a study in contrasts. One is a brash risk-taker who bootstrapped his way from an Alabama cotton farm to one of Wall Streets largest brokerage firms. The other made his mark as a consensus builder who leveraged ties to one of Americas most powerful families to eventually lead the worlds largest media company.

title: Citi May Be Forced to Cut Dividend, Report Says
description: A longtime banking analyst said late Wednesday night that Citigroup might be forced to cut its dividend or sell assets to stave off what she said was a $30 billion capital shortfall, moves that could pull down its shareholder returns for several years.

title: The Science and Art of Shooting Rubber Bands
Financing for Wendys Buyers May Lead to Lower Bids, Report Says
description: Potential suitors for Wendys International have until Nov. 12 to submit bids, and a financing package assembled by its banks could lead to lower offers, The Wall Street Journal reported Thursday in its online edition.

title: Is Nutrition Science Not Really Science?
description: I was hoping to slow the ban-trans-fat cascade by wondering if it would lead to bans of sugar and high-fructose corn syrup  but some readers liked the idea of outlawing those sweeteners. Well, I guess I shouldnt be surprised. But before we pass any more laws on what to eat, I wish wed take a harder look at how often the supposed experts in nutrition have been wrong before.

title: After Write-Down, Credit Suisses Profit Falls 31%
description: Credit Suisse said third-quarter profit at its investment bank was all but wiped out by writedowns, leading to a 31 percent decline in group net earnings to 1.3 billion Swiss francs ($1.12 billion).

title: The Jimmy Cayne Takedown
description: Bear Stearns chief executive James Cayne is apt to be the talk of Wall Street on Thursday, as industry insiders gape over a long, unflattering and at times highly gossipy profile of him in The Wall Street Journal. The account, which tops 3,000 words and makes repeated use of unnamed sources, portrays him as an out-of-touch leader with a penchant for pot smoking who is more interested in his bridge and golf games than tending to his firms recent crises.

title: Wall Street TV Is Primed for Another Season
description: A cable reality show celebrating the lives and lifestyles of Wall Street is coming back for more.

title: The Early Word: Clinton Criticism Continues
description: Criticism of Hillary Rodham Clintons Tuesday night debate performance continued into a second day, prompting her campaign to call it all The Politics of Pile-On.

title: New Edwards Ad: Heroes
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  The John Edwards campaign began broadcasting his first major television advertisement today, a 60-second spot called Heroes portraying him as the voice of working Americans.

title: In Wildfire Case, Age May Make All the Difference
description: Judging by the 115 comments so far, there are a lot of strong feelings about the boy who admitted that he accidentally set one of the smaller wildfires last week in southern California.

title: Too-Free Speech
description: A Baltimore federal jury awarded nearly $11 million Wednesday to the father of a Marine killed in Iraq, deciding that the familys privacy had been invaded by a Kansas church whose members waved anti-gay signs at the funeral, reports the Baltimore Sun:

title: Thursday Morning Kickoff
description: One of the most impressive aspects of Oregons offense, writes ESPN.coms Ivan Maisel, is the speed with which it can get plays off. Thats one of the topics Maisel touches on in his latest edition of I-Formation.

title: Report Sends Citis Stock to Four-Year Low
description: It is quickly turning into a white-knuckle day for Charles O. Prince III.

title: Chaise Longue? Puh-leeze.
description: Simon Winchester kicked-started a genre of sorts when he wrote The Professor and the Madman: A Tale of Murder, Insanity and the Making of the Oxford English Dictionary. Next year, for example, well see Joshua Kendalls The Man Who Made Lists: Love, Death, Madness and the Creation of Rogets Thesaurus  and also the talented Bill Hayess new book The Anatomist: A True Story of Grays Anatomy.

title: Theyre Southbound
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  The Caucus has come down to South Carolina to check out the lay of the political landscape and it turns out there is plenty to check out: So many presidential candidates are visiting here in the next few days, youd think this was Iowa, except theres no corn, or maybe New Hampshire, except here, cell phones work.

title: Have a Flower. Its for the Children.
description: Are those flower-power taxis an advertisement for a new Austin Powers movie or a protest against Iraq? Neither, no matter what stories city residents and taxi drivers are making up about it. As City Room reported in September, its a childrens art project, Garden in Transit.Today, to counter misconceptions about the project, the group responsible, Portraits of Hope, is dispatching schoolchildren to hand out 80,000 sustainable flowers around the city  one for each flower painted on taxis as part of Garden in Transit.
