(The fresh flowers were donated by the Veriflora sustainability program.)

title: I Sing Gooder Than Him
description: Aired Wednesday night on NBC: Well, Dick Cheney had an awkward moment tonight at the White House Halloween party. He went dressed as Darth Vader. And at the party, he ran into the real Darth Vader, who was dressed as Dick Cheney.

title: The Future of Solar-Powered Homes
description: This weekend, at a few minutes past 9 a.m. EST, CBS News Sunday Morning will broadcast my report on this years Solar Decathlon. (This shows stories often get rescheduled at the last moment, but so far its looking good for Sunday.)

title: Performa 07: Scarcity Among the Riches
description: So, most of the various shows happening under the Performa umbrella dont really get going till the end of the week; the bulk of my festival activity the last couple of days consisted of trying to figure out how to see as much as possible on this ridiculous schedule, while still going to everything else I normally see. Allan Kaprows 18 Happenings in Six Parts (Re-doing) in Long Island City, Queens, was proving especially difficult to jam in. Ive been told things that happen in Queens are easy for people who live in Queens to get to, but I remain skeptical.

title: And the Latest Subprime Victim Is . . .
description: Remember the play Six Degrees of Separation, in which it was asserted that every one knew everyone else in the world through no more than six intermediaries?

title: Hotel Tolstoyana
description: If you havent been keeping up with the discussion of Richard Pevear and Larissa Volokhonskys new translation of War and Peace in the Book Reviews Reading Room, todays a good day to check back in  if only to read Bill Keller on translation, journalism, Tolstoy  and the Eagles.

title: Dress Codes | Pants
description: Trousers, slacks, pants: whatever men call them, they aren't saying "jeans" as often.

title: Schreibers Notes: Torres Move Could Set Up Mattingly
description: Murray Chass pointed out yesterday that there is a danger for Joe Torre to keep managing at the age of 67 after a dozen successful years with the New York Yankees.

title: Filling Salazars Running Shoes
description: Even without a name-brand hero to inspire the masses, more than 40 million Americans did some running in 2006, Joseph Plambeck writes in this weeks PLAY newsletter. Gaining entry to the top marathon races, like this weekends New York City Marathon, has become increasingly difficult, requiring a gauntlet of qualifying runs. But many of those who do qualify in marathons dont compete, really  they race against collapse. Would a star raise the competitive stakes, even for amateurs?

title: The Me in Team
description: Kobe Bryant and Alex Rodriguez, arguably the two best players in their respective sports, have made moves recently to change teams. Do you see any similarities in their situations, and would you want either one on your favorite team?Return to PLAY Newsletter

title: Heroes: A Flooded Market?
description: Perhaps recognizing that it can only process so many applications, The Carnegie Hero Commission decided at its founding to focus on one particular kind of hero, the civilian who knowingly risks his or her own life to an extraordinary degree while saving or attempting to save the life of another person.

title: Study Examines Suicide Tourism in New York City
description: Out-of-towners traveling to New York City specifically to commit suicide have accounted for 5.3 percent of city suicides and more than 10 percent of all Manhattan suicides since 1990, according to a new research study. The two highest concentrations of such suicides took place near the George Washington Bridge, in Upper Manhattan, and in the Midtown tourism district, which includes Times Square, the Empire State Building and other skyscrapers, and most of the citys major hotels.Nonresidents committed 21 to 40 suicides in each of those two areas from 1990 to 2004, according to the study, which is to be presented on Monday to the American Public Health Association at its annual meeting in Washington. The research paper [pdf], Suicide Tourism in Manhattan, New York City, 19902004, appears in the November/December issue of The Journal of Urban Health.

title: Biden v. Giuliani, Another Round
description: While you were out trick-or-treating last night, the great Biden-Giuliani debate of 2007 continued apace.

title: The Future of Solar-Powered Homes
description: This weekend, at a few minutes past 9 a.m. EST, CBS News Sunday Morning will broadcast my report on this years Solar Decathlon. (This shows stories often get rescheduled at the last moment, but so far its looking good for Sunday.)

title: Taking a Family Vacation in Christmastime Barcelona
description: We are looking to go to Barcelona between Christmas and New Years (two parents, a 17-year-old and a 20-year-old). Will we run into problems with restaurants, attractions and museums being closed? Where can we find nice accommodations? Thanks for any and all suggestions.

title: Strike Deadline Passes; WGA To Hold Member Meeting Tonight
description: The Writers Guild of America has been forging strike rules, making plans to picket and soliciting support from fellow unions, in anticipation of a strike that could begin as early as Friday, Michael Cieply reports in todays Times.

title: Permanent Art, Evanescent Life
description: Isabella Kirkland, the artist I wrote about who makes intricate paintings in the style of Dutch Masters memorializing natures rarest plants and animals, answered a few lingering questions by e-mail this morning, and her responses are worth sharing.

title: The Secret to Raising the Value of Eyeballs
description: Underscoring all the debates about online privacy, behavioral targeting and Internet advertising is a hard, cold reality: content costs money.

title: The Fragility of Russian Power
description: Russia has always been a power whose ambitions exceeded its capacities. That has made for unfathomable suffering, and more than one collapse.

title: Vince Young Is Shrinking
description: O.K., Titans quarterback Vince Young is still as big as life, but his passing numbers are falling. This isnt a one-game reaction to his 42-yard effort Sunday, either; his passing totals have fallen five games in a row. Take a look:

title: Interview With Barack Obama
description: The following is a transcript of an interview by Michael Gordon and Jeff Zeleny of The New York Times with Senator Barack Obama, conducted on Wednesday afternoon at his campaign headquarters in Chicago. Some of the questions have been edited for brevity and clarity, and extraneous material omitted.

title: Clinton Beefs Up Iowa Operation
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton plans to spend roughly half of November campaigning in Iowa, according to her advisers, and her team continues to staff up there  with a key Washington-based aide heading soon to Des Moines to help run the communications operation.

title: BofA Chief Sees No Investment-Banking Retreat
description: E. Stanley ONeal, until recently the chief executive of Merrill Lynch, is cleaning out his desk. Charles O. Prince III of Citigroup is watching his companys stock price fall. James E. Cayne of Bear Stearns is getting slammed in The Wall Street Journal.

title: Joe Girardi, 32nd Manager of the Yankees
description: Joe Girardi will be introduced, in person, at a press conference thats about to start here at Yankee Stadium. Its pretty crowded.

title: One Year Later, Its a Beautiful Day
description: One year down, one to go, and the Democrats were rocking outside the Capitol this morning, with a DJ spinning the Red Hot Chili Peppers, Bruce Springsteen and, of course, U2s Beautiful Day.

title: Fright Night Scares Off Viewers
description: Halloween festivities took a chunk out of network television audiences on Wednesday, but CBS retained the most viewers overall thanks to Criminal Minds. That show led the night, according to Nielsens estimates, with 14.7 million viewers at 9 p.m.

title: Chrysler and the Fallibility of Private Equity
description: Chryslers statement Thursday that it would cut 11,000 jobs  on top of the 13,000 layoffs it announced in February  came as a surprise to many industry watchers. The market situation has changed dramatically, Chryslers chief executive, Robert L. Nardelli, said.

title: Redskins Campbell and Jets Clemens Can Relate
description: We wrote a story Sunday that looked at teams switching quarterbacks mid-season and wondered how successful those switches generally are. The research showed that teams do not necessarily improve much during the season in which they made the switch, but they do improve markedly the next season.

title: Diller Stands by Home Shopping Network
description: HSN, the home shopping network operated by IAC/InterActiveCorp, is poised to emerge from a period of floundering, the company said yesterday as it released third quarter results.

title: Dutch Deed Fetches More Than a Handful of Beads
description: Back in 1636, a group of Lenape Indians sold a 3,600-acre parcel of land in what is now the Flatlands section of Brooklyn to a pair of Dutch settlers.

title: Taking Hand-Sanitizing to a New Level
description: Antibacteria mania and germ-phobia  twin phenomena in a society increasingly obsessed by cleanliness  have been in full view amid all the public hoopla over MRSA, the drug-resistant staph infection that has caused a public health scare lately.

title: Robert Goulet, Bobby Darin, Andy Williams  and Beefcake
description: Sure, Robert Goulet, who died this week at 73, was every inch the sauve baritone. But of course he was also a game hoofer, as shown in this stripped down song-and-dance with Bobby Darin and host Andy Williams, whose variety shows and specials were big in the 60s and 70s:

title: The First Person to Misplace a Nobel Prize
description: Aired Wednesday night on NBC: Yesterday in Boston, the Red Sox held their World Series parade and an estimated 5 million people turned out. Police said it was the most rowdy drunk people theyve seen in Boston since every other day this year.

title: Renewing the License Debate
The Lender Wants To Lose Money
description: Heres something crazy to ponder.

title: MySpace Joins the Google OpenSocial Team
description: Breaking now: MySpace, the Webs largest social network with more than 110 million members, has joined Googles OpenSocial platform. The New York Times wrote about the effort, designed to counter Facebook, on Tuesday.

title: We Could Fire You and the Entire Management Team
description: The gloves have come off in the wake of the failed buyout of Affiliated Computer Systems.

title: A City of Kids Who Never Sleep
description: Parents who work late often dont make it home before their kids go to bed. So instead of coming home earlier, some parents are keeping kids up later.

title: Defending Pevear and Volokhonsky
description: O.K, gang. No more Mr. Nice Guy Moderator. Today, the gloves come off, which is to say: In re this translation, many of you are  how to put this?  off your rockers. The translators dont need me to defend them  and, as it happens, Richard Pevear has posted his own response. But heres the opinion (from the November 22 issue of The New York Review of Books) of Orlando Figes, the eminent historian of Russia:

title: How Is Bloomberg Like Pope John XXIII?
description: Several hundred leading figures from the government, business and nonprofit realms gathered at the Roosevelt Hotel in Midtown today for a discussion about New York Citys future, organized by the Manhattan Institute, a conservative policy research organization.

title: How Dry You Are
description: The United States has vast resources directed at tracking conditions around the country, from the flow of streams to the vagaries of weather, but often its hard to find what you need when you need it.

title: Podcast: A Political Survivor Turns 90
description: Listen to the Podcast (mp3)

title: The Woman Who Shook Up Citi
description: Citigroups stock closed Thursday down almost 7 percent, its lowest close in four years and about $15 billion of market value wiped out. And the primary driver was a report by CIBC analyst Meredith Whitney, who wrote in a report that the financial giant may need to cut its dividend or sell off assets to avoid a much larger loss.

title: Say What? Beware of the Strawman Edition
description: One of President Bushs signature rhetorical techniques is to set up a strawman  some people dont think Al Qaeda is our enemy, or something of the sort  and then strike it down.

title: Big Brother on the Internet
description: When Internet users surf Web sites, information on where they go is often recorded and saved in ways that are personally identifiable. If you visit a site for alcoholics, or living with AIDS, or spouse abuse, that information could end up in a lot of databases  linked to you by name.

title: The Great Facebook Team-Up?
description: As we reported below, MySpace has joined Googles OpenSocial  initiative, along with social network Bebo and blogging network Six Apart. That means developers can now write their programs only once to make them work on those sites, and others including LinkedIn, Orkut, Ning, Hi5, and the Web platforms of Oracle and Salesforce.com.

title: Construction Progress: Week 13
description: See more photos.

title: Space Station Issue Uncovered Thanks to Eyes Glued to Screen
description: You can get a lot accomplished just looking at a screen.

title: The Kosher Economy
description: Businesses in Israel, including cellphone companies and pizza parlors, are adapting to cater to the country's ultra-Orthodox community.

title: On Staten Island, a Race Worth Watching
description: As New York City election days go, next Tuesdays is an uncommonly sleepy one with few races besides local judgeships.

title: 15,000 Ducks Killed
description: Foie gras producers and animal rights activists agree on one thing: A fire that killed 15,000 breeding ducks at the Hudson Valley Foie Gras company in upstate New York on Tuesday was tragic.

title: Movie Minutes: 'Joe Strummer'
description: A. O. Scott reviews a new documentary about Joe Strummer, frontman for The Clash.

title: Movie Minutes: 'Bee Movie'
description: A. O. Scott reviews "Bee Movie," featuring Jerry Seinfeld.

title: Dipping Into the Halloween Blog Candy
description: What we are reading elsewhere

title: How Much Was That?
description: Those of you who have been following the trail of fashion from the runways to the stores in recent seasons are probably aware that some of the most sought after pieces never make it to the sales rack. Those high-waisted pants from Givenchy and the school-boy blazers and Moroccan scarves from Balenciaga from fall, for example, were largely claimed by the houses best customers last March  through personal shoppers or at trunk shows  before the clothes were produced. Strange to commit to a season so far in advance, but better safe than sorry.

title: S.C. Democrats Say No to Colbert
description: GREENVILLE, S.C.  The momentum of the Colbert presidential campaign hit a cul-de-sac today when the South Carolina Democratic Party decided he wasnt a serious candidate and turned down his application to get on the ballot.

title: Hey, Mr. Escalade Man
description: If he revisits Highway 61 yet again, chances are Bob Dylan will do it in a Cadillac Escalade, just like the one he drives in a new television commercial.

title: Serenade for a Life-Saving Dog and Cat
description: A heroic dog and cat were serenaded by a singing dog during the ASPCA awards banquet today, where they were honored for saving their owners lives.

title: Sun. Sand. Beach. Soccer.
description: Most people in the soccer world know that Brazil was awarded the 2014 World Cup by FIFA earlier this week, the first time the five-time champion will host the World Cup since 1950 (when the host nation was stunned by Uruguay in the final).

title: Moonves: Strike Wont Hurt CBSs Bottom Line
description: Make no mistake: we are prepared, said Les Moonves, the president and chief executive of CBS Corporation, as he discussed the impending writers strike on a conference call with financial analysts this afternoon.

title: Colbert: Heres Todays Word  Stricken (As in From the Ballot)
description: Politico is reporting that the South Carolina Democratic Party has voted not to allow Stephen Colbert to appear on their states presidential primary ballot.

title: Snowflakes Happen
description: In a series of internal musings and memos to his staff, then-Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld argued that Muslims avoid physical labor and wrote of the need to keep elevating the threat, link Iraq to Iran and develop bumper sticker statements to rally public support for an increasingly unpopular war, reports Robin Wright of The Washington Post.

title: Time for Some Jane Jacobs Revisionism?
description: First, Robert Mosess legacy was reassessed. Now, an exhibition takes a look at Jane Jacobss contributions to New York City. Of course, history has been far more kind to Jacobs, who died last year, than to Moses, who died in 1981. But is that a fair assessment?

title: For Cryin Out Loud, Argentina
description: Stephen Colbert on elections across the globe:

title: Bill Clinton Gives Interview to Former Foe
description: File this under Dept. of Strange Bedfellows: Former President Bill Clinton has apparently granted an interview to Chris Ruddy, a one-time archenemy of the Clintons who now runs the conservative publication Newsmax.

title: Road Trip, Part 7
description: In this weeks edition our intrepid travelers, Mike Ogle and Matt Meyers of CSTV.com, get to the bottom of one college footballs most enduring mysteries: what is the Telephone Trophy? Then they talked recruiting and hairstyles with the Missouri quarterbacks coach David Yost. As if that wasnt enough, they caught up with the former Kansas City defensive end Neil Smith. They even got him to do his sack dance. So join Mr. Ogle and Mr. Meyers on their college football odyssey. Its time to hit the road.

title: Touring an Endangered Paradise
description: A tour through the coastal waters of the Florida Everglades, a massive wetland that the state and federal government are hoping to restore.

title: Clinton Signs Letter on Iran
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons Senate office announced this afternoon that Mrs. Clinton, along with 29 other Democratic senators, had signed a letter to President Bush expressing serious concerns about the administrations posture toward Iran and its strategy to stop that nation from developing nuclear weapons.

title: The Worship Rock Scene
description: The worship rock scene at High Desert Church in Victorville, Calif.

title: Review in the New York Review of Books
description: From Michael Tomasky. By George, I think hes got it.

title: If Not Now, When?
description: The 1963 Notre Dame football team finished 2-7 and might have even tied a school record for losses had its game against Iowa not been canceled because of the assassination of John F. Kennedy. Like this years team, that 1963 team enjoyed a victory over U.C.L.A., but what that team is most famous for is being the last Fighting Irish squad to lose to Navy.

title: Squeezing the VCs
description: The nations venture capitalists might need to invest in some group therapy, or appointments at the spa, and certainly accountants.

title: One Strike, Many Opinions
description: The impending writers strike is prompting passionate discussions in TV Decoders comments thread and on Web sites like Deadline Hollywood Daily. Most of the comments on this mornings post about the strike were supportive of the writers.

title: This Year: Guy Fawkes and Cherie Blair?!
description: Cherie as a Guy, Ready to Roast

title: The Robot in the Newsroom
description: Ive written about technology for longer than I want to admit and blogged here since June, but one of the most fun tasks Ive had in a long time has been working on improvements to the technology section of nytimes.com. Some of them went live this morning. Ill resist the temptation to boast and refer whoever is interested to the press release.

title: The Kosher Economy
description: Businesses in Israel, including cellphone companies and pizza parlors, are adapting to cater to the country's ultra-Orthodox community.

title: The Most Amazing Stat Youll Ever See
description: OK, so thats exaggerating. Maybe. This factoid in a column by Bruce Jenkins of the San Francisco Chronicle is simply astounding:

title: Seventies Something
description: I never thought there was going to be any sort of nostalgia for childhood in the 1970s, a time of skyrocketing divorce, latch key kids and newly liberated adults who sometimes behaved rather badly toward their much less with-it offspring.

title: Touring an Endangered Paradise
description: A tour through the coastal waters of the Florida Everglades, a massive wetland that the state and federal government are hoping to restore.

title: F.D.A. Is Unable to Ensure Drugs Are Safe, Panel Is Told
description: The Food and Drug Administration cannot guarantee the safety of the nations drug supply because it inspects few foreign drug manufacturers and the inspections it does carry out abroad are less rigorous than those performed in this country, witnesses told a Congressional subcommittee yesterday.

title: Russia: Evidence Found in Bombing
description: The authorities said they had identified a suspect in Wednesdays bombing of a passenger bus in the central Russian city of Togliatti that killed eight people and wounded more than 50, mostly local university students. The bomber was likely aboard the bus at the time of the explosion, said Aleksandr Bastrykin, the head of the prosecutor generals investigative committee. Mr. Bastrykin said a search of the suspects apartment had turned up elements that could have been used to build a homemade explosive device. He refused to provide the suspects name or say if the suspect was killed in the blast.

title: Giuliani Seen as Sporting Strongest Coattails
description: While members of Congress have their own 2008 elections to worry about, they are hardly disinterested spectators of the presidential race. The identity of the Democratic and Republican presidential nominees is of vast importance to Senate and House candidates facing serious challenges.

title: Manhattan: Garden to Provide More Access
description: The owners of Madison Square Garden will modify the arena to provide greater access to people with physical disabilities, federal prosecutors said yesterday. Under the agreement announced by Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan, the owners will add 50 wheelchair-accessible seats and make other changes to increase access. In a statement, a Madison Square Garden spokesman, Barry Watkins, said the owners had worked for several years to reach an agreement with the government over how best to modify the arena, which was built in 1968.

title: Songs of Love and War From a Gamba Maestro
description: You might wonder what a viola da gamba player can do to sustain an audience year after year, but the question seems not to trouble the Spanish gambist Jordi Savall, long the instruments reigning star. Mr. Savall performs in New York every season, and his visits almost always include more than one concert, either on his own or with one of his three ensembles. And he rarely repeats works from a previous seasons program.

title: Canadian Exporters Hurt by a Soaring Currency
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 1  The morning after the Canadian dollar climbed above its postwar high against the United States dollar, Robert Hattin, the president of a company that makes custom machinery to pack products as diverse as toilet paper, cough syrup and CDs, was not celebrating.

title: Bhutto Heads to Dubai;  Blast Kills 8
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 1  The Pakistani opposition leader Benazir Bhutto left Pakistan today for what she said was a visit to Dubai, according to news agency reports.

title: Art in Review
description: REVOLUTIONS

title: Bush, Defending Justice Nominee, Sees Unfairness
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  The White House began a campaign Thursday to save the candidacy of Michael B. Mukasey for attorney general, with President Bush defending him in a speech and in an Oval Office interview, where he complained that Mr. Mukasey was not being treated fairly on Capitol Hill.

title: Rules Lower Prison Terms in Sentences for Crack
description: Crack cocaine offenders will receive shorter prison sentences under more lenient federal sentencing guidelines that went into effect yesterday.

title: M.T.A. Asks for Restoration of Automatic Dues Payment
description: After a 60-hour strike that halted subway and bus service in 2005, a state judge penalized the Transport Workers Union by taking away its most powerful money-raising tool: automatic collection of dues from members paychecks.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Oct. 11 about a meeting on climate change attended by Nobel Prize laureates noted for their environmental work misstated the position of the United States on the Kyoto Protocol, the international treaty aimed at fighting global warming. It was signed by the United States but not ratified by the Senate; the United States did not refuse to sign the treaty.

title: Of Birds and Planes
description: Superman doesnt solicit donations, but he accepts tips.

title: Employment Report Shows Gain of 166,000 Jobs
description: A robust employment report offered investors a pleasant surprise, but an uncertain climate kept stock markets down most of the day.

title: As Beaches Erode, So Do Solutions
description: OVER the last decade or more, federal and state funds to restore beach sand have become increasingly scarce, as government officials, taxpayers and environmentalists have argued against spending hundreds of millions of public dollars for projects that often wash away after a few strong storms.

title: A Pacesetter in Berlin, Rop Will Try to Win New York on His Own
description: Five weeks ago, Rodgers Rop began the Berlin Marathon under strict instructions. He was to run the first 30 kilometers in precisely 1 hour 29 minutes and then drop out. His job was to set the pace for Haile Gebrselassie of Ethiopia to break the marathon world record.

title: In Wild Swing, Stocks Give Up Rate-Cut Gains
description: A day that dawned bleakly on Wall Street turned even darker late yesterday as an afternoon sell-off sent the Dow Jones industrial average down more than 360 points, or 2.6 percent. Investors worried that Citigroups woes might be worsening and that consumers would not spend freely this holiday shopping season.

title: Preserving Black History in the Military, at the Colored Officers Club
description: FORT HUACHUCA, Ariz.  The door to the tumbledown clapboard building, the one with the Off Limits sign, creaks open, and Harlan Bradfords flashlight beam cuts through the shadows inside.

title: Sweet, Bloody Smell of Success
description: Greatness hovers just outside American Gangster, knocking, angling to be let in. Based in rough outline on the flashy rise and fall of a powerful 1970s New York drug lord, Frank Lucas, the film has been built for importance, with a brand-name director, Ridley Scott, and two major stars, Denzel Washington as Lucas, and Russell Crowe as Richie Roberts, the New Jersey cop who brings him down. Its a seductive package, crammed with all the on-screen and off-screen talent that big-studio money can buy, and filled with old soul and remixed funk that evoke the city back in the day, when heroin turned poor streets white and sometimes red.

title: Broad Comedy
description: A plaintive portrait of a gay high school student looking for love in a small Texas town? Or a warmed-over John Waters-style farce that ridicules easy targets like evangelical Christians and petty high school bureaucrats? Fat Girls doesnt know which it wants to be and ends up stranded between two concepts, either of which might have yielded a more satisfying film.

title: The Real Climate Debate: To Cap or to Tax?
description: We interrupt our coverage of the political campaign for a few words about the cost of preventing climate change.

title: A Fusion of Diverse Sounds and Styles, With Jokes
description: Anyone expecting straightforward bluegrass from Jerry Douglas on dobro, Edgar Meyer on bass and Sam Bush on mandolin or fiddle got just a little bit of it on Wednesday night. At the end of the trios concert at Zankel Hall, the musicians breezed through a banjo tune. Before then, nearly all the music they played was poised comfortably between genres: deeply rooted in bluegrass technique but toying with the parameters and options of string-band music.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Wednesday with a review of The Leopard and the Fox, a play about the overthrow of Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan in 1977, at the TBG Theater in Manhattan, misidentified the actor playing a Washington reporter. He is Michael Crane  not Dave Cherry, the character he played.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the potential payout to E. Stanley ONeal upon his departure as chief executive of Merrill Lynch misstated the amount of money he was paid in his five years on the job. It was more than $70 million, not roughly $160 million. (His payout is expected to be at least $159 million.) (Go to Article)

title: Imus Scheduled to Returnto the Radio on Dec. 3
description: Citadel Radio and WABC-AM, one of its stations in New York City, formally announced yesterday afternoon that the station was hiring Don Imus, right, and that it would begin broadcasting his morning radio show on Dec. 3. The station said that Mr. Imus would be reunited with the cast of his former WFAN-AM show, including Charles McCord, his principal sidekick and longtime news anchor. In its news release, the station did not mention Bernard McGuirk, the producer whose on-air observation about the Rutgers womens basketball team touched off the racially and sexually tinged exchange that got Mr. Imus fired. But the plan is for Mr. McGuirk to return in a role off microphone, said one person apprised of the stations plans who would speak only anonymously about matters not mentioned in the release. In a telephone interview, Phil Boyce, vice president of news-talk programming for Citadel, noted Mr. Imuss more than three decades of experience on New York City radio before adding, The chance to get Don is something we couldnt pass up. Mr. Boyce said he expected other Citadel radio affiliates to carry Mr. Imuss show, but he was not ready to say which ones. The Imus show will replace that of Curtis Sliwa and Ron Kuby. Mr. Boyce said he hoped to find another place on the WABC schedule for Mr. Sliwa but did not expect to keep Mr. Kuby, a civil rights lawyer. Asked why, he said he had no further comment.

title: African Orphans Werent, U.N. Says
description: DAKAR, Senegal, Nov. 1  Virtually all of the children a French aid group tried to fly out of Chad last week had been living with family members in villages and were not orphans of the Darfur conflict, as the group claimed, the United Nations said Thursday.

title: A Decorative Piece of Subway History Is Unearthed in a Busy Station
description: A lovely little piece of subway history on the uptown platform of the No. 1 line at 59th Street-Columbus Circle  so old it actually antedates the trains  was concealed from generations of riders by a false wall.

title: In the Kitchen With Blobs and a Cloud
description: The writer and artist C. H. Greenblatt has SpongeBob SquarePants on his rsum  he shared in a 2005 Emmy nomination for that Nickelodeon series  and it looks as if he has been asked to catch Krabby Patty sauce in a bottle again with Chowder, his new show for Cartoon Network.

title: Income Data Hints at Underlying Economic Strength
description: Personal income and spending continued to grow in September, a government report showed yesterday, suggesting strength in the economy even as analysts feared widespread troubles in the next few months.

title: Guns on San Francisco Bay, and the Hiking Trails Left Behind
description: THE ballroom at the Officers Club is empty and silent, but it looks very much as it did when Army brass and their wives danced there in the 1950s. Gazing at the white Mission-style stucco walls, rough-hewn wooden beams, large alcove fireplaces and 100-light wrought-iron chandeliers, its easy to conjure up those revelers.

title: Thomas Dawes, Musician and Jingle Writer, Dies at 64
description: Thomas W. Dawes, a rock musician and composer who wrote music for some of advertisings best-known commercial jingles, including Plop, Plop, Fizz, Fizz for Alka-Seltzer and 7Up, the Uncola, died on Oct. 13 in Manhattan. He was 64.

title: Footnote
description: Meryl Streep will portray Julia Child in the movie Julie & Julia, being adapted by Nora Ephron from the Julie Powell book Julie and Julia: 365 Days, 524 Recipes, 1 Tiny Apartment Kitchen, Variety reported. It tells of a frustrated secretary who undertakes a yearlong endeavor to cook all 524 recipes in Julia Childs Mastering the Art of French Cooking. Amy Adams is to play Julie.

title: Girardi Will Wear Goal on His Back: No. 27
description: The mission statement is summarized in the two numerals that will follow Joe Girardi wherever he goes. The uniform number of the Yankees new manager is 27, and the reason is rhetorical.

title: Musharraf Is Asked to Resist Emergency Rule
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Friday, Nov. 2  Since Monday, American and European diplomats have been urging the embattled president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, to refrain from imposing emergency rule to maintain his hold on power, a Western diplomat said today.

title: Theater Listings
description: THE USUAL FREAK SHOW In the mid-1980s Jeffrey Essmann was writing and performing satirical character comedy, revuelike shows that were neither theater nor exactly cabaret. The whole East Village thing was kicking in, he said recently, describing a scene busy with performers trying new things in joints now long gone. It wasnt even worth remembering the names of the clubs because they only lasted a few weekends.

title: Fatherhood Puts Game in Perspective
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 1  The Jaguars Fred Taylor said he was dining at a Miami Beach steakhouse in the spring when a Hall of Fame running back stopped by his table to say he admired the way he runs and considered him one of the best backs in the National Football League.

title: Drug Test Hastens Retirement for Hingis
description: A comeback that started auspiciously in 2006 for Martina Hingis shuddered to a halt yesterday, when she announced her second retirement from tennis and revealed that her decision was linked to testing positive for cocaine at this years Wimbledon.

title: Gaul as a Cabinet of Curiosities and Patois
description: The Grand Canyon of the Verdon, a deep, narrow incision in the Alps of Provence, is one of the great wonders of France. The Verdon River, fast and wild, races for 13 miles between sheer limestone cliffs before emptying into the Lac de Ste. Croix, a delight for thousands of kayakers, hikers and camera-toting tourists. Yet until 1905, this natural wonder, located only 60 miles from Marseille, was known only to a few local woodcutters who descended into the canyon on ropes to cut boxwood, which they carved into high-quality balls for boules. Somehow the second-largest gorge in the world managed to hide in plain sight until the age of the automobile.

title: Schumer and Feinstein Back Mukasey
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2  The confirmation of Michael B. Mukasey as attorney general seemed all but assured late this afternoon when Senators Charles E. Schumer and Dianne Feinstein, two Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee, announced that they would vote in favor of the nominee.

title: Citing Oil Prices, Asia Starts Reducing Fuel Subsidies
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 1  Consumers in Asia are feeling the heat of skyrocketing oil prices  which rose above $96 a barrel Thursday for the first time  as governments start rolling back subsidies that have kept costs for gasoline and other fuel artificially low.

title: How the Murder Case Against a Former F.B.I. Supervisor Collapsed
description: In a conference room on the 17th floor of the Brooklyn district attorneys office, in the winter of 2005, a prosecutor and a detective investigator sat down with a woman they did not trust.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article yesterday about the acquittal of a former federal prosecutor on charges that he illegally withheld evidence from defense lawyers in a major terrorism case misstated his given name. He is Richard G. Convertino, not Robert. A picture caption misspelled the surname of another lawyer and misstated his role in the case. He is Thomas Cranmer, not Crammer, and he represented Mr. Convertinos co-defendant, Harry R. Smith III, who was also acquitted; Mr. Cranmer was not the lawyer for Mr. Convertino.

title: Struggling Against Circumstance
description: Love and Honor, the final episode in Yoji Yamadas samurai trilogy, maintains the grace and resonance of its predecessors as well as their focus on class inequality.

title: Movies
description: MOVIES

title: Mayor Weighs Pupil Rewards of Free Phones and Airtime
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he was considering a proposal to give some city students free cellphones and to reward high performance with free airtime, but emphasized that he had no intention of lifting the ban on cellphones in the schools.

title: Room to Share
description: WHO Angie Wiskocil, 55, an information technology executive, and her husband, John, 55, an insurance executive, from Walnut Creek, Calif. WHAT 4-bedroom house WHERE Portola, Calif.

title: Israel Destroys 7 Gaza Tunnels
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 1  The Israeli military said Thursday that its forces had discovered seven tunnels running under the border between Egypt and Gaza.

title: Job Cuts at Chrysler Go Even Deeper Than Expected
description: DETROIT, Nov. 1  Over the last two years, the three American auto companies have vowed that their plans to slash nearly 80,000 jobs and close more than two dozen plants would be enough to transform them into leaner and nimbler competitors.

title: Forever Drawing the World in All Its Minuscule Detail
description: He was an eccentric, disheveled, toothless and impecunious lifelong bachelor, an amateur poet and musician and an autodidact able to converse knowledgeably with experts in many different fields. And he was a genius draftsman, one of 18th-century Frances greatest. Thats Gabriel de Saint-Aubin (1724-80), the subject of a gripping exhibition at the Frick Collection.

title: Clinton and Obama Clash on Piling On Remarks
description: CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 2  Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama tangled today over whether women should be treated equally to men in the boxing ring of presidential politics as Mrs. Clinton backed away from her politics of pile on strategy portraying her as the lone woman under assault from the six male candidates at the recent Democratic debate.

title: MySpace Joins Google Alliance to Counter Facebook
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1  MySpace and Bebo, two of the worlds largest social networking sites, on Thursday joined a Google-led alliance that is promoting a common set of standards for software developers to write programs for social networks.

title: Girardis Introduction Starts the Clock Ticking
description: On his grand tour yesterday of the shell of what will be the new Yankee Stadium, Joe Girardi could peek into the future, all the way to 2009. He could smell the new concrete and see the foul poles already in their outfield places. He could envision the batting cages under the stands and where he hoped to be pressing all the right managerial buttons in the first-base dugout.

title: Cobbling Together a Life Amid Tragedy
description: A triptych of short films set on and immediately after 9/11, A Broken Sole is based on a stage production by its screenwriter and co-producer, Susan Charlotte. One hopes the material played onstage, because it dies on screen.

title: Describing American Life With Gruff Good Cheer
description: To hear the singer Steve Tyrell growl It Had to Be You with the aw-shucks geniality of a Texas good ole boy is to be reminded of something that can be obscured in the rarefied environment of Manhattan cabaret: The great American songbook belongs to everyone. That is what Willie Nelson demonstrated nearly three decades ago with his great album Stardust, in which he treated popular standards as dirt-plain nostalgic touchstones stripped of harmonic complexity and in no need of further explication.

title: Marijuana and College Aid
description: Anything that keeps ex-offenders from attending college makes it more likely that they will be caught in the revolving door that leads to prison. Tens of thousands of people have been pushed in that direction since the 1990s when Congress passed a law that barred even minor drug offenders from receiving federal education aid. The law applies even to offenses so minor that they are normally punished by probation, a small fine or community service.

title: Quitting Smoking: What Employers Can Do
description: To the Editor:

title: F.T.C. Member Vows Tighter Controls of Online Ads
description: A MEMBER of the Federal Trade Commission said yesterday that the agency would be exerting a tighter grip over online advertising, partly because of increased tracking by marketing companies of peoples activity on the Internet.

title: Lundqvist Records 3rd Shutout of Season
description: After his third shutout of the season, in a game that ended with fans chanting his name, Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist ventured through the tunnel at Madison Square Garden last night and endured a few anxious moments that had nothing to do with facing shots from the Washington sharpshooters Alexander Ovechkin or Viktor Kozlov.

title: Theyre All Oldies, Dad Included
description: DISPLAYED under a padlocked cube of glass, something like the case that encloses the Rosetta Stone, were several flat, square boxes with writing scrawled on them. These were indeed much-venerated cultural artifacts. But we were not at the British Museum. We were in Cleveland, at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, and the boxes contained original reel-to-reel master tapes by the Doors.

title: A Slain Broker Is Recalled as a Loyal Friend With Nerve
description: Linda Stein, the punk-rock manager turned real estate broker who was found bludgeoned to death on Tuesday in her Fifth Avenue penthouse, was a vibrant and volatile person who aroused strong and often contradictory feelings in those who knew her, friends and colleagues said yesterday as the police struggled to find a motive in her killing.

title: A Bitter Rift When a Boss Is the Buyer
description: We could fire you and the entire management team, the five directors wrote, but that would not help our shareholders, customers or employees.

title: Meat Loaf Curtails Concert in England
description: The rock singer Meat Loaf, below, cut short a performance in Newcastle, England, on Wednesday night amid claims that he had told the audience it was his final appearance, the BBC reported. But Andrew Miller, promoter of the tour, said: Ive spoken to his doctor, and its clear its just exhaustion and stress. Its not his last ever gig, thats for sure. He added that he hoped Meat Loaf, 60, would perform as scheduled tonight in Birmingham. Meat Loaf, whose real name is Marvin Lee Aday, collapsed onstage at Wembley Arena in London in 2003.

title: Man Meets Boy, Surrenders Heart
description: Trend spotters (and actresses) take note. This season John Cusack is struggling with parenthood and worlds of sorrow: In Martian Child he plays a novelist widower hoping to adopt a small, broken boy, and in the forthcoming Grace Is Gone his working-stiff widower grapples with trying to break the bad news to his girls. In each movie the beloved is already out of the picture, which allows Mr. Cusack instantly to take possession of the screen with his trademark sensitivity. Nice guys rule, and dont you forget it.

title: East Coast Writers Take Their Case to the Streets
description: Members of the Writers Guild of America East took their contract dispute to the public this morning, gathering at Rockefeller Plaza to hand out fliers with their reasons for going on strike against entertainment producers. Organizers estimated more than 50 writers took part in handing out leaflets near the ice rink and a live taping of the NBCs Today show.

title: Rembrandt and Modernists at a Weekend Red-Tag Sale
description: The annual fair sponsored by the International Fine Print Dealers Association can sometimes seem like a high-class jumble sale. Dealers tend to cram their booths full of art, hanging Rembrandt etchings next to Rauschenberg silk-screens and piling excess inventory into forbidding stacks. If you are accustomed to the minimalist pretenses of most contemporary art fairs, however, the print dealers showcase may come as a relief.

title: Bounty Hunter Offers Regrets for Slur
description: Duane (Dog) Chapman has apologized for his repeated use of a racial slur in a tirade addressed to his son Tucker in a private telephone conversation that was recorded and posted online, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Chapmans statement came on the heels of the cable channel A&Es suspension of production of Dog the Bounty Hunter, starring Mr. Chapman, below. In the recorded conversation posted by The National Enquirer on its Web site (nationalenquirer.com), Mr. Chapman spoke disparagingly of his sons girlfriend, who is black, and used the slur six times in a 90-second clip. But he also said he did not care that she was black. In his apology Mr. Chapman, 54, who is based in Honolulu, said he has utmost respect and aloha for black people who have suffered so much due to racial discrimination and acts of hatred. I did not mean to add yet another slap in the face to an entire race of people who have brought so many gifts to this world. I am ashamed of myself and pledge to do whatever I can to repair this damage I have caused.

title: Bloomberg Opposes Spitzers Latest Plan for Drivers
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg came out against Gov. Eliot Spitzers latest drivers license proposal during an interview on CNN last night, saying, I still dont think that it is where we should be.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about the death of a New York City public school student who had been infected with a virulent, drug-resistant strain of bacteria misstated the given name and, because of an editing error, the title of a city official who discussed steps taken to clean Intermediate School 211, which the student attended. The official is James Lonergan, not Joel, and he is the chief executive of all school facilities, not the head of school facilities at I.S. 211.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: A War Game Supposes Scarce and Risky Oil
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  War in Iran. Gasoline rationing, at $5 a gallon. A military draft. A Chinese takeover of Taiwan. Double-digit inflation and unemployment. The draining of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve.

title: Life After Securities Fraud
description: When federal marshals snapped the metal handcuffs around his wrists behind his back and led him away on a chilly December day in 2000, hedge fund manager Michael L. Smirlock wondered if his life was over.

title: Ferndale: Fire at Foie Gras Producer
description: A fire on Tuesday killed 13,000 to 15,000 ducks at the nations largest producer of foie gras, the company said yesterday. The fire may have been caused by a short circuit in a boiler in the duck coop, said Michael Ginor, president of the company, Hudson Valley Foie Gras. But the loss of the ducks will not hurt the production of foie gras, he said. The ducks that died, female Pekins, had been set aside to breed with Muscovy males to produce the Moulard ducks that are used for foie gras. Mr. Ginor estimated the loss at more than $100,000.

title: Humanitys Ascent, in Three Dimensions
description: On Sunday, when the Museum of Modern Arts 30-year retrospective of the sculptor Martin Puryear opens, the New York art world will find itself in what may be an unprecedented situation. For the first time in recent memory  maybe ever  two of the citys most prominent museums will be presenting large, well-done exhibitions of living African-American artists. The Whitney Museums 15-year survey of Kara Walkers work has been searing hearts, minds and eyes since it opened early last month. Now it is Mr. Puryears turn to weave his finely nuanced yet insistent spell.

title: Work Starts on Minneapolis Bridge Replacement
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 1  Three months after the Interstate 35W bridge collapsed, construction of a replacement began here on Wednesday.

title: New York Says Appraiser Inflated Value of Homes
description: The New York attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, accused an appraisal company yesterday of inflating the value of homes under pressure from Washington Mutual, one of the nations largest mortgage lenders.

title: On the Roads of China, the Buddha Was Transformed
description: What an outlandish sight Buddhist monks must have been when they first turned up more than a millennium ago in China, a land where only criminals  the disgraced and the dangerous  had shaved heads, wore patched-together clothes and begged for food.

title: An Anthropologist Evolves With Help From Her Autistic Child
description: Are autistic children normal or are they better than that? Its a question that Vivian (Lisa Emery), an accomplished anthropologist, struggles with in Lucy, Damien Atkinss occasionally provocative drama about a mother who must learn how to take care of her autistic daughter.

title: Africas Chance
description: Amid an AIDS epidemic, against the drumbeat of regional conflicts, overshadowed by the most abject poverty, it is easy to miss the glimmer of hope in sub-Saharan Africa. Rising prices of raw materials are helping the region achieve its best economic performance since independence.

title: Burned Out at 14, Israeli Concert Pianist Is Back Where He Really Belongs
description: The 11-year-old pianist at Carnegie Hall 24 years ago earned high praise from a New York Times critic and a warning: One hopes that he will be allowed his remaining years of childhood and not pushed too far too quickly.

title: Obama Envisions New Iran Approach
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 31  Senator Barack Obama says he would engage in aggressive personal diplomacy with Iran if elected president and would offer economic inducements and a possible promise not to seek regime change if Iran stopped meddling in Iraq and cooperated on terrorism and nuclear issues.

title: A Competitive Spirit Survives the Rigors of the Marathon
description: If he thought he could have been successful playing basketball or soccer or even football, Abdi Abdirahman would have poured his energy into one of those sports. He wanted to compete in something in his second year at Pima Community College, but he had never been very successful. Then he watched a track meet at the nearby University of Arizona and saw a runner finish far behind the field in a distance race.

title: Goblins and Ghosts Spook Tv Ratings
description: Halloween festivities took a chunk out of network television audiences on Wednesday, but CBS retained the most viewers over all thanks to Criminal Minds. That show led the night with 14.7 million viewers at 9, Nielsen estimated. Meanwhile, ABCs drama in that hour, Private Practice (11.2 million), remained No. 1 among adults 18 to 49 even as its ratings fell 15 percent from a week ago. Instead of winning the night in that demographic, as it usually does, ABC tied CBS as ABCs Pushing Daisies at 8 set a new low (8.6 million) for its run. At 10, ABCs Dirty Sexy Money (8.4 million) ranked second behind CBSs CSI: NY (13.5 million) but ahead of NBCs Life (5.8 million). NBC finished third over all, as a two-hour edition of Phenomenon beginning at 8 attracted just 6.4 million viewers. Fox was fourth for the night with a lineup of repeats.

title: At the Debate: Was It Ganging Up, or Actual Debating?
description: To the Editor:

title: Obama Pledges Aggressive Iran Diplomacy
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 31  Senator Barack Obama said he would engage in aggressive personal diplomacy with Iran if elected president, and would offer economic inducements and a possible promise not to seek regime change if Iran stopped meddling in Iraq and cooperated on terrorism and nuclear issues.

title: Feel the Love
description: BRIAN WILLIAMS: Welcome to Drexel University, the site of tonights Democratic presidential debate. Lets get started with Senator Barack Obama. Senator, youve vowed to spend this entire debate standing on Senator Clintons windpipe while reducing her to a quivering mass of jelly. How do you plan on doing that?

title: Paul W. Tibbets Jr., Pilot of Enola Gay, Dies at 92
description: Brig. Gen. Paul W. Tibbets Jr., the commander and pilot of the Enola Gay, the B-29 Superfortress that dropped the atomic bomb on Hiroshima in the final days of World War II, died yesterday at his home in Columbus, Ohio. He was 92.

title: Gates Says Iran Gave Assurances on Explosives
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates indicated Thursday that Iran had told the Baghdad government that it would work to stem the flow of high-powered explosives into Iraq, though he also questioned the credibility of the pledge.

title: Blame the Colts for the New-Look Patriots
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Oct. 31  The transformation of the New England Patriots would probably have happened eventually, because Coach Bill Belichick does not need anyone else to point out the deficiencies in his team.

title: Judges on Other Side of the Bench Plead Not Guilty
description: JERSEY CITY, Nov. 1  At times, the proceeding seemed much like a reunion of longtime friends. But it wasnt.

title: New Haven: Murder Suspect Pleads Not Guilty
description: A man accused of murder in the killings of a Cheshire woman and her two daughters in July pleaded not guilty yesterday, while his lawyers accused the Cheshire Police Department of leaking details about the case to a local newspaper. The suspect, Steven Hayes, 44, of Winsted, also waived his right to a probable-cause hearing in his 10-minute appearance under heavy security in State Superior Court. A second man, Joshua Komisarjevsky, 27, of Cheshire, pleaded not guilty on Tuesday. The men are charged in the deaths of Jennifer Hawke-Petit, 48, and her daughters Hayley, 17, and Michaela, 11, in a home invasion on July 23. Judge Richard A. Damiani scheduled a hearing for Tuesday to consider the defense lawyers request for a gag order. Lt. Jay Markella of the Cheshire police said the lawyers allegations were unsubstantiated.

title: Hula Hoops, Marathon Piano, Revisited Happenings: Artists, Start Your Concepts
description: Performa 07, the second edition of New York Citys much-promoted performance art biennial, is up and running and a lot bigger than the first time around. Some of the events qualify as dance; a few as theater; most fall somewhere in between, in the vast, anarchic ocean of blarney and bliss that is contemporary art.

title: National Archives Gets Catalogs of Looted Art
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  The National Archives announced on Thursday that it would acquire two photograph albums retrieved by an American serviceman during World War II that catalog art looted by the Nazis in France.

title: 3 G.I.s Die in Iraqs North; Baghdad Civilian Toll Falls
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 1  Three American soldiers died in attacks in northern Iraq, the military announced Thursday, while in troubled Diyala Province at least 14 Iraqis were killed in three incidents.

title: Prostates and Prejudices
description: My chance of surviving prostate cancer  and thank God I was cured of it  in the United States? Eighty-two percent, says Rudy Giuliani in a new radio ad attacking Democratic plans for universal health care. My chances of surviving prostate cancer in England? Only 44 percent, under socialized medicine.

title: A Russian Doctor Whose Wife Disappeared Is Charged With Insurance Fraud
description: A Russian doctor whose wife left their Upper East Side apartment to walk a dog in March 2003, and was found drowned in the East River two months later, was arrested yesterday and charged with insurance fraud.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column on Tuesday about the bequest of 18 paintings to two British museums misspelled the given name of one artist whose work is included in the bequest. He is Lucian Freud, not Lucien.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Books of The Times review on Wednesday, about The Star Machine, by Jeanine Basinger, misspelled the given name of an emerging star who appeared in the 1932 film Three on a Match. She was Ann Dvorak, not Anne.

title: With Coles Likely Out, Jets Focus on Basics
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 1  Laveranues Coles joined the Jets for practice Thursday, but he wore a knit cap, a green sweatshirt and green sweat pants instead of a helmet, shoulder pads and shorts, like the other players. That was not a good sign.

title: The Churn
description: People

title: Senator Schumers Statement
description: Following is the statement issued today by Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, announcing that he will vote in favor of President Bushs nominee for attorney general, Michael B. Mukasey.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: 2 Winning Drug Tests, One Expected and One a Surprise
description: An experimental drug from Vertex Pharmaceuticals helped cure more than 60 percent of patients with a tough-to-treat form of hepatitis C, according to data to be presented at a medical meeting that starts today.

title: Puerto Ricos Governor, Under Inquiry, Sees Politics
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  The Democratic governor of Puerto Rico says he has been improperly made a target of Justice Department prosecutors who began by looking into campaign contributions and have since broadened their efforts with a grand jury inquiry including subpoenas of his college transcripts and even questioning about whether he has had a hair transplant.

title: Manhattan: Workers Wages Recovered
description: The United States Department of Labor announced yesterday that it had recovered more than $66,000 in back wages on behalf of 46 workers at seven nail salons in New York City. The department said it had uncovered minimum-wage and overtime violations as part of an initiative to help low-wage workers. The department found violations at Classic Nails; Nails on 54th; Fifth Avenue Beauty; Hair, Nails and Tanning; and several other salons.

title: Verizon to Put Executive Pay to Shareholder Vote
description: Directors at Verizon Communications, under fire from shareholders over executive pay practices, said yesterday that they would put the companys compensation plans to an annual vote by investors beginning at its general meeting in 2009.

title: Starting Over in Texas
description: Texas is reeling from the allegations of brutality, neglect and sexual abuse that have rocked its juvenile justice system. Heads have rolled and reforms signed into law this summer by Gov. Rick Perry have eased the crisis, for the moment. The only real way to remedy the situation is to raze Texass deeply flawed system and build a new one from the ground up.

title: A Modern Marketplace for Israels Ultra-Orthodox
description: BEIT SHEMESH, Israel  When Larry Pinczower switches on his cellphone, the seal of a rabbinate council appears. Unable to send text messages, take photographs or connect to the Internet, his phone is a religiously approved adaptation to modernity by the ultra-Orthodox sector of Israeli life.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary on Oct. 12 about Bud Ekins, a motorcycle and auto stunt driver, referred incorrectly to two of his stunts in the 1968 crime thriller Bullitt. Mr. Ekins drove a Ford Mustang, not a Dodge Charger, as he doubled for Steve McQueen in part of the famous chase scene; the villains were in the Charger. In another scene, in which he laid down his motorcycle in front of a skidding truck, he played an innocent stranger who had been riding by; he was not doubling for Mr. McQueen.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Darfurs Many Horrors, and Glimmers of Hope
description: In Darfur Now, Theodore Brauns absorbing documentary about the atrocities in Darfur, the westernmost region of Sudan, Don Cheadle poses a fundamental question facing moviegoers attending a film about African strife: How do you respond to an event as difficult to understand as a government-sponsored mass murder of part of a countrys civilian population?

title: Bronx: Man Sentenced for Childs Death
description: A Bronx man convicted of manslaughter last month in the fatal beating of his girlfriends 4-year-old son was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to 15 years in prison. The man, Jose Calderon, 19, left, was convicted on Oct. 17 for acting recklessly in the beating death of the boy, Quachaun Browne, in January 2006. Quachauns mother, Aleshia Smith, 28, pleaded guilty this year to manslaughter for failing to seek immediate medical attention for her son. She is serving 2  to 7  years in prison.

title: J. K. Rowling Fights and Writes
description: J. K. Rowling, author of the Harry Potter series, and Warner Brothers, which makes the movies based on the books, have sued a Michigan publisher over its plans to publish a book version of a fan Web site that includes material like lists of spells found in the books and a catalog of magical creatures, according to The Associated Press. The site is edited by a middle-school librarian, Steve Vander Ark, and is known as the Harry Potter Lexicon (hp-lexicon.org). Ms. Rowling gave it a Fan Site Award in 2004 but said that plans to publish its content as a book would interfere with her own intention to compile a Harry Potter encyclopedia. In a statement released by Warner Brothers, Ms. Rowling said she could not approve of companion books or encyclopedias that seek to pre-empt my definitive Potter reference book for their authors own personal gain. Separately, The Associated Press reported that Ms. Rowling has completed her first book since writing the final installment in the Potter series, a collection of fairy stories titled The Tales of Beedle the Bard. Only seven copies are being printed, and one will be auctioned at Sothebys on Dec. 13 with a starting price of $62,000. Proceeds are designated for the Childrens Voice, a charity for vulnerable children in Europe.

title: To Marines Father, Suit Is More Than Money
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 1 After a year and a half of anger, grief and legal maneuvering, the father of a marine killed in Iraq has said the success of his suit against a fundamentalist sect that picketed his sons funeral means more than the jurys $10.9 million damage award on Tuesday.

title: Carelessness by London Police Cited in 05 Killing
description: LONDON, Nov. 1  Londons police force on Thursday was found guilty of putting the public at risk during a counterterrorism operation in 2005 that led to the killing of an innocent Brazilian electrician on a subway train.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about African-American executives misstated the employment plans of Time Warners chief executive, Richard D. Parsons. Mr. Parsonss contract with Time Warner expires in May; he has not announced plans to retire in March.

title: China Bars Exports by 750 Toy Makers
description: BEIJING, Nov. 1  Chinese regulators said Thursday that they had suspended the export licenses of more than 750 toy companies because of quality control problems, according to the state-controlled media.

title: An Online-Gaming Pioneer Is Back, and This Time Hes Banking on Sci-Fi
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  At the age of 46, Richard Garriott is an old man by video game standards. In fact, when it comes to games on personal computers, he could be fairly described as the old man.

title: Manhattan: Five Wounded in Union Square
description: Four people were shot and one was stabbed in Union Square early yesterday, the police said. The shooting took place about 12:45 a.m. at Union Square West and East 14th Street. The shooting victims, young men ages 19, 18, 19 and 15, were taken to Bellevue Hospital Center, where they were in stable condition, the police said. Officers who responded to a report of shots also found an 18-year-old man who had been stabbed, the police said. He was in serious condition at St. Vincents Hospital. The police said the matter was under investigation and could not say what led to the violence.

title: After Charmed Season, Cavaliers Must Regroup
description: INDEPENDENCE, Ohio, Nov. 1  In his new commercial, LeBron James makes the highly counterintuitive, almost comical claim, You dont want to be LeBron James. There are, it seems, some burdens to being rich, young, famous and responsible for the hoop dreams of your home state.

title: New Canaan: State Sues Over F.A.A. Plan
description: Gov. M. Jodi Rell announced yesterday that the state had filed a lawsuit to block a new Federal Aviation Administration plan to reroute as many as 150 planes a day over southwestern Connecticut to relieve congestion. At New Canaan Town Hall, she said that the agency, contrary to federal law, had failed to consider safety and environmental issues and the effect on residents quality of life.

title: Writers Say Strike to Start Monday
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2 Hollywoods two decades of labor peace shattered Thursday night, as movie and television writers declared they would embark on an industrywide strike for the first time since 1988, when both writers and Teamsters walked out.

title: Lobbyist With Friends of All Stripes Joins Spitzer Staff
description: After several tumultuous months of scandal, political missteps and sinking poll numbers, Gov. Eliot Spitzer is adding an affable, well-connected Albany lobbyist to his inner circle to help shape strategy as his first year in office comes to a close.

title: Effort to Save Everglades Falters as Funds Drop
description: MIAMI, Oct. 31  The rescue of the Florida Everglades, the largest and most expensive environmental restoration project on the planet, is faltering.

title: Winehouse Appeals in Marijuana Case
description: The lawyer for the British pop singer Amy Winehouse, below, said yesterday that she will appeal her fine last month for marijuana possession in Norway because she did not understand that under Norwegian law, accepting a fine amounts to pleading guilty, The Associated Press reported. The lawyer, Ole Kvelstad, contended that she had been questioned without legal representation or an interpreter and had not understood the Norwegian-language charges she signed. He said that pleading guilty in a drug case could have serious consequences when Ms. Winehouse, who has spoken openly about her taste for marijuana and alcohol, seeks to enter the United States. Police Attorney Rudolf Christoffersen of Bergen said she was questioned by an English-speaking officer, who translated the charges and explained the consequences of accepting the fine. Ms. Winehouse and her husband, Blake Fielder-Civil, were arrested in Bergen on Oct. 18 and held overnight on charges of illegal drug possession. They were released the next morning after paying fines of $715 each for possessing a quarter-ounce of marijuana.

title: In Recordings From Jail, Polygamist Had Doubts
description: DENVER, Nov. 1  The polygamist sect leader Warren S. Jeffs, in a series of jailhouse conversations recorded in January in Utah, renounced his role as a prophet of God and expressed remorse over immoral actions with a sister and a daughter when he was 20 years old, according to court documents.

title: In Pledge to Voters, Edwards Reflects on His Wifes Fight With Cancer
description: Former Senator John Edwards began running this 60-second advertisement yesterday in Iowa. It is the campaigns first major television buy, kicking off an advertising series in the lead up to the caucuses.

title: Friends Sitting Around a Campfire, Telling Stories About a Legend
description: When the Clash was labeled The Only Band That Matters, it may have been record company hype, but when I was a teenager, there was probably no band that mattered more to me. The idealism, the earnest anger, the democratic, sometimes clumsy way of mixing styles and sounds  I am almost as susceptible to it now as I was at 15. This is all by way of disclosure: Its likely that I would have been stirred and moved by Joe Strummer: The Future Is Unwritten, even if it were the straightforward, VH1-ready rock star biography it might, at first, appear to be. The film, however, is much more than a biography of the Clashs guitarist and lead singer: Its history, criticism, philosophy and politics, played fast and loud.

title: Queens: Clash Investigated as Bias Crime
description: A Halloween night clash between groups of youths in Howard Beach ended with two white teenagers injured and five minority suspects arrested on charges of assault, the police said, adding that the incident is under investigation for possible bias crimes. Investigators said the dispute began with a minority youth approaching whites and glaring at them. A white youth tossed an egg toward him, but missed, the police said. Then, 30 to 40 minority youths gathered and chased the whites, two of whom ran into a McDonalds restaurant. Some minority youths pursued them, the police said, punching one in the face and hitting the other with a stickball bat, causing a head injury requiring seven staples and an overnight hospitalization. One antiwhite epithet was reported by a restaurant worker. The attack occurred in Howard Beach, a predominantly white community where racial tension and violence have flared before. In 1986, Michael Griffiths, one of three black visitors fleeing an attack by whites, darted into a street and was hit and killed by a car.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the potential payout to E. Stanley ONeal upon his departure as chief executive of Merrill Lynch misstated the amount of money he was paid in his five years on the job. It was more than $70 million, not roughly $160 million. (His payout is expected to be at least $159 million.)

title: Japan Ends Afghan Naval Mission
description: TOKYO, Nov. 1  Japans Defense Ministry ordered home its naval ships from the Indian Ocean on Thursday, ending for now a six-year mission in support of the war in Afghanistan that raised the nations military presence overseas but has recently drawn increasing criticism domestically.

title: Sales at Ford Decrease for the 12th Month in a Row
description: DETROIT, Nov. 1  The Ford Motor Company posted its 12th consecutive monthly decline yesterday, while General Motors and Toyota Motor each gained market share in the United States in October on higher truck sales.

title: Astronaut to Make Risky Spacewalk on Saturday
description: Astronauts will take part in an unusually risky spacewalk tomorrow in an effort to mend a torn solar array on the International Space Station.

title: Taliban Retreat Is Seen After an Advance Near Kandahar
description: ARGHANDAB, Afghanistan, Nov. 1  Afghan officials said on Thursday that several hundred Taliban fighters had withdrawn from a strategic area near Kandahar, southern Afghanistans largest city, ending two days of clashes just outside it.

title: Lottery Numbers
Tapped Out, but Hopeful: A Break in Texass Oil Decline
description: CRANE, Texas  The North McElroy oil field here in West Texas has long been a tableau of rusty tanks and worn-out pump jacks. Not in Use is painted across broken electrical panels affixed to an abandoned building.

title: Cut the Scary Music: Here Sharks Are More Endangered Than Dangerous
description: The ocean is just large enough to contain the ambition of Sharkwater. This beautiful and horrifying debut feature by the underwater cameraman Rob Stewart of Toronto characterizes the depletion of the worlds shark population as an ecological catastrophe with dire consequences for humanity.

title: New England Style, Little Known and Liking It
description: AT first glance, Tiverton, R.I., may seem like just another small-town window onto the past. It has the character of a bygone Cape Cod with all its seaside charm, complemented by the nostalgic smell of fried clams in the air. But it doesnt have the Capes trauma of heavy traffic and the swarms of tourists.

title: Being Kept in the Dark on Wall Street
description: Its time for sunlight on Wall Street.

title: Florida: Ruling on Lethal Injection
description: The Florida Supreme Court unanimously ruled that the states new methods for carrying out lethal injections, changes prompted by a botched execution in December, do not violate the United States Constitutions prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment. The decision could clear the way for the scheduled execution on Nov. 15 of Mark D. Schwab, who was convicted in the 1991 killing of Junny Rios-Martinez, 11, of Cocoa, Fla. The court did not specifically rule on Mr. Schwabs request for a stay of execution. At this time, there is nothing prohibiting Schwabs execution from taking place as scheduled, said Sandi Copes, spokeswoman for Attorney General Bill McCollum. But the case could still go before the United States Supreme Court, which staying the execution of a Mississippi inmate on Tuesday, signaling that it intends to block executions until it decides a lethal injection case from Kentucky next spring.

title: Writers Set to Strike, Threatening Hollywood
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1  Hollywoods two decades of labor peace shattered Thursday night, as movie and television writers declared they would embark on an industry-wide strike for the first time since 1988, when both writers and Teamsters walked out.

title: How Iraqs Elections Set Back Democracy
description: Baghdad

title: Correction: Home, Sweet ... Yikes!
description: An article last Friday about city dwellers whose weekend homes are a source of anxiety because of their fear of the darkness and unusual sounds of the countryside misspelled the surname of one homeowner. She is Lindsey Pollak, not Pollack.

title: From Brooklyn to Los Angeles: Dodgers Hire Torre
description: Joe Torres departure from baseballs managerial world lasted two weeks. Torre, the successful and longtime manager of the Yankees, was named to the same position with the Los Angeles Dodgers yesterday.

title: Texas Haute Country
description: THE Hill Country, a swath of about 15 rural counties just west of Austin and San Antonio, has three things most of the rest of Texas doesnt: trees, water and hills. That translates reliably into autumn color. But while a fall trip through the maples and red oaks and mountain cedar looks much the same as it did 10 years ago, another element is changing. The food of the Hill Country has matured to the point that you can have a barbecue sandwich for lunch and pan-seared scallops with chipotle lime hollandaise for dinner.

title: The Blue Planets Lifeblood: A Finite Flow
description: It is impossible to enter Water: H2O = Life, the exhibition opening tomorrow at the American Museum of Natural History, and not feel excitement at its possibilities. You walk into darkened space where a tumbling aqua-lighted waterfall seems to descend from the ceiling; letters projected on its turbulent surface spell water in multiple languages.

title: Militants Draw New Front Line Inside Pakistan
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Nov. 1  For much of the last century, the mountainous region of Swat was ruled as a princely kingdom where a benign autocrat, the wali, bestowed schools for girls, health care for everyone and the chance to get a degree abroad for the talented.

title: Taking the Measure of the Citys Streets: Some Do It by Foot, Others by Car
description: Five years had passed since I last took up the challenge of the race now formally known as the ING New York City Marathon. It was gratifying to see that age had dulled neither the competitive spirit nor the stamina.

title: F.T.C. Member Vows Tighter Controls of Online Ads
description: A MEMBER of the Federal Trade Commission said yesterday that the agency would be exerting a tighter grip over online advertising, partly because of increased tracking by marketing companies of peoples activity on the Internet.

title: Cabdrivers Sweat It Out Bidding on Medallions
description: Dropped, dropped, still good, dropped, dropped. Gary Kanterman was talking to himself as he ran his pen down his list of taxi drivers.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Expecting Presidential Veto, Senate Passes Child Health Measure
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  Talks seeking a bipartisan compromise on health insurance for low-income children were cut short on Thursday, and the Senate then swiftly passed a bill to provide coverage for 10 million youngsters, fully expecting President Bush to veto it.

title: Why Writers Emerged From Behind Shield
description: When two reporters made a decision that unraveled a gangland murder trial in Brooklyn this week with 10-year-old tape recordings, they faced a choice that came down to one question: which of them had less to lose.

title: Government Cannot Halt Oil Incentives, Judge Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  A federal judge in Louisiana handed the oil industry a major legal victory this week, saying the government had no authority to suspend billions of dollars worth of drilling incentives when energy prices were high.

title: Its Alive! Creature Trods From Grave to the Stage
description: I passed a night of unmingled wretchedness, pants the tortured title character in one of many a palpitating passage in Mary Shelleys gothic novel Frankenstein.

title: Channeling the Bigger Games to the Lesser Networks
description: Under old-line television circumstances, the Wisconsin-Ohio State game would never have been carried on the Big Ten Network.

title: Poplar Grove and the Residence Club at Fishermans Cove
description: Poplar Grove

title: Second-Home Horror
description: To the Editor: Re Home, Sweet . . . Yikes! (Oct. 26): Its not only relocated urbanites who have trouble with the country. Robert Frost, Americas poet laureate of snowy woods, golden maples and roads not taken, addresses the subject in three little-known, but chilling poems, The Fear, The Oft-Repeated Dream, and House Fear, which reads in part: Always  I tell you this they learned  / Always at night when they returned {hellip} They learned to leave the house-door wide/ Until they had lit the lamp inside.

title: Amtrak Workers in Cooling-Off Period
