description: Amtrak workers may be able to strike as early as Dec. 1, after rejecting mediation and entering a 30-day cooling-off period, the National Mediation Board said. Amtrak and several unions are deadlocked over health insurance costs, work rules and back pay dating to 2000, when the last contract was approved. Amtrak, the government-subsidized passenger railroad, has never had a strike in its 30-year history. About half of its 15,000 unionized employees belong to labor groups that rejected the boards intervention in bargaining Oct. 25. Amtrak and eight unions were released from mediation Wednesday and began the waiting period yesterday, the board said.

title: Those Uninvited Guests
description: YOU may have heard the story about the woman who waited until July to open her country home and found the living room shrouded in spider webs.

title: Napoleonic Style, in All Its Imperial Self-Promotion
description: Napoleon is claiming a 21st-century moment.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about Superheroes Anonymous, a group of volunteers who gathered near Times Square to publicize their efforts to make their communities cleaner and safer, included an imprecise reference from one participant, Chaim Lazaros, who spoke at the event. He is a co-founder of the group, along with Ben Goldman; Mr. Lazaros is not the sole founder.

title: Another Billionaire Who Wants to Be a Mayor
description: THOSE black plastic eyeglasses  reminiscent of the magnate Aristotle Onassis, say, with a dollop of the presidential hopeful Edmund S. Muskie circa 1972  provide a nice retro touch, especially the dustspeckled lenses. But how the heck does their wearer, John A. Catsimatidis, the Greek-born billionaire toying with the idea of running for mayor of New York City (provided he can persuade sufficient politicos to see things his way), see a blessed thing? In focus, that is.

title: A New Lifestyle in South Korea: First Weekends, and Now Brunch
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 1  When she returned to Seoul in 2000 after 10 years in New York City, Park Su-ji introduced her fellow South Koreans to an exotic way to socialize over food: brunch.

title: A Greener Greenland
description: To the Editor:

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Georgia: Plan on Retaining Lake Water
description: After a meeting with Bush administration officials, the Army Corps of Engineers announced a plan to hold more water in Georgia lakes, rather than sending it downstream to Florida and Alabama. Under the agreement, the corps would reduce flows by about 16 percent in the Apalachicola-Chattahoochee-Flint River basin, a watershed that serves metropolitan Atlanta and parts of Alabama before flowing into Apalachicola Bay in Florida. At the same time, the plan would allow more water from another crucial river basin, the Alabama-Coosa-Tallapoosa, to flow into Alabama. Elected officials representing Florida and Alabama agreed to the plan, contingent on continuing negotiations over the water supply shared by the three states. The new operating procedure must still be reviewed and approved by the Fish and Wildlife Service.

title: As Election Day Nears, Playing the Terror Card
description: In the waning days of New Jerseys election season, some candidates for local and state office are reaching beyond the usual campaign accusations of corruption and overspending. They are charging their opponents with being soft on terrorism  or rather, with knowing someone who is.

title: Britain Praises Iraqi Kurds Efforts to End Crisis
description: SALAHUDDIN, Iraq, Nov. 1  While Turkish and American officials have stepped up criticism of Iraqi Kurdish leaders for failing to curb the guerrilla fighters who have sanctuary in northern Iraq, a top British official lent his support to the Kurdish regional government during a visit on Thursday and indicated that he was confident of its commitment to resolving the crisis.

title: Art in an Era of Big Gaps in Income
description: The stage glistened with curtains of what looked like icicle shards, turning it into a mysterious enclosure. But nothing very interesting happened inside that private place in John Jasperses new Misuse liable to prosecution, performed by the John Jasperse Company on Wednesday night at the Harvey Theater as part of the Brooklyn Academy of Musics Next Wave Festival.

title: Rapier Wit and a Nose for Poetry
description: Sometimes a glass of moonshine is just what you need to take the sting out of life. David Leveauxs disarming revival of Cyrano de Bergerac, which opened last night at the Richard Rodgers Theater, is a double shot of silvery hokum, sweet but surprisingly potent. And it goes down so easily, youre drunk and misty-eyed before you know it.

title: Schumer in a Tough Spot After Supporting Mukasey
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  Senator Charles E. Schumer takes credit for exposing what he calls the politically motivated dismissals of United States attorneys. He takes credit for forcing the resignation of Alberto R. Gonzales. And he takes credit for President Bushs nomination of Michael B. Mukasey to be the next attorney general.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Imus Scheduled to Return

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: Israel and Gaza
description: To the Editor:

title: There Are No Good Options in Iraq
description: Following are excerpts from an interview by Michael R. Gordon and Jeff Zeleny of The New York Times with Senator Barack Obama, Democrat of Illinois, conducted on Wednesday afternoon at his campaign headquarters in Chicago. Some questions have been edited for brevity and clarity, and extraneous material omitted. The full interview: nytimes.com/politics.

title: Convict Charges Cover-Up of New Evidence in 88 Death of Parents
description: A Long Island man appealing his convictions for the grisly 1988 murders of his parents sent court papers yesterday accusing prosecutors of a cover-up, alleging that they concealed two important new witnesses and suppressed their testimony about who they say are the real killers.

title: As Kurds Status Improves, Support for Militants Erodes in Turkey
description: KIZILTEPE, Turkey, Oct. 31  Ten years ago, Turkey ran the Kurdish region here in its southeast like a police state. All signs of Kurdish identity  the language, music, national dress  were strictly banned and subject to punishment. Checkpoints were everywhere. Going out after dark was forbidden.

title: Clinton, a Wellesley Alumna, Comes Home to Stump
description: WELLESLEY, Mass., Nov. 1  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton reached out to the nations young women in an emotional return on Thursday to her alma mater, Wellesley College, where she told students who had started lining up at 6 a.m. to see her that in so many ways this all-womens college prepared me to compete in the all-boys club of presidential politics.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: The Issue Is Torture: Voices of Outrage
description: To the Editor:

title: A Station Worthy of New York
description: After years of secrecy, the first inklings of a new and potentially workable plan to recreate Pennsylvania Station have finally become public. There are no lovely drawings yet, but the barest outline for the future railway terminal  a variation on the vision championed by the late Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan  is now available at nylovesbiz.com/moynihanstation.

title: Spending the Night Under the Lighthouse Beacon on the Hudson
description: LIGHTHOUSES capture the imagination in ways few buildings can. They hark back to an era when nautical travel reigned and time moved at a slower knot. Usually at the end of the road, or beyond the waters edge, lighthouses are in some of the prettiest destinations youll find. They even save lives.

title: A Drone No More: No Hive for Him!
description: Bees rarely fly in a straight line. They hover and zigzag, with a purpose known only to the collective brain of the hive. The most genuinely apian aspect of Bee Movie, DreamWorks new animated movie about, well, bees, is that it spends a lot of its short running time buzzing happily around, sniffing out fresh jokes wherever they may bloom. There is a plot  the usual big, elaborate story with the usual important messages about saving the planet, living together in interspecies harmony and believing in yourself  but its a little beside the point. The real fun is the insect shtick.

title: Tropical Storm Blamed for More Than 100 Deaths in Caribbean
description: NASSAU, the Bahamas, Nov. 1 (AP)  Tropical Storm Noel drenched the Bahamas and Cuba on Thursday while rescue workers in the Dominican Republic headed out in boats and helicopters to reach dozens of communities isolated by floods and mudslides. The death toll in the Caribbean rose to 107.

title: Colberts Presidential Bid Ends After a No in South Carolina
description: GREENVILLE, S.C., Nov. 1  Stephen Colberts nascent and satirical presidential campaign came to an abrupt end on Thursday when the Democratic Party in South Carolina decided he was not serious and turned down his application to get his name on the primary ballot.

title: Impressionists Head South
description: Dozens of the Art Institute of Chicagos great masterpieces  including Caillebottes Paris Street; Rainy Day, Czannes Bathers and The Bedroom by van Gogh  will be exhibited at the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth next year while the Art Institute undergoes a major renovation and expansion.

title: Cashman Says Willingness to Spend Hasnt Changed
description: Somehow, Brian Cashman managed to take his children trick-or-treating. Otherwise, he has hardly had a free moment since the Yankees season ended Oct. 8. Next week comes a trip to Orlando, Fla., for the annual meeting of general managers.

title: The Lucky Strike Extra Hits the Modern Era
description: The efforts by Madison Avenue to counter ad-skipping has revived a pervasive ploy from the early days of the medium as well as from the golden age of radio: integrating products into the plots of programs, a practice known as branded entertainment.

title: Optimism in Central America
description: Meeting in a city that is quickly turning into the Miami of Central America, talk inevitably turned to bubbles during this weeks FIABCI Congress of Americas in Panama City. Latin America is not subject to the problems in the real estate market in certain other countries, Julio Fernando Noval Garci, president of Spanish developer Grupo Mall, told attendees at the conference, one of the key regional events for FIABCI, the industry group.

title: A Nose Is a Nose
description: Photos from the Broadway revival of "Cyrano de Bergerac."

title: Highlights From SEMA
description: The Specialty Equipment Market Association trade show is an idea farm for automotive enthusiasts.

title: Week 9 Gems and Gimps
description: Like many fantasy owners in 2007, Ive found it hard to survive life in Bizarro World. Seriously, how can one retain ones sanity in a season when Wes Welker trumps Marvin Harrison, Torry Holt and Roy Williams; Kenny Watson tops Shaun Alexander, Frank Gore and Steven Jackson; and virtually any skill player on the Browns  yes, the ones from Cleveland  is an uber-stud, with Derek Anderson serving as poster boy for the Fantasy Hall of Fame.

title: Boardroom Mutiny at A.C.S.; the Cayne Memo
description: Wheres the memo? As many DealBook readers have noticed, our link to the internal memorandum from Bear Stearns chief executive James Cayne was broken in Friday mornings e-mail newsletter. Heres the right one  and sorry for the confusion.

title: Petrobas to Take Exxons Stake in Japanese Refinery
description: Brazils state-run Petroleo Brasileiro, or Petrobras, will acquire Exxon Mobils majority stake in a Japan-based refinery, Nansei Sekiyu, MarketWatch reported, citing a story in Nikkei News.

title: Blackstone Joins Bid for Nufarm, Sources Say
description: China National Chemical offered $2.96 billion Australian dollars ($2.7 billion) for farm-chemical maker Nufarm, inviting the Blackstone Group and Fox Paine & Company to join, Bloomberg News reported, citing people familiar with the matter. ChemChina would be the first state-owned Chinese company to team up with buyout firms for an overseas acquisition, Bloomberg wrote.

title: Giant Interactive Has Huge Debut
description: Giant Interactive, an online gaming provider, priced its initial public offering in the United States above the initial range at $15.50 for a total deal size of $887 million. This marks the largest listing by a private sector Chinese company ever in the United States.

title: Media Banking Head is Latest BofA Casualty
description: Stephen Ketchum, head of media investment-banking, is the latest person to leave Bank of America. Mr. Ketchum will be succeeded on an interim basis by Rick Swift, who retains his role as global head of telecommunications, The Charlotte Business Journal reported.

title: Two Private Equity Firms Try Glove Maker On For Size
description: Two Chicago private equity firms have acquired a Nevada-based maker of disposable gloves. The Chicago Tribune reported that BarrierSafe Solutions International was bought by Linden and The Edgewater Funds for an undisclosed sum.

title: Altria to Acquire Cigar Maker for $2.9 Billion
description: Altria Group will pay $2.9 billion to buy a cigar maker, John Middleton, from privately held Bradford Holdings in order to expand its United States business beyond cigarettes.

title: Super Conduit Leaves Many Banks Cold
description: Two weeks after Bank of America, Citigroup, JP Morgan and Wachovia pledged their support for the Master Liquidity Enhancement Conduit, intended to take the sting out of the recent liquidity squeeze, other banks have chosen to look the other way.

title: Verizon to Put Executive Pay to Shareholder Vote
description: Directors at Verizon Communications, under fire from shareholders over executive pay practices, said Thursday that they would put the companys compensation plans to an annual vote by investors beginning at its general meeting in 2009.

title: Cisco Secures a Deal for Securent
description: Cisco Systems announced a $100 million agreement on Thursday to buy venture-backed Securent. The three-year-old company makes security software that helps companies manage different tiers of application users.

title: A Wall St. Switch: Good News May Be Good News
description: Update 8:35 a.m. Eastern: Sure enough, when the October employment report came in stronger than expected  166,000 net new nonfarm jobs, modest growth on wages, unemployment level  the early indicators of investor sentiment all jumped in apositive direction. The next short-term question is whether that euphoric reaction will stick around all day and help reverse some of yesterdays declines. The next longer-term question is whether the economy is out of the credit-crunch woods yet.

title: I Enjoy Bending Steel
Specific Media Raises $100 Million in Second Round
description: In a second round of funding, Specific Media has raised $100 million from private equity firm Francisco Partners. TheDeal.com writes that the funds will be used to fuel acquisitions and an initial public offering of the online advertising agency.

title: Barclays Shares Fall on Emergency Funding Rumors
description: Shares in Barclays fell the most in almost three months Friday morning on speculation that it approached the Bank of England for emergency funding.

title: Peltz Files to Raise $750 Million
description: Nelson Peltz has filed with federal regulators to raise up to $750 million from stock market investors for a large shell company that will pursue acquisitions, according to a report in The Financial Times.

title: Serious Materials Builds Up $50 Million Round
description: In a move to fund construction of as many as three large manufacturing plants to produce construction drywall materials, Serious Materials has raised $50 million in a Series B venture capital round.

title: Bloomberg Calls for Tax on Carbon Emissions
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced today his support for a national carbon tax. In what his aides called one of the most significant policy addresses of his second and final term, the mayor argued that directly taxing emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases that contribute to climate change will slow global warming, promote economic growth and stimulate technological innovation  even if it results in higher gasoline prices in the short term.

title: Private Equity Looking to Go the Distance with Marathons
description: Private equity firms are flexing their muscles to get into the running game. BusinessWeek reported that as marathons, half-marathons, and other running events attract hundreds of thousands of people from around the country every year, private equity firms such as Falconhead Capital and Seaport Capital are beginning to take notice.

title: Unable to Engage, MetroPCS Pulls Leap Offer
description: MetroPCS Communications on Thursday pulled its $7.5 billion offer for Leap Wireless International. MetroPCS, which made an unsolicited takeover bid in September, now says that despite widespread investor and analyst enthusiasm for a deal, it could not engage the target in meaningful negotiations.

title: More Cuts at Cerberus-Owned Chrysler
description: Chrysler announced Thursday it would eliminate 11,000 hourly and salaried jobs in the United States and Canada and cut shifts of workers at five plants. The decision comes on top of a plan, announced in February, to eliminate 13,000 jobs and close a factory in Newark, Del. Taken together, Chrysler will be reducing its 2006 work force of about 80,000 employees by 30 percent.

title: Whose Climate Is It, Anyway?
description: I first encountered lots of young people focused on global warming at the 2005 round of climate-treaty talks in Montreal.

title: Life After Securities Fraud
description: When federal marshals snapped the metal handcuffs around his wrists behind his back and led him away on a chilly December day in 2000, Michael L. Smirlock, a hedge fund manager, wondered if his life was over. Hours earlier, Mr. Smirlock had received a call from his lawyer, William Brodsky, telling him that he had been indicted for securities fraud.

title: MySpace Joins Google Alliance to Counter Facebook
description: MySpace and Bebo, two of the worlds largest social networking sites, on Thursday joined a Google-led alliance that is promoting a common set of standards for software developers to write programs for social networks.

title: Stuff Im Reading, Listening to, Watching
description: 1. While were on the subject of rsums, I stumbled onto this handy post by Pinny Cohen on Web Worker Daily on how to keyword optimize your rsum (that is, load it with the buzz words that will get you noticed). Clearly, I like what they are doing over at Web Worker Daily since I seem to be unable to last a week without linking to them.

title: Boutique Banks Enjoy Being the Little Guy
description: Most of Wall Streets big names had a rough third quarter, but not so smaller advisory firms like Lazard and Greenhill & Company. Breakingviews points out a reason for that: its their size and model, the very self-imposed limitations that keep them from reaching the breadth of their bigger rivals.

title: The Early Word: Obamas Iran Resolution
description: Barack Obama reiterated that hes willing to reach a diplomatic hand out to Iran if elected president. In an exclusive one-hour interview with Times reporters Michael R. Gordon and Jeff Zeleny, Mr. Obama again positioned himself as the alternative to Hillary Rodham Clinton:

title: I.R.S. to Examine Private Equity, Hedge Fund Tax Returns
description: The Internal Revenue Service is to examine the tax returns of private equity houses and hedge funds amid evidence that many partners in such firms do not file returns or may have failed to correctly account for their affairs.

title: Merrill Hedge Fund Deals Likely to Be Examined
description: In a bid to cut its exposure to mortgage-backed securities, Merrill Lynch engaged in deals with hedge funds possibly designed to delay its heavy losses, according to a media report.

title: The Bear Stearns Memo: Cayne Speaks
description: After The Wall Street Journal published a scathing profile Thursday of James Cayne, Bear Stearns chief executive  complete with accusations that he regularly smoked pot and left the office at key moments to play golf or bridge  Mr. Cayne shot back in a memorandum to his staff.

title: Blowback
description: Its not often that an obituary sets off a blogstorm, but in the case of Brig. Gen. Paul Tibbets, the man who piloted the Enola Gay over Hiroshima, it was probably to be expected.

title: Slain Real Estate Broker Stirred Strong Feelings
description: Linda Stein, the punk-rock manager turned real estate broker who was found bludgeoned to death on Tuesday in her Fifth Avenue penthouse, was a vibrant and volatile person who aroused strong and often contradictory feelings in those who knew her, Anne Barnard reports in an article examining Ms. Steins life and mysterious death.

title: iRock
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Busted A.C.S. Deal Sparks Boardroom Mutiny
description: We could fire you and the entire management team, the five directors wrote, but that would not help our shareholders, customers or employees.

title: Stray Questions for: Bill McKibben
description: Bill McKibbens books include The End of Nature, Deep Economy and Fight Global Warming Now.

title: A Readers Obligations
description: Thursday night, with Sams strongly-voiced, fair-minded support of Mr. Pevear and Ms. Volokhonskys translation of War and Peace much on my mind, I sat in an auditorium at the Morgan Library, listening to the new curator of literary and historical manuscripts, Declan Kiely, speak on some of the gems in the librarys collection. One of these was a handwritten draft of a broadcast E.M. Forster delivered on the BBC Radios Far Eastern Service in 1943, about Marcel Proust and The Remembrance of Things Past.* In the broadcast, Forster argued that Remembrance was the second greatest novel in European literature (War and Peace being the first, though he scants it in the essay); and that, as such, readers needed to understand better how to read Proust to get from him what they should. Be patient with him, Forster urged. He does not go with a swing, and only gradually draws you into his mesh. And be intelligent. It is so easy to read books stupidly, not with our full powers, and Proust makes no concessions to stupidity. Some writers  and they are great writers  do make concessions. Dickens does, for instance, and even Tolstoy does. Proust doesnt. He expects a constant awareness, both from the mind and from the senses.

title: Clinton Backer Goes on Faith Tour
description: GREENVILLE, S.C.  The Caucus came over to Greenville Thursday to catch the Rev. Marcia L. Dyson, an African-American minister from Washington, D.C., who is touring South Carolina as part of a faith tour on behalf of Senator Hillary Clinton. This is a new effort by the Clinton campaign to reach black women through religion.

title: Merrill Deals Bring Back Barge-Gate Memories
description: Is that a Nigerian barge on the horizon?

title: Giuliani Seen as Sporting Strongest Coattails
description: In his Web column today, Carl Hulse writes that publicly and privately, some senior Republicans are beginning to express the view that former New York City Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani may be the Republican candidate who provides the most help to Republican Congressional candidates who need it the most. Go to Column

title: Friday Morning Kickoff
description: The Ohio State Buckeyes have more than their share of doubters this season. But in a season where up often turns out to be down, the Buckeyes have simply kept winning and find themselves at the top of the polls. That, writes SI.coms Austin Murphy, is due in large part to quarterback Todd Boeckman.

title: Heisman Contenders Are Grasping at Straws
description: Could there be a sea change in the Heisman Trophy race? One of the nations most prominent Heisman straw polls suggests just that.

title: Making Up Jobs
description: Todays employment report is mediocre at best. But to understand that, you have to look past the headline numbers.

title: Performa 07: Beyond Boxes and Labels
description: Im still digesting Adam Pendletons new piece, The Revival, which had only two showings, both last night. Its one of Performas 10 commissions, and its the sort that is likely to bedevil certain people who like their work kept in easy boxes (grant panelists, marketing departments, journalists).

title: Looks Like Hes Been Riding One
description: Aired Thursday night on CBS: You folks have a good Halloween last night? Boy, it was one of those nights. I dont know what the heck happened to me last night. I woke up this morning dressed as Ugly Betty.

title: Worst Performance Since Their Honeymoon
description: Aired Thursday night on NBC: Well, Dominos pizza said they delivered more than 1 million pizzas last night, nearly a 50 percent increase over a typical Wednesday. See, this is how you know Americans are getting too fat, when we cant hand out chocolate and candy without eating pizza at the same time.

title: E-Commerce Vids Up
description: J. Crew, long known for immaculately wholesome models and looks, has decided to push its image of Fresh-Faced Class just a little harder.

title: Living It Up at the Hotel Pennsylvania
description: The Hotel Pennsylvania, across Seventh Avenue from Pennsylvania Station between West 32nd and 33rd Street, has been through a lot of names over the years. According to the Encyclopedia of New York City, it opened in 1919 under that name, and was successively called the Hotel Statler, the Statler-Hilton Hotel, the New York Statler Hotel, the New York Penta Hotel, the Hotel Pennsylvania (again), and the Ramada Hotel Pennsylvania.

title: Socialized Rudy
description: Sure enough, Rudy Giuliani got his prostate treatment from a government-run insurance plan, very similar to the plans that would be available to all Americans under the Democratic health care proposals. Joe Conason has the goods.

title: The Barry Bonds-Hall of Fame Staredown
description: Back in September, Marc Ecko certainly sounded as if he were delivering the last word on the decision to brand Barry Bonds record-breaking home run ball, which he owns, with an asterisk and then donate it to the Hall of Fame.

title: Alonso leaves McLaren
description: Retrospectively, it looks like the decision for Alonso to leave McLaren might have been something on both Ron Denniss and Alonsos minds for a lot longer than we may have thought. The McLaren statement said The mutual parting of ways has not been discussed until now, since it was felt that any such discussion could have seriously disrupted the teams and Fernandos 2007 Formula 1 World Championship challenge. Both parties believe that this was the right decision.

title: Made by Chimps
description: Aired Thursday night on NBC: Child labor activists are protesting the Gap. Theyre protesting the Gap because there are clothes being sold there that are made by kids. Yeah. Even worse, the clothes at Gap Kids are made by babies, and the clothes at Baby Gap are made by chimps.Watch Conan OBrien

title: Arctic Warming in the Last Century, and Now
description: The Competitive Enterprise Institute, which is fighting hard against treaties or legislation limiting greenhouse gases, has pointed afresh to old media coverage pointing to unprecedented Arctic ice retreats and warming early in the 20th century.

title: Merrill Denies Making Inappropriate Transactions
description: Responding to a Wall Street Journal story that said it tried to use questionable deals with hedge funds to delay potential write-downs, Merrill Lynch has denied doing anything wrong. The rebuttal did little to reverse the sharp decline in the companys stock, however.

title: Giuliani Weighs Veep Choice (Already!)
description: ROCK HILL, S.C.  Is Rudolph Giuliani already measuring the drapes?

title: Writers Close To Setting Strike Date
description: The Writers Guild of America will likely begin to strike on Monday. The WGA board was to meet Friday morning to approve the strike and set a time for the first picket lines. A strike captains meeting was set for Saturday morning, the Associated Press reports.

title: Clintons Pile-On Politics
description: Updated Nearly three days after the Democratic debate Tuesday night, Senator Hillary Clintons post-forum tactics  complete with her video titled The Politics of Pile On and her remarks about the all-mens club of politics  have reverberated with more buzz and backlash than her much-criticized performance in Philadelphia.

title: Booked
description: The image at right  a somewhat defaced copy of The Body Politic, a 1988 novel by Lynne Cheney and Victor Gold  is taken from a gallery of photographs posted by a volunteer at a county jail at Wisconsin. All the images are from books in the prisons library.

title: Cellphones as Incentives for Students? Maybe, Says the Mayor
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is certain that cellphones should not be used in school. That much has not changed. And yet

title: When in Rome, Dont Miss the Pope
description: Now I am not at all religious. But Ive always thought that one of the great experiences that most visitors to Rome overlook is the chance to see the Pope  live and in action. Of course, they visit the Colosseum, the Trevi Fountain and the Vatican Museums. So why not check out the Pope himself? It is a bit of living history and you can see the Pope without much trouble (no lines, no metal detectors!), when he delivers his weekly message to the crowds in St. Peters Square.

title: Bond for Giuliani
description: Another day, another Senator endorses Rudolph W. Giuliani. Senator Christopher S. Bond, a Missouri Republican, announced his support for Mr. Giuliani this morning in Washington saying in a statement, America is hungry for a President who will say what he means, and do what he says.

title: Weekly Pick Em
description: After a two-week sojourn to Thursday, the picks return to Friday this week. Lets hope the move will bring better luck to some of our prognosticators (especially the poor soul currently occupying third place). As always, we can expect a surprise or two this Saturday. Will our experts know where those shockers might be coming from? Check out the picks and see. And if you think you know better, by all means, send your choices into the comments section.

title: New Romney Ad Uses Fox Debate Video
description: In a new television ad introduced today, Mitt Romney replays his attacks on Hillary Rodham Clinton from last weeks Republican debate, where he likens her experience to an internship.

title: Obama Tries to Kick the Habit
description: Senator Barack Obama is using nicotine gum to help him quit smoking. Now the question is, can he quit the gum?

title: According to Down Under, Its All Over
description: Oh, Australia: Great beaches, shrimp on the barbie, Iraq War optimism  huh?

title: Edwards Issues Video Critical of Clinton
description: The Edwards campaign is hitting both ends of the spectrum with their media releases. It followed up the Heroes television commercial release, replete with flags fluttering and working-class images, with a new video, emailed today to reporters, called The Politics of Parsing and featuring images of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Correcting a Michael Vick Profile
description: When the editors at Atlanta Magazine convened for a staff meeting on how to cover the Michael Vick saga, they knew we were as much to blame as anyone else, said Rebecca Burns, the magazines editor in chief.

title: That Love Letter to Vick? We Take It All Back
description: Four years ago, Atlanta Magazine published a glowing profile of the Falcons star quarterback, Michael Vick, who is now suspended from the N.F.L. and awaiting sentencing on federal charges stemming from an illegal dogfighting ring, among other legal problems.

title: Weekly Matchups
description: The Saban Bowl in Alabama is getting a lot of ink, but the best game of the week might again be in the Pac-10, with No. 4 Arizona State traveling to Eugene to take on No. 5 Oregon. These two games will be going on simultaneously so get your remotes and TiVos warmed up. Elsewhere Navy hopes to beat Notre Dame for the first time since 1963, while Kansas hopes to go 9-0 for the first time since the Roosevelt administration. The Teddy Roosevelt administration. Can Connecticut stay atop the Big East? Can Boston College keep it going against Florida State? Does Wisconsin have a shot at knocking off No. 1 Ohio State? Is it possible that U.S.C. could fall out of the top 25? So many questions, so few Saturdays remaining. You better pay attention and appreciate the college football while its still around.

title: Sabotaging the Census
description: Withholding money is one way to make sure a project doesnt move forward.

title: Nostalgia About the News Is So Over
description: Theres a lot of comment about the speech by Tom Curley, the chief executive of the Associated Press at the dinner last night to benefit the Knight-Bagehot fellowship at Columbia.

title: Immigration Contortions
description: The campaign story of the week has been Hillary Clintons performance at Tuesdays debate. Was she ganged up on unfairly by her (male) opponents? Did she waffle on issues she should have spoken directly about?

title: In S.C., One Native Son Misses Another
description: CHERAW, S.C.  John Edwards, it seems, missed an item from the morning newspaper.

title: Three Ways to Bash the Buyout Tax Increase
description: The debate about taxing carried interest is a fierce one. Understandably so, considering that carried interest is the source of billions of dollars of profits for private equity fund managers. Congress is considering more than doubling the tax rate for carried interest  which, to put things in perspective, would simply make it the same as what most people pay on plain-old income.

title: The Business of Biking
description: Officials in Portland, Ore., are encouraging small businesses catering to cyclists.

title: Fridays Links: Give Rex a Break!
description: First Rex Grossman, the Bears quarterback, had to deal with losing his job to Brian Griese, a former Miami Dolphin. Then Saturday, a scarecrow dressed in his jersey lost to a scarecrow that was more fish than man in a contest among different classes of elementary school students. That just feels like piling on to me.

title: Writers Strike: East Coast Update
description: East Coast members of the writers guild leafleted near NBCs headquarters at Rockefeller Plaza in New York City this morning.

title: Executive Pursuits
description: Harry Hurt III struggles to stay in tune during a singing lesson from a professional voice teacher.

title: Gender Politics
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton at Wellesley.

title: Berlin in Lights: Something New Under the Carnegie Sun
description: You think they are just halls? Carnegie, Avery Fisher, Alice Tully? Yes, they have the names of rich people and seats and stages. But they also have administrators  smart and ambitious folk often with music backgrounds. They like to do more than book concerts.

title: Afghanistan's New Cash Crop
description: Farmers in Northern Afghanistan are replacing poppy fields with another illicit crop: cannabis.

title: Family Trumps All in Staten Island Endorsement
description: Its official now. James P. Molinaro, the Staten Island borough president, is turning his back on his one-time aide and is endorsing Michael J. Ryan, the Democratic candidate for district attorney in Tuesdays election.

title: Is Ridgewood the New East Bushwick?
description: There has seemed to be a bit of confusion whether or not the evicted loft tenants (hipsters to some) of 17-17 Troutman actually lived in Bushwick (Brooklyn) or Ridgewood (Queens).A press release apparently went out saying they were Bushwick residents, while the answer is: technically the building lies in Ridgewood.

title: Ratings: A Super-sized Anatomy Crowds CSI
description: The first official night of November sweeps was a close race between CBS and ABC for No. 1 in the ratings. Although CBS earned the most viewers on Thursday, ABC eked out a victory among adults 18 to 49 thanks to a slightly extended edition of Greys Anatomy.

title: Hearts Versus Minds on Spitzers Drivers License Plan
description: Today comes another salvo in Gov. Eliot Spitzers efforts to build support for his new plan to give drivers licenses to illegal immigrants while also offering licenses that will comply with new federal security rules under the Real I.D. Act. And it illustrates the basic issue for Mr. Spitzer as he seeks to cope with what appears to be massive public resistance to the new policy.

title: Almost Soviet
description: Amid all the debate over new surveillance legislation and telecommunications immunity, Shane Harris at National Journal drops this little bomb:

title: Single Dad Soliloquy
description: Just yesterday, it seems, I was in the middle of an 18-month deployment. And my life back home, and my family, went through drastic changes during that time. I felt that the pieces of everything I found familiar were being shattered apart like a busy marketplace during a suicide bombing or a thousand sparrows lifting off from a single tree. I wrote this, and this, and this to describe my feelings back then.

title: If Nothing Else, Theres Applause.
description: Well, fashion fiends, weve come to the end of my term as guest blogger here at OTR. I have to say thank you to all for the gracious welcome, and for not leaving me in shreds. Im sure Ill come back and visit from time to time. It really is addictive, isnt it?

title: A Myth About Growing Old
description: It amazes me that I still hear from people who doubt that white wines can age. Actually, its not so much that they doubt it. It simply doesnt occur to them.

title: Inspiration for Your 26.2 Mile Trek
description: Just in time for this weekends New York City Marathon, Runners World magazine offers an extra dose of inspiration with stories of runners who conquered disability or used running as a way to boost a charitable cause.

title: Kitchen Options
description: Do most people who build a house spend the majority of their time thinking about the kitchen? Although I have certainly concentrated on other issues  bathrooms, decks, closets, etc.  the kitchen has been the room consuming 80 percent of my thoughts.

title: At Slain Brokers Funeral, Downtown Edge and Uptown Glitz
description: Women with Chanel scarves and Prada bags mingled with frizzy-haired men in leather jackets and fedoras at a memorial service today for Linda Stein, a fitting tribute to a woman who brought together New Yorks downtown edge and its uptown glitz.

title: The Three Perils of Contracts
description: Contracts are landmines for any international real estate purchase, fraught with local nuances that can make the simplest of deals a nightmare. You have to have a healthy skepticism when you come to the table, said international tax attorney Kevin Mullin of Mullin, Deane and Heimos, a U.S.-based firm.

title: The Week in Comments: Joe Torre Has Three (Syllables, That Is)
description: Following is a selection of reader comments from the weeks most popular posts. But we should note that one of the busiest was the Joe Torre haiku contest from last month, with more than 150 new submissions. (Follow the syllable-counting rules; we delete without mercy.)

title: Vows: Susan and Peter
description: An extra ticket to a Giants football game on December 17, 2005, brought Susan  Moran and Peter Pangis together.

title: Which Advertiser Is on Your Friend List?
description: There was a backlash when a group of consumer and privacy groups called for a do not track list of Internet users who do not want their actions used to target advertising.

title: Performa 07: The Eye of the Revivalist
description: Today I attended a student matinee of David Neumanns fantabulous feedforward and stuck around for the post-performance discussion. The first question from the moderator was something along the lines of What will stand out for you about this piece a week from now?  a typically asinine variation of the sorts of deep thought questions posed to kids, who are apparently now supposed to be able to know what they will remember in the future.

title: Jozy Altidore  We All Want to Win
description: Red Bulls forward Jozy Altidore contributes items for The New York Times Goal blog each week. In his 10th post, Altidore discusses the first-round playoff games against the New England Revolution.

title: Champagne for the Dead
description: What we are reading elsewhere

title: Frugal Chicago
description: Matt Gross, the Frugal Traveler, cuts down on costs, not culture, on a weekend in the Windy City.

title: ACS Ex-Directors: Fighting the Tide
description: Few tales from the buyout boom have taken as strange a turn as that of Affiliated Computer Services. Not every company can talk of its yacht-owning chairman threatening its five independent directors, in a complicated tale of buyout negotiations gone bad. (Steven Davidoff, who writes the M&A Law Prof Blog, has this to say: Wow, wow, wow.)

title: Out to Sea on Law of the Sea
description: The strange campaign for the Republican presidential nomination took another weird turn this week when every major Republican candidate spoke out against the Law of the Sea Treaty, which was approved by a 17-4 committee vote and may soon come to a vote on the Senate floor.

title: The Strange Case of the Dancing Dentist
description: For some reason, misadventures in a dental office hold a special morbid fascination for many people, and The Lede is no exception. (Otherwise, why would Laurence Oliviers wince-provoking interrogation scene in Marathon Man resonate so deeply, or Steve Martins comic turn in Little Shop of Horrors make us laugh so much?)

title: Finding Zhao Gu
description: At about 10 a.m. on June 19, 2003, in the western Chinese city of Wuwei, a man named Ma Guoxing was walking across town, intent on a pending business appointment.

title: Late for the Sky
description: Comedy Centrals Brian Regan on how chatty pilots get during delays:

title: The Dodd-Biden Run-In
description: Caucus readers often beg for more from the two policy wonks and longtime senators in the Democratic field, Senators Chris Dodd of Connecticut and Joe Biden of Delaware.

title: Edwards and Danny Glover in South Carolina
description: YORK COUNTY, S.C.  John Edwards just left a dusty backwoods community called Blackmon Road, one of the poorest places in South Carolina. The road back here used to be called Trash Pile Road because everyone threw their garbage here.

title: Whos Predator, Whos Prey?
description: Rob Stewart, a 27-year-old diver, photographer and now filmmaker from Toronto, desperately wants us to fall in love with sharks before we wipe them out.

title: Strike News: Writers Block Starts Monday
description: Unless the writers guild and the studios reach a deal this weekend, writers will strike beginning at 3:01 a.m. Eastern time on Monday, the guild announced this afternoon.

title: Strike News: Stop Me If Youve Heard This One
description: Next week on The Daily Show with Jon Stewart is this weeks The Daily Show with Jon Stewart.

title: Kerry Rhodes Questionable for Sunday
description: The Jets released their latest injury report on Friday, and it contained one surprise: Kerry Rhodes, the Jets safety, is questionable with a knee injury. Rhodes talked and joked with reporters in the locker room after practice. He appeared to be doing fine.

title: Hail, the Conquered Hero
description: You take my life when you do take the means whereby I live.  Shylock

title: Sony Ad 2
description: Sony Ad 2

title: Sony Ad
description: An advertisement by Sony featuring Peyton Manning.

title: Citi Watch: The Search for a New Leader
description: Late Sunday update: The New York Times reported Sunday that former Treasury secretary Robert E. Rubin was named as Citigroups chairman at its boards emergency meeting. The firm is expected to still look for a new chief executive.

title: Bloggingheads: The Mormon Problem
description: Journalists Amy Sullivan, of Time, and Rod Dreher, of the Dallas Morning News, on how Romney can quell doubts about his faith.

title: Putting the Reader First
description: I realize that this is always an irksome issue in translation: perfect fidelity versus greater felicity. So let me just go on record as saying that when my work is translated into other languages, I give my translators full permission to fix my mistakes, and to make my work sound more graceful and elegant, better  rather than clumsier and worse  than it is in English. Ultimately, the pleasure of the reader should trump even the brilliance of the translator.

title: Tolstoy as Spinach
description: Hold on a second, Sam. You mean the NY Review of Books, your most formidable competitor, beat us to press with a War and Peace review? AND they got the author of Natashas Dance to do it? Sam, we need to talk

title: Frugal Chicago
description: Matt Gross, the Frugal Traveler, cuts down on costs, not culture, on a weekend in the Windy City.

title: At Fort Drum, Military Families Reunite
description: Soldiers from the 10th Mountain Division's Second Brigade reunited with their families Thursday after spending 15 months in Iraq.

title: Japan's Aging Prisoners
description: With one of the world's most rapidly aging societies, Japan is confronting a sharp increase in the number of older criminals and prisoners.

title: North Texas Troubles
description: When the season began, Todd Dodge was best known for being a real-life Eric Taylor, the coach on the television show Friday Night Lights.

title: Mike Hart: The Run
description: It didnt take long for one of Mike Harts closest high school friends, Carl Runge, to come up with a favorite moment from their days at Onondaga Central High school. And in these wonderful YouTube days, Runge even told me how to look it up.

title: Joel Zumaya and the Perils of a Damaged Shoulder
description: Reading today about Joel Zumaya, I could not help thinking of Brien Taylor.

title: Obama, Civil Rights and South Carolina
description: GREENVILLE, S.C.  Barack Obama spent the day giving formal speeches about the civil rights struggle and said that civil rights pioneers had overcome fears to achieve big dreams  and he asked his listeners to overcome their own fears and support him for president.

title: Clinton and Opponents Tangle Over Attacks on Her
description: CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 2  Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama tangled on Friday over whether women should be treated equally to men in the boxing ring of presidential politics. At the same time, Mrs. Clinton elaborated on the pile-on politics video her campaign prepared, which showed her under assault from the six male candidates at the Democratic debate on Tuesday.

title: Orchestra, Muscles Flexed
description: Figuratively speaking, Yuri Temirkanov and the St. Petersburg Philharmonic Orchestra rained death on Wednesday and Thursday evenings to end their stand at Carnegie Hall. First came pertinent excerpts from Prokofievs ballet score Romeo and Juliet, and you know what happens there. Then, on Thursday, Mussorgskys Songs and Dances of Death set up Prokofievs cantata Alexander Nevsky, with its harrowing song, The Field of the Dead.

title: Welcome the Translators
description: To the Editor:

title: When Happy Songs Are Suspect, No Cheerful Tune Is Safe
description: What really makes us happy is when the Wicked Witch dies, the jazz singer Tierney Sutton observed in her introduction to Ding-Dong! The Witch Is Dead on Thursday evening at Birdland. Musing about the guilty pleasure of schadenfreude, Ms. Sutton and her band (Ray Brinker on drums, Kevin Axt on bass and Christian Jacob on piano) made the crowing victory song from The Wizard of Oz the concluding chapter of a show that was a sequence of biting musical essays on happiness, or the lack thereof.

title: Despite Gain in Jobs Data, Wall Street Is Skeptical
description: A robust employment report offered investors a pleasant surprise yesterday, but some thought it was too good to be true.

title: With Resolution Unlikely, Writers Guild Sets Strike for Monday
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2 When the sun rises here on Monday morning, movie and television writers will be ready to head for their assigned picket lines outside Hollywoods studios and production sites.

title: Toxic Fumes Suspected in 4 Workers Deaths
description: When a worker inside a manhole at a northern Wisconsin landfill was overcome late Thursday, apparently by toxic fumes, a fellow worker went down to help. He, too, was overcome, and another colleague went to the rescue, and then another. By the time firefighters pulled the men, two of them brothers, from the hole, all four were dead, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Rice Under Pressure in Trip to Turkey
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 2  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice came under pressure from Turkish officials upon her arrival here today to publicly blame Kurdish leaders in Iraq for the recent Kurdish rebel attacks on Turkish forces.

title: Bush Vetoes Water Bill, Citing Cost of $23 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2  President Bush on Friday vetoed a bill authorizing $23 billion in water resource projects, calling it overly expensive, and Congressional Democrats responded angrily, accusing him of insensitivity to the hurricane-damaged Gulf Coast, a big beneficiary of the legislation. They pledged to override him.

title: Leaps and Pirouettes and 40 Nasty Whacks
description: Could there have been a time when the heart sank at the prospect of yet another performance of heavily dramatic ballets like Antony Tudors Undertow or Agnes de Milles Fall River Legend? Well, perhaps the murky Undertow is going too far. But in a post-Balanchine era of hectic movement for its own sake, Fall River Legend looked pretty good when American Ballet Theater performed it Thursday night at City Center.

title: As Japan Ages, Prisons Adapt to Going Gray
description: ONOMICHI, Japan  In the prisons brightly lighted workroom here, 47 inmates sat behind long tables and quietly performed their chores.

title: Duran Duran Continues Its Revival With a Debut on a Broadway Stage
description: On Sunday Duran Duran had its first off-Broadway tryout, in Wallingford, Conn. There were the usual technical difficulties  the show started an hour late  and not all the critics were kind. (The group tested lighting schemes, video cues and fans patience, Kenneth Partridge wrote in The Hartford Courant.)

title: The F.C.C., Cable and Competition
description: To the Editor:

title: Magic and Memphis, Along With a Little Bit of Music
description: Its odd to see a play about music in which music is almost an afterthought. Hoodoo Love, by Katori Hall, is about an aspiring blues singer in Memphis in 1933. But while there is some singing onstage, it serves more as embellishment than main event. The lead character, Toulou, gives lip service to her ambition, but it seems to be grafted onto her role. And the casting for this play, which opened on Thursday at the Cherry Lane Theater, was definitely about acting, not about voice.

title: Pittsburgh Episcopal Diocese Votes to Leave the Church
description: JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Nov. 2  By more than a two-to-one vote, members of the Episcopal Diocese of Pittsburgh voted Friday in favor of separating from the national church because of a theological rift that began with the consecration of an openly gay bishop in 2003.

title: Lottery Numbers
Sitter Is Charged in Babys Death
description: A baby-sitter in North Plainfield, N.J., who the police say left a 6-month-old boy unattended, which resulted in his death, was charged with endangering the welfare of a child yesterday.

title: A Few Little Pieces
description: Only 1,729 people asked to be reimbursed for buying James Freys largely fabricated memoir, A Million Little Pieces, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Larry D. Drury, a lawyer, urged Judge Richard J. Holwell of Federal District Court in Manhattan to approve the deal, which offered a refund to anyone who had bought the book before Mr. Freys falsehoods were acknowledged. The book earned the author more than $4 million, Mr. Drury told the judge, who approved a final settlement with disgruntled readers. In January 2006, the Web site thesmokinggun.com revealed that Mr. Freys memoir included numerous fabrications. Mr. Frey and his publisher then acknowledged that he had made up parts of the book. Numerous readers lawsuits were consolidated before Judge Holwell, and a settlement was reached that called for readers to be reimbursed. Random House set aside $2.35 million to cover their costs, but the claims for reimbursement cost just $27,348. Another $783,000 will be paid out in legal fees, along with $432,000 in costs associated with publicizing and carrying out other parts of the settlement.

title: Farm Belt Follies
description: The Senate has one last chance to rid the country of an irrational, outdated and unfair 70-year-old program of federal farm supports that enriches the few at the expense of the many, distorts international trade and damages the environment. It has one last chance, in other words, to produce a farm program of which the country can be proud.

title: Justice Nominee Gets 2 Key Votes From Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2  The confirmation of Michael B. Mukasey as attorney general appeared to be all but certain on Friday after two key Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee announced they would support the nomination despite complaints over Mr. Mukaseys refusal to clarify his views on what amounts to torture.

title: 12 for 26.2
description: The New York City Marathon is among the more difficult races to predict because the challenging course puts an emphasis on race strategy rather than raw speed. This was demonstrated last year, when Marilson Gomes dos Santos, a largely unproven marathoner from Brazil, surged near Mile 20 and left a pack of the worlds fastest men far behind on his way to victory.

title: Pushing the Traditional Toward New Destinations
description: The interplay was congenial, cooperative and briskly confident at Bargemusic on Thursday night during the first of two sets by the guitarist Howard Alden and the clarinetist and tenor saxophonist Ken Peplowski. What it wasnt, on the whole, was conservative or tired. The two musicians were covering familiar turf in one guise or another, but with a spirit of inquiry that renewed itself at every turn.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A sports article yesterday about the N.F.L. career of Jaguars running back Fred Taylor misstated the number of players ahead of him on the career rushing list who are in the Pro Football Hall of Fame. Of the 20 players ahead of him, 10  not 18  are in the Hall of Fame. (Several running backs ahead of him are either still active or retired too recently to be considered for the honor.)

title: Different Situations, Same Goal, for 2 Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 2  Jets left guard Jacob Bender could make his first N.F.L. start Sunday, against the team he grew up rooting for. Laveranues Coles could miss his first regular-season start in 105 games, against the team he left in 2005.

title: Musharraf Warned Not to Impose Emergency Rule
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 2  A senior American commander, Adm. William J. Fallon, warned Pakistans president on Friday not to impose emergency rule, saying that doing so would jeopardize American financial support for the military here.

title: Rating Video Mayhem
description: The Entertainment Software Rating Board, which assigns age ratings to video games, will keep the mature label on Manhunt 2, despite calls from some groups to make the rating more restrictive after hackers defeated measures that blur some of the games violence, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Manhunt 2 went on sale in the United States on Wednesday. On Thursday the games publisher, Take2 Interactive Software, confirmed that hackers had managed to unblur some gruesome scenes on the PlayStation Portable version, which include killing with axes and other implements. The ratings board had originally given the game an adults only rating, but Take2 made modifications, including blurring some details, to gain a mature rating, meaning that it is intended for players 17 and older.

title: No Second Chances in Olympic Quest
description: Among the 131 men vying for one of the top three spots at the United States Olympic trials in the mens marathon are a former world-record holder (Khalid Khannouchi), the reigning Olympic silver medalist (Meb Keflezighi) and a runner who in April became the second-fastest American marathoner in history (Ryan Hall).

title: Thousands Rally in Capital Against Georgia President
description: TBILISI, Georgia, Nov. 2  Tens of thousands of demonstrators converged on the capital of Georgia on Friday, demanding parliamentary elections for early next year and venting dissatisfaction with the countrys once enormously popular government.

title: In Risky Spacewalk, Astronaut Repairs Damage
description: An astronaut on an unusually risky spacewalk yesterday repaired a damaged solar array on the International Space Station.

title: An Italian Author Driven Into the Shadows by Success
description: ROME

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A dance review on Oct. 25 about the opening-night gala for American Ballet Theaters season at City Center, where the company is performing only ballets created since 1940, omitted an American city that will see this modern face of American Ballet Theater. Starting Monday and running through Nov. 11, the company will perform programs from the City Center repertory at Zellerbach Hall in Berkeley, Calif., on the campus of the University of California. New York is not the only city in the United States where these works will be seen.

title: That Promised Peace Conference
description: One month before President Bushs Mideast peace conference  the administrations first serious effort in six years  its still not clear what will be on the agenda or who, beyond the Americans, Israelis and Palestinians, will show up. Even the date is still up in the air.

title: Footnotes
description: Ballet Hispanico will present its 20th annual New York season at the Joyce Theater from Nov. 27 to Dec. 9. For information: joyce.org. ... The Italian Cultural Institute of New York, Fondazione Aida and the Film Society of Lincoln Center are presenting Pier Paolo Pasolini  Poet of Ashes from Nov. 26 to Dec. 4, showcasing the work of Pasolini at locations around New York. For information: www.pasolininewyork.com.

title: Europe Awards Rockers
description: Avril Lavigne, below, and the band Muse each won two awards at the MTV Europe Music Awards in Munich, the BBC reported yesterday. Ms. Lavigne was named best solo artist, and her composition Girlfriend won the award for most addictive song. Muse won for best British, best Irish and best headline act. Rihanna, the R&B singer, won the ultimate urban prize, while the British singer Amy Winehouse took the artist choice prize, chosen by her fellow musicians. Linkin Park won the award for best band of 2007.

title: Hall Earns Olympic Berth With Commanding Win
description: Ryan Hall made a move in the United States Olympic trials marathon this morning reminiscent of his quick rise in the sport over the past year, surging away from a talented pack in the 17th mile to take a commanding victory and grab an Olympic berth. With his victory, he announced himself as a contender for a medal at next years Beijing Olympics.

title: Homeless Man Killed at Shelter
description: A 46-year-old man was stabbed to death at a homeless shelter in Harlem yesterday after a dispute with another man, the police said.

title: Tanker Collision Kills 3 and Closes I-95 in Connecticut
description: EAST LYME, Conn., Nov. 2  A tanker truck veered out of control on Interstate 95 on Friday morning and slammed into five other vehicles, killing three people and injuring at least three others, the state police said.

title: Bush, Mukasey and the Fairness Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: S.I. Borough President Backs Ex-Aides Rival
description: The already heated race for Staten Island district attorney became even more highly charged yesterday when James P. Molinaro, the borough president, officially broke ranks with his former aide, District Attorney Daniel M. Donovan Jr., and endorsed the Democratic candidate in the race.

title: New Yorks Calorie Counter
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the Halloween Adventure store in the East Village, which attracts workers with a theatrical style of dress, referred incorrectly to the operation of the store, part of a nationwide franchise. It is not in fact the only one open year-round.

title: Officials Say Teacher Fled Country With Boy
description: OMAHA, Nov. 2  When a 12-year-old boy from Lexington, a small city about 200 miles west of here, began acting out and his grades fell, it took his family awhile to suspect that his sixth-grade teacher, a popular young woman who had returned to teach in her hometown, might be preying on him.

title: Proclamation of Emergency Issued by Gen. Pervez Musharraf
description: Following is the text of the Proclamation of Emergency declared by General Pervez Musharraf on Saturday, as released by The Associated Press of Pakistan, a state-run news agency.

title: Period Music, This Time on Modern Instruments
description: If Bach were here, hed be rather amazed and wonder what that huge piece of furniture is, the English violinist Andrew Manze said in genial introductory remarks before a recital he presented with the pianist Richard Egarr on Thursday night at Carnegie Halls Zankel Hall. Mr. Manze was referring to the impressive Steinway grand at which Mr. Egarr, his longtime musical partner, was seated at center stage.

title: Germanys Black Years Seen From the Inside
description: PARIS, Nov. 2  It can be argued that Impressionism killed off historical painting, and with it the tradition of portraying military victories on canvas. Yet the genre was not quite dead. Early in the 20th century history painting made another appearance in art, and this time, stripped of glory and heroism, war was finally shown in all its ugliness.

title: Children and Cold Medicines
description: Anyone who doubts the power of drug company marketing to overcome a dearth of scientific evidence need only ponder the disturbing matter of cold medicines used to treat children and infants.

title: From a Trash Bin, Singing Cossacks and a Bitter Dispute
description: LAKEWOOD, N.J.  Like many strange tales, the story of the antiques dealer, the scholars from Scotland and the contested archive of a Russian conductor begins in the suburbs of New Jersey.

title: Live From New York, Its Not Quite the News!
description: A week ago Brian Williams was in a Manhattan department store buying a gift when a woman walked up to him and introduced herself, commenting that she always watched him anchor NBC Nightly News but had recently read that he was going to be the host of that networks Saturday Night Live.

title: Michigans Hart Leads on the Field and on Campus
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  When Michigan Coach Lloyd Carr made a recruiting visit to Mike Hart in Syracuse nearly four years ago, he and Hart ducked out of a frigid and windy night into a local rib joint called Dinosaur Bar-B-Que.

title: Peace of Mind When They Ask to Borrow the Car
description: THERE is no moment where childhood and incipient adulthood collide that is more universal than the moment a teenager gets behind the wheel of a car. For the teenager, it is simple  it is the first real taste of freedom. But for the parents, that is when the worrying begins.

title: As They Say on MySpace, Would You Chillax?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.A.W. and Ford Reach Tentative Agreement
description: DETROIT, Nov. 3  The United Automobile Workers union reached a tentative four-year agreement with the Ford Motor Company early Saturday that follows the pattern set in new contracts at General Motors and Chrysler.

title: The Lords Take the Lead in a Long-Running Battle
description: The 33rd annual bridge battle between the two halves of the British Parliament, the House of Lords and the House of Commons, took place at Crockfords Club in June.

title: 3 Top Republican Candidates Take a Hard Line on the Interrogation of Detainees
description: A central tenet of every leading Republican candidates campaign for president is one simple and powerful idea: I alone can best defend the United States from the threat of terrorism.

title: A Spotlight on the Green Side of Bottled Water
description: LAST summer, environmentalists took on the bottled water industry. On their Web sites and in their press releases, many environmental groups pointed to bottled water as a prime example of an unnecessary product that uses scarce resources and adds more plastic to overtaxed landfills.

title: My Favorite Menace
description: The Law of the Sea Treaty has become a hot-button item in the Republican presidential race.

title: Egg-Throwing Ends in Arrests of 2 Officers
description: Two New York City police officers were arrested yesterday on charges that they drove a 14-year-old boy who had been throwing eggs at cars on Halloween to a remote area on Staten Island and left him there.

title: The Dings and Dents of Toyota
description: DETROIT, Nov. 2  It might seem odd to suggest that a 70-year-old company is going through growing pains, especially one with $183 billion in annual sales.

title: Election Monitors to Head to Russia Despite Limits
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 2  The Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe announced Friday that it would send a skeleton crew of observers to cover Russias December parliamentary elections, after Moscow sharply reduced the number of monitors it normally allows.

title: Medicine That Really Tastes Smooth
description: In recent years classical music has developed a subcategory of concert series devoted to presenting new music to audiences tacitly presumed not to want it. The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Centers New Music in the Rose series, which opened on Thursday, joins other attempts over the years, including the Orchestra of St. Lukes Second Helpings and the societys own Double Exposure.

title: Lowell Smith, 56, Dancer in Harlem Troupe, Dies
description: Lowell Smith, a principal dancer for the Dance Theater of Harlem who used precise mastery of classical ballet and exquisite expressiveness of body and face to convey emotions from tranquility to charged passion, died on Oct. 22, in Los Angeles. He was 56.

title: Let Us Pray for Wealth
description: A GLOBAL survey recently conducted by the Pew Research Center shows that the wealthier you are, the less likely you are to be religious.

title: Bush Sees Iraq Progress From Troop Buildup
description: FORT JACKSON, S.C., Nov. 2  President Bush offered an upbeat assessment on Friday of progress in Iraq, saying that while corruption remained a problem and unemployment was high, the economy was growing, violence was down and, slowly but surely, the people of Iraq are reclaiming a normal society.

title: Corrections
description: A television review last Saturday about Silence of the Bees, on PBS, misstated the cause of death of a honeybee colonys males and also included imprecise references to other aspects of hive life. The males, called drones, die after mating or are driven out of the colony by the females and die of exposure; they are not worked to death. (The females do the work.) The life span of the males can range from two or three weeks to nearly two months or more; their life span is not always limited to 30 days. The number of males in a colony can be in the hundreds or more; a colony is not limited to 100. At the height of the nectar-gathering season, colonies can include 50,000 bees or more; thus a queen can be attended by more than 30,000 subjects, not just 30,000.

title: Imbibers Add It All Up, and Gulp
description: SEVERAL years ago in his book Smart Women Finish Rich, David Bach coined the term latte factor to capture the way in which an innocuous expense  like a daily cup of coffee  could put a dent in your budget.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the Federal Reserves cut in short-term interest rates misspelled the name of Standard & Poors housing price index. It is Case-Shiller, not Case-Schiller.

title: Big Drop in Merrill Stock on Hint of New Troubles
description: Merrill Lynch, still operating without a permanent chief executive, saw its shares fall sharply yesterday on the possibility that it might have to write down more of its high-risk credit exposure.

title: Missile Kills 5 in Northwest Pakistan; U.S. Denies Attack
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Nov. 2  A missile fired from an unmanned aerial drone killed five militants and wounded six other people in Pakistans lawless tribal areas on Friday, according to a Pakistani security official and a local resident.

title: James Ensures Knicks Open With a Loss
description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 2  A new season began at last for the Knicks on Friday, days after most of the N.B.A. got under way and much later than they probably preferred after a disastrous off-season.

title: Citigroup Chief Is Set to Exit Amid Losses
description: The embattled head of Citigroup, the global banking giant, has told directors that he would resign from the bank after an emergency meeting this weekend in the wake of a $5.9 billion write-down and sharp drop in profit, people briefed on the situation said last night.

title: Talking Point for Rodriguez? $350 Million
description: It turns out there might have been a magic number that could have gotten the Yankees the meeting they wanted with Alex Rodriguez: $350 million. That was the minimum bid the Yankees would have apparently had to make to begin negotiations with Rodriguez before he opted out of his contract during Game 4 of the World Series last Sunday.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,831 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Thursday:

title: Corrections
description: A headline in some editions on Thursday with an article about efforts by Dr. Mazoltuv Borukhova, the widow of a Queens orthodontist, to compel the city to return her daughter to her left the incorrect impression that Dr. Borukhova was in court because she had shot her daughter. The shooting victim was Dr. Daniel Malakov, Dr. Borukhovas estranged husband  not their child, Michelle Malakov, who was placed in the custody of Dr. Malakovs relatives. Neither Dr. Borukhova nor anyone else has been charged in Dr. Malakovs killing. (Go to Article)

title: Storied Hotel Is Closing for a Major Face-Lift
description: Pierre New York, the venerable neo-Renaissance hotel on Fifth Avenue that has been the setting for countless society parties and served as a home away from home for famous patrons including Elizabeth Taylor and Richard M. Nixon, is set to close its doors in December for an extensive renovation, according to hotel industry executives.

title: Texas Proceeding With Plan to Auction Preserve
description: As a Comanche moon rose one night last week over the West Texas border town of Terlingua, the Christmas Mountains Association convened over Mexican food in the Longhorn Ranch Motel.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Tuesday about Ronaldo da Costa, a former world-record marathoner, attributed an erroneous distinction to him regarding his running pace. Derek Clayton, who set a marathon record in 1969, was the first man to run the entire event at a pace of less than 5 minutes a mile  not da Costa, who was the first man to run one faster than 3 minutes per kilometer.

title: Defense May Seek U.S. Testimony in Secrets Case
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2  A federal judge on Friday ordered Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Stephen J. Hadley, the national security adviser, to be ready to testify as defense witnesses at the trial of two former pro-Israel lobbyists accused of receiving secret national security information.

title: Maker of Lipitor Digs in to Fight Generic Rival
description: It is shaping up to be the biggest shift yet to a generic drug, potentially saving the nation $2 billion a year or more in prescription costs.

title: Igor Moiseyev, Russian Choreographer, Dies at 101
description: Igor Moiseyev, the Russian choreographer who created a new form of theatrical folk dance and whose troupe was one of the most popular dance companies of the 20th century, died today in Moscow. He was 101.

title: Political Leader of Sri Lankas Tamil Tigers Killed in an Airstrike
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 2  The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, the Sri Lankan separatist group known for suicide attacks on political and military targets, lost their most prominent international representative on Friday when the head of their political wing was killed in an airstrike by the Sri Lankan military, according to the guerrilla group.

title: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about tax legislation proposed by Representative Charles Rangel, a New York Democrat and chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, misstated House Speaker Nancy Pelosis position on the proposal. She supports Mr. Rangels plan. (When she gave a simple no answer to reporters on Oct. 25, she was answering their question about whether the House Democratic leadership supported the plan.)

title: Corrections
description: A headline in some editions on Thursday with an article about efforts by Dr. Mazoltuv Borukhova, the widow of a Queens orthodontist, to compel the city to return her daughter to her left the incorrect impression that Dr. Borukhova was in court because she had shot her daughter. The shooting victim was Dr. Daniel Malakov, Dr. Borukhovas estranged husband  not their child, Michelle Malakov, who was placed in the custody of Dr. Malakovs relatives. Neither Dr. Borukhova nor anyone else has been charged in Dr. Malakovs killing.

title: Russia Temporarily Rescinds Ban on Lufthansa Overflights
description: PARIS, Nov. 2  In an effort to defuse an escalating diplomatic dispute with Germany, the Russian authorities agreed on Friday to allow Lufthansa to temporarily resume cargo flights over Russia.

title: For Teenage Drivers, Ever-Present Parents
description: Following are some of the companies that sell driver tracking devices:

title: Drew Carey Stands Up for Medical Marijuana
description: Drew Carey, above, who recently replaced Bob Barker as the host of The Price is Right, defends the use of medical marijuana in a video posted online Thursday on Reason.tv, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Smell that smell, the 49-year-old comedian says as he walks into a medical marijuana dispensary. Thats the smell of freedom. The video is one of 20 that Mr. Carey plans to make for the Reason Foundation, a nonprofit educational group. Mr. Carey offered to produce brief documentaries on topics ranging from traffic congestion to immigration for the foundations Web site, said David Nott, the president of the foundation. They are to appear every two weeks through the end of the year on the site, Mr. Nott said.

title: Blazed and Confused
description: Los Angeles

title: Head of Class, but Not on Draft Day
description: In the N.F.L., as in Hollywood, landing the right leading man is not as simple as picking through screen tests. Sometimes it works out despite ones best judgment, as it did when Jack Nicholson was cast to play Randle McMurphy in One Flew Over the Cuckoos Nest after James Caan turned down the role.

title: Abbas Meets West Bank Hamas Leaders
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 2  The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, met Friday with a group of Hamas leaders in the West Bank, the first time he has done so since Hamas routed Fatah forces in Gaza in June.

title: Floodwaters Devastate Mexican State of Tabasco
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 2  Navy helicopters plucked people from roofs on Friday as rising floodwaters covered much of the Gulf Coast state of Tabasco, putting the state capital, Villahermosa, underwater.

title: A Prosecution Goes Bad, and a Judge Lets Loose
description: On Thursday morning, Roy Lindley DeVecchio, a retired F.B.I. agent who faced the astounding charges that he helped a mob informant kill four people, walked out of court after the prosecutors suddenly dropped the case. It turned out that their star witness had told an entirely different story a decade ago, to two of the citys premier investigative reporters. After hearing her testify against Mr. DeVecchio, they dug out a tape of that old interview.

title: Credit Ratings Cut to Junk for Top 3 Home Builders
description: Standard & Poors cut the credit ratings of the three largest American home builders  Lennar, Pulte Homes and D. R. Horton  to junk yesterday as demand for new homes deteriorated.

title: Two Mismatched Parts Are Made Into a Whole
description: The New York Philharmonic was the ideal orchestra for two very different pieces on Thursday night. Semyon Bychkov was the visiting conductor at Avery Fisher Hall, and his choice of music  all from the 20th century but with little mutuality to share  suggested that the term 20th-century music doesnt mean a great deal.

title: Mayor Bloomberg to Attend U.N. Meeting on Climate Change
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is once again getting ready to pack up his plane and head overseas, this time to the island of Bali for a United Nations meeting on climate change next month, he said yesterday.

title: Two Suspended
description: World Wrestling Entertainment Inc. suspended two performers for what it said were violations of its substance-abuse and drug-testing policy. Chris Mordetzky, known as Chris Masters, was suspended 60 days for his second violation. Harry Smith, who wrestles under the name D. H. Smith, was barred for 30 days for an initial violation. In July, traces of injected testosterone and painkilling drugs were found in the body of Chris Benoit. Benoit, 40, a performer for eight years, committed suicide in June after killing his wife and 7-year-old son in their Atlanta home, the police said.

title: Risky Spacewalk Saturday to Mend Solar Array
description: Astronauts will take part in an unusually risky spacewalk today in an effort to mend a torn solar array on the International Space Station.

title: A Marriage of Technology and Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Training Through Pregnancy to Be Marathons Fastest Mom
