description: Paula Radcliffe, the British distance runner who holds the world record in the womens marathon, ran throughout her pregnancy last year. She even ran the day before she gave birth to a healthy baby, Isla, on Jan. 17. And 12 days after Islas birth, she started running again.

title: End to a Shabby Prosecution
description: The federal government agreed this week to terminate 20-year-old deportation proceedings against two Palestinian men who were wrongly targeted for their political beliefs and activities. Better late than never, but we fear that there is little hope that the Bush administration will learn any lesson from this shockingly mishandled prosecution.

title: To Correct an Injustice
description: To the Editor:

title: Igor Moiseyev, 101, Choreographer, Dies
description: Igor Moiseyev, the master choreographer who created a new form of theatrical folk dance in Russia and whose troupe was one of the most popular dance companies of the 20th century, died yesterday in Moscow. He was 101.

title: For Soldiers Families, Battles Are Not Far Off
description: FORT DRUM, N.Y., Nov. 2  The last time Bobbi Plautz welcomed home her husband, Travis, from Iraq, he was a changed person. He listened to different kinds of music and craved different kinds of food. He stayed up all night and wrestled with nightmares.

title: Nets Play Poorly Early, and Then It Gets Worse
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 2  About six months after the Nets knocked out the Raptors in the first round of the N.B.A. playoffs, Toronto played like a team with a score to settle while the Nets played like a bunch that spent the off-season in a slumber.

title: Predators Who Fight to Control Yellowstone
description: The template for animal documentaries these days is well established: Go to the ends of the Earth to follow cute, photogenic mammals as they organize their days and lives around the primal functions of eating, mating and nurturing their young.

title: Manning and Brady Bring to Mind Quarterbacks Past
description: Shortly before New England crushed Washington last Sunday in Foxborough, Mass., a few of us began a press-box debate over who is King of The Hill among N.F.L. quarterbacks, the Colts Peyton Manning or the Patriots Tom Brady.

title: Myanmar Junta Orders Top U.N. Official in the Country to Leave
description: BANGKOK, Nov. 2  Myanmars government on Friday ordered the expulsion of the United Nations top diplomat in the country after his office issued a critical statement urging the ruling generals to heed the voices of protesters.

title: Embattled Barnard Anthropologist Is Awarded Tenure
description: An assistant professor of anthropology at Barnard College whose scholarship on the use of archaeology in Israel has attracted both fierce criticism and scholarly support has been approved for tenure, Barnard officials said in a statement released yesterday.

title: Loyal to Kerik, Giuliani Missed Warning Signs
description: This article was reported by Russ Buettner, Michael Powell and William K. Rashbaum and was written by Mr. Powell.

title: Neck and Neck
description: On Thursday, the first official night of November sweeps, CBS had the most viewers but ABC the most adults 18 to 49, thanks to a slightly extended edition of Greys Anatomy, which was the winner in that demographic, according to Nielsens estimates. That network also led the 9 p.m. hour in total viewers (18.8 million)  beating CSI on CBS (18.7 million). But estimates for the ABC show were rough because it ran seven minutes into the 10 p.m. time slot of the struggling Big Shots. ABC remained third in the 10 p.m. hour with an average of 9 million viewers, just below NBCs ER (9.1 million) but significantly behind CBSs Without a Trace (14.6 million). CBS finished a strong second to ABC in the 18-to-49 group, while NBC ranked third for the night in that demographic and fourth in total viewers behind Fox.

title: Zeppelin Injury Raises Questions
description: The press agent in London was getting the same question all day: Which finger was it?

title: Start With the Youth
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Thursday about the legal, political and public relations strategy of Blackwater Worldwide, the security contractor whose operations in Iraq are under scrutiny, misstated the middle initial of the former Whitewater independent counsel who was retained for a time to help handle suits filed by the families of slain Blackwater employees. He is Kenneth W. Starr, not Kenneth D.

title: Baseballs Losing Formula
description: St. Louis

title: Bloombergs Pay Raises for Unions May Trouble the City After He Leaves
description: Amid the gloomy talk of subprime mortgage failures, tumbling profits on Wall Street and a cooling real estate market, one powerful force squeezing New York Citys budget has gone largely undiscussed: the sharply rising cost of municipal labor.

title: Mayors, Looking to Cities Future, Are Told It Must Be Colored Green
description: SEATTLE, Nov. 2  The mayor of Fayetteville, Ark., gushed through a slide show about how his city was in the midst of great change. Bleak roads and bland shopping strips were being redrawn to a more human scale. Downtown condominiums were going for a million dollars. Streets once silent at night now bustled.

title: U.N. Ousts Peacekeepers in Sex Case
description: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 2  The United Nations said Friday that 108 Sri Lankan soldiers from its peacekeeping force in Haiti would be sent home Saturday on disciplinary grounds over accusations that they had paid for sex with local women, many of them minors.

title: Prominent Jesuit Is Target of New Federal Charges
description: A prominent Jesuit priest accused of sexually victimizing teenage boys who were his valets as he traveled the world leading Roman Catholic spiritual retreats was taken into federal custody yesterday in Chicago.

title: UConn 07 Is Having a Year Like Rutgers 06
description: Rutgers opened the season with a bowl victory under its belt, a Heisman Trophy contender in its backfield and a national ranking (No. 16). Expectations ran high for the program, which in its previous season evolved from an afterthought to a powerhouse.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about the ambivalent feelings some Boston Red Sox fans have over the teams newfound success omitted the name of one of the authors of Red Sox Century. Richard A. Johnson was also a writer, along with Glenn Stout, who commented on the psyche of Red Sox fans.

title: Bringing Musical Mercy to the Vocally Challenged
description: I STEPPED up to a music stand in the living room of Judy Blazers off-Broadway apartment clutching the lyric sheet of Oh, What a Beautiful Mornin. It was an unseasonably warm fall afternoon. The window unit air-conditioner hummed like an off-key mechanical bird. The chintz furniture and the Sohmer piano seemed to tremble under an ensemble of spotlights and Web video equipment. Bass clef sweat stains soaked my T-shirt.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A brief report in the Memo Pad column in Business Day on Tuesday, about American Airlines new service between Kennedy International Airport and Stansted Airport near London, misstated Stansteds proximity to Londons financial district in comparison to Heathrow Airport. It is farther away; it is not closer. (A direct express train from Stansted to the Liverpool Street Station in the financial district makes the trip shorter from that airport.)

title: Al Arbour: The Man Behind the Glass
description: Uniondale, N.Y.

title: Free to Roam Onstage Yet Captured on Camera
description: When a dancer works with one choreographer for a long time, its hard to escape the dynamics and coordinations that are embedded in that performers way of moving. Ashleigh Leite, a strong presence in the Stephen Petronio Company between 1997 and 2005, hasnt managed that escape. But perhaps she doesnt need to.

title: Leaving Corporate Life at 60
description: LIFE expectancies are increasing. Phrases like 60 is the new 40 are becoming increasingly commonplace, and just about every survey shows people invariably feel younger than their chronological age.

title: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about an earthquake in the San Francisco Bay Area on Tuesday night misstated the location of the epicenter of the large earthquake that hit the area in 1989. The epicenter was south of the San Francisco Bay, not west of it.

title: Fair Housing and Section 8
description: To the Editor:

title: Ford and U.A.W. in Marathon Contract Talks
description: DETROIT, Nov. 3  Negotiators from the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers union were in a marathon bargaining session Friday, a sign that a tentative labor agreement may be imminent.

title: Chic and Punk Mingle Tearfully at Murdered Real Estate Brokers Funeral
description: Women with Chanel scarves and Prada bags mingled with long-haired men in leather jackets and fedoras at a memorial service yesterday for Linda Stein, the punk-rock manager turned real estate broker who was found slain in her Fifth Avenue apartment this week. It was a fitting tribute to a woman who had brought together New Yorks downtown grit and its uptown glamour.

title: Plaintiffs Awarded Share of Curlins Sale
description: A state judge in Kentucky has given the more than 400 plaintiffs in a diet-drug lawsuit the right to 20 percent of the proceeds from the future sale of Curlin, the Preakness Stakes and the Breeders Cup Classic champion.

title: Trouble at the Winfrey Academy
description: A former dormitory matron at Oprah Winfreys school for disadvantaged girls in South Africa has been arrested on charges of abuse and sexual assault, The Associated Press reported yesterday. A police spokesman said the 27-year-old woman, who had worked at the Oprah Winfrey Leadership Academy for Girls, was arrested on Thursday. At least seven victims have submitted statements, a police spokesman said. The woman is being held by the police and is expected to appear on Monday in Sebokeng magistrates court, south of Johannesburg. Officials at the school announced on Oct. 17 that a dormitory matron had been suspended amid allegations of serious misconduct. The local media recently reported that Ms. Winfrey had made a tearful apology to parents and pupils in a meeting at the school. Ms. Winfrey, above, opened her school outside Johannesburg on Jan. 2 with celebrities like Tina Turner and Spike Lee in attendance, as well as former President Nelson Mandela. The $40 million school, with a first class of 152 girls, was the fulfillment of a promise that Ms. Winfrey made to Mr. Mandela six years ago. It is intended to give girls from deprived backgrounds a quality education.

title: New Life for Initiative to Apportion Electoral Vote
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2  Republican donors are pumping new life into a proposed ballot initiative, considered all but dead by Democrats a month ago, that would alter the way electoral votes are apportioned in California to the benefit of Republican presidential candidates.

title: A Dingy Road Glorified in Music and Cinema
description: The subject of The BQE, the self-described cinematic suite that had its premiere at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Thursday, is an epitome of New York City grime. Sufjan Stevens, the composer, said onstage that the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway is one of the worlds ugliest expressways. But his treatment channeled Hollywood glamour, with three screens of images, a soundtrack of lush, triumphal orchestral fanfares and a chorus line of five people twirling Hula-Hoops.

title: Online Universities: Not Just for the Young
description: To the Editor:

title: F.C.C. Case Is Appealed to Justices
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (Dow Jones)  The Federal Communications Commission has asked the Supreme Court to review a federal appellate court decision that rejected an effort by the commission to enforce indecency standards.

title: Ford and U.A.W. in Marathon Contract Talks
description: DETROIT, Nov. 2  Negotiators from the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers union were in a marathon bargaining session Friday, a sign that a tentative labor agreement may be imminent.

title: Sunnis Say Baghdad Hampers Anbar Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2  The Bush administration has singled out Anbar Province as an example of what can be accomplished in Iraq when local citizens join forces with the American military to fight insurgents. Attacks have declined sharply in the province, and American officials have looked for ways to replicate those gains in other contested regions of Iraq.

title: Cable Networks Help Viacoms Profit Surge 80%
description: A day after CBS Inc. told investors that its third-quarter revenue rose 8 percent but would be down 2 to 3 percent for the full year, Viacom, which like CBS is controlled by the entrepreneur Sumner M. Redstone, said that its third-quarter revenue rose 24 percent, to $3.27 billion.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Trouble at the Winfrey Academy

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Oct. 6 about the Atlantic City mayor, Robert W. Levy, who dropped out of public view after saying he was temporarily stepping aside for medical reasons, misstated his age. He is 60, not 64. (Mr. Levy returned the following week after a stay in a rehabilitation clinic, and subsequently resigned.)

title: Pressed by Turks, Rice Seeks to Solve Kurdish Rebel Threat While Urging Restraint
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 2  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice came under pressure Friday from Turkish leaders seeking American help to curb Kurdish guerrillas in northern Iraq. But it was not clear whether her public pronouncements at the outset of this long-awaited visit would be enough to satisfy them.

title: Dismissal of Agents Murder Charges Returns Victims Family to Square One
description: After 17 years, the killing of Patrick Porco is a cold case. Again.

title: Worsening the Odds
description: Lonnie Lynam, a self-employed carpenter in Pipe Creek, Tex., specialized in spiral staircases. Friends thought of him as a maestro in a toolbelt, a whiz with a hammer and nails.

title: Lawmakers in Venezuela Approve Expanded Power for Chvez
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 2  The National Assembly approved a constitutional overhaul on Friday that would enhance President Hugo Chvezs authority, allowing him to be re-elected indefinitely and giving him the power to handpick rulers, to be called vice presidents, for various new regions to be created in the country.

title: Senate Democrats Facing a Pay as You Go Problem
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2  Senate Democrats face an agonizing choice in the days ahead: find a way to raise at least $50 billion in new taxes, or undermine their most important rule for enforcing budget discipline.

title: Auto Sectors Role Dwindles, and Spending Suffers
description: THE automobile industrys share of the American economy has fallen to a historic low, the government reported this week, a few days before Chrysler announced another round of layoffs.

title: Thousands Rally Against Georgias Once Popular President
description: TBILISI, Georgia, Nov. 2  Tens of thousands of demonstrators converged on the capital of Georgia on Friday, demanding Parliamentary elections for early next year and venting dissatisfaction with the countrys once enormously popular government.

title: An Unlikely Megachurch Lesson
description: One Sunday morning in 1995, Ron Wolfson and Rabbi Lawrence Hoffman braked to a halt in an oddly enlightening traffic jam. The line of cars was creeping toward Saddleback Church in Southern California, whose services were drawing thousands of worshipers. As two Jews, Mr. Wolfson and Rabbi Hoffman had crossed the sectarian divide to try to figure out how and why.

title: Personal Metal Messages From Ancient Egypt
description: In ancient Egypt, stone sculpture was the stuff of intimidation: regal, public, unyielding. A stone statue could be smashed, but it could never be reincarnated. Metal, though, is malleable, unstable. A metal statue could be melted down and re-formed as a weapon or a pair of earrings; it could slowly change color over the years.

title: Quad Q&A: Mike Hart
description: Few players have been more prolific over the past four years than Michigan tailback Mike Hart. Hes became the universitys all-time leading rusher earlier this year. That accomplishment is all the more impressive considering that the Wolverines arent going to be playing teams like Hawaii or New Mexico State anytime soon. But Harts an even bigger deal on the Michigan campus because of his charity work and involvement in student groups. Heres his take on good bar-b-que, his plans on being Michigans head coach, working in the seafood department at a grocery store and why he guaranteed a victory over Notre Dame.

title: Tragic Day at Olympic Trials
description: A U.S. Olympic trials marathon turned tragic when Ryan Shay collapsed less than six miles into the race in Central Park and died at a hospital.

title: Orphans of Rwanda
The Tenth Muse
description: Growing Up

title: Chinese Recycling
U.A.W. and Ford Reach Tentative Agreement
description: DETROIT, Nov. 3  The United Automobile Workers union reached a tentative agreement with the Ford Motor Company early this morning after a 41-hour marathon bargaining session, completing a series of new contracts with the American auto companies.

title: Uh-Oh. Hardy-Har Deficit Looms.
description: Writers strike set for next week, and you know what that means:

title: Straight Arrow With Arrow in Head?
description: In a first you may care about, Brian Williams of NBC tonight becomes the first working evening-news anchor to host Saturday Night Live, Bill Carter reports. Heres Williams on partaking in late-hour sessions this week in the rabbit warren of SNL offices at 30 Rock:

title: Were Having a Party
description: The Quad is doing something a little bit different this Saturday. Instead of the usual morning links, were starting the day off with a tailgate party. The Times own Melissa Hoppert is a veteran of many Ohio State tailgates and she gives us the inside scoop on the granddaddy of them all, Hineygate. Do you have a favorite tailgate? Feel free to tell us about it in the comments section.

title: Musharraf Declares State of Emergency
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 3  The Pakistani leader, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, declared a state of emergency on Saturday night, suspending the countrys Constitution, blacking out all independent television news reports and filling the streets of the capital with police officers and soldiers.

title: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 3
description: Here is a slide show of 12 photographs that tell the story of the past week in the New York region. Subjects include a Halloween parade in the East Village, a fire that left three people dead in Queens and the Metropolitan Operas production of Mozarts Zauberflte.

title: The Early Word: The Kerik Relationship, Clinton Papers
description: We have a real treat for you this morning: the latest in our Long Run series about the presidential candidates is a Michael Powell composition about then-Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and his relationship with Bernard B. Kerik. The former police commissioner currently faces several felony charges, and Mr. Giuliani has faced questions about what he knew about Mr. Kerik and when he knew it. Heres the crux of the issue:

title: Obama Challenges Clintons Textbook
description: Updated, with audioSPARTANBURG, S.C.  Barack Obama just unleashed a corker of a speech that had students here at Converse College on their feet and cheering. He painted a bold new picture of a world in which he were president and that brought wild applause.

title: Hey, not so big spender
description: By now, everyone knows that Bush has been a big spender, betraying the principles of small-government conservatism.

title: Shape of the planet
description: Yesterday I complained that news reports on Rudy Giulianis fake facts describe his position as in dispute, when its actually just false, and describe the truth as something Democrats say rather than as, simply, the truth.

title: Berlin in Lights: Ute in Weimar
description: The Caf Sabarsky in the Neue Galerie is a wonderful place to hear cabaret. Its a small, warm, wood-paneled room in which no one is very far away from the action. But Ute in Weimar, as one might call the opening salvo in the Berlin in Lights festivals series of cabaret evenings there, bore about the same relationship to Lotte Lenya as the Caf Sabarsky bears to the Weimar Republic.

title: Doris Lessing revealed
description: My cat, that is. In the photo for Rolling Stones interview, p. 126

title: Arrrggghhh!
description: The lede, from the AP report on Rudys prostate claims:

title: The Real Climate Debate: To Cap or to Tax?
description: In his Web column today, Tom Redburn writes that as even the most skeptical critics have begun to accept the scientific consensus that the burning of fossil fuels cannot continue uninterrupted without risking a dangerous elevation of the Earths atmospheric temperature, a simmering debate among experts has erupted into the open, and the next Congress and president might have to pick a winner. Go to Column

title: A Rout in Lawrence
description: Its still early, but the most eye-popping score of the day will likely be Kansas 76-39 rout of Nebraska. It was the most points scored against the Cornhuskers in their 117-year history.

title: Scenes From the Campaign Trail
description: On the ground in Iowa, New Hampshire and South Carolina.

title: Who Needs One?
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  There are no palm trees, no beach, no surf, but this is still a paradise  for scalpers.

title: Sundays Breakfast Menu, Nov. 4
description: Be glad that you get an extra hour of sleep tonight, because youll want to set an alarm to catch this Sundays talk shows, each of which boasts a powerful lineup.

title: Personnel File: Willis Is Excelling for Lackluster 49ers
description: There have been few positives for the 49ers during a season in which their 2-0 start had onlookers saying the team was not nearly as good as expected. But one shining light has been Patrick Willis, the rookie linebacker from Mississippi.

title: Week 9 In Preview: Colts May Be Patriots Only Obstacle
description: Anyone who sees the Colts game against the Patriots as a dream matchup is ignoring the downside.

title: Going Green in Eugene
description: EUGENE, Ore.  In a state that prides itself on being environmentally friendly, it was not a surprise that before todays game between No. 4 Oregon and No. 6 Arizona State approximately 150 people had a rally outside Auzten Stadium to encourage the reduction of carbon emissions.

title: There Is No Chance They Will Nod Off
description: Aired Friday night on NBC: Military experts say that companies are now very close to developing technology that can make tanks invisible. Invisible tanks? Dont we have enough defense contractors ripping off America as it is? Whats it going to be like when they start charging us for invisible tanks? You owe us $10 billion. Where are the tanks? Right there.

title: Noun + Verb + 9/11 + Iran = Democrats Defeat?
description: Leave a comment about the Sunday, Nov. 4 column.

title: How Far East? Not Too Far
description: When Europeans arrived in North America around 1600, there were, it is generally believed, 30 to 60 million buffalo roaming from the Hudson Bay to Mexico except for the extreme southeast and southwest of what is now the United States.

title: A Rate Cut, a Rally and a Plunge
description: The Federal Reserve cut short-term interest rates last week, but the broad stock market fell anyway, pulled down by disappointing earnings and concern about the state of the overall economy.

title: Two Necessary Bond Issues
description: These are not the best of times, fiscally speaking, in the great state of New Jersey. Years of irresponsible borrowing by legislators and governors of both political parties have confronted the state with billions and billions of dollars of debt. Unfunded pension costs alone are estimated to be more than $50 billion.

title: A Satirical Sit-Coms Memorable Music
description: SHOULD you find yourself offended by a crass punch line or a tasteless sight gag on Family Guy, the gleefully provocative cartoon sitcom that celebrates its 100th episode on Fox Sunday night, you should direct your displeasure to the numerous arrested adolescents who populate its writing and animation staffs.

title: From One Asian Cuisine to Another
description: THE sign over the door of Paradise Island in Williston Park reads: Chinese Restaurant. Dont you believe it. This is a Vietnamese restaurant, the only one I know of east of Queens.

title: Remembrance of Things Cast
description: The announcement early last year that Ian Schrager was building 40 Bond, a condominium project in downtown Manhattan, with the Swiss architecture firm Herzog & de Meuron set the design world abuzz. It wasnt the first condo to be designed by a star architecture firm, and it wont be the last, but 40 Bonds construction site became a destination for even jaded New Yorkers.

title: Discovering Hartford With Florence Berkman; Can Fake Grass and Dirt Really Be Healthy?; For Unwed Mothers, a Place to Thrive (3 Letters)
description: Discovering Hartford With Florence Berkman

title: Growing Old in New York, and Struggling to Keep Up With Ever-Increasing Rents
description: I went to visit friends in Florida, and I was almost going to move there, but then I didnt like it, said Robert Murphy. He sat in his tidy new apartment in a Manhattan senior housing development. He laughed, dismissing a retirement in Florida. I missed my New York.

title: Where Did the Buck Stop at Merrill?
description: ON Oct. 24, Merrill Lynch announced its biggest write-down ever, an $8.4 billion charge that also represents the biggest known loss in Wall Street history. Six days later, its chief executive, E. Stanley ONeal, retired from the company he had run since 2002.

title: Perhaps a Boor (or a Bore), but Imus Makes It Work
description: ON THE SAW MILL RIVER PARKWAY -- Forget, for a moment, the Rutgers womens basketball team and all that. Heres one drive-time drivers opinion about Don Imuss old morning show. It wasnt very good.

title: Correction
description: Contrary to a statement in last weeks editorial, Christopher Caruso will not be on the ballot Tuesday in Bridgeport.

title: Chelseas Own P.R. Man
description: The Habitats article last Sunday about a jewelry designer who lives in Chelsea and bemoans the gentrification of the neighborhood included an incorrect comment from the designer about the number of self-service laundries on Eighth Avenue between 14th and 23rd Streets. Two remain, not just one.

title: From Restaurant Fryers, a Petroleum Alternative
description: SINCE the Asian restaurant Pearl East opened in Manhasset 10 years ago, its owner, Cathy Huang, has been disposing of the excess cooking grease from egg rolls and fried noodles in a big trap outside that had to be pumped out monthly. She put waste vegetable oil into big barrels and paid a hauler $40 a month to take it for recycling.

title: Safety Note: Smoke Alarms and Carbon Monoxide Detectors
description: Fire prevention authorities recommend changing batteries in smoke alarms and carbon monoxide detectors twice yearly, at the start and the end of daylight saving time. The time change occurred this morning.

title: Fuel Cell Hurdle: Only the Price Tag
description: HIGH on the list of marketing challenges that automakers face in selling zero-pollution cars is convincing the public that the cars can cover sufficient driving distances between refills or recharges.

title: Canada a Favorite Among Gays
description: Canadian cities dominated a recent list of the top 10 international destinations for gay and lesbian travelers, according to a recent survey published by Community Marketing Inc. (www.communitymarketinginc.com), a San Francisco-based gay and lesbian market research company. The 12th annual tourism survey queried 7,561 consumers, who answered 42 questions in an online survey in September. Canada, where same sex marriage is legal, was the overall country favorite with three cities in the top 10  Montreal, Toronto and Vancouver, the latter known for its gay-themed cruises (www.cruiseyt.com). Among individual cities, London took the No. 1 spot. Other popular destinations included Paris, Rome, and Puerto Vallarta and Cancn in Mexico. New York took top honors in the domestic Top 10 list, which also included Las Vegas, San Francisco and Fort Lauderdale.

title: Silver Polish
description: For an iconic example of postwar flatware, Georg Jensens Caravel is hard to beat. It was designed in 1957 by Henning Koppel, whose singular approach to organic design also produced necklaces resembling whale skeletons and a curvy pitcher that was nicknamed the pregnant duck. Caravel combines the primal power of sculpture with the finesse of Danish silversmithing  all the more impressive considering it was Koppels first attempt at cutlery. The flat surfaces of its lean, tapered handles contrast elegantly with the more rounded, sensual forms of the spoons bowl, the forks tines and the knifes blade.

title: Letters
description: Domestic Violence

title: Short Leash for Knicks at Home
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Nov. 3  A year ago, it took Knicks fans less than seven minutes to start booing during the home opener. It will probably not take them that long Sunday night, regardless of how the team plays in the early going against the Minnesota Timberwolves.

title: Put a Lid on It
description: Paris is cuckoo for cocottes.

title: When the Sacrifice of a Queen Leads to a Checkmate Victory
description: There is no moment in chess that is more magical than the queen sacrifice, especially when it leads to checkmate.

title: Political Art: Futile, Maybe, but Still a Noble Pursuit
description: I have always had my doubts about the ultimate purpose of political art. My skepticism stems from a feeling that there are more effective forums for the expression of outrage at social, political and humanitarian injustices than the quiet rooms of a museum.

title: In a Former Mining Colony, a Haven for Artists
description: MINERAL DE POZOS, Mexico

title: The Affordability Problem
description: IN New Rochelle and Mount Vernon this fall, ribbon-cutting ceremonies held to mark the opening of new affordable housing drew elected officials who hailed their own efforts to get such units built, despite the high cost of land in Westchester and public resistance in many communities. So far this year, 95 new units of below-market-rate housing have become available, and 487 are under construction.

title: Even Cut 50 Percent, Earmarks Clog Military Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3  Even though members of Congress cut back their pork barrel spending this year, House lawmakers still tacked on to the military appropriations bill $1.8 billion to pay 580 private companies for projects the Pentagon did not request.

title: The Farther East River
description: The Farther East River

title: Questions to Answer
description: In addition to 120 legislative races, voters will decide four questions on Tuesday.

title: New Detainee Rights Weighed in Plans to Close Guantnamo
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  Administration officials are considering granting Guantnamo detainees substantially greater rights as part of an effort to close the detention center and possibly move much of its population to the United States, according to officials involved in the discussions.

title: Two Different Policies on Subletting in a Co-op
description: Q I am a shareholder in an East Village co-op. Our proprietary lease has a provision that enables existing shareholders to buy additional apartments. The lease also has a provision that if a shareholder who lives in the building has more than one apartment, he or she has the right to sublet the other apartment without board approval. Is this legal?

title: Ex-Treasury Chief to Fill In at Citigroup
description: Citigroups board is highly likely to name Robert E. Rubin, the former Treasury secretary and an influential adviser to its embattled leader, as its interim chairman at an emergency meeting today, according to a person briefed on the situation.

title: No More Mayor Chicken Little
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg, who administered tough medicine and nursed the city back to fiscal health after he took office in 2002, has been warning that another economic cooling is around the corner. Few people have paid real attention, though, and its not hard to see why. Despite the mayors predictions, year after recent year  helped along in a big way by the real estate market  the city has registered billions of dollars in surpluses, $4.4 billion in the last fiscal year alone. No longer.

title: Under 21 and Running for Mayor
description: HARTFORD

title: What You Get for ... $2.5 Million
description: Millsboro, Del.

title: Mouse Almighty
description: RONKONKOMA

title: Brady and Manning Meet in Battle of the Brands
description: They are manly, for what is a quarterback but footballs macho lead actor?

title: The Imperial Presidency
description: Three years after the American invasion of Iraq, after endless searches had found no sign of weapons of mass destruction, President Bush still believed that Saddam Hussein had had them. He expressed that conviction repeatedly to his chief of staff, Andrew Card, until Card left the White House in April 2006.

title: Larissa Brookes, Elizabeth La Blanc
description: Larissa Cheney Brookes and Elizabeth Anne La Blanc were joined in a civil union on Thursday at Town Hall in Ridgewood, N.J. Philip F. Sheridan, a municipal judge there, officiated.

title: A Rail Station Brings London and Paris Closer
description: It will have Europes longest Champagne bar, a daily farmers market, Wi-Fi, dozens of boutiques  and some of the worlds fastest trains. It is St. Pancras International (stpancras.eurostar.com), the new London hub for Eurostar, the high-speed train service that connects England to Belgium and France through the Channel tunnel.

title: Edwina von Gal | Landscape Designer
description: Shes dug dirt for a whos who of international clients, from Richard Serra to Calvin Klein.

title: Susan Moran, Peter Pangis
description: Susan Eugenie Moran was married yesterday to Peter Gus Pangis. The Rev. Ambrose Bitziadis-Bowers officiated at St. George Greek Orthodox Church in Clifton, N.J., with the Rev. Peter J. Orfanakos, another Greek Orthodox priest, taking part.

title: Childhood for Dummies
description: Nostalgic parents who made a best seller of a faux- 1920s rough-and-tumble manual, The Dangerous Book for Boys, may soon do the same with its just-published companion, The Daring Book for Girls.

title: The Performer in Waiting
description: MY grandfather was the president of a small Sephardic synagogue in Coney Island. My father and I would walk there from Brighton Beach for Sabbath services and the high holidays, and walk back. It was a time for conversation about the world, about growing up, about anything I wanted to ask him and vice versa.

title: Its a Dangerous World
description: To the Editor:

title: Could Rodriguez Stay a Yankee? Only for Less Money
description: The only way the Yankees would bring back Alex Rodriguez is if Rodriguez became so desperate to stay that he would take a pay cut, something they do not envision. But Rodriguez has not eliminated the Yankees from consideration, and his agent, Scott Boras, said last night that he was still willing to meet with the team.

title: Man Bites Dog, and Girls, Too
Jamie Rosen, Brian Fields
description: Jamie Beth Rosen, the daughter of Harriett and Frederic Rosen of West Bloomfield, Mich., was married last evening to Brian David Fields, the son of Cynthia and Lawrence Fields of New York. Rabbi Joseph Krakoff officiated at the Ritz-Carlton, Dearborn, in Michigan.

title: Smoke Detectors Are Just a Start
description: SMOKE detectors were just the beginning. Now there are all manner of detectors that can alert homeowners to everything from carbon monoxide to freezing pipes.

description: BRIDGEPORT

title: Demon Barber, Meat Pies and All, Sings on Screen
description: SOME time in 1980, during the five months that the grim and glorious musical Sweeney Todd played the Theater Royal Drury Lane, a California college student visiting London bought a ticket. And another and another and another.

title: Pakistani Sets Emergency Rule, Defying the U.S.
description: This article was reported by David Rohde, Jane Perlez and Salman Masood, and was written by Mr. Rohde.

title: Bonnie Regan, James Gerhart
description: Bonnie Jeanne Regan, a daughter of Regina and John Regan of Mahopac, N.Y., was married on Wednesday to James Robert Gerhart, a son of Kathleen Cronin and a stepson of Timothy Cronin of Suffern, N.Y. The Rev. Richard Hasselbach, a priest affiliated with CITI Ministries, officiated at the home of the brides parents.

title: Noun + Verb + 9/11 + Iran = Democrats Defeat?
description: WHEN President Bush started making noises about World War III, he only confirmed what has been a Democratic article of faith all year: Between now and Election Day he and Dick Cheney, cheered on by the mob of neocon dead-enders, are going to bomb Iran.

title: Outside the Box
description: MANY colleges say their mission is to mold young minds, but a few take it to the next level. They have a particular philosophy about how life should be lived or knowledge absorbed, and they want to make sure their students are not just reading about it or dabbling in it. They want their students to live it, day in and day out, for four years. Sound intense? It is. A bit offbeat? That too. Such colleges are not for everyone, nor do they want to be.

title: Lindsay Schmidt, Jeremy Beard
description: Lindsay Elizabeth Schmidt and Jeremy Alexander Beard were married yesterday at St. Bartholomews Church in New York. The Rev. Elizabeth Garnsey, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Rebecca Gertsmark, Ben Oren
description: Rebecca Anna Gertsmark a daughter of Edith and Aleksandr Gertsmark of West Bloomfield, Mich., was married last evening to Ben Oren, a son of Miky and David Oren of Melville, N.Y. Rabbi Harold Loss officiated at the Royal Park Hotel in Rochester, Mich., with Cantor Neil Michaels taking part.

title: Economic Growth, Clad in Military Garb
description: PAKISTANS recently re-elected leader, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, has indicated that he might finally heed the calls for him to step down as head of the army. But even if the general becomes a civilian president, that will not take the uniform off Pakistans economy.

title: Sara Holmes and George Flowers
description: Sara Catherine Holmes, the daughter of Linda Schwartz of Dumfries, Va., and Hannibal E. Holmes Jr. of Haverstraw, N.Y., is to be married today to George William Flowers, a son of Dr. Loma Flowers and Edgar Flowers of San Francisco. The Rev. Robert E. Slade, a United Methodist minister, is to perform the ceremony at Mount Zion United Methodist Church in Washington.

title: ACT vs. SAT
description: FROM the moment I gave birth, I began to gird myself for the difficult questions that tiny, nosy people might one day ask. I prepared answers worthy of a White House press secretary to address such subjects as teenage sex (never heard of it) and drug use (mild decongestants only).

title: In Local Waters, an Oyster Resurgence
description: TWO years after a failed effort to declare it an endangered species, the Eastern oyster is making a big comeback, thanks in part, experts say, to farming and habitat restoration efforts across the Northeast.

title: Unblinking Look at Death Without Nobility
description: AT the Sundance Film Festival, where the writer-director Tamara Jenkinss second feature, The Savages, had its premiere in January, dysfunctional families are, to an exhausting degree, the norm.

title: The Global Sympathetic Audience
description: ON Aug. 1, Nick Starr, a 27-year-old computer consultant from Tampa, Fla., was tapping text messages into his cellphone, telling hundreds of his virtual friends about his day.

title: A Tiny Child Needs More Help Than a Mother Can Deliver
description: After eight months at a homeless shelter, Rosa Zayas and her young son, Rodwin, recently moved into a one-bedroom apartment of their own. It was the 15th home for this fragile family since Ms. Zayas, 31, and her husband separated in July 2005.

title: Prodigal Returns, Bearing Dialogue
description: THE souvenir shop in Shubert Alley, the heart of the theater district, wasnt open the other morning as Aaron Sorkin walked by, but he stopped and squinted in the window. Frowning, he expressed disappointment that the Wicked T-shirts were stacked untidily on a shelf, the logos unaligned. Mr. Sorkin once worked in this very shop, in the fall of 1983, when he was fresh from studying musical theater at Syracuse University and came to New York to get work as an actor.

title: The Riddle of Steve Levy
description: Steve Levy is a brilliant Suffolk County executive, a leader with tenacity, integrity and a lot of good ideas. He is also a maddening one, a small-bore, surprisingly ineffective mishandler of his signature issue, immigration. Solve that conundrum and you solve the riddle of Mr. Levy, which this page has not been able to do.

title: The Perils of Petrocracy
description: I.

title: I, Robot: The Man Behind the Google Phone
description: Mountain View, Calif.

title: Iraq Postings
description: To the Editor:

title: The Style Network
description: Ask her how she stocks Mc & Co, the under-the-radar home furnishings and accessories boutique in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and the French-born decorative painter Corinne Gilbert will blithely reply, I just go to my friends. Her best buds in Paris, Catherine Lvy and Sigolne Prbois, the team behind Ts & Ts Associes, give Gilbert access to their entire range of tableware and lighting (including their asymmetrical black goblets). Justin Giunta  the founder of Subversive Jewelry, who served as Gilberts assistant before becoming the current darling of costume-jewelry collectors  will unveil his foray into lamp design at Mc & Co this fall. Jagged white ceramic vases appear courtesy of Joan Bankemper. There are new discoveries, too, like Sylvain Willenzs delicate arboreal light sculpture and Casey OConnors glasses with nature-study decals  la Albertus Seba. Gilbert has also chipped in, designing the chicest tarp totes on either side of the Atlantic. What a pal! 57 North Sixth Street; (718) 388-3551.

title: Dear Abby
description: All the nations founding fathers were concerned about how history would judge them, none more so than John Adams. Adams often voiced his apprehension that his contribution to American independence would be overshadowed by the attention paid to George Washington and Thomas Jefferson. Yet the survival of more than 1,100 letters exchanged by John and Abigail Adams, 289 of which are included in this welcome new edition, gives Adams an advantage over his contemporaries in the historical record.

title: Sarah Altman, Bryan Bumsted
description: Sarah Crispin Altman, the daughter of Elizabeth S. Altman and Charles R. Altman of Pittsburgh, was married there last evening to Bryan MacLeod Bumsted, a son of Patricia P. Bumsted and Roy R. Bumsted III of Bonita Springs, Fla. The Rev. Leslie G. Reimer, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Heinz Memorial Chapel.

title: Surrendering to the Suburbs
description: IT was a clear fall day, exactly a year ago, when we left Manhattan for our new home in Westchester. As we ambled up the Sprain Brook Parkway (upstate, in city parlance), I remember thinking how beautiful the leaves were  a brilliant array of golds, reds and browns  and that if we had stayed in the city our foliage appreciation would have been limited to what we could see on quick jaunts through Stuyvesant Town.

title: Rally Salvages More Than Win for L.S.U.
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Nov. 3  On his way off the field, Louisiana State center Brett Helms paused to consider what could have been an unbearable loss to Alabama. Helms had to catch his breath, not because it was a grueling four-hour game, but because it was a four-hour siege of emotion.

title: Swanns Hypothesis
description: Jonah Lehrer strikes me as one of those young people who turn up in articles on how life is now so competitive that children no longer have time for jump-rope or adolescents for baby-sitting. At 25, he has already been a Rhodes scholar, worked in the lab of a Nobel Prize-winning neuroscientist and been a line chef in the kitchens of Le Cirque 2000 and Le Bernardin. He writes a blog on science issues affiliated with Seed magazine, where he is an editor, and now has written Proust Was a Neuroscientist, a precocious and engaging book that tries to mend the century-old tear between the literary and scientific cultures.

title: Getting Along Famously
description: Buddylube

title: Elizabeth Hondl, Adam Trachtenberg
description: Elizabeth Anne Hondl, the daughter of Constance and Roman J. Hondl of Edina, Minn., was married yesterday to Adam Maccabee Trachtenberg, a son of Francine and Stephen Joel Trachtenberg of Washington. Judge Jos A. Cabranes of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in New Haven, officiated at the Mill City Museum in Minneapolis.

title: Can Fake Grass and Dirt Really Be Healthy?; Making Playland Safer: Theres Still Work to Do; For Unwed Mothers, a Place to Thrive (3 Letters)
description: Can Fake Grass and Dirt Really Be Healthy?

title: Week 9 in Preview
description: RAVENS at STEELERS

title: Correction: Shes Famous (and So Can You)
description: An article last Sunday about the model and entertainer Tila Tequila and her rise to fame on the Internet misstated the title of a recent song by Soko, which was also made famous on the Web, through MySpace. It is Ill Kill Her, not Ill Kill Him.

title: Drive for Neediest Cases Fund, a Tradition Since 1912, Begins
description: Sunday begins the 96th annual New York Times Neediest Cases Fund campaign. Since 1912, the fund has provided direct assistance to troubled children, families and the elderly in New York.

title: New Jersey Man Is Killed in Midtown Poker Game
description: A mathematician and former professor was shot and killed when masked men with guns broke into a floating poker game on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan late Friday night, the police said.

title: Yes, Minister
description: It says something about the place of Tony Blair in the contemporary British imagination that he has already faced war crimes charges at least three times  on stage, on television and now in a sharp page turner of a thriller. Even before the prime minister left office in June, London theatergoers had mulled the legal merits of a war crimes case in Richard Norton-Taylors Called to Account, focusing on Blairs decision to join George W. Bush in the 2003 invasion of Iraq. Earlier this year, Channel 4 television minced no words with Alistair Beatons drama, The Trial of Tony Blair.

title: Correction: Naming Names at Gitmo
description: An article on Oct. 21 about Navy Lt. Cmdr. Matthew Diaz, who was court-martialed and convicted on some charges that involved making public the names of detainees at Guantnamo Bay, misspelled the name of a city where he lived as a teenager. It is San Bernardino, Calif., not San Bernadino.

title: What She Learned From Her Alma Mater
description: ADRIENNE KENNEDYS mother used to enthrall her over breakfast by vividly recounting the dreams shed had the night before. And Ms. Kennedys father captivated her  and audiences among Clevelands African-Americans of the 1930s and 40s  with his uplifting orations on how blacks must move forward. Today, at 76, this celebrated playwright has come to recognize a melding of her parents narrative styles in her own work. In spite of the fact that Ive always thought I was influenced by Antigone and Lorca, she said, its now clear to me that in everything Ive ever written, I was trying to do what my parents did.

title: Pretty (Sometimes) in Pink
description: Works by 107 artists from New Jersey, New York and other Northeastern states make up Pink, a pleasant enough if muddled exhibition at the Perkins Center for the Arts. The color pink is the theme; there are also a pink catalog, a pink invitation and even free pink cookies in the galleries.

title: The Law of Unintended Consequences?
description: THE Sarbanes-Oxley Act, enacted in mid-2002 in the wake of the Enron and WorldCom accounting scandals, aimed to improve the accuracy and reliability of corporate financial disclosures.

title: Hot Extinguisher
description: Peter Arnell, the mastermind behind advertising and branding for Donna Karan and M&Ms, also designed Jacob the Jewelers Manhattan store. Now his boundary-averse company has expanded into products.

title: Mexicans Appalled by Scenes From Flooded State
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 3  Mexicans were gripped Saturday by images of dramatic rescues from flooding in the southeastern state of Tabasco, where much of the state capital, Villahermosa, was underwater and the governor said that thousands of people waited on their rooftops for help to arrive.

title: Timing of Borass Bluff May Prove Costly
description: The fallout from the Alex Rodriguez World Series opt-out continues to stain him and his agent, Scott Boras. Rodriguez has been publicly silent on the outrageous timing of his act, but Boras was busy the past week spinning like a whirling dervish. His words and explanations convinced nobody of his innocence in the matter. The more he talked, the more guilty he sounded.

title: A Success Story Out of Post-Soviet Wreckage
description: RIGA, Latvia  Like the coliseums of ancient Rome, Daugava Stadium here in Latvias capital is a decaying monument to a fallen athletic superpower. Once a monument to Soviet sporting prowess, the bulky structure is now a crumbling reminder of past glory.

title: Sophie Donelson, Gregory Lindsay
description: Sophie Dow Donelson, a daughter of Bettyna and Wayne Donelson of Ashburnham, Mass., was married yesterday in Hamilton, Bermuda, to Gregory Thomas Lindsay, a son of Elaine Barrie of Bourbonnais, Ill., and Thomas Lindsay of Kankakee, Ill. Marlene Christopher, the registrar general of Bermuda, officiated at the Government Administration Building.

title: A Vote for the Adirondacks
description: It may seem like a small thing  a new well to give decent drinking water to 71 families in Raquette Lake, a small town north of Utica in the Adirondacks. But the towns request for permission to build the well on state parkland is the only constitutional issue that voters across New York will be asked to approve next Tuesday. New Yorkers should vote yes. And lovers of the Adirondacks should be extremely relieved that even this modest request, for a structure 10 feet wide and 12 feet long, needs statewide approval before it can be built in one of the pristine areas of the park.

title: The Perfect Match With Pigs Tails
description: A LOT of people dont really like it, which I find rather strange, Fergus Henderson said. One suspects that Mr. Henderson, the chef and owner of St. John Restaurant in London, has uttered this sentence before.

title: Deciding Mr. DeLucas Fate
description: A bipartisan State Senate committee has until Nov. 11 to make recommendations on the fate of Senator Louis C. DeLuca, Republican of Woodbury. It is clear that the Senate is uncomfortable judging one of its own. But it is also clear that Mr. DeLuca brought these proceedings on himself.

title: Mayoral Race Propels Shelter Into Limelight
description: FOR 19 years, the Jan Peek House, a homeless shelter in Peekskill, has been so unobtrusive, its supporters say, that most city residents do not even know it exists.

title: The Prizewinning Opera Time Forgot
description: WHILE rummaging through the secondhand department of a Viennese music store many years ago I came across an unusual copy of Samuel Barbers four-act opera Vanessa: one of those rough photocopies used by singers when they are learning their roles for a new work. There were light pencil marks here and there, mostly in the title characters part. Hmm, I thought. Sena Jurinac must have been cleaning out her closets.

title: Joanne Cosiol, Joshua Faber
description: Joanne Cosiol and Joshua Ross Faber were married last evening at Linwood Country Club in Linwood, N.J. Rabbi David Weiss officiated.

title: 36 Hours in Ibiza, Spain
description: AS a nucleus of the electronic music scene, Ibiza attracts party people of every age and demographic, from London fashionistas and Goa-style ravers to French bobos and the prime minister of Spain. But after Oct. 1, when Ibiza's club season comes to a euphoric finale, this Spanish island eases back into its Mediterranean groove. Whether it's hibernating in yoga retreats, trekking through Unesco World Heritage sites or lounging by turquoise blue water and white-sand beaches, Ibiza offers plenty of laid-back after-party spots. Plus, there are phenomenal seafood and glamorous hippies. And if the itch to party should strike, don't worry, the island's original party palace is open year round.

title: Pride in Architecture
description: The In the Region article in New Jersey copies last Sunday about recognition conferred on various New Jersey structures by the state chapter of the American Institute of Architects misidentified the county for Margate, the home of Lucy the Elephant, a popular seaside attraction that was cited as one of states 150 best places. It is Atlantic County, not Ocean.

title: Calendar of Events
description: COMEDY

title: Calendar of Events
description: FILM

title: Correction: The Future Is Drying Up
description: An article on Oct. 21 about the drought in the American West misstated the name of an organization that is a sponsor of Western Water Assessment, one of whose engineers testified before Congress about water shortages. It is the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, not the National Oceanographic Atmospheric Administration.

title: Paperback Row
description: AGAINST THE DAY, by Thomas Pynchon. (Penguin, $18.) Published nearly a decade after Mason & Dixon, Against the Day is Pynchons longest (at 1,085 pages) and, our reviewer, Liesl Schillinger, said, his funniest and most accessible novel. The complex plot unspools during the years from 1893 to the 1920s; one of its strands is the attempt by three brothers to avenge their fathers murder by agents of the plutocracy. Along the way there are dazzling set pieces, Dickensian characters, torrents of words and Pynchons signature puns. Against the Day proves Pynchon the heir to H. G. Wells and Joseph Conrad, Schillinger wrote, and a matchless fantasist of the real.

title: Parlor Tricks
description: William P. Young and Horace J. Gardner promise, in the introduction to their 1935 party manual, Games and Stunts for All Occasions, that we have been careful to eliminate anything that might offend persons of any age, creed or sex, and to avoid incorporating any game which might develop into unnecessary roughness or rowdyism. Young and Gardner are not so tasteful that theyve eliminated Corpse, a game in which a person lying under a sheet with galoshes on her hands must answer the question Oh corpse, are you alive? But in their quest for delicate, finger-sandwich fun, the authors overlook what the Victorians, who invented the parlor game, knew to be true: these games are compelling precisely because they allow people to pop their psychic corsets and indulge their rowdy inner selves.

title: A Battle Rages in London Over a Mega-Mosque Plan
description: LONDON  Disputes over mosques have broken out across Europe. Residents from Belgium to France to Germany have expressed unease at minarets competing in the urban landscape with the spires and stones of centuries-old cathedrals.

title: You Are What Your Name Says You Are
description: IN France, a persons name can signify as little as a measure of whats big on TV at any given time, or as much as an entire countrys nature.

title: Contributors
description: Elisabeth Franck-Dumas

title: Lauren Wiener, Justin Gelman
description: Lauren Beth Wiener, the daughter of Lois Wiener and Robert Wiener of Commack, N.Y., was married last evening to Justin Adam Gelman, the son of Riva Gelman and Dr. William Gelman of Dix Hills, N.Y. Rabbi Howard Buechler performed the ceremony at Temple Bnai Sholom in Rockville Centre, N.Y., with Cantor Ralph Nussbaum participating.

title: Correction: The Cult of Gocco
description: The Consumed column on Oct. 21 carried an incorrect art credit. The illustration was by Peter Arkle, not Leif Parsons.

title: Turkey Skeptical of Iraqi Vows to Stop Kurdish Raids
description: ISTANBUL, Nov. 3  Turkey said on Saturday that two days of meetings with officials from Iraq and the United States on how to stop Kurdish militants who attack Turkey from northern Iraq had produced no new proposals.

title: Top Yanks Managers: Brains, Not Bats
description: The Yankees new manager was never much of a slugger. Nothing new about that. And the transition to Joe Girardi from Joe Torre stirred some commotion. Nothing new about that either.

title: Almost a Gentleman
description: Midway through Donald McCaigs unexpectedly diverting novel, Rhett Butlers People, a black man about to be lynched in the post-bellum South asks Rhett to please shoot him dead before the mob breaks into the jail and does worse. Rhett obliges. Thus does McCaig correct the record. In Margaret Mitchells telling  that is, in Gone With the Wind  we learn that Rhett has been arrested for killing this darky who had insulted a white woman. A few chapters later, Rhett confesses his guilt to Scarlett OHara, the other half of Mitchells famous romantic pair. What else could a Southern gentleman do? he asks.

title: Presidential Politics Have Shifted Already
description: DES MOINES, Nov. 3  With a year to go until Election Day, the Republican and Democratic Parties are going through internal battles over their very identity, even as the races for their presidential nominations intensify. In many ways, the battles over how the parties will define themselves in the post-Bush era are nearly as significant a political fight as the presidential contest itself.

title: Correction: Review of The Almost Moon
description: A review on Oct. 21 about The Almost Moon, a novel by Alice Sebold, misstated the given name of a Russian poet to whom the protagonist compares herself. It is Marina Tsvetayeva, not Maria.

title: The Littlest Big Shots
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Lifting a High Ranch to New Heights
description: ABBEY and E. Rigby, a pair of yellow Labradors, seem to be enjoying the renovation.

title: A Range of Disorders Tamed by the Beat
description: White Plains

title: U.S. Sanctions Force World Bank to Halt Some Iran Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3  The World Bank, newly caught up in the Bush administrations campaign against Iran, has had to suspend payments for earthquake relief, sanitation and other projects there in response to new American sanctions on leading Iranian banks, World Bank officials say.

title: A Modern Buddhist Uprising Strikes a Quieter Chord
description: In this country, no doubt like in others, news about demonstrating monks in Myanmar has been reduced to a trickle, though here and there word leaks out of additional protests against military rule, and these reports find their way into the back pages of the newspapers.

title:
A Place to Find That Elusive Book; Bye-Bye, Street Fairs, Dont Hurry Back; The Faces May Change, but the Heart Remains; We Dont Strand Families
Who Truly Need Shelter (5 Letters)
description: A Place to Find That Elusive Book

title: Re-Arranging the Furniture
description: For more than two decades, Tom Dixon, the renegade British designer, has put his energy not only into furniture design but also into challenging the conventions of the business. This winter, Dixon, the creator of the Mirror Ball, is bringing his show to America; and a premonition of what we can expect harks back to a London morning in September 2006, when Dixon delivered 500 injection-molded polystyrene chairs to Trafalgar Square. Every chair was gone in seven minutes, borne away by city dwellers transformed into worker ants who left behind them the lasting sense of an original event.

title: Home-Office Politics
description: Like other businesses, politics these days is conducted less in person than on speaker phone and laptops. Campaign consultants, policy analysts, fund-raisers and bloggers do most of their work in the comfort of their own homes, or in their cars, or maybe at Starbucks. Political professionals have as a result become part of a much larger American movement. In his new book, Microtrends, the Democratic pollster Mark Penn notes that 4.2 million Americans now work exclusively from home (a nearly 100 percent increase from 1990), while some 20 million do it part time. Some of these workers are employees who telecommute to traditional offices, but most represent a kind of modern, untethered American work force.

title: The New Staples
description: 1. Basil Seeds $5 for 3 ounces at Kalustyans, 123 Lexington Avenue. Call (800) 352-3451 or go to www.kalustyans.com.

title: Straightforward Fare With Little Froufrou
description: NOW heres a dialogue a restaurant critic doesnt have every day:

title: License Issue Figures Large in Local Races
description: BUFFALO  When she arrived at an assisted living center for a candidates forum here recently, Kathleen C. Hochul, the Erie County clerk, spent a few minutes explaining what county clerks do. As the audience listened sleepily, Ms. Hochul, a no-nonsense lawyer, quickly reeled through an explanation of housing permits, business registrations and her plan to shorten lines at the downtown auto bureau.

title: Yours for the Peeping
description: JEREMY FLETCHER and Alejandra Lillo, designers at Graft, an architecture and design firm based in Berlin, Beijing and Los Angeles, were working out a dialogue between voyeurism and exhibitionism, they said, when they designed the swooping, shiny white interiors of the W Downtown, a glass-walled condominium tower to be built in 2009 in Manhattans financial district.

title: Top Marathoner Collapses and Dies in Olympic Trials
description: A triumphant United States Olympic trials marathon turned somber yesterday morning when Ryan Shay, a 28-year-old veteran marathoner, collapsed during the race in Central Park and was pronounced dead at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: Political Tango, Women in the Lead
description: BUENOS AIRES

title: Three Big Names Fall Behind Youngsters
description: The three grew up in Africa, migrated to the United States, became American citizens and made their mark as world-class runners on the track and the roads. All three were given strong chances to make the United States Olympic team in the marathon. None did.

title: By Opting Out, Rodriguez Really Wants In
description: To the New York-centric sports fan, the most newsworthy event of the past week was not the Boston Red Sox sweep of Colorado in the World Series, but the decision of Yankees third baseman Alex Rodriguez to opt out of his contract to pursue the siren song of free agency. Indeed, the opt-out decision was announced during the final Series game, at virtually the earliest possible moment under the contract.

title: Daring You to Try This at Home
description: WHATS hot and whats not? That is the question the Specialty Equipment Market Association trade show strives to answer.

title: Letters: A Man of the World
description: To the Editor:

title: Tour de France
description: Once upon a time, an American girl in Paris went in search of the perfect French boyfriend. Her quest had all the elements of a fairy tale  handsome princes, creepy monsters and benevolent dwarfs  except for the crucial happy ending. For unlike Cinderella, whose foot found its ideal glass slipper, or Goldilocks, with her just-right porridge and lodgings, this heroine never discovered a flawless fit. Instead, her Platonic ideal of Frenchness eluded her at every turn. tienne confessed that he spoke Catalan at home. Bernard, a native of Brittany, grumbled that construing him as a model Franais was not unlike describing an Irishman as English. Ever since the Dreyfus Affair had exposed his compatriots anti-Semitism in the late 19th century, Lon explained, his family had viewed itself as Jewish first, French second. Franois, a haughty aristocrat, informed her that in the 15th century, his ancestors had fought with the Burgundians ... against the French. (But what long memories you Frenchmen have! she protested to both Lon and Franois, endearing herself to neither.) In the end, the damsel had little choice but to abort her mission, leave Paris and marry an American.

title: College Towns Escape the Pain
description: As the inner cities, along with much of Florida and the interior of California, face the prospect of a foreclosure meltdown, American college towns appear to be islands of stability.

title: Ready for City Life
description: IF John Berglund was going to take a job in New York, he and his family most certainly were going to live in the center of the city.

title: TV Show Over? Obsess About It on the Web
description: The broadcast networks are clearly adopting more of an if you cant beat em, join em philosophy toward the Internet. Harnessing a natural human inclination toward gossip, complaint, prediction and obsession, they are using TV show Web sites to offer clips, outtakes, interviews, games, message boards and blogs  not to mention entire episodes.

title: The Conscience of a Liberal
description: To the Editor:

title: Civil Discourse, Meet the Internet
description: WARNING: This column contains rude and objectionable language not normally found in the pages of this newspaper but seen surprisingly often on its Web site.

title: In the Mother Tongue, Songs With a Wide Appeal
description: YIDDISH may seem inseparable from nostalgia, but Eleanor Reissa, a noted performer, revels in its more earthy qualities. Yiddish is so gorgeous, she says, so luscious and sensual and poetic a language, that its funny people think of it as dead. The reality is it bursts with life.

title: Shock Tactics
description: Fashioned from a single metal tube bent into a sleek, low-slung frame, Marcel Breuers Wassily chair was a touchstone of Modernism, a manifestation of the movements faith in technology, convenience and the promise of a better life. In the artist Ivn Navarros rendition of the chair, the frame is made from three neon tubes in a glowing shade of disco-era purple. Navarros Red and Blue Electric Chair is another Modernist remake, this one in the image of Gerrit Rietvelds Red and Blue Chair from 1918. It was kind of a building block for me, Navarro says of the fluorescent piece, an exercise in materials and formalism. Unlike the Bauhaus approach to chairs as machines for sitting, Navarros artwork is not for sitting at all, and he would be more apt to refer to his chairs as machines for killing. Neon is fragile, he says, but it can electrocute you.

title: Extermination States
description: Who, after all, speaks today of the annihilation of the Armenians? Hitler supposedly said on Aug. 22, 1939, as he prepared his henchmen for the savagery of race war and the slaughter of the Jews of Europe. In many ways, this link between the genocide of the Armenians by the Ottoman Empire in 1915 and the genocide of the Jews by the Nazis from 1941 to 1945 brings together the elements of Alan Kramers important book, Dynamic of Destruction: Culture and Mass Killing in the First World War. Kramer believes that the two world wars may be regarded as a single four-decade trauma, and he argues that World War I was considerably more than simply a new industrial form of warfare that brutalized the modern world.

title: Calendar of Events
description: Film

title: Fasten Your Seatbelts
description: The last time I saw Bette Davis, she was in her dotage, the painful ravages of cancer and a paralyzing stroke cruelly evident. We had tea in a Manhattan hotel room, and she admitted her two favorite words were Whats next? Her days in front of a camera were mortgaged beyond revival, but with her flaring nostrils and incendiary nicotine butts, and still walking like an anchovy, she slashed the air with one parting shot: You have not seen the end of Bette Davis!

title: The Inner Scholar
description: TO hear Thomas B. Coburn, president of Naropa University, explain the theory of contemplative education is to grasp a simple concept. The Buddhist-inspired teaching that goes on at this small college, he says, is aimed at giving students "a critical perspective on their inner lives."

title: Hey, Mr. Escalade Man
description: IF he revisits Highway 61 yet again, chances are Bob Dylan will do it in a Cadillac Escalade, just like the one he drives in a new television commercial.

title: December Release Schedule
description: DECEMBER

title: Rethinking How to Teach the New Teachers
description: SCHOOL enrollments are increasing year by year, but qualified teachers are leaving the classroom in droves. More than a million veteran teachers are nearing retirement, and more will follow.

title: Rivers of Blood in a Winter Wonderland
description: THERE is blood on the snow in Lions for Lambs, blood on the living room carpet in American Gangster, blood just about everywhere in No Country for Old Men. The more lighthearted Sweeney Todd has its singing, throat-slitting barber. There Will Be Blood may be the title of a film opening the day after Christmas, but it could be the slogan for this entire holiday season.

title: A Hospitals Journey
description: THE northwest corner of Park Avenue and 70th Street has almost disappeared under construction netting. From the side street, its as if the big 1927 apartment house at 720 Park Avenue, designed by Rosario Candela, had never been built. In fact, it went up at the same time as everything else on the block, replacing the old Presbyterian Hospital, built in 1872, long before the Upper East Side became a desirable neighborhood.

title: Try Giving
description: To the Editor:

title: A Las Vegas Close-Up for Planet Hollywood
description: Movie fans visiting Las Vegas can now stay and play at the new Planet Hollywood Resort and Casino (www.planethollywood.com). Formerly the Aladdin, the property was rebranded last April and underwent a billion-dollar renovation. It will be celebrating its grand opening on Nov. 16 and 17.

title: Correction: Lina DOrazio, Adam Baer
description: A report on Oct. 21, about the marriage of Lina DOrazio and Adam Baer, included outdated information on the location of the ceremony. After the article went to press, the wedding was moved from Malibu to the Mulholland Tennis Club in Los Angeles because of the California wildfires.

title: Beyond Those Health Care Numbers
description: WITH the health care system at the center of the political debate, a lot of scary claims are being thrown around. The dangerous ones are not those that are false; watchdogs in the news media are quick to debunk them. Rather, the dangerous ones are those that are true but dont mean what people think they mean.

title: Now Wearing | Cuff Love
description: Handmade from reclaimed veneer, the Coffee Cuff ($68 from the Vancouver-based firm Contexture Design) is made to fit snugly around a deli coffee cup but does double duty as an eco-friendly bracelet.

title: Willis Is Excelling for Lackluster 49ers
description: There have been few positives for the 49ers during a season in which their 2-0 start had onlookers saying the team was not nearly as good as expected. But one shining light has been Patrick Willis, the rookie linebacker from Mississippi.

title: Golf, Wine and Sheep in New Zealand
description: A new resort, the Farm at Cape Kidnappers, is scheduled to open this month in the New Zealand wine region of Hawkes Bay on the North Island (www.capekidnappers.com). Adjoining the Tom Doak-designed Cape Kidnappers golf course, the property, set on a 6,000-acre sheep and cattle farm, above, includes 24 suites and rooms and a four-bedroom cottage. All rooms have porches with views of the Pacific Ocean.

title: Op-Art: Marathon Man
description: ALBERTO ARROYO calls himself the mayor of Central Park. A former boxer from Puerto Rico, Mr. Arroyo came to New York in 1935. To stay in shape, he ran in Central Park, switching to the reservoir loop after the police shooed him from the bridle path. He says he was the first man to run in Central Park.

title: Wireless Workplaces, Touching the Sky
description: THE Hearst Tower in Midtown Manhattan is known for its environmentally friendly features, along with its stunning design by the British architect Norman Foster. A distinctive triangular structure of glass and steel, it rises from the shell of the original six-story sandstone headquarters erected by William Randolph Hearst in 1928.

title: Incorrect and Insensitive
description: New Jerseys Constitution, drawn up in 1947, is generally regarded as a progressive document that takes into account many of the problems and challenges of the modern era.

title: Heather Gottlieb, Russell Freyman
description: Heather Joy Gottlieb, the daughter of Arline Gottlieb and Sheldon Gottlieb of North Massapequa, N.Y., was married yesterday to Russell Alan Freyman, a son of Andrea Hoffman of Syosset and Richard Freyman of Lakewood Ranch, Fla.

title: Yes, You Are Old
description: For the last 10 years, Beloit College in lower Wisconsin has issued the Mindset List. The creation of Tom McBride, a humanities professor, and Ron Nief, the public affairs director, the popular list is distributed at the start of each academic year to faculty and staff (and the world at large) to remind them of the perspective of each years entering freshmen. Below are a few items from the decades lists.

title: The Dead and the Naked
description: Last week: Detective Oakwood told Miss Skattergoods that a note (written in Latin) was found in G.G.s wallet. Was it a threat?

title: A Month After a Shooting, a Courtyard Has Turned Somber
description: NICK SANCHEZ, a 20-year-old musician, was fiddling with a computer in a recording studio on the top floor of a ramshackle brownstone on West 131st Street. At the touch of a key, a menacing synthesizer line emerged from the speakers, along with a gut-rattling bass beat.

title: Krisjon Olson, Charles Bergstrom
description: Krisjon Rae Olson, a daughter of Candice and Raymond P. Olson of San Diego, was married there yesterday to Dr. Charles Peter Bergstrom, the son of Michele and Pete Bergstrom of Norwood, Mass. The ceremony was led by Stelios B. Papadopoulos, an uncle of the bride who was designated a deputy marriage commissioner by San Diego County to officiate, at the St. Francis Chapel in Balboa Park.

title: Middle Passage
description: To the Editor:

title: San Francisco Self Edge
description: The denim that true jeans aficionados clamor for these days is from Japan, not the United States, and nowhere is that more apparent than at Self Edge, a boutique in the Mission District of San Francisco.

title: T-Bones  and Tea
description: Like Hells Kitchen, the meatpacking district has an uninviting name and increasing popularity as a place to eat well. These restaurants are the neighborhoods latest arrivals.

title: The Green Party
description: The scene: a convivial New York barbecue celebrating a couples return from Los Angeles. Margaritas were blending; the pork shoulder was falling willingly off the bone; the collard greens  straight from a guests garden!  were macerating with their new best friends, the minced onions. Suddenly, the hum of conversation was stopped dead by a plaintive whine from the hostesss husband. Honey! Do you still not want me to use paper plates? Were running out of real dishes!

title: Now Flavoring | Roe v. Wasabi
description: Get out the blinis. This fall, Tsar Nicoulai, the San Francisco purveyor known for its domestic caviar, will introduce trout and whitefish roe infused with the likes of kaffir lime leaf, brandy and vanilla. The unusual collection, called Passot Roe, came about because Roland Passot, the chef who owns La Folie restaurant, began experimenting with adding flavors to trout roe, which has a firm, almost crunchy texture and is fairly inexpensive.

title: Venting, Yes. Profiting, No.
description: WITHOUT quite having a clear plan, Gregg Rottler began contemplating his Web empire last year on his desktop computer at his home near Tampa, Fla. As many bloggers have done, Mr. Rottler, a state environmental code officer, followed an impulse to share stories about annoyances. He and his wife, Karen, an elementary school teacher, often eat out, and he realized that people liked to talk about restaurant experiences gone wrong.

title: Productivity May Explain the Market
description: IF you have been baffled by stocks ability to race higher, even as the price of just about every commodity soars, some clarity may arrive this week with the Labor Department report on third-quarter productivity.

title: 1973: Teddies Apple Cake
description: For reasons that elude me, cakes have come to represent long hours in the kitchen, when anyone who actually makes cakes knows that cookies are the time suck. Cookies require measuring and multiple batches. Cakes get mixed up and go into the oven all at once. The most lovable ones even cool in their pans and require no icing. Which is why if you look back in The Times archives at recipes from 30 or more years ago, when most people cooked every day, there were many more cake recipes. Cake was something you whipped up every couple of days, after the previous one vanished to crumbs.

title: U.N. Restarts Talks to Persuade Myanmars Junta on Reforms
description: BANGKOK, Nov. 3  The United Nations on Saturday began its latest mission to persuade Myanmars military government to reconcile with its democratic dissidents. But the visit by the United Nations special envoy is already being strained by the juntas order to expel the top United Nations official in the country.

title: Sloe and Steady
description: If you thought sloe gin was the treacly red stuff that spawned a million beachfront bar shots with unprintable names, you may be as amazed as I was when you taste the genuine article. Real sloe gin, made with sloe berries and  shouldnt this go without saying?  actual gin, is a homemade treat from rural England that has nothing to do with the cloying liqueur thats usurped its name. Fortunately, some of that misinformation may soon be corrected. Early next year, Plymouth Gin in Devonshire, England, will export a limited release of its unsurpassable sloe gin, made in its Black Friars Distillery, and arguably the only commercial version that is all natural and traditionally produced.

title: Victims Families Denounce Call for Time Limit on Street Memorials
description: NEW HAVEN

title: In Land of Spitzer, a Vile Season of Frost and Fury
