description: ALBANY, Nov. 2  Gov. Eliot Spitzer promised early on to spend his time breaking some china, proclaimed himself a steamroller and often invoked a favorite saying: You cant change the world by whispering.

title: Boldly, Where No Dog Had Gone Before
description: CULVER CITY, Calif.

title: Bourbon & Bluegrass
description: ONE Friday afternoon a few weeks ago, while most people were at work, I stood in a room at Makers Mark distillery, in rural Kentucky, breathing in the pungent fumes of fermenting whiskey mash and feeling a kind of mild contact buzz.

title: A Fairy-Tale Ending Eludes Separated Twins
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., Nov. 1  It had all the trappings of a Cinderella story. Carl and Clarence Aguirre, impoverished Filipino twins conjoined at the top of their heads, arrived in New York in 2003, sick and malnourished, and after a series of death-defying operations, emerged late one night on separate gurneys  fragile, sedated and bandaged, but each with his own life.

title: Tunnel Vision
description: ONE day, when I was 12 years old, I felt a lump in my throat. It was a year of metaphorical lumps  I had just started a new junior high school and my parents were in the middle of a messy divorce  but this lump was real. A doctor diagnosed it as a cyst, benign but dangerously close to my thyroid gland, and on a December afternoon, my mother took me to see a surgeon in Manhattan.

title: Here, the Buffalo Roam
description: AUSTIN TANNER discovered the hard way that loving buffalo, as he has since grade school, is one thing, but raising them is another.

title: Telltale Art
description: A GIANT, gleaming blue diamond  about eight feet tall by seven feet wide  is parked on four gold-colored prongs outside Christies at Rockefeller Center. Just uptown Christies archrival, Sothebys, has another sight gag, an eye-catching confection of similar dimensions: a shiny, bright-red dangling heart. These playful if expensive sculptures by the artist Jeff Koons could be a metaphor for the glittered frenzy of this falls major auctions, which open on Tuesday with a sale of Impressionist and modern art at Christies.

title: Why Google Turned Into a Social Butterfly
description: FACEBOOK is an island. A most convivial island, with ones classmates, friends, workmates and family members close at hand. An island that since May has been enlivened with entertaining fauna and flora in the form of minisoftware applications. But its still an island.

title: Plunging Into the Thicket Known as Henry VI
description: Framed by a buoyant peek at the past and a chilling, defiant look toward the future, Brian B. Crowes new adaptation of Shakespeares Henry VI trilogy wrestles this seldom-played, ungainly behemoth to what could best be described as a standoff. Whittling nine hours of contentious, at times horrific, English history into three is struggle enough, yet Mr. Crowe has actually chosen to add text to Shakespeares already swollen offering.

title: Trying a Shuttle Bus to Make Crossing Safer
description: UNION

title: The Diplomat
description: Q: In your new memoir, Surrender Is Not an Option, you recount your frustrations as ambassador to the United Nations, a position you left in December. This is the way Washington is today. Its very personal in its politics, very bitter and very negative.

title: A Disney Princess, Not Winking but Floating
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.

title: Law & Order Candidate (Chung-chung)
description: WEEKS before the 2004 presidential election, former Senator Fred D. Thompson passionately defended the war in Iraq to a prime-time television audience. Radical fundamentalists are waging a world war, he said, calling the United States invasion a necessary response to Islamic terrorism. They hate our way of life and our freedoms.

title: No, No, No, Dont Follow Us
description: New Delhi

title: Gift of Gall
description: WASHINGTON

title: Space Station Is Repaired in Spacewalk
description: An astronaut on a daring spacewalk yesterday repaired a damaged solar array on the International Space Station.

title: Drums Along the Hudson
description: While you werent looking, a big anniversary has been creeping into view. It is the 400th anniversary of Henry Hudsons sail up his mighty river, an epochal event by any standard. It was in 1609 that Hudson, an Englishman hired by the Dutch East India Company, sailed on the Half Moon into New York Harbor and up the river as far as present-day Albany. He was looking for the Northwest Passage but found something better, and the history and lore that followed  New Amsterdam, New York, Wall Street, Rockefeller Center, the Macys Parade  flow from that date, from that ruff-collared sailor on his poky little ship.

title: From Uzbekistan, a Single Father of 3
description: My son, hes coming. He speak English very well and he can be translator, Yakov Babayev said quietly, sitting stiffly in a straight-backed chair in his overly full living room.

title: Alexandra Piccirillo, Rosario Vaina
description: Alexandra Piccirillo, a daughter of Phyllis and Alexander Piccirillo of Nutley, N.J., was married yesterday to Rosario A. Vaina, a son of Anna and Salvatore Vaina of Brooklyn. Msgr. Joseph J. Granato performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in St. Lucys Church in Newark.

title: Fall in Love for a Good Cause
description: ON the spectrum of aspiring Cupids, Pari Livermore ought to be categorized somewhere between the hundreds of professional matchmakers and the millions of meddling grannies, bubbies, nanas and nonnas.

title: The Domino Effect
description: Most people dont consider the other uses for sugar beyond the pleasures of the tongue. But fortunately there are the odd exceptions, who take their sweet tooth rather seriously.

title: Wesley Werme, Brent Cartwright
description: Wesley G. Werme and Brent Alan Cartwright were married yesterday at St. James Catholic Church in Liberty, Mo. The Rev. Matthew B. Link performed the ceremony.

title: Said That vs. Meant This, a Hot Matchup for 08
description: WASHINGTON

title: Dollars for Scholars, or for the Athletes? (2 Letters)
description: Dollars for Scholars, or for the Athletes?

title: What Would Bacchus Do?
description: The rhetoric and rituals of wine appreciation are sometimes said to be the alimentary equivalent of lipstick on a pig: they are meant to give an attractive sheen to the ugly business of getting drunk. Most oenophiles, of course, take a different view: they regard wine as a uniquely complex beverage  complex in terms of its taste and also the environmental, historical and cultural factors influencing its production  that demands sober reflection (in a manner of speaking). Interestingly, a growing number of academics believe that wine is a subject fit for scholarly reflection. Three years ago, the University of London played host to a symposium on philosophy and wine. Out of that conference grew Questions of Taste: The Philosophy of Wine, a collection of essays examining how we think and talk about wine and how it influences us.

title: Incentives, to Fight the Doldrums
description: DEVELOPERS in central Long Island are increasingly resorting to incentives to lure buyers. Nassau and Suffolk Counties are both affected, though new units in western Suffolk have been particularly slow to sell in the current sluggish real estate market.

title: Reading About Eating
description: When it comes to food, the spirit of adventure would seem to be inherent, not acquired. Some people are simply more game than others, sampling tripe, silkworm pupae and a cobras gallbladder, not to mention small, cuddly mammals that back home might have been christened Snowball or Sparky. (Are these the same people whose idea of fun is bungee jumping?) Recent research suggests that fearlessness is ordained by a gene. Im quite sure I dont have it.

title: Rebecca Walker, Benjamin Grossman
description: Rebecca Erin Walker, the daughter of Sharon and Donald R. Walker of Roxbury, N.J., was married last evening to Benjamin Isaac Grossman, a son of Barbara and Steven Grossman of Newton, Mass. Rabbi David Ross Senter officiated at the Rockleigh Country Club in Rockleigh, N.J.

title: Not All Fusion Food Blends Flavors Well
description: FUSION food, which is meant to blend tastes from different cultures, is a tricky culinary concept. Its easy to create a confused jumble or to reduce everything to the least sophisticated common denominator.

title: Datebook
description: MADRID

title: Out West, a Falling Lake Lowers All Boats
description: LAKE MEAD, Nev.

title: Sarah Willett and Jerry Chang
description: Sarah Elizabeth Willett, a daughter of Evelyn Willett and Dr. J. Michael Willett of New Haven, was married there yesterday to Dr. Jerry Weiger Chang, the son of Jennie Chang and Robert Chang of Houston. The Rev. Callista Isabelle, a minister of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America, performed the ceremony at Battell Chapel at Yale.

title: Harlem Flock Is Staying Put
description: ITS not the greatest story ever told, but in New York, it has become familiar: Church loses parishioners; churchs land gains in value; church sells to developer, who puts up apartments.

title: Elizabeth Hack, Richard Larach
description: Elizabeth Inez Hack and Richard Lloyd Larach are to be married today in Washington. Rabbi Leila Gal Berner is to officiate at the Park Hyatt hotel.

title: Seeing Things
description: After blithely picking off the albatross, the title character in The Rime of the Ancient Mariner loses his soul to a nightmarish, dice-throwing figure called Life-in-Death. The seamans true life-in-death begins once his fantastically ghastly voyage ends: hes doomed to repeat himself obsessively, buttonholing unwitting guests at social events and pouring forth his cautionary tale.

title: Glitz? There Goes the Neighborhood
description: A little before 5 p.m. on Wednesday, as on every other weekday afternoon, the stretch of 32nd Street between Seventh Avenue and Avenue of the Americas was filled with commuters barreling westward, briefcases swinging, in a dash toward Pennsylvania Station.

title: As Hybrids Evolve, Gains Grow Elusive
description: Toyota City, Japan

title: The Audience as the Arbiter
description: CRITICS are sometimes asked how they prepare for premieres. In my business a new piece is a threat; it strips the writer naked. Unlike Brahmss Fourth Symphony, it springs from nowhere and asks on the spot to be loved, hated or endured. Is prior knowledge a kind of cheating, or does a look at the score or a visit to the rehearsal hall create a cushion of experience, something that makes new music more understandable?

title: Stephanie Sakoff, Rudolph Miklosvary
description: Stephanie Lyn Sakoff and Rudolph Peter Miklosvary were married last evening at Cipriani 23rd Street in New York. The Rev. P. Kimberleigh Jordan, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated.

title: Grading the Law Firms
description: To the Editor:

title: Club House
description: If William Randolph Hearst were to come back from the grave, he would surely feel vindicated for his extravagant sense of design. Hearst Castle, the 97,000-square-foot pad in San Simeon, Calif., that he built from 1919 to 1947 in a pastiche of grandiose architectural flourishes, was decorated with truckloads of European art, Italian and Spanish ceilings, enough rugs to fill a bazaar, and an original Roman temple front. Now his baronial-manorial aesthetic is having a second coming  albeit in a slightly more accessible way.

title: Why Study Abroad Costs So Much, What to Do About It
description: In many parts of the world, college is cheap.

title: Son of the South
description: When I was 16, my father left my mother and me for his pregnant mistress, who happened to be a jockey at the racetrack and didnt ride sidesaddle, if you know what I mean. Well, were from Houston; off-color divorce is our municipal hobby. Mothers first words after reading Daddys Dear Jane letter  All that goes back tomorrow!  referred to a cluster of shopping bags we collected earlier that day at Neimans and addressed the real problem for both of us: with my father gone, the gravy train was over.

title: Runners Stunned by News of Death
description: The New York City Marathon has not experienced a runners death since 1994, so when the 28-year-old professional runner Ryan Shay collapsed during the Olympic marathon trials yesterday and died, the running community here was particularly stunned.

title: Taste Maker
description: An unintended consequence of Judith Joness fine memoir is a wistful longing for the glory days of American publishing. Imagine how, in 1950, as a poorly paid assistant to Doubledays Paris editor, working through a pile of submissions that he wanted rejected, Jones could be drawn to a photograph on the French edition of Anne Frank: The Diary of a Young Girl. She did not stop until she had read the manuscript straight through (in French) and persuaded her editor to strongly recommend its publication to Doubleday in New York.

title: A Child From Their First Marriage
description: THE last legal barriers to Porsches control of Volkswagen may have fallen with a decision by the European Court of Justice. Its ruling last month struck down a German law and cleared the way for Porsche, already the largest shareholder, to obtain a majority stake in VW.

title: Dungy Builds Coaching Tree by Going Against the Grain
description: In the early 1980s, 20-something football coaches were rare, 20-something black coaches rarer still. That was the N.F.L. landscape when the Pittsburgh Steelers made 25-year-old Tony Dungy the youngest assistant in league history.

title: For Jews Adrift, a Port of Call
description: WITH her red lacquered nails, coiffed white hair and ever-present shopping cart, Rose Gelfand seems like a typical bubbe from Brooklyn.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Tune In, Tune Out, Move On

title: Correction: Impresarios Back Story of Daring
description: A column last Sunday about Florence Berkman, the art critic for The Hartford Times who befriended A. Everett Austin Jr., known as Chick, when he was the director of the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art, misstated the year of her death. It was 2000, not 1999.

title: Anne Howard, Erik Fahlgren
description: Anne Katharine Howard was married in Fort Worth yesterday to Erik Victor Fahlgren. The Rev. Dr. Michael L. Marshall performed the ceremony in the Leonard Memorial Chapel at the First United Methodist Church of Fort Worth.

title: Rice Adds to Rushing Total, but UConn Adds to Win Total
description: EAST HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 3  In the previous two weeks, Connecticut had halted an N.F.L.-caliber quarterback (Louisvilles Brian Brohm) and turned back a surging young program (the one-time No. 2 South Florida). With their own improbable season in the balance, the No. 16 Huskies did not seem fazed by either challenge.

title: A Man of Many Parts
description: NOTHING is as ephemeral as the theater; when the curtain falls, its gone. It must have been to rectify this that they invented the Broadway-memento kiosk. A Cats coffee mug gives you something to hold on to other than Memories.

title: A Ray of Pension Sunshine
description: THE Securities and Exchange Commissions investigation into possible conflicts of interest among advisers to pension funds has been going on so long  two years  that its practically fallen off the radar screen. But last week, the investigation cropped up again, big time, when Merrill Lynch advised 100 of its pension fund clients in Florida that the S.E.C. has taken issue with its practices as a consultant.

title: A Sanitation Crisis Thats No Joke
description: The nation with the greatest lead in potty technology is, no doubt, Japan. Toilets there arent just self-flushing; thats Jurassic technology by Japans standards. The best detect you as you enter the bathroom, lifting their lids and firing up their seat-warmers. When finished, you have a choice of warm spritzes  bidet or shower  followed, if you like, by a drying blast of hot air.

title: Where Theres Smoke ...
description: Q I live in a New York City co-op, and cigarette smoke is having an impact on the quality of my life. I would like to know how to go about making my building smoke-free.

title: Societys Politics, as Seen Through a Porcelain Lens
description: A public toilet, Harvey Molotch was saying yesterday morning before the daylong symposium he organized on the subject, is a window on the social and political world.

title: Bio Engineering
description: Im going to do everything I can to sabotage you, the writer Nathan Zuckerman tells an upstart biographer in Philip Roths new novel, Exit Ghost. I can prevent your being published, and, whatever the expense, whatever the effort, I will. Zuckerman is incensed that the would-be biographer, a deeply disrespectful, ardent young man named Kliman, is trying to make a name for himself by unearthing the secrets of one of his heroes, the writer E. I. Lonoff. The dirt-seeking snooping calling itself research is just about the lowest of literary rackets, Zuckerman tells Kliman. Youre going to redeem Lonoffs reputation as a writer by ruining it as a man.

title: Voting? Forget the Who. Its the How.
description: To the Editor:

title: $1 a Square Foot! Gross
description: I live in a really big apartment. It has eight rooms, two balconies, high ceilings and a view. The best part is that its cheap, by New York standards, because its in Berlin.

title: The Story Behind the Story Within the Story
description: THE big set piece at the heart of Atonement takes place on the beach at Dunkirk during the British evacuation in 1940. Dazed and exhausted, a wounded soldier named Robbie Turner stumbles onto the beach along with two sidekicks while a six-minute tracking shot establishes a montage of eerie, almost surreal images: a bandstand, abandoned cannons, a choir in rehearsal, an enormous beached boat, wandering circus horses, a Ferris wheel turning idly against a smoke-streaked sky. A little later Robbie takes refuge in a movie house where Quai des Brumes, a noirish Jean Gabin picture from 1938, is playing. He wanders across the screen, passing in front of a close-up of Gabin, and for a moment it looks as if hes standing in your theater, not the one in France.

title: A Tuna Meltdown
description: IT is tuna time in New York. I dont mean its time for local bistros to put salade nioise on their menus. I mean its the time when real, live tuna  some of them eight feet long  enter our waters en route to their spawning grounds in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Reader Questions
description: Keeping Score

title: Town Without Pity
description: Someone  its been attributed to everyone from Dostoyevsky to John Gardner  once said there are only two possible stories: a man goes on a journey, or a stranger comes to town. To these Richard Russo has added a third: schlub stays put. In a time known in trendier circles for literary exile, Russo is the unofficial poet laureate of uneasy stasis, of fixing yourself to the place where you were born. Out the window goes the dynamism of American self-invention; in comes something almost more mysterious: a reckoning with an apparently seamless life continuity. If I didnt invent this self, where exactly did it come from? And yet more queasily: This place that nurtured me  did it also stunt me, inhibit me, even, literally, poison me?

title: The Turning of an Atheist
description: Unless you are a professional philosopher or a committed atheist, you probably have not heard of Antony Flew. Eighty-four years old and long retired, Flew lives with his wife in Reading, a medium-size town on the Thames an hour west of London. Over a long career he held appointments at a series of decent regional universities  Aberdeen, Keele, Reading  and earned a strong reputation writing on an unusual range of topics, from Hume to immortality to Darwin. His greatest contribution remains his first, a short paper from 1950 called Theology and Falsification. Flew was a precocious 27 when he delivered the paper at a meeting of the Socratic Club, the Oxford salon presided over by C. S. Lewis. Reprinted in dozens of anthologies, Theology and Falsification has become a heroic tract for committed atheists. In a masterfully terse thousand words, Flew argues that God is too vague a concept to be meaningful. For if Gods greatness entails being invisible, intangible and inscrutable, then he cant be disproved  but nor can he be proved. Such powerful but simply stated arguments made Flew popular on the campus speaking circuit; videos from debates in the 1970s show a lanky man, his black hair professorially unkempt, vivisecting religious belief with an English public-school accent perfect for the seduction of American ears. Before the current crop of atheist crusader-authors  Richard Dawkins, Daniel Dennett, Christopher Hitchens  there was Antony Flew.

title: Musharraf Leaves White House in Lurch
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3  For more than five months the United States has been trying to orchestrate a political transition in Pakistan that would manage to somehow keep Gen. Pervez Musharraf in power without making a mockery of President Bushs promotion of democracy in the Muslim world.

title: Selling America
description: Karen Hughes brought strengths to the job of public diplomacy, a critical, often overlooked tool for advancing the national interest. She was an insiders insider, a confidante from President Bushs Texas inner circle who could speak for him authoritatively. Yet as she prepares to leave office, polls shows the United States is hated more than ever in the Muslim world.

title: Mary Frekko, Nicholas Kilavos
description: Dr. Mary Ilona Frekko, a daughter of Gertrude D. Frekko and Dr. Tibor E. Frekko of Darnestown, Md., was married yesterday to Nicholas George Kilavos, a son of Georgia N. Kilavos of Dearborn Heights, Mich., and the late George T. Kilavos. The Rev. Donald P. Worch performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Mercy Roman Catholic Church in Potomac, Md.

title: That 70s Show: Bella, the Blackout and the Burning Bronx
description: HOW appropriate. An oral biography of Bella Abzug.

title: Avenue That Used to Be Awaits a Rebirth
description: East Orange

title: Swords, Songs and Women on the Run
description: THE PRINCESS BRIDE

title: Its Not Whether to Kill, but How
description: WHEN the Supreme Court stayed an execution last week for the third time in October, making the month the first in nearly three years with no executions, the justices sent a clear message to the states: Dont execute anybody until we have decided Baze v. Rees, a death penalty case scheduled to be argued in January.

title: Double or Nothing on the Democrat
description: WILLIAM MAYER, shamed and penniless after gambling away his rural Illinois home on a bad wager, hanged himself on Nov. 9, 1904. The New York Daily Herald carried word of his demise in a one-sentence brief alongside more felicitous news of those who had picked more wisely.

title: Next Door to a Poignant Memory
description: The Living In column of Oct. 21, about Battery Park City, omitted a designer of the community. The master plan for Battery Park City was created by Stanton Eckstut and Alexander Cooper, not by Mr. Eckstut alone. At the time, 1979, the men were partners in Alexander Cooper Associates.

title: How I Met Jerry Seinfeld, Scene 1, Take 2
description: THERE are three things people think they know about Jessica Seinfeld, the semipublic wife of the popular comedian:

title: This Is Going to Hurt
description: ASHEVILLE, N.C.

title: A Campaign to Eliminate Cigarette Butt Littering
description: Northport

title: Running Man
description: To the Editor:

title: Spreading Cheer, Doves and Transvestites
description: MIRACLE IN MILAN/WHITE CHRISTMAS

title: Bringing Back Breakfast
description: At Moms Restaurant in Ringoes, its easy to follow the motherly advice not to skip breakfast. Here you wont want to miss the homestyle pancakes, waffles and omelets.

title: Grand Switch Auto
description: ONE recent Saturday, Brian Alcazar was hanging out at RCT Performance, a modest speed shop in College Point, Queens, that specializes in squeezing the most performance out of turbocharged and supercharged cars. Through the shop window, Mr. Alcazars silver 2005 Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution VIII could be seen parked outside under a clear fall sky. Inside, the topic was speed and how to get it. Business as usual.

title: Urban, Hip Place With Locally Grown Focus
description: I LIKE to give a new restaurant several months to establish itself before reviewing it, but sometimes the buzz on a place is such that its hard to wait. Firebox, named for the metal fuel box in the engine of a steam locomotive, opened in Hartford on June 1 and I was there shortly after, my curiosity aroused by the community-conscious entrepreneurship that the restaurant was spearheading.

title: Power of the Press
description: After years of trying to figure out at what age one becomes grown-up, I have decided it is the age I inhabit now. Rather than do anything silly like put a number on it, lets just say its the age when youre caught up on all your tax returns, you sleep on ironed sheets and eat dinner with cloth napkins.

title: As Cool as They Want to Be
description: Gauzy blouses and short skirts filled the junior womens department at a Midtown H&M. I was there last fall at the request of my niece, Madeleine, then 14, who wanted better clothes for school. I dont like sleeveless, she whispered about one blouse. Thats too revealing, she said of another.

title: Daughter of Slain Man in Foster Care
description: A 4-year-old girl whose father was killed at a Queens playground last week was taken from her fathers relatives on Friday and placed in foster care, lawyers in the case said.

title: A Basketball Star Assists Home Talent
description: WHEN Daisy Brand heard that the N.B.A. star Allen Iverson had bought a minor league basketball team in Virginia for his mother, she wondered aloud whether her son Elton should do the same in Westchester.

title: Tufts Asks for 250 Words of Wisdom
description: Tufts has a problem shared by most competitive universities: After it rejects the weak and admits the geniuses, too many decent applicants remain  about three for every spot. Recommendations and polished essays all pretty much say the same things, says Lee Coffin, dean of undergraduate admissions.

title: Portrait of an Ex-Dictator as an Old Man: Suharto Slips Into Irrelevance
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Nearly 10 years after the tumult of his ouster, the old dictator spends his days alone in his sitting room, one friend says, inviting few visitors, making no public statements, eating carefully to avoid hurting his stomach.

title: Musharraf Consolidates His Control With Arrests
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 4  The government of Gen. Pervez Musharraf, making no concessions a day after seizing emergency powers, rounded up leading opposition figures and said Sunday that parliamentary elections could be delayed for as long as a year.

title: SEMA: 2,000 Vendors, but One Star
description: LAS VEGAS

title: The Orphans Who Didnt Need Saving
description: DAKAR, Senegal

title: Move Over, Orbitz
description: WITH so much of college readily accessible on the Web, families may be forgiven for relying on the Internet, too, for advice on how to pay the tuition. And loan companies and entrepreneurs are lining up to give it to them.

title: The Girl, the Swing and a Row House in Ruins
description: EVELYN NESBIT was just 16 years old when she used to kick high into the air from the red velvet swing, aiming her toes at the great Japanese fan that hung from the ceiling of the hideaway built for seduction.

title: Iraq, With U.S. Support, Voids a Russian Oil Contract
description: BAGHDAD, Oct. 29  Guided by American legal advisers, the Iraqi government has canceled a controversial development contract with the Russian company Lukoil for a vast oil field in Iraqs southern desert, freeing it up for potential international investment in the future.

title: The Days Best
description: PERCY HARVIN, left, became the first player in Florida history to have 100 yards receiving and rushing in a game. He ran for 113 yards and 2 touchdowns, and caught 9 passes for 110 yards.

title: Hide and Chic
description: Designer stereotypes are easy to come by  say Gucci girl or Versace babe, and a clear picture (usually involving bikinis in St.-Tropez or fur in Gstaad) instantly emerges. Other labels, however, are harder to classify. Although Bottega Veneta has become the second-most-profitable brand in the Gucci Group stable and is one of the most recognizable luxury names on the planet, one would be hard-pressed to identify a Bottega look. Thats because its creative director, Tomas Maier, likes it that way. Whether hes designing furniture, woven leather handbags, mens and womens clothes, fine jewelry or sunglasses, he always places a premium on materials, handwork and process over glitzy logos and fly-by-night trends. Unlike many of his peers, Maier believes that if youve truly got it, you would never dream of flaunting it.

title: Matthew Morningstar and Alan Van Capelle
description: Matthew Edwin Morningstar and Alan Van Capelle celebrated their partnership last evening at Studio 450, an event space in New York. Mik Moore and Karen Bertulli, friends of the couple, led the commitment ceremony.

title: Is (His) Biography (Our) Destiny?
description: If I am the face of American foreign policy and American power, Barack Obama mused not long ago aboard his campaign plane, as long as we are also making prudent strategic decisions, handling emergencies, crises and opportunities in the world in an intelligent and sober way. . . . He stopped. He wanted to make sure he got this just right, and he had got a little caught up in rebutting the claim, which Hillary Clinton has artfully advanced, that he is not prepared to handle emergencies. Obama stopped picking at his grilled salmon in order to stare out at the sky for a few moments. I think, he said, in that deep and measured voice of his, that if you can tell people, We have a president in the White House who still has a grandmother living in a hut on the shores of Lake Victoria and has a sister whos half-Indonesian, married to a Chinese-Canadian, then theyre going to think that he may have a better sense of whats going on in our lives and in our country. And theyd be right.

title: Grrridlock
description: TRAFFIC, apparently, hits a nerve.

title: Trees Dressed in Leaves, Even This Late
description: SHARON

title: Food-Chain Blues
description: Stewart ONans turf is the large swath of the country that lies in the dark shadow of the American dream. His fiction tends to chronicle the lives of the two classes that dwell there: the poor and, as he puts it, the richer poor. He is a poet of strip mall ennui, road rage, fluorescent lighting and the sparse lawns of prefabricated real estate developments. His characters strive to make their mortgage payments, hold full-time jobs and keep the refrigerator stocked, but struggle to fend off the lurking nightmares of domestic crime, alcoholism and war trauma. They buy lottery tickets, and they always lose.

title: Consciousness Raising
description: Know-it-all career switchers dont need to sit through that introductory psych lecture. The College-Level Examination Program, administered by the College Board, offers a chance to earn course credit at 2,900 two- and four-year colleges. The 34 subjects include educational psychology (recognized by some states, including New York, for teacher certification) and human development (for nursing degrees). The exams are taken by some 150,000 students a year, more than half of them adults. Test your psych smarts with the sample CLEP questions below. Answers at bottom.

title: A Juicy Red to Chill
description: Unaccountably, ric Texiers versatile Rhne portfolio has not yet found a large audience. Thus his basic 2005 Ctes du Rhne is underpriced. It costs $13.49 at Chambers Street Wines, 160 Chambers Street (West Broadway).

title: A Small-Town Feel in an Urban Locale
description: AFTER spending several years in the South, Darrell Wallace and Jennifer Adkins of Greensboro, N.C., decided it was time to move. Were both artistic and politically active, and it was really hard to find peers into the same thing in Greensboro, said Mr. Wallace, 30.

title: Union and Ford Reach Tentative Deal
description: DETROIT, Nov. 3  The United Automobile Workers union reached a tentative four-year agreement with the Ford Motor Company early Saturday that follows the pattern set in new contracts at General Motors and Chrysler.

title: Up Front
description: This week, the Yale legal scholar and novelist Stephen L. Carter reviews Donald McCaigs Rhett Butlers People, the latest authorized sequel to Gone With the Wind. Before beginning work on the review, Carter confesses, he had never read Margaret Mitchells classic novel. My experience of the Gone With the Wind universe was limited to a handful of vaguely remembered viewings of the film, he said in an e-mail message. My expectations for the novel might charitably be called low. I suppose I expected a poorly written racist tract. But Carter, whose own best-selling novels New England White and The Emperor of Ocean Park suggest he knows something about combining literary entertainment and penetrating observation about race in America, found his assumptions upended. I was staggered by the power of Margaret Mitchells imagination and the clean beauty of her prose, he wrote. Her characters are irresistible.

title: The Little Gold Man Made Me Do It
description: SERIOUS moviegoers tend to view the Oscars as a sideshow, and a dclass one at that, with little relation to quality cinema. Important Films, the convention holds, do not don a revealing frock and traipse the red carpet, risking a fondling by Isaac Mizrahi.

title: Devices Enforce Silence of Cellphones, Illegally
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2  One afternoon in early September, an architect boarded his commuter train and became a cellphone vigilante. He sat down next to a 20-something woman who he said was blabbing away into her phone.

title: A Long Weekend? How About a Whole Year?
description: WHEN Peter and Jill Feuerstein sit around the dinner table with their teenage children, Betsy and Ben, its not unusual for them to have an animated discussion about a remote village in China, India or Zimbabwe. But unlike many people in their hometown of Larchmont, N.Y., the Feuersteins have a personal connection with these places. In June 2002, they embarked on a yearlong journey around the world with their two kids, then ages 14 and 11, in tow.

title: Theater Workshop Embraces Those With Autism
description: Montclair

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about Richard Kellys movie Southland Tales misidentified the Web site for Donnie Darko, an earlier film that Mr. Kelly wrote and directed. It is donniedarkofilm.com, not southlandtales.com.

title: Week 9 in Preview
description: COWBOYS at EAGLES

title: Once Just a Stopover, an Australian City Grows Up
description: ONCE just a stopover for tourists en route to either the Great Barrier Reef or the beaches on the Sunshine and Gold Coasts, the eastern Australian city of Brisbane has emerged as an alluring destination in its own right.

title: Its Not a Popemobile but It Comes in Handy
description: Its all white, can lift 20 tons and has custom trim and the Vatican coat of arms on the front  and it cost Pope Benedict XVI nothing. Its the new tractor given to the pope last week by Fiat, the Italian carmaker that also owns CNH Global, the maker of Case and New Holland tractors that is based in Burr Ridge, Ill.

title: Michelle Walton, Evin Dobson
description: Michelle Katherine Walton, the daughter of Mi Cha Han of Chicago and the late Richard K. Walton, was married Friday evening to Evin Ross Dobson, the son of M. J. Dobson and Charles Dobson, both of New York. The Rev. Joel Gibson Sr., an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in New York.

title: The Art of the Pickup, as Novices Seek Advice
description: WESTBURY

title: The Lloyd Aquifer: Hypocrisy and Fairness; The High Cost for High School; For Unwed Mothers, a Place to Thrive (3 Letters)
description: The Lloyd Aquifer: Hypocrisy and Fairness

title: Despite Malls, a Vital Culture
description: ESTABLISHED in the wake of the Great Quake a century ago, San Francisco's Japantown, or Nihonmachi, is the largest of three Japantowns in the United States. The neighborhood still bears the marks of its twin calamities: wartime internment and 1960s redevelopment. But now, with more interest in all things Japanese and still-unbridled investor enthusiasm for San Francisco real estate, Japantown is undergoing a renovation that promises to raise the area's profile considerably.

title: Trying to Stir Up Devils, the Rangers Avery Settles for a Victory
description: Rangers left wing Sean Avery nuzzled up to Devils left wing Zach Parise before a face-off yesterday and started into a conversation that Parise had no interest in joining. As Avery barked, challenging Parise to a fight, Parise stared ahead.

title: Limited Luxury
description: Anyone who has complained that the Internet is denigrating luxury hasnt logged on to 20ltd.com. Created by the British advertising executives Jolyon Fenwick and Marcus Husselby, it showcases only 20 limited-edition products at a time, ranging from designer rings (Solange Azagury-Partridges) to furniture (Peter Anderssons ebony easy chair) that Fenwick has commissioned solely for the site.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: CARNEGIES LEGACY

title: New Centers Planned for Veterans Services
description: MILITARY veterans from Westchester are reacting warily to pending changes in their medical care, with nursing-home and psychiatric beds poised to move out of the county while a plan to build a residential center in Yonkers moves ahead.

title: Whats Behind the Race Gap?
description: High-cost subprime mortgages have often been framed as loans that catered to people with blemished credit records or little experience with debt.

title: The Man I Wish Was Your Father
description: Whos that? asked Katie, my 13-year-old daughter. She was pointing to a photograph I had recently found and put on my office bulletin board at home. A man and I are standing with our arms around each other on Herring Cove Beach on Cape Cod. Katie didnt know him, which is unusual, because as a lesbian parent I make a point of having my male friends around my children as much as possible.

title: Staying Loyal to a Killer, From His Trial to Their Arrest
description: What kind of woman would hitch her wagon to Robert E. Chambers Jr.?

title: Eco-Education
description: As the sun goes down over the College of the Atlantic, the cafeteria gets dimmer and dimmer. But only when it is nearly impossible to see the food does a student, finally, get up and turn on the lights  prompting a collective groan at this wanton use of energy. Another adjusts the lights, bringing them down a notch.

title: January Release Schedule
description: JANUARY

title: Smells Like Team Spirit
description: GRADES, recommendations, SAT scores, who cares? There is another, much easier way of getting into college  if you happen to weigh 250 pounds or so, that is, and can run the 40 in under 4.5. In that happy instance, college will come to you. The football coach, or one of his assistants, will camp on your doorstep, phone you and send you text messages daily, conduct long, earnest conversations with your mom and dad, and arrange for lovely, long-legged coeds to show you around the campus. (If you were being recruited by the University of Colorado a couple of years ago, sex and alcohol were also part of the enticement package.)

title: Metro Briefing
description: Its easy to wake up and spend a day in New York and not notice the wonder of it all. The city offers up daily mysteries and curiosities, yet most of us are so involved in our own neighborhood-centric routines and work-and-love intrigues that what goes on outside our immediate purview is a blur. Which is why God created newspaper feature writers, who venture out to mine the magic in the seemingly mundane.

title: Stephanie Crissy, David Rader
description: Stephanie Lauren Crissy was married yesterday evening to David Matthew Rader. The Rev. Vic Willis, a Methodist minister, performed a nondenominational ceremony at the Breakers in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Republican Tricks on Childrens Health
description: Cynicism and hypocrisy were on full display in the Senate last week when Republican leaders refused to wait for a possible compromise on a bill that would provide health coverage for millions of uninsured children. Instead, they forced a vote on a bill that they know President Bush will veto, with no chance of being overridden.

title: Mom? Lawyer? The Ambivalence Track
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y.

title: Growing Up, Not Out, in Brooklyn
description: ONE way to get to the small carriage house in back is through the mansion in front.

title: Stefanie Firtell, Jame Donath
description: Stefanie Aimee Firtell and Jame Donath were married last evening in New York. Rabbi Hirschy Zarchi officiated at the Metropolitan Club.

title: The Trickle-Down From Pollock
description: Fifty years ago a loud, quarrelsome, hard-drinking artist from Wyoming named Jackson Pollock made himself and American art famous with his drip paintings and aberrant social behavior. Celebrating his life and influence on contemporary artists is Jackson, a lively, wry, suitably wacky exhibition at the Contemporary Art Galleries at the University of Connecticut in Storrs.

title: Kathryn Godburn, Brian Schubert
description: Kathryn Ann Godburn, a daughter of Lynette Godburn and William G. Godburn of North Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Brian Scott Schubert, the son of Ludwig Schubert Jr. of Berlin, Conn., and the late Shannon Schubert. The Rev. William Hegedusich, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Peters Church in Washington.

title: Poetry, Peru, Psychedelia and Soul, With Folkie Flavors
description: SAUL WILLIAMS

title: Clinton Rebuts Accusations of Secrecy
description: DES MOINES, Nov. 3  Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons political camp struck back on Saturday against rivals who were attacking her as overly secretive, circulating legal arguments from a Clinton ally asserting that the Clintons are not blocking the release of presidential papers about their discussions in the White House in the 1990s.

title: Foreign Buyers Take Manhattan
description: KENNY TIMMONS has spent three long weekends in New York City since 2003, catching up with friends he knew in Ireland, visiting ground zero, restocking his wardrobe at Armani and Niketown and chatting about real estate with a bartender in an Irish pub in Midtown Manhattan.

title: Attack From Beyond
description: I recently received a vitriolic diatribe from a friend who died of cancer four years ago. In her will, she ordered her diary entries transcribed and sent to each person she wrote about. Her executor was, I guess, legally bound to follow her wishes, but should he have, knowing that this would more than likely hurt the recipients?  Susan Jackson, San Francisco

title: Another Teardown? No, an Architectural Gem
description: YONKERS

title: Border Politician
description: God is about the only thing that evokes more reverence from the average Mexican than the concept of revolution.

title: The Very Expensive Reality of Chasing Reality TV
description: TO say Tom Sullivan likes Survivor would be a gross understatement. Mr. Sullivan, a radio and television host in Atlanta, auditioned five times for this reality show, which has a $1 million prize. He spent hours shooting, editing and mailing videotapes of himself to producers and casting agents, and has traveled to four cities to compete for the honor of not being voted off the island.

title: The Things They Carried
description: In 2003, when Gen. Colin Powell, then the secretary of state, was making the case to the United Nations Security Council that Saddam Hussein had stockpiled weapons of mass destruction, Elizabeth D. Samet, in a literature class for first-year students at West Point, was teaching Herman Melvilles story Bartleby the Scrivener, with its central character who stubbornly, enigmatically, declines to do as he is told. The syllabus for that week also presented the students with Ambrose Bierces One Kind of Officer, in which young Captain Ransome, with (in Samets words) an aggrieved literalness, continues firing on his own side, in stubborn, rebellious, mad, destructive and self-destructive obedience to orders he knows are wrong.

title: Emorys Little Tibet
description: DRESSED in a pale blue, floor-length chuba, Paige Wilson silently mouthed a paragraph-long greeting, in Tibetan, that she was about to deliver to the Dalai Lama. The members of Emorys chapter of Students for a Free Tibet, of which Ms. Wilson is president, were among the lucky few selected to meet His Holiness in person.

title: Breaking Through
description: Alexandra Maria Lara

title: Does E-Mail Distract? Not if You Take Charge
description: Q. Reading and answering e-mail is taking up more and more of your time at work. How could this affect your work?

title: James Bond in Turkey
description: To the Editor:

title: Glass House
description: Andrew Bradbury, the sommelier behind Clo, the new wine bar and store in the Time Warner Center, follows design as closely as he follows emerging wine regions. So expect to see more than just ho-hum balloon glasses and leaded-crystal decanters. Much of the glassware at the store is culled from his travels and includes Zoe Stantons suite of self-filling Champagne glasses from Britain (above), Julia Leiheners stemless Thup glass from Germany and Takahide Sanos off-kilter Mickey decanter from Italy. There is also Extremiss DollyPop wine cooler (its woolly!) and Hiroshi Tsunodas graphic wine rack. Even the shopping bags  bottle-shaped sleeves made of Bubble Wrap, designed by WineSkin with the cutting-edge firm 2x4  bring some much-needed sass to vinoculture.

title: Brews That Seek Company
description: People go to the Lazy Boy Saloon for many reasons. Some want to remember the taste of their hometown beer. Others are looking for a classic but increasingly rare bar experience, replete with hot chicken wings, shared sports enthusiasms and cold ale. Still others want to try the latest trendy microbrew.

title: Playing Games With Toy Safety
description: With the holiday season approaching, there is more bad news about the federal agency charged with protecting children from unsafe toys. Nancy Nord, acting chairwoman of the Consumer Product Safety Commission, joined industry lobbyists in opposing a Senate bill intended to strengthen her enfeebled agency. That was followed by the revelation that Ms. Nord and her predecessor took free trips from the toy industry.

title: The Queen of Soul Takes Control
description: ON a recent Sunday afternoon the Queen of Souls hotel room on Central Park South looked like an executives pit stop. Aretha Franklin had returned to New York City late after a concert in New Jersey, and the morning had been too busy for maid service. The afternoon was no less active: an interview to promote her new collection of duets, Jewels in the Crown (J Records), and then a fitting for her latest designer dress. There were clothes, cotton puffs and a real-estate brochure on the floor, along with a new copy of Alan Greenspans book The Age of Turbulence, which she said she was planning to read. The television played silently; a laptop computer was open on a coffee table.

title: Arbour Makes His Comeback, and Islanders Make It Count
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., Nov. 3  In his first stint as the coach of the Islanders, from 1973 to 1986, Al Arbour took over a struggling expansion team and won four consecutive Stanley Cup titles. He had a second stint, from 1988 to 1994, before retiring after 739 career victories and 1,499 games with the team.

title: Colts May Be Patriots Only Obstacle
description: Anyone who sees the Colts game against the Patriots as a dream matchup is ignoring the downside.

title: Landmark Status
description: Amid the designer new builds and gut renovations in the far West Village, Sean MacPhersons 1840s house feels as anachronistic as a meatpacking plant  which it actually was. No one wanted this place, he says of the three-story structure he formed from a crumbling, roofless kosher butcher shop four years ago. It was a grisly process, he says, and he means it literally.

title: Newark Arenas Economic Impact Unclear
description: NEWARK

title: Close to Nature, and the Airport
description: TAKE the A train to its less famous, unhurried end. Pay attention after it rises above ground and starts cutting through water. One stop before you hit Rockaway Peninsula and the Atlantic Ocean, get out.

title: Cannabis Thrives in an Afghan Province
description: KHWAJA GHOLAK, Afghanistan  Amid the multiplying frustrations of the fight against narcotics in Afghanistan, the northern province of Balkh has been hailed as a rare and glowing success.

title: But Can He Hum?
description: THE Brooklyn Instrument Museum is a museum only in the loosest sense: Its the living room of a Williamsburg couple, crammed with peculiar relics they collect on eBay and dust off for jam sessions.

title: Calendar of Events
description: Comedy

title: Heading to a Museum? Dont Forget a Laptop
description: Purchase

title: Mr. Geniality
description: The elements of this collection fully justify the rather modest promise offered by the title. All things are indeed considered, and they are mostly considered in a highly considerate manner. As to the due part, John Updike himself informs us: Bills come due; dues must be paid. After eight years, I was due for another collection of nonfictional prose. To which one might add that he seems determined to give everyone his or her due. Indeed, in a highly affable preface he wonders if his only fault might be a tendency to be critical  in the ordinary sense of the term  at all. Rereading his book reviews, he wonders aloud if their customary geniality, almost effusive in the presence of a foreign writer or a factual topic, didnt somewhat sour when faced with a novel by a fellow-countryman. Should he perhaps have been a little kinder to E. L. Doctorow, Don DeLillo and Norman Rush or (by implication) a fraction more harsh with Ngugi wa Thiongo and Haruki Murakami? Such scruple no doubt does its author credit, and yet Customary Genialities would surely have been a rather insipid title.

title: Russian Radar Called Good, but Not Exact Enough for U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2  To block American proposals for building missile defenses in Europe, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia surprised the White House in June with a counteroffer to let the United States use one of the Kremlins most secret early warning radars.

title: Steel Point: A Step Forward
description: The vacant, trash-strewn waterfront acreage of Steel Point in Bridgeport has become the symbol of that citys potential and, at the same time, its maddening inability to prosper. But tomorrow the City Council is scheduled to vote on a land disposition agreement between Bridgeport and the proposed developer of the property, Midtown Equities. If the Council ratifies the agreement, Midtown Equities would buy the property and begin a nine-year project to build 3,500 condominiums, dozens of shops and offices.

title: Inside the List
description: WHY I AM A RICH WRITER: Ken Follett  his new novel, World Without End, is No. 3 on the fiction list  is yet another popular novelist who, to his credit, makes a habit of correcting the errors that creep into his books. Follett is good-natured and witty about his mistakes, even if others sometimes are not. On his Web site, for example, he writes about the following misstep, from his novel The Hammer of Eden: One of the F.B.I. agents is a Hindu called Raja Khan. Raja is a popular Hindu name, but Khan is a typical Muslim name. Some of my readers suffer a sense-of-humor lapse about this error. Follett was the subject of a profile recently in USA Today in which he recounted this conversation with a friend, the novelist and playwright Hanif Kureishi: We were talking about what the readers like, Follett said. He said, I never think about the readers. I told him, Thats why you are a great writer, and thats why I am a rich writer.

title: Luang Prabang, Laos: La Rsidence Phou Vao
description: THE BASICS

title: The Artisans of the Real Dolce Vita
description: A FEW miles from Pisa, in the tiny Tuscan hamlet of Cascina, is a small gourmet shop where gift boxes covered in cellophane line the shelves, customers scurry in to place orders and the sweet, delicate aroma of home cooking drifts in from the kitchen. The proprietor, Paul DeBondt, sets out a platter of bite-size pieces on the countertop for sampling and arranges rows and rows of artfully wrapped packages inside the display case. But you won't find dusty bottles of Super-Tuscan, aging wheels of pecorino or pungent vats of olive oil. That's because Mr. DeBondt makes only one thing  chocolate.

title: Weed It and Reap
description: Berkeley, Calif.

title: Love Triangle
description: EARLY on in the crisp autumn of 1964, it became clear that geometry was not one of my academic strengths. I had already assimilated the prevailing notion that math and science were not a girls domain, an assumption embraced by my guidance counselor, who subtly implied that I ran the losers club in these subjects. Adding to this motivational atmosphere was the fact that, other than its being a school requirement, no one had ever provided a good reason for studying geometry in the first place. There was no talk of its logic, beauty or challenge.

title: Letters
description: Anatomical Correctness

title: Ghosts Writer
description: To the Editor:

title: Gastrography | Mapping Meals
description: Have you been piggy at the table? Do you know which side the fork goes on? These are questions about the landscape of dining that Topoware, a new collection of china, linen and place mats, tries to address. Designed by Alexandra Deschamps-Sonsino and Karola Torkos, using the undulating circles and lines used in topography maps, Topoware bowls are marked full, hungry and very hungry; plates read modest, moderate and greedy. The pine place mats point to where your table setting goes.

title: Meghan Gereghty, Casey Shanley
description: Meghan Eileen Gereghty and Casey Finnerty Shanley were married yesterday at the Church of the Immaculate Conception in Westhampton Beach, N.Y. The Rev. Peter M. Colapietro, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Got Headphones, Gonna Fly Now
description: At the New York City Marathon, thousands of runners will begin their 26.2-mile odyssey through the five boroughs today wearing headphones hooked up to audio players like iPods.

title: Elections Could Shift Power in Nassau
description: THE balance of power in the Nassau County Legislature is at stake in the elections on Tuesday.

title: Macaris Seasonal Portfolio
description: The depth and intensity of Macari Vineyards autumn and winter portfolio are acutely attuned to the rich, deep flavors of the holiday dinners ahead.

title: Shout-Out
description: Chelsea, call me up! That was the caption next to a picture of the cheery author Jenna Bush, lips parted in speaking, the younger daughter (by minutes) of the president described by The Washington Post as giving a shout-out yesterday on NBCs Today. . . . Bush as author praised her first-daughter predecessor for her poise; said shed love to compare notes on their common experience.

title: Capital Cases Stall as Costs Grow Daunting
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 3  When Hilton M. Fuller Jr., a semiretired judge of the silver-haired, Southern-gentleman variety, agreed to preside over the trial in a notorious courthouse shooting here, he took a job no one else wanted  the legal community was still in shock over the death of a judge, a court reporter, a sheriffs deputy and a federal agent.

title: Week 9 in Preview
description: BRONCOS

title: Maura Hogan, Scott Watson
description: Maura Gail Hogan and Scott Andrew Watson were married yesterday at Lowndes Grove, a bed and breakfast in Charleston, S.C. The Rev. Dr. Mary E. Kraus, a United Methodist minister, officiated.

title: Jane Kramer, Kenneth Kaitin
description: Jane Alison Kramer and Kenneth I. Kaitin were married last evening by Rabbi Michael Rothbaum at Doral Arrowhead, a resort in Rye Brook, N.Y.

title: Dont Be Shy
description: CHRISTINE STUART, a communications professor at Pennsylvania State University, stood at the chalkboard and taught her students strategies for mingling at their forthcoming class party. Dont monopolize, she said cheerfully. You need to get around the room. She listed the three easiest forms of conversation  clichs, facts and opinions  on the board and urged students to make index cards with opening lines for starting conversations: Gee, this sangria is great, dont you think? or Sure is humid today.

title: It Baggage
description: We all strive for containment, insists the artist Toland Grinnell. We go home to a box. We put our things in a closet. We carry a bag. Even Neanderthals must have had bags. The urge is primal, basic.

title: New York Schools Brace to Be Scored, A to F
description: By many measures, Intermediate School 289 is a place parents would be happy to send their children. This year, it was the only middle school in New York City to achieve blue ribbon status, a marker of high achievement under the federal No Child Left Behind Act. The leading public schools guidebook calls it a place where solid academics are combined with attention to childrens social and emotional development. Educators from around the country routinely descend upon the school, in Battery Park City, to shadow its teachers.

title: Dannielle Romano, Jean-Paul Kyrillos
description: Dannielle Jenny Romano, a daughter of Patricia Romano of Harrisburg, Pa., was married yesterday to Jean-Paul Kyrillos, a son of Marguerite Kyrillos and Dr. Joseph M. Kyrillos of Middletown, N.J. The Rev. Wayne Meisel, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Metropolitan Building, an event space in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Mei Sze Chan and Jeff Greene
description: IN 2005, Jeff Greene turned 51, the age his father died of a heart attack.

title: The Weeklong Semester
description: WHO said education had to be meted out over 16 weeks, 40 hours a course? After all, the traditional semester was not born of some deep insight into the human learning process; it was just a logical timetable for an agrarian society ordered by harvest times and Christian holidays.

title: Naomi Mersky, Juan Sanabria
description: Naomi Beth Mersky, the daughter of Arlene A. Mersky and Howard W. Mersky of Silver Spring, Md., was married yesterday to Juan Samuel Sanabria, a son of Victoria I. Samuel and Cruz Sanabria, both of Brookline, Mass. Rabbi Leora Kaye officiated at Bridgewaters, an event space in Manhattan.

title: The City That Never Sleeps, Comatose
description: CULVER CITY, Calif.

title: Be Your Own Superhero
description: Following an unpleasant breakup, a despairing Loren Kreiss penned the dark graphic novelette The Artifact and the Manipulated Living. He then asked Mike Lilly, who has drawn for the Batman comic book, to illustrate his neo-noir story on 11 panels (one is shown left) that now sprawl across his Chelsea apartment.

title: An Associate Makes Full Partner
description: PORTLAND, Ore.

title: An Imitator of Chvez: He May Be Sincere, but Is It Flattering?
description: VALENCIA, Venezuela, Oct. 30  President Hugo Chvez has his own weekly television show in which he expounds on Socialist virtues. So does Luis Felipe Acosta Carlez, the governor of Carabobo, a state here in northern Venezuela that is home to a major oil-refining complex.

title: Sarah Cornell, Travis Gorenc
description: Sarah Ashley Haviland Cornell and Travis Allen Gorenc were married last evening at the Church of the Transfiguration in New York. The Right Rev. Andrew St. John, the vicar there, performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: God and Man on YouTube
description: The lost art of pantomime seems to be making a comeback on the Internet. Videos of wordless spectacles  natural anomalies, freak accidents, fistfights, dances, stunts, sleights of hand, animal antics  now attract enormous polyglot audiences to sites like YouTube. A silent clowning routine, Evolution of Dance, is YouTubes all-time most-viewed video. In it, a guy hams up a series of dance moves. It has been played 62 million times.

title: Small Campus, Big Books
description: THERE is a saying at Shimer College: If there are too many people to fit around the table, the class is too big. With an undergraduate student body of 70, this is one of the smallest liberal arts colleges in the United States. It has no lecture halls, and not just because of the enrollment. There are no lectures. Books, not professors, are considered the teachers, and the path to learning relies on the Socratic method of discussion.

title: In Stetson or Wig, Hes Hard to Pin Down
description: LONDON

title: Lottery Numbers
A La Mode
description: Herv Van der Straeten and Bruno Frisoni know that good parties, like good design, are all about the mix. At a recent dinner in their airy Parisian loft, the worlds of fashion and art melded in a perfect reflection of their decorating sensibility: modern chic with an edgy take on the classics.

title: When the Long-Haul Truck Hits a Bridge
description: TRAFFIC jams are a way of life in and around New York City, but few things irritate drivers more than finding out they were delayed by a tractor-trailer that mistakenly drove onto a parkway, slammed into an overpass and had to be pulled off the road.

title: Gridiron Girls
description: CATTYSHACK is a dark, brick-walled club carved from a former office building on Fourth Avenue near Carroll Street, on the industrial western fringe of Park Slope. The club caters to lesbians, and most nights, female revelers pack hip-wiggling dance parties featuring a well-used go-go pole.

title: Pro Shop
description: Food nerds across Los Angeles delight in stumping the equally obsessed staff at Surfas, a 70-year-old restaurant-supply store in Culver City thats the go-to resource for the hardest-to-find ingredients and cookware.

title: Ottoman Intrigue
description: When you read a historical mystery by Jason Goodwin, you take a magic carpet ride to the most exotic place on earth. Like its predecessor, The Janissary Tree, winner of the Mystery Writers of Americas 2007 Edgar Award for best novel, THE SNAKE STONE (Sarah Crichton/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25) is set in 19th-century Istanbul during the reign of Sultan Mahmut II and features the subtle sleuthing of Yashim Togalu, a eunuch with eyes and ears exquisitely attuned to the cacophony of life in his cosmopolitan world. But with the sultan on his deathbed after a 30-year reign, a deep unease has settled over the city, now poised uncertainly for a momentous historical shift.

title: No Exit
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: Merritt Friedman, Adam Pearson
description: Merritt Laurel Friedman and Adam Joseph Pearson were married last evening at the Mint Museum of Art, in Charlotte, N.C. Rabbi Barbara Thiede officiated.

title: Youth Club Finds Windfall in Gift of Stock
description: BOSTON, Nov. 3  The Boys and Girls Club of Pittsfield, Mass., relies, in part, on financial gifts to keep running. But officials were not sure they wanted to take a donation of poorly performing stock in a small company when it was offered two years ago, worrying about potential liability and risk to the organization. And club officials figured it would not net that much money, anyway.

title: A Latin Name, and Best Carefully Cooked
description: Technically, buffalo refers to animals of Asia and Africa  water buffalo and species like Cape buffalo. Those big shaggy symbols of the American West, revered by certain Indian tribes, driven to near extinction and often referred to as American buffalo, are in fact bison with the Latin name Bison bison.

title: Sales Bring Business Class Within Reach
description: HUNTING for holiday bargain fares to Europe? Take a look at the front of the plane. A number of airlines are running business-class sales with discounts so deep they rival coach-class prices.

title: Changing Coasts (and Accents, and Pay Grades)
description: SOME repaving may need to be done on the metaphoric highway between Hollywood and Broadway. Most of the traffic used to be moving west, as actors who had earned their stripes  and a modicum of fame  onstage headed to California, where greater celebrity and greater money beckoned. In the past decade or so, however, the westward traffic has slowed considerably, while the lanes heading east are filling up.

title: Amid Architectural Glories, Piles of Cheap Fun
description: TO drive into Chicago on a sunny Friday afternoon is to experience the city the way God  or at least the holy trinity of Daniel Burnham, Louis H. Sullivan and Mies van der Rohe  intended it. Iconic skyscrapers rise from the strip-mall-strewn prairie to pierce the blue in a jumble of geometries, their glinting glass, steel, stone and concrete announcing the power and prestige of the capital of the Midwest.

title: Dixon Makes Case for Heisman, Then Exits With an Injury
description: EUGENE, Ore., Nov. 3  Less than eight hours before No. 4 Oregon played No. 6 Arizona State on Saturday, the Ducks unveiled a nationwide television spot on ESPN that promoted the senior quarterback Dennis Dixon for the Heisman Trophy.

title: Clemenss Road to Starting Role With Jets Began at the End
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 2  Doubt sank in on the plane ride back from Arizona, as Kellen Clemens stole glances at the boot on his left foot and wondered if his football career was finished.

title: Trends Worth Following as Voters Head to Polls
description: TRENTON

title: Shakespeare in the Round-and-Round
description: FOR some children puppet theater is the gateway to a lifelong passion for a more grown-up kind of drama. For others, like Vit Horejs, who grew up to found the Czechoslovak-American Marionette Theater in New York, its home.

title: In Local Waters, an Oyster Resurgence
description: TWO years after a failed effort to declare it an endangered species, the Eastern oyster is making a big comeback, thanks in part, experts say, to farming and habitat restoration efforts across the Northeast.

title: The Foreign Legions
description: FOR a student at the University of Ghana in Legon, a palm-graced suburb of Accra, a dinner might involve fufu  mashed casava and plantains in a soup of peanut butter and tomatoes  from a local chop bar. Electricity is not a given. Nor is running water. Students might have to fetch buckets of water to flush the toilet and wash clothes. Forget sleeping in. They rise at 5 a.m., when the chaos and din begin: loud music and evangelical preaching, through megaphones. The Challenges of Living in Ghana handout from the University of California advises bringing earplugs.

title: Johtje Vos, Who Saved Wartime Jews, Dies at 97
description: Johtje Vos, a Dutch woman who with her husband hid three dozen Jews in their home during World War II, shepherding them through a tunnel under the backyard and into the woods whenever the Gestapo pounded on the door, died on Oct. 10 in Saugerties, N.Y. She was 97, and had lived in Woodstock from 1951 until a year ago.

title: Where Sales Are Buoyant
description: THINGS are always sweeter at the shore  even in real estate, as indicated by brokers and by fresh data on the market in several beach towns.

title: Heroes and Villains, Swords and Soldiers
description: All dates are subject to change.

title: The Words on the Street
description: enviro-nazi / (en vi ro\ nat se) / n. / a person who imposes his or her environmental activism on friends and family, as in, Shes such an enviro-nazi that she wont use paper plates, so we had to lug china for 12 to the picnic last weekend.

title: Witness to Wackiness on the Night Shift
description: THE human body can adjust to any type of work schedule. I have learned this over the last 12 years as a night auditor at the Hotel Diva in downtown San Francisco. My shift starts at 11 p.m. and goes until 7 a.m. During that time, most of my job is clerical. Because it is night, though, I often find myself face to face with something out of the ordinary that keeps it interesting.

title: My Demitasse Runneth Over
description: NEW YORK is not a hard place to find coffee: street vendors, delis and your own hotel room are among the prominent sources for the not very picky. And of course, there are plenty of cafes  engineered to sell social scenes and designer sandwiches as much as coffee  where you can kill a few hours. Apologies to the French, Spanish and Portuguese, but caf  their word for coffee  has become associated as much with comfy chairs and the clickety-clack of laptops as with the beverage. But that's not what you need on your vacation. You need to get your quick caffeine fix in the most civilized way possible, then be on your way. You have a city to see.

title: Youre In. Can You Back Out?
description: The Reality

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The On Language column on Page 20 of the Magazine today, about the word shout-out, misstated the network of the news commentator Chris Matthews, about whom the word was used in a New York Post headline. It is MSNBC, not CNN. (Go to Article)

title: Clemenss 4th-Quarter Drive Not Enough to Save Jets
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 4  In another losing locker room, the Jets slumped against their lockers. They did not scream. They did not vent. When they spoke, they spoke softly, with hardly a trace of anger or frustration.

title: Pairing Ballet With a Bachelors Degree
description: ON a recent Sunday evening the lobby of the Hotel Pennsylvania in Midtown Manhattan was crammed with weary tourists weighed down by shopping bags and guidebooks, porters wheeling racks of overstuffed suitcases and a sight entirely alien: slim, graceful figures gliding to the elevator bank like swans.

title: The Pod People
description: There are some opinions you never expect to change. As humiliating as this sounds, fancying George Clooney is one. Clever, witty, politically correct and (obviously) knee-knockingly sexy  whats not to like? But that was before I spotted Clooney in an ad for Nestls Nespresso, tapping a coffee capsule as if it were a casino chip in one of his Oceans Gazillion movies. It wasnt the fact that hed stooped to smirk in an ad that irked me; it was what Clooney was advertising. Now, its true that the espresso capsule doesnt score high in the ever-lengthening list of contemporary evils. But those tiny aluminum pods, and the overstyled espresso machines that use them, sum up much of what goes wrong with design when marketing is dressed up as innovation.

title: Too Much Meddling When C.E.O.s Go a-Courtin?
description: ASKING another corporation for its hand in marriage is always a delicate affair. But does a chief executive need to bring the directors along as chaperones? Does a merger-hungry C.E.O need his or her parents blessing before making a proposal?

title: Christina Yuan, Ali Ozturk
description: Christina Yuan, the daughter of Joan Reynolds Yuan and Albert Yuan of Glenside, Pa., was married yesterday in Villanova, Pa., to Dr. Ali Kemal Ozturk, the son of Dr. Gungor Eroglu of Istanbul and Kemal Ozturk of Ankara, Turkey. The Rev. James J. McCartney, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Thomas of Villanova Church.

title: How Smaller College Endowments Still Reap Big Returns
description: IN a world where the wealthiest investors often have access to the best-performing investment managers, it is tough for smaller college and university endowments to match the returns of deep-pocketed rivals like Harvard and Yale.

title: Manishi Prasad and Rohit Mehrotra
description: Manishi Prasad, a daughter of Mamta Gour Prasad and Madhukar Prasad of The Woodlands, Tex., was married in a Hindu ceremony there yesterday to Rohit Mehrotra, a son of Kusum Tandon Mehrotra and Amar Mehrotra of Massapequa Park, N.Y. Kesav Shukla, a Hindu priest, officiated at the Woodlands Resort and Conference Center.

title: Performa 07:  Performance Versus Installation
description: A series of unfortunate events caused me to miss Christian Jankowskis Rooftop Routine this morning, which Im really sad about. The idea was for people to join him on his roof to see a unique form of morning calisthenics, which was either a performance or a voyeuristic endeavor or something in the middle. Did anyone see it? Send me some details. Im picturing a cross between Trisha Browns rooftop dances from the 1970s (which are amazing just on film, and must have been absolutely stunning live) and the morning stretches that this old guy used to do on his roof deck in San Francisco, visible from a friends kitchen window. Spying is grand. And, speaking of Trisha Brown, you can see short films of her and her peers work from the 1960s and 70s in two Performa programs at the Anthology Film Archives on the 12th and 13th. Unless Im overlooking something on the calendar, it will be your only chance to see New York choreographers during the festival, as was discussed in an earlier post.

title: Berlin in Lights: Symphony of a City
description: Walther Ruttmanns Symphony of a City, screened twice at Zankel Hall on Saturday, was conceived as an abstract exercise in composition: think Rodchenko turned to film (though Ruttmann does not quite have Rodchenkos eye for a detail that is both telling and original). But though avant-garde in 1927, today it awakens primarily a voyeuristic response: what was life like then?

Bridge of Sighs
description: BERMAN COURT

title: Due Considerations
description: Everything Considered

title: Foreign Buyers
description: People are coming from around the world to buy property in Manhattan, lured by new condos, a booming market and brand-name cachet.

title: Onward
description: About 20 percent of new college graduates go right on to grad school, especially in medicine and the arts and sciences, according to Debra W. Stewart, president of the Council of Graduate Schools. After 10 years, more than 40 percent have enrolled. (Work experience is especially valued in M.B.A. programs.) Many colleges don't keep tabs on graduates. The institutions below, culled from a Peterson's survey, are some that do poll graduates on what they're up to. Their response rates vary. The chart offers a sketch of what some freshly minted graduates are pursuing.

description: Film

description: Views of Herzog & de Meuron's design for 40 Bond, a condominium project in downtown Manhattan.

description: Coup of the Weekend: Barack Obama showed up on Saturday Night Live, unannounced, to deliver the famous opening line, Live from New York, its Saturday night!
