title: Growing Cannabis in Afghanistan
description: While Balkh Province in Afghanistan has been successful in eradicating opium poppy cultivation, many farmers have merely switched to another illicit crop: cannabis.

title: Clemens Era Begins With a Loss
description: After blowing a lead, the Jets mounted a fourth-quarter comeback to force overtime against the Redskins.  But it wasn't enough to earn a victory.

title: Quit Yakking and Order Your Food
description: We published a story today about the use of cell phone jammers  gadgets that shut down cell phone signals within a several yard radius. The technology is not new, and its illegal, but its getting more popular among individual users who say they are sick of overhearing loud cell phone conversations in public settings.

title: The Joy in Jamming
description: The cellphone jammers express great joy initially at being able to silence chatterers. They also generally seem to feel some guilt, particularly over time.

title: Musharraf and Lincoln, in Their Own Words
description: As David Rohde reported in The Times today, Pakistans president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, speaking on Pakistani television about his decision to suspend his countrys Constitution, compared himself to Abraham Lincoln.

title: Eyewitnesses to the Marathon
description: Updated, Nov. 5 | NYTimes.com invited readers to submit photographs from their own marathon day for display on an interactive race map. Weve received snapshots of the family and friends you cheered on, photographs of the crowds and images of the elite runners.

title: Performa 07: Adam Pendleton, Artists and Statistics
description: My first Performa outing, to Adam Pendletons The Revival, on Thursday night, was a pretty impressive experience. The setting was the cavernous, immaculate space of the Stephan Weiss studio in Greenwich Village (what did the sculptor do with all that space?), outfitted with benches in a slight fan shape around the stage  and it was packed with fashionable Performa people, some standing near the back. The back was where Mr. Pendleton emerged from, but first his disembodied golden voice floated over the crowd, and over the choir and musicians on the stage. With a mixture of oratory, poetry, politico-speak and strident gay protest, he held sway for just on an hour, alternating his resonant, often repetitive text with the choirs gorgeous sonorities.I had my reservations about the text  for one, the section where Mr. Pendleton quotes Aids statistics and talks about the Bush Administrations responses to HIV infection felt like an obligatory gay rights insert rather than integral to the piece. But the man is the most charismatic performer Ive seen on stage for a long time  and the acoustics at the studio were extraordinary  for once, the meaning of crystal clear seemed appropriate: you could hear everything from a whisper to the full-throated roar of the choir with utter purity.It was also an extraordinarily polished and well-paced show, from the grave processional entrance of the choir to their departure and Mr. Pendletons final monologue and slow exit  out back, the way he had come in. But despite that, there was a relaxed enjoyment of performance and involvement amongst the choir that was a pleasure to see. And their singing really did communicate the uplifting joyousness of that religious tradition without quite speaking directly of religion.But quite aside from the piece itself, what struck me strongly was that it was the second time in one week that a performer was up there on stage quoting statistics about life in America to an audience. In his wonderful new work, Misuse Liable to Prosecution, the choreographer John Jasperse offers the audience numbers about the war, the arts, the salaries of various figures, and the costs of his production. Adam Pendleton does something similar in his Aids section. Are artists feeling that things are so bad that their art forms  poetry, the dancing body in these cases  are too inchoate for what they need to say? Perhaps it was a coincidence, but I suspect not.

title: The Fall Auction
description:
Combing through the offerings, The New York Times set out to
identify some tough sells, potential sleepers, familiar wares (read:
shopped) and coincidences.

description: Modern Drunkard magazine looks back at beer and liquor ads that didnt quite hit the mark, offering this prime example:

title: Citi Internal Memo: A New Whos Who
description: Even as turmoil roiled the top ranks of Citigroup throughout the weekend, the financial giant sought to clarify the leadership of its investment banking and alternative investments operations.

title: Sunday Morning Kickoff
description: Boston Colleges loss to Florida State brought the Eagles back to reality, according to Bob Ryan of the Boston Globe. Now they must focus on winning the A.C.C. championship.

title: Correction: A (Sometimes) Deadly Scourge
description: An article last Sunday about the prevalence of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, or MRSA, included information about treatments for infection, provided by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, that was incomplete. As the article noted, MRSA skin infections can respond to oral antibiotics like levofloxacin or moxifloxacin. But those two drugs belong to a class that the agency no longer considers optimal for treatment because MRSA is more resistant to them than to other agents. Instead, the agency recommends treatment with clindamycin, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, doxycycline, minocycline, rifampin or linezolid.

title: Correction: Worrying About the Public Worrying
description: An article last Sunday about a survey of commercial pilots designed to track safety problems misidentified the federal agency that conducted the study. It was the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: History, Youre Toast
description: The Toaster Museum Foundation says it wants to re-establish a permanent home for its namesake appliance (an offering from its toaster art gallery, above). A funny rant in the Book Review last week inveighed against histories of small things, but the foundation justifies the museum thusly:

title: Coles Out
description: The Jets inactive list contains an unfamiliar name this morning  receiver Laveranues Coles will not play because of a concussion he sustained last week against Buffalo.

title: The Week: A Gold Star for Readers!
description: Okay readers, how about a little praise for my last post on praise? Dont I get a little credit? A medal? Something to make me feel good about myself?

title: DARPA's Urban Grand Challenge
description: Built by the Stanford Racing Team, Stanley Jr. shows off the  latest in autonomous navigation technology.

title: New York City Marathon: Elite Runners
description: Martin Lel of Kenya won the mens race and Paula Radcliffe of England was the womens champion.

title: Citi Watch: A Kings Ransom for Princes Exit?
description: Sunday update: Charles Princes departure has been called retirement, which would entitle him to at least the $147.1 million for his time at Citigroup. Well update as we learn more.

title: Recipe: Zucchini-Sausage Pizza
description: There may be more possible combinations of pizza toppings than atoms in the universe, but Ive found that using the fewest components works best. Too many ingredients merely muddy the flavors.

title: Middle of the Pack
description: The New York City Marathon is more than a race. For tens of thousands of runners and hundreds of thousands of spectators, it's an event.

title: Youve Got Questions? Weve Got Answers.
description: Reporters and editors from The Times political desk will be answering questions about the 2008 election throughout the week. Please,E-Mail your questions to askthetimes@nytimes.com.

title: Citi Watch: Rubin and Bischoff Are In
description: It is over. Charles O. Prince III has resigned from Citigroup, with Robert E. Rubin serving as chairman and Winfried Bischoff as interim chief executive. Read Citis statement here.

title: Citi Watch: Meet the Interim C.E.O.
description: Charles O. Prince III has resigned from Citigroup, and Robert E. Rubin has taken the reins as chairman. But whos that interim figure in the chief executives seat?

title: One Collective Soul in Outer Space
description: The crews from the shuttle Discovery and the International Space Station had a farewell ceremony today and closed the hatch between the two craft. Discovery will undock tomorrow and prepare for its return to Earth on Wednesday.

title: Sunday Sampler Platter: Pakistan
description: A talk-show menu that was top-heavy with presidential candidates took a bit of a detour from domestic politics today  to Pakistan. The newly declared state of emergency there evoked sharp expressions of concern from the candidates and a handful of lawmakers, and there was disagreement about whether Americas considerable military aid to the Pakistanis should be suspended.

title: Citi Watch: The Goodbye Memos
description: In formalizing Charles O. Princes departure from Citigroup  officially deemed retirement  Mr. Prince and Robert E. Rubin and Winfried Bischoff sent Citis employees two memorandums addressing the shakeup. Mr. Princes sounds a remorseful note, praising Citis progress under his watch while accepting responsibility for its massive losses (a $5.9 billion in the third quarter, and potentially $8 billion to $11 billion to come).

title: London Slowing Rapidly
description: Knight Franks report on central London released today shows price inflation for residential property slowing rapidly in the last three months. After a crisp growth rate of more than 3 percent a month through the summer, Londons core residential property posted a miserly 0.3 percent bump in October, the smallest increase since 2005, according to the real estate companys research.

title: The First Game of the Clemens Era
description: The Kellen Clemens era kicked off today, and while he showcased that powerful right arm, Clemens also showed another, more unexpected, strength: his feet.

title: Rudy plays the race card
description: A central theme of The Conscience of a Liberal is that movement conservatives have won elections despite their economic message, not because of it, and that the most important factor in the movements electoral success is the exploitation of racial hostility.

title: Bayou Closers
description: It is O.K. if you want to refer to Louisiana States football team as the Closers, not the Tigers.

title: Suffering, Evil and the Existence of God
description: In Book 10 of Miltons Paradise Lost, Adam asks the question so many of his descendants have asked: why should the lives of billions be blighted because of a sin he, not they, committed? (Ah, why should all mankind / For one mans fault be condemned?) He answers himself immediately: But from me what can proceed, / But all corrupt, both Mind and Will depraved? Adams Original Sin is like an inherited virus. Although those who are born with it are technically innocent of the crime  they did not eat of the forbidden tree  its effects rage in their blood and disorder their actions.

title: Bowling in Storrs
description: Officials from the Sugar Bowl were on hand Saturday night in East Hartford to scout No. 16 Connecticut for a possible berth in the Bowl Championship Series, not the Final Four.

title: From Portland, Oregon
description: I get second billing to President Schwarzenegger, but still . . .

title: Carr on Hart
description: Michigan tailback Mike Hart probably wont win the Heisman Trophy this season, after missing two full games and parts of others with injuries. But the fact that he is well known, combined with his production, will likely get him an invitation to New York as a finalist.

title: Are the Patriots Unbeatable?
description: It may have been impossible to live up to the obscene level of hype it received, but the Patriots-Colts game certainly wasnt a stinker. The Timess William C. Rhoden says the game was not the Ali-Frazier type of event that Colts Coach Tony Dungy compared it to, but it proved beyond a doubt that the Patriots and the Colts are No. 1 and No. 1-A in the N.F.L.

title: The Inheritance on Climate
Jay-Z Finds Himself at the Movies
description: Jay-Z introduced himself to the world in 1996, when he released his debut album, Reasonable Doubt. On the front, he wore not only an umlaut (the cover read, Ja-Z) but also a suit with a matching hat; suffice it to say that back then Brooklyn rappers werent usually seen in formal wear. In the songs he played the part of the smooth criminal, delivering slick lyrics that sounded even better because he didnt raise his voice. The idea was, he didnt need to.

title: New CDs
description: CHRIS BROWN Exclusive (Jive/Zomba)

title: Radio Holding Off on Holidays, a Little
description: On Wednesday, the radio station KCKC in Kansas City, Mo., became the first station of the year to start playing Christmas music exclusively. Hundreds of other stations will soon follow, if previous years are any guide.

title: We Mustnt Turn Our Backs on the Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: Tracking of Web Use by Marketers Gains Favor
description: It seems that the Federal Trade Commission is not slowing down the online advertising party.

title: Still No Answer on What Caused Runners Death
description: The day after Ryan Shay died during the United States Olympic trials for the marathon  a seemingly healthy 28-year-old stricken early in a race he had run many times  his family had no more answers.

title: Gates in Beijing for Talks on Military Buildup
description: BEIJING, Nov. 4  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates arrived Sunday in Beijing to begin two days of talks with senior leaders, and Pentagon officials said he planned to press for a more open dialogue on Chinas military while discussing ways to build trust and cooperation.

title: Burlesque Without Borders
description: The program promises Berlin Cabaret. But audiences at the Caf Sabarsky, where the festival Berlin in Lights is presenting eight nights of cabaret this month, are getting Berlin cabaret by way of Vienna, since both the cafe and the Neue Galerie, the museum that houses it, are steeped in Viennese tradition. On Friday night this double dislocation underlined the theme of exile that permeated Ute Lempers opening program, which focused, as those familiar with Ms. Lemper might expect, on Brecht and Weill.

title: Death Camp Concert Is Canceled
description: Protests by Jewish groups ended plans for a rock concert scheduled for last Saturday at the site of a Nazi death camp in Belgrade, Serbia, The Associated Press reported. On Friday, Efraim Zuroff, director of the Nazi-hunting Simon Wiesenthal Center in Jerusalem, issued a statement calling the planned performance a heartless insult to the memory of the victims of the Nazis. The organizers of the concert by the British band Kosheen attributed the cancellation to pressure from foreign and domestic media. The concert was to have been held at Staro Sajmiste, where 48,000 Jews, Serb leftists and Gypsies perished in the 1940s. The Long Play company, which organized the concert, said, We hope that the big publicity created around the Staro Sajmiste site will be used for solving the problem of renovating the place. Members of the dwindling Jewish population in Serbia say the camp needs to be saved from decades of neglect.

title: Sun Reports Profit as Turnaround Continues
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5  Sun Microsystems delivered strong quarterly results today as it continued to benefit from its corporate restructuring and stronger sales of high-end computers.

title: Drawing a Line Between Enduring Harm and Legitimate Fear
description: When Alima Traore was a young girl in Mali, parts of her genitalia were cut off, which is the custom there.

title: Louis Vuitton Ad Shows Gorbachev Accompanied by Subversive Text
description: Even if you dont read Russian, a recent print ad for Louis Vuitton is something of a visual joke: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last leader of the old Soviet Union, sits in a limousine as it passes a remaining part of the Berlin Wall, an open Louis Vuitton bag beside him.

title: Kurdish Rebels Free Turkish Soldiers
description: DAHOK, Iraq, Nov. 4  Kurdish guerrillas on Sunday released eight Turkish soldiers who were captured two weeks ago in a bloody ambush that enraged Turkey and helped stir its government to the verge of invading northern Iraq.

title: Gangster Swats Bee
description: Crime paid for Universal Pictures when its American Gangster, starring Denzel Washington as a drug lord and Russell Crowe as his law enforcement nemesis, won the battle of the buzz by outdrawing Bee Movie at North American box offices. According to estimates compiled by the tracking company Media by Numbers, the two heavily promoted films captured the first two rankings in weekend grosses. Gangster took in $46.3 million, while $39.1 million went to DreamWorks Animations Bee, distributed by Paramount and employing the voices of Jerry Seinfeld, a writer of its screenplay, and Rene Zellweger as his beloved. Having seen better days, including Halloween, last weeks No. 1 film, Saw IV (Lionsgate), plummeted to third place, with $11 million, followed by Dan in Real Life (Disney) with $8.1 million and 30 Days of Night with $4 million.

title: Not Quite Ali-Frazier, but It Lived Up to Hype
description: Indianapolis

title: In Denver, a Ballot Fight Over Marijuana Arrests
description: DENVER  In 2005, voters here approved a measure making it legal for an adult to possess an ounce or less of marijuana. But arrests for misdemeanor marijuana possession have risen since then.

title: Shhhh. Paper and Tape in Use.
description: What must Marie Cool have been like as a child? After watching her task-based collaboration with Fabio Balducci at the Clocktower Gallery in Manhattan on Friday night, an image comes to mind: a pale, solemn girl dressed entirely in black, with a long strawberry-blond braid trailing behind, padding softly through a barren house. Stopping to pick up a paper clip, she unbends it with methodical absorption. Pausing a moment to stare into space, as if framing the action, she soundlessly abandons it in search of the next ordinary object waiting to be turned into art.

title: 26 Miles of Music: Race Is Also a Marathon of Bands
description: For 30 years, Bishop Loughlin High Schools marching band has set up at the very same spot on marathon day. For 30 years, about as long as the song has been around, they have played the theme from Rocky. Over. And over. And over again. Nothing else. All day long.

title: A Roosevelt for Roosevelt Island
description: Slicing into the East River, flanked by Queens and Manhattan, Roosevelt Island should be a destination. Plenty of people take the tram from Manhattans East Side, but unless they live, work or go to school on the island, there is little else to do, except take the tram back.

title: Corrections
description: The headline with an article on Saturday about Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign and the issue of treating women and men equally in presidential politics overstated Senator Clintons response to suggestions that she had been using her gender as a shield against criticism from her male opponents. Mrs. Clinton said her rivals were picking on her because she was winning, not because she was a woman. She then went on to say: I anticipate its going to get even hotter  and if you cant stand the heat, get out of the kitchen. And Im very much at home in the kitchen. Mrs. Clinton did not retreat on issues of men versus women. (Go to Article)

title: A New Arena in the Fight Over Smoking: The Home
description: Jill and Joanie Shockley just want to breathe clean air in their homes. Neighboring tenants want to smoke in theirs.

title: Chef Tell, Who Turned Kitchen Skill Into TV Fame, Dies at 63
description: The Philadelphia culinary legend known as Chef Tell, who gained nationwide fame as an early television chef in the 1970s and 80s, died Oct. 26 at his home in Upper Black Eddy, Pa. He was 63.

title: Dallas to Vote on Remaking City
description: DALLAS, Nov. 5  Municipal officials here recognized decades ago that the grassy flood plain cutting a swath through the city could be transformed into a vast park.

title: Obama Plays Convincing Obama in a Skit Mocking Clinton
description: Saturday Night Live has relentlessly mocked Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and this weekend allowed Senator Barack Obama, a chief rival for the Democratic presidential nomination, to join in the skewering.

title: Parsons to Step Down as Time Warner Chief
description: Jeffrey L. Bewkes will succeed Richard D. Parsons as the chief executive of Time Warner at the end of the year, the company announced today, confirming a widely expected transition of power at one of the worlds foremost media companies.

title: A Winning Soccer Coach Faces a Ruthless Foe
description: It is a crisp autumn day and the Martin Luther King Jr. High School soccer team is winning again. Their precision passing and stifling defense usually make for one-sided games; until a few weeks ago, the squad was ranked first in the nation.

title: Couple Struggles to Pay Bills and Care for Sick Son
description: Like many expectant mothers, Kelly Cabrera was both nervous and eager. Her third child was due, and Ms. Cabrera had decided it would be her last. She was ready to find a job to help her husband, Edison, support their family.

title: Guatemalan Voters Elect Businessman
description: GUATEMALA CITY, Nov. 4  A former army general who once took on the insurgency in Guatemalas long civil war lost his battle for the countrys presidency on Sunday night, with voters rejecting his plan to use an iron fist, as well as the countrys military, to control a sky-high murder rate.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 9 P.M. (22, 26) CAROL BURNETT: A WOMAN OF CHARACTER Whether descending the staircase at Tara dressed in a curtain, with rod, or emitting one of her Tarzan yells, Ms. Burnett, above, made America laugh while also smashing stereotypes and showing that women could be at once feminine, empowered and funny. This American Masters documentary pays tribute to her life and career, using one of her signature devices: the audience question-and-answer session that opened her weekly show, which won 25 Emmys during its run from 1967 to 1978. This program includes clips of Ms. Burnetts appearances on other television shows, in films and on the stage. It also features interviews with performers she inspired, including Tracey Ullman, Ellen DeGeneres, Kristin Chenoweth and Jenna Elfman. Alas, Ms. Burnetts childhood wasnt a laughing matter. But as her grandmother once told her, Comedy is tragedy plus time.

title: Fixing Citigroup Will Test Rubin
description: Throughout a long, public career, Robert E. Rubin spanned the highest reaches of Wall Street and Washington, and succeeded wherever he went.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week included todays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

title: After a Death, Time for Life and a Race
description: It was just a race  one of the best ever in the New York City Marathon, with two great athletes, two mothers, battling each other all the way, but still, only a race, in the opinion of the winner.

title: When Playing With Food Becomes Serious Business
description: One contestant painstakingly made a model of the Starship Enterprise out of an ear of corn, a stalk of celery, an eggplant, a mushroom and other vegetables. Another turned a half-shelled peapod into the hull of a ship. Several contestants made real potatoes into Mr. Potato Head-type creations.

title: In a Troubled World, Its Good to Be Exceptional
description: If you have missed Heroes, the NBC Monday-night series about a group of people with extraordinary capabilities, then you have missed everything, which is to say, you have missed a show that exempts almost no subject of current political or social fascination from the roster of its interests. More than a quarter of the way into the second season, the ratings have slipped somewhat, but it remains the most engaged drama on television at the moment, a big hand with fingers dangling in every pot.

title: From Paris With Love
description: The French president, Nicolas Sarkozy, arrives in Washington tomorrow on a visit to seal the renewal of ties between France and the United States following the crisis of 2003. Heres how the post-Iraq Franco-American lovefest may unfold at the White House.

title: Foster Children at Risk, and an Opportunity Lost
description: Two decades ago, New York City embarked on an experiment aimed at better assisting and protecting its most vulnerable black and Latino children. At its heart, the effort involved creating and supporting foster care agencies that would, at long last, be run by men and women of color.

title: 2008 Already Settled? Not by a Long Shot
description: ALLISON, Iowa  With a year to go until Election Day, the Democratic Party is understandably bubbling with optimism, its spirits raised with almost every new poll, fund-raising report or overflow crowd at a rally for Hillary Rodham Clinton, Barack Obama or John Edwards.

title: Uncle Sam on the Line
description: Washington

title: Second Place Is Enough for a Victory
description: Smiling through her post-race news conference yesterday, Gete Wami of Ethiopia did not look like someone who had spent the entire New York City Marathon within touching distance of first place, only to fall to second in the homestretch.

title: Serious Upscale Dcor for a Wayward Lady
description: La Traviata returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday afternoon. When a Franco Zeffirelli production is on the boards, competition is in the air. Who will win? Verdis beloved music, the people who sing it, or will both be swamped under the force of operas premier interior decorator?

title: Peter A. A. Berle, Lawmaker and Conservationist, Dies at 69
description: Peter A. A. Berle, who spent decades fighting for open space and clean water as a New York State assemblyman, commissioner of the State Department of Environmental Conservation and president of the National Audubon Society, died on Thursday in Pittsfield, Mass. He was 69.

title: Racecar Driver Is Fourth in Handcycle
description: Alex Zanardi, the Italian racecar driver who lost his legs in a crash in 2001, competed yesterday in the handcycle division of the New York City Marathon, his first marathon. Zanardi, 40, finished in 1 hour 33 minutes 17 seconds for fourth place.

title: He Never Met a Deal He Didnt Like
description: One of the greatest bridge players of all time, Tim Seres, died Sept. 27 at 82 in Sydney, Australia, where he lived most of his life. He was born in Hungary, lost his parents in World War II and soon thereafter, with the help of an aunt and uncle, went with his elder brother, George, to Sydney via France and Vietnam.

title: In Portland, Cultivating a Culture of Two Wheels
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Susan Peithman did not have a job lined up when she moved here in September to pursue a career in nonmotorized transportation. No worries, she figured; the market here is strong.

title: Missteps on Both Sides Led to Health Bill Veto
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4  They met almost every day in the spring and summer, a handful of powerful senators who had cleared their schedules to forge a bipartisan compromise providing health insurance to 10 million children.

title: A Folksy Guy, in Recovery, Is About to Land Millions
description: On his daily radio talk show, Glenn Beck portrays himself as an average guy, a recovering alcoholic and a comedian who regularly injects humor into his conservative politics.

title: Bush Offers Turkish Leader Help Against Rebels
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 4  President George W. Bush offered Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan additional help today in containing Iraq-based Kurdish militants, hoping to avert Turkish troops from crossing the border. Mr. Erdogan, however, did not indicate whether the White House reassurances were enough.

title: Armstrong Comes Back for More
description: A year ago, Lance Armstrong came to New York to run his first marathon, hoping to break three hours and finishing in anguish in 2 hours 59 minutes 36 seconds. His shins hurt (he later learned he had stress fractures), and he swore he would never run another marathon.

title: Fixing Citigroup Will Test Rubin
description: Throughout a long, public career, Robert E. Rubin spanned the highest reaches of Wall Street and Washington, and succeeded wherever he went.

title: Tattoo Marked Hip-Hop Killer
description: Jam Master Jays unidentified killer had a tattooed neck, according to a witness, The Associated Press reported. Five years after Jam Master Jay, the D.J. who provided beats and scratches for the rap group Run-DMCs groundbreaking records, was shot to death on Oct. 30, 2002, in his recording studio in Jamaica, Queens, his business partner Randy Allen told The Daily News in an interview published yesterday that he was in the control room, and his sister, Lydia High, was near the entrance at the time. Mr. Allen said she told him that after two gunmen ordered her to the floor, she saw a man with a tattooed neck approach Jay, 37, whose real name was Jason Mizell, and open fire. The first shot wounded another man. The second hit Mr. Mizells head at point-blank range, touching off an investigation that has been blocked by uncooperative witnesses, investigators say, despite a substantial reward. Ms. High has been reported to be in protective custody, and her lawyer said recently that he had not heard from her in more than a year. Mr. Allen said he had cooperated with investigators and was angry that others had not. Mr. Allen said, This is a case that can be solved.

title: Leon Brand, 74, Who Founded New York Architecture Prize, Dies
description: Leon Brand, an architect who conceived and administered the Albert S. Bard Award, an architectural prize intended to raise the standard of excellence for building design in New York City, died on Oct. 24 in Manhattan. He was 74.

title: India, Beyond City Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: Cowboys Rough Up Reid and the Eagles
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4  In the opening moments of the second half, many Philadelphia fans headed for the exits of Lincoln Financial Field. Dallas quarterback Tony Romo had just staked the Cowboys to a 20-point lead, but the real insult was that he did so with a 45-yard touchdown pass to the most hated former Eagle of them all, Terrell Owens.

title: Musical Days of Berlin (the City ... and the Irving)
description: Max Raabe, the wry, unsmiling and nonchalantly charismatic vocalist who headlines the Palast Orchester of Berlin, opened the ambitious 17-day festival Berlin in Lights on Friday night at Carnegie Hall. As is his wont, Mr. Raabe gave running commentary on the songs he and the ensemble were performing.

title: Developer Would Include Low-Cost Units in East Side Towers
description: A developer seeking to build seven high-rise buildings on a former Con Ed property by the East River has agreed to set aside hundreds of apartments for poor and working-class tenants, as well as space for a school.

title: Olson Takes Leave for Personal Matter
description: TUCSON, Nov. 4 (AP)  Arizona Coach Lute Olson is taking a leave of absence for unspecified personal reasons.

title: In the End, Radcliffe and Lel Break Free to Win New York
description: Four miles into yesterdays New York City Marathon, Paula Radcliffe of England and Gete Wami of Ethiopia were clear of the field and running into the medical unknown.

title: Another Question? Why Was She So Funny?
description: Pardon the imitation of the thoroughly unlikable Andy Rooney, but why arent our joke tellers likable anymore? Margaret Cho or Sarah Silverman might make you laugh, but would you want either of them at Thanksgiving dinner with Grandma and the kids?

title: Illness Ends Decemberists Tour
description: The indie-pop band the Decemberists have canceled the remaining dates on their fall tour, citing the illness of an unidentified member. In a statement on its Web site (decemberists.com), the five-member ensemble, based in Portland, Ore., said: One of our band members has been ill for a while, but we thought all would be well in time for these tour dates. After a couple shows, though, it has become clear that the illness is much worse than we had initially realized. We need to return home so our friend can mend. The cancellation of The Long and Short of It tour affects 28 shows, including a concert in New York that was to have taken place last Friday. According to the statement, there are no plans to reschedule.

title: Putting an End to Abusive Lending
description: When members of the House Financial Services Committee meet this week to put the finishing touches on a bill to curb abusive mortgage lending, they need focus only on how to make a good bill better.

title: $7,900 Valentino Gowns, a Click Away
description: ANGELENOS have Rodeo Drive. New Yorkers have Fifth Avenue. Chicagoans have the Magnificent Mile. For many other high-fashion shoppers, the nearest destination is the Web.

title: A Singer With the South in Her Soul and Jazz in Her Heart
description: Listen to almost any recording of the Oklahoma-born 1930s jazz singer Lee Wiley, and you will hear the sultry, honey-dripping voice of a Southern-accented forerunner of the young Peggy Lee.

title: New B.C.S. Formula: Turning Seven Into Two
description: Ten weeks have passed in this volatile college football season, and there finally seem to be some clues as to how it will end. Teams like South Florida and Boston College, which defied pedigree and expectations to rise toward the top of the poll, have settled back to reality. Others, like Florida, Louisville and California, have failed to live up to preseason expectations.

title: Child Prodigy, Grown Up, Returns With Enthusiasm
description: The striking thing was the crowd. Elisha Abas, 35, a former child prodigy on the piano, returned to Carnegie Hall, or at least to Weill Recital Hall, on Saturday night with a program of classical standards. The program was unusual  the printed program, that is, which, in addition to the repertory, included the logos of several sponsors and announced an after-party with a D.J. at an East Village lounge, free to anyone with a ticket stub. Most in the packed auditorium appeared to be of an age to take advantage of this offer. Here was the audience that classical music presenters are continually trying to reach: hip and mostly under 40.

title: Voice of Road Runners Knows About Endurance
description: Ian Brooks, the public-address announcer at the finish line of the New York City Marathon, stood on a platform above the action yesterday and gripped a microphone. A jumbo screen nearby showed Paula Radcliffe of Britain heading through Central Park, with Gete Wami of Ethiopia one step behind.

title: Pakistan Rounds Up Musharrafs Political Foes
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 4  The government of Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the Pakistani president, making no concessions a day after seizing emergency powers, rounded up leading opposition figures and said Sunday that parliamentary elections could be delayed for as long as a year.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,836 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Publishers See a Way to Track Their Content Across the Net
description: Copyrighted work like a news article or a picture can hop between Web sites as easily as a cut-and-paste command. But more than ever, as that material finds new audiences, the original sources might not get the direct financial benefit  in fact, they might have little idea where their work has spread.

title: Culture Institutions Go After the Short-Attention-Span Crowd
description: For a certain, dwindling generation of art-loving Manhattanites, a mental map of Brooklyn resembles a variation on Saul Steinbergs Big Apple-centric New Yorker cover, with the borough an undifferentiated lump save for that citadel of culture, the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Witness the BAMbus, which exists, much to the eye-rolling of locals, to zip Brooklyn-leery audiences to and from a show as painlessly as possible.

title: The Days Best
description: Drew Brees passed for 445 yards and 3 touchdowns in the Saints fourth straight victory, a 41-24 win over the Jaguars. Of his 35 completions, 25 were for first downs.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption in Science Times on Tuesday with an article about sites in Manhattan related to the Manhattan Project misidentified the location of a cyclotron that was used for physics experiments. The cyclotron shown was the one at Nevis Laboratories in Irvington, N.Y., not the one in Pupin Hall on the campus of Columbia University. (Nevis is owned and operated by Columbia.)

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Rosie ODonnell in Talks to Join MSNBC
description: Rosie ODonnell, who abruptly left The View on ABC last spring after drawing attention and ratings for her opinions on everything from the Iraq war to her co-hosts, is in serious discussions to return to television atop a new soapbox: a prime-time show on the cable news channel MSNBC, according to executives on both sides of the negotiations who have been briefed directly.

title: As Citigroup Chief Totters, CNBC Reporter Is Having a Great Year
description: The big story on CNBC all day today will undoubtedly be the fallout from the resignation of Charles O. Prince III as chairman of Citigroup  and Maria Bartiromo, one of the best-known names in business news on television, will surely be among the reporters covering it.

title: Statement from Citigroup on the Resignation of C.E.O. Charles O. Prince III
description: The Board of Directors of Citigroup Inc. (NYSE:C) today announced that Robert E. Rubin, Chairman of the Executive Committee of Citi and a member of the Board of Directors, will serve as Chairman of the Board.

title: Different Rules When a Rival Is a Woman?
description: DES MOINES, Nov. 4  A critical question in this campaign  how to run against a female presidential candidate, or as one  has burst into the foreground in the aftermath of a Democratic debate last week at which Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was repeatedly challenged by her rivals and the events questioners.

title: Bayer Withdraws Heart Surgery Drug
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  Pressured by regulators around the world, the German pharmaceutical giant Bayer A.G. announced Monday that it had agreed to withdraw the controversial heart surgery drug Trasylol after a Canadian study suggested that it increased death rates.

title: U.A.W. Local Chiefs Back Ford Deal
description: DETROIT, Nov. 5  Leaders of United Automobile Workers union locals at Ford Motor unanimously approved a new contract with the automaker today, clearing the way for a vote by 54,000 workers in the United States.

title: PetroChina Shares Triple in Debut
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 5  PetroChina, the state oil and gas giant, became the worlds first company to pass $1 trillion in market capitalization when it debuted on the Shanghai Stock Exchange today.

title: Bronx: Man Is Shot to Death
description: A Bronx man was fatally shot in Longwood early yesterday, the police said. An officer responding to a report of gunshots found the man, Hashim Osbourne, 28, of Gleason Avenue, lying at the corner of Kelly Street and East 163rd Street about 3:15 a.m., the police said. Mr. Osbourne had been shot multiple times in the torso and once in the head, the police said. Medical workers pronounced him dead at the scene. No arrests had been made as of yesterday evening.

title: Olmert Backs Mideast Peace Conference
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 4  Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel issued his strongest and most vocal support yet on Sunday for Secretary of State Condoleezza Rices efforts to forge a Middle East peace plan, raising the possibility of making peace with the Palestinians before the conclusion of the Bush administration.

title: Leslie Orgel, Biochemist Who Studied Origins of Life, Dies at 80
description: Leslie E. Orgel, a biochemist whose studies of early life on primitive Earth helped lead to the formation of a now widely accepted theory about the development of DNA, died Oct. 27 in San Diego. He was 80.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A film review in Weekend on Friday about the documentary Darfur Now misidentified the university attended by Adam Sterling, who worked to get a bill passed to force California to divest from companies whose business benefits Sudan. It was U.C.L.A., not the University of Southern California.

title: So-Called Show Runners Pick Sides in Looming Strike
description: Which top television writers are the least supportive of a strike? Some people in Hollywood are wondering if an unusual advertisement holds the answer.

title: Premier Says Separatists in Kosovo Losing Patience
description: PRISTINA, Kosovo, Nov. 3  Agim Ceku, Kosovos warrior-turned-prime minister, is used to long and treacherous journeys.

title: Head Injury Keeps Coles on the Sideline
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 4  Last week Jerricho Cotchery called his fellow Jets receiver Laveranues Coles the toughest receiver in the N.F.L. Cotcherys statement was backed up by Coless streaks: 104 regular-season starts, 107 games played, 69 games with at least one reception.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The On Education column on Wednesday about online courses included the incorrect cost, from a Pennsylvania State University professor, for the masters program in business administration at the university. It is $49,000, not $52,000. Because of an editing error, the column also referred incorrectly to a course the writer once took that he said would not be as effective if taught online. It was a graduate-level course, not an undergraduate one.

title: U.S. Is Likely to Continue Aid to Pakistan
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4  The Bush administration signaled Sunday that it would probably keep billions of dollars flowing to Pakistans military, despite the detention of human rights advocates and leaders of the political opposition by Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the countrys president.

title: Plan for Nuclear Storage Is Slow to Form
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4  The Energy Department has not finished plans to consolidate storage of nuclear bomb fuel and other high-risk materials now spread among numerous sites, even though the department said in 2005 that it would do so within about a year, according to a Government Accountability Office report to be released Monday.

title: Big Executive of the Tiny Screen
description: LOS ANGELES  When CBS Mobile introduced the Daily Delivery, a short video for cellphones highlighting fashionable shops in Los Angeles and cool gadgets, it was a disaster.

title: U.S. Official Calls Russian Radar Good, but Not Exact Enough for Tracking Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3  To block American proposals for building missile defenses in Europe, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia surprised the White House in June with a counteroffer to let the United States use one of the Kremlins most secret early-warning radars.

title: Justices to Review Death Penalty Case
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  The Supreme Court agreed today to review the case of an Idaho death row inmate who was condemned after following his lawyers advice to reject a plea bargain that would have spared his life.

title: Father Charged in Death of Baby Girl in Queens
description: A Queens man was charged yesterday with the murder of his 13-month-old daughter, who died after she was found bruised and unconscious in the familys home in South Ozone Park, the police said.

title: Hollywood Reporter Starts an Edition for New York
description: To Eric Mika, senior vice president and publishing director of The Hollywood Reporter, the logic of setting up shop in Manhattan is obvious.

title: Trial Near for Shiite Ex-Officials in Sunni Killings
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 3  An Iraqi judge has ruled that there is enough evidence to try two former Health Ministry officials, both Shiites, in the killing and kidnapping of hundreds of Sunnis, many of them snatched from hospitals by militias, according to American officials who are advising the Iraqi judicial system.

title: Things Turn Ugly in the Hacks vs. Flacks War
description: Journalists often call publicists flacks and publicists call journalists hacks, though rarely in earshot of one another. But the gloves came off last week after Chris Anderson, the executive editor of Wired magazine, chided lazy flacks who deluge him with news releases because they cant be bothered to find out who on my staff, if anyone, might actually be interested in what theyre pitching.

title: With a Torrent of Lyrics, Daring the Fans to Keep Up
description: You know that faintly disorienting feeling you get when you see a good, weird band for the first time? Happily devoid of prejudice, you listen without any guesses or opinions about whats coming next. You make out a few snatches of lyrics and resolve to investigate them later. You realize theres a lot youre missing.

title: Guy Fawkes Is Spared, and England Is Restive
description: YORK, England, Nov. 2  Deep in the bowels of the York Dungeon, visitors were being treated to a dramatic rendition of the horrific torture and bloodcurdling screams of Guy Fawkes, the citys most famous deceased resident. Up at the cash register, Kate Stapylton, the duty manager, was talking about the health and safety regulations governing the attraction.

title: Google Enters the Wireless World
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5  Google took its long-awaited plunge into the wireless world today, announcing that it is leading a broad industry alliance to transform mobile phones into powerful mobile computers that could accelerate the convergence of computing and communications.

title: Randolphs Big Finish Gives Knicks a Reason to Celebrate
description: Zach Randolph and Knicks fans were officially introduced last night, a first date that inspired strong mutual affection, if not quite love at first sight. Deeper feelings and Hallmark cards may yet be in their future.

title: Khun Sa, Golden Triangle Drug King, Dies at 73
description: BANGKOK, Nov. 2  Khun Sa, the publicity-loving Golden Triangle drug lord who thrived in the regions kill or be killed cauldron of ethnic rivalries and heroin-financed private armies, has died at 73 in Yangon, Myanmar, according to an officer in the militia he once led.

title: Brokaw Explores Another Turning Point, the 60s
description: Tom Brokaws Boom! orchestrates a baby-boom epiphany. It stages a virtual reunion of Americas Class of 1968, accompanied by a full spectrum of opinions about the impact of that pivotal year. Although he describes his role in this process as that of moderator and class president, theres more to it than that. Mr. Brokaw serves as a latter-day Rip Van Winkle, awakening to marvel at four decades worth of changes in the books dozens of interviewees. He also takes on the perilous job of wondering what it all means.

title: Timing of a Proposed M.T.A. Fare Increase Should Come as No Surprise
description: Officials at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority have tried to frame their proposal for higher subway, bus and commuter rail fares as a departure from past increases. They say it should be seen as part of a long-term financial plan, with a fare increase next year to be followed by an increase in state and city subsidies down the road.

title: The Loose Canon
description: THE New Yorker has announced plans to publish an unedited story by the late Raymond Carver. Since then, the estates of several other deceased writers have also expressed an interest in seeing manuscripts published in their original pre-edited form. Excerpts follow:

title: Writers on the Picket Line Would Feel a Varying Pinch
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 4  Unions typically consist of people with wallets of similar size. The paychecks of auto workers vary depending on seniority and job title but not so much that some drive BMWs and others rusty old Plymouths.

title: Wobbled by Wealth?
description: At just about every stop Ive made so far on my book tour, what Ive come to think of as The Question comes up. I talk about the origins of the long right-wing dominance of American politics, and the reasons I believe that dominance is coming to an end. Then someone asks, How can you be optimistic about the prospects for progressive change, when big money has so much influence on politics?

title: U.S. Is Likely to Continue Aid to Pakistan
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4  The Bush administration signaled Sunday that it would probably keep billions of dollars flowing to Pakistans military, despite the detention of human rights advocates and leaders of the political opposition by Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the countrys president.

title: Radcliffe Shakes Off Rival
description: Four miles into yesterdays New York City Marathon, Paula Radcliffe of England and Gete Wami of Ethiopia were clear of the field and running into the medical unknown.

title: Going to Prague in 1968, but Not Without His Vinyl
description: Get out your handkerchiefs, if you please, for Rock n Roll, the triumphantly sentimental new play by Tom Stoppard.

title: Legal Loopholes in Iraq
description: Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice refers to the lack of legal accountability that allows mercenaries working for the American government to kill Iraqis without fear of prosecution as a lacuna in our law.

title: Writers Begin Strike as Talks Break Off
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 4  A strike by Hollywood writers began just after midnight Monday, as last-minute negotiations between screenwriters and producers to avert a walkout failed.

title: Fatal Beating Unnerves University in Quiet Town
description: GLASSBORO, N.J., Nov. 1  Donald Farrell did just about everything right. As Mr. Farrell, a 19-year-old Rowan University sophomore, walked to a convenience store the night of Saturday, Oct. 27, he had followed nearly all of the precautions given to the colleges students about staying safe. He was traveling in a group. It was about 9 p.m., so he was not out particularly late. And he moved along busy roads in well-lighted areas.

title: Linden: 2 Arrested in Officers Shooting
description: Two people have been arrested in connection with the shooting of a Linden police officer on Friday night, the police said yesterday. After being called to Speedy Check Cashing, on Routes 1 and 9, to investigate a report of a fraudulent check at about 6 p.m. on Friday, Officer Dave Manganiello was shot once in the chest at close range. Officer Manganiellos bullet-resistant vest stopped the round. He was treated at University Hospital in Newark and released. A suspect, Leonardo Grullon, 34, has been charged with attempted murder in connection with the shooting. A woman who came to police headquarters to check on Mr. Grullon, Brenda Hernandez, 35, of Elizabeth, was also arrested, the police said. She has been charged with hindering apprehension and theft by deception, the police said.

title: 50 New York Schools Fail Under New Rating System
description: Under a blunt new A through F rating system, whose results Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg unveiled today, 50 public schools across New York City, most in Manhattan and the Bronx, have been designated failures, placing them in danger of closing as early as the end of the school year and putting their principals jobs on the line.

title: In Mexico, Residents Contend With a Flooded City
description: VILLAHERMOSA, Mexico, Nov. 4  Williams Garca paddled a kayak Sunday over the waters that covered much of Villahermosa, the flooded capital of the state of Tabasco, searching for news of his family.

title: Accounts and People
description: Accounts

title: A Guilty Plea in Film Skulduggery
description: A 37-year-old man has pleaded guilty to two felony charges in connection with the theft of computers and photographs with confidential material related to Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull, Steven Spielbergs forthcoming installment of the adventures of that intrepid archaeologist, The Associated Press reported. The man, Roderick Davis, of Cerritos, Calif., will serve two years and four months in a state prison in a plea deal. He admitted to receiving stolen property and committing commercial burglary. He was arrested on Oct. 4 in West Hollywood in a sting operation by detectives, who learned that some of the stolen material connected to the film, starring Harrison Ford, Cate Blanchett and Shia LaBeouf, was being offered for sale to entertainment gossip Web sites.

title: Treasure Hunt Begins After Runners Leave
description: They came at dawn, from far and wide, gathering at the western end of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge and waiting anxiously for the start of the New York City Marathon. But when the traditional cannon blast signaled the start of one of the worlds biggest footraces, they stayed put.

title: Egg Industry Comes Out of Its Old-Media Shell
description: A campaign is seeking to break through the clutter with the unusual sight of humans, rather than chicks, breaking out of eggs.

title: Redskins Game Plan Kept Portis on His Feet
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 4  In Shaun Elliss eight seasons as a defensive lineman for the Jets, he has seen a lot of unfathomable things unfold on a football field. But he has never seen a team run with as much ease as the Washington Redskins did against the Jets on Sunday.

title: Lel Defeats Goumri Again
description: When the last of their competitors had fallen away and the course tucked into Central Park, Martin Lel of Kenya and Abderrahim Goumri of Morocco turned the New York City Marathon into Part 2 of a battle they began in the London Marathon last April.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Tut Faces His Public

title: At NBC, the Brand Becomes a Slogan
description: As a color and a concept, green will be unavoidable across NBC Universals media properties this week, as network logos turn green, on-screen graphics offer tips for reducing carbon emissions and television episodes emphasize environmentally friendly plot lines.

title: Turning 50 With Wit and Youthful Vigor to Spare (So Who Needs Gimmicks?)
description: SEATTLE, Nov. 3  The Pacific Northwest Ballets new quadruple bill, Contemporary Classics, features one ballet that relies entirely on the use of ropes (Susan Marshalls Kiss). Another depends wholly on spotlights and strobe lighting (David Parsons Caught). A third work makes a greatly diminished effect if performed without billowing clouds of vapor from dry ice (Twyla Tharps In the Upper Room). Though McCaw Hall here is not the best place for dry ice, and though the last two pieces were performed to taped music, these devices all helped the pieces win big applause.

title: The Latest in Job Cuts: Automated Poker Without Dealers
description: FOLSOM, Calif.  Most card rooms and casinos in Northern California offer live poker the old-fashioned way: with dealers doling out cards and players tossing chips into the center of a table.

title: Looking Ahead
description: ECONOMIC INDICATORS The main economic news will come from a report on the trade deficit for September (Friday).

title: Lottery Numbers
2,000-Year-Old Christian Community in Iraq Gains a Spiritual First in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 4  There is neither a cross nor a sign on the heavy metal gate to indicate that this is the official residence of one of the countrys most prominent Christians, the first in Iraq in modern times to be elevated to cardinal by the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Showing Whos No. 1, Patriots Deal Colts Loss No. 1
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 4  This time, the New England Patriots could not run up the score, could not embarrass the Indianapolis Colts, an opponent that was finally their equal. But that was the only unfamiliar part of the ritual for the Patriots on Sunday.

title: A Weekly in New Brunswick Prevails Against Local Family
description: A weekly newspaper publisher who challenged the Irvings, the most powerful family in the Canadian province of New Brunswick and the provinces predominant newspaper owner, has prevailed in court.

title: Small Plane Crashes Into a So Paulo Neighborhood, Killing Six
description: SO PAULO, Brazil, Nov. 4 (Reuters)  At least six people were killed when a small plane crashed into a residential district of So Paulo just after taking off on Sunday, officials said, in the latest accident in Brazils crisis-ridden air system.

title: Next Hurdle for Ford and U.A.W. Will Be Selling Contract Proposal
description: DETROIT, Nov. 4  Over the next few weeks, Ford Motor and the United Automobile Workers union each are faced with the challenge of selling their tentative contract as the best they could get in light of Fords decline.

title: Planes, No Trains, Automobiles, and Plenty of Hockey Mixed In
description: Steve Williamson, a Tampa Bay Lightning fan from Orlando, Fla., is storming through the N.H.L. He began a journey last month that will take him to a game at each of the leagues 30 arenas in 30 consecutive days.

title: Edwards Raises Criticism of Clinton Over Iraq Plan
description: IOWA CITY, Nov. 4  As Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton collected the endorsement today from former Vice President Walter Mondale, one of her Democratic rivals intensified his criticism of her candidacy, saying she had not been forthcoming with voters who will open the nominating contest here in less than two months.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Matt Biscuiti, vice president at the New York office of the Lippin Group, was promoted to senior vice president.

title: Tut Faces His Public
description: The face that launched a thousand trips to museums was revealed yesterday for the first time in more than 3,000 years when the blackened, leathery mummified remains of the Egyptian boy king Tutankhamen were freed from their linen burial windings, Agence France-Press reported. The face of the golden pharaoh is amazing, said Zahi Hawass, above center, secretary general of the Supreme Council of Antiquities in Cairo, adding, It has magic; it has mystery; it has beauty; and his buck teeth are similar to the rest of his familys. The occasion was the removal of the pharaohs mummy from its ornate stone sarcophagus, discovered in 1922, to a nearby climate-controlled case where experts say it will be better preserved. Putting the mummy in this case will make the golden king live forever, Mr. Hawass said. Each day, hundreds of visitors file through his tomb in the Valley of the Kings at Luxor, carrying with them bacteria, humidity and pollutants. The mummy risked being reduced to dust because of the rising levels of humidity due to the visitors, Mr. Hawass said. Rejecting a popular theory that Tut died of a blow to the neck at 19, Egyptian, Swiss and Italian experts have deduced that he did die at 19, after a 10-year reign, but that the cause was an injury to his left leg, which then turned gangrenous. When Tuts tomb was discovered, his embalmed body was encased in three sarcophagi, one of them solid gold, and his face lay beneath a 24-pound solid-gold burial mask encrusted with lapis lazuli and other semiprecious stones. The latest in the popular King Tut exhibitions is to open in London this month and will return to the United States next year.

title: Bankers Lesson From Mortgage Mess: Sell, Dont Hold
description: Bankers on Wall Street frequently describe themselves as being in the moving and not the storage business. They make money by trading stocks and bonds, not by owning them.

title: PetroChina May Become Top Company
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 4  When the government-owned oil and gas giant PetroChina makes its debut Monday on the Shanghai Stock Exchange, Chinas booming stock markets will be on the verge of setting another milestone. Soon after the Shanghai listing, some analysts expect PetroChina to surpass Exxon Mobil as the worlds largest company by market capitalization.

title: Screenwriters Take to Picket Lines as Strike Begins
description: Screenwriters moved to the picket lines this morning, as last-minute negotiations between the writers unions and producers failed to avert a strike over payments from producers for so-called new media, among other issues.

title: A Tongue Thats Tough to Tame
description: Ever since Michael R. Bloomberg entered politics, he has worked hard to control his impolitic tendencies.

title: Still No Giuliani TV Ads, but Hes Ready for the Web
description: It is a question that both Democratic and Republican strategists have been asking often: When is Rudolph W. Giuliani going to start advertising his presidential candidacy on television?

title: Protesting Demeaning Images in Media
description: Wearing white T-shirts with red stop signs and chanting BET does not reflect me, MTV does not reflect me, protesters have been gathering every Saturday outside the homes of Viacom executives in Washington and New York City. The orderly, mostly black crowds are protesting music videos that they say degrade women, and black and Latino men.

title: Hunt for Cholesterol Drug Is Not Over
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 5  Drugs to raise so-called good cholesterol may still have a future despite the widely publicized failure last year of an experimental cholesterol treatment from Pfizer, researchers said at a heart conference here.

title: Bush Urges Pakistani Leader to Hold Elections
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  President Bush urged President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan today to hold elections and give up his army post as soon as possible, but he gave no indication that General Musharrafs decision to impose emergency rule would bring about any significant change in American policy.

title: The Higher Value of Eyeballs
description: The Higher Value of Eyeballs

title: Support for Replay Has Its Limits
description: ORLANDO, Fla.

title: Group Spotlights Jews Who Left Arab Lands
description: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 2  With assertions of the rights of Palestinians to reclaim land in Israel expected to arise at an planned Middle East peace conference in Annapolis, Md., a Jewish advocacy group has scheduled a meeting in New York on Monday to call attention to people it terms forgotten refugees.

title: Stocks Decline on Citigroup News
description: Stock markets declined today as financial companies stumbled in the aftermath of the shake-up at Citigroup.

title: Chaos, Calm and Humor in Irish Composers Work
description: Ireland has produced a remarkable number of popular rock and pop acts in recent years, but few of the countrys classical composers have achieved such international prominence. The Web site of the Contemporary Music Center in Dublin (cmc.ie) lists an impressive number of active Irish composers, among them Gerald Barry, whose music was spotlighted at the Miller Theater on Friday.

title: In Defense of Voting Rights
description: A House Judiciary subcommittee was the site of a sad spectacle the other day: John Tanner, who heads the Justice Departments voting section, trying to explain offensive, bigoted comments he made about minority voters. It was a shameful moment that crystallized the need for immediate steps to fight for the rights that Mr. Tanner has been working so hard to undermine.

title: Lies? What Else Is New?
description: To the Editor:

title: Movies, TVs and Magazines Work Together in Web Campaign
description: THIS month, the Turner Classic Movies cable network is presenting the movie choices of 30 guest programmers like Alec Baldwin, Martha Stewart, Donald Trump, Gore Vidal and even Kermit the Frog.

title: Citigroup Names Rubin as Chairman and Plans More Write-Downs
description: The board of Citigroup today accepted the resignation of its embattled chairman and chief executive, Charles O. Prince III, and appointed Robert E. Rubin, the former Treasury secretary, as its chairman, according to a person briefed on the situation.

title: A Lilly Drug Logs Success and Risks in Heart Trial
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 4  An experimental anticlotting drug from Eli Lilly reduced heart attacks in patients with heart disease by 24 percent compared with Plavix, the current standard treatment, according to a report released Sunday in The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: Staten Island: Man Is Fatally Stabbed
description: A Staten Island man has been charged with fatally stabbing another man during an argument on Saturday morning, the police said. The suspect, Saverio Fabozzi, 25, of Arthur Kill Road, was charged with second-degree murder and assault, the police said. Mr. Fabozzi is accused of fatally stabbing Joseph Flagg, 26, during an argument about 3 a.m. on Excelsior Avenue, the police said. The police said Mr. Fabozzi also stabbed a 21-year-old man, whose name was not released and who was in stable condition at Staten Island University Hospital.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The E-Commerce Report column in Business Day last Monday, about online travel agencies, misidentified the location of LeisureLogix, a technology company that has introduced a personalized search service for travelers. It is based in Tampa, Fla., not Southlake, Tex. The column also misstated, in one reference, the name of the search service on the Travelocity Web site. As the column noted, it is the Road Trip Wizard  not the Road Trip Warrior.

title: Never Too Young to Give, or Take,  Advice
description: At 25, Ramit Sethi seemed to have figured out what so many of my peers (pushing 40 and older) are still struggling with  how to get to the career you want without first putting in a whole lot of time doing something you dont enjoy.

title: Crashes and Traffic Jams in Military Test of Robotic Vehicles
description: VICTORVILLE, Calif., Nov. 4  A Pentagon-sponsored robot race at a former Air Force base here on Saturday revealed that computer-controlled vehicles, at least to date, have failings that are all too human.

title: Lets Heal Our Ailing Health System
description: To the Editor:

title: New Media, New Value, Old Troubles
description: In the hierarchy of things the American public seems not to care about  the national debt, Paris Hiltons charitable works, Fred D. Thompsons campaign for president  the Hollywood screenwriters strike probably wins hands down.

title: Whats More, He Has Hog Warts
description: Excerpts from Weekend Update on NBCs Saturday Night Live:

title: Obama Night Live
description: Saturday Night Live. which has relentlessly mocked Hillary Clinton, let her rival Senator Barack Obama join the skewering in a sketch portraying her as a witch. Read more here and here. And watch the video:

title: Office Challenge
description: A time-waster thats all over the web  for example, here, here and here.

title: Look Ma, No Hands!
description: Calling all funny caption writers: Tell us whats going on in the photo above. Its the latest of the uncaptioned photos weve been posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines here. Last weeks funniest captions are at right.

title: AOL to Buy Israeli Start-Up, Report Says
description: Time Warners AOL unit plans to pay $300 million for an Israeli advertising start-up, Quigo, in a move to compete better with Google and Yahoo, an Israeli newspaper report said.

title: Qatari Fund Withdraws Sainsbury Offer
description: The British supermarkets group J Sainsbury will remain independent after the Qatari-based investment fund Delta Two on Monday abandoned its 10.6 billion pound bid ($22.1 billion).

title: Deal for Canadian Shoe Retailer Collapses
description: The sole remaining Canadian retail business in the Bata shoe empire has quietly slipped into bankruptcy protection after a deal with a would-be buyer, Michael Gold, fell apart over a tax dispute.

title: W2 Scores $30 Million, With More to Come
description: W2 Group, a three-year-old holding company thats been building a business in digital marketing, said on Friday it had received a $30 million cash infusion from Monitor Clipper Partners with a total commitment of more than $100 million.

title: MedQuist Mulls Sale Amid Investor Discontent
description: MedQuist, a provider of medical transcription services, is considering a sale of the company after a majority stockholder, Royal Philips Electronics, said Friday that it wanted to sell its 70 percent stake in the company.

title: The Law of Unintended Consequences?
description: The Sarbanes-Oxley Act, enacted in mid-2002 in the wake of the accounting scandals at Enron and WorldComwas intended to improve the accuracy and reliability of corporate financial disclosures.

title: An Overhyped Role in Overheated Art Markets?
description: When the credit bubble popped this summer, many believed that the art bubble would burst as well. It was feared that as hedge fund managers felt the pain, so too would the auction houses.

title: Blackstone Teams With ChemChina in Nufarm Bid
description: The Blackstone Group has teamed up with China National Chemical and the private equity firm Fox Paine to bid up to $3 billion Australian dollars ($2.75 billion) on Monday for Australias Nufarm, a deal that would create the worlds largest generic farm chemicals firm.

title: PetroChina Skyrockets in Debut
description: PetroChina, the state oil and gas giant, became the worlds first company to pass $1 trillion in market capitalization when it debuted on the Shanghai Stock Exchange on Monday.

title: Is Bad News for Merrill Good News for Investors?
description: The Securities and Exchange Commissions investigation into possible conflicts of interest among advisers to pension funds has been going on so long  two years  that its practically fallen off the radar screen. But last week, the investigation cropped up again, big time, when Merrill Lynch advised 100 of its pension fund clients in Florida that the S.E.C. has taken issue with its practices as a consultant.

title: CIBC Sells Part of U.S. Capital Markets Business
description: The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce said on Sunday it would sell a major part of its capital markets business in the United States to Oppenheimer Holdings as it focuses on its core operations. The businesses to be acquired by Oppenheimer employ more than people, or about half of CIBCs employees in the United States, and had annualized revenue of about $400 million, Oppenheimer said.

title: Filing Is Seen as Signal of Buyout Plan for A.I.G.
description: Is Maurice R. Greenberg planning to make a run on his former firm?

title: Blacks Warhols Go on the Block
description: Conrad Black, the former media mogul convicted this summer of corporate fraud and obstruction of justice, is back in the news. That is because two Warhol paintings he owns will be auctioned by Christies, each with a selling price estimated at $150,000 to $200,000. The first auction is Nov. 14.

title: Singapore Sets Out to Lure Hedge Funds
description: Singapore, striving to become the Switzerland of Asia, is gung-ho on hedge funds, The Deal.com reports. Leading the charge is the Singapore government, which has crafted regulations that both streamline the process for establishing funds and give fund managers some juicy tax breaks when theyre up and running. Its now possible to open a fund in just weeks.

title: SAC May Balk at ITTs Edo Bid
description: The activist hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors served notice late Thursday that it might be dissatisfied with ITTs deal to acquire the defense contractor Edo for $1.5 billion.

title: Yucaipa Plans Bid for Twinkies Bakery
description: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters on Friday joined forces with Ronald Burkles Yucaipa and Bimbo Bakeries USA and have a plan for Yucaipa to buy the bankrupt Interstate Bakeries, which makes Wonder Bread and Twinkies.

title: Neutral Tandem Raises $78.6 Million Despite Choppy Market
description: Executives at Neutral Tandem may have been having some second thoughts on Thursday, when the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 362 points. The last thing that a company going public wants is a down market.

title: The Young and the Not So Restless
description: This week, my column, Never Too Young to Give, or Take, Advice, focuses on some career mavericks  a cadre of 20-somethings (and one not even 20), who have just entered the work force yet have found a way to lead others.

title: Congress Set to Override Water Bill Veto
description: Congress is poised to enact legislation over the objections of President Bush for the first time in his tenure.

title: Kraft Close to $2.8 Billion Deal to Sell Post Cereals, Report Says
description: Kraft Foods is a few weeks away from announcing to a deal to sell its Post cereals business to store-brand food maker, Ralcorp Holdings, for about $2.8 billion, according to The Wall Street Journal.

title: Why are Oil Majors so Keen on Renewable Energy?
description: Just when will oil run out, creating economic and social panic, and putting an end to decades of prosperity based on the plentifulness of petroleum? The answer seems to be soon, according to a documentary called A Crude Awakening, which I saw this weekend in London before it officially opens in cinemas in London Nov. 9. (The film has already been released in Canada, Switzerland, Australia and New Zealand, and is showing on cable television in the U.S. It will be playing at the Guangzhou International Documentary Film Festival, China, at the beginning of December, according to a Web site promoting the film.)

title: As Citi Chief Totters, Bartiromo Is Having a Great Year
description: The big story on CNBC all day Monday will undoubtedly be the fallout from the resignation of Charles O. Prince III as chairman of Citigroup  and Maria Bartiromo, one of the best-known names in business news on television, will surely be among the reporters covering it.

title: Foster Children at Risk, and a Breach of Faith
description: Twenty years ago, New York City embarked on an experiment aimed at better protecting its most vulnerable black and Latino children. At its heart, the effort involved creating and supporting foster care agencies that would, at long last, be run by men and women of color. The Times spent months examining this ambitious, billion-dollar investment in minority-run agencies  what once seemed a bold and overdue shift in one of the most challenging areas of social policy. It found a trail of scandals and disappointments, as well as a new commitment to better caring for the citys vulnerable black and Latino children. Breach of Faith, by Leslie Kaufman, the first in a series of three articles, appears today on the front page. Readers are invited to post their comments here. (See an and a at one foster care provider.)

title: The Early Word: The X Factor
description: Heres a theme that has lasted for nearly a week:

title: Skadden: The Law Firm Behind Private Equity I.P.O.s
description: Much has been made of the private equity and hedge fund industrys move to tap public markets while maintaining their relatively low-level tax structures. Bills in Congress to increase taxes on the industries have pitted Democrats against Republicans, while buyout shops and hedge fund managers have been coughing up cash to lobby against any such efforts.

title: As Icahn Looms, BEA In Race to Restate
description: BEA Systems is under the gun to get its financial restatements in order before its largest shareholder, Carl C. Icahn, calls an annual shareholders meeting.

title: Where Did the Buck Stop at Merrill?
description: On Oct. 24, Merrill Lynch announced its biggest write-down ever, an $8.4 billion charge that also represents the biggest known loss in Wall Street history. Six days later, its chief executive, E. Stanley ONeal, retired from the company he had run since 2002.

title: Bankers Lesson From Mortgage Mess: Sell, Dont Hold
description: Bankers on Wall Street frequently describe themselves as being in the moving and not the storage business. They make money by trading stocks and bonds, not by owning them.

title: Too Much Meddling When C.E.O.s Go a-Courtin?
description: Asking another corporation for its hand in marriage is always a delicate affair. But does a chief executive need to bring the directors along as chaperones? Does a merger-hungry C.E.O need his or her parents blessing before making a proposal?

title: Rubins Big Test: Fixing Citigroup
description: Throughout a long, public career, Robert E. Rubin spanned the highest reaches of Wall Street and Washington, and succeeded wherever he went. Now he may be facing his most difficult challenge  helping to revive Citigroup, which said yesterday that it would take an additional $8 billion to $11 billion write-down related to subprime mortgages, on top of the $5.9 billion reported in early October.

title: Hostile Reactions to CIBCs Citi Report
description: CIBCs Meredith Whitney is a $15 billion woman, after her negative report on Citigroup last week drove the firms shares down 7 percent and perhaps hastened Charles Princes departure. But not everyone was happy with her report (which she discussed with The New York Times here).

title: The Case for Real Food
description: Is there more to a carrot than beta carotene? Is lycopene the best we get from tomatoes? And when we heap our plates with salmon, are we serving up something other than omega-3s?

title: Merrill Is Said to Favor Fink as New C.E.O.
description: Laurence D. Fink may be closer to taking the reins at Merrill Lynch. The securities firms board of directors has told Mr. Fink, the chairman of BlackRock, that the top spot is his should he want it, CNBC reported citing unnamed sources.

title: Pooh-poohing health care problems
description: People have asked me what I think of Greg Mankiws piece in The Times. Ill outsource the criticism to Mark Thoma, Brad DeLong and Dean Baker.

title: The Thin Red Line
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The Greening of the Gridiron
description: Well, we all thought the big news in pro football would be yesteredays much anticipated Colts-Patriots tilt or rookie running back Adrian Petersons record-setting day, but it seems the gridiron is taking on a new shade of green. Chris Mottram, the irreverant Mr. Irrelevant comments on the news: The massive market of hippie football fans is about to get their heads blown: NBC is going green all week. And it kicks off with Sunday Night Football.

title: Barry Dillers Big Breakup
description: IAC/InterActiveCorp, the media-and-Internet conglomerate cobbled together by Barry Diller, said Monday that it plans to carve itself up into five companies. The spinoffs seemed to signal a retreat for Mr. Diller, a media magnate who was the Unites Statess most highly paid chief executive in 2005.

title: The Skim
description: A quick hike through the Sunday (and a few non-Sunday) book review sections.The Independent

title: Nouvelle Chimie
