description: Chefs are learning from the lab how to fry mayonnaise, congeal coconut milk and perform other culinary chemistry experiments

title: Morning Papers: Strike Update, Maria Bartiromo, Family Guy Composers
description: Under the eye of a federal mediator, Hollywoods writers and producers resumed talks toward a new contract Sunday as a midnight strike deadline drew near, Michael Cieply reports from Los Angeles. As of late afternoon here, there was no sign of a breakthrough.

title: Egg Spot 2
description: Spots by the American Egg Board's longtime agency, Grey in New York, play up the benefits of eating eggs, primarily their protein content.

title: Egg Spot 1
description: Spots by the American Egg Board's longtime agency, Grey in New York, play up the benefits of eating eggs, primarily their protein content.

title: Money, Fats and Science
description: During the trans-fat debate here, readers criticized me for quoting the American Council on Science and Health, arguing that it wasnt a credible source and that I should have pointed out it receives donations from corporations. Some accused it of not doing peer-reviewed research and getting most of its money from corporations, and said theyd trust the Harvard School of Public Health over ACSH any day.

title: Newsweek on Bloomberg, the Billion Dollar Wild Card
description: In a 6,962-word cover article in the issue of Newsweek that hits the newsstands today, the magazines editor, Jon Meacham, takes an in-depth look at Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and assesses the chances that he might run for president. Mr. Meacham was given considerable access to the mayor, in interviews at Gracie Mansion, in Seattle and aboard the mayors personal jet.

title: Monday Morning Kickoff
description: After Saturdays debacle against Kansas, John Henderson of the Denver Post writes that Nebraska must fire head coach Bill Callahan and defensive coordinator Kevin Cosgrove, like, five minutes ago. Meanwhile, Steven M. Sipple of the Lincoln Journal Star lists four reasons why he thinks Callahan will be out of a job soon.

title: Thompson in New Hampshire
description: BEDFORD, N.H.,  Fred Thompson has heard the grumbling from New Hampshire voters that he hasnt spent enough time in the state, and he has responded with promises to visit the state early and often.

title: A Hidden Oasis in Las Vegass Water Waste
description: Theres a back to the land movement of sorts around Las Vegas these days, driven by the desert citys growing realization that the only reason it can exist  the sapphire, but shrinking, expanse of Lake Mead 30 miles away  is not as durable as the Hoover Dam that created the reservoir 70 years ago.

title: Whos Watching Over Citi?
description: The turmoil at Citigroup has left the banking giant without a permanent leader. It has also put all eyes on the companys board of directors, a group that includes some of corporate Americas heaviest hitters.

title: No Money, No Funny!
description: The above was one of the chants at Rockefeller Center today as Hollywood writers went on strike  a reminder that many on the picket line on New York work in late-night comedy. But even the quality of the chants left some disenchanted. Still, nothing could be done. The writers, after all, are on strike. Said one half of a pair of married scribes: I was telling my husband that we need some new and better chants, but he reminded me: No writing. None.  Read more

title: Monday Morning Motorsports
description: Formula One: After months of speculation that Fernando Alonso would leave McLaren before his three-year contract was up, the team made it official.

title: In Pakistan, a Fight to Stay Connected on the Web
description: Considering the signals and rumors that have swirled for months, including a particularly intense day in August, it would seem that both the Pakistani government and the political opposition have had time to anticipate and prepare for the emergency-rule decree issued on Saturday by Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the president of the country.

title: Then We Came to the End
description: Hello, one and all. So we have come to the end of this great novel  this huge vision of life. A brief review of Volume IV: The Russian army withstands Napoleons onslaught and does not so much defeat him as outlast him. The French army decomposes, soldiers flee en mass or limp away, taunted by the ragged people who collectively saved Europe.

title: The Debate Over Cellphone Jamming
description: In October, Bruce Schneier, a prominent computer security expert, made note on his blog about the growing use of jammers. He received nearly a hundred comments on the debate, many encouraging jamming.

title: Barry Diller and the Fallacy of IAC
description: Barry Dillers decision, announced today, to split IAC/InterActiveCorp into five parts says a lot about Mr. Dillers restlessness. But it also shows the flaws in the strategy that he has been trying to pursue for a decade: building an Internet conglomerate.

title: 2008 Already Settled? Not by a Long Shot
description: In his Web column today, Adam Nagourney writes that For all the indisputable Democratic advantages, strategists in both parties say it is too early to hand the White House keys over to the Democratic Party.

title: The Feast After the Finish
description: I only half noticed the first person who walked stiffly, with something of a limp, by my friends and me at Primehouse New York last night.

title: Images From the Picket Lines
As IAC Splits, Who Gets the Gehry?
description: In breaking up IAC/InterActiveCorp, Barry Diller is taking a step many thought he should have taken a long time ago. Many analysts and investors have derided the 12-year-old conglomerate as a jumble of companies, jerry-built by Mr. Dillers voracious wheeling and dealing.

title: Writers Strike Begins; Negotiations Break Down; Silver Lining For Networks?
description: A strike by Hollywood writers began just after midnight Monday, as last-minute negotiations between screenwriters and producers to avert a walkout failed, Michael Cieply writes in The New York Times.

title: Why Economists Don't Vote
description: Why you should vote, if you really feel like it.

title: Waterboarding the Wiseguys?
description: The Republican debate over torture has become a debate over resumes, as John McCain warns from personal experience about the dangers of harsh questioning and Rudy Giuliani takes credit for his skill with it as a prosecutor, reports Boston Globe:

title: Bushs Niece Endorses Plastic Bag Recycling
description: A City Council bill that would require supermarkets and other large retail stores to collect, transport and recycle the plastic carryout bags they give to customers received an endorsement today from an unusual source: Lauren Bush, a fashion model and a niece of President Bush.

title: Bracing for Citis Next Surprise
description: Just how many shoes does Citi have?

title: Today at the Ends of the Earth
description: Ann Curry, the news anchor for NBCs Today show, donned a red parka and sunglasses early this morning and prepared for a highly unusual live shot.

title:
Memo to Self:
Dont Throw Novel in Fire
description: Heres a short film from David Wain, made in 1997, that stars himself and Amanda Peet.

title: At Real Hospitals, Less Traumaand Drama
description: Medical shows have long been a staple of prime time television. But how well do they reflect what really happens at the hospital?

title: Do the New School Ratings Match Your Experience?
description: Under a blunt new A through F rating system, whose results Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg unveiled today, 50 public schools across New York City, most in Manhattan and the Bronx, have been designated failures, placing them in danger of closing as early as the end of the school year and putting their principals jobs on the line. Elissa Gootman and Jennifer Medina of The Times explain how the new rating system works and what it means for students, parents and educators. To find the data for your school, consult this graphic, which lists, for each school, the letter grade, the overall score and scores for school environment, student performance, student progress and additional variables.

title: Eric Schmidts GPhone Dance
description: Wheres my Gphone?

title: Oprah Winfrey Addresses Abuse Charges at School
description: Oprah Winfrey is blamed for a lot of things, from ruining the marathon to expanding the popular lexicon. Its mostly light-hearted stuff that comes with the biggest paycheck in television. But today she addressed the world on a much more serious matter.

title: Arena Is Out as Red Bulls Coach
description: Bruce Arenas tenure with the New York Red Bulls ended today, almost 16 months after his appointment as coach and sporting director began with much fanfare and expectation.

title: Colbert Ends White House Bid
description: Its over. So says Stephen Colbert, who has just issued his first formal statement in response to the decision by South Carolina Democrats last week to deny him a spot on the presidential primary ballot.

title: Citi Rewrites Recent History on Earnings
description: Citigroups chief executive isnt the only thing that changed over the weekend. The banks third-quarter earnings, which it reported in the middle of last month, suddenly shifted as well. Downshifted, that is.

title: Rhode Island Juveniles, Caught in Limbo
description: Rhode Island attracted a national spotlight recently when it repealed a disastrous, four-month-old law under which 17 year-old offenders were automatically tried as adults.

title: The Quiet Hedge Fund I.P.O.
description: Scanning the headlines on Monday reveals a blizzard of articles on Citigroup, IAC/InterActiveCorp and PetroChina. Decidedly less obvious is the fact that another hedge fund has gone public in the United States  even though it rang the opening bell Monday morning.

title: Who Cares About Terrorists Attacking Chemical Plants?
description: Terrorism experts agree that one of the most serious terrorist threats is an attack on a chemical plant. A chemical cloud released from such an attack could put hundreds of thousands of lives at risk.

title: Election Day Finds Few Hotly Contested Races
description: Tuesday is Election Day, but there are very few contested races around the city. Most of the elections are for various judgeships: Civil Court, State Supreme Court and  in Brooklyn and Staten Island  the Surrogate Court.

title: 'Vanessa'
description: A video excerpt from the new production of Samuel Barber's opera at New York City Opera.

title: One Other Little Dance
description: On the Google conference call, a reporter asked about another potential reason that Google may want to soft-pedal a possible GPhone: Eric Schmidt serves on Apples board of directors.

title: Romney Lands Big Endorsement
description: Mitt Romney has landed a much-coveted endorsement from the social conservative world: Paul Weyrich, chairman of the Free Congress Foundation and one of the founders back in the day of the Moral Majority.

title: Zen and the Art of Dumpster Diving
description: The middle word in the environmental mantra reduce, reuse, recycle may have a deeper and more ancient root than some realize.

title: Giuliani Praises Former Police Commissioner
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani offered praise on Monday for his disgraced former police commissioner, Bernard B. Kerik. Mr. Giuliani told The Associated Press that Mr. Keriks achievements outweigh his mistakes, and added that if I have the same degree of success and failure as president of the United States, this country will be in great shape.

title: Yolk of the Day
description: Its a live-or-fry situation for these eggs (vegans, discretion advised):Eggs  Funny bloopers R us

title: It Came From Chicago, and Its Not Puffy
description: CB2, Crate and Barrels sprightlier Gen Y offspring, is scheduled to open its 8,000-square foot SoHo store on Tuesday (next to the Muji Store!), as part of the gentretail-ification of the Broadway stretch north of Canal. The eagerly anticipated store, located at 451 Broadway, is the first CB2 outside of the Chicago area (and third over all). For years, this City Room reporter has been obsessed with CB2, once even making a trip to Chicago, in part to see the two CB2 stores there.

title: Parsons to Step Down as Time Warner C.E.O. Next January
description: Richard D. Parsons is about to have a lot of time on his hands.

title: Obama Questions Petraeus
description: Barack Obama was one of five presidential candidates that questioned Gen. David E. Petraeus. (Video From MSNBC)

title: Obama on the Trail
description: Senator Barack Obama delivered his proposal on Iraq to a crowd in Clinton, Iowa, on Wednesday.

title: More Images From The Picket Lines
description: The New York Times reports: The real-life version of picketing in Hollywood, it turns out, bears little resemblance to the rowdy, angry way the industry typically depicts it.

title: A Truffle Heist in Northern Italy
description: Those who covet white truffles  the elusive treasure that has grown rarer still this year  seem to have few choices these days. Either shell out more cash, with an extreme case being the purchase of a single truffle for $7,000 last month. Or downgrade to lesser quality truffles, or worse, truffle oil.

title: Pimp Your Ride? Drain Your Checkbook
description: LAS VEGAS  Mounting an iPod in the center of your steering wheel may seem like a convenient place to put it. But in the event of a hard frontal impact, one of two things is likely to happen: 1. Your air bag might not work anymore; 2. Your air bag will go ahead and deploy, but the front of your skull will thereafter have an iPod embedded in it, instead of a face. In either scenario, the outcome would not be pretty.

title: Edwards on Iran, Pakistan
description: IOWA CITY, Iowa  In a speech today, John Edwards proposed a five-point plan for how to deal with Iran, saying the United States needs to avoid a preventive war strategy and instead employ diplomatic and economic measures to capitalize on what he calls the Iranian peoples readiness for change.

title: Brian Williams Draws a Crowd to SNL
description: What was potentially the last new Saturday Night Live for a while was also the highest-rated Saturday Night Live in a while, NBC said yesterday.

title: Curing Insomnia Without the Pills
description: Better sleep doesnt have to come in a pill.

title: CBS Captures Sunday Night
description: The twelfth edition of The Amazing Race got underway to solid ratings on Sunday as CBS garnered the nights most viewers overall. The network led its competitors by a significant margin going into prime time thanks to an overrun of its afternoon football coverage. A highly anticipated match-up of undefeated teams, the New England Patriots and the Indianapolis Colts, delivered more than 32 million viewers in its final half-hour, according to Nielsens preliminary estimates.

title: Clinton Invokes Gore on the Trail
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa  Al Gore wasnt by Hillary Rodham Clintons side as she delivered a speech on energy efficiency here this morning, but he was here in spirit: Mrs. Clinton mentioned her old rival a few times in her remarks, hailing his Nobel Peace Prize victory and embracing some of his ideas on the environment.

title: Modeling the falling dollar
description: Some models of a plunging dollar look like this.

title: Grim Days for Talk Show Guests
description: Writers, producers and viewers arent the only groups to be affected by the Writers Guild of Americas strike. The authors, musicians and entertainers who rely on television talk shows to promote their products and projects are also feeling the strikes effects, as their guest spots get postponed or canceled.

title: Analysis: BEAs Comedy of Deal Errors
description: BEA Systems may have rebuffed Oracles $17 a share bid. But through a series of negotiating mistakes, it may have unwittingly put itself in a box.

title: The GPhone: So Open It Could Be Closed
description: Eric Schmidts conference call about Googles new cell phone operating system was exactly the opposite of a showy Steve Jobs keynote.

title: The Marathoner Wore Heels
description: What we are reading elsewhere

title: Sophias Bathroom
description: Having decided  as we did last week  that we would have only two bathrooms upstairs instead of the three, as our builder Johnny (strongly) suggested, we still had to figure out a couple of things about the second bathroom:

title: Conserved Woods and Wetlands, Where Orphans Once Romped
description: For about a century, Mount Loretto, on the southeast coast of Staten Island overlooking the Raritan Bay, was a haven for homeless and disabled orphans. The Rev. John Christopher Drumgoole, himself an Irish immigrant, founded the Mission of the Immaculate Virgin in 1871 to help care for Irish children who had lived on Manhattans streets after the Irish potato famine and the Civil War. The mission moved to Staten Island in 1883 and continued, for decades, to provide vocational training and religious instruction for its charges.

title: Who Trusts This Dividend?
description: Why pay a dividend if investors think you cant afford it?

title: A Plea to Open Up Campus Campaign Stops
description: A 2004 Bush-Cheney campaign stop at Allegheny College left some students and faculty peeved at the colleges event policy. Dick Cheney spoke at a ticketed on-campus event that was open to only G.O.P. supporters and 40 Allegheny students who gained entry through the student organization, College Republicans.

title: Guy Fawkes Day Helps Raise Millions for Paul
description: Updated | 11:58 p.m. Historians and British schoolchildren remember Guy Fawkes as the Roman Catholic, anti-Protestant rebel who on Nov. 5, 1605, tried to assassinate King James I by blowing up the Parliament. Supporters of the Republican primary campaign of the libertarian Representative Ron Paul may remember Fawkes as a wildly successful fund-raising gimmick.

title: Romney Gets a Conservative Blessing
description: While his name might not rank up there with Novak and Nagourney, or Broder and Brownstein, David Brody of the Christian news outfit CBN continues to bring in big stories about campaign 08, or at least from the far-right side of campaign 08. Weve found out that Paul Weyrich, the former co-founder of The Moral Majority has endorsed Mitt Romney for President, Brody informs us. If you know anything about the conservative movement in this country in the last 30 years or so, you know how big a deal this is  His claim to fame is that he was one of the co-founders of the Moral Majority.

title: Daniel Cassidy on Slang
description: Mr. Cassidy, a native New Yorker, discusses the similarities between English slang and elements of Gaelic, which his family spoke.

title: Checking In on Radioheads Experiment
description: Way to go Radiohead! was the first of many excited comments on news last month that Radiohead was letting its customers set the price of its new album. Industry observers were just as excited, heralding a game-changing moment. But what happened afterwards?

title: Rising Up in New Orleans, the Post-Storm House
description: New Orleans has always been known for its eclectic housing styles. Now emerging is what could be called a posthurricane vernacular.

title: Award Winning Design
description: The Salt House (Photo: Cristobal Palma)

title: Generals Agree: Waterboarding Is Torture
description: President Bushs nominee for Attorney General, Michael Mukasey, has had trouble deciding that waterboarding  a method of interrogation that is designed to make a prisoner believe that he is drowning  is torture.

title: Q&A: Home Fires
description: The five writers of Home Fires are inviting questions from readers this week. If youd like to submit a question, please leave it as a comment on this post. A selection of questions and answers will be published online next week.

title: Shell Be Comin Round the Mountain
description: When Oprah Winfrey comes to Digital Town, youd better believe the big-name Shriners come out with a welcome wagon  and a marching band and some giant weird pumpkins.

title: Barry Diller Asks and Google Answers With Cash
description: Barry Diller does have a nose for deals. Hes usually not real early on a trend, but hes not that late either. Take Ask Jeeves, which his company, IAC/InterActiveCorp bought in 2005 for $1.85 billion.

title: Human, All Too Human
description: This weekend, as I wrapped up my rereading of War and Peace, I moved on to the book that will be discussed tonight in my book club  a group I formed 7 years ago, to help ensure that, what with all the editing, research, and reviewing I did in my working life, I did not lose the habit of reading for pleasure. (The same sentiment applies to all the women in my group, though some of us are not editors or writers.) A handful of books made me love reading: Jane Eyre, David Copperfield, Pride and Prejudice, The Red and the Black, A House for Mr. Biswas, The Brothers Karamazov, The Heart of the Matter, Pre Goriot, everything by P.G. Wodehouse, and yes, War and Peace. We have read several of those in book club, not War and Peace however. (Weve noticed that books longer than 400 pages tend to defeat our best intentions.)

title: Picketing Writer Struck By Car Outside Paramount
description: The mood was somber outside the stately wrought-iron gates of Paramount in Los Angeles on the first day of the Writers Guild of America strike, where a driver entering the gates struck and slightly injured a picketing writer, according to Bernard Lechowick, who works on the CBS soap opera The Young and the Restless.

title: Fans Still Line Up For Non-Scripted Shows
description: The tension at Television City, a Los Angeles complex that houses CBS headquarters and soundstages for Dancing with the Stars and American Idol, was palpable on Monday as about 120 striking writers marched next to people lining up to get tickets to the afternoon taping of Dancing with the Stars, whose writers are not covered under the Writers Guild of America.

title: Pencils Down, Picket Signs Up
description: The Times's David Carr interviews members of the Writers Guild of America East who are on strike and picketing in front of New York's Rockefeller Center.

title: Tools for the Chronically Obnoxious
description: Matt Richtel got quite a debate going over the use of cell phone jammers.

title: Economy Catching Up as an Issue
description: The Iraq war looms large, but a recent ABC News/Washington Post poll finds increasing concern about the economy.

title: Le Mars, Iowa? Perhaps Its the Ice Cream
description: Ever been to Le Mars, Iowa? Senators Joseph R. Biden Jr., John McCain and Barack Obama have, as have John Edwards, Mike Huckabee and Mitt Romney.

title: The Saturday Night Live Primary
description: Senator Barack Obamas cameo on Saturday Night Live, jesting at Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons expense, raised the question of who is winning the Lorne Michaels primary. Neither Democrat, finance reports show.

title: No, Its Not Dj Vu; Its Real
description: The television writers strike could affect the presidential campaign in one way. It promises to wipe out the part of the echo chamber that is late night comedy.

title: Bred in the Bone
description: A new coffee-table-format book, "Evolution," demonstrates that skeletons provide evidence for the history of life both hard and beautiful.

title: Iowa Dinner for 9,000
description: The Jefferson-Jackson Day dinner is a Democratic tradition throughout the nation. But rarely is it as celebrated as it is in Iowa in the year before a presidential election. The dinner honors Thomas Jefferson and Andrew Jackson and helps raise money for state and local Democratic Parties. In Iowa, it showcases the candidates in advance of the first caucuses, on Jan. 3.

title: Bloggingheads:  Mideast Peace
description:
Heather Hurlburt, of Democracy Arsenal, and David Frum, of the National Review, on whether the Annapolis conference has a chance of success.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: Happy Returns for the Jets
description: Jets fans have at least one thing to be happy about.

title: The Mystery of Buyers Remorse  Or, Should You Look for a Money-Back Guarantee?
description: At a gathering of social psychologists earlier this year in Memphis, I was surprised to hear one of them say mournfully, You know, we havent really come up with a solid concept since cognitive dissonance. What made this surprising was that its been a half century since cognitive dissonance was identified.

title: Neglected Samuel Barber Opera Sees the Light Again
description: Once in a while an opera company presents a new production that prompts a re-evaluation of a misunderstood work. Thats what happened on Sunday when New York City Opera unveiled its staging of Samuel Barbers Vanessa.

title: As Floods Ebb in South, Mexico Tends to Displaced
description: VILLAHERMOSA, Mexico, Nov. 5  Residents of the state of Tabasco woke up Monday to find that the swollen rivers that had flooded much of the state had begun to subside. But there were plentiful signs that the worst may not be over.

title: The Pakistan Mess
description: By imposing martial law, Gen. Pervez Musharraf has pushed nuclear-armed Pakistan further along a perilous course and underscored the failure of President Bushs policy toward a key ally in the war on terrorism. The events should not have come as a surprise to administration officials. This is what you get when policy is centered slavishly on a single, autocratic ruler rather than more broadly on his country.

title: No More Bench Strength
description: In corporate America, it may be time to retire the phrase heir apparent.

title: Rethinking What Caused the Last Mass Extinction
description: FREEHOLD, N.J.  Splashing through a shallow creek in suburban New Jersey, the paleontologists stepped back 65 million years to the time of the last mass extinction, the one notable for the demise of the dinosaurs.

title: With Brothel Plans Delayed, a Madam Does Laundry
description: PAHRUMP, Nev.  Sex is the commodity that Heidi Fleiss says she knows best, but for now she is settling for fabric softener.

title: Nomination of Mukasey Sent to Full Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  The Senate Judiciary Committee this morning endorsed the nomination of Michael B. Mukasey to be attorney general, virtually assuring his confirmation by the full Senate.

title: Rebuilding New Orleans, Post-Katrina Style
description: NEW ORLEANS  This city has always been known for its eclectic housing styles  Greek Revival, Italianate, Creole. Now emerging is what could be called a posthurricane vernacular, wide-ranging architectural responses to what everyone here refers to simply as the Storm.

title: Britain: Bid for Sainsbury Ends
description: A Qatari investment fund, Delta Two, withdrew its 10.6 billion ($22 billion) bid to take control of the British supermarket chain J Sainsbury as a result of escalating borrowing costs, Delta Two said. The fund will still have a 25 percent stake in the British retailer, and the fund manager, Three Delta, expressed confidence in Sainsburys management, a sign it apparently intended to hold onto its stake. The transaction would not be in the best interest of stakeholders, Paul Taylor, a principal of Three Delta, said in a statement.

title: Now They Know: Jimmy Slagle Played Here
description: WORTHVILLE, Pa.  In his day, Jimmy Slagle, a native of this speck of a town in northwestern Pennsylvania, was one of the best players on the most dominant team in major league baseball.

title: Screenwriters on Strike Over Stake in New Media
description: This article was reported by Michael Cieply, David Carr and Brooks Barnes, and was written by Mr. Cieply.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,837 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Zelda Fitzgerald Novel Wins Goncourt Prize
description: A fictional autobiography of Zelda Fitzgerald, wife of F. Scott Fitzgerald, has won Frances highest literary award, the Prix Goncourt, Agence France-Presse reported. Written by a former journalist, Gilles Leroy, above left, the novel, Alabama Song, tells a tale of wild parties in the Roaring Twenties, Zeldas relationship with her husband and her decades of struggle with mental illness. Another of Frances leading literary accolades, the Prix Renaudot, was awarded to Daniel Pennac, above right, for Chagrin dcole (School Blues), about his experiences as a self-professed class dunce. The prizes ushered in the season of French literary awards.

title: House Votes to Override Bushs Veto of Water Projects
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  The House voted 361 to 54 this evening to override President Bushs veto of a $23 billion water projects bill, apparently sealing Mr. Bushs first defeat in a veto showdown with Congress.

title: Memo Pad
description: THE WORST YEAR Domestic airline performance through September of this year ranked as the worst for any comparable period in at least 12 years, the Transportation Departments Bureau of Transportation Statistics reported yesterday. Through September, 73.18 percent of flights arrived on time this year, compared with 76.14 percent in the same period last year and the 12-year high, 82.82 percent in 2003. The worst 3 of the top 32 major airports through September of this year were all in the New York area: Newark Liberty (59.60 percent on time) LaGuardia (59.85 percent) and Kennedy (60.86 percent). The best three were Salt Lake City (80.31 percent), and Oakland (80.22 percent) and San Diego (78.95 percent) in California.

title: More Acidic Seas Can Change Behavior of Anxious Sea Snails
description: Climate change may get the most publicity, but its not the only global phenomenon linked to rising levels of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. Another is the gradual acidification of the oceans, as more of CO2 dissolves in seawater, creating carbonic acid and lowering the pH.

title: Protector of Lake Loses Appeal in Chinese Court
description: BEIJING, Nov. 5  A prominent Chinese environmental leader has lost his appeal of a three-year conviction on blackmail and fraud charges, according to his wife and his lawyer, even as the authorities promised to invest billions to clean up the lake he fought for years to protect.

title: A Planetary System That Looks Familiar
description: They say there is no place like home, but it is beginning to look as if there is a place sort of like home 41 light-years from here in the constellation Cancer.

title: A Little Mopey, a Tiny Bit Lah-Di-Dah and Always Earnestly Melodic
description: Band of Horses wasnt far into its show at Terminal 5 on Sunday night when Benjamin Bridwell, the lead singer, made an observation about New York audiences: They arent as scary as theyre made out to be. Backhanded praise, to be sure, but Mr. Bridwell sounded appreciative and even a bit relieved, and got an encouraging cheer.

title: Big Marathon Payday Becomes More Than a Dream
description: Gete Wami remembered the first time she earned prize money for running.

title: Bond Buyers Are Losing Confidence
description: After a recuperative October, investors in the credit markets are starting to feel a familiar sense of dread.

title: Sun Reports Modest Profit, but Revenue Disappoints Investors
description: Sun Microsystems posted a meager profit yesterday as it continued to benefit from its corporate restructuring and improved gross margins, but revenue disappointed investors who were hoping for a bigger start to the fiscal year.

title: Lundqvist and Rangers Silence the Flyers
description: Until last night, the dynamics of a Henrik Lundqvist shutout had usually looked the same. The Rangers would not muster much offense and Lundqvist had to play every shot as if the game depended on it, because often, it did.

title: Healing Hearts and, Possibly, Divisions in Guatemala
description: GUATEMALA CITY, Nov. 5  Heart surgery might not appear to have much in common with politics, especially the bare-knuckle brand practiced in Guatemala. But this countrys newly elected vice president, a prominent cardiologist here and in Houston, has long dabbled in both worlds.

title: To Coles, Sideline Is More Painful Than Any Hit
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 5  An old friend phoned Jets receiver Laveranues Coles last week, and when he recognized the name and number, he let it pass to voice mail. He already knew what Wayne Chrebet was going to say.

title: Athens Rally Defends Art Deco Building
description: Thousands of protesters demonstrated yesterday in Athens to prevent the demolition of an Art Deco building near a new museum on the Acropolis, Agence France-Presse reported. Neighborhood residents, supported by an international petition carrying 8,000 signatures, are appealing plans authorizing the destruction of the building that were approved this year by the Archaeology High Council and endorsed by the minister of culture. Officials of the new museum, scheduled to open next year at the foot of the Acropolis, say the Art Deco structure and another building, owned by the Greek composer Vangelis, obstruct the view from the museums restaurant. The neighborhood residents are also waiting for a ruling from the Ministry of Environment and Public Works. They are supported by the modern Greek architecture specialist Franois Loyer of the National Center for Scientific Research in France, who said in a letter to the Greek culture minister, Michalis Liapis, that the demolitions would be a major error. The 1930 Art Deco building was designed by Vassilis Kouremenos, who trained at the Beaux-Arts academy in Paris.

title: A Detour From a Battle Against Terror
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 5  While Gen. Pervez Musharraf justified his emergency rule decree as helping him combat terrorism, it could end up weakening his ability to rein in the Qaeda militants who ultimately threaten American interests.

title: At Hearing on Child Neglect Petition, Doctor Testifies That Slain Husband Beat Her
description: A woman whose estranged husband was shot dead on a Queens playground last month cried in Queens Family Court yesterday as she testified about her broken marriage and the custody battle she and her spouse were waging over their 4-year-old daughter.

title: Black Sea Republic Displays Traditions Fierce and Gentle
description: The Georgian State Dance Company belongs at Radio City Music Hall. But you cant be too finicky when it comes to this group of dancers and musicians  even if that means traveling a bit off the dance worlds beaten path, to the Bronx. The company, formed in 1945, performed there on Sunday afternoon at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts.

title: Bush Urges Musharraf to Reverse Course but Signals No Penalty if He Doesnt
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  President Bush on Monday urged Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the Pakistani president, to hold elections and give up his army post as soon as possible, but gave no indication that the generals imposition of emergency rule would bring about any significant change in American policy.

title: Odes to an Ax Murderer From New England and a Singer From Hoboken
description: Gillian Murphy and Michele Wiles may be American Ballet Theaters pre-eminent female technicians, the kind of dancers who shine particularly brightly in abstract works that are all about brilliant movement in space. Both were cast in the frazzling ballerina role in Balanchines pure-dance Ballo Della Regina, new to Ballet Theater this season. And both were less predictably cast as the Accused in Agnes de Milles Fall River Legend, the 1948 ballet based on the story of Lizzie Borden, tried in 1893 on charges of murdering her father and stepmother with an ax.

title: Richard Tucker Night Is Operas All-Star Game
description: Big opera galas have much in common with sporting events: Fans gather to watch, and compare, feats of physical prowess. This parallel is always particularly clear at the annual gala of the Richard Tucker Music Foundation, held this year on Sunday at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Venezuelan General Likens Chvezs Proposals for Constitution to a Coup
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 5  In a sharp indictment of President Hugo Chvezs proposed changes to the Constitution, the former top army commander here described the proposed charter on Monday as in effect a coup dtat intended to abolish checks on Mr. Chvezs expanding power.

title: Tuesday: Election Day
description: NEW YORK Polls in New York City and throughout the state are open from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. The New York Public Interest Research Group and Common Cause New York are running a nonpartisan voter help line. Voters can call (212) 868-3692 to locate a polling site, get advice on voting rights or report problems at the polls. Voters can also call the New York City Board of Elections toll-free at 1-866-VOTENYC (1-866-868-3692).

title: In the Lab: Device Could Help Doctors and Smokers
description: If doctors want to know if their patients smoke, they can always just ask. But researchers say there may be a better way to determine a patients smoking status  and at the same time provide a powerful incentive to quit.

title: IAC/InterActive to Split Into 5 Companies
description: Barry Diller finally decided yesterday to see if the parts of IAC/InterActiveCorp, his grab bag of Internet companies and services, are greater than the whole.

title: Giuliani Says Successes Surpass Keriks Mistakes
description: Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the crime-fighting successes of the disgraced former police commissioner, Bernard B. Kerik, outweighed his legal problems, and added that if I have the same degree of success and failure as president of the United States, this country will be in great shape.

title: Giants Get Back to Work With Goal of Getting Back on Schedule
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 5  The Giants are one of the hottest teams in the N.F.L., having won six consecutive games. They are also one of the most rested, having not played since defeating the Miami Dolphins in London eight days ago.

title: Faults Seen at Agency That Patrols U.S. Borders
description: Thousands of travelers who should have been barred from entering the country last year were allowed in by lax procedures of United States Customs and Border Protection officers, the Government Accountability Office reported yesterday.

title: The Lowly Parking Garage With the Colorful Identity
description: I USUALLY take a commercial car service to and from the airport. I have been using the same service for 20 years, and it has never failed. Ask for a 4:30 a.m. pickup, and the driver is out front at 4:25 a.m.

title: Girardi Will Be Filling Torres Shoes With a Bit of Showalters Style
description: Buck Showalter was watching television with some friends when he learned that Joe Girardi would succeed Joe Torre as manager of the Yankees. The reporter on the broadcast said that the intense Girardi might be more of a control freak than the focused Showalter, who preceded the laid-back Torre in the Bronx. Showalter was not flattered.

title: The Garden and the Trains
description: To the Editor:

title: Mary Lillian Ellison, 84, the  Fabulous Moolah, Is Dead
description: Mary Lillian Ellison, whose flying drop kicks, flying head scissors and hair-pulling flying mare body slams brought her renown as the professional wrestler the Fabulous Moolah, died Friday in Lexington, S.C., near her home in Columbia. She was 84.

title: Flying and Blood Clots: A Deadly Risk
description: Life-threatening blood clots and flying have been linked for more than 50 years, but a new study of business travelers confirms the risk, particularly for those who take long flights or fly frequently.

title: In Iowa Field, Edwards Sees Only Senator Clinton
description: IOWA CITY, Nov. 5  A few minutes before John Edwards delivered a forceful closing argument to the voters who will help determine the fate of his presidential ambitions, he called upon a gentleman seated near a window in the library in downtown Charles City.

title: The Claim: Zinc Can Help You Beat a Cold
description: THE FACTS

title: Sweden: Getinge Buys 2 Units
description: Getinge, the worlds largest maker of surgical workstations, agreed to buy two Boston Scientific Corporation units for $750 million to expand its tools for heart operations. The two divisions are a heart unit, which employs about 450 people at its headquarters in San Jose, Calif., and a factory in Dorado, Puerto Rico, and a vascular surgery unit, which employs 250 people in Wayne, N.J. Getinge, based in Stockholm, said it was cutting expenses and making purchases to become more profitable. Boston Scientific, based in Natick, Mass., said it was selling the units to reduce debt and focus on businesses with more growth potential.

title: On Fur and Feather, Crittercams Turn 20 Seeking New Vistas
description: WASHINGTON  For photographers lacking training, experience and even the ability to click a shutter button, they produce remarkable pictures. Under the sea, deep in the woods and high in the sky, furry, feathery and leathery-skinned creatures are opening up vistas by taking cameras where no human can go.

title: More Readers Trading Newspapers for Web Sites
description: THE circulation declines of American newspapers continued over the spring and summer, as sales across the industry fell almost 3 percent compared with the year before, according to figures released yesterday.

title: Heart Surgery Drug Pulled From Market
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  Pressured by regulators, the German pharmaceutical giant Bayer AG announced Monday that it had agreed to withdraw the controversial heart surgery drug Trasylol after a Canadian study suggested that it increased death rates.

title: Before the Court: Are Munis Like Milk, or Garbage?
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  A case with the potential to unsettle the municipal bond market produced a lively Supreme Court argument on Monday, with no clear indication of whether justices would permit states to continue the widespread practice of exempting the interest on their bonds from state taxation while taxing the interest on bonds issued by other states.

title: Pettitte Is Electing to Pause
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 5  Brian Cashman received a call from Andy Pettitte on Monday, and the message Pettitte delivered was not the worst news Cashman had ever heard. But it was not what Cashman wanted to hear.

title: Torre Gets a Sunny Welcome to Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 5  Joe Torre, the Brooklyn boy who rooted for the Giants, smiled atop a blue-draped platform Monday in center field at Dodger Stadium, where he was extolled as the manager needed by a team that next season will celebrate its 50th anniversary of playing in Los Angeles.

title: Food 2.0: Chefs as Chemists
description: In September, talking to an audience of chefs from around the world, Wylie Dufresne of WD-50 on the Lower East Side of Manhattan waxed enthusiastic about a type of ingredient he has been adding to his restaurants dishes.

title: Google Enters the Wireless World
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5  What Apple began with its iPhone, Google is hoping to accelerate, with an ambitious plan to transform the software at the heart of cellphones.

title: Citi Names Executive to Repair Mortgage Problems
description: Citigroup, reeling from its exposure to billions in assets backed by volatile home loans, has appointed a triage team led by one of Wall Streets best-known fix-it men.

title: Matisse Painting Auctioned for $33.6 Million
description: A Matisse painting depicting one of the artists favorite models fetched $33.6 million tonight at Christies, breaking the previous auction record for the artist in a lively kickoff to the fall auction season.

title: At Time Warner, Successor to Parsons Emerges
description: After months of speculation, Time Warner announced yesterday that Jeffrey L. Bewkes, the chief operating officer, will succeed Richard D. Parsons as chief executive at the end of the year.

title: New Jersey Ballot Asks Voters to Allow More Debt
description: TRENTON, Nov. 2  At a groundbreaking for the Stem Cell Institute of New Jersey recently, Gov. Jon S. Corzine drove a spade into the dirt and declared the site the nexus of cutting-edge scientific breakthroughs.

title: Bad Legal Advice and the Death Penalty
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  Eighteen years have passed since an Idaho murder defendant took his lawyers advice to reject the states offer of a guilty plea that would have resulted in a life sentence. The defendant, Maxwell Hoffman, went to trial instead, and was sentenced to death for participating in the murder of a government informer.

title: Waning Support Led to Ouster of Citigroup Chief
description: As recently as last month, Charles O. Prince III could count on the support of Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia, the biggest shareholder of Citigroup, the financial behemoth that Mr. Prince had run for four years.

title: Spending Trumps Social Issues on Ballots This Time
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  When it comes to the state and local ballot measures before voters across the country on Tuesday, it is mostly about the money.

title: Shining Light on Diseases Often in the Shadows
description: When is a neglected disease no longer neglected?

title: Portrait of the Broadway Theatergoer
description: The League of American Theaters and Producers released its 2006-7 demographic report yesterday, and the standout fact about Broadway theatergoers was that most are not from around these parts. Tourists accounted for 65 percent of Broadway ticket buyers, up from 57 percent last year. Almost 2 million of the 12 million Broadway ticket buyers were foreigners, up more than 44 percent from last year and an all-time high. At the same time, there has been a decline in local theatergoers. The number of ticket buyers from New York was at its lowest in seven seasons; the number of those from the New York suburbs declined for the eighth season. Thanks to shows like The Color Purple, Chicago and The Lion King, Broadway audiences are becoming a little less white  26 percent of theatergoers were not white, a 56 percent increase from five years ago. Otherwise, much was the same as last season: the average age of the Broadway theatergoer was 41, and average household income was $98,900, both slight decreases from last years report.

title: A Top Sicilian Mafia Boss Is Held, Italy Says
description: MILAN, Nov. 5  One of the most powerful bosses in the Sicilian Mafia was arrested Monday, according to the Italian authorities.

title: Bronx: Man Dies After Robbery
description: Six to eight men forced their way into a basement apartment on Glover Street early yesterday, attacked the two occupants and left them tied up after stealing an undetermined amount of cash, the police said. One occupant, 18, managed to free himself and called the police. When officers arrived, they found the other occupant, Antonio Castillo, 44, unconscious. He was taken to Westchester Square Medical Center, where he was pronounced dead, the police said.

title: Lottery Numbers
Living With Pain That Just Won't Go Away
description: Pain, especially pain that doesnt quit, changes a person. And rarely for the better. The initial reaction to serious pain is usually fear (what is wrong with me, and is it curable?), but pain that fails to respond to treatment leads to anxiety, depression, anger and irritability.

title: Watered-Down Mortgage Reform
description: What a difference a day makes. Just yesterday, this page praised the House Financial Services Committee for producing an exemplary bill, the Mortgage Reform and Antipredatory Lending Act of 2007, and urged its members to make only a few improvements before passing the measure. When they meet today, the committee chairman, Barney Frank, is prepared to offer an amendment that will make the weakest part of the bill even weaker.

title: The Price of Sugar
description: To the Editor:

title: Skeletons Flesh Out Lifes Past
description: About half a billion years ago, our ancestors were slender, jawless, fishlike creatures. Their backs were stiffened by a rod of cartilage, along which grew bony prongs. That smattering of bone was the forerunner of our vertebrae, and it gave us and all the other descendants of those ancient animals our name: the vertebrates. Vertebrates have evolved into tens of thousands of species dominating the ocean, land and sky. Much of their success is due to the many new forms their skeletons have taken. A new coffee-table-format book, Evolution (Seven Stories Press), offers hundreds of gorgeous photographs of those forms, as diverse as bats with fingers thinner than pipe cleaners and rhinos with skulls as stubborn as boulders.

title: Water on Mars May Have Piled Up as Ice Near Equator
description: There is plenty of evidence that water once flowed on the surface of Mars, and other evidence that points to where some of that water is now: in layers of dirty ice deposits at the poles.

title: The Power of Light
description: Q. Does reflected light also help plants grow, or does it have to be direct sunlight?

title: New DVDs
description: ANIMATION

title: 50 New York Schools Fail Under Rating System
description: Under a blunt new A through F rating system that judges schools not just on performance but also on progress, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg designated 50 New York City public schools as failures yesterday, saying they were so dismal that their 29,000 students would be allowed to transfer elsewhere.

title: Facebook to Turn Users Into Endorsers
description: Facebook wants to turn every member into a spokesman for its advertisers. Mark Zuckerberg, the founder and chief executive of the superhot social network, today announced what the company calls social ads.

title: Week's Notables
description: PLAYER In Asia, Aleksandar Duric, a 37-year-old striker born in Bosnia, has been called to Singapores national team for its World Cup qualifying match against Tajikistan on Friday. Duric, a naturalized citizen, is the leading scorer in Singapores top league with 37 goals this season.

title: Israelis and Palestinians Say They Want Accord Soon
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank, Nov. 5  Israeli and Palestinian officials hope to reach a comprehensive peace agreement before the end of President Bushs term, Israeli, Palestinian and American officials said Monday.

title: Critics Cite Red Tape in Rebuilding of Louisiana
description: NEW ORLEANS  If rebuilding anything in this storm-scarred place could possibly qualify as simple, surely it would be the administration building in City Park.

title: Adding Color Untangles the Brains Gray Secrets
description: For an organ that has been scanned millions of times by experts using high-end imaging technology, the brain remains in large part a shrouded landscape, as lost in darkness as the ocean floor.

title: Shares of Alibaba.com Climb on First Day of Trading
description: SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Nov. 6  Shares of Alibaba.com, one of Chinas biggest Internet companies, soared in early trading on Tuesday in this countrys latest hot initial public stock offering.

title: Hope After Failure of New Cholesterol Drug
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 5  Drugs to raise so-called good cholesterol may still have a future despite the widely publicized failure last year of an experimental cholesterol treatment from Pfizer, researchers said Monday at a heart conference here.

title: Part of Door Frame Dismantled in Search for Clues to Slaying
description: Investigators removed part of a door frame yesterday from the Fifth Avenue apartment where a celebrity real estate broker was bludgeoned to death last week, a law enforcement official said.

title: Clinton Energy Plan Includes Push for Higher Gas Mileage
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Nov. 5  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on Monday released her plan to combat climate change and to increase energy efficiency, which includes raising fuel standards to 55 miles per gallon by 2030 and creating five million jobs through renewable energy advancements.

title: How Long to Wait for Salmon Before Casting Again? Sometimes, Its All Winter
description: McNAMEE, New Brunswick  To the list of lifes great mysteries  the primacy of the chicken or the egg, who shot J.F.K., why there is an s in the word lisp  I would add one more: how long should an angler wait to cast again to an Atlantic salmon that has come up for, but not taken, a fly?

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 14 about Angolas persistent poverty despite its financial windfall from rising oil prices misstated, in some editions, the countrys daily oil production. It is 1.5 million barrels, not 2 billion. (Go to Article)

title: Armys Aggressive Surgeon Is Too Aggressive for Some
description: SAN ANTONIO  Since the war in Iraq began, Col. John Holcomb has been working to change the way the military takes care of its wounded.

title: Mayor Calls Detective Hero but Adds to the Confusion
description: After a week of intense criticism, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg retreated yesterday from previous remarks and said a retired police detective who died at age 34 after working hundreds of hours at ground zero was indeed a hero.

title: More on the Career of the Genius Who Boldly Compared Himself to God
description: Talking about his own highly eclectic, highly protean style, Picasso once said to his mistress Franoise Gilot: Of course if you note all the different shapes, sizes and colors of models he works from, you can understand his confusion. He doesnt know what he wants. No wonder his style is so ambiguous. Its like Gods. God is really only another artist. He invented the giraffe, the elephant and the cat. He has no real style. He just keeps on trying other things. The same with this sculptor. First he works from nature; then he tries abstraction. Finally he winds up lying around caressing his models.

title: Its Fall in New York, and Cabs Are in Bloom
description: In the early-morning darkness, parked yellow taxis lined West 29th Street. Pungent curries scented the chilly air. For the drivers, it was a chance to grab some chicken korma, use a bathroom, relax for a few minutes or pray. For members of Garden in Transit, it was a ripe opportunity to apply decal sheets of whimsical flowers on the hoods, tops and trunks of the cabs.

title: Democrats Reject G.O.P. Bid for More Iraq Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  House and Senate negotiators approved a $459 billion military spending bill today, but rejected a Republican bid to provide $70 billion more to continue fighting the war in Iraq without any restrictions.

title: Dell to Acquire Storage Company for $1.4 Billion
description: Dell said yesterday that it would acquire EqualLogic for $1.4 billion in a move to claim a larger share of the data storage market.

title: A Few Words of Thanks for a Support System
description: Gratitude first: Thank God for answered prayer.

title: Morocco Angry at Royal Visit to Enclaves
description: MADRID, Nov. 5  Spain moved to soothe diplomatic tensions with Morocco on Monday as the Spanish king and queen began a visit to two territories on the coast of North Africa that both countries claim.

title: Competitively Priced Electricity Costs More, Studies Show
description: Retail electricity prices have risen much more in states that adopted competitive pricing than in those that have retained traditional rates set by the government, new studies based on years of price reports show.

title: A Pointless Slap at Transit Workers
description: For three days at the height of the December 2005 holiday season, New York City transit workers engaged in an illegal strike that stranded everyone who was dependent on subways and buses. It was maddening, dangerous and bad for the economy, and the union was punished for it. Now the city wants to keep the bad feelings alive by denying the union the right to collect dues through an automatic checkoff. Rather than continue the acrimony, the city should try to help usher in more peaceful labor-management relations.

title: Texas: Options Considered in Land Sale
description: The Texas land commissioner, Jerry Patterson, said he hoped to award a state-owned wildlife preserve near Big Bend National Park to one of two private bidders today, but give the National Park Service 90 days to meet or exceed the winning bid. The ideas of selling the preserve, the Christmas Mountains Ranch, to a private buyer and allowing hunting on it have drawn controversy. Both bids would allow hunting, and the National Park Service can seek Congressional authority to allow guns on the land, Mr. Patterson said. The 9,270-acre tract was given to the state in 1991.

title: Last Defendant Is Guilty in Attack on a Gay Man
description: In a case that has drawn intense scrutiny to the legal meaning of hatred, the last of four young men charged with selecting a gay man as a robbery target and chasing him to his death in traffic pleaded guilty yesterday to manslaughter and attempted robbery as hate crimes.

title: Russia: Nursing Home Fire Kills 31
description: At least 31 people died Sunday in a fire at a nursing home in the Tula region south of Moscow. The center did not have an alarm that could notify firefighters. The fire was the latest in a string of blazes in Russia that have caused many deaths and underscored patterns of negligence and poor governance. Fire officials told official Russian news agencies that the nursing home had failed a fire inspection but managed to remain open, and that once the fire broke out the firefighters were not notified for at least 30 minutes.

title: Doing Away With Far and Away
description: I REMEMBER standing in line at the post office in Florence in 1982, waiting with my parents to get into a phone booth to call the United States.

title: Obama and Iran
description: To the Editors:

title: Dog Eats Humble Pie
description: Duane Chapman, the embattled star of the hit A&E series Dog the Bounty Hunter, will appear on the Fox News Channel program Hannity and Colmes tonight to talk about the racially charged comments he made in a private phone conversation. Mr. Chapman, who is also scheduled to appear on Larry Kings CNN program tomorrow night, has been apologizing publicly for the comments, which include extensive use of racial epithets. A&E removed the show as soon as a tape of the conversation was made public by The National Enquirer, which paid Mr. Chapmans son for it. Several advertisers had said they would pull commercials from the show. A&E also announced that it was shutting down for the foreseeable future production on the start of 13 new episodes of the series, scheduled to broadcast in January. But Michael Feeney, a spokesman, said that the show, the most successful series on the cable channel over the past five years, had not been canceled. He added: We are taking a very proactive approach. This is a serious matter.

title: Mental Abilities: Gene Found to Play Role in Benefits of Breast Milk
description: For decades, experts have debated why children raised on breast milk tend to score higher on I.Q. tests. Was it something in the milk?

title: Present at the Creation
description: Amman, Jordan

title: Court-Martial to Open in Killings of 3 Iraqis
description: An Army sniper team leader charged with murdering three men south of Baghdad will go on trial today in Baghdad in a court-martial that is likely to highlight a classified Pentagon program in which snipers placed fake weapons as bait to attract and kill enemy fighters.

title: Aging: Flip Side to Education Is Seen in Dementia
description: People with more years of schooling appear to suffer the symptoms of dementia later than others who have it  but once it does come, it proceeds more quickly, researchers say.

title: A Switch From Beer to Holiday Cheer
description: AT 10:45 p.m. on Saturday, Justin Olsen stood behind the bar at the Gowanus Yacht Club, a seasonal outdoor beer garden on Smith Street in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, and made an announcement. The last keg of the year has been tapped, he said. And with that, the countdown began to the finale of one of the last remnants of summer in New York  even though the calendar says it is fall.

title: Manhattan: Education Campaign for Workers
description: The New York City Central Labor Council plans to begin a campaign today to educate construction workers, truck drivers and other workers in the city to make sure they are not classified as independent contractors instead of as employees. Misclassification often saves employers money while depriving workers of unemployment insurance and workers compensation protections, the labor council said. The council plans to have dozens of union members distribute leaflets. Gov. Eliot Spitzer has asked state agencies to crack down on misclassification.

title: Spending Is Focus of Nations Ballot Measures
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  When it comes to the state and local ballot measures before voters across the country on Tuesday, it is mostly about the money.

title: Iraqi Police Academy Remains Largely Unusable
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 5  More than a year after the Parsons Corporation, the American contracting giant, promised Congress that it would fix the disastrous plumbing and shoddy construction in barracks the company built at the Baghdad police academy, the ceilings are still stained with excrement, parts of the structures are crumbling and sections of the buildings are unusable because the toilets are filthy and nonfunctioning.

title: For Clues on Teenage Sex, Experts Look to Hip-Hop
description: Hip-hop, with its suggestive lyrics, videos and dance moves, has long been criticized by public health experts and parents, who fear that it leads to risky sexual behavior among teenagers.

title: Pakistan Attempts to Crush Protests by Lawyers
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 5  Angry protests by thousands of lawyers in Lahore and other cities on Monday demonstrated the first organized resistance to the emergency rule imposed by the Pakistani president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf. But the abrupt arrests of many of them threatened to weaken their challenge.

title: Ford Warns of New Steps if Sales Decline
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Nov. 5  Even as the Ford Motor Companys 54,000 hourly workers prepare to vote on their new contract, the automaker is warning that it may have to adjust its corporate restructuring plan if industry sales continue to slide.

title: Nor Can British Imperial Customs, Caesar, Stale Her Infinite Variety
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 3  We live in an especially fertile time for inventive reimaginings of operas by Handel, the greatest stage composer of the Baroque era. Even so, a production of Giulio Cesare that was given its American premiere by the Lyric Opera of Chicago on Friday night stands out for sheer audacity.

title: They Look Like Shoes, but Give Her Wings
description: Roxie Stamps, 58, is accustomed to toil. It is idleness that is harder to endure.

title: PetroChina Shares Triple in Debut
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 5  Superheated markets in China drove the value of PetroChina, the state oil and gas company, above $1 trillion today, giving it the highest market capitalization in corporate history and underscoring worries about a fast-growing stock bubble on the mainland.

title: Hillarys Tough Sell
description: The U.S. is in the midst of the most important presidential election campaign since World War II, and if there has ever been a time when women voters had the opportunity to decisively affect the nations future, its now.

title: Footnotes
description: Daniel Radcliffe, the star of the Harry Potter films, confirmed that he would make his Broadway debut next year in Peter Shaffers Equus, the critically acclaimed revival in which he starred in London this year. The show is expected to open in September.

title: Perceptions: Conductors Ears and Eyes Seem to Stay Equally Alert
description: To concentrate on a difficult task that involves listening, people tend to unconsciously divert their attention from what they are seeing. But music conductors, a new study reports, are not as apt to be distracted in this way.

title: When Your Cellphone Is in My Space
description: To the Editor:

title: Queens: Man Denies Killing Daughter
description: A Queens man accused of killing his 13-month-old daughter pleaded not guilty at his arraignment yesterday in Queens Criminal Court. The man, Peter OKeeffe, 35, who is charged with second-degree murder, was ordered held without bail. Judge Alex J. Zigman also ordered that Mr. OKeeffe be placed in protective custody and on suicide watch. Prosecutors said that Mr. OKeeffe beat the girl, Jessica, while baby-sitting on Saturday afternoon because she would not stop crying, and then ran from his house on 117th Street in South Ozone Park and fled to Philadelphia. The babys mother found her when she returned home, prosecutors said. Mr. OKeeffe returned and surrendered to the authorities. His lawyer, Michael V. Cibella, said Mr. OKeeffe worked as an accountant and bookkeeper for a printing company.

title: Led by Troubled Banks, Shares Slide
description: Shares of financial companies stumbled yesterday in the aftermath of the shake-up at Citigroup, sending the stock markets down and leaving investors on edge about further troubles in the credit market.

title: Trading Arcana for Haydn
description: Marc-Andr Hamelin has built a devoted audience by performing difficult piano music, both recent and arcane, demonstrating a solid, often dazzling technique, as well as a thoughtful musicality that reveals the poetry within the virtuosic glare. At his recital on Sunday afternoon at the Rose Theater, he did something different. Leaving his more peculiar specialties aside, he played a program of familiar works, starting with a crisply articulated, if slightly puzzling, account of Haydns Sonata in B minor (Hob. XVI: 32).

title: Publication to Cease for House & Garden
description: House & Garden, one of the nations oldest magazines, will close after the abrupt departure of its publisher and years of losses for its parent, Cond Nast Publications, the company said yesterday.

title: Alibaba Shares Nearly Triple in Debut
description: SHANGHAI, Nov. 6  Shares of Alibaba.com, Chinas biggest electronic commerce company, nearly tripled today in a spectacular opening day of trading, creating an Internet giant and one of the worlds wealthiest technology companies.

title: In Such a Rich Land, a Health Care Disgrace
description: To the Editor:

title: A Corona, Please, and Dont Hold the Lime
description: Moonshine is the kind of cozy, lived-in Brooklyn bar that allowed customers to bring dogs inside and meat for the grill outside, both of which, it would come to learn, are against New York City health department regulations. But no one foresaw one violation uncovered during a recent surprise inspection of the Red Hook tavern.

title: Bail for Dorm Matron at Winfrey Academy
description: A former dormitory matron accused of abusing students at Oprah Winfreys Leadership Academy for Girls in South Africa was freed on $458 bail yesterday and left the Sebokeng magistrate court, south of Johannesburg, with a blanket over her head, Reuters reported. The court postponed the case involving the woman, Virginia Mokgobo, 27, to allow further investigation of charges, including assault, indecent assault and soliciting under-age girls to perform indecent acts. When the charges were read, Ms. Mokgobo, who was not asked to enter a formal plea, said she was innocent, The Associated Press reported. The court postponed the case until Dec. 13 to allow time for additional investigations. At a video news conference from Chicago yesterday, Ms. Winfrey, above, said she was cleaning house at the $40 million academy, which opened in January. Calling the scandal one of the most devastating experiences in her life, she said she had not renewed the contract of the headmistress and was removing the dormitory supervisors.

title: Its Familiar but Just a Little Different
description: It was dj vu all over again, but with a subtle shift. When the pianist Murray Perahia performed at Avery Fisher Hall seven months ago, his program included Bachs Partita No. 3 (BWV 827), Beethovens two Opus 14 Sonatas, Chopins Ballade No. 4 and works by Schumann. When he returned to New York on Saturday evening, this time for a recital at Carnegie Hall, he played Bachs Partita No. 4 (BWV 828), Beethovens Opus 15 Sonata, Chopins Ballade No. 3 and works by Schumanns protg Brahms. It seemed almost as if Mr. Perahia were making his way through a few repertory cycles in slow motion.

title: Telling the Stories Behind the Abortions
description: Dr. Susan Wicklund took her first step toward the front line of the abortion wars when she was in her early 20s, a high school graduate with a few community college credits, working dead-end jobs.

title: Gates Questions China on Military Growth
description: BEIJING, Nov. 5  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates looked directly on Monday into two of the most striking facets of modern China.

title: A Mentor Turns on His Protg at Citigroup
description: As recently as last month, Charles O. Prince III could count on the support of Prince Alwaleed bin Talal of Saudi Arabia, who is the biggest shareholder of Citigroup, the financial behemoth that Mr. Prince had run for four years.

title: Australia: Bid for Chemical Maker
description: The China National Chemical Corporation, backed by the Blackstone Group, agreed to pay 3 billion Australian dollars ($2.8 billion) in cash for Nufarm of Australia to form the worlds largest supplier of generic farm chemicals. The offer by China National values Nufarm at 17.55 Australian dollars a share, 27 percent higher than its closing price on Oct. 30, Nufarm said. The price includes the payment of a 30-cents-a-share dividend by Nufarm, it said. Buying Nufarm gives China National entry to the $36 billion global market for herbicides and pesticides as a worldwide agricultural boom spurs acquisitions.

title: Palestinians Clash in West Bank
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 5  Palestinian security forces clashed with militiamen affiliated with the party of the Palestinian president in the West Bank city of Nablus on Monday, days after the Palestinian Authority sent in a reinforcement of 300 police officers by agreement with Israel.

title: British Intelligence Chief Sharpens Terrorism Warning
description: LONDON, Nov. 5  Britains chief domestic intelligence official said Monday that at least 2,000 people in Britain posed a direct threat to national security and public safety because of their support for terrorism, an increase of 400 in the last year.

title: The Red Bulls and Arena Part Ways
description: Bruce Arena, the man the Red Bulls were desperate to hire as coach but who failed to take the club beyond the first round of the M.L.S. playoffs, is leaving the team after 15 months in charge.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the professional successes of Maria Bartiromo, a business journalist for CNBC, misstated the surname of Citigroups senior vice chairman, with whom she recently conducted a prominent interview. He is William R. Rhodes  not Rose. The article also misspelled the name of a sovereign investment fund that Ms. Bartiromo said she found exciting. It is Qatar Associates  not Cutter.

title: Romney Gets Major Backer on the Right
description: Mitt Romneys presidential campaign announced yesterday an endorsement from the man whom some consider the father of the religious right, Paul M. Weyrich, chairman of the Free Congress Foundation and a founder of the Moral Majority.

title: EADS Warns It Will Take a Hit From Delayed Military Plane
description: PARIS, Nov. 5  The parent of Airbus, European Aeronautic Defense and Space, warned Monday that delays of up to a year for its latest multibillion-dollar military transport aircraft program would reduce third-quarter earnings by as much as $2 billion.

title: Honoring the Hands of a Pianist and a Survivor
description: Neither index finger works anymore, not a good thing for a woman whose life is devoted to the piano. Then again, those fingers are more than 103 years old. At that age, some parts are bound to give out.

title: City Slow to Act as Hope for Foster Children Fails
description: Taken as a young child from her drug-abusing mother, the girl had lived in one foster home after another. Now, at 16, she saw the day approaching when she would become an adult and be sent off to make a life on her own.

title: Candidates Pleased to Remember This Fifth of November
description: Historians and British schoolchildren remember Guy Fawkes as the Roman Catholic, anti-Protestant rebel who on Nov. 5, 1605, tried to assassinate King James I by blowing up the Parliament. Supporters of the Republican primary campaign of the libertarian Representative Ron Paul may remember Fawkes as a wildly successful fund-raising gimmick.

title: A Midseason Injection of Star Power and Momentum
description: The Chicago Fire is the hottest team in Major League Soccer, Coach Juan Carlos Osorio is the maestro of the month, and the provocative Cuauhtmoc Blanco is the spider spinning an unavoidable web.

title: White House to Offer Own Plan on Product Safety
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  The Bush administration on Tuesday will propose a significant expansion of the authority of the federal drug and consumer product safety agencies to inspect and certify imports, White House and other administration officials said Monday.

title: Gazas Reflection in a Foul Threat
description: UMM AL NASSER, Gaza, Oct. 30  Fahmi al-Abrak, 70, was at home on March 27 when a lagoon of human waste broke through its sand embankment and hurtled downhill, inundating this poor village of Bedouins in northern Gaza. It rose to here in 15 seconds, he said, pointing to a discolored line on the walls, four feet above ground.

title: General Managers Can Have Short Shelf Life
description: ORLANDO, Fla.

title: The Land of the Big Sky and the Deep Inner Void
description: The man who is about to die would like you to know that even though he is being portrayed by an actor, his feelings are real. Normally, people in plays do not feel its necessary to assert this.

title: Sarkozy Whirling Into Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  The French president, Nicolas Sarkozy, arrived in Washington today for his first official visit to the White House since becoming president.

title: A Role Thomas Relishes and Needs
description: While evaluating his prize acquisition Zach Randolph and, by extension, the Knicks in their narrow victory over Minnesota on Sunday night, Isiah Thomas seemed to have a new pet phrase.

title: Those Smutty, Nutty Kids With Heart, Treading the Boards in Merry Olde Italy
description: A jolly group of itinerant actors sing of themselves in The Glorious Ones, a new musical about the roistering life of the clowns who paved the streets of 16th-century Italy with sight gags and sex jokes. With buoyant music by Stephen Flaherty and a bawdy book and lyrics by Lynn Ahrens, the show mixes the lowdown pratfalls of commedia dellarte with the rosy sentimentality of classic American musical comedy. It encourages sniggers in one scene, as we watch the players perform classic comic sketches on a scrappy wooden stage, and sympathy in the next, when we sneak behind the scenes to lend an ear to their hopes, fears and heartaches.

title: Macao: Ex-Official Goes on Trial
description: Ao Man-long, the former transport and public works minister, went on trial, accused of taking $100 million in kickbacks from developers. Macao, a former Portuguese colony that is now a special administrative region of China, has overtaken Las Vegas in gambling revenues after a frenzy of casino construction.

title: 500 Million Years Ago, Jellyfish Left Their Mark in Fine Sea Sediments
description: Your average jellyfish washed up on a beach is hardly recognizable  just an amorphous blob, fast decomposing in the sun. (They dont call them jellyfish for nothing.)

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Portrait of the Broadway Theatergoer

title: Dubious Fees Hit Borrowers in Foreclosures
description: As record numbers of homeowners default on their mortgages, questionable practices among lenders are coming to light in bankruptcy courts, leading some legal specialists to contend that companies instigating foreclosures may be taking advantage of imperiled borrowers.

title: Staten Island: 16 Sickened by Chemical Fumes
description: Firefighters removed residents from a section of the Richmond Terrace Houses yesterday after three City Housing Authority workers were overcome by fumes from a cleaning chemical just after 1 p.m., the police said. The Fire Department said that 16 people, including five firefighters, were treated at Richmond University Medical Center in the afternoon. One person was in critical condition, two were in serious condition and the rest were treated for minor injuries. The Fire Department said the workers had used hydrated lime, a cleaning chemical, in an enclosed space.

title: Knicks and Nuggets Say the Melee Has Been Forgotten
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Nov. 5  The competency gap between the Knicks and the Denver Nuggets last year was so great that a mid-December game begot a rout, and the rout begot a brawl. Suspensions, fines and name-calling followed in short order.

title: A Vote for Justice
description: Washington

title: Peter Viertel, 86, Author and Screenwriter, Is Dead
description: Peter Viertel, a noted author and screenwriter who plumbed his relationships with the aristocracy of Hollywood  starting with Greta Garbo, his mothers best friend  and literary lions like Hemingway to produce provocative works of fiction and memoir, died on Sunday in Marbella, Spain. He was 86.

title: Yazoo Pumps: Theyre Back!
description: Like an indestructible ghoul in a low-grade horror flick, the Yazoo Pumps are rising again from the bureaucratic crypt.

title: Newspaper Circulation Falls 3%, Audit Bureau Says
description: The circulation declines of American newspapers continued to accelerate over the spring and summer, as sales across the industry fell almost 3 percent compared with the year before, according to figures released today.

title: Retired Principal Rekindles Competitive Fire for Archery
description: Phyllis Shipman did not look like the other athletes attending the United States Olympic Assembly last month in Houston. Neither buff nor sinewy and, at 64, several decades older, Shipman represented the sport of archery at the annual gathering of Olympic stakeholders.

title: Pope Meets King of Saudi Arabia
description: ROME, Nov. 6  Pope Benedict XVI and King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia clasped hands at the Vatican on Tuesday in the first meeting ever between a pope and the Saudi monarch, who is entrusted to protect Mecca, the birthplace of Mohammad and the center of the Islamic world.

title: Bush Pledges to Help Turkey on Intelligence
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  President Bush pledged Monday to increase intelligence cooperation with Turkey in its fight against Kurdish rebels, hoping to head off any significant Turkish military operation in Iraq.

title: Letters
description: A Borough and the A-Bomb
