title: Bradford Kelleher, Creator of Mets Store, Dies at 87
description: Bradford Kelleher, a pioneer of museum merchandising who founded the Metropolitan Museum of Arts first full-fledged gift shop and oversaw the creation of countless artful and educational tchotchkes, including the museums unofficial mascot, the Egyptian hippopotamus nicknamed William, died on Wednesday in Riverhead, N.Y. He was 87 and lived in Manhattan and Cutchogue, N.Y.

title: Canada: Encana Buys Gas Partner
description: The EnCana Corporation, a Canadian natural gas producer, agreed to buy out its partner in an East Texas gas field for $2.55 billion, its largest acquisition in three years, to increase its presence in one of the fastest-growing sources of the fuel in the United States. EnCana said it had acquired the stake in the field, located about 80 miles northwest of Houston, from Leor Energy, which is privately held. EnCana, which is based in Calgary, said it planned to accelerate drilling there next year by adding three rigs to the seven now in service.

title: The View From Roosevelt I.
description: To the Editor:

title: For a Key Education Law, Reauthorization Stalls
description: The leaders of the Senate and House education committees are signaling that time has run out for reauthorizing the No Child Left Behind Act this year, leaving prospects for rewriting it uncertain during the presidential campaign in 2008.

title: Ex-Contractor Is Convicted in Bribery Case
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 5  After almost four days of deliberation, a federal jury here on Monday convicted a former military contractor of 13 felonies related to the bribery of former Representative Randy Cunningham.

title: A Blossoming Cathedral Tower Sheds Its Scaffolding
description: Fifteen years have passed since the stonemasons put down their chisels and mallets for the last time. Now, they can finally see what their carving wrought: the uppermost 55 feet 2 inches of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine.

title: Despite Strike, Prime-Time TV Marches On
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 5  Worry not, prime-time television fans. Despite a Hollywood writers strike, Meredith will continue to pout on Greys Anatomy, Scofield will continue to scowl his way through Prison Break, House will limp and the Housewives will bicker. And all of those crime-solving, clue-unearthing, cold-case-cracking law enforcers will keep on digging  at least for another month or two, thanks to a backlog of about half a dozen episodes already filmed.

title: Amazing Race Is Off to a Flying Start
description: The 12th edition of The Amazing Race got under way to solid ratings on Sunday, as CBS attracted the nights most viewers over all. The network led its competitors by a significant margin going into prime time, thanks to an overrun of its afternoon football coverage. That highly anticipated match-up of undefeated teams, the New England Patriots and the Indianapolis Colts, delivered more than 32 million viewers in its final half-hour, according to Nielsens preliminary estimates. Although that audience largely dissipated once the game ended around 7:30 p.m., 18.8 million viewers stuck around for CBSs 60 Minutes, and 13.8 million tuned in for CBSs Amazing Race after that, the most ever for a first episode of the contest. For the night, NBCs Sunday Night Football edged past CBS for first place among adults 18 to 49, while ABC had a rare third-place finish, despite leading the 9 p.m. hour with Desperate Housewives (18.5 million). Fox ranked fourth over all. The 100th episode of Foxs Family Guy drew 10.5 million viewers at 9, while the annual Halloween episode of The Simpsons (11.7 million) led its 8 oclock slot in the 18-to-49 set.

title: Loud and Cleared: N.F.L. Says Colts Didnt Pump in Noise
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 5  In case the New England Patriots fourth-quarter comeback to beat the Indianapolis Colts did not do enough to stoke the N.F.L.s best rivalry, what came afterward surely will.

title: Massachusetts Looks at Using Biofuel in Home Heating Oil
description: BOSTON, Nov. 5  Gov. Deval L. Patrick and legislative leaders proposed a bill on Monday to require all home heating oil and diesel fuel to contain at least 5 percent biofuel by 2013.

title: Legal Think Tanks
description: To the Editor:

title: Art Dealer Files for Bankruptcy, Delaying Suits Against Him
description: Lawrence B. Salander, the embattled Manhattan art dealer whose gallery was ordered locked by a State Supreme Court justice last month, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy on Friday.

title: Go Ahead, Rationalize. Monkeys Do It, Too.
description: For half a century, social psychologists have been trying to figure out the human gift for rationalizing irrational behavior. Why did we evolve with brains that salute our shrewdness for buying the neon yellow car with bad gas mileage? The brain keeps sending one message  Yesss! Genius!  while

title: Cable Channel Nods to Ratings and Leans Left
description: Riding a ratings wave from Countdown With Keith Olbermann, a program that takes strong issue with the Bush administration, MSNBC is increasingly seeking to showcase its nighttime lineup as a welcome haven for viewers of a similar mind.

title: A Map of the Oil World
description: In 2006, Saudi Arabia was by far the largest producer of oil, followed by Russia and United States. On average, the United States consumed 20.6 million barrels per day, which made it the largest oil consumer in the world.

title: Injury Roundup
description: * Stop me if youve heard this before: a Carolina Panthers quarterback got hurt Sunday. It was David Carr, again. Carr, who has been battling a bad back for weeks, sustained a concussion Sunday against Tennessee. This is not entirely surprising because he was sacked seven times. UPDATE: The Charlotte Observer reports that Drew Olson is likely to sign with Carolina so there is someone to take reps in practice.

title: $500,000 Homes
description: Properties on the market in South Carolina, Missouri and California.

title: When Corona Beer and Lime Are a Crime
description: A Brooklyn bar has been busted for illicit lime insertion into bottles of Corona. Quoting from the rap sheet against the bar, Michael Wilson describes the crime as:

title: Psychological Tests at Work: Can You Study?
description: A friend (who asked me not to use her name for reasons that will soon become obvious) recently told me that she had interviewed for a job but didnt get it. She said she thought it might have to do with the psychological evaluation she had to undergo as part of the interview process. Of course, shell never know. But it was gnawing at her. It was the first time she had to submit to that kind of test for an interview, and she couldnt help wondering if she made a misstep somewhere.

title: Ex-Executive of Wal-Mart Drops Suit on Severance
description: A former advertising executive for Wal-Mart Stores has decided to drop her breach-of-contract lawsuit against the retailer, saying that the lawsuit had become financially draining and more complex than she had expected.

title: HarbourVest to List Fund on Euronext
description: A Boston private equity house, HarbourVest Partners, said Monday it plans to raise up to $400 million in a listing of one of its funds on the NYSE Euronext exchange in Amsterdam.

title: Grammercy Capital Scoops Up American Financial Realty
description: American Financial Realty Trust, which aimed to become the preferred landlord of leading banks and other financial institutions, announced Monday that it was being bought for $1.1 billion in cash and stock by Gramercy Capital, a New York commercial real estate finance company.

title: A Park Grows in Brooklyn
description: The new South Oxford Park with its whimsical central fountain was quickly converted from a derelict facility into a magnificent public space.

title: Black Loses Bid for New Trial
description: The former press baron Conrad Black and three of his associates, convicted in July of fraud at their company, Hollinger International, lost their request Monday for a new trial.

title: Boston Scientific Unloads Cardiac Surgery Unit
description: Boston Scientific said Monday it would sell its cardiac and vascular surgery businesses to Sweden-based Gettinge Group for $750 million.

title: Bank Write-Downs Unnerve Bond Buyers
description: After a recuperative October, investors in the credit markets are starting to feel a familiar sense of dread.

title: Hedge Fund Group Discloses New Guidelines
description: A leading hedge fund trade group unveiled new recommendations Monday aimed at improving practices in the lightly regulated, $2 trillion hedge fund industry.

title: Investors Eschew Hedge-Fund Start-Ups
description: The hedge fund industry is grappling with its first shakeout in a decade as investors increasingly avoid hedge-fund start-ups considered susceptible to the turmoil in credit markets.

title: Led by Troubled Banks, Shares Slide
description: Shares of financial companies stumbled Monday in the aftermath of the shake-up at Citigroup, sending the stock markets down and leaving investors on edge about further troubles in the credit market.

title: Rewriting Rap to Empower Teens
description: A group of high school girls in Atlanta got tired of taunts and catcalls from men in the street. So they decided to rap about it:

title: Behringer Harvard Signs for Chicago Office Towers
description: Behringer Harvard closed on its $832.5 million purchase of four downtown Chicago office towers from affiliates of Beacon Capital Partners, Behringer announced Monday.

title: V.C.s Turn On to LED Lighting Fixtures
description: LED Lighting Fixtures said Monday the company had raised $16.5 million in a second round of financing to bring energy-efficient lighting to businesses and homes. The funding, led by Digital Power Capital, brings the companys total capital to $23 million.

title: How a Prince Lost His Citi Crown
description: As recently as last month, Charles O. Prince III could count on the support of Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia, the biggest shareholder of Citigroup, the financial behemoth that Mr. Prince had run for four years.

title: Shares of Alibaba.com Climb on First Day of Trading
description: Shares of Alibaba.com, one of Chinas biggest Internet companies, soared in early trading on Tuesday in Chinas latest hot initial public stock offering.

title: No Coke  Politics!
description: The presidential field is full of connections to Saturday Night Live, and not just guest-host and cameo appearances. As Michael Cooper reports on our political blog The Caucus :

title: Dell to Acquire Storage Company for $1.4 Billion
description: Dell said Monday that it would acquire EqualLogic for $1.4 billion in a move to claim a larger share of the data storage market. The deal, Dells largest acquisition to date and its fourth this year, comes as the company is trying to stage a corporate turnaround and reclaim ground lost to more nimble competitors.

title: Buyout Chatter Surrounds ITV
description: The British broadcaster ITV got an initial lift Monday on weekend reports that a British private equity group, Apax could return to bid for the company.

title: Citigroup Names Executive to Oversee Subprime Assets
description: Citigroup named Richard Stuckey to manage most of its $43 billion of subprime mortgage assets, choosing the same executive who nine years ago helped unwind Long-Term Capital Managements bad bets.

title: A Boom Time for Islamic Finance
description: Even as banking segments like those that securitize subprime mortgages and finance leveraged buyouts suffer from the current crisis, Islamic finance is seeing spectacular growth.

title: EnCana to Pay $2.5 Billion in Texas Gas Deal
description: EnCana is paying $2.5 billion to buy out its partner in the Amoruso natural gas field in Texas. The play could become the most important in its North American portfolio.

title: Judge Sets Date in Sallie Mae Trial
description: A Delaware judge on Monday set a tentative trial date in July in the dispute between Sallie Mae and an investor group led by the private-equity firm J.C. Flowers seeking to terminate its proposed $25 billion buyout of the student lender.

title: Northern Rock Falls on Fears That Bidders Will Vanish
description: Shares in the stricken British mortgage bank Northern Rock tumbled more than 6 percent on Monday amid concerns that potential bidders will steer clear as the turmoil in global financial markets deepens.

title: Saving the Heritage Turkey
description: A breeder in Kansas is on a mission to save the rare birds and the culture of raising them.

title: When Theres No Chief on Deck
description: In corporate America, it may be time to retire the phrase heir apparent. For years, the idea of grooming a successor was a job requirement of a chief executive and a priority for a companys board, who both wanted a smooth transition.

title: Banks Are Said to Resume Sale of Chrysler Debt
description: A group of Wall Street banks plan to make another attempt to start selling $10 billion of Chrysler loans this week, according to news reports. The move follows the banks decision in July to shelve the debt offering amid woes in the credit markets.

title: Time Warner May Be in for a New Era of Dealmaking
description: The news that Jeffrey L. Bewkes, Time Warners the chief operating officer, will succeed Richard D. Parsons as chief executive at the end of the year had industry watchers wondering if a spate of dealmaking may be in the offing at worlds largest media company.

title: Comedian Falls Short of Pat Paulsen
description: Stephen Colbert went from running last month, to not running last week, to reruns this week  reruns because of the writers strike. On Monday, heres how the comedian announced his withdrawal from the presidential race:

title: Schlumberger Offers $679 Million for Eastern Echo
description: Schlumberger, the oil-field services company, bid up to $679 million for a Norwegian-listed company, Eastern Echo, on Tuesday to expand its seismic operations at a time when record oil prices are driving demand.

title: ING to Buy Sharebuilders Online Unit
description: The Dutch financial services group ING has agreed to buy ShareBuilders online brokerage business for $220 million to extend its reach in the United States, ING said on Tuesday.

title: Berlin in Lights: Is There Pop After Weimar?
description: Carnegie Hall is pitching Berlin in Lights as a celebration of Berlins Culture With a Capital C: not just its music but its art, architecture and film. And although plenty of the programming is overtly historical, you get the sense that this is all meant to add up to a contemporary portrait of a reborn city.

title: Time (and Paint) on His Hands
description: Could this guy be a Republican? But wait  isnt that his left hand? More hand art found here.

title: In DreamWorks Fight, Its Mogul vs. Mogul
description: All of Hollywood was shaken up this year over reports of a deepening feud between Paramount and DreamWorks, the movie studio that is the home of Steven Spielberg. Press reports were atwitter with word that Mr. Spielberg wasnt happy with the lack of recognition due DreamWorks  and a response in September from the head of Paramounts parent, Viacom, that the studios walking away would be completely immaterial.

title: Whats Next for Zell and Tribune?
description: The real estate magnate Sam Zell is famous for his bluntness and for his history of taking daring business risks  many of which have paid off.

title: Will IAC Breakup Bring Peace Between Moguls?
description: Barry Diller is splitting IAC/InterActiveCorp into five parts, but will that be enough to end the tensions between Mr. Diller and his old partner, John C. Malone?

title: A Different Take on I.P.O. Lawsuits
description: Plaintiffs are counting on a largely overlooked legal theory in their latest lawsuits against Goldman Sachs and other top investment banks that underwrote initial public offerings during the dot-com boom, The Seattle Times reports.

title: The Early Word: Climate Crusaders
description: Climate change is a big talking point for Democratic presidential candidates, and their plans for reversing it come with an even bigger price tag. The Washington Post reports today that the Democrats are counting on voters to get on board with their risky, expensive strategy to reduce greenhouse gas emissions because they believe it will ultimately save Americans money and save the earth.

title: Motionless in London on Congestion Charging in Manhattan
description: This comment excerpt (from this post) made me stop and think a bit:

title: Greece and Quiet
description: A look at a two-story residential-commercial property on the edge of a small Greek island.

title: Making Sense of the New School Rankings
description: The new school ranking system unveiled by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Monday has begun to stir vigorous discussion among parents and guardians.

title: Bloomberg Calls Report of Run Against Spitzer Fictitious
description: In a cover article today, The New York Post reports that Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs top political strategist, Deputy Mayor Kevin Sheekey, met late last month with a former state Republican chairman, William J. Powers, to discuss the possibility that Mr. Bloomberg might run against Gov. Eliot Spitzer in 2010. According to The Post, Mr. Sheekey told Mr. Powers that Mr. Bloomberg is open to the idea.

title: M.L.B. Takes First Step to Add Instant Replay
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 6  With a 25-5 vote, general managers took the first step Tuesday to add instant replay to baseball games. The vote marked a significant departure from previous votes at general managers meetings, where the issue had the support of, at best, half of those present.

title: Mukasey Gets a Hearing
description: Well, for once the other senator from New York has set off the big blog debate. I am voting today to support Michael B. Mukasey for attorney general for one critical reason: the Department of Justice  once the crown jewel among our government institutions  is a shambles and is in desperate need of a strong leader, committed to depoliticizing the agencys operations, writes Charles Schumer on this mornings Times Op-Ed Page.

title: Red Sox Retain Schilling
description: The Boston Red Sox took care of their veteran right-hander Curt Schilling by signing him to a one-year, $8 million contract.

title: Food Stuff
description: For New Yorkers, Never Too Much Chocolate

title: PayPal is Rude in the Lunch Line
description: Its not easy competing with Google. But a few minutes trying to buy my daughters their school lunches showed me why I think eBays PayPal will lose ground to Google Checkout.

title: If You Dont Buy This Magazine
description: The estimable Texas Monthly magazine, based in Austin, hasnt always been kind to the Bush administration  witness the issue at left, which recently won a 2007 American Society of Magazine Editors award for best cover line. (If You Dont Buy This Magazine, Dick Cheney Will Shoot You in the Face.)

title: Heads Turn Over Models Disputed Dollar Diss
description: There are headlines about supermodels, and there are headlines about currency markets, and rarely the twain shall meet. So its no wonder that the following headline from Bloomberg News on Monday turned heads and raised catcalls on Wall Street:

title: The Mysterious Assault on Fortress
description: Fortress Investment Group appears to have a hole in its castle walls. At least, that is the sense you get from its tumbling stock price.

title: Making More Room in Queens for Visiting Fans of Satchmo
description: Louis Armstrong, the acclaimed jazz trumpeter and vocalist, bought a house in Corona, Queens, with his wife, Lucille, in 1943. He lived there until his death in 1971. The house was designated a national historic landmark in 1977 and a city landmark in 1983, the year Lucille Armstrong died. In 1986, the Louis Armstrong Educational Foundation, which she created, donated the house to New York City and made arrangements for Queens College to maintain it.

title: Q&A: Chicago Coach Juan Carlos Osorio
description: Juan Carlos Osorio is no stranger to Major League Soccer. The 46-year-old native of Colombia was an assistant coach with the MetroStars for two years (2000-1) before taking a job as Manchester Citys strength and conditioning coach (2001-6). He returned to Colombia last season as the coach of Millonairos of Bogot before becoming the third coach in the history of the Chicago Fire on July 9.

title: Sullivan & Cromwell Names New Partners
description: How important are overseas markets in the deal-making business these days? Just look at the list of newly elected partners at Sullivan & Cromwell, the New York-based firm that is a perennial front-runner in the league tables that track merger advisory work.

title: Beyond Beyonc
description: Posters on Siraselviler Caddesi tout the eclectic mix of live music in Istanbul.

title: Fossil Hunters!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Tuesday Morning Kickoff
description: When you combine an e-mail newsletter controversy with a disappointing performance on the field, this becomes almost inevitable: Dennis Franchione is on the verge of accepting a buyout from Texas A&M, according to CBSSportslines Dennis Dodd. Ray Melick of the Birmingham News writes that the former Alabama coach Gene Stallings, now a member of the Texas A&Ms Board of Regents, could have a major say in who the Aggies next coach will be. And Steve Campbell of the Houston Chronicle says that the next coach had better be a big name.

title: Pitching Is Mets Priority
description: Mets General Manager Omar Minaya said his priority this off-season was to acquire a top starting pitcher. But with a thin free-agent market, making a trade could be challenging.

title: The Longest Season?
description: This strike could take a while.

title: Tuesdays Links: Those Other A.F.C. Teams
description: Lets make a deal: How about I promise not to mention the Colts or the Patriots?

title: At M.T.A. Hearing, Universal Opposition to Fare Increase
description: The process of raising the fares and tolls collected by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has often been described as a kind of ritual dance, with politicians, transit officials and straphangers all spinning around one another.

title: Import a Good Idea
description: The hat that helps kids in one part of the world turns out to help kids everywhere.

title: Pay Attention to Spot Opportunity
description: Owner Debra St. Claire turned desire for a vegetarian mint into a popular product.

title: Sell Your Unique Talent
description: Talent honed at Disney and Warner Brothers is this company's competitive edge.

title: Be Your Market
description: Brothers who love to surf in Baja brought their favorite Mexican flavors to California.

title: Visiting Venice in the Off-Season
description: I travel a lot but have never to been to Venice, mainly because I am fearful, as I have heard, that it is always so crowded with tourists. I can travel whenever I want and the weather doesnt concern me at all. I was thinking of late November and early December as those seem to be times when the travel season is the lowest and you can get the best fares.

title: Umberto Eco, Not a Cellphone Exhibitionist
description: For most of last weekend, one of the most e-mailed stories on the Timess website was about a device that enables you to silence the cell phones of annoying users. (Sign me up, please.)

title: Taking Leave of an Old Friend
description: Theres a beautiful passage in Edward Gibbons memoirs in which he describes completing The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire after so many years of work and being overcome by melancholy, as if he had taken everlasting leave of an old and agreeable friend. Reading War and Peace, I had been so happily and so fully immersed in the novel that, when I finished the last sentence, I felt a little disoriented and bereft, almost as if I had lost all of my old, agreeable friends at once.

title: Citis New Subprime Manager: The Memo
description: With concerns growing over Citigroups exposure to subprime mortgage-related securities, the firm said Tuesday that it had appointed Richard Stuckey as its point person to manage the business. Mr. Stuckey is no newcomer to helping Citi out of a jam: In 1998, he helped pull the bank out of Long-Term Capital Management.

title: Marmalade or Marmite? 2 shops serve British cravings
description: A small, well stocked store for anglophiles.

title: F1 season snaps back into life
description: Next week Michael Schumacher will be testing in Spain at the same time as some other teams. At almost 39 years old, Schumacher has suddenly become a valuable asset for Ferrari, as the team prepares for the new season without traction control. I imagine Schumacher is also still capable of giving the team technical input worth Felipe Massa and Kimi Raikkonen combined.

title: Its Time to Play Name That Gargoyle
description: End of Quiz: Answer Revealed

title: Brennan and the Dread Heads
description: Hawaii quarterback Colt Brennan is two touchdown passes away from breaking Ty Detmers career college football record of 121. In this essay for The Quad, Brennan reflects on his career, and tips his helmet to his four dreadlocked receivers, who are affectionately known as The Dread Heads.

title: The Week Ahead
description: A look at this week's news events with Alison Smale of The International Herald Tribune in Paris.

title: The Bubble in Tom Perkinss Sails
description: Theres a lot of chatter these days about whether the current state of Silicon Valley qualifies as a bona fide bubble. The tone of this discussion implies that being in a bubble ushers in some sort of dark and dangerous age.

title: Governor Commences Wildfire Aftermath
description: Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger played cheerleader-in-chief as the wildfires raged in Southern California last month, lauding the efforts of emergency workers and steadfastly dismissing criticism of any kind. I think its not the right time now to point fingers or anything like this, he said on Oct. 30. Those that do are opportunists.

title: New Bus Shelter Is Vandalized by Acid
description: Updated, Nov. 7 | The citys new glass-walled bus shelters have received their baptism by acid.

title: A Good Days Work for Ron Paul
description: Republican presidential candidate Ron Paul, aided by an extraordinary outpouring of Internet support Monday, hauled in more than $4.2 million in nearly 24 hours, reports the Associated Press.

title: Book Review: Meat Market
description: Author Bruce Feldman will be signing copies of Meat Market in Manhattan at Borders on 32nd and 2nd on Nov. 6 at 7 p.m.

title: Thompson Joins Air Wars With New Ads
description: If his Meet the Press and Law & Order reruns arent enough for you, Fred D. Thompson is hitting the airwaves even harder starting tomorrow with ads in Iowa and on Fox News Channel.

title: How Will Schumers Mukasey Vote Play in New York?
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, is normally one of the most visible public officials, known for frequent press conferences, a steady stream of news releases and general availability for interviews. But over the past two weeks, he has largely avoided comment on one of the most significant votes of his time in the Senate  his decision today to buck his Democratic colleagues on sending the nomination of Michael B. Mukasey as attorney general  to the full Senate.

title: Easton, Conn.
description: A rural town in Fairfield County, Easton has well-kept antique homes, high-performing schools and areas with close-knit neighbors.

title: Bloomberg Holds Forth on Corn Subsidies
description: The government may have shut down for Election Day, but Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg isnt taking the day off from holding forth on presidential issues while denying that he is a candidate (for either governor or president). In an interview on MSNBC this morning about whether declared candidates like Hillary Rodham Clinton and John Edwards were pandering to Iowa voters by supporting subsidies for corn-based ethanol, Mr. Bloomberg sounded very much like a man who wants to be in that mix.

title: Whistling Past the Credit Crunch
description: Small can be beautiful too.

title: The Animated Life: Yours
description: A 1945 film and song transformed by the art of animation.

title: Images From The Picket Lines, Day Two
description: As the strike entered day two, Writers Guild of America, East members moved from Rockefeller Center in Manhattan to Silvercup Studios in Queens.

title: Berlin in Lights: Cabaret Fare to Go
description: Audience members at Carnegie Hall who attended the concert by Max Raabe and the Palast Orchester, which kicked off the Berlin in Lights Festival on Friday night, scooped up all the CDs of the ensemble that were being sold in the lobby and the gift shop. Clearly, Mr. Raabe, the dapper and stylishly nonchalant vocalist who headlines this 12-piece band, is not just a compelling performer but a savvy promoter.

title: Half-Hour Comedies Take A Hit
description: Most of the television shows immediately affected by the strike are half-hour comedies that are taped in front of a studio audience, Edward Wyatt reports. Yesterday production was shut down on the CBS comedies Two and a Half Men, The Big Bang Theory and Rules of Engagement, and the Fox sitcom Til Death. Why?

title: Any Way You Can Vote I Can Vote Better
description: It used to be that the road to the Presidency wound its circuitous route from Iowa to New Hampshire to South Carolina. Well, that road has been getting a lot circuitouser. Florida, Michigan and even Wyoming have all moved their primaries into January, sacred ground for the Big 3 states.

title: A Love, Fortified
description: Sometimes the process of reporting a story reawakens feelings that have been dormant for too long. For example, I know I love Madeira, but I really havent gone out of my way to drink any recently. Then I spent some time with Joseph DeLissio, the wine director at the River Cafe, who has put together an astounding collection of vintage Madeiras, which Ive written about in Wednesdays newspaper, and I remembered what I loved about them in the first place.

title: Is Burning Coal a Patriotic Duty?
description: Coal companies and utilities have tried a new approach in defending black combustible rock as the fuel of the future, at least in Kansas.

title: Jets Ben Graham, Daddy Dearest
description: Jets punter Ben Graham welcomed his third child into the world Monday at 7:15 p.m., and the birth just happened to coincide with the Jets bye week. Another example of how, for punters, timing is everything.

title: Separation Anxiety as IAC Plans Spinoffs
description: Life wont necessarily be easy for IAC/InterActiveCorps corporate offspring.

title: The Beatle and the M.T.A. Board Member
description: It would seem improbable for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to be fodder for the British tabloids. But the London newspapers  and now The Daily News and The New York Post  are in a tizzy today with reports that Paul McCartney is having a romantic relationship with Nancy Shevell, who was appointed by Gov. George E. Pataki to the M.T.A. board in 2001.

title: The Week Ahead
description: A look at this week's news events with Alison Smale of The International Herald Tribune in Paris.

title: Strikers: Not Writing, But Still Blogging
description: Even when theyre on strike, Writers Guild of America members are still writers at heart. Perhaps for that reason, several television screenwriters and show-runners have been busy blogging about the situation.

title: Satellite Dishes and Pakistans Media Blackout
description: When the president of Pakistan declared emergency rule over the weekend and the government halted private television broadcasts, several networks there turned to the Internet to stream news coverage of the political crisis. One network chief explained the situation this way:

title: New Ads Aim at Single Women
description: Sometimes referred to as the Sex and the City vote, single women get stereotyped out there as more into their clothes, their shoes or their work, (not necessarily in that order), rather than their voting rights.

title: Berlin in Lights: Deutsche Grammophon Serves Up an Appetizer
description: Nov. 13, the official release date of a new recording from the Berlin Philharmonic, comes right in the middle of Berlin in Lights. Did the savvy folks at Deutsche Grammophon purposefully link the recording to Carnegie Halls festival, in which the Berlin Philharmonic plays a major part? Or is this a potentially profitable coincidence?

title: Approaching Panic
description: The financial guarantors are the latest object of fear and loathing on Wall Street. They have guaranteed zillions of dollars of obligations, and some of them are not going to work out well.

title: A Look at the Third Base Market
description: At long last, the Yankees had their meeting with Scott Boras today. It was outside the bank of elevators at the Hyatt Grand Cypress here at the general managers meetings in Orlando, Fla.

title: Leaping from FR.OG
description: Didier Virot, the Jean-Georges-trained chef who landed at FR.OG in SoHo this spring, has already hopped away, Florence Fabricant reports in tomorrows Off The Menu.

title: Winter of our discontent
description: Oil at $97!

title: An Election Day Thought: Time to Change How Judges are Selected
description: Today is election day, and in Pennsylvania, a nasty, high-spending race for two seats on the state Supreme Court is coming to a close. No matter who wins, judicial integrity, independence, and impartiality are already the losers.

title: Cell Phones  Here Come the Jammers
description: One of the Times news stories that has generated the most buzz this week has been this one, reporting on the increasing use of cell phone jammers to cut off conversations of annoying people blabbing on the cell phones in public places.

title: Giuliani on Biden
description: Brian Williams asked Mr. Giuliani about his feud with Senator Joseph Biden.

title: Giuliani Talks About Clinton
description: Brian Williams interviewed Rudolph W. Giuliani in Washington, D.C. Tuesday for a segment on NBC Nightly News.

title: Giuliani on Iraq
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani discussed the troop surge in Iraq.

title: Giuliani on Kerik
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani answered questions about Bernard Kerik, his former police commissioner.

title: Video: NBC Interview With Giuliani
description: Brian Williams interviewed Rudolph W. Giuliani today for a segment that will air at 6:30 p.m. Eastern on tonights NBC Nightly News. The former New York mayor talked about Hillary Rodham Clinton, Joseph Bidens comments about him during the recent Democratic debate, the situation in Iraq and his former police commissioner. Watch excerpts of the interview from NBC:

title: U.N. Panel Says Mercenary Ranks Growing
description: A lot of people call us mercenaries, complained Erik D. Prince, chief of Blackwater USA, at a House committee hearing last month.

title: The Good Doctor
description: Congressman Ron Paul, still trading at 8.7 on InTrade since raising more than $4.07 million yesterday, may already be our Internet president.

title: The Politics of Coal
description: We just thought it would be worthwhile to cross-post to another sib-blog, DotEarth, where politics has entered into the realm of coal.

title: Its Been a Hard Days Blog
description: What we are reading elsewhere

title: More Images From The Picket Lines, Day Two
description: The Associated Press reports:

title: CBGB to Become Mens Fashion Boutique
description: The mens fashion designer John Varvatos  confirmed today that he is building a 3,200-square-foot boutique in the Bowery storefront that housed CBGB, the legendary punk-rock nightclub that closed in October 2006.

title: Baby, Its Cold Inside
description: AMANA, Iowa  The temperature is 41 degrees here this afternoon. The wind has been blowing for a few days now. No, winter hasnt technically arrived, but a 33 degree wind chill makes it seem as though that season is not far away.

title: Nightline May Be a Strike Beneficiary
description: With Jay Leno of NBC and David Letterman of CBS sidelined by a writers strike, ABCs 11:35 p.m. alternative  the half-hour newscast Nightline  may stand to benefit.

title: Kucinich Pushes Cheney Impeachment
description: Its hard to know which effort has longer odds, the bid by Representative Dennis Kucinich, Democrat of Ohio, to become president of the United States, or his bid to unseat Vice President Dick Cheney by trying to get him impeached.

title: Judith Giuliani in New Hampshire
description: Judith Giuliani spoke Nov. 6 at the Vermont-New Hampshire chapter of Susan G. Komen for the Cure group.

title: Schreibers Notes: Will Boras Blink?
description: Everybody is making fun of Alex Rodriguez (calling him Me-Rod) for intruding on the last game World Series when his agent, Scott Boras, announced he would opt out of his contract with the Yankees.

title: Clandestine Dining
description: Scenes from "One Pot," a series of underground, movable dinners run by Michael Hebberoy in Seattle.

title: Ask About New York Foster Care
description: In a series called A History of Neglect [Part 1 | Part 2 | Part 3], Leslie Kaufman and Benjamin Weiser of The Times reported this week on how New York City began an experiment in foster care two decades ago that was aimed at better protecting the citys most vulnerable black and Latino children.

title: Colbert vs. Obama vs. S.C.
description: Stephen Colberts presidential candidacy may have been a joke to many, but apparently some in South Carolina took it seriously enough to lobby Democratic officials in the early primary state to deny him a spot on the states ballot.

title: Bye Bye Independence
description: Accounting rules set by the International Accounting Standards Board are on the verge of taking over the world. Chris Cox, the chairman of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, is pushing through American acceptance of them before it is clear if they are being applied on a consistent basis.

title: Edwards Revises Ad for New Hampshire
description: DES MOINES  The Edwards campaign retooled parts of the television commercial that was released in Iowa last week and broadcast it today in New Hampshire. The 60-second commercial is based on the same themes: support for American workers and the story of the decision Mr. Edwards and his wife made to continue with the race for the Democratic nomination despite the return of her cancer.

title: Yours
description: Yours began with a soundie, a film made for projection in a film jukebox in 1945.

title: Islamabad's Lawyers Defiant
description: The ousted Supreme Court chief justice urged lawyers to defy Gen. Pervez Musharraf's state of emergency in Pakistan.

title: Red Bulls Players React to Arenas Exit
description: It was somber Tuesday at the Red Bulls training facility of the campus of Montclair State University in Little Falls, N.J., less than 24 hours after it was announced that Bruce Arena, the clubs coach and sporting director, had left the club.

title: Tracing My Roots Back to Korea
description: Returning to Korea for the first time since my adoption was a defining moment in my life. It took 20 years to muster the courage to confront the most basic of questions: Who am I? Where did I come from?

title: The Politics of Punctuality
description: Updated | 12:37 a.m.

title: Islamabad's Lawyers Defiant
description: The ousted Supreme Court chief justice urged lawyers to defy Gen. Pervez Musharraf's state of emergency in Pakistan.

title: Project to Capture CO2 With Plankton Puts to Sea
description: The WeatherBird II, a 115-foot private research vessel, has put to sea from Florida as part of a novel and contentious effort to commercialize the removal of heat-trapping carbon dioxide from the atmosphere by triggering blooms of plankton.

title: Port Authority Sets Its Sights on Robust List of Projects
description: For decades, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey was a bastion of patronage and a hulking bureaucracy living on its past success in building much of the regions transportation network.

title: A Second Chance for Ex-Offenders
description: If past patterns hold true, more than half of the 650,000 prisoners released this year will be back behind bars by 2010. With the prison population exploding and the price of incarceration now topping $60 billion a year, states are rightly focusing on ways to reduce recidivism. Congress can give these efforts a boost by passing the Second Chance Act, which would provide crucial help to people who have paid their debts to society.

title: Sarkozy Is Greeted Warmly by Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 President Nicolas Sarkozy of France was greeted with cheers and standing ovations in the United States Congress today, a sign that France was forgiven for opposing the American-led war in Iraq.

title: A High-Five for Roethlisberger
description: It was clear as the Pittsburgh Steelers dismantled the vaunted Baltimore Ravens pass defense Monday night that Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger, below right, was having a special game, but it was not obvious just how unusual it was.

title: Pass the Peruvian F.T.A.
description: Congressional Democrats took their time, but more than a year after it was originally signed, the free trade agreement between the United States and Peru is finally due for a vote in the House of Representatives today.

title: Correction: Pork With Beans, Smoke and Spice to Match the Red
description: Because of an editing error, the Pairing column last Wednesday, about a Portuguese dish that inspired a recipe for a pork stew, referred incorrectly to Mealhada, the town that specializes in the dish. It is not at the mouth of the Douro River.

title: New York Public Librarys Donnell Branch to Share Space With Hotel
description: Shhh, this is a hotel.

title: 2007 Is Deadliest Year for U.S. Troops in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 6  Six American soldiers were killed in three separate attacks in Iraq on Monday, the military said Tuesday, taking the number of deaths this year to 852. The toll makes 2007 the deadliest year of the war for United States troops.

title: Rediscovering a Hidden Island
description: Our kayaks were beached above high tide. The sun had set. We looked out over one of the most beautiful shorelines in the Caribbean. I had just fired up a cigar when we spotted it: a boats searchlight scanning the shore beyond the next point.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A map with a sports article on Monday about a hockey fans 30-day journey to attend a game at every National Hockey League arena misidentified the hometown of the Minnesota Wild. It is St. Paul, not Minneapolis.

title: Overweight People Found Less Likely to Die From Some Diseases
description: About two years ago, a group of federal researchers reported that overweight people have a lower death rate than people who are normal weight, underweight or obese. Now, investigating further, they found out which diseases are more likely to lead to death in each weight group.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,838 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday:

title: More Met Opera Transmissions in More Sites
description: The second season of Metropolitan Opera: Live in High Definition will begin on Dec. 15 with a presentation of Gounods Romo et Juliette, starring Anna Netrebko and Roberto Alagna (right)  and conducted by Plcido Domingo. It will be the first of eight live opera transmissions to be seen in more than 600 movie theaters, arts center and universities in North America, Australia, Europe and Japan  triple the number of last years sites, the Met said. Ticket sales in North America begin on Friday. The 2007-8 series will include a New Years Day presentation of Humperdincks Hansel and Gretel, as well as Verdis Macbeth, Puccinis Manon Lescaut, Wagners Tristan und Isolde, Brittens Peter Grimes, Donizettis Fille du Rgiment and Puccinis Bohme. Among the participating movie houses is the Walter Reade Theater in Lincoln Center. The Live in High Definition program will expand in New York into public schools in all five boroughs.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in the Today in Business column in Business Day yesterday with a brief report about an executive change at Time Warner was published in error. The picture was of Charles O. Prince III, the departing chief executive of Citigroup  not Jeffrey L. Bewkes, the newly chosen chief executive of Time Warner.

title: The Carbon Calculus
description: A CHANGE is in the works that could go a long way toward making alternative energy less alternative, and more attractive to consumers and businesses.

title: Kentucky Governor Loses to Democrat
description: Dogged by political scandal in his first term, Gov. Ernie Fletcher of Kentucky, a Republican, lost his bid for re-election yesterday to Steve Beshear.

title: G.M. Takes $39 Billion Charge on Tax Offset
description: DETROIT, Nov. 6  General Motors said Tuesday that it would take a $39 billion noncash charge in the third quarter to remove net deferred tax assets from its books.

title: Seagoing Climate Experiment Begins
description: The Weatherbird II, a 115-foot private research vessel, has put to sea from Florida as part of a novel  and contentious  effort to commercialize the removal of heat-trapping carbon dioxide from the atmosphere using blooms of plankton.

title: For Suppliers, the Pressure Is On
description: HOME DEPOT did not sell organic roses this past Mothers Day. Why? There were no cheap local ones available. And the amount of carbon that would have been emitted by shipping cheap ones from Venezuela seemed to eclipse any environmental benefit of avoiding pesticides and such.

title: Conservative Authors Sue Publisher
description: Five authors have sued the parent company of Regnery Publishing, a Washington-based imprint of conservative books, alleging that the company deprives its writers of royalties by selling their books at a steep discount to book clubs and other organizations owned by the same parent company.

title: Foreign Firms Envision Wind Farms Dotting the U.S.
description: THE European Union has taken the lead on many climate change issues  from ratifying the Kyoto Protocol to passing laws to require and encourage the development of renewable sources of energy. Why, then, are so many European energy companies looking to the United States for investment opportunities?

title: Aiding the Environment, a Nanostep at a Time
description: SOME of the grandest ideas about how to preserve the environment involve molecular-scale engineering known as nanotechnology. Such visions might inspire more confidence, though, if there were real products available to achieve them.

title: Bonuses Likely to Shrink for Many on Wall Street
description: Wall Street bonuses may be the latest victim of the subprime mortgage collapse and the tight credit market. Over all, bonuses are expected to be flat to down 15 percent, according to compensation experts and Wall Street executives.

title: Dining Briefs
description: NEW PLACES

title: Uzbekistan: Leader Nominated Again
description: Delegates at a congress of the Liberal Democratic Party voted unanimously to nominate President Islam A. Karimov to run in the Dec. 23 presidential election, the Interfax news agency reported. He is constitutionally barred from seeking a third seven-year term, and election officials have not yet explained the legal mechanism justifying his nomination.

title: Private Efforts to Preserve the Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Bus Shelter in Chelsea Is Defaced With Acid
description: The citys new glass-walled bus shelters have received their baptism by acid.

title: Brooklyn: Teenager Shot to Death
description: A 14-year-old boy was fatally shot shortly before 7 oclock last night in the lobby of a public housing complex in Bedford-Stuyvesant, the police said. The victim, Sunny Carter, was shot several times at 85 Tompkins Avenue, part of Tompkins Houses, where he lived in another building. He was taken to Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center and was pronounced dead on arrival. Investigators said it was too soon to comment on a motive or possible suspects.

title: Voters Are Split on Spending Measures
description: In Texas, voters were in a spending mood on Tuesday. In New Jersey and Oregon, they were not.

title: Soon, at a Nearby Theater, Opera From La Scala
description: In a new venture, opera from Teatro alla Scala in Milan and two other renowned Italian houses will be shown at more than 60 theaters from coast to coast, beginning next month with Franco Zeffirellis production of Verdis Aida. The full lineup of high-definition broadcasts, through June, includes Wagners Tristan und Isolde, Donizettis Maria Stuarda, Verdis Traviata and Puccinis Trittico, all from La Scala, as well as Verdis Forza del Destino from Maggio Musicale in Florence, and Puccinis Rondine from La Fenice in Venice. In Manhattan Aida will be seen at Symphony Space on Dec. 2. Tickets for the presentations will be $20. These screenings will be offered at different times in each theater, rather than being live broadcasts on a specific day at a specific time.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening This Week

title: Trade Deal With Peru Likely to Pass House Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  In a rare show of bipartisan cooperation, President Bush and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi appealed Tuesday for passage of a free-trade agreement with Peru in a vote scheduled for Wednesday in the House of Representatives.

title: Musharrafs Martial Plan
description: Islamabad, Pakistan

title: After Completing Marathon, a Runner Dies in His Home
description: Shortly after completing the New York City Marathon on Sunday, Dr. Matthew P. Hardy, a research scientist, returned to his Manhattan apartment and died. He was 50.

title: Bidding War for Rodriguez Needs 2 Teams
description: ORLANDO, Fla.

title: Correction: Recipe: Pork Grillades and Grits
description: A recipe for pork grillades and grits with an article last Wednesday about the New Orleans chef John Besh omitted the amount of butter that should be folded into the grits. One pound of butter should be used.

title: Turkish-Bred Prosperity Makes War Less Likely in Iraqi Kurdistan
description: DOHUK, Iraq, Nov. 6  Viewed from the outside, Iraqi Kurdistan looks close to war. Tens of thousands of Turkish troops are amassed on the border. And thousands of Iraqi Kurdish pesh merga fighters have taken up positions in the Mateen Mountains, ready for a counterattack, their local commanders say, should any Turkish operation hit civilians.

title: Germanys Soccer Power Echoes a League in Transition
description: MUNICH, Nov. 4  In Germanys top soccer league, the empire struck back with a vengeance. The question is whether F.C. Bayern Munich, the countrys most decorated club, can somehow manage to lead the entire league back to greatness.

title: Mushy: Handsome in Uniform
description: WASHINGTON

title: Thompsons Down-Home Pitch
description: This advertisement, the first for Fred D. Thompson since he announced his candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination, is to begin running today in Iowa and nationally on the Fox News Channel.

title: Living the Wild Life at College
description: ADIRONDACK PARK, N.Y.  On a recent afternoon, Katie Powers, 21, swam in the still water of Lake Massawepie, though the lakes temperature was somewhere in the 50s.

title: Financial Ground Has Shifted Under a Record Deal
description: The record price paid in January for the 41-story aluminum-clad office tower at 666 Fifth Avenue  $1.8 billion  was breathtaking, even by the standards of the heady Midtown Manhattan commercial real estate market.

title: Bushs Import-Safety Plan Is Detailed
description: A new Bush administration proposal to give the federal government sweeping authority over imports won plaudits yesterday as a step toward restoring public confidence in product safety. But some advocacy groups warned that unless the plan was backed by significant funds, it would prove meaningless.

title: The Not-Google Phone
description: Two of the biggest technology stories of 2007 have been stories about phones  the solid achievement of Apples iPhone, released during the summer, and the news, announced on Monday, that Google will help orchestrate, develop and fund a new open software standard for mobile phones. Some people were disappointed by Googles announcement, if only because there was no actual gadget to hold in their hands. But it was possibly as groundbreaking in its own way as the iPhone itself.

title: New York Democrats Say License Issue Had Little Effect
description: Democrats declared yesterday that Gov. Eliot Spitzers plan to give drivers licenses to illegal immigrants had not proved to be the electoral boon Republicans had hoped for in local elections, despite the Republicans aggressive efforts to exploit overwhelming public opposition to the proposal.

title: Salt Lake City Is Finding a Payoff in Conservation
description: SALT LAKE CITY

title: Democratic Rival Defeats Mayor in Mount Vernon
description: In a three-way race for mayor in Mount Vernon, N.Y., the Democratic challenger, Clinton I. Young Jr., defeated the incumbent, Ernest D. Davis, last night.

title: Vintage Madeiras Enduring Charms
description: AS the wine director of the River Caf in Brooklyn for almost 30 years, Joseph DeLissio has gladly sold vintage Champagnes and old Bordeaux, California cult wines and rare Burgundies. But about five years ago a terrible thing happened: he put some rare old Madeiras on the wine list  and sold them, too.

title: Fix-It Expert Will Lead a New Team at Citigroup
description: Citigroup, reeling from its exposure to billions in assets backed by subprime mortgages, has appointed a triage team led by one of Wall Streets best-known fix-it men.

title: Bush Brothers Firm Faces Inquiry Over Purchases
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  The inspector general of the Department of Education has said he will examine whether federal money was inappropriately used by three states to buy educational products from a company owned by Neil Bush, the presidents brother.

title: Paper Mills New Chief
description: The Paper Mill Playhouse, which has steadily regained its footing after a financial crisis in the spring almost shut it down, announced yesterday that it has appointed a new executive director, Mark W. Jones. For the last four years Mr. Jones has been the executive director of Shakespeare & Company in Lenox, Mass. He has his work cut out for him in Millburn, N.J., Paper Mills home, where the financial crunch has been addressed in the short term by a $3.5 million bank loan. The theater has been without an executive director since Michael Gennaro unexpectedly announced his resignation last November. Although Mr. Gennaros position at Paper Mill combined the duties of executive director and artistic director, the theater is moving back to the dual structure it once had. A permanent artistic director has not yet been named. Mr. Jones started on Monday.

title: Suicide Bomber Kills 26 in Northern Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 6  A suicide bomber threw himself at a delegation of lawmakers visiting a town in northern Afghanistan Tuesday, killing at least 26 people, including a leading opposition figure, and wounding scores more, many of them schoolchildren forming a welcome parade, local and regional Afghan officials said.

title: F. Maynard Sundman, Stamp Dealer, Dies at 92
description: F. Maynard Sundman, a stamp and coin dealer whose innovative mail-order marketing, using everything from comic books to matchbook covers, introduced millions to the once exclusive worlds of philately and numismatics, died Oct. 31 in Littleton, N.H. He was 92.

title: Corruption Scandal Spreads at Samsung
description: SEOUL, Nov. 6  A corruption scandal at the Samsung Group, the South Korean conglomerate, widened Tuesday as prosecutors opened a formal investigation into charges that its chairman masterminded a broad scheme of bribery and illegal transactions.

title: House Steps Up Confrontation With Bush Over Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  A majority of House Republicans joined Democrats this evening in escalating a confrontation with President Bush over federal spending as the House overrode Mr. Bushs veto of a popular water projects measure.

title: Staten Island District Attorney Is Re-elected in One of Citys Few Contested Races
description: Daniel M. Donovan Jr., the Staten Island district attorney, was overwhelmingly re-elected yesterday following a contentious campaign in which he lost the support of his former boss and political benefactor, James P. Molinaro, the borough president.

title: Manhattan: Man Sought in 17 Bank Robberies
description: The police are seeking a man suspected of 17 bank robberies in Manhattan and the Bronx since May 2006. On Monday, the man entered the Sovereign Bank at 169 Seventh Avenue in Manhattan about 5:20 p.m. and gave a note to a teller demanding cash. He is described as black, with a mustache and goatee, 40 to 45 years old, about 5-foot-3 to 5-foot-5. The police ask anyone with information to call 800-577-TIPS (800-577-8477).

title: Bill Clinton and 2 Democrats Spar Over Comment on Debate
description: Bill Clintons suggestion that his wife faced a Republican-style Swift boat attack during and after the last Democratic debate drew a rebuke yesterday from Senator Barack Obama, who said, I was pretty stunned by that statement.

title: A Guitar-Rock Sandwich With a Soft Acoustic Center
description: Eclecticism can be a curse as well as a blessing for any record label, just as it can for any artist. For Recall Records, a Paris independent that celebrated its 10th anniversary at the Blender Theater at Gramercy on Monday, the philosophy of difference has mostly been a good thing.

title: The Day After School Grades Come In, Parents Are Buzzing
description: It came up over lunch at a Middle Eastern cafe in Brooklyn Heights, where Todd Glass broke the news to Davide Cantoni that Public School 8, where their sons attend kindergarten, had received a C on the citys new report card for its schools. He urged his friend not to panic.

title: Despite Investigations, Perez Is Re-elected in Hartford
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 6  Mayor Eddie A. Perez was able to fight off a field of challengers to win re-election on Tuesday, despite a state investigation into his hiring of a city contractor that had raised questions of conflict of interest during the campaign.

title: Muscles Weakening, 11-Year-Old Speaks Through Painting
description: Thats me and him. He draw for me, Almaz Kelib says.

title: For Citigroups New Head, Focus Is Subprime Tangle
description: Until Sunday, Robert E. Rubin collected over $18 million a year as Wall Streets ultimate hands-off executive. On Monday, he had to roll up his sleeves.

title: Plugging In to Make a Joyful Noise Unto the Lord
description: VICTORVILLE, Calif.  Mike Day, singer and guitarist, gathered his rock band around him.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Robert J. Armband, chief executive and publisher at La Raza Newspaper, Chicago, part of ImpreMedia, is stepping down to spend more time with his family, he said, and pursue new projects and challenges. Mike Cano, marketing director at La Opinin, Los Angeles, a newspaper also owned by ImpreMedia, will succeed Mr. Armband for the time being.

title: Glitch at Start Muddles Times
description: Some of the 38,676 people who completed the New York City Marathon on Sunday were given incorrect finishing times, possibly affecting their attempts to qualify for the Boston Marathon.

title: TV Writer-Producers Show Solidarity
description: BURBANK, Calif., Nov. 7  They face off against each other each week in prime time: Desperate Housewives vs. Family Guy, Ugly Betty vs. My Name is Earl and Private Practice vs. Bionic Woman.

title: Kentucky Governor Loses to Democrat
description: Dogged by political scandal in his first term, Gov. Ernie Fletcher of Kentucky, a Republican, lost his bid for re-election yesterday to Steve Beshear.

title: Manhattan: Minor Injuries in Subway Crash
description: A subway operator received minor injuries yesterday when his train hit a wooden barrier at the end of a track, transit officials said. The southbound M train had just made its final stop and was not carrying any passengers, the officials said. The train crashed shortly before 11 a.m. in a tunnel just south of the Chambers Street station. The driver, who was not identified, was able to walk unassisted, and was taken to St. Vincents Hospital Manhattan, fire officials said.

title: Warning on Impact of China and India Oil Demand
description: LONDON, Nov. 7  A leading international energy agency today urged oil-producing countries to replenish crude oil inventories in light of a record oil price.

title: Republicans Join Vote to Override Water Bill Veto
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  Congressional Democrats escalated a confrontation with President Bush over federal spending on Tuesday as the House overrode Mr. Bushs veto of a popular water projects measure and approved a $215 billion bill to pay for health, education, labor and veterans programs despite a veto threat.

title: Letters
description: Ancient Traditions

title: The Mystery Finger
description: The finger has been identified. The digit that the guitarist Jimmy Page fractured, forcing a two-week postponement of Led Zeppelins reunion concert, was his left pinky. He broke it in a fall after tripping on a stone slab in his garden, he told the BBC. Its a nuisance because its really needed, he said, adding that the damage was not permanent. Which finger was not specified in the vague news release the band issued on Thursday announcing the delay. But the splint was noticeable when Mr. Page accepted a Living Legend honor at the Classic Rock awards in London on Monday night.

title: Shuttle Discovery Lands Safely
description: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla. Nov. 7  The shuttle Discovery glided to a safe landing here Wednesday, bringing to a close an eventful mission that combined challenging space station construction and emergency repairs.

title: On Mukasey: Saying No to Schumers Yes
description: To the Editor:

title: The Meatloaf Conundrum, Solved
description: MEATLOAF is as firmly ensconced in the pantheon of American comfort foods as mashed potatoes and macaroni and cheese. Its also the hardest to get just right. That Betty Crocker archetype  moist and juicy ground meat seasoned barely sweet and spicy with onions, ketchup and Worcestershire sauce  is too often darkened by the school-lunch reality of dense, dry meat that needs more ketchup on the side to make it palatable.

title: Afghan Struggle to Change Poppy Fields Into Roads
description: Joel Hafvenstein returned to Afghanistan in late 2004 armed with nothing but good intentions. Employed by Chemonics, a private company with a contract from the United States Agency for International Development, he was part of a team trying to discourage cultivation of the opium poppy by providing an alternative income for poor farmers.

title: Texas: No Bid Chosen for Wildlife Preserve
description: The Texas School Land Board did not choose to award a state-owned wildlife preserve in West Texas to a private bidder or require that a winning bid allow public hunting, as the states land commissioner, Jerry Patterson, had insisted. Instead, the three-member board, which includes Mr. Patterson, chose to keep the two current bids open while giving the National Park Service 90 days to present an acquisition proposal on the 9,270-acre tract, the Christmas Mountains Ranch.

title: Facebook Is Marketing Your Brand Preferences (With Your Permission)
description: FACEBOOK wants to put your face on advertisements for products that you like.

title: Bronx: Standoff With Police Officers
description: A search for a suspected killer in the Bronx early yesterday turned into a six-hour hostage situation and ended with the arrest of Marlon Sanders, 31, of Queens, on charges of second-degree murder, the police said. Shortly after 3 a.m., detectives went to a home at 4445 Williamsbridge Road in Morris Park in search of Mr. Sanders, who was suspected of fatally shooting Jamal Leavy, 37, of Queens, on Monday, the police said. When they arrived at the home, Mr. Sanders had a woman and her two children captive, but they were removed unharmed about 9 a.m., the police said.

title: Forced to Run Straight, a River Must Now Twist
description: KUSHIRO, Japan  In the early 1980s, engineers straightened out stretches of the Kushiro River, which had meandered some 100 miles under Hokkaidos big sky here in northern Japan, flowing through green hill country and rural towns, winding through the nations largest wetland and this port citys downtown before emptying into the Pacific Ocean.

title: Sarkozy Throws Open His Arms to Bush, and U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  Frances president, Nicolas Sarkozy, burst onto the Washington scene on Tuesday, clearly reveling in his first official visit to the White House and asking the United States to embrace him as a friend.

title: The Knicks Win a Good, Clean Fight
description: There was blood on the baseline and tension along the sidelines, as anyone might have expected when two teams that brawled ferociously 11 months ago reunited last night. But the blood came without violence and the tension was purely organic, produced by a tight, highly entertaining game on the Madison Square Garden court.

title: Nets Build a Lead, Then Hold Off Hawks
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 6  The Nets play their home games at a renamed, repainted arena that squats in the middle of a huge construction zone and is ringed by what seems like miles of temporary chain-link fence.

title: Telling a Tale of Torment, Wordlessly
description: The poor stepchild of the movie industry, what we loosely call experimental film, tends to be banished to the fringes of festivals and out-of-the-way art houses. As a result, the opportunities for mainstream audiences to experience the unconventional are tragically few.

title: Lottery Numbers
Bush Urges Musharraf to Return Pakistan to Civilian Rule
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7  President Bush telephoned President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan today to urge him to return his country to civilian rule as soon as possible.

title: Former Beatle Linked to Member of M.T.A. Unit
description: It would seem improbable for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to be fodder for the British tabloids. But the London newspapers were in a tizzy yesterday with reports that Paul McCartney was having a romantic relationship with Nancy Shevell, who was appointed by Gov. George E. Pataki to the authoritys board in 2001.

title: Within the Fed, Resistance to Further Rate Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  Even if the economy slows sharply in the final quarter of this year, some policy makers at the Federal Reserve are opposed to cutting rates again at their next meeting, in December.

title: From a Palette of Rubble, a Misty Grove, With Room to Run
description: The first time he walked through the broken lot on South Oxford Street in Brooklyn, Emmanuel Thingue, a landscape architect for the Parks and Recreation Department, took the measure of the ground he had to work with. It added up to a bit more than an acre of rubble and weeds, a palette of 52,230 square feet that crunched beneath his shoes.

title: Mums the Word: We Found a Greener Gas
description: PSYCHOLOGISTS and Wall Street traders have long known it: people and markets act on perception, whether it clashes with reality or not.

title: Tonight, Patronizing Language. Enjoy.
description: DINING out nightly has taught me many things, including this: Nothing kills enjoyment like too many mentions of it.

title: A Little Composition and a Little Archaeology
description: The ability to read the score of a complex orchestral composition is by no means a common skill. But even to the untrained eye, the manuscript of the Russian composer Alfred Schnittkes Symphony No. 9 would speak volumes.

title: Outrageous? Hes Heard That Before
description: Seattle

title: Chemical Industry 1, Public Safety 0
description: Air travelers are asking for trouble if they show up for a flight with 3.5 ounces of shampoo in their carry-on bags. But the Department of Homeland Security has decided that the government should not even trouble chemical plants to account for the storage of anything under 2,500 pounds of deadly chlorine. The departments new rules on reporting stockpiles of toxic chemicals, issued last week, have certainly made the industry happy. They should make the public worried.

title: In Long Writers Strike, New York Would Fare Better Than Los Angeles, a Study Says
description: When television and movie writers started walking picket lines in Manhattan and Los Angeles on Monday, their bicoastal protest highlighted the role the two cities play as the hubs of Americas arts and entertainment economy.

title: Report Links 3 Players to the Use of Steroids
description: Three more current or former major league baseball players have been connected in a published report to shipments of performance-enhancing drugs.

title: U.S. Prosecutors to Seek Indictment of Kerik
description: Federal prosecutors are scheduled to seek a grand jury indictment on Thursday of Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York City police commissioner, on a list of charges that include tax fraud, corruption and conspiracy counts, according to people who have been briefed on the case.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about the intentions of Prime Minister Agim Ceku of Kosovo to declare the countrys independence if agreement on its future is not reached with Serbia misstated Mr. Cekus age. He is 47, not 57.

title: Hartford Senators Seek Subpoena Power in Inquiry
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 6  A six-member bipartisan Senate committee investigating the conduct of the former Republican minority leader voted on Tuesday to ask the full Senate for subpoena power in considering whether to expel him for asking a trash hauler with alleged mob ties to threaten his granddaughters husband.

title: The Road to the White House Is Paved With Parodies
description: Trolling the Internet, Laura Bush stumbles across a Democratic candidates Web site and bursts into an exquisite song about the passion between members of rival factions. Tweaking the words to Maria from West Side Story, she sings: The most beautiful name I ever heard  Obama! Obama, Obama, Obama!

title: Rosanne Cash to Have Brain Surgery
description: The singer Rosanne Cash, 52, the daughter of Johnny Cash, announced yesterday that she is to undergo brain surgery at New York Presbyterian Hospital for a rare but benign condition and must cancel the final four concerts of her current tour, The Associated Press reported. Manhattan Records, her label, said Ms. Cash, who lives in New York, is expected to make a full recovery and resume recording and touring in the spring to promote her Grammy-nominated album, Black Cadillac. Earlier her singing career was interrupted for more than two years by polyps on her vocal cords. ... The rocker Meat Loaf has canceled his European tour after developing a cyst on his vocal cords, Reuters reported. In a statement Meat Loaf, whose real name is Marvin Lee Aday, said: It really breaks my heart not to be able to perform these shows. But I have to do what the doctors tell me so I can look forward to healing and coming back strong in 2008. Let me dispel any rumors before they start  I will be back. The statement said most such cysts require surgery, but voice therapy is normally conducted to decide if it is necessary. Four to six weeks are needed to make a determination.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Soon, at a Nearby Theater, Opera From La Scala

title: Dealer Repatriates Art
description: Italian officials, trumpeting another victory in their drive against the illegal traffic in antiquities, yesterday displayed eight Etruscan or Roman statues, bronze figurines and vases, above, they said were looted but had been returned by a New York art dealer, The Associated Press reported. The artifacts, valued at more than $500,000, were bought at auction by the dealer, Jerome Eisenberg of Royal Athena Gallery. Gen. Giovanni Nistri, who leads the art theft squad of the Italian national military police, said Mr. Eisenberg was unaware that the pieces had been looted, and when the Italian authorities showed him evidence, he saw it was right to return them.

title: Cuts Urged in Chinas and Indias Energy Growth
description: Chinas and Indias surging fuel consumption poses a growing challenge to the worlds energy systems and, unless curbed, will strain global oil trade, push up prices and lead to substantially higher carbon dioxide emissions in coming decades, according to a report by an influential energy organization scheduled for release today.

title: Stages Second Serving of Louisiana Gumbo
description: The Brothers Size, which opened at the Public Theater in January as part of its Under the Radar Festival, has reopened at the Public,  425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village; (212) 967-7555. It is running through Dec. 23. Following are excerpts from Jason Zinomans review, which appeared in The New York Times on Jan. 20.

title: Pakistani Lawyers Angered as Hope for Change Faded
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 6  Behind the public rage of Pakistans lawyers, who protested for a second day on Tuesday, lies a long-smoldering resentment toward the countrys military president, who at first held out promise for educated, politically moderate Pakistanis, but steadily squandered their support.

title: Correction: Industry Money Fans Debate on Fish
description: An article on Oct. 17, about a public health group that received money from the fishing industry and then recommended that women of childbearing age eat more fish despite fears of mercury contamination, referred imprecisely to the position of a Web site, realmercuryfacts.com, that also received money from the fishing industry. Although the Web site raises questions about studies that focus on the dangers of mercury in seafood, it does not directly dispute government warnings about mercury in seafood.

title: Students Call Protest Punishment Too Harsh
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 6  A school superintendents decision to suspend, and perhaps expel, about two dozen students who took part in a protest against the Iraq war at a suburban high school drew criticism Tuesday from the students and their parents, who demanded that their children be allowed to return to classes.

title: A 1-Yard Catch, a 50-Yard Receiving Line for Jets Kowalewski
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 6  Joe Kowalewski scored more style points than actual points with his first N.F.L. touchdown and the ensuing celebration.

title: A Daughter Discovers Branches of the Family Tree Pruned by Her Father
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 6  In a white-box living room in an apartment on lower St. Charles Avenue here, the dining table was set for a family party: plastic bowls of chips, dip and salsa; a plastic bag of sepia-toned family photographs waiting to be opened; and a copy of Bliss Broyards new book, One Drop: My Fathers Hidden Life  A Story of Race and Family Secrets.

title: Military Bill Approved, but Without Iraq Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  House and Senate negotiators approved a $459 billion military spending bill on Tuesday, but rejected a Republican bid to provide $70 billion more to continue fighting the war in Iraq without any restrictions.

title: Senate Committee Approves Mukasey Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  The Senate Judiciary Committee voted on Tuesday to approve the nomination of Michael B. Mukasey as attorney general despite opposition from most of the committees Democrats over Mr. Mukaseys refusal to label a harsh interrogation technique used on terrorist suspects as torture.

title: Causes of Death Are Linked to a Persons Weight
description: About two years ago, a group of federal researchers reported that overweight people have a lower death rate than people who are normal weight, underweight or obese. Now, investigating further, they found out which diseases are more likely to lead to death in each weight group.

title: CSX Lawyers Says They Cannot Find Key Witness in Asbestos Case
description: Lawyers for the CSX Transportation Corporation, which is fighting costly asbestos claims, say they have been unable to find a crucial witness in a case, a doctor whom they accuse of fabricating scores of medical evaluations.

title: Life After Rodriguez May Include Cabrera
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 6  The Yankees finally had their long-awaited summit with Scott Boras at the general managers meetings Tuesday. Boras was returning from a workout, drenched in sweat, and he shook hands with General Manager Brian Cashman near a bank of elevators. Then they went their separate ways.

title: Ousted Chief Justice in Pakistan Urges Defiance
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 6  As lawyers protested for a second day in Pakistan on Tuesday, the ousted chief justice of the countrys Supreme Court urged them to continue to defy de facto martial law imposed by the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf.

title: Frank Viola, Leader in Sport of Racing Pigeons, Dies at 87
description: Frank Viola, one of the grand old men of a grand old New York sport  pigeon racing  died on Oct. 3 at his home in the Bath Beach section of Brooklyn. He was 87.

title: At 90, Biaggi Offers Reminders of Survival as Well as Service
description: When Mario Biaggi, the revered Bronx congressman, was about to be sentenced in a racketeering case in 1988, he declared in court that the hostile testimony and unflattering publicity were punishment enough.

title: Fears Over Aftermath of Mexico Floods
description: VILLAHERMOSA, Mexico, Nov. 6  Many parts of this city remained underwater on Tuesday, more than a week after torrential rain swelled rivers that then burst their banks, as the authorities and residents expressed concern about the potential for looting and for outbreaks of disease.

title: Conservation at the Touch of a Button
description: TALK about remote control.

title: In Foster Care Review, Vows of Help and Vigilance
description: John B. Mattingly became New York Citys child welfare commissioner aiming to bring accountability to the dozens of private agencies the city paid hundreds of millions of dollars each year to care for foster children.

title: Some Television Writer-Producers Side With Guild
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 6  Hollywood writers and the studios that produce the most popular programs on television began tightening the screws on each other Tuesday, the second day of the first industrywide strike in nearly two decades.

title: Taming the Guzzlers That Power the World Wide Web
