description: BEHIND every Google search, direct deposit, MapQuest request and rant on a blog is a data center crammed with machines called servers and, behind them, a power plant.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about a lawsuit alleging that a former lawyer for the New York State court system was fired for accusing her superiors of unethical conduct misstated the jurisdiction of the First Department of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court. It covers the Bronx and Manhattan, not most of New York City and Westchester.

title: Wiretapping and the Telecoms
description: To the Editor:

title: When Trust in an Expert Is Unwise
description: A few years ago, an economics graduate student named Henry Schneider drove his dads old Subaru station wagon up to Montreal. He had heard about a Canadian consumer interest group that had done undercover investigations of auto-repair shops, and he wanted to try a more academic version of its experiment.

title: Little-Known Entrepreneurs Putting China Near Top of Billionaires List
description: SHANGHAI, Nov. 6  The United States has more billionaires than any other country: 415 by the last count of Forbes magazine.

title: Conservative Authors Sue Publisher
description: Five authors have sued the parent company of Regnery Publishing, a Washington imprint of conservative books, charging that the company deprives its writers of royalties by selling their books at a steep discount to book clubs and other organizations owned by the same parent company.

title: On a Greek Isle, Preserving Tradition
description: POROS, Greece

title: Islanders Come Alive in Third and Rangers Falter on Road
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., Nov. 6  By the third period Tuesday night, Rangers Coach Tom Renney was starting to feel edgy about how his team was playing against the Islanders. Yes, the Rangers were nursing their familiar one-goal lead, and even when they gave it up, they took another one-goal lead.

title: The Spirits of TV Past, Present and Future
description: No, Virginia, there may not be any new Christmas specials starring Eva Longoria as Slutty Santa and Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen as elves. And while many viewers may consider that potential consequence of the writers strike a cause for seasonal celebration, its not as merry a prospect as one might think.

title: For Fiji Water, a Big List of Green Goals
description: Fiji Water, with annual sales of about $150 million, is but a drop in the bucket of the $15 billion domestic bottled-water industry. But little Fiji could make a big splash on the sustainability front.

title: Deadly Fires Expose Disorder in Putins Russia
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 6  Sergei Babayan was trapped. Minutes before, wisps of smoke had begun flowing through cracks in his classroom door at the private Moscow Institute of Government and Corporate Management.

title: Toy With Date-Rape Drug Recalled
description: HONG KONG, Wednesday, Nov. 7  A bead toy that just won an Australian Toy of the Year award was recalled by its manufacturer on Tuesday after media reports that a chemical in it turns into a powerful date-rape drug, GHB, when eaten.

title: Ex-Worker at AT&T Fights Immunity Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  When Mark Klein, then an AT&T technician in San Francisco, stumbled on a secret room apparently reserved for the National Security Agency inside an AT&T switching center, he hardly expected to be caught up in a national debate over the proper balance between American civil liberties and national security.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about circulation declines in the newspaper industry misstated the overall decline in Sunday circulation. The decline was 3.5 percent, not 4.6 percent. (Sunday circulation dropped 4.6 percent for the top 25 newspapers by circulation; the 3.5 percent figure was for more than 600 newspapers for which numbers were available.)

title: Death Toll in Afghan Bombing at 52
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 7  The death toll from a suicide bombing in northern Afghanistan rose to 52 on Wednesday, making it the worst single suicide bombing in the country since 2001, government officials said.

title: Pope Benedict Meets Saudi King at Vatican
description: ROME, Nov. 6  Pope Benedict XVI and King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia clasped hands at the Vatican on Tuesday in the first official meeting between a pope and a Saudi monarch, who is entrusted to protect Mecca, the birthplace of Muhammad and the center of the Islamic world.

title: Fidelio: From Opera House to Parlor to Concert Hall
description: The year 1902 had no CDs or DVDs, but it did have arrangers. Into them music publishers poured symphonies, operas, string quartets and oratorios, all to be ground to a consistency suitable for parlor piano. Monday nights parlor was the tiny performing space at the Austrian Cultural Forum, where Dennis Russell Davies and Maki Namekawa played Alexander Zemlinskys four-hand version of Beethovens Fidelio.

title: High-Priced Oil Adds Volatility to Power Scramble
description: As the price of oil surges toward a symbolic milestone of $100 a barrel  hitting $96.70 yesterday  it is creating new winners and losers across the globe.

title: What You Get for ...$500,000
description: Aiken, S.C.

title: Enzo Biagi, 87, Journalist Fired in Italian Political Fight, Is Dead
description: MILAN, Nov. 6 (Bloomberg News)  Enzo Biagi, the enduringly popular Italian journalist whose criticism of Silvio Berlusconi during the 2001 election campaign got him ousted from state television when Mr. Berlusconi became prime minister, died Tuesday in Milan. He was 87.

title: A More Direct Route to Spain
description: THE publicity pitch and chatter that attended the transformation of the not-so-old restaurant Urea into the not-exactly-new restaurant Pamplona boiled down to something like this: the chef Alex Urea gets real.

title: Getting a Lower Price, for Repairs You Dont Need
description: In his study of auto-repair shops, Henry Schneider varied what he told the mechanics in one important way. At half of the 40 Connecticut garages where he brought a Subaru station wagon for an inspection, he said that he and his (fictional) wife had just moved to town. At the other half, he said they were about to move to Chicago.

title: New Delhi Air Quality Is Worsening, Group Says
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 6  Air quality in New Delhi has deteriorated significantly in the past two years, exposing the capitals residents to heightened risk of a range of respiratory diseases, a leading environmental research group warned Tuesday.

title: New Jersey Voters Defeat Stem Cell Measure
description: TRENTON, Nov. 6  In a stunning defeat for Gov. Jon S. Corzine, New Jersey voters on Tuesday rejected a ballot measure that would have permitted the state to borrow $450 million for stem cell research.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A profile in Science Times yesterday about Col. John Holcomb, a trauma surgeon who heads the Armys Institute of Surgical Research, misspelled the surname of a former military physician who is the associate director of critical care medicine at Washington Hospital Center. He is Dr. Andrew F. Shorr, not Schorr.

title: Mrs. Giuliani, in Rare Solo Appearance, Campaigns Again
description: LEBANON, N.H., Nov. 6  Judith Giuliani returned to the campaign spotlight Tuesday to make a speech, one of the few without her husband at her side. At a breast cancer forum here, she pledged that a Giuliani administration would provide resources and support for people with cancer.

title: G.M. Posts Its Biggest Quarterly Loss
description: DETROIT, Nov. 7  General Motors reported a nearly $39 billion third-quarter loss today, its largest ever, after it took a huge noncash charge to write down deferred tax credits.

title: Morgan Stanley May Be Next to Write Down Assets
description: Now it is Morgan Stanleys turn.

title: Job Bias Case Turns on Filing Right Form
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  The age discrimination case that was argued before the Supreme Court on Tuesday turned on a hyper-technical issue that only an employment lawyer could love.

title: Proposal Gives More Power to F.D.A.
description: Regulators would get more authority over drugs sold without a prescription under a bill by three Democrats. The proposal would give the Food and Drug Administration power to quickly ban marketing of over-the-counter products linked to potential safety risks, said the lawmakers, Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Representatives Henry A. Waxman of California and Tom Allen of Maine.

title: Pakistans General Anarchy
description: London

title: 1937 Matisse Sells for $33.6 Million
description: Countering speculation that foreigners would emerge as the dominant buyers, Americans took home nearly half the art at Christies last night in the start to the fall auction season.

title: Pat Robertson Endorses Giuliani for President
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani scored a coup today by winning the support of Pat Robertson, who, as one of the nations best-known televangelists, could help Mr. Giuliani reassure Republicans who are wary of his support for abortion rights and gay rights.

title: Concert in North Korea
description: To the Editor:

title: Your Ad Here: Web Surprise Hits 08 Race
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  Visitors to Gay.com can sign up to find the perfect dating partner, advice on sex and how-to articles on same-sex marriage and parenting.

title: Abolish Electoral College
description: To the Editor:

title: A Printed Collection of Heroes Comics
description: The first 34 chapters of the continuing online comic book devoted to NBCs Heroes, a series about ordinary people dealing with extraordinary abilities, will be released today as a hardcover collection. The stories provide additional details about the characters backgrounds. The collection, published by DC Comics, includes an introduction by Masi Oka, the actor who plays the time-traveling Hiro. The book, which sells for $29.99, is available with a cover by Alex Ross or Jim Lee, two of the comic-book industrys most popular artists. The latest chapter of the online Heroes saga can be found at nbc.com/heroes/novels.

title: A Gallerys Money Crisis, and Shaken Trust
description: The artist Paul Resika remembers what someone who is well connected in the art world told him one day last spring as rumors were beginning to swirl about financial trouble at the Salander-OReilly Galleries. He also remembers his reaction.

title: Senator Questioning Ministries on Spending
description: Senator Charles E. Grassley, the ranking Republican on the Senate Finance Committee, is investigating six prominent evangelistic ministries to determine whether they have illegally used donations to finance opulent lifestyles.

title: A College Is Stalked by an Attitude
description: Like all truly scary horror stories, the tale told in Adrienne Kennedys Ohio State Murders leaves a lasting chill in the bones. Hours after seeing this short, sharp, quietly hypnotic play about an infanticide that ruptures a Midwestern winter in the 1950s, you might find yourself looking anxiously over your shoulder or starting awake with an unsettling thought or image in your head.

title: Gay Muslims Find Freedom, of a Sort, in the U.S.
description: SAN FRANCISCO  About 15 people marched alongside the Muslim float in this citys notoriously fleshy Gay Pride Parade earlier this year, with various men carrying the flags of Egypt, Lebanon, Palestine and Turkey and even Irans old imperial banner.

title: Preservations Progress
description: Lindsborg, Kan.

title: BlackRock Chief Is Said to Be Meeting Over Merrill
description: Laurence D. Fink, chairman and chief executive of BlackRock and the leading candidate to take over the job as head of Merrill Lynch, has met with the executive search firm responsible for filling the brokerage firms top seat, according to a person briefed on the discussions.

title: Toyota Reports Strong Profits
description: TOKYO, Nov. 7  Another quarter of higher profits at Toyota, Japans largest automaker, shows the companys growth remains in high gear despite soaring global fuel prices and signs of an economic slowdown in its biggest market, the United States.

title: House Approves Ban on Anti-Gay Discrimination
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7  The House approved a bill this evening granting broad protections against discrimination in the workplace for gay men, lesbians and bisexuals, a measure that supporters praised as the most important civil rights legislation since the adoption of the Americans with Disabilities Act in 1990 but that opponents said would result in unnecessary lawsuits.

title: M.L.B. Takes First Step to Add Instant Replay
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 6  With a 25-5 vote, general managers took the first step Tuesday to add instant replay to baseball games. The vote was a significant departure from previous votes at general managers meetings, where the issue had the support of, at best, half of those present.

title: Terrorism Raids Net 20 Suspects
description: Twenty suspected Islamic militants were arrested around Europe in an operation led by the Italian police to break up what it said was a cell recruiting suicide bombers for Iraq and Afghanistan. Among arrests in Britain, France and Portugal, the Italian authorities said they had arrested 11 men in northern Italy, most of them Tunisians. While the authorities said the group did not appear to be planning attacks inside Italy, they said they confiscated Al Qaeda manuals for making explosives, remote detonators, poisons and instructions on guerrilla techniques. Last month, Spain arrested six North Africans suspected of recruiting bombers to go to Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: Sidewalks of New York Become Premium Space
description: If you think New Yorks sidewalks seem more crowded than ever, you may be right: in some areas, there is less sidewalk square footage to go around.

title: Test to Guide Heart Treatment Inconclusive
description: A diagnostic test intended to identify patients who should receive heart defibrillators did not produce conclusive data, according to initial results from a clinical trial presented yesterday at the meeting of the American Heart Association.

title: Belgium: New No-Government Record
description: Belgium broke its own record for the longest period without a government as tensions continued among the countrys leaders, divided by language. Almost five months since national elections on June 10, Belgium marked 149 days without a government, beating a previous record set in 1988. As the deadlock continues, speculation is mounting that political divisions between the Flemish, who speak a form of Dutch and make up two-thirds of the population, and the Walloons, who speak French, could lead to Belgiums splitting up.

title: A Firsthand Experience Before Decision on Torture
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  The debate over torture here can get heated, as it did this month when a dispute over the legal status of waterboarding threatened to sink the nomination of Michael B. Mukasey as attorney general. Still, it usually remains a matter of strictly abstract legal analysis.

title: Protecting a Wild Patch of City Marshland
description: Simply the last best unprotected New York City coastal wetland, raved a coalition of 20 environmental groups.

title: Brooklyn: Man Charged After Fatal Crash
description: A Queens man was arrested yesterday after having struck and killed a pedestrian in Brooklyn about 5 a.m., the police said. The man, David Aldarondo, 59, of Ozone Park, was charged with criminally negligent homicide, speeding and running a red light, a spokesman for the Brooklyn district attorney said. The police said that Mr. Aldarondo, westbound on Atlantic Avenue, struck a pedestrian, Lillian Mustapha, 63, of East New York, at the Crescent Street intersection. She was pronounced dead at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, the police said.

title: Whats Black and White and Made in Queens?
description: Note by Note: The Making of Steinway L1037 follows the painstaking yearlong process of building and fine-tuning a handmade nine-foot concert grand piano in the Steinway companys factory in Astoria, Queens. A paean to the rewards of old-fashioned craftsmanship in an age of mechanization, the film, directed by Ben Niles, amounts to a de facto infomercial for Steinway & Sons, the 150-year-old company that is the biggest name in the high-end piano business. Steinway produces about 2,000 pianos a year, compared with the approximately 100 a day by other companies, none of whose names are mentioned.

title: Job Opening: State Treasurer. Pay: Not Much for an Executive. Burdens: Huge.
description: TRENTON, Nov. 6  Gov. Jon S. Corzine may soon need to hang a help-wanted sign outside the treasurers office.

title: New Class(room) War: Teacher vs. Technology
description: Halfway through the semester in his market research course at Roanoke College last fall, only moments after announcing a policy of zero tolerance for cellphone use in the classroom, Prof. Ali Nazemi heard a telltale ring. Then he spotted a young man named Neil Noland fumbling with his phone, trying to turn it off before being caught.

title: The Dawn of E2K in India
description: New Delhi

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article and picture caption in some editions on Saturday about a deadly collision on Interstate 95 in Connecticut involving a tanker truck and five other vehicles misidentified the location of the accident. It was near Exit 75, not Exit 47.

title: A Basic Pie: No Oven Required
description: NOT long ago, toppings for pizza were becoming unbearably fancy  hoisin-slathered duck, or fontina and truffles  or just ridiculous (youve seen the ones with pasta?). Pizza threatened to become something other than pizza. Fortunately, that trend has reversed.

title: Correction: Off the Menu
description: A listing in the Off the Menu column last Wednesday about Elementi, a restaurant in Brooklyn, misidentified the owner and the restaurant where the chef previously worked, and misspelled the chefs given name. Elementi is owned by Roy and Mallory Rutledge  not by the chef, Camillo (not Camilo) Bassani. Mr. Bassani previously worked at the restaurant Esca, not Cipriani.

title: A Model for Health Care That Pays for Quality
description: Seeing low fees for family doctors as a weak link in the nations health care system, some big employers and health insurers are seeking new ways to pay doctors to reward high-quality medical care.

title: Radioactive Nimby: No One Wants Nuclear Waste
description: WRENLINGEN, Switzerland

title: Kucinich Offers Bill to Impeach Cheney
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  It is hard to know which effort has longer odds, the bid by Representative Dennis J. Kucinich, Democrat of Ohio, to become president of the United States, or his bid to unseat Vice President Dick Cheney by impeaching him.

title: M.I.T. Sues Frank Gehry, Citing Flaws in Center He Designed
description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology has sued the architect Frank Gehry and a construction company, claiming that design and construction failures in the institutes $300 million Stata Center resulted in pervasive leaks, cracks and drainage problems that have required costly repairs.

title: Calendar
description: Long Island Celebration

title: A Chance to Meet (Four-Footed) Cheesemakers
description: TO explain why she climbed on to a charter bus on Essex Street at 8:30 a.m. on a recent Sunday morning, when the Lower East Side was virtually deserted, Kristina Angelozzi, a clothing designer for the Gap, said, We dont get field trips as adults.

title: $3 Billion More Set for Hurricane Rebuilding
description: Congressional appropriations committees agreed to add $3 billion to the $7.5 billion federally financed program to rebuild hurricane-damaged houses in Louisiana. State officials said that without increased aid, the program, known as the Road Home, would run out of money in January, before an expected 163,000 applicants had all received grants of up to $150,000.

title: Weekly Wrap: Ripping Up the Ravens
description: The Fifth Downs contributors are Andrew Das, Benjamin Hoffman, Naila-Jean Meyers, John Woods and Toni Monkovic.

title: Facebooks Next Privacy Problem
description: I think Facebooks new Social Ad system could be brilliant, but the company may well be in for a storm of user protest. And Im perplexed about why, after all the trouble they had last year, they arent being more sensitive.

title: Facebook Everywhere
description: The most important bit of news at Facebooks press conference yesterday was what they didnt say out loud: Once the company gets the bugs out of its system for social ads on its own site, it will likely create a network to use its data to display advertising on other sites.

title: British Choose Most Absurd Laws
description: A poll ranks Britains most absurd laws, as reported by the BBC:

title: All Six Rocky Films in 10 Seconds
description: Yo, Rockys been doin some speed woik on YouTube.

title: For European Firms, the U.S. Is The Promised Land of Wind Power
description: Desire to tap the United States market for wind energy has sparked a round of dealmaking by European firms. While setting up shop in the United States may seem counterintuitive, given that the European Union has taken the lead on many climate change issues, the reasoning is fairly straightforward.

title: Financial Ground Has Shifted Under a Record Deal
description: The record price paid in January for the 41-story aluminum-clad office tower at 666 Fifth Avenue  $1.8 billion  was breathtaking, even by the standards of the heady Midtown Manhattan commercial real estate market.

title: As Chinese Companies Float I.P.O.s, Billionaires Emerge
description: The United States has more billionaires than any other country: 415 by the last count of Forbes magazine. No. 2, and closing fast? China, with more than 100, according to the widely watched Hurun Report.

title: Commerzbank Names New C.E.O.
description: Commerzbank named a new chief executive Tuesday and said its total write-downs related to the subprime crisis in the United States were 337 million euros ($494 million) during the second and third quarters, more than expected.

title: Nasdaq Said to Be in Deal for Philadelphia Exchange
description: The Nasdaq Stock Market has entered into a preliminary agreement to buy the Philadelphia Stock Exchange for $650 million, according to news reports.

title: Wall St. Bonuses Likely to Shrink
description: Wall Street bonuses may be the latest victim of the subprime mortgage collapse and the tight credit market. Over all, bonuses are expected to be flat to down 15 percent, according to compensation experts and Wall Street executives.

title: Brazil Raids Banks in Money Laundering Probe
description: Police detained 19 people Tuesday for allegedly taking part in a scheme to help large Brazilian companies evade taxes by laundering money through UBS, Credit Suisse and the American International Group.

title: Republicans Raise Privacy Concerns Over Google Deal
description: Representative Joe Barton, the senior Republican on the House Commerce Committee, and other GOP lawmakers are apparently having second thoughts about Googles $3.1 billion takeover of DoubleClick and are calling for a hearing into the privacy aspects of the proposed merger.

title: TCV Raises $3 Billion Fund
description: Technology Crossover Ventures, the Silicon Valley venture capital firm, said Tuesday it closed this years largest tech-focused investment fund at $3 billion.

title: Time Warner Is Said to Tie Bewkes Pay to Stock Price
description: Time Warner is planning to tie a large portion of the compensation it plans to pay its next chief executive to its share price performance, The New York Post reported.

title: SMG to Raise $200 Million in Rights Issue
description: SMG, a Scottish broadcasting company, will raise 95.1 million pounds ($200 million) in an attempt to lower its debt load and avert a fire sale of Virgin Radio.

title: Cox Says S.E.C. Is Examining Banks Subprime Disclosures
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is looking at whether banks made proper disclosures when announcing their investments in subprime-mortgage products, the agencys chairman, Christopher Cox, said on Wednesday.

title: Carlyle Raises First Infrastructure Fund
description: The Carlyle Group said it had raised its first fund to invest in infrastructure projects and received equity commitments totaling $1.15 billion.

title: Swiss Life Sells Private Bank for $1.65 Billion
description: The long awaited next step in consolidating Switzerlands private banks came Wednesday morning as Swiss Life announced the 1.87 billion Swiss franc ($1.65 billion) sale of Banca del Gottardo to BSI.

title: Freddie Mac Ex-C.E.O. to Pay $16.4 Million in Settlement
description: The government on Tuesday reached a $16.4 million settlement with Freddie Macs former chief executive for his role in the mortgage finance companys multibillion-dollar accounting scandal.

title: TomTom Sweetens Offer for Tele Atlas
description: A navigation device maker, TomTom, raised its bid for Tele Atlas, the last remaining independent maker of maps for navigation devices, on Wednesday to $4.2 billion (2.9 billion euros), topping a rival offer from Garmin.

title: BNP Hires New Hedge Fund Executives
description: The French bank BNP Paribas is expanding its hedge fund services divisions in New York, Hong Kong and London.

title: Yahoo Gets Lift from Alibaba
description: Yahoo has been hit hard lately from assorted pundits for everything from falling behind Google, to not getting a stake in Facebook, to colluding with Chinese authorities in the arrest of a journalist.

title: Sullivan & Cromwell Matches Cravath Bonuses
description: Sullivan & Cromwell on Monday became the latest firm to match the bonus range announced last week by Cravath, Swaine & Moore, which said it would pay both year-end and one-time special bonuses to associates totalling $45,000 for first-years and going up to $110,000 for senior associates.

title: Jabre Capital Looks to Raise $728 Million for New Fund
description: Jabre Capital, the hedge fund group founded by a former trader at GLG Partners, is raising a new 500 million euro ($728 million) fund.

title: Hillary Clinton on Immigration
description: At a town hall in Iowa, Hillary Clinton was queried on the issue of drivers licenses for illegal immigrants and border security.

title: War and Peace on the Campaign Trail
description: I reached the final page Tuesday morning on a plane home from Des Moines, after a few days of chasing presidential candidates. Squeezing chapters of Volume IV between campaign events, I found the novel bleeding into my observations of the politicians who would be president. John McCain, with his military breeding and his distaste for sugar-coating unpleasant news, reminded me of a voluble Kutuzov. John Edwards, who has lately amped up his populist fervor (as my colleague Jeff Zeleny recounted in Tuesdays paper) displays definite Denisov tendencies.

title: Armani Welcomes Investors, but Not Private Equity
description: The Italian designer Giorgio Armani told Reuters on Tuesday that he was open to a tie-up with a wealthy fashion lover or another investor. He also told the newswire that he had received an offer from Beiersdorf, the German maker of Nivea cosmetics, two years ago, adding to current talk of a merger amid a flurry of deals in the fashion world.

title: Citigroup Role Will Be Test, Even for Mr. Fix-It
description: Citigroup, reeling from its exposure to billions in assets backed by subprime mortgages, has appointed a triage team led by one of Wall Streets best-known fix-it men.

title: For Citigroups New Head, Focus Is Subprime Tangle
description: Until Sunday, Robert E. Rubin collected over $18 million a year as Wall Streets ultimate hands-off executive. On Monday, he had to roll up his sleeves.

title: Minority Female Associates Early Exits
description: Its no secret that nowadays most associates dont plan on spending their entire legal career at one law firm. But of all associates, minority females are the most likely to head for the exits, according to a study by The Minority Law Journal.

title: The Early Word: Democrats Gain Seats at State Level
description: Election Day 2007 saw a few traditionally red states turn a bit purple. Republican incumbent Ernie Fletcher lost the Kentucky governorship to Steve Beshear, and Democrats won a slim majority of seats in the state Senate of Virginia, which is expected to be up for grabs in 2008. Republicans still control the Virginia House, says the Washington Post:

title: BlackRock Chief Is Said to Be Meeting Over Merrill
description: Laurence D. Fink, chairman and chief executive of BlackRock and the leading candidate to take over the job as head of Merrill Lynch, has met with the executive search firm responsible for filling the brokerage firms top seat, The New York Times reported.

title: Morgan Stanley May Be Next to Write Down Assets
description: Now it is Morgan Stanleys turn.

title: Ousted Citi Executive Todd Thomson Fires Back
description: Todd S. Thomson, the former Citigroup executive whose January ouster was the talk of Wall Street and the tabloids, says that Charles Prince, until recently Citis chief executive, may have been part of a campaign to smear his reputation.

title: Dashed Hopes for Ticket Holders
description: Imagine waiting to see Saturday Night Live for two years  only to find out that a writers strike has put the program on hold.

title:
Living With Music:
A Playlist by Peter Robinson
description: On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for Living With Music, a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage.

title: Filling in the Leadership Gaps at Merrill and Citi
description: Citigroup and Merrill Lynch are in uneviable positions right now, scrambling to find new leaders at the same time.

title: In Local Elections, No Great Backlash Against Democrats
description: Democrats declared that Gov. Eliot Spitzers plan to give drivers licenses to illegal immigrants had not proved to be the electoral boon Republicans had hoped it would be in local elections. Though Democrats appeared to expand their majority in the Legislature in Suffolk County, Republicans were not ready to concede a pivotal Nassau County legislative race, and pointed to significant victories in several county races upstate as evidence of a Republican resurgence in the state.

title: Chris Anderson Is My Hero
description: Chris Anderson, editor of Wired Magazine and author of The Long Tail, sent the public relations community into a tizzy last week when he published a list of e-mail addresses of publicists he never wants to hear from again.

title: Purging the rottenness
description: Robert Samuelson, now:

title: Lets Not Even Talk About It
description: The House voted Tuesday to stop Rep. Dennis Kucinichs, D-Ohio, effort to bring up a debate on impeaching Vice President Dick Cheney, CNN reports, in a manner apparently dedicated to taking all the fun out of one of the more amusing Capitol dustups in recent memory.

title: Denver Voters Set Lowest Priority for Cops: Pot
description: Voters were in a cost-conscious mood this Election Day, rejecting several ballot measures to spend more taxpayer money in new areas, like stem-cell research in New Jersey.

title: For Pay, Its Still Good to Be Goldman
description: When speculation about a buyer for Bear Stearns cropped up a few months ago, several possibilities were mentioned, including a Chinese bank, Wachovia and even Warren E. Buffett. (The struggling investment bank has since unveiled a joint partnership with Chinas Citic Securities.)

title: The Ad Network Campaign
description: Advertising networks hit the front page of the Times today, and not for all the money they are making. Jim Rutenberg reports that political campaigns are increasingly using ad networks in the current campaign.

title: Pat Robertson Endorses Giuliani; Brownback Goes for McCain
description: The televangelist Pat Robertson endorsed Rudolph W. Giuliani today at the National Press Club in Washington, providing the former New York City Mayor with a big symbolic boost as he tries to allay the concerns of Christian conservatives about his candidacy.

title: In Trouble in Islamabad
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Hunting down the Berlin Wall
description: A remaining piece at Bernauer Strasse

title: Wednesdays Links: A Viking Conquerer
description: Adrian Petersons single-game record 296 yards in the Vikings win against the Chargers has to be the story of the week; the Minnesota rookie is on a feverish pace. ESPN.coms Tuesday Morning Quarterback praises the singular concentration displayed by the Vikings rookie. MSNBC.coms Mike Cimini says Peterson is without a doubt the best back in the league. And, just for some perspective, the yards are adding up for Peterson, and so are the dollars.

title: AOLs New Plan: Its Not Working
description: Randy Falco, AOLs chief executive, is betting the entire AOL franchise on building up its advertising network. The Time Warner results released this morning show his horse is slowing down.

title: Is Robertson for Rudy?
description: Mitt Romney got the nod from Moral Majority co-founder Paul Weyrich the other day, but Rudy Giuliani seems to have one-upped him: NBC News reports that religious conservative leader Pat Robertson will endorse Republican presidential hopeful Rudy Giuliani at a news conference this morning in Washington, D.C.

title: Serving in Tongues
description: My Critics Notebook today about the stilted language used by servers (and others) in restaurants is one of those stories that arose from countless conversations with friends, many of which the friends themselves began, about the little locutions that pop up repeatedly and become annoying.

title: With Investigation Winding Down, Mitchell Sets Deadline
description: George J. Mitchell, who is leading Major League Baseball's investigation into the use of performance-enhancing drugs, has set Saturday as the final day he will accept documentary evidence and conduct interviews, according to a lawyer familiar with the investigation. The deadline was first reported by cbsnews.com.

title: Log Off and Get to Work
description: Turns out your bosses dont want you updating your social networking page at the office.

title: A Deadly School Shooting, This Time in Finland
description: UPDATED, 4:34 p.m.

title: Wednesday Morning Kickoff
description: SI.coms Stewart Mandel says style points were not a factor when he put L.S.U. at the top of his latest power rankings.

title: In Big Map Deals, Google Cant Be Found
description: Google, where are you?

title: Bloomberg-Backed Candidate Is Unseated in Virginia
description: Democrats seized control of the State Senate in Virginia on Tuesday. Why might a New Yorker care? As we reported last week, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg flew to northern Virginia to endorse State Senator Jeannemarie Devolites Davis, a moderate Republican who represents Fairfax County. Ms. Davis  whose moderate, pro-gun-control positions were lauded by Mr. Bloomberg  lost to a Democratic challenger, J. Chapman Petersen. As Ian Urbina reports today, the Democratic gains in Virginia could signal that the state is becoming a battleground in next years presidential election.

title: Falafel!
description: Amazing.

title: Tunic Video
description: A video from "Sympathy for the Devil," a show which traces the intersection between images and sounds from the Velvet Underground and beyond.

title: A Note on the Translation
description: Without translation (linguistic and cultural), there would be no intellectual life as we know it. Surely the important point to make about the new translation of Tolstoy is that it has inspired a lot of people to read or re-read War and Peace, as evidenced by this very forum.

title: Too Easy on the Aristocracy
description: Well before you get to the twilight of War and Peace, it dawns on you: what is often acclaimed (rightly in my view) as one of the greatest novels ever written is really about which of two previously married male aristocrats will get the young aristocratic girl. In the end, Count Bezukhov, otherwise known as Pierre, a bastard, obese, weak, wins the hand of Natasha, the self-centered little princess, while Prince Andrei Bolkonsky, her other suitor, perishes from war wounds.

title: Some Advice for the Ladies
description: Online video is excellent for how-tos and demos. Not only is it useful to SEE  in moving images  what exactly hands should do when they bone a chicken or rewire a lamp; its also invaluable to witness the attitude and style of a competent person pulling off this stuff.

title: Iraq War: The Heartland Speaks
description: How does middle America feel about the Iraq War? Yesterdays election gave a good indication, in the results of two referendums in Montana.

title: The Lost World Series Baseballs
description: When Red Sox closer Jonathan Papelbon struck out Colorados Seth Smith to end the 2007 World Series last month, catcher Jason Varitek immediately stuck the ball in his back pocket. Then he gave the ball to Papelbon sometime during the celebration, and now it is gone.

title: Behind Brownbacks McCain Endorsement
description: Senator Sam Brownback, who met with both Mr. Romney and Mr. Giuliani before deciding the endorse Mr. McCain, said that it was the Arizona Senators long record of consistent support of issues important toChristian voters   particularly on abortion - that ultimately led to his decision.

title: The (Warming) World Is Not Flat
description: The world may be flat in some respects, as my colleague Tom Friedman has pointed out.

title: When Doctors Take Their Own Advice
description: For years, when Minnesota physician Dr. Chris Balgobin saw patients with diabetes and high blood pressure, he found it difficult to counsel them about losing weight and exercise.

title: A Cure for Buyers Remorse
description: We have further proof of your superior wisdom. I asked if getting a 30-day money-back guarantee would diminish buyers remorse, and Lab readersnot only guessed the answer from personal experience but found the research to back up their hunches.

title: In Hollywood, Shows of Solidarity
description: Some prominent show runners  the writer-producers who fill multiple roles at the helm of television programs  are siding with the Writers Guild of America.

title: Lamperts Wrong-Way Bet on Citi
description: In August, a hedge fund controlled by Edward S. Lampert, the value-oriented billionaire investor, disclosed that it had built up a $1.3 billion stake in Citigroup, the beleaguered financial giant. At the time, Mr. Lamperts quickly growing stake, backed by his reputation for finding bargains, prompted some to wonder whether Citis battered stock was ready for a rebound.

title: 'No Country for Old Men'
description: A. O. Scott reviews "No Country for Old Men," the new thriller from Joel and Ethan Coen.

title: Gentrification as Benign Ethnic Cleansing
description: If there is a leitmotif this year among scholars and writers who study New York, it is the reshaping of Manhattan by the forces of wealth and gentrification  and the angst accompanying those forces. There have been books on the suburbanization of New York, panel discussions on whether the city has lost its soul and reports about the flurry of bank branch construction.

title: Fried Mayonnaise
description: Life isnt fair. Frozen deep-fried Twinkies are ridiculed as the confection of county-fair waddle-butts, while fried mayonnaise  fried mayonnaise!  is extolled as haute cuisine and a melding of high science and art to boot, as The Times reports this week. So anyway, inquiring real or potential waddle-butts wanna know, how can we whip some up? Its tricky, as Esquire notes on a visit to Wylie Dufresnes New York restaurant WD-50:

title: The God Couples
description: Obviously, commentary on Pat Robertsons endorsement of Rudy Giuliani is not confined to conservative head scratching. Joe Sudbay of AmericaBlog typifies the disgusted amusement to be found on the left: One of the pillars of the anti-gay, anti-abortion theocratic community, Pat Robertson, is supporting the thrice married mayor who supports a womans right to have an abortion.  Apparently, Robertson and his ilk only challenge Democrats on social issues. Robertson is nothing more than a political hack. Lets stop pretending there are any morals behind anything he does.

title: Send Us Your Late-Night Monologue Jokes!
description: Sure, the TV writers are on strike, but the human comedy isnt. Send us your newsy jokes &#224 la Leno, Letterman or OBrien (via the comment link below) and well post the best here if theyre any good. We may even publish some in the paper. Include your name, town and email address. Morally conflicted? Not to worry about crossing picket lines: We wont actually put your jokes on TV. You wont even get paid!

title: Obama Talks About Working Families
description: BETTENDORF, Iowa  As Senator Barack Obama sets off on a two-day Iowa bus tour here today, one goal sits near the top of his agenda: Reminding voters that he understands the daily struggles of working families.

title: On YouTube, Creative Venting
description: As the writers strike enters day three, some writers and producers are taking to the video sharing site YouTube to express their frustrations.

title: Federal Prosecutors Plan to Seek Charges Against Kerik
description: Federal prosecutors are scheduled to seek a grand jury indictment on Thursday of Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York police commissioner, on a list of charges that include tax fraud, corruption and conspiracy, according to people who have been briefed on the case.

title: Pakistani Unrest: The Internet Edition
description: General Pervez Musharrafs ruthless repression in Pakistan may have silenced TV and radio stations in his nation, but the Internet is buzzing.

title: Why Mack Isnt Going Anywhere
description: Wednesday P.M.: Morgan Stanley said that it would take an additional $3.7 billion write-down related to its exposure to subprime mortgages for the two months ended Oct. 31. The results would apply to the fourth quarter, the bank said in a statement.

title: Mayor Grapples With How to Memorialize Post-9/11 Deaths
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has already reached at least one conclusion about how to memorialize people like James Zadroga, whose death has been linked to 9/11, although he did not die on that day. Their names, the mayor said, do not belong with those around the voids at the memorial.

title: Federal Prosecutors Plan to Seek Charges Against Kerik
description: Federal prosecutors are scheduled to seek a grand jury indictment on Thursday of Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York police commissioner, on a list of charges that include tax fraud, corruption and conspiracy, according to people who have been briefed on the case. William K. Rashbaum has the details in City Room.

title: Jets Wave Bye
description: The Jets waved goodbye to their season a few losses ago, but still received a break from the schedule gods this week. After six straight losses, the Jets will not lose again this weekend. Of course, they dont play, either, during their bye week.

title: Formula Ones Next Star
description: Its Adrian Sutil. Really. People have been talking about the reckless German driver since Lewis Hamilton dropped his name in a recent interview with Autosport. In case you missed it, this is what he said:

title: No Disrespect Intended
description: Sheryl Gay Stolberg, who covers the White House for The Times, gets a steady stream of complaints from readers about a curious issue.

title: Ron Paul Wins Straw Vote in New York
description: Ron Paul Wins! Thats the headline today after the first New York State Republican Straw Poll. Clearly, after raking in a record amount of money the other day, Mr. Paul is on a roll. He seems to have out-organized his fellow Republicans  on Rudolph W. Giulianis home turf.

title: $25,000 for a Hot Chocolate?
description: What would you do with $25,000? Buy a new Toyota Camry? Pay for six months at Harvard?

title: Rubin to Back Clinton
description: Aside from Al Gore, the biggest presidential endorsement prize that is still up for grabs from the Clinton administration is Robert E. Rubin, the former Treasury Secretary and deficit hawk who remains one of the most admired economic stewards in Democratic politics.

title: Monday Ratings Update
description: Nielsen delayed the release yesterday of its overnight ratings for Monday due to processing problems. Final numbers issued this morning indicate that ABC came in first for the night, followed by CBS in second place and then NBC and Fox, which tied for third.

title: NCIS Beats Dancing and House
description: CBSs five-year-old series NCIS earned its largest audience ever on Tuesday, surpassing even the nights usual leaders including ABCs Dancing With the Stars and Foxs House. According to Nielsens estimates, the Navy-themed crime drama delivered 18.3 million viewers in the 8 p.m. hour, just more than the 18.1 million who tuned in at 9 p.m. for House.

title: Probation Recommended for Oklahoma State Player Guilty of Sexual Assault
description: Updated: A jury recommended Wednesday that the Oklahoma State sophomore linebacker Chris Collins receive probation for the aggravated sexual assault of a 12-year-old girl three years ago, Bowie County District Attorney Bobby Lockhart said. Collins will be sentenced on Dec. 10.

title: Pakistan Protest Drama Unfolds Online
description: As emergency rule was declared in Pakistan on Saturday, Awab Alvi handed over his blog, Teeth Maestro, to an outsider, and he urged fellow Pakistani bloggers to do the same. We cannot risk it here, he wrote, referring to the governments curbs on the media.

title: Robertson Endorses Giuliani
description: Pat Robertson said he believed "the overriding issue before the American people is the defense of our population from the blood lust of Islamic terrorists."

title: Answers About New York Foster Care, Part 1
description: Following is a first set of answers from Benjamin Weiser and Leslie Kaufman of The Times, who, along with a panel of experts, answered readers questions about foster care from Nov. 7-12. In a series called A History of Neglect [Part 1 | Part 2 | Part 3], Ms. Kaufman and Mr. Weiser reported this week on New York Citys foster care system.

title: Green Car Award: None of the Above
description: LOS ANGELES  One of the highlights of the Los Angeles Auto Show is the presentation of the Green Car of the Year Award. The 2008 winner is scheduled to be announced Nov. 16 during press previews at the 2007 show. After looking over the field of candidates for this years award, Im shifting my rating of the event from highlight to lowlight.

title: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly of the Champions League
description: The European Champions League should, in theory, feature some of the most exciting and competitive soccer games on the continent. And often it does. Each team is top of its domestic league (or near it) and fields some of the most exciting players in the world.

title: A Winning Bathroom Configuration
description: The plumbers started yesterday, so were under pressure to resolve how the guest bathroom will be configured. They need to know where to put water lines and drains. (They also need us to tell them where the sink, dishwasher and ice maker will be located in the kitchen. Well give you an update on Friday.)

title: Obamas Travel Travails
description: WAPELLO, Iowa  When Senator Barack Obama stopped for an ice cream cone and a little lunch in this eastern Iowa town this afternoon, he stopped for a moment to discuss the weighty topic of his travel travails Tuesday, when his private jet mistakenly landed in the wrong Iowa city.

title: Con Edison Is Ordered to Return $18 Million to Customers
description: The New York State Public Service Commission ordered Consolidated Edison today to return $18 million to its customers for failing to provide safe and reliable service in 2006, a year that included a nine-day blackout that began in Long Island City, Queens, and affected 170,000 people. The highly critical decision could affect Con Edisons request for a substantial increase in electric rates.

title: Darth Gore to Senator Obama: I Am Your Father
description: Barack Obama is Luke Skywalker, Hillary Clinton is Princess Leia, Rudolph Giuliani is Han Solo and Mitt Romney looks like the PackBot from iRobot, but is probably R2D2. I dont know what it all means, but Israeli humor site AniBooms new animated series, Race for the White House, is worth a look  particularly if you are starved for laughs during the ongoing Hollywood writers strike.

title: 1830s Warehouse in Lower Manhattan Is Demolished
description: History is disappearing by the inch today on Pearl Street.

title: Right! Thats Why the Kids Had No School
description: Oh, yeah, there was an election yesterday. Or so Im told. The Timess Ian Urbina runs down the results here highlighting the fact that dogged by political scandal in his first term, Gov. Ernie Fletcher of Kentucky, a Republican, lost his bid for re-election yesterday to Steve Beshear.

title: Only Mama Knows This Is the No. 3 Least Caffeinated City
description: What we are reading elsewhere

title: Tallying the Votes in Tuesdays Election
description: Following are the preliminary vote tallies, by borough, of Tuesdays general election in New York City, as provided today by the City Board of Elections. The official election results will not be certified for several weeks. In each race below, the names of the winner or winners are in bold; in races where the same candidate ran on multiple party lines, the party line on which the candidate won the most votes is the one noted in bold. Where voters could select more than one candidate, the number of vacancies is indicated.Citywide: Proposal One

title: For Some Shows, The Strike Offers a Silver Lining
description: For a few new television series, the writers strike may actually be a good thing.

title: New York Lawyers Take Stand on Pakistan Crisis
description: New York City has some of the most hard-charging, influential and learned lawyers anywhere. But even with their collective clout, it is not clear whether they can do much to exert influence on the political crisis in Pakistan. Today, the New York City Bar presented a letter to Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the president of Pakistan, urging him to reverse his decision to fire justices of the Supreme Court, impose emergency rule, crack down on protesters and detain lawyers and other activists without charges.

title: Ad Networks Are the New Dot-Coms
description: Its no longer enough to have a Web site. Blog software let absolutely everyone into that club. Now the way to fame and riches seems to be starting an advertising network.

title: Can Gadgets and Humor Mix?
description: An encore presentation by David Pogue.

title: Leaving Vietnam
description: [The following entry, written by the author at 13 years old, recalls the day of her adoption at age 6.]

title: Pat Robertson Endorses Giuliani
description: The Times's David D. Kirkpatrick discusses Pat Robertson's announcement endorsing Rudolph W. Giuliani for president.

title: Sarkozy Visits Washington
description: International Herald Tribune reporter Katrin Bennhold on President Nicolas Sarkozy of France, who made his first official visit to Washington.

title: Sarkozy Visits Washington
description: International Herald Tribune reporter Katrin Bennhold on President Nicolas Sarkozy of France, who made his first official visit to Washington.

title: Memorable Moments
description: In his latest column, George Vecsey calls Shalrie Josephs pass to Steve Ralston that led to New Englands goal last Saturday night to oust the Red Bulls one of the best plays he has seen in Major League Soccer.

title: Auctioning Americana
description: The contents of the Elvis Is Alive Museum, offered in a single lot on eBay, support its owner's theory that Elvis is alive.

title: Bloggingheads: School Vouchers
description:
Mark Schmitt, of the New America Foundation, and Megan McArdle, of the Atlantic, on whether vouchers are the answer to public education's problems.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: Dubai: Working Class Investment?
description: Rendering of the Burj Dubai, projected as the tallest building in the world

title: Protests in Georgia Become Violent
description: Four years after the "Rose revolution," demonstrators were once again on the streets in Georgia last week.

title: Revisiting Psychological Tests: Can They Really Do That?
description: Tuesdays post about psychological testing in job interviews and other work-related settings caused a mild tempest in the comments section. Im going to address just a few of the many issues that came up, beginning with this one (which Ive abbreviated):

title: Strike Postpones 24 Premiere; Fox Revises Schedule
description: Three days into the writers strike, Fox has become the first broadcast network to announce revisions to its prime time schedule.

title: Coping With the Mexican Floods
description: Residents of Villahermosa, Mexico, were living on their rooftops last week while waiting for the flood waters to recede.

title: Early Victim of Strike: Office Originals End Next Week
description: Television viewers are beginning to get a better sense of how the writers strike will affect their favorite shows. Original half-hour episodes of NBCs hit half-hour comedy The Office will stop being shown after next week.

title: Con Edison Is Penalized for Blackout
description: State utilities regulators hit Con Edison with an $18 million penalty yesterday for its service disruptions last year, which included a nine-day blackout in western Queens and other power failures in Westchester County.

title: Lottery Numbers
Stock Market Continues Downhill
description: Stock markets ended flat for the day as investors showed a spot of optimism in the final hour of trading. But technology stocks swooned as investors faced a grim fourth-quarter forecast from the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke.

title: Mexican Floods Push Families to Last Islands of Home
description: VILLAHERMOSA, Mexico, Nov. 7  Javier Hernndez and ngel Prez killed a pig on Wednesday morning on their rooftop. That is where they are living.

title: Tax Proposal From Rangel Could Benefit His Donors
description: The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee has proposed legislation that would effectively halt some current tax audits of people who get a tax break for living and operating a business in the United States Virgin Islands.

title: Fed Chairman Says Economy Likely to Slow
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, told Congress today that the economy is going to get worse before it gets better, a message that got a chilly reception from both Wall Street and politicians.

title: Corrections
description: Editors' Note

title: It Takes a Big Man to Seek Help on Weight Loss
description: NASHUA, N.H.

title: Selected Studies: Heartburn
description: Government agencies, universities, doctors and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, please visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

title: Southwest Ends Open-Boarding Policy
description: Southwest Airlines abandoned its longstanding first-come-first-served approach to seating yesterday, giving business travelers, who pay the highest fares, first choice in boarding.

title: What Economic Slowdown? Small Businesses Grow Stronger
description: EVEN as oil prices surge, the housing market contracts, Wall Street reels and multibillion-dollar deals falter, small businesses are flourishing and, in fact, are helping to buoy the economy, experts say.

title: Rubin Is Reported Set to Back Clinton
description: Robert E. Rubin, Treasury secretary in the Clinton administration and new chairman of Citigroup, has overcome early misgivings about Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons presidential candidacy and will support her publicly in the fight for the Democratic nomination, people close to both of them said yesterday.

title: Fire Dept. Changes Way Demolition Is Supervised
description: The Fire Department announced yesterday that it was changing the way it inspects buildings under construction or being torn down, to avoid the confusion that contributed to the deaths of two firefighters in a blaze at the former Deutsche Bank building at ground zero last summer.

title: Hank Thompson Is Dead; Country Singer Was 82
description: Hank Thompson, a sequined singer and songwriter who fused jazz-inflected Western swing and hard-edged honky-tonk to produce seven decades of musical musings, seasoned with sly humor, on loving, drinking and dying, died on Tuesday at his home in Keller, Tex. He was 82.

title: Escalation of Tactics in Writers Strike
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 8  At least two major television studios, 20th Century Fox and CBS Paramount, have sent breach-of-contract letters to the show runners on their current series who have stopped performing their production duties once they went on strike with other television writers.

title: European Bank Leaves Rate Unchanged
description: FRANKFURT, Nov. 8  The European Central Bank held interest rates steady today but also signaled its displeasure with the euros rushed rise against the dollar.

title: For Miller, One Not Loneliest Number
description: At this point, Bode Millers motor home is more of a symbol than a means of transportation.

title: A Departure Adds Colors to the Palette
description: Garth Fagan has sometimes seemed a limited modern-dance choreographer, with jagged moves and cross-stage patterns as his too familiar trademarks. There was some of that when Garth Fagan Dance opened at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night. But this first of two programs for once suggested range and invention.

title: Eventful 15-Day Mission for Shuttle Discovery Ends
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Nov. 7  The shuttle Discovery glided to a safe landing here Wednesday, bringing to a close an eventful mission that combined challenging space station construction and emergency repairs.

title: A Sigh of Relief for Heartburn Sufferers
description: Over the last decade, a tide of powerful heartburn medications, many once available only by prescription, has washed over store shelves, helping to introduce gastroesophageal reflux disease -- or GERD, the medical name for persistent heartburn -- into the vocabulary of consumers everywhere. But along with relief has come worry. Many patients fear they are afflicted with an incurable chronic condition that, if left untreated, eventually leads to more serious problems like inflammation or even cancer of the esophagus.

title: Pat Loves Rudy
description: Back in mid-2001, when Mayor Rudy Giuliani was busy committing adultery, lurching into his divorce and third marriage and rooming with a gay couple he promised to marry as soon as the law allowed, who among us would have imagined that one day he would be endorsed for president by Pat Robertson?

title: Indias Solution for Oil Prices: Ban Speculation by Banning Trading
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 7  As oil approaches the $100-a-barrel milestone, M. S. Srinivasan, Indias petroleum secretary, has an unorthodox recommendation for cooling overheated prices: halt trading of crude oil on commodity exchanges.

title: Bending Ears on Economics as 08 Nears
description: On the campaign trail, Barack Obama and John Edwards are aggressively pitting themselves against Hillary Rodham Clinton in the race for the Democratic presidential nomination. But when it comes to something as fundamental as economic policy, the lineup quietly shifts: It is Senators Obama and Clinton against Mr. Edwards.

title: Need a Life? Shell Arrange One
description: ON a warm autumn afternoon, Allison Storr was giving Brad Peik, a San Francisco real estate investor, a crash course on the Chelsea art world. The gallery scene can be a little intimidating, Ms. Storr said as she took him on a tour of galleries that was intended as a primer for cocktail party chatter, not collecting.

title: Another Step for a Remade AOL
description: AOL has scooped up yet another online advertising company  this time, one that has faced off with Google and Yahoo in selling contextual text ads, those small, sponsored links that run next to articles.

title: Toll Rises to 41 in Afghan Bombing
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 7  The death toll from a suicide bombing in northern Afghanistan rose to 52 on Wednesday, making it the worst single suicide bombing in the country since 2001, government officials said.

title: Radioactive Dumping Is Reported in Congo
description: KINSHASA, Congo, Nov. 7 (Reuters)  Officials in Congo said Wednesday that they were investigating reports that 18 tons of highly radioactive minerals had been dumped into a river in Katanga Province, in the southeastern part of the country.

title: Life Sentence in Killing of Police Officer
description: A Brooklyn man who was convicted of fatally shooting a police officer in a wild car chase through Flatbush two years ago was sentenced today to life in prison without the chance of parole.

title: In a Surprise, Pat Robertson Backs Giuliani
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7  They could compete for strangest bedfellows of 2008.

title: These Naughty Gifts Dont Clutter a Closet
description: LAST week, I stumbled across a short item at a site called Mashable.com, which described how one of Facebooks most popular programs allows users to give each other virtual Naughty Gifts.

title: Militant Group Is Out of Baghdad, U.S. Says
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 7  American forces have routed Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia, the Iraqi militant network, from every neighborhood of Baghdad, a top American general said today, allowing American troops involved in the surge to depart as planned.

title: For the Young of Heart and Hair
description: AN hour before walking past squealing kids wobbling cutely around the Bryant Park skating rink, on my way to the BCBG Max Azria flagship, I had been struggling in my bathroom, trying to take my own passport photo.

title: Timing Glitch Affected Thousands in Marathon
description: A technical problem with the timing system at the New York City Marathon on Sunday affected thousands of runners, forcing race directors to resort to the honor system in determining runners precise times and whether some met the qualifying standards for the Boston Marathon, one of the worlds most prestigious races.

title: Stranger Posts Bail for Chamberss Friend
description: When Robert E. Chambers Jr. was arrested on Oct. 22 on charges of selling cocaine out of an Upper East Side apartment, many people saw it as the denouement of a morality tale, the final fall of the preppy killer who pleaded guilty to strangling Jennifer Levin during rough sex in Central Park two decades ago.

title: Fred W. McDarrah, Photographer, Dies at 81
description: Fred W. McDarrah, a self-described square who as a longtime photographer for The Village Voice documented the unwashed exploits of the Beat generation, and as an enterprising freelance talent agent rented out members of that generation (washed or unwashed) to wide-eyed suburban society gatherings, died on Tuesday at his home in Greenwich Village. He was 81.

title: Digital Camera for the PlayStation 3 Is Watching, and Listening, While You Play
description: The idea of watching a video game is not new. But what about when the games start watching back? Last week, Sony released its long-awaited PlayStation Eye, a digital camera that lets players interact with some games using body motions.

title: OBrien Performs Live, but Charity Benefits
description: NBC ran a rerun of Late Night with Conan OBrien on Wednesday night during the ongoing writers strike, but it was still possible for a select few to see the host do an original monologue.

title: Bet on Citigroup Hurts a Prominent Investor
description: In August, a hedge fund controlled by Edward S. Lampert, the value-oriented investor, disclosed that it had built a $1.3 billion stake in Citigroup, the beleaguered financial giant.

title: Free-Jazz Pioneer, Aware of His Legacy
description: The Ohio-born tenor saxophonist Albert Ayler probably would have gotten a kick out of Kasper Collins documentary about his life, My Name Is Albert Ayler, which opens today at the Anthology Film Archives. Named after one of his albums and built around snippets of audio interviews with Mr. Ayler, it attempts and often achieves a fresh, playful style thats equally informed by jazz traditions and Mr. Aylers urge to shatter them.

title: Honors Pile Up for Former Ranger Leetch
description: For the former Rangers defenseman Brian Leetch, being honored yesterday with the Lester Patrick Award for contributions to American hockey was one of a series of events that followed his retirement this year. He dropped the first puck at the Rangers home opener to a thunderous ovation. He will have his number retired at Madison Square Garden in January.

title: Cast Aside Underarm Protection, if You Dare
description: IN Kurt Vonneguts God Bless You, Mr. Rosewater, there is an imaginary country that is in search of a common enemy, but every disease has already been cured and all wars have stopped. So, the country wages a battle against odor. It is a story that feels prescient, minus the disease and war part.

title: Priest Jailed in Stalking of Conan OBrien
description: A priest from Boston has been charged with stalking and harassing the talk show host Conan OBrien, law enforcement officials said last night.

title: MSNBC and ODonnell Cant Make a Deal
description: Two days after NBC acknowledged that it was talking to Rosie ODonnell about a possible show on MSNBC, those conversations have stalled, with no immediate prospect of being revived, an executive of the network said last night.

title: Computer Servers for Home Use Can Help Get a Grip on All Those Photo, Music and Video Files in the PC Attic
description: It may not be the sexiest part of computing, but storage is becoming increasingly critical as masses of photo, music and video files accumulate. Microsoft thinks its time families had help storing it all with computer servers intended for the home.

title: On Campaign Stump, Romney Preaches the Importance of Optimism
description: The question put to Mitt Romney at the Republican presidential debate in Michigan several weeks ago seemed to be a golden opportunity for him to show off his vaunted analytical side. Maria Bartiromo, a CNBC commentator, asked the candidate what he thought posed the greatest long-term threat to the American economy.

title: On the Trading Block: Endless Kobe Rumors
description: Over the last two weeks, we have crowned a new World Series champion, the New York Yankees have been turned upside down, the N.F.L. played a game in London and the New England Patriots won the leagues latest Game Of The Century. All the while, Kobe Bryant has been on the front page of ESPN.com six times. Which is fascinating, considering that absolutely nothing has happened with him for the last two weeks.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,846 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Russia: Parliament Suspends Arms Treaty Compliance
description: Parliaments lower house voted 418 to 0 to back a Kremlin decision to suspend participation in a treaty limiting conventional forces in Europe. In July, a Kremlin statement said that NATO expansion into Eastern Europe had increased the alliances military capacity, in violation of the original treaty adopted in 1990 by NATO and the Soviet Union. Officials in Russia also suggested Russia would stop observing the treaty because of the Bush administrations decision to abrogate another, the Antiballistic Missile Treaty, and move ahead with a missile-defense system in Central Europe. Russian officials have threatened to direct their missiles toward Europe if the United States proceeds with the system. The vote to suspend the conventional forces treaty must be approved by the upper house and signed by President Vladimir V. Putin. Both are expected to do so.

title: China Remarks Drive Dollar Lower
description: Currency traders gave the dollar a thorough pounding today after a Chinese official suggested that the country could begin to diversify its huge foreign-exchange reserves.

title: Homeowners Feel the Pinch of Lost Equity
description: RENO, Nev., Nov. 5  As his wedding day approached last spring, Marshall Whittey found that his money could not keep pace with the grandiosity of his plans. But rather than scale back, he chose instead, like millions of homeowners across the country, to borrow against the soaring value of his home.

title: I Wont Dance? Just Try and Stop Her
description: Chita Rivera has a gleam in her eye, a smirk on her lips and a bounce in her step. That description could, of course, be applied to scads of other entertainers purveying resilience and optimism. But Ms. Riveras brand of vivacity is qualitatively different from almost everyone elses, because it emanates from deep within her.

title: New York Widens Inquiry on Mortgages
description: The New York attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, has subpoenaed Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac as he expands his investigation into what he calls widespread collusion between real estate appraisers and lenders, including Washington Mutual, to inflate home values.

title: Thailand Race Begins
description: BANGKOK, Nov. 7 (AP)  Official campaigning for Thailands first general elections since last years military coup began Wednesday as 18 parties registered for the Dec. 23 balloting.

title: Romanian Premier Tries to Calm Italy After a Killing
description: ROME, Nov. 7  Romanias prime minister visited Italy on Wednesday to try to defuse a week of anger here, after the arrest of a Romanian in the killing of an Italian woman exploded into a national debate on immigration and crime. Some three dozen immigrants have been expelled since then, with calls from the center-right opposition for many more expulsions.

title: A.I.G. Takes a Hit of $1.95 Billion on Housing Investments
description: The American International Group, the worlds largest insurance company, said yesterday that it wrote down nearly $2 billion in investments related to mortgages in the third quarter and expected to write down an additional $550 million in the next quarter.

title: U.N. Objects to Expulsion of Aid Official From Darfur
description: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 7  The United Nations on Wednesday deplored the expulsion of its chief aid official from Darfur, and Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said Sudan was delaying the arrival of peacekeeping troops in Darfur by withholding approval of the forces composition.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Polanski to Film The Ghost

title: Duran Duran Is Still Big, Just the Stage Got Small
description: When a name-brand band settles in for a residency at a small Broadway theater  as Duran Duran is through next Tuesday at the Ethel Barrymore Theater21;151; the selling point is a chance to get closer to the musicians and the songs. On Tuesday night some fans took full advantage of their proximity, like the woman who repeatedly grabbed the singer Simon Le Bons leg whenever he walked too close to the edge of the stage.

title: Civics, Without Passion, From HBO
description: The deal with The Deal isnt that this 2003 British film traces former Prime Minister Tony Blairs early rise to power.

title: Iraq Plans to Confront Security Firms on Guns
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 7  The Iraqi interior minister said Wednesday that he would authorize raids by his security forces on Western security firms to ensure that they were complying with tightened licensing requirements on guns and other weaponry, setting up the possibility of violent confrontations between the Iraqis and heavily armed Western guards.

title: Perfect for Prowling
description: THIS season, the call of the wild sounds more like a primal scream. From top to toe, pith helmet to platform shoe, animal prints are back with a vengeance. Not that they ever went away. A perennial favorite, they emerge in some degree every autumn, as reliable as the Thanksgiving turkey, and for some, just as enticing.

title: After Further Review?
description: Earlier this week, baseballs general managers recommended for the first time that the league allow instant replay. The proposal is limited to instant replay on possible home run balls -- whether they are fair or foul, for instance -- and faces several more layers of approval. Is this a move in the right direction for baseball, or a bad precedent?

title: Recording Video on the Go
description: Q. Can the iPod record video? Are there any portable media players that let you record directly onto the device, instead of having to copy prerecorded files onto the player from the computer?

title: New Ticket to Lady Liberty
description: The company that will replace the Circle Line, which has provided ferry service to the Statue of Liberty for more than half a century, has begun selling tickets online for trips in January.

title: As They Say in France: Whats This?
description: INVITING the public to a fashion show, by plopping one onto the plaza of Lincoln Center, as did Project Runway on Tuesday, or inside Grand Central Terminal, as did Target on Tuesday and Wednesday, would seem to be a fine way to grab attention.

title: Florida Sun Doesnt Shine on Baseball
description: ORLANDO, Fla.

title: A Boys Guide to Narcotizing the Pain
description: The boys, overgrown tykes all, seem endearingly happy in their squalid playpen of an apartment. Oh, not the three potentially suicidal brothers who share a home in Things We Want, Jonathan Marc Shermans thickly whimsical comedy of despair, which opened last night at the Acorn Theater. Theyre pretty miserable.

title: From Streets of China to Family Life in Queens
description: The wisps of smoke were sweet and pungent, seductive and soothing, lazy tentacles unfurling from bamboo pipes. Opium humbled a great empire, creating an addiction that rotted China from within. But in the crevices of the history books, which diligently record the epic battles and the humiliating treaties, lie the families that crumbled and the children who were orphaned, including Tai Run Chen, now 65.

title: States Oldest Inmate Is Granted His Freedom by Parole Board
description: A panel of the State Parole Board voted 2 to 1 yesterday to release Charles E. Friedgood, a wealthy Long Island surgeon who was convicted in 1976 of murdering his ailing wife and who is now, at 89, the oldest state prison inmate in New York. He is expected to be freed in mid-December and admitted to a veterans hospital.

title: Serb Nationalists Trial Begins in The Hague
description: THE HAGUE, Nov. 7  The man considered the main propagandist of the Serbian nationalism that led to four disastrous wars went on trial on Wednesday at the war crimes tribunal in The Hague. He is accused of inflammatory speech and of numerous crimes committed by his own militia.

title: Caution Signs
description: THE American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists makes exercise recommendations for pregnant women. In general, the group suggests that those without medical or obstetric complications should get 30 minutes or more of moderate activity daily. The association made this point in a 2002 committee opinion, the most recent available. The benefits of exercising while pregnant include reduction of backaches, better sleep, and treating or preventing gestational diabetes.

title: Posada and Rivera at Top of Yanks List
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 7  The Yankees are preparing new offers to their top free agents, Jorge Posada and Mariano Rivera, in an effort to sign them before other teams can negotiate with them.

title: Dog and Rabbit Sleuths vs. a Demonic Santa
description: The snow will turn red with the blood of the naughty, screams Santa as he fires a pistol at one of his elves.

title: Unseasonably Higher, Gas Prices Add to Strain on U.S. Consumers
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 7  Most years, the shorter days and lower temperatures of autumn mean falling gasoline prices, as demand eases from the busy summer travel season.

title: Toward Afghan Success
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn: Navy Yard Development
description: The Brooklyn Navy Yard will become home to a historic center as part of its expansion and redevelopment, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn said yesterday. The center, scheduled to open in early 2010 in the Marine Corps commandants residence, is to use multimedia exhibits, including oral history projects, to tell the story of the Navy Yard and provide meeting space and offices for the Brooklyn Center for the Urban Environment. The City Council has promised $10 million of the $15 million needed to renovate and expand the building, which was erected in 1857.

title: Giving Up the Memorabilia, but Not the Belief: Elvis Lives
description: WRIGHT CITY, Mo., Nov. 6  The 16-foot-tall likeness of Elvis Presley that stands sentry here at the Elvis Is Alive Museum, a fading outpost of Americana, has seen better days.

title: Poet Wins $200,000
description: The American lyric poet Anne Stevenson, 74, who has lived in Britain for more than 40 years, was named the winner yesterday of the $200,000 lifetime achievement award of the Lannan Foundation of Santa Fe, N.M. Awards of $150,000 each were made in fiction to A. L. Kennedy of Scotland and Susan Straight of Riverside, Calif., and in nonfiction to Mike Davis of San Diego. Writing fellowships totaling $550,000 went to Paula Gunn Allen of Fort Bragg, Calif.; Daniel Alarcn of Oakland, Calif.; Edie Meidav of Rhinebeck, N.Y.; Dinaw Mengestu and Jeremy Scahill of Brooklyn and Sinead Morrissey of Belfast, Northern Ireland. The Lannan Literary Awards and Fellowships were established in 1989 to honor established and emerging writers of work of exceptional quality. ... Late Nights on Air, the third novel by Elizabeth Hay, 56, a former radio broadcaster in Canada, won the $43,000 Scotiabank Giller Prize, the most lucrative Canadian prize for fiction, Reuters reported. The novel, about loves and rivalries at a small radio station in Yellowknife, in the Northwest Territories of Canada near the Arctic, beat shortlist competition that included Divisadero, by Michael Ondaatje.

title: Right State, Wrong Town for Obama
description: WAPELLO, Iowa, Nov. 7  As presidential hopefuls go, Senator Barack Obama is generally one of the more punctual politicians of the election season.
