title: Paul Soloway, 66, World Bridge Champion, Dies
description: Paul Soloway, five times a world bridge champion and the holder of the largest collection of master points, died on Monday in Seattle. He was 66.

title: Humdinger of a Project: Tracing Slang to Ireland
description: Growing up Irish in Queens and on Long Island, Daniel Cassidy was nicknamed Glom.

title: Global Markets Down After U.S. Sell-Off
description: Stocks in Europe and Asia declined today on worries about rising oil prices and the prospect of an economic slowdown in the United States. But American shares were poised to move upward today, after a heavy sell-off on Wednesday spurred by fears that the problems in housing were likely to persist into next year.

title: Journeys That Leave the Traveler Changed
description: Isaac Juliens beguiling, heady film, Fantme Afrique, demonstrates the wonders of collaboration. A second film, True North, underlines the dangers of accommodation.

title: A Norwegian Orchestra and Its Aural Thumbprint
description: The Bergen Philharmonic has been in business since 1765 and lists Edvard Grieg among its former artistic directors. It is overshadowed these days by the Oslo Philharmonic, but the Bergen musicians seem ready to challenge their Oslo compatriots for a piece of the international spotlight. At Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening, led by Andrew Litton, its conductor since 2003, the Bergen Philharmonic played with an unusual solidity and warmth, and produced a breadth of color that gave it a distinctive sonic thumbprint.

title: Editors Note
description: On Aug. 7, we published a letter from Zachary Townsend, a student at Brown University and a columnist for the student newspaper, about Japans role in sex slavery in World War II, and slavery in the world today. We have now learned that the letter included material taken without attribution from an article in the November/December 2006 issue of Foreign Affairs, The New Global Slave Trade, by Ethan B. Kapstein.

title: G.M.s Attempt  at 2 Steps Forward Is Taken One Back
description: DETROIT, Nov. 7  Nearly two years ago, amid speculation of a potential bankruptcy filing, General Motors unveiled details of its reorganization plan and vowed to end the crisis that had enveloped the company.

title: Georgian Leader Imposes a State of Emergency
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 7  The president of the republic of Georgia declared a state of emergency Wednesday night, after riot police officers used tear gas, rubber bullets and water cannon to clear thousands of demonstrators from the streets. The order immediately closed two television stations and banned public assembly in the capital, and would be in effect for at least 48 hours, a senior government official said by telephone.

title: Dont Throw Out Your Broken iPod; Fix It via the Web
description: A FEW months ago, Stephen Ironside, a student at the University of Arkansas in Fayetteville, confronted a minor but modern tragedy: the iPod that filled his life with song stopped working.

title: Pregnant Exercisers Test Limits
description: JAMES PIVARNIK, the director of the Human Energy Research Laboratory at Michigan State University, is all in favor of a woman exercising when she is pregnant. But some of the athletes he studied seemed to know no bounds.

title: Pete Doherty Apologizes
description: The British rocker Pete Doherty acts stupid. Says who? Mr. Doherty himself, Reuters reported. Mr. Doherty, the Babyshambles frontman, apologized yesterday for using heroin last week, after saying he was conquering his well-publicized drug addiction. Mr. Doherty called his relapse a stupid, stupid action for which I feel only shame. He plans to re-enter a rehabilitation clinic. In a statement, his record label, EMI, said, Doherty would like to apologize to the medical staff, fans and well-wishers who have helped and encouraged his progress in fighting his addiction to heroin. A spokesman said an arena tour planned for this month would proceed.

title: For CBS, Crime Pays
description: CBSs five-year-old series NCIS attracted its largest audience ever on Tuesday, surpassing even that nights usual leaders, including ABCs Dancing With the Stars and Foxs House. Nielsen estimated that NCIS, a Navy-themed crime procedural, delivered 18.3 million viewers in the 8 p.m. hour, slightly more than the 18.1 million who tuned in at 9 for House. But House remained far and away the nights leader among adults 18 to 49, lifting Fox into first place in Tuesdays ratings. CBS ranked second in total viewers, but third in the 18-to-49 demographic behind NBC, which led the 10 p.m. hour with Law & Order: Special Victims Unit (11.8 million). The results episode of ABCs Dancing With the Stars at 9 drew 17 million viewers, fewer than the 20.5 million the show attracted on Monday with an extended edition from 8 to 9:45. Although ABC finished first in the ratings for that night, on Tuesday it suffered a rare fourth-place finish in the 18-to-49 set, partly because of lackluster ratings for Cavemen at 8 (4.9 million) and Carpoolers at 8:30 (5.5 million).

title: Home & Garden Calendar
description: Stitchery

title: Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Musharraf
description: When Zalmay Khalilzad was the U.S. ambassador to Afghanistan, he would clash with Colin Powell, then the secretary of state, over whether Gen. Pervez Musharrafs Pakistan was friend or foe.

title: Alternative Tax Showdown
description: The House and Senate are poised to vote on a vitally important tax bill that poses a test for each chamber of Congress. In the House, the vote on a short-term fix for the alternative minimum tax will test whether Democratic representatives have the courage of their convictions. In the Senate, the vote will test whether Democratic senators have any convictions at all, or just a belief in keeping the world safe for campaign contributors.

title: At Sothebys Art Auction, Buyers Were Not Impressed
description: The combination of estimates that were too high and material that was too familiar made last nights sale of Impressionist and modern art at Sothebys a rocky evening, as second-rate paintings by Picasso, van Gogh and Mir failed to sell.

title: What to Ask About Heartburn
description: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening -- and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why theyre important.

title: A Bit Older, No Reason to Fret
description: TORRINGTON, Conn.

title: What You Said
description: At the point where both players represent the ultimate offensive weapons of their sport and both command huge salaries, the fact that Kobe plays to win clearly makes him more desirable than A-Rod.

title: Do Not Go Gentle Into Pakistans Night
description: To the Editor:

title: Dubai: Court Hears French Boys Rape Testimony
description: A 15-year-old French boy, Alexandre Robert, testified for two and a half hours in the trial of two Emirati men accused of raping him at knife point in July. The court session was closed to the public, but the boys mother, Vronique Robert, said that he identified the men as two of his three assailants. The third suspect is being tried in a juvenile court. Alexandre returned to Dubai from Switzerland, where his mother lives, despite a risk of being prosecuted himself for homosexual activity after pressing the charges against the three suspects.

title: Big Tobacco Defeats Sick Kids
description: One of the biggest disappointments in Tuesdays election was the defeat of an Oregon ballot initiative that would have raised the states cigarette tax by 85 cents a pack to help pay for health care for uninsured children.

title: For TV Executives, Its Time to Juggle
description: Jack Bauer will return to save the world on 24  again  but somewhat later than expected. And Michael Scott, the comically obtuse regional manager on The Office, will not be serving up any original cringe-inducing comments after next week.

title: Marching After Goldwater in the Opposite Direction
description: In 1960 a brash young conservative writer named L. Brent Bozell Jr. ghost-wrote a book for a brash Republican senator from Arizona named Barry Goldwater. That book, The Conscience of a Conservative, argued for a radically different relationship between government and the individual than the one to which Americans had become accustomed.

title: A Trade Publication Alters a Rule, Lifting an Eagles Album to No. 1
description: In the latest indication of the clout of mass retailers, the Eagles, the longtime rock group that is selling its new studio album exclusively through Wal-Mart, seized the top spot on the sales charts this week thanks to an 11th-hour change by a music trade magazine that has stirred up a ruckus in the music industry.

title: Putting the Shower to the Test (and the Nose on Alert)
description: WE asked three adults who have used a deodorant-antiperspirant combination every day since puberty to see how long they could go au naturel. Only one was still abstaining after 12 days.

title: Falcons Babineaux Is Cleared of Charges
description: The Atlanta Falcons finally got some good news about a player accused of killing a pit bull.

title: How to Load a Digital Frame
description: Q. I want to buy one of those digital photo frames. Ill insert a memory card containing the photos, but how do I get the photos on my computer onto that memory card? The computer has no slot for the card.

title: Superdelegates for Clinton (Undecideds No. 1)
description: In an early indication of where Democratic Party leaders are leaning, a survey of the partys superdelegates  elected officials and other leaders who vote at the partys convention but are not selected in primaries  found they are favoring Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York.

title: House Approves  Broad Protections for Gay Workers
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7  The House on Wednesday approved a bill granting broad protections against discrimination in the workplace for gay men, lesbians and bisexuals, a measure that supporters praised as the most important civil rights legislation since the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 but that opponents said would result in unnecessary lawsuits.

title: French Architect Picked for Film Museum
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 7  An architect who helped raise a bustling new quarter from the industrial mess of southeast Paris will now get his shot at a section of this city best known for its automotive repair shops, tumbledown cottages and slapdash sidewalk posters.

title: Senate Confirms Mukasey as Attorney General
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  The Senate confirmed Michael B. Mukasey as attorney general Thursday night, approving him despite Democratic criticism that he had failed to take an unequivocal stance against the torture of terror detainees.

title: Oklahoma State Player Sentenced in Sex Assault
description: The Oklahoma State sophomore linebacker Chris Collins received a five-year prison sentence yesterday for aggravated sexual assault of a 12-year-old girl three years ago. But the jury, in New Boston, Tex., recommended that his punishment be served through probation.

title: A Mishmash Reflective of Country Music
description: Long before the 41st annual Country Music Awards were over last night, the winner for best speech seemed clear. Lets give that award  a meta-award, perhaps  to Jamey Johnson, who helped write the break-up song Give It Away for George Strait, which won song of the year. Mr. Johnson dedicated his award to his ex-wife, inspiring a chuckle from the audience. She certainly deserves half of this award, he added dryly. And half of this song, too.

title: On the Road to Spread the Word of Good, Old-Fashioned Evil
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., Nov. 7  On Tuesday night, in a plush tour bus parked in this citys scruffy downtown, a couple of Norwegians were talking about world music. They were talking about the competing musical traditions of Norway and Sweden. They were talking about Icelandic linguistics and Viking mythology. They were talking about indigenous scenes in Canada, India and lots of places in between. In other words, they were talking about heavy metal.

title: Batmans Energy Crisis
description: The Caped Crusader is in hot water in Hong Kong. When producers of his latest adventure, The Dark Knight, starring Christian Bale, asked tenants on the waterfront to leave their lights on all night, the better to show off that citys glass-and-steel skyline, environmentalists saw red. Gabrielle Ho, a project manager for the conservation organization Green Sense, told The Associated Press, We believe producers are able to create the same effects via postproduction works, but instead they are asking us to turn on so many lights, wasting so much energy. October Pictures, the Hong Kong company handling the production, did not respond to a request for comment.

title: Morgan Stanley Takes a Hit on Mortgages
description: Morgan Stanley, its stock buffeted in recent days by speculation of high credit losses, said yesterday that it would take a $3.7 billion charge for nonperforming assets tied to subprime mortgages.

title: Surge Seen in Number of Homeless Veterans
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7  More than 400 veterans of the Iraq and Afghanistan wars have turned up homeless, and the Veterans Affairs Department and aid groups say they are bracing for a new surge in homeless veterans in the years ahead.

title: In First Bush Veto Override, Senate Enacts Water Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  The Senate voted overwhelmingly today for a popular $23 billion water projects measure affecting locales across the country, thereby handing President Bush his first defeat in a veto showdown with Congress.

title: Birth Control Pills May Clog Arteries
description: Birth control pills taken by about 100 million women worldwide may clog arteries when taken more than 10 years, according to a study. Women on oral contraceptives were 20 percent to 30 percent more likely to have buildup of fat and cholesterol in their arteries, reducing blood flow, according to a study of 1,301 Belgian women ages 35 to 55. Most used birth control now made by companies like Johnson & Johnson and Barr Pharmaceuticals Inc. for more than 10 years. Fatty clogs can lead to heart disease and stroke. The pills in the study were older forms that combined estrogen and progestin, two sex hormones. The finding differs from advice given by doctors based on previous research, said Sharonne Hayes of the Mayo Clinic. The research was reported at the American Heart Association meeting in Orlando.

title: In Tests, AIDS Vaccine Seemed to Increase Risk
description: In a puzzling and potentially troubling development, an AIDS vaccine tested in a closely watched trial might have increased the risk among vaccine recipients of becoming infected with H.I.V., researchers reported yesterday at a scientific meeting in Seattle.

title: The Artists Fall Collection
description: KERI EVILSIZOR trained a covetous eye on the handbags pristinely arrayed on white-lacquered shelves. She was not quite sure what to make of the display, housed in a 1,000-square-foot island of commerce inside the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles. No matter. She was there to shop.

title: New Jersey Democrats Grapple With Rebuke of Stem Cell Initiative
description: TRENTON, Nov. 7  Stung and puzzled by the defeat of a ballot initiative to borrow $450 million for stem cell research, leading Democrats in New Jersey struggled on Wednesday to explain why they were repudiated by voters and how they planned to finance the biomedical research for a center already under construction.

title: Exercise on the Brain
description: FEELING a little less mentally quick than you did a few years ago? Maybe you are among the many people who do brain exercises like sudoku to slow the cognitive decline associated with aging. Weve got a better suggestion.

title: If Rodriguez Price Falls, Mets Might Be Interested
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 7  The Mets had a meeting Wednesday with Scott Boras, the agent for third baseman Alex Rodriguez, staying on the fringes of negotiations for the marquee free agent of the off-season.

title: After Coin Flip, Pennington Takes On New Role
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 7  The former franchise quarterback walked from the sideline to midfield, the same as dozens of times before. He stood next to the other captains as the coin tumbled toward the ground.

title: U.S. Prods Musharraf to End Emergency Rule
description: This article was reported by David Rohde, Jane Perlez, Helene Cooper and Steven Lee Myers, and written by Mr. Rohde.

title: Democrats Divided as House Passes Peru Trade Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  Defying appeals from labor leaders, environmentalists and foes of free-trade, nearly half the Democrats in the House joined today with the Bush administrations backers to support a trade liberalization agreement with Peru that the White House hopes will lead to the approval of future trade deals.

title: Wanted in Germany, Terrorism Suspect Arrested in Turkey
description: BERLIN, Nov. 7  The Turkish police have arrested a suspect in what the German authorities said in September was a plot to conduct a series of deadly bombings against German and American targets.

title: Security Study Urged for Atlantic Yards
description: Of the many criticisms leveled against the planned Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn, two of the major ones are that it would worsen traffic in an already congested area and that its 18,000-seat basketball arena might provide a tempting target for terrorists.

title: Ex-Gov. Ryan of Illinois Reports to Prison
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 7  Former Gov. George Ryan, who drew international attention for halting the death penalty in this state, reported to a federal prison in Wisconsin on Wednesday to begin his six-and-a-half-year sentence for racketeering and fraud.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q.  How do I clean a fabric lampshade?

title: North Korea Still a Threat, South Korean Tells Gates
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 7  The military threat presented by North Korea has not diminished despite its early steps to dismantle its nuclear weapons program, the South Korean defense minister said Wednesday.

title: Small Town Mourns a Running Marvel
description: CENTRAL LAKE, Mich., Nov. 7  It snowed the night they brought Ryan Shay home to bury him. Three hundred candles in paper bags lined the inner lane of the high school track. The wind extinguished some candles and ignited several bags into balls of flame.

title: Polanski to Film the Ghost
description: Roman Polanski has signed on to direct a film adaptation of The Ghost, a political thriller written by Robert Harris and published last month in the United States by Simon & Schuster. The novel is narrated by a ghostwriter for a former British prime minister, Adam Lang, who is writing his memoirs. Lang recently stepped down after a sharp slide in popularity because of his support for an American-led war, and his first collaborator has mysteriously died. In an interview, Mr. Polanski, who lives in France and had been working with Mr. Harris on a film adaptation of Mr. Harriss novel Pompeii, said he read The Ghost and knew right away that he wanted to turn it into a film. A political thriller is exactly what I wanted, said Mr. Polanski, the director of Chinatown and Rosemarys Baby, who won an Oscar for The Pianist in 2003. I like books that I cant put down, and at the same time its a kind of satire on certain political situations with which we are only too well acquainted. A large portion of The Ghost takes place on Marthas Vineyard; Mr. Polanski wont be able to film there because he has remained a fugitive since fleeing the United States in 1978 to avoid prison after pleading guilty to statutory rape. It doesnt really matter where you do it, Mr. Polanski said, referring to filming The Ghost, which he hopes to begin next fall. It just has to be somewhere on the Atlantic off season where you have dunes and empty roads and unlived-in holiday houses.

title: Just Forget All the Muss, Your Photos Will Now Upload Themselves
description: If youve ever looked at a digital camera full of photos and thought, Best get to it, those pictures arent going to upload themselves, you can think again.

title: Giants Keep Running to Delight of Linemen
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 7  The wind swirled around Giants Stadium, and it blew cold across the adjacent practice field. It carried the first icy hint of winter.

title: Blanket Statements
description: WHEN it comes to making a bed, there are two kinds of people: those who like comforters and those who prefer blankets. Bill Sofield, the New York interior designer, counts himself among the latter. On his bed, Mr. Sofield uses a top sheet and a blanket without a bedspread to create a casual but tailored look, he said. Its very satisfying to go to sleep under the weight of a wool blanket, he added. Comforters are too fluffy.

title: Gathering Storm
description: What does it say when a leader tells his people he must suspend their civil rights in order to combat extremism, then locks up judges, lawyers and human rights activists  societys most moderate forces  while Osama bin Laden and the Taliban run free? And what are those oppressed people supposed to conclude when the reaction of the world and even some of their own leaders is grudging?

title: Staten Island: Expanded Train Service
description: New York City Transit will expand the express service on the Staten Island Railway next week. On Wednesday, the railway will add five express trains for the evening rush, for a total of 13. The expanded service will be timed to serve passengers on the Staten Island Ferry leaving Manhattan between 4 p.m. and 7:20 p.m. Morning service will expand on Dec. 5 with the addition of three express trains, for a total of nine. The trains will arrive at the Staten Island terminal in time for riders to board ferries from 7 a.m. to 9 a.m. The evening express trains run nonstop from St. George to Great Kills and then make local stops to Tottenville. The morning express trains make all stops between Tottenville and New Dorp and then run nonstop to St. George.

title: Tell the Man Who Plays Gotcha: Gotcha!
description: Every writer knows that he can peruse his own prose for days and not spot a mistake. But if he casts his eyes over someone elses writing, the errors leap off the page.

title: South Korean Says North Still a Threat
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 7  The military threat presented by North Korea has not diminished despite early steps by Pyongyang to dismantle its nuclear weapons program, the South Korean defense minister said today.

title: Manhattan: Sentence in Terror Case
description: A jazz bassist and martial arts expert from the Bronx who pleaded guilty this year to terrorism charges was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court to 15 years in prison. In April, the defendant, Tarik Shah, 44, admitted taking part in a plot to teach would-be Qaeda operatives to wage jihad with hand-to-hand combat. An undercover F.B.I. informant recorded Mr. Shah making incriminating statements.

title: Oprah Winfrey Spurns Racists Book
description: Oprah Winfrey banished from her list of recommended books a prize-winning best seller written by a white supremacist under a pseudonym, The Associated Press reported. The book, The Education of Little Tree, was supposedly the true story of an orphaned boy raised by his Cherokee grandfather. It was first published in 1976 as the work of Forrest Carter, who was later identified as Asa Earl Carter, a member of the Ku Klux Klan. Mr. Carter was also a speechwriter for George Wallace, the former governor of Alabama, and wrote Wallaces slogan: Segregation today, segregation tomorrow, segregation forever. Ms. Winfrey said the book had been posted in error among recommended titles like The Color Purple and The Grapes of Wrath. She said she did not know how long it had been on the her Web site (oprah.com). In 1994 she discussed Little Tree on her television show, saying she had once been a fan, but when she learned the truth about it, felt she had to take the book off my shelf.

title: A Crowded Family Enters the Space Age
description: ERIC ALAN and his wife, Rhonda Voo, had long wanted to enlarge the 1,100-square-foot bungalow that they shared with their three daughters in the Palms district on the west side of Los Angeles. But it wasnt until they went shopping at the new L.A. Eyeworks store on Beverly Boulevard that they found the right person to do it.

title: M.L.S. Playoffs Ride a Cultured Left Foot
description: Michelangelo, da Vinci, Beethoven and Benjamin Franklin  all ambidextrous. Soccer players are taught to emulate those geniuses with their feet, because you never know when opportunity will come skittering.
Manhattan

title: Personalizing the Management of Heartburn
description: Dr. Joel E. Richter is chairman of the department of medicine at Temple University in Philadelphia and a leading research scientist in the field of gastroenterology. He has published more than 500 articles on gastroesophageal reflux disease.

title: Retailers Report Weak October Sales
description: The holiday shopping outlook just got even grimmer.

title: Recent Dings Dont Dent Toyota Profit
description: TOKYO, Nov. 7  Another quarter of higher profit at Toyota, Japans largest automaker, showed Wednesday that the companys growth remained strong despite soaring global fuel prices and hints of an economic slowdown in its biggest market, the United States.

title: Yes, Tune In Tomorrow: No Soap Reruns for Now
description: While the sidelining of The Colbert Report until further notice is one of the more prominent repercussions of the film and television writers strike, there are other uncertainties: Will that passionate kiss shared this week by Marina and Cyrus after Cyrus nearly died signal a permanent reconciliation?

title: Markets Jolted by Oil Surge and Worries Over Slowdown
description: Stock markets plummeted and the dollar sank to a record low against the euro today as investors worldwide grew skittish over rising oil prices and the prospect of a substantial economic slowdown in the United States.

title: Congratulations on the Book Award, and Welcome to the Scrutiny
description: BRAY, Ireland  The Man Booker Prize carries with it a check for 50,000 (about $105,000), a guaranteed increase in book sales and, for little-known authors, instant popular recognition. But the spotlight sometimes falls in unexpected places.

title: A Painters Painter, Working With a Cast of Big Heads
description: It is instructive to imagine the D C Moore Gallerys 10-year survey of Mark Greenwolds small, fraught Realist paintings in one of New Yorks major museums. Such a fantasy points up how narrowly even the best art institutions tend to define contemporary art, and how easily and rewardingly those strictures might be stretched.

title: Channeling Mother Earth
description: Take one part adventure sports, mix with one part geology class, and youll get Fearless Planet, a new six-part series hosted by Will Gadd, an adventure sports veteran. In the series, which starts Sunday evening on the Discovery Channel, Gadd takes what he describes as a literal jump into the wildest, most beautiful places on Earth, and also talks with some geologists and experts who, with the help of some fancy computer graphics, help explain the areas geological processes.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Encouraging Blooms

title: E.U. Offers Serbia a Deal Towards Eventual Membership
description: LJUBLJANA, Slovenia, Nov. 7  With a deadline for negotiations over the disputed province of Kosovo just a month away, the European Union gave pro-Western forces in Serbia a boost today, initialing with Serbia a deal that could lead to Serbia joining the 27-nation group.

title: Sleuthing for a Danger in Toy Beads
description: HONG KONG, Thursday, Nov. 8  The story started with a 2-year-old boy who was taken to a suburban Sydney hospital on Oct. 5 in a shallow coma and suffering from seizurelike spasms. It ended with the latest recall of a Chinese-made toy, as the Consumer Product Safety Commission ordered the recall of 4.2 million Aqua Dots in the United States on Wednesday evening.

title: Ohio Goes After Charter Schools That Are Failing
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Ohio became a test tube for the nations charter school movement during a decade of Republican rule here, when a wide-open authorization system and plenty of government seed money led to the schools explosive proliferation.

title: U.S. Will Ask a Grand Jury to Indict Kerik
description: Federal prosecutors will ask a grand jury today to indict Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York police commissioner, on charges that include tax fraud, corruption and conspiracy counts, according to people who have been briefed on the case.

title: Really Thinking About Things
description: Boston

title: Tip of the Week: Viewing Gmail From Anywhere
description: If youre a Gmail user, you can now set up your account to use Internet Message Access Protocol (IMAP) with your favorite e-mail program. Unlike the older POP mail system, which typically confines message downloads to the computer or the device you are working on, IMAP is server-based so your mailbox has all the current messages no matter where you use it  on a computer, Web browser or mobile device. Using IMAP with Gmail is free, and instructions on setting it up with different mail programs are at preview.tinyurl.com/yofbl9.

title: Visa Agrees to Pay Amex $2.1 Billion to Settle Suit
description: Visa has agreed to pay $2.1 billion to its credit card rival American Express to settle damages relating to a 2004 antitrust lawsuit.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Georgia Leader Declares Emergency Over Protest
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 7  The president of Georgia declared a state of emergency Wednesday night after riot police officers used tear gas, rubber bullets and water cannon to clear thousands of demonstrators from the streets of Tbilisi, the capital. The order immediately closed two television stations and banned public assembly in the capital, a senior government official said by telephone.

title: Reaching for Apple, Falling Short
description: The iPhones biggest achievement isnt any particular feature; its the way Apple took veto power away from the cellphone carriers.

title: Deputy Is Killed While Transporting Inmate
description: MIAMI, Nov. 7  A 76-year-old Broward County sheriffs deputy was shot to death on Wednesday by an inmate he was transporting to court, the police said. The inmate overpowered the deputy, shot him with his own gun and dumped him in a parking lot before driving away, investigators said.

title: Nigeria: Charges Against American Dropped
description: Prosecutors dropped charges against Judith Asuni, a 60-year-old American activist arrested along with a Nigerian colleague and two German filmmakers in September while doing research for a documentary film about the troubled, oil-rich Niger Delta. Ms. Asuni, left, and her colleague faced charges tantamount to espionage that could have brought a seven-year prison term. She has lived in Nigeria for more than 30 years and is a controversial fixture in the violent and chaotic delta, well known for her links to the power elite. A prosecutor told reporters that the charges had been dropped in the public interest.

title: With Patience, a Family of 6 Builds Up
description: AFTER they had their fourth child, Lucy Musgrave and Zad Rogers realized they had outgrown their four-bedroom, 1,100-square-foot apartment in a central London high-rise. But they found few choices nearby for a family of their size.

title: The Antisuburbanites
description: AS hard as it is to find enough space for a family in New York City, the Census Bureau reports that the number of young children living in Manhattan increased by more than 30 percent between 2000 and 2006. And stroller-clogged sidewalks, child-friendly cafes and busy online message boards for parents in cities around the world confirm that its possible to raise children without moving to the suburbs.

title: Germany: Industrial Output Rises
description: German industrial output unexpectedly increased in September, led by the construction and energy sectors. Production rose a seasonally adjusted 0.3 percent from August, when it advanced 1.9 percent, the Economy and Technology Ministry said. Economists expected a 0.5 percent decline. Output rose 6 percent from the period a year earlier, when adjusted for the number of working days. Construction rose 0.7 percent in September from a month earlier and energy output gained 1 percent, the report said. Production of consumer durables was down 4.4 percent.

title: Ford Narrows Quarterly Loss
description: DETROIT, Nov. 8  The Ford Motor Company said today that it lost $380 million in the third quarter, flipping back to a loss after a surprise profit in the second quarter.

title: New Autopsy of Prisoner Fails to Resolve Mystery
description: A new autopsy report has added to the mystery surrounding the possible beating of an Alabama inmate who died shortly after being imprisoned for killing two police officers.

title: Voters Split on Spending Initiatives on States Ballots
description: In Texas, voters were in a spending mood on Tuesday. In New Jersey and Oregon, they were not.

title: Trump Steps In as Partner for Troubled Meadowlands Project
description: The developer Donald J. Trump pledged yesterday to rescue the troubled EnCap golf and housing development in the New Jersey Meadowlands, saying he would come up with a new design, a world-class golf course and more upscale housing.

title: Renovating for a Flexible Future
description: THERE is a fairly predictable real estate trajectory for the growing family in New York, from single-life studio to one bedroom, from one bedroom to two. A dining alcove becomes the nursery, you annex the apartment next door, and then the outer boroughs and finally the suburbs beckon.

title: Congress Warms to Frances New President
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7  The United States Congress welcomed Nicolas Sarkozy, the French president, with loud cheers and standing ovations on Wednesday, a sign that France had been forgiven for opposing the American-led war in Iraq.

title: Spelling Bee Ends Run
description: After three years in New York, two and a half of them on Broadway at the Circle in the Square Theater, The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee is closing. The musical, which opened on Broadway on May 2, 2005, after a sold-out engagement Off Broadway at Second Stage Theater, will end its run on Jan. 20. It won two Tony Awards and will have played 121 previews and 1,136 regular performances. . ... Second Stage has announced that Alice Ripley (Side Show) and Brian dArcy James (The Apple Tree) will play the lead roles in Next to Normal, a new musical by Tom Kitt and Brian Yorkey starting performances there on Jan. 16.

title: Hearing Begins in O.J. Simpson Case
description: LAS VEGAS, Nov. 8  The man who contends that O. J. Simpson stole $100,000 in sports memorabilia from him told a judge on Thursday that the former football star led a six-minute military-invasion-fashion raid in September in a Las Vegas hotel room.

title: Immigration Status of Newark Shooting Suspect in Question
description: Rodolfo Godinez, one of six suspects in the Aug. 4 shooting deaths of three young people in a Newark schoolyard, will be detained by immigration authorities even if he is able to post $3 million bail, Essex County prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Congressional Democrats Grow Wary of Spitzer License Plan
description: Democratic members of Congress, having watched Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton stumble on the question of whether states should give drivers licenses to illegal immigrants, are growing increasingly agitated over Gov. Eliot Spitzers plan to do so and are calling for him to shelve the idea.

title: Ways to Fix the Health Care System
description: To the Editor:

title: Germany: Suspect in Bomb Plot Arrested in Turkey
description: Atilla Selek, a 22-year-old German with Turkish parents sought in connection with a reported plot to bomb German and American facilities in Germany, has been arrested in Turkey. Turkish officials said he was detained Tuesday in Konya, his familys hometown. Three other men, two Germans and a Turkish resident of Germany, are already in custody. German authorities said the plot was in an advanced stage when they uncovered it in September and seized large quantities of potentially explosive chemicals. German officials said Mr. Selek may have helped obtain detonators. In an interview in September, he denied having any links to the plot or to terrorism.

title: Gunmen Attack Opponents of Chvezs Bid to Extend Power
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 7  Masked gunmen shot into a group of students on Wednesday at this countrys most prestigious university. The students were returning from a march here protesting changes to the Constitution proposed by President Hugo Chvez that could allow him to remain in power indefinitely.

title: For All You Smartphone Users With Big Thumbs: Motorolas New Q Global Aims to Encourage You to Type
description: Motorolas Moto Q line of smartphones has a new entry, the Q Global, also called the Q9h. This one has been redesigned to make services easy to activate with dedicated keys, so it takes one click to get to e-mail, the calendar, music, the Internet, the camera (both still and video) and the phone.

title: Markets and Dollar Sink as Slowdown Worry Increases
description: Stock markets plummeted and the dollar sank to a record low against the euro yesterday as investors worldwide grew skittish over rising oil prices and the prospect of a substantial economic slowdown in the United States.

title: Ingenuity in Space
description: The astronauts and their support team on the ground performed admirably under difficult conditions on an unusually busy and lengthy mission that ended with a smooth landing yesterday. Their accomplishments were a testimonial to the ingenuity of NASA  and a warning of how precarious the nations space ventures can become when unexpected glitches develop far from the nearest repair shop.

title: Country Music Awards
description: The 41st annual Country Music Awards took place in Nashville.

title: Footnote
description: Footnote

title: In Paris? Try inventive British or American fusion fare
description: By Katrin Bennhold

title: Scenes From Performa 07
Finicky Foodies
description: Were far from reader averse, so heres some reader verse. Eat, Drink & Make Crazy, sent in by Leon Freilich of Park Slope, Brooklyn:

title: Feeling Blank Inside
description: Brian Regan of Comedy Central on greeting cards:

title: Build Up That Wall
description: Hallie Stephens and Holly Pakfar made a one-bedroom apartment in Stuyvesant Town more livable by dividing the living room.

title: Nasdaq to Add Philly Exchange to Its Stable
description: The Nasdaq Stock Market confirmed Wednesday that it would acquire the Philadelphia Stock Exchange for $652 million to expand its presence in the fast-growing equity options business.

title: Kirin Swallows Australias National Foods
description: The Japanese brewer Kirin Holdings will buy an Australian dairy and juice producer, National Foods for $1 billion from a Philippine partner San Miguel as it seeks growth away from stagnating beer sales.

title: KRG Capital Closes $1.96 Billion Fund
description: Midmarket buyout firm KRG Capital Partners said it closed its fourth private equity fund at $1.96 billion, beating its $1.25 billion target by 57 percent.

title: K.K.R. Affiliate Stung by Subprime
description: KKR Financial Holdings, a specialty finance unit of the buyout shop Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, shed its mortgage business and closed a series of collateralized loan obligations as the firm swung to a third-quarter loss after taking an expected hit from the credit crunch.

title: Kraft Adds 2 Directors Allied With Peltz
description: Kraft Foods on Wednesday struck a deal with the activist investor Nelson Peltz, adding two board members nominated by his Trian Partners and avoiding a potential proxy battle.

title: Cheyne Pays $6.7 Million in Tax Settlement in Britain
description: Cheyne Capital, the British hedge fund manager whose $6.7 billion structured investment vehicle Cheyne Finance went into bankruptcy last month, has paid a 3.2 million pound ($6.7 million) tax settlement to British authorities.

title: Delphi Gets Exit Financing From Citigroup and JPMorgan
description: Bankrupt Delphi has revealed the lending group that has agreed to provide close to $7 billion to help the insolvent auto parts maker emerge from court protection.

title: American Public Boosts I.P.O. Price
description: American Public Education increased the expected price range of its initial public offering to $18 to $19 a share, setting up the companys two venture capital owners for a richer-than-expected payday.

title: MerchantCircle Rounds Up New Funding
description: MerchantCircle, a pioneer in online local advertising, raised $10 million in a Series B financing round, sticking with its faithful early-stage investors and adding a pair of key strategic partners.

title: Close Brothers Spurns $2.9 Billion Buyout Offer
description: The Close Brothers Group, a 129-year-old British investment bank, rejected a 1.4 billion pound ($2.9 billion) cash offer from Cenkos Securities and a partner, Landsbanki Islands.

title: Morgan Stanley Takes a Hit on Mortgages
description: Morgan Stanley said it would take a $3.7 billion charge for nonperforming assets tied to subprime mortgages, underscoring how much the tight credit market was affecting even peripheral players in the mortgage market.

title: Digg Said to Be Close to Sale
description: Digg, a popular news site where readers rank stories, was the subject of renewed takeover rumors on Wednesday, as the Valleywag blog, citing anonymous sources, said a major media player was close to acquiring it for $300 million to $400 million. Diggs chief executive declined to comment to CNET News.com on the rumor.

title: After Alibaba, Baidu Considers I.P.O. of Its Own
description: The Chinese Internet search firm Baidu.com is pondering acquisitions and possibly a Hong Kong share listing to fuel an expansion into the countrys consumer Internet market, taking on Alibaba.com in the worlds second-largest Web market.

title: Wall Streets Minnows Make Big Calls on Banks
description: A few hitherto unknown analysts have made names for themselves recently with their headline-grabbing calls on investment banking writedowns, Breakingviews says.

title: Buyout Shops Cash in Lenovo Shares
description: Shares of the Lenovo Group, the computer maker, fell 6.4 percent Wednesday in Hong Kong as three private equity firms sold part of their holdings to cash in 2.9 billion Hong Kong dollars ($372 million) after the stock hit a seven-year high.

title: Another Advertising Deal for AOL
description: AOL said it would buy Quigo, a seller of small, sponsored links that run next to articles, marking its fourth advertising acquisition this year. The price was reported to be about $340 million.

title: A New Four-Letter Word on Wall Street: Retirement
description: The Financial Times John Gapper has a bone to pick with Merrill Lynch and Citigroup over the semantics used to describe the departures of the banks chief executives.

title: Will Mergers Ease Investment Banks Pain?
description: With all the misery surrounding investment banks of late, is a spate of industry mergers on the horizon? The answer, one analyst told Reuters, is a resounding yes.

title: Tailor-Made in Hong Kong
description: By Matthew Driskill

title: AQR Capital Said to Shelve I.P.O. Plans
description: AQR Capital Management, the hedge-fund firm run by a former trader at Goldman Sachs, Cliff Asness, has been forced to shelve plans for an initial public offering after poor performance caused several large investors to pull their cash from the firms $38 billion fund, The New York Post reported.

title: Rubin Is Set to Back Clinton
description: Robert E. Rubin, Treasury secretary in the Clinton administration and new chairman of Citigroup, has overcome early misgivings about Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons presidential candidacy and will support her publicly in the fight for the Democratic nomination, The New York Times reported.

title: Kansas Governor Gets No Apology From Big Coal
description: [UPDATE 11/11: See below for Republican lawmakers point of view on this fight.]

title: How Will Keriks Indictment Affect Giuliani?
description: Federal prosecutors will ask a grand jury today to indict Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York police commissioner, on charges that include tax fraud, corruption and conspiracy counts, William K. Rashbaum and Russ Buettner explain in a front-page article.

title: Start of a Trend?
description: From The Onion:

title: S.E.C. Looks Into Merrills Subprime Holdings
description: Merrill Lynch disclosed on Wednesday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had begun an inquiry into its mortgage-related holdings. It also said that its total exposure to mortgage-related securities is $27.2 billion, or $6.3 billion more than what it said last month.

title: Rio Tinto Rejects $140 Billion Takeover Bid
description: BHP Billiton said Thursday that it had approached Rio Tinto about a potential takeover that would create a global mining giant worth about $360 billion. Rio rejected its offer, but BHP added that it would continue to press for a deal, which would rank among the largest mergers in history.

title: The Early Word: Giuliani Backers
description: The unlikely alliance of Rudolph W. Giuliani and evangelical broadcaster Pat Robertson yesterday brought mixed reaction from Republicans. Some conservative Christians worry whether the thrice-married Giuliani shares their values, and other G.O.P. members wonder if Mr. Giulianis alliance with a controversial televangelist will turn off moderate voters.

title: Russians Accused of Poisoning Tennis Star
description: Tommy Haass severe case of food poisoning at the Davis Cup would be a rather tame addition to the annals of Russian poisoning accusations.

title: Jim Cramer in Middle of Spitzer-Cuomo Niceties

title: Mining for a Blockbuster Merger
description: Its hardly a done deal, but if BHP Billiton succeeds in acquiring its rival mining giant Rio Tinto, it would be a tie-up for the record books. Deal price tags have not been this high since 2000, a banner year for megamergers that brought us the union of America Online and Time Warner.

title: Mayor Offers Best Wishes (but No Haiku) to Torre

title: Slowing the Sharks Vanishing Act
description: Two environmental groups have put out a fresh call to the United States to strengthen the Shark Finning Prohibition Act, a 2000 law aimed at blunting the illegal trade in shark fins that biologists say has devastated shark populations worldwide in the last decade or so.

title: Thursday Morning Kickoff
description: Well, well, well. The same place that may have hosted the best college football game of the year also hosted the first huge college basketball upset of the season. We interrupt this football blog for a basketball shocker: The 20th-ranked Kentucky hoops team lost to Gardner-Webb last night. Andy Katz does a nice job here with the late wrap up.

title: Schreibers Notes: Three Lefties to Trade For
description: The Red Sox signing Curt Schilling the other day is a signal that, for a relatively reasonable amount of money ($8 million plus incentives), the team didnt see anybody out there on the free agent market that was very attractive. Boston could have explored trades, but instead they locked up Schilling before he could get away.

title: Berlin in Lights: Weill and a Less Celebrated Name
description: Tonight the Austrian composer H.K. Gruber, also known as a conductor and a most unconventional chansonnier, comes to Zankel Hall to lead a pick-up ensemble in works by Kurt Weill and Hanns Eisler. Though you never know, the program should be fascinating.

title: Genetic Elvis for Sale
description: Bill Beeny, who has run the Elvis Is Alive Museum in Wright City, Mo., for 17 years, is selling the museums contents on eBay. Along with books, newspapers clippings and a Cadillac is, he says, convincing evidence that Elvis Presley did not die in 1977:

title: Online Socializing: Safer Than You Think?
description: To many parents, Web sites like My Space and Facebook are a threat, a door open to the outside world that lets strangers into homes. But the benefits of online interaction may far outweigh the risks.

title: Orange Bowl Memories
description: When Miami plays hosts to Virginia on Saturday it will be the Hurricanes last game in the Orange Bowl before moving to Dolphin Stadium next season. The cost to renovate the stadium was too high and the appeal of more modern facilities was too great. As a result, the Hurricanes 70th season in the Orange Bowl will be their last.

title: After Further Review?
description: Earlier this week, baseballs general managers recommended for the first time that the league allow instant replay. The proposal is limited to instant replay on possible home run balls  whether they are fair or foul, for instance  and faces several more layers of approval. Is this a move in the right direction for baseball, or a bad precedent?

title: Goodbye, You Dirty Old Charmer

title: On the Trading Block: Kobe Trade Rumors
description: Kobe Bryant might be traded, and he might not, writes Will Leitch in this weeks Play newsletter. Hell tell reporters he wants to be traded, then hell back off, then hell post a message to his Web site, then hell recant it hours later. None of it means anything. Currently in Google, Kobe Bryant Championship brings up 702,000 hits; Kobe Bryant trade brings up 926,000. This will be his legacy, and ours.

title: Say, What?: The White House on Pakistan
description: From todays press briefing by White House press secretary Dana Perino, after the Pakistani military ruler, General Pervez Musharraf, announced that elections scheduled for Jan. 15 will be delayed for no more than a month, which means they might now be held by Feb. 15:

title: Town & Country
description: The most exciting thing that happened on vacation was the mouse that came back to life. This happens to a lot of designers we know. A bad season, and then, presto, born again. I tried to do as little as possible during my holiday, which essentially entailed the odd flirtatious dance with the vacuum cleaner. Everything was too much and nothing was too little, if you know what I mean. My son brought home Terry Richardsons book of his father Bob Richardsons photographs and we especially liked Bobs stories and his straight-forward opinions about other photographers, mainly Avedon and Meisel. I think Terry did a great job with the book; its a valuable resource for young photographers, and a week or so later, when I saw Terrys recent pictures in Vogue Hommes International, particularly of James Franco, I sensed again the sons desire to be contemporary. Like his dad. (Vogue Hommes also has a pretty good interview with Calvin Klein; especially interesting was what he had to say about Mark Wahlberg, then and now.)

I think the column is worth looking at, and talking about, because it touches on an issue that no doubt affects most restaurants in this city (and country) and that inspires disagreement among diners.

title: 3 Elections, 3 Victories for Brooklyn Councilman
description: This was widely forecast to be a hotly competitive election season for City Councilman Mathieu Eugene. But Mr. Eugene was unopposed in the September primary, and he won Tuesdays election against a little-known Republican with 90 percent of the vote.

description: I was struck Wednesday reading Louise Storys article on Facebooks new service which would allow users of the social networking site to broadcast ads to their so-called friends. I think this new advertising push is going to redefine friendship on Facebook.

title: Berlin in Lights: Youth and Mahler
description: There is a lot of Mahler in Berlin in Lights, with Simon Rattle leading the Berlin Philharmonic in the Symphonies Nos. 9 and 10 and Das Lied von der Erde at Carnegie Hall. And there is a lot of Gustavo Dudamel and the Simn Bolvar Youth Orchestra of Venezuela, with two concerts at Carnegie Hall. But never the twain shall meet.

title: Will $100 Oil Move the U.S.?
description: Last year New York Times columnist and author Tom Friedman hoped that $100-a-barrel oil would induce the U.S. to finally curb its energy use excesses and jump into alternative energy. The sooner we go to $100 a barrel, the sooner were going to have everyone in America driving a plug-in hybrid car fueled by corn and ethanol, he said.

Cole.)

title: Fiscal Policy, 30 Years After the Crisis
description: If you ask most New Yorkers about GAAP-balanced budgets, four-year financial plans and the citys emergency financial control board, you are likely to get only a blank stare. But any city resident who lived through the pain and tumult of the mid-1970s can attest to the anxiety caused by tens of thousands of layoffs, the disruption of city services and the looming fear of municipal bankruptcy.The citys Independent Budget Office and the Center for New York City Affairs at the New School organized a gathering of the citys leading experts in municipal finance  including Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs budget director, Mark Page  this morning for a discussion, moderated by Joyce Purnick of The Times. The issue is not a theoretical one, because next year will bring a major change  the first since 1975  in how the citys budget works.

description: One of the more pleasant outcomes of the slowly growing trend toward highly involved fatherhood has been, Ive found, the ability to plainly see that total ninnyishness is not a uniquely female thing.

description: Calling the Hollywood writers strike just a shame, Robert A. Iger, the chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, told analysts today in a quarterly conference call that ABC will feel the impacts of a walkout after four weeks of picketing. It will definitely have an impact on ABCs schedule if a strike stretches into next month, he said.

title: Understand?
Blind Date in Addis
description: I met my son Des for the first time in October of 2003. Well, it wasnt a real meeting  just a video tape meeting. A dear friend who had adopted a child from Ethiopia wanted me to consider an adoption from that country and told me that I could see some nice waiting children on a video if I contacted the agency she used. I had no intention of doing such a thing and that was that. I did not call the agency.

title: Fantasy Loyalty: How Little Can You Take?
description: I cant guarantee Steve Smith will dance in the end zone this week, but you have to wonder if he is dancing somewhere right now: it looks like hell get a break from David Carr on Sunday. Not that Smith was pleased when Carr sustained a concussion last week; its just that he and Carr have had little chemistry this season, and while Carolina (8-8) has been able to tread water through injuries to Jake Delhomme and Vinny Testaverde, Smiths numbers have been in a nosedive with Carr at the controls.

title: When Barnum Took Manhattan
description: SINCE 1766 St. Pauls Chapel at Broadway and Vesey Street has been one of the best-known and most revered landmarks in Lower Manhattan, associated with events from George Washingtons inauguration in 1789 to the destruction of the World Trade Center just behind it in 2001.

title: Oil Spill Fouls Shores in San Francisco Area
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8  A South Korean container ship hit one of the stanchions of the Bay Bridge in a dense fog on Wednesday, spilling 58,000 gallons of bunker oil.

title: Fuel Without the Fossil
description: DENVER  Mitch Mandich proudly showed off his baby, a 150-foot contraption of tanks, valves, hoppers, augers and fans. It hissed. It gurgled. An incongruous smell wafted through the air, the scent of turpentine.

title: Riverhead: Nine Arrested in Gambling Raids
description: Nine people were arrested and more than $10,000 in cash was seized in gambling raids in Suffolk County on Wednesday night, prosecutors said. The raids, at eight locations, followed a robbery at an illegal poker game in Lindenhurst in September, said Thomas J. Spota, the Suffolk County district attorney. In a statement, Mr. Spota said the robbery, by two men carrying shotguns, demonstrated the potential danger of high-stakes poker games. He said that the games attracted violence, and that law enforcement is concerned about the safety of the innocent people in the neighborhoods.

title: Broadway Stagehands to Go on Strike on Saturday
description: Broadways stagehands plan to go on strike Saturday against theater owners and producers in a battle over work rules, according to two people who have been briefed on the decision. After three months of negotiations, Local One, the stagehands union, was told last night by its parent union to walk out, the people said.

title: Getting Religious About Street Parking
description: Today is Diwali, the Hindu festival of lights, celebrating the triumph of good, represented by Lord Rama, over the forces of evil. It is a holiday that thrills some of my friends. Not that they are Hindus themselves.

title: Energetic Cosmic Rays May Start From Black Holes
description: They are the zestiest bits of matter in the universe. They can zing through space for millions of years at essentially the speed of light and with 100 million times the energy produced by the biggest particle accelerators on the earth, before crashing occasionally into Earths atmosphere and dying in a spray of microscopic fluff.

title: Mukasey Wins Vote in Senate, Despite Doubts
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  The Senate confirmed Michael B. Mukasey as attorney general Thursday night, approving him despite Democratic criticism that he had failed to take an unequivocal stance against the torture of terrorism detainees.

description: ATHENS, Nov. 8  Wandering along a walkway in central Athens, Tassos Pouliasis found a sport utility vehicle blocking his path.

title: Mets Look at Trades to Replace Free Agents
description: Mets General Manager Omar Minaya left the general managers meetings in Orlando, Fla., yesterday with no more than he arrived with. But he said, There have been some productive talks to follow up on.

title: Stores See Shoppers in Retreat
description: Consumers have rendered a verdict on the coming holiday season: grim.

title: Master Carver of Old Salem
description: Samuel McIntire (1757-1811) spent his entire life in Salem, Mass. Trained as a carpenter by his father, McIntire taught himself the art of architectural drawing, designed several houses and public buildings and went on to become a master woodcarver. Despite never leaving home, he was an enlightened 18th-century American: self-educated, talented, determined and energetic.

title: European Central Bank Chief Laments Euros Climb
description: FRANKFURT, Nov. 8  The European Central Bank threw its weight Thursday behind attempts to rein in the euro, reflecting concern that the currencys ascent against the dollar is making life harder for European businesses.

title: Rutgerss Master Recruiter to Unveil First Prize
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Nov. 8  For those who have wanted proof that Rutgers Coach Fred Hill is indeed a master recruiter, the wait may be about to end. The Scarlet Knights open their season at home Friday against Tennessee Tech, a game that will serve as the debut of the freshman Corey Chandler, Rutgerss first major recruit during the Hill era.

title: Georgia Leader Calls Early Election to Decide His Fate
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 8  The president of Georgia, Mikheil Saakashvili, today called for a special presidential election on Jan. 5, saying he would test whether he retained a mandate a day after a police crackdown and clashes with opposition demonstrators led the government to declare a state of emergency.

title: Parking Rules Change for Diwali
description: Because of Diwali, the Hindu festival of lights, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Study Finds Carcinogens in Water Near Alberta Oil Sands Projects
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 7  High levels of carcinogens and toxic substances have been found in fish, water and sediment downstream from Albertas huge oil sands projects, according to a new study.

description: DANCE

title: China Urges Iran to Respond Positively on Arms
description: HONG KONG, Friday, Nov. 9  China asked Iran on Thursday to respond positively to international pressures to limit its nuclear program, a possible sign that China is responding to American demands that it take a greater role in combating nuclear proliferation.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about circulation declines in the newspaper industry misstated the number of subscribers to The Wall Street Journal Online who are counted in the newspapers print circulation. About 350,000 online customers  not all 1 million  also pay for a print subscription and are counted in the weekday print circulation of 2 million.

title: Chinese Bank to Open in New York
description: The Federal Reserve has approved the application by the sixth-largest Chinese bank to open an office in New York, its first branch in the United States.

title: Demon Deacons Regroup After Coachs Death
description: In his first two years on the Wake Forest mens basketball team, guard Harvey Hale Jr. was often singled out for criticism by Coach Skip Prosser.

title: A Bad Day at the Office
description: Swift and stealthy P2 is a canny exploitation of one of the urban womans greatest fears: the after-hours parking garage. Throw in a car that wont start, a creepy security guard and a filmmaking team with perfect synchronicity, and the result is a minimalist nightmare.

title: Drum Lessons Fall Victim to Hard Times
description: Sherri Yancey said that by the time her son, Tyrone, was 4, he had made his own little drum kit from videocassette boxes and was happily tapping away with an old set of drumsticks. She knew it was time for lessons.

title: An Abrupt Slide for Technology Shares
description: Markets slumped for most of the day yesterday as technology stocks succumbed to the turmoil they had largely resisted in recent weeks. Stocks recovered in the final hour, but investors remained anxious as a shaky week on Wall Street neared its close.

title: Goodbye, You Dirty Old Charmer
description: Rickety. For at least the past 40 years, thats been the default modifier for the Orange Bowl Stadium, a Miami landmark since 1937. Electric is more fitting. Start with the shock upon arriving in the neighborhood, when the guy told you treinta  $30  to park on his lawn. When the stands shook and swayed, it felt like it would register on the Richter Scale. A big-play roar for the home team was like Niagara Falls from the Maid of the Mist. Home-field advantage? Huge. The Dolphins played there from 1966 to 1988, went unbeaten in 1972, and made it to four Super Bowls. None since. The University of Miami, which played its home games there, has won five National Championships since 1985, the most in college football. Now the Hurricanes are turning out the lights at the Orange Bowl for the last time after their game against Virginia on Saturday and will move to Dolphins Stadium in North Miami in 2008. Less rickety, less electricity.

title: What It All Comes Down To: Why You?
description: KNOXVILLE, Iowa  Yes, they still ask about Iraq. And they still wonder about plans to reform health care. But for many Democratic voters, a single question is starting to replace all others: Why you?

title: ESPN and Parks Help Lift Disney Income
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 8  The Walt Disney Company reported a 12 percent rise in quarterly net income on Thursday largely from strong gains at ESPN.

description: DETROIT, Nov. 8  With buyers lined up to bid for its Land Rover and Jaguar brands, Ford Motor said Thursday that it had decided to keep Volvo, at least for now, and would make an effort to fix the money-losing Swedish carmaker.

title: Crook or Crime Fighter? Only He Knows for Sure
description: Heist is a loaded word in movie parlance, holding out the promise of an elaborately planned, slickly executed robbery, smart cops tracking craftier criminals, and, almost always, a brilliant mastermind. The Planman, a crime thriller on BBC America this Sunday, plays on those expectations by veering in and out of the formula just enough to confound.

title: Santana Could Fill a Big Hole for the Yanks
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 8  The general managers meetings are the appetizer of the baseball off-season, a chance for teams to gauge the market for trades and free agents. The winter meetings next month will be more intense, and with Johan Santana of the Minnesota Twins expected to be dangled then, the Yankees will move aggressively to get him.

title: Graphic Horrors and Private Dramas
description: I was in the camps with my wife and my girlfriend, says the 93-year-old Holocaust survivor Jack Polak in Michle Ohayons documentary Steal a Pencil for Me. And believe me, it wasnt easy.

title: Nets Pull Out a Victory by Turning Up the Pressure
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 8  Pale and slight, Nets Coach Lawrence Frank could pass for an astrophysicist. His approach to basketball is much less cerebral: If the Nets can simply play rugged, passionate defense, they can win almost any game.

title: Italy: Big Bank Acquisition
description: Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena, an Italian bank, agreed to buy Banca Antonveneta from Banco Santander of Spain for 9 billion euros ($13.2 billion) to increase its branch network by 50 percent. Monte Paschi, based in Siena, is under pressure to grow after its bigger rivals, UniCredit and Intesa Sanpaolo, expanded through takeovers. Based in Padua, Antonveneta has 1,000 branches concentrated in Italys northwest.

title: Fed Chief Warns of Worse Times in the Economy
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, told Congress on Thursday that the economy was going to get worse before it got better, a message that received a chilly reception from both Wall Street and politicians.

title: Dostoyevskys Homicidal Student, the 90-Minute Version
description: Who would have thought that the novel no high school student has ever finished reading would make such engrossing theater?

title: Rangers and Avery Have Plenty to Celebrate
description: When the rookie center Brandon Dubinsky flipped a backhand shot into the Penguins net early in the third period, a ripple of relief flowed through the Rangers.

title: Is It Collusion or Friendly Chats?
description: ORLANDO, Fla.

title: Art Is Brief. You Just Have to Be There.
description: Ars longa, vita brevis? Physics doesnt really work that way. Everythings falling to pieces all the time, bodies quickly, sculptures and paintings more slowly but just as surely. We build museums that look like banks or arks, but to no avail. Protect and conserve as we will, art is forever going, going, gone.

title: Who Put the Trance in Transylvania?
description: We may as well start with the obvious questions about Young Frankenstein, the really big show from Mel Brooks that opened last night at the Hilton Theater. The answer to all of them is no.

title: Gangs Terrorize Nigerias Vital Oil Region
description: PORT HARCOURT, Nigeria  Rosemary Douglas has no connection to the oil business that pumps more than two million barrels of crude a day from beneath the swampy Niger Delta. But the violence surrounding it pierced her home in September anyway, when a bullet shattered her upper left arm as she napped with her 2-year-old daughter.

title: A Real Estate Speculator Goes From Boom to Bust
description: ST. CHARLES, Mo.  The home foreclosure business was very good to Todd Haupt. He started buying and flipping foreclosed houses in 1994, when he was 20, and by 2000 he graduated to building homes.

title: The Circus as Snow Globe, Shaken Very Hard
description: If youve ever dreamed of sitting inside a snow globe, your lucky day has arrived.

title: Uncorking One Familys Secret
description: Graham Swifts lugubrious new novel, Tomorrow, is told in the voice of an Englishwoman named Paula Hook silently addressing her children. Unable to sleep, Paula worries about what is going to happen the next morning: She and her husband, Mike, have decided that tomorrow is Doomsday or Bombshell Day, the day they are going to tell their 16-year-old twins, Kate and Nick, a family secret that will change all our lives. Mike and Paula have dreaded this moment for years: Earlier this evening they planned a terminal supper, and made love in a special, a poignant, a farewell way. As the narrator sees it, the ordeal to come is her husbands real moment of judgment, and she tells her children that they will be in a position to decide in his favor or not. She says she has no idea how Nick and Kate will react to his news: I picture a bomb going off and this house falling to bits. I picture everything remaining oddly, precariously, ominously the same. An unexploded bomb. It still might go off  next week, the week after, any time. The big secret, which seems pretty obvious to the attentive reader early on, is revealed about halfway through the novel  and this is fair warning to readers who would prefer not to know: that Mike is not the twins biological father, that they were conceived by artificial insemination, using an anonymous donors sperm.

title: Two Sculpture Pals for Adele Bloch-Bauer I
description: Two sculptures by the Belgian artist George Minne have been given to the Neue Galerie by the heirs of Adele Bloch-Bauer, whose 1907 portrait by Gustave Klimt was bought last year for the museum by Ronald S. Lauder for $135 million. The portrait, Adele Bloch-Bauer I, was sold to him after the Austrian government returned to the family five Klimt paintings looted by the Nazis.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: At Morgan Stanley, a New Focus on Succession
description: Like all chief executives on Wall Street, John J. Mack has grappled with the question of who will succeed him.

title: A Former Dutch Enclave Charms a New Generation
description: THERE is no marble in Marbletown, N.Y., but there is a lot of limestone. And starting in the 18th century, Dutch settlers built their homes with gray, squarish chunks of it, giving their walls a marbled cast. On more than three-dozen vintage structures today, that look endures, so perhaps the misnomer can be forgiven.

title: Democrats Tie Iraq Spending Bill to a Pullout Goal
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  Congressional Democrats renewed their challenge to President Bushs Iraq war policy on Thursday, offering $50 billion in interim spending for combat operations coupled to a goal of pulling out most troops within a year.

title: Toward Greater Import Safety
description: Give the Bush administration credit for some sound thinking on how to enhance the safety of imported foods and goods. But whether the thinking will be translated into a vigorous program of safety regulation is still an open question.

title: Life Without Parole for Killer of a Police Officer
description: With his long legs stretched out to cross at the ankles, his gaze like a vacant lot, Allan Cameron was sentenced yesterday to life in prison with no chance of parole for murdering a police officer during a midnight car chase through the streets of Flatbush.

title: Chinese Calls Prompts CBC to Pull Show
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 8  Hours before a heavily promoted documentary about the Falun Gong spiritual sect in China was scheduled to go on the air, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation withdrew the show from its lineup, saying its decision was influenced in part by phone calls from Chinese diplomats in Canada.

title: Bard President to Meet With City Over C Grade
description: One of New Yorks most prominent educators, Leon Botstein, the president of Bard College, has joined the chorus of criticism over the City Department of Educations blunt new A through F rating system for public schools, saying in an interview yesterday that it was reductive and depressing.

title: Willingly or Unwillingly, Calling New York Their Home
description: Making a Home: Japanese Contemporary Artists in New York is the first significant group show at Japan Society since Takashi Murakamis 2005 Little Boy: The Arts of Japans Exploding Subculture. In that exhibition the repressed trauma of the atom bomb played out in video, painting and toylike sculptural objects. If Little Boy offered a glimpse into Mr. Murakamis childhood bedroom, Making a Home, organized by the independent curator Eric C. Shiner, is more of a spec house.

title: Italy: U.S. Black Hawk Crashes; 5 Dead
description: Five American soldiers were killed and seven wounded after an Army Black Hawk helicopter crashed outside Treviso, not far from the Aviano Air Base from which it had taken off. The base supplies soldiers for the American missions in Iraq and Afghanistan and has been a focus of antiwar demonstrators. Local news reports said the helicopter was on a training mission.

title: Congress Turns Back Bushs Veto in  a Test of Power
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  The Senate dealt President Bush the first veto override of his presidency on Thursday, with a resounding bipartisan vote to adopt a $23.2 billion water resources bill that authorizes popular projects across the country.

title: Suit by Civil Liberties Group Presses State on Legal Services for the Indigent
description: On a hapless morning this summer, James Adams, a 44-year-old day laborer, found himself at the Rite-Aid drug store on Salina Street in Syracuse.

title: Art-World Excess Goes to the Butcher Shop
description: Never mind that the world financial markets are in turmoil, or that Sothebys had a very rocky auction night Wednesday. A rich artist and a clever developer will prove this weekend that excess endures.

title: Georgia Leader Calls Early Election to Decide His Fate
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 8  The president of Georgia, Mikheil Saakashvili, on Thursday called for a special presidential election on Jan. 5, saying he would test whether he retained a mandate a day after a police crackdown and clashes with opposition demonstrators led the government to declare a state of emergency.

title: Correction: Room to Share
description: The Living Here column last Friday, about houses with in-law suites, misidentified the university near a house for sale near Bellingham, Wash. It is Western Washington University, not Washington State University.

title: Cat Finds a Roof
description: Nothing is more determined than a cat on a hot tin roof, Maggie the Cat says, and she may be right. The all-African-American revival of Tennessee Williamss Cat on a Hot Tin Roof, which has been in the works for 12 years, seems finally to be settling down on Broadway. We have real estate, the lead producer, Stephen Byrd, said in a telephone interview yesterday. The show, a limited engagement, is to start previews in mid-February at the Broadhurst Theater, with an opening set for March 6. Mr. Byrd would not say anything about the cast, but he did say that Debbie Allen, above, would direct, as previously announced.

title: Righting Human Wrongs
description: Theres a riveting story lurking inside Holly, a documentary-fiction hybrid about sex trafficking in Cambodia. Its just not the one the filmmakers want to tell.

title: Judge Deals Transit Union a Blow on Collecting Dues
description: In scolding language, a state judge refused yesterday to allow the Transport Workers Union to begin automatically collecting dues again from its members, saying he did not find believable the union leaders assertions that it would not strike again.

title: Hearts and Minds: Senator Meets Reporter, Selling a New, Improved War
description: Career Politicians, the Fourth Estate and Disaffected Youth all earn a stern knuckle rapping in Lions for Lambs, Robert Redfords big-screen lecture about civic responsibility and its absence in the Age of Iraq. Those who remain shocked, shocked that elected officials, certain journalists and cosseted college students sat idly by, huffing Hummer fumes and nodding out on 24/7 infotainment (all Britney, all the time), while the administration led the charge, first into Afghanistan and then into Iraq, may find much to embrace here. Everyone else will continue to nod out or resume banging their heads against the wall in bloody frustration.

title: Grand Jury Indicts Kerik on Corruption Charges
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 9  A federal grand jury today indicted Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York police commissioner appointed by Rudolph W. Giuliani while he was mayor, on charges that include tax fraud, obstruction of justice and lying to the White House.

title: Repressed Desires and Sexual Frankness
description: Set over three days, Good Friday through Easter Sunday, and filmed in just as few, Sebastin Lelios raw, largely improvised Sacred Family initially looks as if it were photographed by a 5-year-old.

title: Musical Dreams After Nightmares
description: War/Dance, a visually ravishing documentary that follows a group of schoolchildren from a refugee camp in northern Uganda to a national music competition, raises a fundamental issue for filmmakers confronting unimaginable suffering in war-torn African countries. To what degree should human savagery be softened, sweetened and presented in a spirit of hope to make it palatable to a movie audience?

title: Anger at Decree Runs Deep in Pakistanis
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Nov. 8  Arrested by the hundreds, beaten by the police and tear- gassed, Pakistans lawyers and human rights advocates have led the protests against Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the president. But the anger runs far deeper than Pakistans educated elite.

title: Manhattan: Bail Hearing Set
description: A Manhattan judge scheduled a hearing for this afternoon that could determine whether Shawn Kovell, who was arrested on drug charges last month with Robert E. Chambers Jr., the preppy killer, will be released on bail. The judge acted yesterday, a day after Randy Credico, a comedian who advocates easing penalties for drug use, posted $25,000 cash bail for Ms. Kovell. Prosecutors demanded tax returns and other documents yesterday to determine the source of the money and to ensure that it was not derived from criminal activity. Mr. Credico said he would testify that the bail had come from the sale of land he owned upstate.

title: Merck Agrees to Settle Vioxx Suits for $4.85 Billion
description: Three years after withdrawing its pain medication Vioxx from the market, Merck has agreed to pay $4.85 billion to settle 27,000 lawsuits by people who claim they or their family members suffered injury or died after taking the drug, according to two lawyers with direct knowledge of the matter.

title: Mukasey Sworn In as Attorney General
