description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9  Michael B. Mukasey was sworn in as attorney general this afternoon, less than a day after winning Senate confirmation despite Democratic criticism that he had failed to take an unequivocal stance against the torture of terror detainees.

title: House Approves Creation of a Federal Disaster Insurance Program
description: The House of Representatives approved legislation yesterday that would put the federal government into the home insurance business to deal with natural disasters like hurricanes and the recent wildfires in California.

title: Rising Demand for Oil Provokes New Energy Crisis
description: With oil prices approaching the symbolic threshold of $100 a barrel, the world is headed toward its third energy shock in a generation. But todays surge is fundamentally different from the previous oil crises, with broad and longer-lasting global implications.

title: Releasing Djangos Spirit, With No Brakes Applied
description: There was a time, not long ago, when the Django Reinhardt Festival felt disarmingly like a sance. The spirit of that incomparable Gypsy guitarist was summoned, fearlessly and flagrantly, by a pack of his stylistic heirs. Personalities were celebrated but constrained among the gathered faithful, who strove toward an emulative ideal.

title: John M. Kernochan, Copyright Defender, Dies at 88
description: John M. Kernochan, a leading professor of copyright law and the founder of the Kernochan Center for Law, Media and the Arts at Columbia University, died on Oct. 29 at his home in Jamaica Plain, Mass. He was 88.

title: A Constitutional Centerpiece
description: This advertisement for Representative Ron Paul, Republican of Texas, began running yesterday in New Hampshire. It is part of his first major television campaign, at a total cost of $1.1 million.

title: Police Block Bhutto From Attending Rally
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Friday, Nov. 9  The opposition leader Benazir Bhutto was placed under house arrest this morning, her political party said. Streets were filled with police officers carrying batons and shields, and trucks blocked roads, trying to prevent access to a protest rally that Ms. Bhutto had helped organize in Rawalpindi, the garrison city adjacent to the capital of Islamabad.

title: 500 Iraqis Freed From Crowded U.S. Detention Center
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 8  Nearly 500 Iraqi detainees were released at a ceremony at a sprawling United States detention center in western Baghdad early Thursday, where they were urged by Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki to start a new life, a different life from months ago.

title: Republicans in Congress Propose Bills on Licenses
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  House Republicans have begun to push bills opposing the plan of Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York to grant drivers licenses to illegal immigrants, seeking to step up the pressure on Mr. Spitzers fellow Democrats in Congress, who are increasingly concerned that the issue may become a liability in next years election.

title: Curator of Documentaries and Anthropology Buff
description: THE ode-ettes to joy  and eclecticism  inside Elaine S. Charnovs office at the Museum of Natural History include a pair of throwaway 3-D glasses that project the cheesy insouciance of a John Waters film. Of course she preserved them; theyre functional! Same goes for the vintage Cheerios in her glass bookcase: the box features the cast of Beverly Hills 90210: I plan to sell it on eBay and retire on the proceeds, she jokes.

title: Fiery Speech by Serbian Leader at Trial
description: THE HAGUE, Nov. 8  On the second day of his war crimes trial, Vojislav Seselj, a radical nationalist who is still an influential and popular politician in Serbia, had the chance on Thursday to demonstrate some of his legendary speechmaking prowess. And so he did.

title: Abram Lerner, Museum Director, Dies at 94
description: Abram Lerner, the first director of the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, the repository on the Washington Mall that is part of the Smithsonian Institution and includes works by artists like Picasso, Rodin, Matisse and Mondrian, died on Oct. 31 at his home in Canaan, Conn. He was 94.

title: Protest Greets Police Plan to Map Muslim Angelenos
description: A plan by the counterterrorism bureau of the Los Angeles Police Department to create a map detailing the Muslim communities in that city, an effort described as a step toward thwarting radicalization, has angered civil rights groups, which say it is no better than racial profiling.

title: Reading the Tea Leaves of Financial Statements
description: Mark-to-market accounting is one of those ideas that sound brilliant until you try to do it when there is no market. Thats where mark-to-model comes in: companies say things are worth what they ought to be worth.

title: Brooklyn Convocation of Shakers (and Movers)
description: When the performers of the Tero Saarinen Dance Company and the Boston Camerata concluded Borrowed Light at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday, of course they went backstage and changed into regular clothes and engaged in the usual range of 21st-century activities, including, no doubt, schmoozing at the 25th Next Wave gala after the show.

title: Decks Are Stacked in War Crimes Cases, Lawyers Say
description: GUANTNAMO BAY, Cuba, Nov. 8  The administrations problem-plagued military commission system started up here again Thursday, but it began with contentious new claims that the war crimes cases are unfairly stacked against detainees.

title: Keriks Corruption Case Dogs Giuliani
description: AMES, Iowa, Nov. 8  The scene outside the old Victorian-style courthouse in Dubuque on Thursday morning showed that the indictment of Bernard B. Kerik is at the very least a big distraction for Rudolph W. Giulianis presidential campaign.

title: Police Block Bhutto From Attending Rally
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Friday, Nov. 9  A day after President Bush called, Gen. Pervez Musharraf said Thursday that Pakistans parliamentary elections would be held before Feb. 15. But his security forces widened their crackdown and on Friday moved to prevent the leader of the main opposition party, Benazir Bhutto, from leaving her house to attend a mass protest planned for the afternoon.

title: Trade Accord Causes a Split of Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  Has the Democratic Party gone soft on trade? Or has it opened a bitter internal split that could come back to haunt the party in the coming elections?

title: Hot on the Trail of the Edible Fungi in Illinois
description: TOM NAUMAN was on the hunt, hiking staff in hand, big rubber boots on his feet, tromping downhill through dead leaves and on damp earth. The woods, a deciduous swath next to a golf course, were thick with brambles and vines.

title: Bush Loyalist Now Sees a White House Dangerously Soft on Iran and North Korea
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  The White Houses effort to challenge Irans nuclear ambitions has been hobbled by four and a half years of failed diplomacy. Its policy regarding North Korea is a dangerous fraud. It is pursuing an improbable Palestinian-Israeli peace at the expense of its stance against proliferation in the Middle East.

title: Bill Clinton Says His Wife Took the Rap on Health Care
description: ALBIA, Iowa, Nov. 8  Former President Bill Clinton said Thursday that he should receive more blame than his wife for the failed attempt to revamp the nations health care system more than a decade ago.

title: Witness Supports Simpson on Issue of Guns
description: LAS VEGAS, Nov. 9  The auction house owner who arranged a confrontation between O. J. Simpson and two memorabilia dealers in a Las Vegas hotel room in September said today that Mr. Simpson might not have known two of the men with him brought guns to the incident.

title: Veterans Without Health Care
description: Although many Americans believe that the nations veterans have ready access to health care, that is far from the case. A new study by researchers at the Harvard Medical School has found that millions of veterans and their dependents have no access to care in veterans hospitals and clinics and no health insurance to pay for care elsewhere. Their plight represents yet another failure of our disjointed health care system to provide coverage for all Americans.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Abbado Conducts Again

title: People in the News
description: People

title: Gates Urges More Japanese Action on Global Security
description: TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 9  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates told pacifist Japan on Friday that it had an obligation to take on an expanded role in global security affairs appropriate to its political, economic and military capabilities.

title: They Are Lions, Hear Them Roar
description: ALLEN PARK, Mich., Nov. 8  When the Lions Shaun Rogers rumbled with the intercepted football and his estimated 360 pounds toward the Ford Field end zone last Sunday, he was heading directly toward Harley Duke, who rose to his feet to cheer.

title: Terror in the Bronx
description: To the Editor:

title: Mine Giant Rejects Bid From Rival
description: LONDON, Nov. 8  Underscoring the skyrocketing value of commodities amid increasingly tight supplies, Rio Tinto, the London- and Melbourne-based mining company, rejected a $140 billion bid Thursday from its rival, BHP Billiton  calling it too low. The move squelched, at least for now, what would have been one of the largest acquisitions in corporate history.

title: Spitzer Lawyers Go to Court to Block Subpoenas From State Senate
description: ALBANY, Nov. 8  Lawyers for Gov. Eliot Spitzer asked a state court on Thursday to quash subpoenas from the State Senate seeking information on efforts by the governors aides to discredit Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader. They did so claiming a constitutional privilege to shield the information from disclosure.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Clinton Gets an Instant Chance to Wield a New Weapon
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  It used to be that when a campaign had an argument with a news report, it put out a mass e-mail message disputing the offending item. That was a huge technological leap from the fax machine.

title: U.S. Says South Africa Impedes U.N. Motion to Condemn Rape as a Tactic
description: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 8  The United States accused South Africa on Thursday of obstructing an American-drafted General Assembly resolution that would specifically condemn rape and sexual abuse used by governments and armed groups to achieve political and military objectives.

title: Massachusetts Acting to Extend Abortion Buffer
description: BOSTON, Nov. 8  The Massachusetts legislature gave final approval Thursday to a bill that requires protesters to stand at least 35 feet from clinics that offer abortions.

title: Broadway Stagehands Look Close to Striking
description: The Broadway stagehands union received strike authorization from its parent union last night, and appeared to be on the verge of a walkout against the Broadway producers and theater owners.

title: Trenton: Kean Named Minority Leader
description: Republicans in the New Jersey Senate shuffled their leadership yesterday, replacing Leonard Lance, the minority leader of four years, with Thomas H. Kean Jr., one of the partys youngest and most visible figures. The choice of Mr. Kean was said to be unanimous. Mr. Kean made an unsuccessful run for the United States Senate last year against Robert Menendez. The Democrats new Senate majority leader, Stephen M. Sweeney, said yesterday that he expected to work more closely with Republicans now that Mr. Kean was the minority leader. Compiled by John Sullivan

title: Blame for Poor Home Sales? Its the Press, a Builder Says
description: The housing market is horrible in most parts of the country, says the chief executive of the luxury home builder Toll Brothers, and he fears it will not get better until the newspapers stop saying how bad it is.

title: New Cues for Amtrak
description: To the Editor:

title: Syria to Let U.S. In to Screen Iraqis Seeking Resettlement
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP)  Syria has agreed to allow American interviewers into the country to screen Iraqi refugees for admission to the United States, clearing a major obstacle to the Bush administrations resettlement program, the State Department said Thursday.

title: Thousands of Police Block Pakistan Rally
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 9  In a massive show of force, the Pakistani government stopped a protest rally by the opposition leader, Benazir Bhutto, before it started today, blanketing the rally site with thousands of police, blocking roads to stop demonstrators, and barricading Ms. Bhutto inside her residence in Islamabad.

title: Caution: Children Watching. How Far Do You Push the Envelope?
description: When Ann Liv Young participated in Dance Theater Workshops Family Matters series several years ago, she was asked to make an adjustment in her piece, which involved performers doing upside-down splits with their heads in toilet bowls: Have them don a second pair of underpants.

title: So Much to Juggle in the Middle East
description: To the Editor:

title: California Hot Springs for Any Body
description: JEANRIC held my gaze in his, smiling softly. Close your eyes, he whispered in a gentle French accent, and relax.

title: In Coney Island Creek, Hulk of a Yellow Submarine Sticks Out
description: On long, luckless days when the bluefish and striped bass arent biting, the men who fish in the Coney Island Creek sometimes reel in their lines and contemplate one of the areas enduring mysteries: the wreck of the yellow submarine a few hundred yards from the southern shore of the creek.

title: A Scrappy Tale of a Presidential Campaign
description: At first you are struck by the way the filmmaking in Cocalero, Alejandro Landess documentary about the presidential campaign of Evo Morales in Bolivia, seems to mirror the campaign itself: ragged, bare-bones, perhaps not entirely sure where its going. Hand-held cameras follow Mr. Morales and his supporters on bumpy roads and into remote villages, recording his haircuts and his impromptu jump into a swimming hole in underwear and shirt.

title: Adams Bay Luxury Beach Club and the Ranch Club
description: Adams Bay Luxury Beach Club

title: Christmas Spectacular, by the Numbers
description: Just how extravagant is the extravaganza? Here are some statistics, according to the staff and crew of Radio City Music Hall.

title: Stocks Post Steep Losses, Capping Painful Week
description: Stocks declined sharply today after another large bank said that it would write down the value of some of its assets, reigniting fears of a credit squeeze, and technology stocks extended their losses. The Dow Jones industrial average plummeted more than 200 points, or 1.7 percent.

title: Hear Them Talk and See Them Dance, Then Watch Their Cultures Clash
description: Two men enter the stage and sit on plain office chairs. One opens a laptop and begins to question the other. That was essentially how Pichet Klunchun and myself began, two years ago, when Jrme Bel was invited to a dance festival in Bangkok and proposed a piece with a traditional Thai dancer.

title: The Dependent Claus
description: Given the tasty cocktail of self-amusement and self-contempt that Vince Vaughn brings to almost every on-screen party, it seemed possible that this was one guy who would just say no to Merry Christmas. Forget it: Fred Claus is a tacky would-be comedy about family dysfunction that fronts some Scrooge attitude only to dissolve into slobbering sentimentality and canned uplift. Neither here nor there, the film is Elf without the goofy jokes, Will Ferrell or heart, Bad Santa without the smut, Billy Bob Thornton or spleen.

title: Manhattan: Crane Operators Checked
description: The states labor commissioner, M. Patricia Smith, announced yesterday that she was suspending the certificates of 129 crane operators after learning that licenses were issued to individuals who had failed the crane operators exam. She said that the state inspector general, Kristine Hamann, had recently notified the department that the operators certificates had been improperly issued from 1972 to 2000. This is a public safety issue, Ms. Smith said, adding that the Labor Department was urging the crane operators to retake the practical exam or have their licenses revoked. The Labor Department is checking 3,000 crane operators in the state to determine if their certifications were based on a passing score.

title: Bunnies Who Not Only Hop but Are Also Hip (Alas, the Humans Are Hapless)
description: Finding someone to review a television show for preschoolers is tricky. A lot of people at this newspaper have children, but most of them profess to have no idea what those children are thinking. (Or those children are, well, adults.) As for the youngsters on staff, theyre all busy producing slide shows for the Web site.

title: Fans Return After Knicks Tumultuous Off-Season
description: After dunking against the Denver Nuggets early in the fourth quarter Tuesday, Eddy Curry released a primal scream. As if on key, the capacity crowd at Madison Square Garden yelled back in unison.

title: History, Sure, but Add More Sequins
description: IT snowed last week inside Radio City Music Hall. Not for the first time, and not for the last; the theater seats were draped in protective plastic. Elves lounged around, text-messaging. Upstairs someone was primping a bear head; the dressing rooms were lined with boxes and boxes of bobby pins and false eyelashes. And then, on cue, 36 pairs of legs tapped their way onto the scene. You could hear it coming from the warren of hallways backstage: clickclickclickclickclickclick.

title: Last-Second Rescue Saves Driver From Train
description: A woman who mistakenly drove her car onto the railroad tracks on Long Island last night was rescued from an oncoming train by a couple who plucked her from harms way with the crossing gates down, alarm bells ringing and red lights flashing, the police said.

title: Italy: Utilitys Profit Rises 5%
description: Enel, the Italian utility, said third-quarter profit rose 5.1 percent as international units sold more power. Net income advanced to 696 million euros ($1.02 billion) from 662 million euros a year earlier, Enel said. The company, based in Rome, bought a Spanish utility, Endesa, this year and acquired power and natural gas assets in Russia to add generation and clients and cut reliance on Italy, where power prices fell 10 percent in the first nine months of 2007.

title: HSBC Exits Mortgage Securities
description: HSBC Holdings, the British bank, said it had stopped sales and trading of mortgage-backed securities in the United States after the collapse of the subprime market forced it to close two lending units.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: As Deer Think of Wooing, Maine Thinks of Deer
description: AS a sport, hunting suffers from something of an image problem. To many nonhunters, the idea of shooting an animal is barbaric, associated with rich men collecting trophies or beer-guzzling brutes in pickup trucks.

title: He Found a Bundle of Money, and Now Theres Hell to Pay
description: No Country for Old Men, adapted by Joel and Ethan Coen from Cormac McCarthys novel, is bleak, scary and relentlessly violent. At its center is a figure of evil so calm, so extreme, so implacable that to hear his voice is to feel the temperature in the theater drop.

title: The Complexities of Keeping It Small and Simple
description: WHEN Paul McKean and his wife, Amy Donohue, talked to county officials in Hood River, Ore., about buying a two-acre parcel to build their second home, they got a less than positive response.

title: Jane Cooper, 83, Poet of Womens Lives, Dies
description: Jane Cooper, a prominent poet whose work explored womens struggle to maintain meaningful artistic lives in postwar America  or in fact in the America of any era  died on Oct. 26 in Newtown, Pa. She was 83 and had lived in Manhattan for many years.

title: New Jersey Mansions, Now Forest Floor
description: LIKE some long-lost jungle temple, the former bathhouse at Undercliff Beach in New Jerseys stretch of Palisades Interstate Park has succumbed to vines. They linger on derelict staircases, shroud windows and veil the stone-walled ruin. The floorboards rotted away years ago, and cracks in the mortar have multiplied like spider webs in an abandoned barn.

title: Israel Urges Egypt to Act Against Hamas
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 8  Israel says Egypt is doing far too little to stop the Palestinian Islamist group Hamas, which controls the Gaza Strip, from smuggling weapons, militants and cash into the area from Egypt, and is appealing to Cairo to do more.

title: California Sues Over Emissions Limits
description: California sued the Environmental Protection Agency to force it to decide immediately on the states application to impose strict limits on emissions of heat-trapping gases from cars and light trucks. The application for a waiver from federal law to allow tougher air quality rules than those mandated by the E.P.A. has been pending for nearly two years. Automakers oppose the rules, saying they are unattainable at reasonable cost. Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, a Republican, said the federal government had no basis to deny the waiver. Our health and our environment are too important to delay any longer, he said. Fourteen other states, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, joined California in seeking the new emissions rules, which would require automakers to reduce emissions from current levels by 30 percent or more by the 2016 model year.

title: Myanmar Standoff Appears to Soften
description: BANGKOK, Friday, Nov. 9  In a surprising break from years of deadlock in Myanmar, the pro-democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi said she was ready to cooperate with the government, and the ruling junta said on state television that she would be allowed to meet with the leadership of her political party, something that has not happened in at least three years.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about federal charges of sexual misconduct against a Jesuit priest, the Rev. Donald J. McGuire, referred incorrectly to the response of the Archbishop of Chicago, Cardinal Francis George, to allegations involving Father McGuire. Cardinal George reported the allegations, some of which were known to the church in 1979, to the authorities in 2003 and revoked Father McGuires priestly faculties; Cardinal George did not fail to report the allegations.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 21 about the growing number of critics of L. Douglas Wilder, the mayor of Richmond, referred imprecisely to Mr. Wilders former presidential aspirations and misstated his age. Although Mr. Wilder was briefly a candidate for president in 1991, there was no serious talk in 1994 about his running again. The mayor is 76, not 77.

title: From Back of G.O.P. Pack, Huckabee Is Stirring
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Nov. 8  Mike Huckabees field staff had expected a modest crowd for a campaign event at a tiny rural community college near here on Wednesday. But as people began to cram into the shoe-box-size room, campaign organizers scurried to roll back a dividing wall and set up extra chairs.

title: City Offers Coney Island Plan That Conflicts With a Developers
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg unveiled his administrations long-awaited proposal for revitalizing Coney Island yesterday with a zoning plan that he said would create the nations largest urban amusement park, promote the development of stores and 4,500 apartments along Surf Avenue and preserve historic attractions like the Parachute Jump.

title: Gilding the Ancien Rgime
description: Part time machine, part Masterpiece Theater, the period room is a paradoxical museum animal. Though consisting of original materials like carved wood wall panels, fireplace mantels, beds, chandeliers, paintings and sculptures, it is usually less an intact piece of the past than a creative reconstruction, a historical fantasy that requires much stagecraft to work its magic. To see just how skillfully the gap between authenticity and artifice can be finessed, consider the six newly refurbished 18th-century French period rooms in the Wrightsman Galleries for French Decorative Arts at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Art History, Italian Style: Blessing or Burden?
description: With artists zipping around the globe and the political map in constant flux, is an exhibition that focuses on the art of a single country a viable concept?

title: Stronger Warnings on 3 Drugs for Anemia
description: Amgen and Johnson & Johnson strengthened the label warnings for their widely used anemia drugs yesterday, placing further emphasis on the risk that the medicines could cause heart attacks, a worsening of cancer and death.

title: The Real Life of Bees
description: THE walking, talking, sneaker-wearing honeybees in Jerry Seinfelds animated film certainly are cute. But if a beekeeper like me had been in the directors chair, Bee Movie would have looked quite a bit different.

title: New Life for the Opposite Shore
description: LAKE TAHOEs real estate market is largely defined by two shores.

title: Termination of Contract Means City Paying More to Golf Course Builder
description: The Bloomberg administration said yesterday that its termination of its contract with the developer hired to build a championship golf course in the east Bronx had prompted an additional $7 million payment even though the developer had made little progress building the course.

title: Merck Agrees to Pay $4.85 Billion in Vioxx Claims
description: Three years after withdrawing its pain medication Vioxx from the market, Merck announced today that it will pay $4.85 billion to settle 27,000 lawsuits by people who contend they or their family members suffered injury or died after taking the drug.

title: Threat to Family of Slain Dentist Is Reported
description: A brother of an orthodontist who was shot dead on a Queens playground last month testified in Family Court yesterday that his family had been threatened by the mother of his brothers estranged wife.

title: Next Chief at Citigroup Likely to Be an Outsider
description: Wall Street has been contemplating a successor to Charles O. Prince III almost since he took over as Citigroups chief executive four years ago. Now the job is actually open.

title: Bid for Stem Cell Financing Was Late and Lukewarm, Organizers Concede
description: As the battle over embryonic stem cell research raged for two years in California, Nancy Reagan made emotional appeals in countless television commercials and Brad Pitt passed the word in personal appearances, part of a well-organized $30 million campaign to persuade voters to approve the financing.

title: Manhattan: Bank Robbery Suspect Arrested
description: The police arrested a man yesterday who is suspected of robbing 18 banks in Manhattan and the Bronx over the past year and a half. They identified the man as Farid Abdul-Ali, 52, of the Bronx. The police said they tracked him down based on a tip given to the Crimestoppers hot line. Mr. Abdul-Ali was awaiting arraignment in Criminal Court in Manhattan yesterday afternoon.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: A Football Power in a Small Kansas Town
description: SMITH CENTER, Kan., Nov. 7  Their photos are on the cards traded over at the elementary school, and their exploits are on the lips of the old men who gather at the Second Cup Cafe each morning. They are the sons and grandsons of this north Kansas town, and for 30 autumns now, the Smith Center Redmen have puffed up the chests of folks here.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about federal charges of sexual misconduct against a Jesuit priest, the Rev. Donald J. McGuire, referred incorrectly to the response of the Archbishop of Chicago, Cardinal Francis George, to allegations involving Father McGuire. Cardinal George reported the allegations, some of which were known to the church in 1979, to the authorities in 2003 and revoked Father McGuires priestly faculties; Cardinal George did not fail to report the allegations. (Go to Article)

title: EADS Posts $1 Billion Loss and Talks of More Job Cuts
description: PARIS, Nov. 8  The chief executive of EADS, the parent company of Airbus, warned Thursday that widening losses and the rapidly eroding value of the American dollar could force it to cut an additional one billion euros in operating costs  a move that could result in further job losses.

title: A Post-Iraq G.I. Bill
description: MEMBERS of Congress and other political leaders often say that the men and women who have served in our military since 9/11 are the new greatest generation. Well, heres a thought from two infantry combat veterans of the Vietnam eras wounded generation: if you truly believe that our Iraq and Afghanistan veterans are like those who fought in World War II, let us provide them with the same G.I. Bill that was given to the veterans of that war.

title: Mitchell Report May Name Free Agents, Union Says
description: With George J. Mitchells investigation into drug use looming over Major League Baseball, player agents were informed by union officials earlier this week that up to 11 players who are now free agents could be named in Mitchells report when it is ultimately issued.

title: Brooklyn: Special Prosecutor Appointed
description: A special prosecutor was appointed yesterday to pursue perjury charges against a witness whose testimony derailed the murder trial of a former F.B.I. supervisor. The prosecutor, Leslie Crocker Snyder, left, a former Court of Claims judge, was appointed by the administrative judge for State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, Neil Jon Firetog. The Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, requested the appointment to avoid the appearance of impropriety. His office had built its murder case against the F.B.I. supervisor, Roy Lindley DeVecchio, on the testimony of Linda Schiro, a gangsters mistress, who testified that Mr. DeVecchio had ordered Mafia killings in the 1980s and early 90s. Her testimony was abruptly halted last week when a Village Voice reporter revealed recorded interviews of Ms. Schiro from years ago that contradicted her recent account. The murder charges against Mr. DeVecchio were dismissed.

title: 08 Buzz: Rudy, Hillary ... and Pat?
description: To the Editor:

title: Scranton Diocese to Pay $3 Million in Sex Abuse Case
description: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Scranton, Pa., has agreed to pay $3 million to a man who said that as a teenager he was sexually abused by one of its priests, it was announced yesterday.

title: A Tribute to Bob Dylan, Both Reverent and Rowdy
description: There werent many pretty voices at Im Not There, a tribute to Bob Dylan at the Beacon Theater on Wednesday night tied in with the coming Todd Haynes film. Mr. Dylan wasnt there, but echoes of his voice were. Singers rasped, cackled and near-yodeled, and the songs thrived on the treatment. They were written to provoke, not to soothe.

title: Health Care Excuses
description: The United States spends far more on health care per person than any other nation. Yet we have lower life expectancy than most other rich countries. Furthermore, every other advanced country provides all its citizens with health insurance; only in America is a large fraction of the population uninsured or underinsured.

title: Panel Votes to Revise City Jail Standards
description: The New York City Board of Correction, which oversees the citys jails, voted yesterday to revise the standards that govern jails and detention centers for the first time in nearly 30 years, correction officials said.

title: An Improved Defense Faces a Better Romo
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 8  How much has the Giants defense changed since it was exploited by the Dallas Cowboys in a 45-35 season-opening loss? It depends on whom you ask.

title: History and Calumny
description: Today, Im going to write about a slur. Its a distortion thats been around for a while, but has spread like a weed over the past few months. It was concocted for partisan reasons: to flatter the prejudices of one side, to demonize the other and to simplify a complicated reality into a political nursery tale.

title: Dostoyevsky With Bollywood Style
description: Saawariya announces itself as an adaptation of Dostoyevskys White Nights, but whatever Russian soul may dwell deep within it is pretty well drowned in Bollywood style. Eye and ear candy for fans of Indian musical cinema, it is 2 hours 11 minutes  bracingly compact by Bollywood standards  of wide-screen close-ups, fanciful sets, colorful costumes, bellybuttons, almost-kisses and 10 pumped-up, achingly sweet songs.

title: Military Jury Acquits Army Sniper of Premeditated Murder in Killings of 3 Iraqis
description: The leader of an Army sniper unit was acquitted yesterday of premeditated murder charges in connection with the killings of three Iraqi men in a region south of Baghdad last spring.

title: Myanmar Leader Meets With Party
description: BANGKOK, Friday, Nov. 9  Myanmars pro-democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi met with members of her party Friday for the first time in three years amid early signs that the countrys political deadlock may be easing.

title: The Rich and the Rest
description: To the Editor:

title: Style Makeover at Hotel Aims to Dress Up the Guest Experience
description: LE MERIDIEN, the hotel chain, is trying to shake its image as a faceless stopover for European business travelers.

title: Theater Listings
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

title: Assistant Arrested in Killing of Real Estate Agent
description: A Manhattan personal assistant has told investigators that she fatally bludgeoned her boss, the well-connected real estate agent Linda Stein, in the womans opulent Fifth Avenue apartment because Ms. Stein swore at her, waved a stick at her and blew marijuana smoke into her face, the police said today.

title: 2 Studios Escalate Actions Against Striking Writers
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 8  At least two major television studios, 20th Century Fox and CBS Paramount, have sent breach-of-contract letters to the show runners on their current series who have stopped performing their production duties once they went on strike with other television writers.

title: Wachovia Warns of 1.1 Billion in Credit Losses
description: The Wachovia Corporation today joined the list of companies warning about continuing losses in the credit markets, while Barclays of London denied speculation that it is facing a huge write-down of assets.

title: Wall Street Opens Lower After Sell-Off
description: Stocks opened lower today after a heavy sell-off yesterday, following declines in Europe and Asia on worries about rising oil prices and the prospect of an economic slowdown in the United States.

title: Damaged Perceptions
description: Harsh and intermittently affecting but oppressively contrived and mostly pointless, the writer and director Steve Barrons drama Choking Man is set in and around a diner in Jamaica, Queens.

title: The Mighty Keep Falling; This Time Its Kentucky
description: BOILING SPRINGS, N.C., Nov. 8  Rick Scruggs, the basketball coach at Gardner-Webb University, was not near a television Sept. 1, but he made sure he listened on his car radio as Appalachian State of college footballs championship subdivision stunned Michigan, then ranked No. 5.

title: An Overdue Step for Equal Justice
description: With its vote on Wednesday in favor of a bill to outlaw discrimination in employment based on sexual orientation, the House scored a significant, if long overdue, breakthrough for equality and fairness. The Senate should now pass its own bill, and President Bush should sign this guarantee into law.

title: As Torre Holds His Gala, the Yankees Wait on Pettitte
description: Joe Torre, who is back in the publishing game, will play host to his annual Safe At Home Gala on Friday night at Chelsea Piers.

title: Halfway Through Coughlin Year Zero
description: (We give this space over to one of our readers, who became a friend of the blog with his frequent comments last year. His bio is at the bottom)

title: Where Are Coughlins Critics Now?
description: I love the reader interaction in blogs.

title: Robocar 2057
description: Fifty years from now, cars will want to be robots, at least according to the design challenge at this years Los Angeles auto show.

title: The Billy Graham Library
description: Images from the library in North Carolina.

title: Ford Intends to Keep Volvo
description: With buyers lined up to bid for its Land Rover and Jaguar brands, Ford Motor said Thursday that it had decided to keep Volvo, at least for now, and would make an effort to fix the money-losing Swedish carmaker.

title: Female Directors Earn More Than Men, Study Finds
description: A new survey on corporate board pay has come up with a surprising find: The median compensation for female directors is actually higher than that for male directors.

title: Mixed Signals on MyYearBook Deal Chatter
description: Valleywag reported Wednesday that Barry Dillers IAC/InterActiveCorp, in the midst of breaking up the company into five parts, was planning to take some time off that project to buy youth-oriented social-networking site MyYearbook.

title: Fraud-Buster Iovation Secures $10 Million from Intel Capital
description: Intel Capital, the venture capital arm of chip giant Intel, announced Thursday that it has injected $10 million into security company Iovation, which targets online fraud and abuse based on the identification and reputation of Net-enabled devices.

title: Merrill Said to Take 2nd-Round Bids for Lending Unit
description: Merrill Lynch has put its Merrill Lynch Capital lending unit on the block, and the second round of bids is dominated by private equity firms, The Deal.com reported.

title: China Sets Out Rules for New Investment Fund
description: China has announced the first strategic plans for its new $200 billion investment fund, saying two-thirds of its funds will be invested in Chinese state banks and it will avoid buying into foreign oil, airline or telephone companies.

title: Clifford Chance Jumps Into N.Y. Bonus Wars
description: Clifford Chance has come out as the first British firm to hand out a one-off bonus of up to $50,000 to U.S. associates, as the New York pay war gathers steam. Clifford Chance said it will offer the firms New York-based associates a special bonus ranging from $10,000 for first-years to $50,000 for senior associates.

title: At Morgan Stanley, a New Focus on Succession
description: Like all chief executives on Wall Street, John J. Mack has grappled with the question of who will succeed him.

title: Investment Firm Takes Stake in ValueAct
description: Affiliated Managers Group, which already holds a significant stake in hedge fund AQR Capital Management, said Thursday it will invest in ValueAct Capital, another well-known hedge fund.

title: In Pakistan, a Show of Force
description: Hours before a scheduled rally, police blocked access to the street of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, where they fought off demonstrators.

title: HSBC Exits Mortgage Securities
description: HSBC, the British bank, said it had stopped sales and trading of mortgage-backed securities in the United States after the collapse of the subprime market forced it to close two lending units.

title: American Public Education Raises $94 Million in I.P.O.
description: American Public Education raised $94 million on Thursday with an initial public offering that priced above expectations. The 4.7 million share-offering priced at $20 per share, compared with a forecast range of $18 to $19, which had been raised from $15 to $17, an underwriter told Reuters.

title: Quest Energy Raises $163.8 Million in I.P.O.
description: Quest Energy Partners, an Oklahoma City-based oil and gas exploration company, raised $163.8 million on Thursday with an initial public offering that priced below expectations.

title: Julius Baer Said to Plan I.P.O. for U.S. Fund Unit
description: Julius Baer, Switzerlands third-largest private bank, plans to sell its U.S. fund unit early next year in an initial public offering, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Lehman Leads Round for ExaGrid
description: Disk storage technology developer ExaGrid Systems raised $20 million in a Series C funding round, with new investor Lehman Brothers Venture Partners leading the deal alongside patient existing investors Sigma Partners and Highland Capital Partners, which had previously pumped $45 million into the five-year-old Westborough, Mass.-based company.

title: Singapore Airlines and Temasek Land Stake in China Eastern
description: Singapore Airlines and Temasek have signed a definitive deal to buy a 24 percent stake in China Eastern Airlines for 7.16 billion Hong Kong dollars ($921 million), China Eastern said on Friday.

title: Black Denies Seeking Move to U.K. Prison
description: Conrad Black denied reports that he would seek to serve his prison sentence in a British jail, which would likely let him out on parole earlier than a U.S. facility, The New York Post reported Friday.

title: Write-Downs: The $64 Billion Question
description: Total write-downs of collateralized debt obligations at Wall Street investment banks will probably climb to $64 billion, according to research by the global markets unit of Citigroup.

title: Prison Term in Safety-Kleen Fraud Case
description: The former chief financial officer of the Safety-Kleen hazardous waste disposal company was sentenced Thursday to 5 years and 10 months in prison after admitting to securities and bank fraud charges.

title: Providence May Drop Clear Channel Deal
description: Update: Clear Channel confirmed in a public filing Friday that Providence is considering its options in the TV stations deal, including withdrawing from it altogether. Clear Channel reiterated that no development would affect its own buyout.

title: The Early Word: Spotlight on Huckabee
description: Mr. Nice Guy Mike Huckabee is the man du jour on the pages of The Times and the Los Angeles Times. Our Michael Luo reports that Mr. Huckabees campaign recently has celebrated small milestones, like increased fund-raising, higher Web traffic and its first endorsement from a Christian leader, Rev. Donald E. Wildmon.

title: Restoration Hardware to Go Private for $267 Million
description: Restoration Hardware, the California-based home-furnishings chain, agreed to be acquired by buyout firm Catterton Partners for $267 million.

title: Stuff Im Reading Lately
description: Its Friday, and that means its time to share some of the places Ive been wasting spending time online lately. Here are a few:

title: The Downsides to a Citi Split
description: As Citigroup searches for a new leader mid a series of staggering losses, many investors have clamored for another potential solution to the banks woes. A breakup.

title: E-Mail Scammers Ask Your Friends for Money
description: Nigeria continues to develop and export the worlds most innovative Internet scams. In one bizarre variation that seems to have ramped up in recent months, the scammers are taking a page from Facebook and leveraging the power of social connections.

title: Wachovia Puts Aside $600 Million for Loan Losses
description: Wachovia, the fourth-largest U.S. bank, set aside as much as $600 million for loan losses in the fourth quarter and said the value of some debt securities fell by about $1.1 billion before tax in October.

title: Talent Pool Dries Up Just When Wall Street Needs It
description: Many new words and phrases have been added this year to the everyday lexicon of finance: subprime mortgages, collateralized debt obligations, structured investment vehicles and the ABX index. More recently, Help Wanted: Wall Street C.E.O. has joined the list.

title: Next Chief at Citigroup Likely to Be an Outsider
description: Wall Street has been contemplating a successor to Charles O. Prince III almost since he took over as Citigroups chief executive four years ago. Now the job is actually open.

title: BHPs Rejected Offer for Rio May Trigger Bidding War
description: Rio Tintos rejection of a $140 billion all-share offer from BHP Billiton is likely to trigger rival bids from resource companies awash with cash from record commodity and stock prices, analysts said.

title: What Does the Present Owe the Future?
description: In going over some of the 500-plus comments that have been posted in the first full week of Dot Earth, Ive noticed some signs of the tensions that lie at the heart of the sustainability puzzle  including the push and pull over what one generation owes the next, or what one individual owes to someone elses child.

title: Disaster Warnings and the Never Mind Problem
description: Yesterday, European meteorologists saw bad trouble coming: Strong storm winds would soon be blowing southeastward down the North Sea at a time of peak high tides, and could shove enough seawater into the narrow end of a natural funnel of shorelines to cause serious flooding in low-lying areas of Britain and the Netherlands.

title: Friday Morning Kickoff
description: Guy Morriss is reportedly out as Baylors coach, according to both the Houston Chronicle and the Dallas Morning News, and the former Baylor linebacker and N.F.L. Hall of Famer Mike Singletary is considered a front-runner for the job.

title: High School Asks City to Reconsider Low Grade
description: The citys new school ranking system, which has already created an uproar among many parents and teachers, finds yet another critic in Leon Botstein, the president of Bard College. The Bard High School Early College, associated with the college, earned a tentative grade of C on a draft copy of the report card, Mr. Botstein said. Its grade and those of 22 other schools were reported as under review by the department. Now city officials have agreed to meet with Mr. Botstein, who wants them to reconsider.

title: Charlie Rangel gets his wish
description: From last December:

title: A headline for our times
description: Justice Department returns to enforcing voter laws

title: Reasons to expect less inflation
description: Less inflation on the horizon. You see, theres a global helium shortage.

title: Reconstructing FEMAs Fake News Conference
description: No new heads seem set to roll after an internal inquiry into the fake news conference held by the Federal Emergency Management Agency last week, according to a report in The Washington Post today:

title: Barclays Denies $10 Billion Write-Down Rumors
description: Barclays may soon admit some sort of bad news related to its mortgage holdings. But the embattled British bank says that it isnt $10 billion worth.

title: Chatting With Huckabee
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa  The Caucus sat down with former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee twice, once in New York last week when he was in town for fund-raising and once here, for an article about his candidacy.

title: New Romney Ad on Immigration
description: Former Massachusetts Gov. Mitt Romney has a new advertisement that is to begin running in Iowa and New Hampshire. The spot focuses on immigration. It includes a direct dig at the Democrats, and a subtle one at former New York City Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Stray Questions for: P. J. ORourke
description: P.J. ORourkes most recent book is On the Wealth of Nations.

title: McCain Plays a Kerik Card
description: Updated | 5:23 p.m. CONCORD  The official reason for Senator John McCains press conference in New Hampshire this morning was to talk about the important role first responders play in keeping America safe.

title: Answers About New York Foster Care, Part 3
description: Following is a third set of answers from Benjamin Weiser and Leslie Kaufman of The Times, who, along with a panel of experts, answered readers questions about The Timess series on foster care [A History of Neglect, Part 1 | Part 2 | Part 3] from Nov. 7-12.

title: Mr. Dolan, About That Buyout Offer
description: Be careful what you wish for, Mr. Gabelli.

title: Barry Dillers Bill Gates Imitation
description: I get it now: Barry Diller wants IAC/InterActiveCorp to be the Microsoft of the Internet. Im not saying that he seeks world domination and monopoly power over a billion computers. I always assumed he wanted that. With his imposing stature, bellowing voice and reflective ruminations, Mr. Diller is always the Internet figure most likely to be confused for a villain in a James Bond movie. IACs starship of a headquarters on the Hudson River is certainly playing to type there.

title: Candidates Miss Senate Vote on Attorney General
description: Carl Hulse reports this morning that the Senate confirmed Michael B. Mukasey as attorney general Thursday night, approving him despite Democratic criticism that he had failed to take an unequivocal stance against the torture of terrorism detainees.

title: Writeoff Olympics
description: Half a century ago, Senator Everett Dirksen is supposed to have said, a billion here and a billion there, and pretty soon youre talking real money.

title: Good Food Conferences Take Time
description: People in a hurry to make plans to attend Slow Foods first annual conference in San Francisco next year can, well, slow down. The four-day mega-food event was supposed to be held in May, but the organization has now changed the date to Labor Day Weekend.

title: Renault responds and clarifies its position over McLaren data
description: After the FIA summons yesterday of the Renault team to answer charges of possessing McLaren data and breaking Article 151c of the International Sporting Code, Renault today responded in a team statement. The statement goes into very welcome detail about precisely what happened, and I am going to do the same by simply pasting in the full statement below. Its worth asking just how much this scenario differs from that of the McLaren/Ferrari spy scandal, and I expect that will fuel many a debate until the FIA World Council meeting on Dec. 6.

title: An African Adventure
description: Jozy Altidore, the New York Red Bulls 18-year-old striker, could make his first appearance for the United States senior national team after being named Friday to Coach Bob Bradleys provisional roster for an international friendly against South Africa in the Nelson Mandela Cup in Johannesburg on Nov. 17.

title: Strike, Day Five: Show-Runners Receive Breach-of-Contract Letters, Agents Meet with Guild
description: The New York Times: At least two major television studios, 20th Century Fox and CBS Paramount, have sent breach-of-contract letters to the show runners on their current series who have stopped performing their production duties once they went on strike with other television writers.

title: B.C.S. Fever at Delaware
description: On the University of Delaware campus, where the Fighting Blue Hens, ranked sixth nationally in the Football Championship Subdivision, are preparing to play ninth-ranked Richmond, it has been noted that Delaware is about six degrees of separation from contending for the B.C.S. championship.

title: The Rockettes
description: Melena Ryzik goes backstage at Radio City Music Hall, for the first dress rehearsal of the 75th annual Christmas Spectacular.

title: A Ballot Question for Caucus Readers
description: Hi readers,

title: Lieberman Calls Liberal Democratic Base Paranoid
description: In remarks yesterday, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman criticized the Democratic presidential candidates for their adherence to the views of the politically paranoid, hyper-partisan liberal base of the Democratic party, saying that allegiance could harm the eventual nominees chances of gaining entry to the White House.

title: Once Upon a Word
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Last Hurrah
description: Thanks to all, panelists and commentators alike, for your thoughtful and vivid contributions to our first Reading Room. Anything youve left unsaid? Fresh apercus youre keen to share? In December well return to discuss another classic, The Education of Henry Adams. Therell be a new panel and a new moderator from the Book Review. Youve got a few weeks, so start reading now.

title: Rally in Pakistan Blocked
description: Police blocked all roads going from Benazir Bhutto's home outside Islamabad to Liaquat Bagh, where Ms. Bhutto planned to hold a protest rally.

title: Edwards Gets Iowa Groups Backing
description: Updated | 3:45 p.m.

title: Creature Feature
description: Photos from the Broadway musical "Young Frankenstein."

title: The Cocky Loser
description: Figuratively, this is Dewey celebrating as Truman crosses the finish line:

title: Berlin in Lights: Where Credit Is Due
description: An article in the Carnegie Hall Playbill this month purports to explain the origins of the current festival Berlin in Lights. It tells perhaps half the story.

title: Shareholder Activism, Exit 56A
description: Lion Capitals Sardar Biglari likes to get his message across loud and clear in his proxy fights with restaurant companies. And, Portfolios News Blog points out, in big bold letters too.

title: A Little More Sweat, Maestro
description: For the audience, a symphony performance is about relaxing to beautiful music. But for the conductor, its a workout. Most conductors wave their arms, jump and break a sweat during every performance.

title: Life in the City: Fear of Germs Edition
description: A recent story in the Times Metro section  A Corona, Please, and Dont Hold the Lime  has caused a lot of debate.

title: Feminist Bookstore
description: Carrie Brownstein, from Sleater-Kinney (now on hiatus), and SNLs Fred Armisen have become a comedy team  theyve been making deft and funny short films under the name ThunderAnt.

title: The Fraught World of the Personal Assistant
description: Updated, 4:10 p.m. | The relationships between bosses and their personal assistants can be emotionally intense, to say the least. So were sure a hot topic in many an office today is the arrest of the 26-year-old personal assistant to Linda Stein, the well-connected real estate agent who was bludgeoned to death on Oct. 30 in her Fifth Avenue apartment. According to the police, the assistant, Natavia Lowery, said Ms. Stein had yelled at her, waved an exercise stick at her and blown marijuana smoke into her face.

title: Gotbaums Death Is Ruled an Accident; Alcohol and Prescription Drugs Found
description: Updated, 3:15 p.m. | Carol A. Gotbaum, the Manhattan woman whose body was found in a police holding cell in Phoenix on Sept. 28, died accidentally of asphyxiation, but alcohol and prescription drug intoxication contributed to her death, according to an autopsy released today.

title: Benazir Bhutto
description: Former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto speaking on Friday in Islamabad.

title: Spitzers Courtesy Call in Puerto Rico
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer, who needs to shore up support among Latino lawmakers after his shift on the drivers license issue, appeared at the Somos el Futuro conference this morning  an annual gathering of the states Assemblys Puerto Rican/Hispanic Task Force in San Juan, P.R.

title: Fridays Links: Mutual Respect Society
description: On any N.F.L. team, even the Miami Dolphins, there are some players who transcend the teams standing, and one of those players is Jason Taylor, the Dolphins defensive end and last years defensive player of the year. Allen Wilson of The Buffalo News writes about Taylors mutual respect with Bills left tackle Jason Peters offering a story line much more intriguing than a Bills-Dolphins matchup could ever be.

title: Prince Walid: Citis Surprise Losses Were Unacceptable
description: A major player in the Shakespearean fall of Charles O. Prince III has gone public with his view of the saga.

title: Ohio Governor Endorses Clinton
description: Gov. Ted Strickland of Ohio, the first Democratic leader of that presidential swing state in 16 years, endorsed Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons bid for the Democratic nomination this afternoon.

title: I Am, Therefore I Rationalize
description: Since writing about the newly discovered ability of monkeys to rationalize, Ive gotten reactions to the experiment from some other experts in cognitive dissonance. Some of them find the new research with monkeys intriguing but say it doesnt explain the complicated forms of rationalization employed by human primates.

title: The Kerik Prosecutors Withering Assessment
description: Updated, 4:53 p.m. | Michael J. Garcia has been the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York since 2003, but has generally kept a far lower profile than, say, one of his predecessors, Rudolph W. Giuliani, who held the same job in the 1980s. But today Mr. Garcia stood in front of the television cameras for a major indictment: that of Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York City police commissioner, on charges of conspiracy, tax evasion and making false statements.

title: Twellmans Strike: Over His Head and in the Goal
description: Two things strike me after watching (again and again) Taylor Twellmans dramatic bicycle kick goal for New England in the Eastern Conference championship last night against the Chicago Fire:

title: Absolve My Wife, Please
description: Former President Clinton said Thursday that he is to blame for his administrations failed health care plan, not his wife, who spearheaded the effort, reports CNN.

title: Carpet cluster
description: Readers of my academic work on economic geography may know that the carpet industry of northern Georgia is famous among geographers as a classic example of how regional clusters arise: a teenage girl made a tufted bedspread as a wedding gift in 1895, and through a series of linkages this led to Dalton, GA becoming the center of the US carpet industry.

title: Unsolicited Tips for Time Warners C.E.O.-in-Waiting
description: Add another voice to the swelling chorus of free advice on what Time Warner should do with its long-ailing Internet unit, America Online.

title: Strike News: Ellen Dances Away the Pain
description: After taking the day off Monday in solidarity with striking writers, Ellen DeGeneres returned to the studio on Tuesday, explaining to her audience that while she supports the writers, she knows that people are depending on her to produce the show.

title: Strike News: Criminal Minds Producer Talks to Fans
description: Bypassing the media, the executive director of the CBS drama Criminal Minds has written a letter directly to fans about the writers strike.

title: Wine Without the Whining
description: Just about everybody known as a wine lover has endured the amusing little digs through which friends, colleagues and families express their discomfort and insecurity with wine in general. Over at the erobertparker.com bulletin board, theres an interesting thread that addresses this issue.

title: Von Dutch for Sale the Real Deal
description: On Saturday, Bonhams & Butterfields is holding an auction of rare vintage cars and motorcycles at the Petersen Automotive Museum in Los Angeles. Among the lots are motorcycles from Charles Bronson, Steve McQueen and Clark Gable. But what really caught my attention were several items created by the hot rod legend Kenneth Howard, otherwise known as Von Dutch.

title: Yes, the parties are different
description: I may complain about diffidence on the part of Democratic leaders. But then you get ledes like this:

title: Insider Trading?
description: Barclays, the British bank, sure moved fast today after rumors spread it was going to take a 10 billion pound writeoff.

title: Product Placement at the O.J. Simpson Trial
description: LAS VEGAS  Move over, Bruno Magli  the preliminary hearing of O.J. Simpson is just a day old and already theres been more product placement references than an episode of Mad Men.

title: The Week in Comments: Baby, You Can Swipe My Card
description: A selection of reader comments from some of the weeks most popular posts:

title: Going Long on Fine Art
description: Art investments are risky business, if what happened this week at Sothebys in New York is any indication. On Wednesday, an art auction crashed and burned when five of 26 lots went unsold and another 10 sold at prices below the minimum bids that Sothebys had set. In the wake of that debacle, Sothebys stock took a record 35 percent plunge.

title: Gay Rights, the Transgendered, and Accepting Partial Progress
description: Correction Appended

title: A Call for Eyewitness Photos, Video and Text From Pakistan
description: With opposition protests blocked by the authorities in Pakistan, NYTimes.com is asking readers in Pakistan to help us report on events in the country by sending us eyewitness accounts of protests in photographs, video or text.

title: Press Release: Cadillac Announces Escalade Hybrid
description: Today Cadillac announced the 2008 Escalade will offer a hybrid version that manages about 25 percent better fuel economy than the non-hybrid Slade, which means that by next summer we can expect to see MTV Cribs episodes with the following dialogue: Welcome to my crib Here in the garage we have my Escalade. Ive got the 34-inch cubic zirconium rims, a fireplace in the back, and instead of a hood ornament, Ive got a projector that puts a life-size hologram of me dressed like Superman up there on the hood. Ive got some ostrich-skin seats on order, but theyre not in yet because it takes a long time to get them the right shade of purple so they dont clash with the chandelier. Oh, and this is a hybrid, too, because I find conspicuous consumption vulgar.

title: Rove on Blogs
description: The Web has given angry and vitriolic people more of a voice in public discourse, former top Bush aide Karl Rove told an audience yesterday, according to The Washington Timess Fishwrap blog. Rove observes: People in the past who have been on the nutty fringe of political life, who were more or less voiceless, have now been given an inexpensive and easily accessible soapbox, a blog.

title: Q and A:  Laurent Tourondel
description: Over the last four years, the chef Laurent Tourondel seems to have tapped into the restaurant zeitgeist as well as any New York chef. His BLT restaurants  BLT Steak, BLT Fish, BLT Prime, BLT Burger, BLT Market  are gobbling up the city, and theyre being exported to D.C., to Las Vegas, probably in due time to Mars.

title: Sicilian Mafia Fades but Legend Continues
description: This week, prosecutors in Italy celebrated a key moment in their struggle against the Sicilian mafia, also known as Cosa Nostra: By arresting Salvatore Lo Piccolo, who was set to be the next boss of bosses, they effectively decapitated the group. Alas, there is another mafia left to fight in the country, and it cant be defeated that way, according to an Italian prosecutor interviewed last year by Britains Guardian:

title: Smith Center High School Football
description: The Smith Center High School football team scored a record 72 points against Plainville in a recent game.

title: Smith Center Redmen
description: This video was shot by Gregg Hubbard, edited by Joe Windscheffel, the team's quarterback, and produced by Heath Jepson, a Smith Center senior.

title: Arthur Bremer, Who Shot Wallace, Is Freed
description: How strange is this: An assassin released on parole?

title: For Some, Losses Raise a Ghost From the Past
description: Amid the steady drumbeat of investment banks announcements of incremental losses, investors are struggling to understand just how serious the subprime mortgage meltdown really is.

title: Vows: Alexis and Scott
description: For Alexis Louise Luongo and Scott David Litman, the third attempt at their relationship proved to be charmed.

title: N.J.s Saxton to Retire From House
description: Representative H. James Saxton, a 12-term New Jersey Republican, announced today that he would retire after next year rather than seek re-election. Mr. Saxton, who has been under attack by Democrats in recent weeks because of his opposition to the expansion of a childrens health insurance program, is the 14th Republican this year to announce retirement from the House.

title: Ratings: CBS Crossover A Crossover Hit
description: Thursdays crossover stunt linking popular crime procedurals CSI and Without a Trace proved to be a ratings windfall for CBS. According to Nielsens estimates, 21.9 million viewers tuned in to CSI at 9 p.m., the shows largest audience since its September premiere. Likewise, following it, Without a Trace (21.4 million) delivered CBSs best ratings in the 10 p.m. time slot in almost two years.

title: Americas Soothsayer
description: From the Borowitz Report:

title: Weekly Matchups
description: ESPNs College Gameday will be at WilliamsAmherst this weekend, probably because on paper this seems like a light weekend with Georgia-Auburn as the only matchup featuring two ranked teams. Still, some games have the markings of upset specials. Is Ohio State going to get knocked off by Illinois? Will Kansas sustain its first loss to Oklahoma State? Will Fresno State keep Hawaii out of a B.C.S. game? Will anyone stay up late to find out? Mark my words, something ridiculous is going to happen this weekend if only because it seems like nothing interesting will.

title: Final Performances for a Primary Spoof
description: A presidential candidate with big dreams, but slim chances of winning, bases his campaign on a radical platform of health care reform  Sound familiar?

title: What Would the Tralfamadorians Do?
description: What we are reading elsewhere

title: Strike News: DVD Demands May Boost DVD Sales
description: The Writers Guild of America is demanding an increase in pay for movies and television shows released on DVD. Perhaps ironically, a long strike could benefit DVD retailers like Blockbuster and Netflix, as television viewers choose to watch past seasons of scripted shows.

title: The Kitchen Update
description: Many thanks for all of the comments about the kitchen, and especially to Susan Serra, who was kind enough to draw several alternative plans.

title: New Clinton Ad on Energy Plan
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has a new television ad offering the bare outlines of her energy plan, which she promises would create millions of new jobs and reduce the United States dependence on foreign oil.

title: What It All Comes Down To: Why You?
description: From Iowa, where the caucuses are only 55 days away, Jeff Zeleny writes in his Web column today that for many Democratic voters, a single question is starting to replace all others: Why you?

title: Strike News: Daily Show Plans (Beyond Playing Guitar Hero)
description: Comedy Central has scheduled three weeks of theme week repeats for The Daily Show with Jon Stewart and The Colbert Report with Stephen Colbert, as the writers for both shows conclude their first week on the picket lines.

title: Bad News Often Brings Cabbies to the Pink Palace
description: If youre a taxi, livery cab or commuter van driver licensed by the citys Taxi and Limousine Commission and youre charged with breaking the rules, and if you want to contest that charge, you have to go to a hearing in a place like 32-02 Queens Boulevard. One of the first things you notice - one of the first things I noticed, anyway - is that the building, a big former factory, is pink.Its an odd touch next to the elevated No. 7 train, and felt incongruously festive considering the nonsmiles on the faces of the security guards working the metal detectors. Inside, the hearing rooms are on the third floor, past signs warning that bribery is illegal and that you have to be in your hearing room when the presiding administrative law judge calls your case, or theyll conduct an inquest without you.

title: Striking Back at Big Coal, on Video
description: The opinion editors and writers of The Wichita Eagle have chosen a novel format  Web video  to strike back at the coal company and utility that paid for ads in The Eagle and other Kansas newspapers this week attacking Gov. Kathleen Sebelius for denying permits for two coal-burning power plants.

title: Dobsons Choice
description: In terms of campaign 08, this week has been the week of the great religious-right fallout.

title: Going for the Green Crown
description: One Brighton

title: Weekly Pick Em
description: Its time for another round of picks from our fearless prognosticators. As our colleague Fred Bierman said when running down this weekends matchups, on paper it doesnt look as if Saturday has too many games that will be of tremendous interest. Weve made the mistake of thinking that before. This seasons been wacky and it will only get wackier. So, on to the picks:

title: Fantasy Football Gems and Gimps
description: Here they are  from your friendly neighborhood Fantasy Fanboy Looser [sic], which is what one poster on a sports journalism message board called me recently  your weekly Gems and Gimps.

title: Apple Notes: Another iPhone Jailbreak
description: Cat catches mouse. Mouse escapes. Apple released a new update for its phone software to coincide with the launch of the iPhone in Europe. This software closed the hole that allowed users to install applications from third parties, called a jailbreak. But hours later a group of hackers said they had found a new way to tunnel out of Apples iPenitentiary.

title: Strike News: Lear and Jackson Lend Support at Rally
description: LOS ANGELES - Several thousand striking writers and their supporters turned out Friday morning for a rally near the Fox Studio in Los Angeles, the largest gathering yet in the five-day-old strike by the Writers Guild of America against television and film producers.

title: A Financial Rally, Aborted
description: The financial stocks were having a great little rally today, and then someone looked at the latest S.E.C. filings.

title: Thompson Issues Social Security Plan
description: Fred D. Thompson today rolled out his 401(k)-style proposal to the nations looming Social Security problem, becoming the first Republican candidate to detail such an overhaul.

title: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 9
description: Here is a slide show of 12 photographs that tell the story of the past week in the New York region. Subjects include the 75th anniversary of the Rockettes at Radio City Music Hall, Election Day and the running of the 38th New York City Marathon.

title: AQR Disputes Report That I.P.O. Was Shelved
description: The credit market troubles that swamped financial stocks this week have given rise to all sorts of speculation. Among them was a report by The New York Post that AQR Capital Management, a hedge fund known for its quantitative trading strategies, had shelved its plans for an initial public offering after poor performance.

title: Cheering On the Tech Stock Crash
description: There is a journalistic convention that drives me absolutely crazy: writing about rises in stock prices as good and declines as bad. Here are some of this afternoons headlines.

title: Russia and the Baltics, Part I
description: As Russia rises, pervasive fears spread across Baltic countries.

title: Russia and the Baltics, Part II
description: A Soviet sculpture park in Lithuania stirs old fears of an increasingly hostile neighbor.

title: Apple Notes: Finding Clues About Movie Rentals
description: Where do you look for hints about what Apple is doing next? In bits of text woven into Apple software. Evan DiBiase, an undergraduate at Carnegie Mellon, poked around the most recent release of iTunes and found some new phrases added like rental-content, source-rental-info and supportsRentals.

title: Consumer Fear
description: Do you think this will be a good year for holiday sales? Dont bet on it.

description: Updated | 11:05

title: Health care costs
description: A few people have asked for a link to the McKinsey Global Institute study I mentioned. Its here. Its the most comprehensive analysis out there of why U.S. health care costs so much.

Steve Clemons (l), of the Washington Note, and Eli Lake (r), of the New York Sun, on where America's Pakistan policy went wrong.
