For both Liz, the protagonist of Elsewhere (2005), Zevins first novel for teenagers, and Naomi, the narrator of Memoirs of a Teenage Amnesiac, theres really nothing else to do.

title: Peterson Stealing Lynchs Thunder
description: A rookie running back on a pace for 1,380 yards and 10 touchdowns would usually be a big story at the midpoint of the season, but Buffalos Marshawn Lynch is not. Instead of receiving attention as a rookie of the year contender, he is playing in the shadow of Minnesotas Adrian Peterson.

title: If You Need a Passport, Now Is a Good Time to Apply
description: If youre planning to travel to foreign countries for the holiday season  or at any point next year  now is the right time to apply for passports, according to a State Department official, who said that fall is traditionally a low-volume period for applications, and that January typically gets much busier, which could mean longer processing times. Contributing to the busy season this winter will be the land and sea phase of the Western Hemisphere Travel Initiative, which currently requires passports or other accepted documents for all United States citizens traveling by air within the Western Hemisphere, including Mexico and the Caribbean. The first transition of this phase is scheduled to go into effect on Jan. 31, which will require all citizens of the United States traveling by land and sea to present a government-issued photo identification card, like a drivers license, along with proof of citizenship, like a birth certificate, at the border. It is expected that passports or alternative secure documents will be required for all sea and land travel by next summer (www.travel.state.gov).

title: From the Greeks to Eminem
description: Marc Aronson begins his complex, unusual history of race with a confession. Standing in line at a snack bar, he watches as several boys are accused of stealing money from the tip jar. He believes them guilty, he admits, because they are black.

title: Calendar of Events
description: COMEDY

title: The Garage Guy Dons a Lab Coat
description: THE days when car mechanics were considered grease monkeys have gone the way of the Oldsmobile.

title: Two Short Fables That Revel in Freedom
description: ALBERT LAMORISSES White Mane (1953) and The Red Balloon (1956) are among the worlds most famous and most honored films for children. Both were prizewinners at Cannes, and The Red Balloon, which is 34 minutes long and contains about half a dozen lines of dialogue, improbably received an Oscar for its screenplay. But kids stuff they are not.

title: The Hollywood Diet
description: Nothing over the course of many years of having dinner parties prepared me for the list, provided without request, by the couple I invited to my new Los Angeles home. It contained the items they would not consume: no red meat; no dairy; fish only if grilled, but no salmon; and please, no button mushrooms. Once at my table to eat their prenegotiated meal of grilled tuna and dry couscous, the husband spotted flecks of garlic in the mango salsa and recoiled, demanding to know if he had indeed spied a mote of cheese.

title: Seven Sketches, From a Skewed Eye
description: Advertised as seven madcap comedies for the price of one, Mere Mortals delivers far fewer laughs than that billing might suggest.

title: Stephanie Alperin, Eric Biderman
description: Stephanie Lynn Alperin, a daughter of Lisa and Stuart Alperin of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Eric Adam Biderman, the son of Wendy and Mark Biderman of New York. Rabbi Richard Jacobs officiated at the Pierre in New York, with Rabbi Robert Levine participating.

title: Nancy Becker, Scott Margolin
description: Nancy Ilana Becker, the daughter of Lucy Becker and Robert Becker of Manhattan, was married last evening to Scott Howard Margolin, the son of Sandra Roberts of Tinton Falls, N.J., and Howard Margolin of Deal, N.J. Rabbi David H. Lincoln officiated at the Essex House in Manhattan, with Cantor Dov Keren participating.

title: Correction: Under 21 and Running for Mayor
description: An article last week about Raul De Jesus, a 20-year-old Hartford resident who is running for mayor, misstated the number and length of terms that the incumbent, Eddie A. Perez, has been in office. Mr. Perez was elected to a two-year term in 2001; the next year, the City Charter was changed to make the mayors term four years, and Mr. Perez was re-elected in 2003. On Tuesday, he was re-elected to another four-year term.

title: Theres No Superhero in the Wings
description: LAST weeks ugly action in the stock market was caused in large part by fear about how badly banks will be hit by loan and securities losses. Uncertainty is ever the investors foe, and until we get some clarity on what banks holdings are truly worth, market gyrations will be a fact of life.

title: Hobbled by Injuries, Heat Limps to Slow Start
description: MIAMI, Nov. 10  Shaquille ONeal still has a huge tattoo on his left arm declaring himself a man of steel, with a Superman S to accent the assertion. It is the only Superman-like thing about him right now.

title: Veterans Day Events on Long Island
description: Heres a partial listing of Veterans Day events scheduled for Nov. 11 on Long Island.

title: First-Rate Performances Convey a Tortured Family
description: In one of the juiciest entrances ever written for an actor, Arthur Millers Gregory Solomon arrives huffing and puffing and wheezing after climbing the stairs to the furniture-choked attic apartment of an old Manhattan brownstone. Almost as old as the building  and it is about to be demolished  he has come to assess the contents, the abandoned furnishings of the family who had occupied the house before it was broken up into apartments.

title: Serfs of the Turf
description: Berkeley, Calif.

title: A Principal Who Makes It Happen
description: Mount Vernon

title: Strike Dampens the Moods of Many Tourists
description: As if the Grinch really had stolen Christmas, children cried and parents were crestfallen. Confusion, surprise and anger played at box offices, and dispossessed theatergoers shared the sidewalks with grim pickets yesterday as the stagehands strike shut down most of Broadways plays and musicals.

title: Faking It
description: Carrying this book around recently Ive caught more than a little flak, not least from my kids, who once thought of me as a literary intellectual, or at the very least as a guy who espoused the virtues of reading. Hey, really, I told them  as well as my wife and the guy sitting next to me on the subway  no kidding, its a serious book, written by a professor of literature whos also a psychoanalyst. A French professor/shrink, no less, whos written books on Proust, Maupassant, Balzac, Laclos and Stendhal, among other canonical heavyweights. So lay off.

title: In a Fathers Honor, One Perfect Macoun
description: WHEN my father became critically ill in 1991, he asked for a favor. He was a practical man, so I thought he might say, Take care of your mother  she gets so emotional, or Dont forget  the important papers are in that black box in the bedroom closet. Take them to the lawyer. Instead, he said, Plant a fruit tree for me.

title: A Novelists Nonfiction Captured the American Spirit
description: Norman Mailer was nothing if not ambitious. He once declared he wanted to write a novel which Dostoyevsky and Marx; Joyce and Freud; Stendhal, Tolstoy, Proust and Spengler; Faulkner, and even old moldering Hemingway might come to read. He wanted to alter the nerves and marrow of the nation with his work, to change the consciousness of his times. He wanted to write the Big Book, the Great American Novel. He wanted to hit the longest long ball of them all.

title: Special Teams
description: About 15 years ago, pro football lost me, and therefore I am out of step with millions of Americans, if one believes the weekly TV ratings. Maybe it was the four-hour games that ran the same two commercials on every change of possession. Maybe it was expansion to Jacksonville (the Jaguars) and Charlotte (the Panthers), whose teams seem to have the same teal turbo-cat logos on their helmets and so appeared to be more marketing strategies than football teams. Maybe it was the lack of a sonorous voice like that of Ray Scott  a minimalist announcer, unlike todays bombastic entertainers  who could ennoble a late-afternoon game from the Los Angeles Coliseum by describing an arching touchdown pass from the Rams John Hadl to Harold Jackson with the simple This is Jackson, followed only by the roar of the crowd.

title: Time to Move on a Hudson Tunnel
description: It sounds absurd, but the only passenger rail tunnel that crosses under the Hudson River to New York was built a century ago. It has two tracks, one coming and one going, shared by two very busy railroads, Amtrak and New Jersey Transit. Capacity is limited, delays are frequent. Something clearly must be done to supplement what is, after all, an essential lifeline to the nations largest city.

title: Banks Said to Agree on Credit Backup Fund
description: The countrys three biggest banks have reached agreement on the structure of a backup fund of at least $75 billion to help stabilize credit markets, a person involved in the discussions said yesterday, ending nearly two months of complicated negotiations against a worsening economic backdrop.

title: Inside the List
description: THE BACK LIST: Thirty-five years ago this week, on the Nov. 12, 1972, New York Times best-seller lists  at that time, descriptions of each title were not provided  things looked like this:

title: Being Naughty in a Nice Neighborhood
description: West Babylon

title: Far Out: Studios Imagine Smart Cars for a World Transformed by Robots
description: FIFTY years ago, tail fins were at their most extreme: cars seemed to want to be rockets. But 50 years from now, cars will want to be robots, at least according to the design challenge at the Los Angeles auto show this year.

title: Wild West: The Prequel
description: Buffalo Bill

title: A Body of Work Spanning 59 Years
description: Norman Mailer published more than 30 books in his career. These are among his most notable:

title: A Muddle Over Middle School
description: ON weekday mornings, Llunorkys Veras dresses her four children, takes them by the hand and walks them two blocks from their apartment to Public School 11 on Ogden Avenue in the Highbridge section of the Bronx. But Ms. Veras is dreading what school mornings will be like next year, when her oldest child, Richard, now a fourth grader, will have to travel on two buses to attend Junior High School 166.

title: Bitten by the C.E.O. Bug
description: MY father, a naturalized British citizen, was an important figure in my life. My grandfather, who was the western correspondent of The Times of London, died fairly young, and my father had to skip college and go to work to support the family. He went into underwriting and invested in the Maricopa Land and Cattle Company, whose purpose was to make the desert fertile.

title: Grading the Grades
description: Brilliant proposals are often undermined through less-than brilliant execution. That is clearly the case in New York, where Mayor Michael Bloombergs new system for rating the citys public schools has come under withering fire from across the political spectrum.

title: Charities Trying Mergers to Improve Bottom Line
description: Charities have long been reluctant to merge, fearful of alienating both loyal donors and longtime employees. But with the number of nonprofits increasing rapidly and donors growing weary of the rise in solicitations, charities are experimenting with mergers as a way to cut costs, reduce duplication of services and increase their reach.

title: Balkans Idolatry Delights Movie Fans and Pigeons
description: ZITISTE, Serbia  In this sleepy farming village, residents talk of a new spirit of exaltation ever since a towering bronze and concrete statue of Rocky Balboa was erected in the village square, his boxing gloves raised in a heroic gesture of triumph.

title: The City That Never Shuts Up
description: Lullaby? What lullaby? This droll counting rhyme begins with an explosion of color and energy that will pop your eyes wide open. At a busy intersection, traffic is snarled. Horns blare. A truck driver sticks his head out the window. So does a dog, one car over. Everywhere, heavy black letters spell out sound effects: toot, honk, beep, toooooooot!

title: Week 10 in Preview
description: JAGUARS at TITANS

title: This Is Your Brain on Politics
description: This article was written by Marco Iacoboni, Joshua Freedman and Jonas Kaplan of the University of California, Los Angeles, Semel Institute for Neuroscience; Kathleen Hall Jamieson of the Annenberg Public Policy Center at the University of Pennsylvania; and Tom Freedman, Bill Knapp and Kathryn Fitzgerald of FKF Applied Research.

title: More Than Just a Pretty Face From History
description: The first public showing of the face of the boy pharaoh Tutankhamun, last week, exposed more than cracked, leathery skin and his buckteeth. (Gene Tierneys overbite was much more fetching.) Archaeologists also detected a new feature, the hint of a Tut smile, transfiguring a regal mummy from antiquity into a human being with emotions perhaps like those of people today. The first reaction of Zahi Hawass, Egypts head of antiquities, was unscientific. The face, he said, has magic; it has mystery; it has beauty.

title: With Victory, Volunteers and Their Coach Silence the Critics, for Now
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 10  Tennessee Coach Phillip Fulmer leaned into the microphone. His voice boomed throughout the interview room Saturday, but he insisted that what made his voice fervent was excitement over a 34-13 victory against Arkansas, not defiance in the face of critics who want him fired.

title: Alanna Stack, Byrd Leavell III
description: Alanna McCaffrey Stack and Byrd Stuart Leavell III were married yesterday by the Rev. Carleton P. Jones at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in Manhattan.

title: Recruitings High-Tech Game of Cat and Mouse
description: On Feb. 7, when football recruits signed official letters of intent to attend their chosen colleges, the recruiting Web site Rivals.com claimed a whopping 74.5 million page views, almost five times the number that MSNBC.com drew on its election night coverage a few months earlier. ESPN and Fox Sports Net show high school games weekly to a national audience.

title: Week 10 in Preview
description: BEARS

title: Shock and Awww
description: I remember reading Edie, the oral history of Edie Sedgwick, and thinking that having a story told by a chorus of voices, each with its own point of view and agenda, could make for an interesting novel. And for a while thats what seems to be happening in Maynard & Jennica.

title: An Artistic Neighborhood, Right Down to the Firehouse
description: LAST winter, a firefighter in Ladder Company 104 named Dave Herman called a meeting in his firehouse on South Second Street in Williamsburg.

title: Katherine Davidson, Patrick Hudson
description: Katherine Loretta Davidson, a daughter of Katherine M. Davidson and Kevin D. Davidson of Newtown, Pa., was married yesterday to Patrick Alexander Hudson, a son of Edith Hudson and Robert F. Hudson of Miami. The Rev. Patrick Hollywood officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York, with the Rev. Iain MacLellan, a cousin of the bride who is also a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

title: That Special Something: Kick Returners Running Wild
description: The N.F.L. is in the middle of what will most likely be a record-breaking season for kickoff and punt returns for touchdowns, and it is doing nothing for Steve Taskers mood. Viewed through the critical goggles of a renowned special-teams player, one of footballs most thrilling plays looks more like a series of breakdowns, a reflection of the devaluation of special teams.

title: Bhuttos Persona Raises Distrust, as Well as Hope
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 10  A day after she was barricaded in her home, surrounded by police officers and barbed wire, the opposition leader Benazir Bhutto was quickly back to a world to which she is more accustomed on Saturday.

title: Can-Do Creatures
description: As far back as Aesop, storytellers have projected human traits onto creatures great and small. We know the most popular pairings by heart. Owls are wise. Mice are timid. Bees and beavers? Both busy.

title: Mourning TV
description: Los Angeles

title: Consumers Wont Know What Theyre Missing
description: THE Pennsylvania Department of Agriculture has decided that consumers are too dim to make their own shopping decisions. Agriculture officials in Ohio are contemplating a similar decision.

title: Judy Matz, Ryan Martin
description: Judy Matz and Ryan Joseph Martin were married last evening at Blue Hill at Stone Barns, the restaurant on the Rockefeller familys Pocantico Hills estate in Tarrytown, N.Y. Dr. Robert Berson, the leader of the Ethical Culture Society of Northern Westchester, officiated.

title: Little Girl Sold, and Other Tales of the Sex Trade
description: ONE of the bigger hurdles in producing Holly, a drama about sex trafficking, was finding a Vietnamese girl to play the title character, a 12-year-old sold into the notorious Cambodian brothel town known as K11.

title: Backup Helps Rangers Win on Road
description: TORONTO, Nov. 10  For the Rangers, the beginning of Saturday nights game against the Toronto Maple Leafs was all about Mark Messier, who came through their locker room to encourage them before the game, two days before he will be inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame here.

title: Skateboarding Rolls Out of the Suburbs
description: IT was late afternoon when the young skaters gathered in front of the Brooklyn Museum on Eastern Parkway. Weaving among the commuters who trudged from a nearby subway station, the skaters hurdled steps, slid along curbs and kick-flipped their boards into the air. With a few exceptions, their performances fell somewhere between outright beginner and advanced novice. But it wasnt their ability or the lack of it that made this group notable, it was the composition: most of the skaters were black.

title: A Flawed Law
description: It is hardly a surprise that New Jerseys civil union law is not working very well. During the past several weeks, dozens of same-sex couples have testified that the law has not provided the equal benefits that were promised when it passed.

title: Forgetting Everything
description: 1. Symptoms

title: A Bad Mood May Turn Worse
description: WHEN traders are nervous, danger lurks in every economic report. Two potentially perilous pieces of data this week are snapshots of October inflation.

title: Ears of a Clown
description: In hot pursuit of cold-blooded kidnappers, the Danish clown Kasper Krone  the hero of Peter Hoegs new novel  is shot in the stomach, has his head split open and breaks a wrist and several teeth. Yet as he lies in his hospital cot, slurping soup and leering at an African nun (how could he resist, since her sensuality projects the energy of an Olatunji drum solo, of a gnu trampling through the rain forest), hes able to transcend his physical pain and ponder the transmigration of bouillon: It was beef soup; it tasted of eternal life and of the fact that all living beings consume one another. There hasnt been a day in 20 years when Kasper hasnt longed to give up, to leave Copenhagen for good  to withdraw his savings. Take off for the Fiji Islands. Develop an opium habit. Listen to cello sonatas on the stereo and fade out on the beach. You have to wonder what stopped him. An ordinary person hesitates to leave everyday life and run off to join the circus. But if youre already in the circus, whats holding you back?

title: Albee the Enigma, Now the Inescapable
description: THE small, disintegrating painting  delicate flowers flaking off silk  is the work of a French master, but the story about it is pure Edward Albee. Hanging in his TriBeCa loft, almost unnoticeable amid a forest of African sculpture and walls of bold abstractions, it is, Mr. Albee said during a conversation there recently, a puzzle, or rather the key to one. He bought it ages ago, thinking it some kind of sketch or study, only to discover much later the existence of a larger painting with a hole in its middle, of which his flowers were clearly the missing, central piece.

title: Stars, Stripes, Burgers
description: If youre seeking American food on Veterans Day, consider Williamsburg. Its thriving restaurant scene, while diverse, has a good selection of American places old and new.

title: Killing Sends Tremors Through Citys Illegal Poker Scene
description: For years, they have operated in the shadows of Manhattan. With names like Straddle, the Fairview, Playstation and the New York Players Club, they are remarkably well organized, but nonetheless illegal: poker clubs that attract thousands of players at all hours of the day and night.

title: Calendar of Events
description: Comedy

title: Two New Leaders Take Over Power Authoritys Direction
description: WITH little fanfare, the public-private partnership that supplies electricity to Long Island has been overhauled and put in the hands of different leadership.

title: Magical Mysteries
description: Back in the 1960s, when I was a teenager, I was always melancholic after hearing the last verse of Peter, Paul and Marys Puff, the Magic Dragon, released in 1963. I still feel a gnawing pit in my stomach when Peter Yarrow sings, A dragon lives forever, but not so little boys, and reaches a crescendo with One gray night it happened, Jackie Paper came no more / And Puff, that mighty dragon, he ceased his fearless roar.

title: Insiders Bail, Stockholders Suffer
description: AT first glance, Crocs and Coach might not appear to have much in common. One is known for its plastic clogs that, while comfortable, will never be beloved by the arbiters of style. The other is famous for deluxe leather handbags that command both high prices and respect from tony consumers.

title: Georgian Leader Says Emergency Rule to Last as Needed
description: TBILISI, Georgia, Nov. 10  Anticipating demands from a senior American diplomat that he immediately lift a state of emergency, President Mikheil Saakashvili said Saturday that the emergency decree would remain in effect as long as the Georgian government deemed it necessary.

title: If the Shoe Fits
description: Whom would you invite to a dinner party if it could be anyone in the history of the world? Forget Copernicus and Karl Marx. Think of people who would actually be fun: the storytellers. They had their fingers on the pulse  the desires, customs and gossip  of their day and could spin a great yarn to boot.

title: Arianna Zukerman, Peter Sekulow
description: Arianna Zukerman, a daughter of Eugenia Zukerman of New York and the violinist Pinchas Zukerman of Ottawa, was married last evening to Peter Louis Sekulow, a son of Susan F. Sekulow and Eugene A. Sekulow of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Daniel S. Wolk officiated at the Columbus Club, an event space at Union Station in Washington.

title: The 25-Cent Revolution
description: Quick! What is the best-selling childrens picture book of all time? You might be surprised to learn its The Poky Little Puppy, by Janette Sebring Lowrey, originally published in 1942. One of the first 12 Little Golden Books, it has sold more than 15 million copies and is still in print. For her efforts, Lowrey was paid a fee of $75. This and many other delightfully entertaining nuggets of information are included in Leonard S. Marcuss enthusiastic history of Golden Books.

title: Speak English Like the English
description: IN the Roundabout Theater Companys revival of Pygmalion, Prof. Henry Higgins (Jefferson Mays) vows to teach Eliza Doolittle (Claire Danes) to speak properly. I shall make a duchess of this draggle-tailed guttersnipe, he says, and he does, transforming a Cockney flower girl into a refined socialite.

title: Anatomy of a Director
description: Otto Preminger (1905-86) had, for many of those who worked for him, some of the aspects of an angry eggplant  his bald head and stern face turning purple as he loomed over quaking actors or technicians on a movie set, snarling or screaming outrage at some generally imaginary defect in their work. In fact, he was rather more complicated  a civilized, upper-class Jewish migr from Vienna, son of Emperor Franz Josefs chief legal defender; a political liberal; a man capable of courtly kindness and generosity to favored colleagues; a shrewd showman with a genius for manipulating the press; a producer who in the 1950s became one of the first great masters of independent (as opposed to studio system) production; and, finally, a cinematic stylist with a unique, if sometimes limiting, manner.

title: A Sampler From Mailer
description: Their uniforms were twice blackened, by the water and the dark slime of the trail. And for the instant the light shone on them their faces stood out, white and contorted. Even the guns had a slender articulated beauty like an insect reared back on its wire haunches. Then darkness swirled about them again, and they ground the guns forward blindly, a line of ants dragging their burden back to their hole.

title: Consumers Have Taste for Local Birds
description: MARK MILOSKIS turkeys make a racket, surrounding him as he enters their 25 acres at his farm in Calverton.

title: Antonietta Miniero, Greg Mansfield
description: Antonietta Miniero, the daughter of Concetta and Catello Miniero of Manhasset, N.Y., is to be married today to Greg Brian Mansfield, a son of Stephen Mansfield of New Orleans and the late Kathleen E. Mansfield. The Rev. Damian OConnell, a Roman Catholic priest, is to perform the ceremony at Fordham University Church in the Bronx.

title: In Colombia, a War Zone Reclaims Its Past
description: CANTERING down a muddy path through Tayrona National Park in Colombia, we pulled our horses to a stop and listened as a high-pitched chant in an unfamiliar tongue filtered through the jungle. Thats Lorenzo, our guide told us, turning his horse off the trail and up a steep hill toward a solitary mud hut perched on the summit.

title: The System Flunked, We Didnt
description: OUR public elementary school in East Harlem, Central Park East I, got a D from Mayor Michael Bloomberg last week.

title: Lottery Numbers
New Artistic Director Has Big Dreams for an Expanded Emelin
description: Mamaroneck

title: Very Magic Bullet Theory
description: Some authors are diffident about their thesis, burying it in a blizzard of qualifications and footnotes. James Piereson is not one of them. In Camelot and the Cultural Revolution, Piereson, formerly the executive director of the John M. Olin Foundation and currently a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute, offers a starkly revisionist account, from the right, of American liberalism and the assassination of John F. Kennedy.

title: Muslims on TV, No Terror in Sight
description: RAJA MUSHARAFF is not the foreign exchange student the Tolchuck family of fictional Medora, Wis., was expecting. Tall and gangly with gentle brown eyes, Raja comes from a village in Pakistan. He is a practicing Muslim. He is dark skinned. He is anything but the blue-eyed Euro-teen the family envisioned from the brochure.

title: As It Rises, Russia Stirs Baltic Fears
description: VILNIUS, Lithuania

title: Letters: 1) Insert Between Teeth
description: To the Editor:

title: Alisha Fernandez, Carlos Miranda
description: Alisha Marie Fernandez, the daughter of Mindy A. Fernandez and Alexander Fernandez of Coral Gables, Fla., was married last evening to Carlos Armando Miranda, a son of Amparo Miranda and Raul J. Miranda of Spring, Tex. Ryan Dowell Baum, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the couple, officiated at the Westin Diplomat, a hotel in Hollywood, Fla.

title: Rachel Payne, Matthew Snyder
description: Rachel Godwin Payne and Matthew Filip Snyder were married yesterday by Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel at the Union Theological Seminary in Manhattan. The Rev. Teresa Payne Gocha, an Episcopal priest and cousin of the bride, participated.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In Florida, Loria Must Go

title: Gizmos to Smooth a Drivers Bumpy Road
description: I think you sent me the wrong model, I told the national sales manager of Petersen Brands of Arlington Heights, Ill. This one is for professionals. I need the consumer model, the one any idiot can use.

title: Trust and Caution
description: A few years ago, impressed by the popular success of David McCulloughs John Adams and of Joseph J. Elliss Founding Brothers, I asked my Newsweek colleague Evan Thomas (himself then at work on a biography of John Paul Jones) to write an article for the magazine on what we called Founders Chic. Why, we wondered, were so many millennial Americans so intrigued by the stories of dead white men  heroic and fascinating dead white men, to be sure, but still dead white men  from the late 18th century? The answers we came up with were not particularly surprising. Dissatisfied with contemporary political leaders, many looked back with longing to a time when giants seemed to walk the earth; in those pre-9/11, pre-Iraq days, too, the stakes of the Revolutionary generations struggles seemed epic compared with the squabbles of our own time. They were fighting for the rights of man while we quarreled over a lockbox for Social Security.

title: Comic Genius?
description: It has been a while since Hollywood discovered comics. The film industry learned long ago that a great deal of money could be made producing big-budget action films inspired by cheaply printed little books about men in tights and capes. But its only recently that the comics world really learned what it could get out of Hollywood. Or at least that Scott Mitchell Rosenberg learned an interesting lesson: actual ink, paper and staple comics might just be the least important part of the comic-book industry.

title: Adverse Possession: Mind Your Property
description: EARLIER this year, the New York State Legislature passed a bill that would bar a claim of adverse possession, a centuries-old doctrine that allows a person to claim title to property that he or she has used for a specific period of years, if the person making the claim had actual knowledge that the property was owned by someone else.

title: For Cabbies, Due Process With Dread
description: JUST off Queens Boulevard in Sunnyside, on the third floor of a converted factory building where guards check drivers licenses at the door, a roomful of rumpled men sat slouched on plastic chairs. They napped, stared into space, or flipped through the yellow violation notices that had brought them to this room this weekday morning, at the threshold of the City Taxi and Limousine Commissions administrative tribunals.

title: The Cold War Kid
description: In the spring of 1957, a Hungarian girl appeared one day in my second-grade class in Mount Vernon, N.Y. Our teacher urged us to welcome the new arrival, who spoke no English and would be staying in our class temporarily. Her family, we were told, had just come to America to escape the Russians.

title: Chasing Dreams, Amputee Inspires Others
description: Hicksville

title: Getting Beyond the Ferry
description: CONSIDER yourself a savvy regular visitor to the city, but plagued with guilt about that utterly unknown land mass off the southern tip of Manhattan? Perhaps you've even been there and made a brief toe touch at the ferry terminal before turning around and coming back, or taken the drive-through on I-278 on your way from the Goethals Bridge to the Verrazano-Narrows. Much as you might have been wowed by the accurately painted lane dividers, you know that doesn't count as tourism.

title: Paying a Premium Not to Mingle at Sea
description: BY nature, cruise lovers tend to be egalitarian types. Thats because embarking on a cruise requires a certain willingness to mingle with the masses at the buffet line, pile into the pool with hundreds of other passengers and go onshore with complete strangers  and like it.

title: In Portugal, a New Stop on the Global Wine Trail
description: ON a crisp fall evening a clutch of bigwig museum directors were barefoot and treading grapes in an old stone vat in the Douro, Portugals port wine region. They included Joo Fernandes, the director of the prestigious Serralves Museum in Oporto, and Vicente Todoli, the director of Tate Modern.

title: Wounded, and Sharing War Stories
description: SOUTHPORT

title: So, What About Those Nukes?
description: WASHINGTON

title: Collective Farmers Monuments Meet Paintball
description: IT'S so tempting to call it Stalinland.

title: Jordan, Fearing Islamists, Tightens Grip on Elections
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 9  This months legislative elections were supposed to be a watershed in this pro-American kingdoms slow but committed march to democratic change.

title: Elizabeth Essner, Nils dAulaire
description: Elizabeth Maxine Essner, a daughter of Rosalind Essner of Huntington Beach, Calif., and Robert A. Essner of Morristown, N.J., was married last evening to Nils Parin dAulaire, the son of Emily dAulaire and Per Ola dAulaire of Redding, Conn. Jon Bulette, a friend of the couple who was ordained as a Universal Life minister for this event, officiated at Eleven Madison Park, a restaurant in New York.

title: Daughters of Rival Drug Kings Unite
description: Francine Lucas says she thought her father was in the candy business. Nicole and Ebony Barnes remember a lot of cash around their house, but were not sure exactly what their father did.

title: A One-Woman Vanguard
description: THE conductor Marin Alsop has strong artistic convictions that she puts into practice and expounds on readily. But there is one aspect of her career that she has been ambivalent about discussing: Ms. Alsop is a notable woman in a field that for whatever reasons continues to be dominated by men.

title: How the Western Was Won
description: LIKE A GUNSLINGER standing on a dusty street in a one-horse town, facing down a posse or, if hes wearing a tin star, a gang of outlaws, the western has proved hard to kill. Officially, of course, its death has been documented again and again, with regret and, sometimes, with satisfaction. But as soon as the obsequies have been pronounced and the coffin lowered into the sandy earth, the rumble of hoofbeats sounds on the horizon, and the western rides again. In 1991, for example, the critic J. Hoberman published a thorough and persuasive essay called How the Western Was Lost, documenting the waning of a once-vigorous form. That same year, however, Kevin Costners Dances With Wolves won the Oscars for Best Picture and Best Director, a feat Clint Eastwoods Unforgiven would match two years later. But Hoberman surely had a point. The movie western had retreated from its position as a quintessential and vital form of American storytelling, undone by the same cultural tumult that had put paid to other manifestations of midcentury consensus. The newer westerns, the ones made since Vietnam, were either revivalist or revisionist, seeking to bury the old myths or to exhume them.

title: The Unraveling
description: Who is Craig Venter? One answer is that he is the scientist who instigated the celebrated race between the government and his former company, Celera, to produce the first complete transcription of a human genome. By 2000, when the two parties declared their contest a tie, Venter was a media darling, a brash, entrepreneurial scientist with a taste for sailing and adventure: the Larry Ellison of the lab, the Richard Branson of biology.

title: Ellen Stein, Marc Mellinger
description: Dr. Ellen Meredith Stein, a daughter of Jeanne Stein and Dr. Peter J. Stein of Guilford, Conn., is to be married today to Marc Joseph Mellinger, the son of Janet S. Mellinger and Martin B. Mellinger of Belleville, N.J. Rabbi Jill Hausman is to officiate at the New Haven Lawn Club in Connecticut.

title: A Resource for the Other Westchester
description: Valhalla

title: Getting There Almost as Mom and Dad Did
description: IN a world where portable G.P.S. navigation devices cost less than $200 and free mapping software from Google, Microsoft and AOL is available online, is there any reason to buy a trip-planning program for your computer?

title: Frayed Judicial Robes
description: Imagine a courtroom scene, maybe something out of Law & Order. Then ask yourself which official earns the least of all those important people sitting in front of the jury. If you guessed the judge, chances are youre right.

title: 36 Hours in Marrakesh, Morocco
description: EVERY generation, Westerners find new reasons to go gaga for Marrakesh. For Edith Wharton and Winston Churchill, the draw was medieval Islamic architecture and rugged mountainous landscapes. For the globetrotting hippies of the woozy Marrakesh Express days, the appeal lay in charming cobras and blowing smoke rings, to quote Crosby, Stills and Nash. These days, with Marrakesh emerging as the center of North Africas style and night life, everyone from Julia Roberts to Naomi Campbell has threaded through its labyrinthine old lanes in search of celebrity chefs, opulent spas and designer boutiques. Indeed, for many of Europes jet set playgrounds  Ibiza discos, Riviera beach clubs, Paris hotels  a Marrakesh outpost is now de rigueur.

title: The Devil Went Down to Broadway
description: FLAME licks the upper corner of a playing card, and the suit is spades. If the graphic in the publicity for Conor McPhersons Seafarer spells deviltry and hellfire to you, youre getting the message. Set in a coastal town north of Dublin, the play makes no mystery of the identity of one Mr. Lockhart, a new acquaintance who joins a quartet of raffish, hard-drinking Irishmen one Christmas Eve for a high-stakes game of poker.

title: Correction: Yours for the Peeping
description: An article last Sunday about the recent de-emphasis of privacy in architectural design misidentified the program headed by Sherry Turkle, a psychologist who commented on the significance of glass towers. She is the director of the M.I.T. Initiative on Technology and Self; she is not the director of the Program in Science, Technology and Society, though she is a member.

title: There Are No Easy Answers for Reid and His Family
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9  Sounding less like a coach than a counselor of a 12-step program, Andy Reid talked about how to get his Philadelphia Eagles back on track. He said he had encouraged his players to take one game at a time, to keep it simple, to be accountable. In his experience, those are the guiding principles for overcoming a 3-5 start.

title: Not Everyone Has to Be a Turkey Hunter
description: BOB ERIKSEN knows turkeys. He knows theyre easily startled and will fly up in a jumble if they are. He knows theyre social birds that gobble and yelp and cluck. But he also knows that theyre not easily fooled.

title: Ambush by Insurgents Kills 6 U.S. and 3 Afghan Soldiers
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 10  Six American soldiers and three Afghan soldiers were killed Friday when insurgents ambushed them in eastern Afghanistan, NATO officials said Saturday.

title: Guns, Germs and Latex
description: Once again, a lengthy treatise has been published about a subject that not long ago would have been considered unfit for polite conversation. What? youre saying. Michael Pollan has written another expos about where hamburger comes from?

title: Diane Nabatoff and Robert Machinist
description: SEASONED daters will tell you that in-person chemistry is infinitely more significant than the virtual or pen-and-ink kind. After all, you can jibe with someone via e-mail messages, you can wax poetic (apologies to Shelley, Byron, Keats) over their text appeal, but none of that really counts until you meet face to face.

title: If You Really Want to Hear About It
description: I grew up reading Peter Cameron; he made me want to write. For readers who want to be writers, books are N.F.L. game tapes: they demonstrate what types of plays can be successfully run. What Cameron showed in the mid-1980s, his work appearing regularly in The New Yorker, was that stories could be assembled from moods. The odd sadness his young characters were prone to was something Id never seen before. (Heres the conclusion to one story, Homework: Find the value of n such that n plus everything else in your life makes you feel all right. What would n equal? Solve for n.)

title: Rediscovering New York as It Used to Be
description: MICHAEL ANDALORO lived in Alphabet City for nearly 25 years before moving to Brooklyn last year, and he doesnt long for Manhattan. I didnt miss it for the past 10 years, Mr. Andaloro said facetiously. The bohemian East Village of his younger days had become so bourgeois that he could barely recognize it. On Thursday nights, it was like spring break in Orlando, he said.

title: The Days Best
description: JOE GANZ, left, set Nebraska records by throwing for 510 yards and 7 touchdowns, helping the Cornhuskers stop a five-game losing streak with a 73-31 victory over Kansas State.

title: Doctors With Instruments (Not the Surgical Kind)
description: IF a beeper goes off when the Albert Einstein Symphony Orchestra performs, it might be from the stage. Many members of the orchestra  which opens its new season on Nov. 18 at 3 p.m. in Robbins Auditorium of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx  are doctors. Among them is its founder, conductor and music director, Dr. Stephen Moshman, an associate professor of medicine at New York Medical College in Valhalla and a visiting associate professor at Einstein.

title: Ilana Garber, Adam Berkowitz
description: Rabbi Ilana Chaya Garber, a daughter of Roselyn Garber of Brookline, Mass., and the late Louis Garber, is to be married today in Waltham, Mass., to Adam Jonathan Berkowitz, the son of Joyce Berkowitz and Robert Berkowitz of Rochester. Rabbi James Rosen will officiate at the Westin Waltham.

title: Coddled Workers
description: Anyone who assumed that New Jerseys state employees would sacrifice some of their own benefits for the greater welfare of the state should pay careful attention to the sobering events of the past several days.

title: Cotto Fends Off Mosley and Protects His Title
description: If Miguel Cotto had something to prove  other than that he could beat a champion  it would be that he has honed his craft in the ring. Throughout his young career, he has been criticized for being too slow and for making too many mistakes.

title: Industrial Strength in the Motor City
description: DETROIT

title: Disappearing Into the Desert
description: It took a German to capture on film the seduction of American space, and how it would look to vanish into it. I first saw Wim Wenderss Paris, Texas in 1994, 10 years after it was made. Not long before I drove through the American desert for the first time. I exercised the freedom it offered by driving at very high speeds. When I stopped the car on the side of the road and got out, especially at night, the idea of my own disappearance into such enormousness terrified me. I grew up on Long Island, and whenever my family traveled, we went east, across the Atlantic, back toward the crowded cities of Europe from which wed come. When I left for college, the farthest west Id been was New Jersey.

title: Odd Man In
description: WHEN you have a reputation as Hollywoods reigning deviant, the weirdest thing you can do is act traditional. This is perhaps why Crispin Glover  an actor who counts a century-old ophthalmologists wax model of diseased eyes as a prized possession  seemed eager to discuss his stodgy enthusiasms for Tchaikovsky and antique furniture en route to dinner at Jean Georges on a recent evening out with his girlfriend, Mara LaFontaine.

title: Cowardly Legislators, More Cowardly Voters; What Is the Measure of a Successful Mom? (3 Letters)
description: Cowardly Legislators, More Cowardly Voters

title: Letters to the Editor
description: TRINIDAD TIMELINE

title: Whos Minding the Foster Care System?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Car in Need of a Parade
description: FROM Russia comes word of the Zil Parade, a concept car created by Ilya Avakov, an independent designer who graduated from Shtiglits Arts Academy in St. Petersburg. The Parade, based on the Zil limousine, is intended for use by the Russian president during parades through Red Square, reports cardesign.ru.

title: Credit Crisis Keeps Weighing on Stocks
description: The stock market declined sharply last week, and technology stocks, which had bolstered the market for weeks, fell into a swoon.

title: Maryanne Shanahan, William Amidon
description: Maryanne Shanahan and William Charles Amidon were married yesterday in Camden, Me. The Rev. Jerry L. LiaBraaten, a Lutheran minister, officiated at the Hawthorn Inn, which is owned and managed by the bride.

title: Maliki Asserts Influx Into Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 11  Iraqs prime minister, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, said Sunday that increased security in Baghdad had allowed thousands of families to return to their homes in the capital and outlying areas.

title: Players Face Ejection for Helmet-to-Helmet Hits
description: With the N.F.L. focused on concussions and head injuries, officials have been instructed to eject players who deliver flagrant helmet-to-helmet hits, beginning today.

title: Elizabeth Jurist, Michael Schwarzwalder
description: Elizabeth Paige Jurist, a daughter of Lynne and Eric Jurist of Wantagh, N.Y., was married last evening to Michael Jay Schwarzwalder, the son of Susan and Daniel Schwarzwalder of New York. Rabbi Jonathan Stein officiated at Carlyle on the Green in Farmingdale, N.Y.

title: In DNA Era, New Worries About Prejudice
description: When scientists first decoded the human genome in 2000, they were quick to portray it as proof of humankinds remarkable similarity. The DNA of any two people, they emphasized, is at least 99 percent identical.

title: Ruling Allows Service Providers to Go Head-to-Head for TV Viewers
description: FOR what he called 27 long, painful years, Blase Sanzone put up with poor cable television reception and service.

title: Old Jerseys and Current Events
description: Bob Scheetz went to work last Saturday wearing a game-used Ken Reynolds baseball jersey.

title: Its Time to Act Like Grown-Ups
description: NOW for a few thoughts on the credit crisis and the need to prepare for retirement.

title: And Your Point Is ... ?
description: When a childrens book sends a message  or when an adult book does, for that matter  it is usually strongest when the moral is conveyed with delicacy and complexity. Openly didactic stories rarely make for child or parent favorites, because beloved picture books are read repeatedly. To sustain such repetition, they need to operate on multiple levels: to inspire conversations, laughter, identification, emotion.

title: Long Beachs New Welcome Mat
description: FOR the first time since its heyday as a resort a century ago, the city of Long Beach might finally have a large oceanfront hotel, so that visitors  and anyone house-hunting among the citys new condos for sale  can actually spend the weekend.

title: Tania Balci, George Baptista
description: Tania Balci, the daughter of Alis Balci and Kirkor Balci of Berkeley Heights, N.J., was married in New York yesterday to George Baptista, a son of Antonio Tenorio Baptista of Arlington, Va., and the late Lucy Ferrada Baptista. The Rev. Mardiros Chevian, a priest and dean of St. Vartan Armenian Cathedral, performed the ceremony there.

title: Three Win, With Big Muscle
description: BELLEVILLE

title: Where Cider Gets a French Kick
description: ASK for a glass of cidre in Quebec and you will get not the unfermented, unfiltered juice of the apple that cider drinkers in the United States expect, but an alcoholic, sometimes sparkling beverage that can range from sweet to dry. Ask for cider in the Eastern Townships  a sprawling area east of Montreal and south of Quebec City  and you are likely to be served a flute of cidre de glace, or ice cider, an alcoholic beverage made by fermenting the juice of apples that have been left to freeze in the frigid Quebec winter. In local restaurants, it is offered, well chilled, with the cheese or dessert course.

title: Is the Market Finally Waking Up?
description: IT was a brutal week for equities, as the Standard & Poors 500-stock index fell 3.7 percent and the Nasdaq composite index lost 6.5 percent of its value in just five trading days.

title: Rarity in a Rivalry: A Battle for First Place
description: The Patriots will not be winning this week, because they will not be playing. So that gives other playoff contenders a shot at the spotlight.

title: Perhaps Too Many Acts in the Corporate Tent
description: AS two of Americas biggest companies, Citigroup and Merrill Lynch, scramble to find a leader and hundreds of thousands of employees wonder who their next boss will be, management gurus are quietly asking another question: are these companies simply too big or too complex for any one person to run?

title: Is Private Equity Giving Hertz a Boost?
description: An article on Sept. 23 about the performance of Hertz, the rental car company, since its buyout by private equity firms in 2005 referred imprecisely to some of its past practices. At times, Hertz indeed used outside printers and other outsourcing for some work and used financial yardsticks like Ebitda and cash flow; those practices did not start after the buyout, though they have been expanded broadly. And before 2000, Hertzs chief executive reported directly to senior managers such as the chief financial officer and vice chairman of Ford, a previous owner of Hertz; the chief executive did not report to lower-level managers. A letter dated Oct. 2 from Frank A. Olson, chief executive of Hertz from 1977 to 1999, clarifying certain past practices, was misdirected within The Times. This correction was further delayed for research.

title: A Galaxy in Your Face
description: There are a couple of problems with the publishers description of Matthew Reinharts latest book.

title: Decision Awaits on Rutgers Stadium Plan
description: PISCATAWAY

title: The Web Takes Ron Paul for a Ride
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10  From posting video on YouTube to enlisting friends through Facebook, all of the presidential candidates are looking for ways to harness the Internet. In the case of Ron Paul, the Internet has harnessed him.

title: Leafy Greens Aplenty: It Must Be Gumbo Time
description: THE farmers market in my town in New Jersey is nearing the end of this years run, and in my house that means only one thing: Its gumbo time.

title: Videotaping Board Meetings
description: Q Some shareholders in our co-op want to record or videotape board meetings because the minutes do not always accurately reflect what was said. Can they do this?

title: Megan Wilson, Steven Schroeder Jr.
description: Megan Kathleen Wilson, the daughter of Patricia McCarthy Wilson and Howard E. N. Wilson of Bryn Mawr, Pa., was married yesterday to Steven Betts Schroeder Jr., a son of Pamela Rancke Schroeder and Mr. Schroeder of Summit, N.J. The Rev. Robert Pollard III performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of Bethesda-by-the-Sea in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: The Plague Underfoot
description: The Plague Underfoot

title: Undoing Your Daily Damage to the Earth, for a Price
description: PATTI SARANIERO and her husband, Ben Thoron, who have three sons and live in San Diego, already recycle or compost their trash, and use compact fluorescent light bulbs. Last year, they decided to do even more to help the environment: they paid a company to help them offset some of the carbon they use.

title: Correction: A Culinary Pilgrimage on an Island of Contrasts
description: An article on Oct. 28 about the varied cuisine of Trinidad misspelled the name of an Indian restaurant there. It is Apsara, not Aspara.

title: Cowgirl Blues
description: As a professor of American history at the University of Colorado at Boulder and the chairwoman of the schools Center of the American West, what do you make of the flurry of new films that revisit Jesse James and the town of Yuma and the empty space of the desert landscape? Just as we had an upsurge in difficult westerns when we were struggling with Vietnam, now were struggling with Iraq, and so we are having the same upsurge.

title: Is China the One to Beat Now? Dont Tell This Russian Team
description: The Russians are back.

title: Town at One With Country
description: A RURAL, landlocked town in north-central Fairfield County, Easton has well-kept antique homes, high-performing schools and areas with close-knit neighbors.

title: Reaching for It
description: It looks as if the western has chosen this historical juncture to make its reappearance, after a long absence. A glimpse of the reason can perhaps be obtained from Neil Jordans Brave One, an honorary western of sorts. Jodie Fosters character, a whimsical public-radio chatterer, becomes an urban vigilante after falling victim to street violence. In the midst of her spree of bloodletting, she obliquely alludes to her activities on the air, and quotes from D. H. Lawrences Studies in Classic American Literature: The essential American soul is hard, isolate, stoic and a killer. Whatever Lawrences own political predilections, that line (he was thinking of James Fenimore Coopers Deerslayer) has the oddest of fan bases, making bedfellows of two gangs who, you might think, wouldnt otherwise be caught dead in the same room: European romantics and American right-wing ideologues. The former crowd enjoys the frisson imparted by that remote and menacing Other; the latter imagines seeing it in the mirror. Everyone else may be caught between wonder and suspicion  just whose American soul are we talking about?

title: Go on, Bold Couch Potatoes, Click Into the Unknown
description: Fifty-seven channels and nothin on, Bruce Springsteen sang back in 1992, but nowadays that number is laughably low. If you still live on the mainstream end of the remote, the writers strike that has paralyzed some of televisions most popular shows may be the incentive you need to go searching in the triple-digit reaches of the cable- and satellite-dish world. It is a realm of the odd and the obscure and the low budget. But hey, at least its something different to stare at mindlessly while your favorite show is in reruns. Heres a guide:

title: The New Deal: Band as Brand
description: GEORGE, Wash.

title: Might as Well Jump
description: To the Editor:

title: The Coup at Home
description: AS Gen. Pervez Musharraf arrested judges, lawyers and human-rights activists in Pakistan last week, our Senate was busy demonstrating its own civic mettle. Chuck Schumer and Dianne Feinstein, liberal Democrats from Americas two most highly populated blue states, gave the thumbs up to Michael B. Mukasey, ensuring his confirmation as attorney general.

title: That 70s Girl
description: Reading American Girls line of books about Julie, a girl growing up in the 1970s, makes me feel as old as Betsy Ross. Apparently someone thought that todays girls would like to read about parallel fictional ones who lived just over 30 years ago, and because these novels are a piece of the American Girl books-dolls-accessories juggernaut, that todays girls would also like to act out key moments from those fictional girls lives, using dolls.

title: Hard Work, No Pay, Stiff Competition
description: STAFF members at the Flea Theater have a motto that keeps brows sweating and feet moving nearly around the clock: An empty theater is a shameful one. And by their own standards theyre avoiding disgrace.

title: Athens: Mastihashops
description: The aromatic resin from the mastiha, or lentisk, tree on the Greek island of Chios has flavored potions, sweets and cosmetics in the eastern Mediterranean for thousands of years. In more recent times, entrepreneurs have been transforming the fresh burst-of-sweet, hint-of-bitter sap known in Greece as mastiha into a boutique brand for these healthy-chic times.

title: Up Front
description: This week we present our twice-yearly Childrens Books special issue, a 32-page review within the Review, edited once again by the childrens books editor, Julie Just. It was a massive one-person job; this year Julie selected 37 childrens and young adult books, commissioned reviews of each and then edited the reviews as they came in. She also recruited the three judges who sifted through hundreds of illustrated books in search of the 10 Best (the winners appear here). As was the case last year, a strong selection of young adult novels shares the stage with the seasons outstanding picture books  including first ventures into the field by writers like Peter Cameron, Nick Hornby and Sherman Alexie, whose autobiographical novel is a finalist for the National Book Award for young peoples literature.

title: Cowboys at Giants
description: COWBOYS at GIANTS

title: Melissa Grigorieff, Jonathan Koomey
description: Melissa Lynn Grigorieff and Jonathan Garo Koomey are to be married today at the Main Post Chapel at the Presidio in San Francisco. The Rev. Dr. Caroline Litzenberger, an Episcopal priest, will perform the ceremony.

title: Sheryl Tierney, Richard Finch
description: Sheryl Tierney and Richard C. Finch were married last evening at St. Bartholomews Church in Manhattan. The Rev. Mark Bozzuti-Jones, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: A Newcomer Celebrates the Mediterranean
description: THERES a new kid in town. Johns Best Pizza in Mount Kisco  around for so long that it might have been eligible for landmark status  has been replaced by Brio Mediterranean, a larger restaurant with a lounge and an ambitious pan-Mediterranean menu.

title: Dollar Gets a Snub From the Catwalk
description: As if the weakening dollar didnt have enough problems last week  new lows against the euro, speculation that the Chinese might shift their huge reserves away from the currency and fears that the American economy is slowing  it turns out that there may be an even bigger worry.

title: Beyond the Cover, Whos to Know
description: HOW TO TALK ABOUT BOOKS YOU HAVENT READ

title: Correction: Shakespeare in the Round-and-Round
description: An article last Sunday about the Czechoslovak-American Marionette Theaters production of Hamlet included outdated casting information. Josh Adler portrays Horatio, Laertes, Guildenstern and Marcellus; Nat Cassidy portrays Hamlet. Mr. Adler and Mr. Cassidy do not alternate in the role of Hamlet.

title: Showdown at the Alcove
description: We were standing in the eager ruckus of the entryway at Grill 23 in Boston, waiting to have dinner with Ed Harris.

title: Letters
description: Battle of the Numbers

title: See How They Ran
description: I remember exactly where I was sitting when I started reading What It Takes, Richard Ben Cramers 1,000-page, tiny-print history of the 1988 presidential campaign. Its not a hard thing to remember, because I couldnt sit anywhere else: I had mangled my knee in a touch football game, and all I could do was sit on the couch with my leg strapped into a motion machine. Like a lot of young journalism school graduates then and now, I had come to see political journalism as a lesser form of the craft, populated mostly by the effete and the unindustrious, while the real reporters were out there braving crack corners and foreign wars. What It Takes showed me something else entirely.

title: Picketing but Still Punchy
description: THE writers of The Daily Show With Jon Stewart are some of the newest members of the Writers Guild of America  just over a year old. Developmentally, were babies  still in the oral stage. When we finally get a new contract, the first thing were doing is sticking it in our mouths.

title: Hey, Candidate, Im All Yours, Your Very Own Pied Piper
description: SO the most unlikely pairing of the presidential campaign is unveiled, with the Rev. Pat Robertson flashing a television-practiced smile at Rudolph W. Giuliani, the thrice-married, pro-abortion-rights former mayor of New York.

title: Subcontinental Drift
description: Paul Theroux is the thinking persons James Michener, a globe-hopping chronicler of distant lands whose stories, some reported, some invented, aim to inform and broaden, not merely engage, and permit the armchair voyager to stamp new visas in his intellectual passport. Theroux delivers richer prose than Michener, subtler insights and slyer dilemmas, but he resembles the late mass-market master of narrative geography by treating societies as his true protagonists while giving his characters (in his novels, at least) the auxiliary role of inciting, observing or acting out the conflicts latent in their surrounding cultures. Art for arts sake isnt Therouxs bag, and it neednt be, of course. He likes to lecture a little between the lines, to show off the artifacts gathered during his travels and speculate on their significance.

title: The Terrorism Card
description: Sometimes victory comes at too high an ethical cost. We are talking about the handful of New Jersey candidates in last weeks legislative elections who smeared their opponents with suggestions that they were sympathetic to terrorism. Republicans in one legislative race used the innuendo in an especially vicious, inaccurate and irresponsible manner.

title: Franc Martarella and Alan Herskowitz
description: Franc Martarella and Alan Herskowitz were married on Monday in Toronto. Miceal Welland, an official licensed by the registrar general of the province of Ontario to perform marriages, officiated in the wedding chamber at the Toronto City Hall.

title: On the Bottle, Off the Streets, Halfway There
description: SEATTLE

description: COMEDY

description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia

title: China Confirms Poison Was on Toy Beads
description: HONG KONG, Sunday, Nov. 11  The Chinese government announced late Saturday that it had confirmed the presence of poison on toy beads exported around the world, while in the United States, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said that seven more children had been sickened.

title: The Leaning Tower of West 17th Street and Its Neighbors, Old and New
description: THERES the Tower of Pisa, and then theres 29 West 17th Street, a slim little 1907 loft, 25 feet wide and 10 stories high. Now a new apartment building next door has had to shave a foot off its upper floors to accommodate its older neighbor.

title: Ex-Worker Is Charged in Killing at Boutique
description: A former employee of an Upper East Side jewelry boutique was charged yesterday in the fatal stabbing of the stores bookkeeper, the police said.

title: Jennifer Saranow, David Schultz
description: Jennifer Wynne Saranow, a daughter of Linda L. Saranow and Mitchell H. Saranow of Winnetka, Ill., is to be married this evening to David Samuel Schultz, a son of Sandra Schultz Zeitler of University Heights, Ohio, and Jeffrey A. Schultz of Memphis. Rabbi Eric Ertel is to officiate at the Standard Club in Chicago.

title: The New Frontiers Man
description: IN 1976, WHEN HE WAS 19, Daniel Day-Lewis, who is British and was trained in the grand theatrical tradition of Shakespeare and the classics, saw Taxi Driver and, despite the considerable weight and seeming obligation of his heritage, realized that what he longed to be was an American actor. It was a real illumination, Day-Lewis told me late in August as he sat at the rough wood dining table of a duplex apartment in downtown Manhattan, where he and his wife, Rebecca Miller, and their two boys stay when in New York. I saw Taxi Driver five or six times in the first week, and I was astonished by its sheer visceral beauty. I just kept going back  I didnt know America, but that was a glimpse of what America might be, and I realized that, contrary to expectation, I wanted to tell American stories. It was raining hard outside, and Day-Lewis, who has the look of an elegant vagabond, was wearing clothes seemingly chosen many years ago for their utility and subtle details. His loose denim jeans were worn soft and white by use and the once-vibrant red plaid of his shirt had aged into a warm maroon. Day-Lewis is tall and lean and has tattoos circling his lower arms and the permanently inked handprints of his and Millers two sons climbing up his body to his shoulders. There were gold loops in each earlobe, and although he had left his sturdy, beat-up leather work boots outside the front door and was padding around in his socks, Day-Lewis still had a kind-of-jaunty porkpie hat on his head. The hat covered his long black hair and set off the contours of his face, which is dominated by his noble, bashed nose.

title: Just the Basics, in Shades of Gray
description: ITS hard not to look back on the mid-1980s craze for Cabbage Patch dolls with an amused shudder. But two decades from now, wont the next generation look back in puzzlement at the 2007 mania for a mere cellphone?

title: Stagehands Blame Strike on Theater Management
description: Striking Broadway stagehands accused theater owners and producers this afternoon of provoking the walkout that shut down 27 productions in order to unilaterally impose new work rules that would lead to unsafe conditions in theaters.

title: Too Much Information? Ignore It
description: AS one of Silicon Valleys most respected entrepreneurs, Marc Andreessen is something of a connoisseur of what he calls productivity porn, or techniques to maximize personal productivity.

title: Correction:
description: An article on Oct. 28 about the American Ballet Theaters run at City Center misspelled the surname of one of the stagers of The Leaves Are Fading, a dance that was performed. He is John Gardner, not Gardiner.

title: At Shelters, Its Raining Cats ... and More Cats
description: THE voice mail message at Just Strays, a nonprofit organization in Yonkers, says it all: We are not accepting any more cats and kittens.

title: When the Producer Came to Town
description: ON ONE OF THOSE DRY SUNNY DAYS that make the West majestic, a couple hundred film lovers gathered in a park in Telluride, Colo., deep in the San Juan Mountains, to hear independent filmmakers talk about making movies.

title: Paperback Row
description: NIXON AND KISSINGER: Partners in Power, by Robert Dallek. (HarperCollins, $18.95.) Richard Nixon and Henry Kissinger, his national security adviser and, later, secretary of state, were simultaneously visionaries and cynics, according to the historian Robert Dallek (pictured below). Both were ruthless pragmatists and insecure loners who distrusted and abused those around them, including each other. Their partnership produced bold foreign policy advances like the opening of relations with China in 1971-72, but also prolonged and expanded the Vietnam War and overthrew the democratically elected government of Chile. Relying on recently declassified material, including thousands of pages of transcriptions of Kissingers phone calls, Dallek argues that the careers of both men reflect the extent to which great accomplishments and public wrongdoing can spring from inner lives. Another secretary of state with a complicated relationship to his president is the subject of SOLDIER: The Life of Colin Powell (Vintage, $17.95), by the Washington Post editor Karen DeYoung. Her presentation of Powells early career draws heavily on his 1995 memoir; six long interviews with Powell inform DeYoungs sympathetic account of his contribution to the Bush administrations case for war. DeYoung sees Powells willingness to promote a policy he questioned as rooted in his habitual caution and his view of his duty: His job was to serve the president, not to undermine him, Michael Lewis explained in the Book Review.

title: New York City:  The Carlton on Madison Avenue
description: THE BASICS

title: When You Hit a Wall
description: ONCE she arrived in New York last summer to start a new job, Hallie Stephens, who planned to share an apartment with a roommate or two, kept encountering references to something unfamiliar: building a wall.

title: Chubby Gets a Second Look
description: HEALTH and beauty. They seem inextricable. That smiling, slender woman on the cover of Self magazine. The ripped guy looking out from the pages of Mens Health. Theyre thin. Their eyes are bright. They look like theyre bursting with energy.

title: Ayurveda and Ice at New Resort Spas
description: The Leela Kempinski Kovalam Beach Hotel, a clifftop resort in Kerala, India, has just opened an 8,000-square-foot ayurvedic wellness center called Divya. The center has 15 therapists and 4 physicians trained in ayurvedic medicine, an ancient healing practice, and an open-air meditation hall, above. The resort itself has 181 rooms and suites on 44 acres, including two infinity pools. To celebrate the opening of the center, the resort is offering several packages that start at $1,490 for five days and include beach-view rooms, consultations with ayurvedic doctors, herbal medicines, and a daily ayurvedic massage (www.theleela.com).

title: The County Executive and the Immigrants; What Is the Measure of a Successful Mom? (4 Letters)
description: The County Executive and the Immigrants

title: The Clink of Glasses, the Crash of Pins
description: WHEN the Gutter, the new bowling alley and bar in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, opened its eight lanes on Sept. 15 a block away from Automotive High School, a group of young teachers found their happy-hour holy grail. Before the Gutter, we just had beers, said Lauren Sczudlo. But now we can have a beer and hit things. Ive been here at least five times already.

title: A Fresh Bird Raised Just for a Feast
description: WHETHER its brined, broiled, baked or served up smoked from the barbecue grill, come the fourth Thursday of November, turkey will be the centerpiece of most Americans Thanksgiving feast. Yet the thousands of birds available at grocery stores have drifted ever further from the fresh fowl of our forefathers. Continuous breeding cycles, forced feeding, reliance on hormones and antibiotics, and a lengthy period on ice during transport have taken their toll, which is where Connecticut farmers come in.

title: McGovern Redux
description: Its an article of faith among many centrist Democrats (and nearly all Republicans) that the Democratic Party blundered badly in 1972 when it nominated George McGovern for president. Bruce Miroffs wise and informative book The Liberals Moment invites a peek through the telescopes opposite end. Miroff, a political science professor at the State University of New York at Albany, reminds us gently that the real blunder was committed by the 47 million voters who re-elected Richard Nixon in a 49-state landslide.

title: What Is the Measure of a Successful Mom?; Those Artificial Fields: A Question of Safety (5 Letters)
description: What Is the Measure of a Successful Mom?

title: Letters
description: The Evangelical Crackup

title: Plenty of Hair, Nary a Mustache
description: LUPES PLACE is a shoebox-size beauty parlor and barbershop, wedged between a fried chicken shop and a party goods store, underneath the elevated No. 6 train on Westchester Avenue in the Soundview section of the South Bronx.

title: Where Art Has Met Craft for 100 Years
description: Oakland, Calif.

title: In the Bond Market, a Bleak Prognosis for Iraq
description: PRESIDENT BUSHS surge of troops in Iraq has done little to resolve the political debate over the Iraq war. But global financial markets have been monitoring the war for months, and with remarkable consistency, they have concluded that the long-term prospects for a stable Iraq are very bleak.

title: In Death of Spy Satellite Program, Lofty Plans and Unrealistic Bids
description: By May 2002, the governments effort to build a technologically audacious new generation of spy satellites was foundering.

title: Hollywords
description: Eggheaded showbiz types who seriously insist on calling movies films are hung up on (or as they would say, obsessed with) the word genre. Its French, pronounced only the French way  zhahn-ruh  and means class, kind, category, species. You dont have to be French to understand noir is my favorite genre; any film critic who used the synonym type would be drummed out of the corpse.

title: Rachel Dinkes, Jason Hoffman
description: Rachel Beth Dinkes, a daughter of Ellen Dinkes and Dr. Lawrence Dinkes of Trumbull, Conn., was married last evening to Jason Foster Hoffman, the son of Sheryl Staren of Bethesda, Md., and Jack Hoffman of San Clemente, Calif. Rabbi James Prosnit performed the ceremony at Temple Sholom in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Datebook
description: PARIS

title: The Real, the Mortal, the Inspirational
description: K T TUNSTALL, the Scottish singer-songwriter who was nominated for a Grammy for Black Horse and the Cherry Tree (better known as the woo-hoo song), is back with her second album, Drastic Fantastic (Virgin). In addition to accolades Ms. Tunstalls soulful twang over syncopated guitar riffs has evidently inspired feats of athleticism. I had a lot of trim middle-aged women coming up to me at signings saying they listened to my music in Jazzercise class, she said. Ms. Tunstall, 32, was recently spending a day at her home in London before continuing on a tour that includes Los Angeles, Chicago and New York City, where shell play Nov. 21. She spoke by phone with Winter Miller about what shes listening to and watching.

title: Reluctantly Embracing the Upper East Side
Much Loved, Now Much Used
description: WHEN residents of Darien, Conn., walk into their new library sometime in 2009, they will be able to read a book or magazine while sipping coffee in a cafe that spills out to the sidewalk. They will find books grouped by subject, as they are in bookstores, instead of according to the Dewey Decimal System. They will lounge in overstuffed chairs, peruse DVDs in a Blockbuster-style video section, write a report on a wireless computer or print one on a color copier, and bind a proposal in the buildings small business center.

title: Turkish Newspapers Vie for Fluency in Two Societies
description: MRFELDEN-WALLDORF, Germany  Kerem Caliskan has what sounds like an impossible job. He is working to persuade people born in Germany, educated in Germany and living in Germany  many of them German citizens  to read Turkish newspapers.

title: Hershey Shakes Up Its Board
description: The chocolate maker Hershey, which replaced its chief executive last month, announced a reshuffling of its board of directors late this afternoon as the charitable trust that controls the company stepped up efforts to lift Hersheys languishing stock.

title: Lauren Tabak, Jason Fass
description: Lauren Brooke Tabak, a daughter of Judy W. Tabak and Mark H. Tabak of Livingston, N.J., was married last evening to Jason Frederic Fass, the son of Robin E. Fass and Stephen H. Fass of Marlboro, N.J. Rabbi Irwin Kula officiated at Capitale, an event space in New York, with Rabbi Bernard S. Lipnick taking part.

title: Royalton Shake-Up, From Top to Lobby
description: AS tourists slipped past the tall mahogany doors into the lobby of the Royalton Hotel the other evening, many appeared taken aback. The hotels interior since 1988  a bold confection by the designer Philippe Starck  had been torn out. Gone were the chair legs shaped like rams horns. Gone was the Champagne bar that conjured up the inside of a genies bottle.

title: Garden of Vandals
description: Some local fifth graders vandalized our towns voluntarily financed, old and prestigious organic garden. They were caught and did community service, but there is still several thousand dollars worth of damage. Do their wealthy parents have an obligation to pay for these repairs?  R.S., California

title: Coen Brothers Country
description: Joel and Ethan Coen, who write, direct, produce and edit their films, do not agree that their latest movie, No Country for Old Men, adapted from the Cormac McCarthy novel, is a western. When we think about westerns, Joel explained, we think about horses and six-guns, saloons and hitching posts. Ethan, who was sitting next to his older brother on the couch in their cluttered college-dorm-like production office in downtown Manhattan, continued the thought.  No Country for Old Men is sort of a western, he said, and sort of not.

title: Squaring Off on Global Warming
description: Five Connecticut environmental groups recently called on the state to reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 80 percent by 2050. They promise a proposal in time for the next legislative session that would, if passed, impose mandatory caps on fossil fuel emissions to combat global warming.

title: From Oaxaca, With Echoes of European Art
description: A cradle for early Mesoamerican civilizations, the fertile state of Oaxaca in southwestern Mexico was home to a long list of settlers and conquerors: the Zapotec people, the Mixtecs, the Aztecs and finally the Spanish. Today it is home to Mexicos largest concentration of speakers of indigenous languages.

title: Driving School Students Wait Out the Governor
description: The M-Punctual driving school, a gray-carpeted shoe box of an office on a side street in Kensington, Brooklyn, has been a bit livelier in recent weeks. More immigrants with questionable documents, or no documents, every one of them a potential customer, have been inquiring about the governors drivers license proposal.

title: Illinois Is the Team That Spoils Ohio States Season
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 10  For the second consecutive season, undefeated Ohio State flopped spectacularly in a big game. Only this season, the loss came a few weeks earlier for the top-ranked Buckeyes.

title: Please, Translator, Can I Have Some More?
description: To the Editor:

title: Roots
description: In his childrens novel What-the-Dickens, Gregory Maguire does for the dark and stormy night what he did for witches in Wicked and for the vaguely malevolent kingdom of Snow White in Mirror Mirror: he brings a literary commonplace to booming, three-dimensional life.

title: 2 Die and 2 Are Wounded in Pair of Weekend Shootings
description: Two men were shot, one of them fatally, outside a Brooklyn bakery early yesterday, moments after the men had finished their meal, according to the police and the bakery manager.

title: Me and My Alien
description: Somewhere around age 10, the excitement of reading  of just knowing what those words say on the page  is over. Many readers have plowed through everything they wanted to, meaning theyve read all the series books. Theyve read and reread Warriors, the Alex Rider books, Artemis Fowl, the Percy Jackson books and The Edge Chronicles. Harry Potter is over. Sigh.

title: In Search of Savers: 401(k) Rules Are Changing
description: NEW 401(k) regulations that take effect next month will sharply alter the rules of the game  at least for some employees.

title: Real Retirees, in a Virtual Village
description: NEW CANAAN

title: The Audiences Role; Aretha Franklin; War on Film
description: THE AUDIENCES ROLE

title: Old Walls, New Spirit
description: HALF a thousand years ago, in 1508, Juan Ponce de Len arrived on the island of Puerto Rico and set up an outpost near the back of the great harbor on the island's northeast coast.
