He had with him a company of soldiers, a famously vicious red dog named Becerillo, and permission to use whatever means necessary to convince the local Taino people that they would rather look for gold in the rivers and salvation in heaven than carry on enjoying their little tropical paradise.

title: Rebecca Spielfogel, Daniel Polivy
description: Rebecca Ivy Spielfogel, a daughter of Roni A. Spielfogel and Joel L. Spielfogel of Jericho, N.Y., was married last evening to Daniel Jacob Polivy, a son of Linda G. Polivy and Dr. Kenneth D. Polivy of Newton, Mass. Rabbi Michael Katz officiated at Temple Israel in Lawrence, N.Y., with Cantor Kalman Fliegelman taking part.

title: Stranger in a Strange Land
description: Some of the most accomplished graphic novels in existence are never identified as such. Maurice Sendaks In the Night Kitchen comes to mind, as does Peggy Rathmanns Good Night, Gorilla and David Wiesners recent Caldecott winner Flotsam. Sendak, Rathmann and Wiesner are best known as childrens book illustrators, but these particular works are pure comics in the way they construct their narratives.

title: O Frabjous Day!
description: Christopher Myerss take on the greatest nonsense verse in the English-speaking world  a basketball face-off  combines brio and whimsy with more energy than a power forward. But doesnt shooting hoops with the Jubjub Bird and the Bandersnatch require an incredible leap of the imagination?

title: Sara Kippur, Joshua Lambert
description: Sara Dania Kippur, a daughter of Susan and Stephen Kippur of New York, is to be married today to Joshua Nathaniel Lambert, a son of Elaine and Robert Lambert of Toronto. Rabbi J. Rolando Matalon is to officiate at the Metropolitan Pavilion, an events space in New York, with Cantor Ari Priven participating.

title: Too Much Meddling When C.E.O.s Go a-Courtin?
description: The DealBook column last Sunday, about chief executives who seek merger deals for their companies, misstated the status of a buyout that Richard D. Kinder, the chairman of Kinder Morgan Inc., led to acquire that company. It was completed in May; it is not pending.

title: When One of Me Suddenly Became Three
description: BECAUSE of a twist of fate, I became a grandmother nearly concurrently with becoming a mother, not long after I was reunited with the daughter I had given up for adoption decades before. By the time I found her  I was 42 and she 25  my daughter, who would soon have a child herself, had been with several mothers, but none who had stayed. And I had never had another child. In this way we needed each other; our wounds were clean and deep.

title: For a Hard-Luck Motel, Hard Feelings Down the Street
description: DESPITE its humble appearance, the three-story beige box in East Elmhurst, Queens, known as the Westway Motel is the kind of place that could have inspired an Emma Lazarus sonnet.

title: Deconstruction Zone
description: Young artists enjoying success dont usually move to Shelter Island. But that is what Alan Shields did in 1972, when he was 28 and atop the heap in the New York scene. He simply packed up and opted out for a life on a seaside farm where he grew his own vegetables and fished from a handmade boat.

title: Taint by Association
description: HENRY BLODGET, an author and former stock analyst, is a gifted writer whose work has appeared in The Times four times in the past two and a half years, most recently last month in a special business news section, DealBook.

title: Alkistis Meimaris, Vassilios Papageorgiou
description: Alkistis Georgie Meimaris, a daughter of Helen Callaizakis Meimaris and Alkiviades Meimaris of Fort Lee, N.J., was married on Thursday to Vassilios Papageorgiou, a son of Glykeria Papageorgiou and Panagiotis Papageorgiou of Katerini, Greece. The couple had a civil ceremony at the South County Courthouse of Palm Beach County in Delray Beach, Fla. The Rev. Nicholas Samaras is to lead a religious ceremony next Sunday at Sts. Constantine and Helen Greek Orthodox Church in West Nyack, N.Y., with assistance from the Rev. Alex Karloutsos, another Greek Orthodox priest.

title: What Is the Measure of a Successful Mom?; Those Artificial Fields: a Question of Safety (4 Letters)
description: What Is the Measure of a Successful Mom?

title: Correction: Telltale Art
description: Two picture captions with an article last Sunday about fall art auctions were reversed. The Mark Rothko painting on the right, Untitled (Black and Gray), is being sold at Christies on Tuesday, and the other Rothko painting, Untitled, is being sold at Sothebys on Wednesday.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption last Sunday in T: Design & Living magazine, with an article about the return of the baronial-manorial aesthetic in interior design, included an incorrect location from the Corbis photography agency for a library once owned by William Randolph Hearst. The library was in the Clarendon on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, not in the Hearst Castle in San Simeon, Calif.

title: Doctor, Doctor
description: To the Editor:

title: Full Shelves, Empty Awnings
description: LYDIG AVENUE, a long, curvy street with a bustling seven-block retail corridor in the Pelham Parkway section of the Bronx, seems to have everything a shopping strip might need. Bulbous loaves of crusty bread cool on a wire rack in the bakery window. Snapper fillets and salmon steaks are piled on ice in the fish market. The pharmacy offers sales on paper towels and allergy medicine.

title: Family Secrets
description: Young adult literature has been doing some growing up. Its not that it is getting better (although in a lot of ways it is) but rather that more and more of it is being aimed at older teenagers. Twelve and up used to be the standard reading-level designation for young adult novels; now 14 and up or even 16 and up have become common.

title: Major Changes for Magnet Schools
description: When it comes to desegregating public schools, voluntary measures are best, Connecticut says. State officials have created incentives over the years by offering generous financial support for both the construction of regional magnet schools and the education of the students who attend them. These subsidies have led to the construction of many more magnet schools  from just a few in the early 1990s to 54 statewide today.

title: Rabbit in a Hot Rich Sauce
description: TESTED: 2008 Volkswagen R32

title: Ever Backward Into the Royal Future
description: LONDON

title: Dana Hork, Brad Weckstein
description: Dana Elizabeth Hork and Brad Stephen Weckstein were married last evening at the Kiawah Island Club on Kiawah Island, S.C. Rabbi Arnold Belzer officiated.

title: High-Def at High Noon
description: Todays film fanatics, the ones who buy DVDs of high-definition directors cuts and study all the extras, are sticklers for vividness, crisp borders and high color. In this way, these aesthetes may have something in common with the rugged heroes of Hollywoods great westerns, those austere individualists who also prize clarity. This shouldnt be surprising. Film and frontier have always gone together. Formally, theyre kin.

title: Pieds Can Be  Terre Here, Too
description: FOREIGN and out-of-state buyers and renters seeking high-end pieds--terre so they can take advantage of New York City seem to be figuring out what permanent suburb dwellers already know: Access to Manhattan is a good deal cheaper if your real estate investment occurs just next door.

title: John Lithgow Sings of the Sewer, and Other Funny Stuff
description: MOVIE, television and theater audiences have gotten to know him as a transgendered football player, a kindly alien professor and an evil gossip columnist. But John Lithgow is eager to familiarize people with a new side of him. Actually, a few new sides.

title: Giving to Charity, Through Real Estate
description: SIDNEY AND ELISABETH GARVAIS had a lifetime of memories tied up in their second home, a small cottage on 4  acres on Block Island, R.I. They paid around $20,000 for it in 1965, and used it for summer vacations and to entertain guests on weekends. Of course, it also turned out to be one of their best investments.

title: Americas Team, Right or Wrong
description: Anthony Wright remembers his Dallas Cowboys pajamas. He was 6 or 7, living in Vanceboro, N.C., and rooting for the organization known as Americas Team, sometimes to the tooth-gnashing fury of those who did not fall under the spell.

title: Citys Newest Food Co-op Gains a Foothold in the South Bronx
description: The newest food cooperative in New York City opened for another day of operations yesterday, right underneath the stairwell of a community center in the Bronx.

title: Out of the Fire
description: When Dante wrote the poem we call The Divine Comedy, he called it simply the Commedia: a story, beginning in sorrow and ending in joy, of one mans journey from hell, through purgatory, to paradise. Its a good story. But while many of us are eager to harrow the halls of hell, with its gossipy tales of human suffering, few of us make it to heaven, where we are instructed in the theological intricacies of free will, gravity and the soul. No one said the journey was going to be easy.

title: Correction: The Artisans of the Real Dolce Vita
description: A picture caption last Sunday with the Journeys column, about the growing number of chocolatiers in Tuscany, misidentified the shop where a display of small chocolates with designs was shown. It is La Bottega del Cioccolato, not Slitti Cioccolato e Caff.

title: Letters
description: Jessica Seinfeld, Take 3

title: No Drivers, but a Lot of Drive
description: ON Nov. 3, when robot vehicles raced through Darpatown, a simulated suburbia created in an abandoned Air Force Base in Victorville, Calif., each machine appeared to show its own distinct personality.

title: The Tables Turn for Dilberts Creator
description: THIS is yet another story about a clueless but obtrusive boss  the kind of meddlesome manager you might laugh at in the panels of Dilbert, the daily comic strip.

title: The Subtler Shades of Racism
description: Its hard to imagine, in 2007, a white actor who would avoid going to lunch with the African-Americans in the cast of his Broadway play. But most of the other slights, indignities and just plain idiocies besetting the black performers rehearsing an anti-lynching play in Alice Childresss 1955 backstage comedy-drama, Trouble in Mind, seem as plausible in todays world as they were back when the play opened Off Broadway.

title: Whose Flawed Family Is This, Anyway?
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Your Home Can Be the Star of an Online Show
description: IF youre shopping for a new home, its easy to take a virtual stroll through the ranch house at 640 Hobart Avenue, San Mateo, Calif., asking price $1,049,000. The house has its own Web site, complete with a soundtrack (www.640hobart.com). Click on it and a real estate agent welcomes you in the voiceover, as crisp digital photographs of the sunny rooms flow past on the screen, with each photo neatly dovetailed to the narration.

title: County Seeks to Imitate Water-Quality Plan
description: SINCE 2002, Connecticut has reduced the amount of nitrogen being released into the Long Island Sound by allowing its 79 sewage-treatment plants to trade pollution credits.

title: Notes for a Theory of the Road Movie
description: What is the origin of road movies? A year ago, I interviewed Wim Wenders on this topic for a documentary about On the Road, Jack Kerouac and the legacy of the Beat generation.

title: Hatched
description: In the 1940s, childrens books with holes or windows, as well as those with flaps, tabs, bumps and berms, were likened to toys, introducing new dimensionality to the growing picture-book genre. Todays die cuts (a publishers term for books with holes of various shapes) range from intricate playthings to simple tools for learning.

title: Recognizing the Honor of a Son
description: RIVERHEAD

title: Low-Tech, Perhaps, but They Still Work
description: THERE are more old-fashioned emergency call boxes on eBay than in Linden, Elizabeth, Perth Amboy and dozens of other New Jersey cities combined. But while many towns around the state are deactivating street-corner alarms that have survived 150 years, others continue to rely heavily on them.

title: How Large a Fine Can the Board Impose?
description: Q A controversy has arisen in my co-op about whether the board of directors can levy a fine in excess of the amount provided for in our proprietary lease and without a prior written warning as the lease requires. Or can the board impose a fine it deems reasonable after what it deems reasonable notice?

title: Palestinian Calls Off Meeting With Israelis
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 11  The leader of the Palestinian team working with Israelis to prepare for an international meeting on Middle East peace called off a meeting with his Israeli counterparts on Sunday evening after being stuck at an Israeli checkpoint for 20 minutes, an aide said.

title: Looks Arent Everything
description: Dystopian fantasies are uniquely suited to the young adult reader, mainly because the usual story line  the hero realizes that his or her perfect world isnt perfect after all  mirrors the experience of venturing from the relative safety of childhood into the harsher realities of adult life. Whatever the authors intent, which is usually gloomily political, the storys psychological underpinning is the adolescents shock at learning that some of what youre taught isnt true, your parents are flawed human beings and the world isnt constructed for your benefit. Perhaps that explains why even dystopian novels written for adults, like 1984, are most powerfully experienced in early adolescence, when Winston Smiths realization that Big Brother wants to crush him kind of feels like the readers real life.

title: Off the Rez
description: Arnold Spirit Jr. is the geekiest Indian on the Spokane Reservation. He wears chunky, lopsided glasses. His head and body look like Sputnik on a toothpick. When he doesnt stutter, he lisps. Arnold is a 14-year-old high school freshman. When he goes outside he gets teased and beaten, so he spends a lot of time in his room drawing cartoons. I think the world is a series of broken dams and floods, he says, and my cartoons are tiny little lifeboats.

title: Norwegian Opera Will Perform at Sea
description: Hurtigruten (www.hurtigruten.us), formerly Norwegian Coastal Voyage Inc., has invited the Norwegian National Opera aboard its 674-passenger Trollfjord ship for several opera-themed cruises in late January. The program, Opera Beneath the Polar Sky, will have three-, four- and eight-night versions, which will all feature performances onboard as well as concerts held in sites close to select ports, including the Arctic and Lofoten Cathedrals. Selections include works by Dvorak, Strauss, Sondheim and Mozart, like The Magic Flute, left. The three-night cruise, which starts at $1,399, sails north with calls at Hammerfest, Honningsvag, Vadso and Murmansk (Russia); the four-night cruise, starting at $1,599, sails south with calls at Murmansk, Honningsvag, Harstad and Svolvaer; and the eight-night cruise combines the two itineraries and starts at $2,499. Prices are per person, double occupancy, and include accommodations, all meals and all concerts.

title: Once Again, Johnson Finds Higher Gear in the Chase
description: If ever there was a driver who could run with Jimmie Johnson in the Chase for the Nextel Cup, his Hendrick Motorsports teammate Jeff Gordon should have been the one to do it. But even Gordon, the winner of four championships in his career and the points leader through most of the playoff, is beginning to fade against Johnson, who has become the master of the Chase.

title: A Homeland Beckons
description: IN a soundproof glass booth in the back of a travel agency on Roosevelt Avenue in Jackson Heights, Queens, Alex Polanco was murmuring into his microphone in Spanish. We want to know your thoughts, your opinions, said Mr. Polanco, a host of Grupo Radial Delgado, a tiny radio station aimed at New Yorks Ecuadorean immigrants. The Plan of Return, is it good? Is it bad? The lines are open.

title: The Dead and the Naked
description: Chapter 10: Terrible Things Happen There

title: Isles Foil Brodeurs Shot at 500th Win
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., Nov. 10  Devils goaltender Martin Brodeur has fattened up his impressive victory total by repeatedly foiling the Islanders over the years, beating them 38 times.

title: Correction: Essay About The Toothpick
description: An essay on Oct. 28 about The Toothpick: Technology and Culture, by Henry Petroski, misstated one of the authors academic fields. It is civil engineering, not civic.

title: High Anxiety at a Popular Preschool
description: AMONG the many posts about the Riverside Church Weekday School that appeared on the Urban Baby online message board this fall, one from a parent interested in learning about the school prompted this response: Currently in turmoil.

title: Of Human Bondage
description: The stories told in a pair of trials in federal courtrooms in Lower Manhattan and Central Islip have been heartbreaking. At the first trial, witnesses told of abuses they suffered in what federal agents say was an international prostitution ring  a sophisticated enterprise that smuggled Asian women into the country and forced them to work at massage parlors and spas up and down the East Coast.

title: Democracys Root: Diversity
description: Last Tuesday, King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia met Pope Benedict XVI at the Vatican  the first audience ever by the head of the Catholic Church with a Saudi monarch. The Saudi king gave the pope two gifts: a golden sword studded with jewels, and a gold and silver statue depicting a palm tree and a man riding a camel.

title: A Bite of the Bagel
description: Hillary Clinton had the bad luck to fumble a debate before the writers strike knocked late-night comics off the air.

title: Asian Confusion
description: Miko Hayashi and her colleagues have worked hard to organize the Asian-American Digi-Fest, a little film festival in Berkeley, Calif., and now its time to screen the prizewinner, Fortune Cookie Rookie. The movie is just another piece of high-minded, low-budget hokum, but the Asian-American audience smiles and applauds at the fade-out  except for Mikos boyfriend, Ben Tanaka, a grumpy, 30-year-old Japanese-American, whos having none of it. After refusing to go to the after-party, he starts spewing his usual venom.

title: The Cloistral Hush Revisited
description: Ten more days left to punting season, a longtime Oxfordshire resident mulled as he led a group of us on a nature walk, complete with dogs and muddied Wellington boots, through University Parks. We were blessed with warm, clear weather on a Saturday in early October as we tramped past duck ponds, through pastures and over rickety bridges. But, with a touch of typical English pessimism, we were also told it would not last.

title: Parents Fault School for Delay Over Mold
description: WESTPORT

title: A Big Box of Eagles
description: The new Eagles album  Long Road Out of Eden came out recently, but only at Wal-Mart. One of the points the Eagles may be making is that you have to consider your allegiances in the world of the present, not the past. A few years ago, any link between Wal-Mart and Don Henley, an ardent environmentalist, would have seemed puzzling at best. But there is a simple equation here. This new album was released without the participation of a major record label. This isnt just a case of selling exclusively in the Big Box. Its a case of giving up Big Vinyl and its distribution.

title: The War to End All Wars? If Only...
description: Rutherford

title: Climbing Some Steps on the Pay Ladder
description: THE New York City government is helping Andre Franks and Makida Hall rise from the bottom rungs of the job ladder. And Mr. Franks and Ms. Hall are helping the city become more sure-footed in providing such aid.

title: A New York Refrain: Im Stuck in Traffic!; The Captive Audience of the Transit Preacher; Living Room Couches Are Not Homes (5 Letters)
description: A New York Refrain:

title: Taming the Daily Chaos of Ailments Left and Right
description: For Cheryl and Jose Carmona, daily life is a marathon of obligations. But they do not seem to mind.

title: No Lesbian Bishop for Chicago Diocese
description: WHEELING, Ill., Nov. 10  The Rev. Tracey Lind lost her bid Saturday to be the second openly gay bishop of the Episcopal Church and the first female bishop of its Chicago diocese.

title: Romo Angles for Stardom; Manning Ambles on His Own
description: Unlike Tony Romo, Eli Manning started out famous. Before he was chosen with the first pick of the 2004 N.F.L. draft, Manning was well known as the son of one quarterback and the brother of another. He was flung to the hot lights of New York, a premade star and a savior for the Giants, christened before his first professional snap.

title: Kids Dont Need Protection From Every Little Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: Sewage Plant Trading Program Reducing Pollution
description: SINCE 2002, Connecticut has reduced the amount of nitrogen being released into the Long Island Sound by allowing its 79 sewage-treatment plants to trade pollution credits.

title: Broken Supply Channel Sent Arms for Iraq Astray
description: This article was reported by Eric Schmitt, Ginger Thompson, Margot Williams and James Glanz, and was written by Mr. Schmitt and Ms. Thompson.

title: Rock n Revolution
description: COUNTLESS rock bands have sung about rebellion. One of the few that can claim it spurred a revolution is the Plastic People of the Universe, who  starting with no political agenda  catalyzed democracy in Czechoslovakia.

title: The Homintern
description: Last September in Washington, Larry Craigs risible self-defense was still quaintly competing with his colleagues apparent consensus that if any mere misdemeanor could get you kicked out of the United States Senate, it would be the one he had committed in a Minneapolis airport mens room. Going largely unobserved amid the din was a small ceremony a mile or so away, at which the Smithsonian Institutions National Museum of American History unveiled the glass-encased display of two picket signs that had been carried by homosexual-rights protestors outside the White House in 1965, four years before the Stonewall riot. That these signs are now considered national treasures, worthy of exhibition a few feet from the hat that Lincoln wore to Fords Theater, may tell us more about the long run of historical progress than the Craig mess says about enduring denial and hypocrisy.

title: In Kilter
description: The fashion world is having another fling with Scottish tartan, presently seen as sneakers or a vintage tam-o-shanter. The couple above, seen in Paris last month, were slipcovered in tartan, including their luggage. The man at right is wearing a trompe loeil kilt that was actually a bath towel bought at a Woolworths in Edinburgh. He was at a Scottish dance at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York last week, where many of the guests, bottom row, were wearing tartan clothes. The same week, there was a party for the book Tartan: Romancing the Plaid at Saks Fifth Avenue with the authors, left, Doria de La Chapelle, seated, and Jeffrey Banks.

title: How a Grant Travels From Foundation to Field
description: One challenge that foundations face in giving away large amounts of money is finding organizations that are equipped to handle it. The GAVI Alliance  formerly the Global Alliance for Vaccines and Immunization  has received a commitment of $1.5 billion over 15 years from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation. Here is a look at how the money flows.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE DISCOVERY OF FRANCE: A Historical Geography From the Revolution to the First World War, by Graham Robb. (Norton, $27.95.) Robb presents France as a group of diverse regions, each with its own long history, intricate belief systems and singular customs.

title: Best Illustrated Children's Books 2007
description: The Book Review chooses the year's 10 best illustrated childrens books.

title: No Country
description:
The strivers, weirdos, beauties, believers and
would-be prophets from the films of the Coen Brothers.

title: How to Talk About Books You Havent Read
description: Books You Don't Know

title: The Third Sex
description: Introduction Louis Estve

title: Musharraf Sets Elections, but Will Maintain Rule by Decree
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 11  General Pervez Musharraf, the Pakistani president, appeared to yield to intense American pressure on Sunday by restoring parliamentary elections in early January, but he said his emergency decree would last at least through then, immediately raising new questions about the votes legitimacy.

title: Setting Poems, Revisiting Sonatas, Plunking the Marimba
description: PHILIP GLASS:

title: Sitcombobulated
description: Wow. Were all over the Hollywood writers strike today. Global warming could get an inferiority complex. No fewer than four articles, from Maureen Dowds late-night comedy withdrawal pangs, to intimations of the death of TV in Op-Ed, to a writers first-person account from the pickets

title: The Elephanta Suite
description: Monkey Hill

title: The Quiet Girl
description: She Almighty had tuned each person in a musical key, and Kasper could hear it. Best in the brief, unguarded moments when people were nearby but didn't yet know he was listening. So he waited by the window, as he was doing now.

title: Monday Morning Motorsports
description: Formula One: Ross Brawn, who was Ferraris technical director during Michael Schumachers spectacular run, was named team principal for Honda. After finishing second in the constructors championship in 2004, Honda has fallen far behind the top teams, scoring only 6 points last season. Brawn, who has never been a team principal, had also been courted by his former team. And Autosport reports that shortly after Brawns hire at Honda, Ferrari announced it will move to Stefano Domenical to Director of the Gestione Sportiva, a position held by Jean Todt on an interim basis.

title: Maynard & Jennica
description: JOAN TATE, tipsy after another revelatory lunch with her son, illustrates her point (early August 2000):

title: Romo Outduels Manning
description: Undone by a pair of long touchdown passes from Tony Romo to Terrell Owens in the second half, the Giants fell to the Cowboys, ending their six-game winning streak.

title: The Week Ahead: Nov. 11-17
description: Film

title: This Is Your Brain on Politics
description: Researchers watched the brains of a group of swing voters as they responded to presidential candidates. Here are the results.

title: Still More Fun  Can You Stand It?
description: Its the Week in Reviews

title: News Headlines
description: Interesting stories from the world of real estate:

title: The Joys of Underachievement
description: Has your get-up-and-go gotten up and gone? Say, Hallelujah! Sundays Times is rife with reasons why thats a good thing. Why strive to be well-read (How to Talk About Books You Havent Read); well-informed (Too Much Information? Ignore it); or even thin? The hell with it, we say!

title: More Heat on Ways to Lower the Thermostat
description: The latest reports from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change make clear some very inconvenient realities about the growing human influence on climate.

title: Berlin in Lights: Youth Orchestras First Generation
description: They were uniformly dressed in blue jeans. Leather jackets and hoodies were draped on chair backs. Many were warming up in the auditorium. The musicians of the Simn Bolvar Youth Orchestra of Venezuela took the Carnegie Hall stage on Saturday evening to rehearse Sundays program: Berliozs Carnaval Romain; Chopins Piano Concerto No 2, with Emanuel Ax; Beethovens Fifth Symphony; and unnamed Latin American goodies.

title: Blast From the Past
description: An odd event took place in Moscow on Nov. 8 and 9: A U.S.S.R. team played a 10-board match against a team from Yugoslavia. Of course, neither of these countries exists anymore, having split up after the end of the cold war. But the match was held to commemorate an annual series of friends and rivals matches between the two countries from the 1950s through the 1980s. In keeping with the spirit of the idea, the participants in the current match were players who had competed in those earlier encounters. The official Web site, which is in Russian and English, has all the games as well as pictures of the event.

title: Berlin in Lights: And, oh Yes  She Also Sang
description: Cabaret can often be a disappointingly sedate experience. But from the moment the glamorous singer Meow Meow came rushing through the door of the Neue Galeries Caf Sabarsky in a blur of shopping bags and spiky red heels and glittery makeup, I knew I wouldnt have to stifle any yawns.

title: Sunday Kickoff
description: Ohio States loss wasnt only good for teams like Oregon and Kansas, it was good for the country, writes Stewart Mandel of SI.com. But John McGrath of the News-Tribune in Tacoma, Wash., isnt exactly excited about the prospect of seeing Louisiana State in the B.C.S. title game, either.

title: Edwards Outlines Policies in Des Moines
description: Updated | 6:10 p.m.DES MOINES  Following last nights speech at the Jefferson-Jackson Day dinner, John Edwards released a booklet today summarizing his policies for caucus-goers and reinforcing many of the central issues of his campaign at a speech this morning.

title: Live From Giants Stadium, Its a Blog!
description: It is not often that a team asks its fans to show their support by wearing a color generally not associated with the team. But that is what the Giants have done. Since the players will wear the teams alternative jersey, the ones that are bright red, the Giants asked fans coming to todays game to do the same.

title: Why, Barack, why?
description: The great Social Security debate of 2005 was a seminal moment for American progressives. Conventional fiscal wisdom in the Beltway was that the aging population is THE big problem  when the truth is that grim long-run fiscal projections mainly reflect projected health care costs. And conventional political wisdom was that the Bush administrations fear-mongering on the issue would work.

title: Sunday Sampler Platter, Nov. 11
description: As the presidential campaign progresses, the talk-show hosts seem to be pressing their candidate-guests a bit harder  and the candidates seem quicker to turn on one another. It all makes for good television and, lets say it, entertaining politics, too.

title: Bourdais finishes with another victory
description: Sbastien Bourdais is all set to test with Toro Rosso this week, complete with an eighth victory in his final race of his final year in Champ Car. That was a record number of wins for Bourdais in a single season in Champ Car, and brings his total to 31 victories in five seasons.

title: It Depends What the Meaning of Makes Sense Is
description: Well, it finally arrived, the long-anticipated bump in Hillary Clintons road to the nomination, the bump that many predicted would slow her down and give her competitors a chance to catch up.

title: Tennessee Pulls Itself Together
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.  Just when it looked like all the excitement here would be for basketball, not football (gasp!), Tennessee played another home game and its defense found its groove.

title: A Shining Beacon
description: Retirees are gobbling up old lighthouses in the U.S., according to this article from Barrons Online. Abandoned facilities, many on deserted islands, can be purchased for as low as $30,000 (20,400) and there are reportedly dozens available.

title: Reclaiming Ownership of My History
description: My dad had been serving his tour of duty in Vietnam when hed decided to adopt. He and my mother had already had two boys and wanted a girl. In 1970, toward the last six months of his tour, hed come across me in an orphanage and taken me home.

title: The Anatomy of a Political Event
description: Behind the scenes at the Jefferson-Jackson dinner in Des Moines.

title: The Life and Death of a Climate Hoax
description: The death of manmade global warming theory lasted 70 minutes last week, showing the amazing power of the Web to amplify, and then dismantle, fictions at light speed.

title: Bailing Out a Money Market Fund
description: Wachovia, it its 10-Q filed Friday, became the first money market fund sponsor that I have noticed to have to dip into its own assets to bail out its money market fund.

title: Mississippi Statement
description: When Mississippi State defeated Alabama on Saturday, the Bulldogs became bowl eligible for the first time since 2000. After the victory, Sylvester Croom, the fourth-year Bulldogs coach, emphasized its importance.

title: Bias in Texas?
description: After his teams 59-43 loss Saturday at Texas, Texas Tech Coach Mike Leach blasted the games officials and insinuated that they favored the Longhorns.

title: Another B.C.S. Mess?
description: Just when it seemed that things could be settling down in the Bowl Championship Series standings, the B.C.S. guru Jerry Palm came up with this nugget.

title: Riddle of the Day
description: Q: How many wonks and academics does it take to write a Sunday Op-Ed article called This Is Your Brain on Politics?A: If you answered seven, youre clairvoyant and maybe you should have your head examined too. Read more

title: Murrays Peterson Act
description: When the former Oklahoma tailback Adrian Peterson finished as the runner-up in the Heisman Trophy voting three years ago, the Sooners freshman records he set then seemed unlikely to be challenged anytime soon.

title: Sunday Talking Points
description: There have been plenty of marquee games this season, but for my money, Week 10 figured to be the most exciting week of the season so far. Rematches and rivalries and divisional battles abound. And I am not afraid to admit that almost nothing went the way I thought it would today. Now that the 1 p.m. 4 p.m. all the games are over, here are a few things to discuss:

title: Chinese Novel Wins Prize
description: A Chinese novelist has won the inaugural Man Asian Literary Prize. The author, Jiang Rong, 61, beat four other Asian writers on the short list to capture the $10,000 award established to honor the regions best literature that has yet to be published in English. Mr. Jiangs book, Wolf Totem, above, first published in Chinese, draws on the authors personal experience in the Mongolian grasslands to depict life among the rural poor during the Cultural Revolution of 1966 to 76. Adrienne Clarkson, a former governor general of Canada who was chairwoman of the panel of three judges, said, This masterly work is also a passionate argument about the complex interrelationship between nomads and settlers, animals and human beings, nature and culture. Wolf Totem is to be published in English by Penguin next year. Its translator, Howard Goldblatt, received a prize of $3,000. Because of ill health Mr. Jiang, from Beijing, was unable to travel to Hong Kong to accept his prize.

title: My Network, My Cause
description: IN 2003, as Howard Deans presidential bid surged, the Internet was hailed as a decisive new factor in electoral politics. In 2007, the explosive growth of online social networks seems poised to drive a similar upheaval in the world of philanthropy.

title: Not From Here: An Opera for Houstons Immigrants
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 11  With brickbats flying over border issues, the Houston Grand Opera put immigration center stage this weekend in a dramatic outreach to the more than 1 million foreign-born residents here in the nations fourth largest city.

title: First One Orphan, Then Many More
description: THE United States has plenty of affluent do-gooders who are taken with the idea that with their experience and creativity they could harness expertise and money to better the lives of people in the developing world.

title: A Big Salary With a Big Stipulation: Share It
description: LATE last year, a Bear Stearns employee panicked: had she donated enough money?

title: For a Memorial With Cracks, Fix or Replace?
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11  The fate of the Tomb of the Unknowns at Arlington National Cemetery is uncertain this Veterans Day weekend, as the Army has yet to decide whether to replace or repair the 75-year-old monument, which is marred by several large cracks.

title: Screenwriters Seek Bigger Slice of Half-Eaten Pie
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 11  As Hollywood digs in for a second week of a strike, the screenwriters might want to send a few angry picketers over to Will Smiths place. Or Steven Spielbergs.

title: Bee Bumps Gangster
description: In the second weekend of combat between two of the seasons most heavily promoted films, the DreamWorks Animation Bee Movie (distributed by Paramount) ousted American Gangster (Universal) from the No. 1 spot at North American box offices. Bee Movie, with the voices of Jerry Seinfeld (for Barry B. Benson, right) and Rene Zellweger, took in $26 million, while American Gangster, starring Denzel Washington as a drug lord and Russell Crowe as his law enforcement nemesis, grossed $24.3 million, according to estimates from the tracking company Media by Numbers. We dont often see a movie start out in the No. 2 position then move up to No. 1, Paul Dergarabedian, the president of Media by Numbers, told The Associated Press. It just shows how strong the word of mouth is on this movie and that families are really enjoying it. Third and fourth places went to two newcomers. Fred Claus (Warner Brothers), the comedy starring Vince Vaughn as the disgruntled elder brother of Santa Claus (Paul Giamatti), took in $19.2 million. Robert Redfords current-affairs drama, Lions for Lambs (MGM), with Tom Cruise and Meryl Streep, gathered $6.7 million. Finishing fifth was the comedy Dan in Real Life (Disney), with $5.8 million in its third week. The weekends top per-screen average went to Joel and Ethan Coens latter-day western, No Country for Old Men (Miramax), with Tommy Lee Jones, Javier Bardem and Josh Brolin, which took in $42,929 per screen at 28 theaters, compared with $7,950 for American Gangster at 3,059 theaters.

title: The Real Margo Channings Fasten-Your-Seatbelts Life
description: The legendary film star Bette Davis was what might charitably be called a real piece of work. According to Ed Sikov, author of Dark Victory: The Life of Bette Davis, many who knew her often put it more bluntly. Barbara Stanwyck, no slouch herself in the legends category, described Daviss creative ruthlessness, and her co-star Brian Aherne said nobody but a mother could have loved her.

title: To Tax or Not to Tax Nonprofits? Cities Ask the Billion-Dollar Question
description: DESPITE a long tradition of waiving taxes for charitable nonprofit groups, communities are feeling more pressure to eliminate property-tax exemptions.

title: D-League Team Could Bring Rens Back to Harlem
description: Commissioner David Stern wants to put an N.B.A. Development League team in Harlem, U.S.A. The idea was jolting at first. Now its intriguing.

title: In the Fund-Raising Game, Blogs Cut Both Ways
description: IN the world of animal rights charities, a certain phrase has been fund-raising gold lately  Michael Vicks dogs.

title: Sharp Sell-Off Sweeps Asian Markets
description: TOKYO, Nov. 12  Rising fears of a slowdown in the United States economy sparked a sharp sell-off in Asian stock markets today, driving a leading Japanese index to a two-year low.

title: Whatever the Challenge, Shy Is Not as Shy Does
description: Petite, baby-faced and outwardly diffident, the young French pianist Lise de la Salle presents a shy eye to her audience, but one that turns fierce when the music starts. Her recital at the Metropolitan Museum on Saturday, indifferently attended, was a split-screen advertisement for an impressive talent.

title: Seeking More Aid, Gulf Coast Looks to Foundations
description: AFTER Hurricane Katrina wrecked the Gulf Coast, Kathy Laborde started a nonprofit group in New Orleans to build inexpensive replacement housing. She has one block of apartments nearly finished and a dozen other projects ready to start.

title: Borders Adds TV Watching to Its Bookstores Entertainment
description: Borders bookstores  with their cafes, toys and games and large displays of movies and music  have never exactly been confused with, say, university libraries.

title: Greeks Save Ship With 275 Migrants
description: ATHENS, Nov. 11  The Greek coast guard on Sunday rescued 275 people believed to be illegal migrants crammed on a Turkish cargo ship that nearly capsized in rough seas southwest of the Greek coast, a Greek coast guard spokeswoman said.

title: Musharraf Sets No Date to End Emergency Rule
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 11  Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the Pakistani president, appeared to yield to intense American pressure on Sunday by restoring parliamentary elections in early January, but he said his emergency decree would last at least through then, immediately raising new questions about the votes legitimacy.

title: A Museum Rises, but Not the Usual Way
description: PEOPLE in Denver like to say that while New York may be an experiment that is over, their town is one in the making. Thats the sort of spirit that moved Karl Kister, a philanthropist and entrepreneur, to become involved with the Museum of Contemporary Art/Denver.

title: Pay the Doctor, but Dont Worry About the Pilot
description: Rochester

title: A New York Honor, Centuries Old and Gold-Plated
description: Keep your eye out. Fats Domino could show up anywhere in New York at any moment. He now has the freedom of the city. And an official, five-and-three-quarters-inch-long gold-plated pewter key to prove it.

title: Study: Foreign Students Added to Economy
description: While foreign students at American colleges and universities are most often singled out for their scientific and cultural contributions, their growing numbers help make them an increasingly important economic force as well, according to a new report from the Institute of International Education.

title: Beyond the Gift of Cold, Hard Cash
description: AMONG the items that Tom Bird gave to charity last year was what he considered a lingering asset on his personal balance sheet: the domain name, farm.com, which he retained when he and his business partner sold their Silicon Valley record storage company, First American Record Management (FARM) in 1999.

title: Some Japanese Tonal Colors for Tales Dressed in Kimonos
description: Opera is supposedly a grand form, yet many people devoted enough to present it can realize their passion only on a small scale. New York is rife with small opera companies, ranging from highly professional troupes offering lesser-known works to groups that function essentially as community theater.

title: After Battling Paranoia, a Growing Confidence
description: Sabrina Conney twisted her hand into a C chord and smiled toward the polished surface of her guitar.

title: Colts Manning and Vinatieri Off Target in Loss
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 11 (AP)  Peyton Manning was poised to turn one of his worst games into one of his most memorable Sunday night.

title: Hershey Overhauls Its Board of Directors
description: The chocolate maker Hershey, which replaced its chief executive last month, announced a reshuffling of its board of directors yesterday as the charitable trust that controls the company stepped up efforts to lift Hersheys languishing stock.

title: New CDs
description: ALICIA KEYS  As I Am  (J Records)

title: Game News in a Duel of Print and Online
description: Noel Goodman subscribes to three video game magazines, but he wants information faster than the magazines can reach his mailbox.

title: Iraq Premier Sees Families Returning to Safer Capital
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 11  The Iraqi prime minister, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, said in a news conference on Sunday that increased security in Baghdad had allowed thousands of families to return to their homes in the capital and outlying areas.

title: After Hard Labor, a Soft Landing
description: Keithville, La.

title: Clarity Lacking in Discipline for Hits to Head
description: On the same day the N.F.L. instructed its officials to eject players who delivered flagrant helmet-to-helmet hits, three high-profile college football players sustained injuries from vicious hits involving the helmet. None of the plays drew penalties.

title: Absinthe Returns in a Glass Half Full of Mystique and Misery
description: Dear reader! Should this column impress you as being more than usually lyrical, recalling perhaps the imagery and elegance of poetry by Baudelaire or Verlaine; should it seem a bit decadent, redolent of Oscar Wildes withering hauteur; should it have a touch of madness or perversity, combining, say, the tastes of Toulouse-Lautrec with the passions of van Gogh; should it simply sound direct and forceful and knowing like one of Ernest Hemingways characters; should it do any or all of that, let me credit something that each of these figures fervently paid tribute to: the green fairy, the green goddess, the green muse, the glaucous witch, the queen of poisons.

title: European Tabloids Still Agog Months After Child Vanishes
description: LONDON, Nov. 8  Gerry McCann Back at Work, the tabloid Evening Standard screamed out to London commuters on a recent afternoon.

title: Restoring Confidence in the Balloting Process
description: Since the election fiasco in Florida in 2000, how much progress have the states made in overhauling their election systems?

title: Life After Wartime
description: MY mother, who is 88, told me last month that it had been a long time since shed seen Paul Tibbets in the Bob Evans restaurant on the east side of Columbus, Ohio. She thought this was odd; she ate lunch there so often, and he ate lunch there so often, that his absence worried her.

title: Profile Rises at School Where Going Against the Grain Is the Norm
description: GREAT NECK, N.Y.  A high school social studies class was studying the federal governments response to Hurricane Katrina on a recent afternoon, without any readings, lessons or even desks. Only one student was taking notes.

title: Clinton Aides Prompted Queries at Events
description: At two campaign events in Iowa this year, aides to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton encouraged audience members to ask her specific questions, a tactic that drew criticism from an opponent for the Democratic presidential nomination and led her yesterday to promise that it would not happen again.

title: Cellphone Straitjacket Is Inspiring a Rebellion
description: First come the grumblings, then the torches and pitchforks.

title: Attention Shoppers: Philanthropy in Aisle 5
description: THE lime-green box of chocolate truffles looks like yet another elegant designer package. Round cut-outs reveal rows of confections intricately decorated with everything from a striped candy cane to a snowman donning a bright blue top hat.

title: A Heart Stent Gets a Reprieve From Doctors
description: A year after safety questions about drug-coated heart stents prompted doctors to change treatment for hundreds of thousands of cardiac patients, many physicians say the medical community overreacted and should now reverse course.

title: All They Are Saying Is Give Happiness a Chance
description: The framers of the Declaration of Independence evidently believed that happiness could be achieved, putting its pursuit up there alongside the unalienable rights to life and liberty. Though governments since then have seen life and liberty as deserving of vigorous protection, for all the public policies aimed at increasing economic growth, people have been left to sort out their happiness.

title: Outrage, Bile, Hardcore Punk ... and a Sensible Lost-and-Found
description: This next song is about the people who want to control our bodies, said the singer known as Pink Eyes, adding, This next song is about the police.

title: Lottery Numbers
Day 2 of Stagehands Strike, and a Chill Sets In
description: Just after what would have been curtain time on Saturday night, Day 1 of the stagehands strike on Broadway, things seemed, if not normal, at least bearable. Some theater-district restaurants lost business, but others were buzzing with people who simply turned their pre-theater reservations into 8 p.m. dinners. Chorus folks hit the bars for a rare Saturday night off. There was even some singing in the streets.

title: Giving Away Money, Getting an Education
description: Natick, Mass.

title: SquarePants RoundTrip: SpongeBobs Yearlong Ride to Atlantis, via Korea
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 11  If nautical nonsense be something you wish, it helps to be patient.

title: Why Movie Stars Offer the Clothes Off Their Backs
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Bring the Real World Home
description: In the gym at the NATO base in Kabul, U.S. soldiers hit the treadmills every morning and gaze at TV screens broadcasting Al Jazeeras English news channel. When Osama bin Laden makes news, as he did recently with a statement about Iraq, Americas finest work out beneath the solemn gaze of their most wanted enemy.

title: Giving Goes Global: Three Stories
description: IN the upper stratum of wealth, people are increasingly taking a global view, devoting considerable effort and money to help victims of poverty, war and natural disasters and work for causes like social justice, the environment and peace.

title: Hunger and the Farm Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Envoy in Myanmar to Try to Tally Dead
description: BANGKOK, Nov. 11  A United Nations envoy arrived in Myanmar on Sunday to begin the first independent investigation into the military governments crackdown in September on protests led by Buddhist monks and students.

title: Supreme Court May Take Gun Case
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12  Both sides in a closely watched legal battle over the District of Columbias strict gun-control law are urging the Supreme Court to hear the case. If the justices agree  a step they may announce as early as Tuesday  the Roberts court is likely to find itself back on the front lines of the culture wars with an intensity unmatched even by the cases on abortion and race that defined the courts last term.

title: Dollar Policy: Dont Ask, Dont Tell
description: When asked about the administrations policy on the dollar, Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson Jr. dutifully says a strong dollar is in the nations interest and that markets should determine currency exchange rates.

title: Music for Use: Dance, Sing Along or Examine It Closely
description: It must be odd for those outside Western European culture to find their music presented on brightly lighted stages in front of listeners sitting quietly in the dark. Friday night at Zankel Hall, the Nevzat Akpinar Ensemble  eight musicians performing folk and ritual music of Turks and Kurds  wrestled good-naturedly with a printed program seemingly created to be undermined.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A chart in Business Day last Monday with an article about collateralized debt obligations, a complex investment instrument backed by assets like mortgages, described incorectly a ranking of investment banks. The ranking was of top book runners of collateralized debt obligations, not issuers. (Book runners manage the offerings of new securities.) (Go to Article)

title: Play That Funky Spinning Bike Wheel, Berlin Boy
description: As anyone who frequents New Yorks downtown lofts and Brooklyns nightclubs can attest, cutting-edge music flourishes where rents are relatively low and patrons are unburdened by the rigorous customs of conventional concert life. The model works just as well in Berlin, as the KNM Berlin, an 11-member ensemble founded in the late 1980s by students from the Hanns Eisler College of Music there, proves.

title: Opening Loss Is More Bad News for Rutgers
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Nov. 11  With the Don Imus imbroglio and a defeat in last seasons national championship game behind it, Rutgers was hoping to begin a new chapter and a new season on a positive note Sunday night. Instead, the Scarlet Knights were left to deal with a different kind of painful experience: a last-second loss.

title: Sale of Wendys May Be Delayed
description: The auction of Wendys International may be in jeopardy because of continued turmoil in the credit markets, potentially forcing the company to delay its sale, people close to the situation said yesterday.

title: Will Success, or All That Money From Google, Spoil Firefox?
description: Only a couple of years ago, Firefox was the little browser that could  an open-source program created by thousands of contributors around the world without the benefit of a giant company like Microsoft to finance it.

title: Footnotes
description: Bon Jovi will headline the 2007 Royal Variety Performance gala next month, with Queen Elizabeth II in the audience at the Empire Theater in Liverpool, Agence France-Presse reported. By royal command, other performers will include Kiri Te Kanawa, Enrique Iglesias, James Blunt and Katherine Jenkins. The performance benefits the Entertainment Artistes Benevolent Fund. The queen is a patron. ... Beijing will ring in the New Year with New Years Eve and New Years Day performances at its new National Center for the Performing Arts. The event will feature the China National Symphony Orchestra, led by the Japanese conductor Seiji Ozawa, the Chinese pianist Lang Lang, the Russian violinist Vadim Repin and the American soprano Kathleen Battle. ... American Ballet Theater has changed the name of the ABT Studio Company. This small classical company of 13 young dancers of high potential will now be called ABT II, Kevin McKenzie, artistic director of American Ballet Theater, announced. Wes Chapman, artistic director of ABT II, said the idea was to improve the troupes visibility to the public. ... A new song by the composer and cabaret singing star Michael Feinstein will open the 81st annual Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade on Nov. 22. The number, Making Magic, choreographed by John Dietrich of the Radio City Rockettes and featuring lyrics by Bill Schermerhorn, the parades creative director, was written for 600 dancing children trained by Camp Broadway, which offers summer programs taught by theater professionals.

title: Beware, Conniving Count, This Rugged Figaro Will Have You Dancing to His Tune
description: Cast changes are inevitable during the run of a production at a repertory opera company. But when Jonathan Millers staging of Mozarts Nozze di Figaro returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday afternoon after a break of more than three weeks, the company fielded an entirely different cast from the one introduced in early October.

title: Israeli Police Raid Offices for Evidence on Olmert
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 11  About 100 police investigators from Israels National Fraud Unit conducted unannounced searches in more than 20 locations around the country on Sunday, seeking materials connected with criminal investigations under way against Prime Minister Ehud Olmert.

title: With Health Costs Rising, a Tougher Sell for Hospitals
description: AFTER charging tens of thousands of dollars for a knee replacement, the hospital wants a donation?

title: Film Festival in Baghdad
description: An international film festival is planned for Baghdad next month, an Iraqi director told Agence France-Presse yesterday. The filmmaker,  Abdul Basit Salman, who now lives in Cairo, said the festival, presented by the Association of Iraqi Filmmakers Without Borders Dec. 16 to 19 at a site to be decided, would consist mainly of submissions from Egypt, Jordan and Iran. If the event goes off as planned, it will be the first major cinematic event in Baghdad since a popular festival of short films was held in 2005 in the Al-Mansour Hotel, which this June was the target of a suicide bomber who killed 12 people. Only a few movie theaters in Baghdad still keep their doors open.

title: Redirecting Heartache Into Donor Funds
description: AFTER nine operations for cancer, what Leslie Ries wanted most was to help other people facing treatment by directing money to groups that provide services that large charities do not address.

title: For U.S. Exporters in Cuba, Business Trumps Politics
description: HAVANA, Nov. 11  A trade fair in Communist Cuba is perhaps the last place you would expect to find a Republican governor from the American heartland. Yet last week, Gov. Dave Heineman of Nebraska was here to sign a deal to export $11 million worth of his states wheat to the island.

title: Ray S. Smith, Arkansas Lawmaker, Dies at 83
description: Ray S. Smith, a former Arkansas legislator who during the turmoil after the integration of Central High School in Little Rock in 1957 cast the only vote against a bill giving Gov. Orval E. Faubus the power to close public schools, died on Nov. 1. He was 83.

title: A Canyon Refuge for Animals in Need of Some T.L.C.
description: BECAUSE the pink dunes and sandstone walls of Angel Canyon in southern Utah served as a backdrop for 1950s Westerns, the area had been known as Little Hollywood. Today, Angel Canyon serves a less glamorous if more heartfelt role, as a sanctuary for the thousands of animals that the Best Friends Animal Society saves each year.

title: Congregation Writes Torah, With Help From a Scribe
description: Thousands of years old though it may be, the Torah began anew on a recent Sunday with Helen Margalith, 92 years old. She faced the congregation, then stared at the seeming immensity of a blank white sheet of unblemished parchment. A sofer, or scribe, sat by her side, holding a feather quill. She tentatively grasped it an inch above his hand.

title: Over There  and Gone Forever
description: BY any conceivable measure, Frank Buckles has led an extraordinary life. Born on a farm in Missouri in February 1901, he saw his first automobile in his hometown in 1905, and his first airplane at the Illinois State Fair in 1907. At 15 he moved on his own to Oklahoma and went to work in a bank; in the 1940s, he spent more than three years as a Japanese prisoner of war. When he returned to the United States, he married, had a daughter and bought a farm near Charles Town, W. Va., where he lives to this day. He drove a tractor until he was 104.

title: Editor of More Replaces One at Readers Digest
description: The domestic edition of Readers Digest has replaced its editor in chief, Jacqueline Leo, hiring Peggy Northrop away from the Meredith Corporations More magazine, the magazine announced Friday.

title: Virtual Lures for Holiday Shoppers
description: ONLINE retailers take solace in knowing that no matter how painful it may be to click around endlessly searching for products, it still often beats the mall.

title: An Evenings Serenade Harks Back to Summer
description: One advantage chamber musicians often have over orchestral players is the luxury of ample rehearsal time. At the annual Marlboro Music Festival in Vermont, run by the esteemed pianists Richard Goode and Mitsuko Uchida, veteran and emerging artists collaborate on substantive study and performances of the chamber music repertory. Some of those musicians then tour with works prepared during the summer.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Bee Bumps Gangster

title: For Ousted Citigroup Chief, a Bonus of $12.5 Million
description: This year, thousands of Citigroup employees can expect bonuses based on their work in 2007, when the banks results have been less than stellar. One, however, will get a bonus based largely on his performance in 2006, which was a better year: Charles O. Prince III, who resigned under pressure as chairman and chief executive last week.

title: 3 Dead in Storm That Caused Oil Spill
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 12  A fierce storm in the Black Sea sank at least five ships on Sunday, killing at least three sailors and causing a massive oil spill that could lead to severe environmental damage, officials said. About 20 sailors were missing.

title: Italys Best Battle It Out for Club Title
description: The 96-board final of the Italian Club Championship, which ended Oct. 28, brought together that countrys top four pairs. Representing Torino-Allegra were regulars on the Italian team, Norberto Bocchi and Giorgio Duboin, playing with Agustin Madala and Antonio Sementa. The other team, Tennis Club Parioli, included Italys other two world champion pairs, Fulvio Fantoni-Claudio Nunes and Lorenzo Lauria-Alfredo Versace. Francesco Angelini played the first and fourth sessions with Versace.

title: Westchester Post for Itzhak Perlman
description: Itzhak Perlman has been appointed artistic director of the Westchester Philharmonic, beginning with the 2008-9 season. He is to conduct the orchestra at three of its five programs for three seasons, beginning on Oct. 11, 2008. He will succeed Paul Lustig Dunkel, who helped found the Westchester Philharmonic 25 years ago and has since been its music director and conductor. Mr. Dunkel announced last year that he would step down in May 2008.

title: The Plight of American Veterans
description: As an unpopular, ill-planned war in Iraq grinds on inconclusively, it can be a bleak time to be a veteran.

title: Some Wonder if the Banks Stabilization Fund Will Work
description: When the countrys three largest banks reached agreement on Friday on how to structure a $75 billion fund to prop up distressed securities, an exhausted group of its top planners gathered in a Bank of America conference room to toast their success with 12-packs of Bud Light.

title: Queens: Man Killed in Three-Car Crash
description: A 66-year-old man was killed late Saturday night when the car he was driving was struck by an out-of-control Honda Accord, the police said. The driver of the Accord, Christopher Rivera, 25, of Howard Beach, was arrested and charged with driving while intoxicated and vehicular manslaughter. The collision occurred shortly after 10:45 p.m. on Woodhaven Boulevard near 101st Avenue in Woodhaven, when Mr. Riveras car crossed the median into northbound traffic, striking the victims 1999 Nissan Maxima, the police said. The Maxima then struck a third vehicle, a 2006 BMW. The driver of the Maxima, whose name was not released yesterday, was pronounced dead at the scene. His passenger, a 60-year-old woman, was in stable condition at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center. Mr. Rivera and his passenger were also in stable condition, as were the two occupants of the BMW, the police said.

title: Again and Again in the Balkans
description: The Balkans have a dismal way of living up to their stereotype as a region of ancient, intertwined and irreconcilable feuds. This month was supposed to be the one in which the Kosovo issue was finally put to rest. Now, with Russias active meddling, not only does that look unlikely, but the Serbs are threatening to stir new troubles in Bosnia if Kosovo declares independence. This is a time for urgent, creative diplomacy by the major powers.

title: Giants Saddle Up but Dont Measure Up
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 11  For six consecutive games, all of them victories, the Giants set out to prove that the start of their season was an aberration. Yet all those Sundays removed from a humiliating opening-day defeat to the Cowboys in Texas, the Giants squandered a second chance to make a strong impression and recast themselves as true title contenders.

title: With Ponies, Unicorns and Secret Codes, an Effort to Unleash a Craze for Girls
description: He has already introduced America to a boy-oriented trading card game (Magic: The Gathering) and one with unisex appeal (Pokmon). Now, Peter D. Adkison is hoping to find new success with a line of collectible cards aimed at girls.

title: Brooklyn: Woman Charged in Fatal Stabbing
description: A Brooklyn woman was arrested yesterday on accusations that she fatally stabbed a man during a domestic dispute on Saturday evening, the police said. The woman, Shenequa DeFreitas, 27, of Ocean Avenue, was charged with manslaughter, the police said. Ms. DeFreitas stabbed the man, Thomas Adonis, 25, of East 57th Street, in the torso during a dispute in her home about 6:20 p.m., the police said. Mr. Adonis was taken to Kings County Hospital Center, where he was pronounced dead.

title: Cowboys Serve Big Helping of Reality
description: East Rutherford, N.J.

title: Browns Show Life, but Steelers Survive
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 11  The Browns are improving but are not good enough to beat the Steelers  not yet. Pittsburgh proved that Sunday by coming from behind twice for a 31-28 victory in a battle for first place in the American Football Conference North.

title: Win Fabulous Prizes, All in the Name of Innovation
description: THE quests are monumental: end global warming; build a private spaceship; cure diseases; develop a car that can go 100 miles on a gallon of gas.

title: California Zeros in on the Intractable
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Imagine Theres No Heaven, Just Flamenco
description: At the core of flamenco is the notion of duende: those dark forces contesting within the artists soul, forcing their way out through the dance to evoke the battle with life, with death, with the birth of art itself.

title: A Place to Leave the Wars Behind
description: AS a Vietnam veteran, Michael Howk likes nothing better than fielding questions from newcomers to Stand Down House, a residential program in Lake Worth, Fla., that helps homeless male veterans who are battling mental health and substance abuse problems.

title: Living Paycheck to Paycheck Was Already a Way of Life
description: Bradford Winters, a screenwriter who lives and works in New York, came home very animated after walking the picket line last Monday, the first day of the Writers Guild of Americas strike against the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers.

title: Making a Difference From an Early Age
description: TEACHING by example remains the best way for parents to inspire charitable values, but experts  and some former children  say there are other methods to help young people develop the habit of giving, even in families of modest means.

title: Without Randolph, Knicks Collapse at the End
description: Stephon Marbury heard boos last night, not for anything that happened during his curious, sometimes scandalous off-season, but for everything that happened in the final seconds of a tight game against the Miami Heat.

title: For Chinese-Americans, Schools Earn the Prize
description: LAST February, Jerry Yang and his wife, Akiko Yamazaki, pledged $75 million to Stanford University for a variety of programs. Two-thirds of their gift will go to build a new environment and energy site. The balance will go to the medical school.

title: Heavy Storm Splits Tanker, Spilling Oil Off Russia
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 11  A fierce storm in the Black Sea split a small tanker on Sunday, causing an oil spill that could lead to significant environmental damage, officials said.

title: Striking Writers Peddle Words, for Outlets Off the Picket Line
description: Sometimes it seems that every time the striking television and movie writers put down their picket signs, they pick up their pencils.

title: I.R.S. Moves to Weed Out Deadwood Charities
description: DONORS should get a much clearer picture of how secular charities handle their money, and which charities are legitimate, thanks to new rules imposed by Congress.

title: With Theaters Dark, Finding Their Fun Elsewhere
description: Broadway has gone dark, but a familys vacation must go on.

title: A Young Orchestra Led by a Youthful Major Player
description: When Gustavo Dudamel walked on the stage at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon to conduct the first of two programs with the Simn Bolvar Youth Symphony Orchestra of Venezuela, it looked for a moment as if his much-touted unflappability were going to desert him. With his unkempt mane of curly hair and slight build, he looked a little ashen-faced and shy.

title: Veterans Day: Parking
description: Because of Veterans Day, which is observed today, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Decoding the Markets 101, for the Soon-to-Retire
description: IT has famous Wall Street parents and an alphabet-soup abbreviation known only to investment professionals. Now Finra, the new private regulator for securities firms, mutual fund houses and stockbrokers, has a bold plan: to be a best friend to Americas ordinary investors.

title: Back-Office Support for Busy Microfinanciers
description: THE microfinance industry  bankers to the poor  faces a paradox of scale, growing large in some ways but remaining small in others.

title: A Not-So-Simple Plan to Keep African Girls in School
description: THEY call it the Map of Africa.

title: When Reagan Spoke of States Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: More Than Cinema: A Campaign to End Child Sex
description: THE movie Holly has a pedigree that any independent filmmaker would envy: a critically acclaimed run through the international festival circuit, a recognizable but not-yet-famous actor from Sex and the City, a red-carpet screening at the United Nations with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on the host committee.

title: Security Guard Fires From Convoy, Killing Iraqi Driver
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 11  An Iraqi taxi driver was shot and killed on Saturday by a guard with DynCorp International, a private security company hired to protect American diplomats here, when a DynCorp convoy rolled past a knot of traffic on an exit ramp in Baghdad, the Iraqi Interior Ministry said Sunday.

title: Pigs Fly! Philadelphia Papers Circulation Holds
description: Newspapers in Philadelphia have chosen the image of airborne pigs to illustrate their unlikely achievement: circulation holding steady at a time when the industrys is dropping.

title: Forging Ahead With Lifes Tests, One Day at a Time
description: San Francisco

title: Fighting a Disease of Logistics, He Means Business
description: WHEN Lance Laifer, a hedge fund manager in New Jersey and former Internet entrepreneur, started researching malaria two and a half years ago, a prominent professor with a medical background told him that doctors were not drawn to malaria research because it was a disease of logistics. Doctors dont do logistics, Mr. Laifer recalls that he said. Business does logistics.

title: Contemplating the Meaning of Life
description: In 1977, when Gerald L. Hessell was sentenced to life in prison for second-degree murder, a gallon of gas cost 62 cents and a life term in Michigan meant about 15 years.

title: A Cookbook of Ones Own From the Internet
description: As a founder of the online photography service Ofoto, Kamran Mohsenin took note of the pleasure and pride his customers derived from making personalized calendars and books. The perceived value and the sense of accomplishment in creating your own photo book was high, he said.

title: A Weekend of Skirmishing for Obama and Clinton
description: DES MOINES, Nov. 11  Senator Barack Obama kept on the attack against Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, accusing her of running a poll-driven campaign that avoided tough questions. He said on Sunday that he would increase the amount of income subject to Social Security taxes.

title: A Family Legacy, Built to Withstand Dynamite
description: LAS VEGAS, Nov. 11  With less than 48 hours until one of this citys favorite but rarest of spectacles, the principal players stood around a long table on Sunday morning readying their props and showing no traces of stage fright.

title: The Young and the Restless Try, Too
description: IN many ways, 27-year-old Jonathan Holmes is the picture-perfect next-generation philanthropist. In 2004, he was teaching art at a Maryland boarding school  because I wanted to affect the greater good, he said  when his aunt asked him to return to New Jersey and inject new life into a limping family foundation. He agreed, on the condition that she allow him to find a mission based on what I felt was really needed in these communities.

title: The Days Best
description: Brett Favre passed for 351 yards and 3 touchdowns as the Packers improved to 8-1 by beating the Vikings, 34-0. Favre is 1,105 yards from breaking Dan Marinos N.F.L. career record.

title: Taking It Game by Game Minus Wade, the Heat Looks at Itself as 1-0
description: A Miami Heat losing streak that stretched back to April came to an abrupt halt last night against the Knicks in a defensive struggle at Madison Square Garden.

title: A New Channel for Soft Money Appears in Race
description: The so-called Wounded Warriors Act, legislation intended to improve health care for veterans, has attracted nearly unanimous, bipartisan support in Congress. So why would the newly formed Foundation for a Secure and Prosperous America begin running a television commercial urging the citizens of South Carolina to tell Congress to pass it?

title: A Spys Path: Iowa to A-Bomb to Kremlin Honor
description: He had all-American cover: born in Iowa, college in Manhattan, Army buddies with whom he played baseball.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Grants for Gay Services Grow and Go Mainstream
description: ITS not easy being a teenager and gay in a deeply conservative community like Colorado Springs. This is the headquarters of many Christian groups that strongly disapprove of homosexuality, including Focus on the Family.

title: Google Options Make Masseuse a Multimillionaire
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 11  Bonnie Brown was fresh from a nasty divorce in 1999, living with her sister and uncertain of her future. On a lark, she answered an ad for an in-house masseuse at Google, then a Silicon Valley start-up with 40 employees. She was offered the part-time job, which started out at $450 a week but included a pile of Google stock options that she figured might never be worth a penny.

title: Intel to Unveil Chips for Improving Video Quality on the Web
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 11  Intel plans to announce a family of microprocessor chips on Monday that it says will speed the availability of high-definition video via the Internet.

title: A Stark Reminder of War, 25 Years On
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11  Throngs of veterans gathered on Sunday under a clear sky on the Mall to commemorate the 25th anniversary of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial, a stark symbol of a war that bitterly divided the nation.

title: With Sudden Wealth, the Desire for Sudden Impact
description: SILICON VALLEY is percolating again, with venture capital flowing, Googles stock in the stratosphere and companies like Facebook valued in the billions. And in increasing numbers, the rich are cultivating a sense of noblesse oblige.

title: They Channel Intentions to the Right Places
description: BILL DONNELL is a philanthropist with many charitable interests, among them gay and lesbian rights, the environment, the arts and, above all, the well-being of the city where he lives. Ultimately, he said, its New York City I would like to benefit. I have a genuine love for it.

title: Treasury Auction Set for This Week
description: This week, the Treasury has an auction of four-week bills scheduled on Wednesday.

title: Dogged Cotto Surprised Everyone but Himself
description: Miguel Cotto did some uncharacteristic ducking and dancing in the ring at Madison Square Garden against Shane Mosley on Saturday night. He used an effective jab, which was as surprising as his speed.

title: Romo Solves a Defensive Puzzle
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 11  The T-shirt that Dallas Cowboys quarterback Tony Romo had worn under his jersey was so threadbare that it looked as if it would shred if a defensive tackle even glanced at him. But nine games into the season, the shirt is still intact, and so is the Cowboys control of the N.F.C., saved by Romos improvisational skills that assured that the Giants got an eyeful of him, but not much more.

title: Helping Time Warner Give Away Some of Its Millions
description: THOSE who saw this years Fall for Dance Festival at New York City Center or the August Wilson series at Signature Theater in New York in 2004 might have noticed Time Warners name on posters or in programs. But they probably had no idea how Time Warner came to support such events. A large company with a philanthropic arm must review hundreds of requests for help.

title: A Windfall Illuminates the Poetry Field, and Its Fights
description: IN November 2002, news of a $100 million grant from the pharmaceutical company heiress Ruth Lilly to the Modern Poetry Association, publisher of Poetry magazine, electrified the arts and philanthropic communities.

title: How Long Should Gifts Just Grow?
description: AS nonprofit institutions have seen donations and investments grow spectacularly in recent years, the urge to keep the money rolling in is being supplemented by a new pressure: make it flow out faster.

title: Tuts Tomb to Close
description: Egypt plans to limit the number of visitors to King Tuts tomb and to close it to visitors indefinitely next year to carry out restoration, Agence France-Presse reported. In a statement yesterday Zahi Hawass, secretary general of the Supreme Council of Antiquities, said the number of daily visitors would be restricted to 400 beginning next month, and restoration work on the tomb, discovered in 1922 in the Valley of the Kings, would begin in May.

title: Gilberto Gil to Resign
description: The Grammy Award-winning singer, composer and guitarist Gilberto Gil, above, plans to resign his post as Brazils culture minister next year to treat a polyp on his vocal cords, The Associated Press reported. Citing local news media, the agency said Mr. Gil, 65, had not set a date for his resignation. Since his surprise appointment as culture minister in 2003 he has divided his time between politics and music. He said that at a performance in July, he realized he had a recurring vocal problem. For the first time in many years I had to make a tour under pressure of losing my voice, he said. That really tormented me. Mr. Gil and his friend Caetano Veloso are credited with founding the Tropicalism movement, a blend of rock and bossa nova that influenced David Byrne, Paul Simon and Beck. The political content of its lyrics offended Brazils military dictatorship. Mr. Gil and Mr. Veloso were jailed in 1968 and lived in London from 1969 to 1972.

title: Two-Wheeled Neglect
description: To the Editor:

title: Posada Likely to Return to Yankees
description: Jorge Posada acknowledged last night that he was likely to return to the Yankees next season.

title: City Power Wins Title in Shootout
description: The Martin Luther King Jr. High School boys soccer team defeated Francis Lewis in a penalty-kick shootout yesterday to win the Public Schools Athletic League championship at Icahn Stadium on Randalls Island.

title: Jaguars Bulldoze Titans Ground Defense
description: NASHVILLE, Nov. 11  On game days, Jacksonville tailback Fred Taylor showers in the dark so he does not have to close his eyes to visualize a great performance.
