He sits down in front of his locker and studies a montage of his highlight runs on his iPod, the better to put himself in the right frame of mind to add to the compilation.

title: Mondays Matchup
description: A changing of the guard was predicted in the N.F.C. West. But San Francisco and Arizona have not put up much of a fight, even though Seattle, the three-time defending champion, has left the door wide open. With Shaun Alexander injured and ineffective, Seahawks Coach Mike Holmgren has renewed focus on the passing game, which is ranked 10th in the league. The 49ers, losers of six in a row, wish they had only one facet of their 32nd-ranked offense to be concerned about. The Seahawks, who won in San Francisco in Week 4, are hungry for payback after a season sweep by the 49ers last year. San Francisco Coach Mike Nolans father, Dick Nolan, a former Giants player and 49ers coach, died yesterday, but Mike Nolan is expected to be with his team tonight. NAILA-JEAN MEYERS

title: Mystique Follows Messier Wherever He Goes
description: Three years after he last played and 13 since his transcendent moment as a Ranger, Mark Messier can still light up Madison Square Garden with only one smile.

title: The Film Was Fine, Now That Its Over
description: A study in The Journal of Consumer Research explores peoples faulty memories of how much they liked an experience, showing that they look for cues in their own subsequent behavior.

title: Child Studies May Ease Fears on Misbehavior
description: Educators and psychologists have long feared that children entering school with behavior problems were doomed to fall behind in the upper grades. But two new studies suggest that those fears are exaggerated.

title: Lifestyle Magazine for Jewish Women to Appear
description: More often than not, when Martha Stewart gets out her glue gun to make a holiday decoration, it is a Christmas tree ornament or an Easter display. And when Family Circle reaches out to readers, it may ask them to submit Christmas cookie recipes.

title: Carrie Rozelle, 69, Child Advocate, Dies; Started a Center for Learning Disabilities
description: Carrie Rozelle, whose struggles with the daily hurricane of a son with learning disabilities prompted her to start the National Center for Learning Disabilities, died on Oct. 29 at her home in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif. She was 69.

title: John Firor, 80, Early Voice on Environment, Is Dead
description: John Firor, an environmental scholar and former director of the National Center of Atmospheric Research who was an early voice linking climate change and human activity, died last Monday in Pullman, Wash. He was 80.

title: Whos Afraid of the Menace Within? Not Edward Albee
description: The beast is still scratching at the door, howling, demanding to be let in. And Edward Albee is never going to let us forget its existence, not as long as his plays are being read and produced.

title: U.N. Examining Myanmar Crackdown
description: BANGKOK, Nov. 11  A United Nations envoy arrived in Myanmar on Sunday to begin the first independent investigation into the military governments September crackdown on protests led by Buddhist monks and students.

title: For Children, a Scary World Out There (in There, Too)
description: Fears of crawling insects, the dark and all types of vegetables are common among young children, as any child-rearing expert will attest.

title: U.S. and Israel Play Down Hopes for Peace Talks
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 10  The American-sponsored Middle East peace conference expected by the end of the month looks to be thin on content, mostly serving as a stage to begin formal negotiations on a peace treaty between Israel and the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas.

title: Irish Sheep Hoof-to-Toe With Hip-Hop
description: No article about the Irish tap dancer James Devine has failed to mention that he is the fastest tapper in the world, so lets just get that over with: He can do 38 taps a second. Yes, a second. But from an artistic point of view thats not much more interesting than learning that someone can eat 38 hard-boiled eggs in a minute.

title: New Way of Counting Radio Listeners May Cut Ad Income
description: The test of a new method for measuring radio audience in New York showed big ratings declines for stations appealing to blacks and Hispanics last week, causing considerable consternation among station owners and programmers.

title: Auctioning the Old West to Help a City in the East
description: DALLAS, Nov. 11  Prospective bidders looking to buy a piece of the Old West here over the weekend were greeted by an intimidating view straight down the barrel of a Model 1883 Gatling gun. Behind the weapon, an exhibit hall at a hotel was filled with rows of exquisitely beaded moccasins, revolvers and well-oiled Western saddles.

title: Increased Compensation Puts More College Presidents in the Million-Dollar Club
description: Soaring compensation of university presidents, once limited to a few wealthy institutions, is becoming increasingly common, with the number of million-dollar pay packages at private institutions nearly doubling last year, and compensation at many public universities not far behind.

title: Sharp Sell-Off Sweeps Asian Markets
description: TOKYO, Nov. 12  Rising fears of a slowdown in the United States economy sparked a sharp sell-off in Asian stock markets today, driving a leading Japanese index to a two-year low.

title: Yue Minjun and the Symbolic Smile
description: Images from the exhibition at the Queens Museum.

title: All the Trimmings
description: Images and recipes from the Dining section, past and present.

title: Troy Meets Gabriella, This Time on Skates
description: Its girls night out at the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum from now through Sunday. And at the Izod Center (formerly the Continental Airlines Arena) in the New Jersey Meadowlands from Nov. 20 through 25.

title: Too, Too Solid Flesh
description: Hamlet, of course, involves a fair amount of emotional turmoil and transformation. So you may not be the right performer for it if you have a particularly wooden countenance. If you are, for instance, a marionette.

title: Todays Productivity Tip
description: How to spin a pencil:

title: Flushophobia
description: While nearly half the world suffers the horrors of not having toilets, many of the haves are scared to death of them:

title: Murder and Hymns
description: Images of metal bars, white on black like Wedgwood patterning, run around the shallow stage where the Actors Company Theater revival of The Runner Stumbles is set. The bars sometimes denote a prison, sometimes a church confessional; often the sense of constraint that fetters the lead characters, a priest and a nun; and always the eye to detail that makes this production, directed by Scott Alan Evans, so compelling.

title: Laughter and Tears, One Sketch at a Time
description: It can seem as if theres been a confessional solo show about every kind of tragedy (AIDS, cancer, Jewish mothers), but Jeffrey Essmann, a fixture on the fertile downtown scene of the late 1980s and 90s before decamping for Chicago, says he has a new calamity to wax poetic about: My Journey With Type A Glaucoma.

title: Oak Hill Flies Off With Firth Rixson
description: The private equity firm Oak Hill Capital Partners said Sunday it would buy Firth Rixson, a provider of specialized metal products primarily to aerospace engine manufacturers, in a deal valued at about $2 billion.

title: V.C. Funds Kept Flowing in 3rd Quarter
description: Silicon Valley companies received more than $2.48 billion in venture capital in the third quarter of 2007, which the Mercury News takes as a sign that the regions entrepreneurial culture is thriving even amid the recent market turmoil

title: Start-Ups Trace a Dogs Life
description: The concept behind SNIF Labs verges on the nutty: The Boston-based start-up is developing intelligent tags for dogs to wear, so that their owners can monitor their daily activity and track the friends theyve made at the park.

title: Lessons in Shakespeare, From Stage to Boardroom
description: Shakespeares ability to delve deep into the moralities and consequences of power have fascinated audiences and readers since the reign of Queen Elizabeth. Now, The New York Times takes a look at the sway he holds over a different court: that of corporate America.

title: Countrywides Chief Salesman and Defender
description: In a lengthy profile of Angelo R. Mozilo, Countrywide Financials embattled chief executive, The New York Times takes a look at the man made a fortune shaking up the staid home mortgage business only to see the company he built become the quintessential proxy for the mortgage meltdown that now surrounds it.

title: The End of Childbirth 101?
description: Pregnant women are cutting childbirth class.

title: Sour Grapes in Philadelphia Exchange Deal
description: The proposed $625 million sale of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange to the Nasdaq Stock Market has some stockholders and former members feeling bitter, according to The Philadelphia Inquirer.

title: Canadian Banks Feel Their Share of Pain
description: The credit crunch, which has been hammering the largest U.S. financial institutions, is increasingly taking its toll on Canadian banks.

title: Will Success, or All That Money From Google, Spoil Firefox?
description: Only a couple of years ago, Firefox was the little browser that could  an open-source program created by thousands of contributors around the world without the benefit of a giant company like Microsoft to finance it.

title: C.E.O. Evolution Phase 3
description: Has the time come for C.E.O. Version 3.0?

title: Some Wonder if Banks Stabilization Fund Will Work
description: When the countrys three largest banks reached agreement on Friday on how to structure a $75 billion fund to prop up distressed securities, an exhausted group of its top planners reportedly gathered in a Bank of America conference room to toast their success with 12-packs of Bud Light.

title: Advice from a Silicon Valley Guru: Pull the Plug
description: As one of Silicon Valleys most respected entrepreneurs, Marc Andreessen is something of a connoisseur of what he calls productivity porn, or techniques to maximize personal productivity.

title: How to Stop a Buyout: Think Like Private Equity
description: The specter of private equity  and the prospect of being snapped up, stripped down, and sold at a colossal profit, all in the name of maximizing value  has shaken traditional managers to the core.

title: Following MasterCard, Visa Schedules an I.P.O.
description: Visa, the biggest credit card network in the nation, said in a regulatory filing Friday that it hoped to raise $10 billion in an initial public stock offering. Visa said it planned to deposit a portion of the companys proceeds from the offering into an escrow account to pay settlements or judgments related to litigation.

title: Harvard Endowment Picks a Steward
description: A former Goldman Sachs vice chairman was selected by Harvard University to temporarily manage its $35 billion endowment, the university said Friday.

title: For Masseuse, Google Options Made Millions
description: Bonnie Brown was fresh from a nasty divorce in 1999, living with her sister and uncertain of her future. On a lark, she answered an ad for an in-house masseuse at Google, then a Silicon Valley start-up with 40 employees. She was offered the part-time job, which started out at $450 a week but included a pile of Google stock options that she figured might never be worth a penny.

title: Time Warner Unveils Details of Bewkes Deal
description: Time Warner has signed a five-year employment deal with its incoming chief executive, Jeff Bewkes, for $1.75 million a year in salary and an annual target bonus of $8.5 million.

title: A Very Bad Day for Big Banks
description: Friday proved a dismal day for three major banks in the United States, who announced continued losses related to mortgages. Meanwhile, Barclays of Britain denied that it would announce major write-downs of its own.

title: BHP Outlines Details of Rio Tinto Bid
description: BHP Billiton on Monday mapped out its plan for acquiring rival Rio Tinto, promising to hand shareholders $30 billion via a share buyback if the deal goes through, in the hope of drawing Rios board into talks.

title: Wall Street Regulator Reaches Out to Main Street
description: It has famous Wall Street parents and an alphabet-soup abbreviation known only to investment professionals. Now Finra, the new private regulator for securities firms, mutual fund houses and stockbrokers, has a bold plan: to be a best friend to Americas ordinary investors.

title: Nikes Umbro Deal May Be in Jeopardy
description: Seven months before the European Soccer Championship, Adidas and Nike are angling to grab market share and defend their European turf in the growing $5 billion global market for soccer gear.

title: Hellman and Silver Lake Cash Out of Nasdaq
description: Hellman & Friedman plans to sell its $1 billion stake in Nasdaq Stock Market via a secondary stock offering, while Silver Lake is selling about $530 million of its shares.

title: Goldman Gets a Boost from China Nepstar I.P.O.
description: Goldman Sachs saw its stake in China Nepstar Chain Drugstore skyrocket after the Chinese drugstore chain went public in New York on Friday. Shenzhen, China-based Nepstar raised about $334 million when it sold 20.6 million American Depositary Shares at $16.20 each, up from $11.50 to $13.50 a share.

title: Rexel Wins Hagemeyer With Sweetened Bid
description: Rexel, the worlds largest distributor of electrical equipment, agreed to buy Hagemeyer with a sweetened offer of 3.1 billion euros ($4.5 billion) to expand in Europe as its American market slows.

title: Sale of Wendys May Be Delayed
description: The auction of Wendys International may be in jeopardy because of continued turmoil in the credit markets, potentially forcing the company to delay its sale, The New York Times reported.

title: Silly season movements not only for drivers
description: While we wait in the winter season to find out which drivers will race at which teams next year, and we watch as the pieces fall into place in the way we normally do in the middle of the summer, the so-called silly season is also affecting the team directors market. Today as Honda announced that Ross Brawn  Nigel Stepneys former close associate  would move to Honda  where Stepney had apparently wanted to go with a group of people (remember the early stages of the spy scandal)  Ferrari also made the following interesting announcement:

title: Lampert Revs Up Stake in AutoNation
description: Sears chieftain and well known hedge fund investor Edward Lampert has been buying up shares in automotive retailer AutoNation.

title: NYMEX Buys Stake in Norwegian Exchange
description: NYMEX Holdings has entered into an agreement to buy a 15.1 percent stake in Norwegian sea freight derivatives exchange Imarex.

title: A Focus on the Weirdness of Wall Street C.E.O.s
description: Losses are mounting. Chief executives are quitting. Bonuses are plummeting. And amid all the mania, The Deal.com recaps up some of the weirder facts recently gleaned about Wall Street bigwigs.

title: Bricks and Boredom
description: In todays economic update, wild swings in the construction business:

title: House Passes Rangel Bill on Carried Interest
description: A bill that would more than double the tax that private investment firms pay on their profits passed the U.S. House of Representatives Friday.

title: Facing Looming Threats, From Space or From Us
description: After I wrote my post examining what makes it worthwhile for a current generation to work to limit future risks, I sent an e-mail to a few contacts exploring risks and responses, inviting them to weigh in. A note came back from the Apollo 9 astronaut Rusty Schweickart, who has lately been pressing for the United States to intensify efforts to limit a danger both far more concretely understood than global warming and far less in vogue as a serious threat  the reality that a very large rock will inevitably head on a collision course for Earth.

title: Mums the Word
description: Calling all witty caption writers: Tell us whats going on in the photo above. Its the latest of the uncaptioned photos weve been posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines here. Last weeks funniest captions are at right.

title: Goldmans Level 3 Problem
description: Goldman Sachs reported a blowout third quarter, even as its peers earnings sank. But as some have warned, its profits may stem from accounting maneuvers, a suspicion that may be backed up by a recent regulatory filing.

title: For Prince, Exit Pay Is a Blast From the Past
description: This year, thousands of Citigroup employees can expect bonuses based on their work in 2007, when the banks results have been less than stellar. One, however, will get a bonus based largely on his performance in 2006, which was a better year: Charles O. Prince III, who resigned under pressure as chairman and chief executive last week.

title: The Early Word: Pointed Attacks
description: With the Democrats headed to Nevada for a debate later this week on Thursday, the top three candidates criticisms of one another keep piling up in another version of piling on.

title: Veterans Are on Congressional Minds
description: Congress takes a Veterans Day break today but both Republicans and Democrats sought to use the holiday to demonstrate their gratitude to the nations veterans who, as it turns out, figure into the spending fight that will resume when Congress returns Tuesday.

title: Anxiety Rises as Broadway Shutdown Continues
description: Today is Day 3 of the stagehands strike on Broadway, and anxieties are mounting, as reflected in accusations leveled on both sides, lost restaurant and hotel revenue and worry among workers all along the Great White Way. Campbell Robertson reports that the two sides  the producers league and the stagehands union  do not appear to be near a settlement.

title: Psychological Testing: Still Talking About It
description: People were really up in arms after reading my post about the use of psychological tests at work. And not just readers. National Public Radio asked me to come on their program, The Bryant Park Project, on Friday to discuss these tests.

title: Berlin in Lights: Flamboyance Jostles Solemnity Aside
description: With my colleague Tony Tommasini having handled the critical end of things, here are some random observations about last nights concert by Gustavo Dudamel and the Simn Bolvar Youth Orchestra of Venezuela at Carnegie Hall. Mr. Dudamels many musical gifts aside, he manages to project a good-natured sincerity, an earnestness that seems entirely genuine. When Emanuel Ax, the soloist, played an encore, Mr. Dudamel sat down right in the string section and listened. When he took his bows, he did so off the podium, shoulder to shoulder with the string players, his arm draped over a cellist.***The orchestra players did their signature act, donning jackets with the Venezuelan colors (red, yellow and blue) after a solemn and grandiose Beethoven Fifth Symphony and generally turning into the definition of flamboyance  spinning instruments, standing up and jiving, shimmying, pointing their horns into the air  for the Latin-inflected part of the program. But the same kind of physical enthusiasm, not choreographed and not premeditated, was evident in the Beethoven, where the first violins rocked back and forth together, almost synchronized. For those who missed the concert, the unbridled Latin act  totally infectious  can be seen in several previous versions on YouTube, most prominently from a London Proms concert.***Venezuelan pride was not just on the stage. Several audience members hung the nations flag over the rail of the first balcony and waved it during applause.***On the groups big night at Carnegie, a mishap hit the viola section. A string appeared to break on a first-stand instrument during the first movement of the Beethoven. The players passed it back to the tail end of the section. A last-stand violist passed a replacement instrument forward and changed strings on the viola that had come down the line. Ah, the unexpected nature of live acoustical performance.

title: An Intelligence Officials Privacy Proposal
description: During October, a month filled with urgent headlines about a proposed law governing the wiretapping powers of the executive branch, a senior intelligence official spoke at a conference with a goal in mind.

title: IBM to Buy Cognos in $4.9 Billion Deal
description: That didnt take long.

description: [Correction appended]

title: The Skim
description: A quick hike through the Sunday (and a few non-Sunday) book review sections.

title: Blackstones Stock Falls on 3rd-Quarter Losses
description: Stock in the Blackstone Group slumped on Monday after the private equity giant reported weaker profits than it earned last year.

title: Special Olympics in China
Mailer and the Murderer
description: A tidbit from Charles McGraths lengthy obituary of Norman Mailer, who died on Saturday, intrigued us: Mailers role in helping to win parole for Jack Henry Abbott, a felon, in 1981. Mailer championed Mr. Abbotts release, citing the quality of the prisoners writings, and he agreed to hire Mr. Abbott as a research assistant. But Mr. Abbott went on to commit another murder within weeks of his parole.

title: Mark Twain and Web Hoaxes
description: From the Great Poodle Scam of 2007 to a sensational claim about chocolate toothpaste to the United Nations Windex of Mass Destruction, The Lede loves to keep track of the latest deflated news on the Web.

title: Your Monologue Jokes  Keep Em Coming!
description: Keep sending in the jokes, folks (via the comment link just below). With late-night comedy writers out on strike and the talk shows in reruns, Laugh Lines readers step in to fill the void:

title: Ken Moeliss $11 Million Pad at the Plaza
description: Since he abruptly departed UBS early this year, many on Wall Street have wondered what Kenneth Moeliss next moves would be.

title: Monday Morning Kickoff
description: Everyone loves relaxing on the weekend, but SI.coms Stewart Mandel is always demanding that we learn something. He must have been really popular with his classmates in grade school. To his credit, he writes that the No. 1 thing we learned this weekend is that the pollsters have no idea whos No. 1 this year.

title: Seeding the Google Phone With Apps
description: One of the big challenges for Googles ambitious phone project is persuading software developers to write interesting applications. Already, developers of mobile phone programs complain about having to write for too many different software platforms, like Windows Mobile, Symbian, Palm, RIM, and soon, Apples iPhone. And while those software platforms are already powering millions of phones, there are no phones out there running Googles Android system  and there wont be any until the second half of next year.

title: A $75 Million Year for Goldmans Chief?
description: Lloyd Blankfein is already the highest paid chief executive on Wall Street. But he may be poised to top his own record.

title: Writers Strike Enters Second Week
description: Its very primal for writers to share and communicate, says Jon Robin Baitz, the creator of Brothers & Sisters. Perhaps that is why it seems that every time the striking television and movie writers put down their picket signs, they pick up their pencils, Joanne Kaufman writes in todays New York Times.

title: A Union Leader Does His Math
description: We cannot, and will not, be ignored, Michael Winship, the president of the Writers Guild of America, East, wrote in a letter to members of the East Coast guild Sunday evening.

title: Oil Spill on the Black Sea
description: At least 11 ships sank or broke apart in a storm, and tens of thousands of gallons of oil were spilled.

title: Give and Take, in Words
description: There are many blogs that provide insight into ideas and trends in the world of philanthropy. Here are some of the most popular ones.

title: Performa 07: The Art of Conversation
description: The fall dance season being what it is  busy, busy, busy  I hadnt managed to attend a Performa event since Claudia La Rocco and I had our Pirandellian experience (Two Critics in Search of a Performance) looking for Pablo Bronsteins Plaza Minuet on Wednesday afternoon. Then yesterday I got to two: a talk with Isaac Julien, Russell Maliphant, Shirin Neshat and RoseLee Goldberg at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and later Jrme Bels much talked-about Pichet Klunchen and myself at Dance Theater Workshop.

title:
Remembering Mailer:
The High Heat and the Roiling Simmer
description: Norman Mailer had a straightforward recipe for cooking a steak, the novelist Geoff Nicholson once told me.

title: Go read Jon Cohn
description: This piece about medical innovation is one of the best things Ive ever read on the subject. Bottom line: the US does lead the world in medical innovation, but the high prices we pay for insurance, drugs, etc. have little to do with it. Instead, its about the National Institutes of Health  its the government, not the private sector.

title: Remembering the First
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The Value of a Friend in the Next Cubicle
description: How friendly are you with your co-workers?

title: Release the Zombie Yoga! (Can a Best Seller Be Far Behind?)
description: A few weeks ago, City Room wrote about a casting call for a zombie yoga video in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, which drew about 75 participants who wanted to take the corpse post literally. Now the products of that quick-and-dirty shoot against the New York City skyline has been released at ZenofZombie.com. Its a promotion for a book by Scott Kenemore, The Zen of Zombie: Better Living Through the Undead, a parody of a self-help book. (Boing Boing TV offers a behind-the-scenes look at the making of the video.)

title: Armitages Apology Not Accepted
description: Former Deputy Secretary of State Richard Armitages interview with Wolf Blitzer on Sunday was pegged to the situation in Pakistan, but it did not end before a previously-recorded bit of criticism on another matter was served up. From the transcript:

title: Pope to Visit Ground Zero and Celebrate Mass at Yankee Stadium
description: Updated, 2:12 p.m. | Pope Benedict XVI will make his first visit to the United States as pontiff over six days in April, and he plans to visit ground zero, address the United Nations and celebrate Masses at National Stadium in Washington and St. Patricks Cathedral and Yankee Stadium in New York, officials at the Vatican and the Archdiocese of New York announced today.

title: Bill Clinton Gives Advice on Presidential Role
description: If youre interested in getting an idea of how Hillary Rodham Clinton might act as president  should she make it that far  a good place to look is at an unusually introspective interview Bill Clinton gave for a new book, in which he talked about he would have done differently as president to deal with the polarization afflicting Washington.

title: Autumn of the American Buddhist
description: The dying (literally) of American Buddhism: Do Buddhists in this country need to become, if not more evangelical, then more concerned with passing on their religion to their children? Clark Strand, a contributing editor to Tricycle: The Buddhist Review, worries in The Wall Street Journal that American Buddhism will die with the boomers who adopted it. [$] Strand writes:

title: Where in the World Is SpongeBob SquarePants?
description: The production of SpongeBob SquarePants latest special Monday had a lot in common with the geographic exploits of Carmen Sandiego, right. From inception, work on Atlantis SquarePantis, about SpongeBobs quest to the lost city of Atlantis (featuring David Bowie), spanned more than a year and multiple continents  none of them submerged. Guess thats what it takes for a sponge to soak up viewers. Read more

title: Is It Spelled Yahoogle or Yoogle?
description: Theres actually a lot of good stuff going on at Yahoo, but there is also a tendency for the company to come off like a Google wannabe. Take this release: Yahoo! Launches New Program to Advance Open-Source Software for Internet Computing.

title: Answers About Foster Care, Part 4
description: Following is a fourth and final set of answers from Benjamin Weiser and Leslie Kaufman of The Times, who, along with a panel of experts, answered readers questions about The Timess series on foster care [A History of Neglect, Part 1 | Part 2 | Part 3] during the past week. Previous sets of questions and answers were posted last week.

title: Big Oil Says There is No Energy Problem?!
description: Im here at the World Energy Congress in Rome, a conference of leaders in the energy field that occurs once every five years. I just heard Rex Tillerson, chairman of ExxonMobil say that: The world has plenty of oil resources  Twice the total of oil consumed in human history is still available. OK, so why is oil hitting $100 a barrel? Mr. Tillerson seemed to place much of the blame on oil-rich countries that were not giving oil companies like his adequate access to their riches, nationalizing their oil resources.

title: Investors Flee E*Trade; Will Depositors Follow?
description: E*Trade Financial is a leader in the new generation of Internet-only lenders. But its stock got crushed Monday amid fears about a distinctly old-fashioned problem: a run on the bank.

title: McCain Campaign Warns Donors Away From Foundation
description: Senator John McCain of Arizona has again called upon the newly formed Foundation for a Secure and Prosperous America to stop advertising on his behalf.

title: Heisman Watch
description: Oregon quarterback Dennis Dixon: The trophy is his if Ducks win their remaining three games and he plays well.

title: Adrian Peterson Update
description: According to The Minneapolis Star-Tribune, Vikings Coach Brad Childress announced at his news conference this afternoon that running back Adrian Peterson had a torn lateral collateral ligament in his right knee. He will be sidelined for at least next Sundays game against Oakland (too bad, because the Raiders have one of the most porous run defenses in the N.F.L.)

title: Restoring Confidence in the Voting Process
description: In her Web column today, Katharine Q. Seelye looks at the progress  or lack thereof  states have made in overhauling their election systems since the election fiasco in Florida in 2000. Caucus readers weighed in on how they feel about the balloting system in their states.

title: Monarchs, Presidents and Athletes Are Among Recipients of a Symbolic Key
description: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg gave the jazz musician Fats Domino the key to the city last week, it got us wondering: What is the key made of, what does it represent and who has received this honor? In researching the answers to these questions, we received a list of recipients since 1978. The mayors press office, which furnished the list, cautioned that it would be incomplete before the 1990s, when record keeping was computerized. Additionally, some older names and titles on the list were misspelled or rendered incorrectly, some beyond recognition. Where there was a question that we at City Room could not resolve, we omitted the name, so this roster is not comprehensive.

title: A Superjumbo Jet That Airbus Better Deliver on Time
description: The first person to buy his own Airbus A380, the worlds largest aircraft, is none other than Prince Alwaleed bin Talal, the Saudi billionaire who played a key role in ousting Citigroups chief last week.

title: Daniel Day-Lewis Hearts MotoGP and Valentino Rossi
description: While reading Lynn Hirschbergs profile on Daniel Day-Lewis in the Sunday magazine, I was pleasantly surprised to find out he was a Valentino Rossi fan.

title: Al Gore, Venture Capitalist
description: Add another line to Al Gores ever-expanding resume.

title: Afraid of Trade
description: At first blush, the House of Representatives vote in favor of a free trade agreement with Peru last Thursday might seem to augur great things for trade pacts.

title: As Heads Roll, Jim Cramer Cheers
description: James J. Cramer, co-founder of TheStreet.com and host of CNBCs Mad Money, isnt getting weepy about the recent departures of E. Stanley ONeal and Charles O. Prince III from their respective firms. On that subject, he says the mood on Wall Street is more like goodbye, and good riddance.

title: I.B.M. Blue Gene Still the Fastest Computer
description: The relatively low-power I.B.M. Blue Gene supercomputer located at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory still holds the title of the worlds fastest supercomputer, but the sands beneath it are shifting.

title: Berlin in Lights: A Glorious Blur of Horns
description: The Berlin Philharmonic, the centerpiece of the Berlin in Lights festival, has arrived in New York. As with a corporate sell-off of valuable subsidiaries, the orchestra is sending out its sections to play concerts around town. Im trying out a blog marathon here, hitting three performances in one day.

title: Proposal to Control Pigeons: Fine the Hands That Feed Them
description: Rumors about an avian serial killer on the loose in Brooklyn raise an age-old question: How to get rid of pesky pigeons? Well, one can kill them (not advisable on grounds of ethics or taste), starve them (well, not really starve them, but stop feeding them) or scare them away. At least those are the methods that most have tried in the past.

title: Housewives Rule Again
description: Despite tough competition from Sunday Night Football on NBC and an animated comedy line-up on Fox, ABC eked out a victory on Sunday as the nights most watched network.

title: Performa 07: Restaging Brings Mixed Emotions
description: Its odd to be grateful to have seen a performance yet to feel uneasy about the fact that it is being presented in the first place. On Friday I saw the restaging of 18 Happenings in 6 Parts, Allan Kaprows seminal 1959 performance piece, and Ive been waffling ever since.

title: The Man Who Picked Lincoln Centers Christmas Tree
description: John Egan, the man who selected the Christmas tree that arrived today at Lincoln Center, was in Vallejo, Calif., this afternoon putting up a 132-foot Douglas Fir at a Six Flags amusement park.

title: A First Look at the Google Phone
description: O.K. There is no Google Phone. As we wrote a while back, Google is not building a phone. Instead, the company has teamed up with others in the wireless industry to create an open-source operating system, as well as other services, for mobile phones. Other companies, including Motorola, LG and Samsung, are expected to build phones based on this software.

description: A promotional preview of Framed, a new series from Reebok Entertainment that is to begin next month on the IFC cable channel.

description: A Wall Street Journal blog today interviewed a few experts to find out what was behind the stunning acts of rudeness theyve witnessed on the blog, including one commenter who called a writer a moron who should never procreate. But another headline served as a reminder that world leaders are just as capable of unleashing vitriol as the unwashed masses: Spanish king tells Chvez to shut up.

description: NBCs post-iTunes digital download service, NBC Direct, came online in beta mode two days ago, and the reviews are almost uniformly grim.

description: Not even Carl C. Icahn is immune to market troubles.

description: Our sib-blog, DotEarth, by our colleague Andy Revkin, just flagged a news tidbit about Chevy Chase, that former Saturday Night Live star who now says hes going to be commenting on politics for S.N.L.

title: The Real Thing
description: My husband Tim and I adopted our daughter Willow, who is now 12, from China when she was 9 months old. We were told by the adoption agency that once the process was complete and the three of us were back home, many people would stop to inquire about our daughters Mongolian features or why she did not look like us.

title: Interview:  Newt Gingrich
description: Newt Gingrich, former Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives, has issued a call to conservatives to address such environmental threats as global warming.

description: Tagging along with Mike Huckabee over the course of two days last week as he stumped through eastern Iowa, an observation came to mind time and again about how much he still remained a small-town Baptist pastor.

title: Graphic: Campaigns on the Nightly News
description: Evening news programs on the three major networks have devoted significantly more time to the 2008 presidential campaign so far this year than any of the pre-election years since 1991, according to Andrew Tyndall, a television news analyst. NBC spent the most time covering the campaign with 228 minutes, followed by CBS with 191 minutes and ABC with 180 minutes. Individual candidates and the horse race were covered the most; only 18 minutes has been spent on issues on the trail.

title: Interview: Michael Shellenberger
description: The environmental strategist Michael Shellenberger gave up working with activist groups to campaign for a new, market-oriented and technology-driven environmentalism.

title: Tougher Than the Rest to Beat?
description: Democratic Party elites say Rudolph W. Giuliani would be the toughest competitor for their partys presidential nominee to face next November, according to a survey of superdelegates, which include members of the Democratic National Committee and elected officials.

title: Iowa Caucuses, With Tap Dancing
description: It is unclear when the stagehands strike will end, but Off Off Broadway, you can catch a theater event full of political intrigue and featuring a showstopper of a tap-dance number called The Tough Question Sidestep.

description: On both sides of the ticket, the presidential nominating contest is growing increasingly combative, as voters may well witness Thursday during a debate in Las Vegas among the Democratic candidates.

description: A film by Surface 2 Air.

title: Gasbook Robot Dance
description: A film by Hunter Gatherer.

description: A documentation of a Terence Koh performance. January 18, 2007, video by Matt Wolf.

title: Just a Friendly Game? Good Sportsmanship? Maybe Not.
description: Chess is a bloodless game and over the years it has often had a reputation for being an honorable one as well. But sometimes someone says something that sends all those good feelings packing. The latest statement came from Teimour Radjabov of Azerbaijan, the No. 8 player in the world. In an interview with APA Sport (apparently, an Azerbaijani sports news service) after the European Team Championships (in which Azerbaijan finished third behind Russia and Armenia), Radjabov was quoted as saying about the match with Armenia:

title: The World of Black Money
description: Despite government crackdowns, the use of so-called black money is still rife in Spain and could be skewing officially reported prices by as much as 30 percent, says Martin Dell of Kyero.com, the property portal.

title: Oklahoma State Dismisses Linebacker
description: Oklahoma State permanently dismissed linebacker Chris Collins from the team Monday, six days after he pleaded guilty to felony aggravated sexual assault of a 12-year-old girl in Texas.

title: Spitzer to Drop His License Plan
description: ALBANY, Nov. 13  Gov. Eliot Spitzer is abandoning his plan to issue drivers licenses to illegal immigrants, saying that opposition is just too overwhelming to move forward with such a policy.

title: After Fires, Homeowners Feel an Insurance Pinch
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12  Daniel and Doris Okonsky, whose custom-built 6,500-square-foot house was destroyed in the recent wildfires in Southern California, have been poring over receipts and family photos to estimate the damage.

title: Redesigning a Condom So Women Will Use It
description: The female condom has never caught on in the United States. But in the third world, where it was introduced in the late 1990s, public health workers hoped it would overthrow the politics of the bedroom, empower women and stop the AIDS epidemic in its tracks.

title: With Carter on Bench, Nets Lose to Hornets
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 12  Vince Carter, minus his white headband, reported to the Nets bench minutes before tip-off Monday. Carter wore a tan sports jacket and a walking boot on his right foot that was not exactly conducive to jumping.

title: Born With a Hole in His Heart, a Child Best Known as Magic
description: Chananya Grun, 5, inadvertently named his baby brother Magic. When his mother, Anat Grun, brought home toys for Chananya, his two sisters and another brother, she told them they were from the newest addition to the family, who was still in the hospital.

title: Carter Is Lost Indefinitely to Sprained Right Ankle
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. , Nov. 12 (AP)  Vince Carter of the Nets will be sidelined indefinitely with a sprained right ankle.

title: U.S. to Send Special Envoy to Confront Musharraf
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12  The Bush administration is dispatching a high-level envoy to Pakistan to tell the Pakistani president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, face to face that the United States will not be satisfied with his plan to hold elections unless he first lifts emergency law, administration officials said Monday.

title: Macao: MGM Venture to Open Dec. 18
description: MGM Mirage and Pansy Ho, daughter of the billionaire Stanley Ho, will open their joint ventures first casino in Macao on Dec. 18. The casino, the MGM Grand Macau, will have 600 rooms, suites and villas and 375 gambling tables and cost about $1.25 billion, said MGM, the gambling company based in Las Vegas.

title: Wal-Mart Profit Is Up; Home Depot Takes a Hit
description: Economic unease, from the credit markets to the gas pump, is proving a boon to the nations largest discount retailer, Wal-Mart, but a bust for the biggest home improvement chain, Home Depot.

title: Four Transplant Recipients Contract H.I.V.
description: Four transplant recipients in Chicago have contracted H.I.V. from an organ donor, the first known cases in more than a decade of the virus being spread by organ transplants.

title: Your Bird for the Holiday Will Be Costly and Stuffed
description: AS a major holiday travel season approaches and airlines scramble to cover soaring fuel bills, air fares are going up. And this time, theyre likely to stay up.

title: Top Rhythmic Gymnast Sees Dreams of Beijing Fade Away
description: When the rhythmic gymnast Lisa Wang stood atop the podium at the Pan American Games in July, a gold medal draped around her neck, an exciting thought filled her head, she said: the 2008 Olympics.

title: In Westchester, Cleaning Up After One Flood While Planning for the Next
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  At the First Unitarian Society of Westchester, at the foot of a dead-end road here, there are signs that the congregation is finally patching itself up after a devastating flood in April, one that ravaged parts of the East Coast and was one of the worst in the countys history.

title: Screenings: Colonoscopy Suggestion May Be Made Too Often
description: Colonoscopies are a proven means of detecting small growths and removing them before they become deadly, but a new study suggests that many doctors are recommending them too often.

title: More Than One Way to Help a Business Grow
description: If you Google the phrase grow or die, you get more than 11 million hits. So clearly there is something to the idea that if a business is not expanding it is withering away.

title: Ex-Devil Stevens Considers Next Step After Hall
description: TORONTO, Nov. 12  When the time came for Scott Stevens to put on his Hall of Fame ring, he struggled to slip it over his knuckle. He laughed as he wrenched it on and joked about never being able to take it off.

title: Radiohead to Sell an in Rainbows CD
description: After distributing digital downloads of its new album, In Rainbows, last month, in many cases free, the British rock band Radiohead said yesterday it would begin to sell a version on compact disc through an independent label on Jan. 1. As previously reported, the band will sell the album in an arrangement with ATO Records and a related spinoff label, TBD Records. Representatives of the band, which is fronted by Thom Yorke, above, said yesterday that ATO planned to seek radio airplay for two of the albums songs, Bodysnatchers and Jigsaw Falling Into Place. Questions about the prospects for selling a CD version of In Rainbows have lingered since the band let fans name their own price  even nothing  for downloading the album from a Radiohead Web site, inrainbows.com. So far, the band has declined to detail how many copies were distributed, or for what price, and has disputed a recent outside study suggesting that more than a million copies were downloaded. (The price of the CD has not yet been set.) The shift to an independent label comes after Radiohead fulfilled its long-term contract with the music giant EMI Group. EMI said last week that it planned to package Radioheads six previous studio albums and a live album in a CD box set, and in other formats, for sale on Dec. 10.

title: Strange, Green and Pak Inducted
description: Curtis Strange and Hubert Green, each winners of 2 majors and 17 tournaments on the PGA Tour, were among six golfers inducted into the World Golf Hall of Fame last night.Se Ri Pak of South Korea was inducted based on the L.P.G.A. Tours points system, which she surpassed three years ago, combined with 10 years on the womens Tour.Strange, elected on the PGA Tour ballot with 70 percent of the vote, was the last golfer to win consecutive United States Opens, in 1988-89. Green, 60, captured the 1977 United States Open and the 1985 P.G.A. Championship. Joe Carr, the first Irishman to be inducted; Kel Nagle of Australia, who won the 1960 British Open; and Charles Blair Macdonald, who designed the National Golf Links in Southampton, N.Y., were the other inductees.

title: Division of the U.S. Didnt Occur Overnight
description: During President George W. Bushs first term, one of his senior political advisers summed up the prevailing philosophy at the White House like this: This is not designed to be a 55 percent presidency, he said. This is designed to be a presidency that moves as much as possible of what we believe into law while holding 50 plus one of the country and the Congress. Bold ideas that could mobilize his conservative Republican base were prized over efforts to convince independent voters in the center; sharp divisions over the administrations policies were regarded as proof of Mr. Bushs decisiveness and willingness to challenge conventional thinking.

title: Muslim Singer With a Country Twang
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif.  Ask Kareem Salama, billed as the first Muslim country-western singer, what makes his music country, and he grins for about half a beat before answering, Probably my accent.

title: In Hollywood Hives, the Males Rule
description: In his new animated film, Jerry Seinfeld plays Barry B. Benson, a wisecracking, moony-eyed, charmingly petulant New York honeybee who doesnt want to spend his days as a worker bee stuck on the honeymaking assembly line. You know, Dad, the more I think about it, Barry says, maybe the honey field just isnt right for me. To which his father, a proud, lifelong honey stirrer, snaps: And you were thinking of, what, making balloon animals? Thats a bad job for a guy with a stinger!

title: Rage and Revival in Italys Sports Opera
description: The drama of Italian soccer, the success and the squalor, the skill and the sleaze, has again been laid bare for the world to see.

title: Some Restrictions to Be Lifted in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 12  Iraqi military commanders signaled Monday that they would soon remove some roadblocks and other restrictions that had been imposed over the past nine months as part of the effort to reduce violence here in the capital.

title: Go East, Young Writers, for Theater!
description: Heres a trivia question  category: theater  for all those writers lying on the couch in Hollywood perfecting their video-game scores, or weeding the backyards of their Laurel Canyon haciendas, or doing whatever it is television and movie writers do when they are not cooking up dialogue for detectives, superheroes or nerdy, horny teenagers.

title: Brushing Innovations, Built on Titanium
description: Titanium, the multitalented metal used in everything from jet engines to eyeglass frames, has taken on yet another role as the crucial component of two toothbrushes that aim to shake up the staid world of dental hygiene.

title: Weight Around the Waist
description: Q. If added weight in the midsection raises the risk of health problems like diabetes and heart trouble, does a tummy tuck or liposuction lower the risk?

title: Slowing Economy Posing Test for Disney
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12  Since becoming chief executive of the Walt Disney Company two years ago, Robert A. Iger has dazzled Wall Street by delivering soaring profits and moving aggressively to fix trouble spots.

title: Speculation on E*Trade Hurts Stock
description: Shares of E*Trade Financial tumbled yesterday after an analyst suggested that the company might have to seek bankruptcy protection if panicked customers withdrew deposits because of the brokerage firms faltering mortgage investments.

title: The Public Face of Wal-Marts Health Care Program
description: Linda M. Dillman, who oversees the employee health care program at Wal-Mart, did not ask for the job. Indeed, when the chief executive of the company, the worlds largest retailer, told her of the appointment, she wondered, Did I make somebody mad? Are they trying to tell me something?

title: In Farm Belt, Ethanol Plants Hit Resistance
description: SPARTA, Wis.  When plans were announced for a new ethanol distillery on the outskirts of this city of 9,000, residents complained that it would mar the view from the municipal golf course. They worried that its emissions would taint the milk-based products made at nearby Century Foods International, one of the communitys biggest employers. They even argued over whether the plant would reek like burned molasses or blackened popcorn or fermenting beer.

title: From Ants to People, an Instinct to Swarm
description: If you have ever observed ants marching in and out of a nest, you might have been reminded of a highway buzzing with traffic. To Iain D. Couzin, such a comparison is a cruel insult  to the ants.

title: Chronic Pain: A Burden Often Shared
description: Chronic pain is a family problem. When people experience unrelenting pain, everyone they live with and love is likely to suffer. The frustration, anxiety, stress and depression that often go with chronic pain can also afflict family members and friends who feel helpless to provide relief.

title: On Their Own Stage, Protgs Channel Choreographic Mentors
description: The literary critic Harold Bloom put a catchy phrase into circulation when he published The Anxiety of Influence in 1973, and it could have been the subtitle for the Rolex Arts Weekend presentation at Dance Theater Workshop on Sunday night.

title: Knicks Hope to Leave Bad Habits Behind When They Hit the Road
description: A visit to the back right corner of the Knicks locker room usually provides a glimpse into the teams state of affairs. Quentin Richardson, one of the most seasoned and secure veterans, resides there, dispensing brutal honesty when it is needed most.

title: I.B.M. Offers $4.9 Billion for Cognos
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 12  I.B.M. offered about $4.9 billion in cash today to acquire Cognos, a Canadian producer of software used by corporations to analyze their operations.

title: Exercise Advice Often Ignores Jiggle Factor
description: Exercise is all about moving your body. But some body parts move more than you want them to.

title: Levittown: Woman Killed in Crash
description: An Albertson woman who is the daughter of a renowned Kentucky Derby-winning jockey has been charged with vehicular manslaughter and driving while intoxicated after a crash Sunday morning in which one person was killed and four people were injured, the Nassau County police said yesterday. The accused woman, Sophia Santos, 20, the daughter of the jockey Jos Santos, was in Nassau University Medical Center yesterday, the police said. They said that Nancy Tumminello of Elmont was turning left onto Hempstead Turnpike from Wantagh Avenue about 2:30 a.m. on Sunday when her car was hit by Ms. Santoss, which was westbound on Hempstead Turnpike. One passenger in Ms. Tumminellos car, Virginia Casazza Urgo, 62, of Valley Stream, who was out celebrating her birthday with the group, was pronounced dead at the scene, the police said. Two other passengers were taken to the hospital in critical condition, while Ms. Tumminello and a fourth passenger were treated and released, the police said.

title: France: Strike to Challenge Sarkozy
description: As France braced for a fresh wave of transportation strikes, a union leader said walkouts set to start tonight were not only about plans to roll back the retirement benefits of about 500,000 public sector workers. At stake is whether unions in France will retain their say in economic reform, said the official, Bernard Thibault, secretary general of the Confdration Gnrale du Travail. The protest has become a major test of President Nicolas Sarkozys ambition to bolster the economy by making it easier to hire and lay off public sector employees.

title: Spanning the Blue Globe, for Little White Ones
description: AS a former flight attendant and now as president and founder of my company, PearlParadise.com, Im a lover of both the friendly skies and some of the worlds finest pearls.

title: Abortion Foes Throw Support to Thompson
description: A prominent anti-abortion group has decided to endorse Fred D. Thompsons presidential bid, giving the candidate a boost in his efforts to court conservative voters.

title: N.Y.U. Student Commits Suicide
description: A sophomore at New York University committed suicide in a dormitory room on Friday, university officials said yesterday. The university declined to identify the student or to provide other details, citing requests for privacy from the students family. The suicide was the second at N.Y.U. this semester; a freshman from California jumped from a dormitory roof in September. In 2003 and 2004, five students jumped to their deaths.

title: Stocks Make a Comeback After 4 Days of Declines
description: Stock markets moved into the black after four days of declines, as investors cheered reassuring reports on two recent trouble spots, consumer spending and the credit market.

title: Regimens: Weight Found to Affect Prostate Cancer Outcome
description: A new study reports that overweight men with advanced prostate cancer seem not to live as long as those with normal body mass.

title: Couple Who Helped Lead Khmer Rouge Are Arrested
description: BANGKOK, Nov. 12  Ieng Sary and Ieng Thirith, a husband-and-wife team of French-educated Communist revolutionaries who held senior positions in the Khmer Rouge government in Cambodia in the 1970s, were arrested in Phnom Penh on Monday and charged with crimes against humanity.

title: Righting Reagans Wrongs?
description: Lets set the record straight on Ronald Reagans campaign kickoff in 1980.

title: Dont Rush to a Fare Hike
description: Since the summer, New Yorks Metropolitan Transportation Authority has been trying earnestly to make its case for increasing fares. The needs of the system are overwhelming and, even though the M.T.A. is looking at a $1 billion surplus, substantial deficits are projected starting in 2009. The authoritys chief executive, Lee Sander, has no choice but to find a way to fill the hole.

title: Laraine Day, B+ Movie Star, Dies at 87
description: Laraine Day, a popular actress who appeared in almost two dozen MGM movies during Hollywoods Golden Age, notably as the nurse Mary Lamont in a series of Dr. Kildare movies, died Saturday in Ivins, Utah. She was 87.

title: Containers Wall Off a Newark Housing Project
description: NEWARK, Nov. 7  Tasha Solomon opened the grimy plastic blinds of her first floor-apartment in the Millard E. Terrell Homes, a housing project hard by the Passaic River.

title: Celebrities Chat With Athletes, in Reebok Gear
description: REEBOK will segue next month from shoe business to show business, teaming with the IFC cable network for a celebrity interview series that is being produced by a new entertainment arm of Reebok.

title: Yankees Persuade Posada to Stay
description: The Yankees added a fourth year to Jorge Posadas contract offer late last night, and as soon as Posada completes the formality of taking a physical, he will officially return to the team. Posada has agreed to the terms of the deal, which would make him the highest-paid catcher in the majors.

title: Paranoia Strikes Deep, Into Your Headset It Will Creep
description: The windows near the elevators on the 21st floor of the Sheraton Meadowlands Hotel are fit for football espionage. The Giants practice field sits about a mile in the distance, past the maze of highway lanes and off-ramps, past the massive parking lots.

title: Man, 18, Is Fatally Shot by Police in Brooklyn
description: A young man was fatally shot last night in a hail of 20 bullets fired by five police officers who responded to his mothers 911 call for help in a domestic dispute in Brooklyn, the authorities said.

title: In Mixed Slice of Baghdad, Old Bonds Defy War
description: BAGHDAD  At its oldest spot, a small dusty strip of dirt road near a mosque, the neighborhood of Bab al Sheik  a maze of snaking streets too narrow for cars  dates from a time, more than a thousand years ago, when Baghdad ruled the Islamic world.

title: New DVDs
description: BERLIN ALEXANDERPLATZ

title: Italy Moves to Tighten Soccer Security and Control Fans After Riots
description: ROME, Nov. 12  The Italian authorities moved Monday to ban large groups of soccer fans from traveling to out-of-town matches and imposed stricter security measures in stadiums, in response to rioting that took place in several cities on Sunday after the accidental police shooting of a soccer fan.

title: Letters
description: Recipes and Experiments

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Sunday about the writer Norman Mailer misspelled, in some copies, the surname of the secretary of state whom Mr. Mailer invited to a literary conference, an invitation that prompted criticism of Mr. Mailer from leftists. He is George P. Shultz, not Schultz.

title: Prosecutor Examines Spitzer Aides Statement
description: ALBANY, Nov. 12  The Albany County district attorneys office, which has opened an inquiry into the possibility of perjury by Darren Dopp, a former top aide to Gov. Eliot Spitzer, is examining Mr. Dopps sworn statement denying having ordered surveillance of Senator Joseph L. Brunos travels, according to a person who has been briefed on the investigation.

title: Pakistani Officials Order Detention of Bhutto and Block a March
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, Tuesday, Nov. 13  Hundreds of riot policemen today blocked the opposition leader Benazir Bhutto and her supporters from making a planned long march from this eastern city 160 miles through Punjab Province to the capital, Islamabad.

title: Software for Rent
description: Marc Benioff has never been modest in his dreams for Salesforce.com, the business software company he founded in 1999.

title: For Newsweek, a Political Web Venture
description: Newsweek is to announce today that it is starting the equivalent of a weekly political television show on its Web site, newsweek.com, and that it has hired a producer from MSNBC to oversee it. Tammy Haddad, who was executive producer of Hardball With Chris Matthews until this summer, when she became a vice president of political coverage at MSNBC, will have the title of consulting executive producer at Newsweek. In a statement, Jon Meacham, executive editor of Newsweek, a unit of the Washington Post Company, described Web video as one of the great new storytelling tools of the time and Ms. Haddads charge as devising a fresh way of reaching more readers with our signature coverage of politics. Ms. Haddad is also creating a production company, Haddad Media, which will do similar work with the National Journal Group.

title: Marvel Puts Superheroes Online
description: Marvel Comics, the publisher of Spider-Man, Wolverine and the Fantastic Four, is introducing an online subscription service. For $9.99 a month or $59.88 a year, subscribers will get Web access to a library of 2,500 comic books, as well as 20 new titles each week. For the introduction of the site, marvel.com/digitalcomics, Marvel will offer a free sampling of 250 titles. The service will make it easier and more affordable for people to read the first copy of Captain America, from 1941, which in its print form is valued from $7,433 to $160,000. Though comic books have been available digitally for some time, the paid subscription model is relatively new. For Marvel, a chief concern is to avoid cannibalizing demand for print copies. This is a big step, said Dan Buckley, the president and publisher of Marvel Entertainment, the parent company of Marvel Comics. He added that there would be a timing lag between our print products and going online.

title: Kazakhstan: China Gets a Share in Uranium Mine
description: China will get a stake in a 2,000-ton-a-year uranium mine in Kazakhstan in exchange for its share in a uranium-processing business, the state-owned company Kazatomprom said. The companys president, Moukhtar Dzhakishev, said in Almaty that the company would gain access to Chinese assets, without elaborating. Kazatomprom said on Oct. 12 it signed agreements in Beijing with the China Guangdong Nuclear Power Group and the China National Nuclear Corporation, Chinas largest producers of atomic energy.

title: Google Hits European Hurdle on DoubleClick Deal
description: PARIS, Nov. 13  European Commission competition authorities refused today to approve Googles $3.1 billion purchase of DoubleClick, the Internet advertising company, and ordered an in-depth review amid opposition from rivals, publishers and consumer groups.

title: Reaching Out to Students When They Talk and Text
description: Can the Bloomberg administration convince thousands of low-achieving students that succeeding in school is actually, well, cool?

title: U.S. Prosecutors Start Investigating Oil Spill
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12  The United States Attorneys Office has begun investigating an oil spill last week in San Francisco Bay. The move signals that criminal charges may be filed against the crew of the vessel that lost 58,000 gallons of fuel after hitting the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge.

title: Operas Newest Gimmick: The 90-Minute Tosca
description: ROME  For months the Piccola Lirica company has been staging Tosca here, as its slogan says, in miniatura. The other night I stopped by to see it. It lasted about as long as some Italian governments: in just 90 minutes Scarpia was dead, Tosca had hurled herself off the parapet, and the audience was back strolling the streets, hunting for the perfect linguine alle vongole.

title: Grisly Murder Case Intrigues Italian University City
description: PERUGIA, Italy, Nov. 12  Who is Amanda? the newspaper Voice of Perugia asked Monday. From brilliant student to cold maneater.

title: That Clinton Boy Defends His Wife and Raises Eyebrows
description: Its a Southern thing, not a gender thing.

title: Ex-Publishers Suit Plays a Giuliani-Kerik Angle
description: Judith Regan, the former book publisher, says in a lawsuit filed today protesting her dismissal by the News Corporation, the media conglomerate, that a senior executive there encouraged her to lie to federal investigators about her past affair with Bernard B. Kerik after he had been nominated to become homeland security secretary in late 2004.

title: Magnanimity Becomes One of Raps Moguls
description: Dynastic succession, cutthroat competition, brand reinforcement: these were a few of the items on Jay-Zs agenda at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Sunday night. Of course he covered this ground with exultant style, surrounding himself with constituents, protgs and even a notable rival. Fittingly for any hip-hop mogul, and especially for this one, the show felt scrappy as well as spectacular.

title: Public Works: When Big Government Plays Its Role
description: At the dedication of the Triborough Bridge in 1936, Franklin Roosevelt made an impassioned case for public works. There was a time when no one complained, he said, that our schoolhouses were badly ventilated and lighted or that there were no playgrounds for children in crowded tenement areas. But times had changed. People are demanding up-to-date government in place of antiquated government, he declared, just as they are requiring and demanding Triborough Bridges in place of ancient ferries.

title: Bands to March on Atlanta
description: Ten marching bands, with their strutting drum majors, vibrant dance teams and synchronized drumlines, have been chosen from the nations historically black colleges and universities as the finalists in the sixth annual Honda Battle of the Bands, scheduled for the Georgia Dome in Atlanta on Jan. 26. Nominated from 42 colleges were Virginia State University and Shaw University, representing the Central Intercollegiate Athletic Association; Bethune-Cookman College and Norfolk State University, representing the Mid-Eastern Athletic Conference; Tuskegee University, in Alabama, and Albany State University, in Georgia, representing the Southern Intercollegiate Athletic Conference; Texas Southern University and the University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff, representing the Southwestern Athletic Conference; and North Carolina Central University and Winston-Salem State University, both independents. As sponsor of the event, the American Honda Motor Company will award $142,000 in grants to the bands.

title: Study Indicates Benefit of Vaccines
description: Death rates for 13 diseases that can be prevented by childhood vaccinations are at all-time lows in the United States, according to a study released yesterday.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,848 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans last week:

title: Luis Herrera Campns, Venezuela Leader, Dies at 82
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 11  Luis Herrera Campns, a former president whose years in office were marked by bountiful oil riches and a painful economic bust when oil prices plunged in the early 1980s, died here on Friday. He was 82.

title: Bad Behavior Does Not Doom Pupils, Studies Say
description: Educators and psychologists have long feared that children entering school with behavior problems were doomed to fall behind in the upper grades. But two new studies suggest that those fears are exaggerated.

title: Monitoring Rodriguez, Mets Look for Trades
description: David Wright is one of the few Mets who spend the off-season in New York. Naturally, that makes it easier for him to attend the teams promotional events, oversee his charitable foundations and embrace the community endeavors that have helped cement his status as the teams most visible player.

title: Mayors Offer of Mediator in Theater Strike Goes Nowhere
description: As the stagehands strike on Broadway entered its third day yesterday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and senior members of his administration continued to reach out privately to the producers and stagehands, urging them to negotiate and offering the use of Gracie Mansion and a mediator.

title: 2 States Voters Still Not Settled on Favorite Candidates
description: This article was reported by Adam Nagourney, Marjorie Connelly and Dalia Sussman and written by Mr. Nagourney.

title: Kelly Says Man Provoked Officers
description: New York City Police Commissioner Raymond Kelly said today that the shooting death of an unarmed Brooklyn man by five police officers last night fell within departmental guidelines because the man, an 18-year-old with a history of mental illness, pointed a black object at the officers and claimed it was a gun.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Oct. 29 about the lobbyist Robert D. Blackwill, a former White House aide who works on behalf of the former Iraqi prime minister Ayad Allawi for the Washington firm of Barbour Griffith & Rogers, misstated, in two references, the surname of another former aide who met with one or more of the firms lobbyists to discuss Iraq, according to disclosure reports. She is Meghan OSullivan, not Sullivan. (Go to Article)

title: East Haven: Second Recount Ordered
description: Secretary of the State Susan Bysiewicz ordered a second recount of ballots in East Havens mayoral election yesterday after discrepancies turned up in the first recount. April Capone-Almon, a Democrat, defeated Mayor Joseph Maturo, a Republican, by 21 votes in last weeks election, according to Election Day counts. Local officials who counted the paper ballots on Sunday found that Ms. Capone-Almon had an even bigger lead. Lori Jaffe, an election moderator, declined to reveal the exact discrepancy, but said the victory margin was now about 50 to 60 votes.

title: For Edwards, a Man on the Run, Time Is No Ally
description: DES MOINES, Nov. 12  Night was falling, and John Edwards was an hour late for a campaign event at a recreation center in Williamsburg, Iowa.

title: During War, Tough Mother Sets Out to Shield Her Son
description: Kathleen Chalfant can perform such miracles onstage that she has even found the lifeblood in Howard Barkers bloodless essay question of a play, A Hard Heart.

title: Smoking, the Environment and an Epidemic of Lung Disease
description: Dr. Barry Make is co-director of the C.O.P.D. program at National Jewish Medical and Research Center in Denver.

title: Next Project for eProject: A New Name
description: Not that long ago, when it came to corporate branding the Is had it, and so, too, did the Es, as marketers sought to signal they were part of the Internet boom by starting their names with those vowels.

title: McCain Disavows Group Trying to Help His Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12  Senator John McCain asked his donors on Monday not to send money to independent groups that circumvent campaign finance regulations as they seek to assist his presidential campaign.

title: Challenger Named in Georgian Election
description: TBILISI, Georgia, Nov. 12  Georgias opposition nominated the owner of a winemaking company on Monday to face President Mikheil Saakashvili in early presidential elections, scheduled for Jan. 5.

title: Poisonous Mushrooms Forge Their Own Path, Genetically Speaking
description: Its a thin line between love of wild mushrooms and death. Some species in the genus Amanita are edible, but others are among the most lethal foods known. Thats why all but the most expert mushroom hunters are wise to stay away from Amanita species. Unless you really know what youre doing, your next saut may be your last.

title: Pope Benedict to Visit in April
description: Pope Benedict XVI is scheduled to come to the United States in April, his first visit as the pope, and plans to make stops in Washington and New York, the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops announced yesterday.

title: Oil Drops on Lower Demand Forecast
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 13  The price of crude oil extended its slide today after a prominent energy group lowered its estimate for worldwide oil demand, saying high prices were harming consumption.

title: Selected Studies: C.O.P.D.
description: Government agencies, universities, doctors and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, please visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

title: Jawbone Sheds Light on Divergence of Humans and Apes
description: Scientists who study the divergence of humans from the other great apes have been stymied by a lack of evidence. It is thought that humans and chimpanzees split 6 million to 7 million years ago, and humans and gorillas a couple of million years before that. But almost no ape fossils from this period  the Late Miocene  have been found in Africa.

title: Challenges to Both Left and Right on Global Warming
description: For many years, the battle over what to think and do about human-caused climate change and fossil fuels has been waged mostly as a yelling match between the political and environmental left and the right.

title: The Character Factor
description: Rochester, N.H.

title: Barricaded in Home, Bhutto Says President Should Resign
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, Tuesday, Nov. 13  Hundreds of riot police early today blocked the opposition leader Benazir Bhutto and her supporters from making a planned long march from this eastern city 160 miles through Punjab Province to the capital, Islamabad. Ms. Bhutto, barricaded in her home here, called for the resignation of Pakistans president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, in a phone interview with CNN this morning.

title: Japan: Operating Profit Falls at Isuzu
description: Isuzu Motors, Japans biggest maker of light trucks, had a 26 percent drop in second-quarter operating profit after rising overseas vehicle sales failed to make up for a slump in domestic demand. Operating profit, or sales minus the cost of goods sold and selling, general and administrative expenses, fell to 25 billion yen ($227 million) in the three months that ended Sept. 30, from 33.7 billion yen a year earlier. Sales rose 10 percent, to 472.4 billion yen.

title: Lawyers Long Fight for Democracy Puts Him in Familiar Place: Jail
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 12  Twenty-five years ago, when President Reagan treated Pakistans dictator, Muhammad Zia ul-Haq, to a White House state dinner, a promising young lawyer out of Cambridge University languished in jail. He had protested too loudly, and too often, about the lack of democracy in his country.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Open Book, See Red

title: The Claim: Some Red Lipstick Brands Contain High Lead Levels
description: THE FACTS

title: Warmth Is Found in a Heated Rivalry
description: Choosing which sports rivalry is the fiercest, looniest or nastiest is a timeless, if fruitless, exercise. How do you compare Red Sox-Yankees with Auburn-Alabama, North Carolina-Duke with Real Madrid-Barcelona or Glasgow Celtic-Glasgow Rangers?

title: Germany: Bank to Post a Huge Loss
description: WestLB, the German state-owned bank based in Dsseldorf, said it would report a full-year loss of more than 100 million euros ($145 million) because of persistently difficult market developments. The lender will post a pretax low three-digit million euro loss, in contrast to an original forecast of a profit, according to a statement. The company, which is scheduled to publish nine-month earnings on Dec. 6, blamed the substantial price losses of structured securities in the past weeks.

title: Networking at the Spa
description: The golf course is not the only place to do business in a casual setting. The new spot to network with colleagues and clients is the hotel spa.

title: Addenda
description: Accounts

title: Delbert Mann, Director, Is Dead at 87
description: Delbert Mann, a director from the heyday of live television who won an Oscar for his first big-screen effort, Marty, in 1955, died Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 87 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: One Lawmakers Waste Is Anothers Namesake
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12  Buried deep in the largest domestic spending bill of the year is money for a library and museum honoring first ladies. The $130,000 was requested by the local congressman, Representative Ralph Regula, Republican of Ohio. The library was founded by his wife, Mary A. Regula. The director of the library is his daughter, Martha A. Regula.

title: Europe Advances Plan to Cut Jet Emissions
description: PARIS, Nov. 13  A bold effort by the European Union to impose caps on aircraft emissions received a lift today when legislators voted to raise the costs for airlines and to include international flights sooner than expected.

title: Old Story, Updated: Better Living Through Pills
description: Athletes taking performance-enhancing drugs. Growing concern about a reliance on pills for relief from pain, stress and anxiety. Medical leaders alarmed about drug fads, calling on doctors to exercise restraint when prescribing.

title: Britain Takes Tougher Stance on Sanctions Against Iran
description: LONDON, Nov. 12  Britain will push for a worldwide ban on foreign investment in Irans oil and gas industry and other financial sanctions unless two reports due this month show that the Tehran government is ready to abandon efforts to acquire nuclear weapons, Prime Minister Gordon Brown said Monday.

title: French Literary Honors
description: Frances literary awards season continued yesterday with the Prix Medicis and the Prix Femina, Agence France-Presse reported. The Prix Medicis went to La Stratgie des Antilopes (The Strategy of Antelopes), by Jean Hatzfeld, an account of what happened after the Rwandan authorities allowed 40,000 of those who carried out the 1994 genocide to return to their homes. The Prix Femina, awarded by an all-female jury, went to Eric Fittorino for his novel Baisers de Cinma (Cinema Kisses). The committee awarded its prize for a foreign novel to the British writer Edward St. Aubyn for Mothers Milk, and the Prix Medicis for foreign work went to an American, Daniel Mendelsohn, for The Lost, about a search for family members who died in the Holocaust.

title: Palestinian Refugees
description: To the Editor:

title: I.B.M. Acquires Cognos, Maker of Business Software, for $4.9 Billion
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 12  Cognos, the last major independent producer of software that companies use to analyze mountains of data, agreed on Monday to be acquired by I.B.M. for $4.9 billion in cash.

title: Australian Judge Dismisses Terrorism Case
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 12  A judge in Australia dismissed a case against a terrorism suspect, Izhar ul-Haque, on Monday, and accused the Australian Security Intelligence Organization of false imprisonment and kidnapping.

title: Dressing Up Those Bleak Downtown Construction Sites
description: Yes, those are orange zebra stripes on the traffic barriers along lower Broadway. Yes, the 14-foot-tall plywood lightning bolts on John Street take the place of common sidewalk scaffolding. And yes, that tartan pattern on the construction fence along Fulton Street is made of security netting.

title: The Daily Show
description: Washington

title: Police Transcript of 911 Call
