description: NEW YORK (AP)  The police transcript of the 911 call prior to the police shooting of an 18-year-old in New York:

title: Looks Deceive: This Destination Drew Too Well
description: HOLLIS, N.H., Nov. 10  The town dump here is a kind of unofficial social club, the place to buy Girl Scout cookies, meet political candidates and catch up with friends while unloading a weeks worth of trash.

title: Gumbel Gives His First Year a Low Grade
description: It is rare to hear network announcers say their work is substandard, but Bryant Gumbel said yesterday that he was not very good last season. It was his first as the play-by-play announcer for the NFL Networks eight-game schedule.

title: In a Loss, Dungy Says He Learned a Lesson
description: Few things in football are more unexpected than seeing Indianapolis place-kicker Adam Vinatieri, one of the great clutch performers in football history, blow an easy kick: he missed a chip-shot field-goal attempt Sunday night with a chance to eek out a victory against the San Diego Chargers.

title: Another Impeachment Complaint Filed Against Philippine President
description: MANILA, Nov. 12  Opponents of President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo filed a new impeachment complaint against her today, accusing her of corruption and illegal policies that they said have resulted in the death, torture and disappearance of hundreds of government critics.

title: For the Record: In Tests of Inhalers, Results May Depend on Who Pays
description: Inhalers are an effective treatment for asthma and other respiratory diseases, but they can have adverse side effects. The conclusions of studies on these effects apparently depend in part on who pays for the study.

title: BHP Takes Buyout Plan to Shareholders of Rival
description: BHP Billiton, whose $153 billion takeover offer for a rival mining company, Rio Tinto, was rejected by the targets board, took its case to shareholders yesterday, detailing what it said would eventually be $3.7 billion in annual savings and holding out the promise of $30 billion in payouts if the deal goes ahead.

title: Open Book, See Red
description: Book rage has now been added to the list of neurotic human behaviors. So far confined to Canada, it is characterized by angry outbursts in bookstores and, more specifically, by the hurling of books, The Globe and Mail of Toronto reported. The causes: the declining United States dollar, the rising Canadian dollar and dust jackets imprinted with prices making books more costly for Canadians. For more than 30 years the value of the Canadian dollar has lagged that of its American cousin; five years ago it was worth 62 American cents. As a result, book jackets customarily show a United States price and a higher Canadian price. But last week the Canadian dollar hit $1.10 against the United States dollar; yesterday it stood at $1.03. Thus book rage and widespread reports of unhappiness among buyers expected to pay the higher price. Some Canadian booksellers, including Wal-Mart Canada, have begun to offer their wares at United States prices; others are giving discounts on the Canadian price, rebates or simply marking down the books.

title: Pennsylvania: Boy Talked to Youth in Finland School Shooting
description: A teenager who plotted an attack on a suburban Philadelphia high school discussed the 1999 Columbine massacre with the Finnish student who killed eight people and then himself at a school near Helsinki last week, the teenagers lawyer said. The American, who is 14 years old, contacted the Finnish youth, Pekka-Eric Auvinen, 18, online last summer, and they exchanged views about Web sites and videos, including one that glorified the Columbine attack, said the Americans lawyer, J. David Farrell. Although that video was among common interests the two boys discussed, there was no talk of any plan that Mr. Auvinen had to attack the Finnish school, Mr. Farrell said, adding that his client was shocked by the attack in Finland.

title: Case Touches a 2nd Amendment Nerve
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12  Both sides in a closely watched legal battle over the District of Columbias strict gun-control law are urging the Supreme Court to hear the case. If the justices agree  a step they may announce as early as Tuesday  the Roberts court is likely to find itself back on the front lines of the culture wars with an intensity unmatched even by the cases on abortion and race that defined the courts last term.

title: Korean Officials Accused in Widening Bribery Scandal
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 12  A widening corruption scandal at the Korean electronics giant Samsung engulfed the government of South Korea on Monday when President Roh Moo-hyuns next chief prosecutor and his top anticorruption agent faced accusations of accepting bribes from the conglomerate.

title: Lottery Numbers
Investment Firm Names Gore as a Partner
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12  Deepening his ties to Silicon Valley, former Vice President Al Gore said on Monday that he had become a partner in the venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers.

title: Childhood: Too Little Sleep May Pose Obesity Risk
description: Children who do not get enough sleep may increase their risk for obesity, a new study has found.

title: Voter Anger May Free Up Energy Bills
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12  Congress saw it coming. Earlier this year, lawmakers warned of an impending energy crisis as they debated wide-ranging legislation to improve automotive efficiency, reward energy conservation and spur development of alternative power sources.

title: Football Beaten by Housewives
description: Despite tough competition from NBCs Sunday Night Football and Foxs animated comedy lineup, ABC eked out a victory on Sunday as the nights most watched network. Desperate Housewives, the nights top-rated show, gave ABC its usual lift, drawing 18.5 million viewers at 9, Nielsen estimated. The network also earned solid ratings from Extreme Makeover: Home Edition at 8 (15.1 million) and Brothers & Sisters at 10 (12.5 million). Among adults 18 to 49, ABC finished in a three-way tie with Fox and NBC, which both benefited from live football coverage. Although Foxs comedies, in particular The Simpsons at 8 (10.6 million) and Family Guy at 9 (10.4 million), remained competitive in that demographic, the network began the night with more than 18 million viewers tuning in at 7 for an overrun of its afternoon football coverage. NBCs prime-time Sunday coverage of the Indianapolis Colts at the San Diego Chargers delivered approximately 14.4 million viewers from 8 to 11. CBS ranked a distant fourth for the night in the 18-to-49 set. It earned its best ratings at 8 and 9 with The Amazing Race (10.5 million), followed by Cold Case (13 million).

title: For the Record
description: A letter from Rochester yesterday about Ronald Reagan and states rights misspelled the name of the German city where he spoke at an SS burial ground. It is Bitburg, not Bitberg.

title: Symantec Planning to Cut Some Jobs
description: The Symantec Corporation, the maker of security software, said yesterday that it would cut jobs in some business units, less than a month after its forecast of sales fell short of analysts estimates.

title: Giants May Have Been Close, but Now They Have Far to Go
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 12  When Giants Coach Tom Coughlin addressed reporters minutes after Sundays 31-20 loss to the Cowboys, he stepped away from the podium after answering two questions. Frustration was written on his face and spelled out in his words. He did not like a question about whether the loss represented a squandered chance in a statement game.

title: Warnings of Long-Term Damage After Russian Oil Spill
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 12  An environmental disaster began to unfold in southern Russia on Monday as tens of thousands of oil-slicked seabirds and globules of heavy oil dotted the shoreline, a day after at least 11 ships, including a small oil tanker, sank or broke apart in a fierce storm, Russian officials said.

title: Focus on Names Misses the Steroids Story
description: The feeding frenzy is on. As George Mitchell gets closer to writing and issuing his report on the use of performance-enhancing substances in baseball, the prospect of seeing names in the report has people in Major League Baseball nervous and the news media tingling with anticipation.

title: An Artists Famous Smile: What Lies Behind It?
description: Your first reaction upon meeting Yue Minjun might be, yes, it is indeed he! The face with the enigmatic, jaw-breaking grin, perhaps the most recognizable image in contemporary Chinese painting, is a self-portrait.

title: What to Ask About C.O.P.D.
description: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening -- and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why theyre important.

title: 6 Palestinians Killed in Gaza at Fatah Rally
description: GAZA, Nov. 12  At least six Palestinians were killed and more than 100 wounded here on Monday when a rally by the relatively pro-Western Fatah movement to mark the third anniversary of the death of its founder, Yasir Arafat, ended in armed clashes with its rival, Hamas.

title: An Ailing Health System: Feel Better!
description: To the Editor:

title: On Injury to Vilma, Jets Give an Inch
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 12  Most N.F.L. teams are secretive about injuries, and the Jets are more secretive than most. So it was startling Monday when the Jets disclosed which injured knee had ended the season of Jonathan Vilma, the inside linebacker, defensive captain and backbone of their defense.

title: Picking Up Citys Vibes to Predict Quake Effects
description: The boxy white postal truck bounced along West 28th Street in Manhattan, hit a pothole, shimmied some, then lumbered on.

title: Blackstone, Deal Maker, Posts Drop in Earnings
description: The Blackstone Group yesterday reported third-quarter earnings that were lower than in the period a year earlier, as troubles in the credit market shook up its real estate business.

title: Ministers Want Stronger Chinese Currency
description: European finance ministers meeting in Brussels urged China to let its currency strengthen so Europes economy no longer bears the brunt of the slide in the United States dollar.

title: Nun Pleads No Contest in Sex Abuse
description: A Roman Catholic nun pleaded no contest yesterday to two counts of indecent behavior with a child in connection with accusations from the 1960s when she was a principal and teacher at a Catholic school in Milwaukee.

title: Off Endangered List, but What Animal Is It Now?
Some Help in a New Life
description: In the former Soviet Union, Mikhail Fayner was a physicist and his wife, Aleksandra, an engineer. They are intelligent people, warm and playful. They are also Jewish, and in the Soviet Union, carrying that stamp on your passport meant a lifetime of trouble. By the time the Soviet Union fell, they had long since had enough and were finally free to start a life somewhere new. The United States granted them refugee status, and in 1997 they moved to New York City.

title: A Soldier Home From War, and a Mother Fighting Hard
description: On Veterans Day, all that Cathy

title: A Painless Execution
description: To the Editor:

title: Shooting Kills a Boy, 13, and Wounds Another
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 12  Jacqueline Purdie clutched herself against the cold, stared at the monitor showing the blurry surveillance tape, and watched her 13-year-old son die.

title: Love of Chocolate May Have Begun With Cacao Beer
description: The ancient peoples of Mexico and Central America loved to drink chocolate. But their beverage was nothing like the modern one  it was a frothy, bitter brew of fermented, roasted and ground cacao seeds, often spiced with chile peppers, more like mole poblano than Swiss Miss.

title: The on Wings of Song Series Shows a Fledglings Flights
description: At 19, the soprano Nadine Sierra is a seasoned performer. A native of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., she entered the Palm Beach Operas young artist program at 14 and made her stage debut there two years later. Her 2004 performance of Puccinis O mio babbino caro on the National Public Radio series From the Top generated a buzz. A video clip of Ms. Sierra singing that aria, posted on YouTube last year, has been viewed more than 11,700 times.

title: Justice Dept. Chief Faces a Test in Minnesota
C.I.A. Officer Pleads Guilty to Illegal Searches
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13  A Lebanese-born C.I.A. officer who had previously worked as an F.B.I. agent pleaded guilty today to charges that she illegally sought classified information from government computers about the radical Islamic group Hezbollah.

title: The Prince and His Palace: A 6,400-Square-Foot Getaway That Flies
description: PARIS, Nov. 12  He may be only the worlds 13th-richest man, but Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia will soon be able to claim the bragging rights to the worlds largest private jet.

title: A Lineman in My Bed: Notes on Teeth Grinding
description: I grind my teeth at night. Have for years. Its my secret shame. But now I have the comfort of knowing that at least 8 to 10 percent of the adult population shares my malady.

title: Dick Nolan, 75, N.F.L. Coach and Player, Is Dead
description: Dick Nolan, who played nine seasons as a National Football League defensive back and was later a head coach for 11 years, twice guiding the San Francisco 49ers to conference championship games, died Sunday in Grapevine, Tex. He was 75.

title: Listening to the Fragile, Ethereal Beat of Butterflies Wings
description: At a time when many composers wrote works of gargantuan size and scope, Gabriel Faur produced just one prominent, large-scale masterpiece: the ethereal Requiem. Instead he concentrated on songs and chamber music, the focus of a concert by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center on Sunday at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, its temporary home while Alice Tully Hall is being renovated.

title: A Health Plan for Wal-Mart: Less Stinginess
description: For much of the last decade, the retailing behemoth Wal-Mart Stores has been associated with stingy health care as much as low prices.

title: Memo Pad
description: BUSINESS-CLASS SALES The trans-Atlantic business-class fare war for holiday travel that Continental started recently is escalating as American, Lufthansa and eight other carriers have joined in. Round-trip business-class fares on trans-Atlantic routes, which can cost $10,000 at regular walk-up prices, are being offered at $1,200 and less by some carriers for limited periods over the Thanksgiving and Christmas holidays. Matthew Bennett, publisher of the online premium air travel newsletter Flightbliss.com, suggests that the discounts are a good way for elite-status frequent fliers to take holiday trips in comfort while padding their year-end totals of miles needed to requalify for elite status next year. Business-class fares, he points out, often yield extra qualifying mileage credit.

title: A Toast to Tuscany, With a Staten Island Red
description: CRESPINA, Italy, Nov. 7  The visit to this picturesque corner of Tuscany probably will not spawn a best-selling sequel with a title like Under the Staten Island Sun. But in the not-too-distant future, Staten Island will bring a little bit of Tuscany to New York, in the form of a vineyard being developed at the Staten Island Botanical Garden.

title: Bush Vetoes Major Domestic Spending Measure
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13  President Bush on Tuesday vetoed a major spending measure that would have funded education, health care and job training programs, saying it contained money for too many of the special projects known as earmarks. But he signed a $459 billion bill to increase the Pentagons nonwar funding.

title: Structural Failures
description: The recent crash of an Air Force F-15 fighter jet  and the grounding of the entire 700-plane fleet as a precautionary measure  is the latest reminder of the tough military budget choices this country will face for the foreseeable future. Even if American troops were withdrawn from Iraq tomorrow, billions of dollars would still be needed to replenish military equipment, swap aging weapons systems for new ones and rebuild and expand ground forces strained to the breaking point by this misguided war.

title: Dealers Trove Draws Loyal Collectors and Strong Bids at Christies
description: The quirky eye of the legendary Manhattan dealer Allan Stone drew a loyal following of collectors and dealers last night to Christies, where a selection of the art and objects he collected so obsessively opened this seasons auctions of postwar and contemporary art.

title: M Is for the Many Things We Sell Her
description: The television folks who brought you tmz.com are back online again, this time not with the inside dope on celebrity misbehavior but with a community Web site for mothers.

title: Berlin in Lights: With Two Interlopers, a Doughty Dozen
description: A long day of following the Berlin Philharmonics component parts ended at Zankel Hall on Monday night with a concert by its cello section. The 12, as they are called, have a specific origin.

title: Injury Roundup
description: Adrian Petersons torn knee ligament was the injury news of the day, but the status of several other top players is up in the air.

title: Bee Sting
description: In Science Times, Natalie Anger lays into Hollywood cartoons, in which the overwhelming majority of animal characters are male, despite natures preferred sex ratio of roughly 50-50:

title: Constellation Swills $885 Million Deal
description: Constellation Brands, the winemaker, said Monday that it planned to buy the American wine business of a rival, Fortune Brands, for $885 million, in a move to expand its portfolio of higher-end California wines.

title: Officials Accused in Samsung Bribery Scandal
description: A widening corruption scandal at the Korean electronics giant Samsung engulfed the government of South Korea on Monday when President Roh Moo-hyuns next chief prosecutor and his top anticorruption agent faced accusations of accepting bribes from the conglomerate.

title: BHP Takes Buyout Plan to Shareholders of Rival
description: BHP Billiton, whose $153 billion takeover offer for a rival mining company, Rio Tinto, was rejected by the targets board, took its case to shareholders Monday, detailing what it said would eventually be $3.7 billion in annual savings and holding out the promise of $30 billion in payouts if the deal goes ahead.

title: Borse Dubai Gets Approval in Joint Bid For OMX
description: Swedens financial regulator has given Gulf-based Borse Dubai approval to own OMX, the Nordic stock market operator, bringing Nasdaqs joint $4.9 billion bid to acquire OMX with Borse Dubai a significant step closer.

title: The Unwanted Bounce of Exercise
description: At a recent school function, a mother started talking to me about her exercise routine, but I interrupted with a more pressing question. What sports bra do you use?

title: Gazprom Eyes 2 London-Listed Oil Concerns
description: Gazprom, Russias state-owned energy company, is considering taking equity stakes in two London-listed oil companies that had hitherto faced problems with Russian regulators.

title: Kleiners New Political Rainmaker
description: While Al Gores new role as partner in the venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers will give the Nobel laureate an opportunity to use his expertise in environmental causes to identify investments, it is the former vice-presidents political ties that may come in even handier in nurturing green businesses.

title: Countrywide Warns Against a Junk-Bond Rating
description: Countrywide Financial, the mortgage lender, said Monday that its ability to raise money and increase deposits in its banking subsidiary could be hampered if its credit ratings were reduced below investment grade.

title: The Buyout Boom Is Alive and Well. In China.
description: Private equity dealmaking may be slowing in the United States, but according to The Washington Post, some of the biggest and most powerful dealmakers here have found a way to keep the buyout boom going: by aggressively pushing into China.

title: In Defense of Predatory Lending?
description: There is a new Web site today, which Ill get to in a moment. But first you should check out the site it is parodying, from the Community Financial Services Association of America  otherwise known as the Payday Lenders.

title: Lampert Said to Lose $4.47 Billion in 3rd Quarter
description: The hedge fund controlled by Edward S. Lampert, the value-oriented billionaire investor, may be out $4.47 billion in the third quarter, according to press reports back-of-the-envelope calculations.

title: Hedge Fund Targeted By Overstock Countersues
description: The hedge fund at the center of Overstock.coms controversial short-selling lawsuit has filed a counterclaim against the online retailer, arguing it is trying to cover up questionable accounting and poor business decisions.

title: Death By a Thousand Write-Downs
description: Whats really killing investors confidence in Wall Street firms is the uncertainty and unpredictability of the recent write-downs, David Weidner wrote in a commentary on MarketWatch. The solution may be for more firms to take a tough line on marking to market.

title: Terra Firma Said to Unveil EMI Plans
description: British investor Guy Hands Terra Firma, on the hunt for additional equity investors in EMI, is telling prospective partners they can nearly quadruple their money in the struggling major label and cash out within five years, The New York Post reported.

title: A Prince and His Palace in the Sky
description: Its been a busy month for Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia. After helping to push Charles O. Prince III out of the top job at Citigroup, the banks largest shareholder is now claiming bragging rights to the worlds largest private jet.

title: Villa With a View
description: A look at Villa San Giorgio, a renovated two-story farmhouse in Italy.

title: Food Stuff
description: A Smoked Fish Spot in TriBeCa Cultivates a Last-Century Vibe

title: 12 Wall Street Firms Unite for Trading Platform
description: Twelve Wall Street firms that had started competing platforms for trading unregistered securities known as 144a issues have agreed to cooperate on a single platform operated by the Nasdaq Stock Market, the exchange said Monday.

title: Formula Ones Lewis Said to Eye I.P.O.  Of Himself
description: Lewis Hamilton, the 22-year old Formula One racing sensation who came within inches of winning the Grand Prix championship in his debut season, is now reportedly mulling another bold maneuver  listing himself on the London stock market.

title: Accel Closes $520 Million Investment Fund
description: Early-stage venture capital firm Accel Partners announced the final closing of its 10th investment fund with $520 million on Monday.

title: Private Equity-Backed CDM Resource Plans $140 Million I.P.O.
description: CDM Resource Partners, a company that provides natural gas contract compression services, aims to raise as much as $140 million in an initial public offering.

title: What Should You Do in Your Career?
description: When I decided to become a lawyer 20 years ago, it was a decision laden with shoulds, mostly from my father, who was projecting his wishes onto me. (His Marci should be a lawyer became I should please my father and become a lawyer.) If I had listened better to my own vision for a career, I might have found a career that fit me better the first time around.

title: Vodafone Considers Selling Vodacom Shares in I.P.O.
description: The Vodafone Group , the worlds biggest provider of mobile-phone services, said it may sell shares in Vodacom Group in an initial public offering as part of Vodafones plan to raise its 50 percent stake in South Africas largest wireless provider.

title: Sun Capital Said to Threaten Hostile Bid for Kellwood
description: Investment firm Sun Capital Partners is threatening to take its $544 million buyout offer for Kellwood to the companys shareholders unless the apparel makers board reconsiders its rejection of the bid, the Wall Street Journal reported Tuesday in its online edition.

title: Macquarie Profits Rise in 1st Half, but Outlook Is Glum
description: Macquarie Group, Australias biggest securities firm, said a rally in equity markets may falter in the second half, making it harder to repeat its record 45 percent profit growth of the first six months.

title: $900,000 Homes
description: Properties on the market in Florida, Montana and Washington.

title: Words on Warming: Which Message Works?
description: The books that tend to catch peoples attention are those at the edges of the span of thought on an issue of the day, whether it is the existence of God, the way out of Iraq or the best way to avoid global warming.

title: Cisco Launches Eastern European Venture Fund
description: Cisco Systems said Monday that it will launch a program to make venture capital investments in technology companies in Central and Eastern Europe, a first step into a region where the networking giant hopes to fund startups and potentially make acquisitions.

title: For Barclays Diamond, Succesion Is a No-Brainer
description: Some industry observers cried foul over the lack of succession planning at Citigroup and Merrill Lynch, which became apparent this month after the two banks ousted their chieftains. Financial News now helpfully suggests that the Merrill and Citigroup could get a lesson in succession from Robert Diamond, the head of Barclays investment banking unit.

title: Whats Next for E*Trade?
description: E*Trade Financial lost more than half its market value Monday, after an analyst suggested that the company might have to seek bankruptcy protection if panicked customers withdraw deposits because of its faltering mortgage investments.

title: The Early Word: Thompsons Campaign
description: Fred Thompson picks up a major endorsement today, in the form of support from the National Right to Life Committee, whose backing Mitt Romney and Mike Huckabee had also sought.

title: Brats Rule!
description: Dont tell your child, the class cut-up, about the lead story of todays paper:

title: For Crack Offenders, Reduced Circumstances?
Citi Reorganizes Its Capital Markets Group
description: Citigroups embattled capital markets unit is regrouping under its new leader.

title: Questions Over Police Shooting of Man, 18
description: A police shooting of an unarmed young man drew an angry crowd in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, on Monday night and focused attention anew on the use of force by the police. Khiel Coppin, 18, died in a hail of 20 bullets fired by five police officers who had responded to his mothers 911 call for help in a domestic dispute. The police said officers believed Mr. Coppin had a gun, but it turned out that he had been holding a hairbrush.

title: McCain Ad: Outrageous Spending
description: As if to signal that Senator John McCains campaign doesnt need any help from outside groups, it has released a new advertisement in which he promises to stop wasteful spending in Washington.

title: Glam Lets Rivals Copy Its Ad Network Plan, and Takes a Cut
description: A deal announced Monday in which Glam will run an advertising network for the Lifetime cable network is a textbook example of how to co-opt potential competition.

title: Oxfords Word of the Year, and Runners-Up
description: Not everyone has joined the local food movement, but it has won over Googles cafeteria, Barbara Kingsolvers kitchen, writers at The New York Times, and now, leading wordsmiths at the Oxford American Dictionary, who are adding their lexicographic seal of approval:

title: My Dirty Book Collection
description: Some people wont lend their books because they dont like to. I sometimes wont lend mine because Im embarrassed about them. Some are seriously dirty.

title: Avoiding Climate Change: Why Americans Prevaricate and Delay on Taking Action
The WSJ goes green
description: Let it not be said that the editors of the Wall Street Journal lack ecological awareness. Today they save energy, both theirs and mine, by repeating exactly the same bogus arguments about income inequality that they made  and I refuted  fifteen years ago.

title: Spitzer Gives Up Drivers License Fight
description: Updated, Nov. 14 | Meeting with members of Congress in Washington, Gov. Eliot Spitzer acknowledged this morning that he had misjudged public sentiment in proposing to grant drivers licenses to illegal immigrants, but he vowed to press Washington for comprehensive immigration legislation and said his critics had stoked partisan and irresponsible fears of immigrants. (See this new post for full updates, including the text of the governors remarks.)

title: Tuesday Links: Different Seahawks, Same 49ers
description: For the second week in a row, the Monday night game was a stinker. The Seahawks won, 24-0, to push the 49ers losing streak to seven games. Watch the highlights at your own risk. As a follow-up to the discussion Sunday about division races, add the N.F.C. West to the list of divisions that have an uninspiring race. Jerry Brewer of The Seattle Times says the good Seahawks are back, while his colleague Steve Kelly welcomes the return of the pass-happy offense. Ted Miller of The Seattle Post-Intelligencer writes that a victory over the 49ers isnt something to build an opinion on. Perhaps thats because, as Ray Ratto of The San Francisco Chronicle points out, the 49ers are actually getting worse, as if thats possible. Mark Purdy of The San Jose Mercury News says that Mike Nolans return to the sidelines the day after his fathers death was not the stuff of TV movies.

title: Anti-Musharraf Protests in Pakistan
description: Hundreds of riot policemen blocked the opposition leader Benazir Bhutto and her supporters from setting out Tuesday on a planned march from Lahore across 160 miles of Punjab Province to the capital, Islamabad.

title: I Feel Fantastic
description: Jonathan Coulton, Brooklyn singer-songwriter, offers a medicated way to get through the day:

title: The Second Civil War
description: Preface A Day in June

title: Edwards Takes On Congress in New Ad
description: John Edwards has been promising for months that if he wins the presidency, unless Congress passes a universal health care plan, he would strip all of its members of their own health care.

title: Film Not Responding; Force Quit?
description: What is it with movies?

title: Rivera Has $45 Million Reasons to Stay
description: Somewhat lost in the excitement of Mondays news that Jorge Posada will return to the Yankees was the teams improved offer to closer Mariano Rivera: three years, $45 million. That should be plenty of cash for Rivera, like Posada, to return to the only team hes known.

title: Diller: Id Be at the Door in AOL Auction
description: He may be splitting up his media and Internet conglomerate, but Barry Diller still cant seem to stop talking like an empire builder.

title: Getting Well
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Rather Marks One Year in High-Def
description: Somewhere in Havana, Dan Rather is smiling.

title: Waiter, Are Those Extra Calories on My Plate?
description: Some popular restaurants now offer nutrition information for a few select items. But just how accurate is it?

title: Tuesday Kickoff: The Michigan Rumor Edition
description: Since the game between Michigan and Ohio State lost some of its luster when both teams were upset this weekend, it really needs a new story line.

title: Kohlberg Kravis Still on I.P.O. Track
description: Henry Kravis isnt running for cover just yet.

title: Finding a Draft Card
description: A couple of days ago I found a small box containing what I can only call miscellaneous leftovers from my past  a baseball, a couple of harmonicas, a years worth of weekly rail passes between Princeton and New York, which who knows why I kept.

title: Not Everyone Hearts Huckabee
description: In what can only be described at this point as a full-fledged crusade, Club for Growth is out today with an updated white paper lambasting former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabees fiscal conservative credentials.

title: Alzheimers, Love and the Ex-Supreme Court Justice
description: A new page in OConnors love story would seem just about the most euphemistic headline that USA Today could have written today about the fact that the husband of Sandra Day OConnor, the former Supreme Court justice, has fallen in love with someone else.

title: The Strike Last Time
description: One of the few good things to come out of the 1988 Writers Guild of America strike was a small, photocopied comedy zine called Army Man  a publication that, happily, has been getting its due (here, here, here and here) recently.

title: City Drivers Caught Smoking, Eating, Gabbing  and Putting on Makeup
description: Student researchers at Hunter College spent much of October observing 3,120 New York City drivers at 50 intersections and, according to their study, 1 in 3 were using cellphones, smoking, eating, drinking or grooming while operating their vehicles.The study, overseen by Peter S. Tuckel, a professor of sociology, found that more than 1 in 5 of the drivers were observed talking on their cellphones  half of them on hand-held phones, which has been illegal in New York State since 2001. In addition, about 1 in 10 drivers were engaged in other distractions like eating hamburgers and French fries, drinking coffee or soda, applying makeup, and smoking cigarettes.

title: Fortress Posts Loss for 3rd Quarter
description: The hedge fund and private equity company Fortress Investment Group reported a third-quarter loss on Tuesday, hurt by a special charge.

title: Matewan
description: Since the W.G.A. strike started, Hollywood writers have been trying to crystallize their complaints in online video one form theyre still allowed to write for. (They dont profit from Internet versions of their work anyway; thats at the heart of their beef.)

title: FX President: DVRs Will Hurt Quality
description: The FX drama Damages, beloved by critics and a (relatively small) fan base, has averaged 2.5 million viewers in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic since its debuted in July.

title: NBC Squeaks Out An Evening News Win Over ABC
description: For the first time in almost three months, NBC Nightly News with Brian Williams has attracted more total viewers and 25- to 54-year-old viewers than ABCs World News with Charles Gibson.

title: At CW, Overbearing Mothers Share the Stage
description: The CW will use the finale of its top-rated show, Americas Next Top Model, to launch a new reality show about a mother/daughter beauty pageant competition next month, the network announced on Monday.

title: Welcome
description: With the debut of this blog, Im happy to say that I now have the capacity to receive comments. Unfortunately, I dont have the time to respond to every message, but if all goes well, I will be able to read them. My researcher, Amanda Millner-Fairbanks, will be posting some representative comments after every column appears, and Ill try to blog as often as I can.

title: Name This Solar Twin and Win a Prize
description: The Greeks believed that the Helios, the sun god who drove a chariot across the sky, had two siblings: Eos, the goddess of the dawn, and Selene, the goddess of the moon. But now astronomers have expanded the family by identifying a solar twin.

title: Feed Em Today, Guano Tomorrow
description: Sounds like some people are ready to coronate a New York councilman who wants to ban feeding pigeons. From the Royal Society for the Preservation of Pigeon Killing:

title: Michael Schumacher fastest in Barcelona!
description: Fabulously interesting first day of testing in Barcelona today  and as predicted, Michael Schumacher was the fastest of them all, even after a years absence. Of course, he did try a car once or twice, and a motorcycle. And who knows what sort of fuel there was in the car. But I like this story:

title: A New Green School for Lower Manhattan
description: The city will build a 950-seat elementary and middle school in Battery Park City, a recognition of the unanticipated surge in population in Lower Manhattan since 9/11, officials announced this morning.

title: You, Too, Can Own a Professional Soccer Team
description: Now you, too, can own a professional soccer team. And no, Drew Carey, you dont have to settle for an M.L.S. expansion franchise. Like Malcolm Glazer, Roman Abramovich and other super-rich sports investors, fans can own part of a real English professional soccer team.

title: Hotel Picks for a Capri Weekend in January
description: My wife and I will be in Rome for the month of January and I am planning a surprise weekend on Capri. Im having trouble finding hotels (any class) open then. Do you have a suggestion? I appreciate your assistance.

title: Texas Tech Coach Leach Disciplined
description: All of the talk about the Texas Tech Coach Mike Leach being suspended for his critical remarks aimed at officials following the Red Raiders loss to Texas is just that  talk.

title: Edwardss Threat Is Called a Bluff
description: John Edwards has been promising for months that if he wins the presidency, unless Congress passes a universal health care plan, he would strip all of its members of their own health care, reports Julie Bosman at The Timess Caucus Blog.

title: Thompson at the Citadel
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Visiting the Citadel Military College that has already seen 12 of its graduates killed in Iraq and Afghanistan, Fred Thompson said very little about those wars. Instead, he chose to focus almost solely on calling for strengthening Americas military by increasing its size, something all the Republican candidates agree on.

title: So, You Want To Learn More About This Internet Thing
description: Gabe and Max have just the computer-training product for you:

title: Renault F1 Responds to Spy Charges
description: Not that spy scandal, silly. Another one, a fresh one that isnt past its sell-by date.

title: Goldman Sachss $6 Billion Word
description: No.

title: Drab Construction Sites Get an Artistic Makeover; Whats Next?
description: Artists, architects and designers have reimagined three of the pedestrian obstructions that can make travel through downtown downright disagreeable, if not close to impossible: Jersey barriers, chain-link construction fences and sidewalk scaffolds. If you cant get rid of them, the theory goes, at least make them look better.

title: Misusing Paris Hiltons Good Name?
description: Upon her release from jail, Paris Hilton vowed to Larry King that she would become a more responsible role model. But was a story that emerged this morning from The Associated Press part of her campaign?

title: Face Time Is Important to Iowa and N.H., Poll Finds
description: With their early contests, Iowa and New Hampshire have lured the presidential candidates to their states  and voters there say the face time matters.

title: Bill Would Make Colleges Copyright Cops
description: Q: Why does Hollywood care about student loans?

title: No Sanctuary State of Mind
description: Updated, Corrected at 5:30 p.m. Republican candidate Mitt Romney has been hammering away against illegal immigration in many of his campaign appearances, especially in some spots in Iowa where the issue is a hot topic.

title: Brillo Movie by the Neistat Brothers
description: A film by the Neistat Brothers.

title: A Video Challenge to Green Shoppers
description: Jerry Mander, a 71-year-old patriarch of the antiglobalization movement, has begun a new attack on the merits of linking markets through planetwide flows of resources and goods  and on the very hip notion of late that one can improve the environment by changing shopping habits. (By the way, Jerry Mander is the name his parents gave him.)

title: Interview With Pakistan's President
description: The New York Times spoke with Pakistan's president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, about the state of emergency, upcoming elections and Benazir Bhutto.

title: Todays Literary Moment
description: Condensed works from Books-a-Minute Classics:

title: Are Ethnic Shopping Strips Luring Suburban Customers?
description: Last weekend, thousands of South Asians from across the New York region descended on Jackson Heights, Queens, to celebrate Diwali, the Hindu festival of lights. The neighborhoods central corridor, 74th Street, has become renowned as a Main Street for South Asian Americans, even though few Indians, Bangladeshis and Pakistanis actually live there, according to Madhulika S. Khandelwal, a professor of urban studies at Queens College who directs the Asian American Center there.

title: Ratings: Boost For Samantha and Big Bang
description: ABC remained No. 1 in the ratings on Monday thanks to consistently solid audiences for Dancing With the Stars and Samantha Who. According to Nielsens estimates, the celebrity dancing competition earned the nights top ratings as usual with an average of 21.8 million viewers from 8 to 9:30 p.m. Following it, ABCs Samantha Who, with Christina Applegate, drew 14.3 million, just shy of that series largest audience to date.

title: Michael Biondi, Lazard Banker, Dies at 50
description: Michael J. Biondi, a Lazard partner and a heavyweight among mergers and acquisitions bankers, died Monday evening at his home in Greenwich, Conn. Mr. Biondi worked as Lazards co-chairman of investment banking, a role he held since 2003. The cause of death was unknown, pending an autopsy.

title: Sundhage to Coach U.S. Women
description: According to the Associated Press, Pia Sundhage will become the coach of the U.S. womens national team. The former Swedish star will replace Greg Ryan whose contract was not renewed after his controversial and ultimately unsuccessful stewardship during the Womens World Cup in China.

title: Taking eBay Bids on the Grand Rabbis Glasses
description: The grand rabbis glasses are for sale on eBay.

title: All Pigeon Politics Is Personal
description: At City Hall today, the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, was asked about a proposal by Councilman Simcha Felder, Democrat of Brooklyn, to fine people who feed pigeons. Her reply:

title: Performa 07: Why Dancers Have Left the Galleries
description: Last night at Anthology Film Archives I saw some never-before-shown taped excerpts from 1972 performances by Grand Union, the seminal improvisational dance group that counted among its members Yvonne Rainer, Trisha Brown, Steve Paxton and Douglas Dunn. tonight Im going to a second evening documenting Judson Dance Theater performances and will be reviewing both in the paper. But I just wanted to mention something that a contemporary choreographer, Trajal Harrell, said after the screenings, which pertains to this whole discussion about why there is so little back-and-forth (or at least the perception of that lack) between the dance and visual art worlds today.

title: The Reality of My Fantasy
Berlin in Lights: One Mambo Less
description: Just when it seemed that Berlin in Lights had found its anthem.

title: Americas Leaky Buildings and the Climate Challenge
description: In 2002, President Bush ordered a restructuring of climate research in the United States and a series of reports on points of uncertainty. One of those reports, North American Carbon Budget and Implications for the Global Carbon Cycle, came out today.

title: Wacky Wall Street
description: More than any of the nations other big banks, Citigroup is reeling from the credit squeeze brought on by the bursting of the mortgage bubble. Its write downs are estimated to reach some $20 billion by the end of this year.

title: Press Is Invited, Then Ejected, From Jeb Bush Lunch
description: The group of reporters gathered at the Union Club on the Upper East Side this afternoon, straggling in for one of those lunches where they might salivate for an hour to get just one juicy quote from the featured speaker  in this case, Jeb Bush, the former governor of Florida, who was being introduced by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. At the very least, Mr. Bush might have something to say about the citys new A to F grading system for schools. And maybe hed even float a couple of ideas about the presidential politics. But alas, the reporters were not quite allowed to find out.

title: He Prefers His Hands Drenched in Blood
description: Photos from "Richard III" at the Classic Stage Company.

title: Playing the Victim Card?
description: Just 25% of Americans believe that the Democratic candidates are piling on Senator Hillary Clinton and attacking her unfairly, a Rasmussen Reports national telephone survey finds.

title: An Honor for Nick
description: Theres a very nice profile of Nick in the latest issue of U.S. News and World Report (theres also a video below). Nancy Shute highlights some of the adventures from the Win-a-Trip contest. The magazines editors named Nick one of Americas best leaders. He is on the list with 17 others, including Arnold Schwarzenegger, Michael J. Fox and Yo-Yo Ma. The group was chosen because of their interest in social responsibility. This recognition is a bit better than the recent one from Mad Magazine.

title: Inbox 2.0: Yahoo and Google to Turn E-Mail Into a Social Network
description: Ignore Orkut, OpenSocial, Yahoo Mash and Yahoo 360. Google and Yahoo have come up with new and very similar plans to respond to the challenge from MySpace and Facebook: They hope to turn their e-mail systems and personalized home page services (iGoogle and MyYahoo) into social networks.

title: The Parking Wars Heat Up
description: What we are reading elsewhere

title: State Dept. Struggles to Fill Iraq Posts
description: At the end of October, the State Department threw down the gauntlet on some of its most important and hardest-to-fill foreign assignments in the world: Iraq. If diplomats didnt choose to fill the 48 open positions, the bureau would choose them.

title: A Week Into the Columbia Hunger Strike
description: November seems to be the month for strikes: Hollywood writers, Broadway stagehands and campus activists. Four Columbia University students completed the first week of their hunger strike today, as administrators continued to meet  rather tepidly, some students said  with a negotiating team of students.

title: Netflix Prize: Close, but No $1 Million Cigar
description: Maybe its not so easy to improve recommendation software after all.

title: Thanksgiving Dressing
description: Crisp, crunchy and delicious: Mark Bittman makes a simple stuffing made of fresh breadcrumbs, butter and scallions.

title: News Corp. Accused of Seeking to Protect Giuliani
description: NYTimes.com has justed posted an article by Russ Buettner on Judith Regans lawsuit against The News Corporation, in which the book publisher who was fired by the company last year asserts that a senior executive at the media conglomerate encouraged her to mislead federal investigators about her relationship with Bernard B. Kerik during his bid to become homeland security secretary in late 2004.

title: The Freedom of Free
description: One of the nagging questions of the current Internet world is the economics of Mashups. If a film maker uploads a video to YouTube that is then embedded on someones profile page on MySpace, who gets to make money from ads on the video?

title: Charges Filed in Bus Shelter Vandalism
description: The police have charged a man with criminal mischief and etching graffiti with acid at three Manhattan bus shelters, including the one at 23rd Street and Eighth Avenue that was the subject of a City Room blog post a week ago.

title: 'I Like to Answer Questions Well'
description: Macroeconomics is hard.

title: Who Are You Also Known As?
description: Like many adopted people I never had a simple answer to the question, "Where did I come from?" For most people raised by their biological parents, this question can be answered by simply gazing at their parent's face. There in the turn of a nose and the curve of the eye they are reminded of where they came from. bounded by blood, a part of a human continuum passed from mother to daughter, from father to son.   (Photo: The author, the day she arrived in the United States, walking off the plane at J.F.K. airport. (Photographs courtesy of Hollee McGinnis.)) I, on the other hand, seemingly dropped out of the sky on a Boeing 747, walking, talking and potty trained. I was adopted in May 1975 at the age of 3  with just the clothes on my back: a little red pant suit and vest, and white sweater trimmed in red. I have no memories of that day I arrived in America  but I have been told stories so many times that I feel like I remember: running up and down the escalators of John F. Kennedy airport after being cooped up in an airplane for 28 hours; my parents giving me lollipops because I was too big for a pacifier to quiet me on the ride to my new home in the suburbs of New York City; and pushing the Uncle Ben's white rice on the floor the first morning and eating the Entenmanns's coffee cakes instead.  My parents told me that summer of my arrival I would sing and talk in Korean. Of course they never knew what I was saying. They also told me that in those first weeks I would run up to the front door, throw my body up against it and cry and cry and say in Korean, "Jip e ka le!" My sister, born to my parents and age 9 at the time, thought it might be some strange Korean game. So she would run up to the door, throw her body against it and say, "Jip e ka le!" I can imagine my sister doing this over and over  and turning my tears into laughter. Years later my parents learned what my Korean words meant: I want to go home.   (Photo: The author, front row lower left in the red outfit at the orphanage on Tok Chok Island founded by the Maryknoll priest, Ben Zweber (center).)   This illustrates two things: first, that no matter how old a child is when adopted  whether as an infant, a toddler, or young child  they come with a history, a past that is real. Secondly, it illustrates that when we adopt, there is movement. There is a movement from one place to another, from one culture to another, from one family to another, and in these movements there are both losses and gains. The only way a child gains a family through adoption is by losing another family in some way. This paradoxical nature of adoption raises serious questions that need to be resolved: What are adoption gains and losses? And do the gains outweigh the losses?   Growing up, I was not aware of the losses in adoption, just the gains: parents and siblings and friends who loved me. Like many adopted people who have the fortune of being raised in a supportive home, I did not think much about the fact of my adoption. I thought of my adoption as one thinks about breathing  it was simply part of who I was. I was not necessarily conscious of it as a child growing up unless someone pointed it out to me. And I certainly did not feel like there was anything "wrong" because I was adopted. I grew up knowing very clearly who I was: I was Hollee.   My personal awakening to the losses of adoption began in my late adolescence when I became aware that strangers assumed I was not an American because I did not have blond hair and blue eyes or assumed I spoke Korean (or Chinese or Japanese) or complimented me on my English. I, on the other hand, did not think of myself as Korean  although I felt pride that I was  because I was raised by a non-Korean family. I felt like an imposter because people assumed I knew Korean culture based on my race, but I only knew American culture.   Thus, in my first year of college I sought to fulfill the stereotypes and assumptions people had of me based on my race. I studied Mandarin  because my college did not offer Korean at that time  and took classes in Asian art and history. But it angered me that people would make assumptions about who I was based on things I could not change: my gender, my race, my adoption status  and judge me not for the individual I was. And so in my sophomore year I changed my major to American studies because I wanted to understand how I, as an Asian woman with an Irish last name and blond-haired mother, could be an American too.   Ultimately I realized this conflict about my identity arose because I felt I had only two choices: Korean or American. The reality was that I was both. I felt to identify simply as being Asian would be to deny the love and nurture of my adoptive parents; and to identify solely as American, I would be denying my Korean ancestry and heritage. When I began to embrace both identities rather than trying to "fit in" I realized the gains in my life that came from this duality. I realized, "Well, hey, not everyone gets to be adopted internationally and have two countries and two families."   Learning about the history of intercountry adoptions, I knew I was not the only person who might feel caught between these two worlds. In fact, I was inspired by the fact that there was such a large community of adult international adoptees  an estimated quarter million in the United States  who could share their experiences, especially with the younger generation of families being formed through intercountry adoption. I felt that as a community we could truly create a space in which we could explore, and come to embrace and celebrate our dual heritages given to us by birth and adoption.   Thus, two years after college at the age of 24 I started a non-profit organization for adult intercountry adoptees in New York City  Also-Known-As. The goal of the organization was and is to share the unique experiences and identity of intercountry adoptees and their families and to celebrate the broader transcultural community. The organization works to empower those who have been adopted internationally by providing mentorship to adopted youth, building cultural bridges through awareness and appreciation of one's birth culture, and transforming racial stereotypes.   In accepting my identity as an international transracial adoptee, and rejecting the identities imposed upon me, I realized the question, "Who am I?" can only be answered by my declaration "Who I am."   Who I am is a transcultural, multicultural, interracial, hybrid, bridging worlds, being. I am Hollee McGinnis also-known-as Lee Hwa Yeong. I have an Asian face, an Irish last name, a blond-haired mother.   But who I am is not just about who I know myself to be, but who I want to also be known as in this world. At its best, intercountry adoption demonstrates to me the greatness of our human spirits to love across race, nationality and culture. But I also know that it takes a lot more than just love to make a success;  it requires courage, honesty, and commitment.   This means we must be willing to talk about the hard stuff  the discrimination, inequalities, and prejudices that exist in the world. We must also be willing to change and challenge our societies so that the gift we give our children  adopted or not  besides the love and security of a permanent family is a world that values them for who they are and who they will be  regardless of race, nationality, culture or circumstance.
