title: A Republican dilemma
description: Michael Gerson says that Republicans need to face up to the problem of declining social mobility. But he doesnt say anything about what they should propose.

title: Meltdown at Madison Square Garden
description: As Howard Beck of The New York Times writes this morning, things went from bad to worse for the Knicks on Tuesday, as several players missed a game in Phoenix because of injuries or family crises, and another  the teams most popular member, Stephon Marbury  simply went AWOL.

title: Bear Stearns to Take $1.2 Billion Write-Down
description: Bear Stearns will write down the value of its subprime-related assets by $1.2 billion in the fourth quarter, Chief Financial Officer Sam Molinaro said at a Merrill Lynch conference on Wednesday.

title: Quote: Getting Along With Urban Monkeys
description: In todays article about New Delhis soaring population of wild monkeys  a scourge that has recently left the deputy mayor dead and several children injured  Amelia Gentleman of The New York Times interviewed a government expert and animal rights campaigner named Sonya Ghosh. Heres her advice on how to handle close encounters of a simian kind:

title: Will Dropping License Plan Help Spitzer?
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzers decision to abandon his plan to issue drivers licenses to illegal immigrants comes after a tumultuous public debate that brought into focus national anxieties over immigration and even presidential politics. Judging from the scores of comments on a blog post published yesterday, the issue will probably remain emotional and raw for some time.

title: Fatal Shooting in Brooklyn
description: An 18-year-old man died in Brooklyn on Monday evening after police responded to a 911 call and used deadly force.

title: In Iowa, <strike>They (Heart)</strike> Huckabee Is  Doing Quite Well
description: While most of the chatter surrounding todays New York Times/CBS News primary voter polls centers on the statistical tie between the three big Democratic contenders, theres an interesting subplot developing among the Republicans. Among Republican caucusgoers, 27 percent said they would support Mr. Romney, while 21 percent said they would support Mr. Huckabee and 15 percent said they would support Mr. Giuliani, reports The Timess Adam Nagourney.

title: Spitzer: The Issue Does Not Disappear
description: Updated, 11:23 a.m. | Chastened and contrite, Gov. Eliot Spitzer acknowledged this morning that he had misjudged public sentiment in proposing to grant drivers licenses to illegal immigrants, but he vowed to press Washington for comprehensive immigration legislation and said his critics had stoked partisan and irresponsible fears of immigrants. (The full text of the governors remarks is below.)

title: Wednesday Morning Kickoff
description: Texas Techs Mike Leach did not seem fazed by the record $10,000 fine he was hit with by the Big 12 for criticizing the officials in the Red Raiders loss to Texas on Saturday. His reaction, according to Don Williams of the Lubbock Avalanche-Journal: Weve broken records around here before. Were used to breaking records.

title: Wednesdays Links: Theyre Still the One
description: The Patriots didnt add to their win total last week. They had a bye. But theyre still all anyone can talk about. Next up for them are the Bills, who are sniffing around a possible playoff berth for the first time since Doug Flutie was their quarterback. ESPN.coms Sal Paolantonio says if the Patriots win out, they should be considered the greatest Super Bowl champion. Here, he compares the Pats to three rivals for the best-ever crown. And, finally, in confirmation of at least the notion that most people already believe the Patriots are one of the greatest teams ever, the Boys in Vegas are predicting the Patriots-Jets game on Dec. 16 will have the biggest point spread in N.F.L. history.

title: No Pop for Och-Ziff Shares
description: Shares of Och-Ziff Capital Management posted modest gains Wednesday morning after Daniel Och, the head of the $30 billion hedge-fund firm, rang the opening bell on the New York Stock Exchange to celebrate his firms market debut.

title:
Living With Music:
A Playlist by Kenneth Goldsmith
description: On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for Living With Music, a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage.

title: Kicking About: Retiring, Training and Mourning
description: As one long-time M.L.S. star calls it quits, another new M.L.S. star (perhaps the brightest of them all) looks for ways to extend his international career and maintain his form during the off season.

title: Romes Termini Train Station  Shop and Hop (on a train)
description: Termini, Romes main train station, has come a long way since it was inaugurated for the 1950 Jubilee Holy Year. Most people barely cast a passing glance at the station either becasue theyre either running to catch a train, or eager to hit Romes streets.

description: David Leonhardt has a delightful contrarian column today, in which he finds the good side of falling stock and home prices.

description: Major investment banks are reeling, coming up with one damaging disclosure after another regarding losses from risks they never had quite admitted they were taking. (Had you heard of a liquidity put before a couple of weeks ago?)

title: Hopewell, N.J.
description: A small village in central New Jersey with reasonably priced homes and a quaint downtown may the most un-Jersey-like town in the state.

title: Stolen Bike? Geeky Chat Room Comes to the Rescue
description: When Agata Slotas bicycle disappeared from a spot near Union Square one day in September, the odds were that she would never see it again. About 60,000 bikes are stolen in New York City each year, and only 2 percent of them are recovered by their owners. Because the bike was distinctive - her brother had built it himself - Ms. Slota, 27, posted an ad and photograph on Craigslist in the hopes that someone would notice it.

title: Hedge Fund Urges Delta Merger With United
description: Pardus Capital Management, a New York hedge fund, has sent a letter to the management of Delta Air Lines asking it to seek a merger with UAL, the parent of United Airlines, in a deal that would create the worlds largest airline and could prompt sweeping consolidation in the airline industry.

title: A-Rod Could Opt Back In to the Yankees
description: All along, there has been one avenue for the Yankees to bring back Alex Rodriguez: A-Rod, essentially, would have to beg his way back. He has been considering doing that for weeks, and now he has finally acted on it.

title: Petits-Fours Panic
description: They may well be vestiges of a more formal dining era thats in steady retreat, but Im still a big fan of petits fours.

description: In Kabul, Afghan grooms are increasingly going for broke, spending thousands of dollars in a growing number of lavish wedding halls.

title: Cambodias Quest for Justice
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: When Walking to New Jersey Cost a Nickel
description: At Thursdays monthly board meeting, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is expected to propose raising tolls on its Hudson River crossings, as well as its three bridges in Staten Island and PATH trains.

title: Voices From the Iowa, N.H. Polls
description: The New York Times and CBS News conducted statewide surveys in Iowa Nov. 2-11 and New Hampshire Nov. 9-12. The following comments were obtained in follow-up interviews with respondents after the polls were completed.

title: Rounding Up the Last of Pakistans Opposition
description: Earlier this week, The Associated Press put out one of its helpful sidebars to big news stories: Leading Figures in Pakistans Opposition. After today, only one of them remains free, a pro-Taliban party chief.

title: Day II and Schumacher is still on top
description: It was fun yesterday, but today, frankly, Michael Schumacher risks reminding us all of how monotonous it is when the same M. Schumacher tops the times, wins all the races, wins all the titles, dominates everything. Today the seven-time world champion even sent Felipe Massa more than two seconds behind him.** (Checkmate +?!) We had a great season with competition this year  but were they really the best drivers in the world?

title: They Just Dont Spy Like They Used To
description: Another day, another black eye for Americas intelligence community. A Lebanese-born C.I.A. officer who had previously worked as an F.B.I. agent pleaded guilty on Tuesday to charges that she illegally sought classified information from government computers about the radical Islamic group Hezbollah, reports The Timess Phil Shenon.

title: Yes, Old Jokes Do Go Stale
description: The late-night comedians saw significant losses in their first week of strike-related repeats, according to data released by Nielsen Media Research yesterday.

title: NYSEs Thain Is Chosen to Lead Merrill Lynch
description: John A. Thain, the chairman and chief executive of NYSE Euronext and a former co-president of Goldman Sachs, has been selected to be the next chief executive of Merrill Lynch, a person briefed on the situation told The New York Times.

title: California Wildfires on Weeds
description: Tuesdays episode of the popular Showtime series Weeds ended with an unsettling scene: the lead character, Nancy Botwin, walks into the living room, where her children are watching television coverage of a massive wildfire.

title: Health of Economy is Top Concern (Emphasis on Health)
description: In her Web column today, Janet Elder, The Timess editor of news surveys and news analysis, writes that health care has emerged as a major worry for voters, of equal concern to the war in Iraq. Go to column

title: Heat Rises (Again) Over Climate Rhetoric
description: Dave Roberts over in Gristmill / Huffington Post world has once again taken me to task for writing about people who have either made a career of saying global warming is not a catastrophe (Bjorn Lomborg) or have newly embraced the issue after a career on the right (Newt Gingrich).

title: Off Goes the Power Current Started by Thomas Edison
description: Today, Con Edison will end 125 years of direct current electricity service that began when Thomas Edison opened his Pearl Street power station on Sept. 4, 1882. Con Ed will now only provide alternating current, in a final, vestigial triumph by Nikola Tesla and George Westinghouse, Mr. Edisons rivals who were the main proponents of alternating current in the AC/DC debates of the turn of the 20th century.

title: Will Thain Come Between Merrill and BlackRock?
description: Now that John Thain apparently will take the reins of Merrill Lynch, here is a question to consider: What next for the firms relations with BlackRock?

title: Art for Every Price Range
description: In news out of the the art market today, one million dollars is the new ten grand, an art dealer concluded after Christies managed to sell 61 works at auction for a total of $325 million last night. The sales included an Andy Warhol owned by Hugh Grant, which sold for $21 million even though it was considered heavy-handed and not as sharp as others in the Liz series.

title: Song of Himself
description: In 1979, Norman Mailer was asked by Boston Magazine to write his own obituary, and he complied.

title: Immigration in New York City: Taking the Long View
description: On Tuesday evening - in fact, at the very moment Gov. Eliot Spitzer was abandoning his plan to grant drivers licenses to illegal immigrants - a panel of experts on immigration gathered at the Center for Jewish History on West 16th Street for a wide-ranging discussion about immigration to New York City, past and present.

title: Lunge, Lift, March
description: A peek at the moves that made Cathe Friedrich, Jari Love and Leslie Sansone famous.

title: Whos Left for Citis Top Spot
description: Strike another name off Citigroups list.

title: What to Make of the Metro Theater
description: From the outside, the landmark Metro Theater on Broadway, an Art Deco jewel box between 99th and 100th Streets, looks almost as exquisite as it must have in the 1930s, when movies were still known as photoplays, though no photo has played there for two years.

title: Worried About Global Warming? Why Do You Hate America?
description: If the recent behavior of the coal industry in Kansas is any guide, Congress is in for a brutal fight over global warming legislation.

title: Bus Driver and Cabby Exchange Blows as Traffic Stalls
description: People at the corner of 39th Street and Fourth Avenue in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, got something of a surprise on Tuesday night when, according to the police, the driver of the B35 bus stopped his vehicle and suddenly stormed off.

title: Notes on Times Reader Update 1.1.3.0
description: Because of a change made by Microsoft, we are required to make an update to Times Reader 1.1.3.0 to insure compatibility. (Times Reader runs on Microsofts .Net 3.0 framework, and Microsoft is now pushing a new version of their Framework .NET 3.5.)

title: Letter from Savannah: Praying for Rain
description: A trip to Savannah, Georgia last week found Southerners avoiding their usual boasts about gloriously blue skies and steady sunshine. Instead, the talk quickly turned to water, now in very short supply.

title: Whither TV Watching? Agencies Predict Viewer Reactions to Strike
description: As the Hollywood writers strike continues with no end in sight, advertisers and media buyers are trying to figure out what viewers will do over time and what the implications will be for their clients.

title: Thain and ONeal: Two Cool Customers
description: In ousting its chief executive and installing a new one from outside the firm, Merrill Lynch is sending Wall Street a signal that big changes are afoot. In some ways, though, the man who is set to become Merrills next boss, John Thain of NYSE Euronext, shares traits with the last one, E. Stanley ONeal.

title: A Night With Chumby
description: One of the wonderful defining moments of the early Internet was the Web cam that was pointed at the coffee pot in the University of Cambridge Computer Laboratory in November of 1993.

title: Thain Choice Shows the Long Arm of Goldman Sachs
description: John Thain. Robert E. Rubin. Henry M. Paulson.

title: McCains Double Jeopardy?
description: Senator John McCains campaign site has launched an interactive game-show-style feature, which Patrick Ruffini, writing at the blog of the conservative radio host Hugh Hewitt, finds very nicely produced. Production values aside, Ruffini is displeased: It also makes news, showing how McCain is sharpening his attacks against Rudy Giuliani. A user who answers Rudy Giuliani on question 7 of the game  Which candidate is the best general election candidate the Republican Party could nominate? gets this answer: The nomination of Rudy Giuliani would likely lead to the formation of a third party made up of social conservatives

title: Podcast: Remembering Mailer for Mayor
description: Listen to the Podcast (mp3)

title: L.A. Auto Show: Curtain Rises
description: LOS ANGELES  The 2007 L.A. Auto Show opened to the press Wednesday morning at the Los Angeles Convention Center. Notwithstanding recent industry news about labor shifts, drops in profitability and pledges to restore the greatness of American manufacturers, the L.A. show offers a flurry of press conferences and gives the automakers a chance to promote their shiniest new products.

title: A Win for Biggest Loser
description: While House lifted Fox to another win in the ratings on Tuesday, NBC earned a solid second-place finish thanks to a two-hour edition of The Biggest Loser. The weight loss competition matched its highest ratings of the season among adults 18 to 49, according to Nielsens estimates.

title: Gasping for Air: Life With C.O.P.D.
description: One woman improved her overall health after being diagnosed with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

title: Punk-Rock Band Has Odd Tie to Brooklyn Shooting
description: One of the police officers involved in Mondays fatal shooting of a troubled 18-year-old man in Brooklyn is a vocalist in a punk-rock band called EDP  which, in police parlance, is an acronym for an emotionally disturbed person.The officer, Sgt. Carl Carrara, was one of five officers who fired a total of 20 shots at Khiel Coppin on a dark sidewalk outside Mr. Coppins home on Monday night after Mr. Coppin pulled a hairbrush from beneath his sweatshirt and pointed it at the officers as if it were a gun. Sergeant Carrara, 32, fired five bullets from his semiautomatic gun.

title: Drivers Licenses? Real ID Is a Fork in the Road
description: There seems to be mixed messages on the future of Real ID in New York. In an interview from London, Michael Chertoff, the secretary of the Department of Homeland Security, said that he had spoken to Gov. Eliot Spitzer this morning and had been given no indication that New York would back off from a plan announced three weeks ago to offer new federally recognized licenses known as Real ID by next year.

title: Campus Voices: New Hampshire
description: A small band of students at Harvards Institute of Politics is spending a lot of their time in New Hampshire in the leadup to that states primary, as part of their academic project. In articles and videos on their Web site, CampusVoices.org, theyve been following candidates, interviewing voters and campaign staff members. Take a look at some of their videos on the site; theyre all student-produced and offer a sometimes grainy, uncut view that you wont necessarily see on television  especially because they are shot through the eyes of young potential voters.

title: The Blackwater Gunners Account
description: Hours after The New York Times reported the Federal Bureau of Investigations conclusion that Blackwater guards killed 14 Iraqis without cause in Baghdad on Sept. 16, ABC News published the official account of a turret gunner at the center of the incident.

title: Study: Cash Alleviates Depression!
description: From the abstract of a study by the Bonkers Institute for Nearly Genuine Research:

title: Its Too Quiet
description: I woke up yesterday with a start, realizing that I hadnt heard from John Agnelli in several days. This never happens. He always calls with a quick question, or to complain about someone whos not doing something and how thats causing problems.

title: Berlin in Lights: The Magic of Silence
description: After scattered appearances around town by component ensembles, the Berlin Philharmonic took the stage at Carnegie Hall last night for the first of three programs built around works by Mahler, conducted by Simon Rattle. Anthony Tommasini will review that concert and the orchestras second, tonight, in the Weekend section of the Friday paper.

title: There Will Always Be a Brooklyn
description: What we are reading elsewhere

title: New Hampshire Voters
description: Students from Harvard's Institute of Politics interviewed voters about its tradition of being the first primary in the nation.

title: Valentinoville
description: The Valentinos, as I like to abbreviate one of the last great fashion entourages, are in town. Diane Von Furstenberg and her husband, Barry Diller, had a dinner last night for Valentino and Giancarlo Giammetti at DVFs place on 14th Street. A very fun, casual night. The crowd included Liam Neeson, Natasha Richardson, Daphne Guinness (in a great array of rings and rhinestone bracelets, by Lacroix, that almost looked like gloves), Lynn Wyatt, Stephen and Christine Schwarzman, lots of editors, and Fran Lebowitz. I love talking to Fran, though I always feel like Im the responsible party in a tippy canoe. So great is my laughter at her lightly and liberally dispensed comments.

title: L.A. Auto Show: Is Volkswagen Dreaming Green?
description: Last week, the Rand Corporation, a non-profit think tank based in Santa Monica, Calif., released a study analyzing the societal and private benefits of diesel, hybrid, and E85 vehicles. The study found that diesels provided the most benefits, followed closely by hybrids. E85, a fuel blend of 85 percent ethanol from corn and 15 percent gasoline, was determined to provide no net societal benefits, primarily due to its high cost of production.

title: Redemption Day on Francis Lewis Boulevard
description: Another reminder of the resourcefulness of man  and that it takes all kinds in New York City  was Leung Chi Kee, 60, of Bayside, Queens, who on Tuesday was pedaling his homemade bottle cart up Francis Lewis Boulevard.It was trash day in the neighborhood, and as is his habit, Mr. Leung was pedaling his cart up the boulevard and peering into each trash can at the curb for empty bottles to redeem.

title: Giuliani Battles Romney on Immigration
description: The skirmishing between the Republicans over immigration continued today, and this time it was Rudolph W. Giuliani who had some of the most pointed words, saying that Mitt Romney probably has the worst record on illegal immigration. I think the number of illegal immigrants expanded dramatically while he was governor.

title: Payday Lending, Revisited
description: The blog I posted yesterday on payday lending has provoked a heap of responses, from people who see a clear economic need for such loans and from people who view the lenders as being little more than crooks.

title: Clinton Now Against Licenses for Illegal Immigrants
description: Senator Hillary Clinton has come out firmly against giving drivers licenses to illegal immigrants, one day before a debate against her fellow Democrats, who have put her on the defensive on the issue.

title: The Chant at Ollies: No Justice! No Noodles!
description: A phalanx of Chinese restaurant workers called for a boycott of Ollies Noodle Shop and Grill today. They claimed that the president of the popular restaurant chain was leading a retaliation and blacklisting effort against restaurant workers across the city who were organizing.

title: Be an Eco Sinner or Saint in the New SimCity
description: Most environmental risks can be studied in the lab or out in the field  by tracking the health of, say, a clam species in both a clean river and one thats polluted.

title: Border Bombers
description: The campaign of 2008 now has its own Daisy ad  an explicit appeal to fear that says: Vote for me, or people will get blown up.

title: Respond to Todays Column: What Happens in Vegas
description: We invite you to leave your responses to the Thursday, Nov. 15 column.

title: A Spitzer Reversal on Taxes, Too
description: After shelving its proposed drivers license policy this morning, Gov. Eliot Spitzers administration just said it would also drop a plan to start charging sales tax on Internet purchases.

title: Stage Whispers
description: Look was a great name for a magazine in 1937, when photography was the rage, and its a great name for a movie now, when everyones making videos. The postwar ecstasy of looking at things  from different angles and distances, and at different color levels and resolutions  is back in force now that digital technologies have introduced new vantages.

title: Signs of desperation
description: This represents a level of misunderstanding that has to be deliberate:

description: Blogging is hard. Watching cookie-cutter political commercials and thinking of something interesting to say about them is hard. But, evidently, getting high-level political figures to embarrass themselves is easy, at least for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Mitt Romney and the Mormon Church
description: Dane McBride remembers his time with Mitt Romney when both were Mormon missionaries and then students at Brigham Young University.

title: Greatness Within Reach
description: Nobody needs me to say great things about Ridge Vineyards. It makes one of Americas greatest wines, Monte Bello. Yet when it comes to thinking about great American producers the focus always seems to fall on the cult wines, and rarely on a more accessible producer like Ridge.

title: Bloggingheads: Is Rudy Creepy?
description:
Paul Glastris of the Washington Monthly, left, and Matthew Continetti of the Weekly Standard, debate whether Rudy Giuliani is authoritarian.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: Disney Accuses Strikers of Distorting Facts
description: Are the studios getting more combative as the writers strike continues?

description: Carl Malamuds quixotic mission to free government information took a step closer to reality on Wednesday morning when he struck a deal with Fastcase to electronically publish a free archive of federal case law.

title: New Family Guy Episodes Bypass Central Writer
description: Fox will continue to produce and show new episodes of the animated comedy Family Guy, even though Seth MacFarlane  the executive producer who not only writes for the show but also provides voices for it  is refusing to work during the writers strike.

title: Accused of Witchcraft
description: In parts of Angola, Congo and the Congo Republic, a surprising number of children are identified as witches and beaten, abused or abandoned.

title: E-Mail on My Cellphone
description: An encore presentation.

title: L.A. Auto Show: How Green Is My Valley?
description: LOS ANGELES  The L.A. Auto Show offers more to gawk at than just shiny metal. Some of the display space is given over to accessories and components, like this Super E-Spec tire from Yokohama Tire Corporation. The company says it can reduce the proportion of petroleum products used in car tires by combining citrus oil with natural rubber, producing a compound it calls Super Nano Power Rubber.

title: Beyond Falafel on Atlantic Avenue
description: Seth Kugel samples an array of delicacies on a traditionally Middle Eastern street near downtown Brooklyn.

title: What Has Become of the Iraqitects
Theyve Got Issues
description: If you pick your presidential candidate by issue, theres a new tool in the online toolbox for you: Glassbooth.org.

title: Digital Actors in Beowulf Are Just Uncanny
description: This post has been revised; see update below.

title: Beyond the Lion Dance
description: Jin Yu is 7 now, and lately shes been telling me she wants to go and visit her nannies, the women who cared for her at the orphanage in China.

title: In This Corner, Norman Mailer
description: It was at a vividly bad time in Norman Mailers life that I met him, and a sort of water-treading time in mine. He had stabbed his wife, and I was a copy boy at Time magazine.

title: Recognize That Man?
description: Asa Hoffman, a World Chess Federation master and New York City resident, is being featured in a commercial and print advertising campaign for HIP, the health insurance company. Hoffman, a fixture on the New York City chess scene for decades, said that he got the job through his wife, Eva Veronica Hoffman, an actress. The print ad appeared most recently in Tuesdays New York Post on page 19, although Hoffman is identified as Mooney, Jim in the ad.

title: An Amazing Fraud
description: The story of Universal Express and the contempt in which its former chief executive, Richard Altomare, held the law and the interests of its shareholders, gets more and more outrageous.

title: Looking West for Inspiration
description: No matter what your automotive fantasy, the Los Angeles Auto Show is a vehicular Disneyland where your dreams can come true.

title: Hopes Diminish, but She Still Pursues an American Dream
description: Barbara Cherrington thought that when she arrived in the United States, about 13 years ago, she would be able to go back to school, work and fulfill the American dream. However, it did not all work out as planned.

title: Backer of Digital Trades Rises to Lead Exchange
description: As a pioneer of electronic trading, Duncan L. Niederauer notably took a shot at stock exchange floor workers when he said he didnt want five guys named Vinnie executing my trades.

title: Hardy Succulents Take on a New Glow
description: STREET, Md.

title: Catholic Bishops Offer Voting Guide, Allowing Some Flexibility on Issue of Abortion
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 14  The nations Roman Catholic bishops approved principles Wednesday intended to guide Catholics in choosing whom to vote for but leaving the door open for them to back candidates who support abortion rights.

title: Gains for Biggest Loser
description: While House lifted Fox to another victory in the ratings on Tuesday, NBC earned a solid second-place finish thanks to a two-hour edition of The Biggest Loser. That weight-loss competition matched its highest ratings of the season among adults 18 to 49, Nielsen estimated. In total viewers, a category in which NBC ranked fourth for the night, the show drew a modest 8.2 million, far short of the nights most popular shows. NBC led the 10 p.m. hour, as usual, with Law & Order: Special Victims Unit (12.5 million). Meanwhile House attracted 16.9 million viewers while dominating the night in the 18-to-49 set. CBS and ABC finished in a virtual tie for third in that demographic. Both networks had bright spots on their schedules, particularly in terms of total viewers: CBSs NCIS at 8 and ABCs Dancing With the Stars at 9 outdrew House, each with more than 17 million viewers. But new shows on ABC and CBS continued to struggle. CBSs Cane delivered its lowest ratings to date at 10 (7.3 million), as did ABCs new comedies, Cavemen at 8 (4.6 million) and Carpoolers at 8:30 (5.2 million).

title: 23 Are Charged With Illegal Sports Betting at Borgata Casino in Atlantic City
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 14  It was just another Wednesday at the cavernous Poker Room in Atlantic Citys poshest casino, the Borgata. The cocktail waitresses were gliding around in economical black dresses and the dealers were holding court at packed tables. No one was paying any attention to the television monitors tuned to CNN.

title: Iraq to Spend $19 Billion on Projects
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 14  Iraq will spend an unprecedented $19 billion on capital projects across the country in 2008, including $900 million in Baghdad, senior Iraqi officials said Wednesday, even as they warned that the fight against insurgencies, gangs and militias was far from over.

title: Dell Buoys a Rival by Offering Suns Operating System
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14  Dell and Sun Microsystems, longtime rivals in computer servers, said Wednesday that Dell would sell Suns Solaris operating system, giving Sun a lift as it tries to expand its software business.

title: On the Web With Big Concepts for a Fragmented Long Island
description: OYSTER BAY, N.Y.

title: Lawsuit Over Visa for Muslim Academic
description: Adam Habib, a South African Muslim academic, has been told by the State Department that he was barred from entering the United States because of engaging in terrorist activities, prompting the American Civil Liberties Union to revise an earlier lawsuit. The suit, filed in Federal District Court in Boston in September by the A.C.L.U. for various groups that had invited Mr. Habib to speak, had sought to force the government to issue Mr. Habib a visa on free-speech grounds. Now that the reason for the denial has been stated,the A.C.L.U. wants to force the government to produce evidence, said Melissa Goodman, an A.C.L.U. lawyer.

title: Retail Sales Slip, Signaling Cutback in Holiday Spending
description: Spending is slowing  but so is inflation, offering the Federal Reserve more room to stimulate the economy by lowering interest rates next month, if it wants.

title: A Wall Becomes a Six-Foot Canvas for the Xbox and More
description: Most houses arent big enough for two widescreen TV sets, which can make for a struggle between those who want to watch Dancing With the Stars and those eager to play video games or watch cartoons. The Torpedo Entertainment Projector aims to break that stalemate once and for all.

title: Port Authority Expected to Raise Tolls to Support 2nd Hudson Rail Tunnel
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, at its monthly board meeting today, will propose increasing by $1 billion its contribution to a second passenger rail tunnel under the Hudson River to Pennsylvania Station, supported by a toll increase, an agency spokesman said yesterday.

title: Sad Truths and Sad Lives of Generation Blog
description: There is no one working in television today who has so effectively monopolized a genre as the team of Ed Zwick and Marshall Herskovitz. They have owned the world of ruminative soap opera, the way Ford once owned Detroit. As producers they have evoked the anxieties of nearly every life phase: in Thirtysomething, the marriage and childbearing years; in My So-Called Life, adolescence; in Once and Again, the 40s and divorce. Quarterlife, the teams first venture into Web TV, examines what it is like to be 25 in the privacy-obstructing age of the Internet, but it bears not a fraction of the thoughtfulness that distinguishes nearly everything else on their joint rsum.

title: A Top Rival in Pakistan Is Carted Off by the Police
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, Nov. 14  The opposition politician Imran Khan emerged from hiding on Wednesday to the cheers of hundreds of students protesting against the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, at a university here and was quickly seized by hard-line students and turned over to the police.

title: Obama in Orbit
description: NEW YORK

title: Ranch House Spectacular
description: SHARON, Conn.

title: The Fires in Russia
description: To the Editor:

title: Battling Ghost Calls, That Telemarketing Annoyance
description: The phone rings. But no one is there.

title: Envisioning Lively Downtown at Edge of Nassau Coliseum
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 14  An ambitious plan to transform the vast concrete tundra around the Nassau Coliseum into a downtown district with restaurants, cafes, a pedestrian mall, shops and artificial canals was presented to the local planning agency on Wednesday.

title: House Approves Funds for Military, With Strings
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  The House on Wednesday approved $50 billion of the nearly $200 billion that President Bush had requested for military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan but attached many strings to the measure, virtually guaranteeing that Senate Republicans would block it.

title: Big Prices for Bacon Paintings Lead Sales of $315.9 Million, a Record Total for Sothebys
description: The art world continued its shopping spree last night at Sothebys, where contemporary-art collectors and dealers dropped a cool $315.9 million  a record auction total for Sothebys  on everything from a sculpture of a bright red heart to a somber painting of a bullfight to an image of an electric chair.

title: Gerald D. Feldman, Historian of the Nazis and Finances, Dies at 70
description: Gerald D. Feldman, an eminent historian of 20th-century German history who concentrated on the intersection of economics and politics to explore subjects like the hyperinflation of the 1920s and the cozy relationships between financial companies and the Nazis, died on Oct. 31 at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 70.

title: Enhancing the Mayhem, a Vest Offers Game Players a Chance to Feel the Punches
description: Game players are sticklers for realism. If the slime glistening from an aliens carapace is slightly off-kilter or a gun doesnt look sufficiently dangerous or futuristic, it can ruin the entire experience.

title: TV Shows See Strike as a Second Chance
description: In the television business the grim reality of the writers strike has set in, with the prospect of a long shutdown of scripted shows growing stronger by the day.

title: Nevada: Simpson Is Ordered to Stand Trial
description: O. J. Simpson and two other men were ordered to stand trial on a dozen charges, including armed robbery and kidnapping, related to a confrontation in a Las Vegas hotel room in September.

title: Army Arrests Sergeant Who Went AWOL
description: A soldier who left his post at Fort Drum in Watertown, N.Y., without leave more than a year ago to seek treatment for post-traumatic stress disorder was arrested yesterday at a cafe eight miles from the base as he was preparing to surrender, his lawyer said.

title: Lottery Numbers
Bush Unveils Plan to Ease Holiday Air Delays
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15  Saying it was time to bring order to Americas skies, President Bush today proposed a series of changes to try to ease congestion and delays in holiday air travel.

title: African Crucible: Cast as Witches, Then Cast Out
description: UIGE, Angola  Domingos Pedro was only 12 years old when his father died. The passing was sudden; the cause was a mystery to doctors. But not to Domingoss relatives.

title: Buffett Says No Estate Tax Would Be a Gift to the Rich
description: Warren E. Buffett urged Congress yesterday to maintain the estate tax, saying that plans to repeal the tax would benefit a handful of the richest American families and widen income disparity in the United States.

title: Next to MoMA, a Tower Will Reach for the Stars
description: Cass Gilberts Woolworth Building, William Van Alens Chrysler Building, Mies van der Rohes Seagram Building.

title: For Little Hands, a Camera That Goes Beyond Still Pictures
description: Made for the youngest of shutterbugs, the Kidizoom Camera from VTech has a real viewing screen and binocular-vision viewfinders, much like last years Fisher-Price Kid-Tough camera. But the Kidizoom does more than take pictures. It can capture videos and has an on-screen editor so a child can quickly add a pair of devil horns to a photo of her big sister and display the results on either a TV or a computer screen using the included cables.

title: Foreclosures Hit a Snag for Lenders
description: A federal judge in Ohio has ruled against a longstanding foreclosure practice, potentially creating an obstacle for lenders trying to reclaim properties from troubled borrowers and raising questions about the legal standing of investors in mortgage securities pools.

title: A Dinosaur That Grazed Like a Cow
description: It has been 60 years since French paleontologists first found the dinosaurs bones in Saharan Africa, and 10 years since Paul C. Sereno of the University of Chicago began assembling a more complete skeleton. Only now has his team recognized the plant-eaters peculiar anatomy and foraging behavior.

title: A Garcia Marquez Novel is Banned in Iran
description: Iran has rescinded publication of the latest Gabriel Garca Mrquez novel, Memories of My Melancholy Whores, attributing its release  to a bureaucratic error, Agence France-Presse reported, citing the Fars news agency. It added that the cultural official responsible for authorizing publication had been dismissed, and the culture ministry refused to issue a permit to reprint the book, which appeared in Farsi under the title Memories of My Melancholy Sweethearts. The novel tells of a nonagenarian who celebrates his old age by treating himself to a night with an adolescent virgin and asks the madam of the citys most successful brothel to help. The books first edition, 5,000 copies published three weeks ago, sold out. All publications in Iran must be approved by the ministry of culture and Islamic guidance. Publishers have complained of tighter censorship since Mahmoud Ahmadinejad became president in 2005.

title: Yanks Should Treat Rodriguez the Way He Treated Them
description: Lets think this through.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Prospect of New York Protest

title: Correction: Again and Again in the Balkans
description: An editorial on Monday about Kosovos bid for independence incorrectly described the circumstances behind the NATO intervention in Kosovo in 1999. NATO launched military action to stop Serbias repression of the ethnically Albanian majority in Kosovo, a province of Serbia. Serbia did not invade Kosovo.

title: Red Laser Puts Tooth Decay in a New Light
description: THE next time your dentist tells you to open wide, consider this: dentists fail to accurately diagnose cavities 20 to 30 percent of the time.

title: Your Photos Straight to the HDTV (No PC Middle Man)
description: Youve got a high-definition television set and a high-resolution digital camera. So why not skip the computer and show off those pictures on your mighty home entertainment center?

title: George W. George, 87, Broadway Producer, Dies
description: George W. George, a film and theatrical producer whose credits include the acclaimed film My Dinner With Andre as well as a run of successful Broadway productions, died on Nov. 7 in Manhattan. He was 87.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Disappearing Day Lilies

title: Little Is Said to Address Marburys Absence
description: Stephon Marbury bolted from the Knicks on Tuesday, but MSGs announcers could not summon any real opinions on his decision to leave Phoenix and return to New York.

title: Broker Is Expected to Plead Guilty
description: A former broker at Bear Stearns, Ken Okada, is expected to plead guilty in a wide-ranging insider-trading case, becoming the ninth person to admit wrongdoing in a scheme that also involved employees at UBS and Morgan Stanley.

title: Nimoys Not Bothered by Spurning of Shatner
description: Leonard Nimoy said he was not sympathetic to William Shatners complaints about being left out of the new Star Trek movie. I know hes upset, Mr. Nimoy, 76, said after an appearance on Tuesday at the Elizabeth Foundation for the Arts in Manhattan, where he promoted his new book of photographs, The Full Body Project. But his character died three movies ago, so it would have been very difficult to get him into this one. Mr. Shatner, 76, above, who originated the role of Capt. James T. Kirk on Star Trek, told The Associated Press last month that because of his popularity, he thought it was a bad business decision to leave him out of the new movie, the 11th in the series based on the television show. Mr. Nimoy appears briefly in the new Star Trek, set for a December 2008 release and featuring Kirk and Mr. Nimoys Spock before the era chronicled in the original Star Trek.

title: Weeks Later, Rodriguez Comes to His Senses
description: Alex Rodriguez is performing a baseball version of the hokey-pokey. Yesterday, he put his right arm in, two and a half weeks after taking both arms out. When you do the hokey-pokey, you turn yourself about, and thats what Rodriguez has done.

title: S.E.C. Takes Step Toward Global Accounting Rules
description: Corporations outside the United States that use international accounting standards will no longer be required to adjust their financial statements to comply with American accounting rules, the Securities and Exchange Commission decided today.

title: Cockroaches Respond to Peer Pressure, Study Suggests
description: Many a mother has said, with a sigh, If your friends jumped off a cliff, would you jump, too?

title: Away From SoHo, a Place to Uncoil
description: THERE are those who question whether Forrest Myers makes art that is furniture or furniture that is art. Whatever it is, it is murder on the back.

title: Tidying Up Mailboxes
description: Q. What does it mean to compact messages?

title: Mitchell Under a Protective Umbrella if Lawsuits Arise From Investigation
description: Since the outset of his 19-month investigation into the use of performance-enhancing drugs in baseball, George J. Mitchell has operated under an indemnity clause stating that Major League Baseball would be responsible for legal costs of lawsuits brought in connection with his investigation.

title: Even When Youre a Star, Comedy Isnt Always Pretty
description: In his lean, incisive new book about the trajectory of his life in comedy, Steve Martin describes some of the danger signs that made him realize his career in stand-up had peaked. In 1979 he was booked solid for the next two years and playing auditoriums too large for his sly, intimate stage act to be understood. And the critical backlash had begun: he had gone from being a wild and crazy guy, in his own phrase, to a mild and lazy guy in the none-too-original minds of reviewers.

title: Come Out of Your Cave and Get Used to the Price
description: SOMETIMES when I walk through the East Village, I feel a gust of nostalgia for 1993, when I first moved to New York and lived with my artsy friend Jill in a two-bedroom on 12th Street. It was a carefree, de-gorgeous era, when I often wore girls-size thermals printed with snowflakes or flowers and $3 thrift store bell-bottoms. I even knotted my hair in Bjork buns. I suppose we can all get lost in our nostalgia, no matter how dumb we looked.

title: Sale Clbre: Shopping for a Cause
description: LAST Saturday morning, in a warehouse tucked behind a strip mall and a beauty salon in North Bergen, N.J., it was difficult to say what made for a more jarring picture. Was it the sight of 3,000 boxes full of marked-down Oscar de la Renta gowns, Proenza Schouler bomber jackets and Ralph Lauren cable-knit sweaters? Or was it the Vogue staffers who were unpacking them, wearing sweats (albeit cashmere) and no makeup?

title: Inter-Korean Talks Focus on Expanding Economic Cooperation
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 14  In the first meeting of their prime ministers in 15 years, North and South Korea on Wednesday discussed turning their disputed western sea border, the site of naval skirmishes as recently as five years ago, into a peace and cooperation zone for fishing and manufacturing.

title: Tinkering at Home, Selling on the Web
description: AT a time when most electronic gadgets come out of huge factories in Asia, Limor Fried works on a different scale.

title: Tajikistan: Blast Kills One in Capital
description: A bomb went off in the capital, Dushanbe, outside the presidential palace and a conference hall where Prime Minister Oqil Oqilov was due to speak. A security guard was killed. No one claimed responsibility.

title: Quick-Striking Rangers Stay Hot
description: NEWARK, Nov. 14  The Rangers-Devils rivalry moved into a new arena for the first time  illuminated by the Prudential Centers bright lights, the highlights replayed on its big high-definition screens  but it was hardly the only new thing in a game between old foes.

title: Ford to Offer Buyouts and Scrap Plan for Plant
description: DETROIT, Nov. 15  The Ford Motor Company said today that it would offer more buyouts to unionized workers and that it had canceled plans to build a new low-cost assembly plant in North America.

title: In Eco-Friendly Factory, Low-Guilt Potato Chips
description: CASA GRANDE, Ariz.  At Frito-Lays factory here, more than 500,000 pounds of potatoes arrive every day from New Mexico to be washed, sliced, fried, seasoned and portioned into bags of Lays and Ruffles chips. The process devours enormous amounts of energy, and creates vast amounts of wastewater, starch and potato peelings.

title: Manhattan: Restaurant Boycott Called
description: Workers called for a boycott of Ollies Noodle Shop restaurants yesterday, claiming that the president of the popular restaurant chain was leading a retaliation and blacklisting effort against restaurant workers who are trying to organize. The workers claimed that the president of Ollies, Tsu Yue Wang, had threatened employees, telling them they would not be able to find work. The old boss would call the new boss and say, These guys are causing problems,  said Jerry Weng, 28, an immigrant who said he had worked for wages as low as $2 an hour at an Ollies. In May, the chain closed its West 44th Street location, where a number of the main organizers of a labor lawsuit had worked. Mr. Wangs lawyer, Richard Ian Greenberg, did not respond to calls yesterday.

title: Injury-Riddled Colts Lose Freeney for Rest of Season
description: The Indianapolis Colts, who were without seven starters last Sunday, sustained a potentially devastating blow when defensive end Dwight Freeney was placed on season-ending injured reserve yesterday with a Lisfranc fracture and dislocation to his left foot. Freeney, a three-time Pro Bowl selection and the highest-paid defensive player in the N.F.L., was injured making a spin move during the Colts 23-21 loss to the San Diego Chargers.

title: Amid Drought, a Georgian Consumes a Niagara
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 14  A day after Gov. Sonny Perdue asked God to forgive Georgia for being wasteful with its water, county officials in the wealthy suburbs northeast of Atlanta confirmed Wednesday just how profligate one consumer had been.

title: U.S. Working to Develop and Launch Cheaper Satellites
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14  Chinas success in shooting down one of its own satellites last January has given new energy to efforts in the United States to develop and launch more  and cheaper  satellites.

title: Canada Ends Case Against Aid Worker
description: Canadas attorney general has ended the prosecution of an American refugee aid worker, Janet Hinshaw-Thomas, who had been accused of immigrant trafficking, her lawyer said. Ms. Hinshaw-Thomas, 65, was arrested Sept. 26 at a Canadian border station in Quebec as she accompanied 12 Haitians planning to seek asylum in Canada. The attorney general, Robert Nicholson, ordered a stay of the prosecution on Nov. 8, without explanation, and this week returned $5,000 bail to Ms. Hinshaw-Thomas, said her lawyer, Eric Sutton. Ms. Hinshaw-Thomas, the director of a refugee assistance group in Lansdowne, Pa., said she was giving charitable help to the Haitians

title: 100-to-1 Rule
description: Congress did a serious injustice when it imposed much tougher penalties on defendants convicted of selling the crack form of cocaine  the kind most often used in impoverished, minority communities  than on those caught selling the powdered form of the drug that is popular with more upscale users.

title: Excerpts From Two Letters Written by a 21-Year-Old Mitt Romney
description: During his 30 months as a Mormon missionary in France, Mitt Romney became close friends with two fellow missionaries, Charles Ryan and Dane McBride. Mr. McBride showed The New York Times a few letters Mr. Romney sent his friends near the end of his stint in France, including these two sent in December 1968 shortly before his departure.

title: Barry Bonds Is Indicted for Perjury Tied to Drug Case
description: Barry Bonds, who holds two of baseballs most cherished records, was indicted in San Francisco today on four counts of perjury in connection with his testimony about his use of performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Congress and the Mortgage Mess
description: The House will vote today on much needed legislation to curtail abusive mortgage lending. Last minute lobbying to weaken the bill is coming from all corners: from brokers who hawked the junk loans, lenders who advanced the cash and Wall Street banks that bought the loans and repackaged them into securities for sale to investors. Having profited so immensely during the mortgage bubble, they now want to keep the world safe for future financial excesses.

title: Caught on a Block That Conjures Up the Wild West
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 14  When 13-year-old Elijah Henderson rode a bicycle onto a stretch of Fulton Street early on Monday  and was then killed by a gunshot to the back of the head  he crossed a perilous boundary not found on any map.

title: Romney, Searching and Earnest, Set His Path in 60s
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  In December 1968, Mitt Romney returned home from a Mormon mission in France to find a changed country.

title: Airport Screeners Missed Explosives, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP)  Government investigators smuggled liquid explosives and detonators through airport checkpoints, exposing dangerous vulnerabilities in security efforts, according to a report made public Wednesday.

title: Mom and Dad and All Their Baggage
description: IT sounds like something out of a sitcom: A retired mother in her 50s comes to stay in her single daughters cramped Manhattan apartment, and nerves quickly fray. So a couple of years ago, when Heather Cameron arrived from Scotland for one of her frequent weeklong visits, her daughter, Jacqueline Cameron, was prepared for some aggravation.

title: When Poland Meets Italy, a Match Turns on Bidding
description: The Sixth European Champions Cup took place last weekend in Wroclaw, Poland. The 12 teams from 11 countries (two from Poland) were divided into two sections of six, each playing a round robin of 20-board matches. Four teams qualified for 48-board semifinals. These led to a 48-board final between teams from Poland and Italy. Sygnity AZS Politechnika Wroclaw was represented by Cezary Balicki, Adam Zmudzinski, Alexander Dubinin, Andrei Gromov, Wojciech Olanski and Wlodzimierz Starkowski. Playing for Tennis Club Parioli were Francesco Angelini, Dano De Falco, Fulvio Fantoni, Claudio Nunes, Lorenzo Lauria and Alfredo Versace, who qualified by winning last years Italian Club Championship.

title: Judge Stays Execution, Citing Case Under Review
description: MIAMI, Nov. 14  Citing a pending Supreme Court ruling on the constitutionality of lethal injection methods, a federal judge granted a stay of execution on Wednesday for a man who had been scheduled to die on Thursday evening for the rape and murder of an 11-year-old boy.

title: Prospect of New York Protest sends Ellen Degeneres Home
description: Ellen DeGeneres, right, will not tape two editions of her syndicated show in New York next week, ending the prospect of especially fervent protests from striking members of the Writers Guild of America. News of the canceled New York tapings, first reported yesterday on the Web site DeadlineHollywoodDaily.com, was confirmed by representatives of Ms. DeGeneress production company, Telepictures. Ms. DeGeneres returned to her syndicated daily talk show last week after sitting out just one day of the strike. That decision drew strong protests from the Writers Guild because Ms. DeGeneres is a member of the union. Her writers have been on strike, but Ms. DeGeneres has said she felt obligated to continue taping shows because other staff members would otherwise be laid off. She received support from a different union, Aftra, which argued in a letter to the Writers Guild that Ms. DeGeneres was obligated as a member to continue to work. Her supporters also noted that unlike other shows, including those of Jay Leno and David Letterman, Ms. DeGeneress is syndicated and could be canceled if obligations were not met. The guild countered that Ms. DeGeneres should have made a personal decision to support the writers. Cancellation of the New York shows does not mean Ms. DeGeneres has joined the strike. She will simply tape the shows at her regular studio in Los Angeles, a representative of the show said.

title: With Eye on 08, House Takes on Mortgage Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  Facing the increasing prospect of a Congressional election season colored by economic uncertainty, lawmakers are moving to ease their political exposure on the home-loan crisis.

title: Georgias Future Looks Like More of the Past
description: TBILISI, Georgia, Nov. 15  Educated in America, fluent in four languages and in the values of free-market democracies, Mikheil Saakashvili was supposed to have been different. When he was elected president of Georgia after a bloodless revolution in 2003, he was deemed a savior for the post-Soviet landscape, as if he had been conjured by a committee of Washington think tanks and European human rights groups.

title: Never Miss That Tune From Your Favorite Artists Again
description: In a world where fancy graphics exist on a device as small as a mobile phone, the radio receivers offered by Sirius Satellite Radio and XM Satellite Radio have remained pretty much stuck in the 1990s, often sporting single-line monochrome text displays. Which is why the new XpressRC after-market receiver offered by XM is such a welcome addition to its lineup.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, the About New York column on Saturday, about Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York police commissioner, referred incorrectly in some editions to the judge who presided over Mr. Keriks arraignment on federal tax fraud charges in Federal District Court in White Plains. It was Magistrate Judge George A. Yanthis  not Judge Stephen C. Robinson, the trial judge assigned to the case.

title: A Sound-Bite Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: After Three Games in 12 Days, the Cowboys Could Be Alone at No. 1
description: IRVING, Tex., Nov. 14  Defensive end Marcus Spears leaned back into his locker Wednesday, trying to capture one last relaxing moment before Cowboys practice.

title: Dont Shut Up and Play
description: The game of bridge could almost be a game of international diplomacy, except that its not. It involves strategy, bluffing, up-to-the-minute awareness of the state of play, accurate, but veiled, communication between partners and a feel for the opponents hand that is part instinct, part deduction. But bridge rarely alludes to the real world, except when the American womens bridge team  winners of this years Venice Cup  displayed a small sign at an awards dinner in Shanghai last month. It said: We did not vote for Bush.

title: Britain Plans to Upgrade Terror Security Measures
description: LONDON, Nov. 14  Prime Minister Gordon Brown said Wednesday that Britain would begin improving security at train stations, airports, utility buildings and other crowded or strategic places to lessen their vulnerability to terrorist attacks.

title: Hokum That Stands the Test of Time
description: LOS ANGELES  Before I arrived here, a flier was in my mailbox, an advertisement for China China  Le Grand Cirque. It described an unprecedented dimension of body control, acrobatic precision and unbelievable capability.

title: Gap Campaigns Against Child Labor
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 15  Gap began an effort to rebuild its reputation after a damaging child-labor scandal in India, announcing a package of measures today intended to tighten its commitment to eradicating the exploitation of children in the manufacture of its goods.

title: Crew Involved in Bay Oil Spill Refuses to Talk
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14  The captain and crewmen of a Chinese ship responsible for an oil spill after hitting the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge have refused to speak to federal investigators, a spokesman for the National Transportation Safety Board said Wednesday. But the local pilot who was guiding the ship told investigators that its radar had malfunctioned shortly before the accident.

title: Giuliani Ties New Job Hopes to Old
description: This is the first television advertisement for Rudolph W. Giulianis presidential campaign, to run beginning today in New Hampshire.

title: Days of Creative Ferment in Gloriously Hazy Focus
description: The Performa 07 festival took a break from live programming this week, presenting two evenings of early-postmodern dance recordings at Anthology Film Archives. Much of the mainly black-and-white film in the program, titled Dance After Choreography, was blurry, damaged or poorly shot, and watching it with a host of familiar contemporary dancers and choreographers was rather like settling in for a session of family vacation reels, complete with wry commentary from various generations of New York performers.

title: Longtime Collaborators Stay in Shape, Exploring Some Modern Milestones
description: With a few notable exceptions string quartet players agree, if only tacitly, to devote their musical efforts mainly to the ensemble. But there is something to be said for musicians who keep their solo prerogatives open. The benefits would seem obvious enough. By getting their hands and interpretive sensibilities around a different repertory, and having some time in the spotlight, they keep their sound and musicianship fresh. And unless the lure of the solo life is unusually strong, this can only benefit the quartet.

title: I.B.M. to Push Cloud Computing, Using Data From Afar
description: I.B.M. plans to build a sizable business by bringing Google-style computing to mainstream corporate customers.

title: Corrections
description: An editorial on Monday about Kosovos bid for independence incorrectly described the circumstances behind the NATO intervention in Kosovo in 1999. NATO launched military action to stop Serbias repression of the ethnically Albanian majority in Kosovo, a province of Serbia. Serbia did not invade Kosovo. (Go to Article)

title: Manning Critics Turn Up the Volume
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 14  First, his brother. Then Philip Rivers and Ben Roethlisberger. Now Tony Romo.

title: Talks Set in Stagehands Strike
description: The producers league and the stagehands union have agreed to meet on Saturday for negotiations for the first time since talks ended last Thursday and the stagehands then went on strike.

title: French Strike Continues a Second Day
description: PARIS, Nov. 15  French labor unions met today on whether to prolong a national transport strike that crippled rail services and local transit networks for a second day.

title: The Last Word in Unattainable Luxury
description: Shown on Thursday: 2008 Lamborghini Reventn

title: Cheap, but in a Good Way
description: Introduced on Wednesday: 2009 Lincoln MKS

title: U.S. Sharing Intelligence With Turkey
description: IZMIR, Turkey, Nov 14  The United States has begun to share real-time intelligence with Turkey to assist in its efforts to track down separatist Kurdish rebels hiding in northern Iraq, Ali Babacan, the Turkish foreign minister said on Wednesday.

title: Old Brookville: Rock Kills Car Passenger
description: A three-pound rock smashed through the windshield of a moving automobile here yesterday morning and killed an elderly passenger, the police said. the Old Brookville Police and Nassau County Police began an investigation. The driver, Marie Waters of Bayville, was traveling north on Route 107, through wooded areas near Glen Head and Chicken Valley Roads, when the rock struck the car about 10:15 a.m., the police said. The rock crashed through the windshield and struck Ms. Waterss mother, Ria Oill, 75, also of Bayville. She was taken to North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, where she was pronounced dead.

title: High Court Blocks Florida Execution
description: MIAMI, Nov. 15  The United States Supreme Court blocked the execution of a convicted child killer in Florida today less than five hours before the inmate was scheduled to die by lethal injection.

title: Illness Strikes Disabled Children in Baghdad Home, Killing One
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 14  One child from a Baghdad home for the severely disabled died and 12 others were hospitalized over the weekend with serious diarrhea and dehydration, government officials and doctors acknowledged Wednesday.

title: Towering Vision by Developer Stirs East Side
description: Sheldon H. Solows black Mercedes 500 glided across a wind-swept lot near the East River where he is seeking to turn the former site of Con Edisons Waterside power plants into a luxury development on what is the largest stretch of undeveloped, privately owned land in Manhattan.

title: Challenges Awaiting, Mukasey Takes Ceremonial Oath
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  In taking a ceremonial oath of office as the 81st attorney general of the United States, Michael B. Mukasey made no reference at all Wednesday to the trouble he faces in assuming control of the Justice Department for the last 14 months of the Bush administration.

title: Medal of Arts Winners
description: The artist Andrew Wyeth was among nine recipients of the National Medal of Arts announced yesterday by President Bush. The nominations were managed by the National Endowment for the Arts. At a ceremony in the White House other recipients of the medal, the nations highest honor for artistic excellence, were the composer Morten Lauridsen; the author, essayist, poet, professor and painter N. Scott Momaday; the arts patron Roy R. Neuberger; the Old Globe Theater founding director Craig Noel; the guitarist and inventor Les Paul; the arts patron Henry Steinway; the painter George Tooker; and the Lionel Hampton International Jazz Festival at the University of Idaho.

title: Police Shooting Puts Focus on Mental Crisis Teams
description: As the last chaotic day of Khiel Coppins life unfolded on Monday, an unmarked white sport utility vehicle arrived at his home on Gates Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn. Out came a team of crisis counselors from Interfaith Medical Center, a hospital about a mile away.

title: Yazoo Pumps Project
description: To the Editor:

title: Vatican City: Catholic-Orthodox Accord on Papal Primacy
description: Efforts to reunite the Roman Catholic and Orthodox churches, split for nearly 1,000 years, took a cautious step forward as a joint commission agreed that the pope has primacy over bishops of both churches. But a declaration, to be officially released today, states that the two sides had not agreed on exactly what authority the pope might exercise if the churches came together again. Pope Benedict XVI has declared full communion between the churches a central goal of his papacy, though relations with the Russian Orthodox have proved particularly difficult. The Russian church did not approve the new document.

title: Rumors, Merger Talk and Denial by Airlines
description: Long-simmering talk of an inevitable round of airline industry mergers heated up again yesterday. By the end of the day, after a spike in their share prices, the central players in any merger talks, dismissed the rumors as just that.

title: Being Measured for a Bit of Sweden
description: IN a hotel room in Midtown, customers crowded onto sofas and chairs or stood patiently waiting for a custom fitting. The floor of the room was covered with samples of brightly colored wood-soled shoes. Cecilia Tidlund, the clog lady, was back in town.

title: Break-In at Nuclear Site Baffles South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 14  This much is known: Just after midnight on Nov. 8, Anton Gerber was sitting with his fiance in the control room of South Africas most secretive nuclear facility, the site at which this nations apartheid government conceived and delivered six atomic bombs, when four gunmen burst into the room. Mr. Gerber pushed his fiance under a desk. The attackers shot him in the chest, grabbed a computer and fled, but abandoned their booty as they came under assault by guards.

title: Two Cities Linked by Design
description: The area surrounding Chausseestrasse, a former no mans land where a wall once stood in Berlin, may not seem to invite immediate comparisons with the Red Hook section of Brooklyn. But architects and urban planners see parallels in the rapid growth of both of these formerly gritty neighborhoods, particularly in how the arts have spurred gentrification.

title: Forget Waterloo: London Has a New Route to Paris
description: PARIS, Nov. 14  When it came to promoting the start on Wednesday of its new high-speed rail link between Paris and London, the train operator, Eurostar, took a gamble on French sensibilities.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Saturday about President Bushs meetings with families who have lost relatives in the war in Iraq referred incorrectly to a meeting between Cindy Sheehan, an opponent of the war, and the president. The meeting took place in 2004, not 2005, and Ms. Sheehan complained later  not immediately after the meeting  that President Bush had been dismissive of her.

title: Scientists Use Monkey Clones to Extract Stem Cells
description: Researchers in Oregon are reporting that they used cloning to produce monkey embryos and then extracted stem cells from the embryos.

title: St. Johns Struggles but Finds Its Way
description: So young and inexperienced, St. Johns figures to have plenty of nights like this one. Playing six freshmen, the Red Storm struggled for most of the night before edging St. Francis of Brooklyn, 72-64, in its season opener at Carnesecca Arena.

title: ID Cards for Residents Pass a Vote in California
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14  The San Francisco Board of Supervisors has given preliminary approval to an ordinance allowing municipal identification cards to be issued to anyone living in the city, regardless of their legal status.

title: Vietnam War Novel Wins National Book Award
description: Tree of Smoke, a sweeping novel by Denis Johnson about the Vietnam War that features intersecting stories of an array of American and Vietnamese soldiers and intelligence officers, won the National Book Award for fiction last night.

title: In Las Vegas, Chance for Clinton to Undo Damage
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton heads into tonights Democratic presidential debate in Las Vegas with an opportunity: to try to erase the unflattering image that her chief rivals, and her own mistakes, have helped create.

title: Home & Garden Calendar
description: Maps as Mirrors

title: Ford Workers Approve a Four-Year Contract
description: DETROIT, Nov. 14  United Automobile Workers members at Ford Motor approved a new four-year contract by the widest margin of any auto company, the union said on Wednesday.

title: Greenwich Village With Peach Trees
description: Atlanta

title: Manhattan: Indictment in Brokers Killing
description: A personal assistant accused of killing her boss, Linda S. Stein, a prominent real estate agent who once managed the punk rock group the Ramones, was indicted yesterday on murder charges. Prosecutors said the assistant, Natavia S. Lowery, 26, of Brooklyn, was scheduled for arraignment on Nov. 27. The police have charged that Ms. Lowery beat Ms. Stein to death with a piece of exercise equipment on Oct. 30, and afterward told the police that her boss had mistreated her. She is being held without bail. As Ms. Lowery was led from State Supreme Court yesterday, relatives and supporters rose and shouted encouragement.

title: Correction: The Plight of American Veterans
description: Because of a calculation error by the National Alliance to End Homelessness, an editorial on Monday about the plight of American veterans included an incorrect estimate for the number of veterans who were homeless at some point in 2006. The alliances revised estimate is 336,627, not 495,400.

title: John McCain and the Character Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Is Looking Past Musharraf in Case He Falls
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  Almost two weeks into Pakistans political crisis, Bush administration officials are losing faith that the Pakistani president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, can survive in office and have begun discussing what might come next, according to senior administration officials.

title: Leaders of Two Striking Entertainment Unions Clash
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14  The entertainment industrys labor dispute boiled over anew yesterday, with the leaders of two striking unions criticizing each other and the Walt Disney Company lambasting the tactics of a third guild.

title: Sprechen Sie Deutsch, Vista?
description: Q. Is it possible to change the language of the menus and dialog boxes in Windows Vista?

title: Governors Pushing Caps on Greenhouse Gases
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  Frustrated with the slow progress of energy and global warming legislation in Washington, the nations governors have created regional agreements to cap greenhouse gases and are engaged in a concerted lobbying effort to prod Congress to act.

title: With Many Shows Out, Theatergoers Venture Into the Unknown
description: As Broadway theatergoers know, there is a board at the TKTS discount tickets booth on 46th Street listing the available shows. On a typical Wednesday afternoon, the side of the board listing Broadway shows is lighted up with familiar names like Curtains, Chicago and A Chorus Line.

title: Federers Ability to Dominate May Be Coming to an End
description: SHANGHAI, Nov. 14  Is mens tennis finally becoming more competitive?

title: A New Effort to Remove Bad Teachers
description: The Bloomberg administration is beginning a drive to remove unsatisfactory teachers, hiring new teams of lawyers and consultants who will help principals build cases against tenured teachers who they believe are not up to the job. It is also urging principals to get rid of sub-par novices before they earn tenure.

title: Ohios Charter Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Dont Turn on Ethiopia
description: Washington

title: Chicago Police Abuse Cases Exceed Average
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 14  Chicago police officers are the subject of more brutality complaints per officer than the national average, and the Police Department is far less likely to pursue abuse cases seriously than the national norm, a legal team at the University of Chicago reported Wednesday.

title: Macys Reports a Profit, but Shares Fall on Forecast
description: Macys, the owner of its namesake store chain and Bloomingdales, had a third-quarter profit after limiting expenses. But the retailer cut its fourth-quarter sales forecast, sending its shares lower.

title: Did Chappelle Ever Inspire a Look?
description: THEY may not have shared her moxie or wicked sense of irony, but some of the fans who flocked to see Sarah Silverman practice her barbed brand of comedy at Carnegie Hall last week paid homage to her sedulously cultivated Jewish homegirl style. Among the more audacious was Danny Friedman, who had driven down from Yale with a carload of friends to catch the show. Mr. Friedman and his grinning cohort showed off cascades of jet-tone acrylic hair  Sarah Silverman wigs, they said, which they had purchased at a drugstore on the road.

title: The Governor in His Labyrinth
description: When Gov. Eliot Spitzer dropped his proposal to make drivers licenses available to undocumented immigrants yesterday, he sowed disappointment and anger among many of his supporters  who felt, rightly, that they had been left holding the bag. His original plan to make highways safer and the state more secure was the right idea. But New Yorks embattled governor did not handle it properly, first waffling on his principles under pressure from the Bush administration, and then slowly recognizing that he was endangering the rest of his agenda by knocking over the hornets nest that is the nations immigration debate.

title: A Mentor of Street Ball Dies, and a Missing Knick Appears
description: A gleaming white Cadillac with a license plate reading MISTERLU, its engine off, was parked next to a basketball court in a Coney Island housing project last night.

title: German Rail Strike Disrupts Travel and Freight
description: FRANKFURT, Nov. 15  A bitter three-day strike by train drivers in Germany has tied up freight traffic, shut down an auto factory and stranded hundreds of thousands of passengers, in what has become the largest work stoppage in the history of the German state railway system.

title: U.S. Ponders War Message, and How Best to Deliver It
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  When Representative Ellen O. Tauscher of California, a senior Democrat on the Armed Services Committee, visited Iraq in late summer for a firsthand view of the war, she was greeted by American soldiers and Iraqi officials who seemed to know a lot about her.

title: Mets Say Theyll Pay to Acquire Top Pitcher
description: Omar Minaya left the general managers meetings last week with a pretty good understanding of how to improve the Mets. He has an idea of how much money it will take to sign his desired free-agent targets. And he knows which prospects  and how many  he would have to surrender if the team is to fill its biggest need: upgrading its pitching staff.

title: Fed to Share More of Its Thinking in Its Reports
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  The Federal Reserve said Wednesday that it would take some of the mystery out of its decision-making, disclosing far more information about its economic forecasts  and, implicitly, about its objectives for growth and inflation.

title: Court Rejects Fuel-Economy Standards
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15  A federal appeals court here rejected the Bush administrations year-old fuel-economy standards for light trucks and sport utility vehicles today. It said the rules were not tough enough because regulators had failed to thoroughly assess the economic impact of tailpipe emissions that contribute to climate change.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: After Debate, F.D.A. Backs Sale of Diabetes Medicine
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  After a fierce internal debate, federal drug officials have decided to allow Avandia, the controversial diabetes medicine, to remain on the market but insisted that a new warning about its heart risks be placed on its label.

title: Port Authority Raising Tolls and PATH Fares
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said today that it has proposed eliminating discounts for customers who use EZ-Pass during peak hours on its crossings between New Jersey and Manhattan and Staten Island.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the results of recent DNA testing on the remains of the Notre Dame football legend George Gipp, which showed he did not father a child with an 18-year-old high school student in 1920, contained several incorrect references. The woman who had claimed to be Gipps daughter was Bette Weeks  not Easton, which is the surname of her daughter Ellen. Weeks was born five days after Gipp died, not four. The DNA testing that knocked down the paternity claim involved a tissue sample from Weeks, not a blood sample. Gipps gravesite is near  not in  his hometown, Laurium, Mich. And the headline, which highlighted protests in Gipps hometown, went beyond the article, which did not address such concerns.

title: Governors Join in Creating Regional Pacts on Climate Change
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  Frustrated with the slow progress of legislation in Washington on energy and global warming, the nations governors have created regional agreements to cap greenhouse gases and are engaged in a concerted lobbying effort to prod Congress to act.

title: Trying to Divine the Three Phases of Jim Dolan
description: There are few assets James L. Dolan adores as much as his own glorious head of hair, which he lavishly coifs to Mitt Romney perfection. But as with all of his loves, Dolan can turn on his follicles, too.

title: Vintage 2007
description: WHY are midcentury modern antiques dealers now manufacturing and selling new furniture? Its a function of price and availability, explained Paula Rubenstein, a SoHo antiques dealer who has been watching the trend. Even though dealers will pay the price of increasingly expensive goods, they cant necessarily find them at any price.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,851 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Tuesday:

title: Goldmans Shadow Extends Far Past Wall St.
description: As John A. Thain prepares to take the reins of Merrill Lynch, he is only the latest example of a tradition borne out across Wall Street, in Washington and around the world. He is a Goldman Sachs alumnus who has reached the top elsewhere.

title: Movement That Rides on a Pulse of Its Own
