description: In a discussion for the Works & Process series at the Guggenheim Museum on Monday, Ohad Naharin explained how his movement language, called Gaga, helps dancers focus on the space between the navel and groin: You can ride on it and discover your power.

title: You Say Fake Ads, They Say Satire
description: CALLING all Roys or Troys or Leroys, began an ad posted to Craigslist in October. A photo of a heart-shaped tattoo with Roy inside accompanied the ad, which continued: I was with a Roy before but it didnt last as long as my tattoo. Getting the tattoo removed is not something I want to do, plus Im so accustomed to bellowing it (Roy) out in bed. The writer said she was seeking a new Roy, or anyone whose name could be inked around the word, Scrabble-style.

title: Reagan in Philadelphia, Miss.: The Sequel
description: To the Editor:

title: L.P.G.A. to Start Testing for Performance-Enhancing Drugs
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 14  Professional golfers will be subject to the same drug-screening scrutiny in 2008 as athletes in other sports. The L.P.G.A. Tour announced Wednesday that it would begin conducting random tests to screen golfers for performance-enhancing drugs when the season begins in January.

title: What Happens in Vegas ...
description: Im sure you are excited about the big presidential candidate debate tonight. Nothing in the previous 25 dramatic clashes of the political titans this season can come close to it. Although we did like that moment when Dennis Kucinich revealed that he had spied a U.F.O. at Shirley MacLaines house.

title: Brooklyn Butoh, With Surprise Guest Stars
description: The art of Butoh, exhaustively explored in the New York Butoh Festival this month and last at several New York locations, including Japan Society, has always seemed a ferociously intense theater-dance form with an unyielding grip on life, death and other themes. So a solo by Atsushi Takenouchi, which opened a week of programs at Cave, was something of a surprise. What made the 90-minute event come alive was not so much Mr. Takenouchis piece, Skin: Improvisation No. 1, but the ambient or unplanned effects that accompanied it.

title: Twin Sons of Different Mothers
description: Introduced on Wednesday: 2009 Pontiac Vibe and Toyota Matrix

title: The Fonda Factor
description: IF Debbie Hollingshead hadnt fallen in love with Cathe Friedrichs hairdo  a soft, feathered pixie cut evocative of Dorothy Hamill  her life would not be what it is today.

title: Just Put Your Face in the Little Box and Say Aah
description: AT 23, Alison Muckle never worried about crows-feet or sunspots. So a year ago, when her sister, Zoe Morel, then 27, suggested that they get a free skin analysis at a Sephora outpost, she said sure.

title: Oprah Picks Follett Novel
description: A 973-page Ken Follett best seller is the latest Oprah Winfrey selection for her book club, The Associated Press reported. Published in 1989, the novel is The Pillars of the Earth, a love story set in England in the 12th century. Ms. Winfrey called Mr. Follett a best-selling author that everybody has heard of, but this novel is unlike any of his books hes known for around the world. Mr. Follett, 58, a native of Cardiff, Wales, whose many novels include the thrillers Eye of the Needle, The Key to Rebecca and Night Over Water, has called The Pillars of the Earth his favorite novel.

title: Shakespeares New House Makes Room for Marlowe
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12  Big glass boxes are popping up wherever you look in the capital. On every other corner sits a gleaming new building housing condominiums or corporations or lobbyists, or a vast construction site cleared for same. Soon these new-model monoliths will outnumber the old piles of white marble that have long dominated the cityscape.

title: Chile: Strong Quake Hits Mining Region
description: A powerful magnitude 7.7 earthquake struck in the copper-producing north, killing at least two people, injuring more than 100, flattening houses, causing power outages and panic, and disrupting output at a number of mines. Chile is the worlds biggest copper producer. The quake, centered near the city of Calama, caused shock waves in Santiago, the capital, 780 miles away, and was felt in Peru and Bolivia. It struck at 12:40 p.m. local time. Television stations showed people running out of buildings, students evacuating schools and a car smashed by the collapse of a roof overhang at a hotel in the coastal mining city of Antofagasta.

title: Sorcery, Lust, Chinatown and Opium: Its All Opera
description: The popular soprano Aprile Millo was scheduled to appear in Italo Montemezzis Incantesimo, the second of two one-act operas on fortune-telling themes performed in concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday evening, but it was apparently not in the cards. Along with Franco Leonis Oracolo, it was presented, without Ms. Millo, by Teatro Grattacielo, which specializes in rare verismo operas.

title: Queens: Delay in Police Shooting Trial
description: A justice in State Supreme Court rescheduled the trial of the three detectives charged in the shooting of Sean Bell from Jan. 7 to Feb. 4 yesterday after lawyers for the detectives requested an extra month to prepare for the case, said Michael J. Palladino, president of the Detectives Endowment Association. The rescheduling came during a brief hearing yesterday that the detectives, Michael Oliver, Gescard F. Isnora and Marc Cooper, watched in silence. Mr. Bell, 23, died in a volley of 50 gunshots from the police as he and two friends were leaving his bachelor party in Jamaica on Nov. 25, 2006, unaware that they were being followed by Detective Isnora, who was under cover. He has said he believed that the men were armed; no gun was found. Detectives Oliver and Isnora face manslaughter charges, while Detective Cooper faces two misdemeanor charges of reckless endangerment.

title: Ex-Hostage Says, Dont Fault the Brave Foreign Service
description: To the Editor:

title: Airlines Work on Systems to Reduce Delays
description: FORT WORTH  At any given moment, the airline industrys powerful networks of computers are setting fares, tracking reservations and calculating how much fuel each plane needs to reach its destination.

title: World Bank Reports Progress in Sub-Saharan Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 14  After enduring decades of economic collapse and stagnation, many countries in sub-Saharan Africa have turned a corner and are now growing economically at rates comparable to rates in the rest of the developing world, according to a report released Wednesday by the World Bank.

title: Lawmaker Killed in Manila Bombing Linked to Insurgents in 90s
description: MANILA, Nov. 14  Philippine officials said Wednesday that the congressman killed Tuesday in a bombing outside the House of Representatives had once been a member of an insurgent group linked to Al Qaeda before he switched loyalties and began supporting the government in Manila.

title: Last-Minute Loophole
description: Washington

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Nov. 6 about the comparison of electricity prices between states where they are set by the market and states where they are set by regulators misstated a measure of electricity for nuclear power plants, which in unregulated states have at times charged for power they had offered to give away during low-demand hours. The price is per megawatt-hour, not kilowatt-hour. (Go to Article)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Nov. 6 about the comparison of electricity prices between states where they are set by the market and states where they are set by regulators misstated a measure of electricity for nuclear power plants, which in unregulated states have at times charged for power they had offered to give away during low-demand hours. The price is per megawatt-hour, not kilowatt-hour.

title: Case Is Dropped Against Crusading Street Performer
description: The Manhattan district attorneys office quietly dropped its prosecution today of Reverend Billy, a street performer accused of harassing police officers by reciting the First Amendment at a rally in Union Square Park.

title: 8 Democrats Pose Hurdle for Childrens Health Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  Congressional efforts to expand the State Childrens Health Insurance Program have run into a new roadblock. Eight Democratic senators say they cannot support any compromise that limits their states ability to cover parents along with children.

title: Tip of the Week: Smarter Browsing
description: If you find yourself going to the same old Web sites for information on your favorite subjects, a free browser add-on can help you. Stumble-Upon at www.stumbleupon.com, offers sites recommended by millions of other StumbleUpon users who have shared and rated their discoveries. Once you download and install the add-on, you are prompted to choose a few topics of interest. When you click the Stumble button on the browser toolbar, you are offered links that other users have stumbled upon.

title: Struggling Team Now Confronts a Major Rift
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14  Stephon Marbury returned to the Knicks on Wednesday, and the team got a little closer to whole, though not necessarily closer to normal.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a plan in Europe to impose quotas on the emission of carbon dioxide by airlines misstated at one point the entity that gave the plan preliminary approval. It was the European Parliament, not the European Union.

title: A Genetically Re-Engineered Cat
description: Introduced on Wednesday: Jaguar XF

title: Imponderable? Readers Have Their Say
description: David Pogue is away on a Geek Cruise, but before leaving he posted to his blog the latest collection of answers to Pogues Imponderables, and threw out a few more tech mysteries for readers to consider. A selection of their answers follows; you can read them in full here.

title: Salome Gluecksohn-Waelsch, 100, Geneticist, Is Dead
description: Salome Gluecksohn-Waelsch, a geneticist who had fled Nazi Germany to pursue her studies and whose subsequent research in New York shed light on fundamental questions of development in mammals, died Nov. 7 at her home in Manhattan. She was 100.

title: Hello, Vacation: Its the Boss
description: I JUST booked a brief vacation, to a warm place, now that the weather is finally turning cold and the holidays loom. I clicked through all the usual disclaimers on the travel Web site  the hotel is nonrefundable; changes to flights can be made only with a hefty fee. Then I turned my attention to trip-cancellation insurance, and something new appeared.

title: Wrapped in a Veil of Glamour, the Familiar Wit of Rodgers and Hart
description: Andrea Marcovicci doesnt sugarcoat the unhappy life of the lyricist Lorenz Hart in her new cabaret show devoted to the songs of Rodgers and Hart at the Oak Room at the Algonquin Hotel. After declaring Hart her favorite of all the writers of American popular song, she calls him the lonely Romeo of his generation.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q.  What is a good alternative to conventional hardwood flooring?

title: Sending a Scent by Snail Mail
description: LONDON

title: 5 Officers Who Killed Man Never Shot Anyone Before
description: None of the five officers who fired 20 bullets in Mondays fatal shooting of a troubled 18-year-old man in Brooklyn had ever shot at a person before in a combined 62 years of police service, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Newly Released
description: November is a big book month. Both literally (one of this months entries clocks in at 1,150 pages) and, publishers hope, in sales. Among those scrambling for the best-seller lists in coming weeks will be a new sequel to Gone With the Wind and the latest installment in David Baldaccis Camel Club franchise. Then theres a slim volume arguing that you dont actually need to read books to talk about them. Do you need to read it? Thats up to you.

title: Loving and Hating Marc Jacobs
description: THE New York Post began its review with a question: What is wrong with Marc Jacobs?

title: HSBC Takes $3.4 Billion Charge
description: Two investment banks said yesterday that they would take additional write-downs because of problems related to the housing market.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Oct. 31 about a new work by the choreographer John Jasperse, Misuse liable to prosecution, misstated the daily cost of the war in Iraq, using a figure given by Mr. Jasperse when he recites a list of numbers in the work. It is about $330 million, according to an estimate by the Congressional Research Service, not $720 million. (That figure is an estimate by the American Friends Service Committee, and includes long-term health care for veterans and debt interest, among other factors.)

title: Illinois: Students Allowed to Return to Class
description: Students who faced possible expulsion for participating in an antiwar protest at their suburban Chicago high school will be allowed to return to class, school officials said. More than two dozen students were at risk of being expelled after holding a sit-in Nov. 1 at Morton West High School in Berwyn. Four students deemed more culpable for the protest against the war in Iraq will remain suspended until Friday, school officials said.

title: Dropping License Plan Wins Praise for Spitzer
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  A day after abandoning his proposal to give drivers licenses to illegal immigrants, Gov. Eliot Spitzer won the kind of wide acclaim from elected officials that he could not win for the proposal itself.

title: NYSE Chief Is Chosen to Lead Merrill Lynch
description: John A. Thain won plaudits as Wall Streets Mr. Fix-It by revitalizing the embattled New York Stock Exchange. Now, he faces what could be a more formidable challenge: turning around Merrill Lynch, the once-proud Wall Street firm battered by losses from the mortgage debacle.

title: Israelis Press Plan to Block the Division of Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 14  The Israeli Parliament gave preliminary approval on Wednesday to a bill intended to hinder any division of Jerusalem in a future deal with the Palestinians. The vote came as Israels rightist and religious parties started positioning themselves before an American-sponsored peace gathering expected to take place in Annapolis, Md., this month.

title: Jay-Zs 10th No. 1
description: An American Gangster is gunning for the Beatles. That latest Jay-Z album, inspired by the film of the same name, has become his 10th No. 1 album, tying him for second place with Elvis Presley for the most albums to top the Billboard chart; the Beatles have a big lead, with 19. American Gangster (Def Jam) sold 425,000 copies in the United States, Nielsen SoundScan reported. The Eagles Long Road Out of Eden (Eagles Recording Co.), last weeks No. 1, fell one spot with 359,000 sales. Garth Brookss new collection, The Ultimate Hits (Pearl), opened at No. 3 with 352,000, and the 18-year-old R&B singer Chris Brown bowed at No. 4 with Exclusive (Jive), moving 294,000. Carrie Underwood dropped two spots to No. 3, and Britney Spears is at No. 7, down five in her second week of release.

title: Alex Rodriguez Talks to Yankees Without Agent
description: Alex Rodriguez said all season that he wanted to stay with the Yankees, and now he is finally backing up those statements.

title: The New Green? At VW, Its Blue
description: Introduced on Wednesday: Volkswagen space up! blue Concept

title: Kramnik Leads Tal Memorial, Followed Closely by Carlsen and Mamedyarov
From Audi, Fourward Thinking
description: Introduced on Wednesday: Audi Cross Cabriolet quattro concept

title: Oceanic and Native North American Art
description: Images from the New Galleries for Oceanic Art and Native North American Art in the Michael C. Rockefeller Wing at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Coupe de Show
description: Introduced on Wednesday: Hyundai Concept Genesis Coupe

title: Thursdays Links: Fishing for a Starter
description: So the Dolphins (0-9) finally gave up on Cleo Lemon and replaced him with the rookie John Beck. Hallelujah! says the Miami Heralds Greg Cote. But are you really surprised? Lemon started five games for the Dolphins in the past two seasons and lost them all. He had more touchdowns rushing (four) than passing (three) this season, and the longest completion of his career went for 38 yards. In a city where many still worship Dan Marino, that wont do.

title: You Say Fake Ads, They Say Satire
description: Question: Is it fake or is it Craigslist?

title: Lazards New Energy Head Sees No Deal Slowdown
description: For the new chairman of Lazards global energy practice, Bruce Bilger, the energy industry remains far removed from the slowdown that has gripped deal activity since mid-summer. Indeed, he told DealBook this week that he expects mergers and acquisitions to remain strong across all sectors.

title: A.I.G. Announces $8 Billion Buyback Plan
description: American International Group, the giant insurance company, said Wednesday that it had approved the repurchase of an additional $8 billion in stock.

title: Buffett Says No Estate Tax Would Be a Gift to the Rich
description: Warren E. Buffett urged Congress Wednesday to maintain the estate tax, saying that plans to repeal the tax would benefit a handful of the richest American families and widen income disparity in the United States.

title: Investors Take Wind Out of Och-Ziff Debut
description: Shares of the $30 billion hedge fund Och-Ziff Capital Management Group fell 4.2 percent Wednesday during its first day as a public company. Och-Ziff, which raised $1.15 billion with its initial public offering of stock late on Tuesday, ended the day down $1.35 a share, closing at $30.65.

title: McCormick Adds Lawrys to Its Spice Rack
description: McCormick agreed Wednesday to buy the Lawrys business from Unilever Group for $605 million in cash, adding wet marinades to its selection of dry spices.

title: Barclays Write-Down Is Less Than Expected
description: Barclays, Britains third-biggest bank, said its investment bank unit made a 1.3 billion pound ($2.7 billion) write-down due to its exposure to credit market problems in the four months to the end of October.

title: Biogen Sale: A $30 Bllion Deal or a Busted Auction?
description: Biogen Idec, the biotechnology company that is reportedly attempting to sell itself to a major pharmaceuticals company before the end of the year, may be having trouble finding a buyer. Biogen Idec shares have fallen sharply over the last month on concern the Cambridge company wont fetch much of a premium  if it sells at all.

title: Morgan Stanley Takes Stake in Traxis Partners
description: Morgan Stanley will become an equity investor in hedge fund firm Traxis Partners, which was founded by a team of its own bankers. Morgan Stanley will have a less than 20 percent stake in the $1.5 billion global macro fund firm, according to HedgeFund.Net.

title: Butler in Talks for Lagarderes Virgin France Stake
description: Walter Butler, head of French buyout shop Butler Capital Partners, said Wednesday that he is negotiating to buy roughly a 75 percent stake in retailer Virgin France Group from defense and media conglomerate Lagardre.

title: Cerberus Backs Out of United Rentals Deal
description: United Rentals, the rental equipment company, said Wednesday that Cerberus Capital Management had backed out of its planned $4 billion purchase of the company.

title: Barack Obama Goes to Google
description: Barack Obama announced several new technology policy initiatives Wednesday during a visit to Silicon Valley, including a proposal for a chief technology officer.

title: Skyline Ventures Wraps Up $350 Million Fund
description: Healthcare specialist Skyline Ventures raised $350 million in its fifth investment vehicle, bulking up from a $200 million fund closed in July 2005 to allow the firm to make bigger commitments to portfolio companies.

title: Carlsberg, Heineken Make Fresh Bid for British Brewer
description: Carlsberg and Heineken  raised their bid for Scottish & Newcastle to 7.3 billion pounds ($14.9 billion), aiming to force talks with management after Britains largest brewer rejected their first approach.

title: Goldmans Long Shadow Gets Longer
description: As DealBook noted Wednesday, it seems that no echelon of the financial world remains untouched by the long arm of Goldman Sachs. As former Goldman Sachs alumnus John A. Thain, for example, prepares to take the reins of Merrill Lynch, he is only the latest example of a tradition borne out across Wall Street, in Washington and around the world.

title: Ellison Says New Bid for BEA Would Be Below $17 Per Share
description: Oracle Chief Executive Larry Ellison seems to be enjoying the catbird seat.

title: TPG Capital Said to Enter Race for Japan Airlines Unit
description: TPG Capital, the private equity firm formerly known as Texas Pacific Group, is one of the likely bidders for a stake in Japan Airliness $900 million credit card unit, according to Reuters.

title: Grrrr!!! Meow!!! Dan, Katie and the War of the Overcoats
description: A few months ago, the comedian Harry Shearer dug up an old Dan Rather video to poke fun at the CBS anchormans vanity

title: Hewlett-Packard Engineers Deal for EYP
description: Hewlett-Packard agreed to buy EYP Mission Critical Facilities, a data center engineering firm, for an undisclosed sum in a deal that will provide an exit for TA Associates.

title: When Your Professions Landscape Changes
description: If you want to fill a huge auditorium, set up a panel with the words changing landscape and the name of an industry or profession, then spread the word to members of the industry, who pride themselves on keeping up with trends.

title: What Happened to Laurence Fink?
description: Last week, the smart money seemed to be on Laurence D. Fink as the next chief of Merrill Lynch. The founder and chief executive of BlackRock, the large investment firm partly owned by Merrill, was being widely touted as the front-runner for the position left by E. Stanley ONeal, who resigned in the wake of a multibillion write-down at the investment bank.

title: For Thains Successor, Challenges Ahead
description: Much of the attention surrounding reports that John A. Thain is poised to take the top job at Merrill Lynch has been lavished on the head of NYSE Euronext and the challenges he faces as the investments banks new chief.

title: Hedge Fund Urges Delta-United Merger
description: Long-simmering talk of an inevitable round of airline industry mergers heated up again Wednesday. But by the end of the day, after a spike in their share prices, the central players in any merger talks, dismissed the rumors as just that.

title: Fatdoor Opens Up for V.C.s
description: Fatdoor, a social network for neighbors, on Wednesday said it picked up $5.5 million in a first round of funding and former Yahoo veteran Jennifer Dulski as its chief executive.

title: RWE Postpones U.S. I.P.O.
description: RWE, Germanys second-largest power company, on Wednesday postponed the initial public offering of its American Water business due to market turmoil in the United States, forcing it to abandon plans for a share buyback and significant increase in its dividend.

title: Thains Next Fix-It Job: Merrill Lynch
description: John A. Thain won plaudits as Wall Streets Mr. Fix-It by revitalizing the embattled New York Stock Exchange. Now, he faces what could be a more formidable challenge: turning around Merrill Lynch, the once-proud Wall Street firm battered by losses from the mortgage debacle.

title: The Early Word: Democrats in Vegas
description: Las Vegas, that city of dreams and heartbreak, takes center stage tonight as it hosts the Democratic presidential candidates at a debate on the University of Nevada-Las Vegas campus. Hillary Rodham Clinton may be seeking redemption after poor reviews of her performance at the last debate, and her top rivals John Edwards and Barack Obama likely will continue to direct their most pointed attacks toward her.

title: 3M Buys Aearo Technologies for $1.2 Billion
description: 3M said Thursday that it will acquire Aearo Technologies, a maker of personal protection like hearing and eye protectors, from British buyout firm Permira for $1.2 billion in cash. The deal will be financed by a combination of cash on hand and debt.

title: Kraft to Sell Post Cereals to Ralcorp for $2.6 Billion
description: Ralcorp said on Thursday that it would acquire Kraft Foods Post cereals business in a deal valued at about $1.65 billion. Including about $950 million in debt, the deal is worth $2.6 billion, said Ralcorp, a maker of private-label and frozen bakery foods.

title: Spains Iberia Airline Receives Takeover Bid
description: Iberia Lineas Aereas de Espana, Spains largest airline, received a takeover approach valued at as much as 3.7 billion euros ($5.4 billion) from a group of investors including Spanish billionaire Alicia Koplowitz.

title: The Democratic Debate
description: Following is a transcript of the Democratic Presidential debate in Las Vegas, as provided by the Federal News Service.

title: Your Late Night Jokes  Keep Em Coming!
description: More submissions from readers to tide us over during the TV writers strike (send yours via the comment link below):

title: The Wrong Woman?
description: Why dont we have a stronger Democratic female candidate? asks 90s feminist bte noire Camille Paglia in Salon.

title: Galleon Is Said to Make Big Bet on A.M.D. Shares
description: Galleon Group, a $7 billion hedge fund known for its technology investments, is making a big bet on A.M.D.. Citing an unnamed trader involved in the trade, The New York Post said the fund has purchased several million shares of the chipmaker, which is struggling to keep pace with larger rival Intel.

title: A New Effort to Remove Bad Teachers
description: The Bloomberg administration is beginning a drive to remove unsatisfactory teachers, hiring new teams of lawyers and consultants who will help principals build cases against tenured teachers who they believe are not up to the job. It is also urging principals to get rid of sub-par novices before they earn tenure.

title: Thursday Morning Kickoff
description: If you ever get the chance to have a meal with the Penn State offensive line, make sure to count your fingers when youre done. According to Jeff McLane of the Philadelphia Inquirer, the linemen throw down food as if they were Kobayashi in Coney Island. Teammates estimate that tackle Dennis Landolt eats 7 to 10 peanut butter and jelly sandwiches a night. No word on whether he cuts the crusts off or not.

title: Inquiry: Airport Security Not Tight Enough
description: The folks at the Government Accountability Office may be better known for their regular updates on progress in Iraq and other hardcore analysis, but they apparently go undercover as well. Over the past year, investigators have been testing airport security checkpoints for vulnerabilities, and have found some disturbing ones.

title: Open Caucus: The Voters Speak
description: Were starting a new feature today, called the Open Caucus  a roundtable of people from different parts of the country who will join us now and then in online conversations about the 2008 presidential campaign, the candidates and the issues.

title: Neighborhood of A-List Architects
description: The Museum Tower

title: Democrats Rendezvous in Paris
description: Tonight, after the Democratic presidential hopefuls leave the stage at their debate in Las Vegas, they have another destination on their evening itinerary: Paris.

title: L.A. Auto Show: Potent Quotables
description: LOS ANGELES  If the Los Angeles Auto Show were a race among auto executives to deliver the pithiest phrase for journalists consumption, it would be on.

title: Cronkite Joins Retirement TV
description: Walter Cronkite, the former anchor of the CBS Evening News, will contribute weekly editorials to the start-up channel Retirement Living TV.

title: Smoke Rings
description: Denis Johnson, reporting a story in Iraq, wasnt available last night to pick up his National Book Award for Tree of Smoke.

title: For Thain, a Big Raise in Store
description: John Thain isnt just moving to a new company. Hes moving to a whole new pay scale.

title: Road Trip, Part 9
description: This Thursday the crazy CSTV.com duo of Matt Meyers and Mike Ogle have plenty of new adventures to share. If youre a Giants fan, youll be especially interested. Thats because they caught up with Ron Dayne and Tyrone Wheatley, both great college running backs and former Giants. They also checked in with the linebacking corp at Grand Valley State and learned what its like to have a cool drink of Barry Alvarez. Gas up the tanks. Its time to hit the road.

title: L.A. Auto Show: Fuel Cells Finally Ready for the Masses?
description: LOS ANGELES  At the 2007 Los Angeles Auto Show, fuel-cell vehicles made quite a showing. Oh, were still on that technology? True, its not as trendy or accessible to the general consumer as hybrid, diesel, or even flex-fuel. But it is by no means a has-been  or even an also-ran. For example, Honda has been serious about hydrogen fuel cells since the first-generation FCX in 2002, fine-tuning the technology with a sleeker model in 2005, and pushing the envelope even further with the new FCX Clarity.

title: Strike II
description: Do editors get a cut of online content? Just curious. Its such an editors medium, after all, online video.

title: Lights Out on Broadway
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: And if the Apocalyptic Cult of the Moment Is Right?
description: Sure, its easy to laugh at another great addition to the Oddly Enough archive at Reuters: Sect holes up in cave to await end of world.

title: Will Games Impact Surpass Inconvenient Truth?
description: UPDATE & APOLOGY 11/16: I erred in describing EA folks as the designers of SimCity Societies. Its the crew at Tilted Mill Entertainment, outside Boston. The lead designer and company president, Chris Beatrice, helped clarify this for me (I admit freely that my sons are the gaming experts in my house, not me), and pointed out the importance of distinguishing between the creators of a game and the company that publishes it (which is Electronic Arts).

title: Update: Why Knick Was AWOL
description: Stephon Marbury sparked what seemed like a major Knicks crisis on Tuesday, when he deserted his team during a West coast swing. On Wednesday, he boarded a cross-country flight back, playing in the teams fourth straight loss, this time to the Los Angeles Clippers.

title: Central Park Rape Victim and Oprah, at Odds
description: Oprah Winfreys persistent questioning five years ago of Trisha Meili, the Central Park jogger who was sexually assaulted in 1989, has suddenly returned to the public eye. In an interview with NY1 this week, Ms. Meili said that she was astounded at a line of questioning in which Ms. Winfrey pressed her to explain why she would jog alone in Central Park at 10 p.m.

title: Amaranth Letter Puts Blame on J.P. Morgan
description: It has been more than a year since Amaranth Advisors went down in a blaze of losses, marking one of the largest hedge-fund failures in history. While the cause of its death is generally seen as Amaranths ill-fated energy trades, Amaranth is proposing a controversial new theory. The defunct fund, which once oversaw more than $9 billion, argues that improper meddling by J.P. Morgan Chase was the real reason that it didnt pull through the crisis.

title: Old Age Is Harder for the Overweight
description: For people carrying extra pounds, the news last week was good. Obesity doesnt increase cancer risk, the Journal of the American Medical Association (JAMA) reported.

title: New U.N. Report on Irans Nuclear Program
description: The International Atomic Energy Agency, the United Nations agency responsible for monitoring nuclear activities around the world, is just out with a new report on Iran, focusing on whether the country is living up to its agreements and complying with Security Council resolutions.

title: A Spygate Asterisk?
description: Last week Don Shula, the legendary coach whose 1972 Miami Dolphins were the last team to finish a season undefeated, suggested that if the New England Patriots finish the season unbeaten, the feat would be tainted because the team videotaped the signals of an opposing team. Do you agree with the Hall of Fame coach?

title: Youre Fired! But First, Run the Gauntlet.
description: Theres nothing more humiliating in sports than a doomed college football coach playing out the string. Its like watching someone poke a wounded animal on its last breath, Bryan Curtis writes in this weeks PLAY newsletter. This years walking dead include Nebraskas Bill Callahan, Texas A&Ms Dennis Franchione, and possibly even Tennessees Phillip Fulmer, who won the national championship in 1998 but hasnt done much since. While a coachs final days have never been a happy affair (ask every Notre Dame coach since Lou Holtz), the Internet has made them even more torturous.

title: For Merrill, a Political Shift at the Top
description: The arrival of John A. Thain at Merrill Lynch signals a change not only in the firms focus, as it struggles to recover from the trading losses incurred under E. Stanley ONeal. It also represents an adjustment in the political leanings at the firm  or in the chief executives suite, anyway.

title: To Clone or Not to Clone?
description: The keepers of bioethics are even more alarmed than usual now that scientists have reported cloning a monkey embryo and extracting stem cells. In her article about the monkey research, my colleague Gina Kolata quotes the reaction of the Rev. Tadeusz Pacholczyk, director of education at the National Catholic Bioethics Center:

title: Clinton at the University of N.H.
description: Students from Harvard's Institute of Politics attended a Hillary Rodham Clinton event in New Hampshire.

title: Strike Gives New Life to Marginal Shows
description: In todays New York Times, Bill Carter explains why some struggling television shows are getting a second chance at life because of the writers strike.

title: A Pranksters Latest Victim: Katie Couric
description: Harry Shearer wears many hats, among them comedic writer, voice actor for The Simpsons, radio host, and Huffington Post blogger.

title: Sonnets From the Bosnian
description: Elizabeth Barrett Brownings Sonnets from the Portuguese gets its title, of course, from the fact that Robert Brownings pet name for her was Portuguese, and because they wanted to disguise these intimate poems as translations.

title: L.A. Auto Show: Momentum-Killer?
description: LOS ANGELES  Why are there only 14 world premieres at the 2007 L.A. Auto Show? Has the show lost the momentum it seemed to have gained last year by moving its date from early January to late November? The 2006 Los Angeles show boasted 21 new world debuts.

title: Smirkers of the World, Unite!
description: Thats funny: we thought the late-show comedy writers werent working. A strike update from LateShowWritersOnStrike.com:

title: Farrell Considers Life After Albany. Perhaps the Council?
description: His candidacy may not be official yet. But anyone who has a campaign fund-raising event at Tavern on the Green offers fairly conclusive evidence that he is serious about running.

title: The Top 10 Reasons We Deleted Your Comment
description: A reader named Lipso writes, I love how the liberal NY Times censors posts they dont likeI saw a post up here that made sense about an earlier posting and The Times censored it since liberals are really the thought police..What a rag

title: Who Invited the Non-Hybrid?
description: Introduced on Wednesday: 2008 Toyota Sequoia

title: L.A. Auto Show: The Old Amid the New
description: LOS ANGELES  Not everything on display at the Los Angeles Auto Show is right off the assembly line. The main purpose here, of course, is to showcase new (or newish) models, and the manufacturers trumpet each feature and shade of paint as if theyd developed a rounder version of the wheel. But the shows also offer enthusiasts and car buffs the chance to get close to a few pieces of classic rolling sculpture.

title: Winter of Our Dissed Content
description: Something to keep in mind when youre a media conglomerate going up against comedy writers: They have funny ways of making their point:

title: Did Murdoch Mull a Times Offer?
description: In winning Dow Jones, Rupert Murdoch has taken over the paper he has long dreamed of owning, The Wall Street Journal. But the mogul dropped word earlier this week that he had considered bidding for another storied newspaper: DealBooks parent, The New York Times.

title: Where to Eat Well In Buenos Aires
description: Im planning a trip to Buenos Aires in December and wondered if you could recommend some great restaurants.

title: In Time for Your Holiday Giving: The Alberto Gonzales Defense Fund
description: The Washington Post reports today that Alberto Gonzales supporters have set up a fund to pay his legal expenses.

title: Grist and Dot Earth: Framing the Climate Challenge
description: Off and on for more than a year, Ive been in a running debate with Dave Roberts, an environmental blogger for Grist, over the shape of the climate problem and the prospects of various efforts to tackle it. We held an e-chat Wednesday night to fine tune where we differ and where we agree. (You can see Dave in this Outside Magazine story on Grist.) Hes cross-posting this today as well.

title: The $300 Million Man
description: What we know today is that Alex Rodriguez will soon return to the Yankees with a contract that will guarantee him upwards of $275 million. The new wrinkle is that Rodriguez could actually make at least $300 million if he sets the career home run record in pinstripes.

title: Former Manhattan G.O.P. Leader Admits Tax Evasion
description: The former chairman of the Manhattan Republican organization pleaded guilty this morning to tax evasion and violating the public officers law in connection with money he was paid as a consultant to a real estate company and as an arbitrator in a dispute over helicopter services on the West Side.

title: Paying for Food
description: The CPI report today shows the overall cost of food is up 4.4 percent over the most recent 12 months.

title: 'Margot At The Wedding'
description: A. O. Scott reviews "Margot At The Wedding," starring Nicole Kidman and Jennifer Jason Leigh.

title: Movie Minutes: 'Redacted'
description: A. O. Scott reviews "Redacted," a film exploring the difficulty of cutting through the fog of war.

title: Ratings: Minds, Medicine and Model
description: With its best ratings of the season, Criminal Minds lifted CBS into first place on Wednesday. The 9 p.m. crime show delivered 15.7 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates, while eking out a victory as the nights top rated show among adults 18 to 49.

title: Dont Pepper Spray Me, Bro
description: It was a national news story recently when a University of Florida student was tasered  by police at an appearance by John Kerry  and uttered his now-famous phrase, Dont tase me bro.

title: Spitzers Other About-Face
Backlash Begins: All in Favor of Pigeons, Say Coo
description: The City Council has been ganging up on pigeons lately.

title: The Taurus Is Back What About the Buyers?
description: Before he became chief executive of Ford, Alan Mulally thought the company made a big mistake by killing off one of its most recognizable model names, the Taurus. But did Ford make another mistake by resurrecting the Taurus name this spring and slapping it on a slow-selling full-size sedan?

title: Whew! Those National Security Briefings Sure Happen Fast!
description: At his Senate confirmation hearings, Attorney General Michael Mukasey repeatedly refused to answer some of the most important questions because he said he had not yet received top-secret briefings.

title: How to cope with Paris train strike
description: If youve come to Paris this week, brace yourself for an authenic cultural experience: A national strike.

title: Cravath Names 3 New Partners
description: Cravath, Swaine & Moore, the white-shoe law firm, named three partners from its associate ranks, effective Jan. 1.

title: New Obama Ad: Chances I Had
description: In a new 30-second spot to begin airing tomorrow in New Hampshire, Senator Barack Obama talks education and gets tough with parents.

title: S.E.C. to Allow International Accounting Rules
description: Corporations outside the United States that use international accounting standards will no longer be required to adjust their financial statements to comply with American accounting rules, the Securities and Exchange Commission decided Thursday.

title: Mets on the Verge of Signing Torrealba
description: The Mets are on the verge of signing Yorvit Torrealba, their top catching target, to a three-year contract, according to a team official who did not want his name used because he was not authorized to speak publicly about a deal that was not finalized.

title: Candidates Tested on Courage
description: Its well known that candidates have a knack for talking around tough questions.

title: The Promise of Wave Power
description: In Oregon, scientists work to harness the waves as a new source of renewable energy.

title: M.L.S. M.V.P: Who Gets Your Vote?
description: UPDATE: Luciano Emilio, in his first M.L.S. season, was awarded the Most Valuable Player award.

title: Pinning Down Arm Wrestlers at the Port Authority
description: Here were the tournament rules:

title: Berlin in Lights: Clap Along With Mozart
description: The Berlin Philharmonic, having delivered the second of its three concerts at Carnegie Hall last night, began spreading itself around the city again today. (The first two Carnegie concerts will be reviewed in the Weekend section of tomorrows paper; the third takes place tomorrow night.) This morning a string quartet from the orchestra performed twice for students at the Harlem Childrens Zone on East 125th Street, a program that involves itself in education  from cradle (and before, with parents) to college  over a 100-block area of Harlem.

title: UrbanEye With Melena Ryzik
description: Melena Ryzik of The Times hobnobs at the intellectual center of the world, the 2007 National Book Awards.

title: Regarding the Castration of Victoria Woodhull
description: Many interesting comments and questions but I cant resist getting back to the castration of Victoria Woodhull. During her action-packed career as a 19th-century reformer, free love advocate and presidential candidate, she ran into an extremely tough period involving indictments, bankruptcy and family disorder, and was taken to a doctor with symptoms of a nervous breakdown. He concluded that she suffered from a female ailment that could be cured by removal of her ovaries. That sort of thing happened quite a bit back then, but happily Victoria managed to recover with all her parts intact.

title: Balancing Act
description: Yesterday, Newsweek hired Daily Kos founder Markos Moulitsas as a campaign contributor, and the reaction on the Web was nearly tepid.

title: The Eradication of Autumn Continues
description: What we are reading elsewhere

title: Genzyme May Be Icahns Next Biotech Target
description: When Carl C. Icahn purchased 1-percent stakes in two well-established biotech companies, MedImmune and Biogen Idec, the moves drew little attention.

title: A Case for Tebow
description: With the Heisman campaign seemingly narrowing down to a two-horse race between Oregons Dennis Dixon and Floridas Tim Tebow, the spin is on.

title: Turning the B-Word Into Cash
description: Which is worse? A voter using the word bitch in referring to Hillary Clinton? Or John McCains attempt to cash in on it?

title: A Moral Dilemma in Banks Emerging Markets Push
description: Emerging markets are not known for their transparent business practices. How American and European investment banks navigate such risky waters is the topic of a recent story on The Deal.com.

title: Dell on the Rebound?
description: Dell seems to have put its customer satisfaction troubles behind it, at least in the corporate market. That is one message from a new study this week by Forrester Research.

title: Bloomberg Finds a New Way to Say No
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg must be a fan of the Rockettes. It would be hard to escape that conclusion after an unusual comment he made today on Staten Island, where he spoke at the 46th annual Women of Achievement Awards.

title: Obama Receives Recommendation for Endorsement
description: Clarification | 8:01 p.m.  The vote was a straw poll of U.A.W. Region 4 local unions, which includes Illinois. While Mr. Edwards received more support from Iowa members and retirees, the strength of support from Illinois members pushed Mr. Obama over the edge. Technically, what happened today was not a formal endorsement, rather a recommendation to endorse, which Mr. Obama will likely receive before the Iowa caucusesDES MOINES  Senator Barack Obama collected an endorsement here today from the United Auto Workers, an organization of 30,000 members and retirees across Iowa.

title: Subprime for nothing
description: This is a very good point from Dean Baker. Were told that we mustnt regulate subprime lending, despite the vast wave of foreclosures it has produced, because to do so would prevent minorities and other disadvantaged Americans from achieving the dream of homeownership. Yet homeownership is already back down to about what it was before the big wave of subprime lending began. All that the wonders of the financial market achieved, it seemed, was to give a lot of people a brief taste of homeownership, followed by a nasty foreclosure.

title: L.A. Auto Show: Still Crazy After All These Years
description: LOS ANGELES  With all the hoopla the Los Angeles Auto Show has received during the past two years, due simply to a calendar adjustment, youd think it was in its infancy.

title: Politics, Vegas Style
description: LAS VEGAS  On a busy intersection with a view of this citys legendary downtown Strip, hundreds of supporters and staff members of the Democratic nominees filled the sidewalks at the site of tonights debate, waving placards and chanting slogans at passing cars to crank up support for their candidates.

title: And the Winner Is
description: Score 20 goals, play an entire season and win Major League Soccers Most Valuable Player Award.

title: Live-Blogging the Democrats in Vegas
description: Uniter or Divider | 10:10 p.m. Mrs. Clinton is asked if she is too polarizing to unite the country. She said she heard the same complaint when she ran for the Senate from New York but managed to get elected by reaching out to everyone. She talked about how she worked with Republican colleagues in the Senate and promised as president to spend a lot of my time working not with just Republicans but people who arent in public life.

title: Unhappy Birthday, Dennis
description: The Tyco duo, L. Dennis Kozlowski and Mark H. Swartz, lost their appeal today. Reading the appeals court decision makes it sound like the two men have little hope of overturning their convictions in further appeals.

title: Ritalin Wars
description: The sinking feeling came over me as soon as I saw the Page One headline: Bad Behavior Does Not Doom Pupils, Studies Say: New Look at Attention Deficit Disorders as a Delay, Not a Flaw.

title: Sustainable Mobility
description: As oil prices climb, automakers are showcasing fuel-efficient technologies at the L.A. Auto Show.

title: Debate Wrap: Viva Las Vegas
description: The short answer to the question on everyones mind is this: She did better than last time. Hillary Rodham Clinton may not have been electric, but she was back on solid ground after having wobbled in the last debate two weeks ago.

title: Back in New York City, and Testing Boundaries
description: Until two decades ago the Pennsylvania Ballet performed regularly in New York City. On Wednesday night it returned, opening at City Center with a program, one of two, that was full of surprises.

title: Candidates in a Box
description: Last night, the Democratic presidential candidates took part in yet another debate. Amid all this buzzing, blooming confusion, it becomes ever harder to keep the candidates and their traits clear in ones mind. Fortunately, history provides a remedy.

title: Restless in the City, With Down-Home Accents
description: Country bands are proud to be out of place in New York City. Two million-selling country bands flaunted their rural credentials at the Nokia Theater on Wednesday night. (Outside New York, which has no full-time country-music radio station, their tour, sponsored by the country cable network CMT, is playing in arenas.) Sugarland sang about kettle corn and 4-H babes while Little Big Town declared, I keep my heart and soul in the boondocks.

title: Inflation Was Tame in October
description: Inflation remains contained despite high oil prices and a record low dollar, a government report showed today, offering some reassurance to the Federal Reserve as it considers lowering interest rates at its next meeting.

title: In Florida, Addicts Find an Oasis of Sobriety
description: DELRAY BEACH, Fla.  Whitney Tower, 56, a scion of the Whitney, Vanderbilt and Drexel fortunes, squandered his trust fund and sold family treasures to support a $1,000-a-day heroin habit before landing in a tough-love facility near here seven years ago and never leaving. If I went back to New York Id be dead in two weeks, he said.

title: As Johnson Bears Down on Title, Gordon Rues a Lost Opportunity
description: MIAMI, Nov. 14  By the time Jeff Gordon climbed out of his No. 24 Chevrolet after 312 laps at Phoenix International Raceway on Sunday, his hopes for a fifth Nascar championship were nearly done. The title he so desperately sought had been all but secured by Jimmie Johnson, his Hendrick Motorsports teammate and friend.

title: Gorbachevs Baggage
description: The great man clutches the handle of the vintage limousine, staring sadly out the window at a chunk of the Berlin Wall with an open Louis Vuitton travel bag on the seat next to him. The message, creators of the ad tell us, is a personal journey of a beautiful person.

title: Well-Marked Trails for Bibliophiles
description: ASIDE from checking out the many author readings and book events in the Pioneer Valley, visitors can do what many residents do for amusement: shop myriad independent bookstores.

title: Militants Gain Despite Decree by Musharraf
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Nov. 15  Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the Pakistani president, says he instituted emergency rule for the extra powers it would give him to push back the militants who have carved out a mini-state in Pakistans tribal areas.

title: 50 Years and 600 Women Later, True Love
description: Love in the Time of Cholera sets itself the elusive task of translating Gabriel Garca Mrquezs masterpiece of magical realism into an upscale art film with popular appeal. Faithful to the outline of the novel but emotionally and spiritually anemic, it slides into the void between art and entertainment, where well-intended would-be screen epics often land with a thud.

title: Staten Island: Man Charged in Rape
description: A Staten Island man has been charged with raping a 62-year-old homeless woman under the boardwalk on South Beach in July of last year, prosecutors announced yesterday. The man, Jason Gonzalez, 27, pleaded not guilty at his arraignment yesterday, Daniel M. Donovan Jr., the Staten Island district attorney, said in a statement. Mr. Gonzalez is serving two to four years in a state prison for grand larceny, prosecutors said.

title: Prosecuting Blackwater
description: A report in The Times this week says that the F.B.I. is reaching the same horrifying conclusion as the Iraqi authorities: that the deadly September shooting spree by Blackwater security guards in Baghdad was unjustified and violated the American governments rules for the use of deadly force. The question is, what is the Bush administration going to do about it?

title: The Truth Could Have Set Bonds Free
description: This day never had to come for Barry Bonds. He could have avoided yesterdays indictment by parceling out just enough truth to satisfy a grand jury.

title: L.P.G.A. Finale Is Odd, but Still Quite Engaging
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 15  The curious format may make golf traditionalists cringe and send purists running from the room for their unabridged copy of the Rules of Golf, but what the final event of the L.P.G.A. season may lack in convention it more than makes up in thrills, chills and guilty pleasure.

title: So Few Beats and So Many Things to Get Done
description: In Dwight Rhodens universe, a leg never shoots into the air without a head ducking, arms jerking and a torso convulsing. A classical ballet position is always offset by some annoying would-be-subversive hip wiggle, shoulder isolation or buttock jutting. And any hint of counterpoint or patterning that might organize the eye is determinedly eliminated in favor of frantic multitasking to every musical beat.

title: Marbury May Be Trouble, but He Still Gets the Ball
description: SACRAMENTO, Nov. 15  It was hard to find the traces of Stephon Marburys penance after his unauthorized one-day work stoppage.

title: Michael J. Biondi, Banker and Deal Maker, Dies at 50
description: Michael J. Biondi, a prominent investment banker who advised clients in some of the biggest deals for decades, died Monday evening at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 50.

title: Theater Listings
description: THE ARISTOPHANIC LABORATORY The illustrious playwrights of ancient Greece gave us the tortured Oedipus, the grief-stricken Electra and the jealous and murderous Medea, among other dark and passionate characters, but every play coming out of Athens at that time was not necessarily tragic. Though we see the work of Aristophanes less frequently nowadays, he was toiling away too, writing bawdy, irreverent comedies with overtly political themes. This master of the Greek Old Comedy period is the only parodist from his era whose work survives today  he wrote about 40 plays during his lifetime (around 450 to 388 B.C.), though fewer than a dozen are still extant.

title: Canada Rebuffs 2 U.S. Deserters
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 15  Two United States Army deserters now face being ejected from Canada after the Supreme Court of Canada said Thursday that it would not hear an appeal of their unsuccessful claims for refugee status.

title: People in the News
description: People

title: Grading the Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Announces 5 Nominees for Top Justice Posts
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15  President Bush announced Thursday that he was nominating a federal judge and former prosecutor from Chicago as the No. 2 official in the Justice Department.

title: Betting an Estate on Inhaled Insulin
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 15  Pfizer, the worlds biggest drug company, flopped miserably with a seemingly cant-miss idea. But Alfred E. Mann is so certain he can succeed that he is betting nearly $1 billion of his own money on the effort.

title: S.E.C. Says Foreign Companies Do Not Have to Adjust to U.S. Accounting
description: Corporations outside the United States that use international accounting standards will no longer be required to adjust their financial statements to comply with American accounting rules, the Securities and Exchange Commission decided yesterday.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the ceremonial swearing-in of Attorney General Michael B. Mukasey included incorrect information about a meeting the same day with lawyers for Puerto Ricos governor, Anbal Acevedo-Vil, about a pending corruption inquiry. Mr. Mukasey was not at the meeting, which was attended by other Justice Department officials. (Go to Article)

title: Arizona Defeats Oregon in Seasons Latest Upset
description: Until Oregon quarterback Dennis Dixons left knee buckled in the first quarter last night, he was the front-runner for the Heisman Trophy and the second-ranked Ducks were contenders for the national championship. Dixon never returned and both possibilities were dashed in the Ducks 34-24 loss to the Wildcats in Tucson.

title: It Was Clinton vs. Obama on Health Care
description: So whom is an uninsured voter to believe?

title: Justices Move Again to Postpone an Execution
description: MIAMI, Nov. 15  The Supreme Court on Thursday blocked the execution of a Florida inmate, less than five hours before he was scheduled to die by lethal injection for killing an 11-year-old boy.

title: Barclays to Make $2.7 Billion Write-Down
description: LONDON, Nov. 15  Barclays announced today lower-than-expected write-downs on securities related to the United States subprime mortgage market, calming investors who had recently sold shares of the bank amid fears that it would post losses.

title: Gap in U.S. Access to Space Station Is a Concern
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15  When the space shuttle fleet is retired in 2010, the United States will be dependent on an increasingly hostile Russia for five years to give American astronauts access to the International Space Station, lawmakers and NASA officials said Thursday.

title: Raising Consciousness Beyond the Beaded Curtains
description: Kori Newkirk first came to New Yorks attention in the 2001 group show Freestyle at the Studio Museum in Harlem, which defined the work of certain younger African-American artists as post-black. That phrase, coined by the artist Glenn Ligon in conversation with the curator Thelma Golden, was the source of much confusion and consternation. For some, it implied freedom from the identity politics of an earlier generation; for others, a rejection of a label that threatened to become a label in itself. Either way, it made people look harder at works like the one Mr. Newkirk made for Freestyle, a life-size silhouette of a police surveillance helicopter, painted on the wall with pungent hair pomade.

title: McCain Finds Sympathy on Torture Issue
description: On a bitterly cold morning last week, diners at the Whistle Stop Cafe in Boone, Iowa, were just sitting down for their morning coffee when Senator John McCain entered. Within minutes, Mr. McCain turned to a hot-button topic for which he literally serves as the living embodiment: the subject of torture.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article yesterday about the approval of principles by American Roman Catholic bishops to guide voters misstated what the principles said about intrinsic evils, notably abortion. The document defines them as actions that must be opposed; it does not defend them that way.

title: Barclays to Make $2.7 Billion Write-Down
description: LONDON, Nov. 15  Barclays announced on Thursday a lower-than-expected write-down on securities related to subprime mortgages, calming investors who had recently sold shares of the bank amid fears that it would post a loss.

title: Familiar Thoughts on Suicide? Not So Fast
description: So you were dying to see Tracy Lettss August: Osage County on Broadway, but the stagehands strike left you out in the cold? Not to worry. Theres another stirringly melodramatic Chicago import in town that also begins with a mysterious death before exploring the wildly dysfunctional world that gave rise to the tragedy. With an hour running time and an eerie, almost dreamlike style, the show is both more modest and experimental than Mr. Lettss family drama, but it will leave you just as shaken. Heres the kicker: A boy in the fourth grade wrote it.

title: Before That Winter Getaway
description: NOVEMBER is finally here. The frost is on the windshield, the bitter north wind is wrestling the last leaves from the trees, and your extended winter stay is set, whether its near the ski slopes of Colorado or the golf courses of Florida. But before you take off, there are a few things to tend to at home.

title: Joe Nuxhall, Pitcher for Reds, Is Dead
description: Joe Nuxhall, who became the youngest player in modern major league history when he pitched in one game for the 1944 Cincinnati Reds at age 15, then went on to spend more than half a century with the Reds as a pitcher and broadcaster, died Thursday in Fairfield, Ohio, outside Cincinnati. He was 79.

title: BEA Tries to Prove Its Worth to Oracle
description: BEA Systems has been hoping to prove it is worth more than the $6.7 billion that Oracle offered to pay for it last month.

title: A Very Long Lunch Hour
description: Suicide, infidelity, spousal abuse and arrested development are the building blocks of Park, a wearisome comedy about disturbed, vehicle-bound Angelenos who take a very long lunch hour in a very ugly public park. Viewers familiar with this type of ensemble effort will not be surprised to learn that by the end all have revealed considerably more than whats in their sandwiches.

title: Whitney Biennial Stretches to Armory
description: As the countdown to the 2008 Whitney Biennial begins, details are emerging about that giant survey of American art that takes over most of the museums Marcel Breuer building. The next one, opening on March 6, will briefly spill into another East Side landmark, the Seventh Regiment Armory at Park Avenue and 67th Street.

title: The Everglades and the Climate
description: To the Editor:

title: A Soccer Mom Helps Raise Hofstra to New Heights
description: On the campus of Hofstra University, Brooke DeRosa is known as the soccer mom, but she is not a minivan-driving suburban parent. She is a soccer-playing mom: one of the top college players in the Northeast and the mother of a 14-month-old. The minute practice ends, she is going to a night class or hustling home to Ronkonkoma, N.Y., to care for her daughter, Ciara.

title: Gardner-Webb Is Brought Back to Reality
description: Last night amounted to a reality check for little Gardner-Webb out of Boiling Springs, N.C. Although the Runnin Bulldogs had trounced Kentucky to advance to the semifinals of the 2K Sports College Hoops Classic, they were in over their heads at Madison Square Garden, losing, 78-66, to Connecticut.

title: Back to Barranquilla, Seeking Sense of Place
description: Toward the end of My Colombian War Silvana Paternostro hits on the perfect Spanish word to express her sense of dislocation. She is desubicada, which she translates as difficult and kind of ridiculous, and always out of place. It shows, even to her family. The stork dropped her in the wrong country, her father says.

title: A Gas Tax and Other Energy Ideas
description: To the Editor:

title: Long After Escaping the Holocaust, Need for a Little Help to Adjust in Brooklyn
description: Sixty years later, he still remembers the smell of burning bodies somewhere near him. It was a 24-hour-a-day stench, unrelenting and inescapable. It hung, still, in the air at night. It greeted him when he woke up in the morning: an invisible, pervasive reminder of the living nightmare of Nazi control. Yosef Ostrowicz, born in Poland in 1928, survived the war, going into hiding in 1943 after he escaped the Warsaw Ghetto. But his parents and older sister did not survive. Separated from the three boys in the family, they were ushered off to their eventual deaths as Mr. Ostrowicz and his two brothers watched.

title: When the Golf Course Isnt Enough
description: THERES never been anything terribly sexy about living in a golf community. Imagine cookie-cutter spec homes dotting yet another dull par 4 in Myrtle Beach, and you get the picture. Even if you like the game and are in the market for a vacation home, you may never have considered buying in one of these old-style resorts.

title: Tomorrows Opera Singers Today
description: Alek Shrader, a young tenor, has sung in New York on at least three occasions this year: in Rossinis Signor Bruschino at the Gotham Chamber Opera; as a winner of the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions Grand Finals; and, starting on Wednesday night, in Rossinis Comte Ory with the Juilliard Opera Center, of which he is a member.

title: Manhattan: No More E-Zpass Discounts?
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday proposed eliminating discounts for drivers who use the cashless E-ZPass toll collection system during peak hours on its crossings between New Jersey and Manhattan and Staten Island. Under the proposal, which is subject to public hearings, all drivers would pay $8 to use the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels, the George Washington Bridge and bridges to Staten Island. Drivers with an E-ZPass tag crossing at peak hours now pay $5, while those with cash pay $6. To ease traffic during the most congested hours of the day, the authority also proposes that drivers with E-ZPass pay $6 during off-peak hours. The increases would be the first since 2001.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Bouncers Murder Trial Sheds Light on Citys Night Life
description: The definitive history of New York night life may one day make note of Stephen Sakai in a short chapter called Downtown Bouncer Violence.

title: McCains Stance on Torture Becomes Riveting Issue in Campaign
description: On a bitterly cold morning last week, diners at the Whistle Stop Cafe in Boone, Iowa, were just sitting down for their morning coffee when Senator John McCain entered. Within minutes, Mr. McCain turned to a hot-button topic for which he literally serves as the living embodiment: the subject of torture.

title: Familiar Negotiating Strategy for Rodriguez
description: As Alex Rodriguez appears to be straying from Scott Borass game plan and negotiating with the Yankees himself over a new contract, the Seattle Mariners may be experiencing dj vu.

title: Led by Robots, Roaches Abandon Instincts
description: Many a mother has said, with a sigh, If your friends jumped off a cliff, would you jump, too?

title: Manhattan: Electrical Problems Blamed in Fire
description: A fire that ravaged an upper floor of a skyscraper in Lower Manhattan early yesterday morning was caused by an electrical problem, the Fire Department said, though the exact malfunction had yet to be identified. Firefighters were called to 80 Pine Street at 12:21 a.m. The fire, which started on the 29th floor, was brought under control just over an hour later, the department said. The department said 138 firefighters responded and 8 sustained minor injuries.

title: A Cowlike Dinosaur Comes Into Focus
description: It has been 60 years since French paleontologists found the dinosaurs bones in Saharan Africa, and 10 years since Paul C. Sereno of the University of Chicago began assembling a more complete skeleton. Only now has his team recognized the plant eaters peculiar anatomy and foraging behavior.

title: A Tasty Road to Enlightenment
description: A jaunty mix of chanting, baking and spiritual uplift, How to Cook Your Life introduces us to the cooking classes of Edward Espe Brown, a twinkling Zen priest and vegetarian chef.

title: CBS Asks Court to Dismiss Suit Filed by Rather
description: CBS filed a motion yesterday seeking the dismissal of a lawsuit by Dan Rather, who says that the network violated his contract by giving him too little to do after it forced him off the evening news in 2005 and that its investigation of the news segment about President Bushs National Guard service was politically biased.

title: Inflation Was Tame in October
description: Inflation remains contained despite high oil prices and a record low dollar, a government report showed yesterday, offering some reassurance to the Federal Reserve as it considers whether to lower interest rates again at its meeting next month.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Classical Flair With Vernacular Flourishes
description: If anything linked the four works presented in a recital by the Swiss pianist Louis Schwizgebel-Wang at Zankel Hall on Tuesday night, it was inspiration. Not just in the sense that the composers did their work well  though that was certainly true  but also in the sense that each piece was written in reaction to some outer stimulus.

title: Lottery Numbers
After a Week, Broadway Talks to Resume Tomorrow
description: Tomorrow, the stagehands strike will have reached the one-week mark, and those who make a living on Broadway and in its shadow are still teetering back and forth between fatigue and anxiety.

title: Former G.O.P. Official Admits He Evaded Taxes
description: The former chairman of the New York County Republican Committee admitted yesterday that he had evaded taxes and violated state ethics law in connection with money he was paid as a consultant to a real estate company and as an arbitrator in a dispute over helicopter services on the West Side.

title: Rage, Fear and Revulsion: At War With the War
description: Brian De Palmas Redacted, a prizewinner in Venice and a polarizing selection at film festivals in Telluride, Toronto and New York, is one of a slew of new American movies that try to deal with the war in Iraq and related matters. Their moods and methods vary widely  Redacted is furious and confrontational; Robert Redfords Lions for Lambs is pedagogical and talky; Paul Haggiss In the Valley of Elah is mournful and unsettled  but I find myself drawn, in each case, to more or less the same conclusion. I am glad the movie was made, and I wish it were better.

title: The Gospel of Stop Shopping
description: For some of the parents interviewed in Rob VanAlkemades fast and funny documentary What Would Jesus Buy? the answer to the question posed by the title is simple: whatever gadget of the moment their spoiled-rotten kids are craving.

title: Tufts Says It Fired Administrator Over Missing Money
description: Tufts University said it fired an administrator after finding that $300,000 generated by student-run events and businesses was missing. The official, Jodie Nealley, had been student activities director for the university in Medford, Mass., since 1997, and was fired Nov. 9, university officials said. The university referred the matter to the Middlesex County district attorney. While Kim Thurler, a Tufts spokeswoman, said Ms. Nealley was fired, a lawyer representing the former official described the end of her employment as mutual.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Work on International Space Station Continues
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 16  Even as the shuttle Discovery touched down at the Kennedy Space Center last week, the shuttle Atlantis was being readied for a mission to take up another new module to the International Space Station as early as Dec. 6.

title: The Well-Shaped Phrase as Art
description: So here we are. Just about any scrap of canvas or even paper by Andy Warhol is worth at least a million dollars and usually several. Richard Princes retro Nurse paintings have cleared $6 million less than five years after they were made. And Jeff Koonss least-interesting baubles, despite glimmers of anti-bauble intent, go for as much as $23 million.

title: Manhattan: Man Convicted of False Terror Report
description: A jeweler was convicted yesterday of falsely reporting that five men were plotting to bomb the subways, in a scheme apparently meant to cause trouble for the men, his former business associates. The jeweler, Rimon Alkatri, 35, was convicted in State Supreme Court of falsely reporting an incident and faces up to seven years in prison. The report resulted in a police investigation of the former business associates, and the police searched their homes. Nothing suspicious was found. Mr. Alkatris lawyer, Michael L. Soshnick, said his client admitted making the call but denied that the information was deliberately false.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption yesterday with a theater column about the Shakespeare Theater Companys new Sidney Harman Hall in Washington, and its productions there and at its nearby Lansburgh Theater, misidentified the theater where the company is performing Christopher Marlowes Edward II. It is Sidney Harman Hall, not the Lansburgh Theater.

title: Report Raises New Doubts on Iran Nuclear Program
description: VIENNA, Nov. 15  The International Atomic Energy Agency said in a report on Thursday that Iran had made new but incomplete disclosures about its past nuclear activities, missing a critical deadline under an agreement with the agency and virtually assuring a new push by the United States to impose stricter international sanctions.

title: Simon Rattles Berliners Bring Mahler and More
description: Simon Rattle, halfway through his 10-year contract as music director of the Berlin Philharmonic, has brought that venerated orchestra to Carnegie Hall for the Berlin in Lights festival. On Tuesday and Wednesday nights, in the first two of three sold-out programs, he paired new scores by the Finnish composer Magnus Lindberg and the British composer Thomas Ads with autumnal works by Mahler: the Ninth Symphony and Das Lied von der Erde. I found the performances overwhelming; to judge from the prolonged ovations on both nights the audiences agreed.

title: R&Bs Eccentric, Unbowed
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Nov. 15  Radio D.J.s were shouting themselves hoarse in the parking lot, crowing about one of the biggest concerts this town has ever seen. Cars were crawling down Veterans Parkway, trunk speakers abuzz. The local clergy were not amused.

title: A Campaign Hopes a Slur Will Lead to Donations
description: Senator John McCain of Arizona has sent out a fund-raising appeal based on an episode this week in which a voter referred to Senator Hillary Clinton using a slur.

title: Bonds Charged With Perjury in Steroids Case
description: Barry Bonds, baseballs career home run leader, was indicted yesterday on five felony charges  four for perjury and one for obstruction of justice  for testifying before a federal grand jury in 2003 that he never used anabolic steroids or human growth hormone.

title: Company Offers Genome Assessments
description: The revolution in human genomics, though barely understood by professionals, is about to hit the street, at least for those able to pay about $1,000 for a glance at their entire genome.

title: Early Americas Imported Hero
description: From Lafayette, Wis., to Fayette, Me.; from Fayetteville, Ark., to Lafayette County in Missouri; even in La Grange, Wyo., and La Grange County in Indiana the renowned Frenchman Marie Joseph Paul Yves Roch Gilbert du Motier de La Fayette left his mark (or at least the name of his estate east of Paris, La Grange). Lafayette, as he was more familiarly known here, also left his visage on 19th-century punch bowls and serving plates, clothes brushes and bank notes, pitchers and paintings.

title: Fed Official Hints at No Rate Cut
description: A Federal Reserve governor warned today that another interest rate cut would probably offer few benefits to the economy, an explicit hint that the central bank plans to hold rates steady at its meeting next month.

title: Shaping the System That Grades City Schools
description: JAMES S. Liebman is prone to attempting big-picture corrections, be it by challenging the constitutionality of the death penalty before the Supreme Court or, as happened this month in New York City, by putting the administrative screws to public schools that fail to educate their students.

title: High Oil Prices Confound OPEC
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 16  As oil prices hover around $95 a barrel, OPEC should be in a celebratory mood: its members are reaping record revenue, demand for their product keeps rising and the world economy seems capable of sustaining oil prices that would have seemed suicidal just a few years ago.

title: In ID Theft, Some Victims See Opportunity
description: GIDEON YU, the former chief financial officer of YouTube and current chief financial officer of Facebook, is one of the most notable new executives in Silicon Valley. But while Mr. Yu operated in high-techs highest circles over the last two years, an impersonator was quietly using his name and credit card number to make fraudulent purchases.

title: Concert Company Deal
description: Live Nation, the worlds largest live-concert promoter, said yesterday that it had reached a deal to acquire Signatures Network, a major manufacturer of concert T-shirts and other music merchandise, for about $79 million in cash, stock and debt.

title: After a Death, Use of Taser in Canada Is Debated
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 15  A video recording showing an emotionally wrought immigrant dying after being hit with a police Taser at an airport last month has touched off a fierce debate in Canada on police actions in the case and the rules governing use of the weapon.

title: Gap Campaigns Against Child Labor
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 15  Gap has begun an effort to rebuild its reputation after a child-labor scandal in India, announcing a package of measures on Thursday intended to tighten its commitment to eradicating the exploitation of children in the manufacture of its goods.

title: Kind of Classical
description: WHO David Laverty, 49, a lawyer from Chicago; his wife, Choon Kyoung Lee, 42, an architectural lighting designer; and their 4-year-old son, Alexander Laverty WHAT 3-bedroom house WHERE Buchanan, Mich.

title: Tadahiro Sekimoto, Electronics Executive, Dies at 80
description: TOKYO, Nov. 15  Tadahiro Sekimoto, a former president of NEC, the Japanese electronics company, who presided over its rise into a top global computer maker before resigning in a military procurement scandal, died on Sunday. He was 80.

title: Unlike 68, There Can Be No Tie in the Game
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 15  The legendary Yale quarterback Brian Dowling will travel here this weekend from his home in Boston to watch his alma mater defend a perfect season against Harvard in The Game.

title: Giants Rookie Turning Mistakes Into Lessons
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 15  After the Giants played the Dallas Cowboys on Sunday, Kevin Boss retreated to his apartment in Lyndhurst, N.J., and tried to go to bed early. But he could not fall asleep.

title: Confronting the Fabled Monster, Not to Mention His Naked Mom
description: You dont need to wait for Angelina Jolie to rise from the vaporous depths naked and dripping liquid gold to know that this Beowulf isnt your high school teachers Old English epic poem. You dont even have to wait for the flying spears and airborne bodies that  if you watch the movie in one of the hundreds of theaters equipped with 3-D projection  will look as if theyre hurtling directly at your head. You could poke your eye out with one of those things! Which is precisely what I thought when I first saw Ms. Jolies jutting breasts too.

title: California: Ship Got No Alert From Coast Guard
description: The Coast Guard did not warn helmsmen of a cargo ship that spilled 58,000 gallons of oil into San Francisco Bay that the ship was poised to hit the Bay Bridge, investigators with the National Transportation Safety Board said.
