One board member, Debbie Hersman, said the Vessel Traffic Service of the Coast Guard asked the pilot of the ship, the Cosco Busan, about its course before the accident. They all recognized and were concerned about the vessels position, Ms. Hersman said. But the traffic workers told investigators they decided to limit communication so as not to distract the pilot from a difficult maneuver.

title: Dearly Beloved, We Are Gathered Here Today to Rend One Another Apart
description: In Noah Baumbachs Margot at the Wedding, a face is slapped, some punches and kicks are thrown and a gracious old shade tree is subjected to assault by chain saw. It all sounds pretty tame compared with what you might encounter on neighboring screens at the multiplex. This is, as my colleague Caryn James pointed out in a recent essay, a notably bloody season at the movies. So if you are interested in gore and gunplay, you can seek out Saw IV or No Country for Old Men. When it comes to emotional violence, however, Margot at the Wedding is hard to beat.

title: Commercial Airlines Given Priority in Militarys Space
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15  A week before the peak Thanksgiving travel period, the White House got involved at an unusually detailed level with air traffic on Thursday, as President Bush announced that airlines would be able to make fuller use of military airspace to relieve congestion and cut delays.

title: Parties Searching for Clues to 2008 Find All Politics Is Local
description: Why do leading members of Congress from around the country care about the election of a new Democratic mayor in Canton, Ohio? Or the defeat of a library referendum in Louisville, Ky.?

title: A Nimble 75-Year-Old Gets a Little Nip and Tuck
description: Seventy-five years old and forever young, The Radio City Christmas Spectacular came flying into that Midtown Art Deco cathedral of entertainment on Tuesday night and went out a Superspectacular.

title: Patients Were Not Told of Misuse of Syringes
description: State health officials notified 628 patients this week that they should be tested for hepatitis and H.I.V. infection because they were treated years ago by an anesthesiologist in Nassau County who used improper procedures for preventing the spread of blood-borne diseases.

title: Falling Short on Equal Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Played for a Sucker
description: Lately, Barack Obama has been saying that major action is needed to avert what he keeps calling a crisis in Social Security  most recently in an interview with The National Journal. Progressives who fought hard and successfully against the Bush administrations attempt to panic America into privatizing the New Deals crown jewel are outraged, and rightly so.

title: Court Rejects Fuel Standards on Trucks
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15  A federal appeals court here rejected the Bush administrations year-old fuel-economy standards for light trucks and sport utility vehicles on Thursday, saying that they were not tough enough because regulators had failed to thoroughly assess the economic impact of tailpipe emissions that contribute to climate change.

title: Writers Strike Opens New Window on Hollywood
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 15  David DOrsa, who last week passed his days among the stars, says he may soon be serving up lattes. Leonard Dick told his children they need to get better at turning out the lights. Meredith Buyrucu will go to San Diego this weekend to eat in her mothers kitchen, which is kind of embarrassing, she said, since Im 40 years old.

title: Charges in 17 Robberies
description: A Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday and charged with 17 armed robberies in Lower Manhattan in the past nine weeks, the police said.

title: Beyond the Kitsch
description: The public knew Charles Nelson Reilly, who died on May 25, as a game show guest and a regular on Johnny Carsons couch. But there was more to the man than kitsch celebrity, and Life of Reilly lets the man make the case.

title: In the Valley of the Literate
description: DURING a recent visit to the Pioneer Valley of western Massachusetts, my scribbled list of book events read like a busy dance card.

title: Little Progress for City Schools on National Test
description: New York Citys eighth graders have made no significant progress in reading and math since Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg took control of the city schools, according to federal test scores released yesterday, in contrast with the largely steady gains that have been recorded on state tests.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Red Cross Monitors Barred From Guantnamo
description: A confidential 2003 manual for operating the Guantnamo detention center shows that military officials had a policy of denying detainees access to independent monitors from the International Committee of the Red Cross.

title: Ruling Jolts Even Saudis: 200 Lashes for Rape Victim
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 15  A Saudi court on Tuesday more than doubled the number of lashes that a female rape victim was sentenced to last year after her lawyer appealed the original sentence. The decision, which many lawyers found shocking even by Saudi standards of justice, has provoked a rare public debate about the treatment of women here.

title: Lebanons Presidential Front-Runners
description: The 128 members of Lebanons Parliament have until Nov. 23 to choose a president. Under a power-sharing pact made by religious leaders in 1943, the president must be a member of the Maronite Christian faith. Tensions have risen in Lebanon as the government, led by a Western-backed coalition known as the March 14 movement, has been stalled by political allies of the Shiite militant group Hezbollah. These are the eight most likely contenders for the post:

title: Clara Fox, Tireless Advocate for Subsidized Housing, Is Dead at 90
description: Clara Fox, an advocate of subsidized housing for poor and moderate-income people and the founder of the Settlement Housing Fund, a nonprofit organization that now houses 2,200 families in 44 buildings in New York City, died on Nov. 9 in Manhattan.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Antiques column in Weekend on Nov. 2, about an exhibition related to Napoleon at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, and a table Napoleon commissioned that Sothebys was offering for sale, omitted an organizer of the exhibition, Symbols of Power: Napoleon and the Art of the Empire Style: 1800-1815. While curators at the Museum of Decorative Arts in Paris chose the objects for the show, the American Federation of Arts also helped organize it.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Controversial Project to Begin on Big House
description: The game tomorrow between Ohio State and Michigan for the Big Ten title could be the last in Michigan Stadiums current configuration. Construction is to begin next week on 83 luxury boxes and a broader renovation.

title: Fewer Roadside Bombs in Iraq, U.S. Says
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 15  An American military official on Thursday reported a sharp decrease in the number of roadside bombs and other homemade explosive devices in Iraq. The official, Maj. Gen. James E. Simmons, said Iran, which American officials contend is the source of the deadliest of those weapons, appeared to be abiding by a reported commitment to halt their flow into Iraq.

title: What Does It Take to Restart a Play?
description: Enough doom and gloom. Lets assume the stagehands union and the producers sit down tomorrow morning, drink some coffee and shake hands on a deal by the evening. Will the curtain go up for the Sunday matinees?

title: Musharraf Plans Election as Opposition Vows Unity
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Friday, Nov. 16  Even as emergency rule continued, the Pakistani president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, pushed ahead on Thursday with preparations for elections, while the opposition said it had formed a united front to force him from power.

title: Error by Traffic Controller Draws Two Airliners Too Close
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 15  Two airliners carrying dozens of people came dangerously close to each other 25,000 feet above northern Indiana on Tuesday night.

title: Rarefied World
description: Beyond the many independent bookstores and author events, the Pioneer Valleys literary largess is enhanced by several other book-centered communities whose fascinating wares may be more challenging to find  and considerably more expensive to purchase.

title: Web Videos Stealing TV Viewers, and Marketers
description: WHY are fewer viewers watching the new fall television series? Perhaps because they are too busy watching video online.

title: Fall Art Auctions Limp to Finish on Mixed Night at Phillips
description: As collectors and dealers were fleeing Phillips, de Pury & Companys Chelsea salesroom in droves, Donald Rubell, the Miami collector, and his wife, Mera, hung tough last night. For more than three and a half hours, they sat through a two-pronged auction: a charity sale to benefit the New Museum on the Bowery and, then, the houses regular auction of contemporary art.

title: Art in Review
description: ALAN SARET

title: 22 Years Later, a Child Abuse Suspects Extradition Is Sought
description: Prosecutors in Brooklyn said yesterday they were pursuing the extradition of a man who fled to Israel more than 20 years ago after being accused of molesting young boys.

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about warnings of an environmental disaster in southern Russia after at least 11 ships, including a small oil tanker, sank or broke apart in a fierce storm in the Black Sea included an incorrect conversion to gallons for the amount of fuel oil spilled from the tanker. It was about 360,000 gallons (1,300 metric tons). The figure in the article, 562,000, was the conversion from 2,000 metric tons, the earlier estimate for the spill.

title: Without a Cash Infusion, the Citys OTB May End
description: Off-Track Betting parlors, dingy backdrops for decades of triumph and heartbreak, could become a thing of the past in the city by next June, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday, as officials at the financially precarious operation began devising a plan for its shutdown.

title: Ford Scraps Plans for New Assembly Plant
description: DETROIT, Nov. 15  The car factory of the future is becoming a thing of the past.

title: Yankees May Pay Rodriguez for Home Run Record
description: The Yankees are close to having one future Hall of Famer officially in the fold, working out contract language on a new deal for Alex Rodriguez that will reach at least $300 million if Rodriguez sets the career home run record. But closer Mariano Rivera remains unsigned as he waits for a four-year offer.

title: Pacific Overtures From Mystic Spirits
description: As an object of Western fascination Oceanic art has come a long way. Christian missionaries tried to eradicate it. Scientific explorers anthropologized it. Modern European artists mined it for new expressive possibilities, which led Western sophisticates to revere it as real art, worthy of the same appreciative attention they would pay to Rembrandt.

title: Corzines New Equation: Tolls Up, Borrowing Down
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 15  With more specifics and more urgency than usual, Gov. Jon S. Corzine said on Thursday that he would reveal the details of his controversial and long-percolating plan to reduce the states $32 billion debt by half by refinancing the states toll roads in his State of the State speech on Jan. 8.

title: Iraqi Premier Wants Trial of 2 Shiites in Killings
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq has approved the trial of two Shiite former officials who are accused of killing and kidnapping hundreds of Sunnis, according to American advisers to the Iraqi judicial system.

title: Streaking Rangers Grab Share of First
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15  When the shootout began, Rangers goaltender Henrik Lundqvist had changed. He became confident, skating out from his crease and cutting off Flyers center Daniel Brires shooting angles.

title: Los Angeles Police Scrap Mapping Plan, Elating Muslims
description: The Los Angeles Police Department is scrapping its controversial plan to create a map detailing the Muslim communities in the sprawling metropolitan area, bowing to the outcry among Muslims and others that the project was a thinly disguised form of racial profiling.

title: Bondss Trainer Is Released, but He Isnt in Clear Yet
description: For much of the past year and a half, Greg Anderson sat in a prison 40 miles east of San Francisco for refusing to testify against the friend he had helped break two of baseballs most hallowed records.

title: Jordans Islamists Seek Offices Their Allies Scorn
description: ZARQA, Jordan  This crammed slum of four-story concrete housing blocs has given Jordan some of its biggest headaches: it is a stronghold of the opposition Islamic Action Front and the hometown of Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, who rose from here to the helm of the Iraqi insurgent group Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: McCartney Says the Beatles Are Web-Bound

title: A Less Than Honorable Discharge From the Wrong Plot
description: CALVERTON, N.Y., Nov. 15  The rainfall paused at midday on Thursday as gravediggers lifted a wooden coffin containing the remains of a marine named William Hayes out of the ground and loaded it into a van.

title: Bonds Charges Deepen Baseballs Shame
description: Major League Baseball officials suddenly have a new rooting interest. His name is Alex Rodriguez.

title: Washington Scrutinizes Nursing Homes
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15  Lawmakers in two hearings on Thursday proposed ways to force nursing homes to provide more details about ownership and to hold those owners more accountable when problems emerge.

title: Cima and the Lake House at Chelan
description: Cima

title: Cherishing the Fantasy in 6-Year-Olds of All Ages
description: Mr. Magoriums Wonder Emporium is the only family film I can recall whose title character muses out loud about King Lear and the finality of death in language that wouldnt be out of place in a college Shakespeare course.

title: U.S. Says It Is Close to Filling Envoy Vacancies in Iraq With Volunteers
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15  State Department officials on Thursday said that they were close to filling all vacancies at the United States Embassy in Baghdad and in Iraqi provinces with volunteering Foreign Service officers, but that they were not abandoning a policy to order diplomats to Iraq if there was a need in the future.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about big investment firms that propped up their money market mutual funds misstated the exposure of one such fund to debt issued by complex securities called structured investment vehicles. While Wachovia booked a $40 million loss on securities it bought from its Evergreen fund, which greatly reduced investor exposure, it has not eliminated all risk to SIV debt.

title: Should College Athletes Be Paid? Well, They Are
description: To the Editor:

title: Manhattan: Drug Abuse Blamed for Arrest
description: Robert E. Chambers Jr., known as the preppy killer, blamed drug abuse yesterday for his latest arrest, on charges of selling cocaine from the Upper East Side apartment he shared with a companion, Shawn Kovell. Mr. Chamberss lawyer, Valerie Van Leer-Greenberg, told a justice in State Supreme Court that she was considering a psychiatric defense, among others, for her client, arguing diminished capacity predicated upon polysubstance abuse. The next hearing is on Dec. 18. Mr. Chambers, who was arrested on Oct. 22, has pleaded not guilty.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the ceremonial swearing-in of Attorney General Michael B. Mukasey included incorrect information about a meeting the same day with lawyers for Puerto Ricos governor, Anbal Acevedo-Vil, about a pending corruption inquiry. Mr. Mukasey was not at the meeting, which was attended by other Justice Department officials.

title: Both Parties War Bills Fail in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  Senate Republicans today easily blocked an effort by Democrats to act on a war spending bill that would have provided $50 billion for operations in Iraq and Afghanistan, but would have required that troop withdrawals from Iraq begin within 30 days.

title: Late Shows Move to Help the Workers Not on Strike
description: With no end in sight to the strike by writers against networks and production studios, several hosts of late-night shows have begun taking steps to ensure that their nonwriting staffs receive some portion of their pay, at least in the short term.

title: Bank of America to Open Ad Work to More Agencies
description: Bank of America plans to end five years of having a single advertising holding company in charge of its marketing communications. The decision means, among other changes, that the company will seek a new agency to handle its media planning and buying assignment.

title: Jets Line Will Try to Pull Back Steel Curtain
description: Burdened by a six-game losing streak, the Jets are seeking motivation from individual challenges.

title: Iran Was Blocked From Buying Nuclear Materials at Least 75 Times, Group Says
description: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 15  Iran has been denied purchases of nuclear-related materials at least 75 times over the past nine years because of suspicions the purchases could have been used for building bombs, according to an international monitoring group.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the baseball roundup yesterday about support by Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida for public funding of a ballpark for Tampa Bay misstated the teams nickname in some editions. It is the Rays  not the Devil Rays, a name that the club abandoned earlier this month.

title: White House Rejects Overture to Break Budget Impasse
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15  Trying to break a fiscal impasse with the White House, Congressional Democrats on Thursday made a new overture to reduce the spending sought by Congress, but the administration quickly dismissed the move.

title: A Norman Mailer Idea Whose Time Hasnt Come
description: Norman Mailer was laid to rest the other day. The same cannot be said of an idea that he once championed, namely that this city should pry itself loose from the rest of New York and become the 51st state.

title: Manhattan: Teachers Criticize Review Unit
description: Randi Weingarten, president of the United Federation of Teachers, called for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his schools chancellor to apologize to the citys 80,000 teachers yesterday, a day after the chancellor sent principals an e-mail message announcing the formation of teams of lawyers and consultants meant to help principals remove poorly performing tenured teachers. Ms. Weingarten said that the message seemed timed to the release yesterday of national reading and math test scores showing little progress among New York City students. The first speck of bad news, all of the sudden they go after teachers, Ms. Weingarten said. The mayor said yesterday that removing tenured teachers was a last alternative.

title: Holidays Approach, but Not Everythings for the Kiddies
description: For some people, watching Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat, Andrew Lloyd Webbers biblical musical, is a near-religious experience. Attending an annual production of it somewhere, often around one of the sacred holidays, is a family ritual.

title: A Stem Cell Achievement
description: Scientists in Oregon have successfully cloned monkey embryos from the skin cells of an adult monkey and then extracted stem cells from them  the first time this feat has been achieved in any animal other than mice. The same method might also work in humans, bringing researchers closer to the goal of creating embryonic stem cells to study diseases and ultimately treat them with new drugs or stem cell therapies.

title: Price Rise at Starbucks Cuts Visits and Shares
description: Starbucks, the worlds largest chain of coffee shops, lowered its profit and sales forecasts yesterday after reporting its first decline in customer visits.

title: As Bank Profits Grew, Warning Signs Went Unheeded
description: We should have known something was strange. The banks were doing a lot better than they should have been doing.

title: Wal-Marts Environmental Report Card
description: Officially, Wal-Mart Stores released a comprehensive report of its sustainability efforts yesterday. But the much-anticipated document could more accurately be described as a citizenship report.

title: Mets Are Close to a 3-Year Deal With Torrealba
description: One of the trademarks of Omar Minayas three seasons as the Mets general manager has been his relentlessness in the free-agent market. He isolates an area of need, locks onto a player and does not move on until a deal is completed.

title: Russia: Doomsday Sect Threatens Suicide
description: About 30 members of an eccentric Christian sect have retreated to a cave on a snowy hillside outside Nikolskoye in central Russia, where they have been in a standoff with the police. They took to the cave about a week ago and say they will stay underground until the apocalypse they expect in May. Attempts by the police to coax them out or at least get them to release the children with them have been met with threats to blow themselves up. The sects 43-year-old leader preaches apocalyptic doom and reportedly sleeps in a coffin.

title: Ruling Blocks Challenge to Wiretapping
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  A federal appeals court said today that secrecy laws forced it to exclude critical evidence about the National Security Agencys domestic eavesdropping program from being used by an Islamic charity in a lawsuit even though the mere existence of the program could no longer be considered a state secret.

title: Abbas Calls for Ouster of Hamas Gang From Gaza
description: GAZA, Nov. 15  Three days after Hamas policemen shot and killed at least seven civilians at a rally in Gaza, leading a number of Gazans to express shock and anger at Hamas, Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president and the leader of the rival faction Fatah, called for the ouster of Hamas from power in Gaza.

title: Marketing Moderne to the French Elite
description: Pochoir, a traditional  and laborious  French stenciling technique that dates to the 14th century, was reinvented in the 1920s to promote the new Art Deco and French Moderne styles. Pochoirs (pronounced poh-SHWAHR) depicting Deco interiors in strong, saturated colors appeared in art and design magazines and limited-edition portfolios that decorators produced. Because a pochoir print was hand-colored in watercolor or gouache, it was a particularly vibrant and stylish alternative to drawings or black-and-white photography. Fashioning the Modern French Interior: Pochoir Portfolios in the 1920s, an exhibition at the Wolfsonian-Florida International University Museum in Miami Beach, which opens today, offers a look at the medium.

title: Free Legal Aid Sought for Elderly Tenants
description: Elected officials and housing advocates called on the city yesterday to provide free legal representation in New York City housing court to low-income elderly residents, who they said often had trouble navigating the system and protecting themselves from eviction.

title: German Rail Strike Disrupts Travel and Freight
description: FRANKFURT, Nov. 15  A bitter strike by train drivers in Germany has tied up freight traffic, shut down an auto factory and stranded hundreds of thousands of passengers in what has become the German state rail systems largest work stoppage.

title: Indonesia Bans Sects It Deems Blasphemous
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 15  Indonesian human rights lawyers are again questioning the countrys commitment to religious freedom after the recent arrests of several unorthodox Islamic leaders and the banning of their organizations.

title: Tokyo Seeking a Top Niche in Global Finance
description: TOKYO, Nov. 15  Years ago, Japan rose to economic prominence by taking apart American products like cars and television sets to learn how to make them better.

title: Amid Turmoil, All Eyes Turn to Georgias Patriarch for Stability
description: TBILISI, Georgia, Nov. 14  When Georgias short democratic experiment seemed near collapse last week amid a commotion of flying tear gas canisters, rocks and rubber bullets, the nations leaders, their opponents and the Georgian people looked to Patriarch Ilia II, the leader of Georgias Orthodox Church.

title: In Mississippi, Poor Lag in Hurricane Aid
description: GULFPORT, Miss., Nov. 14  Like the other Gulf Coast states battered by Hurricane Katrina, Mississippi was required by Congress to spend half of its billions in federal grant money to help low-income citizens trying to recover from the storm.

title: China Stand on Imports Upsets U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15  Few American industries have had more success in selling goods to China than makers of medical devices like X-rays, pacemakers and patient monitors. Which is why a recent Chinese decree was so troubling.

title: In Contempt
description: White House Chief of Staff Joshua Bolten and Harriet Miers, the former White House counsel, showed their utter disregard for Congress, the Constitution and the American people when they defied Congressional subpoenas in the United States attorneys scandal. The House Judiciary Committee rightly voted to hold them in contempt, and now the matter goes to the full House.

title: After a Sitcom, Its Back to Stand-Up
description: Last year Louis C. K. set out to reinvent the sitcom.

title: State Tax Officials Dispute Claim of Florida Residency by Jeter
description: ALBANY, Nov. 15  New York State tax officials say that the Yankee star Derek Jeter claimed he lived in Florida to avoid paying city and state income taxes for several years, when he was actually living in New York, according to documents filed last week with an administrative law judge.

title: Getting Lost in History in the Other Las Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS, N.M., laid claim to its name about 70 years before that upstart neon metropolis sprang out of the sands of Nevada  and it shows. With only about 14,000 people, this Las Vegas has 900 buildings on the National Register of Historic Places, four grand old hotels (two still accepting guests), and not one but two period-piece downtowns.

title: Robert Taylor Dies at 59; Won 2 Medals in 72 Olympics
description: Robert Taylor, the American sprinter who won gold and silver medals in the 1972 Olympics in Munich after two of his teammates were memorably disqualified because of a scheduling mix-up, died Tuesday in Houston. He was 59 and lived in Missouri City, Tex.

title: British Banks Debt Complicates Its Sale
description: LONDON, Nov. 15  Two months after Northern Rock was put up for sale to fix Britains largest victim of the subprime crisis, the mortgage lender is still causing headaches.

title: Action Off Broadway
description: Plenty of things are still happening in the theater world, thank you very much, including these two announcements from Off Broadway: Gods Ear, the critically praised Jenny Schwartz play that had its premiere earlier this year at New Georges, is going to open at the Vineyard Theater on 15th Street, with previews set to begin in early April. Anne Kauffman will return to direct the play, which was developed by the Vineyard. The MCC theater company has announced that its prolific playwriting partner, Neil LaBute, has popped in with a new work, reasons to be pretty, the last in a trilogy that began with The Shape of Things and Fat Pig. Mr. LaButes play, slated to run from May 14 through July 5 at the Lucille Lortel Theater in Greenwich Village, is a replacement for The Black Suits, a musical by Joe Iconis that was dropped from the schedule because of casting disagreements.

title: Stories Set the Scene for Vintage Songs
description: Charles Cochran is one of the best of a vanishing breed. Now celebrating his 50th year as a saloon performer, the singer, pianist and raconteur is a storehouse of show business lore as well as a musician who elevates a sophisticated piano-bar tradition synonymous with Bobby Short as close to a high art as it can get.

title: Panel Drops Immunity From Eavesdropping Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15  Reflecting the deep divisions within Congress over granting legal immunity to telephone companies for cooperating with the Bush administrations program of wiretapping without warrants, the Senate Judiciary Committee approved a new domestic surveillance law on Thursday that sidestepped the issue.

title: Albany: Cuomo Criticizes Nuclear Plant Review
description: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo joined five other state attorneys general in criticizing the Nuclear Regulatory Commissions review of applications to extend the operating life of nuclear plants. The group said the N.R.C.s consideration of the potential effect of earthquakes and terrorist attacks was insufficient. The owner of the two reactors at Indian Point, in Westchester County, has applied to extend its license by 20 years. Diane Screnci, a spokeswoman for the commission, said the agency conducted rigorous examinations to determine safety.

title: An Exclusive Beachfront, Far From the Coast
description: THE Indiana Dunes, just 40 miles southeast of Chicago, rise to great heights along the Lake Michigan shore, looking like a swatch of Cape Cod sneaked into the Midwest. A legacy of the ice age, the Dunes lure second-home owners to quiet communities strung along the beachfront. Its promoters call the region Indianas Crescent Coast, Casual Coast, Duneland, Dune Country, even the Lake Michigan Riviera. But the Dunes need no hype.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Dropping Off My Daughter, at a New Life
description: ITS not just the parents of college-bound freshmen who must learn to let go. Its the parents of recent college graduates who have decided to set up housekeeping for the first time 3,364 miles from home.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about transplant recipients who contracted H.I.V. and hepatitis C from donated organs misstated the organization that first reported the news. It was Fox News Chicago, a television station, not The Chicago Tribune.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the selection of John A. Thain, the chief executive of NYSE Euronext, to lead the brokerage firm Merrill Lynch misstated Thursdays closing price for NYSE shares in some copies. It was $86.74, not $78.69.

title: Signs of Slump at Gem Sale in Myanmar
description: BANGKOK, Nov. 15  Officially, the government-sponsored gem auction that opened this week in Myanmar is a success, with 2,667 traders browsing the countrys renowned rubies, jade, sapphires, and other precious stones, the New Light of Myanmar, a state-run newspaper, reported Thursday.

title: Italy: Police Killing of Soccer Fan Set to Be Murder Case
description: A prosecutor said he was preparing to bring a murder charge against a policeman who fatally shot a 26-year-old Roman man over the weekend as he tried to break up a brawl between rival soccer fans. Hundreds of fans went on the rampage after the killing of the man, Gabriele Sandri, near Arezzo, which the authorities initially called a tragic error. But witnesses said the policeman, Luigi Spaccarotella, fired with his arm outstretched and with both hands gripping the gun, suggesting more than a warning shot. A lawyer for the policeman said he was dumbstruck by the development.

title: Two Women Recommended for Federal Court
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer announced yesterday that he had recommended two women to the White House to fill vacant posts on the federal bench in Brooklyn and Manhattan. Mr. Schumer recommended Kiyo Ann Matsumoto, a United States magistrate judge in the Eastern District of New York, for the opening on United States District Court in Brooklyn. If nominated and confirmed, Judge Matsumoto would become the first Asian-American judge in that court. He also recommended Cathy Seibel, the deputy United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, for the district court posting in Manhattan.

title: Clintons in Thick of Barbed Democratic Debate
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton shifted to a much more assertive tone in a debate Thursday night by going directly after her opponents, issuing a stern warning that Democrats should stop throwing mud and adopting tactics right out of the Republican playbook.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,854 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: No. 2 Oregon Falls to Arizona
description: Oregon is the latest top-five team to fall this season, losing on the road to Arizona, 34-24, Thursday night.

title: J Allard: Microsofts Plan to Be King of All Media
description: In November 1994, I had breakfast with Nathan Myhrvold, then the chief technology officer of Microsoft. He talked about how the soon-to-be-introduced MSN online service would best America Online. Central to his thinking was that MSN would give publishers a higher percentage of the per-minute fee for using the service. This would draw more content and thus more users to Microsoft and allow it to earn a smaller fee on a larger block of minutes.

title: J Allard: Dancing Around the Cellphone Question
description: A cynic would describe Microsofts approach to the music player market as simple Apple envy. The iPod has dominant market share and is helping Apple increase its small share of the PC market. So Ive got to imagine that many in the inner sanctums of Redmond are hot to introduce a slick phone from Microsoft.

title: Korean Boot Camp Aims to Cure Web Addiction
description: In South Korea, the Jump Up Internet Rescue School aims to help young Koreans overcome the growing problem of Internet addiction.

title: Cyclone Sidr Kills 240 in Bangladesh
description: NEW DELHI  Packing winds of over 100 miles an hour, the furious cyclone that swept across the low-lying watery edges of southern Bangladesh late Thursday downed trees, sent mobile telephone towers crashing and swept away mud and thatch homes. By midday today local time, the death toll of Cyclone Sidr, as it was called, stood at roughly 240, said an official reached by telephone at the control room of the Disaster Management ministry of Bangladesh.

title: China to Allow Hong Kong Stock Purchases, Analyst Says
description: China will introduce a program allowing individuals to invest directly in Hong Kong equities in the second quarter of next year, HSBC Holdings said.

title: Live Nation Inks Deal for Signature Network
description: Live Nation, the worlds largest live-concert promoter, said Thursday that it had reached a deal to acquire Signatures Network, a major manufacturer of concert T-shirts and other music merchandise, for about $79 million in cash, stock and debt.

title: Resolution and Pearl Continue Takeover Talks
description: Talks continued Thursday between British insurance firm Resolution and its suitor Pearl Group to hammer out a deal that will probably not significantly exceed the 4.9 billion pound ($10.2 billion), or 720 pence per share, offer already on the table.

title: Credit Losses Could Trim Lending by $2 Trillion, Goldman Says
description: Goldman Sachs top economist said losses from slumping credit markets may reduce lending by $2 trillion.

title: D.C. Tech Leaders Create Seed Fund
description: Several leaders of Washingtons technology community are creating an investment firm to back local entrepreneurs as they start up companies, The Washington Post reported, the latest in a series of local organizations helping to turn promising innovations into businesses.

title: Abu Dhabi to Invest $700 Million for A.M.D. Stake
description: A day after a report surfaced that New York hedge fund Galleon Group has purchased several million shares of  Advanced Micro Devices, the U.S. chipmaker looks set to get another large investor.

title: Initiate Systems Tries I.P.O. Route
description: Initiate Systems, a master data management company, filed this week to raise up to $75 million in an initial public offering. But, The 451 Group asks, could an M&A event still be in its future?

title: Automakers Healthcare Fund May Get Wall Street Drooling
description: General Motors, Ford Motor, Chrysler and the United Auto Workers have created a $54.4 billion plum for Wall Street.

title: What Could Cisco Buy Next?
description: If Cisco wants to make a big splash in the managed security arena, it may need to do some more shopping. The 451 Group looks at some of the takeover targets that the company might pursue.

title: TPG Presses Ahead With Iberia Bid Despite Rival Offer
description: TPG Capital will push ahead with its offer for Spains No. 1 airline Iberia Lineas Aereas de Espaa despite seeing its indicative 3.4 billion euro ($5 billion) offer trumped by a rival Spanish syndicate, The Deal.com reported.

title: EnergySolutions Raises $690 Million in I.P.O.
description: Buyout shop Lindsay Goldberg is partially cashing out of EnergySolutions through a $690 million initial public offering of the nuclear services provider.

title: Betting an Estate on Inhaled Insulin
description: Pfizer, the worlds biggest drug company, flopped miserably with a seemingly cant-miss idea. But Alfred E. Mann is so certain he can succeed that he is betting nearly $1 billion of his own money on the effort.

title: Canadian Pension Fund Launches $1.4 Billion Auckland Airport Bid
description: The Canadian Pension Plan Investment Board formally launched a 1.8 billion New Zealand dollar ($1.4 billion) bid for a stake in New Zealands Auckland International Airport on Friday, prompting the airport to seek rival offers.

title: More of Your Late Night Jokes
description: More submissions from readers to tide us over during the TV writers strike (send yours via the comment link below). Look for more posts like this in the days ahead:

title: Amid Credit Woes, Asset Managers Deals Hit New Record
description: Acquisitions of asset management firms have surpassed even last years record levels as financial institutions like Morgan Stanley seek stable revenues amid volatile markets.

title: Tokyo Seeking a Top Niche in Global Finance
description: Years ago, Japan rose to economic prominence by taking apart American products like cars and television sets to learn how to make them better.

title: Congress Examines Nursing Home Buyouts
description: Lawmakers in two hearings on Thursday proposed ways to force nursing homes to provide more details about ownership and to hold those owners more accountable when problems emerge.

title: When Audit Files Become Plaintiffs Fodder
description: When the Shaw Group, an industrial engineering company, became mired in a contract dispute over its construction work on an electricity plant in Texas, it filed a lawsuit against its client, the AES Corporation.

title: Rio Tinto Said to Mull Pac-Man Defense Against BHP
description: Shares in BHP Billiton rose as much as 2.4 percent on Friday, bucking the trend in a broadly falling stock market, following a report that Rio Tinto was considering a counterbid for its BHP.

title: Jozy Altidore: Greetings From South Africa
description: Red Bulls forward Jozy Altidore contributes items for The New York Times Goal blog each week. In his latest post, Altidore discusses his trip to South Africa as a first-time member of the United States senior national team.

title: 3i Goes Undercover With Agent Provocateur
description: London investor 3i Group added new meaning to the term private equity with an agreement announced Thursday to acquire luxury lingerie retailer Agent Provocateur. The price was not disclosed but, according to The Deal.com, the deal valued the company at about 60 million pounds ($124.3 million).

title: Democrats Urge Caution on Media Ownership Rules
description: Two high-ranking Democratic lawmakers asked the Federal Communications Commission not to rush changes in the longstanding rule that had barred a company from owning both a newspaper and a radio or television station in the same city.

title: In ID Theft, Some V.C.s See Opportunity
description: Gideon Yu, the former chief financial officer of YouTube and current chief financial officer of Facebook, is one of the most notable new executives in Silicon Valley. But while Mr. Yu operated in high-techs highest circles over the last two years, an impersonator was quietly using his name and credit card number to make fraudulent purchases.

title: Stray Questions for: Cathleen Schine
description: Cathleen Schines most recent novel is The New Yorkers.

title: Hedge Funds Feel Investment Banks Pain
description: Investment banks, hammered by massive write-downs and trading losses since the summer, are radically shifting business plans of their mortgage-backed securities departments  and its leaving hedge funds out in the cold, according to The New York Post.

title: Thain Plans to Bolster Merrills Trading Division
description: Merrill Lynchs new chief executive, John A. Thain, said price drops in the mortgage- securities market may create great opportunities and plans to hire senior managers to bolster the trading division.

title: Northern Rocks Debt Complicates Its Sale
description: Two months after Northern Rock was put up for sale to fix Britains largest victim of the subprime crisis, the mortgage lender is still causing headaches.

title: Cerberus Offers to Redo United Rentals Deal
description: Cerberus Capital Management, the private equity firm, has offered to negotiate new terms with United Rentals after abandoning a $4 billion buyout this week, according to regulatory documents.

title: With CSXs Letter, Showdown With Hedge Fund Looms
description: CSXs board on Friday publicly backed management and rebutted criticisms by a hedge fund that the railroad operator has overspent and failed to improve its stocks performance.

title: BEA Tries to Prove Its Worth to Oracle
description: BEA Systems has been hoping to prove it is worth more than the $6.7 billion that Oracle offered to pay for it last month.

title: Lost in Translation
description: A series of Fanta soft-drink commercials from Japan:

title: Stuff Im Reading and Liking
description: Its time again for Fridays week in reading:

title: Born Standing Up
description: Beforehand

title: The Early Word: Clinton Back on Her Game
description: Of the seven Democratic candidates onstage at last nights Las Vegas debate, Hillary Rodham Clintons aggressive performance seemed to put her back on her feet after last months debate.

title: Rodriguezs Potential Yankee Deal: A Goldman Connection
description: Goldman Sachs is a perennial leader in the mergers and acquisitions league tables, with strength in nearly every category. Apparently, now its reaching into deal making in the sports arena.

title: Connecting the Energy Dots
description: [UPDATE, 2/13: I wrote a story on a federal court ruling that could open the way for more mountaintop coal mining. Environmental groups say the ruling adds urgency to their calls for President Obama to erase some rules favorable to those seeking to expand such mining that were written by the outgoing Bush administration.]

title: The Generals New Clothes  Must We Watch?
description: Just asking, but have we really thought through the physical implications of what were repeatedly asking Pakistans President to do?

title: National Test Shows Little Progress for City Schools
description: New York Citys eighth graders have made no significant progress in reading and math since Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg took control of the city schools, in contrast with the largely steady gains that have been recorded on state tests, according to the National Assessment of Educational Progress. As Jennifer Medina reports in a front-page article, the results paint a generally stagnant picture for the city, although there are gains in fourth-grade math. On measure after measure, the scores showed no significant change between 2005, when the test was previously administered, and 2007.

title: Garmin Pulls Bid for Tele Atlas
description: Garmin on Friday withdrew its 2.3 billion euro ($3.4 billion) bid for Tele Atlas, clearing the road for TomTom to acquired the digital map maker.

title: Can You Hear Them Now?
description: Reflecting the deep divisions within Congress over granting legal immunity to telephone companies for cooperating with the Bush administrations program of wiretapping without warrants, the Senate Judiciary Committee approved a new domestic surveillance law on Thursday that sidestepped the issue, reports The Timess James Risen:

title: Ho, Ho? No.
description: News from Down Under:

title: UK Gloom
description: Confidence in U.K. housing prices is at its lowest level since 2003, according to the latest report by Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors. Although London remains strong, surveyors reported that house price growth remained negative for the third month in a row.

title: Strike News: Paying the Late Night Crew (For Now)
description: Seven days ago, nonwriting staff members on The Tonight Show with Jay Leno were informed that they would be laid off at the end of this week. But the plan has changed and the staffers will be paid for at least another two weeks, Broadcasting & Cable reports.

title: Strike News: TV Guide Cancels Awards Show
description: An interesting casualty of the writers strike: On Thursday TV Guide magazine said it would cancel a ceremony and a broadcast of its first Online Video Awards, Stuart Elliott notes in Fridays New York Times.

title: Strike News: Strike and Counterstrike
description: Wednesday the writers guilds claims about residuals were rebuffed by ABC Studios. Thursday the studios claims about residuals were rejected by the writers. And the picketers walk round and round.

title: When the Gown Devours the Town
description: Are universities gobbling up New York City? Town-gown disputes have flared recently at such diverse schools as Columbia University (where hunger-striking students are protesting a campus expansion in Harlem), New York University (which is steadily developing more and more of Greenwich Village) and even Queens College (which is building its first dormitory).

title: J Allard: The Failures of the Zune and the Record Labels
description: I posted a few excerpts from my conversation earlier this week with J Allard of Microsoft about the companys grand plans and its ideas about cellphones.

title: No Buyout Tax Debate for These Democrats
description: Taxes on hedge funds and private equity funds made a prominent appearance in the latest Republican debate, but that subject  a hot-button issue for the high-finance crowd  was notably absent from Thursday nights Democratic one.

title: The Art of Persuasion
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Greetings From Albany: Some Bruce Juice for Spitzer
description: After humbling reversals on immigration and sales taxes in the last week, and more troubles on the Troopergate front, how does Gov. Eliot Spitzer unwind?

title: Updikes Major Marginalia
description: A few months ago, in my TBR: Inside the List column, printed weekly on dead trees, I wrote about a galley copy of a Michael Ondaatje novel, Anils Ghost, that was for sale on the used book Web site abebooks.com. What was special about this galley  and the reason it was offered at $1,250  is that John Updike had filled it with comments while preparing a review for The New Yorker.

title: Friday Morning Kickoff
description: Well, it didnt take long for the craziness to start in college football this week. Oregon became the fifth No. 2 team to lose this season when the Ducks were defeated, 34-24, by Arizona on Thursday night. Mike Tokito of the Oregonian writes that Oregon must now adjust in order to salvage something from this season. Stewart Mandel of SI.com writes that the loss showed just how valuable quarterback Dennis Dixon is to the Ducks. The B.C.S. Guru tells us what it all means for the, well, B.C.S.

title: Open Caucus: The Voters on the Debate
description: We asked the Open Caucus, our newly formed virtual roundtable of voters from across the country, for their views on last nights debate among the Democratic presidential candidates. A few commented as the evenings forum unfolded in Las Vegas; others have posted their observations overnight.

title: A Grocery Distortion of Her Record
description: From the Borowitz Report:

title: Opting Out: The Gift That Kept Giving
description: Many people in baseball are privately delighted that the agent Scott Boras will get less than he wanted for Alex Rodriguez. The Yankees will soon make official a 10-year contract with Rodriguez for about $275 million, with the chance to make at least $300 million. Boras had contended that Rodriguez deserved more than $32 million per season.

title: The Debate After-Party
description: LAS VEGAS  It was a long night for the Democratic candidates. After the two-hour debate last night, they went over to the ballroom at the Paris Las Vegas Hotel on the Strip to make their cases to 2,300 Democrats in fancy evening wear at a gala dinner.

title: Another Strike Video, a Good One
description: Irving Brecher, who wrote Meet Me in St. Louis and Bye Bye Birdie, weighs in on the writers strike. Hes 93. His agent died. Hes seeking representation. Hes mad. Here he is:

title: Q and A: Jimmy Bradley
description: With the opening of the Red Cat in 1999, Jimmy Bradley moved to the forefront of New York City chefs, establishing his talent for putting together  and executing  menus that could please both demanding, sophisticated eaters and those just looking to pass the time with comforting, satisfying food.

title: Vows: Merrill and Cory
description: To gain Merrill Beth Winner's heart, Cory Bronson first had to make it past her doorman.

title: All Politics Is Local
description: In his column today, Carl Hulse writes about how Republicans and Democrats are digging into the results from local elections held earlier this month to discern trends for 2008. It is hard to overstate how carefully lawmakers and their political advisers have been combing through the data from municipal, county and state elections to see what it means for them.

title: Different Joe, Different Roles
description: How times have changed for the Yankees: as important as Joe Torre was to the success of the major league team, he was not involved in the larger aspects of the organization. New manager Joe Girardi, meanwhile, has spent the week at the teams academy in the Dominican Republic.

title: A Professors Farewell Sparks a Media Frenzy
description: In September Randy Pausch, a computer science professor at Carnegie Mellon University, gave his last lecture, telling the audience that he would soon die of pancreatic cancer. But those may not be his last public words after all.

title: Removing the Nuclear Threat in North Korea
description: How serious is North Korea about getting rid of its nuclear weapons and forging more normal ties with the United States?

title: An artistic night
description: New York  Unbelievable and Liveable opened at the Opera Galley in Paris on Thursday, IHT writer Emily Badger reports.

title: In Georgia, Fighting Riots With a Horrible Racket
description: Check out this video clip, posted by Russia Today and linked by Wireds Danger Room security blog, showing scenes from the police crackdown on demonstrators last week in Tbilisi, the capital of the Republic of Georgia, where a state of emergency is being lifted today. About halfway through the two-and-a-half-minute clip, youll see what appear to be LRADs  long-range acoustic devices, a sort of sound cannon  in action on the back of two police pickup trucks.

title: Big Bank Seeks C.E.O. for L.T.R.
description: With Citigroups search for a new chief executive entering its third week, columnists Michael Lewis of Bloomberg News and Rob Cox of Breakingviews are offering the gigantic bank their unsolicited  and sharply ironic  advice on the situation.

title: Whats Shaking at the Port Authority
description: At a time when transportation hubs are being reshaped by security measures, it might be logical to infer that the enormous structural outriggers added last weekend to the Port Authority Bus Terminal were intended to protect the structure in an explosion. Or deter pigeons, perhaps. In fact, their primary purpose is to reinforce the terminal against a different kind of trauma: earthquakes.

title: Questions About Carville and CNN
description: There are very few political analysts more closely associated with the Clintons than James Carville, who was a key adviser to Mr. Clinton in the 1992 campaign.

title: Weekly Matchups
description: The game of the week this week is clearly Harvard-Yale. Seriously. Michigan and Ohio State both lost last week to make their game not quite as big as it could have been. Still its for the Big Ten and that still counts for something, right? The other intriguing matchups of the weekend are Georgia-Kentucky, with the new Mark Richt shaking things up in Athens and Boston College looking to stop its free fall and still grab the A.C.C. title. Clemson-Boston College is for the Atlantic Division and that makes it worth watching. Unlike Notre Dame-Duke, which is worth watching like a train wreck. Anyway, not much more college football out there this year so take advantage and watch some games this weekend.

title: Weekly Pick Em
description: The madness has already begun this week, with Arizona knocking off No. 2 Oregon last night. Will the weekend bring more upsets? Or will this be a weekend when the results go to form? And what team will emerge as the king of the Ivy League? Our fearless prognosticators will attempt to answer these questions with their weekly predictions.

title: Microsofts Search Aspirations Revive Yahoo Chatter
description: It doesnt take much to rekindle speculation about a tie-up between Microsoft and Yahoo. Analysts, investors and bloggers have long discussed the pros and cons of this as yet strictly hypothetical pairing. So when a Microsoft executive went on the record Thursday about wanting to triple the size of his companys Internet search business, it was more than enough to get the rumor mill creaking back into action.

title: Katrina Update: Poor People Lose Again
description: When Hurricane Katrina hit, poor people in Louisiana and Mississippi bore the brunt of it  they lived in the most vulnerable areas and structures, and they were in the worst position to escape the storm and deal with the aftermath.

title: Berlin in Lights: The Woman Question
description: Whenever the Vienna Philharmonic comes to Carnegie Hall, much is made of its glacial progress in hiring female players. The Berlin Philharmonic, which plays at Carnegie Hall tonight in the closing weekend of the Berlin in Lights festival, has also had to overcome a long history of exclusion.

title: Anger Simmers in Bed-Stuy Over Police Shooting
description: Listen to the First 911 Call (mp3)

title: Performa 07: Surprise and Other Crucial Elements
description: I was floored to see that Vaughan Rachel, Allan Kaprows first wife, responded to my request for thoughts from people who had seen his 1959 happening  and such thoughtful comments, too; I love the idea of the awkwardness that comes from trying something for the first time, and how vital that awkwardness can be. Just to push my luck, Ms. Rachel: what were the original performers like? I was wondering, while watching last weekend, if the 1959 cast (somehow, that word isnt quite right) was as serious and remote as this one.

title: CNN and the Questionable Question
description: Most observers feel that Hillary Clinton aced the diamonds or pearls question at last nights Las Vegas debate, and many feel that the question was frivolous, trivial, and sexist.

title: Sony Needs a Hero for PlayStation 3
description: Video game sales are hot, despite the continued lag of Sonys PlayStation 3 console.

title: When a Name Leaves a Trail Through the City
description: Kevin Mooney, proprietor of Mooneys Pub on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn, has encountered his fair share of Mooneys who werent related to him in his 72 years. I think I was the latest  I stopped in on Wednesday to interview him about the bar, which apparently is going to be closing soon.I had always seen the place and wondered about it, whether there was some distant family relationship. If there is, it is distant enough that neither Kevin Mooney nor I know about it; he was born in County Galway, in Ireland, whereas my grandfathers family came to New York from Scotland in the early part of the 20th century. Its definitely an Irish name, though, so it seems as my familys Mooneys did some bouncing from island to island long ago. So you never know - I read once that, mathematically speaking, we can all claim descent from Nefertiti and Confucius anyway.

title: Fridays Links: The Unheralded Return of Ricky Williams
description: It seems surprising that the return of Ricky Williams has not produced more news media coverage. A player talented enough to rush for 1,853 yards and 16 touchdowns in a season, who then had his career torpedoed by positive drug tests and a bizarre trip around the world, he should be the talk of the town. Instead, he is being mostly ignored. Jeff Darlington of The Miami Herald took a look at his return with the Dolphins, but most other media outlets have gone with this Associated Press story as the only mention of him. On second thought, a player who cant stay clean, who plays for a team that is 0-9, probably shouldnt expect much more.

title: Ratings: Democratic Debate v. Supernatural
description: For the second consecutive week, CBS edged past ABC on Thursday to lead the nights ratings in both total viewers and among adults 18 to 49. Although Greys Anatomy remained No. 1 in that demographic, giving ABC a strong second place finish overall, CBS proved more consistent throughout the night.

title: The Week in Comments: Great Writing Talent Even Greater Evil
description: A selection of reader comments from some of the weeks most popular posts:

title: A Greenwash Brigade Is on the Prowl
description: Is a buy local economy really sustainable?

title: Back to the Cutting Edge of the Good War
description: That extreme necessity can be the mother of extraordinary invention may never have been more obvious than during World War II. From the blitzkrieg beginning to the atomic end, the course of the conflict was shaped profoundly by which side had the technological upper hand, so both sides kept up a furious pace of wartime R & D that wound up besotting the world with gadgetry and science.

title: Solving the Cold-Water Problem
description: My brilliant wife and talented builder have partially solved a problem that has bothered me ever since I began taking showers at the age of 5.

title: If You Give a Mouse a $25,000 Frrrozen Haute Chocolate
description: Serendipity 3, a popular restaurant on East 60th Street, was in the news last week for a publicity stunt boasting about the worlds most expensive dessert: a $25,000 Frrrozen Haute Chocolate. It was back in the headlines today, after the city shut it down for failing a second health inspection.

title: CNN Boasts Record Debate Ratings
description: The CNN debate last night was the most-watched debate this primaryseason on either a broadcast network or cable channel, drawing 4,036,000 viewers, according to CNN; Nielsen has verified the numbers.

title: Case Over Heads Photo Is Dismissed
description: Do people walking down the street have a right of privacy against having their picture taken, without permission, for a gallery show? The Court of Appeals, the states highest court, skirted that issue on Thursday when it cited procedural grounds to dismiss a lawsuit by an ultra-Orthodox Jewish man who had sued a photographer on religious grounds. The court did not address the privacy issues at the heart of the case.From 1999 to 2001, the artist and photographer Philip-Lorca diCorcia took images of individuals walking through Times Square. None of them knew they were being photographed. In the fall of 2001, Mr. diCorcia exhibited some of the photos at the Pace/MacGill gallery, which published and sold a catalog of images from the exhibition. Ten limited-edition prints of each photo were created for sale to the public.

title: PLAY: Avoiding Infamy
description: On Sunday, the New England Revolution will try to avoid becoming the Buffalo Bills of that other kind of football. The team will play in its third consecutive Major League Soccer Cup title game, and its fourth overall. Like the Bills from 1991 to 1994, the Revs have come up empty each time, the epitome of great expectations unfulfilled.

title: Pop Stars Riding M.L.S.s Coattails
description: For years, soccer supporters in the United States have been predicting the inevitable popular ascent of Major League Soccer. And while Ive never understood their evangelism, I shared their optimism.

title: The Parameters of Our World, Alas
description: What we are reading elsewhere

title: Complicated Drumming Technique
description: A scene from the latest instructional DVD of Jens Hannemann, otherwise known as Fred Armisen.

title: Behind Clintons Diamonds and Pearls
description: At last nights Democratic presidential debate, the candidates faced questions on Pakistan, trade policy, and merit pay for teachers. So how did it come to pass that, at the close of the debate, Senator Hillary Clinton was asked what sort of jewelry she liked?

title: What really came out of the McLaren appeal
description: What was most important in what came out of the McLaren appeal against the stewards decision to not punish BMW Sauber and Williams at the Brazilian Grand Prix was not this statement from the FIA:

title: Mike Nelson: Psychic Vacuum
description: Artist Mike Nelson transformed the Essex Street Market into   a public art installation with reconstructed rooms, passageways, and   environments.

title: Crunch Time for Buyout-Backed Retailers
description: The holiday shopping season kicks off next week, and many private equity chiefs are probably biting their nails. Thats because buyout firms are coming off a years-long spree in the retail sector, during which they borrowed heavily to take chains such as Toys R Us and Michaels Stores private, sometimes at nosebleed prices.

title: Should Bank Regulators Force Writedowns?
description: My column today offers what seemed to me  after I heard it from Bob Barbera, the economist quoted in the piece  to be an obvious explanation of why we should have been suspicious of bank profit reports before the current crisis blew up.

title: Mr. Percentage of a Percentage
description: The second season of [(Layers)] starts today on the humor video site Super Deluxe. Its a spoof about a Hollywood agent who represents Hollywood agents (who in turn has representation himself). Heres the inaugural episode from last season, which contains one passing profanity. (Other episodes have stronger language):

title: Mike Huckabee
description: Students from Harvard's Institute of Politics with Mike Huckabee and his supporters in New Hampshire.

title: 'First Time Ever'
description: Students from Harvard's Institute of Politics in New Hampshire.

title: President Dobbs? Nah
description: Lou Dobbs of CNN swatted away rumors today that he might run for president.

title: Fantasy Football Gems & Gimps
description: Shaun Alexander owners, I hear your collective screams of agony. I knew hed be a big, giant bust heading into the year  yes, Im a soothsayer, perhaps even a warlock, get used to it. I avoided him like Ebola in all leagues. Still, I feel your pain. Seriously, if someone filed a class action lawsuit against Alexander for torpedoing fantasy seasons everywhere, youd want in, right?

title: Landlord Eviction Trick Backfired, Investigators Say
description: Landlord-tenant hostility is nothing new in New York City, but investigators said today that a Brooklyn landlord, Oludola Johnson, took things to a new and illegal level.

title: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 16
description: Here is a slide show of 12 photographs that tell the story of the past week in the New York region. Subjects include the stagehands strike on Broadway, the shooting of an 18-year-old man by police in Bed-Stuy and a mistaken burial at Calverton National Cemetery in Calverton, N.Y.

title: Audio: Whats Coming in Mitchells Steroid Report
description: Assitant Sports editor Jay Schreiber discusses the Mitchell investigation steroid report with reporters Duff Wilson and Michael S. Schmidt. (mp3)

title: E-Trade Over Laundry?
description: One of the best lines of the season thus far came this week from the Harvard sports information director Kurt Svoboda. At Harvards practice Tuesday night, one of the biggest things that stood out compared to a Big 12 or SEC practice was the lack of student managers. Most universities from B.C.S. conferences have at least a dozen managers waiting on the sidelines to help out, shag balls or act as gophers for the coaches.

title: Nascar Still Second Fiddle to N.F.L.
description: Johnson! Gordon!! SUNDAY!!!

title: Football's Tenor
description: Noah Van Niel, Harvard fullback and operatic tenor, showcases his vocal talent.

title: Bloggingheads: The New Social Issue
description:
Rosa Brooks of Georgetown Law School, left, and Jonah Goldberg of the National Review discuss how terrorism is reshaping conservatism.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: Clinton Addresses DNC
description: Senator Clinton addressed the Fleet Center crowd on the first night of the 2004 Democratic National Convention in Boston.

title: Hawks Blog
description: This season fans have been getting an inside view of what makes Colorado Coach Dan Hawkins tick.

title: Being Adopted, and Being Me
description: Being adopted is different. It can be confusing to the adopted kid and to other people (especially if you are a transracial adoptee, because they spot the difference and then want answers). So, adoption to me is black  and my family is white.

title: Why Do We Do It?
description: Harvard fullback Noah Van Niel has made a name for himself nationally by pulling off the rarest of duets. Hes both the bruising starting fullback for the Harvard football team and a promising opera singer who is a regular in campus musical productions. He plans on pursuing singing opera as a career when he graduates this spring. But before that, he has one final game against Yale on Saturday to determine the Ivy League championship. Here are his thoughts on why he and his fellow seniors have traded 355 days of pain for 10 days of bliss each fall.

title: A 4th Climate Warning. Anyone Listening?
description: It was the culmination of an extraordinary meeting on the human-changed atmosphere. For three days, scientists had described how a buildup of long-lived gases emitted by burning fuels and forests would, if it continued, raise temperatures, raise seas and disrupt weather patterns important to agriculture, water supplies and wildlife.

title: Q & A: M.L.S. Commissioner Don Garber
description: Major League Soccer Commissioner Don Garber sat down with The New York Times for a wide-ranging interview to discuss the status of the league. Excerpts from the 45-minute interview appear in the Saturday Interview in the Business section. The full transcript follows.Q: The obvious first question is about the impact of David Beckham, on and off the field, especially considering how much time he missed because of injuries.

title: Respond to Todays Column: Hillary Fries the Waffle
description: We invite you to leave your responses to the Saturday, Nov. 17 column.

title: Jack Kuney, 88, Producer of Notable Early TV Shows, Is Dead
description: Jack Kuney, who produced and directed some of early televisions most widely praised shows, and who also produced a rarely seen, made-for-television farce by Woody Allen that lampooned the Nixon administration, died on Nov. 7 in Bradenton, Fla. He was 88 and had lived in Bradenton in recent years.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some editions on Nov. 1 about the death of Linda S. Stein, a Manhattan real estate agent and a pioneer of the punk music scene during her marriage to Seymour Stein, the founder of Sire Records, attributed an erroneous distinction to him. Although several publications say Mr. Stein was the creator of the Billboard Top 100 music charts, now known as the Hot 100, they were in fact created by Tom Noonan, Mr. Steins boss at the time. The caption for a picture in some editions showing Ms. Stein and some of her music industry associates in 1979 misstated the surname of the wife of the musician Dee Dee Ramone. She is Vera Ramone, not March.

title: A Costly Kiss
description: A judge in Avignon, France, fined a woman 1,500 euros ($2,200) for leaving a lipstick kiss mark on a pure white canvas by the American artist Cy Twombly, Agence France-Presse reported yesterday. The judge also told the woman, Rindy Sam, 30, above, to pay a symbolic one euro in damages to the 79-year-old artist. Ms. Sam, an artist herself, was arrested in July after she planted the kiss on a panel of Mr. Twomblys triptych Phaedrus, in the Museum of Contemporary Art in Avignon. The painting is valued at $2.8 million. At her trial last month, Ms. Sam said: It was an act of love, when I kissed it, I wasnt thinking. I thought the artist would understand. But Agnes Tricoire, the lawyer for the plaintiffs, said, For me love requires the consent of both sides.

title: Questions for Roddick After Rout by Federer
description: SHANGHAI, Nov. 16  Although Fridays matches at the Masters Cup were not unreasonably long  indeed one was rather fast  setting up the events semifinal matchups had a laborious feeling.

title: Figuring the Ultimate Odds
description: The recreational gambler dubbed Old Man was at an adjoining poker table when three masked men broke in from Fifth Avenue, bagged $100,000 and  in what looked like a grotesque accident  shot an innocent player to death. One of these crazies dropped his shotgun and, boom! said Old Man. He was still shaken days later as the police sought the thieves who got the drop on private guards and fleeced 150 players in one of the many illegal poker dens that usually operate in quietude at night across the citys high-rise skyline.

title: Not Much Room for Furniture, but Thats Part of the Game
description: The man at the table wears a gray suit, brown shoes, no tie and a face that looks as if it has seen a thing or two. He doesnt speak. He takes only one sip from his shot glass.

title: Zimbabwe: Mugabenomics Gathers Pace
description: Zimbabwes annual inflation rate, already the worlds highest by far, rocketed to nearly 15,000 percent in October, almost twice the rate for the previous month, the privately owned newspaper The Zimbabwe Independent reported. The government, which normally issues inflation reports early in the month, refused to confirm the report, but similar leaks have proved accurate in the past. The latest rate of price increases amounts to a jump of 132 percent a month, well above the 103-percent-a-month rate reported for September. President Robert G. Mugabe issued a defiant statement, saying that inflation was a plot by Western destructive forces and vowing that Zimbabwe will not collapse, now or in the future.

title: Smoke and Mirrors in the Education Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Immigration Quandary: A Mother Torn From Her Baby
description: Federal immigration agents were searching a house in Ohio last month when they found a young Honduran woman nursing her baby.

title: With Mustache, Without Arrow
description: BOSTON  In person, Steve Martin, now 62, is far from a wild and crazy guy  if he ever really was one. His hair is snow white. Though still youthful, his famously mobile face is mostly in repose. Hes a lot like your tax accountant, only a little shyer.

title: Journalists Killed by Indonesian Army in 1975, Inquiry Finds
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 16  An Australian coroner concluded Friday that the Indonesian Army killed five Australia-based journalists at the beginning of its 1975 invasion of East Timor to prevent news of an Indonesian attack from reaching the outside world.

title: Off for Break, Congress May Still Face Stalemate
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  Congress departed on Friday for a two-week break, leaving behind a stack of unfinished work as a major farm bill became the latest victim of a stalemate that has bedeviled Congress all year.

title: Experts Advise a Grain of Salt With Mail-Order Genomes, at $1,000 a Pop
description: The revolution in human genomics, still barely understood in the doctors office, is about to hit the street, at least for those able to pay about $1,000 for a glance at their entire genome.

title: Pierce Says He Is Ready to Play
description: Giants middle linebacker Antonio Pierce practiced yesterday for the first time since sustaining what the team called a mild concussion last Sunday. The Giants said Pierce would play in tomorrows game at Detroit.

title: Turkey: Legal Moves to Ban Kurdish Party
description: Supreme Court prosecutors accused the only Kurdish political party in Parliament of colluding with separatist rebels and moved to disband it, the semiofficial Anatolian News Agency reported. If convicted of the charges in a 121-page indictment, 221 registered members of the Democratic Society Party, including 8 of its members in Parliament, could face a five-year ban from politics. The prosecutors contend that there are direct links between the partys founders and the rebel group known as the Kurdistan Workers Party, or P.K.K., and that the Democratic Society Party, which won seats in Parliament in July, was simply a re-invention of banned Kurdish parties. The action comes amid tensions with Iraq over Turkeys threat to make cross-border attacks on P.K.K. bases.

title: Silencing La Scala
description: La Scalas 800 workers will go on strike today, forcing the Milan opera house to cancel two shows, Agence France-Presse reported yesterday. The strike over better wages and working conditions follows a similar walkout last Friday, which forced the cancellation of a performance of Verdis Requiem. La Scala will again cancel Requiem today, which was to have been conducted by Daniel Barenboim in Parma as part of the 50th-anniversary celebrations of the death of the conductor Arturo Toscanini.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Spare Times for Children listing in Weekend yesterday about The Cat Who Went to Heaven, a puppet musical at Culture Project, in SoHo, included outdated schedule information. After the section went to press, Culture Project said the production, scheduled to open today, had been postponed indefinitely.

title: Looking for the Truth When It Keeps Changing
description: This is a piece of fiction, Faustin Linyekula says at the start of Festival of Lies, which opened on Wednesday night at Bricstudio in Brooklyn. But one thing is indisputably real: the food and the bar.

title: Bhutto Rejects Caretaker Government
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, Nov. 16  Hours after being released from house arrest, the opposition leader Benazir Bhutto on Friday rejected a new caretaker government appointed by the Pakistani president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, to oversee elections and repeated her vow not to reopen talks with him.

title: On Strike to Protect the Gains of the Past, With an Eye on the Future
description: Suddenly, it seems, organized labor is flexing its muscles again.

title: Reagan in Neshoba
description: To the Editor:

title: Hoping (Dreaming?) of Soccer as National Pastime
description: DON Garber became the commissioner of Major League Soccer in August 1999, after the league lost $250 million over its first five seasons and shrank by two teams to 10. At the time, it appeared to be the latest failure of a soccer league in North America.

title: M.T.A. Executive Gets Political Donation From Bidders on Railyards
description: A vice chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority who is running for Congress in New Yorks northern suburbs has taken political donations from two developers bidding for the right to build a mammoth residential and commercial complex over the authoritys West Side railyards, according to federal election filings.

title: Memphis Squanders Early Lead Before Beating Connecticut
description: The best thing that could be said about Connecticut last night was that the Huskies were resilient. It was just that they needed to be something more.

title: Finding Her Haven From Terror, a Continent Away
description: In 1994, Carlos Raul Bonilla was kidnapped by a guerrilla group known as FARC, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia. His wife, Martha Palomino, who had no idea he was a target, never saw him again.

title: Railroad and Hedge Fund Square Off
description: Directors at CSX, the railroad operator, publicly supported management Friday and rebutted criticisms by a hedge fund that the company had overspent and failed to match its peers performance.

title: CBS Takes Thursday
description: For the second consecutive Thursday, CBS edged out ABC in total viewers and among adults 18 to 49, although ABCs Greys Anatomy remained No. 1 in that demographic. CBS dominated with Survivor: China, (14.8 million viewers) at 8 p.m., Nielsen estimated, and at 9 its CSI attracted 21.3 million viewers, two million more than Greys Anatomy in the hour. At 10, a special broadcast of ABCs Womens Murder Club came in third (8.9 million), behind CBSs Without a Trace (14.5 million) and NBCs ER (9.5 million). NBC ranked third, ahead of Fox, as both 30 Rock at 8:30 (6.5 million) and The Office at 9 (8.9 million) delivered their best ratings since the shows season premieres. On Wednesday, the fourth seasons premiere of Project Runway on Bravo drew 2.9 million viewers, the largest audience ever for a premiere on the cable channel.

title: Brodeur Fails to Win No. 500 on Third Try
description: NEWARK, Nov. 16  Devils defenseman Mike Mottau skated backward with the puck in his zone Friday, scanning the ice for just the right moment to launch another power-play rush. What happened next typified the Devils frustrating season so far.

title: Evaluating Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: China Tilting Away From Longtime Trading Partners
description: THE economy of China continues to grow rapidly, but the benefits of that growth are no longer being spread as widely around the world, with Europe a particular loser as its exports to China begin to fall.

title: Pigeon-Rights Groups Rush to Defend Their Feathered Friends
