description: When Councilman Simcha Felder, a Democrat from Brooklyn, announced on Monday that he was going to introduce legislation that would make feeding pigeons an offense punishable by a fine, he made plain his feelings about rats with wings, a phrase used by a parks commissioner, Thomas P. F. Hoving, in the 1960s and popularized by Woody Allen in his 1980 film Stardust Memories.

title: Gore Plans for a Date at the White House
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  President Bush and former Vice President Al Gore have spoken just a few times since the evening of Dec. 13, 2000, when Mr. Gore conceded the presidential race, five weeks and a Supreme Court ruling after the voting had ended.

title: Art Sale Still Blocked
description: The Virginia Supreme Court has temporarily blocked the sale of four paintings by the financially troubled Randolph College in Lynchburg, Va., The Associated Press reported. The move came after a group opposed to the sale of the art failed to post a $10 million bond on Thursday that would have kept a lower courts injunction against the sale in effect. The state Supreme Court stepped in and lowered the bond to $1 million and gave opponents until Dec. 3 to post it. The works, from the colleges Maier Museum of Art, include a George Bellows painting that Christies has valued at $25 million to $35 million. The first auction of the works had been scheduled for Monday and a second for Nov. 29 at Christies in New York.

title: Ex-Judge Is Sentenced After Sting by F.B.I.
description: A former judge from Long Island was sentenced yesterday to 33 months in prison for conspiring to launder almost $400,000 in proceeds from stolen jewelry.

title: $30 Million for U.C.L.A. Music School
description: The University of California, Los Angeles, received $30 million from the trumpeter and record company executive Herb Alpert, left, and named a new music school after him, Bloomberg News reported yesterday. Mr. Alperts donation is the largest to support the arts in the University of California system, the university said. The U.C.L.A. Herb Alpert School of Music will encompass the universitys departments of music, musicology and ethnomusicology and will be devoted to the performance and study of a range of musical styles, including jazz, world, popular and classical, the university said. The school will contribute to what we hope will be a transformation of music studies in American higher education through an open and inclusive approach to all music, said Christopher Waterman, dean of the universitys School of the Arts and Architecture.

title: Some Hunches About Intuition
description: CAN people improve their intuition?

title: Closing Time for a Diner That Fed the Body and Soul
description: CHAFFEE, N.Y.

title: The Bridge Champs Who Did Not Vote for Bush
description: To the Editor:

title: Tax Inquiries Can Combine Guesswork and Digging
description: Unlike Superman, a tax auditor does not have X-ray vision. When building a case against someone who files a tax return as a nonresident but has an apartment in New York, the auditor cannot look inside the apartment.

title: Cyclone Kills Hundreds in Bangladesh
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 16  Packing winds of over 100 miles an hour, the furious cyclone that swept across the low-lying watery edges of southern Bangladesh late Thursday downed trees, sent cellphone towers crashing and swept away mud and thatch homes, leaving at least hundreds dead.

title: Giuliani, Foe of Socialized Medicine, Expanded Public Care
description: In campaigning for president, Rudolph W. Giuliani has criticized Democrats for promoting socialized medicine, boasted about his record as mayor of New York City for dramatically reducing public assistance, and vigorously opposed expanding government health insurance for children.

title: A Plane to Beat All Planes
description: To the Editor:

title: At Least 15 Died in Crackdown, Myanmar Tells Envoy
description: BANGKOK, Nov. 16  Paulo Srgio Pinheiro, the United Nations human rights envoy to Myanmar, said Friday that Burmese officials had acknowledged that 15 people, not 10 as they previously said, were killed in the military governments crackdown on protesters in September.

title: Merrill to Pay Chief $50 Million, More if Stock Rises
description: Call him Wall Streets richest mop-up man, at least for now.

title: Marbury Says He Is Willing to Accept Role as a Backup
description: SACRAMENTO, Nov. 16  His practice jersey was white, a symbol of his reduced status. His left knee was wrapped in ice, a reminder of his decline. His personal space was cramped by reporters  a sure indication that Stephon Marburys travails are far from over.

title: Corrections: or the Record
description: The Books of The Times review on Thursday, about Born Standing Up, by Steve Martin, misstated his connection to Saturday Night Live. While he has appeared on the show many times, he was not a cast member.

title: Florida: Former Sheriff Is Sentenced
description: A former Broward County sheriff was sentenced to a year and a day in prison after resigning as sheriff and pleading guilty in September to federal tax evasion and mail fraud charges. The former sheriff, Ken Jenne, 60, was charged with secretly accepting tens of thousands of dollars from contractors doing business with the sheriffs office and falsifying his tax returns in 2001, 2002 and 2004. Mr. Jenne had served as the Broward sheriff since 1998. Before that, he was a state senator for almost 20 years, four of them as Senate Democratic leader.

title: U.S. Acts to Bolster Supply of Water for Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 16  With only a few months of readily available drinking water remaining for Atlanta, federal biologists on Friday allowed Georgia to keep more water in a reservoir that supplies the city and elsewhere in the northern part of the state, a decision that reduces flows to Florida.

title: Coin Dealers Sue State Dept. for Details on Import Bans
description: Three organizations representing coin collectors and dealers have filed a lawsuit against the State Department demanding greater disclosure of how the government makes decisions on the import of ancient artifacts from abroad.

title: Joe Nuxhall, Modern Baseballs Youngest Player, Is Dead at 79
description: Joe Nuxhall, who became the youngest player in modern major league history when he pitched in one game for the 1944 Reds at age 15, then went on to spend more than half a century with Cincinnati as a pitcher and broadcaster, died Thursday in Fairfield, Ohio, outside Cincinnati. He was 79.

title: Election Watchdog Group Cancels Russia Mission
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 16  Western election observers on Friday pulled out of a mission to monitor Russias Dec. 2 parliamentary vote, citing restrictions imposed by the Kremlin on their work.

title: Bread Is Broken While Interfaith Bonds Are Built
description: FRISCO, Tex., Nov. 15  The outcome was uncertain when a group of mostly strangers sat down together for dinner Thursday night at a home in this Dallas suburb. Among the gathering were three Jews, two Mormons, three Muslims, two Bahais, two secular humanists and a Catholic-Baptist.

title: A Smokers Tax, Defeated in Oregon
description: To the Editor:

title: ONeills Landscape, Still Untrodden
description: The early, little-known Eugene ONeill one-acts presented as The Pioneer by the Metropolitan Playhouse show the playwrights dramatic universe in embryo. Here, born battling, are all the downtrodden and trapped who grope for meaning in his world: the prostitutes, pimps and pipe-dreamers, sailors and drunks, mismatched husbands and wives.

title: Doping Officials Question Baseballs Policy on Drugs
description: MADRID, Nov. 16  After years of criticizing Major League Baseball for what he called useless, toothless drug-testing policies, Dick Pound, chairman of the World Anti-Doping Agency, chastised the sport again Friday, saying that Barry Bondss indictment on perjury charges confirmed that the leagues doping problems were out of control.

title: Shopping Bargains Before the First Bite of Turkey
description: Yes, the economic outlook is grim.

title: Abu Dhabi Takes 8% Stake in Advanced Micro
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 16  Advanced Micro Devices said Friday that an investment arm of Abu Dhabis government had taken an 8 percent stake in the company for $622 million.

title: China: Loans Cut for Polluters
description: The government suspended bank loans to 12 polluting companies as part of its new green-credit policy, the newspaper China Youth Daily reported. The report did not name the companies but said they included a brewery and a power company. The purpose of this move is to force enterprises to pay the price for environmental violations, the newspaper quoted an Environmental Protection Administration official as saying.

title: In U.S. Name Count, Garcias Are Catching Up With Joneses
description: Step aside Moore and Taylor. Welcome Garcia and Rodriguez.

title: Kmart Items Marked Safe Had Lead
description: Kmart said yesterday that it would remove all jewelry advertised as lead free from its shelves after workers at lead monitoring programs who tested the pieces found that some actually contained high concentrations of the metal.

title: Timing of Bondss Indictment Feeds Speculation
description: Why now? A defense lawyer for Barry Bonds and two outside legal experts raised questions yesterday about the timing of the perjury indictment against Bonds, saying they did not understand why it came this week and not months or even years ago.

title: U.N. Report Describes Risks of Inaction on Climate Change
description: VALENCIA, Spain, Nov. 17  Secretary General Ban Ki-moon, describing climate change as the defining challenge of our age, released the final report of a United Nations panel on climate change here Saturday and called on the United States and China to play a more constructive role.

title: Living History, in Veterans
description: To the Editor:

title: When Doctors Inject a Disease
description: The discovery of a Long Island doctors astonishingly lax approach to infection control has raised troubling questions about the adequacy of medical oversight in New York State  and the packaging of medicines in vials that are easy to contaminate.

title: Swedish Warhols Are Fake
description: Six wooden Brillo boxes in the Andy Warhol collection at a Swedish museum are fakes that were made in 1990, three years after Warhol died, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Warhol created the original reproductions of Brillo soap pad cartons as part of a 1964 exhibition of art resembling supermarket products. (At right is a version of the 1964 original.) The museum, Moderna Museet in Stockholm, said it had investigated the six Brillo boxes, donated in 1995 by its former director, Pontus Hulten, after a Swedish newspaper claimed that they were copies. In a letter to the Andy Warhol Art Authentication Board in New York, the museum director, Lars Nittve, confirmed the claims. These boxes are not authorized by the artist and should be removed from the official list of Andy Warhol Brillo boxes, Mr. Nittve wrote. The Swedish paper Expressen reported in June that Mr. Hulten, who was director of the museum in the 1960s and the Georges Pompidou Center in Paris in the 1970s and 1980s, had Swedish carpenters build 105 copies of the box for an exhibition in Russia in 1990. Expressen claimed that Mr. Hulten, who died last year, sold a number of the copies with certificates falsely stating that they were made for a Warhol exhibition in Stockholm in 1968.

title: OPEC Gathering Finds High Oil Prices More Worrisome Than Welcome
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 16  As oil prices hover around $95 a barrel, OPEC might be expected to celebrate. Its members are reaping record revenues, demand for their product keeps rising and the world economy seems capable of sustaining oil prices that would have seemed unthinkable a few years ago.

title: Rhode Island Will Trim State Work Force
description: BOSTON, Nov. 16  About 500 state employees in Rhode Island are expected to lose their jobs, Gov. Donald L. Carcieri announced on Friday. The state is trying to close a projected $450 million budget gap for the next fiscal year.

title: Judge Declares a Mistrial in Texas Cat Killing Case
description: A judge in Galveston, Tex., declared a mistrial on Friday in the case of a bird enthusiast who killed a cat that he said was stalking endangered birds. Jurors said they were hopelessly deadlocked.

title: Canada Bars Seaweed-Apparel Health Claims
description: Lululemon Athletica, a yoga apparel maker, has agreed to stop making health claims in Canada about its VitaSea clothing, a line that the company says is made with seaweed.

title: Democrats Find Their Voice
description: It has been two long months since Gen. David Petraeus, the top commander in Iraq, cowed Congressional Democrats into silence, championing President Bushs misguided course on the war. Were pleased to see that the effects of his briefing are finally wearing off. The bad news, as ever, is that Mr. Bush and his Republican allies continue to resist reason.

title: Lottery Numbers
Awareness of Dog Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Keeping Track of the Tracks
description: The private racing club concept is becoming popular, though the road from pipe dream to pavement can be long and difficult. In addition to the track at Monticello, there are others in varying stages of development. Here are a few:

title: Judge Demands Documentation in Foreclosures
description: After the recent dismissal of 14 foreclosure cases by a federal judge in Cleveland, another federal judge in Ohio has given lenders 30 days to prove that they own the properties they intend to seize from troubled homeowners in 27 other cases.

title: More Than a Social Worker, a Friend
description: Mariana Duenas is a caseworker from Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, where she has worked for almost four years. She has been working passionately on behalf of her client Martha Palomino for almost that long.

title: A Taste of Baboon and Monkey Meat, and Maybe of Prison, Too
description: It takes strategic thinking to find monkey meat in New York. Best to avoid the word monkey, for one thing  start with something innocuous-sounding, like dry meat, or common, like grass cutter, a rodent similar to the guinea pig. Seek out the proprietors of tiny West African restaurants, or the bushmeat market queens who do business out of their homes.

title: Indian Coalition Wins Political Dispute Over Nuclear Pact
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 16  The governments Communist allies gave Prime Minister Manmohan Singh significant breathing room on Friday to push ahead in pursuing a landmark nuclear accord with the United States.

title: In Theater District Bars, Many of the Glasses Are Half-Empty
description: Broadway, like the old Fulton Fish Market, is a business and a culture  once described by Stanley Walker, the Jazz Age city editor, as an excited condition of fourth-rate emotions realized, at street level, in chow-meineries, peep shows for men only, flea circuses, lectures on what killed Rudolph Valentino and other amusements that he was too much of a prude to put in print.

title: Hard-Working Plagiarist Just Wants to Keep Her Job
description: Theres a top-notch satire, probably a one-act, lurking in Body Parts, a full-length work by Ishmael Reed receiving its East Coast premiere at the Nuyorican Poets Cafe. Mr. Reed, though, is a man angry about many things, and all of them are crammed into this play, which makes it more like target practice with a machine gun than like well-aimed criticism.

title: The Bluefin Slaughter
description: The hunting of highly valued animals into oblivion is a symptom of human foolishness that many consign to the unenlightened past, like the 19th century, when bird species were wiped out for feathered hats and bison were decimated for sport. But the slaughter of the giant bluefin tuna is happening now.

title: Sorenstam Ends Season Without a Win
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 16  Annika Sorenstam was about to hit her last full shot in her last official L.P.G.A. competition of 2007, a 5-iron from the middle of the 18th fairway. In years past, when Sorenstam ruled womens golf, such a shot would have been almost as routine as hitting a wedge from 100 yards.

title: Angioplasty and Stents
description: To the Editor:

title: Car of Today Is Laps From Being Yesterdays News
description: HOMESTEAD, Fla., Nov. 16  Chad Knaus, crew chief for the Nascar driver Jimmie Johnson, made a quick pitch when asked what Hendrick Motorsports planned to do with all the racecars that Johnson, Jeff Gordon and others have put in victory lane over the years.

title: French Transit Strike Falters, but Stretches Into Weekend
description: PARIS, Nov. 16  No relief was in sight for weekend travelers as a strike that has snarled public transportation across France appeared likely to continue into next week.

title: Chvezs Vision Shares Wealth and Centers Power
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 16  In two weeks, Venezuela seems likely to start an extraordinary experiment in centralized, oil-fueled socialism. By law, the workday would be cut to six hours. Street vendors, homemakers and maids would have state-mandated pensions. And President Hugo Chvez would have significantly enhanced powers and be eligible for re-election for the rest of his life.

title: Stretching and Soaring to Bach, Balanchine and Shostakovich
description: The Pennsylvania Ballet opened its second night at City Center on Thursday with Concerto Barocco, George Balanchines classic set to Bachs Concerto in D minor for Two Violins, and that choice signified more than just another repertory evening. In 1964 Concerto Barocco was part of the first program presented by the company, formed the year before by the intrepid Barbara Weisberger, who had been Balanchines first child pupil. He didnt, it should be noted, charge her a cent for Barocco. Those were the days.

title: The M.B.A. Under Attack
description: THERE is a rising reaction against management theory, according to The Economist. A new book by the management expert Gary Hamel, The Future of Management, notes that several well-known executives of hot companies  among them, Sergey Brin and Larry Page of Google and John P. Mackey of Whole Foods Market  did not go to business school.

title: Why Must ID Security Be So Hard?
description: TWO and a half years ago, someone managed to swipe just enough of my personal data to create a fake debit card that was linked to my checking account. Through a series of shopping sprees  nicely detailed in my online account statement  the thief charged about $1,700 before I noticed, called the bank and stopped the crime.

title: Drama, Perhaps, but Only From Negotiations
description: The producers league and the stagehands union are set to sit down for talks this morning to try to end the strike that has kept most of Broadway dark for a week.

title: Forget Fair; Its Litigation as Usual
description: They had the kits ready to go. The trial package, they called it.

title: WADA Election Now 2-Man Race
description: MADRID, Nov. 16  The election of a chairman of the World Anti-Doping Agency to succeed the controversial and outspoken Dick Pound went from simple to decidedly complex Friday, when the presumptive new leader of the antidoping agency  who was running unopposed  found out a day before the vote that he might have competition.

title: Koreas Announce New Cooperation
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 16  The prime ministers of North and South Korea announced a significant package of cross-border economic projects today to help rebuild the Norths broken economy and ease military tension on the divided Korean Peninsula by increasing human and cargo traffic across the demilitarized zone. At the end of three days of talks here, North Koreas prime minister, Kim Yong-il, and his South Korean counterpart, Han Duck-soo, agreed to start cross-border freight-train service for the first time in more than half a century, scheduling the first, and highly symbolic, border crossing a week before South Korea holds presidential elections on Dec. 19.

title: Storied Rembrandt to Be Shown at the Getty
description: An early Rembrandt portrait that has not been on public view for more than two decades and has a lively criminal past  it was stolen at gunpoint from the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, more than three decades ago  will re-emerge for several months, beginning on Tuesday at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles.

title: New Plays Inspired by Those Oldsters, Homer and Stravinsky
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12  Making old things new again is a frequent preoccupation of artists in many mediums. Classic stories are revisited by writers hundreds of years apart; an image in an old master painting inspires a contemporary riff; a Jane Austen novel becomes a glossy popular movie.

title: Harold Alfond, Donor and Shoe Factory Owner, Dies at 93
description: Harold Alfond, a former factory laborer who parlayed a hitchhikers tip into a fortune by founding the Dexter Shoe Company and running it for four decades, died Friday at a family home in Belgrade Lakes, Me. He was 93 and lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Gaza: Rally Detainees to Be Released
description: The Hamas-run Interior Ministry in Gaza announced the release of dozens of Fatah supporters detained after Mondays pro-Fatah rally. A Fatah spokesman, Hazem Abu Shanab, said that just a small number of the scores arrested had been freed. The mass rally ended in violence, with at least seven civilians killed by Hamas police fire. Yesterday, thousands of Hamas supporters rallied after noon prayers outside the abandoned Gaza home of the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, of Fatah. A Hamas leader, Khalil al-Hayya, warned Mr. Abbas against making any concessions to Israel on Palestinian rights or Al Aksa mosque in Jerusalem, threatening a huge explosion. Mr. Abbas governs from the West Bank and has not been in Gaza since Hamas took control there in June.

title: Whos Afraid of Those Smart Women?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Measure Against Rape Fails at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 16  The United States has failed to obtain a General Assembly resolution focused on rape used by governments and armed groups to achieve political and military objectives.

title: British Composer Sits In With Visiting Berliners
description: Thursday was a rare night off for the Berlin Philharmonic, a mainstay of Carnegie Halls Berlin in Lights festival. You could not have blamed the musicians for wanting some time to relax.

title: Thefts at Open Houses Put Marketers on Alert
description: While the Manhattan real estate market, defying national trends, still remains strong, city brokers are being warned to turn away two potential buyers: a team of thieves who, the police say, have attended at least six open houses in recent weeks and stolen expensive items like diamond rings, a fur coat, handbags and a bottle of Champagne.

title: Gift to Smithsonian Is Rescinded
description: The American Petroleum Institute has rescinded a controversial $5 million gift to the Smithsonian Institutions National Museum of Natural Historys Ocean Initiative exhibition hall. The Smithsonian said it received notice of the withdrawal in a one-sentence letter from the institute. The Smithsonian Board of Regents had been scheduled to vote on Monday on whether to accept the donation. Cristin Samper, the former director of the natural history museum, who is now acting secretary of the Smithsonian, approved the gift, but some regents have questioned its appropriateness. Mr. Samper, a candidate for the secretary position, has been serving since March, when Lawrence M. Small resigned the post after revelations about lavish personal spending. The Washington Post reported yesterday that some government scientists had complained that Mr. Samper ordered last-minute changes to the museums 2006 exhibition on the Arctic to avoid political problems. The additions suggested that there was scientific uncertainty about climate change, The Post said, but Linda St. Thomas, a Smithsonian spokeswoman, said yesterday that the show was never intended to be a comprehensive exhibition on climate change.

title: First Tourney Win for Hofstra Women
description: The junior midfielder Edel Malone and goalkeeper Krystal Robens carried Hofstra to a 1-0 victory over Ohio State yesterday in the opening round of the N.C.A.A. tournament at Penn States Jeffrey Field. Robens set university records with her seventh consecutive shutout and 12th of the season in the Prides first N.C.A.A. tournament victory. Hofstra (18-3) will face top-seeded Penn State tomorrow.The Pride scored 7 minutes 38 seconds into the second half when the freshman forward Kayla Pifer sent a low cross through the middle, where Malone was waiting at the far post.

title: Growing Focus on Reused Medicine Vials
description: Tucked inside the tale of a Long Island pain management doctor who used unsafe infection control practices is a growing public health concern: the risks of transmitting blood-borne diseases through medicine vials that hold more than one dose and can be used for injections for multiple patients.

title: Sergio del Valle, a Castro Stalwart, Dies
description: HAVANA, Nov. 16 (AP)  Gen. Sergio del Valle Jimenez, a doctor in Fidel Castros rebel army in the late 1950s and army chief of staff during the 1962 Cuban Missile Crisis, died on Thursday, the state media reported today.

title: Boston Scientific and Consultant Settle a Lawsuit
description: With a Dec. 3 trial date fast approaching, Boston Scientific and the ECRI Institute have settled a potentially controversial lawsuit that could have spotlighted efforts by Boston Scientific and other medical device companies to keep the prices of their major products secret.

title: A Clinton Friends Role Sets Off Intense Criticism of CNN and a Re-examination
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton prepared for a battle with her Democratic rivals at the CNN-sponsored debate on Thursday night. She did not have much to fear from the postdebate round table.

title: Giuliani Vexes Audiences With His Abortion Views
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  On the campaign trail, Rudolph W. Giuliani has made the case that while he believes that abortions are wrong, he thinks the ultimate decision of whether to have them should be up to women, and not the government. But he has also pledged to appoint the kind of conservative judges who might be expected to rule against abortion.

title: Envoy Elicits No New Promises From Musharraf
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 17  Continuing to defy the United States, President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan declined to say when he would lift a two-week-old state of emergency during a meeting with a senior American envoy today, Pakistani and Western officials said.

title: Yankees Use Economics to Their Advantage
description: With Alex Rodriguez virtually back in pinstripes, the Yankees have come full circle in an episode that epitomizes what separates them from the Boston Red Sox.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Swedish Warhols Are Fake

title: Brothers, Bad Blood and the Blackwater Tangle
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 16  They were smart, scrappy brothers who rose from modest circumstances in Baltimore to become lacrosse stars at Princeton, succeed in business and land big government jobs.

title: Georgia: Emergency Rule Lifted
description: As promised, the government of President Mikheil Saakashvili lifted a state of emergency imposed nine days ago after a crackdown on street protests. Mr. Saakashvili, left, also appointed a new prime minister, Lado Gurgenidze, chief of the private Bank of Georgia, to replace Zurab Nogaideli. Mr. Saakashvili is expected to resign his post next week, a legal requirement as he prepares for a presidential election he called for Jan. 5.

title: State of Emergency Lifted in Georgia
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 16  Georgias government lifted a state of emergency as promised today, nine days after the emergency was imposed following a crackdown on anti-government protests. The crackdown and emergency drew harsh Western criticism of a country considered to be one of the regions most democratic.

title: Cousins Sue Over Gipp Exhumation
description: Two distant cousins of George Gipp filed suit yesterday in a Michigan court against his great-nephew, ESPN, a biographer of Gipps and several others over the exhumation last month of the remains of Gipp, the Notre Dame halfback who died in December 1920.

title: Sunni Group Says U.S. Killed Its Members
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 16  A tribal group tapped by American forces to root out extremists here said Friday that more than four dozen of its members were killed during United States air and ground strikes north of the capital this week. But the United States military insisted that the attacks had been aimed instead at Al Qaeda and had killed 25 insurgents.

title: Herbert Barrett, Musicians Manager, Is Dead at 97
description: Herbert Barrett, a leading business manager who oversaw the careers of prominent musicians, particularly in classical music, for more than half a century in New York and helped organize the first Great Performers series at Lincoln Center, died on Nov. 5 in Manhattan. He was 97 and had lived in Manhattan his entire life.

title: The Russian Songbook, Under Western Influence
description: European culture has been chipping away at Russia for three or four centuries, with varying success. Dmitri Hvorostovskys elaborate evening at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday went back and forth on the subject.

title: Its Not Just the Uninsured
description: Sandra Hightower never thought of herself as particularly political. She worked, and much of her free time revolved around her daughter, Brittney, a fiercely outgoing teenager with a passion for cheerleading at her high school in Nacogdoches, Tex.

title: Photos Add to Problems of Beset Hoboken Police
description: HOBOKEN, N.J., Nov. 16  It has been a difficult few weeks for the Police Department in this trendy riverfront town. The beleaguered mayor, David Roberts, heaved a sigh as he summed it all up in a news conference this week: We have been on a slippery slide of matters getting worse.

title: Adding Math to List of Security Threats
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 16  One of the worlds most prominent cryptographers issued a warning on Friday about a hypothetical incident in which a math error in a widely used computing chip places the security of the global electronic commerce system at risk.

title: Judge Finds Tampering in Verdict on Teacher
description: SYRACUSE, Nov. 16  A music teacher charged in what prosecutors had called one of the largest molestation cases in central New York won the latest in a series of legal victories on Friday when a judge threw out his convictions, finding that two jurors had tried inappropriately to sway the others toward guilty verdicts.

title: As Presidential Vote Nears, Beiruts Residents Sense They Wont Be the Winners
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 16  Mireille Adas took part in a march through downtown Beirut this week, demanding that Hezbollah end its yearlong occupation of the citys commercial center. Her jewelry shop, steps away from the organizations tent camp, has suffered major losses as a result of the power struggle between Hezbollah and the government, which has paralyzed the capital and brought Lebanese politics to a standstill for nearly a year.

title: Barcelona Party Boys Mix Styles and Languages for a Good-Time Electronic Vibe
description: Is everybody happy? asked a voice from the stage as the Pinker Tones headed into the last stretch of their set at S.O.B.s on Thursday night. The grinning, dancing audience  small but elated  made the answer obvious. No one onstage had spoken; the words were samples, but that didnt make them any less sincere. The Pinker Tones are a trio of producers and disc jockeys from Barcelona who aim for nothing less than euphoria.

title: Condemned to Death and Capitalism
description: In recent years politically minded American filmmakers have, with reasonable cause, turned their artistic attention to the Iraq war and the various domestic policy issues that have arisen from it. And so the treatment of struggles in other parts of the world may have been sacrificed in some sense to that cinematic fashion.

title: A Health Dept.s Quandary: Warn the Public or Supervise the Doctor?
description: Days after a cluster of hepatitis cases in 2002 led health investigators to a clinic in Norman, Okla., the states chief epidemiologist held a news conference to urge anyone who had been a patient there to get tested immediately for blood-borne diseases. A nurses improper use of syringes was said to be the cause.

title: Detective Is Accused of Making Drug Runs
description: A police detective was arrested yesterday and accused of taking cocaine from the Bronx to Virginia as part of a drug-trafficking operation, law enforcement officials said.

title: Nets Start Slowly and Never Catch Up to Magic
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 16  The past week has not been kind to the Nets.

title: School Lesson
description: To the Editor:

title: My Genome, Myself: Seeking Clues in DNA
description: The exploration of the human genome has long been relegated to elite scientists in research laboratories. But that is about to change. An infant industry is capitalizing on the plunging cost of genetic testing technology to offer any individual unprecedented  and unmediated  entree to their own DNA.

title: Footnotes
description: The soprano Dawn Upshaw will perform Berios Folk Songs with the New York Philharmonic from March 5 to March 8. She replaces Audra McDonald, who withdrew because of a scheduling conflict. The concert is part of a program that includes Haydns Symphony No. 48, Maria Theresia, and Beethovens Symphony No. 4. ...Sandy Duncan, Fred Willard, above, Shonn Wiley and Mara Davi will join Rosie ODonnell and Beth Leavel in No, No, Nanette, the final 2008 Encores! presentation, with performances from May 8 to May 12 at New York City Center; nycitycenter.org.

title: Football Bruiser With Pavarotti Dream
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 13  For the final performance of his football career at Harvard, the senior Noah Van Niel can picture the perfect closing scene.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Newly Released column on Thursday, about books, referred imprecisely to Jonathan Hayes, author of Precious Blood, a novel described in the column. Dr. Hayes continues to work as a medical examiner for New York City.

title: Coin Collectors Sue State Department Over Import Rules
description: Three organizations representing coin collectors and dealers have filed a lawsuit against the State Department demanding greater disclosure of how the government makes decisions on the import of ancient artifacts from abroad.

title: U.N. Report Describes Risks of Inaction on Climate Change
description: VALENCIA, Spain, Nov. 16  In its final and most powerful report, a United Nations panel of scientists meeting here describes the mounting risks of climate change in language that is both more specific and forceful than its previous assessments, according to scientists here.

title: With a Full Quiver, Eager to Join the Band of Merry Men
description: I GRIPPED the plastic handle of my 66-inch-long rented bow, pretending to be a modern day Robin Hood. My surrogate Sherwood Forest was Pro Line Archery Lanes, an indoor range in Ozone Park, N.Y., with an outdoors motif. Deer, boar and bear heads adorned the walls.

title: Totals
description: Previously recorded $2,249,585.28

title: Love Takes a Tumble Amid a Brewing Storm
description: Love and the weather: what else is there, really? These far-reaching, changeable systems dominate our lives in myriad ways, big and small.

title: Courts Fuel-Economy Ruling May Prod Congress to Set Even Higher Requirements
description: DETROIT, Nov. 16  A ruling by a federal appeals court this week to throw out proposed fuel-economy standards is likely to accelerate efforts in Congress to set higher requirements for all vehicles, industry analysts said Friday.

title: Wal-Mart and Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets Washington Sees an Opening in the Pro Bowl
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 16  It is not easy to find a Pro Bowl candidate on a team with a 1-8 record, but the Jets have one in Leon Washington.

title: Prosecutions Best Pitch Is Precision, Experts Say
description: As news of Barry Bondss indictment on federal charges of perjury and obstruction of justice spread, handicapping a likely trial and predicting possible strategies immediately became popular throughout the nations law schools.

title: Hillary Fries the Waffle
description: Its remotely possible that some of you missed the very important and very lengthy Democratic debate this week. Perhaps you started watching it but had to switch off during the section on trade relations when you discovered your children had grown up and wanted to say goodbye before they left for college.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Spare Times for Children listing in Weekend yesterday about The Cat Who Went to Heaven, a puppet musical at Culture Project, in SoHo, included outdated schedule information. After the section went to press, Culture Project said the production, scheduled to open today, had been postponed indefinitely. (Go to Article)

title: Too Small a Sample
description: To the Editor:

title: When Their Alter Egos Come Out to Play
description: By day, Jennifer Donovan works as an astronomer, listening for the faintest whispers from atoms in deep outer space, the tracings of movement in galaxies millions of light-years from Earth.

title: Obstacles: Crowded Sidewalks and Misconception
description: In a blur, the New York University mens cross-country team ran west on 14th Street toward the Hudson River, passing through a bustling Union Square at midday. After the team crossed the West Side Highway, the Chelsea Piers descended quickly from the horizon as the runners headed south on a scenic pedestrian path in Hudson River Park and Battery Park.

title: Glavine Is Given an Offer by Braves
description: The likelihood that Tom Glavine will finish his career where it began increased yesterday when the Atlanta Braves offered him a contract. Last season, Glavines decision to re-sign with the Mets was made easier by the Braves inability to make him an offer. But this time Glavine has the option of returning to Atlanta, where his family lives.

title: When a Bad Break Is Good, and Other Lessons
description: The Internet has shrunk the world. At www.bridgebase.com we can watch live play in important bridge tournaments around the globe. Last weekend, while the European team champions were competing in Poland, the first semifinal of the English open trial took place at the West Midlands Bridge Club in Solihull.

title: Fed Official Hints at No Rate Cut
description: A Federal Reserve governor said yesterday that another interest rate cut would probably offer few additional benefits to the economy, a hint that the central bank plans to hold rates steady at its meeting next month.

title: The Case of the Rosenbergs: Their Sons View
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Bars Secret Papers in Eavesdropping Case
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  A federal appeals court said Friday that secrecy laws had forced it to exclude crucial evidence about the governments wiretapping of an Islamic charity, making it far more difficult for the charity to proceed with its challenge to the National Security Agencys eavesdropping program.

title: The Vitality of Youth Meets the Ripeness of Experience
description: International youth orchestras have become useful symbols for the world peace lobby. The UBS Verbier Festival Orchestra, which played at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night, advertises musicians from ages 17 to 29 and from 29 countries, among them a Chinese concertmaster and a Bulgarian timpanist.

title: Knicks Fall in Double Overtime, Stretching Losing Streak to Five
description: SACRAMENTO, Nov. 16  For one night, the Knicks had more pressing concerns than demotions, hurt feelings and their point guards frequent-flier miles. The problems were more fundamental: missed layups, fumbled rebounds and frequent miscues at the worst possible times.

title: Discontented, DreamWorks Is in Talks to Join NBC
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 16  Seeking a way out of an acrimonious relationship at Paramount, the DreamWorks principals  two Hollywood heavyweights, David Geffen and Steven Spielberg  have been negotiating to move their operation to NBC Universal, according to people close to the talks. But negotiations have hit a wall over financing.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column on Wednesday about the departure next month of a co-host of the new National Public Radio morning program The Bryant Park Project referred imprecisely to the programs scheduling on KCPW in Salt Lake City, where some listeners have complained that the program lacks substance. It did not replace NPRs Morning Edition on that station; Morning Edition follows it.

title: Set to Electric Violin, Thoughts Posted on YouTube
description: Daniel Bernard Roumain has built his career so far on small-scale works, partly because the orchestral commissions a young composer gets tend to be for scores lasting less than 15 minutes, and partly because his pop hybrids  the Hip-Hop Studies and tudes, for example  demand concision. So his 80-minute multimedia piece, One Loss Plus, which had its premiere at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday evening, is a technical and conceptual leap for him.

title: Herbert Barrett, 97, a Manager of Musicians, Dies
description: Herbert Barrett, a leading business manager who oversaw the careers of prominent musicians, particularly in classical music, for more than half a century in New York and helped organize the first Great Performers series at Lincoln Center, died on Nov. 5 in Manhattan. He was 97 and had lived in Manhattan his entire life.

title: One Market Remains Sound: Money Is Still There for Best Art
description: Never mind the gyrations on Wall Street or the subprime mortgage and equity crisis. Theres still plenty of money out there and an unquenched appetite for art. At least that seems to be the verdict after a two-week round of auctions at Christies, Sothebys and Phillips de Pury & Company, with bidders paying record prices for everything from a rare Matisse to a red heart sculpture by Jeff Koons.

title: In Fight Against Terror, Keen Ears Undistracted by Sight
description: ANTWERP, Belgium

title: NBC Acquires Quarterlife; Internet Series Will Run First Online
description: NBC has concluded a first-of-its-kind deal to acquire the talked-about new Internet and social network series Quarterlife for distribution as an hourlong drama series on the NBC network after it has first played in eight-minute segments on several Web sites.

title: Gotham Girls Roller Derby
description: The Gotham Girls Roller Derby League prepares for its season championship bout.

title: Two Words
Perelshteyn Wins Spice Cup
description: Eugene Perelshteyn, a grandmaster from Massachusetts, won the Spice Cup, a tournament at Texas Tech University in Lubbock, Tex. He led from start to finish, scoring 6.5 out of 9. Gilberto Hernandez, a grandmaster from Mexico, finished second, a half point back. The games from the tournament can be replayed at Monroi.com. The tournament, which was a memorial to Samuel Reshevsky, the Polish-born American grandmaster, was organized by Susan Polgar, chairwoman of the United States Chess Federation, and Paul Truong, Polgars husband.

title: Newbie Subie: Gnome on the Range
description: Introduced on Thursday: Subaru Impreza WRX STI

title: Mere Anarchy
description: To Err Is Human-to Float, Divine

title: 'Born Standing Up'
description: Beforehand

title: Long-run budget math
description: Some commenters have asked for more about Social Securitys role in the long-run budget problem, and in particular an explanation of my assertion that the Beltway obsession with Social Security reflects ignorance. So heres a quick, informal explanation.

title: Mystery of the mortgage mess
description: Theres a very good Economic Letter from the Dallas Fed about the housing crisis, which explains a lot about how the mess happened. In short: lenders began making lots of dubious loans in large part because they were able to slice and dice the loans and sell them off to investors who didnt know what they were buying. My only fault with the letter is that it doesnt emphasize the extent to which borrowers were also suckered in.

title: Saturday Morning Kickoff
description: In the wake of the news that Oregon quarterback Dennis Dixon will miss the rest of the season with an injured left knee, John Hunt of the Oregonian reports that Dixon actually tore the anterior cruciate ligament in his knee against Arizona State two weeks ago. After discussing the situation with his family and the Ducks coaching staff, he decided to continue to play despite the injury.

title: L.A. Auto Show: Governor Schwarzeneggers Environmental Message
description: LOS ANGELES  For the second year running, the biggest power name at the L.A. Auto Show was Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger. When it comes to the environment and California, hes the states A-list celebrity in more ways than one. And for an event that has become overwhelmingly green, hes the ultimate display-booth babe.

title: The Early Word: Giulianis New York Trail
description: Following his speech before the Federalist Society, a conservative legal group, Rudolph W. Giuliani is in the news. So is his wife, Judith, and in a departure, shes getting much better press than he is.

title: The Scene in Ann Arbor
description: While the national relevancy of Ohio State-Michigan is only a fraction of what it was last season, it goes without saying that folks around Ann Arbor are still fired up for this grandest of rivalry games.

title: Ratings: SpongeBob Earns 8.8 Million Viewers
description: On Monday on Nickelodeon, the first-ever made-for-TV Spongebob movie, Atlantis SquarePantis, attracted a staggering 8.8 million viewers at 8 p.m. The movie, which featured a special voice-over by David Bowie, was Monday nights No. 1 entertainment program on cable.

title: Strike News: Back To the Table (After Turkey)
description: Representatives of the writers guild and the studio alliance will resume contract negotiations on November 26, after the Thanksgiving Day weekend.

title: Quarterlife Makes Leap From Web To NBC
description: The creators of Quarterlife, a Web series about tech-savvy twentysomethings, havent hid their television ambitions.

title: The Scene in New Haven
description: The stakes are high this year at The Game, and the tension spread to the tailgate.

title: M.L.S. Cup: D.C. Field of Dreams
description: Please indulge my silly personal story.

title: Dancing With the Cars: Vote Now
description: LOS ANGELES  Chevrolet introduced three design studies for a proposed 50-miles-per-gallon city car at last Aprils New York International Auto Show. The company invited the public to vote online for their favorite  Beat, Trax or Groove  promising that the winner would be greenlighted for production.

title: A Whistle-Blower Speaks Out
description: Cynthia Fitzgerald has filed a False Claims Act lawsuit against a slew of health care companies alleging Medicare fraud.

title: eGherkinomics 101
description: Todays economic question is whether new technologies create wholly unanticipated new market opportunities. The online offering below suggests that the answer is indubitably in the affirmative:

title: Greece Query
description: An IHT reader sent in the following question:

title: First and Tenor
description: Clues to Harvards football prowess come in todays paper, in a story about Noah Van Niel, a fullback who has established himself as a promising opera singer:

title: Yet Another Holiday To Plan For
Dangerous Warming Still Undefinable to White House
description: Throughout the Bush presidency, there has been an aversion to addressing one question about global warming: How much is too much?

title: Meet M.L.S. in St. Louis
description: WASHINGTON   Or Collinsville, Ill.

title: Last Call for Carr?
description: No one came out and said it. But if you listened to the tone and heard the way people talked about Michigan Coach Lloyd Carr after his fourth consecutive loss to Ohio State on Saturday, it certainly seemed as if it was his last game as a head coach at Michigan Stadium.

title: Personnel File: Bengals Hope Henry Gets Back on Track
description: The return of the suspended wide receiver CHRIS HENRY should have been a boon for Cincinnati last week. Henry, who was sidelined by legal troubles, had averaged a touchdown every 4.46 receptions entering 2007 and was expected to draw attention from the Bengals other receivers while being a weapon himself.

title: Week 11 in Preview: Pressure Is on Panthers to Stop Favre
description: There are those who say the Packers  a young team led by an old quarterback  have been winning with mirrors. That may be the only thing they have not tried this season. They beat Philadelphia on a last-second field goal. They beat Denver on an 82-yard pass in overtime. They beat Minnesota last week with their first shutout in five years.

title: Nutt Reacts to Reports
description: After Arkansass 45-31 victory over Mississippi State today, Razorbacks Coach Houston Nutt addressed recent reports that have said he would not be back next season.

title: Living With the Three Gorges Dam
description: According to an official count, more than a million people were displaced by the building of the world's biggest dam. Now the "hidden dangers" of the project are coming to light.

title: Sundays Breakfast Menu, Nov. 18
description: This Sundays breakfast menu focuses on quality over quantity, with shows devoting their programs to a small number of big-name guests.

title: Friday Night Fights
description: A group of New York's firefighters and police officers spent Friday night punching one another's faces at a gym in Brooklyn.

title: You Asked. Now the Candidates Answer.
description: Weve told you before about 10Questions.com, an effort (with which The Times Editorial Board is affiliated) to let voters around the country decide which questions to ask the presidential candidates. Today, the second round officially begins, with users top 10 questions posted and candidate responses beginning to come in.

title: Liquid Gold in Morocco
description: The road from Marrakesh to Essaouira is craggy and bleak, an arid moonscape dotted only by a few roadside towns and the occasional Berber village. In the 60s and 70s, Essaouira was a stop on the hash-filled hippie trek  land in Marrakesh, load up your magic bus and head west for the windswept beaches and clear blue waters of this former Portuguese fishing village. Back then, Jimi Hendrix made the pilgrimage, as did Bob Marley and Cat Stevens. Essaouira still has remnants of its boho past: crocheted Rasta beanies are sold alongside fezzes in the souk; surfers come to lap up the waves in what is now one of the worlds top windsurfing and kiteboarding spots; and a dilapidated fort, which legend has it was the inspiration for Hendrixs Castles Made of Sand (he actually recorded the song nearly two years before touching down here), is just south of town.

title: The Cleanup After the Cleanup
description: THE year 1999 seemed to mark the end of an era for the Gowanus Canal, and a smelly era it was. In summers past, said Craig Hammerman, the district manager of Community Board 6 in Brooklyn, the odor would curl your toes.

title: The Lottery Industrys Own Powerball
description: STANDING recently in a Knoxville stadium filled with roaring University of Tennessee football fans, Rebecca Paul Hargrove, the highflying impresario of legalized gambling, proudly waved a symbolic check for a billion dollars. The moment, captured on jumbo screens across the stadium, was among the countless plugs for the fund-raising prowess of Tennessees lottery, which Ms. Hargrove started four years ago.

title: N.F.L. Matchups Week 11
description: CHARGERS at JAGUARS

title: Pakistans Collapse, Our Problem
description: Washington

title: Helsinkis Grub Club
description: Each night in Helsinki, Finland, a random assortment of people, from celebrities to the living dead, line up in front of a tiny metal hutch tucked behind the Finnish parliament building. Inside the kiosk sits an old woman sporting granny glasses and a Soviet-era dye job that tints her hair an iridescent tangerine. Two outsize condiment dispensers hang, udderlike, from the ceiling; meat patties in puck form are lined up in front of a grill. The Finns have a word for their proudest national characteristic: sisu, or, roughly, guts. It takes sisu  a lot of sisu  to eat at Ykkos Jaskan Grilli.

title: N.F.L. Matchups Week 11
description: BEARS

title: If Buyout Firms Are So Smart, Why Are They So Wrong?
description: ENOUGH already.

title: Yes, Its True: After Six Years, a Victory
description: The Bassick Lions finally roared. The high school football teams 62-game losing streak ended on Nov. 8 when it defeated another Bridgeport team, Harding, 20-18, at Kennedy Stadium.

title: Austrian Echo via the Island
description: Like Beaujolais nouveau, which arrived Thursday, Macaris Early Wine, a Long Island chardonnay, is suitable for Thanksgiving. The 2007 edition is aromatic and vivacious.

title: Under Siege, Life in Gaza Just Shrinks
description: ITS a miserable time to be a Gazan.

title: Bicyclist Killed in Fall on Bridge
description: A bicyclist riding on the Manhattan Bridge late Friday died after taking a wrong turn and flipping over a retaining wall on the bridges upper level, causing him to fall 15 feet to the lower level, where he was hit by a car.

title: Every Workday Needs a Game Plan
description: Q. You just finished an eight-hour day at the office and, looking back, you barely got anything done. Now you feel guilty and worthless. What happened?

title: 2 Koreas Agree on Aid to North and Trains Across Border
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 17  The prime ministers of North and South Korea have announced a significant package of economic projects to help rebuild the Norths broken economy and ease military tension on the divided peninsula by increasing traffic across the demilitarized zone.

title: Crazy Little Thing Called Risk
description: BACK when I was managing other peoples money, I had a client, a doctor, who enjoyed giving away money to his daughters. He was lucky, because an extended bull market was under way with only minor interruptions. The more he gave away, the more the market replaced what he had parted with. As generosity appeared to be a cost-free form of recreation, he considered the whole thing a riskless enterprise.

title: Dont Call Him a Filmmaker, at Least Not First
description: THE paintings on broken plates that made Julian Schnabel an art-world star in the early 1980s seemed to announce their importance not just by their retrograde swagger but also by their sheer weight. Hanging one on a wall was like suspending a cabinet full of Buffalo china.

title: Correction: Joy de Menil and Laird Reed
description: A report on Oct. 7, about the marriage of Joy de Menil and Laird Reed, misstated the title held by Ms. de Menil in 2005 when she worked at Heinemann Publishers in London. She was editorial director, not senior editor.

title: Clinton & Clinton
description: It is a brave author indeed who, without benefit of full hindsight or personal experience, proposes to write yet another nearly contemporaneous account of the most overexposed presidency of modern times. Bill and Hillary Clinton, separately and together, have inspired dozens of journalists, historians, prosecutors and partisans  not least themselves  to disgorge millions of words in biographies, memoirs, apologias, polemics and official independent counsel reports. Many of these narratives  notably Bob Woodwards Agenda, George Stephanopouloss All Too Human and Dick Morriss Behind the Oval Office (to say nothing of The Starr Report)  flooded the bookstores in the midst of the two-term Clinton presidency, whose triumphs, failures and grubby melodramas were already 24/7 grist for the cable news networks and the emerging World Wide Web.

title: In a Battle With Illness, Co-Workers Can Inspire
description: IN 2001, I learned I had ovarian cancer. I had no symptoms. One night I stepped off the treadmill and my stomach muscles seemed tighter. I reached down to feel them and found a lump on the left side of my abdomen. I knew it shouldnt be there.

title: Remains of the Day
description: There is a milking stool in Achille Castiglioni's design studio, the wooden kind that Swiss farmers have used to milk their cows for centuries. It isn't what you'd expect to find in the studio of one of the 20th century's most famous industrial designers, but Castiglioni rarely did the expected.

title: Nicole Dunn, Steven Fisher
description: Nicole Ashley Dunn, a daughter of Mitchell P. Dunn of Hewlett, N.Y., and the late Pauline Dunn, was married last evening in Lawrence, N.Y., to Steven Harris Fisher, a son of Susan and Mark I. Fisher of Harrison, N.Y. Rabbi Norton D. Shargel performed the ceremony at Temple Israel of Lawrence.

title: Democrats Outline Plans to Improve Environment
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 17  Three Democratic presidential hopefuls described their plans to combat global warming and promote energy independence at a forum here Saturday, with each emphasizing the need for government mandates to reduce greenhouse gases and voicing commitment to treaties on the environment.

title: Ochoa Trying to Build a Foundation for the Future
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 17  For the first time in a long time, the L.P.G.A. has what appears to be a cant miss story line as it closes out 2007 and looks ahead to the coming season.

title: Oceanic World Orders
description: It is impossible to imagine George W. Bush eating cucumber sandwiches on an English lawn while discussing the latest cricket scores. Yet this president, the one with the fewest English airs, has nonetheless inspired rampant Anglophilia among some foreign policy experts. With his unashamedly civilizing mission in the Middle East, and his deployment of gunboats as a tool of diplomacy, Bush has sent intellectuals dashing back to the British Empire for parallels and predecessors.

title: Aileen Humphreys, Matthew James
description: Aileen Ford Humphreys, the daughter of Virginia L. Humphreys of Lancaster, Pa., and the late James A. Humphreys III, was married last evening to Capt. Matthew Mackenzie James, the son of Lois M. James and Alan M. James of Lititz, Pa. The Rev. T. Alan W. Garrity, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Coral Beach and Tennis Club in Paget, Bermuda.

title: A Home for a Ballet Academy, and the Vision of Its Namesake
description: Peekskill

title: A Loud Legal Voice on Warming
description: While Washingtons politicians dither, the federal courts have become increasingly active in the debate over global warming, aggressively pushing the White House and Congress to regulate greenhouse gases or explain why they cannot. These rulings add the force of law to the demands for action from scientists, a growing number of business leaders, and many state governors.

title: From Trenton to Piscataway, a Virtual Tour of the State for Laughs
description: PRINCETON

title: Perlman Takes Post With Philharmonic
description: ITZHAK PERLMAN, the heralded violinist who counts among his fans several presidents, Queen Elizabeth II and Elmo of Sesame Street, has been appointed music director of the Westchester Philharmonic, beginning with the 2008-9 season.

title: With Carter Out Again, Nets Lose Fifth in a Row
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 17  The lineup may have been different Saturday night, but the result was a familiar one for the Nets. They lost again, this time to the Miami Heat, 91-87. That is five losses in a row for a team that continues to sputter without Vince Carter.

title: The Food of Love
description: Reading Service Included, Phoebe Damroschs memoir about waiting tables at the acclaimed Manhattan restaurant Per Se, I was reminded of George Orwell. The waiters skill, Orwell wrote, is chiefly in being servile. ... He lives perpetually in sight of rich people, stands at their tables, listens to their conversation, sucks up to them with smiles and discreet little jokes. He has the pleasure of spending money by proxy. Orwell quotes one waiter waxing rhapsodic about a particular meal: It was splendid, mon ptit, mais magnifique! Jesus Christ! The Champagne, the silver, the orchids  I have never seen anything like them, and I have seen some things. Ah, it was glorious!

title: In a Catalog of Catastrophes, Hurricanes Rule
description: A calamity-ridden part of the year  hurricane season  is about to end, and the United States was lucky to dodge the worst of its wrath in 2007. Mexico, Central America and the Caribbean bore the brunt of the damage this time.

title: In Frying Pan and Fire
description: WAR is hell, as General Sherman observed, but its many other things besides. Like no other earthly endeavor, war calls forth the best and the ugliest that humans can be: brave, brutal, petty, loyal and bored. The American venture in Iraq has summoned the whole range of human experience, from the hopes and hubris of the invasions first days to the dark and uncertain place the country is today.

title: Datebook
description: WALLAND, TENN.

title: For Late Autumn, Apple Gathering
description: The hayrides into the apple orchards of March Farm, in rural Bethlehem, ended a few weeks ago, but you can still enjoy the pretty panorama of farmland and surrounding hills by gathering apples yourself.

title: Fighting to Fix Whats Not Broken
description: Social Security isnt broke. So why are Democrats fighting so hard right now over how to fix it?

title: A Personal Salute to a Heros Memory; To Keep Oceans Full of Bluefin Tuna; The Yonkers City Council and a Historic Home (3 Letters)
description: A Personal Salute to a Heros Memory

title: As You Live and Breathe
description: To the Editor:

title: Shake, Rattle and Roll
description: WASHINGTON

title: Protocons
description: In the years between Franklin Roosevelts first victory in 1932 and Richard Nixons resignation in 1974, the Republican Party experienced many disasters. Behind them was a conservative movement that started in the political wilderness, a band of maverick intellectuals exiled from fashion and power in the 1940s and 50s, doubtful of their claim on the future.

title: When One Job Is Enough
description: When Joseph Lieberman hedged his bets by running for the United States Senate at the same time he ran for vice president, his dual candidacy was allowed because Connecticut law does not prevent one person from running for two seats.

title: A Private Club Where the Privileged Can Play With Cars
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y.

title: Letters: Is (His) Biography (Our) Destiny?
description: Those who feel safer with Hillary Clintons old-school big stick diplomacy than with the kind of intelligent use of soft power that Barack Obama endorses are living in the past. Our experiences in Vietnam and Iraq have established that use of force does not necessarily lead to beneficial results. What a President Obama would offer is a new avenue to power and respect, not through military might, but through cooperation and understanding. There is no strength more powerful than countries and peoples working together for the common good; and in the face of the dire threats we all share  from global warming to desperate acts born of social inequity  such cooperation can occur none too soon.

title: Stagehands Strike Continues, but Negotiations Resume
description: The producers league and the stagehands union negotiated into the night yesterday in an attempt to bring an end to the strike that has darkened most of Broadway for more than a week. They plan to begin talking again this morning at 9:30.

title: A Park That Ran With the Wrong Crowd
description: SALEM, Ore.

title: Harold J. Berman, 89, Who Altered Beliefs About Origins of Western Law, Dies
description: Harold J. Berman, a scholar whose expertise in Russian law took him to a Soviet courtroom to fight for royalties owed Arthur Conan Doyle, and whose forceful scholarship altered thinking about Western laws origins, died on Nov. 13 in Brooklyn. He was 89.

title: Alison David, Adam Cole-Kelly
description: Alison Nicole David, the daughter of Cookie David and Brian David of Chicago, was married there last evening to Adam Cole-Kelly, the son of Kathy Cole-Kelly of Shaker Heights, Ohio, and Thomas Kelly of Cleveland Heights, Ohio. Rabbi Daniel G. Zemel officiated at the Peninsula Hotel.

title: New Japanese Immigration Controls Worry Foreigners
description: TOKYO, Nov. 17  Japan has tried hard in recent years to shake its image as an overly insular society and offer a warmer welcome to foreign investors and tourists. But the country is about to impose strict immigration controls that many fear could deter visitors and discourage businesses from locating here.

title: So Many Nutcrackers, So Little Time
description: WELL, we are one more Nutcracker nearer death, the British critic Richard Buckle wrote in 1972. You get the tone. Here is the true sophisticate (note the royal we), jaded to the core, but there is this unkillable ballet, this glut of sweetness, this inevitable part of the dancegoers Christmas routine. If you think The Nutcracker is all tinsel, sugar and infantile twee-ness, then thats the tone you too should adopt at this time of year. In the United States, several stagings of The Nutcracker start on Thanksgiving weekend, and we wont be out of this Nutcracker season until after the New Year.

title: City of Priam
description: Peter Ackroyd belongs to another age. The author of more than a dozen novels, as well as volumes of poetry, plays and miscellaneous works of nonfiction, he recalls a time when it was commonplace for writers not merely to be prolific but to exhibit a sometimes bewildering catholicity of interest. In addition to biographies of Shakespeare, Dickens, T. S. Eliot and the city of London, he has written a book on transvestism and childrens guides to ancient Greece and Rome. Most of his novels are historical, depicting figures as diverse as Milton, Chatterton and Oscar Wilde. Now, in The Fall of Troy, he turns his attention to the 19th-century German archaeologist Heinrich Schliemann, whose quest to discover the ancient city of Troy becomes the occasion for a novel that is engaging, disturbing, intellectually complex and just a little kitschy.

title: Outside Yale Bowl, Plenty of Wine and Cheese
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 17  With a Proud Yalie sticker on the lapel of his trenchcoat, Stuart Tisdale stood outside the Yale Bowl Saturday afternoon, his face expressionless. Inside the Bowl, the final minutes were ticking away in Harvards 37-6 rout of the favored Bulldogs.

title: Garden City Gets Closer to Saving a Landmark
description: AFTER nearly 15 years, two lawsuits and several rejected proposals, Garden City is edging toward a decision to save the historic 500-room Cathedral School of St. Pauls, a stately landmark in the heart of the village.

title: Amy Goldman, Eric Falkenstein
description: Amy Elizabeth Goldman, a client relations manager for a law firm, and Eric Matthew Falkenstein, a Broadway theater producer, were married last evening. Rabbi Sylvin L. Wolf officiated at the Ritz-Carlton in Key Biscayne, Fla.

title: Channeling Dick Cheney
description: I have no idea who is going to win the Democratic presidential nomination, but lately Ive been wondering whether, if it is Barack Obama, he might want to consider keeping Dick Cheney on as his vice president.

title: Without a Trace
description: Not knowing is one of the more uncomfortable, if not terrifying, states of being. Without a clear ending, theres no escape. When the television goes to black, we find it far safer to assume that the cable connection is out, rather than accept that the self-reflective screen is all well get.

title: Steelers at Jets
description: JETS RUSHING OFFENSE

title: Sweeping the Clouds Away
description: Sunny days! The earliest episodes of Sesame Street are available on digital video! Break out some Keebler products, fire up the DVD player and prepare for the exquisite pleasure-pain of top-shelf nostalgia.

title: Italian Newcomer With a Bold Outlook
description: BRIVO is the kind of restaurant Long Islanders love. It is Italian, the Islands favorite. It is fancy enough for a special occasion, with crystal chandeliers, a waterfall wall and large mirrors framed in black wrought iron. Best of all, its menu is exciting, loaded with dishes I couldnt wait to try.

title: Finding That Hidden Gem
description: WHEN she relocated to New York three years ago, Karen Yau looked at dozens of apartments before finding her one-bedroom rental in London Terrace Gardens in Chelsea. It was lovely and large, with a classic layout. I thought I was never going to leave, she said.

title: You From Around Here?
description: Nobody wants to eat at a chain restaurant on vacation. And in more and more cities, you dont have to. The virtue of localism, long cherished by small towns, is taking hold in urban centers across the country. The new $41 million SouthBridge complex in Scottsdale, Ariz. (right), is devoted entirely to one-off, locally owned stores and restaurants  no chains allowed, not even Starbucks. Although a few public efforts, like San Franciscos Hayes Valley (see Page 38) and Denvers Cherry Creek North shopping district (which is 75 percent chain-free), have succeeded in fending off franchises, SouthBridge is the first private urban development of its size to go completely indie. Other projects have made a similar effort. The Second Street District shopping center in Austin, Tex., opened in 2005 with 65 percent local tenants, and the owners of Larimer Square in Denver have spent the last several years letting the leases of places like Williams-Sonoma lapse and replacing them with regional businesses. It all adds up to a more exciting urban landscape. When I go to New York, I love to find the little restaurant no ones heard of, says the SouthBridge developer Fred Unger. I think thats what were all yearning for, going back to Mayberry and Floyd the barber.

title: Preventing Shocks and Electrical Fires
description: HOME electrical fires kill some 480 people a year in the United States, injure more than 2,000 and destroy more than $868 million in property, the National Electrical Manufacturers Association says. And while smoke detectors can alert the household to a fire, other devices can help prevent a fire in the first place. There are also devices that can protect people from electrical shock.

title: These Pour Well With Turkey
description: Lieb Family Cellars is a producer whose name is apt for Thanksgiving. When Long Island families sit down to turkey on Thursday, Liebs newest whites and reds could easily accompany a broad spectrum of first and second courses.

title: Saluting a Champion of All That Jazz
description: More than 800 people turned out last week to pay tribute to Ed Bradley, the late 60 Minutes correspondent, at a benefit for Jazz at Lincoln Center in Manhattan. Mr. Bradley was a member of the organizations board and host of its weekly radio show.

title: Correction: At Shelters, Its Raining Cats ... and More Cats
description: An article last Sunday about county animal shelters being inundated with pregnant cats and kittens misstated the role of Dr. Michael Woltz at the Central Animal Hospital in Scarsdale. He is the owner, not the co-owner.

title: Aboriginal Lit
description: When Carpentaria, Alexis Wrights epic novel about Aboriginal life, appeared last year, readers in Australia were slow to warm to its magisterial yet colloquial voice, which transformed the oral tradition of the countrys indigenous people into a swirling narrative spiked with burlesque humor and featuring a huge cast of eccentric characters. Despite highly laudatory reviews, Wrights 500-plus-page tale of the tortured relations between blacks and whites in the sparsely populated desert country around the Gulf of Carpentaria in northern Queensland languished on bookstore shelves. With a few exceptions, the independent bookstores run by political liberals, who have often expressed embarrassment at the sorry treatment of Australias indigenous people, were reluctant to promote it. Too difficult stylistically, said the salespeople at the Macleay Bookshop and Bookoccino, two of Sydneys top literary outlets, where Wrights novel was hard to find in the months after its publication.

title: NY1 Anchor Quits After Calling a Show on the Station Under a False Name
description: Gary Anthony Ramsay, a longtime reporter and a weekend anchor for NY1 News, left the station this week, days after calling in to one of the channels live shows under a false name and commenting on a news story, a lapse in judgment that Mr. Ramsay described as a flash moment of frustration.

title: These Scientific Minds Think (and Drink) Alike
description: THE young men and women crowded into the basement of the Union Hall bar in Brooklyn looked as if they were used to spending time in dark steamy rooms. Dressed in plaid flannel shirts and corduroy coats, and carrying canvas bags, they could have come in search of the latest breakthrough band.

title: Bread Making and Truffle Hunting in Italy
description: Lush, green Piedmont in northern Italy is the center of the slow-food movement, which emphasizes local produce  not exactly a hardship for the truffles-and-wine-rich region. Martin Randall Travel (www.martinrandall.com) in London is capitalizing on Piedmonts natural attributes with its new culinary walking tour there. From Sept. 21 to 27, Gastronomic Piedmont will take participants to restaurants and wineries, on truffle-hunting trips near Alba and on tours through a sausage factory and cheese farms. The package, excluding airfare, includes private bus transportation, lodging with breakfast, five lunches, one picnic, four dinners with wine, and wine tastings, and costs 1,710, about $3,560, at $2.14 to the pound.

title: Producer? Sos Your Old Man
description: THE name Gersten is back on an office door at the Public Theater.

title: U.N. Chief Seeks More Climate Change Leadership
description: VALENCIA, Spain, Nov. 17  Secretary General Ban Ki-moon, describing climate change as the defining challenge of our age, released the final report of a United Nations panel on climate change here on Saturday and called on the United States and China to play a more constructive role.

title: On a Deadly Day, U.S. Reports Drop in Iraq Attacks
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 18  An American official announced Sunday that attacks and attempted attacks across Iraq last week dipped to their lowest point for any week since January of last year, and that attacks had dropped by more than half since the United States increased its troop levels in June.

title: Dressed to Sip
description: TO the sartorially challenged, the closet usually appears half-empty. When youre dressing for Stacy London, who mends errant wardrobes on TLCs What Not to Wear with all the tenderness of a darning needle, your closet might as well be bare.

title: A Fiddler and Painter Whose Love of Music Shaped His Work
description: Last year, the Long Island Museum of American Art, History and Carriages put together a major, revealing exhibition on William Sidney Mount (1807-1868) and his brother Shepard (1804-1868), two often-overlooked artists who were also native Long Islanders. This year, to observe the 200th anniversary of William Sidney Mounts birth, the museum has installed a small but still significant new show, Praise for the Artist: William Sidney Mount at 200.

title: The Perfect Shade of Papaya
description: APATHY comes in many forms. But to Elaine Ryan, it comes in just one color  beige  though it may use dangerously seductive aliases: vanilla, mocha, crme caramel. To her, these shades represent nothing short of a renunciation of the inalienable right to happiness in home dcor.

title: In a City of Sprinters, One Eye on the Clock
description: NEW YORKERS who have visited cities like Washington and San Francisco, and watched the blinking numbers on electronic traffic signals counting down the seconds to cross, often wonder, sometimes enviously, why they cant have blinking numbers of their own.

title: A Little Bit Country in Florida
description: It takes many fingers to count all of the allurements Florida claims for itself. According to assorted tourist literature, the state simultaneously contains the Winter Strawberry Capital of the World (Plant City), the Indoor Foliage Capital of the World (Apopka) and the Lightning Capital of the World (the whole state), among lots of other Capitals of the World, including the Cigar, the Nudist, the Possum, the Shark Attack, the Golf, the Phosphates, the Scientology and the Sponge.

title: Hockey Rivalries Take to the Rails
description: Newark

title: Calendar of Events
description: COMEDY

title: Forty Acres and a Gap in Wealth
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: Deborah Glickstein, Brett Feltingoff
description: Deborah Joy Glickstein, the daughter of Eydie Glickstein and Neil E. Glickstein of Allentown, Pa., was married there last evening to Brett David Feltingoff, the son of Arlene Feltingoff, also of Allentown, and the late Barry Feltingoff. Rabbi Moshe Reem officiated at Temple Beth El, with Rabbi Robert B. Lennick taking part.

title: Johnson Making New Era His Own
description: HOMESTEAD, Fla., Nov. 17  With four Cup championships in his trophy case, Jeff Gordon already has a secure place among the great drivers in Nascar history. Now Gordons teammate and protg, Jimmie Johnson, is about to join him among the Nascar elite.

title: Values on Rise for Rare Collectibles
description: In the fall of 2005, Charles Hack, a New Yorker who has made a fortune in real estate and spent a lot of it on old master paintings and Renaissance sculpture, noticed a newspaper advertisement for an auction of a rare stamp.

title: For Kevin Bacon and Local Arts Scene, Zero Degrees of Separation
description: THE Stamford Town Center Plaza may seem like an odd place for a performance by the Bacon Brothers, but early next year, Kevin Bacon plans on being there with his brother, Michael, to celebrate the newly expanded mall with some of the new songs they are preparing to release on an album next spring. This is the sort of local thing that Mr. Bacon, a part-time resident of Sharon, likes to do, despite his frenetic movie career.

title: Cupcakes a Chicken Can Love
description: Cupcakes are inherently cute, but at Sweet Avenue Bake Shop in Rutherford theyre also playful and sometimes even slightly psychedelic.

title: But Soft! Less Woe for Juliet and Her Romeo
