description: LETS start with Act IV, No. 51, Leon Botstein, the conductor, says after bringing the rehearsal to order. The happy ending.

title: For the Police and Fire Departments, a Night to Get Their Jabs In
description: The jurisdictions were unmistakable.

title: Ching May Miss Dynamo Title Defense
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17  Brian Ching is exactly where he and the defending Major League Soccer champion Houston Dynamo wanted to be  back in the M.L.S. Cup. The leagues championship game Sunday at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium is a rematch of last years game between Houston and the New England Revolution.

title: Love in the Time of Dementia
description: SO this, in the end, is what love is.

title: Caroline Cohen, Robert Wall
description: Caroline Elizabeth Cohen, a daughter of Joanne Bernstein-Cohen and Dr. David Cohen of Manhattan, is to be married this afternoon to Robert Peter Wall, a son of Ellen Wall and Basil Wall of Freelton, Ontario. Marilyn D. Go, a United States magistrate judge for the Eastern District of New York in Brooklyn, is to officiate at Studio 450, an event space in Manhattan.

title: Funnyman, Who Art Thou?
description: BURBANK, Calif.

title: Manhunt
description: Stories and novels, Walter Mosley once observed, are entertainments that help us cope with the intense pressures mortality brings.

title: Words of Wisdom for the Toastmaster
description: SISTER WENDY ON PRAYER

title: A Personal Salute to a Heros Memory; To Keep Oceans Full of Bluefin Tuna (3 Letters)
description: A Personal Salute to a Heros Memory

title: Among the Contenders: Appetizers and Espresso
description: IF its possible to judge a restaurant by its espresso, Due Terre is excellent. Deep, dark and mesmerizing, with a beautiful caramel swirl of crema on top and without a hint of bitterness, the espresso comes with a miniature pitcher of steamed milk for a do-it-yourself macchiato.

title: Expanding the Frontiers of the Vegetarian Plate
description: VEGETARIANISM is a simple idea  don't eat animals  with an ancient pedigree. According to the Vegetarian Resource Group, 4.7 million American adults are vegetarians or vegans (people who avoid all animal products, including cheese and eggs).

title: Countrywides Chief Salesman and Defender
description: An article last Sunday about Countrywide Financial misidentified the institutional investor that has called for the resignation of three directors at the company. It is the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees Pension Fund, not the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Investment Fund.

title: Grazing from Delhi to London
description: THINK of Brick Lane, and images of London's most famous immigrant street, depicted in Monica Ali's novel (and soon-to-be film) of the same name, come to mind, as do the spicy smells of cumin, cardamom and turmeric emanating from the more than 50 Bangladeshi restaurants that line the historic thoroughfare.

title: Maryland Parents Told to Have Children Immunized
description: UPPER MARLBORO, Md., Nov. 17  Hundreds of parents, who had been warned that they might face fines and jail time unless they had their children immunized, brought their children to a courthouse here Saturday for the vaccinations.

title: Bengals Hope Henry Gets Back on Track
description: The return of the suspended wide receiver CHRIS HENRY should have been a boon for Cincinnati last week. Henry, who was sidelined by legal troubles, had averaged a touchdown every 4.46 receptions entering 2007 and was expected to draw attention from the Bengals other receivers while being a weapon himself.

title: Patients Without Borders
description: Long before the dentists and the doctors got there, before the nurses, the hygienists and X-ray techs came, before anyone had flicked on the portable mammography unit or sterilized the days first set of surgical instruments, the people who needed them showed up to wait. It was 3 a.m. at the Wise County Fairgrounds in Virginia  Friday, July 20, 2007  the start of a rainy Appalachian morning. Outside the gates, people lay in their trucks or in tents pitched along the grassy parking lot, waiting for their chance to have their medical needs treated at no charge  part of an annual three-day expedition led by a volunteer medical relief corps called Remote Area Medical.

title: Whitney Wright, Brett Ehrlich
description: Whitney Elizabeth Wright, a daughter of Robin F. Wright and Richard N. Wright of Greensboro, N.C., was married last evening to Brett Stuart Ehrlich, the son of Ronnie Ehrlich and Harvey D. Ehrlich of New City, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. J. Christian Wilson, a Methodist minister, officiated at the Carolina Inn in Chapel Hill, N.C.

title: A Blues Icon Comes to Life Through a Kindred Voice
description: There is much in the life of the blues icon Bessie Smith that has the makings of potent drama: racism, domestic violence, alcoholism, bisexuality, all set against the suffocating backdrop of a largely segregated America in the Prohibition and Depression eras.

title: Profiling by the Numbers
description: On Nov. 9, the New York Police Department quietly released its latest figures about the number and race of New Yorkers whom police officers stopped and frisked, giving the public access to data from Jan. 1, 2006, to Sept. 30, 2007. An analysis of these figures shows that racial profiling continues in the city, and that blacks are bearing the overwhelming brunt of police stops.

title: Letters
description: A Search for Answers

title: Feminine, but Not Much to Explain the Mystique
description: Billed as a showcase of contemporary art by women addressing feminist issues, The Feminine Mystique: Contemporary Artists Respond is little of the sort. The more than two dozen artists in the show are women, but much of the work is insubstantial.

title: Museums Solicit Dealers Largess
description: LOS ANGELES

title: 36 Hours in San Sebastin
description: WHAT is it about San Sebastin that has foodies reaching for superlatives (culinary capital of Europe; best place to eat in the world)? Maybe it was the French aristocracy, who imported their haughty chefs in the 19th century, turning this belle poque town on the Basque coast of northern Spain into an epicurean resort. Or maybe it's the food-rich geography, a scallop-shaped coastline sandwiched between the fertile sea and mountainous farmlands. And then there are the Basques themselves, who approach eating with the same fervor as they do soccer. Whatever the case, this laid-back surfing resort is not for weak-willed dieters. There are sweet-smelling cafes and mouth-watering bites to tempt you at every turn  not to mention having one of the highest concentrations of Michelin stars in the world.

title: The Sleep-Industrial Complex
description: Pete Bilss background is in sales  or, as he puts it, retail concepts. He joined Select Comfort 12 years ago to teach its salespeople how to better sell the companys Sleep Number Bed. The Sleep Number Bed is an air-filled mattress. Each side can be inflated with a little remote control to the ideal level of firmness for the person sleeping on it  his or her sleep number, zero to 100  thus accommodating a husband who prefers his side firm and a wife who likes hers softer. You may recognize the Sleep Number Bed from its television commercials featuring the original Bionic Woman, Lindsay Wagner. Or you may have seen Bils himself explicating its many features and benefits in the loneliest hours of the night on the QVC shopping network.

title: Artificial Intelligence
description: IN the last months before the American-led invasion of Iraq, as we now know all too well, the administration of President George W. Bush showed a fine disregard for truth or consequences. This manifested itself in many ways, from insinuations about Saddam Husseins ephemeral Qaeda connections to the Pentagons willful refusal to address the human and economic costs of occupation. Bookstore shelves now groan with wide-ranging accounts struggling to chronicle the pathological hubris that drove the United States onward to Baghdad.

title: Susan Becker, William Gould
description: Susan Lavinia Becker, the daughter of Jeffrey Becker of New York and the late Tess Becker, was married last night to William Harris Gould, the son of Jean Gould and Bruce Gould of Great Neck, N.Y. Dr. David M. Posner, the senior rabbi at Temple Emanu-El in New York, officiated at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: Talk Softly but Carry a Big Louis XIV Foot
description: AT the moment, Picasso has nothing on John Richardson. Sure, Picasso was the greatest artist of the 20th century, redrawing the lines of perspective, politics and portraiture (to start with the Ps). Even in his complicated personal life, flawlessly excavated in Mr. Richardsons new volume of biography, A Life of Picasso: The Triumphant Years, 1917-1932 (Knopf), he recast old ideas of an artists relationship with his subjects.

title: N.F.L. Matchups Week 11
description: REDSKINS at COWBOYS

title: What to Do When Goliaths Roar?
description: AS shoppers arm themselves for post-Thanksgiving bargain hunting later this week, theyll also indulge in another, newer annual tradition: surfing the Web for advance information about Black Friday retail sales. By organizing sale prices from scattered newspaper circulars into a single database, the Internet has made it easy to search for particular items and compare prices  too easy, at least in the eyes of many major retailers.

title: Iraq Credits Iran for Helping to Curb Attacks by Militias
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 17  The Iraqi government on Saturday credited Iran with helping to rein in Shiite militias and stemming the flow of weapons into Iraq, helping to improve the security situation noticeably.

title: 1. Find Drum. 2. Grab Stick. 3. Bang! Boom!
description: JENS HANNEMANN might be the funniest drummer who has no idea that people are laughing at him. In a scene from his latest instructional DVD, this vaguely Teutonic musician has just finished demonstrating the step-by-step mechanics of an overly elaborate rhythm: in this case a two-handed drum pattern from his song Just in Time that he illustrates by calling out the words left and right, seemingly at random, about 31 times in a row. Then he turns to the camera and with a straight face tells his would-be pupils, You might want to memorize that for when youre practicing at home.

title: Builders Return to Class for Lessons in Green
description: Because of an editing error, the National Perspectives article last Sunday about developers learning to build environmentally friendly houses and condominiums referred imprecisely to the development of the Withers Preserve, a housing project in Myrtle Beach, S.C. The developers are building around the wetlands, not on them.

title: In Luxurious Detail
description: WAY back in 1999, the last time Tony Duquette, the brilliant and eccentric California designer of interiors, stage sets and jewelry, was rediscovered, Amy Spindler, the style editor of The New York Times Magazine, made an observation in these pages that still rings true. When a Banana Republic catalog starts to look like the trendy, vacuous pages of Wallpaper, and Club Monaco is indistinguishable from Prada, she wrote, you know its time for high style to move on.

title: Needle and Thread and the Chinatown Night
description: A GOLDEN phoenix and a dragon kept watch over the wedding reception at the Golden Unicorn dim sum palace in Chinatown, their tiny light bulb eyes blinking like Christmas lights. It was 7:30 on a Saturday night in September, and just as I was tucking into the second dish of the 10-course banquet, the spaghetti strap on my black designer dress snapped and hung like a lo mein noodle.

title: Blowing the Whistle, Many Times
description: WHEN Cynthia Fitzgerald started out in pharmaceutical sales 20 years ago, she received ample training on the right and wrong ways to sell medical products. Right was selling on the merits. Wrong was luring customers with perks and freebies. It was O.K. to buy doctors lunch or dinner, for example, but tempting them with lavish gifts was taboo.

title: Immigrants Could Face Tighter Rules in Michigan
description: Several Michigan lawmakers, frustrated with the defeat in Congress of an immigration law overhaul, are proposing state laws to punish employers who hire illegal immigrants.

title: Watch and Release
description: THE news media have a penchant for reliving major events on significant anniversaries. So it came as no surprise this year that we were bombarded with 30-year-old memories of the summer of 1977, when the Bronx was burning, the Son of Sam was on the loose and a blackout led to days of widespread looting.

title: U.S. Secretly Aids Pakistan in Guarding Nuclear Arms
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17  Over the past six years, the Bush administration has spent almost $100 million on a highly classified program to help Gen. Pervez Musharraf, Pakistans president, secure his countrys nuclear weapons, according to current and former senior administration officials.

title: The Patriots Are Coming, and the Bills Are Ready
description: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y., Nov. 14  They are all there in a gallery of large, fading photographs that decorate the walls of the Buffalo Bills field house. Bruce Smith, Andre Reed, Jack Kemp: plexiglass-encased reminders that the best days of the Bills have often seemed to be behind them.

title: Sergeant Fled Army, but Not the War in His Head
description: EAST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 15  The psychotherapist remembers the strapping young soldier, slouched in a chair in her office one morning last month, asking if God could be punishing him because he had once thought it would be exciting to fight in a war.

title: Two Sides of Mr. Sarkozy
description: The picture of a French president who jogs, vacations in New Hampshire and even seems comfortable around President Bush is so unusual that it has earned Nicolas Sarkozy the nickname of Sarko the American. That, along with Frances toughened stand against Irans nuclear appetites, won Mr. Sarkozy bipartisan applause in Washington this month.

title: Elizabeth Davison and Van Gothner
description: Elizabeth Anne Davison and Karl Ivan Folke Gothner were married yesterday afternoon at St. Pauls Chapel on the campus of Columbia University in New York. The Rev. Kathryn Kibbie Laird, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Lobbying Helps Spur Talks in Writers Strike
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 17  An agreement by striking writers and Hollywood studios to resume bargaining was prompted by back-channel talks and mounting worries on both sides about their image, people with knowledge of the situation said Saturday.

title: Truck Rated Safe, With Asterisk
description: WHEN the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety announced the latest list of what it considers the safest vehicles last week, there was a surprising newcomer: a pickup truck.

title: Seeking a Homer, Rejoicing in Singles
description: WOODMERE, N.Y.

title: As Theatergoers Alter Plans, a Juggling Act for Ticket Agents
description: Most of the big-ticket plays and musicals were quiet last week, but there was plenty of Broadway drama around the country.

title: Federer Defeats Ferrer in Masters Cup
description: SHANGHAI, Nov. 18  Roger Federer, who ended his season on Sunday with a straight-set victory over the hottest player in the Masters Cup tournament, now gets to rest a bit before taking on his only serious remaining opponent: history.

title: Amanda Entin, Patrick Nichols II
description: Amanda Sue Entin, a daughter of Lois J. Entin and Alvin E. Entin of Tamarac, Fla., was married last evening to Patrick James Nichols II, the son of Beth C. Nichols and Mr. Nichols of Great Falls, Va. Sheldon R. Schwartz, a county court judge for Floridas 11th Judicial Circuit, officiated at the Hyatt Regency Pier 66 Hotel in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Calendar of Events
description: COMEDY

title: Take Me Out to the Courtroom
description: Buy yourself some peanuts and Cracker Jack, court fans, as a fascinating trial is coming. Can the government convict Barry Bonds of perjury? Will Mighty Casey strike out? Unless the government has an undisclosed eyewitness who saw Bonds receive injections or heard him admit to steroid use, this trial stacks up as a classic credibility contest.

title: Doc Holiday
description: For decades, travelers have journeyed to spas not only for healthy food and daily massages but also for spiritual sustenance, a chance to look inward in a pampering environment. And in recent years the menu has veered off into New Age la-la land with chakra balancings, sage clearings and Zen archery. But now, at an increasing number of spas, resorts and hotels, travelers are being offered a chance to look inside literally  at their DNA, bone density and cardiac stress levels. So long, drum circle: the wellness quest has evolved from navel gazing to the science of longevity.

title: In Korea, a Boot Camp Cure for Web Obsession
description: MOKCHEON, South Korea  The compound  part boot camp, part rehab center  resembles programs around the world for troubled youths. Drill instructors drive young men through military-style obstacle courses, counselors lead group sessions, and there are even therapeutic workshops on pottery and drumming.

title: In Poor Health
description: For anyone who still believes that New Jerseys health care system actually works, a recent study should come as a shocker. In a ranking of states based on overall health, New Jersey declined sharply in the past year, slipping from 14th to 21st. Experts say a major reason is the alarming increase in the number of residents without health insurance.

title: Practicing Different Religions (but United on the Issue of Pork)
description: ON the morning in August 2005 when Sam Habib and Cindy Gluck opened their first Dunkin Donuts, they awoke at dawn to make sure that the glazed fritters and French crullers were out on the counter. Then Mr. Habib sneaked off to the neighboring mosque to pray, and Ms. Gluck, panicky about the prospects of their new venture, went to the back of the store to cry.

title: A Culinary Explorer in a Land of Opportunity
description: IN July 2007, Neil Ferguson, having been abruptly dismissed as chef de cuisine at Gordon Ramsays New York City franchise, saw an opening up the Hudson, adjusted his toque, and headed against the current to claim new ground. As executive chef at Monteverde at Oldstone Manor, a handsomely renovated restaurant, inn and spa on a river estate near Bear Mountain, Mr. Ferguson has brought fresh talent to fill Monteverdes luffing sails.

title: Snowbound in Japan
description: It was after a three-hour train ride north from Tokyo, heading for Tsurunoyu Onsen, that I learned Tsurunoyu isnt an onsen at all. Its really more of a hitou, Moto, my guide, delicately pointed out. We were in Honshu Islands far-north prefecture of Akita, winding our way up the unpaved road to the 300-year-old mountain lodge, and Moto seemed especially intent on setting me straight. An onsen, he explained, is a natural hot spring. A hitou is a natural hot spring that is hidden. Ah. Hiddenness being perhaps the most prized characteristic in Japanese culture  second only to a love of drawing precise distinctions on a minute scale  I undertood this was a critical difference.

title: Lips Move, but No Mergers Result
description: ATLANTIC CITY

title: When a Sixth Avenue Flagship Struck Its Colors
description: The Streetscapes column on Oct. 21, about the first B. Altman department store, at 19th Street and Sixth Avenue, misstated the given name of the founder of Greenhut & Company, which opened at the site after Altman moved. He was Joseph B. Greenhut, not Jacob.

title: Beckoned by Bivalves
description: MY usual method for harvesting oysters goes something like this: I lift my right hand. I extend it toward a neatly arranged platter on a tidily set table, taking care, at least on my better days, not to drag my sleeve through a ramekin of mignonette sauce.

title: The Days Best
description: JEREMY MACLIN, left, scored 3 touchdowns for Missouri, including a 99-yard kick return, and had 252 total yards to set the N.C.A.A. single-season freshman record for all-purpose yards.

title: In Rustic Tavernas, a Classic Cuisine Gets Its Due
description: WINE surely isnt supposed to be brown. Not anywhere. True, a Provenal ros can have a hint of rustiness in its depth, but flat-out brown  surely not a good sign. But Crete is full of surprises, and when you order a copper carafe of local wine at the Old Phoenix Hotel on the south coast, near the town of Loutro, its possible the wine that comes out of it may even be the color of fresh engine oil.

title: Here at the New Yorker
description: When the New Yorker Hotel swung open its brass doors at Eighth Avenue and West 34th Street at the beginning of the Depression, the 2,500-room Art Deco structure was considered a marvel of engineering and construction. A private tunnel whisked guests directly from the 43-story hotel into nearby Penn Station, and a laundry handled 15 tons of linen daily.

title: Marianna Olszewski, Christopher Rounick
description: Marianna Olszewski and Christopher Robert Rounick were married last evening at the Union Club in New York. Bruce M. Kaplan, a retired New York State Family Court Judge, officiated.

title: Editors Choice
description: A LIFE OF PICASSO: The Triumphant Years, 1917-1932, by John Richardson. (Knopf, $40.) The third, penultimate installment in Richardsons powerhouse of a biography spans a dauntingly complicated time in Picassos life and in European history.

title: The Stomach-Surgery Conundrum
description: Bariatric Surgery

title: The Blue-Collar Thoroughbred
description: LIKE many New Yorkers, she came to the city from someplace else, aiming to go as far as her talent could take her. She was just starting out, and when she arrived from rural Florida, she moved into a small place in South Ozone Park, Queens, so close to Kennedy Airport she could hear the planes roaring overhead as she ate breakfast.

title: Energy, Tech and Wal-Mart Aid the Market
description: The stock market rose last week, bolstered by better-than-expected earnings from Wal-Mart Stores, a big stock buyback by Cisco Systems and analyst upgrades of some technology and energy stocks.

title: Argentina Without the Long Trip
description: The next time youre craving empanadas, you wont have to hop a flight to Buenos Aires. Pittsburgh will do, or even Denver. Through February, select Omni Hotels are offering the Discover Argentina package, which introduces guests to the foods and wines of Argentina, South Americas second-largest country. The package has a cooking class that includes a three-course dinner, a wine and cheese plate, and a leather wine tote with Malbec and Torronts wines and a CD with tango music. Menu items  featured in all Omni Hotels restaurants  include grilled meats like tira de asado braseada al Malbec (Malbec-braised beef short ribs, above), sauces like chimichurri, desserts like dulce de leche crepes and wines from Mendoza. Packages start at $350, double occupancy (www.omnihotels.com).

title: Lisa Gallagher, William McCabe
description: Elizabeth Frances Gallagher, a daughter of Martha Wang Gallagher and William Gallagher of Ardsley, N.Y., was married yesterday to William Laws McCabe, the son of Louise B. McCabe and James L. McCabe of Bryn Mawr, Pa. Msgr. Thomas P. Leonard performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: M.T.A., Lend Them Your Ears
description: Riders in large numbers showed up at eight public hearings this month, invited by the board of the state-run Metropolitan Transportation Authority to share their thoughts on its plan to raise fares for subways, buses and commuter rails, as well as tolls at bridges and tunnels.

title: Moira Egan and Damiano Abeni
description: THE muse blessed Moira Egan with the gift of words. But numbers have been known to trouble her,  or at least they did when she met Dr. Damiano Abeni.

title: Wrong Premise for War
description: To the Editor:

title: Topalov Pulls Off Yet Another of His Last-Minute Victories
description: Veselin Topalov of Bulgaria thrives on adversity.

title: Improvements in a Rental
description: Q I live in a rent-stabilized apartment in Manhattan. As apartments become vacant, the owner is making major improvements to the kitchens (new refrigerators, stoves, cabinets, etc.).

title: Housing May Dim Retail Hopes
description: THE holiday season begins this week, but if you expect Champagne corks to pop on Wall Street, prepare to be disappointed.

title: Talks Continue in Broadway Strike
description: Talks continued today between the producers and theater owners and the stagehands union, with both sides negotiating over a settlement that would end the strike that has darkened most of Broadway for over a week.

title: Letters: Recipe Redux: Teddies Apple Cake
description: Ive been baking what I call Jean Hewitts version of the cake since 1973, when, as a junior in college, I read the recipe in The Times Magazine (Amanda Hesser, Nov. 4). The cake is delicious, easy to make and affordable  and thus proved useful to me as a college student, graduate student, young professional and working mother. The serving of this cake (at dinner parties, potluck suppers, fund-raisers at my childrens schools) always elicits requests for the recipe, which I have amended over the years to include some brown sugar, a bit of whole-wheat flour, lots of vanilla, more cinnamon, nutmeg, a variety of raisins and about twice as many apples. Tart are best, as you note. The cake also freezes well, but that rarely happens. Years ago, a roommate wrote on the recipe I clipped from the magazine  Let cool before inhaling the entire cake.

title: The Game Is Not Even a Contest: Harvard Routs Yale for the Ivy Title
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 17  Buying time by scrambling, Harvard quarterback Chris Pizzotti looked upfield and spotted wide receiver Matt Luft, who had abandoned his pattern to look for some room deep in the secondary.

title: What You Get for...$900,000
description: Lakewood Ranch, Fla.

title: The Life of Riley
description: It is Sam Rileys first time in New York City, but given the elegantly dilapidated state of his surroundings  a grand house that has been through better days, on a soundstage at Pier 59 Studios  it might as well be Leeds. The weather outside is what you might imagine Leeds to be: gray, drizzly, vaguely depressing. Yet today, Riley, who is 27, couldnt be farther from his English roots. Little more than a year ago he was folding shirts in a Leeds warehouse, his dreams of becoming a rock star  not to mention his band, 10,000 Things  shelved indefinitely by the record label and a vindictive 1-out-of-10-points review. Things cant get any worse, he thought, so he might as well act. Maybe Im going to have to swallow my pride and do TV or something just to get some money, Riley recalls thinking. Im never going to be a singer again.

title: The New Jersey Exodus That Wasnt
description: Trenton

title: Building an Enclave Around a Mosque in Suburban Toronto
description: Toronto

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Baseballs Teaching Moment

title: Real Retirees, in a Virtual Village
description: The In the Region article in some copies last Sunday about virtual villages, in which older people stay in their own homes with help from a grass-roots support network, included an incorrect time frame provided by Staying Put, a virtual village in New Canaan, for its goal to recruit 150 household memberships. The group aims to achieve this total by the end of 2008, not the end of this year.

title: Suicide Artist
description: It is Rome, 1948, and Dante Sabato, a poet and translator  having negotiated his own survival throughout the war  is ready to end it all. Contemplating a dive off the Ponte Sisto bridge and into the Tiber, he is interrupted by an American G.I., who escorts him straight to a party. There Dante meets the Godfrey sisters, Gladys and Prudence, American actresses trying to make it in the booming Italian film industry. Gladys is a sexual adventurer, self-possessed and assertive. She fulfills all her wants and needs and, along the way, some of Dantes. She appreciates Dantes fervent lovemaking and the fact that hes a busy man, busy with his work, busy with his other women, and doesnt have the time or inclination to control her. Prudence, rumored to be fleeing an unfortunate affair with the director Billy Wilder, is reserved, the more beautiful of the two. Shuttling between them both, Dante finds  in the sum  love.

title: With Parents Ill, Happiness Seems Worlds Away
description: All my happiness was in Poughkeepsie, said Kajahda McKoy, 9, sitting on her bed. Tears rolled down her cheeks as she looked out her window in her familys three-bedroom basement apartment in the Bronx.

title: Back to the Lighthouse
description: Paris has her tower, the promotional blurb reads. London has its bridge. China has the Wall. Long Island will have ... THE LIGHTHOUSE.

title: Norways Message in a Bottle
description: The scene at Fyret, a dimly lit aquavit bar in central Oslo, looked like a scene from a Flemish painting: a well-padded blond barkeep kept the howling patrons in line while doling out steins of beer alongside shots of the fiery homegrown spirit. The rollicking atmosphere was so convivial, I had to wonder: why is it so rare to find aquavit drinkers in Norway these days?

title: Paperback Row
description: THANKSGIVING NIGHT, by Richard Bausch. (Harper Perennial, $15.95.) Bauschs 10th novel, set in the fictional town of Point Royal, Va., as its citizens prepare to celebrate the last Thanksgiving of the century, is old-fashioned  generously full of quirky characters, humor and details as well as real emotion. Its as if Bausch had set out to create the biggest dining table he could find, then put everyone he could think of around it, Meg Wolitzer wrote in the Book Review. A very different Thanksgiving dinner, this one in Concord, Mass., is the subject of THE GHOST AT THE TABLE, by Suzanne Berne (Shannon Ravenel/Algonquin, $13.95). Two sisters  the elder determined to make everything perfect, the younger sullen and aloof  battle over their memories of childhood, particularly the death of their mother. One critic called it a witty, moving and psychologically acute story.

title: An Exotic Oasis in Brooklyn
description: If your knowledge of Middle Eastern food starts with falafel and ends with hummus, a few hours on Atlantic Avenue should set you straight.

title: The Dead and the Naked
description: Chapter 11: Prisoners in Paradise

title: Australian Wins Contentious Vote to Become Next Chief of WADA
description: MADRID, Nov. 17  Several hours before his successor as World Anti-Doping Agency chairman was elected here Saturday, Dick Pound bade goodbye to the job that made him one of the most polarizing personalities in sports.

title: Congestion an Issue in Coliseum Property Plan
description: UNIONDALE

title: Rise and Fall at the Big Board
description: FEW financial institutions are more important to America than the New York Stock Exchange, and no one understands that better than Richard A. Grasso, its long-embattled former chairman.

title: In Tuscany, a Converted Convent
description: ORBICCIANO, Italy

title: Joanne Tulin, Jeremy Lane
description: Dr. Joanne Rachel Tulin, a daughter of Riki Tulin and Stanley Tulin of Highland Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Jeremy I. Lane, the son of Kathy Lane and Alan Lane of Atlanta. Rabbi Fred Kazan officiated at the National Constitution Center, a museum in Philadelphia.

title: English, Algebra, Phys Ed ... and Biotech
description: MORE than a decade ago, after George Cachianes, a former researcher at Genentech, decided to become a teacher, he started a biotechnology course at Lincoln High School in San Francisco. He saw the class as way of marrying basic biotechnology principles with modern lab practices  and insights into how business harvests biotech innovations for profit.

title: Report Cites Mine-Safety Agency Failures
description: Government investigators have found that the Mine Safety and Health Administration failed to conduct required inspections last year at 107 of the nations 731 underground coal mines.

title: Alt-Country Finds Red Dirt Under Its Nails
description: FORT WORTH

title: Bullfighting in the Park, and the Sword Is Real
description: MONTCLAIR

title: Making It Easier to Anticipate the View
description: ALTHOUGH developers planning high-rise condominiums can imagine the views from the top floors, actually getting to see them in advance is a lot better.

title: Mukasey and the Senate
description: To the Editor:

title: Everyone Wants to Be Taking Pictures
description: LOS ANGELES

title: The Game That Never Ended
description: AS the young soccer players in jerseys and cleats scampered across the field, it looked like a normal fall Saturday at Seton Park in Riverdale. But soon a scuffle began, and grew, and eventually the game stopped and parents swarmed onto the grass.

title: N.Y.U. Wins Cross-Country Title
description: The New York University mens cross-country team won the N.C.A.A. Division III national championship yesterday in Northfield, Minn.

title: New Weekly Makes News and Waves
description: PLEASANTVILLE

title: New York: The Royalton Hotel
description: THE BASICS

title: Taurus Thirstus
description: PRIMEHOUSE NEW YORK, the latest addition to the stampede of steakhouses that have recently opened in Manhattan, has a gimmick.

title: No Place to Light Up
description: Overconfidence is usually a recipe for trouble. For a case in point, consider a recent episode in Danbury.

title: A Symbol of Activism Is at Center of Court Dispute
description: John L. Phillips Jr. took a seat in the last row of the theater and surveyed its crumbling ceiling, the debris strewn in the aisles and the faded art that he had hung a generation ago.

title: A Stores Toast to Park Avenue
description: SHERRY-LEHMANN INC., one of Manhattans best-known wine and spirits shops, recently moved to a new site at 59th Street and Park Avenue after spending 60 years a few blocks away on Madison Avenue. The design brief for the new space was straightforward: improve on an already high level of service but dont give short shrift to the romance and tradition that customers associate with the products.

title: Counting on Chaos at the Polls
description: New York State elections officials have been so embarrassingly slow in figuring out how to buy new voting machines that the federal government has stepped in to clean up the mess. The trouble is that Washington could make things a whole lot worse.

title: Darcy Pulitzer, Jeremy Goldstein
description: Darcy Lowen Pulitzer, a daughter of Sandra Buring Pulitzer and Arthur C. Pulitzer of New Orleans, was married last evening to Jeremy Zev Goldstein, a son of Eileen Rubenstein Goldstein and Dr. Paul D. Goldstein of Highland Park, Ill. Rabbi Edward Cohn officiated at Temple Sinai in New Orleans.

title: What That Regan Woman Knows
description: NEW Yorkers who remember Rudy Giuliani as the bullying New York mayor, not as the terminally cheerful Americas Mayor cooing to babies in New Hampshire, have always banked on one certainty: his presidential candidacy was so preposterous it would implode before he got anywhere near the White House.

title: Records Are Made to Be ... Overstuffed With Significance
description: BARRY BONDSS indictment Thursday on four counts of perjury and one count of obstruction of justice put a kind of official imprimatur on his presumed villainy. Bonds, who broke Hank Aarons career home run record on Aug. 7, has long been suspected of using performance-enhancing drugs. And though he has not been convicted, his indictment goes a step further in raising doubts about how Bonds accrued his 762 home runs, and threatens to emblazon the record with baseballs favorite punctuation mark, the asterisk.

title: Susanne Nifong, Benjamin Baker
description: Susanne Elizabeth Nifong and Benjamin Spencer Baker were married yesterday at St. Pauls Episcopal Church in Ivy, Va. The Rev. John E. Shields performed the ceremony.

title: Inches Above the Road and in The Mans Face
description: LOWRIDERS are riding high. For instance, the Petersen Automotive Museum in Los Angeles has just opened an exhibition entitled La Vida Lowrider: Cruising the City of Angels. It includes 21 cars, several bicycles, pedal cars, scale models, photographs and other images from the lowrider culture of Los Angeles.

title: Calendar of Events
description: Film

title: Anne Marie Squeo, Philip Maggi
description: Anne Marie Squeo and Philip James Maggi were married yesterday in Washington. The Rev. Benton L. Garrett, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Shrine of the Most Blessed Sacrament.

title: Mexicos Cultural Revolution
description: You're going to be part of an experiment tonight, Justo Fernndez Garibay said. We couldn't find chestnuts for the stuffing, so we're using macadamia nuts. I was about to sit down to Thanksgiving dinner at the Posada Coatepec, a beautiful inn owned by Fernndez's family on the outskirts of Xalapa, the state capital of Veracruz. When he's not balancing budgets, Fernndez, a representative in the legislature, oversees the menu.

title: The Real Meaning of Nov. 6
description: If there is one central political truth to emerge from the Nov. 6 election returns, it is this: New Jersey voters want fiscal sanity restored, even if it means sacrificing programs they would normally support.

title: Elizabeth Keohane, Tyler Burbridge
description: Elizabeth Anne Seton Keohane, a daughter of Dolleen-Day Keohane and John Keohane of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married yesterday to Tyler David Burbridge, a son of Ann Burbridge and Dr. Geoffrey Burbridge of Lenoir, N.C. Msgr. John F. X. Smith officiated at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church in Tuxedo Park, N.Y., with the Rev. Michael P. Ferrick, another Roman Catholic priest, participating.

title: Handcuffing the Wounded: A Police Tactic Hits a Nerve
description: It was done after three men were shot in Queens a year ago in a hail of 50 police bullets. It occurred again on Monday, after five officers fired 20 shots at Khiel Coppin outside his Brooklyn home, killing him.

title: Letters: The Perils of Petrocracy
description: At last someone in the north is hammering out details of what Venezuelan bloggers have been saying for a long time  that under Hugo Chvez, what was once one of the best-managed oil industries in the world is heading for disaster. What Tina Rosenberg (Nov. 4) doesnt address is the fact that Chvez probably knows this. Which may be why his forceful governance and love song to the poor are being rushed into place. There is little reliable data on the extent of his misiones for the poor (financed by oil revenue). But while filming for two weeks in October, for HDNet World Report in Maracaibo, Caracas and at a massive cult gathering of 10,000 spiritualists outside Barquisimeto (celebrating Chvezs Day of Indigenous Resistance, formerly Columbus Day), I talked to people from all over Venezuela. All reported that misiones are visibly active in their town, city, state.

title: Learning Young to Help Heft a Familys Burdens
description: At 5 on a recent afternoon, the smell of baked chicken wafted through the Serranos three-bedroom apartment in the Bronx. Victor Serrano, 45, and his wife, Brenda, 39, were in the living room with their children Samantha, 14, Sabrina, 12, and Victor, 11.

title: Yes, Thank You
description: The meal was lavish. The hosts very gracious. One told me as I was leaving: Dont bother writing a thank-you note. You dont have to kiss up to us.

title: Retronymy
description: Crossword-puzzle addicts will remember 2007 as the year that The Timess puzzle offered as its clue to an eight-letter word:  acoustic guitar or push lawn mower.  The word to fill the boxes, as readers of a column in this space 11 months ago instantly knew, was retronym.

title: Brazils Beach Party
description: Brazil is to cool what China is to commerce. And Bahia is the country's beachside boom state, the red-hot resort of the moment drawing a new wave of pleasure seekers  the fashion crowd, music lovers, off-duty movie stars  to its 650 miles of palm-fringed sand.

title: One-Woman Connecticut Book Tour
description: New Milford

title: For Clinton, More Time and More Advertising
description: DES MOINES, Nov. 17  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York has nearly doubled the size of her staff in Iowa and has substantially increased her advertising here as her campaign reinforces its effort to prevent Democrats from coalescing around a single alternative to her candidacy.

title: The Neediest Cases: When Families Fall on Hardship, the Young Shoulder the Weight, Too
description: Many families have reaped the rewards of New York Citys prosperity in the last decade. They can afford private schools, comfortable homes and generous giving during the holidays.

title: Guardians of Retired Judge Accused of Lax Accounting and Improprieties
description: Those close to retired Judge John L. Phillips Jr., including his court-appointed property guardian, blame his previous guardians for much of the financial mess that may force the sale of the Slave Theater to pay the judges debts.

title: California Dreaming, Tinted Green
description: Los Angeles

title: Electoral Landscaping
description: Morton Kellers Americas Three Regimes: A New Political History is unusual in two respects. Academic historians like Keller  a Brandeis professor emeritus  are often said to be incapable of writing the kind of lively, engaging accounts the public yearns for. But Keller, known for substantial but less than sparkling histories of American administrative practices, has put together one of the most engaging and accessible portraits of Americas political evolution of recent years. He leavens his discussion with lively quotations and a sprinkling of apt statistics. Just as striking is that in the course of writing this popular overview, Keller effectively challenges the reigning academic assumptions regarding what are called realigning elections.

title: A Mother Fights for Autism Services
description: Mineola

title: Ohio State Heads Into B.C.S., and Michigan Into Unknown
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 17  The surveyors outlines in the concourse of Michigan Stadium hint at an off-season change: luxury boxes are to be hoisted atop this grand edifice.

title: Letters: Questions for John Bolton
description: I enjoyed the irony of the headline The Diplomat on the John Bolton interview. When you dismiss those who disagree with you (including the vast majority of climate scientists, in this case), you pretty much close down the discussion  not a useful tactic for a diplomat.

title: Dont Let the Titles Fool You
description: First installed at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art in 2002, the Farrah Fawcett project by Keith Edmier may well be the most daft in a long line of ill-conceived collaborations involving celebrities undertaken by contemporary artists. Mr. Edmier and Ms. Fawcett created nude sculptures of each other.

title: Wiseguys
description: The F.B.I. director J. Edgar Hoover long denied the existence of the Mafia in America. He did not deny the existence of criminals, of course, or the fact that many of them came from Sicily; but he did not believe, or said he did not, that these men, dispersed in cities across the nation, worked in conspiracy, either because he underestimated them, had been paid off or simply did not care. Hoover was obsessed with revolutionaries, Communists and anarchists; gangsters, no matter what else they do, tend to support the status quo  they like the world the way it is. So in the end, the Mafia was first understood not by G-men but by the bureaucrats at the federal governments Bureau of Narcotics, a precursor to the Drug Enforcement Administration. By following drug traffic across the nation, the orderly flow from port to truck to distributor to consumer, these men inadvertently mapped the underworld, and in the process created thousands of files, with each page dedicated to another hoodlum, another cog in the machine  runner, killer, distributor, shylock, boss. In the late 1950s, Senator John McClellan used these records to guide the hearings that finally brought the underworld to light.

title: After the Caudillo
description: Bona fide examples of poetic justice in politics, where the innocent are vindicated and the wicked get their just deserts, are about as rare in real life as they have been commonplace in popular culture, dating at least as far back as The Count of Monte Cristo. And yet to the extent that such things do occur, the political triumph of Michelle Bachelet, the current president of Chile  and the first woman in South America who can be said to have earned the title on her own merits  has been just such an event. The woman who was, as a 23-year-old medical student, briefly imprisoned along with her mother by the dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet and whose father, Air Force Gen. Alberto Bachelet, was tortured and died in military custody in 1974, is now Chiles chief of state  while the dictator died, his reputation in tatters, shortly after she took office.

title: As the Calendar Turns, So Do Many Stocks Fortunes
description: ITS hardly earth-shattering news when a particular stock performs better in one month than another. But what if those standout months  of especially strong or weak performance  remain the same, year in and year out?

title: Uptown Epicure
description: If the Lower East Side has long been a place where many young hipsters hang, the Upper East Side has plenty of restaurants for grown-ups.

title: Making Room Among Powers of the Pacific
description: Last season, the Anaheim Ducks finished atop the Pacific Division en route to their first Stanley Cup. The Dallas Stars and the San Jose Sharks, perennial powerhouses, finished 3 points behind.

title: Where Everybody Really Did Know His Name
description: ASIDE from the green and white sign with the three-leaf clovers, there isnt much to catch the eye about Mooneys Pub on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn, unless youre a frequent passer-by with an apartment nearby and what you had always thought was an uncommon last name. In that case, you wonder idly what these other Mooneys are like, and make a mental note to stop in sometime and say hi.

title: Kathleen Zebrowski, Michael McGraw
description: Kathleen Ann Zebrowski and Michael Scott McGraw were married on Friday in Weehawken, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Edward G. Lambro, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Chart House, a restaurant.

title: DNA and Race: The Delicate Helix
description: To the Editor:

title: Life, Liberty and a Musicals Pursuit
description: Once upon a time, there were 13 colonies. The story of how they unshackled themselves from the greatest military power on earth has been reprised so often that it has come to seem as remote and magical as a fairy tale  a tale no less remote and magical for being true. And therein lies the secret of 1776, the unlikely musical retelling of the nations creation.

title: Totals
description: Previously recorded $2,249,585.28

title: Through the Roof
description: IN the classic New York City real estate dream, the sleeper discovers a room, maybe an entire wing, that he or she never knew existed. Then, just as the exhilaration of the newfound space starts to settle in, the dreamer awakens to crashing disappointment.

title: Lingering Memories of Sarah and Israel; The Red-Diaper Baby and the Moving Van; To Keep Oceans Full of Bluefin Tuna (4 Letters)
description: Lingering Memories of Sarah and Israel

title: A Grandson Tries to Give Back to the One Who Gave Her All
description: The most important person in Felipe Arbelaezs life is his maternal grandmother, Luz Giraldo.

title: Plane Rerouting Landing in Court
description: AS the holiday travel season nears, thousands of residents in the tristate region may have a new reason to dread the crush at the airport  even if they never leave home. The Federal Aviation Administration says it will begin phasing in its controversial plan to reroute flight paths in the congested skies over the Northeast in mid-December, which could put planes over some communities in New Jersey, New York and Connecticut for the first time.

title: A Good Day for Baseball, and a Better One Looms
description: The prevalent reaction to Barry Bondss indictment was that it was a bad day for baseball, even a sad day. But to me, it was a good day for baseball. Or at least the dawn of a good day, a dawn without a cloud in the sky.

title: Police Shoot Officers Son; by Accident, Officials Say
description: The 16-year-old son of a Plainfield, N.J., police officer was shot accidentally by a police officer in Roselle, N.J., during a confrontation on Friday evening, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Young Man Behaving Badly
description: The winter of 1991 found me stunned and shivering in the aftermath of an imploded love affair. Being 26, I flung myself actorishly on London and without any intimations of my own ludicrousness spent two years showing God what I thought of him by letting myself go. I drank and took drugs sufficient to give me bleeding gums and a Parkinsonian head wobble, conditions that compromised but did not prevent my other main hobby  having sex as often as possible. A lot of girls didnt mind. A lot of them had troubles of their own. It was a cheering surprise, the sort of dismal shape you could be in and still get into some maenadic self-harmers pants. Granted, these encounters never developed  no morning-after breakfast or fun in the shower  but encased as I was in the armor of nihilism, I wouldnt have stuck around for any of that rubbish anyway.

title: Letters: The Turning of an Atheist
description: Heres hoping the gaggle of so-called believers chasing fading atheist Antony Flew find what theyre seeking in their quest to reduce deity to scientific certainty. With proof of their gods easy accessibility to human inquiry, they can give up their already tattered pretense of faith.

title: At Michigan, Even the Marching Band Has a Superfan
description: Rishi Moudgils approach to game day at Michigan Stadium is pretty straightforward.

title: On 4th Try, Brodeur Earns 500th
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 (AP)  Devils goaltender Martin Brodeur made 26 saves Saturday night to earn his 500th career victory in a 6-2 win over the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: Mailers Nonfiction Legacy: His 1969 Race for Mayor
description: You could argue, as Herman Badillo did the other day, that Norman Mailer cost him the mayoralty of New York City in 1969.

title: Migrant Money Flow: A $300 Billion Current
description: THE money flows in dribs and drabs, crossing borders $200 or $300 at a time. It buys cornmeal and rice and plaid private school skirts and keeps the landlord at bay. Globally, the tally is huge: migrants from poor countries send home about $300 billion a year. That is more than three times the global total in foreign aid, making remittances the main source of outside money flowing to the developing world.

title: Correction
description: A review on Oct. 28 about Legends of the Chelsea Hotel, by Ed Hamilton, misidentified the place where William Burroughs wrote Naked Lunch. He wrote it at the Villa Muniria in Tangier and revised it for publication at the Paris rooming house known as the Beat Hotel; it was not written at the Chelsea.

title: How to Rule the World
description: The emperor Claudius thought about the dynamics of imperial ingestion. He reminded the Roman Senate that the founder Romulus would both fight against and naturalize a people on the same day. Claudius argued that the Gauls, by logical extension, could be accepted into the Senate because they no longer wear trousers  that is, they could be counted on to come to work wearing the Roman toga and thus to have effectively become Romans.

title: War and Morality
description: To the Editor:

title: Torres Is Getting Older, but Swimming Faster
description: Dara Torres, the fastest female swimmer in America, plunged toward the bottom of the pool, like a child scavenging for coins. She came up for a breath, grinning. The lanes next to hers pulsed with swimmers pushing themselves through 100- and 200-meter timed sprints, but Torres was under orders from her coach to rest, the better to let her 40-year-old body recover.

title: Jamie Rosenberg, Lewis Eisen
description: Dr. Jamie Bella Rosenberg, a daughter of Caryn G. Rosenberg and Dr. Leon I. Rosenberg of Cherry Hill, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Lewis Ari Eisen, the son of Carole Eisen and Martin M. Eisen, also of Cherry Hill. Rabbi Isaac Furman officiated at the Westin Mount Laurel hotel in New Jersey.

title: Up Front
description: Theres no entry for Allen, Woody in The Film Snobs Dictionary, the book David Kamp wrote with Lawrence Levi, but that doesnt mean Kamp is not a fan (theres also no entry for Bergman, Ingmar or Fellini, Federico). His favorites of Allens movies, he said in an e-mail message, are Love and Death, for sheer pleasure; Stardust Memories, for the ideal balance of laughs and artiness; and Crimes and Misdemeanors, for insightfulness and Jerry Orbach playing a heavy. Kamp, the author of The United States of Arugula: How We Became a Gourmet Nation, added: We mustnt discount Woodys influence on the food world. His putting the original Dean & DeLuca in Manhattan was a ratification of that stores mission and the way of life it represented. And his literary comic short Fabrizios: Criticism and Response, which I first read as a boy, alerted me to the possibilities of food humor.

title: Does Death Penalty Save Lives? A New Debate
description: For the first time in a generation, the question of whether the death penalty deters murders has captured the attention of scholars in law and economics, setting off an intense new debate about one of the central justifications for capital punishment.

title: Up, Up and Away
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y.

title: Musharraf Refuses to Say When Emergency Will End
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Sunday, Nov. 18  Continuing to defy the United States, Pakistans president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, declined to tell a senior American envoy on Saturday when he would lift a two-week-old state of emergency, Pakistani and Western officials said.

title: Julie Kanfer, Scott Polirstok
description: Julie Beth Kanfer and Scott Michael Polirstok were married last evening at Carlyle on the Green, an event space and restaurant in Farmingdale, N.Y. Rabbi Elyse Frishman officiated.

title: For Sale From Puget Sound: 2 Fixer-Upper Ferries
description: SEATTLE, Nov. 17  Look for two more items on the sale rack after Thanksgiving: the Chinook and the Snohomish, last seen ferrying people across Puget Sound. The big boats can be yours for $4.5 million each. As is. Exclusively at eBay.

title: Memo to Yeats: Ireland Has Changed
description: IRELAND has changed dramatically in recent years thanks to a soaring economy and unprecedented prosperity, but in terms of its literature many still associate the country with its masters George Bernard Shaw, W. B. Yeats and James Joyce.

title: If Its Lunch Time, Its Mix-and-Match Pasta
description: PONTE VECCHIO is a sweet-looking restaurant at the back of one of those ubiquitous strip malls that line Route 1 in Fairfield. The Italian-American menu is standard fare, with a few non-Italian additions.

title: False Endorsement
description: Last Exit to Nowhere

title: Merrill Winner, Cory Bronson
description: Merrill Beth Winner, a daughter of Rochelle and Stewart E. Winner of Tenafly, N.J., is to be married today to Cory Benjamin Bronson, a son of Andrea and Jon H. Bronson of Blue Bell, Pa. Rabbi Richard F. Steinbrink is to officiate at the Glen Island Harbour Club in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Pittsburgh Allows Its Opportunities, and Rutgers, to Slip
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Nov. 17  At the end of a slow, frustrating afternoon of missed opportunities at Rutgers, Pittsburgh had one final chance to steal the game.

title: A Foggy Reunion With Horrors Master
description: STEPHEN KING likes to joke that Frank Darabont, the director of The Shawshank Redemption and The Green Mile, has made a specialty not just of Stephen King movies but of Stephen King prison movies. You could argue that Mr. Darabonts new film, The Mist, based on the King novella of that title, is in the same vein. The difference is that the characters are holed up not in a penitentiary but in a supermarket.

title: Bad Grad, Good Grad
description: One of my grad students copied a term paper from the Internet, cutting and pasting from various uncredited sources. The universitys rules say expulsion or an F in the course is appropriate, but I proposed that she search out the several dozen articles she used to compose her paper and write each author an apology. I will mail the letters. My department chair thinks this is unethical  a cruel and unusual punishment. You?  P.R., Houston

title: Sifting for Facts Amid the Promises
description: With what feels like a debate every other day, no one can say that the presidential candidates are suffering from any lack of exposure. But the voters are still being denied a complete look at the aspirants finances and their health records.

title: Black Americans: One Race, or More?
description: The Pew Research Center released a nationwide survey last week on racial attitudes. More than a third of black respondents said that blacks no longer can be thought of as a single race because their community is so diverse. The results could reflect diverging social values and economic fortunes among blacks.

title: Margaret Ellis, Walter Bottger
description: Margaret Holben Ellis and Walter Frederick Bottger were married yesterday at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Michael L. Lindvall performed the ceremony.

title: The New New List
description: Pied--terre are the new hotels. Who needs a penthouse suite when you can buy a penthouse? Global nomads with growing buying power are forgoing room service for serviced abodes in cities like New York, Berlin and Buenos Aires.

title: Wholl Stop the Ring Tones?
description: LONDON

title: A Bond-Worthy Beauty
description: TESTED 2007 Aston Martin V-8 Vantage Roadster

title: Letters to the Editor
description: A SOUTHERN GENTLEMAN

title: Betting Against the Dollar? This Time, Asia May Deserve a Look
description: JIM ONEILL, the chief economist of Goldman Sachs, has been down on the American dollar for at least 10 years. Being bearish on the dollar has been one of the easiest things to do, Mr. ONeill said. And there are still lucrative currency bets to be made, Mr. ONeill and many other financial professionals say, even though the direction of the American currency isnt as obvious today. Its getting trickier, Mr. ONeill said.

title: Bias Is Suspected in Attack on Teen
description: A 14-year-old boy in Lakewood, N.J., was beaten last night by a group of black youths yelling anti-Semitic slurs, the police said. The beating is being treated as a bias attack, at least the second in recent weeks in Lakewood.

title: Raina Forman and Todd Silver
description: Raina Bree Forman and Todd David Silver were married last evening at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, N.Y. Rabbi Morris Zimbalist performed the ceremony.

title: On the Q.T.: Rocco Forte
description: More than a decade old, the Rocco Forte Collection is verging on empire: 11 hotels and counting. We caught Sir Rocco amid a flurry of openings  Munich, check; Geneva, check; up next, Prague  and gave him the T Travel Questionnaire.

title: A Cleaner Sound
description: Much progress toward a cleaner environment has been made through the market-based magic of pollution credits. The government sets a goal for reducing the levels of a given contaminant  sulfur dioxide, say  and allows polluters to reach it by negotiating among themselves. Efficient high achievers who surpass given cleanup targets earn credits that they can sell to those who do not. Laggards can buy time, but they cannot necessarily wriggle out of the obligation to come clean, or at least cleaner. That is because the tolerable level of a pollutant is gradually lowered, and lowered again, until the air  or water, or whatever it is  is clear.

title: Travel Time Signs Receive Mixed Reviews
description: NEW signs on the Northern State Parkway estimate the length of time it should take motorists to reach specific locations ahead, but some drivers say the signs are of uncertain value.

title: Iceland, Nigeria, New York: Discovery and Rediscovery
description: Sigur Ros

title: Silver Bullet
description: When Viscount David Linley thinks of his childhood, he remembers the family siphon fondly. We always had a drinks trolley, he says, and young David used the siphon to top up the adults whiskeys. We in this case includes Britains most glamorous couple of the 1960s and 70s: his mother, Princess Margaret, and his father, the photographer Lord Snowdon.

title: Bronwyn Spira, Mark Lieberman
description: Bronwyn Anne Spira and Mark Spencer Lieberman were married on Wednesday on Anguilla, in the Caribbean. Rev. John A. Gumbs, a Methodist minister, officiated at a law office in The Valley, the islands capital. Rabbi Charles J. Davidson performed a religious ceremony last evening at the Malliouhana Hotel and Spa, on the islands west end.

title: A Harvest of Trash and Turmoil for an Agent Fighting Steroids
description: Jeff Novitzky is an unlikely contender for the role of Eliot Ness of the steroids age. He is an I.R.S. special agent, a position that is rarely glamorous. The work is often tedious and dull, poring over bank records and tax returns, and writing reports.

title: Rumors of Drug Use Have Damaged for Decades
description: Barry Bonds may go to jail if a jury believes he lied about using steroids. Many other players could face suspensions next season if George J. Mitchell identifies them in his coming investigative report on steroids in baseball.

title: Washingtonienne
description: Theodore Roosevelts older daughter, Alice, moved into the White House at the age of 17, in 1901, 100 years before the arrival of the Bush twins. To grasp the longevity of Princess Alice upon the Washington scene, one must imagine either Jenna or Barbara showing up for a party at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue in the year 2071, the way Alice Roosevelt Longworth took her seat in the Rose Garden for Tricia Nixons White House wedding 65 years after her own. Indeed, Mrs. Longworth survived for almost another decade, sticking around to oppose Jimmy Carters effort to give away her fathers boldest accomplishment, the Panama Canal.

title: A Diesel Engine Woke Up Our Marriage
description: WHENEVER my husband casually says, Hey, hon, come take a look at this Web site, I know its going to cost me. All of our largest purchases were preceded by my being summoned to his computer in this manner. So, three years ago, when he said this a few weeks before his 40th birthday, I knew it was really going to cost me, and I dont mean just financially.

title: Betting on Buckhead
description: Standing in the August heat amid cranes and bulldozers in Atlantas affluent Buckhead district, the citys mayor, Shirley Franklin, rallied a late-morning crowd by proclaiming a renaissance  a resurgence of Atlanta is how she put it  in this Southern metropolis. The occasion was the announcement of a $1.2 billion mega-development called the Streets of Buckhead. Scheduled to open in the fall of 2009, it will be a mini-town of fashionable hotels, boutiques, restaurants and condos. And along with it, public roads will be expanded into wide boulevards with tree-lined sidewalks. Since Atlantas boosters have always loved slogans (The City Too Busy to Hate; Atlanta: People Seem to Like It Here; Every Day Is an Opening Day), its likely that Franklins prophesy will soon be fashioned into a catchy new mantra.

title: Torrealba Out of Mets Picture
description: The Mets are back in the market for a starting catcher after their negotiations with the free agent Yorvit Torrealba dissolved yesterday afternoon. Torrealba had agreed to a three-year, $14.4 million contract Thursday, pending a physical. But barring another sudden turn of events, he will not play for the Mets next season.

title:
A Personal Salute to a Heros Memory; The Intimate Story of an Apple Tree; Why Raise Buffalo
Just to Kill Them? (3 Letters)
description: A Personal Salute to a Heros Memory

title: Funny Songs Are Inspired by Sad Times for the Rich
description: Its true that the country singer Merle Hazard has never been to the Hamptons.

title: With Tank Drained, Knicks Fall Again
description: DENVER, Nov. 17  As the hour grew late Saturday and the suspense had long since been drained from the Pepsi Center, there were really only two curiosities left. Would the Nuggets keep their starters on the court in another rout of the Knicks? And if they did, would the Knicks respond as violently as they did last year?

title: Dont Eat Your Vegetables
description: Storrs

title: The Media Mogul
description: As the former C.E.O. of Disney and the founder of a privately held company that invests in the digital future, you were recently speaking at a conference when you used the words stupid and insanity to describe the Writers Guild strike. Can you explain? What I was driving at was that it was a foolish time to have a strike issue over a business and a marketplace that is not evolved enough to even know if there is a business or a marketplace there.

title: Bragging Rights at the Plaza
description: THE Astor Suite was designed to be the most expensive condominium in the conversion of the storied Plaza Hotel on Fifth Avenue. In its previous life as a three-bedroom hotel suite, the Astor was layered in crystal and gold and with brocade in pink, cream and rose, with a dining room that seated 10 and a master bedroom that had a king-size canopy bed.

title: Record Number of Nuisance Bears Are Killed
description: DENVER, Nov. 17 (AP)  A berry-killing drought and a late spring freeze pushed hungry Colorado bears into more confrontations with humans this year, and wildlife managers say a record 59 bears have been killed as a result.

title: Harold Robbins, Pioneer
description: To the Editor:

title: Memories of World War II, Still Fresh in Collectibles
description: WHEN Dan Crews was 15, he struck a deal that few boys his age would have considered. He swapped $20 worth of baseball cards with a neighbor for a musty World War II uniform brought back from Europe 30 years earlier.

title: Coming Soon: Affordable Views
description: BAYONNE

title: From Armory to Zoo to Museum to Offices
description: THE Arsenal, completed in 1851 in Central Park at East 64th Street, is near the end of a complete exterior restoration. This unusual structure, built to store explosives and ammunition to defend 19th-century New York State, later served as the American Museum of Natural History and as a zoo, and is now the headquarters of the citys Parks and Recreation Department.

title: Cambodias Coast of Utopia
description: Languidly reclining under a beach umbrella at the Sokha Beach Resort after a dip in the sea, a lithe woman in a bikini on the beach chair next to me sits up and decides to write postcards. Like Dorothy waking up in Oz, she looks around to get her bearings. There are no signs, no landmarks, just a glimmering ocean, an empty white-sand beach and the clear blue sky. This could be Thailand or Bali. In fact, it could be anywhere hot, exotic.

title: Sarah Bainton, Zecharia Kahn
description: Sarah Elizabeth Bainton, the daughter of Linda Bainton and Wayne Bainton of Middletown, R.I., was married yesterday to Zecharia Seth Kahn, the son of Barbara Kahn of Warwick, R.I., and Paul Kahn of Paris. The Rev. William Wiethorn, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Marys Church in Newport, R.I.

title: All the Presidents Powers
description: As the Bush administration enters its final year, how fares its effort to remake the law for the benefit of the presidency? With the resignation of Alberto Gonzales, the withdrawal of the infamous 2002 torture memos and setbacks at the Supreme Court in the Guantnamo cases, executive supremacy no longer reigns entirely supreme. At the same time, it hasnt been dethroned either: witness the recent revelations about further Justice Department memos that permit forms of torture, written in 2005 and still in place. And then theres the testimony of Michael Mukasey, George W. Bushs choice for attorney general, who surprised the Senate by unabashedly promoting the presidents authority to act outside statutory boundaries in sensitive areas like wiretapping and by refusing to renounce waterboarding. The salient question of the moment, then, is about Bushs legal legacy. After his tenure, what will come of the changes his lawyers have wrought, especially their attempts to expand executive power?

title: Its in New Jersey, but It Screams Vermont
description: MAYBE the people who live in Hopewell Borough have Jersey fatigue. Or maybe they just yearn for a simpler place and time, before traffic jams and planned communities. Whatever the reason, they are quick to describe this small village in central New Jersey as the most un-Jersey-like town in the state.

title: He Aimed at the Stars but Hit London
description: Wernher von Braun was a giant of the 20th century. But what, in the modern imagination, did he represent? Visionary science? Cynical manipulation? The marriage of science and technology? The convergence of war and peace? Was von Braun the Columbus of space? The brains of the military-industrial complex? The face of modernity? Was he a war criminal, as many of his contemporaries believed? Or was he, as Michael J. Neufeld argues in Von Braun: Dreamer of Space, Engineer of War, a modern Faust, in league with the devil?

title: Genevas Swiss List
description: Geneva has long been known for its influence in banking and world affairs  but not exactly for its sense of style. Now, however, chefs, designers and artisans in the Italianate quarter of Carouge are lending the city a little boho cool.

title: Slow Down? Never. Well, Maybe.
description: WEST BABYLON, N.Y.

title: Colleen Walsh, Stephen Prostor
description: Colleen Elizabeth Walsh and Stephen Victor Prostor were married yesterday at St. Patricks Roman Catholic Church in Johnstown, N.Y. The Rev. Kenneth J. Swain officiated at the ceremony, in which the Rev. Joseph Barker took part.

title: Proposed Colorado Measure on Rights for Human Eggs
description: DENVER, Nov. 16  A proposed amendment to the Colorado Constitution that would give legal rights to fertilized human eggs may be headed for the ballot next year, raising the prospect of a heated local debate over abortion at the same time that Democrats are gathering here for their national convention.

title: Republican Uncertainty Amid a Push by Giuliani
description: DES MOINES, Nov. 17  With a surge of radio advertisements, telephone calls and mailings, Rudolph W. Giuliani is stepping up his efforts to compete in the Iowa Republican caucuses, complicating Mitt Romneys effort to nail down a clean victory here and underscoring the fluid nature of the contest less than seven weeks from the voting.

title: Duplicate Motion, Then Capture Emotion
description: SWEET-FACED children on a magical train trip to the North Pole present one kind of challenge; hulking warriors soaked in sweat and engaged in bloody battle pose an entirely different set of problems.

title: A Personal Salute to a Heros Memory; Will Rutgers Sell Its Soul for a New Stadium?; To Keep Oceans Full of Bluefin Tuna (3 Letters)
description: A Personal Salute to a Heros Memory

title: Stock Market Likely to Stay Under Pressure
description: As the air came out of the technology and telecommunications bubble this decade, the stock market found a new champion in the financial sector.

title: Vocabulary
description: trophy / (tro fe) / adj. / prized for prestige-enhancing qualities. In the world of travel, applied to places, experiences and things that are sought after because they are little known or inaccessible to hoi polloi, as in, Everyone whos anyone will be in Miami for Art Basel  the art-show circuit is the new trophy trip, or, Southern Cambodia is so great, Im sure its going to be the next trophy beach destination.

title: Rupert Murdoch, Embroiled in the Caucasus
description: TBILISI, Georgia

title: In Transition, a Thanksgiving Tradition
description: TOIKEY. Thats what my Eastern European grandmother called a kind of poultry she didnt know or trust. And roasting that bird was never high on Gertrude Goldbergs list of priorities. In late November, she was too preoccupied struggling to get through the busy season in the mom-and-pop fruit store in Philadelphia that she owned with Joseph, her sweet, silent husband, to worry about toikey.

title: The Grand Tour
description: I arrived in Miami knowing nothing. I was ignorant, to put it mildly, an art-world neophyte embarking on the first leg of what would become a delirious journey: one year, four countries, two art fairs, one biennial and, God help me, one quinquennial  a trip propelled by planes, trains, automobiles, water taxis and more alcohol than I had consumed during all of college. My education would begin with a primer at Art Basel Miami Beach in December, a five-day contemporary art fair known as the feistier sister production of Art Basel in Switzerland, the granddaddy of the fair circuit, which I would also stop by, come summertime, as part of the glittering cattle call known in the art world as the grand tour. Once each decade, the planets align and four major events open within days of one another: first there is the Venice Biennale; then Art Basel; followed by Documenta, a serious survey of contemporary art that takes place every five years in the German town of Kassel; and finally Sculpture Projects Mnster, a show of mainly massive sculptures that is held every 10 years in the nearby German hamlet.

title: Melissa Dittmar and Stephen Bruno
description: Melissa Elizabeth Dittmar, a daughter of Zenaida M. Dittmar of San Marino, Calif., and the late William H. Dittmar, was married yesterday to Stephen Douglas Bruno, a son of Karen R. Jacobson of Blue Bell, Pa., and Dr. Leonard A. Bruno of Philadelphia. The Rev. J. P. Reynolds, a nondenominational minister, officiated at the Ritz-Carlton, Huntington Hotel & Spa in Pasadena, Calif.

title: Markets as Both Feast and Spectacle
description: IT is a given that no serious traveler would forgo visits to museums, cathedrals, castles, monuments and legendary streets. Yet food markets deserve equally high billing on a must-see list. For as inspiring as the more standard sights can be, they do not rival the ebullience of modern-day markets and their colorful links to the economy, customs and even dialects of a city.

title: Rita Hillman, Art Lover and Advocate for Nursing, Dies at 95
description: Rita K. Hillman, a philanthropist and art collector who used the proceeds from the sale of Picassos Mother and Child to support the education of hundreds of nurses, died on Nov. 8 at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan, one of the institutions that benefited from her charity. She was 95 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Correction: December Release Schedule
description: An article on Nov. 4 in the Holiday Movies section about the film adaptation of Sweeney Todd misstated the number of Tony Awards that musical won for its original Broadway run in 1979. It was eight, not seven.

title: Affordable Family Planning
description: Budgeting is an important part of a college education. But try to factor this into monthly expenses: prescription contraceptives that cost $10 for last months supply will now cost $50.

title: A Blue State Gets Bluer
description: Republicans might have seen last years election results, in which Democrats made big gains, as part of the backlash from an unpopular war. Republicans lost two Congressional seats to Democrats, and in the Legislature, the Democrats gained seats in both the House and the Senate.

title: Seeking Asylum
description: Every family has a kook in its ranks. In mine, it was my Great-Aunt Affie, whod drop by our house in Indiana unannounced as she drove across the Midwest. She always had a mysterious, brooding child in the back seat, surrounded by toys and hamburger wrappers. The kid  it was a different one each time  was never introduced and never got out of the car. After a short visit in the driveway, Aunt Affie would leave as abruptly as shed arrived, to my parents palpable relief. Your Aunt Affie is ... unique, was all theyd say. Meaning, in that time and place: Shes absolutely bonkers.

title: Pieds Can Be  Terre Here, Too
description: The In the Region article in New Jersey copies last Sunday about foreign and out-of-state buyers and renters seeking pieds--terre near the Hudson River in New Jersey misstated the name of a Midtown Manhattan brokerage firm active in the area. It is Marketing Directors, not Market Directors.

title: Trend Spotting | Liner Notes
description: Cruising less-traveled waters used to mean rustic cabins and close quarters. Now several high-end cruise lines are sending some of their poshest boats to exotic destinations. This January, Aqua Expeditions will launch the 12-suite M/V Aqua, which will sail the Peruvian Amazon year-round and serve nouveau Andean dishes courtesy of the Lima chef Pedro Miguel Schiaffino (www.aquaexpeditions.com; $1,950 to $4,550 per person). In Russia, the 58-cabin Volga Dream  decked out in mahogany and etched glass  sets sail on the Volga from Moscow to St. Petersburg (May through September; 800-633-1008; www.exeterinternational.com; from $6,700 per person). And come spring, Silversea, the company that stocks its ships with goods from Loro Piana and Acqua di Parma, will make stops in Iran; the Silver Cloud is set to dock in Bandar Abbas on its Dubai to Dubai cruise (800-722-9955; www.silversea.com; from $2,937 per person).

title: Private School, Public Fuss
description: IT was an O captain! My captain! moment.

title: Drama Is Building in the L.P.G.A.s Game of Survivor
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 17  The entertainment just kept coming at the ADT Championship, where the day began with golfers lighting up the leader board with birdies and eagles and ended with the eight lucky and talented finalists all seated on a makeshift stage, cracking jokes and picking their own tee times for Sundays final-round pairings.

title: The Sweet Hereafter
description: For Gail Monaghan, memory lane is paved with dessert. Blums coffee crunch cake. The Brown Derbys orange chiffon cake. Butterscotch sundaes from Schraffts  all vestiges of the vanished coffee-shop culture of her childhood. And then there are the tortes, fools, charlotte russes and other sweets that have gone the way of the dessert trolley. While Monaghan, a New York cookbook author and cooking teacher, could appreciate what weve gained  individual chocolate pudding cakes and cleverly concocted confections  she wondered more about what had been left behind.

title: Teutonic Plates
