description: Before the meal proper begins at Silk, Frankfurt's most futuristic restaurant, you're handed a ceramic spoon containing what appears to be the yolk of an egg. It isn't. The blob quivers like a yolk and looks like a yolk. But the color is emphatically, undeniably green.

title: Paris: Goumanyat & Son Royaume
description: Situated in an obscure patch of Paris between the Marais and the less chic Place de la Rpublique, Goumanyat & Son Royaume is not an ordinary spice emporium. Set in what was once an apothecary shop, it is open only four afternoons a week and from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. on Saturdays. Pierre Gagnaire and Alain Ducasse are among the star chefs who buy spices there. You have to ring to be let in. You are greeted by the tinkle of a wind chime and the expertise of the owner, Jean Thiercelin.

title: Who Can Tell You What
description: FINDING out whether you can build an addition on your buildings roof is more complicated than you might think.

title: Auction Houses in the Suburban New York City Region
description: Here is a list of auction houses in the suburban New York City region, with some coming auctions included.

title: A Sea Toy James Bond Would Envy
description: GREENPORT

title: For Chairman Moe, One Last Salute
description: EVEN into his 90s, Moe Fishman never missed a protest. So it was only fitting that the memorial service for Mr. Fishman, an Astoria-born radical who fought Fascism in Spain in the 1930s and in his later years demonstrated against the Iraq war from his folding chair in Greenwich Village, was equal parts a celebration of his life and a rousing antiwar rally.

title: Paige Lance, Alexander Hahn
description: Paige Virginia Lance and Alexander Mark Hahn were married yesterday in Charleston, S.C. Rabbi Anthony D. Holz officiated at the William Aiken House.

title: Life as the Regginator
description: I GREW up in a lower-middle-class environment, usually the lone minority among my classmates. My parents, both immigrants from Haiti, had a Romeo-and-Juliet type of story. My maternal grandfather, a doctor by training, was in the Haitian government. My paternal grandfather was in the opposing military. As young adults my mother and father came to New York, where their romance was able to flourish.

title: As Owners Feel Mortgage Pain, So Do Renters
description: LAS VEGAS  In the foreclosure crisis of 2007, thousands of American families are losing their homes without ever missing a payment. They are renters in houses whose owners default on their mortgages  a large but little noticed class of casualties.

title: Jessica Kouvaros and Marc Wiener
description: Jessica Megan Kouvaros, a daughter of Anna R. Kouvaros and Michael A. Kouvaros of Reading, Pa., was married yesterday to Marc Douglas Wiener, a son of Susan A. Wiener and Michael Wiener of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. Arthur Eccleston, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony at St. Patricks Cathedral in New York.

title: Woody Talks
description: Not only does Woody Allen profess not to care one whit about his legacy as a filmmaker; hes also fashioned some choice Woodyisms on the topic. Heres one: Im a firm believer that when youre dead, naming a street after you doesnt help your metabolism. Heres another: Rather than live on in the hearts and minds of my fellow man, Id prefer to live on in my apartment.

title: Forever Weird
description: On July 2, 1974, I started work as deputy Washington bureau chief for Rolling Stone magazine. My unlikely boss was Richard Goodwin, the former Kennedy speechwriter, who invited me to join him in temporary residence at Ethel Kennedys home in McLean, Va. (the owner was in Hyannis for the summer). On July 3, Hunter Thompson joined us. Much of what ensued that holiday weekend is lost in the mists of history and a fog of controlled substances. There were extensive conversations about the viability of renting a truck, filling it with rats and dumping them on the White House lawn. There was also an effort to remove all the Andy Williams songs from the Kennedy jukebox and replace them with Otis Redding. But mostly I remember having a marathon conversation with Hunter about books and writers, settling finally on Joseph Conrads exhortation in Lord Jim: In the destructive element immerse!

title: Mind of a Rock
description: Most of us have no doubt that our fellow humans are conscious. We are also pretty sure that many animals have consciousness. Some, like the great ape species, even seem to possess self-consciousness, like us. Others, like dogs and cats and pigs, may lack a sense of self, but they certainly appear to experience inner states of pain and pleasure. About smaller creatures, like mosquitoes, we are not so sure; certainly we have few compunctions about killing them. As for plants, they obviously do not have minds, except in fairy tales. Nor do nonliving things like tables and rocks.

title: Plane Rerouting Landing in Court
description: AS the holiday travel season nears, thousands of residents in the tristate region may have a new reason to dread the crush at the airport  even if they never leave home. The Federal Aviation Administration says it will begin phasing in its controversial plan to reroute flight paths in the congested skies over the Northeast in mid-December, which could put planes over some communities in Connecticut, New York and New Jersey for the first time.

title: Plane Rerouting Landing in Court
description: AS the holiday travel season nears, thousands of residents in the tristate region may have a new reason to dread the crush at the airport  even if they never leave home. The Federal Aviation Administration says it will begin phasing in its controversial plan to reroute flight paths in the congested skies over the Northeast in mid-December, which could put planes over some communities in Westchester, Connecticut and New Jersey for the first time.

title: Bush Failed to See Musharrafs Faults, Critics Contend
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17  In the six years since Pakistans president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, joined President Bush in the fight against Al Qaeda, it has been an unlikely partnership: a president intent on promoting democracy and a military commander who seized power in a bloodless coup.

title: Correction: January Release Schedule
description: An entry on Nov. 4 in the Holiday Movies listings misidentified the actor who portrays a member of a small-time crime duo preparing to rob a local church in First Sundays. He is Tracy Morgan  not Chi McBride, who plays the pastor at the church.

title: The Generals New Clothes
description: Just asking, but have we really thought through the physical implications of what were repeatedly asking Pakistans president to do? TOM KUNTZ

title: Lottery Numbers
Those Moments When You Fly
description: BARBARA COOK loves her new iPhone. At her home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan recently Ms. Cook moved her fingertips across the gadgets small screen to show off some of the miscellany she had stored: a YouTube video of the conductor Gustavo Dudamel, photographs of a friends artwork, links to clips of herself in performance.

title: State Gets a Taste for Goats
description: Tranquility

title: On the Tequila Trail in the Place Where Its Made
description: It can make you crazy. It can calm you down. It can make you hallucinate or just have a really colorful night on the town. Its tequila, the spirited spirit from Mexico with a history that can be traced to the Aztecs. Starting Dec. 20, aficionados of the blue agave concoction can take advantage of the tequila package offered by the Presidente InterContinental Hotel Guadalajara (www.intercontinental.com). The package includes a tour of the town of Tequila and visits to an agave plantation and Mundo Cuervo, the oldest distillery in the Western Hemisphere. Through March 1, the package starts at $364 a couple and includes lodging, breakfast and tequila cocktails upon arrival. Guests who arent satisfied after one round can visit the hotels new tequila lounge, where 100 tequilas are available.

title: Letters
description: Of Soldiers and High Finance

title: Out of the Blue in the Caribbean
description: Is an archipelago off the coast of Venezuela, 45 minutes, Fantasy Island-style, by propeller plane from Caracas. From above, the more than 300 islands scatter over the Caribbean's blue water in various sizes and shapes: one just a long stripe of green mangrove trees, others with paisley-shaped coves, and countless impossibly small sand mounds with a lone palm tree, like one of those New Yorker cartoons. The biggest island, Gran Roque, stands out from these specks like three lumps of coffee ice cream. Most Roquenos live there; it has an airstrip and a town that is about twice the size of the airstrip.

title: The Woman in the Shadow
description: OF all the vivid characters who came and went in the tumultuous 84-year life of Norman Mailer, perhaps none played such a sensational role, and then vanished so completely from the public eye, as the authors second wife, Adele. Forty-seven years ago Tuesday, during an all-night blowout party at the couples Upper West Side apartment, Mr. Mailer, who died last weekend, came home in an alcohol-soaked rage and stabbed Adele Mailer near the heart with a penknife hed found in the street.

title: Record in the Making
description: PAUL DAVIES, the British interior designer and developer of luxury homes, has signed a contract to buy three upper floors in the glass tower on East 22nd Street known as One Madison Park. Mr. Daviess $31 million transaction may set a record for a downtown Manhattan condominium.

title: Old Enough to Vote, Old Enough to Win
description: BRANFORD

title: Making College a Reality for Hispanic Students
description: FOR most high school students in Westchester, going to college is a given. But for many Hispanic teenagers, higher education can seem like a costly, intimidating fantasy.

title: That Space Is Fair Game
description: That Space Is Fair Game

title: Leonora Zilkha, Frank Williamson
description: Leonora Rebecca Zilkha, a daughter of Frances Rogers Zilkha and Daniel Abdulla Zilkha of Portland, Me., is to be married today to Benjamin Franklin Williamson, a son of Ann Niemeyer Williamson and Benjamin Franklin Williamson of Darlington, S.C. The Rev. Andrew Rivers ODell, an Episcopal priest, is to officiate at Oaklyn Plantation, the home of the bridegrooms parents.

title: On Time? Late? Here We Go Again
description: PRESIDENT BUSH began a speech last Thursday with three utterly unassailable facts. Thanksgiving is a week from today, and Christmas will quickly follow, Mr. Bush said. Then he added, Unfortunately, this is also a season of dread for too many Americans.

title: Lisa Wagner, Denis Somar
description: Lisa Michelle Wagner, the daughter of Cynthia J. Wagner and Michael E. Wagner of Northville, Mich., was married last evening to Denis Emile Somar, the son of Odiana Dauman of New York. The Rev. James P. Russell, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church of Northville.

title: Whose Line Is It Anyway?
description: To the Editor:

title: 310-Pound Lightweight Carries a Heavy Load for the Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 15  Dewayne Robertson actually smiled when he said he was bearing the brunt of a heavy workload. He often spends Sunday afternoons wrestling two men even bigger than he is, and he is listed at 310 pounds.

title: Meredith Nash, Noah Rosen
description: Dr. Meredith Bea Nash and Dr. Noah Lawrence Rosen were married last evening in Roslyn, N.Y. Rabbi Michael White performed the ceremony at Temple Sinai.

title: Melinda Gray, Mahindra Maharaj
description: Melinda Joelle Gray, a daughter of Roxie Lent of Carlisle, Pa., and the late James A. Gray, who lived in Dillsburg, Pa., was married last evening to Mahindra Maharaj, a son of Joyah Maharaj of Jersey City and the late Parmeshwardath Maharaj. The Right Rev. Andrew St. John, the vicar of the Church of the Transfiguration in New York, performed the Episcopal ceremony there. The previous evening, Pandit Chandica Misra led a Hindu ceremony at the home of the bridegrooms mother.

title: Renovation Premium
description: WHEN it comes to buying and renovating Manhattan town houses, the whole is often greater  millions of dollars greater  than the sum of its parts.

title: Reagans Southern Stumble
description: Summerland, Calif.

title: Hectic, Precarious Time at Busy Soup Kitchen
description: Mount Vernon

title: Candidates Walk a Tightrope on Immigration
description: THE Republican presidential candidates talk about illegal immigration as if they were in an arms race on toughness. The Democratic candidates have begun to tread more warily on the issue, as their debate last week in Las Vegas showed, but they still favor the language of accommodation over alarm.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Nov. 4 wrongly stated that voters authorized borrowing $270 million last year for new stem cell facilities. The Legislature authorized the borrowing.

title: Contributors
description: William Grimes

title: Federer Controls Nadal and Will Meet Ferrer in Final
description: SHANGHAI, Nov. 17  Roger Federer followed up a routine-looking performance Friday against a player he usually dominates with a dominating performance Saturday against the only player who routinely challenges him.

title: The Encyclopedists Lair
description: Idea of a perfect day: Spend about 10 hours online getting lots of things done. Then go out for a drink.

title: Inside the List
description: LONG-RANGE FORECAST: The 2008 edition of the Old Farmers Almanac has been loitering on the paperback advice extended list in recent weeks. Over the decades, this publication has lost little of its folksiness. This years version is filled with advertisements for things like bag balm, and articles on topics like how to grow your own popcorn and All the Right Reasons to Raise Pigs. The almanac makes the biggest headlines each year for its long-range weather forecasts. (This year in the Northeast, it reports, winter will be about a degree milder than normal, on average, with slightly above-normal precipitation. ... The snowiest periods will be in mid-December, mid- and late January, and early to mid-March.) How accurate was last winters forecast? Dont ask. The editors write: Our forecast for the winter of 2006-07 resulted in our lowest verification scores ever, with a 61 percent accuracy rate on the monthly regional precipitation and a 49 percent accuracy rate on monthly regional temperatures. A coin toss would have beaten our monthly regional temperature forecasts by 1 percent. But the optimists at the almanac conclude: We expect to do much better in our forecast for the winter of 2007-08.

title: Erica Greenbaum, Mark Gerson
description: Rabbi Erica Rachel Greenbaum, the daughter of Sandra and Kenneth Greenbaum of New York, was married last evening to Mark Lee Gerson, a son of Susan and Michael Gerson of Short Hills, N.J. Rabbi Matthew Reimer officiated at the couples vacation home in Sag Harbor, N.Y.

title: Pressure Is on Panthers to Stop Favre
description: There are those who say the Packers  a young team led by an old quarterback  have been winning with mirrors. That may be the only thing they have not tried this season. They beat Philadelphia on a last-second field goal. They beat Denver on an 82-yard pass in overtime. They beat Minnesota last week with their first shutout in five years.

title: Creative Loans, Creative Compensation
description: THINGS arent going very swimmingly for investors in NovaStar Financial, a subprime mortgage originator in Kansas City, Mo. Its stock plummeted last week on news that the company lost $64.05 a share in the third quarter, that it had canceled its preferred stock dividend and that it was no longer able to reap the tax advantages of a real estate investment trust status.

title: Calendar of Events
For Giants, Focus Is on Being Quick and Careful
description: If the Giants can snap the football in time and avoid delay-of-game penalties today in Detroit, they will then encounter at least one other concern: keeping their hands on that same ball. The Lions lead the N.F.L. in takeaways.

title: Rock N Roll; Edward Albee; Rite of Spring; The Audiences Role
description: ROCK N ROLL

title: Giving to Charity, Through Real Estate
description: The Ventures column last Sunday, about donating real estate to charitable organizations, misspelled the surname of the director of gift planning at New York University, where donated apartments have been used to house faculty members. He is Alan Shapiro, not Shaprio.

title: Advice to the Hungry: Bring It Yourself
description: AIRLINE food has gotten so bad that Padma Lakshmi, cookbook author and host of Top Chef on Bravo, often heads to the airport with a container full of spinach leaves and leftovers like grilled chicken, along with a separate container of dressing. Once on the plane, I put it together and shake it up, she said.

title: The Tories Find Their Inner Liberal
description: LONDON

title: The Campaign and the Horse Race
description: LATE last month, two respected organizations  the Project for Excellence in Journalism and the Joan Shorenstein Center on the Press, Politics and Public Policy at Harvard University  released a study of news coverage of the 2008 presidential campaign. It reached some familiar conclusions.

title: Third World Clinic, First World Country
description: How some of the uninsured of Appalachia get their health care.

title: Saturday Night Live and In Person
description: On the weekend before Thanksgiving, Saturday Night Live originated not from Studio 8H, but from a theater in Chelsea.

How the little-known star of Anton Corbijns
Control brought down the house.

Conversations With Woody Allen
description: Introduction

description: The Metterling Lists

title: Blonde Faith
description: It's hard to get lost when you're coming home from work. When you have a job, and a paycheck, the road is set right out in front of you: a paved highway with no exits except yours. There's the parking lot, the grocery store, the kids' school, the cleaner's, the gas station, and then your front door.

title: The Fall of Troy
description: He fell down heavily on his knees, took her hand and brought it up to his mouth. "I kiss the hand of the future Mrs. Obermann." He spoke in English. Neither she nor her parents understood German, and he disliked speaking demotic Greek. He considered it vulgar.

title: Barkeep, Gimme Something With a Kick
description: This isnt a gag. Well, maybe it is  but not the joke kind. A drink offered by the new steakhouse Primehouse New York:

title: The Woodman Speaketh
description: Sundays Book Review shows Woody Allen burnishing his legacy through a new collection of interviews  even though he downplays immortality in classic Woodyisms like this

title: Tweaking the Designated Player
description: WASHINGTON  Major League Soccers plan, the designated player, to sign international stars was a measured success in 2007.

title: Funnyman, Who Art Thou?
description: Sundays Times profiles the impressionist Frank Caliendo, whose dozens of voices will be displayed on his TBS sketch-comedy series Frank TV, making its debut on Tuesday at 11 p.m. Like the more than 6.5 million who have already done so on YouTube, you can sample his stuff here:

title: Jets' Balanced Attack Leads to Win
description: Some Jets players said they had forgotten what it felt like to win a football game. Against the Steelers, they remembered.

title: The Week Ahead: Nov. 18-24
description: Film

title: Corrections
description: Arts & Leisure

title: Berlin in Lights: A Collage of Images and Voices
description: One particular focus of the Berlin in Lights festival has been Berlin in the years 1927 and 1928. Weve had Walter Ruttmanns abstract documentary film Symphony of a City (1927), excerpts from the Brecht-Weill Threepenny Opera (1928), and Berlin Alexanderplatz (1929, but set mainly in 1927 and 1928). P.S. 1 is showing Berlin Alexanderplatz, Fassbinders monumental made-for-TV film, nonstop through January; for its contribution to the festival, the Goethe Haus, on Saturday, offered a marathon reading of the no less monumental novel by Alfred Dblin on which it was based.

title: Pawns of St. Petersburg
description: Ronan Bennetts ZUGZWANG (Bloomsbury, $24.95) takes its title from a chess term for those endgame maneuvers in which a player must execute moves that can only lead to defeat. However inelegant the word sounds when applied to a thriller set in St. Peters burg in 1914, it aptly conveys the refined cruelty of the games of intrigue that entrap a respected psychoanalyst, Otto Spethmann, when he undertakes the treatment of two problematic patients.

title: A Problematic Park
description: A series of events this year led officials to believe that Holman State Wayside Park was no longer providing 10 acres of wholesome diversion to Oregon's residents.

title: Sunday Morning Kickoff
description: Oklahomas loss to Texas Tech last night provided another B.C.S. shakeup. As SI.coms Stewart Mandel tells us, West Virginia was the big winner last night, with the door also slowly cracking for Ohio State to possibly sneak back into the national championship picture. ESPN.coms Pat Forde writes that West Virginia is in a good position to make the title game.

title: Theyd Rather Be Hookers
description: Thats the finding of an informal Would You Rather poll on our companion blog Freakonomics, asking if youd rather be arrested for embezzlement or prostitution. By a measure of nearly 4-to-1, respondents chose prostitution. Read more

title: B.C.S. Down to Four, Maybe
description: The race for the two B.C.S. title-game spots is seemingly whittled to four teams. Unless, of course, more chaos ensues in the following weeks. Those teams are No. 1 L.S.U. (10-1), No. 2 Kansas (11-0), No. 3 West Virginia (9-1) and No. 4 Missouri (10-1).

title: Berlin in Lights: Simon Rattle, Absent and Present
description: Some years ago my boss stopped by my desk one day to ask, Is there something called The Rite of Spring? Yes, there is - or rather, there are. In the last 18 months or so, Ive probably seen a dozen variations on the Stravinsky-Nijinsky theme: Tero Saarinens, Emanuel Gats, Shen Weis, Johan Ingers for Nederlands Dans Theater II  (I was on vacation during Wall to Wall Stravinsky at Symphony Space in March 2006, and so missed the belly dance version by Sharita.)

title: Berlin in Lights: The Berlin Philharmonic Takes the A Train
description: I have heard some renowned ensembles perform in unusual places. But, I never would have imagined that I would someday hear the mighty Berlin Philharmonic performing in a converted movie palace in the Washington Heights section of northern Manhattan.

title: Burress and Pierce Play, but Kiwanuka Is Hurt
description: Plaxico Burress, playing all season with an injured right ankle, was back in the starting lineup for the Giants Sunday at Detroit and caught a pass for a nine-yard gain on the Giants first play from scrimmage. Antonio Pierce, the middle linebacker who missed two practices last week with a mild concussion, also was back in the lineup for the Giants.

title: Clinton Is New to Nafta Criticism, Obama Says
description: MARION, Iowa  Senator Barack Obama is accusing Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of waiting until she was a presidential candidate to suggest that the North American Free Trade Agreement - enacted during her husbands administration - was a mistake.

title: Premature anti-Bushism
description: Tyler Cowen, now:

title: Sunday Sampler Platter: Huckabees Record
description: On a talk-show lineup dominated by three presidential contenders, Chris Wallace gave Mike Huckabee a pretty good going-over  perhaps signifying that the Arkansas politician is indeed joining the mix of Republican contenders seen as serious (a national Gallup Poll on Friday among likely Republican voters put him in double digits  at 10 percent  for the first time, and he is showing up in second place in some polls in Iowa).

title: Martin Honored by Jets
description: Curtis Martin addressed reporters before the Jets-Steelers game on Sunday. He looked dapper in his pinstripe suit, pink shirt and striped tie. He looked like he could still play, although Martin did say his knees hurt after jogging, and he has been told the pain will never get better.

title: Dollar panic
description: Warning: economistic post, plus Im not quite sure what I think myself.

title: Suphala | Musician
description: For Suphala, home is where the rhythm is. Once Im onstage, I feel complete, says this New York-based tabla player, who was the first female musician to perform in post-Taliban Kabul. A Minneapolis native, she studied tabla  a traditional North Indian drum  with the master Alla Rakha and has collaborated with the hip-hop producer Timbaland. She takes her blend of electronic and classical Indian music everywhere, from Brooklyn (where she recorded her most recent album, Blueprint) to a royal palace in Jodhpur, India (the acoustics are amazing), but Suphala finds some of her most attentive audiences at the airport. Its a given that my tabla gets lots of looks at security, she says. The case does look like something out of Star Wars.

title: Were even more doomed
description: So far, media behavior in the 2008 campaign has been even worse than in the 2000 and 2004 campaigns. Were mired in a disastrous war, theres a crisis in the housing market, the health care system is collapsing  yet the coverage is all about the horserace, rather than the issues.

title: Hot Stove Roundup
description: With Alex Rodriguez almost certainly heading back to the Yankees, where does that leave the Marlins Miguel Cabrera? Cabrera, who is likely to be traded as Florida looks to cut its payroll, was considered a candidate to replace A-Rod at third base.

title: Scattered Among Many
description: Almost eleven years ago, I stood in the orphanage in Hoa Binh, Vietnam, waiting to meet my adoptive parents for the first time. I was just six years old. This past spring, we journeyed back to Vietnam for my first visit since my adoption. We visited my orphanage and many other wonderful places in Vietnam. My visit to the orphanage triggered so many memories of my time there and of that first meeting with my new parents. The poem I wrote reflects some of those memories and instances. There were so many but that first meeting was what stood out most in my remembrances. Time changes many things but our memories somehow survive. I look back now and dont have any regrets or fears about changing my life. This experience has enabled me to revisit the past with a new outlook.

title: Morriss Out at Baylor
description: What has long been reported and speculated became official Sunday, as Baylor announced that it was firing Coach Guy Morriss. This is somewhat old news at it had been leaked out weeks ago, but it will be interesting to see who takes over this most difficult of jobs.

title: The Black Pantsuit as Uniform
description: Since so many of you have commented about the first-woman-candidate thing, let me suggest a subject thats obviously trivial, but one Ive always found interesting. When Hillary Clinton first ran for the U.S. Senate in New York, she wore the same thing virtually every daya black pantsuit and a pink blouse. She was doing exactly what men do, which is to adopt a kind of uniform.

title: Ask Activist Dai Qing About the Three Gorges Dam
description: Welcome back to our expert roundtable discussion of Chinas environmental crisis. Later today we will be posting answers to reader questions from Peter Bradford, an expert on renewable energy, on possible solutions to Chinas need for energy to fuel industrial expansion. On Wednesday, we will be joined by Dai Qing, a prominent activist in China, who has been an outspoken critic of the Three Gorges Dam for two decades and was the editor of The River Dragon Has Come: The Three Gorges Dam and the Fate of Chinas Yangtze River and Its People.

title: Carr Officially Retiring
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich, Nov. 18  The inevitable became a reality Sunday when Michigan Coach Lloyd Carr gathered his players at a 4 p.m. meeting and told them he planned to retire at the end of the season.

title: Glad Im not young anymore
description: Twenty-five years ago I was on the staff of the Council of Economic Advisers (yes, it was the Reagan administration  but I had a technocratic, non-political position, and was one of a number of Democrats working there, including a guy by the name of Larry Summers). And one of my jobs was to go to international meetings, where I helped draw up communiques. These communiques were, by design, bland and uninformative  because consensus, not insight, was the goal, so anything controversial was fuzzed over.

title: Van Niels Swan Song
description: Harvard fullback Noah Van Niel ended his career on a fitting note Saturday in the Crimsons 37-6 victory over Yale, which gave the Crimson an Ivy League championship. Van Niel has received national recognition by virtue of the fact that he is a rare combination of a bruising fullback and a promising tenor, and he particularly enjoyed the postgame celebration.

title: Uh oh
description: Eek. Via Mark Thoma.

title: Mexicos Mini-Matadors
description: School-age bullfighters have become the rage in Mexico, drawing crowds and criticism.

title: Ignoring a Warning
description: Nick Saban, Alabamas first-year coach, warned his team not to overlook Louisiana-Monroe. Before the game Saturday, he reminded the Crimson Tide of college basketball surprises this season, like Grand Valley States victory over Michigan State in an exhibition game and Kentuckys loss to Gardner Webb.

title: Maclins Impact
description: Missouri quarterback Chase Daniel is being mentioned as a candidate for the Heisman Trophy, but he is well aware that the freshman receiver Jeremy Maclin has been an instrumental part of his success this season.

title: Sesame Street Is a Dark Alley
description: Virginia Heffernan writes in her column The Medium:

title: More of Your Late Night Jokes!
description: Once again, with late-night comedy writers on strike and the talk shows in reruns, Laugh Lines readers step in to fill the void (send your monologue jokes via the comment link below):

title: After Global Agreement, Companies May Bid Higher at Wireless Auction in U.S.
description: PARIS, Nov. 18  When and if Google, Apple, Yahoo and the other potential bidders participate in the auction for wireless licenses in the United States in January, the prices they offer could be the first measure of the impact of the monthlong global radio-frequency spectrum conference that ended in Geneva on Friday.

title: A Fresh Flip Through the Pages of Swing
description: The Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra has been around long enough to have its regulars, in the form of audience members and paper on music stands. Both showed up for Best of the Big Bands, the orchestras speed tour through American dance-palace ingenuity at Rose Theater on Friday night.

title: Martin D. Raab, 75, an Architect for the City, Is Dead
description: Martin D. Raab, a former senior partner at one of New Yorks prominent architecture firms who was chosen by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to lead the citys School Construction Authority at a time when the agency was struggling with long-delayed projects, cost overruns and charges of corruption, died Wednesday in Hartford. He was 75 and had homes in Manhattan and Stockbridge, Mass.

title: The All-American Family Man
description: This 30-second advertisement for the Republican presidential campaign of former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts is to begin running in Iowa and New Hampshire on Monday.

title: Humor Can Bring Back an Audience
description: If the writers strike drags on, one TV show after another will exhaust its supply of fresh episodes and move into repeats. Executives are aware of the wide disparity in how different types of programs are received the second time around.

title: Lottery Numbers
A (Bronx) Zoo Tale
description: A colorful campaign aimed at parents and children is playing up the wild in the premier attractions owned and operated by the Wildlife Conservation Society.

title: Keeping Americans in Their Homes
description: The nations housing market is in a deep recession, and further declines in new construction, sales and prices are imminent. By the end of next year, falling home values, combined with rising payments on adjustable mortgages, tighter lending conditions and, in all probability, a faltering job market, will have unleashed mass foreclosures  estimated at several hundred thousand to two million  unless something is done to help keep Americans in their homes.

title: Steelers Are Hit Where It Hurts
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 18  Before Sundays game, the numbers suggested the Jets would get blown out by the Pittsburgh Steelers.

title: Web Sites Go Fishing in TVs Advertising Revenue Stream
description: LONDON, Nov. 18  Web sites have been draining the life out of newspapers and radio for years, according to one of the founders of an Internet video site, and now they are going after the advertising revenue stream of television as well.

title: Publishers Seek to Mine Book Circles
description: In early June, at Book Club Expo, a gathering of reading group members and book lovers, the author Khaled Hosseini opened the first session with heartfelt thanks to the attendees.

title: Dynamo Repeat as M.L.S. Champions
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18  It probably should not come as a surprise that Dwayne De Rosario scored the goal that gave the Houston Dynamo its second consecutive M.L.S. Cup title.

title: A 9 to 5 Musical and Theater Notes
description: The Grammy-Award-winning singer-songwriter Dolly Parton has another job, writing the music and lyrics for a new stage version of 9 to 5, based on the 1980 movie starring Ms. Parton, left, Jane Fonda, Lily Tomlin and Dabney Coleman. Patricia Resnick, a co-author of the original screenplay, wrote the new book. Joe Mantello (The Ritz) is slated to direct the production, which is to have its premiere at the Ahmanson Theater in Los Angeles next fall. Andy Blankenbuehler (In the Heights) will handle the choreography. Previews are scheduled to begin Sept. 3. The main roles have been cast: Allison Janney of the TV series The West Wing, Stephanie J. Block (The Pirate Queen, Wicked) and Megan Hilty (Wicked) as the three co-workers who take control of the office from their egotistical boss, Franklin Hart Jr., to be played by Marc Kudisch (The Glorious Ones). ... Speaking of In the Heights and Mr. Blankenbuehler, he and the Broadway-bound shows director, Thomas Kail, are the winners of the 2006-7 Joseph A. Callaway Awards for excellence in direction and choreography. The awards have been presented annually since 1989 by the Society of Stage Directors and Choreographers, and winners are chosen by a committee of society members. The presentations will be made tonight at the groups annual membership meeting. In the Heights, with music and lyrics by Lin-Manuel Miranda and a book by Quiara Alegra Hudes, will begin previews Feb. 14 at the Richard Rodgers Theater, with opening night scheduled for March 9.

title: Knicks Look Ahead to Long Season
description: A few weeks ago, when the season was new and a reasonable optimism filled the air, Stephon Marbury was asked to assess the Knicks chances. He hesitated.

title: Stagehands and Producers Break Off Talks
description: The latest round of talks between the producers league and the stagehands union broke down last night, leaving no end in sight for the strike that has darkened most of Broadway for nine days.

title: Part of an Oil Book Relied on Wikipedia
description: The publisher John Wiley & Sons confirmed last week that its book Black Gold: The New Frontier in Oil for Investors by George Orwel had lifted almost word for word about five paragraphs from a Wikipedia article on the Khobar Towers bombing in Saudi Arabia.

title: U.S. Considers Enlisting Tribes in Pakistan to Fight Al Qaeda
description: This article was reported and written by Eric Schmitt, Mark Mazzetti and Carlotta Gall.

title: Goldman Sachs Rakes In Profit in Credit Crisis
description: For more than three months, as turmoil in the credit market has swept wildly through Wall Street, one mighty investment bank after another has been brought to its knees, leveled by multibillion-dollar blows to their bottom lines.

title: 4 More Years: Castillo and Mets Nearing Deal
description: The Mets, who spent a tumultuous weekend unexpectedly re-entering the market for a starting catcher and preparing for life without Tom Glavine, edged closer to filling their vacancy at second base last night. Luis Castillo and the Mets are nearing completion on a four-year, $25 million deal that will establish continuity at a position that has lacked it during Manager Willie Randolphs tenure.

title: Irvington: Woman Wounded by Stray Shot
description: A woman returning home from church yesterday afternoon was wounded by a stray gunshot, the police said. The woman, whose name was not released, was a passenger in a car that had parked in front of a home on Montrose Terrace. As she got out of the car, a bullet crashed through the rear window and struck her on the left side of the face. She was taken to University Hospital in Newark, where her injuries were described as not life-threatening. The police said that the bullet appeared to be a stray shot from several that were fired from a nearby white car at a black car. Compiled by John Sullivan

title: Ochoa Wins ADT Championship in Stunning Fashion
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 18  Lorena Ochoa picked the perfect time and place Sunday to bury any lingering doubt about her ability to finish. On the frightening final holes of the course built by the author of The Art of the Deal, Ochoa, 26, wrote a chapter of her own on how to close the deal on the richest season a female golfer has had.

title: Strike or No Strike, for a Select Few, Saturday Night Was Live
description: Thirty minutes before showtime just about all the cast members of Saturday Night Live were gathered in a green room, going over their bits. Fred, remember on the cold open, you wait for Darrell, Seth Meyers, one of the shows head writers, instructed Fred Armisen. Kenan Thompson ran his lines and brushed his teeth; Rachel Dratch adjusted her Debbie Downer wig; Kristen Wiig gathered her props. Norah Jones, a surprise guest, arrived and greeted the guest host, Michael Cera, the deadpan boy-hero of Superbad.

title: Electrical Problem Halts Trains
description: All train service between Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan and Penn Station in Newark was disrupted for nearly six hours yesterday after an eastbound New Jersey Transit train became entangled in overhead wires in a tunnel under the Hudson River. The break in service, which began about 8:30 a.m., affected dozens of Amtrak and New Jersey Transit trains and more than 30,000 riders, according to representatives of the railroads. The disabled train, traveling from Long Branch, N.J., was carrying about 300 passengers, who were transferred in the tunnel to a Long Island Rail Road train, a New Jersey Transit spokeswoman said. Both railroads said that normal service resumed in the afternoon and that the disruption was not expected to affect this mornings commute.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Beowulf Destroys the Competition

title: In Railyards, Seeing a Blank Canvas on the Hudson
description: Five developers are competing to buy the development rights over the Metropolitan Transportation Authority railyards that straddle 11th Avenue, between 30th and 33rd Streets. They have submitted billion-dollar offers and elaborate development plans for what would be the largest project in Manhattan, on 26 acres stretching across the equivalent of six city blocks overlooking the Hudson River.

title: Creativity, Strikes and Power
description: It was a good weekend for the labor that is organized around the creative arts.

title: Rudi Schmid, 85, Leading Liver Researcher, Is Dead
description: Dr. Rudi Schmid, a liver specialist and medical educator who was an early champion of establishing organ transplant centers to make donor livers widely available, died on Oct. 20 in Kentfield, Calif. He was 85.

title: Carr to Retire From Michigan
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 18  In the chilly parking lot outside Schembechler Hall on Sunday night, reporters hovered around Lloyd Carrs silver Lexus sport utility vehicle.

title: Big Fish May Be Easier Targets
description: In the past two months, three of the worlds most highly visible professional athletes have been fingered for wrongdoing, one in connection with dogfighting, two in connection with the use of performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: McCains Rocky Relationship With the Hawkeye State
description: There was a particularly striking number contained in The New York Times/CBS News poll of Iowa caucus-goers last week and it told the story of the complicated  and cool relationship that Senator John McCain has always had with Republicans in Iowa. The number was four the percentage of Iowa Republicans who said they would support him. He is running fifth in the state.

title: Injury Report
description: Donovan McNabb sprained his ankle in the second quarter of Philadelphias game against Miami. A. J. Feeley played well in relief, but Coach Andy Reid moved quickly to head off a quarterback controversy. If Donovans healthy, hes the quarterback, Reid said. ... Receiver Santonio Holmes left the Steelers game against the Jets with an ankle injury and did not return. ... Jaguars linebacker Mike Peterson will be out indefinitely after breaking his right hand against the Chargers.

title: Rendition, Torture and Accountability
description: Maher Arar, a Syrian-born Canadian, was stopped at Kennedy Airport in 2002 while returning from a family vacation. After being held in solitary confinement in a Brooklyn detention center and interrogated without proper access to a lawyer, he was spirited off to Syria. He was tortured there for months before officials decided that their suspicions that he was a member of Al Qaeda were mistaken and let him go.

title: Craig Smith, Boston-Based Conductor Noted for Bach Cantatas, Dies at 60
description: Craig Smith, who as the founding music director of the Emmanuel Music orchestra and chorus in Boston led the first complete cycle of Bachs cantatas in the United States as well as expansive explorations of works from the 16th century to the present day, died on Wednesday in Boston. He was 60.

title: Diplomacy With the Devil
description: Washington

title: Federer Shows the Upstart Ferrer Whos No. 1
description: SHANGHAI, Nov. 18  Roger Federer, who ended his season with a straight-sets victory over the hottest player in this elite, year-ending tournament, can now rest a bit before taking on his only serious remaining opponent  history.

title: U.S. Approves $1.3 Billion for 2nd Avenue Subway
description: The long-dreamed-of Second Avenue subway will take another important step toward becoming a real thing of concrete and steel today, as the federal government plans to announce that it has formally approved $1.3 billion in financing for the projects first phase.

title: In a Quiet Suburb, a Quiet Life Darkened
description: Maybe she taught you ballet, or piano, or the violin. She might have been your kindergarten teacher, or the neighbor lady who baby-sat, or your favorite grandmother. She wore pastel cardigans and eyeglasses that hung from a chain around her neck. She smelled like nobody else, of flowers and powder and gentle decay.

title: Advertising Accounts and People
description: Accounts

title: Celgene to Acquire Pharmion
description: The biotechnology company Celgene said yesterday that it would pay $2.9 billion in cash and stock to acquire Pharmion, strengthening Celgenes cancer drug portfolio and its distribution in Europe.

title: Remember the War on Drugs?
description: It is good to see Mexico and the United States working together to battle the drug cartels that deliver hundreds of tons of illegal drugs to American consumers every year, killing more than 2,000 Mexicans annually along the way. Still, the Bush administrations proposed $1.4 billion counternarcotics aid package falls far short of what is needed to confront the problem.

title: Hewlett-Packard Beats Earnings Estimates
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 19  Hewlett-Packard, the worlds largest technology company, today reported fourth-quarter sales and earnings that well exceeded Wall Streets estimates.

title: Defense Carries Giants Over Lions
description: DETROIT, Nov. 18  After the Giants earned a tense and rugged 16-10 victory against the Lions at Ford Field on Sunday, someone told Michael Strahan that Detroit quarterback Jon Kitna said that the Giants were not the better team.

title: Off City Turf, Haggling for Food
description: Until Jennifer McLean and two drivers from City Harvest showed up at Joe Sidotis farm last Friday, the radishes still growing in his field were goners.

title: Sometimes a Double Gives Away Too Much
description: Gandhi said, If I had no sense of humor, I would long ago have committed suicide. One hopes that West has a sense of humor because he committed metaphorical suicide on the diagramed deal, which occurred during a knockout team event at the Lancaster Red Rose Regional in Lancaster, Pa., this month.

title: French Commuters Face Longer Strike
description: PARIS, Nov. 18  Exasperated French commuters braced for a sixth day of no train service and snarled traffic on Monday after transportation unions voted Sunday to press on with their strike against the governments effort to change some early retirement benefits.

title: ... And the Pursuit of Happiness
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Schusses Overcome Kosovos Ethnic Schisms
description: BREZOVICA, Kosovo  War is not forgotten here, but there is at least one place  at this ski resort, 5,600 feet high on a mountain blanketed with snow during winter  where Kosovos Albanians and Serbs try, however uneasily, to get along.

title: Gala to Honor Plcido Domingo
description: This past weekend was the 40th anniversary of Plcido Domingos Los Angeles debut: He was on tour with the New York City Opera when he first stood on stage at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion, on Nov. 17, 1967, singing the title role in Alberto Ginasteras Don Rodrigo. To commemorate the event, the Los Angeles Opera has announced the Plcido Domingo 40th Anniversary Gala on April 18. Since 2003, he has been the Eli and Edythe L. Broad General Director of the Los Angeles Opera.

title: Bronx: Firefighter Injured in Fall
description: A firefighter was hurt yesterday afternoon when he fell from an aerial bucket while battling a blaze in an apartment in Highbridge, the Fire Department said. The firefighter, Brian Smith, 43, was taken to St. Barnabas Hospital, where he was listed in serious but stable condition. One apartment resident was also injured in the fire, neighbors said. The fire was on the second floor of a six-story building on Shakespeare Avenue. Melissa Gonzales, who lives above the apartment that was on fire, said she believed that Firefighter Smith was trying to break a window on her floor to gain access. A bystanders video of the accident shows two firefighters in the bucket, and one falling.

title: Environmental Groups Cutting Catalog Stacks
description: Consumers who curse the growing stacks of holiday catalogs in their mailboxes have a new alternative: a coalition of environmental groups has introduced a free Web site, CatalogChoice.org, that allows people to remove themselves from more than 1,000 mailing lists.

title: Jets Show They Remember How to Win
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 18  Through the doors of the Jets locker room came the unfamiliar sounds of celebration: grown men singing in the shower, the hooting and hollering of a team that had watched 55 days pass between its first and second victories.

title: New CDs
description: CELINE DION Taking Chances  (Columbia)

title: Totals
description: Previously recorded $2,249,585.28

title: Notes on Mortality and Darkness
description: Thomas Bernhard once wrote that all of Austria was suicidal, but that not all of its citizens followed through on the inclination. The Berlin Philharmonic concert at Carnegie Hall on Friday, the third and last of a series and a centerpiece for the Berlin in Lights festival just ended, seemed at one moment to be running into the arms of death and at the next backing away. The music was Gyorgy Kurtags Stele and Mahlers 10th Symphony. Simon Rattle conducted.

title: Greece and Turkey Open Gas Pipeline
description: ATHENS, Nov. 18  Greece and Turkey opened a $300 million pipeline on Sunday, creating an energy corridor that connects the rich natural gas fields in the Caspian Sea region to Europe, bypassing Russia and the volatile Middle East.

title: Faith and Family Boost a Mans Resolve
description: Noel M. Hall sometimes found the chemotherapy so unbearable that he wanted to quit. He wanted to let the cancer take his liver and his life.

title: Study Finds Higher Costs for Caregivers of Elderly
description: The out-of-pocket cost of caring for an aging parent or spouse averages about $5,500 a year, according to the nations first in-depth study of such expenses, a sum that is more than double previous estimates and more than the average American household spends annually on health care and entertainment combined.

title: Making News, Without Saying a Word
description: As journalistic blunders go, it wasnt quite up there with Dewey Defeats Truman. But last week, The Associated Press had to eat its words after running a news article about Paris Hiltons supposed desire to publicize the plight of elephants in northeastern India.

title: The Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC SIGNALS The main economic news of the week will come on Tuesday, when the Federal Reserve releases the minutes from its October meeting and issues its first of its new economic forecasts.

title: Manhattan: Man Found Fatally Shot in Hallway
description: Police officers responding to a report of an unconscious person in Hamilton Heights yesterday found a dead man who had been shot, the police said. The officers were summoned to the third-floor hall at 201 West 146th Street about 8:45 a.m. and found a man, 39, lying there with a single gunshot wound to his chest, according to the police. His name had not been released yesterday evening because his family had not yet been notified, the police said.

title: Pakistani Group, Suspected by West of Jihadist Ties, Holds Conclave Despite Ban
description: RAIWIND, Pakistan, Nov. 18  For six days they came: hundreds of thousands of Pakistani men squashed onto a barren rice field, dressed in baggy trousers, crocheted caps on their heads, sandals on their feet and long beards a common feature.

title: Children Play With Fire by Doing Riffs on Stravinsky
description: The Berlin in Lights Festival neared its close on Saturday night with the charming Rite of Spring Project, an evening of music and dance created by members of the Berlin Philharmonic, a guest choreographer and some 200 children from schools in New York City. But is charm all that appropriate, given the raw and pounding violence of the Stravinsky classic that inspired the program, performed at the resplendently funky United Palace Theater in Washington Heights?

title: Fox Cable Guy Edges Into the Big Pay Leagues
description: Roger Ailes, the chairman of the Fox News Channel, calls Shepard Smith his go-to guy, the person he wants leading the channels coverage any time news breaks.

title: Chinese Dam Projects Criticized for Their Human Costs
description: JIANMIN VILLAGE, China  Last year, Chinese officials celebrated the completion of the Three Gorges Dam by releasing a list of 10 world records. As in: The Three Gorges is the worlds biggest dam, biggest power plant and biggest consumer of dirt, stone, concrete and steel. Ever. Even the projects official tally of 1.13 million displaced people made the list as record No. 10.

title: A Delicate Glass Roof With Links to the Past
description: WASHINGTON  However entertaining you may find its cutthroat political atmosphere, this city has long been a backwater in terms of contemporary architecture. More often than not, when anyone here tinkers with old landmarks, they turn them into kitsch.

title: Strike Causes NBC to Skip Event for TV Journalists
description: Come January, television networks hobbled by the writers strike may not have many new shows to promote. So, for the first time in 20 years, one network is not attending the twice-yearly conference for television journalists, and the other broadcast networks are uncertain about their participation.

title: New Jersey Moves to End Death Penalty
description: TRENTON, Nov. 18  The eight men confined to the Capital Sentences Unit of 3 Wing in the New Jersey State Prison, ranging in age from 77 to 30, have a better chance of dying of old age than they do of lethal injection on an executioners gurney.

title: Examining the Many Hues That Create Black and White
description: What is black dance? The question, usually asked by white dance writers, tends to be greeted by groans from black choreographers, company directors and performers. But Gesel Mason, herself a black dancer and choreographer, plunged headlong into the subject on Friday night at Joyce SoHo in No Boundaries: Dancing the Visions of Contemporary Black Choreographers and came up with some provocative responses.

title: Baby Shower in Brooklyn Ends in Deadly Gunfire
description: A manager at a Brooklyn banquet hall shot three people outside the hall early yesterday, one of them fatally, and was then shot by one of two men who intervened, the police said. The men were arrested moments later, after a police sergeant fired at them twice during a foot chase, striking one of the men in the leg, the authorities said.

title: Jesuit Order Settles Suit on Sex Abuse in Alaska
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Nov. 18 (AP)  A Roman Catholic religious order has agreed to pay $50 million to more than 100 Alaska Natives who say they were victims of sexual abuse by Jesuit priests, a lawyer for the victims said Sunday.

title: A Russian Pianist Finds a Place for Both a Hush and a Roar
description: The atmosphere was electric before a recital by the pianist Denis Matsuev at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night, and the accent of the throng was mostly Russian. Mr. Matsuev, 32, won the prestigious International Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow in 1998. He has since been heralded by some critics as the successor to Russian keyboard lions like Evgeny Kissin and Arcadi Volodos, and perhaps to Vladimir Horowitz as well.

title: Reform and Consumer Safety
description: With the recent reports about toxic toys from China, the public is right to be alarmed by the withering of the governments consumer product safety protections. Congress has been moving ahead on reform bills, but Congressional leaders will have to act deftly to prevent rivalry between the House and Senate from hampering passage of a truly effective final measure. Industry lobbyists are working hard to promote gridlock and stop the tough changes consumers need.

title: Johnson Wins 2nd Nascar Championship
description: HOMESTEAD, Fla., Nov. 18  To understand the level of dominance displayed by Jimmie Johnson in this years Nascar Nextel Cup series, consider that it has been nine seasons since any driver has won as many as 10 races in a season. Even when Jeff Gordon managed 13 victories in 33 races back in 1998, only 17 drivers competed in every race.

title: Cost of Elderly Care Is Double Prior Estimates
description: The out-of-pocket cost of caring for an aging parent or spouse averages $5,531 a year, according to the nations first in-depth study of such expenses, a sum that is more than double previous estimates and more than the average American household spends each year on health care and entertainment combined.

title: Financials, Once a Balm, Now Hamper the Market
description: As the air came out of the technology and telecommunications bubble this decade, the stock market found a new champion in the financial sector.

title: Hollywood Producer of Varied Interests, Many Hits, but Little Fame
description: LOS ANGELES  Brian Grazer, one of the most successful producers in Hollywood, would seem to be a memorable guest, with his energetic manner and elaborately spiked hair. But to make sure he is not forgotten, he will often leave behind a small photo of himself in an inexpensive heart-shaped frame after attending a dinner or party, hiding it among his hosts family photographs.

title: Homeland Security Adviser Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  Frances Fragos Townsend, the White House adviser on terrorism and homeland security, whose tough and aggressive approach had made her one of President George W. Bushs most trusted aides, has resigned.

title: The iPhone?  Microsoft Shrugs
description: The iPhone? Microsoft Shrugs

title: Mondays Matchup
description: Titans quarterback Vince Young threw for a career-high 257 yards last Sunday, but given his shaky passing this season (4 touchdowns, 10 interceptions) it may be safer for Tennessee to keep the ball on the ground. Fortunately for the Titans, the Broncos rank 31st against the run, giving up 151 yards a game. LenDale White will have some help attacking that defense with the expected return of Chris Brown from an injury. Travis Henrys sore knee may keep him out of the Broncos lineup, leaving Selvin Young to stare down the Titans second-ranked defense. If he cannot move the ball on the ground, Jay Cutler (nine touchdowns, nine interceptions) will have to pass it. The good news for Cutler is that he may not have to worry about Albert Haynesworth, who is nursing a hamstring injury. ANDREW DAS

title: A Blues Diva in Weimar, Visiting on Her Own Terms
description: Cassandra Wilson ventured out of her normal comfort zone on Saturday evening to give a recital of popular standards at Caf Sabarsky as the final event in the Neue Galeries cabaret sidebar to Berlin in Lights, a festival presented by Carnegie Hall. Talk about crossover! Ms. Wilson is a singer who plays by her own rules. With her dark, loamy jazz and blues voice, she likes to make it up as she goes along, even in a recital format.

title: Retailers Explore New Ways of Being Paid
description: A DECADE ago, PayPal was best known as the payment method of choice for Beanie Babies purchases on eBay. This holiday season, it could pay for a diamond ring on the online jeweler Blue Nile.

title: Stocks Fall on Fresh Woes in Banking Sector
description: Stocks fell sharply today, led lower by the financial sector, with the Dow Jones industrial average declining more than 200 points and closing below 13,000. It was the Dows lowest close since the depth of the markets plunge in August.

title: Capturing the Moment With Fewer Minutes
description: Pop stars have kept photojournalists in check for a long time now, having them restricted to pens or escorted from concert halls after only a few songs. But lately some leashes have been especially short. At Stevie Wonders concert at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night, photographers were told they could shoot only the first 5 to 10 seconds of Mr. Wonders entrance and the first 60 seconds of his first song. Then they had to leave.

title: A Web Site for Pet Lovers, and Marketers Who Love Them
description: KNOWING that you can never underestimate peoples love for their cats and dogs, NBC Universal and Procter & Gamble have set up a Web portal that looks something like a Yahoo or AOL for pet owners, with a bit of Facebook and MySpace thrown in.

title: A Deeply Green City Confronts Its Energy Needs and Nuclear Worries
description: FORT COLLINS, Colo.  This city takes pride in being green, from its official motto, Where renewal is a way of life, to its Climate Wise energy program, which helps local businesses reduce the carbon emissions that scientists say can contribute to global warming.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,859 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Footnotes
description: On Thursday Lindsay Lohan spent just 84 minutes in the Century Regional Detention Facility in Lynwood, Calif. (the old stomping grounds of Paris Hilton). Ms. Lohan, 21, was to serve a one-day sentence passed in August for a drunken driving and cocaine-possession conviction. ... Barbara Cooks 80th Birthday Celebration with the New York Philharmonic, tonight and tomorrow night, will have an encore performance. Ms. Cook will return on Jan. 8, with tickets already on sale. The January program will be the same as this weeks: a mix of Broadway songs and popular standards with Lee Musiker conducting. {hellip} Brent Weinbach, a stand-up comedian who works in the Bay Area, won the Andy Kaufman Award at the Comedy Festival in Las Vegas on Friday night. The award, which was inaugurated in 2004 and recognizes a comedian with an original approach, had previously been presented as part of the annual New York Comedy Festival. ... Calvin Levels will perform his solo play James Baldwin: Down From the Mountaintop from Dec. 7 through Dec. 9 as part of a 20th-anniversary commemoration of the writer, who died in 1987. Performances will be at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Harlem. There will also be a panel discussion on Dec. 9, moderated by Amy Goodman of Democracy Now. Panelists scheduled to participate include Cornel West and Amiri Baraka. Visit JamesBaldwinPlay.com for details.

title: A Guerrilla Video Site Meets MTV
description: Vice magazine has built a small media empire out of a raw, ironic sensibility, risqu photographs and a willingness to deal in taboo subjects.

title: St. Anthonys Wins Title
description: St. Anthonys of South Huntington, Long Island, won its seventh consecutive Catholic High School Football League AAA title yesterday, beating Mount St. Michael of the Bronx, 26-20, at Hofstras Shuart Stadium. Mount St. Michael also lost in last years final.The Rutgers-bound defensive tackle Scott Vallone had nine tackles, two sacks and a fumble recovery. He also made a potential game-saving tackle, taking down quarterback Jayson Holt short of a first down at the St. Anthonys 15 with 59 seconds remaining. William Ruggiero scored two rushing touchdowns for St. Anthonys (10-1).

title: Study Links Drop in Test Scores to a Decline in Time Spent Reading
description: Harry Potter, James Patterson and Oprah Winfreys book club aside, Americans  particularly young Americans  appear to be reading less for fun, and as that happens, their reading test scores are declining. At the same time, performance in other academic disciplines like math and science is dipping for students whose access to books is limited, and employers are rating workers deficient in basic writing skills.

title: MTV Heads to the Middle East
description: Hoping to take advantage of demographics in the Arab world, where about two-thirds of the population is under 30, MTV started MTV Arabia in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, at midnight Saturday night, the BBC and The Associated Press reported. MTV Arabia, entering a market already teeming with more than 50 music channels, will present Arab music videos and other shows, and adapt current hits like Pimp My Ride for a new audience. The channel will also broadcast new reality shows like Hip HopNa, featuring two Arab hip-hop stars. The first program on Saturday night, a pretaped show, featured the Grammy-winning rapper Ludacris, above, the Senegalese soul singer Akon and the Lebanese-born singer-songwriter Karl Wolf of Montreal.

title: Broadway Strike Threatens to Take a Toll on City
description: With Broadway theaters shutting down for the rest of the busy Thanksgiving week, and possibly longer, because of a strike, businesses around Times Square are bracing for what could be a major loss of customers and revenue during their busiest time of the year.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes todays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

title: Brazil Discovers an Oil Field Can Be a Political Tool
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 17  With the price of oil hovering near $100 a barrel, the discovery of the biggest deep-water oil field off the southeastern coast has the potential to transform Brazil into a global energy powerhouse and to reshape the politics of this energy-starved continent.

title: The Days Best
description: Antrel Rolle scored on two interception returns as the Cardinals beat the Bengals, 35-27. He also returned a third interception for a score, but it was called back because of a penalty.

title: Calling Country Stars of Tomorrow
description: Country Music Television and FremantleMedia North America, the production company behind American Idol, have announced the date for open auditions for Can You Duet?, a new music competition show that aims to find the next big pair in country music. The cattle call will take place in Nashville on Jan. 12, but future Johnny and Junes or Kenny and Dollys can also submit videotaped auditions. (Details are at canyouduet.com.) Judges for the show, expected to reach the air next spring, have yet to be announced.

title: Keeping Witnesses Off Stand to Keep Them Safe
description: The strategy sounds almost illogical: Detectives in New Jersey are being urged to build criminal cases with as few witnesses as possible. Or with none at all.

title: Democrats Say They Wont Back Down on War
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18  Democrats in Congress failed once again Friday to shift President Bushs war strategy in Iraq, but insisted that they would not let up. Their explanation for their latest foiled effort seemed to boil down to a simple question: What else are we supposed to do?

title: U.S. Hopes to Use Pakistani Tribes Against Al Qaeda
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18  A new and classified American military proposal outlines an intensified effort to enlist tribal leaders in the frontier areas of Pakistan in the fight against Al Qaeda and the Taliban, as part of a broader effort to bolster Pakistani forces against an expanding militancy, American military officials said.

title: Child Matadors Draw Ols in Mexicos Bullrings
description: MRIDA, Mexico  Michelito Lagravere Peniche, 9, put his fingers to his head to create mock horns and charged at Jairo Miguel, 14, who gracefully dodged him on the first pass. But Michelito was an aggressive bull and he circled back, this time striking his friend Jairo in the leg. Both boys erupted in laughter.

title: Israel, Palestine, Crab Cakes
description: I would like to invest hope in the Annapolis Middle East peace conference, or meeting, or parley, or whatever the term is. Really, I would. The 59-year battle for the same land of Zionist and Palestinian national movements has not been good for anyone.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Roger Ardan joined Gibbs & Soell Public Relations, New York, as vice president and group head at the professional and financial services group. He had been senior vice president and head of the legal and professional services group at Edelman, New York, part of Daniel J. Edelman Inc.

title: With No Suspense, Patriots Stay Unbeaten
description: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y., Nov. 18  The evening started promisingly enough for the Buffalo Bills, with Kevin Everett making his first public statement since he sustained a severe spine injury 10 weeks ago, exhorting his teammates from the big video screen, Lets beat the Patriots.

title: Paul Tibbets at Hiroshima: What Is His Legacy?
description: To the Editor:

title: McCain Takes On Clinton, With an Eye to Civility
description: RINDGE, N.H., Nov. 18  Senator John McCain tried Sunday night to make the case that he was best positioned to defeat Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in a general election, outlining a series of contrasts with her on issues including national security and health care.

title: U.S. Says Attacks in Iraq Fell to Feb. 2006 Level
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 18  The American military said Sunday that the weekly number of attacks in Iraq had fallen to the lowest level since just before the February 2006 bombing of the Shiite shrine in Samarra, an event commonly used as a benchmark for the countrys worst spasm of bloodletting after the American invasion nearly five years ago.

title: How to Tell Someone Shes Being Sued, Without Really Telling Her
description: Along with the media gossip and real estate erotica that fill The New York Observer, a dishy weekly newspaper for Manhattans political and media clans, there are more than four pages of advertisements in tiny type aimed at a different readership.

title: Increase in Teacher Resignations
description: More teachers resigned during the last school year than at any time in recent history, according to figures released yesterday by the United Federation of Teachers, the citys teachers union. According to the figures, 4,606 certified teachers resigned last year, not including teachers who retired or had problems with certification. The numbers have been steadily increasing since 2001, when 2,544 resigned; last year 4,273 teachers did so. Of the 7,069 teachers who were hired in 2006, nearly 14 percent resigned by the end of the year, the union said, up from about 11 percent the year before. The numbers showed that losing good teachers is the predominant staffing issue that the City Department of Education needs to address, said Randi Weingarten, the president of the union. Chris Cerf, a deputy chancellor at the Education Department, said in a statement that the numbers were inaccurate, and called the release of the figures a media stunt.

title: Critics Assail Weak Dollar at OPEC Event
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 18  A rare meeting of the heads of state of the OPEC countries ended here today on a political note, with two leaders  President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela and President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran  blaming the weakness of the United States dollar for high oil prices.

title: Owens Has Hands All Over Dallass Win
description: IRVING, Tex., Nov. 18  Only a prayer remained in the playbook for the Washington Redskins, who appeared ready to knock the Dallas Cowboys off the razor wire they had been straddling at times this season.

title: Stevie Wonder and Friends, Here and Gone
description: Stevie Wonder has asked some unanswerable questions in his songs, but he deals mostly in optimistic certainty; the ideas of eternity and unconditional love dont vex him.

title: Two More Injuries Could Be Costly for Giants
description: DETROIT, Nov. 18  The Giants took a big step toward a possible playoff berth Sunday, but they have still not managed to shake the injury bug that has dogged them this season.

title: Brooklyn: Driver Injured Fleeing Crash, Police Say
description: A man was seriously injured early yesterday after fleeing the scene of a car crash in Flatbush, the police said. Shortly after midnight, a police officer spotted a car that had jumped a curb and hit a light pole near the intersection of Avenue H and East 16th Street, the police said. The driver ran down an alley and jumped over a fence. He was seriously injured because the ground dropped about 20 feet on the other side of the fence, the police said. The driver, whose name was not released, was taken to Kings County Hospital Center, where he was in serious but stable condition yesterday evening, the police said. The crash was under investigation.

title: Bulletins From a Bustling Undiscovered Land
description: Its a little embarrassing to watch the New York art world discovering Latin American modernist art year after year, as if forever only half-aware of its existence. And its depressing to know that the Museum of Modern Art, which could have been collecting widely in the field for decades, had to wait for a windfall in the form of a gift collection to deal with this material in a serious and committed way. We are, after all, talking about the art of a continent and a century, not just a fad from yesterday.

title: Beowulf Destroys the Competition
description: Beowulf, the Old English epic poem being brought to gory, 3-D life through performance-capture technology (the film is neither live nor animated but somewhere in between) slew all rivals at the box office over the weekend. The film, Robert Zemeckiss latest effort, which stars Ray Winstone, above, in the title role battling the monster Grendel (Crispin Glover) and his vengeful mother (Angelina Jolie), took in $28.1 million in its first weekend, according to studio estimates. The film, with a screenplay by Neil Gaiman and Roger Avary, cost Paramount Pictures about $150 million to make and employs technology similar (though updated) to that used by Mr. Zemeckis in The Polar Express in 2004. More than 40 percent of the total receipts came from the 742 3-D theaters showing the film. DreamWorks Animations comedy Bee Movie, starring the voices of Jerry Seinfeld and Rene Zellweger, fell from first to second place with $14.3 million in its third weekend. The movies cumulative total to date is $93.9 million. Also dropping one spot, to No. 3, was American Gangster (Universal), the 1970s crime thriller starring Denzel Washington and Russell Crowe. That film, directed by Ridley Scott, took in $13.2 million in its third weekend, bringing the total haul so far to $101 million. Falling from third to fourth place was the Vince Vaughn comedy Fred Claus (Warner Brothers) with $12 million in its second weekend and a total of $35.8 million to date. And rounding out the Top 5 was the new Dustin Hoffman fantasy, Mr. Magoriums Wonder Emporium (20th Century Fox), earning $10 million in its opening weekend.

title: Italians Tune in to Real-Life Sopranos
description: ROME  Its said that the Mafia has a hold on Italy. Of late that has been especially true on Thursday nights, when millions of television viewers have tuned in to watch the biographical rise-and-fall saga of Salvatore (Tot) Riina, the murderous mob boss who once commanded organized crime in Sicily.

title: U.S. Pushes for Turnout at Middle East Conference
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18  By pushing Israel to accept immediate negotiations with the Palestinians on the thorny final status issues, with the aim to conclude a peace settlement within a year, the Bush administration is trying to attract a significant Arab presence at the peace conference in Annapolis, Md.

title: Navigating Two Worlds With a Compass of Lies
description: There are two genuinely honest characters in Roopa Farookis fizzy debut novel, Bitter Sweets. One is named Candida, the other Verity Trueman. While these monikers may sound heavy-handed, Ms. Farooki makes them genially absurd by putting them in context. Everyone else in this boisterous, multigenerational tale is a congenital liar.

title: Republicans and Race
description: Over the past few weeks there have been a number of commentaries about Ronald Reagans legacy, specifically about whether he exploited the white backlash against the civil rights movement.

title: New Twist in 1990 Murder Case as Star Witness Vanishes
description: This much is known about Thomas Morales. He is known as Spanky on the street, and also goes by the name Jimmy Rodriguez. He is about 5-foot-8 and in his 40s, thin, wears an earring in his left ear and a mustache.

title: Police Kill a Man Armed With a Broken Bottle
description: A blood-streaked, shirtless man wanted for stabbing a roommate was killed in a hail of gunfire by two police officers on a Brooklyn street yesterday when, the police said, he brandished a broken wine bottle, advanced on them as they backed away, ignored their orders to drop it and finally lunged at them.

title: Around Baghdad, Signs of Normal Life Creep Back
description: With security in Baghdad improving, residents across the city are taking steps to return to normalcy.

title: Farmers Feed City's Hungry
description: The Times's Patrick McGeehan meets a farmer in Orange County, N.Y., who is working with City Harvest to provide produce to New York's hungry.

title: Week 11 Talking Points
description: 1. The Patriots are back in action and back to their old tricks, reasserting their power in the A.F.C. on a day when the Steelers lost to the Jets and the Colts looked shaky for the second week in a row. A lot seems to have happened since Week 9, but is it all back to where it started, with the Patriots light years ahead?

title: Kramnik Dominates
With Not a Joke Written, Jimmy Kimmel Hosts Music Awards
description: More than 13 minutes into ABCs live broadcast of the American Music Awards last night, after musical numbers by Fergie, will.i.am and Nicole Scherzinger, the host finally made his appearance and opened with the lines: Im Jimmy Kimmel and this is my fourth time hosting the show and, uh, my first time hosting it drunk. So Im very excited to be here. Presumably it was an ad-lib: Mr. Kimmel went on to explain that as a member of the Writers Guild he was on strike  in my heart, at least  and couldnt write any jokes.

title: Mexico's Child Bullfighters
description: Child bullfighting has become popular in Mexico, where there are no age limits for matadors. (This video contains footage that may be disturbing.)

title: The Unofficial Halftime Show
description: At Jets games, women have been the targets of harassment by groups of taunting male fans. Security guards have allowed the behavior to continue unchecked.

title: Live (but Off-Air), Its Saturday Night!
description: With the writers strike keeping Saturday Night Live off the air, the cast performed the show at a Chelsea improv theater before a small audience. Read more

title: Office Rhythm
description: How to pace yourself during the workday:

title: Revisiting Malones Playbook
description: The last time media baron John Malone had an integrated media company, Tele-Communications, he sold it to a predecessor of AT&T for $48 billion in 1999.

title: Judge Approves Delphi Loans, but Admonishes Investor Group
description: Delphi, the bankrupt auto parts maker, notched a victory Friday when a New York judge approved a fee and engagement letter regarding a $6.8 billion exit loan for the company.

title: Swiss Life Unloads Units for $1.54 Billion
description: Swiss Life Holding, Switzerlands largest life insurer, agreed to sell its Dutch and Belgian units for as much as 1.54 billion euros ($2.3 billion) and said it would use the proceeds to buy back shares.

title: Chinese Interest Propels Standard Chartereds Shares Up
description: Standard Chartered shares jumped in London on Monday morning following a report that a group of Chinese banks may be gearing up to invest in the firm.

title: Celgene Coughs Up $2.9 Billion to Acquire Pharmion
description: The biotechnology company Celgene said Sunday that it would pay $2.9 billion in cash and stock to acquire Pharmion, strengthening Celgenes cancer drug portfolio and its distribution in Europe.

title: Financials, Once a Balm, Now Hamper the Market
