description: As the air came out of the technology and telecommunications bubble this decade, the stock market found a new champion in the financial sector.

title: Goldman Rakes in Profit in Credit Crisis
description: For more than three months, as turmoil in the credit market has swept wildly through Wall Street, one mighty investment bank after another has been brought to its knees, leveled by multibillion-dollar blows to their bottom lines.

title: Is a Brokerage Float the Answer for Citi and Merrill?
description: As John A. Thain prepares to take the helm at Merrill Lynch and Citigroup continues its search for a new captain, rumors are surfacing that the two banks may soon consider floating minority stakes in their brokerage arms.

title: Raps Rhyme Deficit  Now Theres Less of It
description: Hmmm, euro rhymes with  ? The London Independent reports on the greenbacks fall from fashion in hip-hop:

title: Pearl to Buy Resolution in British Insurance Merger
description: Pearl Assurance, the British closed-life fund manager, on Friday agreed to acquire a rival, Resolution, for 4.98 billion pounds ($10.21 billion), after a competing bid from a traditional insurer, Standard Life, collapsed the previous weekend.

title: Zosano Pharma Swallows $90 Million
description: Zosano Pharma closed on the final tranche of a $90 million Series A funding that will enable the company to complete Phase 2 clinical trials of a lead drug candidate to treat osteoporosis and advance preclinical development of other drugs using the companys proprietary drug delivery patch technology.

title: SABMiller Taps Grolsch in $1.2 Billion Deal
description: SABMiller, the worlds second-biggest brewer, has agreed to buy a Dutch rival, Grolsch, for 816 million euros ($1.2 billion) to strengthen its position in the fast-growing premium beer market.

title: M2E Power Recharges With $8 Million
description: M2E Power on Friday said it landed $8 million in funding for its charging technology activated by motion that could be used to recharge MP3 players, electric vehicles, or the night vision goggles of soldiers.

title: Wattle It Be?
description: Calling all witty caption writers: Tell us whats going on in the photo above. Its the latest of the uncaptioned photos weve been posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines here. Last weeks funniest captions are at right.

title: At Bonus Time, Keeping Up With the Goldmans
description: Shareholders in the securities industry are having their worst year since 2002, losing $74 billion of their equity. That wont prevent Wall Street from paying record bonuses, totaling almost $38 billion, according to Bloomberg News.

title: Northern Rock Plummets on Lowball Bids
description: The stricken British lender Northern Rock warned investors on Monday that the takeover proposals it has received so far are materially below the market price at the close of business on Friday.

title: Investors Said to Leave Carlyle Hedge Fund
description: The private equity giant Carlyle Group is facing challenges with its first hedge fund, Carlyle-Blue Wave Management Partners, a $700 million fund built as part of a diversification strategy, according to Reuters.

title: Does Private Equity Have a Pulse?
description: When will private equity deals, which all but stopped on a dime this summer when the credit crisis emerged, get back on track?

title: Buyout Lender Taps Public Markets in Search of Fresh Capital
description: a leveraged buyout lender, American Capital Strategies priced a $157 million share offering to raise more capital, as credit remains scarce and overall private equity mergers plummeted 72 percent in the third quarter.

title: Private Equity M&A May Have Peaked, Report Says
description: Mergers and acquisitions by private equity firms might have peaked, according to an investment bank report. The number of deals is falling and sovereign wealth funds will fill up the breach, according to Brian OReilly, director and global equities strategist at UBS wealth management.

title: Spains Bankinter Sells $1.18 Billion Stake to Credit Agricole
description: Spains Bankinter said Monday it had agreed to sell a 20 percent stake to Frances Credit Agricole for 809 million euros ($1.18 billion).

title: When Foreign Governments Buy American
description: Funds owned by foreign governments have been buying up United States assets, as shown by last weeks investment by Abu Dhabi in the chip maker Advanced Micro Devices.

title: Thains $50 Million Clean-Up Job
description: Call him Wall Streets richest mop-up man, at least for now.

title: Abu Dhabi Fund Seeks to Invest in Emerging Markets
description: The $650 billion Abu Dhabi Investment Authority is seeking to invest more in emerging markets to get higher returns than from its assets in Europe and the United States, a senior HSBC executive said on Sunday.

title: DreamWorks Is Said to Hold Talks With NBC Universal
description: Seeking a way out of an acrimonious relationship at Paramount, the DreamWorks principals  two Hollywood heavyweights, David Geffen and Steven Spielberg  have been negotiating to move their operation to NBC Universal, The New York Times reported on Saturday, citing unnamed people close to the talks. But negotiations have hit a wall over financing.

title: Univision Music Bidders Said to Cut Offers
description: Potential bidders for the music assets of the Spanish-language broadcaster Univision Communications are reportedly shaving their offer prices by at least $50 million becasue of concerns over its artist contracts and access to advertising on the television network.

title: To Some, New Media Proposal Is Same Old Song
description: The last time federal regulators tried to change the rules on how many media outlets companies could own, the effort bombed like a bad movie. According to The Los Angeles Times, the sequel appears to be headed for the same fate.

title: Bill Belichick: Have You No Decency, Sir?
description: Is Bill Belichick paying his opponents the ultimate compliment? Thats one way to look at it. He respects that they wont give up, he respects the game and he respects the games history.

title: When Buyout Firms Arent the Smart Money
description: In his weekly DealBook column, Andrew Ross Sorkin calls for a moratorium on what he regards as the recent bullying tactics by the buyout shops eager to cut and run from some of the lousy deals they made prior to the credit squeeze.

title: My Pet Peeves About Informational Interviews
description: In reading through the comments on this blog, I stumbled onto this smart blog post by Steve C. Wilson about how to think about and conduct informational interviews. Im a fan of informational interviews, and as Mr. correctly points out, they can be very handy not only when youre searching for a job but at other moments in your career, like when youre searching for a mentor.

title: The Early Word: McCain Stresses National Security
description: Set to receive an endorsement from former New Jersey Gov. Tom Kean (who also was the co-chairman of the 9/11 Commission) today, Senator John McCain has continued to push his national security credentials as de defines contrasts with the leading Democratic candidate, Senator Hillary Clinton.

title: Obama: Takes Terrorism Deadly Serious
description: GRUNDY CENTER, Iowa  It was the final question last night at a town meeting here for Senator Barack Obama. Of all the hands that were raised in the air, he called on a woman seated in the middle of the crowd.

title: Quanex to Split in Two, as One Unit Merges with Gerdau
description: Quanex, a maker of components for vehicular- and building-products makers, said on Monday that it would spin off its building products unit as a separate company and merge the remaining vehicular-products business with Gerdau in a deal the company said would value it at $1.67 billion including debt.

title: Another Fatal Police Shooting in Brooklyn
description: One of the top stories today is about a fatal police shooting of a mentally ill man in Brooklyn.

title: Republican Repression
description: The New Yorkers George Packer, in a Talk of the Town column, says the dirty secret of the Republican presidential campaign is that, despite the bellicose rhetoric all of the candidates use, some of the candidates have responsible views and serious proposals. Packer explains:

title: Some Get Clearer Signals on Potential EchoStar Deal
description: Though EchoStar Communications stock dipped last week, or perhaps because of it, speculation over a deal with AT&T has risen yet again.

title: McCains Speech in New Hampshire
description: Following is a transcript of Senator John McCains speech at Franklin Pierce University in Rindge, N.H., Sunday night:

title: Monday Morning Motorsports
description: Nascar: Jimmie Johnson has gone back to back. Johnson finished seventh at Homestead-Miami Speedway, which was enough to secure his second straight Nextel Cup title. He dominated the season like no driver has since Jeff Gordon won 13 races in 1998. This year, in a more competitive field, Johnson won 10, including four straight heading into the finale at Homestead, where he played it safe.

title: McCain, Giuliani Vie for 9/11 Brand
description: NASHUA, N.H.  It is shaping up to be a bit of a rough day for the Giuliani 9/11 brand today.

title: Doubts on Bushs Plan to Ease Holiday Travel
description: By this stage of his presidency, George W. Bush must be accustomed to more than a little criticism. But when he took to the lectern on Thursday, his goal seemed to be delivering some honest-to-God good news that everyone could agree on.

title: Trying Times for Citis New Risk Czar
description: The first day in a new job is always a bit stressful. But consider the pressure cooker that Jorge A. Bermudez walked into Monday, as he took over as the chief risk officer for Citigroup, the troubled banking giant.

title: Monday Morning Kickoff
description: It appears you need to lock up the linen when Ole Miss comes to town. David Brandt of the Clarion Ledger reports that 20 Mississippi players have been put on probation for twice stealing pillows and radios from team hotels.

title: The Skim
description: A quick hike through the Sunday (and a few non-Sunday) book review sections.

title: Estimating the Broadway Strikes Economic Cost
description: With the breakdown of talks between the stagehands union and the producers league, the Broadway theater strike is now in its 10th day, with no end in sight. The week of Thanksgiving is a crucial one for the citys retail, entertainment, hospitality and tourism industries, and already, experts are estimating that the total economic loss for the city is in the tens of millions of dollars.

title: United Rentals Sues Cerberus Over Failed Deal
description: Another collapsed buyout has hit a courts docket.

title: High Noon for the Carbon Offset Cowboys?
description: Paying people to cut carbon emissions so that others can continue flying and driving (or using the tumble dryer) has become immensely fashionable.

title: Bronx Zoo Spot
description: A colorful campaign aimed at parents and children is playing up attractions owned and operated by the Wildlife Conservation Society.

title: A Doctors Disdain for Medical Googlers
description: Can a patient ever show up at the doctors office with too much information?

title: Seconds To Shoot
description: Photos from the first moments of the Stevie Wonder show at Madison Square Garden.

title: Obama and the activists
description: OK, I try not to write horserace, how-well-is-the-campaign-being-run stuff. But this looks to me like part of a pattern, following Obamas invocation of a Social Security crisis:

title: Is Manhattan Turning Against Congestion Pricing?
description: Support for congestion pricing is falling  even among Manhattan voters, who among all city residents have been the staunchest supporters of the proposed traffic fees  according to a Quinnipiac University poll released this morning. The poll also found that Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kellys popularity has slipped after the fatal police shooting of a mentally disturbed Brooklyn teenager on Nov. 12.

title: Strike News: Writers Gain P.R. Advantage
description: As the writers strike enters its third week, the studios are fretting about their public images.

title: Is the Media Blob Pass?
description: Viacom has tried it. So has Time Warner. E.W. Scripps and Belo are getting in on the trend.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. Messages on news coverage can be e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left toll-free at 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397). Comments on editorials may be e-mailed to letters@nytimes.com or faxed to (212) 556-3622.

title: McCains Rocky Relationship With the Hawkeye State
description: In todays Web column, Adam Nagourney writes that John McCain has long seemed at once troubled and a bit mystified by his difficulty winning over Iowans, particularly compared with New Hampshire.

title: How to Save a Life?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Road Stories
description: The best-ever book on tape, Ive claimed in print, is Amanda Plummers reading of Joyce Carol Oatess Black Water, a slim 1992 novel based loosely on Chappaquiddick. In Plummers telling, the story is pointillistic, onrushing and spooky; it casts the kind of spell that lets 300 miles roll under your wheels before youve had the chance to notice your coffees gone cold.

title: Bangladesh Cyclone Toll Exceeds 3,000
description: The United Nations estimated that a million people had been left homeless by the cyclone.

title: From King of All Spaniards to King of the Web
description: One of the many grand assertions of King Juan Carlos of Spains official biography  that he pays constant attention to intellectual developments and innovation  seems to at least suggest that hes kept abreast of the situation on the Internet as it marches on at its baffling pace.

title: Amazon Pitches a Wireless iPod for Books
description: Amazon.com introduced its electronic book reader today at a packed event in New York. Unlike other products in this area, Amazons $399 Kindle is designed to be used without ever connecting to a computer. Instead it has a wireless Internet connection that lets users browse Amazons online store on the device and download a book in less than a minute.

title: Gawking at the Kindle
description: Is this thing a game-changer?

title: Clinton and Clark Campaign in Iowa
description: DES MOINES  File this under the Department of Getting Ahead of Ourselves: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is campaigning in Iowa this morning with a political ally, Gen. Wesley K. Clark (ret.), and on first blush its pretty easy to see a future political ticket there.

title: Country Music and Political Connections
Thank You, Chuck Norris
description: Just when Mike Huckabee was starting to be taken seriously, he brought back Chuck Norris.

title: The Surprises Keep Coming
description: It was less than two weeks ago that Swiss Re reported third-quarter earnings, and gave reassuring statistics about its exposure to subprime paper.

title: The Many Roads to Happiness
description: Happiness seems to be one of those squishy, hard-to-pin-down states of mind that you cant really aim for  you just know it when you get there.

title: All Pumped Up for Baseballs Next Act
description: Steroids: Theyre the cloud hanging over Americas pastime  one that never quite turns into a rain delay since everyones making so much money from them. Barry Bonds indictment last week for lying arrives just before the Mitchell report, the inquiry commissioned by baseball that is expected to name Names. Timed for the winter meetings, the Mitchell report is meant to allow owners to cut salaries of named players. to restore the sports credibility. To guide you through this complex scandal, heres help with some frequently asked questions:

title: Holiday Business in Bryant Park, Once Cold as Ice, Heats Up
description: Over the last five years, the holiday market at Bryant Park has been transformed from being a static and tepid street fair to a bustling showcase of plexiglass booths with $5 million to $6 million in total retail sales for its vendors. But in the early days, the market struggled to fill up the slots with mass mailings, recruiting at street fairs, and persuading skeptical retailers to open a second location in Bryant Park for the holidays.This year, the market, which opened on Saturday and will run for six weeks, had 300 applications for the 100 or so booths, which cost from $9,000 to $40,000 to rent. Vendors  which generally sell high-end crafts, jewelry and clothing  now do an average of $60,000 to $70,000 in sales, with a handful breaking $100,000. The top vendor clears $300,000 in merchandise during the period.

title: Strike News: NBC to Press, No Tour For You!
description: NBC isnt attending Januarys Television Critics Association press tour because of the writers strike, and the other broadcast networks say they are still deciding whether to attend.

title: Food for Thought
description: Are food banks counterproductive? Writing in The Washington Posts Sunday Outlook section, Mark Winne, who founded a food bank in Hartford, Conn., says Americans need to rethink our devotion to food donation. Winne says one of the most lasting effects of emergency food programs has been to sidetrack efforts to eradicate hunger and its root cause, poverty. Later in the article, Winne explains:

title: Dubai Feels Sting as Och-Ziff Slides
description: Funds from overseas have been eagerly acquiring stakes in United States-based private equity firms and hedge funds, with mixed results so far. The Chinese governments $3 billion investment in the Blackstone Group has been a money loser. On Monday, Dubais big bet on Och-Ziff Capital Management offered another cautionary tale.

title: Talking Replacements at Michigan
description: Michigan Athletic Director Bill Martin shed some light on the process of replacing Lloyd Carr as Michigans coach. He said he will not hire a search firm and he has already whittled a list of 30 candidates down to 20. He said that a large buyout would likely not turn him off of a candidate. He said hes also not averse to waiting a few weeks, as the decision is of a magnitude that its going to reverberate for years.

title: Benchmarks: Passed the Difficult Stage in Baghdad?
description: Update, 10:41 p.m. Just published on NYTimes.com: Baghdad Starts to Exhale as Security Improves ***

title: Thinking about the dollar
description: I have to do some teaching on the subject of the falling dollar and whether its recessionary. So herewith some ruminations. WARNING: FAIRLY WONKISH.

title: MTV Sans Frontires
description: Hey, whats that little icon you click to signify that you want to watch MTV Arabia in English? A polar bear? And theres a palm-tree-desert-island that gets you Arabic. As a wintry Anglophone, I guess Im clicking the bear, but Im not thrilled about it.

title: A Real Question About Global Warming
description: KNOXVILLE, Iowa  Hillary Rodham Clinton just wrapped up a speech on the economy  much more on that soon  but there was one moment in the Q & A that is worth highlighting quickly.

title: What Are These Bands Trying to Say?
description: Interpretations of promotional photos.

title: In One Fell Swoop, Jay-Z Impresses Critics, Fans, the U.N. and Wall Street
description: The accolades Jay-Z have recently poured forth from all sectors. His new album was critically acclaimed and sold more than any other last week, which tied him with Elvis at 10 chart-topping albums.

title: Enough About Kindle 1.0. What About Kindle 2.0?
description: As Saul Hansell described below, Amazon is trying to awaken the slumbering electronic-book business with the Kindle, its long-awaited e-book reader and online service, which we first wrote about in September. Remarkably, this is the first physical product from the Seattle-based Internet retailer, and a major commitment by its chief executive, Jeff Bezos, to forging the future of books.

title: Clinton and Obama Spar Over the Economy
description: KNOXVILLE, Iowa  Underscoring the fierce competition to win the Iowa presidential caucuses in January, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton this morning intensified her critique of a leading Democratic rival, Barack Obama, suggesting that he lacked her ability and experience to manage the economy.

title: The Gift of Potties, the Latest in a Quest for Public Toilets
description: The Charmin public toilets are back. Charmin said the 20 temporary potties  part toilet paper promotion and part public service  were used more than 500,000 times last year.

title: Sooners Road Woes
description: Oklahomas loss Saturday night to Texas Tech, which was unranked, further illustrates the Sooners recent road woes under the ninth-year coach Bob Stoops.

title: Youve Got to Have Friends
description: When I was reading over the Q and A that Jimmy Bradley completed for this blog, I noticed what seemed to be an acknowledgment of a close friendship with Jonathan Waxman, and I found myself curious about the relationships between chefs in this city. Who hangs out with whom? Are there small, tightly knit groups of chefs who spend enough time together to constitute culino-social posses?

title: Mark Your Calendars!
description: Yes, there are more debates in your future. The Commission on Presidential Debates has announced the debate dates and sites for next years general election:

title: Ratings: Sunday Means Cartoons (and 60 Minutes)
description: Foxs animated comedy line-up ranked No. 1 in the ratings on Sunday in the much sought-after demographic of adults 18 to 49, as The Simpsons and Family Guy earned the nights top ratings in that age group. Both shows fared more modestly in terms of total viewers. The Simpsons drew 10.6 million viewers at 8 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates, while Family Guy garnered 10.5 million at 9.

title: Pier D Stands Out in the West Sides Industrial Past
description: It isnt your conventional luxury amenity.

title: Avoiding Hospital Gridlock
description: Faut Sarieminli, 41, is a hospital transporter at Long Island College Hospital, acting as a combination of hospital bellhop and parking attendant.

title: These Wonderful Warriors
description: The United States reaped a new crop of green card soldiers this month.

title: Its the End of the World, and They Built It
description: Last week, pictures of a scale model of an apocalyptic Manhattan caught the attention of City Room, mainly because they were not scenes from either of the forth-coming Hollywood films that destroy New York but also because something about the apartment used for the giant model seemed vaguely European. (Look closely at the radiators.)Well, as it turns out, the project is the creation of group of Swedish artists and set designers and the apartment is in Skelleftea, Sweden. One of the artists, Magnus Johannson, first posted images of Apocalyptic Manhattan (in an Apartment) on a game-designing forum in October.

title: Atlas Provides Jets With Premonition
description: Teddy Atlas holds an interesting title in the Jets media guide  special assistant, boxing. But the famed boxing trainer might want to add the title of team prophet to his business card after the voicemail he left for Coach Eric Mangini before the team stunned the Steelers on Sunday.

title: Ex-Principal of Arabic School Sues City
description: Debbie Almontaser, the founding principal of the citys first Arabic-language school, filed a federal lawsuit today [pdf] against the citys Education Department, Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, charging that they violated her right to free speech and conspired to deny her the opportunity to regain her position as principal of the school, the Khalil Gibran International Academy.

title: McCains 9/11 Endorsement
description: BOSTON  Despite the best attempts by a large contingent of local and national media gathered at Logan Airport here, former New Jersey Gov. Thomas Kean, co-chairman of the 9/11 commission, declined today to criticize Rudy Giuliani directly. But the mere fact that he officially endorsed Senator John McCain was criticism enough.

title: An Avocado a Day
description: What we are reading elsewhere

title: Beaujolais Nouveau Thats Worth a Try
description: Last Thursday was Nov. 15, which, as assiduous students of mass marketing know, is the day that the Beaujolais nouveau can legally be sold. Despite the slogan  le Beaujolais nouveau est arriv  it usually arrives days before and sits until the 15th.

title: Whacking Those Moles
description: Building a custom house is like playing Whac-A-Mole, the arcade game. As fast as we tackle one problem, another appears, so it feels like were not making much progress.

title: Hearing Planned on Gang Insignia on Clothing
description: Updated, Nov. 21 | Are apparel manufacturers and retailers deliberately selling sports-themed clothes with gang colors and symbols?

title: An Accidental Beneficiary of Warfare: Wildlife
description: [UPDATE, 4/5: Carl Zimmer passes along news about a deadly virus spreading through bonobos. Anyone know more?]

title: Ferrari Promises CO2 Reduction in Future Models
description: This just came in through the wires: Ferrari is setting a goal to produce cars that are 40 percent more fuel efficient by 2012:

title: Strike News: An Ending, Not End, For Heroes
description: The writers strike appears to have prompted NBC to promote the last original episode of Heroes as a mid-season finale.

title: Strike News: CBS News Staffers Authorize Action
description: Several hundred CBS News staffers represented by the Writers Guild of America have voted to authorize a strike against the company, union officials said Monday.

title: Bloggingheads: Killing Fields
description:
From Cambodia, Megan McArdle of The Atlantic assesses the legacy of Khmer Rouge rule.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: R6s Rosenberg Jumps to Eton Park
description: From DealBook colleague Jenny Anderson:

title: AT&T Actor Ad
description: AT&T commercial where city names are "mashed up" to create amalgams.

title: AT&T Businessman Ad
description: AT&T commercial where city names are "mashed up" to create amalgams.

title: The Top of The Times
description: Nick Bilton climbs the mast at the top of The New York Times building.

title: Ahead of Schedule on Punta Mita
description: On Punta Mita, the peninsula north of Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, developers are seeing little indication of a slowdown in the American market.

title: Re-enter Sandman: Mariano Rivera Returns to the Yanks
description: A friend of mine sent me a postcard from the Hall of Fame the other day. On the front was the plaque of Kirby Puckett. Delightful in its simplicity, it lists just one team under his name: Minnesota, A.L., 1984-1995.

title: I Am Not a Bridge
description: The town where I grew up was small and less than an hours drive from Dallas. Miles of farming land surrounded this small pocket of humanity. The population consisted of mostly white residents with a minority of African- and Latino-American residents and me. It was the 1970s  the Age of Aquarius, disco and human rights awareness  but the population was still split into black and white. The war in Vietnam had come to an end and America was still counting its losses. It was in this setting that I grew up loved and protected.

title: Monday Injury Roundup
description: UPDATED

title: The 'Surge' in Baghdad
description: Iraq may feel safer since the "surge" in U.S. troops, but for two Baghdad women recovery remains limited.

title: Attention Paid, and Paying Off
description: Some voters outside the early voting states have been grumbling lately about all the attention being paid to the people of Iowa and New Hampshire. But voters in those two states seem to be taking their civic duty seriously.

title: Patterns: Children With Hearing Loss Spend More Time in E.R.
description: Children who have hearing problems are much more likely than other children to end up in an emergency room with a wide variety of injuries, researchers say.

title: A Most Valuable Performance
description: We salute the great Alex Rodriguez today not only for his third American League Most Valuable Player award, but for his powerbrokers enlistment of a virtual league of American business savants in pursuit of the capitalist dream with a self-serving spin:

title: Pakistans Court Dismisses Election Cases
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 19  Pakistans Supreme Court, filled with supporters of the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, after he imposed emergency rule on Nov. 3, dismissed on Monday the main challenges to his re-election, all but ensuring his confirmation to another term by the court this week.

title: For His 50th Birthday, a Test of Virtuosic Mettle
description: To celebrate his 50th birthday  and also to benefit a scholarship fund at Ben Gurion University of the Negev, in Israel  the violinist Shlomo Mintz played Paganinis caprices, all 24, at Carnegie Hall on Sunday evening.

title: Companies Bolster Sales Abroad to Offset Weakness at Home
description: SALISBURY, N.C., Nov. 16  If the fortunes of the Power Curbers company were tied solely to business in the United States, these would be grim days at its factory on the fringes of this Piedmont town. The small, family-owned company makes machines that turn concrete into curbs, and with the American construction industry in distress, domestic sales are expected to drop at least 10 percent this year.

title: Choreographic Challenge: Another Dive Into the Enduring Mystery of Rite of Spring
description: Once upon a time (1913), in a magical kingdom far, far away (Paris), two kings (Stravinsky and Nijinsky) shocked the world with a grand collaboration (The Rite of Spring).

title: Ant Power
description: Q. Where does that famous ant that can lift something like 20 times its weight get its power? Is it muscle fibers or some sort of hydraulic fluid?

title: Kidman in Court
description: Nicole Kidman told a jury in Sydney, Australia, that she had been reduced to tears and feared a car accident as she was chased by a celebrity photographer two years ago, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Ms. Kidman was testifying in the photographers defamation suit against a Sydney newspaper that said he had hounded her. She said that a trip in a chauffeured car in 2005 turned into a dangerous chase as she was pursued by Jamie Fawcett, who is suing The Sun-Herald newspaper for defamation over an article that said he was Sydneys most disliked freelance photographer and was determined to wreak havoc on Ms. Kidmans private life. A jury previously found that the article defamed Mr. Fawcett; the current hearing is to decide whether the newspapers publisher, Fairfax Media, should pay the photographer damages, and how much.

title: Bringing Chaos to This Part of Universe
description: When Nergal, the leader of the long-running Polish metal band Behemoth, starts a concert by growling, Get ready for chaos, hes not kidding.

title: Judge Orders 17-Year-Olds Cases Moved to Family Court
description: BOSTON, Nov. 19  A judge in Rhode Island has ruled that some of the 400 or so 17-year-olds charged with misdemeanors in the four months this year when a change in law treated 17-year-olds as adults in the criminal justice system should have their cases moved to Family Court.

title: Raising Children Behind Bars
description: The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 created a far-sighted partnership between the federal government and the states that agreed to remake often barbaric juvenile justice systems in exchange for federal aid. Unfortunately, those gains have been steadily rolled back since the 1990s when states began sending ever larger numbers of juveniles to adult jails  where they face a high risk of being battered, raped or pushed to suicide. The act is due to be reauthorized this year, and Congress needs to use that opportunity to reverse this destructive trend.

title: A Bit of Broadway, but Dramas Mostly Offstage
description: If you go to one of the eight Broadway shows still running, youll find tiny strike-related differences. Some are just sad: When cast members make their semi-annual, post-curtain-call plea for contributions to Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS, you realize how severely that charity must be hit since 27 other shows are not collecting donations. Other differences come with silver linings: It is so easy to find a free taxi sailing up Eighth Avenue or down Broadway at 10:15 p.m.

title: Beat-Up vs. Unbeaten: McNabb May Face Patriots
description: The Philadelphia Eagles got some good news yesterday: quarterback Donovan McNabb does not have a high ankle sprain, just a regular one that may not even keep him out of Sundays game.

title: F.A.A. Oversees Aerial Ballet and Foot Shuffling
description: HERNDON, Va., Nov. 21  The Federal Aviation Administrations Strategic Command Center here got started early on Wednesday, with the first conference call with the airlines at 5:15 a.m. instead of the usual 7:15, a head start usually used only when there is a prediction of snowstorms or thunderstorms.

title: For Want of a Proofreader, or at Least a Good One, a Reading Exam Is Lost
description: In an episode that has embarrassed the Department of Education, thousands of flawed testing booklets forced the invalidation of United States reading scores on an international exam administered without major mishap in 56 other countries.

title: Parasite and Host in Constant Game of Catch-Up
description: In evolution, host and parasite can engage in a kind of arms race. One side adapts and evolves; the other side adapts and evolves to keep up. At the end of the day, neither side is necessarily better off than the other.

title: Equity Firm Is Sued Over Withdrawal From Deal
description: United Rentals, the rental equipment provider, sued the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management yesterday over its cancellation of a $4 billion buyout of the company.

title: A Swarm of Swindlers
description: Chicago

title: When Works Are Staged as Well as Played
description: Jo Kondo, an eminent Japanese composer, and Robert Wilson, the internationally renowned stage director, have both drawn on elements of traditional Japanese art in their work. You might have anticipated that their idioms would merge seamlessly in a collaboration presented on Sunday night at the Guggenheim Museum.

title: Cyclone Toll Exceeds 3,100 in Bangladesh
description: The number of people left dead after the powerful cyclone that swept through Bangladesh on Thursday rose to more than 3,100 yesterday, the government said. The United Nations estimated that a million people had been left homeless, many of them in remote areas without predictable food supplies.

title: New Worries About Credit Drive Down Stock Markets
description: Where will it end?

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Ex-Getty Curator Is Now on Trial in Greece

title: Cambodia Arrests Former Khmer Rouge Head of State
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Nov. 19  The former Khmer Rouge head of state Khieu Samphan, who was taken from a hospital here and arrested on Monday, is the last of five top figures targeted by prosecutors in advance of trials expected next year for the atrocities of the late 1970s.

title: Amway Adds Entertainment to Product Line
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 19  Amway, the door-to-door peddler of vitamins and soap, wants to reinvent how Hollywood sells entertainment.

title: Bees on the Big Screen (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Fox Toons Triumph
description: Foxs animated comedy lineup ranked No. 1 on Sunday among adults 18 to 49, as The Simpsons and Family Guy (with the guest star Wallace Shawn providing the voice of Stewies archrival, Bertram, below) earned the nights top ratings in that age group. The Simpsons drew 10.6 million total viewers at 8, and Family Guy 10.5 million at 9, Nielsen estimated. Foxs ratings for the night also benefited from an overrun of its afternoon football coverage, which meant more than 20 million viewers were tuned in to the network as prime time began at 7. NBC and ABC tied for second in the 18-to-49 set. NBCs Sunday Night Football match-up drew approximately 12.4 million viewers, while ABCs broadcast of the 2007 American Music Awards, from 8 to 11, averaged 11.8 million, the shows largest audience in three years. CBS ranked fourth in the 18-to-49 demographic but led the night in total viewers, thanks to 60 Minutes at 7 (14.6 million), The Amazing Race at 8 (12.5 million), Cold Case at 9 (13.9 million) and Shark at 10 (13 million).

title: Audit Finds Misuse of $34 Million Student Loan Subsidy
description: The student loan corporation in Pennsylvania improperly exploited a subsidy program to collect $34 million from the government, said a report released yesterday by the inspector general of the federal Education Department.

title: Footnotes
description: Natalie Merchant, who came to fame with 10,000 Maniacs in 1981, will play five or six shows  her first full concerts in four years  at Club Hiro in New York. The first is scheduled for Jan. 4. ... Cirque du Soleil said that it would create a show for the Kodak Theater, home of the Academy Awards, in Los Angeles. Under a 10-year agreement, a cast of 75 will present a show in the 3,400-seat theater 368 times a year. Guy Lalibert, the circuss founder, said the show would focus on Hollywoods place in movie history. ...The Vineyard Theater, at 108 East 15th Street in Manhattan, announced a two-week extension of Julia Chos play The Piano Teacher, starring Elizabeth Franz, about a retired piano teacher who reaches out to her former students to find out why they abruptly stopped taking piano lessons years before. The play, originally to have run through Dec. 9, will now run through December 23. ... The Kohar Symphony Orchestra and Choir from Armenia will play Carnegie Hall tonight as part of a North American tour, its first. Information: koharconcert.com or (323) 469-7356.

title: With Shows Now Dark, Visitors Improvise
description: You came to New York with dreams of Broadway theater. Now most of those productions remain dark, with no end in sight to the stagehands strike that has canceled performances of 27 shows, at least through Sunday. But if its live performance you want, hope springs eternal.

title: Suit on Apple Options Is Dismissed
description: Apple won dismissal yesterday of a lawsuit claiming that company directors and managers, including the chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, lied to shareholders about the backdating of option awards.

title: Pioneer Lodging Chain Aims to Get Its Consistency Back
description: IN the late 1950s, I had an aunt who was widely regarded as putting on airs, and who displayed in her guest bathroom a pair of those iconic Holiday Inn towels with the big green stripes.

title: Release Justices Secrets
description: MICHAEL MUKASEY has been confirmed as attorney general. But the profound moral, legal and constitutional issues raised at his Senate Judiciary Committee hearings are unresolved. Mr. Mukasey should open the door to their resolution by releasing the Justice Departments long-secret legal opinions that have warped our fight against terrorism.

title: U.S. Attorney in Minnesota Is Reassigned
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  The embattled United States attorney in Minnesota announced today that she would be stepping down to go work at the Justice Department in Washington on legal policy issues.

title: Helping Finance Documentarians
description: The Tribeca Film Institute and Gucci have joined to create the Gucci Tribeca Documentary Fund, which will offer financing and production guidance to help independent filmmakers complete documentaries that promote social change, focusing on issues neglected by the mainstream news media. The fund will provide grants totaling $80,000 to a minimum of three filmmakers in 2008 and will be administered by the Tribeca Film Institute. Recipients will be selected by the Tribeca Film Institute, along with Gucci and a selection committee of documentary filmmakers. All documentary filmmakers who have projects in production or postproduction may apply. Applications can be sent from Feb. 5 to April 11, 2008. Recipients will be announced next summer. Information: tribecafilmfestival.org.

title: Ate Too Much? Tight Pants May Be the Smallest Worry
description: This week marks the beginning of the gluttony season, the time when even the most health-conscious diner succumbs to the temptations of the holiday buffet.

title: Freddie Mac Posts a $2 Billion Loss
description: Turmoil in the housing sector continued to reverberate today across several parts of the industry, reinforcing the mood among investors that the downturn has not yet reached its bottom.

title: New Hampshire Sets Jan. 8 Primary
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21  The New Hampshire primary, a tradition-steeped event in American presidential politics, will be held on Tuesday, Jan. 8, the New Hampshire secretary of state, William M. Gardner, decreed this afternoon.

title: Fed Report Trims Economic Outlook
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  Policy makers at the Federal Reserve expect the economy to keep expanding over the next year, but they have lowered their forecasts and are much more uncertain about the outlook than just four months ago, the central bank reported today.

title: Switzerland: Insurer to Sell Units
description: Swiss Life Holding, Switzerlands largest life insurer, agreed to sell its Dutch and Belgian units for as much as 1.54 billion euros ($2.3 billion) and said it planned to use the proceeds to buy back shares. SNS Reaal, a Dutch financial services company, is buying the units, Swiss Life said. Swiss Life shares rose as much as 5.8 percent in Zurich trading after the insurer said proceeds from the sale would be used to buy back up to 2.5 billion francs ($2.2 billion) of shares over 18 months. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

title: The Family Redgrave, Together Onstage
description: The siblings Vanessa, Lynn and Corin Redgrave have joined the journalists, military officials, entertainers and academics participating in A Question of Impeachment, a series of evenings, presented by the Culture Project, exploring the case for the impeachment of President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney. The first event in the series took place yesterday at the Culture Project theater at 55 Mercer Street in SoHo. The Redgraves: Poems From Guantnamo, which will take place on Dec. 9 at 7:30 p.m., includes recitations from Guantnamo: The Detainees Speak (University of Iowa, 2007), a collection of poems written by detainees. Marc Falkoff, a lawyer for some of the detainees and the editor of the collection, will take part in the event. For information: cultureproject.org.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,861 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Speaking Up for the Stagehands
description: The man at the center of the breakdown in the talks between the Broadway producers league and the striking stagehands union had one thing he wanted to say before the first question in an interview yesterday: It is not about him.

title: Icahn Acquires More Shares of Blockbuster, Nudging His Stake to 16%
description: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn has raised his stake in the Class A shares of Blockbuster, the video rental chain, to 16 percent, from 15 percent.

title: Where Never Again Is Happening Now
description: With every news outlet and cause-oriented celebrity having discovered Darfur by now, the very word may activate your plug-ears/cover-eyes instinct. But On Our Watch, tonights Frontline on PBS, isnt just another report on that bloodstained region of Sudan. Its more like an indictment.

title: Congo Creates Massive Reserve to Protect Close Human Cousin
description: Congo has announced the establishment of a rain-forest preserve intended to shield the bonobo, one of human beings two closest ape relations, from wildlife poachers and deforestation.

title: From Queen to Academe
description: Brian May, the guitarist in the band Queen, has been appointed chancellor of Liverpool John Moores University, The Associated Press reported. Mr. May was an astrophysics student at the university before he joined Freddie Mercury and Roger Taylor to form Queen in 1970, and was awarded his doctorate in the field this year. Liverpool John Moores University has a well-known astrophysics research institute. Mr. May will be installed in the ceremonial chancellorship early next year. He succeeds Cherie Blair, wife of former Prime Minister Tony Blair.

title: Republican Congressman in New Jersey Will Retire
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  Representative Mike Ferguson of New Jersey, a Republican who narrowly won re-election last year and faced the prospect of another tough race in 2008, announced on Monday that he will retire, dealing an unexpected setback to national leaders of his party.

title: Holiday on Thursday: Thanksgiving Day
description: NEW YORK

title: In Thanksgiving Speech, Bush Urges Americans to Give Back
description: CHARLES CITY, Va., Nov. 19  In a reflective mood as he looks toward his final year in office, President Bush delivered his first official Thanksgiving speech Monday, urging Americans to show their thanks by giving back and to remember that our nations greatest strength is the decency and compassion of our people.

title: New Haven: Police Chief to Resign
description: The New Haven police chief, Francisco Ortiz, announced yesterday that he would resign in January to take a security post at Yale University. Chief Ortiz, left, 48, a member of the force for nearly three decades and chief since 2003, had faced calls for his resignation this year after an F.B.I. sting exposed corruption in the Police Departments narcotics division and gun violence spiked in the spring. The former chief of narcotics and two detectives pleaded guilty last month to federal charges, and an independent report released last week said the department needed an overhaul in order to regain the public trust. But the mayor, John DeStefano Jr., praised Chief Ortiz for helping to reduce crime by more than 40 percent over the last decade. The city has been made a much better place, Mr. DeStefano said.

title: City Bows to State on a School Improvement Plan
description: After months of negotiation, the City Department of Education capitulated to state education officials on how to spend millions of dollars in new state aid by agreeing to shift more money to reduce class sizes and to spend more on low-performing schools.

title: Disparities: With Cancer Treatment, an Edge for Rural Patients
description: It seems only natural to assume that when cancer strikes people who live in rural areas, more time will pass before it is discovered than for people in cities.

title: Sarkozy Takes Unfamiliar Stance on Strikes: Silence
description: PARIS, Nov. 19  President Nicolas Sarkozy has been called Frances Energizer bunny, a hyperactive head of state criticized for doing the jobs of his ministers, hogging the airwaves and refusing to rest or reflect.

title: On the Job, Everywhere
description: One challenge of the work-anywhere lifestyle is that not everywhere is designed for people who need to do work.

title: U.S. Prosecutors Subpoena Blackwater Employees
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  Federal prosecutors have issued grand jury subpoenas to some of the Blackwater employees present at a Sept. 16 shooting in Baghdad in which the companys security personnel killed 17 Iraqi civilians, lawyers in the case and government officials briefed on the matter said Monday.

title: City Claims Final Private Island in East River
description: South Brother Island, seven acres of dense forest, bittersweet vines, flocks of wild birds and little else, is a speck in the East River  and a glimpse of what the rest of the city might have looked like thousands of years ago.

title: Suicide Attack in Afghanistan Kills 7 but Spares Governor
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 19  A provincial governor in southwestern Afghanistan narrowly escaped a suicide attack on Monday, but his 25-year-old son and five of his bodyguards were killed in the blast. A civilian bystander was also killed, and 14 others were wounded, the police said.

title: Separatist Rebels Accuse Ethiopias Military of Killing Civilians in Remote Region
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 19  Separatist rebels fighting in the Ogaden region of Ethiopia accused the government on Monday of strafing nomads in recent days at a watering hole with helicopter gunships, killing up to a dozen civilians.

title: Georgia: Young Boys Charged With Rape
description: Three boys, one 8-year-old and two 9-year-olds, were charged with kidnapping, rape, false imprisonment and sexual assault after an 11-year-old girl accused them of attacking her in the woods behind the apartment complex where the children live. Capt. Wayne Dennard of the Acworth Police Department north of Atlanta said the girl told officers she was playing with the boys on Thursday when they lured her into the woods and raped her. The investigators who are working the case are confident that they have evidence to support the charges, Captain Dennard said. But the father of one of the accused third-grade boys told The Associated Press that what happened was consensual.

title: Clemens Finds Time to Shine During Jets Late Comebacks
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 19  As the seconds tick away in the fourth quarter and the Jets try to whittle another deficit, Kellen Clemens transforms from promising first-year starter into a green-and-white-clad Captain Comeback.

title: Manhattan: Suspect Sought in Drugstore Holdups
description: The police are seeking a man who has robbed six drugstores in Manhattan in the past two months. The man, described as slightly over 6 feet tall and wearing a hooded sweatshirt, seeks out the stores manager and starts a conversation before pulling a revolver and forcing the manager into an office, the police said. So far, the man has robbed three Duane Reade stores, a CVS, a Rite Aid and a Walgreens, the police said. The last holdup was on Nov. 15, at the Walgreens at 350 Fifth Avenue, the police said.

title: Ian Douglas Smith, Ex-Leader of Rhodesia, Dies
description: Ian Douglas Smith, the former prime minister of the rebellious British colony of Rhodesia, who rose to power and then slipped from it again, committed all the while to an unshakable belief that Africa without whites would not work, died today. He was 88.

title: Ear Pendants Reveal the Antiquity of Commerce in Jade
description: Jade has been prized for thousands of years, and has been traded for nearly as long. The extent of the trading has been demonstrated by Hsiao-Chun Hung of the Australian National University and colleagues in a study of jade ornaments from Southeast Asia.

title: Queens: Man Admits Strangling Wife
description: A Queens man pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court to the 2004 strangulation of his wife, whose body was found five days later in a car along with her 2-year-old daughter, prosecutors said. The man, Leonardo Almonte, 40, of 115th Avenue in Jamaica, is scheduled to be sentenced to 20 years in prison for manslaughter, Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, said in a statement. Prosecutors said Mr. Almonte, a bodega owner, strangled his wife, Cesarina Colon, 32, on Oct. 23, 2004, at the family home. He left her body, along with her daughter, in a vehicle he parked about a mile away, prosecutors said. A pedestrian who spotted the body called 911, and firefighters rescued the child, who was strapped into her car seat, prosecutors said.

title: Sometimes Con Men Wear Lab Coats
description: Curing cancer would be nice, to be sure, but does it really compare to the feeling of being published in The New England Journal of Medicine, winning a Nobel Prize or sleeping with your beautiful lab assistant?

title: Surprise Pressure From Myanmars Neighbors
description: SINGAPORE, Nov. 19  An emerging rift among Asian leaders over Myanmar burst into the open at a regional summit meeting on Monday when the Philippine president suggested that her country might not ratify a new regional charter unless Myanmar committed to democratic reforms and released the pro-democracy leader Aung San Suu Kyi.

title: The Garden May Be No Place Like Home
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Nov. 19  Stephon Marbury disappeared again Monday afternoon, not because of an aversion to his coach, but because of a much stronger impulse: to avoid television cameras, microphones and notepads.

title: Sect Leader Is Sentenced in Utah
description: ST. GEORGE, Utah, Nov. 20 The polygamous leader of a fundamentalist Mormon sect was sentenced Tuesday to 10 years to life in prison for forcing a 14-year-old girl to spiritually marry her 19-year-old cousin and commanding the nave bride to submit to sexual relations against her will.

title: Britain: A Diamond Year for the Crown
description: About 2,000 people, including more than 30 members of the royal family, attended a service at Westminster Abbey observing the 60th wedding anniversary of Queen Elizabeth II and her husband, Prince Philip. Dame Judi Dench read a poem, Diamond Wedding, by the poet laureate, Andrew Motion, and everyone sang The Lords My Shepherd, the hymn chosen by Elizabeth for her wedding. Afterward, the two greeted 10 couples who had married on the same day, Nov. 20, 1947.

title: Baghdads Weary Start to Exhale as Security Improves
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 19  Five months ago, Suhaila al-Aasan lived in an oxygen tank factory with her husband and two sons, convinced that they would never go back to their apartment in Dora, a middle-class neighborhood in southern Baghdad.

title: Amazon Reading Device Doesnt Need Computer
description: Jeff Bezos knows that the world is not exactly clamoring for another way to read electronic books.

title: Power to Soothe the Savage Breast and Animate the Hemispheres
description: In books like The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat and An Anthropologist on Mars, the physician Oliver Sacks has given us some compelling and deeply moving portraits of patients in predicaments so odd, so vexing, so metaphysically curious that they read like something out of a tale by Borges or Calvino.

title: Dick Wilson, Squeezer of Tissue Rolls on Television, Dies at 91
description: Dick Wilson, a British-born character actor who won American television fame as Mr. Whipple, the comically fussy star of two decades of Charmin toilet paper commercials, died on Monday at the Motion Picture & Television Fund Hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 91 and had lived at the organizations residence in Woodland Hills since 2002.

title: Panel Picks 4 Debate Sites, Angering Excluded New Orleans
description: The Commission on Presidential Debates has picked Oxford, Miss.; St. Louis; Nashville; and Hempstead, N.Y., as the sites of the presidential and vice-presidential debates in the general election campaign next year.

title: New Bribery Allegation Roils Samsung
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 19  Samsung, which has vigorously denied bribery charges in a snowballing corruption scandal, sustained another blow to its image on Monday when a former legal adviser to President Roh Moo-hyun said the company had once offered him a cash bribe.

title: In Iowa, Democrats Focus on Economy and Experience
description: KNOXVILLE, Iowa, Nov. 19  Gloomy news about the economy formed a backdrop for the leading Democratic presidential candidates Monday as they intensified their fight over which one had the best experience to lead the nation.

title: James Joseph Claffey Jr.
description: BORN: Jan. 24, 1964, in New York.

title: Halting Steps Taken to Frame Mideast Talks
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 19  Israeli and Palestinian leaders made new efforts on Monday toward preparing a joint statement before an international peace gathering planned for next week, but some issues have yet to be resolved, Israeli and Palestinian officials said.

title: Democrats and White House Continue Feud Over Money for Iraq War
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  House Democrats and the White House continued their public relations battle over money for the Iraq war today, as two leading lawmakers accused the administration of trying to scare people for political gain.

title: 43 in Contractors Convoy Held After Baghdad Shooting
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 19  The Iraqi military detained 43 people in a convoy for a contractor with the United States military on Monday after the shooting of an 18-year-old woman in central Baghdad, the military said.

title: Surge in Wages on Wall Street in First Quarter Helps Borough
description: On Wall Street, the first quarter of 2007 may wind up as one of those periods, like the height of the dot-com bubble in early 2000, that is remembered wistfully for years.

title: Swiss Re Takes $1 Billion Write-Down
description: LONDON, Nov. 19  Swiss Reinsurance, the worlds biggest reinsurer, said Monday that it had taken a $1.07 billion write-down on the value of some derivatives backed by mortgage securities.

title: Once Again, Islanders Handle the Rangers
description: For everything the Rangers have done right in climbing to the top of the Atlantic Division this season, they seem at a loss when they play the Islanders.

title: Webisodes of Lost: Model Deal for Writers?
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 19  On the picket lines, striking television and film writers adamantly claim that studios are refusing to pay for the use of writers scripts on the Internet.

title: Pay Me for My Content
description: INTERNET idealists like me have long had an easy answer for creative types  like the striking screenwriters in Hollywood  who feel threatened by the unremunerative nature of our new Eden: stop whining and figure out how to join the party!

title: To Resolve Strike, Mayor Prefers a Backstage Role
description: To some, the situation seems dire: most of Broadway staying dark as the bustling holiday season begins, restaurants losing customers at a critical money-making time and the striking stagehands trudging picket lines in the bitter cold.

title: A New Science, at First Blush
description: GRASSE, France  The delicate hybrids thriving in the balmy climes of Provence, southern Frances traditional perfume region, include sweet jasmine, May roses  and fresh layers of artificial human skin.

title: Japan: Olympus Plans to Expand
description: The Olympus Corporation, a maker of cameras and other optical products, agreed to buy the Gyrus Group of Britain, a maker of surgical tools, for about 935 million ($1.9 billion) to gain tools that allow quicker and less painful surgical procedures. Olympus bid 630 pence a share, a premium of 58 percent to Gyruss closing price Friday. The acquisition gives Olympus surgical devices that will help it expand in the United States, a market that accounted for about 80 percent of Gyruss 213 million in sales last year. Olympus is based in Tokyo. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

title: Are Scientists Playing God? It Depends on Your Religion
description: Now that biologists in Oregon have reported using cloning to produce a monkey embryo and extract stem cells, it looks more plausible than before that a human embryo will be cloned and that, some day, a cloned human will be born. But not necessarily on this side of the Pacific.

title: Options Narrowing as Britain Tries to Stabilize Bank
description: LONDON, Nov. 19  Northern Rock, the troubled regional mortgage lender, said on Monday that it had received a number of disappointing takeover proposals, increasing the pressure on the British government to either find a solution or consider nationalizing the bank.

title: Europe Warns Kosovo on Separation
description: European Union foreign ministers warned Kosovo against unilaterally declaring its independence, cautioning that such a move could spur the Serbian minority to ally with Belgrade and the Serb half of Bosnia and Herzegovina to push for statehood. The warning came after Hashim Thaci, whose party claimed victory in Saturdays parliamentary elections, said Kosovo would declare independence after a Dec. 10 deadline. Jean Asselborn, foreign minister of Luxembourg, warned: Theres a certain explosiveness in this region.

title: On Broadway, Growing Gloom About the Holidays
description: After strike talks between the Broadway producers league and the stagehands union unexpectedly broke down on Sunday night, the quick return to work that many had expected just hours earlier turned today into a gloomy prospect of absent paychecks and huge losses during the lucrative holiday season.

title: Ex-Getty Curator Is Now on Trial in Greece
description: A former antiquities curator for the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles went on trial yesterday in Athens on charges of conspiring to acquire an ancient gold funerary wreath that Greek officials say was illegally removed from Greek soil about 15 years ago. The former curator, Marion True, did not attend the hearing. Her lawyer, Yannis Yannides, submitted a motion for dismissal, citing a California state law that sets a three-year statute of limitations for prosecution once a stolen artifacts whereabouts have been made known. (The Getty acquired the wreath in 1993 and agreed to return it nearly a year ago, citing concerns about its provenance.) Greek investigators assert that the gold wreath was illegally excavated from an archaeological site in the northern province of Macedonia. Ms. True is also on trial in Italy on charges of trafficking in stolen antiquities acquired for the Getty. She has denied wrongdoing in both cases. In a related development The Associated Press reported that a judge in Pesaro, Italy, yesterday dismissed a local prosecutors legal claim to a bronze statue of a youth that is in the Gettys collection. (The statue has also been claimed by Italys national government.) After long negotiations, the museum agreed in August to return 40 other artifacts to Italy. Italy said it would consider whether to press its case on the bronze after the case in Pesaro was resolved.

title: For Children of Norway, a Rift With the Mother Country
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Around a table at Ingebretsens, an 86-year-old market stocked with Norwegian staples like lutefisk, meatballs and fruit soup, the women of the Monday knitting club were upset.

title: New DVDs
description: SUSAN HAYWARD

title: Vatican: Pope Lashes Out on Abortion
description: Pope Benedict XVI accused international agencies of promoting abortion in Africa and blamed disordered notions of marriage and the family for the spread of sexually transmitted diseases there. The globalized secular culture is exerting an increasing influence on local communities as a result of campaigns by agencies promoting abortion, he told a visiting group of bishops from Kenya. While Benedict did not single out particular agencies, the Vatican has in the past criticized the human rights group Amnesty International for backing a womans right to an abortion in the event of rape or if her life was in danger.

title: Mary Walker Phillips, 83, Knitter of Art, Is Dead
description: Mary Walker Phillips, a prominent textile artist who took the utilitarian craft of knitting and gave it bold new life as a modern art form to be displayed on the walls of museums around the world, died on Nov. 3 at her home in Fresno, Calif. She was 83. A longtime resident of Greenwich Village, Miss Phillips had lived Fresno in recent years.

title: As Somali Crisis Swells, Experts See a Void in Aid
description: AFGOOYE, Somalia, Nov. 19  The worst humanitarian crisis in Africa may not be unfolding in Darfur, but here, along a 20-mile strip of busted-up asphalt, several top United Nations officials said.

title: Even a Trump Can Trigger an Alarm
description: IVE been traveling my entire life. With parents like mine, Im sure thats no surprise. I was in Central Europe, the south of France and the Amalfi coast all before I was 6 years old.

title: The Lure of Togetherness ( 2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Starting a Small Business? A Retired Executive Wants to Help
description: The saying that nothing good in life is free may be true most of the time. But Martin R. Lehmans little office in Manhattan is one of the exceptions.

title: A New Condom for Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Exploring the Elements of (Human) Nature
description: Science tells stories that help us negotiate the world around us; the stories change with our needs. Euclid works for carpenters but not astrophysicists. The fact that one story  the theory of the four elements and their corresponding four temperaments in human life  endured for 2,000 years is a triumph of wishful thinking over cold evidence.

title: Denial Makes the World Go Round
description: For years she hid the credit card bills from her husband: The $2,500 embroidered coat from Neiman Marcus. The $900 beaded scarf from Blake in Chicago. A $600 pair of Dries van Noten boots. All beautiful items, and all perfectly affordable if she had been a hedge fund manager or a Google executive.

title: Vick Begins Serving Time Ahead of Sentencing
description: In an apparent attempt to speed his return to football, Michael Vick began serving time in prison yesterday, more than three weeks before he is scheduled to be sentenced after pleading guilty to federal dogfighting charges.

title: Many Treatments Can Ease Chronic Pain
description: There is one undeniable fact about chronic pain: More often than not, it is untreated or undertreated. In a survey last year by the American Pain Society, only 55 percent of all patients with noncancer-related pain and fewer than 40 percent with severe pain said their pain was under control.

title: Totals
description: Previously recorded $2,257,285.28

title: On Broadway, Growing Gloom About the Holidays
description: After strike talks between the Broadway producers league and the stagehands union unexpectedly broke down on Sunday night, the quick return to work that many had expected just hours earlier turned into a gloomy prospect of absent paychecks and huge losses during the lucrative holiday season.

title: Brooklyn: Action Filed Over School Admissions
description: A public-interest law firm in Washington filed a class-action lawsuit against the New York City Education Department yesterday, charging that a program created to increase the number of black and Hispanic students in the citys elite specialized high schools violates the Constitution by excluding whites and Asians. The law firm, the Center for Individual Rights, filed the suit in Federal District Court in Brooklyn on behalf of three Chinese-American parents whose children were denied admission to the Specialized High School Institute, which prepares students for the test determining admission to schools like Stuyvesant and the Bronx High School of Science. Andrew Jacob, a spokesman for the Education Department, said it was reviewing the programs eligibility criteria in light of a June decision by the Supreme Court that struck down two race-based school integration programs. Since the institutes creation more than a decade ago, the proportion of black and Hispanic students at the citys most elite high schools has actually decreased; last year, 2.2 percent of Stuyvesant students were black.

title: A Subway for 2nd Avenue (Really)
description: The Second Avenue Subway seems like the stuff of urban legend. City and state officials have been promising since the 1920s to build another line on Manhattans East Side to relieve overcrowding on the Lexington Avenue line. They have already presided over four groundbreakings. These promises look as if they could finally come true now that the federal government is adding $1.3 billion to the effort.

title: Morality and the Death Penalty
description: To the Editor:

title: A Health Systems Miracles Come With Hidden Costs
description: HAVANA, Nov. 16  A shiny new tour bus pulled up to the top eye hospital in Cuba on a sunny day this month and disgorged 47 working-class people from El Salvador, many of whom could barely see because they had thick cataracts in their eyes.

title: Imitation Hits the Marketing Business. Again.
description: THEY say that imitation is the sincerest form of advertising, and once again a skein of look-alike, sound-alike, seem-alike campaigns is raising eyebrows along Madison Avenue.

title: Allies Shun Berlusconis New Party
description: ROME, Nov. 19  With his customary brio, former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi is forming a new political party to propel him back to power, vowing Monday to go forward without his allies on the center-right, who are growing exhausted with him.

title: Through Genetics, Tapping a Trees Potential as a Source of Energy
description: It might be true that only God can make a tree, as the poet Joyce Kilmer wrote. But genetic engineers can fundamentally redesign them.

title: Freed From Debt, a Hair Stylist Looks to a Brighter Future
description: The Jolie Femme hair salon is carved out of a barbershop in Harlem. Past the black combs soaking in blue Barbicide and the buzzing clippers, Aurea Casellas, 33, tends to her clients. She twists womens hair into up-dos, or irons spiral locks pin-straight. Her specialty, however, is weaves.

title: Employees at CBS News Vote to Authorize a Strike
description: Several hundred CBS News employees represented by the Writers Guild of America have voted to authorize a strike against the company, union officials said yesterday.

title: Katrinas Damage to Trees May Alter Carbon Balance
description: The world knows the kind of destruction that Hurricane Katrina brought to New Orleans and other cities and towns on the Gulf Coast.

title: Health Care, Denied
description: To the Editor:

title: A Hazy Future for a Jewel of Space Instruments
description: The next time an unexpected comet shows up in the inner solar system, Amy J. Lovell may not get time at the Arecibo radio telescope in Puerto Rico to observe it before it swings back out.

title: Pride and Nostalgia Mix in The Timess New Home
description: Writing about your employers new building is a tricky task. If I love it, the reader will suspect that Im currying favor with the man who signs my checks. If I hate it, Im just flaunting my independence.

title: Guns and Random Death: Be Careful Out There
description: The bullets were meant for him, but Andre Santana ducked in time. Or maybe the gunmen were just lousy shots. Whatever, he lived and a woman died, having committed the sole crime of walking along the wrong street at the wrong time.

title: As Carr Reflects, Michigan Starts to Move On
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 19  Lloyd Carr announced Monday that he was retiring as Michigans football coach, a move that opens one of the premier jobs in college football and ends the career of one of the games top coaches.

title: U.S. Withdraws Approval for Tysons Antibiotic-Free Label
description: Tyson Foods was widely hailed in June when it announced that it would produce all of its branded fresh chicken from birds raised without antibiotics. The company, hoping to cash in on consumer demand for more natural products, said it would promote the antibiotic-free birds as part of a $70 million advertising campaign.

title: As Nascar Changes, Johnson Seeks the Same Success
description: HOMESTEAD, Fla., Nov. 18  The cloud of smoke from Jimmie Johnsons celebratory burnout at the Homestead-Miami Speedway finish line had not yet cleared Sunday night when his intense crew chief, Chad Knaus, started talking about 2008.

title: A Reprieve on Foreclosures
description: To the Editor:

title: The Scientists Speak
description: The worlds scientists have done their job. Now its time for world leaders, starting with President Bush, to do theirs. That is the urgent message at the core of the latest  and the most powerful  report from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, a group of 2,500 scientists who collectively constitute the worlds most authoritative voice on global warming.

title: Helping Documentarians
description: The Tribeca Film Institute and Gucci have joined to create the Gucci Tribeca Documentary Fund, which will offer financing and production guidance to help independent filmmakers complete documentaries that promote social change, focusing on issues neglected by the mainstream news media. The fund will provide grants totaling $80,000 to a minimum of three filmmakers in 2008 and will be administered by the Tribeca Film Institute. Recipients will be selected by the Tribeca Film Institute, along with Gucci and a selection committee of documentary filmmakers. All documentary filmmakers who have projects in production or postproduction may apply. Applications can be sent from Feb. 5 to April 11, 2008. Recipients will be announced next summer. Information: tribecafilmfestival.org.

title: Known for Delays, Denver Shows Dispatch
description: DENVER, Nov. 21  The light snow that dusted the city early today was far less than the crippling blizzard that closed Denver International Airport for nearly two days just before last Christmas. Lines at the airports security checkpoints, which set national records between September 2006 and October 2007, moved briskly, which had travelers and airport officials smiling.

title: The Power of Suggestion (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Amid Turmoil, U.S. Attorney Will Shift to Headquarters
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  The embattled United States attorney in Minnesota announced on Monday that she would step down to go to work at the Justice Department in Washington on legal policies.

title: Smithsonian Is Planning a Big Fund-Raising Push
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  The Smithsonian Institutions Board of Regents voted Monday to undertake a major capital campaign to help raise the $2.5 billion needed to improve and repair its buildings. It is the first large-scale private fund-raising effort in the organizations history.

title: Victor Rabinowitz, 96, Leftist Lawyer, Dies
description: Victor Rabinowitz, a leftist lawyer whose causes and clients over nearly three-quarters of a century ranged from labor unions to Black Panthers to Cuba to Dashiell Hammett to Dr. Benjamin Spock to his own daughter, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 96.

title: Pocket Change for Pockets Already Full
description: Oh what a relief it is. No one has to buy Alex Rodriguez lunch today. Even better, no one has to buy dinner for him and his family tonight. Hes got it covered.

title: Whites Take a Majority on New Orleanss Council
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 19  In one of the clearest signs yet of Hurricane Katrinas lasting demographic impact, the City Council is about to have a white majority for the first time in over two decades, pointing up again the storms displacement of thousands of residents, mostly black.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Sunday about Jeff Novitzky, a special agent for the I.R.S. who is the governments leading investigator of doping in sports, misstated the name of a performance-enhancing drug and referred imprecisely to one of Mr. Novitzkys high school athletic accomplishments. The drug is erythropoietin, a blood-boosting hormone; there is no steroid known as eritropotin. Although Mr. Novitzky indeed cleared 7 feet in the high jump, he did not set a state record. (Go to Article)

title: Memo Pad
description: THANKSGIVING TRAVEL With gasoline prices averaging well over $3 a gallon nationally, the overall number of Americans traveling during the Thanksgiving holiday season will rise by a slight 1.5 percent this year, the automobile and travel association AAA says. A year ago, prices were in the range of $2.20 a gallon, so this year travelers are really feeling the pinch, Robert L. Darbelnet, the groups president, said in a statement. (AAA has a state-by-state gasoline cost and fuel-mileage calculator at www.fuelcostcalculator.com.) While other surveys show that rates at luxury and big city hotels are up, there is some good news. Rates at midlevel hotels with AAA Three-Diamond ratings are down 3 percent from last year. THE BRITISH ARE NOT COMING Although the weak dollar compared with the pound makes travel in the United States a bargain for Britons, British leisure and business travel to the United States is down by 11 percent since 2000, says the Discover America Partnership, a travel industry group. It cited Commerce Department figures. Without the lure of the exchange rate, the persistent decline in British travelers would be even worse, the group says. It blames time-consuming and sometimes rude Customs and Immigration procedures at airports and a poor image of the United States abroad for an overall 17 percent decline in overseas travel to the United States since late 2001.

title: Spitzer Calls for M.T.A. to Keep Base Fare at $2
description: New York State Gov. Eliot Spitzer announced today that he was calling on the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to throw out a controversial proposal to raise subway and bus fares and to keep the base fare at $2 per ride.

title: Glimpses of Life in a City Yearning for Normalcy
description: THE happy couples announced their unions with the blare of car horns, bursting from freshly washed sedans draped with garlands of sunshine-yellow flowers. A wedding!

title: U.N. to Say It Overstated H.I.V. Cases by Millions
description: The United Nations AIDS-fighting agency plans to issue a report today acknowledging that it overestimated the size of the epidemic and that new infections with the deadly virus have been dropping each year since they peaked in the late 1990s.

title: Giants Assess Damage and Have Holes to Fill
description: The Giants are 7-3 after a satisfying but far from artistic victory over the Detroit Lions, but Coach Tom Coughlin has concerns. Linebacker Mathias Kiwanuka has a broken left leg and is out for the season, and the fleet of running backs is no longer deep.

title: Glavine Will End Career on Own Terms in Atlanta
description: No one on the Atlanta Braves has worn No. 47 since 2002, out of respect for the man who wore it last. That man, Tom Glavine, will wear it again next season after what had been apparent all along became official yesterday.

title: Dirty, Sexy and Sold
description: Dirty Sexy Money, the freshman drama on ABC, has been picked up for a second season, and Lolita Davidovich, above, has joined the cast in the recurring role of a hospital administrator who is a potential love interest for the character played by Donald Sutherland, Reuters reported. The show is the first on any network to be picked up since the start of the writers walkout.

title: Fighting Gridlock Where Minutes Can Mean Life or Death
description: Fuat! Weve run out of stretchers!

title: Manhattan: Principal of Arabic School Sues City
description: The founding principal of the citys first Arabic-language school has filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court against the citys Education Department, Chancellor Joel I. Klein and Mayor Michael R.
