Bloomberg, claiming that they violated her right to free speech and conspired to deny her the opportunity to regain her position as principal of the Khalil Gibran International Academy, in Brooklyn. The principal, Debbie Almontaser, resigned under pressure this summer, following a furor that erupted after she was quoted in The New York Post defending the use of the word intifada on a T-shirt sold by a Brooklyn-based organization of Arab women. Last month, Ms. Almontaser said she was a victim of a smear campaign by conservatives and would apply to get her job back. But Education Department officials said they would not consider her application among the 25 others that were submitted at the time.

title: The Segmented Society
description: On Feb. 9, 1964, the Beatles played on The Ed Sullivan Show. Or as Steven Van Zandt remembers the moment: It was the beginning of my life.

title: Another Very Scary Germ
description: The bacterial infection that killed a Brooklyn middle school student, panicked many parents and sent school officials in many states into a frenzy of cleaning and disinfecting is only the latest manifestation of a very dangerous problem: the development of bacterial strains that are resistant to many antibiotics. It is a problem that needs to be tackled broadly, not just in a hasty reaction to the recent incidents.

title: Gun Dealers Lawsuit Moves Ahead
description: A South Carolina judge has ruled that a lawsuit against Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and New York City over tactics used against out-of-state gun dealers can go ahead. Roger M. Young, a State Circuit Court judge in Berkeley County, found against the citys motion to dismiss the 2006 lawsuit, brought by the Mickalis Pawn Shop of Summerville, S.C., according to papers filed yesterday. The suit was filed in response to city lawsuits against gun dealers in Georgia, Ohio, Pennsylvania, South Carolina and Virginia alleging that improper sales practices had led to a large number of guns ending up in criminals hands in New York. Some of the dealers settled the suits and agreed to work with a court-appointed monitor, but the owner of the Summerville shop, Larry Mickalis, countersued, accusing Mr. Bloomberg and the city of conspiracy, fraud and libel, among other charges.

title: Decline of the Tenure Track Raises Concerns
description: DEARBORN, Mich.  Professors with tenure or who are on a tenure track are now a distinct minority on the countrys campuses, as the ranks of part-time instructors and professors hired on a contract have swelled, according to federal figures analyzed by the American Association of University Professors.

title: Rodriguez Is M.V.P.; Rivera Says Hell Re-Sign
description: When it seemed as if Alex Rodriguez would become an ex-Yankee, and he was seeking counsel from all manner of friends and tycoons, Mariano Rivera was a voice of reason. Rivera spoke regularly to Rodriguez, urging him to broker a peace with the Yankees and show them that he wanted to return despite opting out of his contract.

title: Lottery Numbers
Addiction: Lowering Nicotine Levels May Help Cut Smoking
description: Smokers who were given nicotine-reduced cigarettes for five weeks and then allowed to return to their regular brands ended up smoking less, according to the authors of a small study.

title: As U.S. Cools, World Demand Helps H.P. Outpace Rivals
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 19  Buoyed by its heavy international presence, Hewlett-Packard appears to have sidestepped the softening demand from corporations inside the United States for new technology.

title: Looking Ahead After a Frightening Day
description: A vacation in Italy was about to come to an appropriate end, a trip to a soccer game between Roma and Cagliari. Leslie Osborne, Heather OReilly and Lindsay Tarpley, members of the United States womens national team, were on a bus, and Romes Olympic Stadium was in view.

title: Is Gorbachev Cashing in? Give an Icon His Due
description: To the Editor:

title: Aging: Walking Faster and Outpacing Death
description: Researchers who followed the health of nearly 500 older people for almost a decade found that those who walked more quickly were less likely to die over the course of the study.

title: Rescuing Newspapers
description: To the Editor:

title: Ministering to Chaos Abroad, Echoing at Home
description: The Huey lands gracefully, a butterfly alighting on a rose, its high mast and tail rotor making a wind that turns pages and reinvigorates the dust. I have to grab my cap.

title: The Claim: White Meat Is Healthier Than Dark Meat
description: THE FACTS

title: Supreme Court Agrees to Hear Gun Control Case
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  The Supreme Court announced today that it would l decide whether the Constitution grants individuals the right to keep guns in their homes for private use, plunging the justices headlong into a divisive and long-running debate over how to interpret the Second Amendments guarantee of the right of the people to keep and bear arms.

title: Twins on a Medical Odyssey After a Diagnosis of Diabetes
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y.   On Oct. 3, 2005, the eve of Rosh Hashana, Ali and Marissa Newman and their parents, Stacey and Rick, drove from their home here to Long Island to have dinner with cousins. It was supposed to be a pleasant holiday, a time to be with family and to celebrate the Jewish New Year in temple.

title: At Jets Game, a Halftime Ritual of Harassment
description: At halftime of the Jets home game against the Pittsburgh Steelers on Sunday, several hundred men lined one of Giants Stadiums two pedestrian ramps at Gate D. Three deep in some areas, they whistled and jumped up and down. Then they began an obscenity-laced chant, demanding that the few women in the gathering expose their breasts.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in the special Giving section on Nov. 12 about young philanthropists misstated the name of an organization that Jonathan Holmes, a 27-year-old who was asked to run his familys foundation, went to for support. It is the Association of Small Foundations, not the Association for Small Foundations.

title: Hepatitis Found Again Among Doctors Patients
description: Nassau County health officials yesterday reported another positive test for hepatitis among the patients of an anesthesiologist on Long Island whose faulty infection-control practices put hundreds of people at risk.

title: Home, or Not, for the Holiday
description: Most years, it might appear unseemly to mix presidential politics with Thanksgiving. But rules of political etiquette may not apply this year, considering the holiday falls six weeks before voting begins.

title: Ron Pauls Tight-fisted Campaign
description: Voters looking for a candidate who will be tight with their money might have found their man in Ron Paul, if campaign spending is any indication. At the moment, Mr. Paul, a Texas congressman who is seeking the Republican presidential nomination, is rolling in cash. He already had raised $5 million this year when a one-day Internet drive tied to Guy Fawkes Day on Nov. 5 brought in another $4 million.

title: Intipa Awachan? Helia? Phaethon? Fred?  The Solar-Twin Naming Contest Flares Up
description: The grand prize  your very own copy of Bullfinchs Mythology  is still up for grabs, but weve had some promising names and myths nominated for the newly discovered twin of the Sun. (You can read about the contest and see some nominations here.)

title: A Statistical Tie in Iowa
description: It is increasingly evident that Iowa is not going to be as easy terrain for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton as her campaign had hoped. Mrs. Clinton and Senator Barack Obama are in a tough fight in that state, as a Washington Post/ABC News poll of Iowa Democrats released yesterday seems to show.

title: Paris strike comfort food: hot chocolate and pastries
description: As the Paris transportation strike lingers into its seventh day along with a general walkout, I think its fair to say that French residents and tourists deserve comfort food for coping with the perils of crowded platforms and mobbed metros.

title: Love, the Universal Language?
description: Its a match made in Babel when a translation Web site gets involved:

title: Icahn Nudges Blockbuster Stake to 16%
description: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn has raised his stake in the Class A shares of Blockbuster, the video rental chain, to 16 percent, from 15 percent.

title: Suit on Apple Options Is Dismissed
description: Apple won dismissal Monday of a lawsuit claiming that company directors and managers, including the chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, lied to shareholders about the backdating of option awards.

title: Before Stockpickr.com, a Hedge Fund Deal Not Done
description: In a mini-profile of a hedge fund manager, James Altucher, and his investment Web site Stockpickr.com, BusinessWeek reports that Mr. Altucher eschewed a tantalizing offer from a large hedge fund to bring his investment strategy  and that of Warren E. Buffet and George Soros  to the masses.

title: Madison Dearborn Chief Steps Down
description: John Canning, the chief executive of Madison Dearborn Partners, a private equity firm in Chicago, has stepped down as the company begins a $10 billion fundraising drive.

title: Calpine Chief Gets $10.9 Million Stock Incentive
description: Calpines chief executive, Robert May, can expect a $10.9 million stock incentive for guiding the struggling San Jose-based power producer out of the largest United States bankruptcy of 2005, according to papers filed in United States Bankruptcy Court in New York.

title: What About the Strategy?
description: Lets set aside the appropriateness of going for it on fourth down  and keeping the starters in  with a gigantic lead in the second half.Patriots fans have made their point. For those interested in revisiting that issue, see the post below. (Bill Belichick as an Ayn Rand disciple  only in The New York Times).

title: Applied Materials Scoops Up Baccini
description: A semiconductor equipment maker, Applied Materials, said Monday it was purchasing  Baccini, a supplier of automated metalization and test systems for making solar systems, for about 225 million euros ($330 million).

title: Former Countrywide Executives Sentenced to 3 Years Probation
description: Three former executives of Countrywide Financial who pleaded guilty to criminal insider trading charges were sentenced Monday to serve three years probation, the United States attorneys office said.

title: Russian Energy Concern Files Suit Against Abramovich
description: An affiliate of Sibir Energy is seeking what could be billions of dollars in damages in a lawsuit in London against the billionaire Roman Abramovich and his investment company, Millhouse Capital, saying that it was cheated out of its Russian assets.

title: Hedge Fund Co-Founder Enters Guilty Plea
description: Portus Alternative Asset Managements co-founder, Michael Mendelson, was sentenced Monday to two years in prison after pleading guilty to fraud related to the collapse of the company, a Canadian hedge-fund firm, in 2005.

title: Looking for Diamonds in Rough Times for Financial Stocks
description: It has been a rough few months for Americas vaunted financial institutions, which are under siege. Shares of many Wall Street bank and Wall Street investment houses have taken a beating amid losses related to the mortgage market meltdown and the abrupt exits of several chief executives.

title: China Railway Said to Seek $5.5 Billion in I.P.O.s
description: The China Railway Group, a construction contractor, plans to raise up to $5.5 billion from its Hong Kong and Shanghai initial public offerings amid booming railway investment in China, Reuters reported.

title: Facebook Denies Talks for China Deal
description: Facebook is denying a report that it is chasing a Chinese social network, Zhanzuo.com.

title: SAP May Sell Unit as Senior Managers Resign
description: The software maker SAP said Monday that it might sell its TomorrowNow business following an announcement that senior managers at the unit, which has embroiled the company in a legal dispute with a rival, Oracle, had resigned.

title: Hudson Capital Said to Deal for Former Warner Studio
description: A Los Angeles investment firm, Hudson Capital, has a preliminary agreement to buy a former Warner Brothers studio that is now home to station KTLA-TV Channel 5, according to The Los Angeles Times.

title: S.E.C.s Cases Grow, but Fines Shrink
description: Sanctions imposed by the Securities and Exchange Commission fell this year to the lowest level since 2002, after Republican commissioners complained that heavy penalties hurt investors and the agency brought fewer billion-dollar accounting fraud cases.

title: Wall Streets 1st-Quarter Surge Lifted Manhattan Wages
description: On Wall Street, the first quarter of 2007 may wind up as one of those periods, like the height of the dot-com bubble in early 2000, that is remembered wistfully for years.

title: New Buyout-Loan Chill Hitting Chrysler?
description: Is demand for buyout-related debt drying up again? That question was raised late Monday by reports that the planned sale of $4 billion in loans tied to Cerberus Capital Managements acquisition of Chrysler will likely be postponed amid weak demand.

title: Hedge Fund Counter-Sues Fairfax Financial
description: A hedge fund has filed a counter-claim against an insurer, Fairfax Financial Holdings, and its law firm for defamation and using private investigators to harass its employees.

title: Rio Tinto May Offer BHP an Alliance, Report Says
description: Rio Tinto is considering offering joint ventures with BHP Billiton as an alternative to BHPs proposed $140 billion takeover, The Telegraph reported.

title: Travel Basics: Moscow
description: by Sophia Kishkovsky

title: Clinton Confronts Polarizing Issue
description: TAMA, Iowa  On one of the most provocative political questions of the day  is Hillary Rodham Clinton too polarizing to be president?  Mrs. Clinton delivered a punchy and pointed rejoinder at a town meeting last night, using some of her most memorable language in a recent string of campaign stops in Iowa.

title: Blowtorch Sparks Up $50 Million Round
description: Blowtorch Entertainment has raised $50 million in first-round funding for its plans to create a digital media company that distributes its content through all the channels used by the coveted demographic of always-connected young adults.

title: Edith Wharton Letter
description: A newly revealed letter from Edith Wharton sheds light on the ending of "The House of Mirth."

title: In Blast from the Past, Flowers Leads $1.8 Billion Shinsei Bid
description: J. Christopher Flowers just cant seem to get enough of Shinsei Bank.

title: A Poem Called Spell Checker
description: Looks like Keats can rest easy. A bit of verse found here:

title: Sears May Make Rival Bid for Restoration Hardware
description: Sears Holdings, the parent of retailers Sears and Kmart and run by Edward S. Lampert, has bought a 13.9 percent stake in Restoration Hardware and is considering a possible takeover, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing Monday.

title: Vintage shopping in Berlin
description: By Natasha Montrose

title: King Tut Does London  Again
description: O2 (at night) now hosts King Tut by photo by colin philip

title: UBS Asks Judge to Let It Out of Genesco Deal
description: Genesco, the shoe retailer seeking to be bought by Finish Line, fell the most in five years after UBS asked a judge to let it out of an agreement to finance the $1.5 billion acquisition.

title: Will Buyout Targets Bid Adieu to Break-Up Fees?
description: The legal fight between United Rentals, the rental equipment provider, and Cerberus Capital Management, the private equity firm that is trying to cancel its $4 billion buyout of the company, has Breakingviews wondering if these reverse break-up fees, which allow buyers to walk away from a deal freely for a nominal sum, might become a thing of the past.

title: Candover Buys Alama Consulting From Apax
description: A London buyout shop Candover, announced an agreement Monday to buy the Alma Consulting Group, a French tax recovery and cost reduction services company, from a private equity firm in Paris, Apax Partners, an independently managed member of the Apax Group, and Chequers Capital, a private equity firm also in Paris.

title: Done Anything for Your Brand Lately?
description: Theres been a lot of talk about personal branding lately. A few weeks ago, I heard Catherine Kaputa, author of U R a Brand, speak at a conference. She told a story about a book with a great idea that achieved only modest sales. But then it was repackaged with some attention paid to branding and went on to captivate dieters around the country. The books original title was The Moderate Carbohydrate Diet. The books modified title? The South Beach Diet. Ms. Kaputas book is about how to apply this kind of thinking to ourselves.

title: Still More of Your Late Night Jokes
description: Readers continue to prove that even with late-night comedy writers on strike, theres no shortage of shtick out there (send your jokes via the comment link below). Here are some from Alan Ray of Stockton, Calif., who runs a daily comedy service for radio shows, newspapers, and comedians:

title: Options to Stabilize Northern Rock Are Narrowing
description: As Northern Rock, the troubled British mortgage lender, confirmed that it had received a number of disappointing takeover proposals, The New York Times says that the British government is under increasing pressure to either find a solution or consider nationalizing the bank.

title: Freddie Mac May Seek Capital After Big Loss
description: Freddie Mac, the No. 2 guarantor of home mortgages in the United States, reported a much bigger-than-expected $2 billion loss for the third quarter and said Tuesday it had hired Goldman Sachs and Lehman Brothers to help it consider very near-term capital raising alternatives.

title: Gloom Mounts on Broadway as Strike Goes On
description: The stagehands strike is costing the citys economy millions of dollars each day and is especially painful this week, one of the busiest of the year. Campbell Robertson, who covers Broadway for The Times, reports that the big shock came on Sunday night, when the league of theater producers and owners and the union suddenly broke off talks, after spending the weekend trying to end the strike. The sticking point in the talks has been the leagues desire for looser work rules for members of the union.

title: The Early Word: Polls, Policy and Politics
description: With the latest Washington Post-ABC News poll showing a tight race between Democratic candidates Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton in Iowa, The Timess Adam Nagourney points out that nothing can be taken for granted in the Hawkeye State.

title: Radiohead Frontman Pays Nothing for His Album
description: Rock fans and the music industry have watched with great interest as Radiohead offered downloads of its latest album, In Rainbows, to the world at the vaguest of price points. Allowed to pay whatever they wanted, how many would jump at the chance to pay zero?

title: Spitzer Directs M.T.A. to Keep Base Subway and Bus Fare at $2
description: Updated, 4:13 p.m. | Gov. Eliot Spitzer announced this morning that he was directing the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to scale back its plan to increase subway and bus fares, holding the base fare at $2 per ride. His plan would still allow the authority to increase some fares, including the cost of the 7-day and 30-day unlimited-ride MetroCards and fares on the Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North Railroad.

title: Much Ado About Huckabee
description: Huckabacklash: Mike Huckabee, the former Arkansas governor who is in second place in Iowa right now according to many polls, is doing well enough that its time for opinion writers to find fault with him. The Washington Posts Richard Cohen, for example, says that he finds Huckabees religiosity more worrisome than Mitt Romneys Mormonism. Cohen writes:

title: Food Stuff
description: Building a Better Plastic Wrap

title: Will H&R Blocks Shake-Up Lead to Break-Up?
description: Score another point for Richard Breeden, the Securities and Exchange Commission chairman turned activist investor. Two months after winning seats on the board of H&R Block, Mr. Breeden was named chairman of the tax-preparation company on Tuesday, filling a post created by the abrupt resignation of Mark Ernst.

title: New Clinton Ad: Machine
description: In a new television ad running in New Hampshire, Hillary Rodham Clinton ignores her Democratic opponents and takes on the Republican attack machine.

title: An Effort to See That Carbon Saved Is Carbon Earned
description: Its worth exploring a fine blog at our sister paper, the International Herald Tribune, called Business of Green.

title: Eagleton v. Amis v. Islam
description: What does it mean to be an Islamophobe, and once we have that sorted out, is Martin Amis an exemplar of the species?

description: From todays Washington Post:

description: On Monday, the broadcast networks offered three more hints of what their strike-impacted schedules would look like:

title: The Romantic Toll of Diabetes
description: Most people with diabetes worry about the effect the disease has on their bodies. But what about the effect it has on their relationships?

title: Vizio Stays on Top in L.C.D. TVs
description: As the hard-core deal hunters ready their thermoses so they have coffee while camping out early Friday morning for the doorbuster sales at Best Buy, Wal-Mart and so on, returns from the third-quarter electronics derby are coming in.

title: Brown's Lobster Pound
description: Students from Harvard University's Institute of Politics talked to Bruce Brown, owner of a popular New Hampshire stop for Republican candidates.

title: $20 Million Homes
description: Properties on the market in California, Florida and New York.

title: Amphicar Ahoy!
description: PARIS  The  transit strike that brought train service in Paris and other parts of France to a screeching halt for the last week is causing commuters no end of pain and annoyance. But Parisians are coping with the inconvenience by taking advantage of the citys new rent-a-bike program, car-pooling, or by putting on their most comfortable walking shoes. To see how the strike had affected everyday life in my new hometown, I decided to take a walk through the Place de la Concorde.

title: Tuesday Links: This Has Nothing to Do With the Patriots
description: Watching last nights game, I was at first wondering, Werent the Broncos just on Monday Night Football? But by the end, it seemed as if this was an entirely different team than the one that lost to the Packers on MNF three weeks ago (Here is some video to compare: Week 8 vs. Week 11). And Denver might be peaking at the right time. The A.F.C West is a mess, just waiting for a team to take charge. After the 34-20 victory over the Tennessee Titans (6-4), the Broncos (5-5) are now tied for first place with the confounding San Diego Chargers.

title: Tuesday Morning Kickoff
description: No one has ever accused football coaches of having the best perspective. Nick Saban, when talking about Alabamas back-to-back losses to Mississippi State and Louisiana-Monroe had this to say, according to Kevin Scarbinsky of the Birmingham News:

title: Here Comes the Stain Again
description: I suppose I knew it already, but a recent visit to the restaurant Fiamma in SoHo hammered home this lesson:

title: Thanksgivings Modern Joys
description: The Onion reports that Americans are enjoying their Thanksgiving tradition of waiting around at the airport:

title: Broadway Strike Survival Guide
description: Updated: Nov. 30 | 10:54 a.m.

title: Cellphones Get Cheaper, So People Pay More
description: Theres no place that the relentless reduction in prices for technology products is more visible than cellphones. It seems like only months between the time a phone is offered for sale at $300 and it is ready to be given away free in cereal boxes. (O.K. not quite, but thats not a bad marketing idea.)

title: Report Finds Racial Disparities in Police Searches
description: Updated, Nov. 21 | A study by the private nonprofit Rand Corporation found that blacks and Hispanics were more likely than whites to be searched when stopped by police officers, but the report does not accuse the department of racial profiling, according to Warren Robak, a spokesman for Rand.

title: Finding the Traditional Seven-Fish Christmas Eve Dinner in Rome
description: Im searching for a restaurant in Rome, preferably serving traditional seven-fish Christmas Eve dinner. Any suggestions?

title: Poem-Based Movies
description: Seen Beowulf yet?

title: Gobble, Gobble and Gobble Some More?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Strike News: Daily Show and Colbert Ratings Decline
description: The tentpoles of Comedy Central have recorded ratings declines in the first two weeks of the writers strike.

title: Buffett and CarMax: Less Than Meets the Eye?
description: Four times a year, fans of Warren Buffett  and there are a lot of them  rush to see which stocks his Berkshire Hathaway has bought in the latest quarter, in hopes of getting a good investment tip or two. Last week, there was a flurry of excitement about CarMax, the seller of used cars, because it appeared that the legendary investor had added nearly 14 million CarMax shares to his portfolio. That was enough to send CarMaxs stock price soaring 7.5 percent in much heavier-than-normal trading.

title: Electronic Books: If It Aint Broke . . .
description: At $400, Amazons Kindle seems rather expensive. The books may be cheap, but you would have to read well over 40 of them before you began to save any money. And really, who reads 40 books a year? Or even in two years?

title: Ex-Bush Spokesmans Tantalizing Snippet on C.I.A. Leak
description: The hints of intrigue and betrayal at the trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. over the leaking of a C.I.A. agents identity grew even more intriguing today as a snippet made the rounds from the forthcoming memoir by Scott McClellan, who was President Bushs chief spokesperson in 2006.

title: Are Guggenheims True Colors Shining Through?
description: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum will remain light gray.

title: Thanksgiving Rush Is On at Hunts Point Market
description: Pumpkins are out. Cranberries are in. This is a peak week for the Hunts Point Cooperative Market, which is the source for approximately 60 percent of New York Citys produce. On Sunday night, the market opened at 6 p.m. instead of a normal 9 p.m. to handle the nighttime rush  about twice the volume of any other day. That day some 500,000 pounds of fresh cranberries  mostly from the bogs of Massachusetts and New Jersey  passed through the market.Cranberries are a unique item in that more than half of the fresh cranberries are consumed at one meal, Thanksgiving Day, said Matthew DArrigo, whose family has been distributing cranberries for 25 years. Most of the rest of the year, we limp along and sell 20 to 40 boxes a day. And then I put 12,000 into storage and starting about 10 days before Thanksgiving they start flying out, he said. Its a very encapsulated market.

title: Dianne Feinstein: Backlash on the Left
description: Liberal California Democrats  and liberal bloggers  have a new Public Enemy No. 1: Senator Dianne Feinstein. They have begun to make their objections very public.

title: Scenes From Nimrod Nation
description: A series about a boy's varsity basketball team becomes more of a portrait of a small town.

title: Sweatshop Crucifixes at the St. Patricks Gift Shop?
description: Charles Kernaghan stood in the rain before St. Patricks Cathedral this morning, brandishing a crucifix from the cathedrals gift shop that he claimed had been made under terrible conditions at a factory in China. It is immoral, it is unjust and it has to change, he said.Mr. Kernaghan, the head of the National Labor Committee, an advocacy group that has unearthed past examples of abusive work conditions, and a veteran of battles with industries over the treatment of foreign workers, said the six-inch wooden crucifix and other religious articles are frequently made by women who toil for pennies an hour in an unrelenting grind of assembly work. (The Archdiocese of New York said today that it would investigate the charges.)

title: Detroit: Most Dangerous, or Most Disrespected?
description: A publishing company that each year ranks the most dangerous cities in the United States says it does so to encourage local conversation about crime prevention. But in the city that topped this years list, Detroit, people are talking only about how much they think the researchers manipulated and sensationalized the data.

title: 'Starting Out in the Evening'
description: A. O. Scott reviews "Starting Out in the Evening," about a graduate student who writes her Master's thesis on a once-famous author.

title: Some Voters Eye McCain Warily
description: Talk to moderate and independent voters who really liked John McCain in 2000 and very often, if they are leery of supporting him now, it has something to do with the past. They say its about what they see as his willingness to embrace his old foe President Bush as he campaigned in 2004  even as he railed against the administrations oversight of the war in Iraq  and making amends with the late Rev. Jerry Falwell, who worked hard to derail Mr. McCains campaign.

title: Iraqi Answers: 'Is Baghdad Stable?'
description: Shema Al-Muhammad's heartfelt response.

title: Buy High, Sell Low
description: If ever there was an example of the way share buybacks help the shareholders who flee  and can hurt those who hang around  it is provided by Freddie Mac today.

title: Mans Conviction for Standing on Sidewalk Is Overturned
description: The Court of Appeals, New York States highest court, threw out the conviction today of a man who was arrested for standing and not moving on a Times Square corner in June 2004.

title: Ratings: Dancing Holds ABC Aloft
description: Mondays semifinal installment of Dancing With the Stars lifted ABC to an easy victory in the nights ratings. According to Nielsens estimates, 23.1 million viewers tuned in to the celebrity competition from 8 to 9:30 p.m., the series best showing since its fall finale last November. The strong ratings also helped boost ABCs Samantha Who, which followed at 9:30 with a series-best 15.4 million viewers.

title: Oxygen Takes Its Last Unaided Breath
description: Oxygen, a seven-year-old cable channel aimed at women, is now officially part of NBC Universal.

title: Three Howls for Bryzgalov
description: Having just moved out to Arizona after 24 years in New York, Im getting to see a lot of the Western teams you rarely see in the East, thanks to the N.H.L.s goofy, rivalry-driven schedule.

title: Clinton vs. Obama, Take 2 in Iowa
description: Updated SHENANDOAH, Iowa  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton just sharpened her new attack on whether Senator Barack Obama is experienced enough to be president, questioning his recent statement that living overseas as a child contributed to his experience level.

title: The New, Sedate J.R.
description: You never shrug when the subject of Jeremy Roenick comes up. The options are:

title: Readers Questions: Stem Cells
description: Two teams of scientists have managed to produce stem cells from human skin cells, Gina Kolata reports today. Their achievement may end the enormous ethical debate surrounding the destruction of human embryos for scientific research.

title: The Scent of a Borough
description: What we are reading elsewhere

title: On the Road: Obama Caters to Small-Town Media
description: CLARION, Iowa  Last week, Senator Barack Obama appeared on NBCs Meet the Press, sitting in the venerable chair where presidential hopefuls have tested their mettle for 60 years. That, however, is not the only important interview Mr. Obama has conducted in recent days.

title: Food Pantries and Soup Kitchens Are Struggling
description: This is a week for turkey lotteries for the citys food pantries. Though with declining federal support, some pantries are finding they have no turkeys to ration.

title: Everybodys in Showbiz
description: With Ric Flairs endorsement, Mike Huckabee appears to be quietly turning his campaign from a viable dark-horse bid into something far more ambitious: a surreal, postmodern satire on the intersection of celebrity culture and presidential politics.

title: How The Strike Affects Your Favorite Shows
description: As the writers strike enters its third week, networks have been forced to scramble.Heres how your other favorite shows have been affected. Check back frequently for updates.

title: Pairing the Wine, When Dinner Is Solo
description: I will get to the Kermit Lynch wines soon, I promise. But first I need to vent a little bit.

title: Answers From Peter Bradford
description: This afternoon we have answers to questions prompted by the fourth article in our series on Chinas environmental crisis, on the countrys attempt to use hydropower to meet some of it energy demands. Our expert this afternoon is Peter Bradford.

title: Living in Pomona
Is Hugo Chavez Smiling Over Kansas, or Coal?
description: [UPDATE, 5/5: The prolonged fight over proposed new coal plants in Kansas has ended with a compromise forged by the new governor. As Green Inc. reports, one plant would be built, with Republicans giving support to the new Democratic governor for a push on renewable energy.]

title: Revisiting Flowers (First) Shinsei Deal
description: J. Christopher Flowers has been a busy globe-trotter lately. As The Financial Times Alphaville points out, the head of J.C. Flowers & Company has bid for, and subsequently tried to run away from, Sallie Mae; reportedly made an offer for Britains Northern Rock; and taken a stake in Germanys HSH Nordbank. But on Tuesday, he returned to the deal that put him on the map, leading a consortium for a $1.8 billion stake in Japans Shinsei Bank.

title: Nina
description: Chalk up one more term from the credit debacle.

title: Coles Limited in Practice
description: Two rather talkative wide receivers remained mum. For Laveranues Coles, nursing another injury, it was expected. For Terrell Owens, coming off four touchdowns, it was a surprise.

title: Cheerful thought of the day
description: From Brad Setser, on US foreign debt and the falling dollar:

title: I get an endorsement from Tom DeLay
description: No comment:

title: Rockefeller Tree Is Green, but Is It Green?
description: A City Hall news release today states that Rockefeller Center has installed its first-ever green Christmas tree.

title: K.K.R. Hires Deal Adviser as General Counsel
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts announced on Tuesday three high-ranking appointments, including its longtime outside legal adviser.

title: Q & A: Baghdad Correspondent on End of the Surge
description: Damien Cave of the Baghdad Bureau of The New York Times is back assessing another rush of good news in Iraq (the last plateau was in late July). This time, the starting point is a front page article he wrote today with Alissa J. Rubin, Baghdads Weary Start to Exhale as Security Improves.

title: In Defense of the Kindle
description: A lot of people are writing off Amazons Kindle book reader much too quickly.

title: Studying Teen Gambling  And Adding to It
description: New York State experts were surprised recently when they tried to figure out how many teenagers in the state have a gambling problem. The answer, according to a new survey: an alarming 10 percent.

title: The Butcher Carves a Turkey
description: Ray Venezia, the manager of the meat department at New York's Fairway Market, shows his technique for effectively carving a turkey.

title: MoveOn Takes On Facebook
description: MoveOn.org is turning its organizing prowess on one of the very tools it uses for its mobilizing efforts. The liberal groups Civic Action division mounted an effort today against Facebooks Beacon advertising feature, claiming it infringes user privacy and sullies social networking communities.

title: Family Football
description: Thomas and Julius Jones once shared a bunk bed. Now they are both starting N.F.L. running backs who will play against each other on Thanksgiving Day.

title: Reunion
description: In the shady side yard of the adoption equation are birth mothers  silent, mostly invisible women who have given up their children without fanfare and often with considerable grief.

title: Egypts Leader Endorses Peace Meeting
description: SHARM EL SHEIK, Egypt, Nov. 20  With the prime minister of Israel standing beside him, Egypts president, Hosni Mubarak, gave his full endorsement today to the American-sponsored Middle East peace gathering in Annapolis, Md., next week, and raised hopes among Israeli officials of wider Arab participation in it.

title: Stocks Fall as Oil Flirts With $100 a Barrel
description: A late sell-off in the final minutes of trading sent stocks down sharply today, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing at its lowest level since April. The Standard & Poors 500-stock index, a broad measure of the equity market, fell into negative territory for the year.

title: A Songwriters Gamut, Personal and Poignant With Notes in Between
description: Blue neon over the stage outlines a craggy face with a sardonic smile that hovers in afterglow even after the light is switched off. The face is that of William Finn, songwriter, and it is an appropriate illustration for a revue of his work, Make Me a Song, at New World Stages. Like the songs, at once slightly mocking and slightly cartoonish, it dominates the stage much as Mr. Finns persona dominates the songs, to such an extent that even when a voluptuous blonde (Sally Wilfert) is singing, you hear the dry voice of this gay Jewish songwriter coming through her own.

title: Democrats and Bush Spar on Military Spending Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  The Bush administration sought to ratchet up pressure on Congressional Democrats on Tuesday over a military spending bill for operations in Iraq and Afghanistan. The White House and the Pentagon warned of dire consequences if the measure was not passed, including the potential layoffs of 100,000 civilian Defense Department employees.

title: New Cable Head Named
description: NBC Universal completed its acquisition of the Oxygen cable channel yesterday and named Lauren Zalaznick as the executive in charge. Ms. Zalaznick will also remain president of the companys Bravo channel. Jeff Zucker, the president of NBC Universal, announced the agreement to purchase Oxygen Media in October; in its announcement yesterday NBC Universal placed the net value of the deal at $875 million. NBC Universal executives said they had sought the channel to reach more female consumers, a group the Bravo Channel, which has performed consistently well under Ms. Zalaznick, also appeals to.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: The Peppers Claim Californication for Themselves

title: Candidate Drops Bid for Congress
description: A vice chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, who was expected to pour his own money into a bid for Congress, abruptly dropped out of the running yesterday.

title: 200 Neglected Buildings Get 4 Months to Improve
description: In a crackdown on some of the worst landlords in New York City, housing officials have identified 200 of the most poorly maintained apartment buildings and are renewing efforts to force owners to repair hazardous conditions.

title: Khmer Rouge Hearing Ends
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Nov. 21  More than 28 years after the killing stopped, the first Khmer Rouge defendant stepped into a public courtroom on Tuesday to answer for the deaths of 1.7 million people  a tiny, self-effacing man who once commanded an efficient and ruthless torture house.

title: Recipe: Waldorf Slaw
description: 1/3 cup rice vinegar

title: German Police Arrest Third Suspect in Perugia Murder Case
description: ROME, Nov. 20  The hunt for a 20-year-old man suspected in the puzzling slaying of a British student in Italy ended after he was picked up by the German police on Tuesday for riding a train without a ticket.

title: Canada: Huge Conservation Area Set for North
description: The government plans to convert 25.5 million acres of northern woodland into a new national park and wildlife protection area that will be one of North Americas largest conservation areas. The land is within the boreal forest, a nearly contiguous band of mostly coniferous trees about 600 miles wide that sweeps across much of Canada and continues in Scotland, Scandinavia and Russia. About 77 percent of Canadas forest is in the band. Under the plan to be announced tomorrow (cabinet orders putting it into effect were published to little notice last week), 8.5 million acres surrounding the eastern arm of Great Slave Lake in the Northwest Territories will become a national park. An additional 15.3 million acres between the new park and an existing wildlife refuge will be designated conservation land under the management of native groups. Farther northwest, near the Mackenzie River Valley, 3.7 million acres will be turned into a national wildlife area.

title: Holiday Closures
description: NEW YORK

title: In Shift, Fare for the Subway Will Stay at $2
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer abruptly announced yesterday that he was shelving a plan to raise the base subway fare, saying that an unexpected increase in ridership and other revenues have made it unnecessary.

title: Cardiologists Question Delay of Data on 2 Drugs
description: Prescriptions for the cholesterol-lowering drugs Zetia and Vytorin are written for almost 800,000 Americans every week, at a cost this year of about $4 billion. Yet it still is not clear how well the drugs work.

title: Clinton Challenges Obama on Foreign Experience
description: SHENANDOAH, Iowa, Nov. 20  Fog may have diverted Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons plane from her campaign stop here on Tuesday, but that did not prevent her from continuing her attacks on Senator Barack Obamas experience.

title: Corrections
description: The VC Nation column on the Street Scene page of Business Day on Friday, about identity theft, misstated the background of Robert Maynard, a founder of LifeLock, a security firm in Tempe, Ariz. Although Mr. Maynard spent a week in jail on fraud charges, as The Phoenix New Times reported, he made restitution and was not convicted. Mr. Maynard does not have a criminal record. (Go to Article)

title: Manhattan: Ambulette Injures Boy
description: An ambulette driver was charged with vehicular assault and driving under the influence after his ambulette struck and critically injured a 12-year-old boy yesterday, the police said. The driver was identified as Juan Ortiz, 57. The boy, who was hit while trying to cross East 20th Street near First Avenue, was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center, the police said.

title: Opponents of California Ballot Initiative Seek Inquiry
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 20  The chairman of a committee formed to fight a ballot initiative to change how Californias electoral college votes are apportioned has asked the city attorney here to investigate a report that a group collecting signatures for the initiative has offered food to homeless people in exchange for signing the petitions.

title: Redefining Whats Preferable
description: What is more humiliating for a player in the second half of a blowout defeat?

title: New Stem Cell Method Could Ease Ethical Concerns
description: Two teams of scientists are reporting today that they turned human skin cells into what appear to be embryonic stem cells without having to make or destroy an embryo  a feat that could quell the ethical debate troubling the field.

title: Democrats Move to Block Bush Appointments
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  Who says the Senate cannot act quickly? It conducted a full days business in less than 30 seconds on Tuesday.

title: Scientists Bypass Need for Embryo to Get Stem Cells
description: Two teams of scientists reported yesterday that they had turned human skin cells into what appear to be embryonic stem cells without having to make or destroy an embryo  a feat that could quell the ethical debate troubling the field.

title: Fantasies Without Bounds for a Lothario With Limits
description: Crispin Hellion Glovers planned trilogy of blatant weirdness continues with a second installment, It Is Fine! Everything Is Fine. Like last years Part 1, What Is It?, this follow-up (with David Brothers as co-director) will attract only the most adventurous filmgoers, who will have to wade through some rather repugnant material to weigh the movies merits.

title: Stamford: Inmate Charged in Killing
description: Nearly five years to the day that a Stamford woman was found slain in her waterfront condo here, the authorities obtained a warrant on Nov. 6 to arrest a New York inmate serving a 25-year sentence for the attempted murder of her own husband. The Stamford police were seeking to extradite the woman, Sheila Davalloo, above, to stand trial in the killing of Anna Lisa Raymundo, 32, on Nov. 8, 2002. Ms. Davalloo was sentenced in April 2004 for stabbing her husband, Paul Christos, in 2003. The police said Ms. Davalloo tried to rid herself of both her husband and Ms. Raymundo, whose boyfriend, they said, she wanted to date. Compiled by John Sullivan

title: Metropolitan Opera Performances Online
description: The Metropolitan Opera said yesterday that 100 recorded performances from its archives from as far back as 1937 were now available on the Rhapsody digital music service (rhapsody.com/metropolitanopera). More will be added, the Met said. The venture, announced last year, is part of efforts by the Met to distribute its performances outside of the house, including on the Internet and in movie theaters.

title: Girardi Shows His Hands-On Approach
description: Two weeks ago, Joe Girardi was in Orlando, Fla., huddling with coaches at the general managers meetings to plan spring training for the Yankees. Last week, he was in the Dominican Republic at the teams new academy, viewing tryouts and speaking to the players, some as young as 16.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening This Week

title: Another Side of Bob Dylan, and Another, and Another ...
description: From Andy Warhol to Lonelygirl15, modern media culture thrives on the traffic in counterfeit selves. In this world the greatest artist will also be, almost axiomatically, the biggest fraud. And looking back over the past 50 years or so, it is hard to find anyone with a greater ability to synthesize authenticity  to give his serial hoaxes and impersonations the ring of revealed and esoteric truth  than Bob Dylan.

title: Travelers Odds Decline on Airline Baggage
description: CHICAGO  Why do so many passengers get off the plane only to discover that their baggage did not make the trip with them?

title: Correction
description: An Op-Art on Friday, about assessing presidential candidates, misstated the era in which The Monthly Magazine conducted its review of British politicians. The year 1823 was in the Georgian era, not the Victorian.

title: Conviction for Standing in Times Sq. Is Overturned
description: The Court of Appeals, New York States highest court, threw out the conviction yesterday of a man who was arrested for standing and not moving on a Times Square corner in 2004.

title: New York Aids in Jewelry Recall
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission recalled 507,900 pieces of childrens jewelry this morning from stores like Michaels and Big Lots because they contained hazardous levels of lead.

title: Someday My Prince Will ... Uh, Make That a Manhattan Lawyer
description: The movies like to promise girls and women a happily ever after, but its unusual that one delivers an ending that makes you feel unsullied and uncompromised, that doesnt make you want to reach for your Simone de Beauvoir or a Taser. Enchanted, an unexpectedly delightful revisionist fairy tale from, of all places, Walt Disney Pictures, doesnt radically rewrite every bummer clich about girls of all ages and their dreams. But for a satisfying stretch, the film works its magic largely by sending up, at times with a wink, at times with a hard nudge, some of the very stereotypes that have long been this companys profitable stock in trade.

title: Mets Acquire Estrada in a Trade for Mota
description: The Mets improved themselves on two fronts yesterday. They traded for a starting catcher and, in doing so, got rid of a player who, in many ways, embarrassed them in 2007.

title: No Easy Solution for Congestion at J.F.K. Airport, Experts Say
description: It has become an agonizingly familiar formula for delays and frustration: high winds, rain and holiday crowds. And when those elements converge on Kennedy International Airport, as they do routinely at Thanksgiving time, the delays ripple out to airports across the region and often the nation, leaving millions of fliers angry.

title: Manhattan: More Hunger in New York
description: Demand at New York City food pantries and soup kitchens jumped 20 percent this year, according to an annual survey released yesterday by the New York City Coalition Against Hunger. The demand, along with dwindling federal resources, has forced about half of the food providers surveyed to ration their supplies. The increase continues from 2006, when demand jumped 11 percent over the previous year. The survey was based on responses from 291 of the more than 1,200 agencies that run soup kitchens, food pantries and emergency food programs in the five boroughs.

title: Anna Freuds Insight
description: To the Editor:

title: Border Fence Work Raises Environmental Concerns
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 20  The Department of Homeland Security is ahead of schedule in building some 700 miles of fencing along the Mexican border, but some environmental groups, elected officials and local Indian tribes say too little attention is being paid to the environmental consequences of the barriers.

title: Broadway Is Mostly Dark, but Oh, All the Other Places to Go
description: As you might just possibly have heard, Broadway is mostly dark this weekend, as the stagehands strike continues.

title: For the Many Who Have Come, a Place for Them to Go
description: On a long, blustery day of hiking through Midtown, it was inevitable that members of the Yankton High School Marching Band and Colorguard, 268 strong and visiting from South Dakota, would discover one of the citys timeless challenges.

title: In Bangladesh, Picking Through the Pieces
description: KHATACHIRA, Bangladesh, Nov. 20  The wind whipped through the sky. The river swelled above the tree line. And in a flash, Mamataz Begums youngest child, barely 2 years old, was swept from her arms, as a tidal wave smashed through the fragile mud homes of this village and scooped up everything in its watery arms.

title: China Wins Trade Ruling About Paper
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  In a setback for American producers fighting Chinese imports, a federal trade panel ruled Tuesday against the American glossy paper industrys request for tariffs on imported Chinese paper. The decision threw out duties that had been authorized by the Bush administration early this year.

title: Pale Gray or Light Yellow? A Ruling on Guggenheim
description: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum will remain light gray.

title: Manhattan: Population Milestone
description: New York Citys population has passed another milestone, officially topping 8.25 million. The Census Bureau originally reported that from mid-2005 to mid-2006, the population grew by a statistically insignificant 587 people, with gains in Manhattan and Staten Island. But the Department of City Planning challenged the census count, drawing on construction permits and other documents. Yesterday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced that the bureau had concurred that the citys official count was 8,250,567, up more than 36,000 since the adjusted 2005 total. The mayor said the revisions would mean an additional $77 million in federal aid to the state by the end of the decade.

title: Gleefully Upsetting the Artistic Apple Cart
description: Spoiler alert: The hero dies at the end, but shed no tears. Modernism, the artistic revolution that began with the poetry of Charles Baudelaire in the 1840s and quietly expired in the 1960s with Andy Warhols Brillo boxes, enjoyed a good long run. So Peter Gay concludes in the final sentence of Modernism: The Lure of Heresy From Baudelaire to Beckett and Beyond, his sweeping survey of the poets, playwrights, painters and architects who set out to rewrite the rules of art, transform consciousness and, wherever and whenever possible, shock the complacent middle class.

title: Loan Crisis Entangles Freddie Mac
description: Losses at Freddie Mac underscored the continuing turmoil in the housing industry yesterday, and other developments reinforced the sense that conditions would not improve soon.

title: Diplomacy Entails Compromise, Our U.N. Envoy Says
description: To the Editor:

title: The Drug War Continues
description: To the Editor:

title: Goldman Sachs Starts Drive to Build Philanthropy Fund
description: On the back of record profit so far this year, Goldman Sachs, the global investment bank, is starting a donor-driven philanthropy fund that aims to reach $1 billion over the next few years.

title: Brothers Are Tied to Home, No Matter Where They Run
description: BIG STONE GAP, Va., Nov. 16  The story of the brothers Jones, who once shared a bunk bed and now share a job title, starts in this sliver of southwest Virginia in the heart of coal country.

title: Gates Halts Cut in Army Force in Europe
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates has decided to freeze plans for further reducing Army forces in Europe and will maintain about 40,000 soldiers in Germany and Italy, nearly twice as many as had been envisioned under a drawdown that began two years ago, according to senior Pentagon and military officials.

title: For Edwards, a Marriage Made in Politics That Never Quite Fit
description: John Edwards, accepting his partys nomination for vice president, roused a cheering crowd at the 2004 Democratic convention with the kind of buoyant refrain that had become his trademark: Hope is on the way.

title: Cave May Hold Secrets to Legend of Ancient Rome
description: ROME, Nov. 20  Italian archaeologists have inched closer to unearthing the secrets behind one of Western civilizations most enduring legends.

title: Charges of Traitor for Chvez Ally Turned Critic
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 18  For years before rising to power here, President Hugo Chvez conspired alongside Ral Isaas Baduel, who recently retired as army commander, in a secretive cell of leftist military officers intent on fomenting revolution. It was General Baduel who led the paratrooper raid that returned Mr. Chvez to office after he was briefly deposed by a coup in 2002.

title: A Pianists Tour of Styles, From Weighty to Delicate
description: Competitions are now so plentiful as to be meaningless, the large ones as well as the small. Or at any rate, they have become useless at the business of star-making, and the most famous of them are scarcely better than the most obscure. They are, however, a part of the musical ecology. For young performers building their repertories and looking for performance opportunities, they offer chances to play for particularly nerve-racking audiences (juries), and the prospect of walking off with some cash and a few underwritten concerts.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article in some editions yesterday about lower estimates of the number of H.I.V. infections worldwide misstated a researchers explanation for a drop in infection rates in some African countries. The researcher, Daniel Halperin of the Harvard School of Public Health, said surveys indicated that people in Kenya and Zimbabwe chose to have fewer sexual partners rather than to use condoms more often. He did not mention circumcision to prevent AIDS as a consideration in those countries.

title: Milo Radulovich, 81, Dies; Symbol of 50s Red Scare
description: Milo Radulovich, who became a searing symbol of the excesses of anti-Communism in the 1950s when Edward R. Murrow broadcast an account of his firing as an Air Force reserve officer because of his relatives associations, died Monday in Vallejo, Calif. He was 81.

title: Recipe: Turkey Artichoke Omelet Adapted from Mr.Breakfast.com
description: For the sauce:

title: U.S. Accuses Iraqi Photographer of Aiding Rebels
description: The American military is sending an Iraqi photographer for The Associated Press it accuses of aiding the insurgency into Iraqs criminal justice system, according to the American authorities and The A.P.

title: A Modest Victory for Transit Riders
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer called on the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday to keep the basic subway and bus fare at $2. It is good that he has weighed in against the M.T.A.s plan to raise the fare to $2.25  and that the authority has just found a windfall of $220 million that it is committing to holding down fares and tolls. That does not mean that riders should start a conga line on the A train just yet. Even if the $2 fare is saved, riders who get discounts through multiple-use MetroCards should still brace themselves for a hit in the wallet.

title: Eat, Drink, Pretend to Care About the Games
description: The Super Bowl is the National Football Leagues yearly orgy of capitalism, but the role that the league plays in our Thanksgivings is perhaps even more vital: It allows us, mercifully, a few precious minutes away from our extended family. (Or at least something else to talk about besides than Aunt Carlas drinking.) We tend to remember the great Thanksgiving game moments  the famous coin flip fiasco of 1998, Leon Letts brain-dead blocked field goal kick in the snow in 1993  even better than we remember playoff games.

title: Man Arrested in the Killing of a Dentist
description: It was a crude device, a silencer fashioned from a plastic bleach bottle wrapped in duct tape and left behind among the leaves in a Queens playground where a 34-year-old orthodontist was shot and killed as his estranged wife and 4-year-old daughter looked on.

title: Moving on, a Step at a Time
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  After back surgery over the summer left him without feeling in his right foot, Ohio State Coach Thad Matta has still not adjusted to life with limited mobility.

title: Dissents, Strongly Issued
description: With screenwriters and Broadway stagehands on strike, you might expect the spoken words of 1930s union organizers to land with an extra, galvanizing layer of meaning. But Rebel Voices, the Culture Projects staged reading of monologues from the disenfranchised, is so flat and earnest that it seems detached from the moment even when it should speak eerily to the present.

title: Labor Group Says St. Patricks Sells Sweatshop Goods
description: A workers rights group yesterday accused St. Patricks Cathedral of selling religious items made under terrible conditions in sweatshop factories in China.

title: Ian Smith, Defiant Symbol of White Rule in Africa, Is Dead at 88
description: Ian Smith, the former prime minister of Britains rebellious colony of Rhodesia, who once promised that white rule in Africa would endure for 1,000 years, died yesterday in South Africa. He was 88.

title: Musharraf Meets With Saudis to Discuss What to Do With One of His Rivals
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 20  In his first trip out of the country since declaring emergency rule, the Pakistani president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, arrived in Saudi Arabia on Tuesday to discuss the future of one of his main political rivals, former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, who lives in exile there.

title: Majoring in Mailroom Management
description: LOS ANGELES  There was the ant farm, the air-conditioner, the barbecue grill. Then there was the chalk, pool cues and pool balls, and the car tires and a bumper.

title: Lowell Opts for Comfort and Stays With Red Sox
description: Mike Lowell wanted to keep playing third base for the Boston Red Sox, but he also wanted a four-year deal. The Red Sox wanted to re-sign Lowell, but they did not want to give him a contract for more than three years.

title: Khmer Rouge Figure Appears in Court
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Nov. 20  More than 28 years after the killing stopped, the first Khmer Rouge defendant stepped into a public courtroom on Tuesday to answer for the deaths of 1.7 million people  a tiny, self-effacing man who once commanded an efficient and ruthless torture house.

title: Bridge World Brouhaha Ends With a Statement, Not Punishment for Players
description: The United States Bridge Federation has dropped its effort to punish six members of the womens championship bridge team for holding up a sign that said We did not vote for Bush during an awards ceremony last month in Shanghai.

title: Polygamist Sentenced to 10 Years in Prison
description: ST. GEORGE, Utah, Nov. 20  The polygamous leader of a fundamentalist Mormon sect was sentenced Tuesday to 10 years to life in prison for forcing a 14-year-old girl to spiritually marry her 19-year-old cousin and commanding the nave bride to submit to sexual relations against her will.

title: Ex-Alabama Star Survives
description: A van driven by the former Alabama star running back Siran Stacy was struck by a pickup truck at an intersection in Dothan, Ala., late Monday. Six people were killed, including Stacys wife and four of his children, the police said. The driver of the second vehicle was also killed. The police said the pickup was on the wrong side of the four-lane road when it struck Stacys van on the passenger side.Stacy, 39, the first pick of the Philadelphia Eagles in the 1992 draft, was listed in stable condition in surgical intensive care in Dothan. His 3-year-old daughter, Shelly, was taken to Childrens Hospital in Birmingham, which did not release her condition.The victims were identified as Stacys wife, Ellen Stacy, 36; their children, Lequisa, 18; Bronson, 10; Sidney, 8; and Ellie, 2; and the other driver, Adam W. Wayman, 29.

title: Zeppelin Concert Is on Track
description: Jimmy Page, the Led Zeppelin guitarist, said that a broken finger on his left hand was healing well and that he was confident of performing in a reunion concert on Dec. 10, rescheduled from November, Reuters reported yesterday. Its going to be fine for the concert, Mr. Page, 63, said. Led Zeppelin is getting back together to take part in a benefit concert to raise money for the Ahmet Ertegun Education Fund, named for the record executive who originally signed them in 1968; Mr. Ertegun died on Dec. 14. Demand for tickets was so great that the concert Web site, ahmettribute.com, crashed. One fan paid 83,000 pounds ($170,000) for two tickets in a charity auction.

title: Southeast Asian Pact Exposes Rifts
description: SINGAPORE, Nov. 20  Southeast Asian leaders signed a charter here on Tuesday that was drafted as a watershed document to bind the region together in a European-style economic community, but the pact has instead exposed the sharp divisions over one of its members, Myanmar.

title: Broadway Visitors Find Other Games in Town
description: Last weekend, as Broadways strike talks resumed, there was a surge of optimism among theatergoers in New York and around the nation. When talks faltered on Sunday night, that optimism died.

title: Battlestar Goes Boldly Into the DVD Universe
description: Forget the robot killers with machine guns built into their arms. The DVDs are taking over.

title: California Sues a Voting Machine Maker Over Changes
description: The California secretary of state, Debra Bowen, filed a lawsuit yesterday against a voting machine manufacturer for the reported sale of uncertified machines to five counties in northern California.

title: U.S. and Iranian Officials Plan Talks on Iraqi Security
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 20  On a day of scattered violence across Iraq, American and Iranian officials said they would meet for a fourth round of talks aimed at stabilizing the security situation here.

title: Rollins Tops Holliday to Win M.V.P.
description: Jimmy Rollins predicted before the season that his Philadelphia Phillies would be the team to beat in the National League East, which proved true as they won the division. Rollins neglected to predict that he would win the Most Valuable Player award along the way, but that happened, too.

title: The Peppers Claim Californication for Themselves
description: The Red Hot Chili Peppers are suing Showtime Networks over the new television series Californication, which is also the name of the bands 1999 album and one of its songs, The Associated Press reported yesterday. The lawsuit, filed on Monday, states that the title is immediately associated in the mind of the consumer with the Chili Peppers. Additionally, the series, starring David Duchovny, features a character named Dani California, which is also the title of a Red Hot Chili Peppers song released in 2006, the lawsuit noted. The suit also names the shows creator and executive producer, Tom Kapinos, and two production companies, Twilight Time Films and Aggressive Mediocrity Inc. The suit seeks a permanent injunction barring Showtime and the other defendants from using Californication for the shows title, as well as other penalties.

title: BlackRock Is Likely to Lead Banks Safety Net Fund
description: BlackRock, the big investment firm, is expected to be the main asset manager for a $75 billion fund being created by three large banks to help shore up the market for asset-backed securities, a person briefed on the situation said late yesterday.

title: Artist at Work: Taste if You Dare
description: ALTHOUGH restaurant reviewers often have to divine a chefs thinking, Sam Mason has spared us the effort. Hes spelled out his mind-set in big letters on a page of the publicity materials for his new restaurant, Tailor.

title: Dining Briefs
description: NEW PLACES

title: Wharton Letter Reopens a Mystery
description: Literary biography is never finished, Hermione Lee, the Goldsmiths professor of English at Oxford and author of acclaimed books about Virginia Woolf and Edith Wharton, said the other day. New information keeps turning up. In the case of Wharton, what has just turned up is a letter that casts new light on the vexing question of what exactly happens at the end of her 1905 novel, The House of Mirth. Does Lily Bart, the novels heroine, kill herself or die of an accidental overdose?

title: How to Improve Your Prospects
description: If you are going to check bags this holiday season, a few suggestions:

title: ABC Dances to the Top
description: Mondays semifinal installment of Dancing With the Stars lifted ABC to an easy victory in the nights ratings. Nielsen estimated that 23.1 million viewers tuned in to the competition from 8 to 9:30, the most since its fall finale last November. That helped ABCs Samantha Who, which followed, draw its biggest audience, 15.4 million viewers. CBS ranked second for the night, leading the 10 oclock hour with CSI: Miami (16.2 million). In third place over all, NBC benefited from Chuck, which delivered its largest audience in five weeks (7.8 million). Among adults 18 to 49, Chuck finished in a virtual tie for second at 8 oclock, with CBSs comedies in the hour, How I Met Your Mother (8.5 million) and The Big Bang Theory (8 million). Fox ranked fourth over all.

title: Teaching English to the Visually Impaired
description: Jacqueline Suh teaches English at the Guild for the Blind.

title: Slaughter on Parade, Without Joystick
description: Based on the video game franchise of the same title, Hitman exploits every action-flick clich imaginable and still manages to be dull. Its bang, boom, blah  action movies for bored dummies.

title: Irving Bluestone, 90, Top U.A.W. Negotiator, Dies
description: Irving Bluestone, chief negotiator for more than 400,000 workers at General Motors in the 1970s and an advocate of worker participation in management, died on Saturday at his home in Brookline, Mass. He was 90.

title: From an Artist Who Wears Many Hats, a Recital of 20th-Century Works
description: As with the work of any living composer, people are bound to have varied reactions to Thomas Adss music. But no one can fairly question that this 36-year-old Englishman is among the most accomplished all-around musicians of his generation.

title: In New Orleans, a Test of Mixed-Income Housing
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 15  Despite the havoc wrought by Hurricane Katrina around this city, one slice of the devastated housing market is showing resurgence. The multifamily sector is more active than it has ever been, with nearly 5,400 units being created or undergoing major rehabilitation, according to a recent brokers report covering rental apartment complexes with 100 units or more.

title: Three Sentenced in Death of Gay Man
description: In a case that put sexual identity, hatred and ultimately forgiveness in leading roles, three men were sentenced to prison yesterday for their roles in chasing a gay man to his death in highway traffic in Brooklyn last year.

title: No Longer Wearing Two Hats
description: Lloyd Carr resigned this week as the University of Michigan football coach, prompting Josh Tyrangiel to wonder whether he might have one of the last pieces of autographed merchandise from Carrs 13-year tenure in Ann Arbor. It came into his possession unexpectedly, after Carr sent an e-mail to Tyrangiel praising his article, A House Divided, in the November issue of PLAY. In it, Tyrangiel chronicled his extended familys Civil War over the Michigan-Ohio state rivalry and his own conversion to Wolverine fever after years of neutrality.

title: As a Life Is Celebrated, a Death Is Questioned
description: Not a whole lot was said about Khiel Coppins life at his funeral yesterday.

title: Totals
description: Previously recorded $2,257,285.28

title: Knicks Start Marbury, but Nothing Changes
description: After another night of disjointed, distressing basketball, not to mention boos, taunts and chants, Isiah Thomas found a new person to blame last night.

title: Jim Ringo, Pro Football Hall of Fame Center, Dies at 75
description: Jim Ringo, an undersized center who played 15 seasons in the National Football League and was elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 1981, died Monday in Chesapeake, Va. He was 75.

title: A Zippy Update for a Mild-Mannered Standard
description: AS a child, whenever I wanted comfort food for dinner, I left the watercress-salad-and-fish confines of my parents kitchen and trotted down the block to the Coopers house.

title: Recipe: Wild Turkey Hash From Toppers at the Wauwinet on Nantucket
description: 1 shredded meat from 1 10- to 12-pound turkey

title: After the Meal, the Credit Card Scanner Is Served
description: THE waiter gives you the bill. You check it and then, right at the table, you swipe your credit card in a portable device. A receipt pops out, you sign it, and you are on your way.

title: A Stocking-Stuffer Idea: Lots of Old Resentments
description: In movies the holidays are a time when families come together, and a lifetime of secrets boil to the surface over a few short days.

title: Instead of Fighting Ad Leaks, Some Retailers Embrace Them
description: Every year, retailers denounce the renegade Web sites that prematurely disclose leaked copies of discount-filled advertisements for the day after Thanksgiving.

title: A 19th-Century Ghost Awakens to Redefine Soul
description: FOR nearly seven years Jan Longone, an antiquarian cookbook collector, has been haunted by a ghost. The spirit came into her life as thousands of other vintage volumes from book dealers had before: in a plain brown wrapper. But as soon as she held Malinda Russells Domestic Cook Book: Containing a Careful Selection of Useful Receipts for the Kitchen, she could see its author and her world  the small, seldom-discussed society of free blacks in the 19th century  coming to life before her eyes.

title: Making Social Connections and Selling Cookies
description: FOR decades, Nabisco has sold cookies called Social Tea and crackers called Sociables. Now a competitor, Pepperidge Farm, is going all social, too, by entering the increasingly popular field known as social media with a Web site devoted to social networking.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,864 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Renewable Electricity
description: To the Editor:

title: A Prophet With a Lot of Support
description: When you remember the House of Windsors origins, it is easier to accept that the British choral tradition also has a couple of Germans as its bedrock. Handel turned to oratorios in the first part of the 18th century, and if his operas dropped out of sight until relatively recently, Messiah has ruled the world uninterrupted.

title: Manhattan: Contractor Guilty of Fraud
description: Tri-Built Construction, a New York drywall contractor, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court to conspiring to defraud the carpenters union.. Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, said the two owners, Patrick N. McCaul and James D. McGonnell, had diverted at least $6.5 million from the unions benefit funds. They face up to five years in prison and agreed to forfeit $1.5 million.

title: Berkeleys Wine Radical, 35 Years Later
description: BERKELEY, Calif.

title: Manhattan: H & M Workers Organize
description: The Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union announced yesterday that it had organized more than 1,000 employees at nine H & M stores in Manhattan. Stuart Appelbaum, the unions president, said the sales clerks, cashiers and other workers unionized through an expedited process.

title: Recipe: Turkey Potpie With Chipotle and Cheese Sticks Crust
description: 1 quart low-sodium chicken stock or broth

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING | EUROPE: Germany: Inflation Indicator Rises
description: German producer-price inflation, an early indicator of price pressures in the economy, accelerated more than economists expected in October after the price of oil rose to a record and the cost of food surged. Prices for goods ranging from newsprint to plastics climbed 1.7 percent from a year earlier after rising 1.5 percent in September, the Federal Statistics Office said. Economists had expected a 1.6 percent gain. Price pressures are now definitely building up, said Rainer Guntermann, an economist at Dresdner Kleinwort in Frankfurt.

title: Singing About Dark Emotions, but Keeping Things Upbeat
description: Not far into his briskly energetic show at the Nokia Theater on Monday night, Caetano Veloso revisited a song from the early 1970s, the phase in his career when he was more of an upstart than an eminence. It was Nine Out of Ten, a product of his exile in London after running up against political pressures in Brazil; its lyrics, in English, celebrate the sound of music banging in my belly, with a spirit of wonder appropriate to the age.

title: Recalling the New Deal: What Government Can Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Will The Grinch Escape a Strike? Ask the Judge
description: And on the 11th day, they went to court.

title: Wiretap Issue Leads Judge to Warn of Retrial in Terror Case
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  A federal judge warned Tuesday that if the government did not allow lawyers to review classified material on possible wiretapping of an Islamic scholar convicted of inciting terrorism, she might order a new trial for him.

title: Merrill Fires Executive in Asian Unit
description: Merrill Lynch ousted the co-head of its Asian fixed-income business yesterday amid a management shake-up after $8.4 billion of losses on subprime mortgage-related securities and bad loans.

title: Soon the Bread Will Be Making Itself
description: I THOUGHT the Dining section published the easiest bread recipe possible last year when Mark Bittman wrote about the no-knead approach of Jim Lahey, owner of Sullivan Street Bakery.

title: Turkey Again, Thanks to the Italians
description: TO the long and ever-growing list of things you can do with leftover turkey, you can add a hearty, pleasant and easily made barley risotto.

title: Plant Approved, With Carbon Study
description: The Indiana Utility Regulatory Commission approved Duke Energys application yesterday to build a new coal-fired power plant, and ordered the company to submit a plan within six months on how to capture some of the carbon dioxide it would produce.

title: City Police Stop Whites Equally but Frisk Them Less, a Study Finds
description: Whites and members of minorities have a roughly equal chance of being stopped by police officers and questioned on the street in New York City. But officers are more likely to frisk, search or arrest black and Hispanic people -- or to use force against them -- according to a study released yesterday.

title: In Florida, Bear Tracks Everywhere
description: If youre hunting for Golden Bear tracks  that is, a sampling of Jack Nicklauss course designsyou will surely bag your limit along Floridas Gold Coast, where Nicklaus has resided since the early 1970s. Nicklauss design style is on display across Palm Beach County, where he has constructed more than a half-dozen courses. So is his largesse: Jacks gift to his adopted hometown was to reconfigure its tired muni into a local treasure  North Palm Beach Country Club  and he did it for the princely design fee of $1. Reopened in November 2006, the rolling, 7,100-yard layout boasts two holes along the Intracoastal Waterway and a high season green fee thats well south of $100.

title: Recipe: Barley Risotto With Turkey and Mushrooms
description: 4 tablespoons butter or extra virgin olive oil, or a combination

title: Lottery Numbers
Obama Feels the Chill
description: To the Editor:

title: Coaching Timetable
description: If Les Miles, the coach of the top-ranked L.S.U. Tigers, wants the open job at Michigan, his alma mater, when should he announce his interest? Now, so that the speculation doesnt hang over the two schools? Or after the Tigers bowl game?

title: Debating Iraqs Transition
description: Watching Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice making repeated trips to Israel to try to broker some kind of deal between Israelis and Palestinians, while Iraq remains politically unresolved, leaves me feeling like my house is burning down and the fire department has decided to stop along the way to get two cats out of a tree.

title: Near St. Louis, Where a Game Is More Than a Game
description: KIRKWOOD, Mo., Nov. 19  For much of the past week, students in Tom OTooles home maintenance class at Webster Groves High School have immersed themselves in the precise dismantling of wooden pallets. The goal is to create the perfect Thanksgiving Day pep rally bonfire.

title: Queens: Toddler Falls to His Death
