description: A 2-year-old boy died yesterday after falling six stories from a window in his familys apartment in Rego Park, the police said. The police did not release the childs name. His mother, Sandra Perez, said he had crawled out the window while she was taking a shower, a law enforcement official said. The boy fell shortly after 8 a.m., the police said, and he was pronounced dead at Elmhurst Hospital Center at 8:45.

title: A High School Struggles With Surprise Students
description: Several weeks ago, Cristal Urena proposed what should have been the most prosaic of activities. As the student government president at Beach Channel High School in Rockaway Park, Queens, she asked the administration to allow an after-school dance in December to celebrate the coming holidays.

title: Kohlberg Hires Deal Adviser to Be Top Lawyer
description: The private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has hired as general counsel the lawyer who worked on several of its biggest deals, an indication that it may be moving ahead with plans to go public.

title: Annapolis and the Mideast Divide
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Agency Denies Inflating Cases of H.I.V. Deliberately
description: After releasing new figures showing that the global AIDS epidemic is smaller than it previously reported, the United Nations AIDS-fighting agency denied yesterday that it had inflated estimates for years in an alarmist effort to raise funds.

title: Behind Wheels of Black Cabs, Mostly White Faces
description: LONDON, Nov. 20  As many tourists know from personal experience, London taxi drivers like to point out that unlike other cabbies, they actually know where they are going.

title: New Jersey Senator Urges Delay on Repeal of Death Penalty
description: TRENTON, Nov. 20  The leading social conservative in the New Jersey State Senate, Gerald Cardinale, accused Democrats on Tuesday of trying to rush a bill repealing the death penalty through the Legislature without sufficient deliberation.

title: Marbury-Thomas Struggle Has No Winner
description: Can the point guards latest exasperating power struggle with yet another beleaguered coach be having the same effect on Isiah Thomass Knicks as it had on Larry Browns?

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING | EUROPE: Switzerland: U.S. Approves Spinal Treatment
description: Synthes, the worlds largest maker of devices to mend broken and malformed bones, won approval in the United States for a new spinal fusion strip. The synthetic ceramic bone graft substitute, called Chronos, is used to fill gaps in bones that result from surgery or traumatic injury, the company said. Synthes, based in Oberdorf, Switzerland, expanded its range of spinal products this month by purchasing the closely held N Spine, based in San Diego. This new biomaterial offers surgeons increased handling options, Synthes said.

title: Thompson Wants Corporate Tax Cut
description: The Republican presidential candidate Fred D. Thompson said the top federal tax rate for corporations should be cut, to 28 percent from 35 percent to help keep companies competitive with those in other nations. We have the second highest tax rate in the industrialized world," said Mr. Thompson, a former senator from Tennessee. I look at our international competitors and see that 28 percent would be the norm. He said he did not support proposals in Congress to lower the corporate tax rate in exchange for eliminating the tax breaks some companies enjoy. Mr. Thompson said he would release a plan outlining changes in tax policy in the next few days.

title: Building a Clear Vision of Independence
description: Sitting in his living room in the Bronx on a recent afternoon, Jesus Pamias demonstrated his ability to read using a closed-circuit television, though he is legally blind. The device, which magnifies text on a monitor, helps Mr. Pamias, 47, to maintain a hard-won sense of independence.

title: Hollywood and Strikers Watch Clock
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 20  Sun Tzu, the Chinese sage, warned of the danger in prolonged conflict. Let your great object be victory, not lengthy campaigns, he wrote in The Art of War.

title: As French Strikes Grow, Sarkozy Speaks
description: PARIS, Nov. 20  President Nicolas Sarkozy urged transit workers to end their weeklong strike over pension benefits on Tuesday as civil service employees, including primary school teachers, firefighters, newspaper printers and weather service employees walked out in a separate dispute over job cuts.

title: Make It an Early Bird
description: Charlottesville, Va.

title: Limiting Powers Natural Tendency
description: After a long and frightening period of acquiescence, Congressional Democrats are standing up to President Bushs assault on civil liberties  demanding an end to spying on Americans without court supervision.

title: Greeks Charge Ministry Employee
description: Greek police arrested a culture ministry employee after discovering dozens of ancient Greek and Byzantine antiquities in his home, Reuters reported yesterday. The collection included 57 clay amphorae  ceramic storage vases  as well as bronze coins dating back as far as the fourth century B.C. and two Byzantine religious icons. He has been taken to the prosecutor to be charged with antiquities theft, a police official said. The ministry worker told police the antiques had been passed down to him by his grandfather, the police said. The ministry in recent years has conducted vigorous searches for ancient artifacts in museums and elsewhere that were illegally excavated and smuggled out of the country.

title: A Faded Downtown Gets Luxury Housing, but Retailers Stay Away
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 20  When Ray Schramm, who owned a wine shop in Pelham, explains why he left a dependable business and risked opening a trendy wine bar, the Gnarly Vine, in this shabby downtown, he points to two new towers soaring above the local skyline.

title: The Art of Hunting Deer the Old-Fashioned Way
description: ARCADE, N.Y.  Thomas Aquinas Daly, wielding a slender stick as straight as a conductors baton, pointed out a bright droplet of blood splashed across a yellow maple leaf. She went off the trail again, he muttered, hunched over and resting his palms on his knees. No wonder we didnt find blood where weve been looking.

title: Recipe: Kerry Morans Turkey Gobbler Frittata With Red Pepper Pure
description: 3 red bell peppers for sauce

title: Heartbreak and Healing, Sometimes Both at Once
description: From the moment Barbara Cook planted herself on stage at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday evening and sang Lucky to Be Me, a blissfully confident declaration of well-being from On the Town, it was obvious that Ms. Cook, who celebrated her 80th birthday on Oct. 25, meant every word. I could laugh out loud became a whoop of joy. The concert found this Broadway lyric soprano not only alive and kicking but in great voice and the best physical shape (trimmer, walking without support and breathing easily) than Ive seen her in many years.

title: John D. Rock, Former G.M. Executive, Is Dead at 71
description: DETROIT, Nov. 20  John D. Rock, a blunt-talking General Motors executive who tried unsuccessfully to save the Oldsmobile division, died Friday in Hot Springs, S.D. He was 71.

title: Weather and Preparation Ease Holiday Travel
description: The annual American rite of Thanksgiving travel has begun, with millions of people escaping some of the driving and flying delays that have become as much a part of the holiday as overeating and family tension.

title: Wanted: Participants for Mideast Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  The Bush administration finally acknowledged publicly on Tuesday that it had issued formal invitations to 40 countries and organizations that it hopes will attend a heavily anticipated Middle East peace conference scheduled for next week in Annapolis, Md. But the long, drawn-out route that State Department officials followed before making the acknowledgment reflected the high-stakes gamble that the administration is taking, as well as the unsettled nature of the outcome. Even late Tuesday afternoon, administration officials were still in negotiations with their Arab counterparts over whether Saudi Arabia and Syria would send their foreign ministers to the conference, or make do with lower-level envoys.

title: Justices to Decide on Right to Keep Handgun
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  The Supreme Court announced Tuesday that it would decide whether the Constitution grants individuals the right to keep guns in their homes for private use, plunging the justices headlong into a divisive and long-running debate over how to interpret the Second Amendments guarantee of the right of the people to keep and bear arms.

title: French Ban Britney Spears Video
description: Louis Vuitton, the luxury goods maker, has won a French lawsuit that contended that a music video by Britney Spears violated counterfeiting laws, The Associated Press reported. A Paris civil court ordered Sony BMG and MTV Online to stop broadcasting or marketing the video for Do Somethin and fined them 80,000 euros ($117,000) each, a spokeswoman for Louis Vuitton said on Monday. The ruling was issued last week. In the video, above, Ms. Spears appears in a pink Hummer; one shot shows fingers drumming on a dashboard upholstered with what looks like a Vuitton design, embossed with the LV logo. The ruling said the video constituted an attack on Louis Vuittons brands and its image, the spokeswoman said. It was not clear how the ban would be enforced, or whether the companies would appeal. The video was still on YouTube and other Web sites visible in France on Monday.

title: Fight to Keep a Language on the Stage
description: When the Israeli filmmaker Dan Katzir met Zypora Spaisman, the Polish-born Yiddish diva and onetime mainstay of the Folksbiene Yiddish Theater (today called the National Yiddish Theater-Folksbiene), the result was a project he had never planned to make.

title: Electronic Pioneer With Ties to Dance
description: The choreographer Merce Cunningham has played an invaluable role in fostering the creation of a substantial body of contemporary American music over the last half-century. Experiments in the Studio, a new series at Mr. Cunninghams West Village headquarters, is taking stock of that impetus through concerts largely devoted to composers who have been associated with the company. Gordon Mumma, who worked with Mr. Cunningham from 1966 to 1974, was the subject of the second installment, on Monday night.

title: Butchers Method Takes Carving Off the Table
description: BEFORE breakfast on Thanksgiving, as the first Americans rise to preheat the oven, the question of who is going to carve the bird starts to ripple anxiously across the land.

title: Book Award Finalists
description: The Costa book awards, formerly the Whitbread Awards, released this years short list in the fiction, first novel, biography, poetry and childrens book categories. Winners, announced on Jan. 3, receive 5,000 ($10,260) each. The Book of the Year, to be announced on Jan. 22, receives 25,000 ($51,303). Only books by writers based in England and Ireland are eligible. The fiction short list includes Skin Lane, by Neil Bartlett; Day, by A. L. Kennedy; Death of a Murderer, by Rupert Thomson; and The Road Home, by Rose Tremain.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A pop entry in the Week Ahead report in Arts & Leisure on Sunday misstated the dates for two concerts this week at Nokia Theater. Caetano Veloso ended its performance last night; it does not perform tonight and tomorrow. As noted, Youssou NDour performs tonight and tomorrow, but not on Friday.

title: Method Equalizes Stem Cell Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  It has been more than six years since President Bush, in the first major televised address of his presidency, drew a stark moral line against the destruction of human embryos in medical research.

title: Cuba: Critical Elections Called for January
description: Cuba will hold elections on Jan. 20 to choose delegates for provincial assemblies and the National Assembly, the official newspaper Granma reported, in what could be the next step toward formally ending President Fidel Castros 48-year rule. For Mr. Castro to continue as president, he must hold a seat in the National Assembly. It will be important to see if Fidels name appears on the ballot, said Jorge Pion, a senior researcher at Center for Hemispheric Policy at the University of Miami. This is key to whether he remains president. Mr. Castro, 81, handed interim power to his brother Ral, 76, after gastrointestinal surgery last year.

title: Clinton Takes On Republican Attack Machine
description: This television advertisement for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton began running yesterday in New Hampshire:

title: IPhone Must Be Offered Without Contract Restrictions, German Court Rules
description: PARIS, Nov. 20  Last month, French law forced Apple to promise that consumers could buy a version of its iPhone in this country without having to be locked into a long-term contract with Orange, the only mobile phone operator offering the new device.

title: The Court and the Second Amendment
description: By agreeing yesterday to rule on whether provisions of the District of Columbias stringent gun control law violate the Second Amendment to the Constitution, the Supreme Court has inserted itself into a roiling public controversy with large ramifications for public safety. The courts move sowed hope and fear among supporters of reasonable gun control, and it ratcheted up the suspense surrounding the courts current term.

title: Britain: 33 Years for Last Bomber in Failed 2005 Attacks
description: Manfo Kwaku Asiedu, a 34-year-old immigrant from Ghana who had admitted taking part in the botched July 21, 2005, suicide attacks on Londons transit system, was sentenced in London to 33 years in prison. He pleaded guilty this month to conspiracy to cause explosions. With his sentencing, all six men caught by the police for their part in the abortive plot are serving prison sentences. The cell planned to attack three trains and a bus. No one was hurt when the explosives failed to detonate completely.

title: Fed Expects Slowdown to Deepen
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  The Federal Reserve expects economic growth to slow sharply next year, and policy makers there are worried that even this forecast may prove too optimistic, according to an assessment that the central bank released on Tuesday.

title: Something Creepy This Way Creeps, and It Spells Bad News
description: Until the director Frank Darabont decides that hes saying something important instead of making a nifty horror movie, The Mist isnt half bad. In fact, until the monsters and the meaning start to emerge, this shivery story works your nerves far better than most recent horror does, largely because it knows that nothing scares moviegoers better than our own overactive, reactive imaginations. This is a film that knows how to make you jump in your seat simply by showing you next to nothing: It knows youll eagerly fill in the blanks all by your lonesome, genre-conditioned self.

title: Picasso Suit Rejected
description: A New York judge has ruled that the Andrew Lloyd Webber Art Foundation, owner of a Picasso painting, cannot be sued by a German collector who contended that the Nazis had forced his relative to sell the work, Bloomberg News reported yesterday. The foundation and Christies auction house withdrew the work from sale a year ago after the collector, Julius Schoeps, said it was forcibly sold by his great uncle, Paul von Mendelssohn-Bartholdy, a banker in Berlin. The foundation argued that Mr. Schoeps couldnt sue for restitution because he wasnt appointed to represent his relatives estate, and Justice Rolando T. Acosta of the State Supreme Court concurred. Christies had valued the 1903 Portrait of Angel Fernndez de Soto, above, at $40 million to $60 million. A Christies spokesman declined to say if the painting would now be auctioned. A lawyer for Mr. Schoeps did not immediately return a telephone call seeking comment.

title: North Babylon: Three Found Dead
description: Three people died and two others were sickened by fumes at a North Babylon home, the Suffolk County Police said. The police said the deaths may have been caused by carbon monoxide poisoning. The bodies of Ricardo Pearce, 27, Tanisha Armstrong, 25, and Talani Johnson, 4, were discovered at 437 Route 27 when officers responded to a 911 call. The police said they removed a generator and kerosene heater from the home.

title: Senator Decries Behavior at Jets Games
description: Richard J. Codey, the president of the New Jersey Senate, did not witness fans unruly behavior on a pedestrian ramp at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., when he attended the Jets-Steelers game on Sunday, but yesterday he emerged as the public official who seemed the most determined to crack down on the activities.

title: Is That Music We Hear or a Tykes Beating Heart?
description: To describe August Rush as a piece of shameless hokum doesnt quite do justice to the potentially shock-inducing sugar content of this contemporary fairy tale about a homeless, musically gifted miracle child. August Rush (Freddie Highmore) hears music everywhere. Whether its the wind in the grass or the roar of a subway, the sounds of the world are a symphony to his ears, and the movies soundtrack offers a Hollywood realization of a John Cage idea in which all sounds are music.

title: Calendar
description: Food on the Edge

title: Man Killed Fleeing Police After Botched Grenade Sale
description: An undercover operatives attempt to buy a hand grenade in the Bronx last night ended with the suspected seller being fatally shot in the head as he tried to drive away from law enforcement officers, the authorities said.

title: Deal Is Reached in New Orleans Bias Case
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 20  A multimillion-dollar race discrimination judgment that had threatened to shut down the district attorneys office here will be paid largely by the state and the city, officials announced here on Tuesday.

title: Shes No Morgenthau
description: WASHINGTON

title: Recipe: Apple-Fennel Soup
description: 3 apples (Granny Smith, Winesap, Cameo or Cortland)

title: Stalking the Placid Apples Untamed Kin
description: Geneva, N.Y.

title: Republican Rivals Continue Attacks on Immigration
description: The back and forth between Mitt Romneys and Rudolph W. Giulianis presidential campaigns over illegal immigration continued yesterday, with each side impugning the others record on the issue.

title: Strike News: Thousands Attend Hollywood Rally
description: Screenwriters, represented by the Writers Guild of America East and the Writers Guild of America West, took to the streets of Hollywood with supporters from other unions on Tuesday afternoon in a demonstration that was meant to telegraph resolve. The show was complete with a performance by Alicia Keys and the presence of eight aging actors who played Munchkins in The Wizard of Oz.

title: Bangladesh Struggles to Recover
description: Villagers try to pick up the pieces following the devastation of Cyclone Sidr.

title: Weekly Wrap: The Proper Way to Win?
description: The Fifth Downs contributors are Andrew Das, Benjamin Hoffman, Naila-Jean Meyers, John Woods and Toni Monkovic.

title: Wednesdays Links: All Over but the Winning
description: They are the new Evil Empire, these Patriots. Stealing a moniker hard-earned by the Yankees, perhaps even coveted by the Red Sox. New England runs up scores, it breaks records. Through it all, though, SI.coms Peter King reminds us that Patriots Coach Bill Belichick is only human. On the other hand, ESPN.coms Liz Merrill goes to great lengths trying to come to the same conclusion. I dont mean to condone gambling but it seems noteworthy to point out that the early line has the Patriots a 23.5-point favorite over the Eagles this week, the largest point spread for an N.F.L. game not involving an expansion team. And it could get larger if Donovan McNabb doesnt play. While were at it, Jackie MacMullan at the Boston Globe thinks there is something about the Patriots youve been overlooking. And, finally, heres this weeks Tom Brady Watch.

title: 'Late Titian'
description: Images from the exhibition at the Kunsthistorisches Museum in Vienna.

title: Light Touch
Cartoon Social Critic and Pain in the Butt
description: Meet Bottom-Biting Bug  a Japanese cartoon insect who bites rear ends and social consciences. The critters gone from an afternoon childrens television program to karaoke favorite to live stage show. Hes seen as a catalyst to end the everyday social isolation of Japanese:

title: Merrill Fires Executive in Asian Unit
description: Merrill Lynch ousted the co-head of its Asian fixed-income business Tuesday amid a management shake-up after $8.4 billion of losses on subprime mortgage-related securities and bad loans.

title: BlackRock Is Likely to Lead Banks Safety Net Fund
description: BlackRock, the big investment firm, is expected to be the main asset manager for a $75 billion fund being created by three large banks to help shore up the market for asset-backed securities, The New York Times reported.

title: SolFocus Adds $11.6 Million to the Pot
description: SolFocus has now raised a total of $63.6 million in series B funding to move into production of its solar power plants.

title: Newmont Plans Billion-Dollar I.P.O. for Franco-Nevada
description: The biggest stock introduction on the Toronto Stock Exchange so far this year was given the green light Tuesday, setting the stage for the billion-dollar rebirth of Franco-Nevada, the Canadian gold and energy royalty company sold to Newmont Mining in 2002.

title: Abu Dhabi Deal for PrimeWest Is Approved
description: The Canadian government has approved the takeover of the PrimeWest Energy Trust by Abu Dhabi National Energy, but National Energy, which is owned by the Abu Dhabi government, will face new federal hurdles in its Canadian acquisition spree.

title: British Brewer S&N May Break Up to Defeat Takeover Bid
description: Scottish & Newcastle s chief executive, John Dunsmore, has signaled he would consider a partial break-up of the company, the biggest brewer in Britain, to guard its independence.

title: News of Undervalued Bids Chips Away at Northern Rock Shares
description: The struggling British bank Northern Rock said it has received more rescue proposals, but warned that one of them contemplated an offer well below Tuesdays closing price, sparking a new slide in its shares on Wednesday.

title: Ahold Has Appetite for Deals
description: the Dutch supermarket group Ahold is on the lookout for acquisitions in the regions where it has operations, its chief executive said on Wednesday.

title: SuccessFactors Jumps 40% in Debut
description: Shares of SuccessFactors, a human-resources software provider, climbed nearly 36 percent in their first day of trading Tuesday after the companys initial public offering of 10.8 million shares priced at the high end of the expected range.

title: Shareholder Sues Bear Stearns Over Subprime Exposure
description: Bear Stearns, which expects a fourth-quarter loss after writing down $1.2 billion linked to mortgages, got hit with a shareholder lawsuit that claims it should have known it was overexposed to subprime lending.

title: More Deals Ahead for Software AG
description: After absorbing webMethods and seeing immediate returns from the deal, Software AG of Germany is shopping again.

title: Bank of America Continues Shuffling Its Investment Bank
description: The Bank of America has reshuffled its investment management arm, as it continues to sort out senior staff changes at its investment bank.

title: Candover Sells Nowegian Cable Firm for $1.1 Billion
description: The private equity arms of the Quadrangle Group and Goldman Sachs have agreed to acquire a Norwegian cable group, GET, for 5.8 billion Norwegian kroner ($1.1 billion) in a secondary buyout from Candover Investments of London.

title: Medingo Gets $27 Million Injection
description: Medingo, an Israeli medical device start-up, closed a first round of outside financing, raising as much as $27 million to support continued development and regulatory advancement of a patch pump to deliver insulin to patients with diabetes.

title: Hedge Fund Copper Arch to Liquidate, Reports Say
description: Copper Arch Capital, a New York-based hedge fund founded by Scott Sipprelle, a former banker at Morgan Stanley, is winding down operations, according to press reports.

title: Delta Pilots Union Criticizes Funds Merger Proposal
description: Delta Air Lines pilots union on Tuesday reiterated its deep hostility to a hedge funds recent proposal for a merger between Delta and the parent of United Airlines, UAL.

title: DP World Raises $4.86 Billion in I.P.O.
description: DP World, the Dubai-owned port operator with terminals from Britain to China, raised $4.96 billion in the Middle Easts biggest initial public offering ever.

title: Sears and the Return of the Strategic Bidder
description: If Sears Holdings, the parent of the retailers Sears and Kmart, decides to challenge Catteron Partners $366 million buyout of Restoration Hardware, it has a pretty good chance of winning, according to Breakingviews.

title: Former Citadel Trader Hangs His Own Shingle, Report Says
description: Anand Parekh, a former head equity trader at the Citadel Investment Group, is setting up his own hedge fund, according to Reuters.

title: Goldman Sachs to Build Philanthropy Fund
description: On the back of record profit so far this year, Goldman Sachs, the global investment bank, is starting a donor-driven philanthropy fund that intends to reach $1 billion over the next few years.

title: How Childs Play Can Shape Careers
description: In honor of Thanksgiving, Im giving you a career story that may inspire some indulgence around the holiday table. And a link to a funny video for dessert.

title: Gore May Still See Green From V.C. Firm
description: Al Gore made big news this month when he said he would join Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers as a partner focusing on clean-technology investments. At the time, much of the attention was focused on how he would donate his salary to a nonprofit advocacy group he founded.

title: Banks Fail to Sell $4 Billion of Chrysler Debt, Reports Say
description: Chryslers bankers failed to sell $4 billion of loans that backed the purchase of the automaker by Cerberus Capital Management , according to press reports.

title: The Early Word: Its All About Iowa
description: Most of the candidates are focusing on Iowa right now, and the states dedicated and not-so-dedicated voters. Lois Romano delves into the psyche of the fickle  or maybe just disenchanted  Iowa voter in todays Washington Post. She looks at the solidly conservative town of Le Mars, where caucus-goers dont feel strong loyalty toward any G.O.P. candidate, and frankly, they dont even know if theyll be caucus-goers, since the Orange Bowl will be held the same night as the Jan. 3 vote.

title: Law Firm Bonuses: The Last Hurrah?
description: Its a great time to be a young lawyer at a top firm. Or is it?

title: Oprah May Campaign for Obama
description: Barack Obama has been dropping hints for months that Oprah Winfrey would be going out on the campaign trail for him, and he hinted again yesterday, in comments overheard by the Chicago Sun-Times, that plans are in the works for her to start stumping for him in Iowa.

title: Making Every Step Count
description: Looking for a simple way to improve your health? Consider the lowly pedometer.

title: Investors Seem to Question Wisdom of 2 Jaguar Bidders
description: Buying Ford Motors premium Jaguar and Land Rover brands would catapult the Indian auto makers Tata Motors or Mahindra & Mahindra onto the global stage, but doubts that either company can successfully pull off such a deal are weighing on their share prices, Reuters said.

title: Will Preserving $2 Fare Help the M.T.A.s Image?
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzers announcement that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority had identified $220 million in unanticipated revenue and would use the money to keep the base subway and bus fare at $2 dominated local news coverage this morning.

title: They hate me! They really hate me!
description: Wow. Early in my tenure at The NYT, I was advised that its a bad idea to devote a column to attacking another columnist  not just at The Times, but anywhere. Why? Because it makes you look small  as if you have nothing better to do than snipe at other commentators, rather than trying to deal with real problems.

title: A Scrooges Thanksgiving
description: Thanksgiving: Great American Holiday, or The Greatest American Holiday? Writing on the op-ed page of The Wall Street Journal, Joseph Epstein appears to opt for the second choice. He writes: [$]

title: United May Throw Off Baggage to Fly Higher
description: Airline consolidation is a perpetual conversation topic in the industry, but analysts so far have dismissed the recent push to combine Delta Air Lines and UALs United Airlines.

title: Sad Songs: Warners Stock Hits New Low
description: The Eagles first studio album in 28 years, which topped the charts when it went on sale this month, features a single called How Long? But for the private equity backers of Warner Music Group, a more appropriate song title might be How Low?

title:
Living With Music:
A Playlist by Fernanda Eberstadt
description: On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for Living With Music, a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage.

title: Port Authority Braces for Record Air Travel
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is anticipating a record number of travelers  nearly 1.7 million  at its four major airports over the five-day holiday travel period that starts today and ends on Sunday.

title: Clips: L.A. Job Losses, NFL Offer, 30 Rock On Stage
description: A prolonged writers strike would translate into a loss of 15,000 jobs and $21.3 million a day in direct spending in Los Angeles, according to the nonprofit group FilmL.A., The Los Angeles Times reports. The conservative estimate doesnt include service industry jobs or the feature film sector.

title: Strike News: Shhhh! Show Runners Returning
description: Some of the powerful writer-producers, also known as show runners, who have withheld their services during the writers strike may be quietly returning to work.

title: Wednesday Morning Kickoff
description: If you think Miamis season was bad already, now the Hurricanes are being taunted by Donald Trump. It seems that Trump strongly recommended that Mike Leach be hired to replace Larry Coker, instead of Randy Shannon. The Palm Beach Posts Jorge Milan reports that Trump sent a letter this week to Miami President Donna Shalala saying she should have listened to him.

title: A look around the web and elsewhere
description: One thing I have been meaning to do as a regular feature since this blog started, but never got around to doing even once (I think), is to do a little roundup of news and views that appeal to me at other sites. So heres a glance at the latest talk on a few blogs and other sites:

title: Madame Bovary Deux Point Zero
description: This Thanksgiving, lets all be grateful that no one were in love with frequents AshleyMadison.com. On the other hand, at 9:44 on Wednesday morning, 4,451 people were on the site. And evidently 1.6 million people have signed up.

title: First Casualty of Britains Personal-Data Breach: Trust
description: When a senior American official marveled a few weeks ago about the publics willingness to trust green-card holders with their personal data, but not the government, one writer remarked that its hard to have too much confidence when the F.B.I. is busy losing laptops.

title: Apparently Torture Means Never Having to Say Youre Sorry
description: Maher Arar gained his expertise about Americas lawless program of extraordinary rendition the hard way.

title: Coaching Timetable
description: If Les Miles, the coach of the top-ranked L.S.U. Tigers, wants the open Michigan job, when should he announce his interest? Now, so that the speculation doesnt hang over the two schools? Or after the Tigers bowl game?

title: The New York Times  Building
description: Additional images of the new building.

title: The Restaurants the Chefs Visit
description: In the Chef Q and A features that this blog periodically runs, each chef is asked is to name the best New York City restaurant that no one talks about, with the qualification that he or she should try not to plug a friend.

title: Throwing Away Young People: Prison Suicide
description: The United States made a horrific mistake when it embraced the practice of holding young teenagers in adult jails, often in connection with minor crimes that never lead to conviction.

title: How Does President Vallone Sound?
description: He has one of the best-known family names in Queens politics. And, after years in the City Council, Councilman Peter F. Vallone Jr. says he is seriously considering running for borough president  though he is unlikely to have the field to himself.

title: An Angel in Queens
description: Thanksgiving may be the stuff of volunteerism, but for Jorge Muoz it's another night of serving dinners to immigrant day laborers in Queens.

title: Reaching for the Sky
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Not Exactly Netflix, But
description: The best part of Thanksgiving, some years, is crashing in front of a movie when youre too stuffed to do anything else.

title: Holiday Feasting Without the Cranberries
description: The healthiest food on the holiday menu may soon be in short supply.

title: Farms Grow More Expensive
description: The average price for U.K. farmland is rising at the fastest rate in 30 years, according to Knight Frank, the property company. Values jumped 33.2 percent in 2007, hitting 4,178 per acre in the third quarter (5,798), compared to 3,137 a year earlier (4,353).

title: A Father's Memorial to His Son
description: Al Petrocelli created a memorial in his front yard for his son, Mark, who died on Sept. 11, 2001, when he was 28.

title: Glaxo to Acquire Reliant for $1.65 Billion
description: GlaxoSmithKline has agreed to buy a privately held heart drug specialist, Reliant Pharmaceuticals, for $1.65 billion to restore its flagging drug sales in the United States.

title: Labor Strikes in France Continue
description: Roger Cohen, op-ed columnist for the International Herald Tribune, examines the motivations behind the labor strikes in France.

title: Strike News: Seth Meyers Brings It  Every Day
description: Seth Meyers favorite day of the writers strike was the first, as he and his Saturday Night Live colleagues gathered outside Rockefeller Center to picket. His least favorite day was the second, across the East River at Silvercup Studios in Queens.

title: Stopping the Unstoppable
description: As this years day of giving thanks approached, a thought occurred to me: Wouldnt it be a good idea to lend a helping hand to the beleaguered defensive coordinators who have found it more difficult to solve the Patriots offense this season than to crack the Navajo Code?

title: As Merrills Stock Falls, So Does Thains Hurdle
description: Merrill Lynchs stock changed hands at $50.50 late Wednesday morning, touching its lowest level in four years. This is painful news for Merrills shareholders. But, somewhat perversely, the decline, if it proves to be short term, could end up enriching the firms next chief executive, John A. Thain.

title: Come Fly With Me (and Me and Me and Me)
description: On one of the busiest days for air travel in the United States, I thought it would be worth a quick look at one of the more stunning recent visual depictions of the growing human imprint on the Earth  a set of animations built with data from a 24-hour stretch of air travel over the United States a couple of years ago. Watch how the pulses of flights build as dawn sweeps east to west.

title: Name Americas Most Liberal City
description: By now, its become part of the conventional wisdom that Rudolph W. Giuliani is both predicating much of his presidential candidacy on his two terms as mayor here and also running against New York City, as a symbol of American liberalism.In a new advertisement (as political blogs, including The New York Observers, have pointed out), Mr. Giuliani promotes his record on cutting crime, slashing welfare rolls and holding the line on taxes in New York City. The ad describes New York as Americas most liberal city.

title: Publisher Deflates Tantalizing Snippet on C.I.A. Leak
description: A 151-word excerpt from the memoir of Scott McClellan, chief spokesman to President Bush in 2006, was not meant to be as tantalizing as it sounded, according to the publisher of the book.

title: Mr. Whipple, R.I.P.
description: Dick Wilson, who died this week at 91, in his top Please, dont squeeze the Charmin form back in the 1960s:

title: When Bankers Go Abroad
description: For many bankers, Thanksgiving brings a welcome break from life on the road. Traveling abroad is often a job requirement in the deal-making business, especially as acquirers become more willing to cross borders in search of takeover targets. China, with its fast-growing economy, and the Middle East, bursting with petrodollars, are especially hot areas for deals these days.

title: Americas Most Liberal?
description: In his most recent campaign ad, Rudolph W. Giuliani continues his strategy of embracing New York City while also running against it.

title: Answers From Dai Qing
description: This afternoon we have answers to questions prompted by the fourth article in our series on Chinas environmental crisis, on the countrys attempt to use hydropower to meet some of it energy demands. Our expert today is environmental advocate Dai Qing, who has opposed the Three Gorges Dam project for two decades.

title: A Holiday Guide to Window Gazing
description: All week, major New York City department stores have been unveiling their decorated holiday windows, which by some estimates draw more than 6,000 viewers per hour at the peak of the season.

description: With only a week to go before the Republican CNN/YouTube debate next Wednesday, voters are lighting up the video site with serious and not-so-serious questions for the eight candidates.

description: Stick a Pitchfork in them: these music hipsters are done. Via College Humor, a sketch from the Australian series The Ronnie Johns Half Hour:

description: After they had lived in close proximity but never met, a friend and the 2005 transit strike brought Jessica Sheena and David Cohen together.

title: The Latest G.O.P. Foot Soldiers  The Homeless?
description: Republican operatives in California have cooked up a dirty trick that looks like an election reform measure. They are trying to put an initiative on the ballot to divide the states 55 electoral votes between the winner and loser in next years presidential race, replacing the current winner-take-all method.

title: Mr. Mayor, the Blogtalk Headline Contest Is Now Open
description: The parade weather is expected to be nice for Thanksgiving Day, but watch out for the balloon menace. [The Mayor of Television]

title: The Brothers Jones: 1 in 1 billion
description: For todays article on running backs Thomas and Julius Jones, I e-mailed an expert in probability to see if he could figure out the chances of having two brothers from a town of fewer than 6,000 residents both start in the N.F.L. at running back and play against each other on Thanksgiving.

title: A Thanksgiving Blessing
description: Or: Of Pilgrims and Portable Devices.

title: Refugees: More Good News From Iraq?
description: Reports that residents of Baghdad are seeing commerce and movement finally increase as violence has declined in the city provided the leading edge of an altogether sunny week for news out of Iraq.

title: Q & A: Giancarlo Giammetti
description: There are few people in the fashion world I like as much as Giancarlo Giammetti, Valentinos business partner and alter ego, even though we occasional disagree and he doesnt mince his words. Maybe thats the source of warmth. I remember his portrayal in Michael Specters 2005 profile of Valentino, which captured, I think, the dynamic between these glamorous figures and their extended family, as well as Giammettis frank personality. Some might call him politically incorrect. I dont think so. Anyway, what would you prefer? Giammetti and I met last week in his new apartment in New York. In January, of course, Valentino will retire.

title: The Spread: Spreading to the N.F.L.?
description: The daily transcripts from Bill Belichicks news conference that the New England Patriots send out are typically some of the most interesting things that pop up in my in-box every day. Belichick is often portrayed as dry and confrontational by those who cover the N.F.L. Since I dont, the transcripts are often some of the most insightful things I read about football. Belichick may not talk much about injuries or running up the score or whatever the P.T.I. topic da jour is, but he has an astonishing grasp of football and its history. Thats why I particularly enjoyed his take when the use of the spread offense in college football came up at his new conference today.

title: Now, Were Cooking
description: Hey!

title: GMAC May Seek Non-U.S. Mortgage Lender
description: Update: Reuters is reporting that the unidentified non-U.S. mortgage firm GMAC is considering pursuing is Northern Rock, the troubled British mortgage lender. Cerberus Capital Management, which is the majority owner of GMAC, reportedly has already bid for Northern Rock.

title: Putting the Atlantic Yards Arena in a Secure Place
description: Once the basketball arena at Atlantic Yards in Brooklyn gets built  assuming it does get built  it should be fairly obvious where it is. But until now, the precise location of where the arena is going to be has proved strangely elusive.The location matters, somewhat, because elected officials and opponents of the $4 billion Atlantic Yards project have raised questions about security at the site based on the arena setback. In Newark, where a new arena recently opened, that city decided at the last minute that at 20 feet from the curb, the arena was too close to the street for comfort, so now Newark closes streets around its arena during events.

description: Most of the Democratic candidates for president said today that they would skip the Dec. 10 presidential debate sponsored by CBS News if news writers decided to strike.

title: Ratings: House, Dancing And The Bachelors Final Rose
description: Charlie Brown and the semifinal results on Dancing With the Stars delivered solid ratings for ABC on Tuesday, but the shows were no match for the eccentric doctor on Fox. House earned the nights top ratings among adults 18 to 49, according to Nielsens estimates, making Fox first for the night in that demographic.

title: Strike News: Appearances On The View Canceled; CBS Debate Could Be Jeopardized
description: Less than a week after becoming the first candidate to visit the writers picket lines in Southern California, John Edwards and wife Elizabeth said today that they had canceled their scheduled appearance on the ABC talk show The View next week to honor the members of the Writers Guild of America.

Surprisingly, the toilets are attracting international attention.

Bloggers Henry Farrell, left, and Daniel Drezner, right, debate the glamorous new world of global philanthropy.

description: Hank Steinbrenner may have already decided the fate of Joba Chamberlain, but that doesnt mean we cant have some fun debating how the Yankees should use their gifted young right-hander.

description: We invite you to leave your responses to the Thursday, Nov. 22 column.

title: More Troubles for Mukhtar Mai
description: Word comes from Pakistan that Mukhtar Mai is up against tough times in the wake of the political crisis. Nick first wrote about her three years ago after she had been gang-raped on order of a local tribal council. Tradition in rural Pakistan would have had her commit suicide, but instead she prosecuted her attackers. She won her case and used the compensation money to start schools for girls. We visited her earlier this year in her village, Meerwalla.

title: Spared Cyclones Worst, Area Still Suffers
description: KANAINAGAR, Bangladesh, Nov. 21  To the naked eye, this looks like a village that Cyclone Sidr barely grazed. Most of the houses are standing. No one has died. The trees are not even decapitated, as they are in so many hamlets swallowed by the storm.

title: Uh-Oh, Knicks (2-9) Are Headed Home
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., Nov. 21  The Knicks will no doubt face a hostile crowd when they return home to Madison Square Garden to play the Bulls on Saturday. And no doubt the calls for team management to fire Coach Isiah Thomas will grow even stronger than they were during the Knicks 28-point loss to the Warriors on Tuesday.

title: YouTube, MySpace and Californias D.M.V.
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 21  As YouTube videos go, Kyles driving test has nothing on Gizmo, the toilet-flushing cat.

description: Off to See the Wizard, by Way of Hollywood

description: Packers at Lions

title: Sentencing Delayed for Steroid Distributor
description: The sentencing date for Kirk Radomski  the former Mets clubhouse attendant who earlier this year pleaded guilty to distributing steroids and has been cooperating with investigations by Major League Baseball and the federal government  has been pushed back for a third time.

title: Court Upholds $1 Billion Award to Motorola
description: Motorola, the largest American cellphone maker, may seek $1 billion in punitive damages from the former owners of a Turkish wireless carrier, a federal court ruled yesterday, rejecting claims that the former owners cannot afford to pay the amount.

title: Israel Allows Some Gaza Exports
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 21  Israel has approved the transfer of 25 armored personnel carriers from Russia to the Palestinian Authority and will allow the export of some agricultural produce from Gaza for the first time since Hamas took over the area, Israeli government officials said Wednesday.

title: Ms. Paulose Departs
description: While Alberto Gonzaless Justice Department was purging some of its most talented and upstanding prosecutors, it hired Rachel Paulose as United States attorney for Minnesota. Ms. Paulose was not qualified, but she did have the right political connections. The recent decision to remove her from the job is overdue and a hopeful sign that the new attorney general, Michael Mukasey, may be serious about fixing his department.

description: To the Editor:

title: Young Coach Aids Rebuilding at New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 21  On the morning of July 6, Buzz Williams resigned as the mens basketball coach at the University of New Orleans after one season.

title: As Conceptual Art Evolves, One Mission Is Unchanged: Keep Expanding the Possibilities
description: During Not for Sale: Conceptual Art and Dance in Visual Arts, a symposium last Saturday at the Judson Memorial Church on the final weekend of Performa 07, the Swedish artist Marten Spangberg addressed the need for performance that is not here to consolidate your identity, but offers the choice to lean forward  becoming oneself differently  to expand the possibilities of what one can be.

title: Lost, Found and Sold
description: A painting by the Mexican artist Rufino Tamayo that was found next to garbage bags on a Manhattan sidewalk four years ago sold for $1.049 million Tuesday at a Sothebys auction in Manhattan. An undisclosed American collector bought the work. Sothebys estimated that the 1970 canvas, Tres Personajes (Three People), above, could fetch $750,000 to $1 million, so the hammer price, $900,000, was considered a strong result. (The final price includes the auction houses commission.) The painting was purchased for $55,000 at auction in 1977 by a Houston man as a present for his wife, but disappeared after being placed in storage in a warehouse about a decade later. Then in 2003 Elizabeth Gibson, who was perusing trash on an Upper West Side sidewalk, spotted the canvas and took it to her apartment, little realizing that it was by a celebrated painter. The wife who received the painting in 1977 was the seller at auction, and gave Ms. Gibson a $15,000 reward; Sothebys also paid her a finders fee.

title: Canada to Announce Vast New Park
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 21  The Canadian government plans to announce today that it will convert 25.5 million acres of northern woodland into a new national park and wildlife protection areas.

title: Helping Fight a Battle for a Friend Who Cant
description: IRVING, Tex., Nov. 21  Every time Everson Walls sees his former Dallas Cowboys teammate Ron Springs, he flicks him on the forehead, slaps his cheeks, jabs at his jaw; anything to get a reaction.

title: List: New Bodies for Older Cars
description: HERE are some of the replacement bodies for classic cars and trucks offered by aftermarket suppliers.
