description: To the Editor:

title: Paul Wasserman, 73, Publicist to Rock Stars, Is Dead
description: Paul Wasserman, a publicist for the Rolling Stones, Bob Dylan, U2, the Who and other top musical acts whose career collapsed when he was caught using some of his famous clients names in a financial scheme, died on Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 73.

title: Citizen Vigilance Leads to Toy Recalls
description: When the Consumer Product Safety Commission ordered a recall of half a million pieces of lead jewelry yesterday, it had two unusual partners: Ward Stone and his 10-year-old daughter, Montana.

title: An In-Car Bluetooth Mini Device With Maxi Features
description: In-car Bluetooth devices  wireless systems for making and taking calls on the road without a headset  are a dime a dozen. There are all kinds on the market, from bulky visor-mounted gadgets to invisible factory-installed models. The Venturi Mini, however, is refreshingly different.

title: Lundqvist Lets Rangers Remain Hot on the Road
description: TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 21 (AP)  Henrik Lundqvist made 32 saves to lead the Rangers past the Tampa Bay Lightning, 2-1, on Wednesday night.

title: Berlin and Caracas Show New York a Thing or Two About Music Outreach
description: The main goal of Carnegie Halls Berlin in Lights Festival, which ended on Sunday, was to convey to concertgoers in the New York area what musical life in culturally diverse Berlin is like these days. We found out how the venerable Berlin Philharmonic is faring under the adventurous leadership of Simon Rattle. We heard leading Baroque, contemporary-music and chamber ensembles from Berlin. The vocalist Max Raabe, with his Palast Orchester, and the composer and chansonnier H K Gruber took us to the days of Weimar-era cabaret and theater music.

title: How to Keep the Juice Flowing
description: Q. I am using a Dell Inspiron laptop as my home desktop computer. Can I remove the battery? Is there a danger of a crash if a sudden power failure occurs?

title: Let Us Give Thanks. In Writing.
description: IT is Thanksgiving Day, the one day of the year when youre expected to be grateful.

title: Foreign Fighters in Iraq Are Tied to Allies of U.S.
description: BAGHDAD  Saudi Arabia and Libya, both considered allies by the United States in its fight against terrorism, were the source of about 60 percent of the foreign fighters who came to Iraq in the past year to serve as suicide bombers or to facilitate other attacks, according to senior American military officials.

title: Tip of the Week: Reading Long Files on Your iPod
description: Want to read long files on your iPod or iPod Nano, but cant get around the iPods 4-kilobyte size limit on text documents? Upload that hefty text or e-book file to the iPod eBook Creator site (snipurl.com/1tpx6) and get it back in a batch of linked 4K chunks. Copy those files into your iPods Notes folder and youve got a pocket book for the morning commute. You can find plenty of free e-book text files to download at Project Gutenberg (www.gutenberg.us).

title: Museum Official Charged With Theft
description: The former chief financial officer of the Bellevue Arts Museum in Washington State has been charged with embezzling $300,000, The Associated Press reported yesterday. King County prosecutors filed 38 counts of theft against Janet Ellinger, 53, of Redmond, Wash. They said that she stole the money from the museum from October 2005 to May 2007, and that she took most of it by writing checks to herself and then covering them up with false entries in the museums financial ledger. Prosecutors said that Ms. Ellinger told investigators she took the money because she was separating from her husband and felt financially compromised.

title: Friends Clash Reflects Battle Over Israeli Court
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 21  In recent days, Aharon Barak, the internationally esteemed jurist and retired chief justice of Israel, has broken a self-imposed silence and spoken publicly against an old friend, Daniel Friedmann, Israels minister of justice.

title: Togetherness Finally Arrives in the Form of Headphones That Double as MP3 Players
description: MP3 players have mostly left the heavy lifting of actually producing sound to speakers or headphones. Koss decided to mash the two together with its MP3 Tgo (as in to go), a pair of audiophile-style headphones with a built-in player.

title: At the Grown-Up Table
description: I am sitting at the northwest corner of my grandmothers table in a house on the edge of a small Iowa town. Im young enough to feel that my presence at the table is a promotion. Theres something bewildering in the passing of plates, the coming and going of serving dishes, and I can see  looking into this memory from a long ways away  that the adults at the table find my presence a little comical. It makes them speak to each other in asides and to me in a language that seems both ironic and slightly formal, as if I were an ambassador from the everyday planet of children to the special planet of Thanksgiving, where dinner is eaten at three.

title: Wizards Lose Arenas for Three Months
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Nov. 21 (AP)  Gilbert Arenas of the Washington Wizards had two surgical procedures on his left knee Wednesday and will miss about three months.

title: Western Union Empire Moves Migrant Cash Home
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21  To glimpse how migration is changing the world, consider Western Union, a fixture of American lore that went bankrupt selling telegrams at the dawn of the Internet age but now earns nearly $1 billion a year helping poor migrants across the globe send money home.

title: The Brightest Sellers Have the Biggest Prices
description: JESSICA and MELANIE McDONALD, sisters from Baltimore and cute as the proverbial button, were in Bloomingdales last Friday night. Shopping, what else?

title: Presidential Shopping List
description: I am making a list called Qualities We Dont Want in the Next President, based on lessons learned from the Bush administration. The first undesirable attribute was loyalty, in the sense of valuing personal relationships over competence. Really, we need to elect someone who would push his/her grandmother under a bus if she screwed up the mission.

title: Lottery Numbers
U.N. Extends Bosnia Peacekeepers
description: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 21 (Reuters)  The United Nations Security Council passed a resolution on Wednesday authorizing a European Union peacekeeping force in Bosnia for another year.

title: Nursing Home Operator in Connecticut Files for Bankruptcy
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 21  Amid accusations that it shortchanged patients while it was diverting millions of dollars to a country music label in Nashville, Connecticuts second-largest operator of nursing homes filed for bankruptcy protection this week along with dozens of its affiliates.

title: Publicity-Shy Giuliani Backer Is Thrust Into Spotlight
description: Paul E. Singer is the founding partner of one of the oldest hedge funds around. And while he has become a major donor to Republican and conservative causes in recent years, he has largely managed to stay out of the limelight, even avoiding having his picture appear in newspapers.

title: Just Think of Them as Medals
description: APART from the great debate on the significance of sporting an American-flag pin (Barack Obama reportedly finds them phony; Rudolph Giuliani wont leave home without one), lapel pins dont get much attention. And unless its the Lgion dHonneur, they get even less respect.

title: Woman Burned in Explosion at Queens Home
description: An explosion rocked a Queens home yesterday afternoon and badly burned one of its residents as firefighters and utility crews were searching for the source of a natural gas leak wafting through the neighborhood.

title: Stocks Plummet on Ugly Week for Investors
description: A late sell-off sent stock markets down sharply yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing at its lowest level since April. The plunge came as investors remain frightened and uncertain about a credit crisis that does not show any signs of easing.

title: Rice Defends Mideast Peace Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21  The Bush administrations Annapolis, Md., conference on Middle East peace will tackle the entrenched core issues that have bedeviled negotiators since 1979, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said on Wednesday, pushing back against critics who say the conference may be just a photo opportunity.

title: Genuine Wonders From the Flea Circus: Photos by Arbus
description: We had our awe and our shame in one gulp, Diane Arbus wrote of watching the assorted freaks and sideshow performers who populated Huberts Dime Museum and Flea Circus, a celebrated basement phantasmagoria on 42nd Street in Manhattan where she began shooting in the late 1950s as she was beginning to hone her stark signature style.

title: Killing Leads to Protest of Spanish Tv Show
description: A Spanish television station faced demands that it scrap a popular talk show after a man fatally stabbed his ex-girlfriend after she refused his marriage proposal on the show, Reuters reported yesterday. Five days after being rejected on the Nov. 14 show, the man went to the womans home and killed her, Reuters said. The Association of Television Viewers in the eastern region of Catalonia demanded that the station, Antena 3, drop the show, Patricias Diary, which attracts more than two million viewers a day. Womens groups accused the show of using deceit to lure the woman, who had obtained a court order requiring the man to keep at least about 550 yards away from her, onto a stage with him.

title: Baghdad Thanksgiving, 2003
description: I HAVE always hated Thanksgiving. Christmas, now there was a holiday: food, presents, elves and angels, colored lights. Thanksgiving was clunky and secular, devoid of mystery or ritual yet still reeking of guilt: you didnt get any presents, but you were supposed to be grateful for something.

title: For Lawyers, Perks to Fit a Lifestyle
description: Even lawyers need a hug. When workdays stretch into worknights and the pressure to meet the quota for billable hours grows, lawyers and staff members at the firm of Perkins Coie can often expect a little bonus.

title: Verve, Affection and Glitter in a Gala Tribute to Kirstein
description: All that was missing from Dancing for Lincoln: A Centennial Celebration, the New York City Ballets spirited, affectionate opening-night gala on Tuesday at the State Theater, was the once-familiar sight of Lincoln Kirstein staring down from his seat in the first ring, keen-eyed, at all that he had wrought as a founder of the company with George Balanchine.

title: Breast-Feeding Mother, and Family, Deported
description: A Honduran mother who was separated for 11 days from her nursing baby after being arrested in an immigration search was deported to Honduras, along with her three children and her husband. The woman, Sada Umanzor, 26, was separated from her American-born baby, Brittney Bejarano, when she was detained by the authorities with a deportation order on Oct. 26 in Conneaut, Ohio. After 11 days, Julie L. Myers, the head of Immigration and Customs Enforcement, ordered Ms. Umanzors release and issued instructions for illegal immigrants who are nursing mothers to be released after arrest in most cases. The agency paid the airfare to Honduras for all three children: Brittney and another daughter, who are United States citizens, and a son born in Honduras.

title: Directors Resign From Affiliated After a Review
description: Affiliated Computer Services said its independent directors had resigned, less than a month after they accused the chairman, Darwin Deason, of bullying them over a failed takeover bid.

title: Business (Some Unfinished) From Titian, 1500s C.E.O.
description: VIENNA  Late Titian here at the Kunsthistorisches Museum is one of those serious exhibitions in which inferior work sometimes tests the eye. Partly, its a scholars paradise, with murky workshop daubs; various versions of the same pictures, more or less good; homages by Rubens and others who fell under the sway of cunning and erotic canvases like the divine Venus With a Mirror, and in general a range by the great man himself that lays out the eternal mystery of his aging style.

title: The Journey Home Making a New Life in the Old Country
description: CALITRI, Italy

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, the Brezovica Journal article on Monday, about surprisingly friendly relations between Serb and Albanian skiers on the slopes of Brezovica, in the Serbian enclave of Strpce in Serbias ethnic Albanian province of Kosovo, misidentified the city used as a reference point for Strpces location. Strpce is about 40 miles from Pristina, the provincial capital of Kosovo  not from Belgrade, the capital of Serbia. (Belgrade is about 180 miles from Strpce.) (Go to Article)

title: Computer Game With a Special Special Effect, Facial Expressions
description: Most game designers dont worry about wrinkles. Casey Hudson does, which is one reason Mass Effect, which he spent the last three years directing, is a landmark of interactive storytelling.

title: Killing of Chicago Student Unsettles Campus Life
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 21  The students stood in a circle on the campus quadrangle at the University of Chicago and held slender white candles as they remembered a gentle graduate student from Senegal who was killed early Monday, weeks before he was to receive his doctorate.

title: China to Address Issues Around Dam
description: BEIJING, Nov. 21  China has announced new plans to confront environmental and geological problems around the Three Gorges Dam, even as a landslide in the region on Tuesday killed one construction worker, injured a second and trapped two others beneath a mound of fallen earth.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Plant May Never Be a Star

title: The Broadway Strike, Now Starring the Grinch
description: The Grinch hated Christmas!

title: Data Leak in Britain Affects 25 Million
description: LONDON, Nov. 21  The British government struggled Wednesday to explain its loss of computer disks containing detailed personal information on 25 million Britons, including an unknown number of bank account identifiers, in what analysts described as potentially the most significant privacy breach of the digital era.

title: Shades of McCarthy Era
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan and the Success of the Southern Strategy
description: To the Editor:

title: Totals
description: Previously recorded $2,275,895.90

title: Warming Up for San Francisco
description: Today sees the start of the American Contract Bridge Leagues Fall North American Championships. Play takes place through Dec. 2 in the San Francisco Marriott.

title: Singing Bout a New Generation ...
description: To the Editor:

title: California Tries to Engage Drivers With the Web
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 21  As YouTube videos go, Kyles driving test has nothing on Gizmo, the toilet-flushing cat. But the California Department of Motor Vehicles remains convinced that its 54 videos now running on the site will make the states roads a better place to travel, or at the very least get new drivers to embrace the logic of a traffic circle.

title: Perhaps the Best Freshman Player, and Perhaps the Best Player, Period
description: Dalonte Hills first glimpse of the awkward, 6-foot-7 kid stumbling up and down the basketball court in clownlike size 22 shoes was difficult to ignore.

title: Those Mexican Rockers Who Defy Expectations
description: For a while, during the mid-1990s, the Mexican rock band Caf Tacuba looked as if it was heading toward a careful balance of past-meets-future, mixing up Mexican folk and bolero roots with progressive, futuristic, pan-national ideas about rock or electronic music. But even that balance ended up as a limitation; it seems the band would rather work without any expectations at all.

title: Lafayette in America
description: To the Editor:

title: Remains of 40 Found in Mass Grave
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 21  The Iraqi police on Wednesday discovered a mass grave near Ramadi with at least 40 bodies, some of them children, and a suicide car bomb exploded inside the city near a courthouse, killing at least six people and wounding eight.

title: Fearing Worst, Air Travelers Find Smooth Going
description: The confluence of good luck and better planning made much of yesterday a surprisingly smooth one for holiday travelers at many airports across the country, passengers, airline executives and their employees said.

title: Etched in Mommys Heart and Now (Ouch!) on Her Ankle
description: LAURA SCARBOROUGH of Manteca, Calif., would do anything for her five children, ages 5 to 20. But when they ask her to show her chest to their friends, she draws the line.

title: House Is Ratings Leader
description: House earned the top ratings among adults 18 to 49 on Tuesday, Nielsen estimated, giving Fox first place for the night in that demographic. But in total viewers ABCs Dancing With the Stars results episode outdrew House in the 9 p.m. hour, with 20.7 million versus 16.8 million viewers. ABC pulled in the most viewers overall. That networks 8 p.m. annual rebroadcast of the Peanuts Thanksgiving special attracted 10 million viewers, the largest audience for that show since ABC began rerunning it in 2001. At 10, ABCs special The Bachelor: After the Final Rose (12.8 million viewers) won the hour by edging past NBCs Law & Order: Special Victims Unit (11.7 million viewers). CBS finished third in total viewers, leading the 8 p.m. hour with NCIS (17.4 million viewers). NBC ranked third in the 18-to-49 set, averaging 7.5 million viewers from 8 to 10 for The Biggest Loser.

title: A Tip of the Hat for Jobs Well Done
description: Despite a perjury indictment in baseball, dogfighting and criminal conduct in pro football, a referee scandal and a franchises intramural mess in pro basketball, and the forfeit of Olympic medals by a track queen who confessed to using steroids, sports little corner of the world still has many people to be thankful for today.

title: In Some Households, Every Day Is Turkey Day
description: It is one thing for the president of the United States to pardon a pair of turkeys every year and then send them off to live out their days in Florida. Its quite another to save a turkey from the Thanksgiving table by inviting it to live with you.

title: Playing to Meet a Self-Imposed Standard
description: For its marriage of precision and imagination, and the outright beauty of its broad-canvas compositions, the Maria Schneider Orchestra has no peer in the realm of jazz. And because improvisation serves so much more than an ornamental purpose for the group, it has no real equivalent in classical music, or among any species of pop. As a result the toughest standard faced by Ms. Schneider and her musicians is self-determined: a compulsion to soar higher than before.

title: If Not First in Time, First in the Countrys Heart
description: PLYMOUTH, Mass., Nov. 20  This year, as Jamestown, Va., splashily celebrated the 400th anniversary of its founding as the nations first permanent English settlement, the home of Plymouth Rock found itself on the defensive.

title: Gmail Is More Than Just Mail
description: Q. Is it true you can use your Gmail address for instant messaging?

title: Agent Called Justified in Killing a Suspect
description: The fatal shooting by a federal agent of a man suspected of selling a hand grenade in the Bronx on Tuesday appears justified, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Deutsche Telekom Will Let Rivals Operate iPhones
description: Deutsche Telekom, whose exclusive rights for the Apple iPhone in Germany are contested by the Vodafone Group, said yesterday that it would change some terms and let the handset operate on rival networks.

title: This Laptops Frills Arent Much, but Neither Is the Price
description: Ultralight laptops can easily cost more than $2,000. On the other end, ultracheap machines can be found in seductive ads with prices of $400 after rebates, but theyre usually hefty full-featured versions with big screens.

title: The Mixed Blessings of Travel and Other Eternal Verities
description: Liz Callaway has a gleaming theater-ready voice with a machete-sharp edge that is made to deliver reach-for-the-stars Broadway showstoppers like The Story Goes On, her signature song from the 1983 musical Baby. In that show she played a pregnant college student who feels her baby kick inside her and has an ecstatic vision of herself as a part of an endless chain of life.

title: Turkey Tune-Out Time
description: When I became a U.S. citizen a few years back, I was not asked the meaning of Thanksgiving, but I was asked why the Civil War was fought and made to take an English test in the form of a dictation.

title: The Short but Powerful Reign of a Mozart Queen
description: The Queen of the Night in Mozarts Zauberflte is a fiendishly difficult and dramatically exasperating role. Its a crucial but short part. The maniacal Queen appears, mainly, to sing two show-stopping, blazingly brilliant arias.

title: Drug Said to Shrink Tumors
description: The drug Revlimid, made by the Celgene Corporation, can shrink tumors and slow down the spread of multiple myeloma, a deadly cancer of the bone marrow, according to two studies conducted in the United States and Europe. Revlimid, a derivative of thalidomide, helped shrink tumors for about 60 percent of patients in combination with dexamethasone, a corticosteroid, and stopped the cancer from spreading for six months, according to two studies published in this weeks New England Journal of Medicine. The drug, known chemically as lenalidomide, won American approval for multiple myeloma in July 2006 based on the studies.

title: Economic Forecast Index Sees Weakness Into 2008
description: The economy may continue to slow into 2008, according to a measure of its performance over the next three to six months.

title: Rail Sabotage Is Reported in France
description: PARIS, Nov. 21  As a national transit strike stretched into its second week, arsonists disrupted high-speed train service on four main routes on Wednesday. Government officials called the fires a coordinated act of sabotage.

title: Alicia Keys at No. 1
description: With record sales heating up for the holiday season, Alicia Keys topped the Billboard album chart this week. As I Am (J), Ms. Keyss fourth record to reach No. 1, sold 742,000 copies, Nielsen SoundScan reported. It was the best week for a solo female artist since Norah Joness Feels Like Home three years ago. Every album in the Top 10 sold at least 100,000 copies, a benchmark that these days is rarely crossed by more than two or three albums a week. Josh Grobans Nol (Reprise) climbed four spots to No. 2 with 223,000 in sales; Celine Dions Taking Chances (Columbia) opened at No. 3 with 214,000; and Vol. 26 of the pop compilation series Now Thats What I Call Music! bowed at No. 4 with 208,000. A new two-disc hits collection by Led Zeppelin, Mothership (Atlantic), reached No. 7 with 136,000 in sales, a quarter of which came in a format the band long resisted but has finally embraced: downloads.

title: Home & Garden Calendar
description: Beyond Western Borders

title: Players to Watch
description: Stephen Curry

title: Irving Bluestone, 90, Head of Union Talks With G.M., Dies
description: Irving Bluestone, chief negotiator for more than 400,000 workers at General Motors in the 1970s and an advocate of worker participation in management, died on Saturday at his home in Brookline, Mass. He was 90.

title: Congestion Relief
description: President Bushs announcement this week of measures to reduce air traffic congestion was welcome news, especially his decision to open military air lanes along the Eastern Seaboard to commercial planes from the Wednesday before Thanksgiving to the Sunday after.

title: Not Just Mans Best Friend but Gods Best Ally
description: Trixie Koontz has left this earthly plane, but she can still be found on the Internet. There she is on Dean Koontzs Web site (deankoontz.com), an animated golden retriever conversing with her animated Dad. He addresses her fondly as Fur Face and Fluffy Butt. She tells him that she is in a better place. He wonders whether she was looking over his shoulder as he wrote his latest novel. She advises him to be ready for fun when he gets to the next world, and to be sure to wear comfortable shoes.

title: Room to Improve
description: A. Even an everyday meal like spaghetti and meatballs can seem special if you serve it with flair.

title: Short Layoff, Long Comeback
description: WHEN Helen Betancourt, an assistant coach at Princeton, was preparing for the World Championships in rowing in 1998, she suffered an overuse injury: stress fractures of her ribs. She competed anyway, but then had to take five months off.

title: The Art of Air Traffic, in All Its Delicate Flow
description: HERNDON, Va., Nov. 21  The Federal Aviation Administrations Strategic Command Center here got started early Wednesday, its first conference call with the airlines at 5:15 a.m. instead of the usual 7:15.

title: Merle Sande, AIDS Pioneer, Dies at 68
description: Dr. Merle A. Sande, a leading infectious-diseases expert whose early recognition of the looming public health crisis posed by AIDS led to the development of basic protocols for how to handle infected patients, died on Nov. 14 at his home in Seattle. He was 68.

title: Mouse With a Memory Can Be Used for File Storage
description: Packing a laptop bag at the last minute is hectic enough, but a new travel mouse ensures there will be one less thing to forget. While it looks like a typical cordless model, the Mobile Memory Mouse 8000 from Microsoft has a U.S.B. transceiver that doubles as a one-gigabyte flash drive for storing and transferring files.

title: A Path From Questions to Answers to Solutions
description: If the stem cell wars are indeed over, no one will savor the peace more than James Thomson.

title: Wal-Mart and Sustainable Business
description: To the Editor:

title: Screening Off the Guests
description: THE problem: guests are coming for the holidays, but your home has no spare room. The solution: carve out a semiprivate space with a screen or room divider. Some can be hidden away until the next onslaught, while others are more permanent.

title: Trying to Save Lebanon, Again
description: Nearly three years after the assassination of the former prime minister Rafik Hariri  the suspected handiwork of Syria  the struggle for Lebanons soul continues. Tomorrow is the deadline for Parliament to pick a new president, but the countrys parties, divided by religious and personal rivalries and stoked by Syria and Iran, are deadlocked. There are fears of renewed civil war if a compromise is not found.

title: Where Design Heads Double-Dip
description: WE are pack rats who are evolving, said Matthew Birnbaum, a 33-year-old chef who lives in the West Village, cocking an eyebrow at the acrylic desk organizers, storage containers and place mats he and his wife, Jennifer, 28, were carrying through the crowd at the Muji SoHo store on Friday.

title: At a Cigar Show, an Air-Quality Scientist Under Deep, Smoky Cover
description: The agitators met a few blocks from the target at a secret location, so as not to call attention to the devices in their bags.

title: Cerberus Seeks Court Ruling to End Deal
description: Cerberus Capital Management, still trying to scuttle its $4 billion purchase of United Rentals Inc., said yesterday that it had filed a request for declaratory judgment in New York State Supreme Court.

title: J.F.K.s Death, Re-Framed
description: FORTY-FOUR years ago today, a clothing company owner named Abraham Zapruder filmed the assassination of John F. Kennedy in Dallas. And for 44 years, most people have presumed that his home movie captured the assassination in its entirety. This presumption has led to deep misunderstandings.

title: School Aide Says Union President Quashed His Bid
description: A dissident member of a school employees union local is accusing the locals president, one of the most powerful union leaders in New York, of using that power to suppress her opposition.

title: For Hartford Mayor, Election Is Over, but Investigations Are Not
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 21  When he declared victory on election night, Mayor Eddie A. Perez said voters had endorsed the direction that Hartford is headed. Little more than weeks later, that direction may be into uncharted territory.

title: As Temperature Falls, Nugents Success Rate Rises
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 21  When the temperature drops, Mike Nugent somehow warms. When the wind whips at its worst through Giants Stadium, Mike Nugent somehow kicks footballs farther and with increased accuracy.

title: Missing Witness Turns Up in Case of Slain Bouncer
description: A missing witness in a 17-year-old murder case reappeared yesterday, and lawyers hoped he would solve the mystery of who killed a bouncer at the Palladium nightclub in Manhattan.

title: Dubai: Port Operator Raises $5 Billion
description: DP World, the Dubai-owned port operator with terminals from Britain to China, raised $4.96 billion in the biggest initial public stock offering ever in the Middle East. The company sold shares for $1.30 each, the top of an indicated range, after buyers put in orders for 15 times the number of shares offered, the company said. The stock sale gives the company a market value of $21.6 billion. The offering surpassed the initial stock offering of the Saudi Telecom Company, which raised $4.1 billion in 2003. The fact the I.P.O. has been so heavily oversubscribed reflects the markets confidence. DP World will have a solid base of international investors, Sultan Ahmed Bin Sulayem, DP Worlds chairman, said in a statement.

title: Formal Investigation Against Chirac Begins
description: PARIS, Nov. 21  Former President Jacques Chirac was placed under formal investigation on Wednesday on suspicion of misusing public funds by handing out bogus work contracts when he was mayor of Paris.

title: Man Who Helped Start Stem Cell War May End It
description: If the stem cell wars are indeed nearly over, no one will savor the peace more than James A. Thomson.

title: Fewer New York Murders, and Even Fewer by Strangers
description: New York City is on track to have fewer than 500 murders in 2007, by far the lowest amount in a 12-month period since reliable Police Department statistics became available in 1963.

title: A Displaced Jazz Musician Rebuilds in New York
description: The musical Prince of New Orleans has been touring New York in vagabond shoes.

title: After 88 Years of Rivalry, the Last as Us and Them
description: UNION CITY, N.J.  For 88 consecutive years, two high school football teams here, Emerson and Union Hill, have done battle on Thanksgiving Day, undeterred by mud, rain, divided family loyalties, two World Wars and the Great Depression.

title: Quitting Their Day Jobs and Scaling Up
description: FOR years, Sam Davol, who is 37, worked as a Legal Aid lawyer in Lower Manhattan while moonlighting as the cellist for the indie-pop band the Magnetic Fields. As the band, led by the enigmatic singer and songwriter Stephin Merritt, flourished  a new album comes out in January, followed by a national tour  Mr. Davol decided to give up his day job to devote more time to music.

title: Off to See the Wizard, by Way of Hollywood
description: The Yellow Brick Road helped Dorothy find a way back to Kansas, and it also took the Munchkins, above, to Hollywood, 68 years after the release of The Wizard of Oz, Reuters reported yesterday. Seven of the nine surviving Munchkins, out of 124 adults and children who played them in the movie, received a collective star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame, inscribed The Munchkins. The honor stemmed from a campaign by Ted Bulthaup, who owns a Chicago movie theater and became friends with some of the Munchkin actors a few years ago. He led a petition drive, with support from Steven Spielberg, George Lucas and Mickey Rooney. The Munchkins on hand were Jerry Maren, a Lollipop Guild member; Mickey Carroll, a fiddler; Margaret Pellegrini, a sleepyhead and potted flower; Karl Slover, a trumpeting herald; Clarence Swensen, a soldier; and Meinhardt Raabe, the coroner who certifies the Wicked Witchs death.

title: Keep Your Little Picasso Busy (and Away From Your Walls)
description: You can transform a personal computer into an easel for preschoolers with the Digital Arts and Crafts Studio, a $50 device from Fisher-Price. About the size of a standard keyboard, the device plugs into your computers U.S.B. port, which also supplies it with power.

title: Georgia Justices Overturn a Curb on Sex Offenders
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 21  The Georgia Supreme Court unanimously struck down a state law Wednesday that limited where registered sex offenders could live, ruling that the statute was so restrictive it unconstitutionally deprived the offenders of their property rights.

title: What Diplomats Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Nassau to Look Into Infections Tied to Doctor
description: The Nassau County district attorney, Kathleen Rice, said yesterday that she would investigate the entirety of the circumstances that led a patient to be infected with hepatitis C and hundreds more to be placed at risk by the improper infection-control practices of an anesthesiologist on Long Island.

title: Ohio State Stars Depart, but Help Has Arrived
description: The last time Ohio State reached a tournament final, the best freshman in the country, Greg Oden, led the Buckeyes to the N.C.A.A. championship game in April. Odens supporting cast included two more stellar freshmen, Mike Conley Jr. and Daequan Cook.

title: Francine Parker, 81, Director of Antiwar Film, Dies
description: Francine Parker, director of a controversial anti-Vietnam War documentary film that mixed footage of spoofing entertainers including Jane Fonda and Donald Sutherland with interviews with disillusioned soldiers, died on Nov. 8 near her home in Los Angeles. She was 81.

title: Germany: Denial From Suspect in Italy Killing
description: A new suspect in the slaying of a British student in Italy proclaimed his innocence in a German courtroom, but said he would not fight extradition to face charges in Italy. The suspect, Rudy Hermann Guede, 20, was arrested Tuesday near Mainz by German transportation police officers after he was caught riding a train without a ticket. Two other suspects are being held in the Nov. 1 slaying of the student, Meredith Kercher, 22, in Perugia. They are Amanda Knox, 20, an American student from Seattle, and her Italian boyfriend, Rafaelle Sollecito, 24. Both have also maintained their innocence. German officials said Mr. Guede was likely to return to Italy within two weeks.

title: New Hampshire Selects Jan. 8 for Its Primary
description: New Hampshire last night officially scheduled its first-in-the-nation presidential primary for Jan. 8, ending months of hedging from officials there and solidifying what has been a chaotic primary calendar that moves the nominating process closer to the start of the year.

title: Bad Taste Need Not Apply
description: A MATHEMATICIAN once told me that when long, complicated equations work, they give off a resonant, almost aural ping!

title: Your Rock n Roll Fantasy
description: JOYSTICKS can take you only so far. To get in on the seasons biggest game craze, you need a guitar  or at least a plastic gadget that looks like a guitar.

title: For $103.35, You Take What You Can Get
description: People heard him before they saw him, mumbling  croaking, really  in a low voice that seemed to come from nowhere. Is the show starting? Then: Hold up, hold up. Then, seemingly to an assistant: I dont want to fall. This was good news. It was Tuesday at the B. B. King Blues Club & Grill, and Sly Stone was in the building.

title: Anne Klein Dresses Down
description: LAST year, Jones Apparel Group hired Isabel Toledo, a remarkably unsung force in American fashion, to do something with Anne Klein, its flagging sportswear label, which, of course, she did.

title: Spanish Video Game Opens Old War Wounds
description: A video game in Spain that allows players to refight the Spanish Civil War and even to change the outcome has stirred controversy some 70 years after that conflict ended. The game, Shadows of War, was released on Tuesday, the anniversary of the death of the dictator Francisco Franco, whose forces declared victory in 1939. The game, created by a Spanish company, Legend Studios, at a cost of more than $1 million, has created an unusual amount of controversy, the Spanish daily El Pas reported. Carlota Leret, the daughter of Virgilio Leret Ruiz, the man commonly cited as Francos first victim in the war, told the newspaper that she was not honored that her fathers death is depicted in the game. Im surprised that someone has been capable of inventing a video game about a tragic event like the Spanish Civil War, she said. Its not a historical event thats buried in the past.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: A Thanksgiving Tradition With an Ever-Evolving Cast
description: HAVERSTRAW, N.Y.

title: Chinese Warship Visits Japan
description: BEIJING, Nov. 21  A warship sailed Wednesday for the first port visit by the Chinese Navy to Japan since the end of World War II, Chinese state media reported.

title: Brazil: Oceanair Orders Planes
description: Airbus won a $2.65 billion order from OceanAir, a Brazilian carrier that plans to add domestic and international flights. OceanAir agreed to buy seven A330-200 widebody planes, 14 A319s and seven A320s, Airbus said. OceanAir also took options for 13 more aircraft worth $900 million. The estimates are based on list prices and do not reflect discounts applied to large orders. The new aircraft will allow closely held OceanAir to better compete with TAM and Gol Linhas Areas Inteligentes, which have a combined 91 percent of domestic air travel in Brazil. We want to woo those future customers, OceanAirs owner, German Efromovich, above, said. The carrier will change its name to Avianca next year, matching its brand in Colombia. The airline wants to increase its Brazilian market share to as much as 15 percent by 2010, from 2.2 percent now, Mr. Efromovich said.

title: Teams to Watch
description: Marquette

title: Colleges Shaken by Soaring Cost of Birth Control
description: In health centers at hundreds of colleges and universities around the country, young women are paying sharply higher prices for prescription contraceptives because of a change in federal law.

title: Grandparents Care for Siblings Orphaned by Violence
description: At an age when most people are thinking of retirement, Oscar Mayorga is concerned about how to find more work.

title: Did Pakistan Ease Rule? A Little Test Says No
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 21  One of Pakistans most distinguished jurists and a dissident lawyer approached a police cordon on Wednesday in a residential quarter here, and demonstrated in no time that even though the government claims it is taking steps to ease emergency rule, it remains firmly in place.

title: 5 Countries, 5 Composers, 5 Explorations of Atonality
description: The programs Joel Sachs assembles for the New Juilliard Ensemble almost invariably bring together works from several countries, usually by composers who are not well known but perhaps will be. Many are young: The ensembles concert at the Juilliard School on Tuesday evening began with a work by Ryan Gallagher, a composer born in 1984, and ended with a pop hybrid by Daniel Bernard Roumain, born in 1972. And although both are American, the other composers were from Korea (by way of Germany), Estonia and Britain  globe-trotting being a central characteristic of Mr. Sachss programming style.

title: With the Grace of Liberace Go I
description: I USED to give the worst holiday get-togethers. I was a jittery mess, the sort of person who leapt to refill a glass and filled any conversational lull with nervous chatter. Of course, that was before I discovered My Way of Life, Joan Crawfords 1971 guide to gracious living, six years ago.

title: Listen to the Sounds, but Pay Attention to the Space
description: Small, shiny new and with seats that descend toward the stage at a dangerously Alpine-like slant, the Morgan Library & Museums concert hall has a vivid sound with dangers of its own. The George London Foundation for Singers has been putting on a series of recitals with singers in pairs, pauses rather than intermissions and programs that tend to be shorter than the customary two hours.

title: An Alternative to Annuities for Retirees Seeking Income
description: When they were young, members of the baby boom generation did not do things the way their parents did. But now, as they start to retire, some may wish they could retire the way their parents did.

title: Look What the Hounds Dragged In
description: ONE of the nice things about Mount Everest is its lack of fashion intrusions. There, on the remote border of Nepal and Tibet, miles up into the atmosphere, if people worry about what to wear, the concerns are along the lines of, Will this jacket keep me from dying a horrible frostbitten death? not Does this T-shirt show off my guns?

title: Millions in Sales From 3 Simple Words
description: Even though he broke his foot dancing at his brothers wedding one recent weekend, life is still good for Bert Jacobs.

title: Giants Are Suddenly Short Key Ingredient
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 21  For Thanksgiving, Derrick Ward is bringing the ham. Reuben Droughns is bringing the macaroni and cheese. Brandon Jacobs will provide the deep-fried turkey and gumbo.

title: Adapting Finance to Islam
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  Rising oil wealth is lifting Islamic banking  banking that adheres to the laws of the Koran and its prohibition against charging interest  into the financial mainstream.

title: Thanksgiving Matchups
description: Jets Darrelle Revis

title: Russia: Putin Increases Pre-election Oratory
description: At a campaign rally less than two weeks before parliamentary elections, President Vladimir V. Putin used some of his most nationalistic oratory to mobilize his party, United Russia. Mr. Putin assailed his opponents, whom he did not specify, as tools of unidentified foreign governments, likening them to jackals who hang around foreign embassies in order to obtain funds. They need a disorganized and disoriented society, a split society in order to wheel and deal behind its back, he said. United Russia, with Mr. Putin heading the ticket, is expected to win an overwhelming majority in the elections.

title: Inventive in Theory, Deadly Adventure Fizzles in Action
description: Assassins Creed is full of clever, original ideas. The player can leap from rooftop to rooftop, ride a horse across the countryside, jump off a 100-foot tower into a bale of hay or knife a victim in the back unnoticed and then calmly join a group of religious scholars and walk away.

title: An E-Book Reader That Just May Catch On
description: Youve got to have a lot of nerve to introduce an electronic book reader in 2007.

title: Big Rise in Cost of Birth Control on Campuses
description: In health centers at hundreds of colleges and universities around the country, young women are paying sharply higher prices for prescription contraceptives because of a change in federal law.

title: A MapQuest for Our Money
description: MY adjustable-rate mortgage is going to adjust soon. I suspected this moment would arrive, but thought it would be a happier occasion, more like the day a few years ago when I persuaded my husband to sign up for our current 4-percent interest rate, and less like, well, the end of the world.

title: The 5th Down Blog Entry That Predicts Which Players In Fantasy Football Will Score More/Fewer Points Than Usual Each Week
description: Like the catchy new blog title, everyone? Me, too. As Paris Hilton might say, That new titles hottthot like Melvilles social allegory Moby-Dick, whose New England whaling ship served as a metaphor for the expansionist society in which he was living and a condemnation of mid-19th century American values.

title: Jets' Offense Staggers Against Dallas
How the Punsters Stole Headlines
description: It was quite the week for Grinch parodies as a judge in Manhattan ordered that the Dr. Seuss musical show must go on:

title: Natixiss Bond Insurer to Receive $1.5 Billion
description: Nov. 22 (Bloomberg) -- Natixis SA's bond-insurance unit, CIFG Guaranty, will be taken over by the French bank's controlling shareholders in a $1.5 billion rescue to preserve its top credit rating.

title: A Hoosier Reflects
description: It has been quite a year for the Indiana football team. In June, Hoosiers Coach Terry Hoeppner died after an 18-month fight with brain tumors. Earlier this month, the Hoosiers (7-5), now coached by Hoeppners former assistant Bill Lynch, became bowl eligible for the first time since 1994 with a victory over Ball State. Indiana running back Bryan Payton has written for The Quad before, reflecting on the impact Hoeppner had on his players and the legacy he left. Today, Payton takes a look at the Hoosiers season, from early practices in 100-degree heat to Austin Starrs winning kick in last Saturdays 27-24 victory over Purdue in the annual Bucket Game. This Thanksgiving Day essay is offered instead of The Quads usual morning links.

title: From Project Runway to Cheap Chic
description: Project Runway is extending its runway from TV sets into stores around the country.

title: No Holiday in the Blogosphere
Jozy Altidore: Home for the Holiday
description: Its nice to be home for the holiday, back in Florida. It should be interesting with everyone coming down  friends and family  it should be nice and relaxing. Just take a load off and ease my mind and relax. There will be six of us, with my brothers and sisters, and were probably going to be going somewhere.

title: The Skinny on Holiday Weight Gain
description: Reports of your holiday weight gain have been greatly exaggerated. Media stories often suggest that the average person gains 7 to 10 pounds between Thanksgiving and Christmas. And in surveys, people say they gain, on average, about five pounds this time of year.

title: Aix-en-Provence at Christmastime
description: Our family has decided to forgo the usual and head to Provence for the Christmas holidays. We love winter in Europe and have been told that Provence is quite wonderful after the crowds leave. Are we headed toward an early-winter delight or have we steered down a path of folly?

title: Counting Calories? Big Meals Make It Tough
description: How good are your calorie counting skills? It all depends on the size of the meal.

title: International Award Winners
description: La Residence at the Lotus

title: Our Founding Illegals
description: Happy Thanksgiving, pilgrim. A spoof from Super Deluxe:

title: Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade
description: Photographs from the 81st annual parade.

title: The unknown Ron Paul
description: Doing research for tomorrows column, I ran across a chapter most Ron Paul supporters probably dont know about.

title: A Fresh Advertising Pitch: Buy Nothing
description: As millions of Americans brace for the jammed parking lots and mobbed closeout racks that come with the holiday shopping season, a small but determined network of antishopping activists is girded for action as well.

title: Thankful
Out of Prison, Back to Houston
description: Former prison inmates often return to sections of large cities populated with a disproportionate number of men who have served time.

title: A Hole in the Head
description: Last weekend found me dumpster-diving in my back alley.

title: Thanksgiving in Afghanistan
description: When Thanksgiving arrived at Forward Operating Base Airborne, it came to a small and isolated world.

title: Fridays Matchups
description: The day after Thanksgiving is not without its big games. First Arkansas will look to knock off the No. 1 team in the land, and L.S.U. will need to play better than they did last week against Mississippi. Think Les Miles is sick of answering questions about Michigan? Texas-Texas A&M has been a good game in the past and is worth keeping and eye on, as is Colorado-Nebraska, but the game of the day is a late starter from the far West Coast. Boise State and Hawaii will tangle for the W.A.C. crown and a possible B.C.S berth. That one ought to make for compelling drama as Colt Brennan can set an N.C.A.A. record with one more touchdown pass and Boise State can continue to make its case as the best non-B.C.S. program with another victory. Enjoy, and make sure all of your food is digested since I would put the over/under on that one around 78.

title: Trailer for Super Mario Galaxy
description: A commercial for "Super Mario Galaxy."

title: Sweden Turns to a Promising Power Source, With Flaws
description: MALMO, Sweden  Steadying himself on the heaving foredeck of an inspection ship recently, his face flecked by spray, Arne Floderus pronounced it a good day for his new offshore wind farm.

title: Thanksgiving and a Mission Unite Diverse Forces
description: FORWARD OPERATING BASE AIRBORNE, Afghanistan, Nov. 22  The soldiers filed into the dining tent in the soft light before evening, carrying heaps of food for a Thanksgiving gathering as polyglot as anywhere.

title: Palestinian Says a Joint Document Is Unlikely
description: RAMALLAH, Nov. 22  A senior Palestinian official said here on Thursday that it would be a miracle if the Palestinian and Israeli negotiating teams agree on a joint document, as they had hoped, to present at the American-sponsored Middle East peace gathering scheduled to start on Tuesday in Annapolis, Md.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Wednesday about a Supreme Court gun control case incorrectly described a lower courts decision. The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit reversed the District Court and ruled Washingtons law on gun ownership unconstitutional. The District Court did not overturn the law.

title: French Banks Acquire Bond Insurance Company
description: Another crack in the subprime mortgage market appeared to have been patched yesterday as two French banks bought out a bond-insurance company that has exposure to the mortgage crisis.

title: Totals
description: Previously recorded $2,275,895.90

title: The Immigration Wilderness
description: The nation certainly sounds as if its in an angry place on immigration.

title: Letter to the Editor
description: A KEY PIECE OF THE VALLEY

title: End to French Transportation Strike Seems Near
description: PARIS, Nov. 22  A crippling national transportation strike that has lasted nine days appeared to be sputtering to an end on Thursday as rail workers fighting to retain early retirement rights seemed willing to accept negotiations and voted throughout the country to return to work.

title: New Numbers on AIDS
description: It looks as if the global AIDS pandemic may not be spiraling out of control after all. Instead, the devastation is stabilizing at an unacceptably high level.

title: Understanding Pasolini by Revisiting His Work
description: Poet, playwright, screenwriter, filmmaker, Communist, Christian, moralist, pornographer, populist, artist: 32 years after he was murdered by a teenage hustler (who later tried to recant his confession), Pier Paolo Pasolini remains, perhaps above all, a subject for furious argument. In an era when Italy produced a bumper crop of difficult, passionate artists, especially in the cinema, he may have been the most difficult of all, and arguably the most prodigiously talented.

title: The Jets Try, but Things Just Arent Cooking
description: IRVING, Tex., Nov. 22  For the Jets, Thanksgiving Day at Texas Stadium played out the way it probably did in some kitchens across America. They tackled the task before them with a can-do spirit that was commendable, but the result was hard to swallow.

title: The Experience Argument
description: In 1960, Richard M. Nixon ran for president against John F. Kennedy on a slogan that had powerful resonance for a Cold War America: Experience Counts. Mr. Nixon had been vice president for eight years, a senator for two, and a congressman for four. Mr. Kennedy had been a senator for eight years and a congressman for six, and was also a war hero and the scion of a politically powerful family.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: The Angels Sign Hunter to a $90 Million Deal
description: The Los Angeles Angels have long desired another superb hitter to protect Vladimir Guerrero in their lineup. When the Angels finally added that hitter by signing the free agent Torii Hunter late Wednesday night, they did it with shocking speed.

title: Syria and Our Suspects
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Warship Misses Thanksgiving in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 22  China reversed a decision on Thursday to block a United States aircraft carrier from making a four-day port call in Hong Kong, but the change of heart by Beijing officials came too late to stop the ship from returning to its base in Japan and missing families who had flown to Hong Kong to celebrate Thanksgiving.

title: Japanese Shift Cash Out of U.S. Investments
description: TOKYO, Nov. 22  Many in Japan are starting to speak of quitting America, but they are not talking about a rise in anti-American political fervor. Rather, they mean a move away from American investments that is altering global capital flows and helping to weaken the dollar.

title: Never Mind the iPods, the Boxed Set Lives
description: Leftovers? For the holidays? Thats one way to look at this years crop of boxed sets. Now that most pop careers have already been distilled to a handful of discs, culling has given way to expansion. Musicians and labels are combing archives for outtakes, alternate versions, videos and other curios, rewriting pops past and revealing how good  or how misguided  the original selection process was. And many of the leftovers deserve their second chance. JON PARELES

title: Pact Unlikely Before Talks in U.S., Palestinian Insists
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank , Nov. 22  A senior Palestinian official said here on Thursday that it would be a miracle if the Palestinian and Israeli negotiating teams agreed on a joint document, as they had hoped, to present at the American-sponsored Middle East peace gathering set to start Tuesday in Annapolis, Md.

title: Drug Makers Help Lead Rebound in Overseas Shares
description: Global stocks rebounded yesterday from their lowest point in more than two months, led by drug makers and utilities, whose profits are less vulnerable to an economic slowdown. United States markets were closed because of the Thanksgiving holiday.

title: Oktoberfest Reigns, but the Mountains Arent the Alps
description: IN Helen, Ga., a Blue Ridge Mountains town where even the liquor stores stick to city codes that require Alpine-themed architecture, hundreds of people gathered recently in the municipal Bavarian-style beer hall for the first night of Oktoberfest. Locals, second-home owners and tourists alike danced to an accordion-driven band that played traditional German tunes, but also dished out American flavors like Hang On, Sloopy and Waltz Across Texas.

title: The Real Rudy
description: Rudy Giuliani can play a little rough at times, but there are some moments when an inner light turns on and he turns downright idealistic. One of those moments came on Oct. 10, 1996, as he stepped on the podium at the Kennedy School of Government to deliver a speech on immigration.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Tuesday about the decline of tenure-track professors and the rising numbers of part-time instructors and professors at colleges nationwide misidentified the affiliation of John W. Curtis of the American Association of University Professors, which has studied these shifts. He is the director of research and public policy of the association, not of the American Federation of Teachers. (Go to Article)

title: Megachurches Add Local Economy to Their Mission
description: In Anchorage early in October, the doors opened onto a soaring white canvas dome with room for a soccer field and a 400-meter track. Its prime-time hours are already rented well into 2011.

title: Teams to Watch
description: Tennessee

title: Down on the Farm With Your Sleeves Rolled Up
description: AT an early morning hour most vacationers would spend unconscious, a few intrepid city dwellers outfitted in borrowed boots hunch over a creek full of watercress, carefully cutting the plants with kitchen scissors.

title: Detroits Latest Model: A Retooled Museum
description: DETROIT  The Detroit Institute of Arts, one of the countrys small but classic encyclopedic museums, could be on an open prairie rather than in the center of a city, so faint is the urban buzz around it. Little commercial energy warms the nearby streets. Residential neighborhoods are at a distance. Traffic on the broad thoroughfare running past the museum is sparse, even as this institution, closed for the last six months, celebrates a reopening on Nov. 23 that is being advertised as a resurrection.

title: Tough Race in Australia for Supporter of Bush
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 22  The center-right coalition of Prime Minister John Howard, who has been in power for 11 years and is one of the most stalwart supporters of President Bush in the Iraq war, faces a stiff challenge in Australias elections on Saturday, polls indicate.

title: Made in China on the Sly
description: Paris

title: In Reversal, Safe Is Risky, Risky Is Safe
description: For a long time, if there was a problem on Wall Street, Credit Suisse was not far away. From its high-flying mortgage desk that blew up in 1998 to its superstar technology team that promoted Internet stocks in the late 1990s, Credit Suisse could be counted on as an example of problems on Wall Street.

title: Where the Votes Are, So Are All Those Calories
description: Running for president is like entering a competitive eating contest and a beauty pageant all at once. Candidates are expected to eat local specialties often and with gusto, yet still look attractive and fit.

title: Landslide Toll Jumps as China Finds Bus Buried Near New Dam
description: BEIJING, Friday, Nov. 23  Chinese authorities on Friday confirmed the deaths of about 30 more people from a landslide that struck this week in the Three Gorges Dam region. The news comes as Chinese officials are facing growing questions about environmental and geological problems related to the dam project.

title: Samuel L. Leonard, Cornell Zoologist, Dies at 101
description: Samuel L. Leonard, a zoologist at Cornell University whose studies of reproductive hormones in animals helped prepare the foundation for in vitro fertilization in women, died on Nov. 11 in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 101.

title: Retail Desperation on Display in Early Hours
description: American consumers flooded stores Friday on the unofficial first day of the holiday shopping season, but the irrational exuberance that marked Black Fridays of the last five years has been replaced by pragmatic restraint.

title: Riding the Rail to the Top, and Not Amused
description: The Mount Washington Cog Railway, which chugs up the side of New Englands tallest peak, has been called the Railway to the Moon. Some people have been taking that title a bit too literally.

title: Movie Listings
description: MOVIES

title: Warning: This Worm Wears a Suit
description: He Was a Quiet Man, a surreal creep show with a scatological sense of humor, tosses out ideas about vigilante justice, sanity and madness, personal redemption and corporate duplicity with the abandon of a crazed juggler tossing pins too high to catch. Such is the bravado of the movie, written and directed by Frank Cappello, that your initial impulse is to assume that it must know what its doing. But by the time it reaches a weak, ambiguous conclusion, the movie has gone everywhere and nowhere, much like its psychotic main character, Bob Maconel (Christian Slater).

title: A Scholarly May and a Literary December Meet in a New York Autumn
description: A crepuscular glow suffuses Starting Out in the Evening, Andrew Wagners intelligent, careful adaptation of a near-perfect novel by Brian Morton. This is not only a matter of the cinematography  digital video given an unusual burnish by Harlan Bosmajian, the director of photography  or of the setting. Late in the day, the sun slanting down over the North American mainland cloaks the brick and limestone of the Upper West Side of Manhattan in a somber, serious light that may, more than anything else, explain the areas reputation for deep and lofty thought.

title: For You, a Dream. For Them, Bo-ring.
description: FOR years, Stacey Bender Hammerling and her husband, Robert, partners in a public relations and marketing firm, rented houses at the Jersey Shore with their four children. The kids so looked forward to our time there the last two weeks in August, Ms. Hammerling said.

title: Digging In Deeper in Pakistan
description: Gen. Pervez Musharraf has done far too little to drive Al Qaeda and the Taliban from its Pakistani sanctuaries over the last six years, but President Bush still insists on linking Americas interests to the generals erratic and authoritarian whims.

title: A Cold Look at Warming Mixes Pep and Despair
description: Here is an idea worth pondering from Everythings Cool, a breezy polemic about the politics of global warming: The fossil fuel industry doesnt care who wins or loses the debate about the reality of global warming, as long as the public continues to feel that it is debatable.

title: A Rivalry Born in Bloodshed Becomes Pivotal to the B.C.S.
description: Most great college sports rivalries emerge from memorable moments on the field, coaching feuds or recruiting battles, but the annual football game between the Kansas Jayhawks and the Missouri Tigers, to be played tomorrow night in Kansas City, Mo., with unusually high import, taps into a mutual animosity born of a flashpoint in American history.

title: Cowboys Step on Jets, Then Look Past Them
description: IRVING, Tex., Nov. 22  Maybe the Dallas Cowboys have set the bar too close to perfection. Maybe they were simply peeking ahead to next weeks showdown with the Green Bay Packers.

title: Surge Brings New Immigration Backlog
description: Immigration authorities are swamped in new bureaucratic backlogs resulting from an unanticipated flood last summer of applications for citizenship and for residence visas, officials said.

title: Maurice Bjart, 80, Ballet Iconoclast, Dies
description: Maurice Bjart, the French choreographer whose flamboyant and populist ballets made him the equivalent of a pop star in Europe, died yesterday in Lausanne, Switzerland. He was 80.

title: Selling Americans on a Speedy Rail Link From London to Paris
description: A WEAK dollar? Bah. Rail Europe, which sells tickets in the United States for Eurostars high-speed train service between Paris and London, has a new advertising campaign that it hopes will excite Americans enough about European tourism that they can put aside any concerns about exchange rates.

title: What the Corporate Auditor Is Told, a Plaintiff Could Exploit
description: When the Shaw Group, an industrial engineering company, became mired in a contract dispute over its construction work on an electricity plant in Texas, it filed a lawsuit against the company that hired it, the AES Corporation.

title: Captain Guides Rutgers With Quiet Confidence
description: C. Vivian Stringer, the womens basketball coach at Rutgers, is a person of many words, not all of them clear. At times, when her patience wears thin, Stringer speaks to her team in strange dialects  some of which she says she picked up long ago in her hometown near Pittsburgh, others that she made up herself.

title: Second Chance to Make a Good Impression for Niagara Star
description: LEWISTON, N.Y., Nov. 20  In the first half against the University at Buffalo on Tuesday night, Niagaras Tyrone Lewis led all players with 13 points and 2 blocks.

title: Art Listings
description: ART

title: Careers Give Indias Women New Independence
description: BANGALORE, India  Not long ago, an Indian woman, even a working Indian woman, would almost always have moved from her parents house to her husbands. Perhaps her only freedom would be during college, when she might live on campus or take a room for a year or two at what is known here as the working womens hostel.

title: Latin American Modernism, the Sequel
description: New York has been invigorated by a one-two punch of Latin American Modernism this season. The first blow was The Geometry of Hope: Latin American Abstract Art From the Patricia Phelps de Cisneros Collection, at the Grey Art Gallery at New York University. That shows main drawback is that it will return home to Mrs. Cisneros in two weeks. Now the Museum of Modern Art is weighing in with a similarly long-titled exhibition whose 250-plus pieces are here to stay: New Perspectives in Latin American Art, 1930-2006: Selections From a Decade of Acquisitions.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: From the Glove Compartment to the Shelf
description: If 90 percent of life is showing up, the other 10 percent is figuring out how to get there. Thats where maps come in.

title: She Has Respect. Now She Wants a Title.
description: STORRS, Conn.  Here are recent assessments of Renee Montgomery, the Connecticut basketball co-captain and point guard:

title: Correction: Getting Lost in History in the Other Las Vegas
description: A map with the American Journeys column last Friday about Las Vegas, N.M., gave the incorrect location for Montezuma Castle, part of the American campus of United World Colleges. It is on Highway 65 six miles west of Las Vegas, not east of the town.

title: Classical Music and Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Sympathy for the Devil: The Nice-Guy Serial Killer Next Door
description: During the past two years Showtime has made its mark with series that ostentatiously demand our sympathy for narcissists, wrongdoers, the egregiously misbehaved. At the center of Californication is a wounded philanderer. Brotherhood delivers a thug with brain trauma. On Weeds a widowed mother, her options foreclosed, turns to drug dealing and parental neglect. What does it say that Dexter Morgan, a forensics expert and serial killer, is the most likable character in this assembly?

title: Chinese Maker to Sell $7,000 Cars in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 22  A Chinese automaker, First Automobile Works, will begin exporting cars to Mexico by years end, looking to tap into the market for inexpensive cars, the companys Mexican partner, Grupo Salinas, said Thursday.

title: Art in Review
description: URS FISCHER

title: Woman, 69, Dies From Injuries Suffered in Queens Gas Explosion
description: A 69-year-old woman died yesterday, one day after a natural gas leak touched off an explosion in a residential neighborhood in Queens, leading a city councilman to call for an investigation into whether residents should have been evacuated more quickly.

title: In Time, a Glimmer of Light in Disappointed Lives
description: Is William Trevor writing or is he breathing? His 12th collection of short stories is now out, added to 15 novels and novellas, and with each new publication it becomes less a matter of a book in the hand than a presence in the room. We hear a breath stir and feel a pulse.

title: The Giants Spin a Loss Into a Gain
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 21  When linebacker Mathias Kiwanukas left leg was broken in the first quarter last Sunday against the Lions, a string of good fortune for the Giants was also broken.

title: A Gutbucket Full of Loss and Torchy Dreams
description: If Rebecca Parris, the Boston jazz singer who is playing a rare New York engagement at Birdland, were a blues-rock artist, she would belong to the school of gutbucket mamas whose delivery is the vocal equivalent of wielding an ax. Her voice, a rich contralto with a baritone resonance, is so commanding that when a songs attitude is combative, she can scare you. But when the mood is playful, she can also enfold you in a musical bear hug.

title: Britain: Airport Expansion Plan
description: The British government laid out a multibillion-dollar proposal to allow construction of a third runway and a sixth passenger terminal at Londons chronically congested Heathrow Airport, stoking the ire of environmentalists who fear that increases in air traffic are accelerating global climate change. Ruth Kelly, the transport secretary, said the expansion plan would pave the way for a near doubling of the number of passengers using the airport, Europes busiest, to 120 million a year by 2020. The British Civil Aviation Authority has estimated that the project could cost as much as 9 billion ($18.5 billion).

title: Insurers Shift Cost Burdens to Homeowners
description: PALMETTO BAY, Fla.  Charles R. Williams stood near the glass sliding doors in his home south of Miami and pointed out parts of the ceiling and walls that had crumpled after Hurricane Andrew ripped open the roof 15 years ago.

title: Rising Early, Not to Start the Turkey, but to Shop
description: Thanksgiving has long been a day reserved for feasting on turkey and televised football. But Americas most recent national pastime, shopping, is increasingly encroaching on that tradition.

title: Suit Over a Womans Suicide at an Elite Private Hospital
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Nov. 22 Silver Hill Hospital was familiar to Ruth A. Farrell as a place of refuge, one she had sought more than a dozen times when life seemed too hard to bear.

title: Oil Spill Near Jones Beach Gets Broad Response
description: The Coast Guard and environmental agencies from Nassau County and New York State deployed pollution investigators and a task force of aircraft and ships yesterday to cope with an oil spill along several miles of oceanfront on the Atlantic and Lido Beaches of Long Beach Island.

title: Europe Fears That Meth Foothold Is Expanding
description: JESENIK, Czech Republic  The methamphetamine epidemic is not just a scourge of the American heartland. It has a powerful foothold here in the heart of Central Europe. Home meth labs are sprouting up all over the country to produce this cheap, potent drug using the pseudoephedrine found in common cold medications.

title: Violence in Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: A Universe of Black Film
description: The African Diaspora Film Festival has grown each year since its genesis in a kitchen-table conversation between a couple of film fanatics frustrated by the shallow pool of black films in New York. Starting today the 15th edition of the festival will offer something for just about anyone interested in the global black experience: 102 films from 43 countries in a 17-day feast of documentaries, comedies, musicals, dramas and romances.

title: The Gleaming Trophies for a Countrys Heroes
description: The urn that put Thomas Fletcher and Sidney Gardiner on the map greets visitors in all its gleaming, eclectic glory at the start of Silversmiths to the Nation at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Standing almost 30 inches from its hairy paw feet to the furrowed brow of a bellicose eagle mounted on the lid of its soup tureen bowl, it was, according to the exhibitions catalog, the heaviest, tallest and most complex work in silver ever produced in North America.

title: Laying Down the Vintage
description: ROB LIKOFF and Sheri Rosenblatt of Manhattan owned their weekend house in Easthampton, N.Y., for 10 years before installing a walk-in wine cellar with temperature and humidity controls. Before, they had simply stored wine in the basement.

title: Trying to Break Cycle of Prison at Street Level
description: HOUSTON  Corey Taylor, a convicted drug dealer, recently got out of prison and moved into his grandmothers house in Sunnyside, a south central Houston neighborhood of small, tidy yards.

title: Somali President Reveals Pick for Prime Minister
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 22  The president of battle-scarred Somalia on Thursday chose a man who has been both a police colonel and an aid official to be the new transitional prime minister, a decision that Western diplomats say could be a make-or-break one for the country.

title: The Playing Is Parody, but the Devotion Is Real
description: The Detroit Lions played yesterday on Thanksgiving for the 68th time. West of St. Louis, a couple of small-town high school football teams have gone at it on Thanksgiving for 100 years. In Union City, N.J., two high schools have done the same for 88 years, though their imminent merger will end that rivalry.

title: Lottery Numbers
Proposed Ban on Genetically Modified Corn in Europe
description: PARIS, Nov. 22  European Union environmental officials have determined that two kinds of genetically modified corn could harm butterflies, affect food chains and disturb life in rivers and streams, and they have proposed a ban on the sale of the seeds, which are made by DuPont Pioneer, Dow Agrosciences and Syngenta.

title: Players to Watch
description: Candace Parker

title: Canada: Man Dies After Shock From Taser
description: A 45-year-old man who had been arrested on assault charges died, about a day after the police in Nova Scotia used a Taser to subdue him. The man was the third person to die in Canada in just over a month after being shocked by Tasers wielded by police officers. Justice Minister Cecil Clarke ordered a review of the use of the hand-held stun guns following the mans death, the latest in a series of government inquiries into the use of Tasers by the police. Widespread outrage in Canada followed the broadcast of a video last month that showed another man being shocked at least twice with Tasers at a Vancouver airport by officers of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. The man, a Polish immigrant who appeared extremely confused on the video, died. A Montreal man also died last month, three days after he was subdued by the police with a Taser while being arrested for drunken driving.

title: Christophe Harbour and Wilderness at the Smokies
description: Christophe Harbour

title: An Art Nouveau Room Thick With Wisteria
description: Now tucked away on the second floor of the Metropolitan Museum, in its newly refurbished 19th- and early-20th-century European paintings and sculpture galleries, is an Art Nouveau period room that had languished in storage since 1966, when the Met acquired it in France.

title: Gunmen Dressed as Iraqi Troops Kill at Least 11 in Village Near Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 22  Men described by witnesses as Sunni insurgents dressed as Iraqi Army troops stormed a Sunni village on the southeastern outskirts of Baghdad at dawn on Thursday, killing at least 11 people during a three-hour firefight before American and Iraqi soldiers drove them off.

title: L.I. Woman Is Charged With Strangling Husband
description: A Long Island woman who was married in September to a man 21 years older, 8 inches taller and 100 pounds heavier was accused yesterday of strangling him with an electrical cord in their South Shore waterfront home while her 7-year-old daughter slept in an adjacent bedroom.

title: Nuclear Agency Wants More From Iran
description: VIENNA, Nov. 22  Iran is making progress in resolving suspicions about past nuclear activities but must do more before the International Atomic Energy Agency can verify important aspects of the countrys nuclear program, the agencys director said Thursday.

title: U.S.C. Keeps Its Pac-10 Hopes Alive
description: TEMPE, Ariz., Nov. 22 (AP)  Forty-seven days after an unimaginable loss to Stanford, Southern California is back in the Rose Bowl hunt.

title: Legal Dispute Forces Americas Cup Postponement
description: With a court ruling pending and negotiations at a standstill, Americas Cup organizers announced yesterday that the next edition, scheduled for 2009 in Valencia, Spain, would be postponed.

title: Restoring House to Home After the Floods in Queens
description: When a storm hit New York on Aug. 8, bringing a tornado and torrential rain, Kathleen Conways neighborhood in Woodside, Queens, was hit hard. Sewage and water flooded her live-in basement in minutes, knocking over steel shelves and putting bureaus and beds afloat. Ms. Conway helped her daughter and son-in-law grab what they could and went up to the first floor.

title: New Philadelphia Mayors Top Task: Fight Crime
description: PHILADELPHIA  The day after Michael Nutter won a landslide victory to become this citys next mayor, he put on a charcoal gray suit and drove to his first public event: the funeral of a police officer shot in a brazen daytime robbery.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Plan Increases Role of G.I.s in Iraq Training
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22  With violence in Iraq on the decline and a quarter of American combat brigades scheduled to leave by July, commanders plan to give the remaining brigades an expanded role in training and supporting Iraqi forces, according to officials involved in a confidential military review of the next phase of the American troop deployment.

title: Green Menace Is Back, Just in Time for Holidays
description: Patrick Page, it appears, is out of stamps. When youre reprising a seasonal role, and half of your audience hasnt yet celebrated a 10th birthday, youre supposed to be mailing it in, as they say. But Mr. Page, in his second year as the title crab face in Dr. Seuss How the Grinch Stole Christmas! The Musical at the St. James Theater on Broadway, is delivering an extraordinary performance.

title: $300 Billion in Write-Offs Is Predicted
description: FRANKFURT, Nov. 22  Losses in the distressed mortgage sector of the United States could reach $300 billion, only a portion of which has so far been accounted for by write-offs at major banks, according to a study released on Thursday by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

title: Where the Music Surrounds Him
description: IT had been a whirlwind couple of weeks for the trombonist Roswell Rudd: a performance in Berlin, a recording session in Brussels and, just hours after he got off the plane in New York, a master class and concert in western Massachusetts. At the end of it all last month, he retreated to his second home in Kerhonkson, N.Y., at the southern edge of the Catskills.

title: Plumbers Progress
description: Mario, the goofy, fat Italian plumber, is by far the most famous character in video games and perhaps one of the worlds most-recognized fictional characters in any medium. Think back, if you can, to 1981 and Donkey Kong. Mario was there.
