description: BEIRUT, Nov. 22  Nassib Lahoud, a contender for president, excused himself for a moment, interrupting an interview in his palatial living room, where the curtains have been drawn for two months as a precaution against would-be assassins.

title: China Cracking Down on Illegal Currency Conversion
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 22  When China announced plans in August to allow individual mainland investors to trade directly on the Hong Kong stock market, it was seen as a breakthrough that sent share prices soaring here.

title: Diplomatic Overtures in Fine Porcelain
description: Gift giving is the timely subject of Fragile Diplomacy: Meissen Porcelain for European Courts. The show, an examination of early German porcelain as a diplomatic tool, is ambitious and dazzling. Some 300 objects made between 1710 and 1763  pristine carved and modeled white vases, gilded teapots, animal-encrusted hunting cups and bowls decorated with bouquets of flowers  fill three floors at the Bard Graduate Center Gallery in Manhattan.

title: Colombia Ends Venezuelas Hostage Mediation Efforts
description: BOGOT, Colombia, Nov. 22  President lvaro Uribe withdrew his support late Wednesday for efforts by President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela to broker the release of dozens of hostages believed to be held by this countrys largest rebel group, including three American military contractors who were captured in 2003.

title: South Africa: Renault to Build
description: Renault of France will start building cars in South Africa from 2009 to expand its share of sales in rapidly growing emerging markets. The company will assemble entry-level Sandero cars at a plant owned by its affiliate, Nissan Motor, north of Pretoria, Patrick Pelata, Renaults vice president of Asia-Africa projects, told reporters in Johannesburg. Renault may export the car to other parts of Africa and to Europe. South Africa produced 590,000 vehicles last year, giving it a share of world production of just under 1 percent. The government encourages exports by giving carmakers discounts on imported vehicles and components. Renaults chief executive, Carlos Ghosn, says he intends to increase the companys total sales by 39 percent, to 3.33 million vehicles, in the next three years.

title: Spanish Civil War, This Time Fought in Pixels
description: MADRID, Nov. 22  A new video game that invites players to rewrite the course of Spains devastating civil war has touched a nerve in a country that is often reluctant to revisit its past, let alone play with it.

title: A Fallen Plane Is Loaded With Tensions
description: The synopsis of this film by Izuru Narushima promises a Jerry Bruckheimer-style pyrotechnic action picture. But the result is a personal and political melodrama with perfunctory gunplay and explosions.

title: On the Jersey Shore, a Question of Beach Access
description: LONG BRANCH, N.J.

title: Banks Gone Wild
description: What were they smoking? asks the cover of the current issue of Fortune magazine. Underneath the headline are photos of recently deposed Wall Street titans, captioned with the staggering sums they managed to lose.

title: Eni of Italy Signs a Pipeline Deal With Gazprom
description: BERLIN, Nov. 22  Gazprom, the Russian state-owned energy giant, strengthened its grip on the European natural gas market on Thursday by signing a contract with Eni, the Italian energy group, to conduct a feasibility study on a pipeline linking Russia to Europe via the Black Sea.

title: Family of Strangers on the Sunset Limited
description: WHERE else can you dine with an astronomer and a Buddhist monk? said Ann Smith, a retired teacher from California heading home across Texas aboard the Sunset Limited.

title: Critique of Iranian Leader Reveals Political Rift
description: TEHRAN, Nov. 22  An influential hard-line newspaper has made a rare direct attack on President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad over his recent harsh accusations against veteran politicians before parliamentary elections in March.

title: Ballet and African Steps, Delivered at Warp Speed
description: In preparation for The Peace Project, a new program presented by Complexions Contemporary Ballet during the second half of its Joyce Theater stint, the companys artistic directors, Dwight Rhoden and Desmond Richardson, asked the participating artists, What does peace mean to you?

title: Court Loyal to Musharraf Clears Re-election Path
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 22 Pakistans Supreme Court, stacked with appointees loyal to Gen. Pervez Musharraf, dismissed the last legal challenge to his re-election as president on Thursday, paving the way for his swearing-in to a second five-year term.

title: The Sum of Their Parts
description: The first thing that struck me as I sat in the Rattlestick Playwrights Theater on Tuesday for the New York premiere of Noah Haidles Rag and Bone was the extent to which one of its lead actors, Michael Chernus, bore a likeness to Mario Batali, the chef and restaurateur. The resemblance made me hungry.

title: Theater Listings
description: KLEYNKUNST! After the First World War, Poland became an independent nation after more than a hundred years of foreign rule. In Warsaw, where a quarter of the population was Jewish, the citys rising class of secular Jews included lots of artistic types who were riding the new wave of Polish nationhood and looking toward a bright future. Kleynkunst teaters (little art houses) thrived during this vibrant period, offering irreverent, politically charged Yiddish cabaret that drew from a variety of sources, including Weimar cabaret, Russian folk music, jazz, tango and traditional cantorial music. Sadly, its a type of performance that has largely been lost to time, but Rebecca Joy Fletcher, the writer and creator of Kleynkunst! Warsaws Brave and Brilliant Yiddish Cabaret, is bringing it back. Its almost unimaginable for most American Jews how vital, hip and avant-garde Yiddish-speaking Warsaw was between the wars, she said.

We couldnt enjoy its loveliness any more if we had millions of dollars and ropes of diamonds.

title: African Diaspora Film Festival: Screenings and More
description: The African Diaspora Film Festival opens today and runs through Dec. 9 with screenings of more than 100 films, as well as panel discussions and parties, at several Manhattan sites. Today at the Anthology Film Archives, 32 Second Avenue, at Second Street, East Village: Goodbye Momo (Uruguay, 2005), at 1 p.m.; City Teacher (United States, 2007), at 3 p.m.; Samual (The Netherlands/Ghana, 2005) and No Time to Die (Ghana/Germany, 2006), at 5:15 p.m.; A Winter Tale (Canada, 2007), at 7:45 p.m.; and Marrakech Inshallah (United States/Morocco, 2007), at 10:20 p.m.

title: Bondss Defense Team to Add Some Experience
description: Barry Bonds will retain his lead criminal defense lawyer, Michael L. Rains, and add at least one more lawyer with more experience in federal court as he prepares to defend himself against charges of perjury and obstruction of justice, Bondss personal lawyer said Wednesday.

Reminiscent of the leaked information in Italy during the heat of the spy scandal, a McLaren memo was leaked to the British press overnight that makes the Renault story look worse than previously described. The key word is the 780 drawings of the McLaren car  reminiscent of the 780 pages of Ferrari data that McLaren had.

But last week they took in the Michigan-Ohio State game, finding out how love can trump even the fiercest of rivalries. They also got to see some cars get smashed and to get the lowdown on the N.F.L. draft from St. Louis safety Corey Chavous. Gas up your tank. Its time to hit the road.

Richard Paeys Thanksgiving

Yesterday was a considerable improvement, as you can tell from this headline in the Tampa Tribune: Pardoned Man Thankful To Be With Loved Ones.

Hopefully this weekend will bring the kind of excitement that weve been used to since the season began. As always, if you have your own thoughts about these games, feel free to let us know.

description: IRVING, Tex., Nov. 23  Excellence on the field has proved elusive and so the Jets must find comfort in this existential idea: It may be better to have played and lost to the two best teams in the National Football League than not to have played them at all.

description: A music column on Thursday about the outreach and education programs that were part of Carnegie Halls recent Berlin in Lights festival, which included performances by the Simn Bolvar Youth Orchestra of Venezuela, misstated part of the term referring to Venezuelas program of orchestral training and music instruction. It is el sistema, not la sistema.

title: Greene Impresses Again in Syracuse Victory

Season Tip-Off tournament. Five seasons after Carmelo Anthony, then a freshman, led Syracuse to a national championship, the Orange has another young gun that could take it a long way.

title: Jets Snags Dont Deter Boeings Fans
description: BOEING has been blessed with a nearly perfect environment in which to do business, at least until recently. Persistently low interest rates and a sizzling global economy, apart from the odd credit squeeze, are ideal conditions for selling commercial jets.

description: The Medicare doughnut hole is the federal provision that older Americans love to hate.

title: Thinking Beyond Annapolis
description: The invitations have been delivered and it looks as if there will indeed be an American-led conference next week in Annapolis to address the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. After six years of neglecting the issue, President Bush and Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice are to be commended for finally trying. Just getting all the key players in the same room, however, assuming they can pull that off, will not be enough.

title: No Conditions for Talking to Obama, but Many Questions
description: So, its Jan. 20, 2009, and Barack Obama has just been sworn in as president.

title: Enemy Aircraft Sighted and, Above All Else, Heard

title: Parents, Children and Immigration Nightmares
description: To the Editor:

title: Australias Prime Minister Defeated After Four Terms
description: SYDNEY, Nov. 24   Prime Minister John Howard of Australia suffered a comprehensive defeat today, with a coalition led by his Liberal Party losing its majority in parliament.

title: Loss of Tax Data Rocks British Government
description: LONDON, Nov. 23  The uproar over the British tax agencys loss of computer disks with personal and financial information on about 25 million Britons has rocked the five-month-old government of Prime Minister Gordon Brown, raising new questions about its competence and ability to withstand the challenge of a resurgent Conservative Party.

title: Deputy Finance Minister Is Charged in Russia
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 23  Russian prosecutors charged a deputy finance minister who was the countrys chief sovereign debt negotiator on Friday with conspiring to embezzle $43.4 million in a politically tinged case seen as undermining the position of liberals in the Russian government.

title: Housing History Sends Recession Warning
description: THE Federal Reserve Board forecast this week that there will be no recession in the United States in the foreseeable future. It says the gross domestic product will grow by as little as 1.6 percent in 2008, but is confident that growth will accelerate after that.

title: Bargain Hunting on Wall Street
description: Holiday shoppers werent the only ones seeking bargains yesterday.

title: Denmark: Three Sentenced in Bomb Plot
description: A court sentenced two Danish Muslims and an Iraqi Kurd to prison sentences ranging from 4 to 11 years for planning a bomb attack in Copenhagen. A fourth man was acquitted. The men were accused of planning to bomb Copenhagens City Hall Square or the Tivoli amusement park to protest the publication of cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad in a Danish newspaper, as well as the presence of Danish soldiers in Iraq. The four were among nine people arrested last year and accused of collecting bomb-making materials.

title: New Yorks Gambling Dens
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg, who is already famous for getting rid of the smoke in New York Citys bars, has now taken on gambling. The mayors target is the citys Off-Track Betting parlors, which were established more than 35 years ago to reroute profits from illegal back-room bookies to the state government. The misnamed parlors were also intended to offer a convenient alternative for bettors who could not get to the tracks.

title: Bomb at a Market Shatters Lull for Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 23  Last Friday, the Ghazil animal market was a crowded bazaar in a city willing itself into recovery. Cautious but hopeful parents led fun-starved children by the hand to show them parakeets, tropical fish and twittering chicks painted in bright, improbable hues.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A music review on Thursday about Liz Callaway, at the Metropolitan Room, misstated the evening of the performance that was reviewed. It was Tuesday evening, not Wednesday.

title: A Turnaround Plan That Includes Baconators
description: KERRII ANDERSON believes she has a good story to tell about her tenure as chief executive at Wendys, but she has struggled to find anyone willing to listen.

title: Lost in a Flood of Debt
description: CHICAGO

title: Bargains Draw Crowds, but the Thrill Is Gone
description: American consumers flooded stores yesterday on the traditional first day of the holiday shopping season, but the irrational exuberance of the Black Fridays of the last five years has been replaced by pragmatic restraint.

title: Fire and Con Ed Officials Defend Gas Leak Response
description: The Fire Department and Consolidated Edison yesterday defended their responses to a gas leak that resulted in a deadly explosion in a home in Sunnyside, Queens, on Wednesday.

title: Serenading Sculptures in Dance at Louvre
description: PARIS, Nov. 23  The space could hardly be more theatrical. Stretching 300 feet through two galleries of the Louvre, it leads from Michelangelos statue The Dying Slave, past the marble poses of Greek gods and Roman senators, to the foot of the grand staircase leading to The Winged Victory of Samothrace.

title: Thomass Knicks Reign Appears Near an End
description: I had hoped that Isiah Lord Thomas would be the prince who turned the frog into a champion.

title: Vote Is Postponed as Lebanese President Leaves
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Saturday, Nov. 24  The departing Lebanese president, mile Lahoud, asked the military to take charge of the nations security on Friday, a few hours after the speaker of Parliament prolonged the countrys political crisis by postponing for a week a vote to choose a new president.

title: Chris Long Depends on Hard Work More Than Famous Name
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Nov. 20  Virginia defensive end Chris Long sat on a trainers table with an intravenous drip stuck in his left forearm. He had strep throat as well as a hesitancy to scale back, as evidenced by the 45-minute weightlifting session he had just completed.

title: Russia: Deal for Nickel Complex
description: Three of Russias richest men are in advanced stages of negotiations over the sale of a 25 percent stake in the Norilsk Nickel mining and smelting complex in Siberia. The factory, built by gulag prisoners, produces 20 percent of the worlds supply of nickel, an alloy used in stainless steel.

title: Broadway Now Brighter as The Grinch Reopens
description: The stagehands strike had most of the theaters on West 44th Street dark. The Majestic Theater, home to The Phantom of the Opera, and the Shubert, festooned with posters for Monty Pythons Spamalot, stood empty.

title: The Continuing Cult of Glenn Gould, Deserved or Not
description: When Glenn Gould died unexpectedly in 1982, a victim of a stroke at the unseemly age of 50, his red-hot reputation had calmed to a simmer. Gould, a sufferer from extreme stage fright but a winner in the stock market, had quit performing in public 18 years earlier, using the proceeds of his financial ventures to soften the burdens of early retirement. Much of his time later was spent with television projects in his native Toronto, not all of which had to do with the piano.

title: Transit Strike Across France Winds Down
description: PARIS, Nov. 23  The transportation strike that snarled traffic, shortened tempers and frayed the fabric of daily life in France for 10 days wound down on Friday, with most trains, buses and subways rumbling back into service.

title: Far From Beijings Reach, Officials Bend Energy Rules
description: QINGTONGXIA, China  When the central government in Beijing announced an ambitious nationwide campaign to reduce energy consumption two years ago, officials in this western regional capital got right to work: not to comply, but to engineer creative schemes to evade the requirements.

title: Courthouse Bombings Strike 3 Indian Cities
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 23  At least 13 people were killed and more than 60 were wounded Friday in a series of nearly simultaneous bomb blasts outside courthouses in three cities in northern India, the authorities said.

title: An American in Paris, Making Classical Dance Training (Gasp!) Fun
description: PARIS  Brooke Desnos was 10 or 11 when her parents sought to enroll her in the Alabama Ballet School. Can you frog? asked Sonia Arova, the star ballerina turned teacher. What Ms. Arova meant, in ballet parlance, was could she lie on her tummy and splay her legs like a frog, a test to see if she had the flexibility to dance. Puzzled, young Brooke crouched down like a frog and began hopping around the room. She died laughing, Ms. Desnos said.

title: New Jersey Company That Recalled Hamburger Meat Declares Bankruptcy
description: The Topps Meat Company of Elizabeth, N.J., which nearly two months ago recalled 21.7 million pounds of hamburger meat, has declared bankruptcy, according to papers filed on Wednesday in federal bankruptcy court in Newark.

title: A Brooklyn Arena and the Street: Whats the Right Distance?
description: Throughout the contentious prehistory of the Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn, just about every fact and figure about the planned development has been passionately debated, from the height of its tallest building, to the number of apartments that will be affordable to those of modest means, to the amount of taxpayer financing it will require.

title: Shortsighted Management
description: SENIOR managements that focus on immediate results have been blamed for ethical lapses and shortchanging their companies future. But that may be only the start of the story.

title: Netherlands: Akzo Offers to Sell Assets
description: Akzo Nobel, the worlds largest maker of paints and coatings, has offered to sell assets including its British Crown brand to win European antitrust approval for its proposed $16 billion purchase of Imperial Chemical Industries.

title: In Bushs Last Year, Modest Domestic Aims
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23  As President Bush looks toward his final year in office, with Democrats controlling Congress and his major domestic initiatives dead on Capitol Hill, he is shifting his agenda to what aides call kitchen table issues  small ideas that affect ordinary peoples lives and do not take an act of Congress to put in place.

title: The War on Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Kerik Loan Activity Is Brought to Light After Indictment
description: Bernard B. Kerik fully repaid a $250,000 personal loan cited in his recent federal indictment days after city investigators began asking about it in 2005, according to people who have been briefed on the transaction.

title: Jump the Shark
description: WHILE there are, admittedly, figures more deserving of sympathy than unemployed pool players, the demise of the hustler is an occasion to be mourned. As recently as 10 years ago, it was possible for a pool player to earn a living hustling, provided he was armed with the requisite chops and disposition. Plenty of roadmen made plenty of money with scores at Chelsea Billiards in Manhattan or Mikeys 24/7 in Oklahoma City or the Sports Palace in Columbia, S.C. Odds were good that there was at least one unsuspecting local in the joint with an inflated impression of his talent for pocketing balls, and thus a willingness to throw down big timber against the out-of-towner.

title: There Are Alternatives: Insuring to Bridge the Gap or Opting Out
description: One way for Medicare Part D enrollees to deal with the doughnut hole is to insure themselves against it. Another way is to simply not get involved with Part D in the first place.

title: The Tale of the Tuna
description: To the Editor:

title: Lottery Numbers
The Many Errors in Thinking About Mistakes
description: OF the many mistakes I have no doubt made over the last few weeks, two stand out: One cost me money and one cost me some pride.

title: Municipal Fraud Inquiry Clouds Washington Anew
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23  It takes a lifetime to build a reputation  and a moment to destroy it.

title: Robert McNair, Governor of South Carolina in the 60s, Dies at 83
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 23  Former Gov. Robert E. McNair of South Carolina, the political moderate who was a finalist to become Vice President Hubert H. Humphreys running mate in 1968 but whose promising career was cut short by what became known as the Orangeburg Massacre, died last Saturday in Charleston. He was 83.

title: A Revisionist Historian Looks at Religious Toleration
description: At this moment, there may be no more important story than the one Europeans and Americans proudly tell themselves about the rise of religious toleration. So please take note of Benjamin J. Kaplans argument that the story may be dangerously flawed.

title: Taking Science on Faith
description: Tempe, Ariz.

title: Two Blasts Target Pakistani Military
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 24  Two suicide car bombers attacked military targets this morning in Rawalpindi, the site of military headquarters, killing at least 15 service personnel, a military spokesman said. The bombings raise tensions in the country, which is already beset with political and security problems.

title: Britain: Banks Buy Utility
description: JPMorgan Chase and Commonwealth Bank of Australia agreed to buy the United Utilities power-distribution unit in Britain for 1.14 billion ($2.34 billion), adding electricity customers to their British water assets.

title: For Film Companies, a State of Flux
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 23  When Brad Pitt dropped out of the political thriller State of Play at the 11th hour on Wednesday, he did more than throw a wrench into the works of one of the highest-profile movie productions under way in a Hollywood already overheated by strike-related contingency planning. He might have helped tip the balance of power between actors and studios, at least temporarily, in the employers favor.

title: Bearing Aid, U.S. Vows to Tread Lightly in Bangladesh
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh, Nov. 23  As an American warship with more than 3,000 troops arrived off the coast of Bangladesh to help deliver food, water and medicine to the most remote corners of this cyclone-battered country, United States military officials took pains on Friday to say they would not take any steps that might seem intrusive.

title: Asking Hard Questions About Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Theft of Grave Markers Spurs Outrage and Call for Crackdown
description: CAYUGA, N.Y.  Under the outstretched limbs of oaks, Revolutionary-era headstones, some covered with lichen, tilt this way and that, while new monuments reveal the doting attentions of the living. As resting places go, Lake View Cemetery is special: five acres where generations of local families lie buried beside the clear waters of Cayuga Lake.

title: The Circus Is in Town. All Over It, in Fact, in Six Troupes.
description: For three decades, the Big Apple Circus has virtually owned the Christmas-circus season, and has brought its one-ring show to Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center since 1980, after three years in considerably less iconic locales.

title: One Way to Help
description: Last January, The Times profiled a bright young woman named Wanda Reynoso, a teenager whose bone marrow disorder left her weakened and ill.

title: Subways Increasingly Running Late; Problem Is Worst During Morning Rush
description: More and more subway trains have been running behind schedule this year, part of a trend that has seen the number of late trains increase every year since 2004, according to data compiled by New York City Transit.

title: A Year Later, Poisoned Agents Family Accuse Russia
description: LONDON, Nov. 23  On a day of private grief and public anger, the family and friends of Alexander Litvinenko, a former K.G.B. officer poisoned in London a year ago, identified a Russian nuclear plant for the first time on Friday as the likely source of the radioactive isotope that killed him.

title: Detective Misses 5 Calls to Testify in Beating
description: Despite a court order, a police detective has repeatedly failed to show up to give a deposition in a Brooklyn mans lawsuit charging police brutality. Now the city says the detective has retired and cannot be found, an explanation that has failed to satisfy the judge overseeing the case.

title: Giuliani and Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Freeing Chimps From Labs
description: To the Editor:

title: Saudis to Join Mideast Talks; Syria Wavers
description: CAIRO, Nov. 23  Saudi Arabia joined 14 other Arab nations on Friday in an agreement to attend the American-sponsored Middle East peace conference in Annapolis, Md., next week, while Syria  the last key holdout  was inching closer toward agreeing to participate.

title: Australia: Election Day
description: Australians are voting today in general elections that are expected to bring the end of 11 years in power for Prime Minister John Howard, one of President Bushs closest allies. But opinion polls showed that Mr. Howard had closed some of the gap between his coalition and the Labor Party led by Kevin Rudd. Mr. Howard campaigned on his economic record, saying a Labor victory would threaten Australias prosperity. Mr. Rudd has said that one of his first steps if elected would be to negotiate a withdrawal of the countrys 500 troops in Iraq.

title: Turning Things Around, and Up a Notch
description: EVANSVILLE, Ind., Nov. 18  The new coach at the University of Evansville stalked the court one afternoon last week, clapping his hands, waving his arms, urging his young team to play tougher defense. At 6 feet 5 inches and about 300 pounds, Marty Simmons moved from the baseline to midcourt at Roberts Municipal Stadium, sweaty and scowling, before finally halting practice and bellowing, Get over here.

title: Congressman Sees Bias in Chicago Traffic Stop
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 23  A black Congressman who was issued a ticket this week after being pulled over while driving with three black passengers has accused the Chicago police of racial profiling in the traffic stop.

title: Theatergoers Rejoice at Return of the Grinch
description: The ongoing stagehands strike had most of the theaters on West 44th Street dark. The Majestic Theater, home to The Phantom of the Opera, and the Shubert, festooned with posters for Monty Pythons Spamalot, stood empty. But the sidewalk outside the St. James Theater, where Dr. Seuss How the Grinch Stole Christmas! The Musical reopened for an 11 a.m. Friday matinee, was thronged.

title: Immigration and the 08 Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: The Wary Skies of Modern Travelers
description: Predictions that five million travelers will lose pieces of checked luggage at some point this year provide depressing food for thought as we line up belt-free and shoeless, clutching the see-through bags of mini-measured toiletry vials that are demanded of modern air travelers. There is plenty of time, while creeping through the security maze, to ruminate over questions like whether potential terrorists have the same preoccupations as the Homeland Security authorities who issue their increasingly detailed instructions.

title: Bland Menu if Cable Goes  la Carte
description: Twice in the last few months, Ive written columns about the bitter carriage dispute between the NFL Network and the nations two largest cable companies, Comcast and Time Warner. This column, I swear, is not going to be the third in a series. As annoyed as I remain over the tactics of the National Football League, Ive had my say.

title: With Thomass Job in Question, the Knicks Snap Streak
description: The worst Knicks losing streak in two seasons mercifully ended Saturday afternoon when they finally found a team in worse shape than they are.

title: Knicks Face Bulls; Thomas Faces Fans
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Nov. 23  The consequences for a depressing losing streak and an unsightly record are expected to be simple and straightforward: Isiah Thomas will be forced to stand on the Madison Square Garden court Saturday afternoon and endure cacophonous vitriol, most of it directed at him.

title: An Illness Brings Hardship; a Diagnosis, Relief
description: Shanta Williams worries that one day she will wake up and have one child, not two.

title: Barely Getting By and Facing a Cold Maine Winter
description: MILBRIDGE, Me.  They have worked since their teens in backbreaking seasonal jobs, extracting resources from the sea and the forest. Their yards are filled with peeling boats and broken lobster traps.

title: Time to Speak Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Too Much Turkey? State Employees in New Jersey Worked It Off
description: NEWARK, Nov. 23  Duane Buck, a senior postal clerk at the New Jersey Motor Vehicle Commission, usually spends the day after Thanksgiving Christmas shopping with his wife.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about a judges ruling forcing the St. James Theater, part of the Jujamcyn theater chain, to open for performances of Dr. Seuss How the Grinch Stole Christmas! The Musical referred imprecisely to a decision by the chain to impose new work rules last month on stagehands, who are now on strike. While it did not impose them on stagehands at the St. James, it did on the stagehands at its other four Broadway theaters.

title: In Board-a-Match Contest, Down Two Was Good Enough
description: The premier event at the Fall North American Championships at the San Francisco Marriott is the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams, which will be contested on next Friday and Dec. 1 and 2.

title: Bounty Not Trickling Down
description: To the Editor:

title: Croatias Prime Minister Looks for Votes From Croats Living in Bosnia
description: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina  There is no avoiding Ivo Sanaders glare on Mese Selimovica Boulevard.

title: Man Dies of Stabbing at Nightclub in Flatiron
description: A 25-year-old man was fatally stabbed in Manhattan early yesterday, at a nightclub in the Flatiron District, the police said.

title: Britain: Slower Growth in Third Quarter
description: Britains economic growth unexpectedly slowed to the weakest pace in a year during the third quarter as service industries cooled and factory production stalled. Gross domestic product rose 0.7 percent in the three months through September, the Office for National Statistics said in London.

title: F.D.A. Staff Recommends a Warning on Flu Drugs
description: Makers of the two most common drugs used to treat and prevent flu should add warnings that they may cause psychiatric side effects, federal regulators have recommended.

title: Dismissing Thomas Could Backfire on Garden
description: Not long ago, a sexual harassment lawsuit appeared to be the greatest threat to Isiah Thomass position as coach and president of the Knicks. Now, that very same lawsuit could possibly help Thomas keep his job.

description: To the Editor:

title: Left Off Debate List, New Orleans Sees Politics at Play
description: When presidential debates are in the news, it is usually because of something a candidate says. But the omission of New Orleans this week from the roster of four cities that will hold the 2008 debates raised the question of whether politics was behind the site-selection process.

title: A Letter Grade for Schools?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Detours of a Coaching Life
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 23  With Kansas only two victories from playing for college footballs national championship, perhaps the only thing more unlikely than its undefeated record and No. 2 Bowl Championship Series ranking is Coach Mark Manginos ascent to the top of his profession.

title: Being Skeptical of Green
description: EVERY retail trend has its excesses. In the late 90s, the natural supplement fad reached a zenith (or nadir) with the introduction of potato chips laced with St. Johns wort, said to be a natural cure for depression.

title: Icy Rescue as Seas Claim a Cruise Ship
description: They were modern adventure travelers, following the doomed route of Sir Ernest Shackleton to the frozen ends of the earth. They paid $7,000 to $16,000 to cruise on a ship that had proudly plowed the Antarctic for 40 years.

title: A Filmmaker and a Challenger of Brazils Conscience
description: RIO de JANEIRO

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,866 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Symphony Will Sell a Collection in Dispute
description: A group of investors, including businessmen who are twin brothers and amateur violinists, have agreed to buy a controversial collection of rare string instruments from the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra. The investors are to pay the orchestra $20 million and a share of the proceeds from the instruments future sale.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article last Saturday about an illegal immigrant mother who was separated from her baby, an American citizen, after a search by immigration agents in Ohio misstated the minimum age when American citizens can petition for their parents to immigrate legally to this country. It is 21, not 18. (Go to Article)

title: Citing Weak Dollar, Airbus Chief Talks of More Cost Cuts
description: BREMEN, Germany, Nov. 23 (Reuters)  Airbus faces a serious dollar problem that is forcing it to consider cutting costs more deeply, its chief executive, Thomas O. Enders, said Friday.

title: In Plans for Railyards, a Mix of Towers and Parks
description: The West Side railyards are the kind of urban development project that makes builders dance in the streets. A footprint bigger than Rockefeller Centers and the potential for more commercial and residential space than ground zero: what more could an urban visionary want?

title: Publisher Gets Web Readers to Fill the Pages of Its Magazines
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 21  A funny thing happened while Halsey Minor was trying to kill print journalism. He ended up publishing magazines  big, heavy magazines, with beautiful pictures on quality paper  the kind he and others had declared obsolete.

title: Top-Ranked L.S.U. Falls; Title Picture Is Blurred
description: Unranked Arkansas stunned top-ranked Louisiana State in Baton Rouge, La., yesterday, further scrambling the national championship race and continuing a season-long pattern of upheaval in college football.

title: Selling Jewelry Is Mostly Pitfalls, Not Much Glitter
description: IT may be a cameo handed down from your grandmother or your fathers 1940s Hamilton watch or a ring you bought years ago that you no longer wear and now want to sell. While buying jewelry, whether at department or specialty stores, craft fairs or on eBay, is quick and easy, selling it is often slow, difficult and confusing.

title: Fixing Subways With Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: West Side Railyards
description: Images of the five development proposals for the West Side Railyards.

description: by Paul Geitner

title: Pop Art in the Popes Stables
description: JFK courtesy of the Scuderie

title: In the Raids Wake
description: Though accused of immigration violations, the men who were arrested in a raid in Greenport, N.Y., were known as good workers and family men.

title: L.A. Auto Show: Driving Hondas Fuel-Cell FCX
description: LOS ANGELES  Before hustling off to LAX for my flight home from the auto show last Sunday, I spent a morning driving what may be the most advanced road vehicle on the planet: the Honda FCX Clarity. This fuel-cell-powered car, unveiled in production-ready form at the convention center earlier in the week, will be built in small numbers and leased next summer to retail customers for their everyday use.

title: Saturday Kickoff: Nebraska Fires Callahan
description: To the surprise of no one, Bill Callahan is out as Nebraskas head football coach. Tom Osborne announced Callahans firing this morning, a day after the Cornhuskers lost 65-51 at Colorado to complete a 5-7 season. Brian Christopherson of the Lincoln Journal Star reports that Nebraska has already contacted the current L.S.U. defensive coordinator and former Cornhuskers defensive coordinator Bo Pelini about the job.

title: The Greench Who Guilt-Tripped Christmas
description: The holidays have always been an emotionally combustible time for families. But that was before the finger-wagging eco-evangelist killjoy made the scene. Read more

title: Chris Longs Cowboy Way
description: Virginia defensive end Chris Long admits he is quite competitive. The former Dallas Cowboys executive Gil Brandt witnessed this firsthand last May, when Long was riding a mechanical bull at a Playboy party.

title: The Early Word: Candidates as Managers
description: As they run for C.E.O. of the nation, the candidates management abilities are in focus in todays papers. The Timess Michael Luo looks at Mitt Romneys governing and campaign style, which is heavily influenced by his years as a business consultant:

title: Romneys Dig at His Friend
description: AMHERST, N.H.  Mitt Romney and Rudolph W. Giuliani are pals.

title: The Work of Saul Steinberg
description: The drawings, cartoon sketches and other work of Saul Steinberg show off the range of an artist as closely attuned to 20th-century American life as almost anyone.

title: Personnel File: Once Again, Dayne Makes a Late Arrival
description: With the seasons end drawing near, it is once again time for Ron Dayne, a backup running back for the Texans, to stand tall. In the teams past two games, Dayne, filling in for the injured Ahman Green, has rumbled for 211 yards and a touchdown. Similarly, from Weeks 13 through 16 last season, Dayne amassed 429 yards and 5 touchdowns.

title: Week 12 in Preview: Buccaneers Face a Test of Their Progress
description: Going by division standings, the game between the Buccaneers and the Redskins today in Tampa, Fla., is a matchup of the first-place team in the National Football Conference South and a team tied for last place in the N.F.C East. But Tampa Bay (6-4) and Washington (5-5) are separated by only one game in the conference standings, and winning this game is vital to each teams playoff hopes.

title: Welcome to Morgantown, Center of the Universe
description: MORGANTOWN, W.Va.  Here at the foot of the Allegheny Mountains, they are starting to party like its 1988.Thats the last time the Mountaineers had such a clear shot at the national title. That Major Harris-led team lost to Notre Dame in the Fiesta Bowl.If West Virginia defeats Connecticut today and Pittsburgh next week, it will most likely play for the national title on Jan. 7 in New Orleans. That notion hasnt been lost on the locals.Zippy Shearer, a member of that 1988 team, said in the parking lot before the game that folks at a local Buffalo Wild Wings last night celebrated Arkansass upset of top-ranked Louisiana State by hoisting chairs in the air. The Arkansas victory put West Virginia, which entered the week No. 3 in the Bowl Championship Series, into the top two.Our run came a little more out of nowhere, Shearer said in comparing his team with the current team. They were ranked to start the season.The feeling that the Mountaineers are on the cusp of something special could be felt throughout the parking lots surrounding Milan Puskar Stadium.Bill Henderson had just finished deep-frying a turkey at his tailgate, which was marked by the pirate flag hanging over the trailer. He said the main talk of the morning was about making flight and hotel reservations for New Orleans.Theres a lot more anxiety, he said when asked the difference between todays tailgate and most others.A few yards away, Greg Stevens was sipping Crown Royal from a plastic cup and savoring the moment. He has been a season-ticket holder for 20 years, and before that he patrolled the sidelines while working for the West Virginia State Police. He said he thought that the Mountaineers would beat Connecticut by 14 points. When Pittsburgh comes here next weekend, it could be a different story, however.The backyard brawl is never easy, Stevens said.He took another sip of Crown Royal and continued soaking in the rarefied air in Morgantown, the improbable center of the college football universe.

title: Kansas Farmyard Distillery
description: Seth Fox decided two years ago to take advantage of generations of his family's moonshining expertise to supply high-end spirits.

title: Aboard the Pushpak Express
description: Dreams in tow, rural passengers aboard India's Pushpak Express  hope to build better lives for themselves in the city.

title: Week 12 Fantasy Football Picks
description: So I had a couple misses on Thanksgiving. Clemens, Cotchery, Leon Washington for three. (Man, I really underestimated just how bad the Jets really are). But Im still glowing like a debutante opening a Tiffany box about my dead-on call of Anthony Gonzalezs 6 catch/105 yard game. Im going to put that and last weeks Vince Young prediction on my gravestone. Which is kind of pathetic considering that those fantasy stats will bump things like Loving Father and Devoted Husband. I think my priorities might be a tad askew.

title: A Strenuous Parade
description: DERRY, N.H.Mitt Romney is developing something of a trademark style for doing paradeshe jogs them.

title: Could Orgeron Help at U.S.C.?
description: How could a fired coach in Oxford, Miss., help rejuvenate a dynasty in Los Angeles?

title: No Conditions for Talking to Obama, but Many Questions
description: In her Web column today, Helene Cooper envisions a Barack Obama presidency, including the issues surrounding his pledge to meet with Iranian leaders without preconditions. Go to column

title: Sundays Breakfast Menu, Nov. 25
description: Like turkey and cranberry sauce, the war in Iraq and presidential politics mesh perfectly on Sundays talk show schedules. Patrick Healys latest article about how Democrats are shifting their tones as violence eases in Baghdad is a good prelude.

title: Letters: The Readers Speak
description: Re The Campaign and the Horse Race (Nov. 18):

title: Clinton Takes On Student Loan Industry
description: SIOUX CITY, Iowa  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton had some tough words Saturday afternoon for the college student loan industry, saying banks and other lenders had ripped off students with high interest rates and repayment plans that were onerous on recent graduates and their families.

title: Let The Debate Continue
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va.  What would November be without some serious debate about college football? So we at The Quad want to know how you think West Virginia stacks up with Ohio State.

title: On Patrol in Afghanistan
description: A platoon from the 82nd Airborne Division searched for Taliban fighters with Afghan security forces.

title: Obama and Clinton Tangle Over Health Care
description: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa  As they campaigned in western Iowa today, two Democratic presidential rivals gently tangled over their health care plans, with Senator Barack Obama drawing criticism from Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton after suggesting his plan would cut costs and help consumers more than any other proposal in this race.

title: Radio Interview With Relative Choices Writers
description: Listen to an interview on National Public Radios Talk of the Nation with three writers from Relative Choices  Katy Robinson, Jeff Gammage and Sumeia Williams, first broadcast on Nov. 20. The writers discuss their personal experiences with adoption and the stories they have shared this month.

title: The Song of the Hunted Humpback Whale
description: The clash between Japan and many Western nations over killing whales clicked up another notch last week. As Japanese whalers, claiming to operate under the mantle of science, steamed toward waters near Antarctica, one of the new species on their harvest list was the humpback  a whale whose eerie song became a platinum-selling recording and whose full-body breaches are a draw for whale watching fleets worldwide.

title: Chadron State 76, Abilene Christian 73. Honest.
description: Remember Danny Woodhead of tiny Chadron State in Nebraska? He was involved in one of the most exciting games in N.C.A.A. playoff history yesterday, when Chadron State rallied from a 29-point deficit to defeat visiting Abilene Christian, 76-73, in three overtimes.

title: Ada Sheng, Brad Williams
description: Ada Yue-Hong Sheng, a daughter of Deborah W. Sheng and Ping Sheng of Princeton, N.J., and Hong Kong, was married on Tuesday to Dr. William Bradford Williams, a son of Carolyn L. Williams of Raleigh, N.C., and Bill C. Williams of Wilmington, N.C. Morris E. Lasker, a Federal District Court judge in Boston, officiated in his chambers. In August, Sujit Raman, a friend of the couple, led a ceremony at Prospect House, the faculty club at Princeton University, where the brides father gave a Chinese blessing.

title: Raha Ramezani and James Brown
description: Raha Ramezani, the daughter of Mojgan and Mohammed Reza Ramezani of Bayside, Queens, was married yesterday to James Patrick Brown, a son of Linda and James Brown of Dover, N.J. The Rev. Leslie Harry, an interfaith minister, officiated at Studio 450, an event space in Manhattan, where Jaleh Moslehi led a Persian cultural ceremony.

title: Thompson Woos Gun Rights Contingent
description: LADSON, S.C., Nov. 24  Joe McCormick, a burly man over six feet tall, a World War II-era Mauser rifle at his side, said he was frightened.

title: In Europe, Fractional Properties Have Room to Grow
description: Claus Soerensen became a fractional owner of a second home before the term was even coined. Years ago, Mr. Soerensen inherited a share of a vacation house that had once belonged to his great-grandfather. When other heirs sold their shares, he essentially owned the house in common with strangers.

title: Correction: The Devil Went Down to Broadway
description: An article on Nov. 11 about the play The Seafarer misidentified the speaker of a line in Marlowes Doctor Faustus. It was a line from Mephostophilis, who is a messenger to Lucifer in the play, not Satan.

title: Dcor, Not Food, Gets the Edge
description: PAUL GARBUIO, the owner of Piave, a handsome new restaurant and bar, has an eye for dcor. The best part of dining in Caf Antico, his previous restaurant, was the romantic edge provided by dozens of candles multiplied in the reflection of the polished glass walls.

title: Letters
description: Great Is the Truth

title: Correction: The Week Ahead: Nov. 18-24
description: A dance entry in the Week Ahead report last Sunday about a performance by Complexions Contemporary Ballet included outdated program information. The Rennie Harris piece Endangered Species was no longer on the program, and two works by Dwight Rhoden, Precious Blood and Lament, were added.

title: The Afterbath
description: ROSIE PEREZ prides herself on her waitressing skills and her ability to make a perfect mojito, but on a trek to Socialista, the West Village restaurant and lounge, she was content to have someone else serve her. Ms. Perez  the choreographer turned actress turned documentary filmmaker  was fresh from a performance of The Ritz, a revival of the Terrence McNally comedy in which she stars as a bathhouse chanteuse. The Ritz is one of the few Broadway shows unaffected by the stagehands strike.

title: The Butler Could Do It
description: PERHAPS you have heard of getting a free gift with a purchase? Now the purveyors of a $45 million triplex condominium atop a 60-story glass tower facing Madison Square Park have taken that concept to a new level: free butler with purchase.

title: The Church in England: Downright Un-American
description: BATH, England

title: Jody Beck, Ross-Alan Tisdale
description: Jody Beck, the daughter of Dr. Ruth Hanno Beck and Dr. Roy W. Beck of Tampa, Fla., was married at the home of her parents last evening to Ross-Alan Tisdale, a son of Donna-Francine Tisdale and Alan Tisdale of Daytona Beach, Fla. Rabbi Richard J. Birnholz officiated.

title: A Time to Rethink AIDSs Grip
description: IGNORE the fuss over the news last week  the United Nations AIDS-fighting agency admits to overestimating the global epidemic by six million people. That was a sampling error, an epidemiologists Dewey Defeats Truman.

title: Correction
description: An article in the Arts & Leisure section last Sunday about the No Music Day campaign in Britain included several incorrect references to Muzak, the company that sells prerecorded background music.

title: Ally of Bush Is Defeated in Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 24  Australias prime minister, John Howard, one of President Bushs staunchest allies in Asia, suffered a comprehensive defeat at the hands of the electorate on Saturday, as his Liberal Party-led coalition lost its majority in Parliament.

title: Books of Style
description: THE BLACK DRESS

title: When Ownership of a Home Turns Negative
description: When you buy a house, it isnt supposed to work this way. Among homes bought in the last year, nearly 16 percent are now worth less than the amount of the original mortgage, according to third-quarter data from Zillow, a real estate research firm.

title: Looking for Green Lights in the Suburbs
description: HARDING TOWNSHIP, N.J.

title: Barbecue, Brazilian-Style
description: WHEN Marcias Kitchen opened in Huntington Village in mid-August, it created a buzz. Everyone was talking about this small storefront that served huge portions of moderately priced Brazilian food.

title: Yankees and Rodriguez Receive Approval for Deal
description: Four weeks after Alex Rodriguez walked away from his contract with the Yankees, he and the club have gained approval for a marketing deal tied to his home run milestones, the last significant step in completing a contract that restores Rodriguez to the Yankees roster.

title: Aboard Planes, Class Conflict
description: OVER the past few years  and this will probably come as no surprise to anyone who has gotten on a plane over this Thanksgiving weekend  flying in coach has become an increasingly miserable experience. Legroom is practically nonexistent. Passengers are more tightly packed together. Hot meals have been eliminated. Ditto pillows and blankets. And the next time that guy in front of you leans his seat back directly into your face, few of your fellow passengers are likely to blame you if you feel a brief, murderous urge to strike back.

title: Smoking Guns and Mushroom Clouds
description: It is a reasonable assumption that three nuclear powers, the United States, India and Israel, have prepared a variety of more or less robust contingency plans to neutralize Ptakistans nuclear arsenal of some 40 or so warheads, should Islamist militants appear to threaten the regime of President Pervez Musharraf. There have been ominous signs that other Middle Eastern states, including Egypt, Turkey and Saudi Arabia, are considering their own nuclear options as they contemplate a future that may feature a nuclear-armed Iran.

title: Week 12 in Preview
description: SAINTS at PANTHERS

title: Homing In
description: Though the Israeli author Meir Shalev attracts a primarily Jewish readership in the United States, his new novel, translated by Evan Fallenberg, is less concerned with the intricacies of a particular religion than with the question of what any person needs in order to be happy. A Pigeon and a Boy may be filled with references to Jewish traditions, but its told from a distinctly secular point of view  that of Yair Mendelsohn, an Israeli tour guide who sees himself as a casualty of modern life.

title: Paul Roche, Poet in Bloomsbury Group, Is Dead at 91
description: Paul Roche, a noted English poet and translator who was among the last living associates of the Bloomsbury group, the skein of artists and writers twined around Virginia Woolf and her family, died on Oct. 30 at his home in Sller, Majorca. He was 91.

title: Bulls Go Cold, and Season Starts Black and Blue
description: Forward Andres Nocioni slumped at his locker after the Chicago Bulls latest loss, covered from knees to toes in ice. Bags hung on his kneecaps. His knees extended into an orange cooler, its contents so cold that his feet turned bright red.

title: When Solar Power Is Short on Charm
description: BELLEROSE

title: Youve Got (No) Mail!
description: To the Editor:

title: What You Get for ...$20 Million
description: Jupiter Island, Fla.

title: Correction: The Perils of Petrocracy
description: A picture caption on Nov. 4 with a contents entry for an article about Venezuela and its nationalized oil misidentified a piece of equipment used in oil fields. It is a pump jack, not a drilling rig.

title: Another Top Tennis Star Takes a Shot at Real Estate
description: Juan Carlos Ferrero of Spain and Andre Agassi were each ranked No. 1 in professional tennis in 2003. Now Mr. Ferrero appears to share Mr. Agassis passion for real estate. In September, Mr. Ferrero opened a luxury hotel near Valencia, Spain. (Mr. Agassi and his wife, Steffi Graf  another top-ranked tennis star  have hotels being built in Costa Rica and in Idaho.) Four years ago, at the urging of Antonio Martnez, his coach, Mr. Ferrero bought a 19th-century house and 120,000 square feet of land. They renovated for three years, spending seven million euros, about $11,720,000. The hotel  with a periwinkle exterior and a light-drenched, modern interior  has 12 suites, a swimming pool, a spa, two restaurants and, of course, tennis courts. Rates start at 250 euros a night (www.hotelferrero.com).

title: Letters: Disappearing Into the Desert
description: As creative director of NASAs Voyager Interstellar Message project, I wish to thank Nicole Krauss (Nov. 11) for her elegant description of our work and to clarify one statement she makes. The Voyagers are leaving our solar system but not the vastly larger Milky Way galaxy  unless, of course, they happen to be flagged down by the music-loving intergalactic travelers of some more advanced extraterrestrial civilization.

title: Coast Guard Searches for Source of Long Island Oil Spill
description: Environmental crews using shovels and mesh scoops yesterday cleaned up the last remnants of a mysterious crude oil spill that began washing ashore in gooey blobs three days ago in Nassau County, the Coast Guard reported.

title: A Congested Economy
description: Bellbrook, Ohio

title: Puebla, Mexico: La Purificadora
description: THE BASICS

title: Nedra Pickler, Eric Conner
description: Nedra Pickler and Eric Allen Conner were married yesterday in San Miguel de Allende, Mexico. Maria de Lourdes Bravo Villanueca, a municipal judge, officiated at the Casa Schuck, a hotel.

title: A Shift, but for Some Drivers, a Vicious Circle
description: Wall Township

title: The Poor, Shortchanged Again
description: For anyone wanting an idea of how the poor get taken advantage of, the sad story of the Millard E. Terrell homes in Newark offers a graphic example.

title: The Plight of the Part-Time Professor
description: To the Editor:

title: Pleased to Be Here
description: Run down to the bar and rouse the culture editor: the impossible has happened. In the dispiriting age of Bush and Britney, with our military still bogged down in Baghdad and our media still bewitched by Beverly Hills, an accomplished, respected American writer (a recent National Book Award Winner, in fact) has published a serious patriotic novel. Its title, A Free Life, is not altogether ironic. Its subject, everyday bravery and nobility in a system built on risk and too often based on mutual exploitation, is delivered straight. Finally, its Chinese-born author, Ha Jin (whose seven previous works of fiction have all been set abroad), seems positively pleased and proud to be here.

title: Political Upheaval Follows a Rare Decision to Retire
description: SANTA FE, N.M.  New Mexicans like to hold on to their United States senators.

title: At Odds Over Degrees of Assistance
description: WARMING centers began operating this month in Peekskill, New Rochelle and Mount Vernon as part of a campaign by the county to help get the chronically or hard-to-place homeless off the streets and into a shelter. Noticeably absent from the list, however, was White Plains, where local clergy members, homeless advocates and government officials are grappling with what constitutes fair treatment for those unable  or unwilling  to enter the countys shelter system.

title: Deborah Glasser, Adam Forchheimer
description: Deborah Lauren Glasser, the daughter of Alice and Steven T. Glasser of Plainview, N.Y., was married last evening to Adam Irwin Forchheimer, a son of Rochelle and Mark V. Forchheimer, also of Plainview. Cantor Morris Wolk performed the ceremony at Temple Israel of Lawrence in Lawrence, N.Y.

title: One-Word Review: Hilarious
description: Overdreamt in New

title: Talking About Sex. Then Again, Maybe Not.
description: NYACK, N.Y.

title: A Remedy Against Vandals, but Now the Solution Is a Problem
description: EASTON

title: Lisa Lalezarian, Richard Cohen
description: Lisa Lalezarian, a daughter of Flora and Frank Lalezarian of Great Neck, N.Y., was married last evening to Richard Manoochehr Cohen, a son of Joan and Edward Cohen of Katonah, N.Y. Rabbi Tom Weiner officiated at the Waldorf-Astoria in New York, with Rabbi Howard J. Goldsmith taking part.

title: Blind Woman Came to City for Marathon, and Stayed
description: Nihal Erkans eyes are nearly closed under the bill of her pink baseball cap.

title: Art by the Beach, but No Sand Castles
description: ATTENDING Art Basel Miami Beach, the Lollapalooza of international art fairs, is a lot like going to college. You can party nonstop and still manage to get an amazing education. And the real action happens off campus.

title: Neuberger, 104, Honored for Helping Young Artists
description: WHEN 104-year-old Roy R. Neuberger received a 2007 National Medal of Arts from President Bush in the East Room of the White House on Nov. 15, a large contingent of his extended family was on hand to celebrate the occasion. He was also nominated last year, his son James Neuberger said. Luckily, hes healthy.

title: Can a Co-op Sponsor Be an Officer?
description: Q Can a sponsor also be vice president of the co-op board? Isnt this a conflict of interest?

title: The Return of the Prince
description: Milford, Mich.

title: Where Boys Grow Up to Be Jihadis
description: No one thought it was strange when Muncif Ben Aboud disappeared from his crowded, unkempt neighborhood in the Moroccan city of Tetouan. Men are always leaving Jamaa Mezuak, as the quarter is known. And Muncif, who was 21, had ventured off before, roaming the worn medinas of Casablanca and Marrakesh, posing stiffly for snapshots to take home. His curiosity pulled him in many directions. He was brilliant with numbers but would lose himself in novels. He began training to be a military pilot but then changed his mind and settled on engineering. A year later, in 2006, he switched to mathematics.

title: Serendipity Transcends All Barriers
description: WHEN he was 20, Arturo Vidals told his father there were no good job opportunities in his hometown, Puebla, Mexico. If youre an eagle, then fly, his father replied.

title: Those City Report Cards: Did Good Schools Fail?; Battle Over Air Rights on the Upper East Side (5 Letters)
description: Those City Report Cards: Did Good Schools Fail?

title: Discontent on a Tip of the Island at the Center of the World
description: ON a cold morning last week, bundled-up tourists strolled south along the East River from the South Street Seaport, past the pier where they could buy helicopter rides and the ornate Battery Maritime Building, where opaque green waves lapped against steel foundations.

title: Injured in Iraq, a Soldier Hobbles Toward Recovery
description: FREDERICKSBURG, Va.  It is hard to know whether Master Sgt. Joseph Santiago was wincing from the pain creeping from the hole in his head to his atrophied legs or from the words of the politicians who were calling him a hero. After they were done commending his sacrifice on the battlefields of Iraq, he grabbed the microphone, handed his cane to his wife, and announced that he wanted to set the record straight.

title: Constitutional Detour
description: "Hail to the Chief has not always been No. 1 on the hit parade of American conservatives. In fact, for most of the 20th century, they viewed executive power as the great engine of an overreaching, war-prone federal leviathan. When liberals praised the energy and vision of crusading presidents like Woodrow Wilson, Franklin Roosevelt and Lyndon Johnson, conservatives would wave The Federalist at them, warning of the dangers of royalism and insisting on the need for firm checks and balances as libertys safeguard.

title: All Eyes on Durant
description: Second Pick at Forefront

title: Idol of Evil
description: How did they get that way? Thats the natural question about historys monsters. They all seem to start out the same as everyone else: And whos this little fellow in his itty-bitty robe? / Thats tiny baby Adolf, the Hitlers little boy! as the Polish poet Wislawa Szymborska wrote. Many Georgian boys were beaten by their drunken fathers, but only one grew up to be Stalin. What were the factors of character and circumstance that made the crucial difference?

title: You Cant Hold It, but You Can Own It
description: ART can be defined, provocatively, as an intangible quantity that transforms an ordinary object  a urinal, a soup can, an unmade bed  into something worth many times more than its material value. Tino Sehgal seeks to isolate precisely that intangible quantity. His art is completely immaterial; it can be bought and sold without involving any objects whatsoever.

title: 50 Years Ago, Modernism Was Given a Name: Agon
description: A MAN and a woman are alone onstage. He kneels, facing her, as if in fealty. She extends a leg high above his head like a sword, then rests it on his shoulder, perhaps in the traditional gesture with which a monarch dubs a squire a knight. (Arise, Sir Arthur.) But this scene isnt medieval. Shes wearing black leotard and white tights; he has a white T-shirt over black tights. The music is 12-tone for strings playing without meter or pulse.

title: Evangelicals Everywhere
description: In August, Washington watchers were titillated by a particularly fascinating insider account of the Bush White House: Matthew Scully, one former speechwriter, accused another, Michael Gerson, of egocentric careerism. It is not usually considered sinful in Washington to advance yourself; that is pretty much what the place is about. But Gerson, an evangelical Christian, had developed a reputation among the Washington press corps just this side of sainthood. One need not accept every word Scully wrote to conclude that Gerson had expended considerable energy on his own deification.

title: The Lottery Industrys Own Powerball
description: An article last Sunday about Rebecca Paul Hargrove, who has run state lotteries in Illinois, Florida, Georgia and now Tennessee, misstated a former title of her husband, Jere L. Hargrove. He was a Tennessee state representative, not state senator. The article also referred incorrectly to the location of two retailers that reflect Ms. Hargroves tastes as a consumer. The stores, Target and Tiffanys, are across the street from each other in the Buckhead area of Atlanta, not in downtown Nashville.

title: From Street to Scholar, a Writer Shows Off His Dexterity
description: JUNOT DAZ is up on the highest hill in Rome, the gift of a writing fellowship, far from the gritty neighborhood in Parlin, near Perth Amboy, where he grew up. As a boy, he spent hours reading everything he could in a local library. Yet, he says, he hung out on the street corners, half as a dodge to throw people off from his intellectual bent. He sometimes speaks in street argot, then switches abruptly to the precise language appropriate to the writing professor and novelist that he now is.

title: Sampling the Best of the Northwest
description: THE dining room at Cascadia  one of Seattle's top restaurants, with a cutting-edge chef, luminous dcor and a cellar lauded by Wine Spectator  was empty. No one sat on the green banquettes, eating Alaskan king crab with white-truffle gnocchi under the coppery mahogany paneling, and empty wineglasses sparkled on white tablecloths. Only an occasional wandering waiter disturbed this stillness.

title: Pigeon Paranoia
description: WHILE a proposal by Councilman Simcha Felder, a Democrat from Brooklyn, to ban the feeding of pigeons in New York City  and fine the violators  may speak to those who detest the humble rock dove, the proposition itself is sadly misguided.

title: Correction: Muslims on TV, No Terror in Sight
description: An article on Nov. 11 about the portrayal of Muslims on television misstated the month Little Mosque on the Prairie returned for its second season. It was in October, not November.

title: The Latte War Around the Corner
description: JOU JOU CAFE is a bustling coffee shop on West 168th Street near Broadway. With its big, midpriced sandwiches and the usual array of flavored lattes, it is a favorite of the dangling-ID-card set from NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Columbia University Medical Center down the block. And like many blocks of Washington Heights, this one has changed drastically since early 2001, when Jou Jou opened.

title: A Web Tour Will Show Stores From the Inside Out
description: THREE-DIMENSIONAL mapping programs like Google Earth let people fly over the rooftops of virtual cities, and other online services lead them down individual streets.

title: Jolly and Green, With an Agenda
description: LAST Christmas, Donna Hoffman, an ardent environmentalist who lives in Austin, Tex., came up with an unlikely gift for each member of her family: an energy-efficient compact fluorescent light bulb.

title: A Touch Lighter
description: If those second helpings of Thanksgiving turkey left you craving lighter fare, consider these places in Astoria, Queens, for small plates of mezedes, or Greek tapas.

title: Samantha Miller, Warren Bloom
description: Samantha Moriah Miller and Warren Jeffrey Bloom were married yesterday at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Rabbi Jaymee D. Alpert officiated.

title: Hard to Be an Audiophile in an iPod World
description: IN the heyday of the stereophonic recording boom, during the 1960s and later, there were several magazines for serious classical music buffs with reviews of almost every new recording. But what truly defined these publications, like High Fidelity and Stereo Review, were critical reports on stereo equipment. The big advertising bucks came from the makers of hi-fi equipment, and well more than half the pages of such magazines were devoted to coverage of the latest stereo system products.

title: Town Resists Bidding Farewell to Beloved Diner
description: New Rochelle

title: Paperback Row
description: WHAT WAS ASKED OF US: An Oral History of the Iraq War, by the Soldiers Who Fought It, by Trish Wood. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $14.99.) Wood, a Canadian investigative reporter, interviewed 29 American veterans of the Iraq war. The men and women came from different personal and ideological backgrounds, but their descriptions of their experience all display a sense of duty and courage in the face of wars violence. Funny and horrible, coarse and colloquial, the soldiers accounts are honest, agenda-free and chilling, Tara McKelvey wrote in the Book Review.

title: Developer Duets
description: NOT only does he come from a family of developers, but these days it also seems that Scott H. Rechler is the developers developer.

title: A Touch of Tokyo, but Very California
description: SANTA MONICA

title: In Maine, a Hardy Few Are Still Stalking Ducks in a Time-Honored Way
description: BOWDOINHAM, Me., Nov. 23  There are wild goose chases, and then there are extremely deliberate ones. One hunter who prefers the deliberate ones is Alfred Hall of Topsham, Me.

title: As Democrats See Security Gains in Iraq, Tone Shifts
description: As violence declines in Baghdad, the leading Democratic presidential candidates are undertaking a new and challenging balancing act on Iraq: acknowledging that success, trying to shift the focus to the lack of political progress there, and highlighting more domestic concerns like health care and the economy.

title: Blame the Borrowers? Not So Fast
description: IT has become fashionable of late to say that Americas subprime borrowers themselves deserve a good part of the blame for the current mortgage mess. They were either greedy (looking for easy money in a bubbly real estate market) or irresponsible (assuming a debt whose terms they did not understand).

title: Knicks Finally End Slide, but Theyre Not Off Slope
description: A new feeling swept through Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon, something that was neither elation nor misery and not easily defined. Cautious joy? Angst-riddled relief? Modest merriment?

title: Amid the Willows and Chickadees, Bird-Watchers Spot a Red Flag
description: ONE recent morning, a 52-year-old computer technician and amateur naturalist named Rob Jett tucked a pair of binoculars and The Sibley Field Guide to Birds of Eastern North America into his bag and headed out of his Park Slope apartment for the F train.

title: Attacks on Pakistani Military Kill 15
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 24  Two suicide car bombers attacked military targets on Saturday morning in Rawalpindi, the site of the militarys headquarters, killing at least 15 service members, a military spokesman said. The bombings raised tensions in the country, which is already beset with political and security problems.

title: Holiday Sales Climb, but Shoppers Spend Less
description: Black Friday was big  but with a big caveat.

title: Media Studies
description: Q: Although youre known best as the author of the highbrow murder mystery The Name of the Rose, youre also a prolific political commentator whose essays have now been collected in a book, Turning Back the Clock, in which you warn against the dangers of media populism. How would you define that term? Media populism means appealing to people directly through media. A politician who can master the media can shape political affairs outside of parliament and even eliminate the mediation of parliament.

title: West Virginia Wins Big East and Sets Sights on a Bigger Title
description: MORGANTOWN, W.Va., Nov. 24  The leaves have mostly fallen here at the foot of the Allegheny Mountains. The barren trees set behind Milan Puskar Stadium offer a fitting backdrop as winter beckons in this cozy college town. In this season of incessant and unpredictable change in college football, No. 4 West Virginia has become the latest team to improbably thrust itself to the forefront of the national title race.

title: A Defiant Coffee Shop Stares Back at Starbucks
description: LITTLE FALLS, N.J.

title: William ONeill, a Connecticut Governor, Is Dead at 77
description: William Atchison ONeill, the son of a small-town tavern owner who rose through Connecticut politics to serve as governor for a decade, died yesterday. He was 77.

title: Letters: Jewish Marrakesh
description: To the Editor: Marrakesh is surely a visitors delight for reasons you give in 36 Hours in Marrakesh, Morocco (Nov. 11). You should add that the Jewish sites are just as exciting and deserve more mention than lunch next to the former Jewish quarter.

title: Julie Krasnogor, Tamir Daniel
description: Julie Beth Krasnogor, a daughter of Norine and Lester Krasnogor of Stamford, Conn., is to be married this evening to Tamir Daniel, a son of Yael and Itzhak Daniel of Petah Tikva, Israel. Rabbi David Nadav will officiate at Cassiopeia, an event space in Herzliya Pituach, Israel.

title: Suddenly, Connecticut Is Stem Cell Central
description: FARMINGTON

title: Heaping Helping of Americana
description: TESTED 2008 Hummer H3 Alpha

title: In Afghanistan, Hunt for Militants Can Be a Slog
description: ESPANDI, Afghanistan, Nov. 18  First Lt. Aaron W. Childers stood before a doorway inside a mud-walled compound while an Afghan and American patrol searched behind him. Paratroopers swept metal detectors over the dusty ground, looking for buried weapons and ammunition.

title: If Truman Were Here
description: To the Editor:

title: The Goodbye to Paper Airline Tickets Is Speeding Up
description: China is the front-runner in the global race to convert from paper to e-tickets, according to a representative of the International Air Transport Association. Earlier this year, the association placed its final order for paper tickets  16.5 million  to keep airlines supplied until the world goes paperless on June 1. After that date, paper tickets will no longer be available, except in very rare cases.

title: Movie Deals
description: Its high season for Oscar bait, and multiplexes are filled with literary adaptations, including the Coen brothers bloody take on Cormac McCarthys No Country for Old Men and Mike Newells film of Gabriel Garca Mrquezs Love in the Time of Cholera. Coming later this fall are big-screen versions of Ian McEwans Atonement, Philip Pullmans Golden Compass and Marjane Satrapis Persepolis, among others.

title: Gay Playwrights
description: To the Editor:

title: The Big Sleep
description: Oxford, England

title: Farmyard Stills Quench a Thirst for Local Spirits
description: ATCHISON, Kan.  The main still of the High Plains liquor company here was scraped together from junked parts of an old food processing plant. The tubing for the bottling equipment had been used to milk cows, and one of the tanks was actually an industrial vacuum cleaner.

title: Letters: The Turning of an Atheist
description: Mark Oppenheimer (Nov. 4) mentions me as a source for the science that turned Antony Flew from skeptic to believer. Some people may believe that Flew, being old and therefore possibly senile, was duped by this pseudoscience.

title: An Exhilarating Tease, but Really Just a Game
description: Donald Muller, the 12-year-old at the center of the 90-minute thrill ride that is Doubt, never shows up on the stage. But even if he did, the TheaterWorks audience, in Hartford, would be hard-pressed to figure out which of the plays four adults is truly looking out for him.

title: Parallel Processor
description: One of the most closely read chronicles of Silicon Valley over the past year or so has been The Secret Diary of Steve Jobs, a running satire written by an anonymous blogger who assumed the persona of Apples brilliant, enlightenment-seeking co-founder and chief executive.

title: Why He Moved Into My Car, and Why I Let Him
description: IN the early 90s, when I moved to New York, I brought my car with me. Being from the New Jersey suburbs, I felt that a car was like an essential organ. It was not something I was prepared to give up.

title: Rumbling Across India to a New Life in the City
description: ABOARD THE PUSHPAK EXPRESS, India  The man with neatly parted hair stood in the doorway of the hurtling train. And then, at the perfect moment, he jumped.

title: Plenty of Confidence, and No Pants
description: AS an encore at her recitals Susan Graham often sings the song Sexy Lady. Written for her by the composer and lyricist Ben Moore, its the comic complaint of a star mezzo-soprano trapped in an endless round of trouser roles: lovesick adolescents in operas by Mozart and Strauss, dysfunctional knights in Handel.

title: The Namesake
description: Back in 1985, while working at Hughes Aircraft in Long Beach, Calif., I met a fine young woman named Addie. She worked in a different department, but whenever I saw her, Id flirt with her. Eventually she became my girlfriend. I was a fixture at her mothers house in the Fruit Town hood where Addie lived with her two sons. It was known as Fruit Town because of the names of the streets  Cherry, Peach, Pear  and it was one of the roughest neighborhoods in Compton, home of the Fruit Town Piru gang, one of the original gangs in the confederation known as the Bloods.

title: A Good Mystery: Why We Read
description: PERHAPS the most fantastical story of the year was not Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, but The Uncommon Reader, a novella by Alan Bennett that imagines the queen of England suddenly becoming a voracious reader late in life.

title: Glasses White With Foam
description: IF you're in Napa, would you order a Cte du Rhne syrah? In Italy, would you eat microwavable Chef Boyardee? In Belgium, would you buy a Hershey bar?

title: Toledo, Here He Comes?
description: It is hardly typical of the agent Scott Boras to accept a below-market contract offer. But if Alex Rodriguez, Borass marquee client, hammers out the 10-year, $275 million deal he is negotiating with the Yankees, he may be leaving money on the table. Although no other major league team made a formal offer to Rodriguez, he did receive one proposal for $35 million a season from an unlikely suitor: the Toledo Mud Hens, the Class AAA affiliate of the Detroit Tigers.

title: The Geography of Hate
description: FROM the 1880s to the 1960s, at least 4,700 men and women were lynched in this country. The noose remains a terrifying symbol, and continues to be used by racists to intimidate African-Americans (who made up more than 70 percent of lynching victims).

title: Thats My Pride Beneath the Love Train
description: BY age 23, I had romanced cigarettes, chocolate souffl, my pet cat and (through the TV screen) James Franco on Freaks and Geeks. But I had yet to experience an actual human romance.

title: A Soldiers Tale
description: Were all familiar with the pictures of American servicemen being dragged through the streets of Mogadishu. Weve seen the movies and television programs inspired by this tragic event and have read the books and newspaper and magazine articles that analyze how Somalia changed the United States attitude toward military intervention, at least in the 1990s. But we havent read the fiction inspired by this crucial moment in American military history  because there has been so little.

title: The Wizard of Whimsy
description: FOR slightly more than a year, a mysterious little periodical has been circulating through the cubicles of New York publishing offices, attracting the kind of cultish attention usually reserved for letters stamped with secret societies seals.

title: In the Majority, Democrats Tighten Control on County Government
