description: WHAT a difference a decade makes.

title: Gender Gap Might Be Wide, but Women Have Their Days
description: For whatever reason, women lag behind men when it comes to chess. The best women rank below the best men (with the exception of Judit Polgar of Hungary, the only woman ever to reach the top 100), but there is no obvious reason why.

title: The Fish
description: As soon as the elderly waiter  placed before me the fish I had ordered,  it began to stare up at me  with its one flat, iridescent eye.

title: Most Experience or Enough Experience?
description: IN 1960, Richard Nixon ran for president against John F. Kennedy on a slogan that had powerful resonance for cold war America: Experience Counts. Nixon had been vice president for eight years, a senator for two, and a House member for four. Kennedy had been a senator for eight years and a House member for six, and was also a war hero and the scion of a politically powerful family.

title: When Night Falls at School, Should Darwin Go Home?
description: Northport

title: Life Lessons Learned
description: KAREN TANG was determined to find an affordable apartment. The target price was just $200,000.

title: Illusions of Grandeur
description: The 1970s, with their glamour and glitter, are big right now. But 70s design wasnt just a look; it was about mixing common sense and theatricality to make the ordinary extraordinary.

title: New Voting Machines Are Put to the Test
description: HARTFORD

title: Julie Bierman, Jordan Solomon
description: Julie Lynn Bierman, the daughter of Mara-Lee Bierman and Dr. Fredrick Z. Bierman of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening in Pearl River, N.Y., to Jordan Lev Solomon, a son of Susan Solomon Stibel of Marblehead, Mass., and the late Bennett I. Solomon. Daniel Klein, a spiritual leader at Harvard Hillel, officiated at the Hilton Pearl River.

title: Letter: Questions for Patty Limerick
description: We agree with Patty Limericks concern about abandoned Western mines not being a major story source for Hollywood (Deborah Solomon, Nov. 11). But it should be noted that films about such problems have been made.

title: A Cloud Over Reborn Shelby Mustangs
description: FIVE years ago, amid a sharp rise in prices of vintage muscle cars, Carroll Shelby licensed his name to a Texas company to construct replicas of the 1967 Shelby GT500E used in the 2000 remake of the drive-in classic Gone in 60 Seconds.

title: The Pretenders
description: Guitar Hero

title: Jessica Sheena, David Cohen
description: Jessica Ann Sheena, a daughter of Rita and Sami S. Sheena of Old Westbury, N.Y., was married last evening to David Bryan Cohen, a son of Sheryl and Lewis J. Cohen of Roslyn Heights, N.Y. Rabbi Michael Katz officiated at the Puck Building in New York, with Cantor Kalman Fliegelman taking part.

title: Maggie Rivage-Seul, Kerry Reilly
description: Elizabeth Marguerite Rivage-Seul, the daughter of Peggy and Michael Rivage-Seul of Berea, Ky., was married yesterday to Kerry Flannery Reilly, a son of Dr. Maureen A. Flannery of Berea, and the late Peter C. Reilly III. The Rev. Frank Lehnerd, a Roman Catholic priest and a great-uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. Clare Church in Berea.

title: Running the Ball: Anyone Can Do It?
description: The debate has simmered for a decade, at least since the Denver Broncos began making a habit of turning unsung players into 1,000-yard rushers. Other championship-caliber teams, like the Indianapolis Colts and the New England Patriots, began casting aside top running backs, finding younger and cheaper alternatives with no regrets.

title: Calendar of Events
description: COMEDY

title: The Days Best
description: MATT RYAN, left, threw for 369 yards and 3 touchdowns as No. 15 Boston College got ready for the Atlantic Coast Conference title game by beating Miami for the first time since 1984.

title: Persuading Them
description: The announcement this month that Karen Hughes would be stepping down as undersecretary of state for public diplomacy was greeted with a combination of relief and derision. In her first appearance in the Middle East, in 2005, this Bush confidante and fellow Texan avoided substantive issues while reassuring audiences that my most important title is Mom and that Americans greatly value many religious faiths. The trip was a very public fiasco for the White House; thereafter, Hughes appears to have been largely withdrawn from circulation.

title: Luxury Lodging for the Eco-Tourist
description: FOR many travelers, Costa Rica has become a destination for eco-tourism  that is, vacations intended to celebrate and preserve the natural environment. And over the years, travelers on such trips have come to expect mostly ascetic accommodations after long days of surfing or hiking, typically not much more than a decent bed in a bug-free room with a semiprivate bathroom.

title: A Cover Girl Whos Simply Himself
description: WHAT follows is, in brief (well, not so brief), the curious tale of how a handsome black man who can also look an awful lot like a beautiful black woman, except with better legs than most and a beard, happened to end up on the November cover of French Vogue.

title: Pasture-ized, Not Pasteurized
description: 5 Spoke Creamery, a new artisanal cheese purveyor based in Port Chester, is giving county residents access to a rare and wonderful taste: small-batch cheeses made with raw milk from grass-fed cows.

title: Missouri Hands Kansas Its First Loss
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 24  After No. 3 Missouris 36-28 victory against No. 2 Kansas on Saturday night, Tigers fans proudly made the No. 1 sign with their index fingers.

title: DNA Tests Find Branches but Few Roots
description: HENRY LOUIS GATES JR., whose PBS special African American Lives explores the ancestry of famous African-Americans using DNA testing, has done more than anyone to help popularize such tests and companies that offer them. But recently this Harvard professor has become one of the industrys critics.

title: The Store Is Jumpin. The Stock Isnt.
description: ITS always been one of the most appealing bits of investor folklore: the retailer you discover after a visit to the mall, or the hip clothing company you hear about from your teenager and whose stocks end up going up through the roof.

title: Sanctuaries From Trouble, but No One Is There
description: ONE of the more unlikely witnesses to the changing commercial face of the Upper West Side is Annemarie Legendy, a short woman with a soft German accent and a cap of highlighted blond hair.

title: Suffolk Schools to Say Goodbye to DARE
description: FOR nearly 20 years, Suffolk County police officers have been teaching students in the countys five western towns about the risks of tobacco, alcohol and other drugs, as well as about peer pressure and safety. But that is changing as the county police department eliminates its DARE program, which will be replaced with a more general health and safety curriculum.

title: In Broadway Dispute, Questions of Fairness
description: From the day the stagehands strike began two weeks ago, the Broadway producers courted public opinion by insisting that the dispute was about one issue: fairness.

title: Going to Brooklyn for the Views
description: PARK SLOPE. Williamsburg. The Heights. Brownstones. Tree-lined streets. Cute restaurants. With-it galleries. Great museums.

title: Calendar of Events
description: Film

title: For Riders of a Stepchild Line, Even an F Looks Good
description: THE culture of the victimhood designated on subway maps by a green line snaking from Queens to Brooklyn is well established. And so, when it comes to the Metropolitan Transportation Authoritys rider report card program, which solicits rider evaluations, there is little suspense.

title: Correction: Producer? Sos Your Old Man
description: An article last Sunday about Jenny Gersten, who has followed in her fathers footsteps as associate producer of the Public Theater, misspelled the given name of her younger sister. She is Jilian Cahan Gersten, not Jillian. The article also misstated the role of Jenny Gerstens husband, Willie Reale, at the 52nd Street Project. He is the founder, not a co-founder.

title: Up Front
description: The novelist and poet Jim Harrison, who reviews a new collection of Charles Bukowskis poems in this issue, has been treated pretty well by critics over the course of his more than 40-year career. Some of Harrisons early novels, though, were attacked for featuring characters who were perhaps on the far side of macho.

title: Sir Nols Epistles
description: The astute English critic Kenneth Tynan identified Broadway humor as being chiefly of two kinds: Jewish and homosexual. He might have called it kvetch and bitch, perfectly good types, but not really British. Nol Coward, who was only one of those two things, specialized in neither type in his oeuvre. He kept it all for his correspondence.

title: Years of Thunder for Woman Called Lightning
description: Juanita Epton saw red at her first auto race on a dirt track in Charlotte, N.C., in 1945.

title: Bitterest Rival of Musharraf Returns Home
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, Nov. 25  Nawaz Sharif, the Pakistani opposition leader and former prime minister, arrived home from exile to a tumultuous welcome at Lahore airport on Sunday evening. Hundreds of supporters whistled and cheered, hoisting him and his brother, Shahbaz Sharif on their shoulders through ranks of wary riot police.

title: The Enabler
description: If there was a single low point in American diplomacy in recent years, it may have been the Bush administrations handling of the 2006 Lebanese war. For weeks, while Israel responded to Hezbollahs abduction of two soldiers on July 12 by heavy bombing of Lebanons infrastructure and Hezbollah rained rockets on Israel, the United States blocked efforts to arrange a cease-fire. On July 21, asked why she had delayed going to the Middle East, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice explained that the devastation represented the birth pangs of a new Middle East  and whatever we do we have to be certain that were pushing forward to the new Middle East, not going back to the old one.

title: Erin Holt, Patrick Sloane
description: Erin Gentry Holt, a daughter of Joyce Gentry Holt and Michael F. Holt of Charlottesville, Va., was married yesterday in Healdsburg, Calif., to George Patrick Harvey Ingalls Sloane, a son of Kathleen McNally Sloane and Dr. G. Harvey I. Sloane of New York and Washington. Judge Michael Daly Hawkins of the Federal Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, for whom the bride was a clerk, officiated at Barndiva, a restaurant.

title: Food, Drink, and Plenty of Literary Dish
description: WESTCHESTER is a bookish place, especially if youre a woman. Spoken Interludes, a literary event held Nov. 6 at Trinity Bar & Grill in Harrison, was notable for its gender split. Of the 70 or so people there who had paid $30 to eat penne and hear four writers, including Michael Korda and Susan Cheever, fewer than 10 were men  and two of them were behind the lectern.

title: In a Catalog of Catastrophes, Hurricanes Rule
description: The Count column last Sunday, about insurance losses from catastrophes, misstated the year of Hurricane Katrina, which was responsible for $41.1 billion in losses. It was 2005, not 2002.

title: In the Back, Not All Cattle Are Equal
description: FLYING in coach doesnt have to be a horrific experience. Really. You just have to pay more.

title: More Sex, and the City Is Happy About It
description: ONE recent afternoon Bettiann Fishman climbed a ladder in front of the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue and brought a bullhorn to her mouth. Hey, everybody, she said, addressing crowds gathered on the library steps, on the sidewalk and in the street. Were going to roll now, so please dont shoot.

title: Where the Roads Begin
description: A SKY-BLUE smokestack rises above an elevated section of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, sending swirling clouds of dissipating steam over the endless traffic. The stack marks the top of the Hamilton Avenue Asphalt Plant, which churns out much of the sticky, smoking substance that will become the surface of the citys roadways.

title: Golden Years
description: To the Editor:

title: Tax for 2 Cents Plain Is Anything but Simple
description: VOTERS in Upper Freehold Township passed a bond question this month that will raise an additional $264,000 annually to preserve farmland in their Monmouth County community.

title: Fordham Keeps Coming Back Before UMass Pulls Away
description: AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 24  After a 3-8 season last year, the Fordham Rams simply wanted to be respectable this fall. Instead, they found themselves in a postseason game Saturday in front of a national television audience, with an outside chance at a national title.

title: Calendar of Events
description: COMEDY

title: Torture as Campaign Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: More Than a Little Night Music
description: WHEN Uma Dixit, a 44-year-old Indian immigrant, first arrived at her one-bedroom apartment in Inwood two winters ago, she was greatly underwhelmed.

title: Medical Examiner, Differing on Ground Zero Case, Stands His Ground
description: No New Yorker is privy to as many secrets of the dead as Dr. Charles S. Hirsch. During nearly two decades as New York Citys chief medical examiner, he has quietly overseen autopsies on more than 100,000 people, hoping to learn something more about the way they lived, and why they died.

title: Caregivers Are Just a Few Clicks Away
description: Lets say youre visiting New York and want to go to the Metropolitan Opera. Or youre in Washington and want to spend the day at the Smithsonian. The only problem: that demanding toddler, teenager, mother-in-law or puppy who has no interest in going with you. Care.com, a new Web site, hopes to provide assistance to travelers in the United States. It provides a city-by-city directory of caregivers for children, pets and the elderly, as well as tutors, who have posted online profiles detailing their availability, experience, abilities and skills and rates. Caregivers may also include photographs and give information about themselves. Interested employers may click on send a message if they would like to contact a caregiver or add the caregivers profile to a favorites list. Basic membership is free, but there are also premium memberships ($25 to $120), which provide unlimited access to all providers and free background checks.

title: My Last (Probably Only) Year at Marienbad
description: THE doctor looked at me over his steel-rimmed glasses. And what is your problem? he asked.

title: Freud Is Widely Taught at Universities, Except in the Psychology Department
description: PSYCHOANALYSIS and its ideas about the unconscious mind have spread to every nook and cranny of the culture from Salinger to South Park, from Fellini to foreign policy. Yet if you want to learn about psychoanalysis at the nations top universities, one of the last places to look may be the psychology department.

title: Conventions Throw Doors Open to Bloggers
description: The Democrats are opening the doors of their convention in Denver next year to more bloggers than ever before. The move gives bloggers and the new media a chance to shine, much as they did at the trial of Scooter Libby earlier this year, and to bring a whole new perspective, and competition, to convention coverage. This is, after all, the first convention since the rise of YouTube.

title: Letters: The Ethicist
description: I quibble with the Ethicist (Oct. 21) on the matter of whether to pay a rabbi who became incapacitated just days before a wedding.

title: Antipasto in Abundance
description: THE makings of traditional Italian antipasto, the savory snacks served before the meal, are the specialty at Razzanos Salumeria in Glen Cove.

title: A Time for Bold Thinking on Housing
description: WE have to consider the possibility that the housing price downturn will eventually be as big as that of the last truly big decline, from 1925 to 1933, when prices fell by a total of 30 percent.

title: Just Dont Call It Scotch. Or Irish. Or Tequila.
description: Distilleries? In the Midwest? Why not? Except for a few geographically specific spirits, like tequila and Scotch and Irish whiskeys, anyone can make just about any spirit, anywhere.

title: Anne Livet and John Langdon
description: Anne Hodge Livet and John E. Langdon were married on Friday at Mr. Langdons home in Fort Worth. The Rev. Jan Orr-Harter, a Presbyterian minister, officiated with the Rev. Susan OConnell, a Zen Buddhist priest, participating.

title: Ex-Con Back in the Hood, Hustling His Novel Now
description: Plainfield

title: Debating the Degree of Dominance of the Patriots
description: In a season of superlatives, the New England Patriots are also dominating the category of divided opinions. Roughly midway through what often feels like an inexorable march to perfection, the Patriots, 10-0 and heavy favorites to beat the Philadelphia Eagles at home tonight, are already being compared with the greatest teams ever.

title: Massachusetts Faces a Test on Health Care
description: BOSTON, Nov. 20  As the Democratic presidential candidates debate whether Americans should be forced to obtain health insurance, the people of Massachusetts are living the dilemma in real time.

title: Amateurs Unravel Russias Last Royal Mystery
description: YEKATERINBURG, Russia  On the outskirts of this burly industrial center, off a road like any other, on a nowhere scrap of land  here unfolded the final act of one of the last centurys most momentous events.

title: In Defense of Lurking
description: For years, Ive spent hours a day on Web sites devoted variously to television, finance, consumer electronics, celebrity gossip, furniture design, health anomalies and real estate. To the sites message boards, which I follow almost as avidly as I did the first seasons of Damages and Mad Men, Ive contributed a total of three overwritten comments. I can recall them verbatim. They sank like stones.

title: Rejwana Haque and Hasan Khondker
description: Rejwana Haque, the daughter of Mursheda Haque and Dr. Mohammad Haque of Jamaica Estates, Queens, was married on Friday to Dr. Hasan Karim Khondker, a son of Dr. Sultana Khondker and Sufian A. Khondker of Hollis, Queens. Imam Ghazi Y. Khankan, a Muslim cleric, officiated at the Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, N.Y.

title: Letters: Home-Office Politics
description: Matt Bai (Nov. 4) might have mentioned that a large proportion of the independent self-employed got there involuntarily. They were laid off from corporate jobs and, for reasons fully examined by Louis Uchitelle, a New York Times reporter, in his book The Disposable American, couldnt find their way back into cubicleland. They need help, above all, with medical-insurance costs.

title: U.S. Scales Back Political Goals for Iraqi Unity
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24  With American military successes outpacing political gains in Iraq, the Bush administration has lowered its expectation of quickly achieving major steps toward unifying the country, including passage of a long-stymied plan to share oil revenues and holding regional elections.

title: Payload: Taking Aim at Corporate Bribery
description: LATE last month, five jumbo jets from Riyadh touched down at Heathrow Airport in London. They brought with them 13 members of the Saudi royal family, including King Abdullah and his retainers  and controversy. Over the last four years, the British government has been dogged by criticism of its relationship with Saudi Arabia, which is Britains biggest trading partner in the Middle East.

title: Peace Corps Looks for Older Volunteers
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 The Peace Corps is asking older Americans who might have heard President John F. Kennedys call to service more than 40 years ago to heed his request.

title: The Dead and the Naked
description: Chapter 12: Busy, Busy, Busy

title: Revised Rule for Employers That Hire Immigrants
description: The Bush administration will suspend its legal defense of a new rule issued in August to punish employers who hire illegal immigrants, conceding a hard-fought opening round in a court battle over a central measure in its strategy to curb illegal immigration, according to government papers filed late Friday in federal court.

title: Cheesemaking: A Science of Good Taste
description: CHEESEMAKING and Connecticut is not a combo that comes trippingly to the tongue. Yet in recent years the artisanal, or hands-on, method of cheesemaking in small batches from the raw milk of cows, sheep and goats has taken hold in the state. Consumers are increasingly aware of cheese quality and variety. More specialty food stores are stocking artisanal cheeses and more restaurants than ever before are offering high quality cheese plates. Cheese stores, like Darien Cheese & Fine Foods in Darien, are flourishing.

title: The Case for Illegal Mingling
description: One of the most talked about stories in the Middle East last week came out of Saudi Arabia, where the government affirmed the sentence of 200 lashes for a 19-year-old Shiite girl who was sitting in a car with a male acquaintance last year when they were attacked by seven men who gang-raped both of them.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday with the Evening Hours column misidentified the person in a mask who was shown embracing Elizabeth McCormack at the Asian Cultural Council gala on Nov. 13. He is Dokorda Gde Arsa Artha, a Balinese dancer  not Joseph Polisi.

title: Jennifer Oppenheimer, Samuel Gutmann
description: Jennifer Lauren Oppenheimer, the daughter of Joan and Robert L. Oppenheimer of Cliffside Park, N.J., was married last evening to Samuel Eric Gutmann, a son of Susan and Ben H. Gutmann of Norwood, N.J. Rabbi Kenneth A. Stern officiated at the Mandarin Oriental hotel in New York.

title: Forget the Game. Where Can We Eat?
description: NEWARK

title: So Odd, but Lately in Classic Fashion
description: ON a break from rehearsals for Cymbeline at Lincoln Center Martha Plimpton dashed outside for a cigarette and immediately ran into a classmate from her alma mater, the nearby Professional Childrens School. It turned out he too was still performing, as a dancer at the Met. They chatted briefly about work and compared notes about Lincoln Centers employees-only canteen, which evidently serves excellent chocolate-chip cookies.

title: Hope for Leaders Cooperation, but Little for Results
description: Israeli and Palestinian leaders gather tomorrow under American tutelage, with Arab foreign ministers in attendance amid anxiety about Iran, to try again to negotiate an end to nearly 60 years of conflict.

title: Kasparov Gets 5 Days in Jail for Marching
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 24  Garry Kasparov, the former chess champion and opposition leader, was arrested Saturday and sentenced to five days in jail after trying to lead a march to the offices of the federal election authorities.

title: Correction: Letter
description: Because of an editing error, a letter on Nov. 4 about the Turkish writer Orhan Pamuk and a James Bond film set partly in Istanbul misstated the first word of the movies title. It is From Russia With Love, not To.

title: Debating the Merits of Energy From Air
description: THE tiny Greek island of Serifos, a popular tourist destination, depends on its postcard views of sandy beaches, Cycladic homes and sunsets that blend sea and sky into a clean wash of color. So when a mining and energy company floated a plan earlier this year to build 87 industrial wind turbines on more than a third of the island, the Serifos mayor, Angeliki Synodinou, called it her worst nightmare.

title: Gotcha!
description: The gotcha politics will begin, predicted the TV interviewer Chris Matthews, on MSNBC this summer, each side trying to catch the other. I am all too familiar with that adjective, having misidentified Matthews a few weeks ago as being on CNN, which triggered a volley of corrections from his fans, who are presumably snapping up copies of his new book, Lifes a Campaign.

title: Home Economics
description: The housing bubble has burst, the dollar is in free fall and oil prices are at an all-time high. At the same time, unemployment remains down, as does inflation. How do Americans feel about the economy? For the second year in a row, the Op-Ed page asked four writers from around the nation to provide quarterly snapshots of their local economies. Here is their third round of dispatches.

title: Rock of Ages, Ages of Rock
description: On a muggy afternoon in July, a group of geologists from around the country put on some bug spray and fanned out along one of Ohios richest fossil beds. The rock walls were slippery and steep at points, and some people came in their dress shoes straight from the conference that brought them together. But no one seemed daunted; when let loose on the rocks they behaved like children with a piata, filling their pockets with local specimens and cooing over their treasure. Ahh, thats a beautiful brachiopod! or A fine trilobite! Let me see that.

title: The Office Party, as a Tightrope Walk
description: IMAGINE trying to plan a dinner party for 20 people with different dietary needs. Or think about organizing a wedding reception where both bride and groom have their share of fractious family members, and the new in-laws dont get along.

title: He Still Has Fire in His Throat and His Belly
description: WESTFIELD, N.J., Nov. 18  Gregory Tanis steps into his tuxedo pants, slips on his rhinestone-studded bow tie and piles crates full of props into his 1987 Buick LeSabre. About 70 years after he first entertained at a birthday show for $5 or $10, Mr. Tanis is still performing magic tricks at parties around the state.

title: Correction: 	Melissa Grigorieff, Jonathan Koomey
description: A report on Nov. 11 about the marriage of Melissa Grigorieff and Jonathan Koomey misspelled the bridegrooms middle name. It is Garo, not Caro.

title: Deal if by Air, Steal if by Sea
description: Georges Duboeuf has given Sherry-Lehmann specially blended Beaujolais nouveau for 23 years.

title: Just Off Insular Senate Floor, Life of the Uninsured Intrudes
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24  When senators debate health care, they usually speak in abstract terms about soaring health costs and the plight of the uninsured.

title: Immigrant Workers Caught in Net Cast for Gangs
description: GREENPORT, N.Y.  It was still dark the morning of Sept. 27 when armed federal immigration agents, guided by local police officers, swept into this village on the East End of Long Island. Within hours, as the team rousted sleeping families, 11 men were added to a running government tally of arrests made in Operation Community Shield, a two-year-old national program singling out violent gang members for deportation.

title: California Fire Eases as Winds Subside
description: AGOURA HILLS, Calif., Nov. 25  Fierce Santa Ana winds that blew a destructive blaze through Malibu on Saturday died down today, allowing firefighters to gain the upper hand in efforts to battle the destructive fire, a month after wildfires destroyed large parts of Southern California.

title: Letters: Looking for Their Childrens Birth Mothers
description: Looking for Their Childrens Birth Mothers

title: The Bears Among Us
description: No one can say for sure when things got out of hand  when relations between humans and black bears in the Canadian resort town of Whistler grew untenable for each side  but by the height of last summers tourist season, many of the bears that live around the densely developed, Swiss-style village in the mountains of British Columbia had apparently learned some new foraging techniques, and life for the humans took on an aspect of siege: Bears hitting the bearproof garbage bins along Highway 99; bears breaking into the loading bays and trash compactors behind the Hilton; bears discovering that snorting, jaw-snapping and bluff-charging golfers on the Whistler greens would cause those golfers to surrender their carts with their hands in the air.

title: Week 12 in Preview
description: SEAHAWKS

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Arts & Leisure section last Sunday about the No Music Day campaign in Britain included several incorrect references to Muzak, the company that sells prerecorded background music.

title: For All the Rock in China
description: BEIJING

title: Where Mansions Go Begging
description: Grosse Pointe, Mich.

title: The U.S. Economy: Trying to Guess What Happens Next
description: YOU need not be a Wall Street chieftain to feel the anxiety that has wrapped its arms around the American economy. The stock market seems locked in a downward spiral as one bank after another suffers its day of reckoning with bad mortgages. Companies are sharply cutting profit forecasts as the sense takes hold that American consumers are finally too loaded with debt to buy the next flat-screen television. The dollar has fallen to inglorious depths, turning Manhattan department stores into something like a Tijuana street market for Germans. One unpleasant word hovers large: recession.

title: Roar of the Engines? Its an Electric Hum
description: Portland, Ore.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article last Sunday in T: Travel magazine, about three popular musicians in the Brazilian state of Bahia, misspelled the surname of one. She is Ivete Sangalo, not Sangolo.

title: Small Things in Good Packages
description: TOKYO

title: Feds Forecast Weighs on Stocks
description: Despite a rally during a shortened trading session on Friday, the stock market gave up more ground last week, as the Federal Reserve issued an expanded and rather gloomy report on the economy.

title: Man Dies in Fire in a Queens Shanty
description: A 68-year-old man died early yesterday in a fire that destroyed a shanty used by homeless people on a vacant lot in Queens, the police and fire officials said.

title: And Thats the News From Watersmeet
description: THE director Brett Morgen hails from Santa Monica, Calif., lives and works in Rockaway Park, Queens, and has made feature documentaries about young Brooklyn boxers (On the Ropes), the idiosyncratic Hollywood producer Robert Evans (The Kid Stays in the Picture) and the trial of protesters at the 1968 Democratic National Convention (the forthcoming Chicago 10).

title: Tax Defeat Spells Setback for Land Preservation in Brookhaven
description: AS the Nov. 6 local election fades in the memory, one result stands out  a setback for open-space preservation plans in Brookhaven, Long Islands fastest-growing and second most populous town, and its largest geographically.

title: 88, and Still Working His Magic on 88 Keys
description: Uncasville

title: Year After Year, Giving Thanks (3 Letters)
description: Year After Year, Giving Thanks

title: Letters: How the Western Was Won
description: I enjoyed A. O. Scotts article on western movies (Nov. 11). However, he didnt mention three of the very best: William Wellmans Ox-Bow Incident, Henry Kings Gunfighter and Howard Hawkss Red River. If I were teaching a film class, I would assign these three to represent the classic westerns.

title: Letters: The Evangelical Crackup
description: Praise the Lord! It looks as if evangelicals have finally seen the light (David D. Kirkpatrick, Oct. 28). Theyve been pimped by the godless neocons of the G.O.P. Regarding Terry Foxs comment comparing this countrys religious zealots to a snake in a hole right now, its not a hole they crawled into; its more like crawling back under the rock they came from.

title: Can a Co-op Board Change Voting Rules?
description: Q I am the president of a co-op in the Bronx. Recently, the board amended the bylaws to prohibit anyone who is in arrears on his or her maintenance or who is in violation of the house rules from voting their shares or running for the board. Can we actually enforce this amendment?

title: Elizabeth McCarthy, Benjamin Wikler
description: Elizabeth Grant McCarthy, a daughter of Suzanne Grant McCarthy and Dr. Richard E. McCarthy of Little Rock, Ark., was married yesterday to Benjamin McDonald Wikler, the son of Marilyn R. McDonald of London and Dr. Daniel I. Wikler of Cambridge, Mass. Msgr. Francis I. Malone performed the ceremony at Christ the King Roman Catholic Church in Little Rock.

title: CSI: Vancouver? Well, Not Exactly
description: VIEWERS disappointed with this falls crop of new crime shows  or worried that a lingering writers strike will rob them of their favorite old crime shows  can take solace, were told, in DVDs. But what if youve already watched all 10 seasons of The Sopranos and The Wire, as well as the 14 Orbach-Noth-Florek-Moriarty episodes of Law & Order? Whats left to discover?

title: Time Runs Out on a Place to See and Be Seen
description: FOR one brief shining moment that was known as Camelot. ...

title: After a Coachs Scandal, the L.S.U. Women Rebound
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 21  When Pokey Chatman resigned last March as the womens basketball coach at Louisiana State, amid accusations by an assistant that she had improper sexual relationships with former players, many wondered whether the fallout would undermine one of the nations top programs.

title: A Long Road Back After Exoneration, and Justice Is Slow to Make Amends
description: Christopher Ochoa graduated from law school five years out of prison and started his own practice in Madison, Wis. He has a girlfriend and is looking to buy a house.

title: Tea Leaves Dont Show a Holiday Lift
description: THIS is the time of year when traders look for share prices to begin rising as holiday cheer engulfs Wall Street. A rally this season may be a tall order, though.

title: Rediscovering Drawing, the Forgotten Art
description: Drawing is one of the foundations of art. It is probably even fair to say that there would be no art without it. It is also a universal language, speaking to us across time and space. But today many artists no longer know how to draw. Nor do they really need to, for cameras and computers do all the work for them.

title: Just Married? Now, Get Out of Town
description: ANY couple planning a wedding trip will welcome a gift of luggage. The choices include colorful pieces that will not get lost on an airport carousel in the sea of all-black cases that hip travelers have been carrying for years.

title: Greatest Hits
description: The rounds in boxing are separated by a 60-second hiatus. But as the Hall of Fame trainer Angelo Dundee observes in his memoir, by the time your man gets back to his corner and sits down, you have only about 45 seconds to work your magic. As this book attests, being a professor of pugilism can be a stressful way to make your daily bread, since there will be contests in which you have to ponder not only strategy but also the health and perhaps life of your fighter.

title: Totals
description: Previously recorded $2,275,895.90

title: Calendar of Events
description: Theater

title: Showtime
description: This is showdown time for Gov. Jon Corzine. During the next few months, he will have to make good on his promise to put New Jersey on a sounder financial basis.

title: It May Not Be Double-Digit, but Its Still a Gain
description: WITH only five weeks left in 2007, and the Standard & Poors 500-stock index down 5.6 percent in what is supposed to be its best quarter of the year, Wall Street is becoming understandably anxious.

title: An Architects Flotilla of West Side Buildings
description: THE New Orleans architect Albert C. Ledners three offbeat creations for the National Maritime Union came ashore in New York in the 1960s, their porthole facades impudent in the face of doctrinaire modernism. The union sold off all three buildings within two decades. One of the pair on Ninth Avenue and West 17th Street is now the Maritime Hotel; the other, too, may soon morph into a hotel.

title: A Room That Simply Beckons You to Sew
description: I FELL under the spell of the sewing room the moment I crossed its threshold 26 years ago. I could sense the decades of solitary endeavor that must have taken place there since the house was built in 1849.

title: Correction: A Home for a Ballet Academy, and the Vision of Its Namesake
description: An article last Sunday about the Margot Fonteyn Academy of Ballet in Peekskill misquoted its director, Ken Ludden. He said in an interview that Dame Margot felt that she would have been a better dancer had she had formal training in art, music and drama  not art, music and dance. The article also included outdated information on the location of the academys production of The Nutcracker. After the article went to press, the production was moved from the Paramount Center for the Arts to the Tarrytown Music Hall, where it will be performed on Dec. 21 at 8 p.m. and Dec. 22 at 3 p.m. and 8 p.m.

title: Mobile Web: So Close Yet So Far
description: ON the surface, the mobile Web is a happening place. Theres the iPhone in all its glory. More than 30 companies have signed up for the Open Handset Alliance from Google, which aims to bring the wide-open development environment of the Internet to mobile devices. Nokia, which owns nearly 40 percent of the world market for cellphones, is snapping up Web technology companies and has made an eye-popping $8.1 billion bid for Navteq, a digital mapping service. There are also the requisite start-ups chasing the market.

title: When Campaigning Strays Off Script
description: OBSERVERS of modern presidential campaigns might be allowed some despair over the highly produced, theatrical productions that pass for campaign events these days.

title: Once Again, Dayne Makes a Late Arrival
description: With the seasons end drawing near, it is once again time for Ron Dayne, a backup running back for the Texans, to stand tall. In the teams past two games, Dayne, filling in for the injured Ahman Green, has rumbled for 211 yards and a touchdown. Similarly, from Weeks 13 through 16 last season, Dayne amassed 429 yards and 5 touchdowns.

title: The Nymphet Is a Lethal Weapon
description: FRANK WEDEKINDS Lulu is the modern ur-drama of sex. Its not an edifying fable about gender roles or sexual politics, or a tragedy of clueless, randy youth (like Wedekinds earlier Spring Awakening), or even at heart a marriage play, though four marriages go bad in it. Lulu is a ruthless examination of the terrible destructive potential of a basic human drive, and of that favorite scapegoat for that destruction, the femme fatale.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Steroids and an I.R.S. Agent

title: Letters
description: Lynn Hirschbergs article on Daniel Day-Lewis was an unforgettable depiction of a man who is surely a master at his craft (Nov. 11). In her novel-like interview, she drew me into the picture, absorbed by his quest for perfection. I need to find the right kind of silence or light or noise, he said, and I believe he has. Indeed, Day-Lewiss idea of America as a place of infinite possibilities has come to pass for him. Thanks for a great read!

title: The List Is Stellar, but a Little Dated
description: When Doubledown Media published the first issue of Corporate Leader magazine this month, it included a list of the 100 Best C.E.O.s. But if there is a second annual listing, at least four of those chief executives will be missing.

title: Think Global, Read Local
description: Hillsborough, N.C.

title: Returning Courts to the People
description: The writers of Connecticuts Constitution thought judicial secrecy to be so corrosive to the public good that they included five simple but powerful words: All courts shall be open.

title: A Scenic Los Angeles Enclave, Without Glitter
description: IS this really still Los Angeles? asked Hlne Rottier, a friend from Tahiti, peering across the Santa Monica Mountains obscured in the Wagnerian carpet of mist rising from the Pacific 2,000 feet below. We had hiked up the four-mile Temescal Canyon Trail, which twists from the village center of Pacific Palisades through thick scrub, sycamores and oaks and past a small waterfall where deer and an occasional cougar pause to drink.

title: Taking Stock of Your Stuff
description: WHAT is your stuff worth? That is a question the Insurance Information Institute, a Manhattan industry group, thinks everyone who has homeowners or renters insurance needs to answer.

title: Natural Detection
description: Diana Abu-Jabers second novel, Crescent, was a love story involving an Iraqi-American cook and an exiled Iraqi professor, in which Abu-Jaber made pleasing use of the elements of literary romance: a heroine and her nemesis, a talismanic object, delayed revelations. Set in the warmth and light of Southern California and told in tactile and olfactory prose, it was grounded on two subjects she obviously knew well: Arab-American communities and cooking.

title: Shh! Its a Secret Kind of Outside Art
description: Los Angeles

title: Dr. Drug Rep
description: I. Faculty Development

title: Vindicated by DNA, but a Lost Man on the Outside
description: As a boy, Jeffrey Mark Deskovic could swim the length of a pool underwater without coming up for air. On sultry days at the Elmira state prison, where he spent most of his 16 years behind bars for a rape and murder he did not commit, Mr. Deskovic would close his eyes under a row of outdoor showers and imagine himself swimming.

title: Bad Bags
description: Plastic bags are nasty little things. Environmentalists  check out a persuasive article by Katharine Mieszkowski in the Web publication Salon in August  argue that plastic bags are the ultimate emblem of a society addicted to consumption, waste and petroleum, the raw material from which most bags are made. It takes millions of barrels of oil to make the 100 billion plastic bags that Americans use every year. About 2 percent of those bags are recycled. The rest are still with us, and will be long after we die, since they do not rot.

title: The Line Between Homage and Parody
description: ENCHANTED, a Walt Disney musical comedy that opened Wednesday, would have been labeled as treason in the Magic Kingdom just a few years ago. The grounds: mocking classic Disney characters.

title: Rahdi Taylor and David Maynard
description: Rahdi Taylor, a daughter of JoAnn Taylor-Masterson of Loma Linda, Calif., and Clyde R. Taylor of New York, was married yesterday to David Maynard, a son of Nancy H. Maynard of Santa Monica, Calif., and the late Robert C. Maynard, who lived in Oakland, Calif. The Rev. Madison T. Shockley II, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at Cafe Pinot, a restaurant in Los Angeles.

title: Datebook
description: CHICAGO

title: A Serious Side of Fun
description: MY parents, both born in Latvia, emigrated separately to Palestine and met on a kibbutz in 1930. My last name means son of freedom in Hebrew. Growing up, I was embarrassed to have such a weird name, but I grew into it and became proud of it.

title: Wild Wild Lit
description: Readers who like their plots clear and coherent and their prose clean and Hemingwayesque will drop this book in a hurry. Readers with a taste for inspired Joycean wordplay and a tolerance for narrative anarchy will scoop it up in delight.

title: Editors Choice
description: CONVERSATIONS WITH WOODY ALLEN: His Films, the Movies, and Moviemaking, by Eric Lax. (Knopf, $30.) In hours of nonconfrontational interviews, Allen ranges freely over his work and reveals a man who hasnt changed much on a personal level.

title: Zipcar, a Car-Sharing Service, and a Rival to Merge Fleets
description: Last month, Zipcar, a car-sharing service with hourly and daily rates  popular on both college campuses and in congested cities  announced that it was acquiring Flexcar, a similar car-sharing company.

title: How What It Takes Took Me Off Course
description: MORE than any other book, Richard Ben Cramers What It Takes, about the 1988 battle for the White House, influenced the way I cover campaigns.

title: The High Cost of Health Care
description: The relentless, decades-long rise in the cost of health care has left many Americans struggling to pay their medical bills. Workers complain that they cannot afford high premiums for health insurance. Patients forgo recommended care rather than pay the out-of-pocket costs. Employers are cutting back or eliminating health benefits, forcing millions more people into the ranks of the uninsured. And state and federal governments strain to meet the expanding costs of public programs like Medicaid and Medicare.

title: Correction: The Hollywood Diet
description: The Food column on Nov. 11, about dishes popular in Hollywood, referred imprecisely to the amount of butter used in the cake for peanut-butter cupcakes. While the amount is one and a half sticks, that is the equivalent of three-quarters of a cup, not two-thirds.

title: Reading Not Required
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: Review of A Life Decoded
description: A review on Nov. 11 about A Life Decoded. My Genome: My Life, by J. Craig Venter, misidentified the organism that was the first to have its entire genome charted, a feat accomplished by Venter and colleagues at the Institute for Genomic Research. It was a bacterium, Haemophilus influenzae, once thought to cause flu; it was not the flu virus.

title: Jamie Zucker, Jared Sharfman
description: Jamie Lauren Zucker, the daughter of Linda Zucker and Joel Zucker of East Hills, N.Y., was married last evening to Jared David Sharfman, a son of Rita Sharfman-Cristallo of North Bellmore, N.Y., and the late Saul Sharfman. Rabbi Alan B. Lucas performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn Heights, N.Y.

title: Bakers Million
description: Mort Zachters small, wry memoir suggests that with the right sort of talent a man can not only rob and ill-treat his nearest and dearest, but also convince them its his just prerogative.

title: An Unpredictable Path for a Present Imperfect
description: AT this point in the march of modern design, the idea of perfection is so complicated, has been shot so full of holes, that you cant believe it ever held water. But while many designers prattle on about embracing imperfection, few have developed a whole aesthetic around it.

title: Other Voices: In the Horse Race, Do the Media Pick the Horse?
description: Re The Campaign and the Horse Race (Nov. 18):

title: When a Mother Country Tells Its Kid, Shut Up
description: CARACAS, Venezuela

title: What Price Utopia?
description: As the march of events has lurched in unexpected directions over the past three decades, many a political thinker has been thrown off track and hurled into confusion, if rarely into silence. But not John Gray. He has usually been a little ahead of the zeitgeist, waxing contrarian about whatever consensus is about to form. Gray has been called a chameleon. If so, he belongs to a very peculiar species: one with precognition, able to change colors before landing on whatever patch of landscape lies just around the corner.

title: Letters
description: The Market for Iraqi Bonds

title: On an Unloved Lot, a New Source of Friction
description: FOR at least 13 years, neighbors say, the overgrown land behind the ShopRite parking lot in Borough Park, Brooklyn, has been a headache. Among many complaints made to the city, they pointed in 1994 to fire damage to an old warehouse at the site, in 1998 to the danger that the warehouse roof would collapse, and, just this fall, to homeless people slipping into the burned-out shell of the building.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Picture captions last Sunday with an article in T: Travel magazine, about five Baroque churches in the Pelourinho district of Salvador in the Brazilian state of Bahia, appeared out of order. The churches are, from left, the Church of Nosso Senhor do Bonfim, Church of So Francisco, Church of Nossa Senhora do Rosrio dos Pretos, Cathedral Baslica and Carmo Church.

title: Master of Doomed Love and Dark Surprises
description: ANYONE prone to attacks of vertigo should approach the works of Max Ophuls (1902-57) with some caution. Watching an individual Ophuls picture, in which, typically, the camera is in perpetual motion, can be a dizzying enough experience, but attempting to take in the whole of his career  by, say, attending the 12-movie retrospective that begins Friday at the Brooklyn Academy of Musics Rose Cinemas  could be more disorienting yet, because Ophuls did a fair amount of moving around himself.

title: A Country Village Caught Up in the Times
description: IN the 40 years that Anthony Occhipinti, the owner of Stop Realty, has been selling homes in the Rockland County village of Pomona, he has witnessed the demise of a bucolic way of life with mixed feelings.

title: A Comic Genius at Play in the Land of Foible and Folly
description: It would be hard to think of an artist more closely attuned to 20th-century American life than Saul Steinberg, one of our pre-eminent illustrators. His drawings and cartoon sketches for magazines take on almost every subject imaginable, always teasing out a comic dimension. Mr. Steinberg, who died in 1999, at age 84, depicted our follies and foibles for almost 60 years.

title: Letters: Conductor of the People
description: Arthur Lubows article (Oct. 28) on the flowering of classical music in Venezuela has rich implications for American diplomacy with that country. In the spirit of cultural exchange, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, an accomplished pianist, might improve relations with Venezuela by performing a concerto with the Simn Bolvar Youth Orchestra, under Gustavo Dudamel (when hes not conducting the Los Angeles Philharmonic).

title: Rust-Free Reality: Creating an All-New Classic
description: IN his 35 years of restoring cars, Mark Miller has seen it all  the good, the bad and the unsightly.

title: Young Matadors
description: To the Editor:

title: Underworld
description: To the average tourist, or even the devoted Italophile, the Italy of Roberto Savianos Gomorrah is an utterly unrecognizable place. There is no Renaissance art, no leisurely lunches or bustling piazzas, no world-class design, no achingly beautiful landscapes. Instead, we find an alien land of doped-up child soldiers, gun-toting clan women, illegal Chinese immigrants, sweatshops, drug smuggling, garbage and cement.

title: Katherine Van Loon and Jon Steitz
description: AT a bar near Yale, Katherine Van Loon figured out what few Ivy League hitters could: how to make solid contact with Jon Steitz, a highly touted pitching prospect.

title: The Chicken and Rice Man
description: EVERY weekday, starting as early as 7 in the morning and continuing until 7 at night, weary-looking men dressed in threadbare jackets and worn running shoes gather at the corner of Roosevelt Avenue and 73rd Street in Jackson Heights, Queens, under the gloomy shadow of the el.

title: Amid Affluence, the Hidden Homeless
description: HEMPSTEAD

title: Blue Jackets and Their Goalie Turning Corner
description: Fans of the Columbus Blue Jackets have been waiting for the team to become competitive since its inception in the most recent N.H.L. expansion, in 2000  and particularly for goaltender Pascal Leclaire to fulfill the promise that made him the eighth overall draft pick in 2001.

title: Just Call Our Band the Model Guests
description: IN her Midtown office, Jennifer Chiara, a travel agent, pulled out one of the standard nine-page riders she faxes to Manhattan hotels on behalf of her clients. In it were the customary requests: organic coffee and snacks, a room in a quiet part of the hotel, smart water and San Pellegrino served at room temperature.

title: Pakistani Middle Class, Beneficiary of Musharraf, Begins to Question Rule
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  For the last eight years, Tanveer Ahmed, a 40-year-old pharmaceutical company manager, has prospered under the economic reforms put in place by Pakistans president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf.

title: Nostalgia That Cant Miss (but Does)
description: Some moments seem surefire. Take a lovely young woman in a red turn-of-the-century ball gown. Stand her in the middle of a darkened Victorian dining room draped with holiday greenery, a Christmas tree twinkling in the corner. Strike up the orchestra, and turn her and her strong, clear voice loose with some beloved lyrics  say, Here we are as in olden days/Happy golden days of yore. And what youve got is a certain kind of magic. Normally.

title: Gay Pastor in the Bronx Could Lose Her Collar
description: In 1994, when the Rev. Katrina D. Foster became pastor of Fordham Evangelical Lutheran Church in the Bronx, she threw herself into ministering to her small, mostly Caribbean-born congregation. She not only preached to them on Sundays but lived in the neighborhood and showed up to support them in everything from surgeries to legal matters.

title: 36 Hours in Oaxaca, Mexico
description: OAXACA, the southern Mexican city with Zapotec roots and a Spanish colonial gloss, simmers with a passionate spirit. Although it's known as a hotbed for social justice rallies (including a large-scale teachers' strike in 2006), the city's infectious zeal goes far beyond the political, spilling into all its pursuits. You'll feel it in the buzzing markets, see it in the wealth of colorful crafts, and taste it in the culinary specialty: mole. Come during one of Oaxaca's many festivals like Christmas week or the Festival of the Radishes, and you'll experience the city in its full glory. Fetes, however, can be found anytime. Andale!

title: Japan Hunts the Humpback. Now Comes the Backlash.
description: THE ritual has been the same for nearly 20 years. Japan, while adhering to a 1986 moratorium on commercial whaling, has sent sturdy ships to Antarctic waters and, more recently, parts of the Pacific Ocean to kill hundreds of whales in the name of scientific research.

title: Home Sweet Dome
description: Home Sweet Dome

title: Searching for New Yorks Hidden Places
description: IMAGINE living on a quiet street lined with postcard-perfect historic houses, a street so secluded that it is unmarred by honking cars and casual pedestrians.

title: Our Side of the Mountain
description: Missoula, Mont.

title: An Allowance Thats Measured in Minutes, Not Cents
description: HOWARD AND LIZZIE SHERMAN, ages 15 and 9, know that they need to complete all their homework and chores in order to receive their weekly allowance. The amount may be a little less than usual if theyve misbehaved, or a bit larger if they have done some extra work around the house.

title: Legacy of the DeLuca Case
description: Now that Senator Louis C. DeLuca, Republican of Woodbury, has announced he will retire at the end of the month, the Legislature should create a standing ethics committee with set procedures for handling ethics charges against its members. With no such committee in place, the General Assembly was forced to improvise when Mr. DeLuca pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor threat charge in June but refused to resign. The guilty plea came after an F.B.I. investigation revealed that Mr. DeLuca had asked James Galante, a man suspected of having ties to organized crime, to intimidate his granddaughters boyfriend.

title: Letters: Class and Cruising
description: To the Editor: Regarding your Practical Traveler column on cruise ships, Paying a Premium Not to Mingle at Sea (Nov. 11): Segregation aboard cruise ships is inevitable, but I hope it doesnt extend to separate lifeboats for the upper class.

title: On the Waterfront, With Style
description: OVERSHADOWED by larger, wealthier and more flashy European countries with world-renowned design specialties  Italian lighting, Scandinavian furniture, French fashion  Portugal has long hid on the Continent's margin both geographically and creatively. For years, the best-known cultural contributions from this small seafaring nation were those stewed up in cauldrons from humble materials like squid and cod.

title: House Demolition? Fire? Hell Be There, With Camera
description: WESTPORT

title: Correction
description: A headline last Sunday about a Muslim man and an Orthodox Jewish woman who are partners in two Dunkin Donuts stores described their religions incorrectly. The two faiths worship the same God  not different ones.

title: U.S. Starts First Major Pullout From Iraq, Beginning With Brigade Members
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 24  The first substantive drawdown of American troops in Iraq has begun, as the first members of a brigade in Diyala Province have started to leave, American military officials in Baghdad said Saturday.

title: From New Mutual Funds, Help in Serving the Nest Egg
description: WALL STREET has repeatedly sounded alarms to spur working Americans to save more for retirement, but it has been less interested in helping convert nest eggs to spendable, post-paycheck income.

title: So You Want to Be a Nobelist
description: A couple of years ago, I was wandering the stacks of the science and engineering library at my alma mater, the University of New Mexico, when I spotted, naked on the open shelves, ancient bound copies of the British journal Nature. I pulled down a volume stamped 1953 and it fell right open to Page 737: James Watson and Francis Cricks well-thumbed paper on the structure of DNA.

title: Buccaneers Face a Test of Their Progress
description: Going by division standings, the game between the Buccaneers and the Redskins today in Tampa, Fla., is a matchup of the first-place team in the National Football Conference South and a team tied for last place in the N.F.C East. But Tampa Bay (6-4) and Washington (5-5) are separated by only one game in the conference standings, and winning this game is vital to each teams playoff hopes.

title: Mitchell Report Could Have Impact on Visas
description: Ten days ago, Robert Hill sent a memo to clients and other interested parties. ALERT, the memo began in capital letters. Anticipated December Release of Mitchell Report May Have Unintended Consequences for Foreign Athletes.

title: Stalins Children
description: For many years, Orlando Figes observes, the memoirs of intellectual dissidents, like Eugenia Ginzburg and Nadezhda Mandelstam, and the work of Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, were widely greeted as the authentic voice of the silenced, telling us what it had been like to live through the Stalin Terror as an ordinary citizen. Their books did indeed reflect the experience of people like themselves, who were strongly committed to ideals of freedom and individualism. But they did not represent what happened to millions of other people who were not opponents of the regime and did not engage in any kind of substantial dissent, but were still dispatched to labor camps, to exile in remote settlements or to summary execution. As Figes, a leading historian of the Soviet period, concludes in The Whisperers, his extraordinary book about the impact of the gulag on the inner world of ordinary citizens, a great many victims silently accepted and internalized the systems basic values and conformed to its public rules. Behind highly documented episodes of persecution, famine and war lie quieter, desperate stories of individuals and families who did what they could to survive, to find one another and to come to terms with the burden of being physically and psychologically broken. But it was not only repression that tore families apart. The regimes reliance on mutual surveillance complicated their moral burden, instilling feelings of shame and guilt that endured long after years of imprisonment and exile.

title: Tightening the Beltway, the Elite Shop Costco
description: WASHINGTON

title: Social Security, Privatized
description: To the Editor:

title: Security Patrols
description: Security Patrols

title: Monte Carlo Off the Track
description: THE powerful Chevrolet Monte Carlo SS stock car is leaving Nascars top series and will be replaced next year in all 36 races by Chevys version of the Car of Tomorrow, which will have the Impala SS nameplate splashed across its front bumper.

title: Fire in Southern California Prompts Evacuations
description: AGOURA HILLS, Calif., Nov. 24  Fierce Santa Ana winds blew a destructive blaze through Malibu on Saturday, a month after wildfires destroyed large parts of Southern California.

title: Correction: The Cloistral Hush Revisited
description: The Day Out column on Nov. 11 about Oxford University misstated the name of a college there. It is Christ Church, not Christ Church College.

title: It Looks Old but Drives New
description: THE availability of complete reproduction bodies for some classic models raises many questions, including what to call a car built from such a replica shell. Purists would argue that technically it is not a restoration.

title: Governor Spitzers Holiday Cheer
description: After a recent nose dive in the polls, Gov. Eliot Spitzer appears to be trying to sidle back into the publics good graces. He comes, as many experienced politicians have learned to do, bearing cash. In little more than a week, the governor has announced state money for upstate and down. The showering of good news for schools, the economy and the citys transportation system has become so noticeable lately that one suspects the governor was saving a lot of these announcements for his rainy days.

title: In Kids Stealth Foods, Similar Strategies Dished
description: Irvington

title: A Chicken Coop, but No Tigers
description: THE director Ang Lee, whose films have won eight Oscars out of 27 nominations, does not have a screening room in his four-bedroom home in Larchmont, N.Y., and rarely uses a computer or a cellphone. And instead of a fancy swimming pool in his backyard, he has a chicken coop.

title: Surfs Up, Hopes Are Too
description: Seattle

title: Vikings at Giants
description: Vikings run offense/defense

title: Catch a Train, but Look at the Prancing Horses
description: MOUNT ARLINGTON

title: Talk of Efforts to Fix Matches Rattles Pro Tennis
description: As the venerable Davis Cup finals begin Friday in Oregon, tennis is mired in a widening gambling scandal in which at least a dozen ranked players have said they have been asked to throw matches or have heard of similar approaches to others.

title: Armchair Traveler
School Renovation as a Learning Experience
description: THE career aspirations of Maxwell Rivas and Gar Yan Yeung, students at a high school in Manhattan, should please a group of New York City architects and designers.

title: Colombian Metamorphosis
description: To the Editor: I very much enjoyed the recent Explorer column about Tayrona National Park, In Colombia, a War Zone Reclaims Its Past (Nov. 11).

title: Firefighters Found No Gas in House Before It Exploded
description: Firefighters checked a multifamily house in Sunnyside, Queens, shortly before it exploded last week, but found no evidence of a natural gas leak, the Fire Department said yesterday.

title: Hits and Misses and Hairy Shows
description: Yo Gotti and Pleasure P

title: Loves the Beach, the Planet and Movies
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.

title: What Makes an N.H.L. Goaltender?
description: While I was in Phoenix with the Coyotes last week, I ran into Darren Pang the energetic TV color analyst and former Blackhawks goalie. I asked him about Pascal Leclaire, whom we wrote about on Sunday. Leclaire, the eighth overall pick in 2001, got his sixth shutout on Friday, and with a Ken Hitchcock team in front of him playing hard on every inch of the ice, Leclaire suddenly looks huge in net.

title: A View of the Penthouse
description:
A 1970s penthouse thats modest in scale but
big on invention.

title: The Patriots Place Among the Greats
description: It seems the readers of this blog have a lot to say about the Patriots. So here is more food for thought. Judy Battistas article for Sundays Times compares the Patriots to other dominant teams in N.F.L. history. The Patriots are the 18th team to start a season 10-0; only seven of those teams won a championship. In the article, John Madden said that the Patriots have the best offense he had ever seen, but that their defense does not compare with those of the Steelers of the 1970s and the 1985 Bears. Heres what others had to say:

title: Out of the Way
description: Houses tucked away in mews and alleys offer refuges from the chaos of New York City. They rarely come up for sale, and they don't come cheap.

title: Inside the List
description: BURSTING ON THE SCENE: The Virginia-based thriller writer David Baldaccis new novel, Stone Cold, appears at No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list this week. The book is about a secretive and feared Washington group called the Camel Club  feared in part, surely, because its fictional leader is named Oliver Stone. Baldaccis books have a real audience inside the Beltway. (Bill Clinton was spotted buying Baldaccis Simple Truth at a bookstore in 1999.) And like a politician, he is often asked to speak in public. Baldaccis Web site, helpfully, provides an introduction text for him  that is, suggested words for presenting him to a crowd. The first sentence of this text probably startles the librarians who must sometimes need to recite it, with its code-red level of thriller-world bombast: Internationally acclaimed best-selling author David Baldacci shocked the publishing world when he burst on the literary scene with his incredible first novel, Absolute Power.  The suggested text ends more demurely: Please help me welcome David Baldacci.

title: The Week Ahead: Nov. 25-Dec.1
description: Film

title: Vikings Defense Has Manning's Number
description: The Vikings defense utterly confused the Giants and Eli Manning, who threw four interceptions, three of them returned for touchdowns, in a loss to Minnesota.

title: An Angel in Queens
description: Thanksgiving may be the stuff of volunteerism, but for Jorge Munoz it's another night of serving dinners to immigrant day laborers in Queens.

title: Avoid Boring People
description: Remembered Lessons from Childhood on Chicago's South Side

title: A Free Life
description: Finally Taotao got his passport and visa. For weeks his parents had feared that China, even if not closing the door outright, would restrict the outflow of people. After the Tiananmen massacre on June 4, 1989, all the American airlines except United had canceled their flights to Beijing and Shanghai. At the good news, Pingping burst into tears. She quickly rinsed the colander in which she had drained the shredded turnip for her jellyfish salad, took off her apron, and set out with her husband, Nan Wu, for the town center of Woodland, where the office of Travel International was located.

title: Methodology
description: To build a comprehensive picture of what happens to wrongly convicted people after they leave prison, The New York Times tried to reach all 206 exonerated prisoners tracked by Aug. 1 by the Innocence Project, based in New York. All were exonerated based on DNA evidence. Although defense lawyers pointed out a few names missing from the Innocence Projects list, it is widely regarded as the most thorough record of DNA-related exonerations.

title: Arsenals of Folly
description: To the Chernobyl Sarcophagus

title: Dough
description: REMEMBRANCE 2006

title: The Confidante
description: At the Conservatoire Hector Berlioz in Paris, an eager group of sixteen French youngsters were learning to read music when they received a special visitor: a secretary of state on a mission to reshape American diplomacy-and her own image.

title: Dont Faze Me, Hermano
description: Dont Tase Me, Bro T-shirts are so yesterday  and so Anglo. The slogan du jour in the Spanish-speaking world is Why dont you shut up?  after the King of Spains gentle suggestion to President Hugo Chavez of Venezuela. Its become an instant hit in ringtones (see below) and apparel (right). And as the Week in Review notes, the episode has become a comic opera illustrating the unendingly complicated relations between Spain and its former colonies.

title: In Iowa, Clinton Is Pressed on Murdoch
description: FORT DODGE, Iowa  The curious relationship between Hillary Rodham Clinton, presidential candidate, and Rupert Murdoch, media baron, flashed briefly before the eyes of Iowans on Saturday night during a Clinton campaign event.

title: Did Obama Inhale?
description: AUDUBON, Iowa  In early caucus and primary states, voters play one very important role in the presidential race long before they cast their ballots: They ask questions.

title: On coming across
description: Why Im not a proper political journalist:

title: Red tide rising
description: The fall in the federal deficit since 2003 has been widely used by conservatives  including the Bush administration and all the leading candidates for the GOP presidential nomination  as proof that tax cuts actually increase revenue.

title: Sunday Kickoff: Missouri Has That Winning Feeling
description: Playing on a neutral field with a crowd split practically down the middle proved that Missouri was simply better than Kansas, writes Tom Keegan of the Lawrence Journal-World. Joe Posnanski of the Kansas City Star writes that quarterback Chase Daniel was the difference for Missouri, and his Star colleague Jason Whitlock says the Tigers left no doubt that they are worthy of the No. 1 ranking.

title: HIP Times
description: Dreaded Home Information Packs (HIPs) will become mandatory for sellers in the U.K. after Dec. 14. Under the program, sellers must provide a lengthy packet of information to potential buyers, including data on energy usage and local title notices.

title: Huckchuck
description: With the endorsement of Chuck Norris, Mike Huckabee can tap the large Web sub-genre of Chuck Norris martial arts humor  such as it is. (Some people wear Superman pajamas. Superman wears Chuck Norris pajamas  You get the idea). And tap Norris is just what Huckabee does, in this ad in Iowa (but have they thought through the formulation Huckchuck and what it can be used to rhyme with?):

title: Giants and Vikings, Some Running Thoughts
description: Vikings running back Chester Taylor gained more than 1,200 yards last year. Giants running back Reuben Droughns has gained more than 1,200 yards in a season twice, first with the Broncos, then with the Browns.

title: King of Pain
description: Poetry shouldnt tell us what we already know, though of course it can revive what we think we know. A durable poet, the rarest of all birds, has a unique point of view and the gift of language to express it. The unique point of view can often come from a mental or physical deformity. Deep within us, but also on the surface, is the wounded ugly boy who has never caught an acceptable angle of himself in the mirror. A poet can have a deep sense of himself as a Quasimodo in a world without bells, or as the fine poet Czeslaw Milosz wrote:

title: Growing Pains in the Pursuit of Happiness
description: Theres a particularly disturbing line in Peter S. Goodmans sobering cover story on international economic trends and recession forecasts in Week in Review: Americans have been buying staggering quantities of goods from overseas using money lent by foreigners.

title: Clinton: a Liberal, or a Moderate?
description: PERRY, Iowa  It is a favorite question of voters: Hillary Rodham Clinton, a liberal or a moderate?

title: Fear creeps in
description: More about the developing liquidity crisis, again from the Financial Times:

title: Sunday Sampler Platter: Thompson Strikes Back
description: Perhaps Chris Wallace on Fox News Sunday wanted to stir things up a bit   the mission of every good talk-show host, no?  or perhaps Fred Thompson had had enough. Regardless, when Mr. Wallace mentioned a buzz that the Thompson campaign was underperforming, a feisty Mr. Thompson lashed back.

title: Health Care: Round II
description: PERRY, Iowa  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton just finished a mid-afternoon news conference with reporters here. No major news, but she whacked Senator Barack Obama again  this time by name  over his health insurance plan and the estimates that it would not cover about 15 million Americans.

title: Helping the Next Generation
description: Im so sick of being asked if Im adopted, says Lila, and there are nods of understanding.

title: Big 12 Trophies Come First for Pinkel
description: While Missouri Coach Gary Pinkel spoke to the news media after Saturday nights 36-28 victory against No. 2 Kansas, he sat in front of a crystal trophy given to the Big 12 North division champion.

title: When They Told Me Norman Wrote a Book
description: Im mightily impressed by the literacy, enthusiasm and high quality of your comments on my previous column, on Norman Mailer.

title: Sharif Returns to Pakistan
description: Former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif arrived home in Pakistan from exile to a tumultuous welcome on Sunday evening.

title: Week 12 Talking Points
description: Its Sunday afternoon and I am manning (womaning?) the sports fort at the shiny new New York Times building on Eighth Avenue in New York City. No one else will be here for another four hours, so I thought, its time to spend some quality time on The Fifth Down. Ive got the AP wire at my disposal, and the Giants-Vikings game on one screen, and  nothing on the other (thanks, CBS). Ill try to keep you posted on todays big headlines and happenings. If youre out there, please feel free to join the discussion and tell me what you see (just no profanity, no matter how badly your team  real or fantasy  is playing). Just dont get used to thiskind of attention. Its a holiday weekend after all. Its my gift to you (you may not consider it such a gift when this is over).

title: Manhattan: Woman Hit by Bus
description: A woman crossing the street was struck yesterday by a charter bus leaving Chinatown for Atlantic City, the police said. The woman, 78, whom the police did not identify, was reportedly in critical condition at Bellevue Hospital Center, the police said. The accident occurred shortly after 11:30 a.m. on the Bowery at Broome Street. The woman was crossing Broome, walking south, when the bus, traveling northbound, turned left on Broome and struck her. A witness, Greg Horowitz, 23, an employee at a Bowery lighting store, said the woman was thrown several feet. No charges were filed against the driver yesterday. A man answering the phone at the bus company, Skyline Travel and Tour Bus, declined to comment.

title: In a Cycle of Attacks, Giuliani Gives and Receives
description: HAMPTON, N.H., Nov. 25  As the presidential campaigns ratcheted up for the post-Thanksgiving countdown to the first nominating contests, Rudolph W. Giuliani found himself under increasingly fierce attacks on Sunday from two of his rivals.

title: Queens: Officer Struck by Vehicle
description: A New York City police officer was hit by a vehicle as he was crossing Queens Boulevard in Elmhurst, the police said. The police located the vehicle nearby, but it had been abandoned, said the police, who were searching for its driver. The officer, whose name was not released, was in stable condition in Elmhurst Hospital Center and was expected to recover, the police said.

title: Virgin Group in Lead for Bank
description: LONDON, Nov. 26  The Virgin Group appeared as the front-runner today to buy Northern Rock, the troubled British mortgage lender, after winning the backing of the Treasury and Bank of England, which is trying to recover billions of pounds in emergency loans that have been made over the last two months.

title: Redskins Taylor Is Seriously Injured in Shooting
description: MIAMI, Nov. 26  Sean Taylor, a safety with the Washington Redskins, was unconscious and fighting for his life today after being shot by an intruder at his home south of Miami, the authorities and one of his lawyers said.

title: President Bush and Madame Rice: A Personal Bond Helps Align Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25  Condoleezza Rice and President Bush are often described as opposites, but their closest advisers say they are remarkably alike. Both are products of their own elites  Mr. Bush from the old East Coast establishment, Ms. Rice from Southern black professionals  who are supremely self-confident on the surface but harbor resentments underneath. Ms. Rice, like Mr. Bush, has been underestimated her entire life, as an African-American, as a woman and often as the youngest person in the room.

title: A Low-Tech Writer With a High-Tech Appetite
description: Alan Flacks has been a consummate Upper West Side gadfly for years and a fixture at meetings of the community board and political clubs, including the Three Parks Independent Democrats, where he is the house nudge.

title: Menagerie, Not Museum, for Words That Live
description: In his 1755 dictionary Samuel Johnson defined the lexicographer as a writer of dictionaries; a harmless drudge, that busies himself in tracing the original, and detailing the signification of words. Unfortunately Johnson was uncharacteristically wrong. A lexicographer, if any good, is hardly a drudge, and if bad, is hardly harmless.

title: Bushs Best Hope
description: The Palestinians are the cause of exiting and ex-presidents. Theres no electoral payback in supporting them. Jews and Israel-loving evangelicals dwarf any Arab lobby to the extent its not even funny.

title: Rio Tinto Defends Rejection of Bid
description: SINGAPORE, Nov. 26  Almost three weeks after rejecting a takeover proposal from the rival mining company BHP Billiton, Rio Tinto laid out its case today for why it thinks its shareholders should hold out for a better offer.

title: Fed Injects Funds to Ease Lending Concerns
description: Seeking to reassure banks amid the ongoing credit crisis, the Federal Reserve said today that it would provide $8 billion in funds to ease concerns over lending during the holiday season.

title: A Gimmick Becomes a Real Trend
description: TWO years ago, Cyber Monday was a marketing gimmick in search of shoppers. This year, it seems to be a genuine trend that retailers have embraced.

title: Manhattan: Man Charged in Killing
description: The police have charged a man with murder in the shooting of a man whose body was found on a street corner in Harlem last week. The suspect, Mohamed Musaid, 30, who the police said had no known address, was charged in the fatal shooting of Rafik Alsamet, 39, of Melville Street in the Bronx. The police said the killing was part of a continuing dispute. Mr. Alsamets body was found at West 133rd Street and Lenox Avenue on Wednesday.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Wednesday about Milo Radulovich, an Air Force reserve officer whose firing over suspicion that his relatives had Communist connections prompted an Edward R. Murrow documentary on CBS in 1953, omitted a survivor. She is his sister, Margaret Fishman of Detroit. (Go to Article)

title: New York Manhole Covers, Forged Barefoot in India
description: NEW DELHI  Eight thousand miles from Manhattan, barefoot, shirtless, whip-thin men rippled with muscle were forging prosaic pieces of the urban jigsaw puzzle: manhole covers.

title: Thompson Calls for Option of a Simplified Income Tax
description: Fred D. Thompson recommended yesterday that people have the option to pay a simplified tax on their income.

title: Dueling Guitars in Gameland: MTV and Activision Face Off
