description: The holiday season is when all the action takes place in the video game business, and this year has already pitted Microsofts Xbox 360 against Sonys PlayStation 3, and sleek new software against sequels like Halo 3.

title: New York Public Library Buys Schlesinger Papers
description: In a 1976 letter accompanying seven chapters of his biography of Robert F. Kennedy, Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. advises his editor at Houghton Mifflin to prepare for a very long book and promote it.

title: A Piano Pounder Stops by, but Things Remain Orderly
description: Not too long ago, even just 10 years ago, Jerry Lee Lewis treated songs as if they didnt matter. In concerts at times he sped them up, slowed them down, abandoned them in the middle, acted disdainful of them.

title: The Child in Balanchine Still Jumps for Joy
description: Why has George Balanchines production of The Nutcracker remained the gold-standard version of this holiday classic? The New York City Ballet began its annual run of the piece on Friday night at the New York State Theater and worked its usual magic, despite generally run-of-the-mill performing. Part of the charm comes from the timelessly old-fashioned costumes by Karinska and sets by Rouben Ter-Arutunian: like candy but not too sweet and blessedly unchanged in spirit over the 53 years since the premiere. And there are a few choice choreographic set pieces and effects in the second act, which essentially departs from the narrative to spool out a series of traditional divertissements, most of them alluding to holiday treats.

title: Syria Says It Will Join Conference in Maryland
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25  Syria announced Sunday that it would attend the Middle East peace meeting beginning here Monday night, joining Saudi Arabia and the rest of the Arab League participants in a turnabout that represented a victory for the Bush administration.

title: Youre Eating That?
description: A few years ago Americans walked into the grocery store and plucked items from the shelves with a confidence that the world could only envy. Now, according to a survey for the Food Marketing Institute, only 66 percent of consumers in the United States are confident that the food they buy is safe, down from 82 percent last year. With news of killer spinach, tainted hamburger patties and imported seafood that can provide as many toxins as omega-3s, who can blame them?

title: A Flow of Three Composers With a Flavor of the New
description: It is said that people tend to think of themselves as younger than they really are. This is eminently true of classical music. Randall Hodgkinsons piano recital at Bargemusic on Friday night would qualify to many as contemporary when it should be labeled classic.

title: Up Close, Farms Annoy Some Seekers of Rural Life
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  Out where the Long Island Expressway and suburban sprawl fall away and the village of Riverhead opens onto the North Forks expanse of produce stands, farmhouses and acres of crops, a luxury-home development called the Highlands at Aquebogue has sprouted up on Sound Avenue.

title: Grandparents Face the Challenges of 2 Households
description: Rosario Bencosme, 64, has two homes, two centers of gravity that she travels between on the No. 1 train: the subsidized one-bedroom apartment in Harlem that she and her husband, Pablo Octavio, got in September, and the rented room in Washington Heights that is the home of her younger son and three of her grandchildren.

title: Car Bomb Kills 9 in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 25  A car bomb killed nine people near Baghdads medical district on Sunday. It was the second major bomb in the Iraqi capital in three days, after a recent lull in violence.

title: Misgivings Rise Along With Antarctican Tourism
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 25  From its beginning until its demise, the Explorer was an Antarctic pioneer. Launched in 1969 under the name Lindblad Explorer, it was the first ship built specifically to ferry tourists to Antarctica. When it disappeared beneath the polar regions waters last week, it became the first commercial passenger ship to sink there.

title: Chinese Art Sales
description: A five-day sale of 20th-century and contemporary Asian art at Christies International in Hong Kong opened yesterday with two works selling for a total of just over $9 million, Bloomberg News reported. An abstract oil by Zao Wou-Ki, a Chinese painter long based in Paris, sold for $3.3 million, a new record for Mr. Zao, and a piece by Chen Cheng-po, a Taiwanese painter who died in 1947, went for $5.8 million. Among the highlights of this weeks sales  which will also include antiques, jewelry and ceramics  are a set of 14 works in gunpowder on paper by Cai Guo-Qiang, a Chinese artist whose solo show at the Guggenheim opens in February, and a Ming dynasty jar expected to fetch $3.9 million.

title: Conference Title Game Seen as an Obstacle
description: In a college football season that has rendered predictions and prognosticators nearly useless, there is still the comfort of one certainty: There will be controversy over which two teams play for the national title.

title: Folk, With an Unusual Bunch of Instruments
description: In the tradition of the American folk singer that he has upheld for the last 40 years, Arlo Guthrie usually performs on his own or with a few sidemen. But for his annual holiday concert at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening Mr. Guthrie went symphonic, turning up with the University of Kentucky Symphony Orchestra, led by John Nardolillo. Mr. Nardolillo and his ensemble also accompany Mr. Guthrie on his latest album, In Times Like These (Rising Son Records), recorded this year.

title: A Long Shot With the Gift for Resisting
description: Bernie Parrish has been a thorn in many sides.

title: John Noble, Gulag Survivor, Dies at 84
description: John H. Noble, an American who never knew why the Soviets imprisoned him in their notorious gulag, but not only lived to write books on the grim, decade-long experience but also recovered his familys company and castle in the former East Germany, died on Nov. 10 in Dresden, Germany. He was 84.

title: Talks Adjourned in Broadway Strike
description: Talks in the Broadway strike were adjourned at 6:30 a.m. Monday between the league representing the theater owners and producers and the union representing the stagehands.

title: Short of Funds, G.O.P. Recruits the Rich to Run
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25  Confronting an enormous fund-raising gap with Democrats, Republican Party officials are aggressively recruiting wealthy candidates who can spend large sums of their own money to finance their Congressional races, party officials say.

title: Syria Plans to Attend Meeting on Mideast Peace
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25  Syria announced Sunday that it would attend the Middle East peace meeting beginning here on Monday night, joining Saudi Arabia and the rest of the Arab League participants in a turnabout that represented a victory for the Bush administration.

title: Blocking Shots in N.H.L. Involves Skill and Abandon
description: In a blink of time, a sliver of space opened between Philadelphia forward Joffrey Lupul and the Rangers net. It was a tantalizing moment for Lupul, who stood to the left of the crease, seemingly set up for a sure goal. But as soon as Lupul took the shot in that Nov. 15 game, he saw Rangers defenseman Fedor Tyutin sliding into his peripheral vision, hurtling legs-first into Lupuls treasured open space.

title: In Miles of Alleys, Chicago Finds Its Next Environmental Frontier
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 25  If this were any other city, perhaps it would not matter what kind of roadway was underfoot in the back alleys around town. But with nearly 2,000 miles of small service streets bisecting blocks from the North Side to the South Side, Chicago is the alley capital of America. In its alleys, city officials say, it has the paved equivalent of five midsize airports.

title: Kudos for Spike Lee
description: Spike Lee, below, has been chosen to receive the Wexner Prize, a $50,000 award given by the Wexner Center for the Arts at Ohio State University to a contemporary artist in any field who has been consistently original, influential and challenging to convention, the Wexner Center announced. Mr. Lee, 50, is to receive the award in a ceremony at the Wexner in February. Previous recipients include the choreographer Bill T. Jones, the architect Renzo Piano, the director Martin Scorsese and the painter Gerhard Richter.

title: Enchanted Charms Filmgoers
description: Enchanted, starring Amy Adams, right,  as a fairy-tale princess exiled to a place where there are no happily-ever-afters  that would be present-day New York City  was the top draw at movie theaters over the holiday weekend. The film, directed by Kevin Lima and released by Disney, grossed $35.3 million from Friday through Sunday, with a five-day take of just over $50 million since its release on Wednesday, according to estimates by the box-office tracking firm Media by Numbers. This Christmas (Sony/Screen Gems), also released Wednesday but shown on only 1,858 screens in the United States and Canada  half as many as for Enchanted  came in second with a five-day gross of $27.1 million ($18.6 million from Friday to Sunday). The semi-animated Beowulf (Paramount), No. 1 last weekend, fell two spots with five-day ticket sales of $23.3 million and a three-day take of $16.2 million, bringing its two-week total to $56.3 million. Hitman (Fox) opened in fourth place with five-day sales of $21 million ($13 million from Friday to Sunday), and Bee Movie (Paramount) pulled in just less than $16 million since Wednesday and $12 million since Friday, for a four-week total of $112 million.

title: The Vikings Defense Belies Its Statistics
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 25  After their decimation of the Giants offense on Sunday, the Minnesota Vikings defensive players came up with two major reasons.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Albany Bars Rent Rise for Thousands
description: A loophole in New York States rent regulations that would have led to sharp rent increases for thousands of tenants was closed last week by housing officials.

title: Getting Paid to Chew Gum Can Be Sweet, but Also Sour
description: WHIPPANY, N.J.  Sue McNamara is the envy of friends and family alike. For a few hours four mornings a week, she sits in a spotless room in a lab coat and chews gum. Then she tells her boss how it tastes. Then she gets paid.

title: Totals
description: Previously recorded $2,275,895.90

title: Reading for Test Scores, and for Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Polite Entertainment From New Yorks House Band
description: Music lovers in this city are lucky to have an orchestra as good as the New York Philharmonic to complain about. It plays skillfully, it makes lovely sounds, and Lorin Maazel has schooled it to new heights of discipline. All this was demonstrated once again in the palindromic program  beginning and ending with short, light pieces that bookended a symphony and a concerto  with which the Philharmonic celebrated the Thanksgiving holiday weekend.

title: Bush Voices Optimism on Eve of Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26  President Bush today welcomed key participants in the Middle East conference that is getting under way in Annapolis, Md., with an acknowledgment that the United States cannot force peace on the region.

title: Laugh Lines in the Hollywood Strike
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 25  When the 12,000 members of the Writers Guild of America decided on Nov. 4 to strike, Hollywood wondered how hard the white-collar group would fight. The guild addressed the worry before the first pickets hit the streets.

title: Rite Aid Stores in West Selling a Paternity Test Kit
description: Genetic testing is now available at the drugstore. A company called Sorenson Genomics has started selling a paternity test kit through Rite Aid stores in California, Oregon and Washington. It appears to be the first time a DNA test is being sold through a major pharmacy chain.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week included todays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, an auction of four-week bills tomorrow, an auction of two-year notes on Wednesday and an auction of five-year notes on Thursday.

title: Gene Therapy Study to Resume After Womans Death
description: Federal regulators have given permission for a company to resume a gene therapy study in which a woman died, the company is expected to announce today.

title: Bitterest Rival of Musharraf Returns Home
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, Nov. 25  Former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif arrived home from exile to a tumultuous welcome on Sunday evening, providing a new rallying point for Pakistans disillusioned opposition and setting the stage for an overnight shift of the political scene in the country.

title: Second Day of Protests Against Putin in Russia
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 25  On a second day of rallies against President Vladimir V. Putin, riot police officers broke up a protest in St. Petersburg on Sunday, detaining numerous marchers, including two prominent politicians.

title: Security Increased at Giants Stadium Ramps
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 25  The security presence on the two spiral ramps at Gate D of Giants Stadium was overwhelming Sunday during halftime of the Giants game against the Minnesota Vikings. More than 25 state troopers and 50 security guards patrolled the multilevel ramps.

title: Test and Switch
description: Congress hoped that if it required the states to give annual tests in return for federal education aid, state politicians would be encouraged  or at least embarrassed  into improving dismal schools and closing the achievement gap between rich and poor children.

title: Australias Path Bends Away From U.S.
description: LONDON, Nov. 25  The defeat of John Howard, Australias prime minister, in Saturdays election deprived President Bush of one of his most steadfast allies and will bring changes in Australias foreign policy that will be felt in Washington.

title: Manhattan: Three Men Stabbed
description: Three 28-year-old men were stabbed in a parking garage in Midtown early yesterday after an argument, the police said. The stabbing occurred shortly after 4 a.m. in the garage at 810 Seventh Avenue, near a restaurant and bar, Mars 2112, the police said. One man was stabbed eight times in the torso; he was taken to NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell hospital, where his condition was upgraded during the day to stable from critical. The other two victims were in stable condition at St. Vincents Midtown Hospital, the police said. One of them had been stabbed six times, the other, once. There were no arrests yesterday.

title: F.C.C. Chief Seeks Votes to Tighten Cable Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25  The head of the Federal Communications Commission is struggling to find enough support from a majority of the agencys commissioners to regulate cable television companies more tightly.

title: True November
description: A couple of days ago we had what the forecasts call a wintry mix, which always sounds to me like something youd set out in bowls at a cocktail party this time of year. It was, in fact, rain, snow and sleet mixed with sand and salt and the sludge that gets thrown from the treads of tires. One minute snow was falling in clumps, and the next it was raining. The sky was the color of duct tape, and it let about that much light through. What a wintry mix does is make you want to stay home  or perhaps go into the world foraging for provisions simply for the pleasure of getting home again.

title: A Big Book Advance for a Last Lecture
description: A book based on a heartfelt public talk by an ailing Carnegie Mellon professor is to be published by Hyperion, according to Crains New York Business. The Last Lecture, written by Randy Pausch, a 47-year-old computer science teacher who has terminal pancreatic cancer, and Jeff Zaslow, a columnist for The Wall Street Journal, will be based on a wide-ranging talk that Professor Pausch gave at Carnegie Mellon, in Pittsburgh, on Sept. 18. With scans of the tumors on his liver in the background, Professor Pausch reviewed his life and career. Brick walls are there for a reason, he said in the lecture. They let us prove how badly we want things. The lecture became a Web video phenomenon and led to appearances on The Oprah Winfrey Show and Good Morning America. Citing unnamed sources, Crains said that Hyperion offered $6.7 million for the book, beating HarperCollins in a bidding war.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Enchanted Charms Filmgoers

title: Immigrants Pull Weight in Economy, Study Finds
description: Immigrants contribute nearly one-fourth of the economic output of New York State, and outside of New York City, they are overrepresented in some of the most critical occupations, including higher education and health care, according to a study to be released today.

title: Doorstep Protest: Very Real, Very Virtual
description: ON a recent Sunday afternoon, a varied group of 20 or so protesters  some wearing nose rings, others sensible shoes  gathered on Central Park West on the Upper West Side and started shouting insults like animal murderer at the top of their lungs, standing a court-ordered 45 feet away from the apartment of Robert J. McSweeney, a former senior vice president of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Theater Notes
description: Urban Stages holiday show, The Blue Bird, written by Stanton Wood and Lori Ann Laster, will run from Dec. 14 to Jan. 13. In the musical, based on the play by Maurice Maeterlinck, a mysterious visitor on Christmas Eve leads a city girl on a fantastical journey in search of the blue bird of happiness. Information: urbanstages.org. ... Jonathan Groff, above, of Spring Awakening, is one of several strike-bound Broadway stars who lent their voices to a recording of The Sound of Music being used for a touring production by the Salzburg Marionette Theater. The show will run at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark (njpac.org) for four performances beginning Friday and at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (metmuseum.org) for four shows beginning Dec. 7. ... The Roundabout Theater will offer a discussion series following performances of The Ritz at Studio 54 tomorrow and on Dec. 4. Sex & the Ritz will be a candid talk with authors and other participants about the sexual revolution and the emergence of AIDS.

title: Thomas and Knicks Savor One Victory for All Its Worth
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Nov. 25  Isiah Thomas blew past Fred Jones for a layup, hit a jumper over Jared Jeffries and made a left-handed runner over Nate Robinson. Thomas chuckled throughout it all, projecting the image of a man who had just had a great burden lifted from his psyche.

title: Vladimir Kryuchkov, Ex-Chief of K.G.B., Dies at 83
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 25  Vladimir A. Kryuchkov, who as the K.G.B. chief denounced perestroika as a menace to the Soviet Union and then took matters into his own hands by helping to spearhead a coup against Mikhail S. Gorbachev in 1991 that collapsed after only three days, died on Friday. He was 83.

title: Edwards Offers Heating Plan
description: Former Senator John Edwards outlined a proposal yesterday in New Hampshire to lower the cost of heating oil, increase regulation of oil companies and promote energy efficiency.

title: Rangers Are Fighting an Inefficient Offense
description: Rangers left wing Brendan Shanahan will celebrate his 39th birthday in January, but he grappled with Dallas Stars forward Steve Ott yesterday and drew a lusty cheer from the crowd at Madison Square Garden after he knocked off Otts helmet, then wrestled him to the ice.

title: Talks Resume Again in Broadway Strike
description: Talks in the Broadway strike resumed yesterday between the league representing the theater owners and producers and the union representing the stagehands.

title: The Days Best
description: Patrick Kerney had three sacks and an interception to lead the Seahawks past the Rams, 24-19. Kerney, a defensive end, also forced a fumble for the second week in a row.

title: Its How Much You Think You Have
description: People spend money, in large part, based on how much they think they have; and that perception, it seems, is easily manipulated. A series of experiments reported in The Journal of Consumer Research tested the malleability of peoples understandings of how much money, or other resources, they have on hand, and explored the effects on consumption.

title: From Vienna, a Killer in a Cowboy Suit
description: In his awkward new book about a particularly unappetizing criminal, John Leake struggles to make a case for the egomaniac he has studied. The killer in question, Jack Unterweger, was Austrian born. He has been unknown to English-language readers except for those who favor serial-killer anthologies with titles like Vulture, The Unknown Darkness and The Human Predator.

title: Rutgers Gets Physical to Win a Rematch
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Nov. 25  About seven months after Rutgers steamrolled Louisiana State to reach the national championship game, the rematch was immensely more difficult. It was 40 minutes of bump-and-grind basketball and the outcome was not decided until the Lady Tigers missed a last-second shot.

title: Missouri, No. 1? College Football Surprises Again
description: Imagine Albania playing for the World Cup title in soccer, or an amateur golfer approaching the final hole with the United States Open at stake. Think of Adam Sandler as a nominee for best actor at the Academy Awards.

title: HSBC Moves to Rescue 2 S.I.V.s
description: LONDON, Nov. 26  Europes largest bank, HSBC Holdings, said today that it would bail out its two structured investment vehicles, or S.I.V.s, by taking $45 billion in assets onto its balance sheet.

title: In the Netherlands, Eat, Drink and Be Monitored
description: WAGENINGEN, the Netherlands  At first sight, nothing betrays the strange happenings at the Restaurant of the Future, a spacious, bright university canteen where scientists and students stop in for food and lunchtime chatter.

title: Lott to Resign His Senate Seat Before Years End
description: PASCAGOULA, Miss. Nov. 26  Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, who was forced to step down as Republican leader in 2002 after making a remark that seemed to support segregation, announced today that he will resign by the end of the year.

title: A Magazine Challenges the Big Boys
description: There is a room in our house where time has been stopped. There are no flat-panel TVs, no docking stations for the iPod, and no keyboards save my wifes accordion. In that room  the quaint description is living room  there is a large comfortable chair, a good lamp, and a magazine rack groaning with the fruits of American journalism. Almost every day, I drop a magazine there or a longer newspaper article, with the best intention of getting to it when things slow down a bit.

title: Mondays Matchup
description: After a stunning loss to the Jets last week, Pittsburgh is happy to be back at Heinz Field. The Steelers are 5-0 at home, where they have outscored their opponents, 154-54, and outgained their opponents by 1,804-923. Willie Parker was held to 52 rushing yards last week, but Miami entered the weekend with the N.F.L.s worst run defense, allowing 154.9 yards a game. This will be Miami linebacker Joey Porters first game against his former team. Porter went to three Pro Bowls in eight seasons as a Steeler, but was cut in a money-saving move in the off-season. He signed a five-year, $32 million contract with the Dolphins. Porter was certainly a leader on the team, but Pittsburgh has had the No. 1 defense without him.

title: Patriots Are Unbeaten but Dont Look Unbeatable
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Nov. 25  A golden full moon loomed over Gillette Stadium a few hours before kickoff, which should have been all the indication anybody needed that strange things might happen.

title: A Notorious Main Drag, in Line for Big Changes
description: DENVER, Nov. 21  Colfax Avenue is often described as one of Americas wickedest streets. Jack Kerouac wrote of its tawdry watering holes in On The Road. In the movie Every Which Way But Loose, Clint Eastwoods character and his pet orangutan, Clyde, came here looking for action.

title: Pressure for Results: The Politics of Tallying the Number of Iraqis Who Return Home
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 25  At a row of travel agencies near the highway to Syria, the tide of migration has reversed: the buses and GMC Suburban vans filled with people heading to Damascus run infrequently, while those coming from the border appear every day.

title: If at First You Dont ... You Know the Rest
description: Surely no publication has struggled to follow its own advice more than Success, the small-business magazine that has failed repeatedly since it was founded in 1891.

title: Rough Day for Manning and the Giants
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 25  Eli Manning wore a look of disgust. He had just thrown an interception, and a Vikings defender had run past him on the way to the end zone. Manning looked as if he could not believe what he had done and what he was seeing.

title: Two Titles in San Francisco
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 25  The first national titles at the Fall North American Bridge Championships were decided here Saturday. Bjorn Fallenius and Zia Mahmood of New York won the Bobby Nail Life Master Pairs, just under one board ahead of Michael Prahin of Irvington, N.Y., and Alex Perlin of Metuchen, N.J. Third were Bobby Levin and Roy Welland of New York.

title: ABC News and Facebook in Joint Effort to Bring Viewers Closer to Political Coverage
description: Facebook, the popular social networking site, has become a full-fledged platform for communicating, sharing and advertising. ABC News is betting that it will become a platform for political coverage, as well.

title: This Years Models: Searching for Fresh Approaches in Photography
description: Bright letters announce New Photography 2007 on a wall outside the Museum of Modern Arts photography galleries. Just inside is a room of vintage-looking black-and-white photographs. Contemporary photographers are showing a strong interest in early photography, so your first thought is that the curator has unearthed someone recycling the ideas and methods of Eadweard Muybridge, Alfred Stieglitz or Clarence White.

title: Ruminations on Food as Soap, Food for Singles and Henry Miller
description: IT is time again to ask 20 questions about advertising, marketing, media and popular culture.

title: A Surprise Gig by Two From U2
description: Bono and the Edge (above, left and right) of U2 made a surprise appearance at a charity concert in a London church on Friday night, The Associated Press reported. Warming up a crowd of about 250 as part of a benefit for Mencap, a British organization that helps people with learning disabilities, they played four songs in a 20-minute acoustic set: Stay (Faraway, So Close!), Desire, Angel of Harlem and Wave of Sorrow (Birdland), a rarity that was intended for U2s 1987 album, The Joshua Tree, but not released until the records new 20th-anniversary edition. Dont tell Larry and Adam weve done this, Bono said, referring to Larry Mullen Jr., the bands drummer, and Adam Clayton, its bassist. The show was at the Union Chapel, a church that also presents concerts, and Reuters reported that Mr. Clayton was in the audience.

title: Doling Out Other Peoples Money
description: A couple of years ago, Judge Harold Baer Jr. found himself with $6 million of unclaimed money from the settlement of an antitrust class-action lawsuit. The case had involved fashion models, so he decided to give the extra money to charities likely to assist them.

title: Behind Rices Shift on Leading Mideast Peace Efforts
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25  At President Bushs first National Security Council meeting in January 2001, he announced that he did not want to be drawn into the shattered Middle East peace process, people at the meeting recalled, because he believed that former President Bill Clinton had pushed so hard for an Israeli-Palestinian accord that he made the situation worse.

title: Winter of Our Discontent
description: Americans Economic Pessimism Reaches Record High. Thats the headline on a recent Gallup report, which shows a nation deeply unhappy with the state of the economy. Right now, 27% of Americans rate current economic conditions as either excellent or good, while 44% say they are only fair and 28% say they are poor. Moreover, an extraordinary 78% of Americans now say the economy is getting worse, while a scant 13% say it is getting better.

title: Oxford Union Debate Features Holocaust Denier
description: OXFORD, England, Nov. 26  In the face of angry protests, the Oxford Union debating society went ahead today with plans for an evening debate featuring David Irving, a British author jailed in Austria in 2005 for denying the Holocaust, and Nick Griffin, leader of the far-right British National Party, acquitted by a British court last year of stirring racial hatred.

title: Faux Fiscal Discipline
description: In the 2000 campaign, Gov. George W. Bush rebutted charges that he was a big spender, noting that on his watch, Texas state spending had been modest when adjusted for inflation and population. That answer is utterly reasonable. Spending that is more or less constant in terms of the cost of living and the number of beneficiaries is hardly runaway.

title: High Empathy (Mostly Women), Low Empathy (Mostly Men) and the Movies
description: Women looking for a movie date and filmmakers looking to increase box-office receipts both know that many men have little interest in melodramatic tearjerkers. New research, however, suggests that producers of emotional films can increase their male audience by emphasizing the films disconnection from reality.

title: Looking Ahead
description: ECONOMIC SIGNALS Housing will be a focus for the week. On Wednesday, the National Association of Realtors reports on existing home sales for October. And on Thursday, the Commerce Department reports on new-home sales for October and Freddie Mac reports on mortgage rates.

title: Antismoking Activist Calls Rolling Stone Insert One Great Big Cigarette Ad
description: An insert in Rolling Stone magazine sponsored by Camel cigarettes is under fire from antismoking activists because, they say, it blurs the line between advertising and editorial content  and worse yet, features cartoons.

title: Alternative Journalists Web Site Is Scrutinized for Writers Strike News
description: When some striking members of the Writers Guild of America created a series of videos depicting speechless actors in support of the writers cause, they did not post them on the guilds Web site or on YouTube. Instead, the videos made their premiere exclusively on Deadline Hollywood Daily, a Web site owned and operated by Nikki Finke, a columnist for the alternative newspaper LA Weekly.

title: Rice Benefits From a Tight Bond With Bush
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25  Condoleezza Rice and President Bush are often described as opposites, but their closest advisers say they are remarkably alike. Both are products of their own elites  Mr. Bush from the old East Coast establishment, Ms. Rice from Southern black professionals  who are supremely self-confident on the surface but harbor resentments underneath. Ms. Rice, like Mr. Bush, has been underestimated her entire life, as an African-American, as a woman and often as the youngest person in the room.

title: Malibu Fire Is Largely Contained
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 25  The fire that burned nearly 5,000 acres and destroyed about 50 homes in Malibu over the weekend was 70 percent contained on Sunday, officials said.

title: Let Venezuela Ask First
description: To the Editor:

title: New CDs
description: JORDIN SPARKS  (19/Jive/Zomba)

title: Rices Turnabout on Mideast Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25  At President Bushs first National Security Council meeting in January 2001, he announced that he did not want to be drawn into the shattered Middle East peace process, people at the meeting recalled, because he believed that former President Bill Clinton had pushed so hard for an Israeli-Palestinian accord that he made the situation worse.

title: In West Iowa, Obamas Man Thinks Locally
description: MISSOURI VALLEY, Iowa, Nov. 24  Rory Steele had bounced along a gravel road that rides like a washboard to get to the farmstead. He stepped across a few rows of soybeans, climbed up the steps of a red Case combine and squeezed into a seat next to Lyle McIntosh, who was circling a field.

title: Jaguars Roll Into a Rematch With the Colts
description: Fred Taylor ran for a season-high 104 yards and a touchdown, Josh Scobee kicked five field goals and the Jaguars routed the Bills, 36-14, yesterday.

title: Coupless Back, and His Game, Hold Up Fine
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. Nov. 25  Impervious to the whims of style, the ravages of time and even global warming, Fred Couples is still as cool as a fall morning in the desert. This has always been one of golfs sure things, and it remains unchanged. Only one thing in life can make Couples sweat, and Sunday his often-injured back felt good enough to prevent any beads from popping out on his brow.

title: Talks Resume Again in Broadway Strike
description: Talks resumed today between the Broadway producers league and the striking stagehands union as they tried to reach an agreement that would end the walkout that has left most theaters dark for 16 days.

title: Retail Sales Rise, but Stores Relied on Discounts
description: Black Friday was big  but with a big caveat.

title: Starting a New Chapter After Foundation Jobs End
description: When Susan V. Berresford steps down as president of the Ford Foundation in January, she hopes to join the LAFF Society. That is, If theyll have me, she said.

title: Classic, Flashy, Naughty: Which Nutcracker Works for You?
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 25  From Baryshnikov to Barbie, anyone who has ever spent time on toes, it sometimes seems, has danced The Nutcracker.

title: Wholl Pay the Price for Corporate Failure?
description: To the Editor:

title: New Yorks Construction Boom Puts More Women in Hard Hats
description: Olga Aguilar walked through a tunnel of scaffolding at 6:30 a.m. on a recent weekday and into the Brompton, a 20-story condominium building going up at 86th Street and Third Avenue in Manhattan.

title: Taking Marriage Private
description: Olympia, Wash.

title: Addiction and Community
description: To the Editor:

title: Take Tea and See, Again
description: Decades ago, tea makers took out ads that urged coffee-mad consumers to Take tea and see. Today, a leader in the booming tea market is asking tea drinkers to take another look at their favorite beverage.

title: An Indiana Representative Has Terminal Cancer
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 25 (AP)  Representative Julia Carson, Democrat of Indiana, has terminal lung cancer, a newspaper reported Sunday.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Franco Bonadio was named chief executive at Identica, London, part of the Cossette Communication Group, effective in early January. He will succeed Michael Peters, the founder of Identica, who will serve as a consultant. Mr. Bonadio is global creative director at the Body Shop retail chain, London, part of LOral.

title: Tensions Rise for Colombia and Venezuela
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 25  Venezuela and Colombia moved toward a diplomatic crisis on Sunday after an exchange of insults between President Hugo Chvez and his Colombian counterpart, lvaro Uribe.

title: A Touch of Lavender Amid an Embarrassment of Suitors
description: Faced with the challenge of staging a 17th-century play, a director is generally thought to have two options: Stay true to the period or update. With her production of George Farquhars Constant Couple, written in 1699, at the Pearl Theater Company, Jean Randich has the sense to leave a good play largely alone and the wit to establish small links to the present: bits of anachronistic costuming (a pair of defiantly 21st-century shoes) or speech inflection.

title: After Cyclone, Bangladesh Faces Political Storm
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh, Nov. 24  The political storm that preceded natures latest assault on this country still swirls overhead.

title: British Firms Urge Action on Climate
description: LONDON, Nov. 25  Britains largest companies are pledging to offer greener products and invest in research and technology as part of a wider push to reduce carbon emissions.

title: William ONeill, 77, a Connecticut Governor, Is Dead
description: William A. ONeill, the son of a small-town tavern owner who rose through Connecticut politics to serve as governor for a decade, died Saturday. He was 77.

title: Anti-Putin Protesters Arrested in Russia
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 25  On a second day of rallies against President Vladimir V. Putin, riot police officers aggressively broke up a protest in St. Petersburg on Sunday, detaining numerous marchers, including two prominent politicians.

title: Lottery Numbers
Stocks Plummet; Bond Yields Sag
description: The stock market fell sharply late today and investors rushed to the safety of Treasuries as concerns about mortgage-related losses continued to unsettle the financial market.

title: Bits
description: What Amazons E-Reader Needs

title: Around the World in One Night
description: The fifth annual GlobalFest, a one-night showcase of top world-music performers, will be held on Jan. 13 at Webster Hall in Manhattan. Connected to a conference of the Association of Performing Arts Presenters, this years GlobalFest will feature 13 performers on three stages, including the eccentric Italian songwriter Vinicio Capossela; Fallou Dieng, a rising star of Senegalese mbalax; the Korean drumming group Dulsori; Chango Spasiuk, an accordionist from Argentina; Jos Manuel Cobles (a k a Puerto Plata), an octogenarian guitarist and singer from the Dominican Republic; Samarabalouf, a French Gypsy jazz band; and Toumast, a guitar group from the deserts of Niger. Tickets: (866) 448-7849 or globalfest-ny.org.

title: Reader Responses
description: "I just finished reading your article in today's paper. I am a physician and occasionally debate the topic of mistakes, errors, and negligence with legal acquaintances. The plaintiff attorneys equate error with negligence (and therefore payment) without exception. I counter that while certainly not desired, and as you point out when someone's life is in your hands we strive to "avoid mistakes as much as possible", perfection is not humanly possible. Negligence is, or should be, harmful action beyond the range of customary or expected outcome. In my opinion, this is not the same as error free which is an unattainable standard. Yet, try and convince a lay jury in retrospective analysis a decision, diagnosis, judgment was "wrong" but not negligent.

title: Looking Back at Four Crossroads
description: Excerpts from recent interviews with some of the Country Music Television series alumni.

title: Suzanne Farrell Ballet
description: Images from the company at the Kennedy Center.

title: The Stock Isnt Jumpin, but the Store Is
description: Starbucks stock has been decaffeinated lately, as The Times notes. Maybe Starbucks needs to reconsider a rejected ad jingle:

title: More of Your Monologue Jokes!
description: Readers continue to prove that even with late-night comedy writers on strike, theres no shortage of jokes out there (send yours via the comment link below). Here are a few (more than a few, actually) from something of a ringer: Patrick Gorse of Pasadena, Calif., who cranks em out daily for radio shows:

title: Costco Diplomacy
description: A story on our most e-mailed list about the belt-tightening Washington elite notes that the Cheney family, Sally Quinn and foreign embassies all shop at Costco now. But Jimmy Kimmel shows how its really done:

title: Hedge Fund Raises Stake in Northern Rock
description: As bidders continued to circle Northern Rock, SRM Capital, a Monaco-based hedge fund firm, has bumped up its stake in the troubled British lender.

title: Britains Kelda Accepts $6.2 Billion Bid
description: The Kelda Group, a British water utility, said Monday that it had accepted a 3 billion pound ($6.2 billion) takeover approach from a consortium of infrastructure investment firms. Its announcement of the bid on Friday sent its shares almost 15 percent higher.

title: French Banks Acquire Bond Insurance Company
description: Another crack in the subprime mortgage market appeared to have been patched Thursday as two French banks bought out a bond-insurance company that has exposure to the mortgage crisis.

title: Wonder Woman
description: Gail Simone has become the first woman to serve as ongoing writer  in Wonder Woman's 66-year history.

title: Four Bidders Said to Consider DundeeWealth Bid
description: At least four of Canadas biggest financial institutions have signed confidentiality agreements to explore a takeover of DundeeWealth, and potential bidders are expected to decide within days whether to submit offers, The Globe and Mail reported.

title: Fund of Hedge Funds Taps Public Markets
description: Gottex Fund Management, the Lausanne- and London-based fund of hedge funds group, this month made its opening on the Swiss Exchange, the latest in a line of alternative asset managers cashing in on a perceived appetite among investors for publicly quoted hedge funds.

title: China Railway Raises $3 Billion in I.P.O.
description: The China Railway Group, a construction contractor, said it had raised 22.44 billion yuan ($3 billion) in its initial public offering in Shanghai on Friday after generating record interest in its $5.5 billion offer on the Hong Kong and Shanghai markets.

title: Diller Plans $100 Million Push into China
description: Barry Diller, the chief executive of the Internet conglomerate IAC/InterActiveCorp, said Friday that the company would invest $100 million to expand in China by creating services for local users.

title: Hagemeyer and Rexel Finalize $4.6 Billion Deal
description: Dutch electrical wholesaler Hagemeyer threw its full support behind a 3.13 billion euro ($4.6 billion) break-up bid from a French rival, Rexel on Friday.

title: Philips Hits the Switch on $2.7 Billion Genlyte Deal
description: Philips Electronics has agreed to buy the Genlyte Group, a lighting maker based in Louisville, Ky., for $2.7 billion (1.8 billion euros), making it the top lighting company in North America and sending its shares up to a week-high.

title: Bain Taps New Chief for Yacht Builder
description: Bain Capital has appointed the former chief operating officer of Arcor, a German fixed-line telecommunications provider to run one of its portfolio companies.

title: Spanish Bank Boosts Stake in Iberia Airline
description: An unlisted savings bank Caja Madrid has built a stake of more than 23 percent in the Spanish flagship airline Iberia in a move that could disrupt a potential bidding war for the airline, Europes fourth-largest carrier.

title: Banks Also Got a Boost on Black Friday
description: Holiday shoppers werent the only ones seeking bargains on Black Friday.

title: Islamic Banking Enters Mainstream
description: Rising oil wealth is lifting Islamic banking, which adheres to the laws of the Koran and its prohibition against charging interest, into the financial mainstream.

title: Enron Lawyers Seek $700 Million in Fees
description: Lawyers who recovered about $7.2 billion in settlements for investors who were damaged by the collapse of the energy trader Enron in late 2001 are seeking $700 million for their efforts, the largest fee in history in a securities fraud case.

title: Britain Plans New Look at Private Equity
description: The British House of Commons Treasury Select Committee plans another inquiry into Britains private equity industry, which continues to fend off criticism over its secretive nature and swelling profits.

title: Cerberus Responds to United Rentals Suit
description: Cerberus Capital Management, in its latest attempt to scuttle its $4 billion purchase of United Rentals, said it had filed a request on Wednesday for declaratory judgment in New York State Supreme Court.

title: Goldman Boards TPGs $2 Billion Russian Deal
description: The buyout shop, TPG Capital, is teaming up with Goldman Sachss private equity arm to help finance its acquisition of a Russian supermarket chain, Seventh Continent, as TPG seeks to expand its European network.

title: Is Murdoch Mulling Deal for LinkedIn?
description: Does Rupert Murdoch have his eye on LinkedIn, the networking site for professionals? TechCrunch reported that it had heard an unconfirmed rumor from a reliable source that LinkedIn is in talks with the media giant News Corporation over a possible buyout in January.

title: Google-Backed 23andMe Debuts
description: 23andMe, an online company backed by funds from Google that is selling a personal DNA test for $999, has made its start as a kind of genetics-focused MySpace or Facebook, but with the more serious aim of allowing medicine someday to target Americans ills more precisely.

title: Goldman Said to Seek $6 Billion for New Fund
description: Goldman Sachs is aiming to raise between $4 billion and $6 billion for a new hedge fund as the investment bank tries to rebuild its reputation in the hedge fund business, The Financial Times reported.

title: Branson Group Chosen for Northern Rock Rescue
description: The British government has chosen a consortium led by Richard Bransons Virgin Group as the preferred bidder to rescue the troubled lender  Northern Rock. The Virgin group has said it plans to repay 11 billion pounds ($22.6 billion) quickly to the Bank of England.

title: The List Is Stellar, but a Little Dated
description: When Doubledown Media published the first issue of Corporate Leader magazine this month, it included a list of the 100 Best C.E.O.s. But if there is a second annual listing, at least four of those chief executives will be missing.

title: Rio Tinto Defends Rejection of BHP Billiton
description: The mining giant Rio Tinto promoted its assets and growth prospects Monday as it moved to justify its earlier rejection of a takeover proposal from a rival, BHP Billiton, a multibillion dollar deal that would be among the worlds largest buyouts.

title: This Weeks Links: The Thumb Generation and the Rise of the Writer-Entrepreneur
description: Since last week ended on a Wednesday, I never got around to my Friday links. So now that Im completely off schedule, Im treating Monday like Friday and sharing a couple of inspiring reads I consumed these past few days between turkey and television.

title: Using Genius, Are the Weinsteins Plotting an I.P.O.?
description: Genius Products, whose main business is the home video distribution of The Weinstein Company, is stirring considerable commotion with plans to list on the Nasdaq exchange as soon as next month, Fortune reports.

title: Does She Get a Raise if She Can She Walk at the Same Time?
description: From Mondays paper:

title: Union Backs Tata Bid for Jaguar and Land Rover
description: Ford Motors British union Wednesday endorsed India-based Tata Groups bid to buy the Jaguar and Land Rover units.

title: Spector Keeps Vested Stock in Bear Exit
description: The exit package for Warren Spector, the former president of Bear Stearns, insures that the man charged with the oversight of two internal hedge funds that spectacularly blew up this summer wont want for money, The New York Post reported.

title: New York On Track to Outdo London Listings
description: The amount of money raised through initial public offerings in New York is set to surpass London for the first time in three years as companies fuel a surge in I.P.O. volume in spite of the turmoil in capital markets, The Financial Times reported.

title: For Lawyers, Perks to Fit a Lifestyle
description: The perks for lawyers have burgeoned in recent years as firms pull out the stops to attract top-notch talent. While extras for the partners have always been common, many are now finding their way to associates  young lawyers who have not yet made partner, The New York Times reports.

title: $300 Billion in Mortgage Write-Offs Is Predicted
description: Losses in the distressed mortgage sector of the United States could reach $300 billion, only a portion of which has so far been accounted for by write-offs at major banks, according to a study released on Thursday by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

title: Citadel Said to Be Up 27% for the Year
description: Despite market volatility, the Citadel Investment Group, a hedge fund based in Chicago, has gained 27 percent year to date in whats shaping up to be its second straight showing of double-digit returns, The Chicago Tribune reported.

title: Why hate Huckabee?
description: There are things about Mike Huckabee that make me very nervous  things like this:

title: HSBC to Restructure 2 SIVs
description: HSBC Holdings said Monday it would consolidate two structured investment vehicles, or SIVs, bringing $45 billion of assets onto the British lenders balance sheet. The move, which is expected to reduce the worldwide assets in SIVs, comes as United States banks are trying to organize an $80 billion fund to stabilize these kinds of vehicles.

title: Dubai Buys Substantial Stake in Sony
description: Dubai International Capital, a private equity company owned by the ruler of Dubai, said it had made a substantial investment in Sony, boosting the shares of the Japanese electronics and entertainment firm.

title: Unleash Your Wit
description: Arf! Tell us whats going on in the photo above. Its the latest of the uncaptioned photos were posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last weeks funniest captions are at right.

title: Oprah Set to Campaign for Obama
description: DES MOINES  Oprah Winfrey is coming to town for Senator Barack Obama, his campaign announced today, scheduling a three-state tour beginning here on Dec. 8.

title: The 2007 Awards Season Begins
description: Starting today, the Bagger returns for another year of Oscars analysis and more.

title: The Early Word: Giuliani Revives N.H. Campaign
description: G.O.P. candidate Rudolph W. Giuliani criss-crossed New Hampshire on a bus this weekend, shifting his strategy a bit away from his concentration on the states that vote Feb. 5 and focusing more on his rivals who have long courted the Granite States vote.

title: A Glorious Trainwreck
description: Thankfully, the one thing the Bagger has been allowed to do is see movies, although he has been forced to wear a disguise that involves a fake nose and a rather unfortunate beret. And so far, this season has been like a trip to the magic multi-plex, where the Goobers are free, the popcorn is bottomless and all the clinkers are at some other theater.

title: Jaunty Is as Jaunty Does
description: Take a good long look at that new logo hanging over the proceedings above us. The Bagger has gone all jaunty. During the off-season, corporate did extensive consumer research and discovered that the rumpled, over-the-hill version of the Bagger was in need of updating. The focus groups have spoken and the hoary use of metaphor in the blog will now be a thing of the past, as will cute asides about stuff that has nothing to do with movies.

title: Albany Bans Rent Increases for Thousands of Mitchell-Lama Tenants
description: A loophole in New York States rent regulations that would have led to sharp rent increases for thousands of tenants was closed last Wednesday by housing officials. The rule allowed landlords withdrawing from government subsidy programs to immediately bring the rent in their apartments up to market rate by claiming that exiting the programs created a unique and peculiar circumstance.

title: BofA Said to Take Lead in Super-SIV Outreach
description: The much-ballyhooed $75 billion fund known as the Super-Siv seems to be moving full-speed ahead, despite ongoing concerns that it will do little to revive the asset-backed securities market.

title: No Fond Farewells for Lott
description: Sen. Trent Lott, R-Miss., the minority whip is in the midst of informing close allies that he plans to resign his senate seat before the end of the year, reports NBC News.

title: Finding Perfect Jeans for an Imperfect Body
description: Is it your body that is the wrong size? Or is it your jeans?

title: U.N. Torture Panel Singles Out Tasers
description: All news reports about deaths that follow Taser shocks seem to come with two accompaniments: outrage over police brutality on the one hand, and a lack of definitive proof that the weapon was to blame on the other. A mans death in Vancouver, B.C., on Saturday was no different. But it happened to come a day after a United Nations panel appeared to take a stand against Tasers.

title: Londons Savoy: Buy a Piece of Hotel History
description: On December 15th one of Londons oldest and most famous hotels, The Savoy, will be closing its doors for a 16 month, 100 million pound restoration.

title: The Skim
description: A quick hike through the Sunday (and a few non-Sunday) book review sections.

title: McCain Ad Touts His Fighting Spirit
description: Senator John McCain of Arizona has a new presidential ad up thats fascinating in its complexity.

title: Go Shop or No Shop? Sears Criticizes Restoration Board
description: As the holiday season swings into high gear, will Sears Holding put Restoration Hardware in its shopping cart?

title: Citi May Start New Round of Layoffs
description: Is more pain in store for Citigroup?

title: ABC Plans Back-To-Back New Hampshire Debates
description: ABC News, Facebook and WMUR, the ABC affiliate in New Hampshire, will sponsor back-to-back Democratic and Republican presidential debates on Saturday, Jan. 5, three days before the states primary election.

title: Yes, Theyre Still Talking About It
description: Sometimes, long after blog articles scroll down and even off the City Room front page, readers keep talking. Here is a sampling of some recent comments on older posts.

title:
Talk to the Newsroom:
Fiona Spruill, Editor of the Web Newsroom
description: Fiona Spruill, editor of the Web newsroom, answered reader questions Nov. 2630. To read her most recent reply, click here.

title: Huckabee Zeroes In on Iowa Christians
description: Faith doesnt just influence me, it really defines me, says G.O.P. candidate Mike Huckabee, an ordained minister, in a new television spot intended to woo Iowa evangelicals.

title: Tragedy at Soccer Stadium in Brazil
description: After the good news earlier this month that Brazil was chosen to host the 2014 World Cup, some very sad news: Seven spectators were killed Sunday when a section of stadium seats collapsed during a postgame celebration in Salvador in Northeast Brazil.

title: Conventions Throw Doors Open to Bloggers
description: In her Web column today, Katharine Q. Seelye writes about how the Democrats are opening the doors of their convention in Denver next year to more bloggers than ever before. The move gives bloggers and the new media a chance to shine, much as they did at the trial of Scooter Libby earlier this year, and to bring a whole new perspective, and competition, to convention coverage.

title: New Trains Know Where You Are, and Tell You
description: For many riders, the subway system is no larger than the line they take. So they may miss innovations that have made their debut on other routes.

title: Getting Close to Liars
description: What do people really, really look like when theyre lying?

title: On the Road: Clintons Iowa Holiday
description: My Thanksgiving was bookended by Iowa: Monday-Wednesday there with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton; Thursday-Friday at my parents home in Boston; Saturday-Sunday there with post-holiday Hillary. This meant keeping pace with an atypical load of logistics.

title: Monday Kickoff: Coaching Carousel Starts Spinning
description: With the regular season over for many teams, there will be plenty of hiring and firing in the next few weeks. Mike Sherman is expected to be named Texas A&Ms new football coach at a news conference today, according to a report by Brian Davis of the Dallas Morning News. Georgia Tech has scheduled a news conference for later today and ESPN.coms Mark Schlabach is reporting that the university will announce the firing of Coach Chan Gailey. As for Nebraska, it has interviewed Bo Pelini and Turner Gill is expected to be next, according to Brian Christopherson and Steven M. Sipple of the Lincoln Journal Star.

title: Climate, Coal and Crematoria
description: [UPDATE, 11/26, 2:45 p.m.  Ive added a couple of significant reactions to the bottom of this post.][UPDATE 12/3, A newer post includes much more from Dr. Hansen and many interesting reactions. Theres also a piece coming in Science Times on 12/4 exploring the limits of language in exploring the climate question.]

title: Analysis: Beware Hedge Funds Bearing Advice
description: Hedge funds can inspire terror in boardrooms these days. Whereas directors might once have trashed an angry letter from a hedge-fund manager holding a few million shares of their companies, in this age of investor activism, they are far more apt to listen  and, in many cases, go along with the fund managers demands.

title: Strike News: Writers, Studios Return To Negotiating Table Today
description: The Writers Guild of America and the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers return to the negotiating table today at 10 a.m. Pacific time.

title: Poli-Book Best Sellers for November
description: The latest list of best-selling political books offers up quite an eclectic mix, from the humorous to the historical views of a wide range of authors.

title: The Making of Lists
description: Its list-making season in the book world  you can find the Book Reviews roster of 100 Notable Books of the Year here  and thats as true in the U.K. as it is on this side of the Atlantic.

title: A Tale of Two Feet
description: Josh Ruxin is a Columbia University expert on public health who has spent the last couple of years living in Rwanda. Hes an unusual mix of academic expert and mud-between-the-toes aid worker.

title: A Positive Spin On Housing
description: I came across a blog that thinks I simply do not understand what is going on in the housing market, as shown by the Off-The-Charts column on Saturday. That column argued that weve never had a severe decline in housing starts  such as we have now  without a recession.

title: News Roundup
description: Headlines from the world of real estate:

title: Another Prize for Goldman: Best Buyout-Backed I.P.O.s
description: With private equitys buying bonanza over, at least for now, it may be time for buyout firms to think about selling their portfolio companies back to the public. By some estimates, two-fifths of the new shares offered in initial public offerings this year will come from private-equity-backed companies.

title: A Monk at the Met
description: Kazutaka Yamada, known as Kossan, is a rollerblading Buddhist monk who offers prayers to passersby in front of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: A Little Attack Ad for Apple
description: There is a strain in the comments to this blog that I have some sort of axe to grind against Apple. Not so, although I certainly dont think everything it does is wise. Let me say this: Apples Mac versus PC ads may be the best television and Web video out there.

title: The Case Against a Mideast Fact Box
description: Here are facts, The Associated Press wrote in the introduction to a 178-word sidebar to its coverage of the the Middle East peace meeting beginning tonight in Annapolis, Md. But in the Middle East, the facts are rarely so easily summed up, as evidenced by an 886-word rebuttal to the sidebar, posted at Just World News, a blog by Helena Cobban.

title: On Ships (Not Chips)
description: Hey, gang, Im back. And darned glad, too. I appreciate your tolerance for my two-week absence from this blog; during that time, I finished a 900-page book (writing, not reading), spoke on a ten-day Geek Cruise to the Panama Canal, got sick and then better, and, of course, had Thanksgiving.

title: On the Road: Giulianis Granite Bus Guide
description: BEDFORD, N.H.  The big news this weekend, for reporters covering the Giuliani campaign, was that Rudolph W. Giuliani had gotten a bus.

title: Searching for Names on an Island of Graves
description: New York City has agreed to turn over 1,300 pages of records that could shed light on the identities of some 50,000 people who have been buried over the past several decades at Hart Island, the citys public burial ground in Long Island Sound.The records are a missing piece of a puzzle that has obsessed Melinda Hunt, a sculptor, writer and filmmaker who lives in the East Village, for more than 16 years.

title: Ex-Credit Suisse Banker Pleads Not Guilty to Insider Trading
description: A former Credit Suisse investment banker accused of leaking inside information about a string of merger deals intends to plead not guilty to a new indictment, his lawyer said on Monday.

title: I (Heart) Wes Welker
description: Last night, Wes Welker put our entire WCOFF team on his seemingly undersized shoulders and carried us to a likely league championship and $7,000, assuming our very tough opponents last remaining player, Willie Parker, doesnt rush for 200 yards and five TDs, which, come to think of it, could happen when the Steelers play the Dolphins tonight.

title: Day Dreams
description: Since its clear youre already avoiding your responsibilities by visiting the Diners Journal blog, you might as well go all the way and indulge in some food-related daydreaming.

title: Whos Afraid of Soulless Scientism?
description: Some Republican presidential candidates are breathing easier because of the news on stem-cell research, and some religious leaders are proclaiming a truce in their conflict with scientists. But I wouldnt bet on any longterm peace, for a couple of reasons.

title: Will Wall Street Layoffs Squeeze the BlackBerry?
description: Wall Street is tightening its belt these days, as highlighted by Citigroups carefully worded announcement Monday about becoming more cost-effective. As layoffs and cutbacks pile up, it seems increasingly likely that the pain will spread beyond the financial industry.

title: Edwards Leans on Mill Roots in New Ad
description: BOW, N.H.  As a politician, Senator John Edwards has always leaned heavily on his modest background as the son of a mill worker, but today he used it to argue that he is the most trustworthy candidate in the presidential race.

title: The Chanting, Rollerblading Monk at the Met
description: Video

title: A Smoother Ride for JPMorgans New Risk Chief?
description: JPMorgan Chase announced on Monday that it has appointed Barry Zubrow as its chief risk officer, a position that had been vacant since Don Wilson retired last year. In some ways, though, the bank seems to have done better than its rivals even without an official top risk manager  for now, at least.

title: Walking Off Into the Vista
description: I was also bemused by Apples Dont Give Up on Vista ad that is described below, but not so detached.

title: Lotts Resignation Sets Off G.O.P. Scramble
description: The decision by Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi to resign sets off a shuffling of the Republican leadership that will likely keep Capitol Hill insiders scrambling throughout the remainder of the Thanksgiving recess.

title: Broadcast Turkey
description: NBCs traditional Thursday morning telecast of the Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade delivered a cumulative audience of 41.4 million viewers  its smallest audience in at least five years.

title: Mondays Links: Favre Tackles Complacency
description: It is hard to define what makes a great quarterback, but when Brett Favre, quarterback of the 10-1 Packers, comes out and says that hes concerned about the teams complacency and rather than celebrate their success is worried about their future, it seems as if that might just be a blueprint. Favre tells Chris Jenkins of The Capital Times I never thought wed be 10-1 and be as loose as we are. I worry each week that this complacency and stuff will creep up on us, and it may. I dont know.

title: In Defense of Cable Bundling
description: To consumers who pay dearly for cable television  sometimes more than $100 a month  a la carte pricing sounds like common sense, not to mention a welcome innovation. Why not pay just for the particular channels you watch and not for the ones you dont?

title: Cleantech Investors Keep One Eye on Washington
description: Its the latest fashion in venture capital: investing in technologies  known as cleantech  that aim to reduce fossil fuel emissions or provide alternative energy sources.

title: In London, Stand Clear of the Closing Bores?
description: Emma Clarke, Londons voice of the Tube, has been heard by tens of millions of people since 1999, when she began relaying stand clear of the closing doors and other canned messages to commuters in her calm yet compelling way.

title: Planning Panel Approves Columbia Expansion
description: After a tumultuous and bitter meeting replete with persistent heckling, the New York City Planning Commission voted this afternoon to approve Columbia Universitys much-debated plan for a 17-acre campus expansion in Harlem. The plan now goes to the City Council, which is expected to modify it before giving final approval.The commissions decision marks an important step  though not the final one  in the often difficult process known as the Uniform Land Use Review Procedure, or Ulurp.

title: The Heisman Watch
description: Florida quarterback Tim Tebow: His broken right hand wont stop him from hoisting the Heisman.

title: Full Gallop
description: What the Giammetti post reveals to me is that a candid discussion leads to all kinds of other thoughts and information: the real tool of our lives. We cannot have enough sharp tools in our box. I did not see a recent discussion about George Orwell on one of the TV book-chat programs, but I heard the participants discussed how language (and, inevitably, our understanding of events) is increasingly corrupted by feel-good phrases, like support our troops  mainly offered by political conservatives and spread by the media to help avoid scrutiny. I mention this because the fashion industry is under extreme pressure from marketing. One of the biggest marketing/PR hoaxes is that grand old Paris fashion houses should be revived. Why on earth do we need Schiaparelli? Ah, because Diego Della Valle can make some money. Its not complicated. There is no altruistic motive (lets save a great name!). The fashion world, like the literary and art worlds, is full of great names that only a few people take the time and interest to investigate. But its limited, and should be limited. So they are reviving Ossie Clarkto capitalize on the fact that dozens of designers have already dipped into the Ossie well? Too late. Anyway, Im not interested. I am intrigued by the latest Halston revival, mainly because of the players involved and because I like the challenge of seeing Halston done in a contemporary way. A journalist can examine the details of the current strategy without shoveling the nostalgia.

title: Free Garry Kasparov
description: Garry Kasparov stopped by The Times recently to talk about his campaign in opposition to Russian President Vladimir Putin. Mr. Kasparov, the former world chess champion, was realistic about the steep odds against his fledgling movement succeeding at the ballot box. The point is not to win elections, he said, but to have elections.

title: Take a Bow, Joe Giglio
description: Looking back at The Associated Press poll from the start of the season, I couldnt help but notice that one scribe had the foresight to vote West Virginia No. 1 at the start of the season.

title: Coming Up: A New Reality Squirmfest
description: When Mike Darnell, the president of alternative entertainment for Fox, says the last time I felt like this was before Joe Millionaire, it seems like a sure sign that another scandalous reality show is on the way.

title: 'Crossroads'
description: A clip from Country Music Television's "Crossroads" featuring Joss Stone and LeAnn Rimes singing "Tell Me About It."

title: Its a Sign, Evoking Memories of Lonnies in Chinatown
description: Old Chinatown and New Chinatown are united at 21 Mott Street, where a rusty 50-year-old coffee shop sign was uncovered, refurbished and placed on the front wall of a hip new noodle shop  the sort of lost New York tale that draws people who yearn for tangible echoes of their memories.For more than 20 years, starting in 1956, Lonnies Coffee Shoppe sat alone among dozens of Chinese restaurants as the solitary Happy Days-style burger joint on Chinatowns narrow streets. Lonnie was Lon Ying Lee, whose family originally hailed  like 80 percent of Chinese American immigrants before 1950  from the Taishan region of the Guangdong Province, also known as Toisan.

title: Drudge on the Hunt for Spiked Election News
description: In what Sky News heralded as his first interview in four years, Matt Drudge served notice to corporations that dont want to report real news about the presidential election.

description: NBCs Sunday Night Football broadcast of the game between the Philadelphia Eagles and the New England Patriots lifted the network to a first place win on Sunday night. The game scored the highest metered-market ratings for a prime time football game since November 2005, according to early data.

description: The dispute over the estate of Brooke Astor preceded her death on Aug. 13, at age 105.

title: Bad News About Bears, and Other Things That We Hold Dear
description: Teddy Bears were dragged into a scandal at a school in northern Sudan, as a British teacher was put in jail for allowing a student to name her stuffed animal Muhammad. How can you call a bear Muhammad? a government spokesman told The New York Times. Muhammad is the holy prophet of Islam. The article notes that Muhammad is also one of the most common names in the Muslim world.

description: Behind the pitched Cyber Monday battle of online retailers is the battle of the payment systems. Both Google Checkout and eBays PayPal unveiled generous promotions today to increase their share of holiday spending.

title: Toxic Mold Complaints? Albany Wants to Hear Them.
description: In 2005, the State Legislature found that certain forms of mold pose an unacceptable risk to New York States health and environment and that indoor toxins, specifically toxic mold, have been an under-recognized health and environmental problem. The Legislature passed a law, effective Aug. 2, 2005, that called for the creation of a 14-member Toxic Mold Task Force to assess, based on scientific evidence, the nature, scope and magnitude of the adverse environmental and health impacts caused by toxic mold in the state.

The Israeli journalist Gershom Gorenberg, left, and Khaled Dawoud of Al Jazeera TV debate the possibility of a Mideast peace.

description: The baseball writers 2008 Hall of Fame ballot was revealed today, with Tim Raines the most notable name on the list. David Justice, Robb Nen, Rod Beck, Chuck Knoblauch and many others were also included. But Raines, who had his best years with the Montreal Expos and had three productive seasons with the Yankees (1996-1998), appears to be the only player worthy of any consideration.

Two yellow-helmeted tree climbers painstakingly hoisted themselves up ropes and climbed branches to reach the top of some old-growth redwood trees at a Marin County park near here called Roys Redwoods. More than 200 feet above the ground they cut branches to be used to create hundreds of redwood clones.

Now Im living that dream by visiting ranches around the world.

The next collider to be built, the International Linear Collider, will operate at only 0.5 trillion electron volts. Why are we going backward in collider energy levels?

description: I was a hairdresser until a couple of years ago, Gail Simone said. It took me a long time to admit that I was a professional writer.

description: The data continue to be favorable for Abbott Laboratories new drug-coated heart stent, Xience V, a device for which the company hopes to win federal approval.

description: Citigroup announced last night that it was selling a $7.5 billion stake to a Middle Eastern sovereign fund in the latest bid to shore up its balance sheet.

title: Wash Your Clothes: Elephants Can Smell You a Mile Away
description: Its a jungle out there  and a desert, an ocean and a savanna, too. So it helps to know your enemies. While many animals can tell friend from foe, relatively few have been shown to be able to distinguish among predator species based on the type of threat they represent. A potentially even more useful ability would be to be able to tell which of several groups of a single predator species are the ones to worry about.

title: Australia: Murphy Oil Buys Stake in Offshore Project
description: The Murphy Oil Corporation bought a stake in an offshore oil project in Australia from the closely held Finder Exploration, its first venture in the country. Murphy, based in El Dorado, Ark., said it had agreed to acquire a 40 percent stake in an exploration permit for an area northwest of Australia and operate the project. Terms were not disclosed. This acreage acquisition is important as it not only marks our entry into Australia where we see further growth opportunities but complements our existing Southeast Asia position, which is already yielding strong results in Malaysia, Murphys chief executive, Claiborne P. Deming, above, said in a statement.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,867 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Court Is Closed for Testimony in 1990 Nightclub Killing
description: Reporters were barred from a Manhattan courtroom yesterday when a man both prosecutors and defense lawyers say was one of the gunmen in the killing of a nightclub bouncer in 1990 took the witness stand.

title: Our House, Not Bauhaus
description: The German government invited architects yesterday to submit proposals for the task of reconstructing Berlins Stadtschloss, right, a Baroque royal palace torn down in 1950, Bloomberg News reported. The project is to include the partial re-creation of its facade and a towering cupola. A panel of specialists, including the architects David Chipperfield, Giorgio Grassi and Petra Kahlfeldt, is to judge entries in a competition lasting until November 2008, the German building minister, Wolfgang Tiefensee, said. Construction of the new building, which is to house some of Berlins antiquities and art holdings as well as parts of Humboldt University and the city library, is expected to begin in 2010 and be completed in 2013 or 2014, he said. To make way for the reconstituted castle, German lawmakers ordered the razing of the Palace of the Republic, home of the former East German parliament, a huge steel-and-concrete building with bronze-colored windows that opened in 1976. Critics have protested the demolition of the old building, asserting that it holds a beloved place in the citys popular culture and that a rebuilt Baroque castle would be a parody of history. The Stadtschloss was the seat of the Prussian kings until Kaiser Wilhelm II abdicated in 1918.

title: Despite Spitzers Efforts, Commuter Costs Will Rise
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzers decision to freeze the base subway fare at $2 will not take the sting out of commuting costs for everyone: Yesterday, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said commuter rail tickets and the citys bridge and tunnel tolls will jump an average of 3.85 percent.

title: Hamden: Lawsuit Over Death in Custody
description: The mother of a 26-year-old drug user who died shortly after the police stunned him at least four times with a Taser has sued the town of Hamden and the sergeant who used the Taser. The lawsuit, filed in Federal District Court in New Haven this month and served on the defendants last week, charges the town with failing to provide adequate instruction on the use of the Tasers. It also accuses the sergeant, William Sikorsky, of having used unreasonable force to subdue the man, David Mills, on April 21. Jonathan J. Einhorn, the lawyer representing the mother, said yesterday, that theres no question that Mr. Mills was on PCP, an illegal drug, at the time of his death and that the police were justified in responding to an altercation in the neighborhood. The question is, Mr. Einhorn said, did they use excessive force? Connecticuts office of the chief medical examiner ruled in June that the death was an accident. The Hamden police did not return a phone call seeking comment yesterday.

title: Moving Beyond Joysticks, and Off the Couch
description: As a new parent eight years ago, I swore never to buy a video game system, certain that my child would spend her leisure time reading and playing outside.

title: Slow Progress Reported in Broadway Talks
description: The stagehands union and the league representing Broadways theater owners and producers resumed talks last night after a 12-hour break from a marathon session the day and night before.

title: Those Lovely Manhole Covers
description: When it comes to manhole covers, New Yorkers have been known to swoon over the handsome portals connecting whats above and below the city streets. The photographs by J. Adam Huggins in Mondays Times offer a much uglier reality.

title: Greece: Strikes Against Pension Change Begin
description: Striking teachers marched through Athens streets, part of a planned wave of strikes against what unions describe as government plans to raise retirement ages and cut benefits to millions of future retirees. The journalists union was set for a 24-hour nationwide strike today, with a general strike scheduled for Dec. 12.

title: After a Rough Start, Spitzer Rethinks His Ways

Hours passed before someone asked the question on everyones mind: Should Mr. Spitzer drop his plan to give drivers licenses to illegal immigrants?

description: PALMETTO BAY, Fla., Nov. 26  Sean Taylor, a Pro Bowl safety with the Washington Redskins, was fighting for his life Monday after being shot by an intruder at his home in this affluent suburb south of Miami, the authorities and one of his lawyers said.
