description: MIAMI, Nov. 27  Sean Taylor, a Pro Bowl safety with the Washington Redskins, who was shot early Monday by an intruder at his Miami home, died early today from his injury, one of his lawyers said.

title: Selling Art for Charity
description: The Bank of America Corporation is selling four paintings, including one each by N. C. Wyeth and his son Andrew Wyeth, in hopes of raising more than $1 million for three New York City nonprofit groups, Bloomberg News reported yesterday. The bank, the nations second largest, will auction the paintings from its collection of several thousand artworks on Wednesday at Sothebys in New York. The works include Port Clyde, Maine, above, by N. C. Wyeth, and The New Table, by Andrew, which together carry a high estimate of $950,000. The other paintings are Opening the West (Stagecoach Through the Missouri Hills), by Oscar Berninghaus, and Newport Beach, by William Trost Richards, each with a high estimate of $250,000. The works will be part of Sothebys sale of American paintings, drawings and sculpture. Proceeds will go to the Police Athletic League, which provides educational and social programs for New York children; Bette Midlers New York Restoration Project; and the New York Public Library. This is the first time Bank of America has auctioned pieces for charity. We wanted to make the outcome simpler rather than giving them the painting to sell themselves, said Rena DeSisto, who is in charge of arts and culture for the bank.

title: After Stem-Cell Breakthrough, the Work Begins
description: If stem cell researchers were oil prospectors, it could be said that they struck a gusher last week. But to realize the potential boundless riches they now must figure out how to build refineries, pipelines and gas stations.

description: Ask successful entrepreneurs the best advice they ever got, and what may be most surprising is how quickly they come up with an answer and how specific it is.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26  The District of Columbia has the highest rate of AIDS infection of any city in the country and the disease is being transmitted to infants, older adults, women and heterosexual men at an epidemic pace, according to a report released Monday by city health officials.

description: Before Alexander Imich lost all his money in the stock market, he earned his living as a chemist. But he remains in debt, because at 104, he is in no position to re-enter the work force.

description: Kevin DuBrow, a gravelly voiced singer for Quiet Riot, a heavy-metal band that peaked in the 1980s, and who captivated decibel-tolerant fans with high-intensity musicality, quirky theatricality and a hint of menace, died on Sunday at his home in Las Vegas. He was 52.

title: A Banker in Germany Says Trouble Is Not Over
description: FRANKFURT, Nov. 26  Klaus-Peter Mller spent the better part of a decade working in the New York branch of Commerzbank, the German bank he now heads as chief executive. His daughter was born in Manhattan, and he has kept close ties to the United States.

description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 26  The Sudanese police arrested a British schoolteacher and accused her of insulting Islam after she allowed her 7-year-old pupils to name a class teddy bear Muhammad, Sudanese officials said Monday.

description: Hackers obtained access last month to the e-mail addresses and passwords of thousands of donors to 92 charities that use online database software and services from Convio Inc.

description: Stephon Marbury might never explain the controversy that engulfed him earlier this month, or what he might have said to Coach Isiah Thomas on a fateful flight to Phoenix. The way he is playing now, those mysteries might quickly lose all relevance.

title: F.C.C. Chief Forced to Scale Back Cable Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  In the face of a lobbying blitzkrieg from cable television executives and their lobbyists, the head of the Federal Communications Commission said this evening that he had struck a compromise to salvage but scale back his agenda to regulate the industry more tightly.

title: Germany: VW Labor Leaders Sue Porsche
description: Volkswagen labor leaders sued Porsche in an effort to gain more influence on the board of a holding company that will oversee Porsches stake in Volkswagen. The Volkswagen works council filed the complaint Friday, said a spokesman for the German labor court in Stuttgart that is handling the case. Volkswagen labor leaders are unhappy that Porsche workers will get half of the six seats reserved for employees on the new board. Volkswagen workers want the seats distributed based on each carmakers size.

title: In Study of Brain Evolution, Zeal and Bitter Debate
description: Twelve brains were arranged on the work bench of Ralph Holloways anthropology laboratory at Columbia University. They were not real brains, but endocasts  latex molds made from the interiors of the skulls that once housed them. Nevertheless, many of their ridges and furrows were clearly visible.

title: Back in Pakistan, Sharif Condemns Musharraf
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 26  As prime minister in the 1990s, Nawaz Sharif was a religiously conservative, nationalist leader who allowed the Taliban to flourish in Afghanistan and detonated a nuclear weapon despite an American plea not to.

title: Air Traffic Delays Up Over Last Thanksgiving
description: Air traffic delays were worse on the three main travel days of this Thanksgiving holiday period compared with a year ago, according to preliminary Federal Aviation Administration statistics. Delays on the Tuesday before Thanksgiving affected 3,124 flights, an increase of 65.9 percent; on Wednesday, 2,678 flights, up 21 percent; and on Sunday, 2,442 flights, up 14.1 percent. Delays were down slightly on Thursday, Friday and Saturday. Weather was the major cause of delays, and the figures do not include mechanical breakdowns. Though President Bush ordered military air space opened to relieve flight congestion, its use appears to have been light. About 60 planes used the military space from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Sunday, the F.A.A. said. The agency did not have figures for later in the day.

title: No Charges as S.E.C. Inquiry Ends
description: The Computer Sciences Corporation, a provider of computer services to government agencies and businesses, says that regulators do not plan any action against it after an investigation of stock option grants.

title: City Panel Approves Columbias Plan for Expansion in Harlem
description: After a tumultuous and bitter meeting replete with heckling, the New York City Planning Commission voted yesterday to approve Columbia Universitys much-debated plan for a 17-acre campus expansion in Harlem. The plan now goes to the City Council, which is expected to modify it before giving final approval.

title: Tournament Planned
description: Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland have agreed in principle to play each other in a tournament every other year starting in 2009, the Football Association of Ireland said. It would be similar to the defunct Home International Championship, which featured England instead of the Republic of Ireland.

title: Bottom Line and Replays Replacing Tradition
description: Lou Lamoriello, the Devils chief executive, president and general manager, considers himself a hockey traditionalist, which should come as no surprise to those who have watched the teams he assembled win three Stanley Cups.

title: Two Women Accused of Looting Apartments
description: The two women wore fancy clothes and presented themselves to the world as Upper East Side sophisticates searching for an elegant apartment. For weeks, the police said, they visited open houses in Manhattan organized by real estate agents to show expensive apartments to potential buyers.

title: Britain: Voice of the Tube Is Fired
description: Emma Clarke, a 36-year-old voice-over specialist whose recorded warning to mind the gap is familiar to millions of London Underground riders, was fired after telling the newspaper The Mail on Sunday that she does not use the Tube anymore because it is dreadful. Miss Clarke, who has recorded hundreds of announcements for the Tube since 1999, had done a good job until she started criticizing our service, Dan Hodges, a London transit spokesman, said, adding, London Underground is sorry to have to announce that further contracts for Miss Clarke are experiencing severe delays.

title: Feeley Sparks Eagles and (for Fans) a Debate
description: A. J. Feeley was close to tears at the end of Sunday nights game, and Philadelphia Eagles fans may want him to pass the tissues.

title: What to Ask About Cholesterol
description: Cholesterol treatment should be considered in relation to your risk factors for heart disease. Here are some questions Dr. James Cleeman, the coordinator of the National Cholesterol Education Program, recommends you ask your doctor to determine the best course of treatment for you, along with notes on why theyre important.

title: Defendants Oppose Request
description: Lawyers for four people convicted two years ago in the Balco steroids case filed a motion yesterday to oppose a government order that they return or destroy all grand jury transcripts and other sealed materials in the case, according to Victor Conte Jr., founder of the Bay Area Laboratory Co-Operative. The defendants were given materials to prepare their defense; they later pleaded guilty. The 18-page motion says the government request  which was made under seal and signed by a judge Sept. 11  is futile and unenforceable because the sealed materials have already been widely shared, leaked and published outside of the criminal defense team. It also argues that the order would pose an open-ended danger of further leak investigations against the defendants, Conte, James Valente (Balcos former vice president), Barry Bondss former trainer Greg Anderson and the track coach Remi Korchemny. It argues they may need the materials to prepare for testimony in future cases. Troy Ellerman Jr., a former defense lawyer, was sentenced earlier this year to two and a half years in prison for obstruction of justice after admitting he had leaked grand jury transcripts to a reporter for The San Francisco Chronicle. Natalya LaBauve, spokeswoman for the United States attorney, declined to comment.

title: Separating Friend From Foe Among the Bodys Invaders
description: Even metaphorical wars can have flesh-and-blood casualties, and hospitals around the country are now tending to the victims of one of our fiercest. It is not so much that we are losing this particular war; simple notions of victory and defeat dropped away some time ago. Rather, locked in a spiral of costly and controversial escalations, we may have lost sight of who the enemy actually is.

title: Text of Bushs Remarks at Annapolis Conference
description: Here are the remarks President Bush delivered today at the United States Naval Academy in Annapolis, Md., as transcribed by Federal News Service, Inc., a private firm not affiliated with the government.

title: Express Lanes Moving Slowly
description: The Registered Traveler program was supposed to offer regular air travelers the technology that would speed them through airport security. But now that the technology has hit big road bumps, the program has, for the time being at least, evolved into something else.

title: Son of Astor Is Said to Face Criminal Case
description: Brooke Astors only son and one of her former lawyers have been indicted on criminal charges stemming from the stewardship of her financial affairs and the handling of her will, according to people who were briefed on the situation.

title: The U.S.S.R. Is Back (on Clothing Racks)
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 26  Empowered by an oil boom that pushed the countrys trade surplus past $94 billion this year, Russia has been flexing its muscles abroad. At home, meanwhile, young and trendy Muscovites are in the throes of nostalgia for the staples of Soviet childhoods, relics of a time when the U.S.S.R. was at the height of superpower status.

title: The Timing, Luck and Lust Behind the Forming of That More Perfect Union
description: Henry Adams once observed that a chronological survey of American presidents might suggest that Darwin got it exactly backward, and many students of history have come to see the founding fathers as a generation of demigods whose like will never be seen again  demigods who magically devised a set of ideas and institutions that would eventually become a blueprint for democracy around the world. George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, John Adams, James Madison, Alexander Hamilton  these members of the Revolutionary generation and their colleagues were visionaries responsible not only for the triumph of representative government rooted in the principle of popular sovereignty, but also for the flowering of a free-market economy, a secular state unaffiliated with any official religion and the rule of law based on the equality of citizens.

title: Wachovia Broker, Guilty of Illegal Trades, Is to Pay Fine
description: A Wachovia Securities broker must pay more than $346,000 after a judge found that he illegally traded on insider information concerning the acquisition of the propane gas distributor Blue Rhino.

title: HSBC Sets Bailout Plan for Assets of 2 Funds
description: LONDON, Nov. 26  Europes largest bank, HSBC Holdings, said Monday that it would bail out its two structured investment vehicles, or SIVs, by taking $45 billion in assets onto its balance sheet.

title: Airbus Part of $30 Billion in Contracts With China
description: The aircraft maker Airbus and the French nuclear company Areva were among half a dozen companies to sign roughly $30 billion in contracts yesterday with Chinese partners.

title: European Official Faults Ban on Genetically Altered Feed
description: PARIS, Nov. 26  The European agriculture commissioner, Mariann Fischer Boel, warned farm ministers on Monday that Europes resistance to importing genetically modified products like livestock feed was contributing to the rising cost of raising pigs and chickens and could pose a threat to the meat industry.

title: Broadway Talks to Resume After Break
description: Negotiations are scheduled to resume at 10 a.m. Wednesday in the dispute between Broadway theater owners and producers and striking stagehands after breaking off today when 13 hours of bargaining failed to produce deal.

title: Thanks to a Protge, Power in Rarely Seen Balanchine
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26  The story of the ballerina Suzanne Farrell and the choreographer George Balanchine  so central to the development of the art of ballet from the early 1960s until his death in 1983  is still in progress. These days Ms. Farrell runs a ballet company based at the Kennedy Center here, and though she has presented works by other choreographers, she is in the vanguard of restoring to the stage ballets by Balanchine that have long passed undanced.

title: Congress and Diabetes (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Zahringer Is Top Amateur
description: George J. Zahringer III of Deepdale Golf Club in Manhasset, N.Y., a fixture of amateur golf in the New York area for more than 30 years, won the 2007 Jerry Courville Sr. Metropolitan Golf Association Player of the Year award. It was the 10th time Zahringer won player of the year, extending his own record. Zahringer had 844 points, 209 more than Brian Komline of High Bridge Hills and 264 more than the third-place finisher, Joe Saladino of Huntington.

title: A Common Casualty of Old Age: The Will to Live
description: Suicide is more common among older Americans than any other age group. The statistics are daunting. While people 65 and older account for 12 percent of the population, they represent 16 percent to 25 percent of the suicides. Four out of five suicides in older adults are men. And among white men over 85, the suicide rate  50 per 100,000 men  is six times that of the general population.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about the decision by Norwegian officials to close their consulate in Minneapolis misstated the annual cost, supplied by the Norwegian Embassy, of operating the facility. It is about $1 million a year, not $2 million. (Go to Article)

title: Mixed and Matched Stars Help Country Meet City
description: FRANKLIN, Tenn.  Joss Stone crumpled a piece of paper and tossed it over her shoulder. It contained the lyrics to Bruised but Not Broken, from her most recent album, and soon after, a second wad (Girl They Wont Believe It) traced the same trajectory.

title: Framework Set by Palestinians and Israelis for Peace Talks
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 27  The Israeli and Palestinian leaders committed themselves today to negotiate a peace treaty by the end of 2008, setting themselves a deadline for ending a conflict that has endured for six decades.

title: Israelis and Palestinians Try to Set Pace for Peace Talks as Bush Plans Speech
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26  Israeli and Palestinian negotiators made progress on Monday toward completing a joint statement for the planned Middle East peace conference in Annapolis, Md., and President Bush appeared ready to paper over remaining differences between the two sides with his planned speech on Tuesday.

title: Clemens Caught in Middle of Jets Struggles
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 26  This is how quickly perceptions change around the Jets:

title: Manhattan: Supervision for Carpenters Union
description: The carpenters union local for the East Side was placed under emergency supervision yesterday by Douglas McCarron, the president of the parent union in Washington. In a news release, the parent union, the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners, said officials with Local 157 here had acted inconsistently with the standards expected of the unions employees. Members of the carpenters union said its independent investigator was looking into allegations of no-show jobs at Local 157. Also yesterday, the union announced that the business manager of Local 157 had resigned. One business representative was fired, a second resigned and a third was suspended, the union said. Mr. McCarron has appointed the unions Eastern District vice president, Frank Spencer, to temporarily oversee Local 157.

title: Red Cross Dismisses President, Citing Relationship
description: The American Red Cross today dismissed its president and chief executive, Mark W. Everson, citing his personal relationship with a subordinate employee. He had been in office for only six months.

title: Science, Religion and God (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Antidepressant Seems to Extend Life of Roundworms
description: That laboratory workworm, C. elegans, is at it again.

title: City Ballet and Opera Now Agree on Theater
description: Nearly a year after the New York City Opera gave up on the idea of leaving Lincoln Center to build its own home, the opera and the New York City Ballet have agreed on making changes to the New York State Theater, which they share at the center. The changes include a modular acoustical system that can be moved in for the opera and out for the ballet.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Our House, Not Bauhaus

title: Citigroup to Sell $7.5 Billion Stake to Abu Dhabi
description: Citigroup announced last night that it was selling a $7.5 billion stake to a Middle Eastern sovereign fund in the latest bid to shore up its precariously low capital base.

title: Britain: Water Utility Acquired
description: The Kelda Group, a water supplier to British cities including Leeds and Sheffield, agreed to be bought by a group including Citigroup and HSBC Holdings for 3.04 billion ($6.26 billion). Keldas shareholders will receive 1,100.65 pence a share, including a dividend of 10.65 pence, a premium of 17.5 percent over the closing price on Wednesday, the day before Kelda said it had been approached. Kelda, based in Bradford, also reported a 58 percent increase in first-half profit after raising prices at its Yorkshire Water unit, which supplies about 4.7 million people and 140,000 businesses.

title: Bush Offers a Nudge to Start Mideast Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26  It might seem, after nearly seven years of deliberate detachment from Arab-Israeli peace negotiations, that President Bush has plunged into Middle Eastern diplomacy with Clintonesque energy.

title: A Stable Doctor for a Scattered Life
description: It was clear when we met that the patients intelligence was severely limited. He could hardly find his own thoughts. Rocking in a chair not built for rocking, he gave a scattered history of head trauma and explosiveness. He was fresh from prison (another sentence for assault), living in the shelter and tired of himself. He hated hurting people, he said. He wanted a medication to cure this once and for all.

title: Laid-Back Manning Fires Up His Critics
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 26  After the Giants lost to the Vikings on Sunday afternoon  largely because of three interceptions returned for Minnesota touchdowns  quarterback Eli Manning was asked if he was angry, shocked or embarrassed.

title: Selected Studies: Cholesterol
description: Government agencies, universities, doctors and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, please visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

title: Astors Son Surrenders on Charges
description: Brooke Astors son and one of her former lawyers have been indicted by a grand jury on criminal charges stemming from the stewardship of her financial affairs and the handling of her will, the Manhattan district attorney said in a news conference today.

title: Fed to Inject $8 Billion to Lubricate Economy
description: Seeking to reassure banks amid the continuing credit crisis, the Federal Reserve said yesterday that it would provide $8 billion in funds to ease concerns about lending during the holiday season.

title: Manhattan: Clarification on Teachers
description: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein sent a letter to all teachers in the citys school system yesterday, praising their efforts and saying that a new push to remove unsatisfactory teachers had been badly misunderstood and mischaracterized. The letter came as teachers held a candlelight vigil on the steps of the Education Department headquarters to protest the new teacher performance unit, made up of five lawyers, that Mr. Klein created earlier this year. Recently, Randi Weingarten, the president of the citys teachers union, said Mr. Klein was creating a climate of fear among teachers. In his letter, sent via e-mail, Mr. Klein emphasized that just 10 of the citys 55,000 tenured teachers were removed last year because of incompetence. At the protest, Ms. Weingarten called the letter a good step, and said she hoped that the blame-the-teacher routine will stop and we can get back to helping kids.

title: Divers Who Jump in to Take the Mystery Out of City Waterways
description: Having frequently pedaled his bike over the Gowanus Canals bridges in Brooklyn, Ludger K. Balan was familiar with its sickly green tint, oil-slicked surface and rotten-egg smell. Then, one day about eight years ago, he looked into the canal and saw a school of striped bass chasing minnows.

title: Born in Brazil, but Representing Someone Else
description: The influx of Brazilian-born soccer players in domestic leagues around the world could endanger the geographic integrity of future international tournaments, said Joseph S. Blatter, the president of FIFA. More than 1,000 players who have left Brazil are playing this year for clubs in far-flung places like Moldova, Russia and Japan.

title: Radio Rater Postpones People Meter in Some Cities
description: Arbitron delayed a wider rollout of a contentious new system for measuring radio audiences yesterday, prompting sighs of relief from some New York radio stations but driving the companys stock price sharply lower in after-hours trading.

title: Memo Pad
description: EVERYBODY INTO THE ACT  Another domestic carrier, US Airways, plans to start serving Heathrow Airport in London in late March, with flights from its hub in Philadelphia. A new Open Skies agreement between the United States and the European Union is opening Heathrow to more United States carriers. Continental Airlines recently said that starting in March it would fly into Heathrow. The airport had previously restricted landing rights to only two United States carriers, American and United.

title: Brooklyn: Man, 30, Is Fatally Stabbed
description: A 30-year-old Brooklyn man died from stab wounds early yesterday, and officers arrested a 30-year-old woman who the police said had a history of mental disturbances. Officers were called at 3 a.m. to a fourth-floor apartment in a residential building at 1718 East 15th Street by another woman  the mans companion  after he had been stabbed in the neck and head. The suspect had been staying in the couples apartment, and was found by the officers in the buildings lobby, the police said. The motive was unclear, and the police declined to identify either the man who died or the woman who was apprehended.

title: Manhattan Building Evacuated After Flood Forces Power Cut
description: Hundreds of residents were evacuated yesterday from a 23-story building in Lower Manhattan after rainwater flooded the basement garage and forced emergency crews to shut off power, the Fire Department said.

title: The Dance of Evolution, or How Art Got Its Start
description: If you have ever been to a Jewish wedding, you know that sooner or later the ominous notes of Hava Nagila will sound, and you will be expected to dance the hora. And if you dont really know how to dance the hora, you will nevertheless be compelled to join hands with others, stumble around in a circle, give little kicks and pretend to enjoy yourself, all the while wondering if theres a word in Yiddish that means she who stares pathetically at the feet of others because she is still trying to figure out how to dance the hora.

title: Tiffany and eBay in Fight Over Fakes
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 26  For years, eBay has defined itself simply as an online marketplace that links buyers and sellers.

title: The Feud
description: What may be medicines most famous feud  and certainly one of its longest-lived  has apparently ended.

title: Exit, Russian Democracy
description: For a leader who has everything  control of the military, the government, the voting process and the media  President Vladimir Putin of Russia looks increasingly desperate and threatened ahead of parliamentary elections on Sunday. Polls suggest his United Russia party will win the balloting overwhelmingly, giving him leverage to continue wielding power in some form. But his greedy grab for victory while quashing credible political opposition demonstrates that this is no free and fair election and Russia is no democracy.

title: Spain: Iberian Air Takeover Plan Stalls
description: British Airways said it would not increase its stake in Iberia Lneas Areas de Espaa, dimming prospects that British Airways would be part of a takeover bid for Iberia and increasing the likelihood that it would remain in Spanish hands. By not exercising its right to buy shares being sold by two of Iberias Spanish investors, British Airways and the American private equity firm TPG are unlikely to mount a full takeover bid of 3.4 billion euros ($5 billion), as was expected, analysts said. The decision opens the door for Caja Madrid, a large Spanish savings bank, to raise its interests in Iberia. Caja Madrid said last week that it wanted to exercise its own option to buy the Iberia shares held by Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria and Logista, the logistics arm of Altadis, raising its stake in the Spanish carrier to about 24 percent.

title: Kennedy Memoirs Said to Fetch $8 Million
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the most prominent surviving member of the Kennedy family, has agreed to sell his memoirs for an advance of more than $8 million, people with knowledge of the negotiations say.

title: Miracle-Gro Maker Pays U.S. Fine
description: Scotts Miracle-Gro, maker of Miracle-Gro plant food, agreed yesterday to pay $500,000 to resolve allegations that it violated testing rules for genetically engineered creeping bentgrass, the federal Department of Agriculture said.

title: Behind the Curtain
description: A friend of mine, talking about the Democratic presidential candidates, tossed out a wonderful mixed metaphor: This is awfully weak tea to have to hang your hat on.

title: U.S. and Iraq to Negotiate Pact on Long-Term Relations
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26  The White House announced Monday that it had reached a deal with the Iraqi government to negotiate a formal agreement defining long-term relations between the two nations, including the legal status of American military forces remaining in Iraq.

title: Mel Tolkin, Lead Writer for Show of Shows, Dies at 94
description: Mel Tolkin, the long-suffering head of Sid Caesars celebrated television writing team, who was present from the cramped, sweaty, malodorous beginning, died yesterday at his home in Century City, Calif. He was 94.

title: Home Prices Down 4.5% Nationwide From Last Year
description: The troubled housing sector reached a new low this summer, and consumers remain deeply skeptical about the economy, according to reports released today.

title: Yankees and Twins Start Talks on Santana
description: Hank Steinbrenner, the senior vice president for the Yankees, said yesterday that the team had had conversations with the Minnesota Twins about trying to obtain pitcher Johan Santana. But Steinbrenner stressed that the discussions were at an early stage.

title: Defense Secretary Urges More Spending for U.S. Diplomacy
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates called Monday for the United States government to commit more money and effort to soft power tools, including diplomacy, economic assistance and communications, because the military alone cannot defend Americas interests around the world.

title: The Claim: Growing Pains Are Caused by Growth Spurts
description: THE FACTS

title: Scientific Method: Evidence, Not Faith
description: To the Editor:

title: In Aid of a Bird, Some Inconveniences for People
description: REVERE, Mass.  When two Atlantic piping plovers nested on busy Revere Beach last summer, scientists knew that the tiny birds indicated something big.

title: Round 2 for Biotech Beets
description: Each growing season, like many other sugar beet farmers bedeviled by weeds, Robert Green repeatedly and painstakingly applies herbicides in a process he compares to treating cancer with chemotherapy.

title: Changes at Spoleto
description: The Italian culture minister, Francesco Rutelli, announced yesterday that Giorgio Ferrara, a film and stage director, had been asked to guide the rebirth of the Spoleto Festival, which takes place in the small Umbrian city of Spoleto each summer (and whose independent American counterpart is held annually in Charleston, S.C.). The move aims to end years of tension and disputes between the current director of the festival, Francis Menotti  the son of the composer Gian Carlo Menotti, who founded the festival in 1958 and who died this year  and local administrators who have objected to the way the festival is managed. The culture ministry has been an important financial supporter. Critics have complained that the infighting had begun to take a toll on the quality of the festivals offerings and its international standing. Mr. Rutelli said the new Spoleto festival, which may operate under a different name, would offer more opportunities to young artists, play host to performances throughout the year and open up to other cultures. Mr. Menotti has not yet responded to the proposed changes. It is a decisive step, based on the desire to recreate, in a few years, an event of national and international standing, Mr. Rutelli said. Details of how the new organization will be structured were not made public yesterday.

title: Atlanta Hospital Moves to Unburden Itself of Debt
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 26  The politically appointed board of Atlantas troubled charity hospital effectively voted itself out of business Monday, the first step in at least a short-term escape from the insolvency that had threatened the regions only top-level trauma center.

title: Polio Fight Gets $200 Million Injection
description: India, Pakistan and Afghanistan, along with the African nation of Nigeria, are the only countries where polio remains stubbornly endemic. The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation announced that it was giving $100 million to the Rotary Foundation of Rotary International to try to stamp out the crippling disease, and Rotary, which has already contributed $633 million to the fight, pledged to match the Gateses grant. Most of the money will be used for immunization.

title: Gore Makes It to the Oval Office, if Only for a Chat
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26  Al Gore has traveled the world to spread his message that climate change is creating a planetary emergency.

title: Protests Greet Far-Right Speakers at Oxford
description: OXFORD, England, Nov. 26  Demonstrators broke into the Oxford Union on Monday and sat on the head table of the 184-year-old debating society, disrupting a forum featuring a British author who denies the Holocaust occurred and a far-right British politician.

title: Sharing the Waves, a Wavelength Away
description: When Dane Reynolds is not riding waves or hanging out with friends, he likes to read. Lately, he recommends John Fantes The Road to Los Angeles, for its protagonist, the struggling writer Arturo Bandini.

title: Study Finds Reproductive Edge for Men With Deep Voices
description: A man with a deep voice may have a survival advantage, a better chance of passing on his genes.

title: Warners Production Chief to Also Oversee Distribution
description: Warner Brothers yesterday named Jeff Robinov, its head of film production, to be the president of a newly created Warner Brothers Pictures Group, which will manage the companys filmmaking operation along with worldwide theatrical marketing and distribution.

title: 10 Years Later, a Claim the Wrong Man Was Convicted of a Bronx Killing
description: As the chilly evening of March 30, 1997, stretched into early morning, an ambitious young killer from the Bronx named David Prieto was walking through a sketchy neighborhood  gun at his side, Clint Eastwood style  believing he was on his way to taking over the lucrative drug trade on the streets near his childhood home.

title: Newark: Claim of Improper Questioning
description: The New Jersey attorney general said yesterday that a city police official acted improperly by asking about the immigration status of two journalists who witnessed a crime scene in September, violating a state directive on immigrants and law enforcement. The journalists, a freelance photographer and the editor of The Brazilian Voice newspaper, reported to the police that the photographer had found a womans body in a Newark alley. They were questioned about their immigration status by the official, Deputy Chief Samuel A. DeMaio, the attorney generals office said. The directive, introduced in August, tells the police to ask the immigration status only of those arrested on indictable offenses or for drunken driving. In a statement, Attorney General Anne Milgram, above, said the directive specifically prohibits police from inquiring about the immigration status of any victim, witness or person requesting police assistance. The Newark police director, Garry F. McCarthy, said the Police Department would review the matter before deciding whether to reprimand Chief DeMaio.

title: Clinton to Offer an AIDS Policy, Joining Her Main Rivals
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton will propose steps today to strengthen the governments strategy to battle H.I.V. and AIDS in the United States and the rest of the world, becoming the latest Democratic presidential candidate to commit to a significant expansion of federal efforts to combat the epidemic.

title: Follow the Fundamentals
description: Beijing

title: Police Arrest Bronx Man in Killing of 2
description: Investigators searching for a missing woman and her two grown sons entered their Bronx apartment through a window yesterday afternoon and found a trail of blood on the floor, the police said. Outside, they found one son  and a grim answer to the mystery: He admitted he had shot his mother and younger brother to death, cut their bodies into pieces and dumped them into the Harlem River at a nearby park, the police said.

title: Putin Accuses U.S. of Trying to Discredit Russian Vote
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 26  President Vladimir V. Putin on Monday accused the United States of trying to taint the legitimacy of next weeks Russian parliamentary elections by pressing a group of prominent independent election observers to abandon efforts to monitor the campaign.

title: Frank Guarrera, 83, Lyric Baritone at the Met, Is Dead
description: Frank Guarrera, a lyric baritone who sang at the Metropolitan Opera for nearly 30 years, died on Friday at his home in Bellmawr, N.J. He was 83.

title: A Capacity for Denial (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Hamas Urges Taking Hard Line Against Israel
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 26  The leaders of Hamas espoused a hard line against Israel at a conference that they and the militant Islamic Jihad faction convened in Gaza on Monday, the eve of the American-sponsored Middle East peace gathering in Annapolis, Md.

title: A Plan to Reunite The Jackson Five
description: The Jackson Five, Michael included, may reunite next year for a tour, the BBC reported yesterday. Jermaine Jackson, below, who sang lead vocals in the group before the advent of Michael, told BBC that concert dates have been discussed and that the tour could take place sometime in 2008. Michael will be involved, he said. The group last toured as the Jacksons  with six members  in support of the album Victory in 1984. It was on the final night of that tour that Michael told the audience he was leaving. In 1989, the group released one more album, 2300 Jackson Street, before formally disbanding the next year. The Jacksons  Michael, Jermaine, Tito, Marlon, Jackie and Randy  became famous in the 1970s with hits like I Want You Back and ABC.

title: The Citizenship Surge
description: About the only point of agreement on immigration in this country is that newcomers who play by the rules  fill out their forms, pay their fees and wait their turn  are welcome. But that great American dogma is being sorely tested by the inability of the federal governments feeble citizenship agency to deal with a flood of applications that arose this summer.

title: In-Store Wi-Fi Is Free, but Not Commercial-Free
description: PEOPLE who like to use their laptops, iPhones and other devices in public are always so delighted when they stumble on a wireless hot spot in an unexpected place. Will they be pleased enough to look at ads before getting their broadband fix?

title: Which Rudy?
description: To the Editor:

title: In Elderly Women, Clinton Sees an Electoral Edge
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 26  They usually sit in the front row  to hear her better, to see her better and to make sure they have a chance to shake her hand. Some lean on canes. Some have traveled a great distance. Some have never been to a political event before.

title: One Holiday Down, More Headaches to Go
description: I FIRST checked the flight delay reports early yesterday afternoon. It did not look good. By late afternoon, the following airports were subject to the Federal Aviation Administrations ground delay programs, defined as a situation where projected traffic demand is expected to exceed the airports acceptance rate for a lengthy period of time: Atlanta, Chicago, Philadelphia, Charlotte, Newark, Kennedy and LaGuardia.

title: Manhattan: Heroin Charges Dropped
description: A Swiss man arrested in September at Kennedy Airport on 20-year-old charges of taking part in the vast heroin smuggling case known as the Pizza Connection was released last week and allowed to return to Switzerland after federal officials acknowledged that they had destroyed evidence crucial to his prosecution, his lawyer said yesterday. The suspect, Enrico Frigerio, 65, was taken into custody on Sept. 3 when he arrived at the airport with a Swiss film crew making a documentary about his life, unaware that he had been accused in 1987 of drug charges in a federal indictment, said his lawyer, Peter S. Ginsberg. Federal officials dismissed the case against Mr. Frigerio on Wednesday after an F.B.I. agent admitted, without elaborating, that video and audio evidence against the suspect had been destroyed. The United States attorneys office in Manhattan declined to comment on the case.

title: Youths Clash With the Police in France
description: VILLIERS-LE-BEL, France, Nov. 26  Dozens of youths clashed with the police for the second night in a row in a working- and lower-class suburb north of Paris on Monday, throwing stones, glass and firebombs against large contingents of heavily armed riot police officers and moving nimbly from target to target on several fronts, burning cars and a garbage truck.

title: Mississippis Lott to Leave Senate Seat
description: PASCAGOULA, Miss., Nov. 26  Senator Trent Lotts announcement on Monday that he would resign in a few weeks added to the growing Republican exodus from Congress, but may have strengthened Mr. Lotts post-Senate job prospects.

title: Stockpiling Center Fielders, but at What Cost?
description: When the Angels learned they would not be able to spend their money on Alex Rodriguez, they did not waste time feeling sorry for themselves or figuring out what to do with those available millions. They immediately signed Torii Hunter to play center field.

title: A 1930s Song of Americana Still Resonates
description: He crouched by a corner newsstand on the Upper West Side, a pathetic figure with his hand out. Youve seen him a thousand times, him or countless other street people like him. Youve also heard his cry: Can you spare any change?

title: Sturdy Sea Lion Under Growing Threat From Acidic Algae
description: The California sea lion is a robust species, but in the past decade marine biologists have recognized domoic acid poisoning as a growing threat to its health. In large enough doses, the acid, a neurotoxin, can cause disorientation, seizures, brain lesions and, eventually, death in the animals (and in humans, for that matter).

title: Regulating Cable
description: In 1984, cable companies convinced Congress that they were mere minnows that needed to be exempted from many regulatory requirements so they could compete against the titans of broadcast television. That may have been true back then, but now cable companies are media titans, and they should be regulated. Today the Federal Communications Commission can take an important step toward that goal.

title: Rio Tinto Defends Rejection of Bid
description: SINGAPORE, Nov. 26  Almost three weeks after rejecting a takeover proposal from the rival mining company BHP Billiton, Rio Tinto laid out its case Monday, trying to persuade shareholders to hold out for a better offer.

title: The Gangs All Here Again: W, Bill and of Course Jack
description: Ellen DeGeneres presides over a prime-time variety special. A Charlie Brown Thanksgiving earns its highest ratings in years. And now TBS brings back that lowest comedy denominator, celebrity impersonation, in the late-night series Frank TV. Whats next, a talking horse?

title: Back to the Animated Future, This Time on DVD
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  As far back as 2002, a year before the last original Sunday night episode of Futurama was broadcast on Fox, it was clear to the shows creators, Matt Groening and David X. Cohen, that their show was about to be history. An animated vision of the 30th century, it was a brightly colored world populated by larcenous robots; one-eyed, purple-haired mutants; space alien news anchors; and one very confused cryogenically frozen pizza delivery boy.

title: Neediest Cases Totals
description: Previously recorded $2,393,421.37

title: Monday Injury Roundup: Quarterbacks Take a Beating
description: Seems a bit trivial to be talking about bad backs when Washington safety Sean Taylor is clinging to life in a Florida hospital. But the game goes on, and so must the injury roundup.

title: Uncertainty at Hometown Hospice
description: A hospice serving Alabama's poorest citizens is one of hundreds across the country that is facing a financial disaster.

title: Scans of Pregnant Women on the Rise
description: Pregnant women are exposed to twice the amount of radiation from medical scans as they were a decade ago, a new study has found.

title: Next Stop: the Dole
description: From Reuters:

title: Wachovia Broker Fined for Insider Trading
description: A Wachovia Securities broker must pay a fine of more than $346,000 after a judge found that he illegally traded on insider information concerning the acquisition of the propane gas distributor Blue Rhino.

title: S.E.C. Ends Inquiry into Computer Sciences Options
description: Computer Sciences, a provider of computer services to government agencies and businesses, said federal regulators have concluded an investigation of stock option grants and do not plan any further action.

title: Cigna, Expanding in the West, Buys Great-West
description: The health insurer Cigna said Monday that it had reached an agreement to buy the health care unit of Great-West Life & Annuity Insurance for about $1.5 billion in a move to expand its business in the western United States.

title: Yodle Funded to the Tune of $12 Million
description: Yodle, which aims to solve the knotty problem of using the Web to connect potential customers with the local plumber, pizzeria, or podiatrist, has landed $12 million in a second round led by Draper Fisher Jurvetson, the company announced Monday.

title: $6 Million Homes
description: Properties on the market in California, Florida and Colorado.

title: Carbylan Lands $20 Million
description: Carbylan BioSurgery, a medical device company focused on medical products for osteoarthritis and chronic rhinosinusitis, said Monday it had closed a second round of funding with $20 million.

title: Classmates.com Looks to Raise $144 Million in I.P.O.
description: Classmates.com on Friday set the terms of its initial public offering at 12 million shares, with an estimated price range of $10 to $12 per share in a bid to raise as much as $144 million, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

title: Fraud Trial of Former Brocade Executive Begins
description: Prosecutors argued Monday that a former Brocade Communications Systems executive was a key enforcer in an illegal accounting scheme, while her attorney said she was just following instructions when she backdated stock options.

title: British Airways and TPG Pull $5 Billion Iberia Bid
description: British Airways and TPG, the American private equity firm, on Monday withdrew their 3.4 billion euro ($5 billion) offer to buy Iberia, setting the stage for a prolonged contest for control of Spains flag carrier and increasing the prospect it could remain in Spanish hands.

title: Kerkorian Decries Tesoros Poison Pill
description: Tracinda, Kirk Kerkorians investment company, said Monday that a decision by the refiner Tesoro to adopt a poison pill shareholder rights plan could jeopardize its offer to buy 16 percent of Tesoros shares.

title: For Angels, the Sidecar Gains Prominence
description: Until recently, angel investors were regarded as detached from the companies they backed, wealthy amateurs who dropped in between rounds of golf to cut checks and rub elbows with entrepreneurs.

title: Nice Billfold
description: Yo, heres what you can do with your dead prezzes now that the dollars tanking and models and rappers have taken to euros. Money origami found here.

title: Commerzbank Chief Says Trouble Is Not Over
description: Nearly five months after the mortgage mess spilled into Europe, Klaus-Peter Mller, the chief executive of Commerzbank and president of the German banking association, said the full extent of the damage was still unclear.

title: Fed to Inject $8 Billion to Lubricate Economy
description: Seeking to reassure banks amid the continuing credit crisis, the Federal Reserve said Monday that it would provide $8 billion in funds to ease concerns about lending during the holiday season.

title: Rio Tinto Is Open to Offers  at the Right Price
description: While Rio Tinto continued Monday to outline why a $153 billion takeover proposal from rival mining company BHP Billiton was not in its best interests, the company nevertheless seemed to signal that it was receptive to suitors.

title: Despite Bailout Plan, HSBC May Be in for More Stormy Weather
description: HSBCs announcement Monday that it would bail out its two structured investment vehicles, or SIVs, by taking $45 billion in assets onto its balance sheet, was an attempt to repair investor confidence and create a long-term solution for assets that have become difficult to value or sell since the meltdown of subprime mortgage market.

title: In Winning EMI, Is Guy Hands Losing Out on Other Deals?
description: Guy Hands, the chief executive of the buy-out group Terra Firma, is in a wild panic about his $4.7 billion acquisition of EMI and how hell manage to make a return on the record company, according to The Financial Times Alphaville blog.

title: Citigroup Sells Abu Dhabi Fund $7.5 Billion Stake
description: Citigroup announced Monday night that it was selling a $7.5 billion stake to a Middle Eastern sovereign fund in the latest bid to shore up its balance sheet.

title: Barcelona Reaches Round of 16
description: Nov. 27 (Bloomberg) -- Two-time winner Barcelona reached the round of 16 in European soccer's Champions League after a 2- 2 draw at Lyon today, while Inter Milan, Roma and Sevilla advanced with victories.

title: Federal Prosectors Subpoena Genesco Over Buyout Deal
description: The shoe and hat retailer Genesco said on that it had received a subpoena from federal prosecutors in New York for documents related to buyout negotiations with Finish Line.

title: Swedish Bank Picks Up Fund of Hedge Funds
description: A Swedish bank, SEB, acquired Key Asset Management, a manager of funds of hedge funds based in London.

title: Ackman Raises Borders Stake to 17.1%
description: The activist hedge fund manager William Ackman has raised his stake in the Borders Group, the countrys second-largest book seller, to 17.1 percent, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing late Friday.

title: Comments on Peace
description: President Bush

title: More of Your Late Night Jokes
description: Once again, with late-night comedy writers on strike and the talk shows in reruns, Laugh Lines readers step in to fill the void (send your monologue jokes via the comment link below):

title: Lessons From The Today Show
description: My book was featured on the Today show yesterday. A one-minute appearance on national television may not sound like a big deal for someone who writes for The New York Times regularly. But it did feel like a big deal. Television is very different from print. And even though Ive appeared on television several times to talk about my book, its still new enough to me that each time I do it, I learn something. The experience reminded me of a few truths about careers  and a few truths about publicity.

title: Bush and Gore on Global Warming. Imagine That.
description: And now for something completely different. Im putting out a call to any creative souls willing to break the Hollywood writers strike and post how they imagine the conversation went yesterday when President Bush and former Vice President Al Gore met privately for 30 minutes at the White House. (The meeting happened after a photo op in which Mr. Bush congratulated the American winners of Nobel Prizes, including Mr. Gore, of course). Mr. Gore told Sheryl Gay Stolberg of The Times that the entire chat was on global warming. Half an hour of conversation between Al Gore and George Bush on climate?

title: Merrills Barge-Gate 2.0? Not So Much
description: Shortly after Merrill Lynch ousted its chairman and chief executive several weeks ago, a report in The Wall Street Journal added to the firms troubles by saying it had committed to off-balance-sheet deals with hedge funds to delay the reporting of potential losses. The Journal article even mentioned the dreaded E word: Enron (a Merrill client for whom the bank allegedly tried to help hide losses via sham transactions involving Nigerian barges).

title: Indian Property I.P.O. Doubles Value in Debut
description: An Indian property magnate, Gautam Adani, just added $4.3 billion to his personal fortune.

title: Stephen Schwarzman Speaks
description: From a DealBook colleague, Jenny Anderson:

title: The Evil Twin of Jesus Christ Kicks Butt
description: Not all that much of a story, and probably not a future Oscar candidate, but I liked writing the headline and its fun to imagine the pitch meeting. Then again, its hard to resist the project in development, at least as Reuters describes it: The story traces the journey of two German archaeologists looking for evidence that Jesus visited India. The researchers, who are twins themselves, find that Jesus had an evil twin brother

title: The Early Word: A Recession Could Shift 08 Priorities
description: Recession. The word alone is enough to send shivers down the spines of many Americans. A Wall Street Journal article today explores the ways in which an economic downturn could cause voters to re-evaluate their priorities.

title: Hes So Not There
description: Greg Mitchell, writing in Editor and Publisher, points out that the press conference scene in Im Not There, in which Cate Blanchett aka Jude Quinn aka Bob Dylan snipes his way through a flock of clueless reporters, does not take a lot of dramatic license. In the PBS documentary No Direction Home, Dylan tells Martin Scorsese:

title: The Gun Goes Off. Duck and Cover.
description: Tonight, the Bagger is putting on the asbestos sport coat  hes thinking of the very guido black-tie, black shirt combo  and heading over to Brooklyn for the Gotham Awards, the opening salvo in a long, long awards season. Mira Nair, the director of The Namesake, is letting the Bagger tag along to make some video  she said it was an act of charity, like giving to the March of Dimes  so he will be rooting for his story and host.

title: MySpace Isnt Just for People Who Like to Watch
description: UPDATE: See comments from Fox at the end.

title: Spitzers Rocky First Year
description: Does Eliot Spitzer have the judgment to succeed as governor? For a front-page article that looks at Gov. Eliot Spitzers tumultuous first year as governor, Nicholas Confessore and other reporters interviewed a dozen top aides and advisers to the governor, and more than two dozen lawmakers, former elected officials, labor leaders and political experts. Many seemed almost bewildered by how swiftly his fortunes have declined. Nearly all of the advisers now concede that they deeply misjudged how the drivers license proposal would fare, though few believed that it would permanently hobble Mr. Spitzer and fewer still blamed the governor himself.

title: Clinton Is Ahead! (Unless, Of Course, She Isnt)
description: Hillary is unstoppable:

title: Sovereign Wealth Funds: A Shopping List
description: The announcement Monday night that Citigroup was selling a $7.5 billion stake to a Middle Eastern sovereign fund, the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority, is just the latest in a recent string of acquisitions by Middle Eastern and Asian sovereign wealth funds.

title: Restoration Names Terms for Sears Talks
description: Restoration Hardware said on Tuesday that its ready to open its books for Sears  on certain terms.

title: Tracinda Withdraws Tesoro Bid, Citing Poison Pill Plan
description: Tracinda, the investment company of the billionaire Kirk Kerkorian, withdrew its $1.4 billion tender offer for 16 percent of Tesoro, citing a stockholder-rights plan adopted by the oil refiner.

title: Ishiguro, on Ice
description: A few weeks ago, a friend turned me onto Breakfast on the Morning Tram (Blue Note), the new CD from the American-born, London-based jazz singer Stacey Kent. Now I cant get it off my iPod.

title: Hosts of The View Support Strikers, Too
description: The women of The View expressed support for the striking television writers on Monday, following the decisions by Michelle Obama and John and Elizabeth Edwards to cancel their appearances on the show as a gesture of solidarity with the writers.

title: From Roundabouts to Naked Streets?
description: I got a kick out of reading Jill P. Capuzzos story on the introduction of roundabouts in New Jersey. Growing up outside of Boston, I was raised on roundabouts and rotaries. There was a roundabout between my house and the high school. There was another one on the way to a local farmers market. I never thought twice about them.

title: A Long Way to the Bottom of a U.N. Index
description: Every year, the United Nations ranks its 175 members plus Hong Kong and the Palestinian territories using an index of human development  mainly life expectancy, literacy rates and income. The usual suspects occupying the top spots on the list all have affluent, well-developed market economies, and politely switch places from year to year over small statistical shifts.

title: Ask the Urban Rodentologist
description: Robert M. Corrigan, a well-known urban rodentologist and Brooklyn native who works as a research scientist for the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, took questions on the City Room blog from Nov. 26-30.

title: Violence in a Paris Suburb
description: A chilling new factor makes the recent violence in France more menacing: the rioters have taken up hunting shotguns and turned them on the police.

title: Insert Pun Here: NBC Saves Life
description: On Friday, after TV Decoder noted that NBC was pre-empting the detective drama Life on Dec. 12, dozens of fans immediately wrote in to come to the shows defense.

title: Radioheads Genius?: Making Music Downloading Pay
description: Could this be the dawn of a new business model for the music industry? Following Radioheads decision last month to let fans pay whatever they wanted to download their latest album In Rainbows, other artists, staid and crazy, are trying the same tactic.

title: Taking Stock of Citis $7.5 Billion Deal
description: The good news for Citigroup is that it just found $7.5 billion to freshen up its wilting balance sheet. The bad news is that it sacrificed a lot to get it  and it may still need more.

title: Consistency at Last
description: The Standard & Poors/Case-Shiller home price indexes showed something in September that they have never shown before  lower prices everywhere.

title: The tax cut ratchet
description: So the WSJ says that a recession is good for Republicans  as Atrios likes to point out, for the news media everything always is. In this case, its because tax cuts will suddenly become desirable as a way to stimulate the economy:

title: Verizon Wireless Says Bring Your Own Device
description: Verizon Wireless has stunned the wireless world by announcing that by sometime next year it will open its network to any apps, any device.

title: Tuesdays Links: Everglades in Pittsburgh?
description: The Monday night game was a truly terrible one, though the presence of the Dolphins can hardly be blamed. Heinz Field was a bog after pouring rain water-logged the new sod that had been put in because of wear and tear from five football games over the weekend. The red zone was reached only once, by the Steelers on their final drive, when Jeff Reed kicked the winning field goal with 17 seconds left for a 3-0 victory. (Ive been saying this a lot about the Monday night game this season: Watch the highlights at your own risk.)

title: Quote: Dept. of Too Juicy to Be True
description: From a news release from the Federal Bureau of Investigation on Monday:

title: Literature Tailored for a Trip Through India
description: I am planning my first trip to India in December and was wondering if you had any good books (novels and fiction particularly welcome) that I could read prior and during my trip?

title: Holy Halliburton
description: Crony capitalism rears its ugly head. If this is as bad as it looks, the subprime mess has just entered a whole new level of scandal:

title: Send in the Exterminators
description: Dave Polands thanks-filled Thanksgiving blog, give or take some bugs:

title: Outbreak!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Shes Back. Not.
description: Kate Winslet for best supporting actress? For what exactly? The Bagger is so far into the tank for Winslet that he needs a scuba tank, but even he cant buy into Kris Tapleys DOA effort in his Variety blog to push her along in that category for Romance and Cigarettes. It would be a better season with her working the carpet, but it aint gonna happen.

title: Modesty Becomes Nikki Finke
description: TOLDJA! Warners Jeff Robinov Promoted  headline on Nikki Finkes Deadline Hollywood Daily site on a story about some wiring rearrangement at Warner Bros. Now if she could just rig the DHD site so it plays a herald of trumpets every time you open it.

title: Feel Your Inner Muse Wither to Nothing
description: One of my favorite blogs, in a Debbie Downer kind of way  I tend to poke around in it on days when Ive read 7 bad novels in a row and feel like I may never read a good one again  is 101 Reasons to Stop Writing, written by Sean Lindsay. Its a daily blast of unfiltered comic bile, aimed at writers who arent smart enough (in Lindsays opinion) to know theyre terrible.

title: God is Dead, Unless Its Time to Sell a Movie
description: Vulture at New York magazine points out that efforts to soft-peddle the darker implications of The Golden Compass are bumping up against the author of the book, who refuses to shut up long enough for New Line to tamp down the debate about whether or not God is killed in the movie. Among other golden bits of spin, Phillip Pullman has suggested, Im trying to undermine the basis of Christian belief, and My books are about killing God.

title: A 9/11 Memorial Fountain on Wall Street, Under Glass
description: What could be simpler than a glass bowl?

title: Tuesday Links: Fall Out From Black Monday
description: The reverberations from college footballs Black Monday reached from the SEC to the Big 12 and the Pac 10.

title: Googles New Search  for Cheap, Clean Electricity
description: A heap of climate and energy experts have been aching for government and/or the private sector to step forward in a big way to take on the challenge of diverting the world from its expanding appetite for fossil fuels.

title: Poll: New Yorkers Welcome Papal Visit
description: Nearly one-quarter of New York City voters have an unfavorable opinion of Pope Benedict XVI and a similar proportion do not approve of the way he is doing his job, but an overwhelming majority of New Yorkers  70 percent  believe his planned visit in April will be good for the city, according to Quinnipiac University poll results released this morning.

title: Smells Like Independent Spirit
description: The nominations for the Spirit Awards, which are handed out the day before the Oscars and often are a good measure of heat in the indie world, were announced this morning. Best feature nominations include The Diving Bell and the Butterfly, Im Not There, Juno, A Mighty Heart and Paranoid Park. Later tonight after the Gotham Awards, which are an Eastern version of the same award ethos, the Bagger will do vector analysis to figure out what it all means.

title: More Hispanics, Blacks and Women Pass Firefighter Exam
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and other city officials announced this morning that 38 percent of the 21,183 applicants who passed the citys firefighters examination on Jan. 20 are minorities, calling the result a significant improvement since the last time the exam was administered, in 2002, when 21 percent of those who passed were minorities. The Fire Department has historically been criticized for having relatively few women, blacks and Hispanics, compared with the far more diverse Police Department.The city also noted a 50 percent increase in the number of women test-takers who passed: 770 this year, compared with 512 in 2002.

title: Sean Taylor, Redskins Star, Dies After Shooting
description: The Washington Redskins' defensive back who was shot by an intruder at his Miami home died from his injury.

title: Oh, the Humanity!  Oops, Wrong Disaster
description: Found here.

title: NBC Will Buy TiVo Data
description: NBC Universal has agreed to start offering interactive advertising services and subscribe to a ratings service from TiVo, Reuters reports.

title: Oversized Portions? Blame the Chef
description: Nutrition experts have long urged Americans to pay more attention to portion sizes. But someone forgot to tell the chef.

title: New Direction for Discovery Times
description: The Discovery Times Channel, which was founded four years ago in a partnership between Discovery Communications and The New York Times Company, will be re-branded as Investigation Discovery in January 2008.

title: Demystifying the Turkish meyhane
description: In Rome, its pasta. In Paris, its bistro fare and sauces. What springs to mind when it comes to dining out in Istanbul?

title: First Impressions: Brasserie 44
description: Hotel restaurants that dont have their own entrances on the street  that are tucked inside the hotels they inhabit, accessible only through the lobbies  have it tough.

title: The Art of Charting the Changes in Chinatown
description: In preparation for a $15 million expansion into a 14,000-square foot space designed by Maya Lin, the Museum of Chinese in America  renamed this month from the Museum of Chinese in the Americas as part of a rebranding campaign  is starting an archaeological project around five Lower Manhattan sites to document the shifting patterns of immigration and assimilation in New York City.

title: Did Bush Help Clear Holiday Airways?
description: President Bush tried to soothe the nations anxiety about the Thanksgiving travel rush with a plan to cut delays by opening military airspace for commercial flights. Immediately, there were doubts that it would help, with one critic saying quite clearly that it will not make the slightest difference in airline delays.

title: For Mideast Funds, the Worlds a Bazaar
description: The governments of the world are on a buying spree, and with the price of oil near record levels, the United Arab Emirates are feeling especially flush. Where are they spending their cash? All over the world, but especially in the United States, where the declining dollar has made assets especially cheap.

title: Is Congress Partly to Blame for D.C.s AIDS Crisis?
description: AIDS cases are increasing in the nations capital and Congress may be partly to blame.

title: Rally for Writers Draws the Curious and the Media-Hungry
description: A rally in Manhattan on Tuesday afternoon in support of the Writers Guild of America drew several hundred people, though not the thousand that the labor unions that organized the event said they had anticipated.

title: Hillarys Secret Weapon: Colin Powell?
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has been talking for some time now about how, if she is elected president, she will ask both Democratic and Republican statesmen to hit the road on her behalf to declare that bipartisan foreign policy is back in post-George W. Bush America.

title: Thompson Releases 2 New Campaign Ads
description: Fred Thompson, seeking to inject some life into his struggling campaign, released two new television ads that recall the events that first catapulted him to national prominence.

title: Walids New Rival for Citis Deference
description: He isnt a Citigroup executive or director. But for more than a decade, Prince Walid bin Talal has been an unofficial godfather at the firm by dint of his stake in the financial giant. Securing his blessing was often necessary to introduce new initiatives at the bank. Conversely, the withholding of his backing was a damaging, if not fatal, blow. Just ask Charles O. Prince III.

title: In Fair Calorie Counts, Who Screams for Ice Cream?
description: So how many calories, exactly, are in that tempting slice of Fudgie the Whale ice cream cake?

title: Streisand Endorses Clinton
description: Barbra Streisand endorsed Hillary Clinton today. Tawk amongst ya-selves!

title: Falafel Report? They Feel Awful About It
description: Our blog The Lede reports that the F.B.I. is denying a report that it tried to track down terrorists through sales spikes in Mideast foods like falafel.

title: Romney and Muslims (And That Other Religion )
description: A Christian Science Monitor opinion piece claims that, when asked the rather odd question of whether he would consider including qualified Americans of the Islamic faith in his cabinet as advisers on national security matters, Mitt Romney reportedly gave an even odder answer: Based on the numbers of American Muslims [as a percentage] in our population, I cannot see that a cabinet position would be justified. But of course, I would imagine that Muslims could serve at lower levels of my administration.

title: More Teens Victimized by Cyber-Bullies
description: The schoolyard bully has gone digital.

title: A Judges Inexplicable Madness Over a Cellphone
description: The next time you pass through the city court system in Niagara Falls, N.Y., remember to turn your cellphone off.

title: The Other Half of Open: Competition
description: Verizon Wireless has said it will open its network to any device and any application. But it hasnt said on what price and on what terms. These are, of course, crucial to understanding how much effect this move will have.

title: Romney on Muslims in His Cabinet
description: Throughout the day, reports have been circulating that Mitt Romney said during a fund raiser that he would not appoint a Muslim to a Cabinet post. Today, after a campaign stop in Florida, Mr. Romney confronted the issue, saying those reports were not accurate.

title: Bike Lane Scofflaws, Beware. You Too, Officer.
description: What we are reading elsewhere

title: ABC Takes Monday Night With Dancing
description: ABCs Dancing With the Stars drew its largest audience of the season on Monday as 24.7 million viewers tuned in at 8 p.m. for the shows final round of competition, according to Nielsens estimates. Thanks to those impressive numbers, ABC led the nights ratings overall, but the network lost a disappointing number of those viewers as the night wore on.

title: He Rendered Unto Caesar (Sid, That Is)
description: Mel Tolkin, long-suffering head of Sid Caesars celebrated television writing team, has died at 94. Heres the famous sandwich skit from their classic Your Show of Shows in the 1950s:

title: Memo From Merrill: The Journal Correction
description: From DealBook colleague Jenny Anderson:

title: Microsofts Windows Live Yahoo Hotmail Problem
description: Henry Blodget has a thoughtful post in which he tries to imagine how a combination of Yahoo and Microsofts Internet operations might work. His vision is much the same as the one Microsoft and Time Warner considered a year ago for combining MSN and AOL.

title: Sipping With a Pro
description: Man, I cant wait to tell you about all the exciting wines Ive had in the last week. But I will have to, because Ive had a few other things on my mind. Like bourbon, which Ive been obsessed with since a tasting we did several weeks ago. You can read my report on bourbon in the newspaper on Wednesday.

title: Rewriting the History of New York Preservation
description: A new book challenges the widely held notion that the destruction of the original Pennsylvania Station in 1963-64  a watershed event in New Yorks postwar history  gave birth to the movement to preserve landmarks and save the citys architectural heritage.

title: Atlantic Yards Ombudsman Is Named
description: The Empire State Development Corporation named an ombudsman today to serve as a public liaison for the contentious Atlantic Yards development near Downtown Brooklyn.

title: Housing Game, California Style
description: This Blog on housing in Irvine, Calif., which I got to from the calculated risk blog, tells the story very well.

title: Bracketed
description: On my recent Geek Cruise to the Panama Canal, I took along the Nikon D300 camera, which Im reviewing. Its a monster camera (at $1,900, it had better be). But a quirk of one high-end feature almost got me in a heap of trouble.

title: Head Hunting
description: For all the good things happening with Flyers rebuilding this season, which I wrote about early in the season, they keep throwing cold water on their story by sprinkling the N.H.L. with some of the worst hits on opposing players heads.

title: Remembering Sean Taylor
description: It is a sad day in the N.F.L. with the news that Redskins safety Sean Taylor died this morning from wounds he sustained in a shooting at his Miami home yesterday.

title: Iowa Women Encouraged to Caucus
description: Its fun to caucus!

title: Historic Harlem Theater Gets a Developer, at Last
description: After years of delay and political squabbling, state officials have selected Danforth Development Partners to redevelop the long-vacant Victoria Theater on 125th Street, once Harlems largest and most elegant theater. Danforth plans to transform the Victoria, which sits a couple of doors east of its more well-known sister, the Apollo Theater, into a cultural center, with two live theaters and space for the Jazz Museum of Harlem, along with a hotel and 91 condominium apartments.

title: The New York Times Close Up
description: In his weekly program on NY1, Sam Roberts, the Times's urban affairs correspondent, speaks with New York City Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein and Dan Barry of The Times.

title: Celebrity Face-Off: Streisand vs. Oprah
description: Barbra Streisand is endorsing Hillary Clinton. Its no great surprise, given her longstanding ties to the Clintons, but she had also given contributions to Barack Obama and John Edwards.

title: Democrats Supply Video, You Make the Ad
description: Heres yet another example of how the Internet is changing politics: The Democratic National Committee is putting online all the digital video that its trackers are recording of the major Republican candidates.

title: Gotham Awards: You are There, Sort Of
description: We are just off stage left at the Gothams at Steiner Studios in Brooklyn, an exotic place our driver had apparently not visited. Ever. The Bagger, schnorrer that he is, slipped into the car with Mira Nair, the director of The Namesake, one of the nominees for best feature. Mira  the Bagger calls her by her first name because they are pals for the night  is also going to be honored with a tribute tonight for her film work, which began after she attended some seminars put on by the IFP, the sponsor of the Gothams.

title: Gotham Awards: Running Tributaries
description: There were several tributes at the Gothams, including one to Mayor Michael Bloomberg for his renewed support for film-making in New York. He bragged about his acting career, and said he had recently played a role in Sex and the City, the movie. I was the city, he deadpanned.

title: Varied Views on Poverty and Climate
description: The new United Nations Human Development Report is the first of these annual surveys to focus on the intersection of climate change and efforts to improve the human condition.

title: South Korea and Its Children
description: I was 24 when I first returned to my birth country. Stepping onto the plane that would carry me back to a country I had left 21 years before, I felt dizzy at the convergence of my past and present. Once again I was the 3-year-old girl, traveling halfway around the world to an unknown future in a foreign land  now a woman returning, a foreigner again.

title: Despite Strike, Carson Daly to Resume Show
description: The NBC talk show Last Call With Carson Daly will resume production Wednesday, making it the first late-night program to produce original episodes since the Writers Guild of America went on strike three weeks ago.

title: Gotham Awards: A Wild Ride
description: Well, its officially official. Into the Wild blew in out of nowhere and won best feature. Ellen Page, cute as bugs ears and a lot more articulate, picked up the breakthrough actor award for her preggy teen in Juno. And there were some kissing cousins in the ensemble award, with Before the Devil Knows Youre Dead and Talk to Me tying.

title: Iceland Stomps Norway
description: Using a formula that apparently doesnt involve the number of available beach palapa bars or recent World Cup finishes, a new United Nations study deems Iceland the worlds most desirable country to live in.

title: G.O.P. Rivals Trade Jabs in Debate
description: The Republican presidential candidates engaged in a slashing debate tonight over immigration and other issues, confronting each other in testy encounters that reflected the wide-open nature of the race in the final sprint toward the Iowa caucuses.

title: Iran Casts Shadow on Mideast Talks
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 27  The Middle East peace conference here on Tuesday was officially about ending the Israeli-Palestinian dispute. But there was an unspoken goal just below the surface: stopping the rising regional influence of Iran and Islamic radicalism.

title: Manhattan: Parade Ban Upheld
description: A federal judge upheld a city regulation yesterday that bans new parades on Fifth Avenue, ruling against an antiwar group that had sought to challenge it as a violation of the First Amendment. The challenge to the ban came in a lawsuit filed two years ago in Federal District Court by the International Action Center, an antiwar group that was denied the right to march against the Iraq war on March 19, 2005. The city contended that the ban was a reasonable exercise of power that reduced congestion in Midtown and did not discriminate against applicants because it applied to all parades that had not been granted a permit before July 2001. Jeffrey E. Fogel, a lawyer for the demonstrators, said he would appeal.

title: Candidates Offer Different Views on Energy Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  As oil prices flirt with record highs, hovering around $95 a barrel on Tuesday, the Democratic and Republican presidential candidates are offering few quick fixes but profoundly different long-term approaches to energy policy.

title: Dragnet That Ensnares Good Samaritans, Too
description: At first, an epidemic of absent-mindedness seemed to have broken out.

title: Screenwriters and Producers Set 4th Day of Talks
