description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 28  Striking screenwriters and Hollywood producers agreed to extend their renewed contract talks to a fourth day this evening, signaling at least some progress toward ending a work stoppage that began three and a half weeks ago.

title: A Slowdown in Jobs Lost, and Created
description: For a few years starting in the late 1990s, Honeywell was one of those companies that couldnt stop announcing job cuts. It cut jobs in 1999, even as the rest of the economy was booming. It cut more jobs in 2000, when the stock market bubble began to leak. After the 9/11 attacks, the company, which makes cockpit controls and other high-technology equipment, announced its biggest layoff of all: 15,800 jobs.

title: Cracking the Code of the Zombie
description: THE culinary world seems to inspire a certain kind of dedicated, if slightly obsessive, connoisseurship. Think of Elizabeth Tashjian, who for 30 years ran the Nut Museum out of her house in Old Lyme, Conn., and spent her off hours painting portraits of walnuts. Or, more recently, Steven Kaplan, an American academic whose scholarly energies are principally focused on French bread.

title: Iran Reopens Investigation Into Killing of Journalist
description: TEHRAN, Nov. 27  The Iranian Supreme Court has ordered a new investigation into the death of an Iranian-Canadian photojournalist who was killed in Tehran in 2003 while in custody, the judiciary spokesman said Tuesday.

title: Ex-Commander of NATO Named Mideast Liaison
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  A day after the Israelis and Palestinians agreed to negotiate a peace treaty, the Bush administration appointed a former NATO commander to act as a liaison between the two sides, an administration official said today.

title: State Quarters Near End of Popular Run
description: The final five designs in the popular State Quarters series were announced yesterday by the United States Mint.

title: 35 Are Killed in Iraq, 5 by U.S. Troops
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 27  American troops in Iraq killed at least five people, including a child, when they fired on vehicles trying to drive through roadblocks in two separate episodes over the past two days, military officials and witnesses said Tuesday.

title: Recipe: Beachbums Own
description: Adapted from Jeff Berry

title: Broadway Talks Scheduled to Resume After Break
description: Negotiations are scheduled to resume this morning between the stagehands union and the league representing Broadway theater owners and producers after a one-day hiatus that was described by a union spokesman as a rain delay.

title: Recipe: Garbage Salad
description: Adapted from Gene & Georgetti, Chicago

title: History and the Problem of Following the Cameras Gaze
description: Over the past few days, Ive looked again and again at recently published images, drawn from two enlarged photographs in the Library of Congress, that very likely show Abraham Lincoln at Gettysburg 144 years ago on the November day, the 19th, when he delivered that famous address. A bearded man in a top hat rises above the crowd (we are looking at him from behind, over his left shoulder) and theres no real reason to doubt that its Lincoln. He appears in a minute portion of two stereoscopic photographs that were meant to be looked at in a special 3-D viewer.

title: When a Poll Changes the Way People Think About the Race
description: It was inevitable. A poll comes out and it dominates the news and changes the way people are thinking about the campaign. Thats just what happened last week when ABC News and The Washington Post released a poll of Iowa caucusgoers.

title: Suspect Spent Calm Week After Murders, Police Say
description: Two Sundays ago, the police say, Lamar J. Platt, a Bronx barber, fatally shot his mother and younger brother, cut up their bodies with a machete and a serrated knife, then packed the pieces into several plastic bags.

title: A Hoax Turned Fatal Draws Anger but No Charges
description: DARDENNE PRAIRIE, Mo., Nov. 21  Megan Meier died believing that somewhere in this world lived a boy named Josh Evans who hated her. He was 16, owned a pet snake, and she thought he was the cutest boyfriend she ever had.

title: Astors Son Appears in Court and Denies Charges
description: Anthony D. Marshall, 83 years old, the only son of Brooke Astor, leaned forward slightly and gazed down at the table. The only sound in the courtroom yesterday afternoon was the voice of an officer reading a litany of criminal charges against him.

title: New Method for Making Diesel Fuel Uses Vegetable Oils
description: A Portuguese oil company, Galp Energia, plans to announce today that it is building a 6,500-barrel-a-day plant to make diesel fuel from vegetable oils using a method akin to refining oil.

title: Fugitive From U.S. Justice Leads Panamas Assembly
description: PANAMA  The hand that Pedro Miguel Gonzlez Pinzn extends in greeting  the one that wields the gavel during proceedings of the National Assembly, the one that waves to rural constituents and signs legislative documents  may have blood on it.

title: Recipe: Spiced Nuts With Sugared Bacon
description: Time: 50 minutes

title: Theater Awards in London
description: Shakespeare was a big winner at the annual Evening Standard Theater Awards, held at the Savoy Hotel in London, the BBC reported yesterday. The West End production of Macbeth won two awards: best actor for Patrick Stewart, left, and best direction for Rupert Goold. Anne-Marie Duff was named best actress for her lead role in Saint Joan. A Disappearing Number won best play, and Hairspray took best musical. Stephen Wight was named outstanding newcomer for his roles in Dealers Choice and Don Juan in Soho. Polly Stenham won for most promising playwright.

title: Once Again, the Nets Hit the Wall at Home
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 27  After returning from a four-game western trip, the Nets probably cannot wait to get back on the road again. The unfriendly confines of Izod Center tripped them up again Tuesday night as they lost their fifth straight game at home, falling to the Memphis Grizzlies, 110-103.

title: Pairings
description: AT the old Trader Vics in the Plaza Hotel of yore, my favorite cocktail was an Eastern sour, a whiskey sour made with bourbon. The sweetness, spice and strength of bourbon, when blended with sour and bitter components, can result in a drink that offers a particularly fine balance. At Lucy of Gramercy, Gary Dusek, the beverage director, makes a bourbon manhattan, the Spanish Harlem, with sweet Pedro Ximinez sherry in place of vermouth for a nuttier flavor. He also uses maraschino cherries; bartenders superstition decrees you not use an even number. Michael Cecconi, the drink master at Back Forty in the East Village, makes its house cocktail with Tennessee whiskey, though he would allow bourbon in the drink.

title: For Abu Dhabi and Citi, Credit Crisis Drove Deal
description: A falling dollar, a growing pile of oil revenue and an interest in not being overshadowed by neighboring Dubais increasingly high profile spurred Abu Dhabi to break with its low-key investing tradition to purchase a big $7.5 billion stake in Citigroup.

title: A Violist and His Friends, Assertive and Collaborative
description: Top-drawer soloists are plentiful on most instruments these days. But you have to be a viola fanatic  and how many of those are there?  to be able to list more than a few violists with thriving recital careers. There are Yuri Bashmet and Kim Kashkashian, and once there was William Primrose. Orchestral violists sometimes step out on their own but retain the security of their night jobs. And violinists like Pinchas Zukerman and Janine Jansen occasionally spend quality time with this mezzo-soprano of the violin family.

title: Fed Officials Remarks Send Stocks Soaring
description: Stocks soared on Wall Street today after a top Federal Reserve official appeared to open the door for additional interest rate cuts, pledging to follow flexible and pragmatic policy making as the central bank decides how to cope with the current financial upheaval.

title: Caution: Taliban Crossing
description: Albuquerque

title: Police and Protesters Clash Near Paris
description: VILLIERS-LE-BEL, France, Nov. 27  Dodging rocks and projectiles, the police lined the streets of this tense suburb Tuesday where angry youths have vowed to seek revenge for the deaths of two teenagers who died in a weekend collision with a police car.

title: Recipe: Plantation Daze
description: Adapted from Jeff Berry The Coco Palms hotel on Kauai devised this drink with a tropical flavor.

title: House Cleaning
description: After months of delay, a legislative task force is now expected to recommend the creation of an independent office to goad action and accountability from the Houses ethically challenged ethics committee. In a bipartisan ode to the unrocked boat, the committee sat passively through corruption scandals in the last Congress that put two lawmakers behind bars.

title: Defense in Teenagers Death Invokes Memories of Lynch Mobs
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y., Nov. 27  The trial of a black man accused of killing a white youth who threatened his son will be as much about race and the echoes of Jim Crow lynch mobs as about the five minutes on a hot August night in 2006 when a white teenager was shot in the face, defense lawyers for the man suggested on Tuesday.

title: As Rents Go Up, Some Offices Go South
description: When the public radio station WNYC, which was in the City Hall area, set out to find bigger and better space for new offices more than a year ago, it cast an eye to the concrete and steel skyscrapers of Midtown Manhattan.

title: Musharraf Prepares to Drop Army Role
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 27  The Pakistani president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, conducted what the Pakistani military said was a round of farewell calls to the countrys armed forces today, a day before officials say he will relinquish his role of chief of the army.

title: Dancing to the Top
description: ABCs Dancing With the Stars drew its largest audience of the season on Monday as 24.7 million viewers tuned in at 8 p.m. for the shows final round, Nielsen estimated. This helped ABC lead the nights ratings overall, but the network lost many of those viewers as the night wore on. While ABCs comedy Samantha Who? was about average at 9 (12.6 million), the season premiere of Notes From the Underbelly at 9:30 earned just 8.3 million viewers. At 10, the second season of ABCs October Road made its debut with 6 million viewers, good for third place behind NBCs Journeyman (6.2 million). CBSs CSI: Miami (15.5 million) dominated the 10 p.m. hour, helping CBS finish in a tie for first with ABC among adults 18 to 49. NBC ranked third overall as Heroes at 9 (11.9 million) delivered its strongest ratings in eight weeks. Fox trailed in fourth for the night.

title: Recipe: Beachbum Berrys Zombie
description: Adapted from Jeff Berry This recipe nearly matches the flavor of the 1934 Zombie, but it is simpler.

title: After 10 Years and 3 Plans, U.N. Renovation Is in Sight
description: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 27  Cruise ships, barges, islands, tent settlements, a 30-story annex, a Wal-Mart-size building, even Brooklyn.

title: Grim View of Iraq Dangers in Survey of Journalists
description: In a newly released survey, American journalists in Iraq give harrowing accounts of their work, with the great majority saying that colleagues have been kidnapped or killed and that most parts of Baghdad are too dangerous for them to visit.

title: Minayas Next Move: Finding Elite Starter for Mets
description: Like all the other teams in baseball, the Mets would love to put Johan Santana at the front of their rotation in 2008. But short of agreeing to drive the Twins prospective haul to Minneapolis himself  and who knows, stranger things have happened  General Manager Omar Minaya may be unable to put together a package of prospects enticing enough to beat out suitors that have richer farm systems.

title: Miamis Williams Back on Sideline
description: Whether it is because of suspension or injury, Dolphins running back Ricky Williams has shown quite a knack for not being on the field in recent seasons.

title: The Gift Is in the Mail, and on the Web
description: TWENTY-FIVE years after writing my first column on sweet, savory and useful mail-order gifts for the holidays  one filled with imported goodies  Im amazed by how butchers, bakers and candy makers around this country keep coming up with delectable surprises.

title: The Burger and the Philosophy Behind It
description: THOUGH it is not a hamburger restaurant, Back Forty has a $10 hamburger that says a lot about the place.

title: Foreclosure Charges by Lender Investigated
description: The federal agency monitoring the bankruptcy courts has subpoenaed Countrywide Financial, the nations largest mortgage lender and loan servicer, to determine whether the companys conduct in two foreclosures in southern Florida represented abuses of the bankruptcy system.

title: Economic Development Corporation Is Seeking New Heliport Manager
description: After 47 years of operating the Downtown Manhattan Heliport, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is getting out of the helicopter business.

title: Venezuela Recalls Colombia Envoy
description: Venezuela called home its ambassador to Colombia for consultations after an exchange of insults over the weekend between President Hugo Chvez and the Colombian president, lvaro Uribe. Colombia opted not to reciprocate. The presidents spat erupted after Mr. Uribe withdrew his support for Mr. Chvezs mediating role with the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, Latin Americas largest rebel group. Mr. Chvez had been attempting to win the release of about 45 hostages believed held by the group, including three Americans. Concern persists for the disputes potential impact on trade between the countries, valued at more than $4 billion.

title: Purification That Comes in a Bottle: Water Takes on New Responsibilities
description: AT a tiny table for two in the back of her cafe in Chappaqua, N.Y., on a recent Saturday evening, Diane Felicissimo was expounding on the virtues of a mineral water from an ancient French spring called Wattwiller. They say its so old it has a soul, she said.

title: Congress Called Near Compromise on Fuel Economy Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  Congressional negotiators are nearing agreement on a measure to set significantly higher fuel economy standards for cars and light trucks, according to aides and lobbyists following the talks.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report on Thursday in the Mens College Basketball Preview about the outlook for Georgetown misstated the stage of last seasons N.C.A.A. tournament at which the Hoyas lost. It was the national semifinals, a Final Four matchup against Ohio State, not the title game. (Florida defeated Ohio State for the championship.) (Go to Article)

title: Stuck on a Family Hamster Wheel, Mile After Mile, Year After Year
description: The hands that rock the cradle sometimes tip it over. Watching The Savages, Tamara Jenkinss beautifully nuanced tragicomedy about two floundering souls, you have to wonder if those hands didnt also knock that cradle clear across the nursery, sending both Savage children into perpetual free-fall.

title: Bidding Adieu to a Treasured American Heirloom
description: He is a French aristocrat who created a stir in America as a precocious teenager, and then returned decades later to the United States to be celebrated in New York, Philadelphia, Washington and Boston.

title: Back to Dont Look Back, This Time With Dylans Songs in the Spotlight
description: The great relief of D. A. Pennebakers 65 Revisited  which pulls together never-released footage shot for his documentary Dont Look Back  is that this time you can hear the songs in their entirety. Because Mr. Pennebaker wanted Dont Look Back to be about Bob Dylan, not his 1965 British concert tour, he made the somewhat maddening decision to cut down the songs in that first film to tantalizing bits and pieces. The problem of course being that the songs were as much a part of this youthquaking sensation as his pipe-cleaner-skinny legs, his fuzzy fro, bobbing head, sly smile, riffs, rants, puns and playful, otherworldly genius.

title: Making Old Hardware Play New Tunes
description: Jeremiah Johnson, 27, is a chiptune composer: His instrument is not the guitar or the piano or even the latest music software, but old-school video hardware like the Nintendo GameBoy. Working with screwdrivers and soldering irons, he painstakingly reprograms the rudimentary sound chips in the game machines to create songs that play right from the console. The sound is less Super Mario Brothers and more post-punk, New Wave electronica (albeit with that familiar, bleepy timbre).

title: Verizon Plans Wider Options for Cellphone Users
description: In a major shift for the mobile phone industry, Verizon Wireless said yesterday that it planned to give customers far more choice in what phones they could use on its network and how they use them.

title: J. Robert Cade, the Inventor of Gatorade, Dies at 80
description: J. Robert Cade, a nephrologist who mixed water, sugar, salt and cunning dashes of whatever to invent Gatorade, of which 12 million bottles are guzzled daily by electrolyte-depleted athletes, post-operative patients and the simply thirsty, died yesterday in Gainesville, Fla. He was 80.

title: Recipe: Back Forty
description: Adapted from Back Forty

title: Longtime Mentor Thrives With a Sense of Wonder
description: When I was 14, I was caught fishing illegally in a drinking-water reservoir by a game warden named Joe Haines. Instead of giving me a ticket, he took me under his wing.

title: Mbekis Support Erodes in Party Vote in South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 27  With a national conference looming in mid-December to choose the next leader of South Africas ruling party  and by extension, the nations probable next president  President Thabo Mbekis control of the party has shifted to his former vice president and bitter rival, the populist politician Jacob Zuma.

title: Recipe: Hot Pot
description: Time: 30 minutes

title: Group Urges Immediate Action to Reduce Size of Classes
description: City school officials could begin reducing class sizes immediately in more than 150 of New Yorks lowest performing schools, according to a report released yesterday by the Campaign for Fiscal Equity, the advocacy group that successfully sued the state for more money for the public school system.

title: Manhattan: Movement in Theater Redevelopment
description: After years of delay and political squabbling, state officials have selected Danforth Development Partners to redevelop the long-vacant Victoria Theater on 125th Street, once Harlems largest and most elegant theater. Danforth plans to transform the Victoria into a cultural center, with two live theaters, space for the Jazz Museum of Harlem, a 200-room hotel and 91 condominiums. The theaters would be used primarily by the Classical Theater of Harlem and the Harlem Arts Alliance. Danforth, a Harlem-based developer, said it would restore the Victorias Ionic columns, terra cotta rosettes and other historic elements.

title: In French Suburbs, Same Rage, but New Tactics
description: PARIS, Nov. 27  Two years after Frances immigrant suburbs exploded in rage, the rituals and acts of resentment have reappeared with an eerie sameness: roving gangs clashing with riot police forces, the government appealing for calm, residents complaining that they are ignored.

title: Footnotes
description: In Bruges, a first-time feature written and directed by the playwright Martin McDonagh, below, will open next years Sundance Film Festival. The film stars Ralph Fiennes, Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson, and is about of two London hit men ordered to take a forced vacation in Bruges, Belgium. The festival runs from Jan. 17 to 27 in Park City, Salt Lake City, Ogden and Sundance, all in Utah. ... Constantin Costa-Gavras, the Greek-born director of Z and Missing, will head the jury at the annual Berlin Film Festival in February, The Associated Press reported yesterday. The Italian director Francesco Rosi will receive the festivals Golden Bear award for lifetime achievement. ... The Manhattan Theater Club has announced that Mary Catherine Garrison, Elizabeth Marvel, Martha Plimpton and Marisa Tomei will star in the Broadway premiere of Caryl Churchills Top Girls at the Biltmore Theatre. Previews begin on April 15; the official opening is May 7. ... The Public Theater has announced the lineup for its annual Under the Radar Festival for new theater, running Jan. 9 to 20; for schedule and ticketing information: publictheater.org. ... Good Boys and True, by Roberto Aguirre-Sacasa, which forces a mother to confront the truth about her son, will be the third production of the season at Second Stage Theater. The play, about a scandal at a boys prep school, will begin previews in late April and open in mid-May.

title: Oil Producers See the World and Buy It Up
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  Flush with petrodollars, oil-producing countries have embarked on a global shopping spree.

title: In New Hampshire, Some Fret About Too Little, Too Early
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., Nov. 27  At the Merrimack Restaurant on Elm Street, where a mural of past presidential candidates adorns the red brick facade, Maria Saitas is worried. Not only will New Hampshires primary be over earlier than ever next year, but the window between the Iowa and New Hampshire contests  a mere five days in early January  will be wincingly brief.

title: Top Prospects Merely a Down Payment on Santana
description: When Johan Santana of the Minnesota Twins thinks about the seven-year, $126 million contract that Barry Zito signed with the San Francisco Giants 11 months ago, it would be natural for him to smile. And when general managers ponder that bloated contract, it would be just as natural for them to cringe.

title: Blurring the Line Between a College Application and a Slick Sales Pitch
description: The language is pure Madison Avenue, but it is richly in vogue among paid counselors who advise students on how to make strong impressions with top-flight colleges. Package yourself, they say. Brand yourself.

title: A Star Is Bailed
description: The Bollywood star Sanjay Dutt, above,  was granted bail yesterday and is expected to be released by today, after serving 19 months of a six-year sentence for illegal weapons possession, The Associated Press reported. The Supreme Court in New Delhi agreed to free Mr. Dutt pending its decision on an appeal of his sentence, his attorney said. The actor was sentenced in July for possessing three automatic rifles and a pistol that had been supplied to him by men subsequently convicted in the 1993 Mumbai bombings, which killed 257 people. He was originally arrested on suspicion of involvement in the bombings, but was acquitted of terrorism and conspiracy charges.

title: Bourbons Shot at the Big Time
description: IN the recent history of whiskey, bourbon would seem to have had a lot going for it. Its homegrown, for one thing. Grass-roots acceptance counts for a lot when you are battling for shelf space. Bourbon has always been right up there with college football, Nascar and canned beer  the sort of whiskey that anyone can order without fear of being labeled effete or snobbish.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Science Times on Nov. 20 about the role of denial in nourishing close relationships misstated the title of a book. It is Predictably Irrational: The Hidden Forces That Shape Our Decisions, not Hidden Forced.

title: Supreme Court Is Referee in Delaware River Fight
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  If litigation is war by other means, then the Supreme Court case of New Jersey v. Delaware is nothing less than civil war  the latest battle in a dispute over the two states Delaware River boundary, which has flared up periodically for well over a century.

title: Recipe: Spanish Harlem
description: Adapted from Lucy of Gramercy

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report on Thursday in the Mens College Basketball Preview about the outlook for Georgetown misstated the stage of last seasons N.C.A.A. tournament at which the Hoyas lost. It was the national semifinals, a Final Four matchup against Ohio State, not the title game. (Florida defeated Ohio State for the championship.)

title: Israel and Palestinians Set Goal of a Treaty in 2008
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 27  The Israeli and Palestinian leaders committed themselves on Tuesday to negotiate a peace treaty by the end of 2008, setting a deadline for ending a conflict that has endured for six decades.

title: In an Ever-Changing Galaxy, the Actions Starting to Get Intriguing
description: One of the strengths of an online computer game is that what you see when it first appears is not necessarily what you get if you pick it up years later.

title: Bill Hartack, 74, Champion Jockey, Dies
description: Bill Hartack, a Hall of Fame jockey who was a five-time winner of the Kentucky Derby, died Monday night in Texas while on a hunting vacation. He was 74.

title: A Switch for Exhibition on Black Migration
description: A traveling exhibition of panels from Jacob Lawrences seminal Migration series  scheduled to appear at the Studio Museum in Harlem  has opened instead at the Whitney Museum of American Art because of last-minute problems with the Studio Museums space, officials from both museums said. The 30 paintings, 17 of which are owned by the Phillips Collection in Washington, depict the flight of African-Americans from the rural South to the industrial cities of the North. Thelma Golden, the Studio Museums director and chief curator, said that as she was preparing to install the works, instruments showed that one wall in the exhibition space was undergoing temperature fluctuations that could have threatened the paintings. For me it was very important that the show be in New York, she said, and with the help of the Whitney it is. The show will remain at the Whitney through Jan. 6, then travel to the Mississippi Museum of Art in Jackson before returning to the Phillips.

title: Oasis or Mirage?
description: Annapolis, Md.

title: A Shift in Applications as Early Admission Is Cut
description: When Harvard, Princeton and the University of Virginia announced that they would eliminate early admission starting this fall, many educators wondered whether the decision would alter the strategies of thousands of students seeking a spot at the nations most selective colleges and universities.

title: Red Cross Fires Its President, Citing Relationship
description: The American Red Cross dismissed its president and chief executive, Mark W. Everson, yesterday, citing his personal relationship with a subordinate employee. He had been in office for only six months.

title: With an Eye on Olympics, Lochte Is a Fish, in and Out of Water
description: Does Ryan Lochtes sketch pad contain the blueprint for beating Michael Phelps? Lochtes drawings are as vivid as hallucinations, full of raindrops falling up and fish swimming in the sky.

title: Spitzer, Hat in Hand, Asks Fellow Democrats in the Assembly for a Second Chance
description: At first, Gov. Eliot Spitzer told a packed room of Assembly Democrats yesterday, his wife didnt like him much either.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded: $2,404,555.37

title: Elaine Lorillard, 93, a Founder of the Newport Jazz Festival, Is Dead
description: Elaine Lorillard, a socialite who with her husband, Louis, lured jazz greats to their hometown in Rhode Island for a two-day concert series in the summer of 1954, starting the Newport Jazz Festival and creating the model for what became a worldwide circuit of outdoor jazz festivals, died on Monday near her home in Newport. She was 93.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening this Week

title: Health Care: A National Conversation
description: To the Editor:

title: Chinas Denial of Port Calls by U.S. Ships Worries Navy
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  Two senior American admirals expressed concern on Tuesday over decisions this month by China to refuse access to the port of Hong Kong for three American warships, including two seeking fuel and sheltered waters ahead of a major storm.

title: Broadway Stagehands in Tentative Agreement
description: The 19-day strike by stagehands that had closed most Broadway theaters ended late tonight as a tentative agreement was struck.

title: West Orange: Two Shot Behind Apartments
description: Two men were shot, one fatally, early yesterday behind an apartment complex, the police said. Each man had been shot in the head at point-blank range, the police said. The dead man was identified as Devon Rodriguez, 20. The other man, a 19-year-old, was not identified; he was in critical condition yesterday at University Hospital in Newark. Witnesses reported hearing four shots from behind the complex, the Hutton Arms, before hearing a car speeding away. The shooting took place about four blocks from the home of the State Senate president, Richard J. Codey.

title: Black and Hispanic Firefighter Applicants Have Doubled
description: The Fire Departments pool of black and Hispanic job candidates has more than doubled since 2002, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday, raising hopes that efforts to hire more minority firefighters might be yielding results.

title: Brooklyn: Apartment Building Stairway Collapses
description: Up to 50 residents of an apartment building were displaced from their homes after stairs in an apartment building collapsed last night, officials with the police and the Fire Department said. No one was hurt in the collapse, which occurred about 8 p.m. at 1568 Sterling Place, in the Weeksville neighborhood, the authorities said. The cause of the collapse was under investigation. City agencies helped find temporary housing for the tenants.

title: Greek Court Dismisses Case Against Ex-Curator
description: ATHENS, Nov. 27  An appeals court here dismissed a criminal case on Tuesday against Marion True, a former curator for the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles who had been accused of conspiring to acquire an ancient gold wreath that Greece says was looted from its soil.

title: Bracing for Home Loan Losses, Wells Fargo to Take Big Charge
description: Wells Fargo & Company, the nations second-largest mortgage lender, after Countrywide Financial, said yesterday that it would take a $1.4 billion fourth-quarter charge for losses it anticipated in connection with home loans.

title: Challenging Tradition, Young Jews Worship on Their Terms
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  There are no pews at Tikkun Leil Shabbat, no rabbis, no one with children or gray hair.

title: Herb McKenley, 85, Top Jamaican Runner, Is Dead
description: Herb McKenley, the worlds fastest 400-meter runner more than half a century ago and later the driving force in Jamaicas climb to track and field glory, died Monday in Kingston, Jamaica, where he lived. He was 85.

title: To the Things That Remain
description: YOU always remember your first time, but what about your last?

title: Survivor of Connecticut Home Invasion Urges Stricter Laws
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 27  The man whose wife and two daughters were killed during a night of terror in their Cheshire home appealed to Connecticut legislators on Tuesday to address glaring defects in the criminal justice system that may have opened the door to the accused men last summer.

title: Recipe: Hot Coffee Grog
description: Adapted from Jeff Berry This warm, spicy after-dinner drink is suitable for parties or quiet winter nights.

title: Manhattan: Environmental Tests Downtown
description: Initial tests at 53 apartments and in the common areas of nine buildings within 1,500 feet of ground zero found three dust samples that were contaminated with asbestos above safe levels and 71 samples that were laced with lead that exceeded federal standards, environmental officials said yesterday. The spaces were tested under a controversial program of the Environmental Protection Agency. Since the testing began this year, most of the 5,600 samples the agency has analyzed have fallen below federal benchmarks for exposure. Mary Mears, a spokeswoman for the agency, said that 272 apartments and 25 buildings below Canal Street will be tested within the next year, and any contamination will be cleaned. Complete test results can be seen at www.epa.gov /wtc/testandclean.

title: Nose on the Prize, but Which Oscar to Sniff?
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 27  Eddie Valiant, the hard-nosed private eye played by Bob Hoskins in Who Framed Roger Rabbit, wasnt about to fiddle with animation. Forget it, he said. I dont work Toontown.

title: How the Job Churn Numbers Are Counted
description: The numbers on job churning compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics are based on a quarterly canvass of work sites across the country. The survey includes all of the roughly seven million private-sector work sites that are part of the unemployment-insurance system. These work sites account for 112 million workers.

title: South Korean Leader Allows Inquiry Into Samsung Bribes
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 27  President Roh Moo-hyun of South Korea agreed on Tuesday to an independent investigation into a slush fund and bribery scandal at the Samsung Group, including accusations that he and his aides may have accepted bribes from the conglomerate.

title: Pro Bono Efforts Follow Targets to the Web
description: A NONPROFIT organization founded when The Pride of the Yankees meant a movie about Lou Gehrig, rather than the feelings of a departing manager, is taking a more contemporary tack in selecting the media in which its campaigns appear.

title: Home Prices Post Big Drop in Survey
description: Housing prices fell the most in almost 20 years this summer, and consumers remain deeply skeptical about the economy, according to reports released yesterday.

title: Despite Strike, Carson Daly to Resume Show
description: The NBC talk show Last Call With Carson Daly will resume production today, making it the first late-night program to produce original episodes since the Writers Guild of America went on strike three weeks ago.

title: China Says Three Gorges Dam Is Not Responsible for Landslides
description: BEIJING, Nov. 27  Chinese officials overseeing the Three Gorges Dam defended the projects environmental record on Tuesday and asserted that pressure from rising waters in the dams reservoir was not to blame for any major geological problems or disasters in the region.

title: Defending Rights, He Said He Was Marked to Die
description: The assassins name was Panther. He had a stocky 5-foot 8-inch frame. Though he was only 26, a look of hatred was encrusted on his face.

title: A Battle-Scarred Edwards, Emerging a Fighter
description: MILFORD, N.H.  He has beat his Diet Coke addiction  too much caffeine. He no longer shrinks from foreign policy talk and salts his speeches with lines like, I saw a piece recently in the Guardian newspaper, a British newspaper. And where he once meandered from topic to topic, the John Edwards of today tries to keep it concise.

title: Palestinian Is Killed in Hebron as Police Disperse Protest Over Mideast Peace Talks
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 27  A Palestinian man was killed Tuesday in Hebron on the West Bank as Palestinian Authority police officers loyal to President Mahmoud Abbas fired weapons to disperse protests against the Middle East peace conference taking place in Annapolis, Md.

title: For a Communal Meal, One Pot, Many Cultures
description: THERE is no more communal dish than hot pot, which goes by various names, like horhog (Mongolia), huoguo (China) and shabu shabu (Japan). You cut up some meat and vegetables, set a heated pot in the center of the table, fill it with seasoned water or stock and let your guests take over.

title: One-Year Term for Oilman Convicted in Iraq Kickbacks
description: Oscar S. Wyatt Jr., the self-made Texas oilman who pleaded guilty in October to violating the rules of the United Nations oil-for-food program, was sentenced yesterday to a year and a day in prison, half the maximum penalty he faced under federal sentencing guidelines.

title: Jump on the Peace Train
description: WASHINGTON

title: The Best of Bad Sex
description: Norman Mailer won The Literary Reviews Bad Sex in Fiction Award, becoming the first posthumously honored author, Bloomberg News reported yesterday. The judges paid tribute to a notable coupling in The Castle in the Forest, Mailers novel about Hitler. We are sure that he would have taken the prize in good humor, the judges said of Mailer, who died this month at age 84. Among this years eight finalists were a lusty automaton in Jeanette Wintersons Stone Gods, a Russian oligarch in Gary Shteyngarts Absurdistan and a breathless Shakespeare in Christopher Rushs Will. Other finalists included Clare Clark, for The Nature of Monsters, Richard Milward for Apples and David Thewliss Late Hector Kipling, about an artist who dabbles in S & M.

title: Recipe: Zombie Punch
description: Adapted from Jeff Berry Mr. Berry believes that this recipe, found in a waiters notebook, is the original Zombie introduced at Don the Beachcombers in 1934.

title: Rewritten, in a Language of Its Own
description: MORE than a few chefs have spent more than a little time trying to turn carpaccio into an intricate production that reflects and trumpets their ingenuity.

title: Some Big Bets That the Funky Bowery Can Be Luxe
description: The Bowery might sound like the last place in Manhattan where you would go to pick out a new designer suit, dine at a chic restaurant or stay in a $1,200 hotel suite. But much of the old Bowery is being swept away faster than you can say skid row, and new high-end offerings are on the horizon.

title: Wedding a Blur? Heres the Recipe
description: AT my wedding I had weightier matters to focus on than sampling every hors doeuvre. But then I heard that the sugared bacon my friend Shawn Kelley had brought was devoured before the ceremony. After listening to wistful descriptions of the caramelized porky strips that stood tall in a glass until they crunched in the mouth, I felt deprived  until I asked Shawn for the recipe.

title: Antarctic Voyage
description: To the Editor:

title: Lottery Numbers
Googles Next Frontier: Renewable Energy
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 27  Google, the Internet company with a seemingly limitless source of revenue, plans to get into the business of finding limitless sources of energy.

title: Car Bomb Attack Kills 2 in Afghan Capital
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 27  A huge car bomb exploded in a residential district of Kabul that is used by foreign diplomats and international organizations, killing two civilians and wounding four others, the police said. Two vehicles in a United States military convoy were damaged, but no servicemen were killed or wounded, said a military spokesman, Col. David Johnson.

title: Nixon Papers Recall Concerns on Israels Weapons
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  In July 1969, while the world was spellbound by the Apollo 11 mission to the moon, President Richard M. Nixon and his close advisers were quietly fretting about a possible nuclear arms race in the Middle East. Their main worry was not a potential enemy of the United States, but one of Americas closest friends.

title: Patriots Lose Colvin to Foot Injury for Rest of Season
description: The New England Patriots, whose undefeated start has been largely free of serious injuries, absorbed their first big jolt yesterday, when the starting outside linebacker Rosevelt Colvin was placed on injured reserve with a foot injury.

title: Recipe: Hong Kong Spare Ribs
description: Adapted from Bruce Aidellss Complete Book of Pork, by Bruce Aidells with Lisa Weiss (HarperCollins, 2004)

title: Indexes Up Sharply on Some Good News
description: Stock markets snapped back yesterday as promising news on credit and oil emerged from the Middle East, offering investors some reassurance about two recent trouble spots.

title: To Muslim Girls, Scouts Offer a Chance to Fit In
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Sometimes when Asma Haidara, a 12-year-old Somali immigrant, wants to shop at Target or ride the Minneapolis light-rail system, she puts her Girl Scout sash over her everyday clothes, which usually include a long skirt worn over pants as well as a swirling head scarf.

title: O.J. Simpson Pleads Not Guilty
description: LAS VEGAS, Nov. 28  O.J. Simpson pleaded not guilty today to a dozen charges, including kidnapping and armed robbery, stemming from a confrontation in a hotel room here on Sept. 13.

title: A Cultural Critics Restless Last Night
description: If one views the growing work as a blazing pyre, its commentator can be likened to the chemist, its critic to an alchemist, Walter Benjamin once wrote. While the former is left with wood and ashes as the sole objects of his analysis, the latter is concerned only with the enigma of the flame itself.

title: Stocks Rebound on Citigroup Deal and Oil News
description: Stock markets snapped back today after promising news emerged from the Middle East.

title: U.N. Official Criticizes Sudan for Resisting Peace Force in Darfur
description: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 27  The United Nations top peacekeeping official said Tuesday that obstacles created by the Sudanese government were jeopardizing the deployment of the joint African Union-United Nations force in Darfur.

title: Cable Industry Wins Compromise on F.C.C. Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  In the face of a lobbying blitzkrieg by the cable television industry, the Federal Communications Commission drastically scaled back Tuesday evening a proposal by the agencys chairman to more tightly regulate the industry.

title: China Rejects Europes Call for Currency to Rise Faster
description: BEIJING, Nov. 27  China signaled Tuesday that it would resist European demands for rapid appreciation of the yuan and would instead continue gradual progress toward a more flexible exchange rate.

title: Authorities Search for Killer of Redskins Taylor
description: MIAMI, Nov. 27  The authorities searched Tuesday for the killer of Washington Redskins safety Sean Taylor, who died early in the morning after he was shot by an intruder at his home south of the city.

title: Mugabe Says He Will Attend Meeting With Europeans
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 27  President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe said Tuesday that he would attend a summit meeting of European and African leaders next week, a move guaranteed to provoke divisions over human rights and a boycott by Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain.

title: Data Seen as Favorable for Abbotts Proposed Heart Stent
description: The data continues to be favorable for Abbott Laboratories new drug-coated heart stent, Xience V, which the company is hoping will win federal approval.

title: Iran: New Long-Range Missile
description: The defense minister, Mostafa Mohammad Najjar, said Iran had built a new long-range missile. In comments reported by the Fars news agency, he said the missile had range of 1,200 miles. He did not say how the missile, called Ashoura, differed from the Shahab-3, also with a range of 1,200 miles, or if it had been test fired.

title: Starting From Annapolis
description: The American-led Annapolis peace conference achieved the minimum  a pledge by Israel and the Palestinians to begin immediate negotiations with a goal of reaching a peace treaty by the end of 2008.

title: Details of Shifting Story Emerge in 5th Ave. Death
description: At first, according to court documents released yesterday, Natavia S. Lowery told investigators that her last day with her boss, Linda Stein, had been a normal one. She did Ms. Steins makeup and hair, laid out her clothes and helped with her work, she told detectives on Nov. 8, nine days after Ms. Stein, a prominent real estate broker, was found bludgeoned to death in the living room of her Fifth Avenue apartment.

title: Nascar Driver Taking Antidrug Message on the Road
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 27 (AP)  The Nascar driver Aaron Fike understands where he was headed when he was arrested while shooting heroin in an amusement park parking lot this summer.

title: A Loss for Privacy Rights
description: The Constitution protects individuals against unreasonable searches, but for this protection to have practical meaning, the courts must enforce it. This week, the Supreme Court let stand a disturbing ruling out of California that allows law enforcement to barge into peoples homes without a warrant. The case has not prompted much outrage, perhaps because the people whose privacy is being invaded are welfare recipients, but it is a serious setback for the privacy rights of all Americans.

title: Marbury Hasnt Won Since His Breakup With Garnett
description: Stephon Marbury was all smiles as he left the Knicks locker room, shuffled down a dim hallway and ducked through double doors to meet a crowd of friends and family late Monday night. There was no wrecking Marburys mood at this moment.

title: Mitchells Report Due Before End of Year
description: George J. Mitchells report on the use of performance-enhancing drugs in Major League Baseball will be issued before the end of the year, a spokesman for Mitchell said yesterday, confirming speculation about the timing of the report.

title: On the Way to the Common Good, Delegates Found Words That Still Apply
description: For those of us interested in the promise of the American Constitution and also in its imperfections, it is a happy coincidence that these two volumes have appeared at the same time, for they nicely complement each other.

title: Elevating Show Tunes Into American Art Songs
description: You can take the girl out of Texas, but you cant take Texas out of the girl. For the singer and actress Victoria Clark, that is a good thing. Although fortified by a fancy music-theater education that carried her to Austria to study opera, fundamental true grit that smacks of her hometown, Dallas, seeps through her impeccable musical training.

title: U.N. Warns of Climate-Related Setbacks
description: A new United Nations report warns that progress toward prosperity in the worlds poorest regions will be reversed unless rich countries promptly begin curbing emissions linked to global warming while also helping poorer ones leapfrog to energy sources that pollute less than coal and oil.

title: Brooklyn: Ex-Prosecutor Charged With Leaks
description: A former assistant district attorney in Brooklyn was charged yesterday with providing information about prosecution witnesses to a defense lawyer who is now her husband, prosecutors said. The former prosecutor, Sandra Fernandez, 35, of Queens, was charged with official misconduct and with offering a false instrument for filing, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, who acted as a special prosecutor in the matter. Mr. Brown said in a statement that Ms. Fernandez, who worked in the office for more than five years until she was fired in February, obtained confidential criminal histories on two prosecution witnesses in cases in which the defense lawyer was her then-fianc.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Film Garlands From the Gothams

title: Oral Roberts U. and President Part Ways
description: DALLAS, Nov. 27  Oral Roberts Universitys regents announced Tuesday that they would legally and financially separate the university from the ministry headed by Richard Roberts, the television evangelist accused last month in a lawsuit of tapping university and ministry money to finance a lavish lifestyle .

title: Musharraf Quits Pakistani Army Post
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, Nov. 28  President Pervez Musharraf resigned his military post as chief of army staff today, handing over the baton of command to his successor in a ceremony at Pakistans army headquarters and ending his eight years of military rule. He remains president and will be sworn in to a new five-year term in the capital on Thursday, but as a civilian president his grip on power is expected to loosen in coming months.

title: Calendar
description: The Dogs of Winter

title: Panel Rebukes Judge, Citing Lunacy in Court
description: The next time you pass through the city court system in Niagara Falls, N.Y., remember to turn your cellphone off.

title: Porsche to Wait Until Holidays End to Take Over Volkswagen
description: STUTTGART, Germany, Nov. 27  Porsche is bestowing an early Christmas present on the workers at Volkswagen: a pledge not to take over their company, at least before the holidays.

title: In Iowa, Mormon Issue Is Benefiting Huckabee
description: The religious divide over Mitt Romneys Mormon faith that his supporters had long feared would occur is emerging in Iowa as he is being challenged in state polls by Mike Huckabee, a former Baptist pastor who has played up his faith in his bid for the Republican presidential nomination.

title: Senate Race That Fizzled Honed Skills for 08
description: By the time Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York stepped before a wall of television crews in the Public Hearing Room at City Hall on May 19, 2000, there were no surprises left.

title: Cyclings Drug Problem Leads T-Mobile to End Sponsorship
description: T-Mobile, the professional cycling team that began this year with the sports largest budget and an ambitious plan to reform the sports drug problem, lost its sponsor yesterday because of continuing doping controversies.

title: Bill Clinton Flatly Asserts He Opposed War at Start
description: During a campaign swing for his wife, former President Bill Clinton said flatly yesterday that he opposed the war in Iraq from the beginning  a statement that is more absolute than his comments before the invasion in March 2003.

title: The Solar Wawas: Not a Happy Family
description: Our judges need your help in the Solar-Twin Naming Contest. Theyve been sorting the many nominations for the name and accompanying myth for the Sun-like star in the constellation Draco. Now Jorge Melendez, one of the two Peruvian astronomers who discovered this twin, has submitted a myth to go with the Quechua name, Intipa Awachan, suggested by his collaborator, Ivan Ramirez.

title: The Genius of America
description: THE MORE FATAL PROBLEM LIES AMONG THE PEOPLE THEMSELVES

title: Dow Jones Considers Selling 23 Papers
description: Dow Jones, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, said Tuesday that it was considering the sale of the rest of the Ottaway community newspaper group.

title: Porsche to Wait Until Holidays End to Take Over Volkswagen
description: Porsche is bestowing an early Christmas present on the workers at Volkswagen: a pledge not to take over their company, at least before the holidays.

title: Japans Astellas to Buy Agensys
description: In what might be the hottest sector of the drug industry, another biotech firm is now off the table. Japans second-largest drugmaker, Astellas Pharma, said Tuesday that it would buy Agensys of Santa Monica, Calif., to add biologic drugs to its pipeline.

title: Qwaq Suits Up With $7 Million Round
description: Much like Second Life, Qwaq Forums uses animated avatars representing users to populate 3-D office spaces, complete with rotating fans and potted plants. Only instead of being a time killer, Qwaq Forums aims to actually increase productivity by allowing clients to skip those long flights and stuffy conference rooms and let their avatars take the meeting for them.

title: Private Equity Firm Cressy Nabs Frist as Partner
description: Cressey & Company, a recently formed private equity firm focused on the health care industry, said the former Senate Majority Leader, Bill Frist, a doctor by training, has agreed to join the Chicago-based firm as a partner.

title: Wheeling-Pitt Investors Approve Esmark Deal
description: Steelmaker Wheeling-Pittsburgh and steel distributor Esmark said their shareholders approved the merger of the two companies.

title: Xiotech Adds $40 Million to Its Coffers
description: Xiotech, a data-storage provider, announced Tuesday that it had secured $40 million in mostly equity financing from a group led by Steve Luczo, the chairman of Seagate Technology, who is joining the board of Eden Prairie, Minn.-based Xiotech.

title: More Headaches for Zell as Tribune Reports Drop in Revenue
description: Tribune, which is in the process of going private through a deal with the real-estate magnate Samuel Zell, reported a 9.3 percent decline in revenue during October on Tuesday as advertising continued to slump at its broadcast and publishing segments.

title: Googles Next Frontier: Renewable Energy
description: Google, the Internet company with a seemingly limitless source of revenue, plans to get into the business of finding limitless sources of energy.

title: Frances Thales Puts Merger Plans on Hold
description: Proposals for a merger between Thales, the French defense electronics group, and security and aerospace equipment conglomerate Safran have been shelved, according to the chairman of Thales.

title: PPR Mulls Swap for Clarins Stake, Report Says
description: Shareholders in Clarins might need to reach for the companys famous creams to smooth out some recently acquired worry lines.

title: With Merger Talk in Vogue, UALs Tilton Feels Vindication
description: The head of United Airlines parent company said Tuesday he no longer feels like a voice in the wilderness in arguing that airlines must consider consolidation to withstand competitive challenges, including rising fuel costs.

title: The Naked and the Awful
description: Norman Mailer won The Literary Reviews Bad Sex in Fiction Award, becoming the first posthumously honored author. The judges paid tribute to a notable coupling (discretion advised) in The Castle in the Forest, Mailers novel about Hitler. We are sure that he would have taken the prize in good humor, the judges said of Mailer, who died this month at 84. Read more on the awards (fifth item).

title: UBS Shares Rise on Speculation of Stake Sale
description: Shares in UBS powered higher on Wednesday on speculation that Asian or Gulf-based investors might target European banks whose stock has weakened in the wake of the subprime crisis. The speculation was prompted by Citigroups $7.5 billion stake sale to Abu Dhabis sovereign wealth fund.

title: Absolute Capital Hires Outsider for Review
description: Absolute Capital, an Australian hedge fund that suspended withdrawals because of the turmoil in credit markets, has appointed an outside administrator to review the business, the company said Tuesday.

title: British Hedge Fund Hires Lawyer for Litigation Investments
description: A British hedge fund has hired a former litigator to invest $100 million in European legal disputes, in what The Times of London says is believed to be the first formal arrangement of its kind.

title: Gotham Awards: Indier Than Thou
description: The Gothams last night had significant virtues. Into the Wild, and Before the Devil Knows Youre Dead, two of the evenings big winners, represent both the cantankerousness of the indie genre and its enduring value. And there was something sort of remarkable about holding the whole shindig at Steiner Studios. Yeah, it was a schlep and the Bagger commuted home in a car full of Manhattanites who all had strong opinions about how to get out of Brooklyn even though none of them any idea of what they were talking about.

title: 2 Small Hedge Funds Merge
description: Two small hedge funds have merged in a rare deal as tiny investment pools, watching giants such as the Citadel Investment Group prepare  to post returns of up to 27 percent for the year, huddle together looking for better returns.

title: Wells Fargo to Take Big Charge on Loan Losses
description: Wells Fargo & Company, the nations second-largest mortgage lender, said Tuesday that it would take a $1.4 billion fourth-quarter charge for losses it anticipated in connection with home loans.

title: Mideast Funds Go on Global Shopping Spree
description: Flush with petrodollars, oil-producing countries are buying up assets all over the world. The Abu Dhabi Investment Authoritys $7.5 billion investment in Citigroup is just the latest example, and its not likely to be the last.

title: Citi Said to Reject Proposal for BofA Merger
description: Was Bank of America, known for its acquisitive streak, considering swallowing rival behemoth Citigroup?

title: While Were Talking About Branding
description: A savvy reader pointed out that on the same day that I linked to a smart post by Pamela Slim, an entrepreneur/blogger/consultant, she blogged about how successful branding needs to have a clear and focused message. What does that mean for all those slashes (the consultant/cartoonist, the lawyer/filmmakers) I write about, asked the savvy reader?

title: Carlyle Raises First Infrastructure Fund
description: The Carlyle Group, the private equity firm, has raised its first infrastructure fund, which is focused on North America, where the company believes public-private partnerships will increase. Common in Europe, these arrangements involve private companies that deliver and run public assets such as roads, schools and hospitals.

title: NYSE Euronext Expects More Secondary Listings
description: The transatlantic exchange NYSE Euronext expects United States companies with New York Stock Exchange listings to seek secondary listings in Amsterdam, a Dutch newspaper quoted a NYSE Euronext board member as saying on Wednesday.

title: The Early Word: G.O.P.s Turn for CNN/YouTube Forum
description: Sanctuary cities  referring to towns that harbor illegal aliens  likely will be a hot topic tonight at the CNN/YouTube debate between G.O.P. candidates, who are looking to paint their opponents as soft conservatives, writes Brian C. Mooney of the Boston Globe.

title: Gotham Awards: Getting Dude-ed at the Gothams
description: As Juno, Canadian actress Ellen Page described her characters ill-timed pregnancy as an affliction, a kind of slow-moving body snatch. The awards season, too, will make the business of daily living seem a bit like a kidnapping. Ms. Page, who will be spending the next several months on carpets hither and yon answering the same inane questions about inhabiting a pregnant teen character, is more skate punk than Valley Girl, and is always cracking wise.

title: A Helluva Lot for a LinkedIn Sale?
description: Tongues were wagging earlier this week on speculation that the News Corporation would buy LinkedIn, the professionals-oriented social network, early next year. (Never mind that the rumors were thinly sourced.)

title: Mr. Picasso Head
description: An interactive cubist time-waster diversion.

title: Only at "T": The New Museum
description: Exclusive tour of New York's New Museum of Contemporary Art.

title: It's All About...Hiroshi Sugimoto
description: The acclaimed photographer discusses his work, including his first-ever fashion commission for T.

title: All the 'T' in China
description: Fendi and Karl Lagerfeld turn the Great Wall of China into the world's largest catwalk.

title: S.E.C. Expected to Limit Proxy Access
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to adopt a proposal Wednesday that allows companies to bar shareholders from access to ballots for board elections. Some major pension funds and governance advocates said the move could make corporations less responsive to investors.

title: The Republican Debate
description: Following is a transcript of the Republican Presidential debate in St. Petersburg, Fla., as provided by the Federal News Service.

title: In Court, Astors Son Denies Charges
description: The top local story in todays newspapers is the court appearance of Anthony D. Marshall, who pleaded not guilty on Tuesday to charges of stealing millions of dollars and valuable property from his mother, Brooke Astor, the philanthropist and socialite, after she was found to have Alzheimers disease. Among the charges against Mr. Marshall, who had been his mothers salaried financial adviser: scheme to defraud, grand larceny, criminal possession of stolen property and falsifying business records.

title: Advice for Meeting-Weary Mideast Peace Talkers
description: Tuesdays kickoff of the Mideast peace conference in Annapolis, Md., raised hopes for a final settlement, but now the real work will begin, in countless meeting rooms and on conference calls, not to mention frequent visits by American mediators.

title: May the force be with them
description: Or at least a little Kingfisher beer. I know its a corny headline and that it will be used again and again and again in stories relating to Force India. But todays announcement by that team does call for something like that headline.

title: Bill Clintons War Dance
description: During a campaign swing for his wife, former President Bill Clinton said flatly yesterday that he opposed the war in Iraq from the beginning  a statement that is more absolute than his comments before the invasion in March 2003, reports The Timess Patrick Healy.

title: Wildfire Danger in Southern California Today
description: The National Weather Services red flags are flying again in Southern California, and they are being whipped by the Santa Ana winds that were merciless during late Octobers blazes. A severe warning of fire risk is in effect until 10 p.m. Eastern time for much of the region.

title: Wednesday Kickoff: The B.C.S. vs. Playoff Argument
description: We open today with an age-old argument: What would be better, the B.C.S. or a playoff system? The Tennesseans Joe Biddle is clearly on the side of the playoffs. Meanwhile, David Whitley of the Orlando Sentinel writes that people should simply sit back and enjoy the B.C.S. madness.

title: Romes stray cats
description: By Elisabetta Povoledo

title: The Social Security obsession, again
description: By any reasonable standard, Social Security is at most a second-tier policy issue.

title: A Message in Volatility
description: The stock market is up today. Assuming that holds, we will end the rotation of big days at four. (Up 1 percent one day, down 1 percent the next, and so on.)

title: Food Stuff
description: If It's Frozen and Comes in a Box, Is It Really a Latke?

title: Blankfein Tops Buffett in Fortunes Power List
description: Goldman Sachs Lloyd C. Blankfein has lapped his rivals at other investment banks this year. But who knew he would outshine Warren E. Buffett, the legendary investor, and the three guys behind the Internet giant Google?

title: Google Doesnt Know Where You Are (But It Has a Good Guess)
description: UPDATE: See comment from Google at the end.

title: How Badly Do the Yankees Want Santana?
description: As they prepare for the winter meetings in Nashville next week, the paramount question for the Yankees is how badly do they want Johan Santana?

title: Wall Street Research, Made in India
description: Wall Street firms are cutting costs and tightening belts these days  just try ordering a new BlackBerry at Bank of America. This could accelerate a cost-cutting trend that was already gaining momentum: The outsourcing of junior research and investment banking activities to India, where analysis and pitchbooks come far more cheaply than in the United States.

title: Please Please Me, Like I Please You
description: Enough crying about the schedule already. The N.H.L.s board of governors, which will meet Thursday in Pebble Beach, Calif., will attempt to fix it and be done with the whole subject for a while. But it will not be soon enough to quiet Canadian fans, who blame N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman for the lockout, low scoring, no team in Hamilton, a team in Nashville, Versus and the schedule (And if the loonie heads south while Bettman is in office, count on the commissioner taking a bit of a hit for that one, too.

title: The Strike: Almost Over, Or Just Begun?
description: For three weeks, Writers Guild of America members circled the picket lines while union leaders and the studio heads stood on the sidelines.

title: Giving and Receiving
description: A couple of trends are clear in todays list of holiday gifts in the Dining section.

title: SEC vs. the Other Conferences: A Look at the Evidence
description: I saw the comments made by the analyst and oddsmaker Danny Sheridan in the Times about the Southeastern Conference and the alleged imbalance among the other B.C.S. conferences, which he said handicapped the SEC in the national championship race.

title:
Living With Music:
A Playlist by Stephen Elliott
description: On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for Living With Music, a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage.

title: Fat Boys and Dreamliners, but No Mustangs?
description: ROME  Airbus, the giant Europe-based aircraft maker, complained this week that its American archrival, Boeing, is killing us.

title: Disturbing the Peace?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Log-rolling in Our Time
description: After live-blogging the Gothams last night to mixed effect  he got the name of the winning movie, Into the Wild wrong for a few minutes  the Bagger was sort of played out. Perhaps it was the final stop of the evening, at the Tick Tock diner on Route 3 in New Jersey, where he flyspecked the copy he had put up and finally ate something. If there is a place psychically more distant from the glamour of the Gothams than the Tick Tock, the Bagger has never been there. It is the kind of joint where third-string mafiosi go to profile, being careful not to park in that one spot where Uncle Vinny was probably buried under the asphalt some time ago. The food, though, is wonderful and if its good enough for the real-life Sopranos, it is good enough for the Bagger.

title: More Late Night Jokes From Readers
description: Send your jokes via the comment link below:

title: When the 6-Year-Old Artists Came to Sothebys
description: When a Harlem school official sat down with a Sothebys executive in May to plan an exhibit of her first graders art at the famed auction house, one of the issues he brought up was insurance.

title: Does Bloch Feel Roves Pain?
description: Foxes and henhouses, etc. The head of the federal agency investigating Karl Roves White House political operation is facing allegations that he improperly deleted computer files during another probe, using a private computer-help company, Geeks on Call, reports The Wall Street Journals John R. Wilke.Scott Bloch runs the Office of Special Counsel, an agency charged with protecting government whistleblowers and enforcing a ban on federal employees engaging in partisan political activity. Mr. Blochs agency is looking into whether Mr. Rove and other White House officials used government agencies to help re-elect Republicans in 2006. At the same time, Mr. Bloch has himself been under investigation since 2005. At the direction of the White House, the federal Office of Personnel Managements inspector general is looking into claims hat Mr. Bloch improperly retaliated against employees and dismissed whistleblower cases without adequate examination.

title: Q & A: Approval Ratings, Pessimism and Annapolis
description: As the Middle East peace process restarts down in Annapolis, Md., The Lede asked one of The New York Timess resident experts to answer a few questions. Ethan Bronner is deputy foreign editor until next year, when he will move back to Jerusalem as bureau chief. Mr. Bronner was the Jerusalem correspondent for The Boston Globe from 1991 to 1997 and for Reuters from 1983 to 1985.

title: When a Poll Changes the Way People Think About the Race
description: In her Web column today, Janet Elder writes about last weeks ABC News/Washington Post Poll of Iowa caucus goers.

title: Its a Plan!
description: Late last week, our architect Laura Gee e-mailed us a revised set of house plans, but with the rush of Thanksgiving preparations, Paul and I didnt have a chance to give them more than a passing glance. Over the weekend, we sat down at the kitchen table to take a closer look.

title: Its Lonely at the Coliseum
description: Announced attendance for the Islanders-Stars game Monday night: 8,161.

title: Rangers Lose Avery Again
description: Rangers forward and prime agitator Sean Avery will undergo arthroscopic surgery to his left wrist Thursday afternoon, he said after practice Wednesday at the Rangers practice facility in Greenburgh. Neither Avery nor team officials had any timetable for how long he would be out of action. Hopefully it will only be a week or two, Avery said.

title: In Real Estate, Even Smart Money Got Burned
description: If you are nursing losses on real estate deals, heres a small piece of consolation: Some of Wall Streets hotshot investors seem to have made similar mistakes.

title: If White House Walls Could Talk
description: On Monday, I put out a call asking if anyone overheard what President Bush and former Vice President Al Gore discussed after the White House photo op honoring American Nobel Prize winners. Mr. Gore told The Times that the

title: When Surgeons Cut the Wrong Body Part
description: It sounds like something out of a horror movie, but wrong-sided surgery happens more often than you think.

title: Can New York Be Too Successful?
description: Has New York Citys remarkable economic expansion of the past decade been too much of a good thing? A panel of developers took up this question on Tuesday night in a panel discussion organized by the Municipal Art Society, with the title The Oversuccessful City, Part 1: Developers Realities.Not surprisingly, no one really argued that the city could be too successful. Instead, the often spirited discussion  which at times seemed dominated by angry members of the audience  focused on the dilemmas of affordable housing and out-of-scale development. Projects like Atlantic Yards and the redevelopment of the Far West Side came up. Charles V. Bagli, who covers economic development for The Times, moderated the discussion.

title: A Casualty in the Atlantic Yards Battle
description: The Brooklyn borough president, Marty Markowitz, has named a local community board chairwoman to the City Planning Commission, following the political downfall of his previous appointee, Dolly Williams, a self-inflicted casualty of the Atlantic Yards battle. Ms. Williams agreed last month to a $4,000 fine from the city Conflicts of Interest Board, the board announced Tuesday, settling a complaint over a crucial zoning vote that paved the way for the Brooklyn mega-project in 2004. The planning commission is a 13-member body whose part-time commissioners are paid $48,000 per year to oversee zoning and urban renewal, subject to approval of the City Council.

title: Cocktails of the South Pacific
description: You may laugh at drinks with umbrellas in them but Jeff Beachbum Berry doesnt. While you slowly sink beneath the tiki bar, hes working to elevate the Zombie and the Mai Tai into the cultural pantheon, as the

title: Well, Can I Use My Cell in My Cell?
description: An upstate New York judge who detained 46 people in his courtroom when a cell phone call interrupted proceedings was removed from the bench Tuesday. The phone rang while Niagara Falls City Court Judge Robert Restaino was hearing domestic violence cases. Everyone is going to jail, Restaino said. Every single person is going to jail in this courtroom unless I get that instrument now. Read more.

title: Hip-Hop D.J., Fired for Threats, Returns to Airwaves
description: Updated, 3:54 p.m. | Don Imus is not the only shock jock to make a comeback from disgrace.

title: Bear Stearns to Cut 650 Jobs
description: Bear Stearns, the investment bank, is eliminating 650 jobs, or 4 percent of its workforce, as it seeks to lower costs after losing bets on risky subprime mortgages. Bloomberg News said a majority of the cuts would be in the firms fixed-income business; the Associated Press said cuts would likely come from the operations side, which includes information technology and legal departments.

title: Ashcroft Takes Waterboarding Bait  To No Avail
description: On Tuesday night, former Attorney General John D. Ashcroft became the latest backer of waterboarding to face a stirring moral appeal that came from the Bible, and may be written into our genes: Do unto others as you would have them do unto you.

title: The Top 10
description: Look here for a list of the Book Reviews Top 10 Books of 2007.

title: Blue Crush
description: Im spectacularly late to this sublime surfing video from YouTube. But its the first video from that site that has me fantasizing about setting it up in my living room, on some Bravia plasma screen, at obnoxious Anselm Kiefer size.

title: Answers From the Urban Rodentologist
description: Following is a first set of answers from Robert M. Corrigan, a well-known urban rodentologist and research scientist for the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene who is taking questions on the City Room blog this week. Readers are invited to submit additional questions using the comment link below.

title: Almost 25 Million Watch The Dancing With the Stars Conclusion
description: Nearly 25 million viewers tuned in for final results of ABCs Dancing With the Stars on Tuesday, according to Nielsens estimates, the largest audience for the series this season but less than the fall finale a year ago. The two-hour show, which followed a rebroadcast of the Charlie Brown Christmas special at 8 p.m. (which drew 13.6 million viewers), helped put ABC on top of the nights ratings overall.

title: Media-Coaching Mr. Schwarzman
description: Nearly five months after the Blackstone Group went public, Stephen A. Schwarzman finally spoke out in defense of his firm and the private equity industry. But at least a few observers thought that the speech was a little too defensive and more than a little too late.

title: Report: Giuliani Billed City Agencies for Trips
description: The Politicos Ben Smith takes a look at previously undisclosed records that indicate Rudolph W. Giuliani billed obscure city agencies  including agencies responsible for regulating loft apartments, aiding the disabled and providing lawyers for indigent defendants  for tens of thousands of dollars in security expenses amassed during the time when he was beginning an extramarital relationship with future wife Judith Nathan in the Hamptons.

title: Bertuzzi Returns and Leaves Quietly
description: While you were sleeping on Tuesday night, Todd Bertuzzi came back to Vancouver for the first time since 2006, when he was traded to Florida for Roberto Luongo. And while reports indicate that he said all the right things, he left town as a minus player in Anaheims 4-0 loss to the Canucks.

title: Pledge of Allegiance
description: Open primaries  in which voters dont have to be a member of a party to vote for its candidates  have long been a thorn in the sides of national Democrats and Republicans. Now, according to the Associated Press, Virginias G.O.P. is going to do something about it: If youre planning to vote in Virginias February Republican presidential primary, be prepared to sign an oath swearing your Republican loyalty. The State Board of Elections on Monday approved a state Republican Party request to require all who apply for a G.O.P. primary ballot first vow in writing that theyll vote for the partys presidential nominee next fall.

title: What It Takes to Make a Sandwich
description: It is becoming easier for those of us who are conscientious diners to figure out where and how ingredients were grown. But learning the social provenance of food, or, in this case, of a sandwich, is often more challenging.

title: Lolcats on 24
description: Writers strike? Hah! With funny cats and other free, high-quality Internet content filling in the plot and character gaps, its no problemo:

title: The Multi-Purpose Room
description: If you have read this blog for even 12 seconds, you know my co-author is very, very smart. She proved it again yesterday, by solving a problem that has been (vaguely) bothering me from the beginning.

title: European Writers Show Support
description: The Associated Press reports:

title: Chairman Ben and Chairman Mao
description: Chairman Mao once led a campaign called Let a Hundred Flowers Bloom, which encouraged dissent. Is Chairman Ben running a similar operation?

title: City Moves to Put Parking Regulations Online
description: Updated, 6:18 p.m. | The City Council today passed a bill that would require the Transportation Department to create a searchable Web site with detailed, block-by-block parking regulations around the city, an attempt to mitigate the confusion that often arises from parking signs that are unclear or seem to be inconsistent.

title: Holding an Open House? Hiding Valuables May Not Be Enough
description: Even before two women were charged on Monday with wearing disguises, sneaking into open houses and looting expensive apartments in some of the citys most elegant buildings on the Upper East Side, real estate agents had gone on the alert.

title: Its Still Pork Time In Washington  Time to Fund the First Lady Museum
description: When Democrats took control of Congress, they pledged to reduce the use of earmarks  budget allocations inserted by individual Congress members that often end up as pork.

title: Is Nuclear Fusion an Answer to Climate Change?
description: My last posting was on a technology (carbon capture and sequestration) that seems to promise more than it can deliver within a time period that could help the planet avoid some of the worst ravages of climate change.

title: Russian Politics
description: Two campaign commercials for the United Russia party.

title: Hawaii's Colt Brennan
description: Hawaii Quarterback Colt Brennan sustains a concusion against Fresno State on November 10th, 2007.

title: Stanford's Tavita Pritchard
description: Stanford quarterback Tavita Pritchard sustained a concussion against Notre Dame on Nov. 24. (Courtesy: ESPN)

title: Sundance Rolls Out Its Picks
description: Sundance has unveiled its 2008 schedule, and David M. Halbfinger, the Baggers colleague, is reporting in  from Beverly Hills, no less  with a nifty run-down on the doings in Redford-land. The piece will be in the paper tomorrow, but readers are invited to place their fingers on the festivals pulse now.

title: How About Those Knicks?
description: What we are reading elsewhere

title: NYers Prepared for the Dance
description: In search of that elusive New York angle for Sundance? The Reeler found plenty in todays announcement of the slate for this years festival that redounds to the benefit of the New York film community.

title: Pathway to Less Polarized Politics?
description: Party polarization is the historical norm, not the exception, said Pietro Nivola, vice president of the Brookings Institution, a Washington think tank.

title: Survey Sees Rise in Childrens Asthma From 9/11 Dust
