description: A survey of post-9/11 effects on children released today found that children exposed to the dust cloud following the collapse of the twin towers were twice as likely to be diagnosed with asthma as those not caught in the dust cloud.In general, children under 5 years old had an elevated likelihood of being diagnosed with asthma in the two to three years after the event, though not as sharp an increase as the rescue workers (who were 12 times as likely to be diagnosed as the general population). The survey did not reveal evidence of elevated levels of post-traumatic stress in children.

title: The Late Show Dilemma
description: Come Monday, will Carson Daly be the only late-night talk show host back on television?

title: Democrats Cancel CBS Debate
description: The Democratic National Committee, finding itself in the middle of labor disputes between television writers and CBS, announced this evening that it was canceling the debate among Democratic presidential candidates that had been scheduled to be broadcast on some of the networks stations on Dec. 10, Bill Carter reports.

title: Shorting Bond Insurers for Charity
description: William Ackman has never lacked for confidence in his bets on companies like Target and McDonalds. Now, he seems so assured of his bet against bond insurers that he says he will donate the more than $500 million he expects to earn from those short positions to charity.

title: Zombie ideas about income mobility
description: Many politically charged topics are overrun with zombie ideas  false stories that refuse to die, and just keep coming back. Another one has just resurfaced  the idea that Americas rich are just kings for a day, and that pretty soon theyll be replaced by another lucky group.

title: G.O.P. Pro-Choice Group Releases Anti-Romney Ads
description: A Republican abortion-rights group is set to begin an advertising offensive against Mitt Romney on Sunday in Iowa and New Hampshire, attacking him as a flip-flopper on the issue.

title: CBS Cancels Democratic Debate
description: It looks like the Dec. 10 Democratic debate on CBS is off now because of the writers strike. The leading Democratic candidates have said they wont cross the picket line of the striking writers in Los Angeles, and the Democratic National Committee has said it will not try to find an alternative venue.

title: The New Zunes
description: David Pogue on Microsoft's Zune, which is taking on Apple's iPod.

title: Bloggingheads: Annapolis Enigma
description:
Journalists David Corn of Mother Jones, left, and James Pinkerton of Newsday ponder the Bush administration's erratic attitude toward Mideast peacemaking.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: The Bagger Is Back
description: David Carr (a k a the Carpetbagger) kicks off another season of awards by escorting Mira Nair to the 17th Annual Gotham Awards.

title: Readers Questions: C.O.P.D.
description: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, or C.O.P.D., includes both chronic bronchitis and emphysema  progressive, incurable lung diseases usually caused by smoking. Twelve million Americans are living with C.O.P.D., but researchers think at least that many have the disease but do not know it. In its early stages, C.O.P.D. may go unnoticed; doctors do not test for lung disease as aggressively as they do for high blood pressure or cholesterol. Yet, as The Times reports today, there are treatments that can ease symptoms and help patients live longer.

title: Ron Paul Fans in Florida
description: By land, by air and by sea, the disciples of Ron Paul converged on the debate hall here in St. Petersburg, Fla., in the hours before the debate here tonight. There were two planes circling overhead, one flying a Ron Paul banner, another with lights spelling out his name Goodyear Blimb-style. A ship circling in the bay just outside the hall was festooned with Ron Paul paraphernalia, blaring martial music. In the park, just beyond the security fences erected around The Mahaffey Theater, the Paulites outfitted a group that was decidedly young and decidedly loyal with shirts and stickers and other assorted Paul gear.

title: The Baddish and the Beautiful
Live-Blogging the YouTube Debate
description: 10:12 p.m. | Last Question What is this, Meet the Press? The final question is about sports. Mr. Giuliani is put on the spot about how on earth, as a Yankees fan, he could support the Red Sox after they beat the Yankees in the playoffs. He says hes an American League fan and notes that when he was mayor, the Yankees won the World Series four times; since he left office, the Yankees have won none.

title: El Gordo Can Still Eat Defenders for Lunch
description: On Tuesday, Manchester Uniteds Cristiano Ronaldo delivered a splendid performance against his former club, Sporting Lisbon. The Portuguese wing again proved why he and AC Milans Brazilian maestro Kak are, according to FourFourTwo magazine, the top two players in the world.

title: The Annapolis Conference
description: The New York Times's Steven Erlanger looks at next steps for Israelis, Palestinians and the Middle East.

title: The Annapolis Conference
description: The New York Times's Steven Erlanger looks at next steps for Israelis, Palestinians and the Middle East.

title: Dont Give Up on Leopard (Despite the Bugs)
description: After I wrote about Apples latest attack ad featuring a flashing banner that reads Give up on Vista, I heard from several people (only one of whom works for Microsoft) pointing out that Apples own new operating system, OS X Leopard, is having its own problems.

title: Averting Our Eyes': James Hansens New Call for Climate Action
description: James E. Hansen of NASA, brushing off coal-industry criticisms but acknowledging the need to be sensitive to people still haunted by the Holocaust, has elaborated on what he meant when he recently described continued coal burning as akin to sending untold species to their destruction in death trains and crematoria.

title: Warmth in a Cup of Hot Chocolate
description: Seth Kugel of The Times checks out some of the thickest, spiciest and richest hot chocolate in New York City.

title: Slive Pushes Plus-One
description: Mike Slive, the B.C.S. coordinator, talked openly today about college football moving on to a so-called Plus One system in 2011, a sign that the sport could be inching toward some type of championship playoff.

title: The Bagger is Back
description: David Carr (a k a the Carpetbagger) kicks off another season of awards by escorting Mira Nair to the 17th Annual Gotham Awards.

title: Post-Debate Video Wrap-Up
description: Questions posed in video format really arent that different than those asked of candidates on the campaign trail by voters. But in this YouTube generation, what we look for are ways in which the camera enhances the question, offers up a new view or a panoramic setting in which the question is posed. Maybe Im asking too much, given that a lot of YouTube videos remind us of playful, sometimes scatological juvenile efforts to be funny.

title: Weekly Wrap: Dolphins Williams Back on Sideline
description: The Fifth Downs contributors are Andrew Das, Benjamin Hoffman, Naila-Jean Meyers, John Woods and Toni Monkovic.

title: Debate Wrap-Up: Tough Talk
description: A very hard-hitting  and grim  two hours  with the Republicans tonight.

title: Relief Greets End of Broadway Strike
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg just issued this statement in response to the tentative settlement ending the 19-day strike by Broadway theater stagehands:

title: Betrayal of Body and Soul: A Tribute to Ben
description: Nguyen, Nam Van A or B (Ben)

title: Respond to Todays Column: Paging the Lesser of 8 Evils
description: We invite you to leave your responses to the Thursday, Nov. 29 column.

title: Patriots vs. Dolphins: Close Calls on Road to Perfection
description: O.K. Lets be honest. Didnt you think the Patriots were off to the races again Sunday night against the Eagles when Asante Samuel returned an interception for a touchdown and a 7-0 lead 1:22 into the game?

title: Read This
description: For those in need of book recommendations, the National Book Critics Circle has created a monthly Best Recommended List, polling its 800 members, as well as the former finalists and winners of its book prize. The first list, divided into fiction, nonfiction and poetry categories, went up yesterday at bookcriticscircle.blogspot.com. Inaugural top spots were filled by Junot Dazs Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao in fiction and Edwidge Danticats Brother, Im Dying in nonfiction. Works by Robert Hass, Zbigniew Herbert and Robert Pinsky tied for first in poetry.

title: DNA Evidence Frees a Woman Convicted of Killing Her Daughter
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 28  In 1994, Lynn DeJac was found guilty of strangling her 13-year-old daughter during a night of drinking and bar hopping. On Wednesday, Ms. DeJac walked out of the Erie County courthouse free, and the first woman in the United States to have her conviction for killing someone overturned based on DNA evidence.

title: Room for Blood, Sacrifice and Lyricism in Glucks House of Atreus
description: It took 90 years, but Glucks Iphignie en Tauride has finally returned to the Metropolitan Opera. On Tuesday night the Met unveiled a grimly effective production of this work, one of the greatest of all operas, staged by Stephen Wadsworth and vibrantly conducted by Louis Langre in his company debut. The operas previous history at the Met amounted to just five performances, with the original French libretto translated into German, during the 1916-17 season.

title: Nevada: Simpson Pleads Not Guilty
description: O. J. Simpson and his two co-defendants pleaded not guilty to a dozen charges stemming from a confrontation in a hotel room here on Sept. 13. Judge Jackie Glass of Clark County District Court set a trial date for April 7. The three men are accused of storming the room and departing with memorabilia including items related to Mr. Simpsons professional football career. Mr. Simpson has said he only wanted his own items, which he said had been stolen.

title: U.S. Military Plans to Bolster Iraqi Sentry Forces by 10,000
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 28  The American military expects to add roughly 10,000 Iraqis to its roster of unofficial security guards who act as paid neighborhood sentries here, and will then cap the program, a military official said Wednesday.

title: Strike Settled, Broadway Races to Reopen Shows
description: The Broadway theater district buzzed today as producers, actors, musicians and workers prepared to revive a show season interrupted by a 19-day strike by stagehands. A spokeswoman for the League of American Theaters and Producers said all the shows that had been idled by the walkout would have performances this evening.

title: Tip of the Week: Desktop Widgets to Help Ease Holiday Travel
description: With the holiday travel season upon us, timely updates on traffic conditions, weather, flight times and gas prices can save time and frustration. Instead of checking a series of different Web sites, you can use desktop widgets  small Windows and Mac OS X programs designed to display a specific piece of information like the weather forecast.

title: FEMA Sets Date for Closing Katrina Trailer Camps
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 28  Almost 3,000 families here and across Louisiana will have to leave their government-supplied trailers over the next few months under a new schedule prepared by the Federal Emergency Management Agency.

title: Bushs Mideast Diplomacy: What if ...
description: To the Editor:

title: Immigration at Record Level, Analysis Finds
description: Immigration over the past seven years was the highest for any seven-year period in American history, bringing 10.3 million new immigrants, more than half of them without legal status, according to an analysis of census data released today by the Center for Immigration Studies in Washington.

title: Setting the Beat, and the Style
description: JUSTINE DELANEY speaks fashion like a native, her conversation studded with insider argot and references. She is drawn to hipster clothing brands like Preen and Comme des Garons, and is as well acquainted with the Bauhaus aesthetic as she is with Vivienne Westwood or Siouxsie Sioux. A onetime Goth, she describes her current style as preppy, but with a darker edge.

title: The Jets and the Dolphins Share a Voyage of the Awful
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 28  The Jets play the Dolphins Sunday in what qualifies more as a miserable matchup than a marquee game.

title: Bill Willis, 86, Racial Pioneer in Pro Football, Dies
description: Bill Willis, the Cleveland Browns Hall of Fame guard who played a major role in breaking professional footballs racial barrier in the decade after World War II, died Tuesday in Columbus, Ohio. He was 86.

title: Sears Barely Shows a Profit; Stock Falls 11%
description: Sears Holding, the owner of Sears and Kmart, said today that profit for the third quarter plunged an eye-popping 99 percent, from $192 million last year to just $2 million, as customers flocked to rival stores during the back-to-school shopping season.

title: Celtics Are an Example of How Quickly a Team Can Turn It Around
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Nov. 28  If the Boston Celtics could go from an also-ran last season to a title contender this season, then why shouldnt the Knicks keep dreaming of big changes in small time frames?

title: Firing Stirs New Debate Over Red Cross
description: Just as it seemed to have turned a corner, the American Red Cross finds itself in the spotlight again.

title: Footnotes
description: Doris Lessing, 87, will be unable to travel to Stockholm to receive the Nobel Prize in Literature on Dec. 10 because of back problems. Instead, the $1.5 million prize will be presented to her in London, where she lives, The Associated Press reported. {hellip} The JAM Awards and Concert at the Hammerstein Ballroom tonight, a tribute to Jam Master Jay, is to include appearances by DMC, Snoop Dogg, De La Soul, Q-Tip, Raekwon and others.

title: A Black Box Among the Georgians
description: HOME exterior colors go in and out of fashion, but uninterrupted black has seldom been a popular choice. That doesnt bother Ed Reeve, whose inky new house lurks among the 1830s brick Georgians in De Beauvoir Town in London like a stealth bomber in a field of biplanes.

title: Gudrun Wagner, of Bayreuth Festival, Dies at 63
description: Gudrun Wagner, who as the wife of Wolfgang Wagner, the director of the Bayreuth Festival, played a major behind-the-scenes role in guiding the event, the worlds pre-eminent Wagner opera festival, died yesterday in Bayreuth, Germany. She was 63.

title: Stagehands End Walkout on Broadway
description: The league representing Broadways theater owners and producers and the union representing its stagehands announced a settlement last night, bringing to an end a strike that had shuttered most of Broadway for 19 days, disrupted the plans of thousands of theatergoers and cost the city tens of millions of dollars in lost revenues.

title: Dow Surges on Hints of a Cut in Interest Rates
description: Capping a series of wild swings, the Dow Jones industrial average soared to its biggest one-day percentage gain in more than four years yesterday after a top Federal Reserve official hinted at another interest rate cut and oil fell below $91 a barrel.

title: Bicycles That Carry Powerful Beats, and Even a Rider or Two
description: A new biker gang is roaming the streets of Richmond Hill, Queens. This crew of mostly teenagers can be seen riding along 103rd Avenue just west of the Van Wyck Expressway. The bikes roar, but the booming sound has nothing to do with engines  because there are no engines. They are ordinary bicycles, not motorcycles, although these contraptions look and sound more like rolling D.J. booths. They are outfitted with elaborate stereo systems installed by the youths.

title: Striking Screenwriters Dismiss New Proposals
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 29  Striking screenwriters on Thursday night dismissed a new set of proposals from producers as a massive rollback, and called on their members to continue their walkout with fresh resolve despite a plan to continue talks on Tuesday.

title: Shy About  Ones Apertures
description: Q. How does Flickr.com know what kind of digital camera I use when I post photos on the site? Is there a way to keep this information from being displayed?

title: Spare the Velvet, Spoil the Child
description: STYLE filed by in twos, as scores of little ones  including a parade of twins  converged last week on Radio City Music Hall for the 75th anniversary Christmas Spectacular. In keeping with the festive air, the children trotted out fashions suited for a gala at Santas Arctic outpost. Curbing a toddlers impulse to compete with the stars, most turned their backs on glitter in favor of fur-bordered velvet, cashmere and tweed.

title: Biker and Rapper Reach Agreement
description: Evel Knievel, above left, said that he and Kanye West, above right, had settled a lawsuit concerning Mr. Wests use of the motorcycle daredevils image in a music video, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Knievel sued Mr. West, the rapper and producer, and his record company last year over a 2006 music video for the song Touch the Sky, in which Mr. West portrays Evel Kanyevel, who tries to ride a rocket-powered motorcycle over a canyon. We settled the lawsuit amicably, Mr. Knievel said. A spokesman for Mr. West confirmed the settlement.

title: New Findings Underscore an Earth-Venus Kinship
description: Other than the hellish heat, a crushing carbon dioxide atmosphere and corrosive clouds of sulfuric acid, Venus is a lot like Earth, scientists said yesterday.

title: An Early Show Exit
description: Hannah Storm, below, the former NBC sportscaster who has been a co-anchor of The Early Show on CBS since 2002, is being reassigned. In a statement released yesterday afternoon, the president of CBS News and Sports, Sean McManus, said he and Ms. Storm were in discussions to determine the scope and depth of her new duties. Ms. Storm was quoted as saying she had loved every minute of her time with the show. As was the case with its predecessors on CBS, The Early Show has never surpassed NBCs Today or ABCs Good Morning America in the ratings. Ms. Storms departure is the latest in a series of shuffles, which in the last year have included the arrival of a senior executive producer (Shelley Ross, formerly of Good Morning America) and the departure of another host, Ren Syler. The show will continue to be led on camera by Harry Smith, Julie Chen, Dave Price and Russ Mitchell.

title: Back in Ascendance
description: Eighteen months after being fired for threatening a radio rival, the D.J. Star, below, is returning to the airwaves. At a Midtown Manhattan news conference yesterday, Star, born Troi Torain, and Buc Wild (a k a Timothy Joseph), his on-air partner and stepbrother, said they would be the hosts of a morning show on 87.7 FM. Now a Russian-language station, it will be reprogrammed as Pulse 87, a Top 40 station, in January. The Star & Buc Wild Show, set for the 6 to 10 a.m. time slot, is to begin on Jan. 15. In May 2006 Mr. Torain was dismissed from Power 105 (WWPR-FM) for on-air threats directed at the family of a D.J. at a rival station, Hot 97. Though the charges were dropped, Mr. Torain said there was still litigation pending that prevented him from discussing the case.

title: Packers vs. Cowboys
description: Packers at Cowboys

title: Looking Back on a Ballrooms Past, With Kicks and Lifts and Leaps
description: Ballet Hispanicos Palladium Nights has many more musicians onstage than dancers; since there are 11 dancers, thats saying plenty. The two-act show at the Joyce Theater begins with a brief, appealing and appetite-whetting film documentary on the Palladium Ballroom as it developed from its opening in 1947 to its peak of popularity in the 1950s as Manhattans principal location for Latin ballroom dancing with big-band accompaniment. While watching this film, youre dimly aware of the Afro-Latin Jazz Orchestra waiting onstage to play. Realizing that this short 2-D black-and-white history is about to be replaced by an extended 3-D color re-enactment creates all the anticipation of the perfect overture.

title: Mexico Tries to Show Resolve With Big Drug Seizure
description: MANZANILLO, Mexico, Nov. 28  Mexico tried to send a pointed message to the world on Wednesday that it took its fight against drug trafficking seriously. Officials burned one of the largest shipments of narcotics ever seized, sending about 23 tons of cocaine into the tropical sky in a black plume.

title: In the Theater District, Merchants and Fans Are Eager for Reopening Night
description: The tentative settlement of the Broadway strike won rave reviews from merchants in the Theater District whose businesses had flopped during the prolonged closings  and from frustrated fans waiting to see the shows.

title: Not Down and Out in Moscow
description: MOSCOW

title: Scientist Presents Case Against Possible Pollocks
description: A forensic scientist said yesterday that a large group of paintings discovered several years ago and thought by some to be by Jackson Pollock included many containing paints and materials that were not available until after the artists death in 1956.

title: Once a Mainstay of Magazines, Cigarette Makers Drop Print Ads
description: A CIGARETTE maker that once used print advertising to ask smokers to walk a mile for a popular brand is walking away from the medium, at least for next year.

title: A Portable Multimedia Player Takes on the Apple Nano
description: SanDisk, like other makers of portable multimedia players, seems to always be one step behind Apple. But that may be changing.

title: Lebanon: Backing for Army Chief for President
description: The main faction in Parliament agreed to amend the Constitution to allow the head of the military, Gen. Michel Suleiman, to assume the vacant presidency. The announcement by the Future Movement, which is the largest bloc in Parliament and is led by Saad Hariri, was seen as a breakthrough after weeks of parliamentary stalemate that has left the country without a president since Friday, when the term of mile Lahoud ended. General Suleiman has stayed neutral in the bitter power fight between anti- and pro-Syrian politicians and is said to have the respect of both sides. The Constitution bars the sitting head of the armed forces from moving directly to the presidency.

title: Prudential Officer Gets Chiefs Post
description: Prudential Financial, the nations second-largest life insurer, said yesterday that its vice chairman, John R. Strangfeld, would take over as chief executive on Jan. 1 and become board chairman in May.

title: Democrats Cancel Debate Because of Writers Strike
description: The Democratic National Committee, finding itself in the middle of labor disputes between television writers and CBS, announced this evening that it was canceling the debate among Democratic presidential candidates that had been scheduled to be broadcast on some of the networks stations on Dec. 10.

title: Certain Symptoms Should Raise Red Flags for Doctors
description: Not everyone needs to be tested for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. But certain symptoms are cause for concern: shortness of breath, chronic coughing or wheezing, congestion or clogging of the airways with mucus.

title: NATO Strike Is Said to Kill 14 Civilians in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 28  A NATO airstrike killed 14 workers for an Afghan company that had been contracted by the United States Army Corps of Engineers to build a road in Nuristan, a mountainous province in eastern Afghanistan, officials said Wednesday.

title: After Death, Unfinished Artwork Gets a Life
description: In the dark days and weeks after the suicide of the artist Jeremy Blake in July, his friends and colleagues were left to pick up the pieces, literally.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Senator Turned Lobbyist Sees Job for Pal
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  Could it be called Senators and Sons, L.L.P.?

title: Is Tavares the Next Great One?
description: OSHAWA, Ontario  On the ice, during the precious time between whistles of a hockey game, John Tavares finds freedom. He finds it by taking a pass on his stick, sliding a shot past another befuddled goalie, celebrating with the same smile he wore when he was 5 and hardly anyone was watching.

title: Ending Dispute, Starbucks Is to Help Ethiopian Farmers
description: After a dispute over coffee trademarks that turned into a public relations problem for Starbucks, the company said yesterday that it would open a center in Ethiopia to help coffee farmers improve the profitability of their crops.

title: What Price is Right?
description: Johan Santana, the star pitcher of the Minnesota Twins, is at the center of trade talks between the Twins and a number of clubs. He wont come cheaply. The team that lands him would likely have to give up multiple top prospects and sign Santana to a long-term contract. How far should a team go to get Santana?

title: U.S. Takes Steps to Simplify Voting From Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  For Americans abroad, who often feel underrepresented, overlooked and little appreciated in the United States, the approach of the 2008 elections has brought some grounds for hope that this time their votes have a better chance of counting.

title: Supreme Court Weighs Maines Tobacco Law
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  The latest battleground in the federalism wars at the Supreme Court is an unlikely one: the state of Maine, which is trying to prevent under-age consumers from buying cigarettes over the Internet.

title: Teammate's Death Leaves the Grieving Redskins Numb
description: ASHBURN, Va., Nov. 28  Less than 36 hours after Washington Redskins safety Sean Taylor died of a gunshot wound in Miami, his father, Pedro, stood in an auditorium here at Redskins Park, addressing the team that joined him in mourning one of their own.

title: Court Calls a 40% Fee to Lawyers Defensible
description: A 40 percent contingency fee negotiated by a Manhattan law firm retained by the widow of a real estate developer involved in a multimillion-dollar estate dispute was not unconscionable on its face, an appeals court ruled yesterday.

title: Salsa for Toddlers
description: Parents of young children often squeeze in a workout by joining a gym with childcare. But as The Times reports today, many parents dont like leaving a toddler in a room where the main attraction is often a blaring television set. The result is the rise of group exercise at gyms for children 5 and under. For a fee, sometimes a steep one, toddlers as young as 2 can be left in the hands of fitness instructors to do gymnastics or learn salsa dancing while a parent works out in another room.

title: Manhattan: 5 Charged in Drug Investigation
description: Five people, including a police official and airport workers, were charged in Colombia yesterday as part of an investigation into heroin smuggling, federal prosecutors in Manhattan said. The five will be extradited to the United States to face federal drug charges in Manhattan, the prosecutors said. The arrests are part of an investigation into heroin smuggling from Medelln, Colombia, to the New York City area, Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan, said in a statement. Prosecutors have already charged three other people, including two Colombia police officials, in connection with the case. They charge that the suspects carried the drugs hidden in suitcases, clothing and computers.

title: Bush Promotes Middle East Peace Dialogue
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  A day after Israeli and Palestinian leaders committed themselves to negotiating a peace treaty, the Bush administration sought Wednesday to give practical and symbolic impetus to their reinvigorated peace process.

title: Size Limits for Cable Look Likely
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  Coming off a setback at the hands of the cable television industry, the head of the Federal Communications Commission moved to reassert himself on Wednesday by proposing that the commission quickly adopt a rule that would prevent Comcast, the nations biggest cable company, from becoming larger, commission officials said.

title: From Smoking Boom, a Major Killer of Women
description: For Jean Rommes, the crisis came five years ago, on a Monday morning when she had planned to go to work but wound up in the hospital, barely able to breathe. She was 59, the president of a small company in Iowa. Although she had quit smoking a decade earlier, 30 years of cigarettes had taken their toll.

title: As Lenders Tighten Flow of Credit, Growth at Risk
description: Credit flowing to American companies is drying up at a pace not seen in decades, threatening the creation of jobs and the expansion of businesses, while intensifying worries that the economy may be headed for recession.

title: Rutgers Continues Quest for Meaning
description: There is apparently no such thing as a meaningless football game to Rutgers Coach Greg Schiano, whose teams seemed to play them most of the time only a few years ago.

title: Kyrgyzstan: Premier Steps Down
description: Prime Minister Almazbek Atambayev stepped down and was presented with a service award by President Kurmanbek Bakiev. But members of Mr. Atambayevs Social Democratic Party, an opposition party, said he was forced from the post to keep him from interfering with what they said were government plans to rig parliamentary elections scheduled for Dec. 16, according to news agency reports.

title: Holiday Spirit Descends on Austenland
description: Jane Austen fans and scholars need not read any further; they are more or less required to attend Innocent Diversions: A Christmas Entertainment With Jane Austen and Friends, just as they are compelled to take in any Austen-inspired film or public television program. They may or may not find anything interesting or enlightening in this production by Theater Ten Ten, but for the die-hards that hardly matters; if its Austen, attention must be paid.

title: Paging the Lesser of 8 Evils
description: Debate time! Once again last night, Republican candidates came together to taunt the viewing public with the reminder that one of them is going to have to be nominated for president.

title: Kosovo: Independence More Likely as Talks Fail
description: A last round of United Nations-sponsored negotiations on the future status of Kosovo between Serbian authorities and leaders of the provinces ethnic Albanian majority broke up in Austria without an agreement. Kosovos leaders are widely expected to declare independence soon after mediators from the European Union, the United States and Russia submit their report to the United Nations by Dec. 10.

title: Child Deaths in Shelters Are Rising
description: The number of children dying in the citys homeless shelters is on the rise, according to a report released yesterday by the New York City public advocate.

title: Trees? Cliffs? Rocks? Perfect.
description: Perhaps no winter sport is immune to the X-Games factor, the adrenaline-juiced force that can turn a sport into an amped-up version of itelf. The latest sport to get a jolt is sledding, thanks to a new breed of equipment that allows downhill riders to jump, spin, flip and glide on the snow.

title: Subprime Woes Hit Norwegian Brokerage
description: LONDON, Nov. 28  A Norwegian brokerage firm said Wednesday that it would file for bankruptcy protection after losing its license because of accusations that it made four remote towns victims of subprime lending problems in the United States.

title: Cowboys Defense Plans to Show Progress by Shutting Down Favre
description: IRVING, Tex., Nov. 28  A T-shirt reading, The Pack vs. The Boys was among the most popular items flying off the shelves at the Pro Shop, the Dallas Cowboys merchandise store outside Gate 8 at Texas Stadium. Underneath the headline, action photos of Brett Favre and Tony Romo were emblazoned opposite each other, framed at the exact moment they fired passes in their distinctive motions.

title: Saudis Arrest 208 in a Sweep to Head Off Terrorist Attacks
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 28  Saudi Arabia announced Wednesday that it had arrested 208 people across the country who were suspected of having ties to Al Qaeda and had been planning attacks on oil facilities in the Eastern Province and killings of clerics and security forces.

title: Bush Presses Congress for Iraq Money
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  President Bush began a new offensive against Congressional Democrats today over money for the Iraq war, calling on the lawmakers to give American troops what they need to succeed in their missions and pass a bill without strings attached.

title: For Musharraf, Reduced Power as the President
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 28  A day after resigning as army chief, Pervez Musharraf will be sworn in as a civilian president on Thursday, leaving him with vastly reduced powers and Washington with a far more complex Pakistan to deal with in its fight against Al Qaeda and the Taliban.

title: South Africa: Phone Company Ends Takeover Talks
description: Telkom South Africa abandoned talks to sell its mobile and fixed-line phone assets to the Vodafone Group and the MTN Group, ending the possibility of South Africas biggest takeover. Vodafone, which owns 50 percent of Vodacom Group, South Africas largest cellphone company, was in talks to buy the other half from Telkom. The MTN Group was negotiating to buy Telkoms fixed-line business.

title: Israels Nuclear Arsenal Vexed Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  In July 1969, as the world was spellbound by the Apollo 11 mission to the moon, President Richard M. Nixon and his close advisers were quietly fretting about a nuclear arms race in the Middle East. Their main worry was not a potential enemy of the United States, but one of Americas closest friends.

title: Botched Surgery Suspected in a Death in New Jersey
description: RAHWAY, N.J., Nov. 28  It was the day before Thanksgiving when Ronald Livingston looked through the big plate-glass window of the Just a Little Healthier restaurant here and watched as an ambulance pulled up to the white Cape Cod two doors down on West Scott Avenue.

title: High-End Workstation Works Hard, Plays Hard
description: You can party on your ThinkPad, but you perform serious work on your ThinkStation D10 from Lenovo. It is a PC that is primarily intended for game designers, videographers and other high-end users, with powerful components and classy black styling.

title: Sharp Drop in Deaths From Measles Reported
description: Improved routine immunization programs and huge national drives to give children a second dose of the inexpensive measles vaccine have contributed to a stunning 91 percent reduction in measles mortality across Africa, with deaths plunging to 36,000 last year from 396,000 in 2000, the World Health Organization and Unicef reported. Globally in that period, measles deaths fell 68 percent, to 242,000.

title: For a Tunnel to Go 16 Miles, No Light Yet
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y.

title: The Powder Rush
description: Extreme winter sports became part of Wayne Johnsons life during childhood, when he realized that mainstream pursuits wouldnt satisfy him. Just skiing, unless it is racing, isnt enough anymore, he writes in his new book, White Heat: The Extreme Skiing Life (Atria Books, $26). So for more than 40 years, Johnson, now 51, pursued breakneck speeds and daring jumps on skis, and now satisfies his appetite by volunteering as a rescue worker at Park City, Utah. Along the way, he built a stable of friends who pursue extreme skiing or any other thrilling quest they can find.

title: Qualcomm Chief Welcomes iPhones Spread
description: PARIS, Nov. 28  Paul E. Jacobs, chief executive of Qualcomm, the maker of chips for mobile phones, insisted it was pure coincidence that he found himself within a few blocks of where the iPhone was introduced to France on Wednesday.

title: The Boom Is Drowned Out by the Boys on Motorbikes
description: JUBA, Sudan  To many people here, one of Africas biggest boomtowns is already starting to look like a bust.

title: Senator Criticizes Genentechs Limits on a Cheaper Drug
description: Genentechs plan to restrict the availability of Avastin so doctors cannot use it instead of a more expensive medicine for eye disease will cost taxpayers $1 billion to $3 billion a year, according to Senator Herb Kohl.

title: Rebel Officers Surrender in Manila
description: MANILA, Nov. 29  Shortly after a police armored personnel carrier rammed through a hotel lobby in the Philippine capital, a group of soldiers and military officers announced they were ending the standoff with police that had begun this morning.

title: Banking Giant Wachovia Settles With Regulator
description: The banking giant Wachovia will pay $300,000 to settle claims that it failed to disclose conflicts of interest in research reports by analysts, the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority said yesterday.

title: $200 Billion to Invest, but in China
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 28  As governments in the Middle East take big stakes in American companies, Chinas state-run investment fund has quietly shifted its focus from overseas deals to bolstering the countrys troubled banking system.

title: Soup Up Your Cellphone
description: It is all too easy to get caught up in the hype that comes with the latest and greatest cellphones. And right now, the latest and greatest are the iPhone and the iPhone clones that, with a touch of the finger, open up maps, restaurant listings and the weather.

title: Russias Election Is for Parliament, but the Real Vote Is on Putin
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 28  His valor is extolled on billboards across the nation, and his daily feats dominate the television news. At a keynote election speech last week, his handlers even showcased a shimmying girl band singing an ode to that heartthrob in the Kremlin: I want a man like Putin, full of strength!

title: Theyre Mad, Theyre Bad, They Sell Accent Pieces
description: IF the flame-colored lettering on the fire exit at the Manhattan apartment of Garry Jensen and Elena Bertinetto looks like graffiti, that is because it is: domesticated graffiti, if you will. Walking through Harlem, Mr. Jensen and Ms. Bertinetto spotted the artist at work and hired him on the spot.

title: Big Easy Is Denied Its Chance
description: The muddle of excuses being offered for the rejection of New Orleans as a site for one of next years showcase presidential debates cannot hide the fact that a disservice has been done to the electorate and the nation.

title: Manhattan: Asthma Linked to Trade Center
description: Children who inhaled dust from the collapsed World Trade Center may be twice as likely to develop asthma as children who were not exposed, according to preliminary findings released yesterday by the City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. The department based the observation on self-reported symptoms from the World Trade Center Health Registrys initial survey, which was conducted in 2003 and 2004. Health officials said about 6 percent of the 3,100 children under 18 who are enrolled in the study received a new asthma diagnosis after 9/11. The asthma rate for children under 5 who were directly exposed to the dust cloud was even higher  possibly three times the rate for the same age group across the Northeast, officials said. But they cautioned that it was too early to tell whether the increase is due to exposure, better detection or the tendency of parents of children with asthma symptoms to join the registry. A follow-up survey is under way.

title: Lawyer Battling for Katrina Payments Is Indicted
description: Richard F. Scruggs, a prominent trial lawyer who has been fighting insurance companies over payments for damage from Hurricane Katrina, was indicted yesterday by federal authorities on charges of offering a bribe of $50,000 to a Mississippi state judge in a dispute over fees with another lawyer.

title: Study Sees Signs of Obesity Rates Stalling
description: Obesity rates in women have leveled off and stayed steady since 1999, long enough for researchers to say the plateau appears to be real. And, they say, there are hints that the rates may be leveling off for men, too.

title: The Right Way to Handle Former Inmates
description: To control recidivism, and thus have a shot at controlling prison crowding and costs, the states and localities need to develop comprehensive programs that help former inmates find jobs, housing, training, drug treatment and mental health care. A promising model has emerged in Brooklyn, where District Attorney Charles Hynes started his re-entry program long before other jurisdictions even realized they were necessary.

title: The Immigration Divide, Seen From Three Angles
description: To the Editor:

title: Coming at Sundance: Personal Explorations and Stories of Survival
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Nov. 28  Personal stories, individual solutions to societys problems and an unexpected strain of optimism will supplant diatribes, exposs and gloom at the 2008 Sundance Film Festival in January.

title: White House Issues Upbeat Economic Forecast
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  The White House issued an economic forecast today that calls for solid growth through next year, a prediction that is more optimistic than that of the Federal Reserve and far more optimistic than those of many analysts on Wall Street.

title: What Do I Do? Depends on What Week It Is
description: WHEN Sean Aiken was a boy, he thought he might like to be a professional basketball player once he grew up. Now he is 25, and he is decidedly less certain.

title: The Year of Eco Decorating
description: ONE mark of a really good party has always been an almost biblical catalog of waste and excess, lovingly expressed in gallons of Champagne, acres of fabric, plywood and red carpet, and jetloads of exotic flowers. But in a year dominated by talk of the green movement, such practices can be viewed not just as unseemly but as downright anarchic  and not in a good way.

title: A Nokia Camera Phone Thats More Like a Camera With a Phone Attached
description: It didnt take long for camera phones to grow up. Only a few years ago, the best ones took pictures with 1 megapixel of resolution. Now Nokia is coming out with the N82, a phone that takes 5-megapixel photos, higher quality than some point-and-shoot cameras.

title: Fox Station Challenged on Renewal of License
description: NEWARK, Nov. 28  The Federal Communications Commission gave the public the opportunity on Wednesday to weigh in on whether a Fox-owned station with a unique relationship to New Jersey has earned the right to have its broadcast license renewed.

title: India Promises to Protect Threatened Writer
description: India has pledged to protect a Bangladeshi writer who is in hiding after receiving threats from Islamic groups, Agence France-Presse reported yesterday. The writer, Taslima Nasreen, right, was moved from her adopted home of Kolkata in West Bengal state last Thursday after riots by thousands of Muslims calling for her expulsion from India. India has never refused shelter to those who have come and sought our protections, Foreign Minister Pranab Mukherjee told Parliament. Militant Muslims accuse Ms. Nasreens 1993 novel Lajja, or Shame, involving riots between Muslims and Hindus, of blasphemy and have called for her execution for it and other works. West Bengals government has come under fire from the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party for refusing to harbor the author on security grounds. Over the weekend Ms. Nasreen, 45, was brought to New Delhi, where the government has kept her at an undisclosed location.

title: What the Acorn Grew Up to See
description: AN American sycamore in Sharpsburg, Md., was just a sapling beside a stone bridge when Union troops blocked the first Confederate invasion of the North during the horrific battle at Antietam Creek in 1862.

title: Sharif, Bhutto and the (Ex-) General
description: The triumphal return of Nawaz Sharif, the prime minister that Gen. Pervez Musharraf overthrew in 1999, has made the contest for Pakistans future more uncertain than it already was and injected another player into the game: Saudi Arabia.

title: From Smoking Boom, a Major Killer of Women
description: For Jean Rommes, the crisis came five years ago, on a Monday morning when she had planned to go to work but wound up in the hospital, barely able to breathe. She was 59, the president of a small company in Iowa. Although she had quit smoking a decade earlier, 30 years of cigarettes had taken their toll.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: India Promises to Protect Threatened Writer

title: China to Let Market Forces Weigh on Value of Yuan
description: BEIJING, Nov. 28  China will allow market forces to exert more influence over the value of the yuan as the country moves toward a fully convertible currency, Prime Minister Wen Jiabao said on Wednesday.

title: Chvez Says Hell Cut Ties With Colombia and Its Leader
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 28  President Hugo Chvez said on Wednesday that he would sever ties with Colombias government and its president, lvaro Uribe, in an escalation of a dispute after Mr. Uribes withdrawal of support last week for Mr. Chvezs mediating role with Colombian guerrillas.

title: Italy: Analysts Warn of Alitalias Valuation
description: Alitalia, the unprofitable airline that the Italian government is trying to sell, may have no value because labor costs remain too high compared with its peers, Deutsche Banks European airline analysts said. The airline, the largest carrier in Italy, will struggle to cut personnel expenses further without clashing with unions, the analysts said. Cutting labor costs will be hard for Alitalia without a bankruptcy filing, they said.

title: Obesity Rates Are Leveling Off
description: Obesity rates in American women have leveled off and stayed steady since 1999, a long enough time for researchers to say the plateau appears to be real. And, they say, there are hints that obesity rates may be leveling off for men, too.

title: Manhattan: Ex-Officer Is Sent to Prison
description: A former city police officer who helped his brother distribute vast quantities of cocaine and marijuana throughout the New York area from 2002 to 2005 was sentenced in Federal District Court to 10 years in prison yesterday. The former officer, Jose Torrado, 32, of the Bronx, pleaded guilty earlier this year to drug trafficking charges. Mr. Torrado joined the Police Department in 2001 and resigned in 2006 amid an investigation into his crimes. While serving with the department, Mr. Torrado worked with a criminal group that smuggled drugs from Mexico to New York in trucks, prosecutors have said.

title: Writers Strike Leads to End of Debate Plan
description: Finding itself in the middle of labor disputes between television writers and CBS, the Democratic National Committee announced yesterday evening that it was canceling the debate among Democratic presidential candidates scheduled for Dec. 10.

title: One Frog Turned Into a Prince
description: For my money, the most accurate judgment yet pronounced on Isiah Thomas was offered this fall by one Tommy Vasquez, a Bronx maintenance man and prospective juror in the Anucha Browne Sanders trial. "I can speak freely?" Vasquez inquired of the court, when asked about Thomas, the Knicks coach and president who was named in Browne Sanders sexual harassment lawsuit along with Madison Square Garden and its chairman. "Hes a pretty good talent evaluator," he went on, according to the Timess Harvey Araton, "but hes not so good a G.M."And there it was, round and pithy and delivered under oath, the perfect summation of the Isiah Thomas era in New York. Everyone was said to have laughed, except Thomas. Vasquez, after all, had just provided his epitaph.

title: Bloombergs Latest Itinerary Lists China and Indonesia
description: As Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg again prepares to trot around the world with a gaggle of cameras behind him, a question is emerging: Is he traveling so much for the city? Or for much-denied presidential aspirations?

title: Garden Q.&A.: Burning Bush Substitute
description: Burning Bush Substitute

title: Spreading the Misery
description: The nations foreclosure crisis is metastasizing, and communities are in harms way as property values and tax bases decline and crime increases.

title: Youth Charged in Killing of a Student
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 28  Prosecutors charged a 16-year-old Wednesday in a series of crimes that occurred on an early morning last week, culminating in the death of a University of Chicago student from Senegal.

title: An Airline Shrugs at Oil Prices
description: Southwest Airlines, in danger for much of this year of losing its quirky dominance in the domestic airline industry, could soon be standing, once again, head and shoulders above the competition.

title: Clashes at Funeral of Man Killed in West Bank Protest
description: HEBRON, West Bank, Nov. 28  Palestinian Authority security forces loyal to President Mahmoud Abbas opened fire here today to disperse a funeral procession that had turned into a pro-Islamic rally, marking a second day of violence in this usually staid city of the West Bank.

title: The Collapsible Colossus
description: CORRY L. FLADER, an owner of the Umbrella Shop in Vancouver, British Columbia, offered a rule when walking in the rain: Dont poke or hit other people with your umbrella, she said, unless provoked.

title: On the Go With a Camcorder That Requires No Hand-Holding
description: Many digital video cameras fit comfortably in the palm of your hand. But sometimes you need your hands for other things, like steering a bike.

title: Police See Shooting of Taylor as Random
description: MIAMI, Nov. 28  A top police official here said Wednesday that the evidence collected so far in the investigation of Sean Taylors death suggested he was the victim of a random crime and not a premeditated target of his killer.

title: Regenerons Supermouse Lures Sanofis Money
description: Mighty Mouse has come to save the day for Regeneron Pharmaceuticals.

title: Painting Sounds Using a Palette of Shadowy Colors From Pop and Postbop
description: The Hammond B-3 organist Sam Yahel began his second set at the Jazz Standard on Tuesday night with a row of intervals arranged to avoid any hint of resolution. This dash of atonality was fleeting  after a minute or two he plunged into a tune along with guitar and drums  but Mr. Yahel made it an efficient statement of purpose. This was an organ-trio gig, he seemed to be saying, but maybe not in all the ways you might expect.

title: Fourth Grader Is Suspended for Taking a Loaded Handgun to School in New Jersey
description: PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 28  A 9-year-old boy who took a loaded semiautomatic handgun to school has been suspended, police and school officials said Wednesday, adding that they were trying to determine how the boy had obtained the weapon and what he had planned to do with it.

title: Calls for Philippine Officials to Step Down Over Killings
description: MANILA, Nov. 28  Philippine legislators and human-rights advocates today demanded the firing, at least, of senior officials in the administration of President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, charging that they were responsible for a policy that authorized the murder, torture and disappearances of hundreds of political activists in the last six years.

title: A Fund-Raising Rainmaker Arises Online
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  They may not inhabit the traditional world of high-dollar campaign fund-raising, but two youthful computer whizzes are quietly and behind the scenes trying to change how campaigns raise money, netting millions of dollars for Democrats in the process.

title: Hello, Day Spa? This Order Is for Delivery
description: TRYING to get an appointment at the Face Place or Cornelia is like negotiating with the hostess at the Waverly Inn, said Celia Chen, the editor in chief of Notesonaparty.com, a new online magazine about entertaining. Now you have to name-drop or say who your clients are just so you can get an appointment. Spas are supposed to be relaxing.

title: Like Marriage, Business Takes Work
description: AFTER about nine years together, Marcia Mul and Bryan Scott noticed that a bit of the thrill in their relationship had worn off. In fact, they had some issues that were getting in the way of moving forward. So they decided to seek help.

title: G.O.P. Rivals Exchange Jabs in Testy Debate
description: The Republican presidential candidates engaged in a slashing debate last night over immigration and other issues, confronting one another in testy exchanges that reflected the wide-open nature of the race in the final sprint toward the Iowa caucuses.

title: A Scramble for Power and Treasure in South Africa
description: The Fate of Africa was Martin Merediths monumental study of 50 years of postcolonial African history, all of it compressed into a single, mesmerizing volume. Although the range of his material was enormous, Mr. Meredith managed to present a strong narrative and sharp overview.

title: E.P.A. Is Sued by 12 States Over Reports on Chemicals
description: Twelve states, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, sued the Environmental Protection Agency yesterday for weakening regulations that for two decades have required businesses and industries to report the toxic chemicals they use, store and release.

title: New Orleans Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: A Daughter Dies Suddenly, and a Mother Loses Her Way
description: During the months after her daughters death in May, Felesha DeGracia eventually made a plan.

title: Deal Reported in Cuban Custody Battle
description: MIAMI, Nov. 28 (AP)  A settlement was reached Wednesday in the court battle between a Cuban farmer and a wealthy Florida couple over the mans 5-year-old daughter, and a person familiar with the deal said it gave the farmer sole custody.

title: Home & Garden Calendar
description: Preservation History

title: For Toddlers, Toy of Choice Is Tech Device
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 28  Cellphones, laptops, digital cameras and MP3 music players are among the hottest gift items this year. For preschoolers.

title: Shutting Up Venezuelas Chvez
description: CARACAS, Venezuela

title: Rices Way: Restraint in Quest for Peace
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  Three weeks ago, in a windowless conference room in the David Citadel Hotel in Jerusalem, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice confidently dismissed the Middle East peacemaking attempts of her predecessors. It hasnt worked, she told reporters traveling with her. So, with all due respect, Ill try it my way.

title: Penny Foolish
description: THE migrant farm workers who harvest tomatoes in South Florida have one of the nations most backbreaking jobs. For 10 to 12 hours a day, they pick tomatoes by hand, earning a piece-rate of about 45 cents for every 32-pound bucket. During a typical day each migrant picks, carries and unloads two tons of tomatoes. For their efforts, this holiday season many of them are about to get a 40 percent pay cut.

title: Sarkozy Pledges Crackdown on Rioters
description: PARIS, Nov. 28  President Nicolas Sarkozy made a lightning strike into Frances troubled suburbs on Wednesday, visiting a wounded police captain and pledging afterward in front of the trailing television cameras to hunt down the attacking rioters and bring them to justice.

title: S.E.C. Bars Investors Directors
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission ruled yesterday that public companies could block investors from putting director candidates on corporate ballots, a major setback for shareholders seeking a greater say in boardroom affairs.

title: American Airlines Parent Plans to Shed Regional Carrier
description: The parent company of American Airlines, AMR, said yesterday that it planned to shed its American Eagle regional airline unit, after an investor group called on the company to bolster its stock price by getting rid of some operations.

title: Twins Get Rays Young for Garza in 6-Player Deal
description: The Minnesota Twins traded a starting pitcher, but it was not the elite pitcher they are expected to eventually move. Instead of relocating Johan Santana, the Twins shipped Matt Garza to the Tampa Bay Rays for outfielder Delmon Young as part of a multiplayer deal.

title: Russians Play Down Davis Cup Chances
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 28  For once, it is tempting to take Shamil Tarpishchev at his word when he claims that his Russian Davis Cup team has only a 35 percent chance of winning this weekend against the United States.

title: Wrist Worsens, So Avery Opts for Surgery
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Nov. 28  Sean Avery, one of the most energetic Rangers and their chief agitator, will have arthroscopic surgery on his left wrist Thursday and will be out indefinitely, the team announced Wednesday.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded: $2,404,555.37

title: An Afghanistan War-Crimes Case Tests Polands Commitment to Foreign Missions
description: WARSAW, Nov. 28  Poland is facing a rare war-crimes prosecution at a crucial juncture for both the newly elected governments commitment to overseas military engagements and the effort to overhaul the nations armed forces.

title: Board-a-Match Titles Awarded at San Francisco Tournament
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 28  The winners of the Victor Mitchell Open Board-a-Match Teams at the Fall North American Championships here on Monday night were Aubrey Strul of Delray Beach, Fla.; Michael Becker, David Berkowitz and Larry Cohen of Boca Raton, Fla.; Chip Martel of Davis, Calif.; and Lew Stansby of Castro Valley, Calif.

title: ABC Takes Tuesday
description: Almost 25 million viewers tuned in for final results of ABCs Dancing With the Stars on Tuesday, according to Nielsens estimates. The two-hour show, which followed a rebroadcast of the Charlie Brown Christmas special at 8 p.m. (13.6 million), helped ABC win the nights ratings over all. Fox ranked second thanks to House at 9 p.m. (16.9 million), which had the best ratings among adults 18 to 49. CBS and NBC trailed the other networks over all, with CBS third in total viewers and NBC third among adults 18 to 49. CBSs NCIS, the nights second-most watched show, earned 17.1 million viewers at 8 p.m. while NBCs Law & Order: Special Victims Unit (12.3 million) finished in second at 10 p.m. in the 18-to-49 market.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about Dr. Charles S. Hirsch, the New York City medical examiner, whose review of an autopsy on a city police detective has generated controversy, referred incorrectly in some copies to the size of a state medical review panel that in 1989 contradicted Dr. Hirschs findings in the case of Richard Luke, a 25-year-old man who died while in police custody. (The same error appeared in an article on Dec. 29, 1989, about the panels decision.) At the time, the panel had three members, not two. (It was authorized to have seven members, but four seats were vacant.)

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Kevin DuBrow, lead singer for the rock group Quiet Riot, misstated the circumstances of an accident in 1982 involving Randy Rhoads, who formed the band. Mr. Rhoads was a passenger in a plane that clipped a tour bus of Ozzy Osbourne, for whom he played guitar. The plane then crashed, killing all three people aboard; he did not die in a traffic accident.

title: The Met on Demand
description: The Metropolitan Opera and In Demand Networks have signed an agreement to offer the eight operas from the Mets second season of Metropolitan Opera: Live in High Definition, which are transmitted to movie theaters, to on-demand television subscribers in the United States. Beginning in January, performances will be available within 30 days of theatrical release. The first opera will be Gounods Romo et Juliette on Jan. 16, starring Anna Netrebko and Roberto Alagna, and conducted by Plcido Domingo.

title: 3 Bankers Plead Guilty in Case Tied to Enron
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 28  After more than a year awaiting trial in the United States on Enron-related charges, three British bankers pleaded guilty Wednesday in federal court here to one count each of wire fraud.

title: Christmas Is Almost Here and Santa Is in Her Sights
description: A seriously deranged dramedy about finding yourself through terrorism, Be My Oswald attempts high-wire artiness on a bargain-basement budget. This works for 15 of the films 94 minutes, suggesting that somewhere inside this labor of lunacy lies a solidly engaging short film.

title: City Said to Have Paid Bills as Giuliani Affair Began
description: Late in his tenure as mayor of New York, Rudolph W. Giuliani billed tens of thousands of dollars in travel expenses to little-known city agencies as he was beginning an extramarital affair, a political Web site reported yesterday.

title: Manhattan: Council Passes Emissions Bill
description: The City Council passed a greenhouse gas reduction bill yesterday that puts into law the ambitious carbon dioxide emissions goals that were laid out in Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs sweeping sustainability plan last April. The bill, which Mr. Bloomberg supports, requires that heat-trapping gases from city government buildings and vehicles be cut 30 percent from current levels by 2017. Moreover, it requires that carbon emissions from the entire city, including privately owned buildings, be reduced by 30 percent by the year 2030. Transforming the emissions controls from goals into law will ensure that they will be enforced in future administrations, said Councilman James F. Gennaro, chairman of the Environmental Protection Committee.

title: Correction: Short Layoff, Long Comeback
description: The Personal Best column last Thursday about athletes recovering their conditioning after a layoff misstated the name of the university where Joseph Houmard is the director of the Human Performance Laboratory. It is East Carolina University, not East Carolina State.

title: Federal Informer Testifies Against Sailor Accused of Aiding Terrorism
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 28  A former American sailor accused of helping support terrorism by leaking classified information about the whereabouts of Navy vessels in early 2001 told jihadist supporters that if they were not going to do anything with his information to just destroy it, a government witness told a federal judge here on Wednesday.

title: Briton Charged With Insulting Islam in Sudan
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 28  The Sudanese government decided Wednesday to charge a British primary school teacher with blasphemy, inciting hatred and insulting Islam after she allowed her 7-year-old students to name a class teddy bear Muhammad.

title: Expanding Postal Services
description: To the Editor:

title: Lottery Numbers
New New Jersey Festival
description: C3 Presents, the producers of Lollapalooza in Chicago, and Festival Republic (formerly Mean Fiddler), the producer of the enormous Reading and Glastonbury festivals in England, have announced a new event: The Vineland Music Festival, in Vineland, N.J., about 40 miles southeast of Philadelphia, is scheduled to run Aug. 8 to 10 next year, the weekend after Lollapalooza. The producers promise a mixture of big-name rock bands and rising stars.

title: The Pour-Me-Into-It Party Dress
description: IS that the shortest dress in the world? Oscar de la Renta asked teasingly of Bee Shaffer, the daughter of Anna Wintour, as she navigated the crowd two weeks ago at 7th on Sale, the fashion industrys closest approximation of a holiday ball.

title: After Early Success, Operations to Remove Damaged Tissues Have Fallen Sharply
description: Intently watching the rise and fall of Madeline Gallaghers abdomen as she lay on the operating table, Dr. Mark Ginsburg said, Her diaphragm is finally moving. Thats a really good sign.

title: A Woman of Thoughtless Erotic Force Has Her Day, and Many Men
description: They dont make femmes fatales  or their victims  the way they used to, a cultural change at the core of the Thalia Theater of Hamburgs often mesmerizing, revisionist Lulu, Frank Wedekinds play about one of the worlds most enduring vamps.

title: The Twins Are Not Sharing the Wealth
description: Unfortunately for Minnesota Twins fans, Carl Pohlad is no Ewing Kauffman.

title: Manhattan: Analyst Admits Tax Fraud
description: A former investment banking analyst has been sentenced to 1  to 4  years in state prison for stealing more than $572,000 from state tax authorities and attempting to steal an additional $4.6 million, prosecutors said yesterday. The analyst, We Jin Shon, 25, a Canadian citizen who worked for Morgan Stanley in London, pleaded guilty to grand larceny and attempted grand larceny in State Supreme Court on Tuesday, Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, said in a statement. He was sentenced the same day. Prosecutors said Mr. Shon filed 30 fraudulent tax returns using fake names and sought more than $5 million in refunds. Not all the returns were processed, but some money was wired to bank accounts in Mr. Shons name, prosecutors said. He was arrested after a bank manager questioned Mr. Shon after noticing that he was withdrawing $189,681 and that the original source of the money was a tax refund in another persons name, prosecutors said.

title: Two City Employees Charged With Soliciting Bribes
description: Two City Department of Transportation employees, including a high-ranking official earning $106,000 a year, were charged yesterday with soliciting hundreds of thousands of dollars in bribes from a company handling bridge repairs.

title: Between the Rocks and a Hard Sell
description: PERCEPTION really is reality.

title: Armed With Inside Information, Giants Defensive End Is Set for His Friends
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 28  There is no practical reason for Osi Umenyiora to know this, but he did. Without hesitation, he said Adewale Ogunleye had nine sacks. He knew that Mark Anderson had four and a half. He knew how many tackles each had, and how many forced fumbles.

title: Holiday Songbook Blends Familiar Carols and Revenge Medleys
description: Beneath the festive trappings of Michael Feinsteins annual holiday extravaganza (this years edition is titled Winter Dreams) is one of his most personal shows. Along with the usual frolics  a peppy Jerry Herman Christmas medley, a playful recreation of Kay Thompsons vocal arrangement of Jingle Bells with three backup singers  is a program in which Mr. Feinstein pays heartfelt tribute to departed friends and musical idols.

title: A Rural Dance Tradition in Twilight
description: OMAHA  It was a Sunday afternoon at the South Omaha Eagles Hall, a Czech stronghold in an increasingly Hispanic neighborhood here. Under a low ceiling and fluorescent lights, Lila Dvorak, 74, danced a two-step polka to the music of a three-piece combo.

title: After Hepatitis Case, New York State Acts to Speed Alerts to Patients at Risk
description: After coming under blistering criticism for a nearly three-year delay in notifying patients who might have been exposed to hepatitis C because of a Long Island doctors poor infection-control practices, the state health commissioner, Dr. Richard F. Daines, has proposed a series of internal changes to prevent such delays in the future.

title: Smile and Say Carrot Cake
description: KYM CANTER, the creative director of J. Mendel, the fur and luxury house, would like it known that her employment contract includes certain provisions about her standards. She does not use fake fur. And she would never work with so lowly a fur as rabbit.

title: A Closer Look at the Sanctuary City Argument
description: So was New York a sanctuary city for illegal immigrants when Rudolph W. Giuliani was mayor?

title: U.S. Says China Agrees to End Some Subsidies
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  Bowing to American pressure on the eve of high-level talks to reduce economic tensions, China agreed today to end a dozen subsidies that promote exports and discourage imports of steel, wood products, information technology and other manufactured goods.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q. How can I freshen up my sofa without reupholstering it or resorting to slipcovers?

title: Police Chase Ends in Death of 2 Officers
description: MIAMI, Nov. 28  Two sheriffs deputies in Palm Beach County were killed Wednesday when another sheriffs office vehicle ran into them during the pursuit of a stolen car, the authorities said.

title: Researchers Focus on Genes and Inflammation in Search for Clues to Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease
description: Two big ideas dominate the latest thinking about chronic obstructive pulmonary disease: one, genes determine who develops it, and two, it involves systemic inflammation that affects far more than the lungs.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some editions on Tuesday about a feud in a Long Island surrogates court over the estate of Monique de T. Eastman  the widow of Lee V. Eastman, a lawyer who represented Paul McCartney and who is the father of Linda Eastman, Mr. McCartneys first wife  misstated in one reference in some copies the surname of one of Monique Eastmans sons from her first marriage. He is Peter Sprayregen, not Eastman. (Go to Article)

title: Drop Down and Give Me a Handstand
description: SEARCHING for a timeout of her own, Kelly Mateo, a stay-at-home mother, thought shed try leaving her son in her health clubs baby-sitting room while she went to yoga class. While lying on her back in deep relaxation, her gym-issued pager started buzzing. She scrambled to gather her things and fetch her inconsolable child, who suffered from separation anxiety.

title: Playing .AVI on a Macintosh
description: Q. I get a white screen and no picture when I try to play an .AVI movie with the QuickTime Player on my Mac. What kind of software do I need?

title: Microsoft Challenges the iPod (Again)
description: Dont look now, but Microsoft might finally be getting the hang of hardware.

title: Oprah Sells Groban
description: Last week the classical crossover star Josh Groban performed on The Oprah Winfrey Show and, predictably, sales of his latest CD, Nol (Reprise), jumped. In its eighth week of release the album moved 405,000 copies  an 81 percent weekly gain  to reach No. 1 on the Billboard 200, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Alicia Keyss As I Am (J), last weeks top seller, fell one spot with 349,000 units sold. Now Thats What I Call Music Vol. 26 is No. 3; Garth Brookss Ultimate Hits (Pearl) is No. 4, and the Eagles Long Road Out of Eden is No. 5.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some editions on Tuesday about a feud in a Long Island surrogates court over the estate of Monique de T. Eastman  the widow of Lee V. Eastman, a lawyer who represented Paul McCartney and who is the father of Linda Eastman, Mr. McCartneys first wife  misstated in one reference in some copies the surname of one of Monique Eastmans sons from her first marriage. He is Peter Sprayregen, not Eastman.

title: State-Run Florida Fund Hit by Withdrawals
description: School districts and local governments in Florida have pulled $8 billion out of a state-run investment pool, or 30 percent of its assets, after learning that the money market fund contained more than $700 million of defaulted debt.

title: Former Trainer Provides Insight Into the Mitchell Steroids Investigation
description: Four times over the last year and a half, including once in the past week, investigators for George J. Mitchell have interviewed a former major league trainer in the hopes of learning the names of players who used banned performance-enhancing substances.

title: Nascar Hits a Bump in the Road
description: Hearing a faint ping from its psychic engine for the first time this decade, Rudy Giulianis newly discovered sport of auto racing is making its annual postseason pit stop in New York.

title: Having Too Much
description: To the Editor:

title: Dell Reports 26% Rise in Quarterly Earnings
description: Dell Inc. reported today that third-quarter net income increased 26 percent to $766 million, or 34 cents a share, on sales of $15.6 billion.

title: Concussions Put College Players in Murky World
description: Last Saturday, Stanford quarterback Tavita Pritchard was struck in the head by an opponent so violently that his helmet was ripped off, his bare head snapped back and forth and his skull slammed to the ground with a thud.

title: Court Awards Damages to Reporter Whose Home Was Raided
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 28  In a ruling seen as a victory for freedom of the press, a European court has awarded damages to an investigative journalist whose home was raided and computers confiscated after he published articles alleging fraud within the European Union.

title: Biking to a Different Beat
description: For young friends in Queens, bikes souped up with stereo systems function as rolling D.J. booths.

title: Writers, Producers Set 4th Day of Talks
description: Striking screenwriters and Hollywood producers agreed to extend their renewed contract talks to a fourth day this evening, signaling at least some progress toward ending a work stoppage that began three and a half weeks ago, Michael Cieply reports in Thursdays New York Times.

title: Listen Up
description: A decade ago, only a handful of women could claim the kind of style clout that comes with a presence in the D.J. booth. That has changed.

title: Prudential Officer Gets Chiefs Post
description: Prudential Financial, the nations second-largest life insurer, said Wednesday that its vice chairman, John R. Strangfeld, would take over as chief executive on Jan. 1 and become board chairman in May.

title: Wachovia Settles Research Conflict Claims
description: The banking giant Wachovia will pay $300,000 to settle claims that it failed to disclose conflicts of interest in research reports by analysts, the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority said Wednesday.

title: State-Run Florida Fund Hit by Withdrawals
description: School districts and local governments in Florida have pulled $8 billion out of a state-run investment pool, or 30 percent of its assets, after learning that the money market fund contained more than $700 million of defaulted debt.

title: Frazier Healthcare Closes 6th Fund
description: Frazier Healthcare Ventures said its closed its sixth institutional fund, having raised $600 million and bringing its total capital under management to $1.8 billion.

title: $200 Billion to Invest, but in China
description: As governments in the Middle East take big stakes in American companies, Chinas state-run investment fund has quietly shifted its focus from overseas deals to bolstering the countrys troubled banking system.

title: Vodafone, Telefonica Take Stakes in Mobile Ad Start-Up
description: Mobile phone group Vodafone Group and Spanish carrier Telefonica are taking stakes in a mobile advertising company in a move to battle the threat of online giants Google and Yahoo.

title: Blacks Holding Firm Is Ordered to Pay Fine
description: A federal judge Wednesday ordered Conrad Blacks Canadian holding company to pay $13 million in fines and restitution as punishment for taking part in a scheme to defraud shareholders of the parent company of the Chicago Sun-Times.

title: AMR Plans to Shed Regional Carrier
description: In another win for activist investors, the parent company of American Airlines, AMR, said Wednesday that it planned to shed its American Eagle regional airline unit.

title: F.C.C. Chief Moves to Limit Comcast and Help Tribune
description: Coming off a setback at the hands of the cable television industry, the head of the Federal Communications Commission moved to reassert himself on Wednesday by proposing that the commission quickly adopt a rule that would prevent Comcast, the nations biggest cable company, from becoming larger, commission officials said.

title: Tesla Names Ex-Racer as New C.E.O.
description: Tesla Motors, the Silicon Valley electric-car start-up, has put a fast driver behind the wheel.

title: Chinese Insurer Takes $2.7 Billion Stake in Fortis
description: Chinese insurer Ping An said it has paid $2.7 billion to take a 4.2 percent stake in the Belgian-Dutch financial-services group Fortis, continuing a trend of Asian and Middle Eastern interest in Western financials.

title: S.E.C. Bars Investors Directors From Ballots
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission ruled Wednesday that public companies could block investors from putting director candidates on corporate ballots, a major setback for shareholders seeking a greater say in boardroom affairs.

title: Bankers Plead Guilty in Case Tied to Enron
description: After more than two years awaiting trial in the United States on Enron-related charges, three British bankers pleaded guilty Wednesday in federal court here to one count each of wire fraud.

title: Deal Reached to Cover Remaining Risks at Germanys IKB
description: KfW Group, which organized the bailout of IKB Deutsche Industriebank over subprime losses, said an agreement was reached with German banking associations to cover the lenders remaining risks of about $520 million.

title: EU Considers Law to Regulate Sovereign Wealth Funds
description: The European Commission is exploring plans for an EU-wide law to regulate sovereign wealth funds, a move that could vastly complicate the City of Londons ability to serve as hub for the investment flows from Asia, the Middle East, and Russia.

title: U.K. Security Firm in Talks for Global Solutions
description: Group4Securicor, a British security firm, is in talks to buy Global Solutions, a company it used to own, for around 350 million pounds ($774 million), The Telegraph reported.

title: Citadel, BlackRock to Inject $2.5 Billion into E*Trade
description: E*Trade Financial, the troubled Internet bank and brokerage, said Thursday it secured a $2.55 billion cash infusion from a group led by hedge-fund firm Citadel Investment Group.

title: National Australia Bank Buys Great Western
description: National Australia Bank, the nations largest bank, agreed to buy U.S.-based Great Western Bancorporation for $798 million, its biggest acquisition since the 1998 purchase of HomeSide Lending led to billions of dollars in losses.

title: Baer Now Mulls I.P.O. for U.S. Unit
description: Swiss private bank Julius Baer Holding is eyeing an initial public offering or a management-led buyout of its U.S. asset management unit after talks to sell it stalled, according to Reuters.

title: Couples Therapy for Business Partners
description: A few months ago, I wrote a column, Blurring by Choice or Passion, about people who choose a life with few boundaries between their work and the rest of their life. The article featured the story of Anthony Sandberg, an entrepreneur who turned his interest in sailing into a thriving business. When he told me about how he accomplished that, much of the story had to do with finding the right partner, Richard Jepsen, who could bring complementary skills to the business.
