title: Analyst to BHP: Raise Rio Bid or Ditch It
description: BHP Billiton, the worlds largest mining company, should increase its $132 billion proposal to win over shareholders of rival Rio Tinto Group or drop the takeover bid, RBC Capital Markets said.

title: Temasek Sells Shares in China Cosco
description: Singapore state investment company Temasek Holdings is selling up to $277 million worth of shipping company China Cosco shares in a placement, marking its third divestment of holdings in Chinese firms this week.

title: Sallie Mae Appoints Lord as Executive Chairman
description: The chairman of Sallie Mae, the big student lender locked in a dispute with an investor group over a buyout deal, is assuming the additional role of executive chairman with an approved $3 million annual pay package, the company said Wednesday.

title: Ebert Keeps an Eye on the Future
description: As a consumer, the Bagger has never been a big Roger Ebert fan. His tendency to go so deep into the tank for a film that he risks getting the bends when he returns to the surface always seemed excessive. But sitting near the stage the other night at the Gothams, the Bagger watched him take what could have been a forlorn turn during a tribute and turn it into yet another triumph.

title: Fantasy Bank Mergers: How About Citi-JP Morgan?
description: A report that an ambitious banker recently pitched a CitigroupBank of America merger has got the folks at Breakingviews thinking: Wouldnt a combination of Citi and J.P. Morgan Chase make more sense? (At least one commenter on DealBook has been thinking the same thing.)

title: A Nation Going Down the YouTubes?
description: Questions not aired in the CNN/YouTube Republican debate last night:

title: Kucinich Holds Alternate Forum
description: Democratic presidential candidate Dennis Kucinich had a stage all to himself last night as he broadcast a Manchester, N.H., town hall meeting live at the same time the G.O.P. candidates were competing for the spotlight in Florida.

title: The Funniest Thing Ever. Well, At Least About the Oscars
description: Awards Daily pointed us to a scabrous video take on the cravenness and calculation of some in the movie business at this time of the year. It was produced by The Soup over at E! Apparently  the Bagger is shocked  some movie producers are so infected by gold lust that they may even allow it to affect their choices of themes, talent, and story.

title: For Investors, Multi-Strategy Funds Take the Cake
description: At a time when hedge fund investors will be glad if they end the year with 12 percent to 14 percent positive returns, multi-strategy hedge funds like Citadel Investment Group are increasingly finding themselves in the sweet spot, Breakingviews says.

title: Who Will Wear the Moustache?
description: PopCandy at USA Today tips its hat to a feature about the best movie moustaches. There are the predictable nods to Erroll Flynn and Charlie Chaplin, but the Bagger thinks putting Ben Stillers Dodgeball stash at number 12 was a grave injustice.

title: Video: The Bagger Is Back
description: The Bagger hits the streets once again! In this clip, he heads to the 2007 Gotham Awards with Mira Nair.

title: Milan T Party
description: Clockwise from top left: Sofia Coppola, Donatella Versace with T Editor Stefano Tonchi, Mischa Barton, Ottavio and Rosita Missoni, T columist Suzy Menkes and Matthew Williamson, a T fan and Rosario Dawson, Times Magazine editor Gerald Marzorati and Franca Sozzani, Skin and her nuovo B.F.F. (Stefano Guindani for The New York Times)

title: The Early Word: Republicans in Attack Mode
description: Right out of the gate, last nights Republican debate took on a weighty topic  immigration  and had two leading candidates playing defense. It was a night for sharp jabs among several of the contenders, who also offered up some veiled charges underlining recent controversies.

title: Talk Off | The Jodhpur
description: (Stefano Rellandini/Reuters/Corbis; 20th Century Fox/Photofest)

title: Settlement Ends 19-Day Broadway Strike
description: Broadway performances are to resume this evening, following a settlement reached late Wednesday by the theaters producers league and the union of stagehands, which had engaged in a costly 19-day strike.

title: At Odds Over Iraqi Refugees
description: Was it the success of the surge, or the urge to make a living? The motivations of Iraqi refugees returning home from Syria came into focus on Tuesday, when 20 busloads of them set out for Baghdad, though not before a sampling were interviewed by staff members of the United Nations refugee agency:

title: Boutique Beat | Pushing Envelopes
description: A new frontier in the worlds of luxury (and luxury trappings) is the receipt packagea precious little envelope to carry your carefully folded proof of purchase. Borrowed from those connoisseurs of all things shopping and packaging, the Japanese, the conspicuously tiny envelope is in circulation at stores including J. Crew, Phillip Lim, Diesel, Louis Vuitton, Marni and Calvin Klein. Its these little things that make a difference, says Millard Drexler, the mastermind behind J. Crews turnaround and its amped-up luxe quotient. It says, I really care about your shopping experience. (What these high-design disposables say about waste management, however, is another issue.) Pradas embossed, stiff card stock is Milanese navy; Diane von Furstenbergs open-top version has a sexy, low-cut back to expose its fuchsia interior; Jil Sanders has a bold-lettered, starkly minimal style; R by 45rpms envelope is slightly rough, unbleached paper. Of course, the amenity has its practical purposes. As Diesels envelope puts it: A token of our time spent together And a keepsake for a change of heart.

title: Thursday Kickoff: Is Miles the Right Coach for Michigan?
description: In the wake of the news that Michigan has sought permission to talk to Louisiana State Coach Les Miles, Michael Rosenberg of the Detroit Free Press writes that its time to take a step back and examine whether Miles would really be the best fit for the Wolverines. Rosenberg doesnt think so. He prefers Jeff Tedford of Cal instead.

title: Karl Lagerfeld, Piano Man
description: (Andrew H. Walker/Getty Images)

title: Army-Navy: It Just Drips With Tradition
description: New England Patriots Coach Bill Belichick has again found time in his busy media schedule avoiding talk of a possible perfect season to grace us with some college thoughts.

title: Scent Notes | Elle by YSL
description: On the Richter scale of disasters, some are more inexplicable than others. Consider one of the latter. But first, some background: The Yves Saint Laurent scent collection is among the strongest on the market. It contains an effectively perfect perfume, Paris, the paradigmatic rose created by the legendary perfumer Sophia Grojsman; Baby Doll, the brilliantly executed scent of a young girls sweet laughter and the world standard in the sweet helium/chic kitsch category; Opium, the still-great reference oriental; and Rive Gauche, now a retro masterpiece. YSLs revolutionary Nu stumbled commercially but it too is an excellent perfume. Finally, In Love Again is yet another standard-setter of its type (post-modern fruit neon). And now Yves Saint Laurent is rolling out Elle.

title: Out of Left Field
description: Well, at least the candidates were probably all Republicans. As for the questioners, thats a different story, writes Rick Moran at Rightwing Nuthouse, pretty much summing up the outrage among conservatives that at least 4 of the questioners from last nights CNN/YouTube Debate were Democratic party supporters and activists including one gay general who worked for John Kerrys campaign and is on Hillary Clintons LGBT Steering Committee.

title: Las Vegas in Spain
description: Plans are moving forward to build a Las Vegas-style gambling center in eastern Spain, outside Zaragoza.

title: Fine Print | Bob Colacellos Out
description: Paloma Picasso, 1980

title: The List: January 10, 1943
description: In 1940 and 1941  the lead-up-to-war years  the New York Times Book Reviews bestseller list appeared only rarely. In 1940, it ran exactly once.

title: Campus Voices: G.O.P. Debate Reaction
description: A group of undergraduates at Harvards Institute of Politics watched the Republican debate last night and offered their thoughts below. These students are participating in an academic project that has allowed them to spend a lot of time on the ground in New Hampshire, talking to voters and studying the candidates in the leadup to the primary on Jan. 8. (Their videos and takes on the Granite State primary race can be found at CampusVoices.org)

title: Were From Citadel, and Were Here to Help
description: When Amaranth Advisors was collapsing last summer because of energy trades gone bad, the firms chief operating officer, Charles Winkler, got a call from Kenneth Griffin. Mr. Griffin came right to the point: Charlie, he said, according to documents Amaranth filed in a recent lawsuit, what can we do, and how can we help?

title: Asking the important questions  not
description: So CNN chose which questions would be asked in the Republican debate last night. And guess what: not one question about health care, the central domestic issue for this election.

title: TPG to Acquire Axcan Pharma for $1.3 Billion
description: Axcan Pharma, a Canadian pharmaceutical company specializing in treatments of gastrointestinal disorders, said Thursday that it will be acquired by TPG Capital for about $1.3 billion in cash. It is the latest in a string of smaller buyouts, since the summers credit market squeeze halted the mega-deals from earlier this year.

title: Springtime on NBC
description: NBC is dropping hints about what its spring programming schedule will look like if the writers strike continues.

title: New Leader at Discovery Channel
description: John Ford, a successful programmer for TLC, Discovery Health and National Geographic Channel, is taking the reigns at Discovery Communications signature channel, the company said today.

title: The Iraqi Spy Who Did Nothing
description: Your mission, if you choose to accept it: Go live in the United States and await further instructions.

title: Open Caucus: Voters on the G.O.P. Debate
description: Several of the voters weve gathered from around the country for our Open Caucus forum weighed in overnight on the Republican debate, broadcast by CNN from St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: Helping the Chicken and Rice Man of Queens
description: Many readers have written to The City section and the City Room blog, asking how they can help support the work of Jorge Muoz, the chicken and rice man profiled on the cover of the weekly Sunday print section and in this video.Mr. Muoz, a 43-year-old former illegal immigrant from Colombia, is called an angel by the dozens of day laborers  many hungry, homeless and without work  who congregate at the corner of Roosevelt Avenue and 73rd Street in Jackson Heights, Queens, looking for odd jobs. He shows up at 9:30 every night driving a white pickup truck laden with enough home-cooked fare to feed them all at no charge.

title: Christmas Trees Go Green
description: The greenest tree in N.Y.C. (Credit: James Estrin/The New York Times)  Over the last several years, several big-city mayors, led by Michael R. Bloomberg of New York and Richard M. Daley of Chicago, have made pronouncements that amount to a race to see which metropolis is the greenest in the country. Theyre retrofitting old city buildings to cut energy waste and greenhouse gases, trying to curtail traffic, putting up solar panels. (For two independent analyses of green cities, go to the Green Guide and Yahoo.)  In the latest move, New York Citys Rockefeller Center Christmas tree, illuminated last night, shines not with old-style incandescent bulbs but with 30,000 electricity-sipping light-emitting diodes, or L.E.D.'s, powered in part with solar panels. (And the tree was even cut with a hand saw, the city says.)  There are some signs of spreading green tree envy.   A recent article in The Minneapolis Star Tribune questioned the cost and carbon dioxide emissions from lighting St. Pauls giant, and incandescent-lit, Christmas tree. The headline asked: A bright and shining energy waste?  The reporter, Karen Youso, wrote that the citys tree-lighting practices, with 60,000 incandescent bulbs burning around the clock for five and a half weeks, costs about $1,300 and results in 18.7 tons of carbon dioxide, the main heat-trapping emission from human activities.  She asked state energy officials to calculate the financial and environmental cost if St. Paul erected the tree and bulbs now blazing in Rockefeller Center. The answer was $136.80 and one-tenth as much carbon dioxide.   Itll be interesting to see what St. Paul and the corporate partners that pay for the display do next year.   What are other cities doing about the kilowatt-hours and carbon dioxide that come with holiday decor?

title: Green Tree Envy?
description: Over the last several years, several big-city mayors, led by Michael R. Bloomberg of New York and Richard M. Daley of Chicago, have made pronouncements that amount to a race to see which metropolis is the greenest in the country. Theyre retrofitting old city buildings to cut energy waste and greenhouse gases, trying to curtail traffic, putting up solar panels. (For two independent analyses of green cities, go to the Green Guide and Yahoo.)

title: In Ontario, They Learn Hockey When Theyre Young
description: Hockey is a red-blooded, manly endeavor, and with that in mind have a look at Agence France Presses report on the bench-clearing brawl between two teams of 8-year-olds that took place in Guelph on Friday. Ontario hockey authorities are tut-tutting the sordid episode  clearly players shouldnt fight until theyre 15. To start earlier would be, why, obscene.

title: Shanghais Skate Showdown
Calling the Shots
description: When football players sustain traumatic blows to the head, some television commentators see a great play while others take a more sober tone. Few announcers have been as aghast at a concussion-causing tackle as ESPNs Ed Cunningham on Saturday, when he watched Stanford quarterback Tavita Pritchard have his helmet knocked off before his head slammed to the ground

title: Wisconsin's Jefferson Laid Out
description: When Wisconsin played Michigan State on Sept. 29, Badgers' receiver Kyle Jefferson suffered a helmet-to-helmet tackle. (Courtesy: ESPN)

title: Youth Leading the Way
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: 'The Diving Bell and the Butterfly'
description: A. O. Scott reviews a new film based on the book by Jean-Dominique Bauby.

title: What Price is Right?
description: Johan Santana, the star pitcher of the Minnesota Twins, is at the center of trade talks between the Twins and a number of clubs. He wont come cheaply. The team that lands him would likely have to give up multiple top prospects and sign Santana to a long-term contract. How far should a team go to get Santana?

title: What Gives?
description: It is a little early in the season for the Bagger to mount his hobby horse, but how come Lars and the Real Girl and Once are getting so little love? Lars, a touching story of romance between Ryan Goslings character and a blow-up doll, got bubkes at the Gothams and ditto from the Spirit nominations. Once got a foreign film nod from the Spirits, but thats it. Both films would seem to embody indie excellence and ambition, but dont seem to be gaining the kind of traction they deserve.

title: Sweeney Todd, a Battleship About to Dock?
description: One of the games we play out here in the land of much portent and little impact is The Big One That is Still Coming. So far, with Charlie Wilsons War getting a wan initial reception, that would be Sweeney Todd.

title: At the Center of the Vortex
description: Backstage at the Gothams, two Oscar vets  Tom ONeil of the Envelope and Dave Karger of EW  talk smack about this years race.

title: No Quarter for Ending of No Country
description: Anne Thompson, writing in Variety, said that the refusal of the Coen Brothers to let good triumph over evil in No Country for Old Men is a subject of discussion that is showing up everywhere, including her book club. The ending hews closely to the book and the Bagger found it in keeping with a film that constructed its own moral universe. Others, though, arent so sure. Nora Ephron gets a laugh out of the debate in the New Yorker, while Alec Baldwin uses it as a soapbox for a short speech. Go see No Country for Old Men. Its a metaphor for Iraq and the post 9/11 world,he concludes.

title: A Milestone Approaches for Commissioner Kelly
description: At years end, Raymond W. Kelly will have logged the longest continuous period as police commissioner of anyone who has held that post since 1945. Thats not including his first of term of service in the Dinkins administration.

title: PopularityDialer Goes Offline
description: Over a decade ago, I remember seeing a "Saturday Night Live" skit that still stays with me. It was a talk show where all of the guests had one thing in common: they were all jerks or psychopaths whose one-time actions had created lifelong inconvenience for the rest of society. There was that guy who put poison into a bottle of Tylenol, initiating the era of the childproof (and adult-proof) package. There was the hijacker, whose actions led to the nationwide construction of airport X-ray machines. And so on.

title: A Cricket Death That Will Be Left Unresolved
description: Back in June, The Lede thought that all the air had leaked out of the deflating cricket mystery that we had covered with zeal. But there were still further disappointments to be suffered by anyone hoping for final word on the death of Bob Woolmer, the coach of Pakistans national cricket team.

title: Sizing Up Your Bone Health Online
description: A new online calculator can help women over 50 gauge their bone health even if they havent had a bone scan.

title: Moonlight, Gossip Girl, Big Bang Theory Show Momentum
description: In a press release from CBS projecting that it would finish in first place among total viewers for the November ratings sweeps period, this sentence stands out:

title: How That Streisand Endorsement Came About (Hint: Not Like Buttah!)
description: HOLLYWOOD, Calif.  Barbara Streisands endorsement of Hillary Clinton a day after word came that Oprah Winfrey would stump for Barack Obama made for delicious timing, and The New York Post, for one, couldnt resist slapping together a battle-of-the-divas tale of the tape, stacking up Babss 71 million albums sold against Oprahs 9 million viewers.

title: New Contract for ABC News Writers
description: The Writers Guild of America and ABC have reached an agreement on a new contract for 250 ABC News writers, editors, artists, assistants, and researchers, the guild said Thursday morning.

title: Boom Bikes
description: In Richmond Hill, Queens, teens have turned bicycles into rolling outdoor sound systems.

title: Quote: Olmert on the End of Israel
description: At the beginning of the peace conference in Annapolis, Md., Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel said that he had many good reasons not to come here to this meeting. Today, he explained the biggest reason why he did. From an interview with Haaretz, an Israeli newspaper:

title: At Sears, Soft Sales Bring Hard Times
description: A rough patch just got rougher for Edward Lampert, the famed value investor who runs ESL Investments.

title: Fund-Raising Fever Runs High for 2009
description: These days, the best place to find someone who is bent on running for a city office in the 2009 election is at a fund-raising event - generally their own.

title: PopularityDialer Goes Offline
description: Over a decade ago, I remember seeing a Saturday Night Live skit that still stays with me. It was a talk show where all of the guests had one thing in common: they were all jerks or psychopaths whose one-time actions had created lifelong inconvenience for the rest of society. There was that guy who put poison into a bottle of Tylenol, initiating the era of the childproof (and adult-proof) package. There was the hijacker, whose actions led to the nationwide construction of airport X-ray machines. There was the creep who put razor blades into Halloween candy. And so on.

title: A Brick Facade Remains as a Signal for Change
description: And then there was one. Or rather, the brick facade of one.

title: After Giving Thanks, Satisfaction
description: It was a week of some wonderfully satisfying wines, and Im not just thinking of Thanksgiving, which in my case was fairly simple: a case of white, a case of red, and 35 people (not all of them wine drinkers). It was not a day for reflective drinking, except for a lull in the cooking when my cousins and I opened a dry, delicate 98 blanc de blancs from Duval-Leroy, which, as Garrison Keillor says, gave us the strength to do what needs to be done.

title: Construction Progress: Week 17
Nanos Rear-View Mirror
description: Nanotechnology is often spotlighted for the novel things it has produced or may produce in the future by rearranging the molecular structure of everyday building blocks like metals and plastics. But nanotechnology might also revive some products given up as lost causes.

title: Would You Like Your Veggies Plain or Succulent?
description: Heres a recipe to encourage your family to eat more vegetables: Just add adjectives.

title: Shrek Beats the Tree Lighting
description: On the final night of the November sweeps period, ABCs new holiday special Shrek the Halls lifted the network to a first place finish among adults 18 to 49 on Wednesday. Attracting an impressive 21.1 million viewers at 8 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates, Shrek delivered ratings in the 18-to-49 set higher than any other program on network television last week with the exception of Sunday Night Football.

title: The Opposite of Water Conservation
description: The Atlanta metropolitan area has been hit by a drought so severe that Georgias governor has resorted to praying for rain.

title: The Ice Is Tilted in Colorado
description: The Oilers played the Avs at the Pepsi Center on Wednesday night and managed only 13 shots. They were 0 for 4 on the power play. Still, they lost by only 4-2 with Peter Budaj manning the net for Colorado. Edmontons Dustin Penner, the behemoth with the five-year, $21.25 million contract, had one shot and no points. Somewhere I hear Brian Burke chuckling.

title: More Late Night Jokes From Readers
description: Send your jokes via the comment link below:

title: Where Have All the G.O.P. Attack Ads Gone?
Christmas Day in New York
description: My husband and I will be spending Christmas in Manhattan. Can you suggest any outings we can do on Christmas Day? Any restaurants that will be serving that evening?

title: Romo the Next Favre, According to Bowens
description: Add Jets linebacker David Bowens to the list of those who watch the Cowboys Tony Romo, the new It quarterback in the N.F.L., and see the veteran Packers quarterback Brett Favre.

title: Green Is the New Green
description: Id love to know if anyone from the Greenwash Brigade is in Chicago right now.

title: Podcast: Crusading Governors, Past and Present
description: Listen to the Podcast (mp3)

title: Boots on the Ground in Brooklyn, Plastic Pigeon in Hand
description: In between the remarks about crime-fighting, terrorism and any future role he has in city government, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly dispensed with some funny business at a breakfast meeting this morning in Borough Park, Brooklyn. It involved a plastic, life-size model of a pigeon. The commissioner, who is approaching a modern-day record of sorts for continuous service in his post, presented the figurine, along with a certificate of appreciation from the police commissioners office, to City Councilman Simcha Felder for taking on a real serious quality-of-life issue.

title: Rubenstein and the Perils of the Private in Private Equity
description: Private equity firms have been asleep at the public relations switch, more interested in reaping profits than cultivating a positive public image, Carlyle Group co-founder David Rubenstein said Wednesday, according to TheDeal.com.

title: Answers From the Urban Rodentologist, Part 2
description: Following is a second set of answers from Robert M. Corrigan, a well-known urban rodentologist and research scientist for the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene who is took questions on the City Room blog from Nov. 26-30. A first set of answers was posted on Wednesday.

title: Mormons and the Bible
description: One moment that got some attention at Wednesdays CNN-YouTube Republican debate was when the candidates were asked whether they believed every word of the Bible.

title: Clinton Polls Best Among Gays, Lesbians
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York is the clear favorite among gay and lesbian voters, who see her as a champion of gay rights, according to new nationwide poll released today by Hunter College in New York. Almost 63 percent of respondents said they supported Senator Clinton, with Senator Barack Obama of Illinois a distant second with just over 22 percent.

title: Will Kennedys Remarks Hog the Attention in Iowa?
description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. endorsed Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton for president today, and headed out to campaign for her in Iowa  a state where he once told residents, large-scale hog producers are a greater threat to the United States and U.S. democracy than Osama bin Laden and his terrorist network.

title: CNN/YouTube Debate Breaks Ratings Record
description: CNNs Republican YouTube debate last night attracted 4.4 million viewers, making it the most-watched debate of this presidential primary season and breaking all records for any primary debate on cable television in cable history.

title: Wipe That Brilliant Idea Off Your Face
description: Just asking, but doesnt this miss the point of spontaneous, back-of-the-napkin creativity? Maybe someone doodled the idea on a Post-It note. More here.

title: Im a Blackhawk and Shes Joan Cusack
description: The Chicago Blackhawks are making progress, and moving out of obscurity.

title: Senators Press Japan on Whale-Hunting Plan
description: A group of eight senators sent a letter of protest today to Ryozo Kato, the Japanese ambassador to the United States, over Japans impending whale-hunting operation near Antarctica. The operation is billed as scientific research but has been widely criticized by other countries, many environmental groups and marine biologists as a slaughter conducted for relatively unpopular meat and national pride.

title: S.E.C.s Lead WorldCom Lawyer to Join Simpson Thacher
description: Peter H. Bresnan, the man who led the Securities and Exchange Commissions landmark accounting fraud lawsuit against WorldCom, is trading his enforcement duties for private practice.

title: Say No to Computerized Voting Machines
description: The 2008 presidential election is fast approaching and some states are still using unreliable paperless computerized voting machines.

title: Bacardi
description: A TV commercial promoting Bacardi rums for the holidays.

title: Bacardi
description: A TV commercial from Bacardi asking consumers to drink responsibly.

title: Annoying Things To Do on an Elevator
Will That Be Virtually All?
Profits Head Down
description: The governments estimate of corporate profits for the third quarter is out today, and while everyone should understand the early figure is little more than an educated guess, it is interesting. (The figures will eventually be adjusted using tax return data.)

title: Joy of Failure
description: Do you think financiers should be embarrassed and repentant as the financial system erodes? Or do you see an opportunity for a party?

title: Do We Need Another El Camino?
description: Autoweek recently reported that General Motors is on the verge of approving an El Camino-like vehicle to slot into the new Pontiac G8 model lineup (based on vehicles sold by G.M.s Australian subsidiary, Holden).

title: Bubbe Says You Dont Have to Squeeze the Latkes
description: What we are reading elsewhere

title: A Trifecta of Excuses
description: Sears fell to its lowest level since the KMart-Sears merger today, although it did somehow eek out a profit of a penny per share.

title: New Years in Des Moines
description: It pains me that several of you feel that I dissed the farmers in Iowa and South Dakota in my Nov. 29 column. After spending years working with Verlyn Klinkenborg on the editorial board here, Ive become a fan of all things farm related, give or take a few subsidies.

title: Dig This: Red Bull Park, the New Design
description: Promises, promises. Soccer fans in the New York metropolitan area have heard them before.

title: Road Trip, Part 11: The End Is Near
description: The dynamic CSTV.com duo of Matt Meyers and Mike Ogle are nearing their end of the season-long odyssey known as Going Big. Along the way theyve seen a little bit of everything, but nothing as jaw-dropping as Missouri assuming the No. 1 ranking. They also managed to solve the season-long mystery of why a flag from Washington State has been in the background for 61 consecutive broadcasts of ESPNs College Gameday. So make sure the gas tank is full. Its time to hit the road.

title: Quips Fly as Council Ponders Recycling Plastic Bags
description: Plastic bags, according to the lobby group reusablebags.com, are responsible for the deaths of hundreds of sea turtles, whales and other marine life that accidentally ingest them.

title: Intensifying the Hunt Against Somali Pirates
description: Pirates operating off the coast of Somalia havent caused so much havoc by simply being ruthless. Their innovative tactics have enabled them to launch attacks farther out on the high seas than small skiffs should be able to go, and then they evade pursuers by floating closer to the shore, where international patrols cant follow without permission from Somalias embattled government.

title: Blogtalk: CNN Debate Under Fire
description: Whew. CNN had barely been confronted by the disclosure last night that one of the video questioners  (the gay retired general)  served on two of Hillary Clintons committees before computer keyboards from one coast to another began sounding off heatedly.

title: A How-To Guide for Sovereign Wealth Funds
description: Sovereign wealth funds based in Asia and the Middle East are on the move. In recent months, these huge government-backed investment firms have taken stakes in Bear Stearns, the Carlyle Group, Advanced Micro Devices, and perhaps most notably, Citigroup.

title: Cruz Is Out at Morgan Stanley
description: Morgan Stanley said Thursday that Zoe Cruz, a co-president and one of the highest-ranking women on Wall Street, would leave the investment bank in the latest management shakeup since the summers credit turmoil.

title: Could Home Sales Be Better Than Reported?
description: The home sales numbers are dismal, but they may not be as bad as some think.

title: Broadway Goes Back to Work
description: After 19 dark days, Broadway theaters reopen for business.

title: Facebook Executive Discusses Beacon Brouhaha
description: Update: The interview below took place hours before Facebook announced a major change in its Beacon system, one that requires users to explicitly approve the sending of information to their friends News Feeds. See our article for details.

title: Jozy Altidore: Next Stop China
description: Red Bulls forward Jozy Altidore contributes items for The New York Times Goal blog each week. In his latest post, Altidore discusses a coming trip to China with the United States mens Olympic team for games on Dec. 13 in Changsha and Dec. 16 in Guangzhou, and his brief off-season.

title: The Banjo Santa
description: Meet Warren McKnight of Riverhead, N.Y., on Long Island.

title: Broadway Goes Back to Work
description: After 19 dark days, Broadway theaters reopen for business.

title: Verizons Real Move to Openness
description: Verizon Wireless got a lot of attention Tuesday for its vague announcement about offering open access to its network. But a much geekier announcement today may well be more important.

title: Cowboys-Packers Pregame: Who Knows?
description: Pregame warm-ups arent necessarily an accurate barometer for things to come. Maybe with field-goal kickers clanking a few off the goal posts or hooking a few balls into the parking lot. But this moment stuck out like Jerry Jones ringing a bell in a Santa Claus outfit:

title: The New York Times Close Up
description: The guests on Sam Roberts's weekly NY1 program include Ira Berkow, a sports columnist for The Times.

title: Ouch  Packers Starters Out
description: I know a lot of folks cant watch the game because they dont have the NFL Network, so Ill try to post a few updates from Texas Stadium.

title: Garry Kasparov on Russian Media
description: An excerpt from an interview with The New York Times conducted last month.

title: One More Beacon Amendment From Facebook
description: Bowing a bit more to the recent angry sentiment from privacy advocates and some users, Facebook just made yet another change to its controversial Beacon program. No longer will the social network publish a users Internet activities to his or her friends on the service without getting explicit approval.

title: Reality Check
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani's tenure as mayor is a central part of his stump speech, but the statistics he cites are sometimes exaggerated or wrong. (Video: NBC News)

title: The Back of Henry Blodgets Envelope
description: In a cross-blog dialog, I challenged Henry Blodget of Silicon Alley Insider to estimate what the MSN division is worth if Microsoft traded it to take a partial stake in Yahoo. (This was Mr. Blodgets sensible proposed alternative to an outright purchase of Yahoo.)

title: Facebook Bows to Privacy Protest
description: We told you last week about the outcry  spearheaded by MoveOn.org  over a new feature on Facebook that broadcasts users purchases and other activity on some external websites to their friends and in their profiles on the social networking site.

title: This Might Be a Blowout
description: Somebody has to give in on this NFL Network issue, because 74 million or so of you are missing a shootout that the Cowboys are threatening to turn into a rout.

title: Favre is Out With Elbow Injury
description: Brett Favre has been knocked out of the game for at least one series with a right elbow injury. His return has been announced as questionable. Aaron Rodgers replaced him, and the Packers promptly went three-and-out.

title: Helicopter Parenting Turns Deadly
description: Megan Meier, a 13-year-old from Dardenne Prairie, Missouri, killed herself last year after an online relationship she believed she was having with a cute 16-year-old boy named Josh went very sour. What she didnt know  what her parents would learn six weeks after her death  was that Josh was the fictitious creation of Lori Drew, a then-47-year-old neighbor and the mother of one of Megans friends.

title: 'Promise' From Rudolph W. Giuliani
description: First aired on Nov. 29, 2007.

title: The Evolution of Facebooks Beacon
description: Facebook keeps tweaking its new Beacon advertising program, which tracks users actions on sites other than Facebook. The program ignited a petition from MoveOn.org Civic Action that has won the support of 50,000 Facebook users. Facebook introduced a new version of the Beacon alert box on Thursday that still lacks an easy way to avoid participating.

title: Favre Looks Done
description: Favre received treatment and had an X-ray at halftime. No word yet on the extent of the injury to his right elbow. He came out a few minutes into the third quarter and put a Packers cap on his head. Going by his body language, hes not coming back in, and now the Cowboys are teeing off on Aaron Rodgers. Just sacked him.

title: Home but Not Home
description: Iraqi officials handed out cash to returning refugees during an event at a Baghdad hotel.

title: Coach Rods First Quarterback
description: Jed Drenning was the first quarterback in Rich Rodriguezs spread offense. Drenning started for Glenville State in 1991, when Rodriguez was the coach. Now that the coach has West Virginia in the hunt for a national title, Drenning has fond memories of the spreads early days and he was nice enough to share them with us here at The Quad.

title: A YOO Conversation
description: One New York newspaper described YOO co-founders John Hitchcox and Philippe Starck as the odd couple of the building industry. In the framework of YOO, the design-focused development company with apartment tower projects around the world, Hitchcox is the businessman, the operator, the numbers guy; Starck is the flamboyant designer, able to speak for hours about the shape of a chair.

title: Cowboys 37, Packers 27, Final
description: Postgame: The Cowboys improve to 11-1 and cement their reputation as the N.F.C.s favorite to be the Patriots whipping boys in the Super Bowl. (New England has already beaten Dallas, 48-27, this season).

title: That Aloha Feeling
description: One of the inherent joys of college sports is the surreal feeling of discovery when a team or programs reaches the peak for the first time. This obviously happens more in basketball than football, as small schools often ambush their major-conference brethren in the N.C.A.A. tournament, which is almost tailor-made for such moments.

title: The New York Times Close Up
description: This week, Sam Roberts's guests include the Metro reporters Leslie Kaufman and Ben Weiser and the film critic A.O. Scott.

title: Police Say Olmert Inquiry Should Be Closed
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 29  The Israeli authorities, who were investigating whether Prime Minister Ehud Olmert acted criminally in the 2005 sale of a bank, recommended on Thursday that the case be closed, citing a lack of evidence.

title: U.S. Leans on Subprime Lenders to Freeze Rates
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  The Treasury Department is leaning on the nations biggest subprime mortgage lenders to help at least some of their borrowers avoid foreclosure, but the biggest obstacle is not the lenders themselves.

title: Manhattan: Job Numbers Continue to Rise
description: New York City has replaced nearly all of the jobs lost since employment in the city peaked before the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, according to federal data released yesterday. The number of jobs in the city, adjusted for seasonal hiring trends, rose to 3.742 million in October, from 3.738 million in September, figures from the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics showed. That was the highest level of employment in the city since January 2001, when there were 3.748 million jobs. Employment in the city has risen steadily all year, outpacing the rate of job growth in the nation, the Labor Department said, but some economists expect that trend to be disrupted soon by various labor strikes and layoffs at big financial firms.

title: Bombs Found Near Home of Politician in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 29  Two car bombs were found near the house of a senior Sunni political leader on Thursday, and seven of his bodyguards were arrested, an Iraqi military spokesman said.

title: Latino Immigrants Children Found Grasping English
description: Most children of Hispanic immigrants in the United States learn to speak English well by the time they are adults, even though three-quarters of their parents speak mainly Spanish and do not have a command of English, according to a report released yesterday by the Pew Hispanic Center in Washington.

title: New Look for the New Museum
description: New York is in the cultural doldrums. The city is bursting with gorgeous art exhibitions, but where is the raw energy? Where is the new blood, intent on upending the establishment? Today, once-rebellious talents often seem to be wandering lost in the constellation of celebrity, where they soon settle into complacency.

title: Bush Renews Call for Congress to Pass Iraq Financing Bill With No Strings
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  President Bush on Thursday began a new offensive against Congressional Democrats over money for the Iraq war, calling on the lawmakers to give American troops what they need to succeed in their missions and pass a bill without strings attached.

title: A Landscaper Is Mauled, and an Outpouring of Sympathy Goes to the Dog
description: PRINCETON, N.J.

title: Mexico: Governor Off the Hook in Press Case
description: The Supreme Court ruled that Gov. Mario Marin of Puebla State did not violate the rights of a journalist, Lydia Cacho, when he had her briefly jailed on slander charges that were later dropped. She had accused a well-connected Puebla businessman of having links to a pedophilia ring. The case had been closely followed in Mexico as a test of press freedom.

title: Plans for Annex to Governors Mansion Draw Critics
description: NASHVILLE, Nov. 29  A low-key Democrat, Gov. Phil Bredesen is often praised for his level head and business sense. He was easily re-elected to a second term last fall, sweeping every county in Tennessee.

title: Turkey Takes Publisher to Task Over Book Questioning God
description: ISTANBUL, Nov. 29  Turkish prosecutors on Thursday questioned the Turkish publisher of the book The God Delusion, by a British author, Richard Dawkins, after a young reader complained that it was offensive, the publisher said.

title: Spas and Stars, but Ojai Tries to Stay Grounded
description: FINDING the ideal small-town retreat is getting tougher these days, at least for urban escapees whose checklist for perfection includes some potentially contradictory traits.

title: Medicares Doughnut Hole
description: To the Editor:

title: Queens: Shots Fired at Police Officers
description: A 33-year-old man was arrested yesterday after he fired at police officers who were trying to arrest him after they saw him toss aside a different gun. The officers, none of whom were hurt, arrested the man without returning fire, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said. It showed tremendous restraint on the part of the officers, Mr. Kelly said. He said that a police sergeant and two officers saw the man, identified as Nnamdi Clarke, toss the gun shortly before 1 a.m. near 97th Place and 57th Avenue. They chased him, and Mr. Clarke, of Horace Harding Expressway, fired one shot before his weapon jammed, the police said. They said that Mr. Clarke had not yet been charged yesterday evening. The police commissioner said that the suspect had two guns, a .25-caliber automatic and a .32-caliber automatic, as well as several bags of marijuana.

title: The Kids Got Energy. Now Watch Him Conduct.
description: AND now, the real debut.

title: British Teacher Found Guilty in Sudan
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 29  The British teacher in Sudan who let her 7-year-old pupils name a class teddy bear Muhammad was found guilty on Thursday of insulting Islam and sentenced to 15 days in jail and deportation.

title: For Both Sides in Broadway Strike, the Message Was: Take Me Seriously
description: After a two-and-a-half week strike that sapped the city of nearly $40 million, wiped away millions of dollars of potential ticket sales and left hundreds of actors, musicians and stagehands without paychecks, the payoff finally arrived. And anyone not intimately familiar with the business of Broadway could be forgiven for asking: Is that it?

title: Rangers Win Game According to Plan
description: When Rangers center Brandon Dubinsky scored to put the final touch on the Rangers 4-2 victory against the Islanders, his exuberance included raucously slamming against the boards with his linemates, Martin Straka and Jaromir Jagr.

title: Strings and Things: Classicals Best and Brightest
description: The talk of doom and gloom for the classical recording industry, or at least its CD wing, proceeds apace. Yet recordings continue to stream out from new sources as well as from major labels in retrenchment or recovery. And many of them are truly excellent. The classical music critics of The New York Times here offer a guide to the some of this years most notable.

title: TV Host to Pay Some of His Staff
description: Conan OBrien, the host of NBCs Late Night show, has agreed to pay nonwriting staff members on his show their regular salaries starting on Monday if the strike by scriptwriters against networks and studios is not resolved.

title: Rebel Officers Surrender in Manila
description: MANILA, Nov. 29  Philippine SWAT teams stormed a five-star hotel commandeered by dissident army officers today, arresting a senator, a former vice president, a Catholic bishop and several journalists after a seven-hour standoff.

title: China Agrees to Remove Certain Export Subsidies
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  Bowing to American pressure on the eve of high-level talks to reduce economic tensions, China agreed Thursday to terminate a dozen different subsidies and tax rebates that promote its own exports and discourage imports of steel, wood products, information technology and other goods.

title: In a House of Connection, Isolated Still
description: Gina Gibneys distinctive choreographic voice has made her one of the most intellectually stimulating of New York dance artists. There is nothing particularly brainy about her dances. She does not play mind games. Instead, quietly, she deals in abstractions, making them do the work of expression for her.

title: A Payoff for Syrians: Seats at the Table, at Least
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  For almost three years, Syria has been in the diplomatic doghouse, shunned by the United States, disrespected by France, bombed by Israel and even scolded by its fellow Arab governments for cozying up to Iran.

title: Musharraf Sets Date for End of Emergency Rule
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 29  Hours after being sworn in to a second term, President Pervez Musharraf announced Thursday that he would lift his state of emergency on Dec. 16, leaving barely three weeks for election campaigning and setting the stage for further confrontation with his opposition.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article in some editions yesterday about the Republican presidential debate misstated the response of former Senator Fred D. Thompson in a passage about high points for many candidates. During the debate, he offered a spirited defense of gun rights, not gun control.

title: The Davis Cup and the Greatest Generation
description: Their moment to collectively shine did not simply materialize. The opportunity to define their comparatively under-credentialed generation of American mens tennis did not present itself like some slick marketing campaign.

title: Knicks Are a Flop in Prime Time
description: BOSTON, Nov. 29  Fifty-two points separated the Boston Celtics from the Knicks late Thursday night, and it was hard to say whether the biggest gap was on the scoreboard, or between Coach Isiah Thomas and his players.

title: Slumping Motorola Replaces Its Chief
description: Motorola said today that its chief executive was stepping down, a move Wall Street had long expected as the company struggled to revive its troubled mobile division.

title: Fed Chief Offers New Hint on a Rate Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, acknowledged on Thursday that a fresh wave of investor concern had led to tougher credit conditions that posed new risks to the economy, reinforcing the view that the Fed is likely to cut interest rates again, when it meets on Dec. 11.

title: Court Orders Police to Return Marijuana
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 29  A California appeals court has ordered the police in Garden Grove to return marijuana that was seized from a man during a routine traffic stop, ruling that enforcement of federal drug laws did not supersede the states allowance of marijuana for medicinal purposes.

title: 3 Held in Killing of Sean Taylor
description: The police have detained three men for questioning in death of Washington Redskins safety Sean Taylor, according to two law enforcement officials in Lee County, Fla.

title: Broadways Delayed Curtain
description: The just-ended strike by stagehands that shut down most Broadway theaters went on an agonizingly long 19 days. Besides disappointing anyone holding tickets, the strike was particularly unnerving for the thousands of people whose livelihoods depend on the money that theatergoers spend in and around the district.

title: Bobby Van, Saloonkeeper and Pianist in the Hamptons, Dies at 64
description: Bobby Van, a pianist and restaurateur who for nearly two decades presided over the Bridgehampton saloon that bore his name, an upscale oasis frequented by literary royalty like Truman Capote, Kurt Vonnegut and Joseph Heller, died on Tuesday in Nassau County. He was 64.

title: Google to Join Spectrum Auction
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30  True to its promise earlier this year, Google said today that it was preparing to take part in the federal governments auction of radio frequencies that could be used to deliver the next generation of Internet and mobile phone services to consumers.

title: Henry J. Hyde, a Power in the House of Representatives, Dies at 83
description: Former Representative Henry J. Hyde, the powerful Illinois Republican who won battles to prohibit federal financing of abortions and to impeach President Clinton but who failed to persuade the Senate to convict and remove him from office, died yesterday in Chicago. He was 83.

title: Putting on Weight for Football Glory
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 29  When the Desire Street Academy football team plays in a Louisiana state semifinal playoff game Friday night, the Lions will feature three starting linemen who weigh at least 300 pounds and two others who weigh 270 and 280 pounds, reflecting a trend in which high school players are increasingly reaching a size once seen almost exclusively among linemen in college and the N.F.L.

title: Brief but Pointed Journeys in the Wilderness Within
description: The poor guy slumps before a cluster of microphones, sweating defeat and helplessness. This should all come as no surprise, he says. The phrase, of course, you are familiar with. It was a building year, this last year was. We suffered some losses, yes, we suffered some last season, and we had to start out all over.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Polishing Sets and Lines, Broadway Comes Back
description: At Chicago, the cast had to do a run-through because the new leading man and two other stars joining the show  Vincent Pastore and Aida Turturro, of The Sopranos  had never rehearsed together.

title: Familiar With Emo, Intimate With Upbeat
description: Around 10:30 on Wednesday night, Paramores short and generally sharp set ended, and a few thousand people started filing out of the Roseland Ballroom. Outside on West 52nd Street, there was a barricade and, behind it, a row of eager faces.

title: Giuliani Defends Spending on His Mayoral Security
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani last night called a Web sites account of his spending a political hit job as his campaign struggled to explain why hundreds of thousands of dollars in travel expenses for his mayoral security detail were billed to obscure city offices instead of the Police Department.

title: Closing Arguments Begin in Trial of Men Charged in Plot to Destroy the Sears Tower
description: MIAMI, Nov. 29  A group of Miami men led by an impoverished construction worker tried to form an alliance with Al Qaeda and start a homegrown religious insurrection against the American government that would include spectacular attacks just as good or greater than 9/11, a federal prosecutor said Thursday in closing arguments in the trial of the group.

title: Sprint Is Said to Reject Offer by Investors and SK Telecom
description: Sprint Nextel has rejected an offer from Providence Equity Partners and SK Telecom of South Korea to replace management and invest $5 billion in the company, according to people apprised of the situation.

title: Countering Schizophrenia by Finding Solace in Art
description: Rodney Smith sat and shuffled and reshuffled a small stack of business cards he held in his large, gentle hands.

title: Bush Urges Congress to Increase AIDS Money
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  Marking the 20th anniversary of World AIDS day, President Bush urged Congress today to make more money available to fight the disease, and he announced that that he and his wife, Laura, will visit sub-Saharan Africa early in 2008.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article in some editions yesterday about the Republican presidential debate misstated the response of former Senator Fred D. Thompson in a passage about high points for many candidates. During the debate, he offered a spirited defense of gun rights, not gun control. (Go to Article)

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column on Nov. 20 about performances by the singer and songwriter Natalie Merchant at Club Hiro in New York starting on Jan. 4 misstated her recent performing history. The Club Hiro dates will be her first full concerts in four years, not her first live appearances in four years.

title: Wounds of the Revolution
description: BEIJING

title: Food and Fun
description: A cloying blend of Bollywood sentiment and Amlie whimsy, Ninas Heavenly Delights is a lesbian-foodie fairy tale that keeps its appetites well under control. The title may hint at naughty pleasures, but the director, Pratibha Parmar, is more interested in pappadams than passion.

title: Romo, T.O. Stand Tall as Injuries Fell Favre
description: IRVING, Tex., Nov. 29  The Dallas Cowboys stamped their claim to N.F.C. supremacy with a 37-27 victory against the Green Bay Packers on Thursday night when the duel between Tony Romo and Brett Favre never materialized.

title: Ecuador Congress Is Dissolved in Vote
description: Members of an elected assembly convened to rewrite Ecuador's Constitution voted last night to dissolve Congress, a move expected to strengthen President Rafael Correa. The decision gives the assembly the legislative powers of Congress while it debates a new Constitution over the next six months. Mr. Correa has been seeking to strengthen the office of the president after a long bout of political instability; he is the eighth president in 10 years. The assembly is controlled by Mr. Correa's movement.

title: Pushing for Livability Amid Downtowns Chaos
description: Sure, urban lobbyists are made, not born. But if the force field emanating from Elizabeth H. Berger, the excitable, fancifully attired (she swears by quirky designer finds from her neighbor, the Century 21 store) new president of the Alliance for Downtown New York, is a reliable signifier, once a lobbyist, always a lobbyist.

title: On Lake Michigan, a Port of Call for Art
description: THE building at 328 Main Street in Racine, Wis., started life as a dry goods store in 1854. A newspaper named The Times-Call took it over at the turn of the 20th century. In the 1930s, it became a high-end fur shop, with a facade reflecting its elegance, and later it did a stint as a church.

title: Giuliani on Taxes, Democrats and Record as Mayor
description: The campaign of Rudolph W. Giuliani began running its fourth advertisement yesterday in New Hampshire.

title: A Seascape Dotted by Chaotic Bursts
description: Some theatrical pieces inspire a vague and intermittent boredom as they are performed, yet feel worthwhile by the time you emerge, blinking, into the theater lobby. Such was Ship in a View, a work performed by the Japanese dance-theater company Pappa Tarahumara, which opened at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday night as part of the Next Wave Festival.

title: Study Details How U.S. Could Cut 28% of Greenhouse Gases
description: The United States could shave as much as 28 percent off the amount of greenhouse gases it emits at fairly modest cost and with only small technology innovations, according to a new report.

title: Hedge Fund to Nominate Four for Brinks Board
description: Millbrook Capital, the activist hedge fund seeking a breakup or sale of the Brinks Company, is expected to announce its four nominees today for directors of the security company.

title: Some Essential Hardware (Even Away From the Street)
description: For almost every lawyer, accountant, Wall Street executive or deal maker, the briefcase and the BlackBerry can be a lifeline to the office, particularly for those on the road for business or commuting from the suburbs. Executives these days cant go anywhere without the cellphone or the BlackBerry, but there are other gadgets and high-tech devices that are also catching on  some for work, but many for relaxation.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: The Economic Effect

title: Atlanta Police Tied to Child Pornography Case
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 29  The husband of a city police sergeant was arrested on a child pornography charge on Thursday, and federal investigators said police officers had apparently withheld and destroyed evidence in the case.

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: Chiefs Lineman Tries to Spark Generosity
description: Kansas City Chiefs lineman Kyle Turley wants his contribution to be the first of millions of dollars donated by todays players to the pioneers of the N.F.L. He said he hoped that his announced donation would prompt other active players to turn over their game paychecks on Dec. 23, a day being called Gridiron Guardian Sunday.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Body Unwilling, a Mind Takes Flight
description: Julian Schnabel has made three feature films: Basquiat, Before Night Falls and now The Diving Bell and the Butterfly. All are biographical, examining the lives of real people, and in each case the protagonist struggles with a condition of literal or metaphorical imprisonment. Jean-Michel Basquiat, Mr. Schnabels younger colleague in the New York art scene of the 1980s, is trapped by addiction and by his outsider status. Reinaldo Arenas, the gay Cuban poet whose memoir was the basis of Before Night Falls, is censored, harassed and locked up by successive dictatorships.

title: States Take Up Immigration Issue
description: State lawmakers, stepping into a vacuum left by the defeat of immigration legislation in Washington, have considered more than 1,560 bills related to immigration this year and enacted 244 of them in 46 states, according to a report by the National Conference of State Legislatures. The number of measures enacted nearly tripled from the 84 in 2006, creating a legal patchwork for immigrants across the country. A large number of measures determined whether states would give drivers and other licenses to illegal immigrants, and established penalties for employers hiring those immigrants.

title: Dell Raises Earnings and Sales; Shares Fall
description: Dell, undergoing a transformation to reach consumers worldwide and a broader base of business customers, reported improved financial results that nevertheless disappointed Wall Street.

title: Russia: Berezovsky Sentenced in Absentia
description: A Moscow court convicted the Russian oligarch Boris Berezovsky in absentia of embezzling millions of dollars from the national airline, Aeroflot. Mr. Berezovsky, one of President Vladimir V. Putins most vocal critics, received a prison sentence of six years. He lives in Britain and did not contest the charges, saying they were trumped up. Britain will not extradite him.

title: Panel Rebuffs White House Privilege Claim
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  The Senate Judiciary Committee inched forward Thursday in its struggle with the White House over subpoenas demanding information from current and former Bush administration officials about the firing of several United States attorneys last year.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded: $2,417,341.86

title: Beautiful Manhole Covers, but at What Price?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Wednesday about Ryan Lochte, an elite American swimmer, misstated the distance of a long-course race in which he has posted three of the 10 fastest times. It is the 200-meter individual medley, not the 400. As the article noted, Lochte also swims in the short-course 200-yard individual medley. (Long-course events take place in a 50-meter pool, and short-course races are in a 25-yard pool.)

title: A Hero of Hockey
description: Youre the Babe Ruth of hockey. Thats what Dick Irvin (Stephen McHattie), coach of the Montreal Canadiens, says to Maurice Richard (Roy Dupuis), the teams great star of the 1940s and 50s. The Rocket, Charles Binams 2005 film (which starts a brief theatrical run in Manhattan today), certainly gives him the kind of adoring biopic treatment sports heroes used to enjoy routinely. Mr. Binam and the movies screenwriter, Ken Scott, present a Richard who has, off the ice, little in common with the boisterous Babe. Hes a faithful husband and a strong, silent hunk of blue-collar stoicism, as well as a fighter against discrimination and injustice  a combination of Jackie Robinson and the Gary Cooper version of Lou Gehrig, if you insist on a baseball analogy.

title: Capital Is King Once Again
description: When you take big risks, you expect big rewards if all goes well. Right?

title: Stocks Surge, Then Give Up Early Gains
description: Stocks soared early today, but gradually gave up much of their gains as investors weighed the bad news with the good.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption with an article yesterday about high-technology toys misidentified one item shown. It was the ClickStart, My First Computer, by LeapFrog, not the Easy Link Internet Launch Pad by Fisher-Price.

title: A Cosmopolitan Voice Wedded to a Smoky Sax
description: A peripatetic jet-set couple shuttling between London and Paris with extended visits to Rio de Janiero and Tokyo: that is the glamorous picture that the pop-jazz singer Stacey Kent and her husband, the saxophonist Jim Tomlinson, conjured on Wednesday evening at Birdland.

title: Stormy Outlook in Vienna: Atonal, Serial and Cryptic
description: There were two ways to approach the concert that Tactus, an exemplary young contemporary-classical ensemble from the Manhattan School of Music, presented in the schools Ades Performance Space on Wednesday night. On the program were Schoenbergs Pierrot Lunaire and Bergs Chamber Concerto for Violin, Piano and 13 Winds. (A third work previously announced, Jorg Herchets Piece for Solo Flute, was omitted without comment.)

title: Giants Struggles Go Beyond Manning
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 29  Little has gone right for the Giants offense in the last three games. Take the rushing attack. During the first eight games of the season, the Giants averaged 138 yards on the ground. In the three since then, two of them losses, they averaged 84 yards.

title: Broadway, Restaged
description: SO: the curtains are up, the marquees are glowing, the Playbills are once again stacked in their neat little piles. Now what?

title: Miami Art Museum to Unveil Design for New Building
description: Although revisions are usually inevitable, museums planning a new building typically present the design as a done deal, with every detail resolved and the architects ready to break ground.

title: Corzine Is Set to Revamp School Aid Formula
description: After more than a year of review, Gov. Jon S. Corzine will propose a new school financing formula as early as next week that would give at least $400 million in new state money to poor and disadvantaged children who live outside traditional inner-city school districts, according to officials familiar with the plan.

title: Missing Top Players, Jets Look to Tight End for a Boost
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 29  Laveranues Coles, one of the Jets starting wide receivers, has missed two of the last three games. Jerricho Cotchery, the other starting wideout, hurt his right index finger in Mondays practice.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The On Education column on Nov. 28, about private firms that use branding techniques to coach high school students who apply to college, misstated the educational credentials of Chioma Isiadinso, founder of a small New York coaching firm, Expartus. She has a masters in education from the University of Pittsburgh, not an M.B.A. from Harvard.

title: Ralph Beard, Kentucky Star Involved in Point-Shaving Scandal, Is Dead at 79
description: Ralph Beard, who propelled the University of Kentucky to two consecutive N.C.A.A. basketball championships in the late 1940s, and starred in the N.B.A. before his career was shattered by involvement in a widespread collegiate point-shaving scandal, died yesterday in Louisville, Ky. He was 79.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A headline and picture caption with an article in some editions on Wednesday about a search for a new operator of the heliport in downtown New York misidentified the agency that is conducting the search. It is the citys Economic Development Corporation, not the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. (The Port Authority, the current operator, did not renew its lease.)

title: Lottery Numbers
Prosecutor Seeks to Pull Kerik Lawyer
description: A judge should consider removing the defense lawyer representing Bernard B. Kerik, the citys former police commissioner, because the lawyer might be called as a witness, federal prosecutors said yesterday in a request they sent to a court.

title: Former Rep. Henry Hyde Is Dead at 83
description: Former Representative Henry J. Hyde, who won battles to prohibit federal funding of abortions and to impeach President Clinton but failed to persuade the Senate to convict and remove him from office, died yesterday.

title: Lebanese Opposition Leader Backs Army Chief for President
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 29  The political logjam over Lebanons vacant presidency was broken Thursday when a leader of the Syrian-backed opposition announced his support for the compromise candidate accepted by the pro-Western alliance. The deal follows Syrias participation in the American-sponsored Middle East peace conference.

title: Musharraf Defends Actions After Taking Oath
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 29  President Pervez Musharraf was sworn in to a second five-year presidential term today, a day after stepping down as military chief. He warned foreign diplomats assembled for the ceremony not to force democracy and human rights on developing countries, but to let them evolve in their own time.

title: 1,000 Police Enforce Uneasy Peace in Paris Suburb
description: VILLIERS-LE-BEL, France, Nov. 29  The first thing everyone mentions is the helicopters: the relentless throbbing of blades cutting through the skies above the housing projects and the probing searchlights that have kept the residents of this heavily immigrant suburb of Paris awake over the last four nights.

title: Reveling in the Stillness, Puzzling Over the Self
description: There is something distinctly female about the quiet, controlled worlds that Beth Gill creates. They conjure the still interiors of an Anita Brookner novel, or the sensual gradations in an Agnes Martin painting. Disruptions are subsonic.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article yesterday about John Tavares, a promising 17-year-old hockey player for the Oshawa Generals in Ontario, misspelled the surname of the former National Hockey League defenseman who coaches the team. He is Brad Selwood, not Sellwood.

title: Yankees and Red Sox Competing for Santana
description: The Yankees and the Boston Red Sox have been competing on and off the field for more than a century. So it is not surprising that the teams are now feverishly competing to acquire Johan Santana, the elite left-handed pitcher from the Minnesota Twins.

title: Appeals Court Voids Agreement to Pay Freelancers for Work Published on the Web
description: A federal appeals court yesterday threw out a hard-fought agreement between publishers and freelance writers to pay the writers for electronic reproduction of their work.

title: Reading Fun Before Frosty Melts Away, and After
description: Will there be another white Christmas? The polar bears, dressed for snow, nervously await the answer. Given current climate trends, future generations will no doubt marvel at folk memories of snowball fights, ice skating and arguments about how anyone can possibly know that no two snowflakes are alike. Yes, Virginia, we used to have winter, and Santa traveled with a herd of reindeer, not camels.

title: A Soccer Players Ordeal in an Argentine Prison
description: From an early scene in which a gang of thugs kicks and yells at the frail, cowering mother of a man whose whereabouts they demand to know, Israel Adrin Caetanos film Chronicle of an Escape makes your stomach knot in anticipation that worse is to come. Minutes later, as the object of their search, a soccer player named Claudio M. Tamburrini (Rodrigo de la Serna), makes his way home after a game, he is blindfolded and dragged into a car. Taken to a sinister mansion in suburban Buenos Aires, he is thrown into a room with other prisoners who have been rounded up for interrogation.

title: Chvez Proposals Would Make Finances Opaque
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 29  As petrodollars stream into oil-producing countries, Western officials have begun to demand greater accountability for how they are spent. Some countries known for corruption, like Nigeria and Azerbaijan, have heeded the call, increasing their financial transparency, or at least paying lip service to it. But Venezuela under the leadership of President Hugo Chvez appears headed in the opposite direction.

title: Army Official Resigning
description: The Armys top procurement official, Gen. Claude M. Bolton Jr., is resigning, Army officials said. General Boltons resignation comes one month after an independent panel criticized how the Army oversees $4 billion a year in contracts for food, water, shelter and other supplies to sustain American forces in Iraq, Kuwait and Afghanistan. General Bolton, a retired two-star Air Force general, plans to leave on Jan. 2, after exactly six years in his current job. He is scheduled to testify before a Senate subcommittee next week on the review panels conclusion that the Army failed to train enough experienced contracting officers to operate in combat zones.

title: Former Governors Daughter Seeks a Congressional Seat in New Jersey
description: TRENTON, Nov. 29  Another aspiring politician hopes to go into the family business in New Jersey.

title: In Chvez Territory, Signs of Dissent
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 29  Three days before a referendum that would vastly expand the powers of President Hugo Chvez, this citys streets were packed on Thursday with tens of thousands of opponents to the change. The protests signaled that Venezuelans may be balking at placing so much authority in the hands of one man.

title: New York TV Station Takes Chance on Liquor Ads
description: ALMOST six years after NBC ended an experiment to bring the first liquor commercials onto national broadcast network television, the flagship station it owns, WNBC-TV in New York, has started running such spots.

title: Citadel Throws E*Trade a $2.55 Billion Lifeline
description: When shares of E*Trade Financial began tumbling this month amid speculation that its faltering mortgage investments were jeopardizing its health, the company began casting about for a solution.

title: Haunted History
description: The documentary Oswalds Ghost initially plays as yet another primer on the assassination of John F. Kennedy, the vilification of Lee Harvey Oswald, the normalization of conspiracy theory and the collective aftershocks of a murder many Americans still consider unsolved.

title: Cyclocross: Mud, Sweat and Gears
description: ABOVE the pool of filth, but still within the shadow of the ditch, my bike skidded sideways in muck. Heads up! yelled a fellow racer, elbow out, body a blur.

title: Kasparov Warns of Chaos in Russia
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 29  Released from jail after serving a five-day sentence for leading an opposition march, Garry Kasparov, the former chess champion, warned today that Russia was heading toward chaos under President Vladimir V. Putin.

title: Gay Question Puts CNN on Defensive
description: The president of CNN said yesterday that the cable channel would redouble its efforts to vet the campaign affiliations of questioners at open-forum debates, after a retired brigadier general was permitted Wednesday to ask the Republican presidential candidates about gay men and lesbians in the military without CNNs knowing that he was listed on an advisory committee of Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Here Comes the Bride With Chewing Gum
description: Anyone too busy during the last couple of decades to make it to the Off Broadway production that inspired Tony N Tinas Wedding can relax: the film version is now being granted a limited release. Exactly how limited will depend on your tolerance for tasteless behavior, extravagant overacting and a decibel level to rival the unveiling of Oprahs Favorite Things.

title: Art in Review
description: CHARLES RAY

title: Sharing (for a Price)
description: PART of the joy of owning a second home is sharing it with others. And all the better if those others are willing to pay for the privilege. If thats one of the reasons youre thinking of buying a ski condo  or renting out one you already own  then you need to consider a few big questions.

title: A New Push to Roll Back Dont Ask, Dont Tell
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  Marking the 14th anniversary of legislation that allowed gay men and lesbians to serve in the military but only if they kept their orientation secret, 28 retired generals and admirals plan to release a letter on Friday urging Congress to repeal the law.

title: Resurrecting a Firebird and Transcending a Choreographer in a Single Bound
description: For those of us who attend too many galas, Wednesdays opening night of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater season at City Center was a happy model of how these things should be done. The onstage speeches projected good humor; a sense of pride in work and in colleagues; and belief in the work, the cause and indeed the whole art form of dance. Especially in the personality of the companys artistic director, Judith Jamison, they built a showbiz sense of anticipation before each dance.

title: Central Rome Streets Blocked by Taxi Drivers
description: ROME, Nov. 29  If the question ever arises again, Romans now know how long it takes to paralyze the entire city center: 20 minutes.

title: Oxygen Suppliers Fight to Keep a Medicare Boon
description: Millions of people with respiratory diseases have relied on oxygen equipment, delivered to their homes, to help them breathe. A basic setup, including three years of deliveries of small oxygen tanks, can be bought from pharmacies and other retailers for as little as $3,500, or about $100 a month.

title: Rivalry With Celtics Stirs Thomass Passion
description: BOSTON, Nov. 29  Isiah Thomas started his day with talk of rivalries and hatred and the sort of fierce competition that drives a team deep into the spring. The references were all in the past tense, however; his current team is not ready for such weighty emotions.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption with an article yesterday about the Bush administrations effort to provide impetus for peace efforts on the day after Israeli and Palestinian leaders committed themselves to negotiating a peace treaty reversed the position of the leaders shown walking with President Bush. Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel was on the left and Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president, was on the right.

title: British Muslim Leaders Propose Code of Conduct
description: LONDON, Nov. 29  Moderate British Muslim leaders on Thursday proposed guidelines that aim to root out extremism, promote a culture of civic responsibility and foster womens rights in the countrys mosques, Islamic centers and Muslim schools.

title: By the Beach, a Town Where Winter Also Has Its Fans
description: ON the drive south from Neahkahnie Mountain toward Manzanita on the north coast of Oregon, the view is startling: broad cobalt skies above shaving-cream waves that ghost toward shore, all complemented by low, purple mountains that bulk in the distance.

title: On the Golden Eagle Jump, Its Form Against Fear
description: BEAVER CREEK, Colo., Nov. 29  One of the most fearsome jumps in downhill ski racing is on the second half of the Birds of Prey course at Beaver Creek, the only stop the mens World Cup circuit makes in the United States.

title: Mandates and Mudslinging
description: From the beginning, advocates of universal health care were troubled by the incompleteness of Barack Obamas plan, which unlike those of his Democratic rivals wouldnt cover everyone. But they were willing to cut Mr. Obama slack on the issue, assuming that in the end he would do the right thing.

title: Facebook Retreats on Online Tracking
description: Faced with its second mass protest by members in its short life span, Facebook, the enormously popular social networking Web site, is reining in some aspects of a controversial new advertising program.

title: Hokulia and Seclusion Bay
description: Hokulia

title: Suspect Is Arrested in Clinton Office Standoff
description: A tense standoff at a presidential campaign office of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in Rochester, N.H., ended shortly after 6 p.m. this evening when a man later identified as Leeland Eisenberg was taken into police custody after holding at least four people hostage. There were no apparent injuries.

title: A War Heros Terror, Tragedy and Rescue
description: Badland, a melodrama by the writer and director Francesco Lucente, stands apart from the recent throng of post-9/11 dramas by posing a burning question we havent heard yet: Can a mentally ill Iraq war veteran who murdered his pregnant wife and two of his children learn how to love again?

title: Drop in Sales of a Drug Leads to a Write-Down
description: Johnson & Johnson said last night that it would record a $440 million write-down to account for declining revenue from its heart-failure infusion treatment, Natrecor.

title: Lott the Latest in Unusual Retirement Trend
description: There used to be a saying about the Senate that the only way someone left was by the ballot box or feet first. Except for the occasional run for the White House or governor, hardly anyone voluntarily relinquished such a rarefied position, with its attendant aura of power and dignified public service.

title: Keeping the Focus on AIDS
description: To the Editor:
