title: The Evolution of a Broken Play
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Nov. 27  In the fall of 1991, Glenville State quarterback Jed Drenning left the field with a few fractured fingers and numerous body bruises. He had been sacked 20 times by West Virginia State, and no one was more embarrassed than his coach, Rich Rodriguez.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day last Friday about a deal between Gazprom, the Russian energy giant, and Eni, the Italian energy group, referred imprecisely to its scope. It was a contract to conduct a feasibility study on a pipeline linking Russia to Europe via the Black Sea; it was not a contract to build the pipeline. (A memorandum of agreement between Gazprom and Eni signed in June detailed the companies plans to design, finance and manage the construction of the pipeline.)

title: Mexican Court Finds No Violation of Rights in Jailing of Journalist
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 29  In a setback for journalistic freedom in Mexico, the Supreme Court ruled Thursday that the governor of Puebla did not violate the rights of a journalist when he had her jailed on defamation charges.

title: Europeans Endorse Stricter Gun Control
description: The European Parliament overwhelmingly backed a set of stricter gun-control rules that would limit gun ownership across the 27-member European Union. Under the rules, which must be approved by national governments, minors under 18 would be allowed to possess a firearm only for hunting or target shooting under the guidance of an adult, and anyone over 18 who has been convicted of a violent crime would be banned from buying a gun.

title: In Slovakia, Three Are Held in a Uranium Smuggling Case
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 29  Two Hungarians and a Ukrainian were arrested Wednesday after trying to sell highly enriched uranium, Slovak diplomats and police authorities said Thursday. The quantity, however, was far too small to make a crude warhead.

title: No Longer a Secret, Paternos Base Coaching Salary Is $512,664
description: Joe Paternos salary as Penn States coach is $512,664, which is relatively modest among his peers for a man of his accomplishments and tenure.

title: Florida Freezes Its Fund as Governments Pull Out
description: Seeking to stem a multibillion-dollar run on an investment pool for local governments, top Florida officials voted yesterday to suspend withdrawals from the fund, leaving some towns and school districts worrying about how they would pay their bills.

title: Books to Make Spirits Bright
description: Here is information about the books included in William Grimes's 2007 Holiday Gift Guide:

title: Sears Profit Plunges; Cost Cuts Get Blame
description: Edward S. Lampert, the billionaire financier and chairman of Sears Holdings, is fond of saying that a company must be regularly pruned, like a tree or a wardrobe. But you cant cut your way to success, he warned investors in his annual letter this year.

title: M.T.A. Savings Proposal May Mean Service Cuts
description: Straphangers could be forgiven if they see something Grinchlike about the Metropolitan Transportation Authority this holiday season.

title: Its Not About Money in Pettitte Wait
description: Seven weeks after Andy Pettittes season ended with the Yankees, he is no closer to deciding if he will return and pitch for them again next season. Tom Pettitte, Andys father, said yesterday that Pettitte has not determined if he will retire or rejoin the Yankees for his 14th major league season.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,869 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Nov. 21 about a RAND Corporation study on street stops by the New York Police Department referred incorrectly at some points to an overall figure and misstated the number of individual officers who were found to be disproportionately more likely to stop whites. There were 508,540 street stops in 2006  not 508,540 people stopped  and 13 officers, not 9, tended to stop whites more often. The article also misstated the finding of a racial disparity in the handing out of summonses. Whites are more likely  not less  to receive them.

title: Business and Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: In Galleries, a Nervy Opening Volley
description: Nothing raises expectations or dashes hopes like a new building. When the New Museum of Contemporary Art opens tomorrow in its first built-from-scratch home, it will represent hope fulfilled and be a much more visible element in the always interesting New York museum landscape. Its new building is a stack of neutral, elegantly off-register, no-frills white cubes not only inside, but outside too. Its great truth in advertising, and achieves the bracing spareness of the best Swiss-German museums.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Economics, Immigrants and Lou Dobbs
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Advertising column on Wednesday, about efforts by the Advertising Council to devote more attention to online media, included a foundation erroneously in a coming campaign to discourage violence among teenagers. The Robert Wood Johnson Foundation is not involved in the campaign.

title: How the Littlest Nazi Turned Out to Be a Jew
description: A little boy running from the people who killed his mother, brother and sister is lost for months in a dark forest in Eastern Europe. He survives on wild berries and ties himself to trees to escape the howling wolves. Frozen and starving, he happens upon a hut that holds out the promise of food and warmth, but as with the hut in Hansel and Gretel, the promise is cruelly deceptive, and again he narrowly escapes death. Eventually he is rescued by soldiers. But they are dangerous, too, and he must hide from them the truth about himself. It is a truth so frightening that as time passes he gradually forgets who he is, to the point that he cannot even remember his name.

title: Injuries Reported in Train Crash
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 30  An Amtrak train slammed into a freight train at a Chicago South Side rail yard today, the impact forcing some passenger seats off their bracing and leaving dozens of people injured, authorities said.

title: Sanctuary Was a Lovely Word. Then the G.O.P. Got Hold of It.
description: When they finally got down to business, after being serenaded by a guitarist on YouTube, it took the Republican presidential candidates 11  minutes Wednesday night for one of them to acknowledge that illegal immigrants are human beings.

title: Obamas Color Line
description: BARACK OBAMA is running an astonishing campaign. Not only is he doing far better in the polls than any black presidential candidate in American history, but he has also raised more money than any of the candidates in either party except Hillary Clinton.

title: Russia Decides to Keep Davydenko in Reserve
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 29  Nikolay Davydenko, eager for this tumultuous season to be over, will get the chance Friday to take an early break.

title: Iraq Lacks Plan on the Return of Refugees, Military Says
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 29  As Iraqi refugees begin to stream back to Baghdad, American military officials say the Iraqi government has yet to develop a plan to absorb the influx and prevent it from setting off a new round of sectarian violence.

title: Minaya Rules Out Trading Reyes
description: Omar Minaya understands what it is like to be forced to trade a top pitcher. As the general manager of the Montreal Expos, Minaya was ordered to slash payroll after the 2002 season. So off went Bartolo Coln, whom Minaya had acquired only six months earlier.

title: Adult but Not Old
description: WHO Sheldon Cherapp, 66, a consultant and retired accountant, and his wife, Elaine, 65, of Rockville, Md. WHAT 4-bedroom house WHERE Lake Worth, Fla.

title: New in New Orleans
description: WHILE New Orleans continues to struggle to repopulate many residential neighborhoods after Hurricane Katrina pummeled the region in late August 2005, the bulk of the citys popular cultural assets, which generally suffered little damage, are pulling in tens of thousands of out-of-town visitors. And not only are those old venues still big draws  breakfast at Brennans, a stroll past street artists on Jackson Square, a visit to Preservation Hall to hear traditional jazz  an entirely new selection of cultural and culinary sites has emerged.

title: Theater Listings
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

title: On Nuclear Seesaw, the Balance Seems to Shift to Iran
description: PARIS, Nov. 29  Irans president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, is known for overheated, boastful pronouncements. So it was hardly a surprise earlier this month when he declared that despite demands from the United States and other countries that Iran stop enriching uranium, Tehran was pressing ahead and negotiations were out of the question.

title: Problematic Medical Scans
description: CT scans have long been cited as a prime example of how the overuse of fancy medical technologies can drive up the cost of health care. Now there are newly voiced concerns that computed tomography, or CT, may be a health risk as well.

title: Everything's Popping Up Showbiz
description: Like a Disney show itself, How Does the Show Go On?, a whiz-bang introduction to the inner workings of the commercial theater from Disney Editions, is gorgeously produced and cunningly designed to appeal to the largest possible audience. Kindergarten concepts (what is a ticket?) are explained alongside complicated issues that longtime theatergoers will have wondered about. In easily digestible, winking prose, Thomas Schumacher, who runs Disneys theatrical unit, and Jeff Kurtti, a Disney historian, define dummy lyrics, fight calls and house heads, and parse which union member is in charge of a candle.

title: Producer of Poisonous Toy Beads Issues Apology
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 29  The Hong Kong company that manufactured millions of poisonous toy beads in mainland China issued a public apology on Thursday, with the chairman saying that it had not occurred to anyone to check whether an inexpensive glue ingredient in the beads would be dangerous for children to eat.

title: Morgan Stanley Executive Ousted After Trading Loss
description: Morgan Stanley, its reputation battered over a recent $3.7 billion subprime trading loss, has become the latest Wall Street firm to force the retirement of a senior banking executive.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption with the Shifting Careers column in Business Day yesterday reversed the identifications of two of the three men shown. Richard Jepsen, a partner in OSCS Sailing School in San Francisco, was in the middle, not Larry Ledgerwood, a consultant, who was at the left.

title: Tower Planned Atop Port Authority Bus Terminal in New Wave of Development
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has revived plans to build a sleek 40-story office tower over the north wing of the West Side bus terminal at the suddenly hot intersection of Eighth Avenue and 42nd Street.

title: Obama Takes His Campaign to Harlem
description: Senator Barack Obama held a fund-raiser in Harlem last night, his first event in the historic seat of black cultural and political power since he announced his Democratic presidential candidacy and a place where Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton enjoys wide popularity.

title: Citing Statistics, Giuliani Misses Time and Again
description: In almost every appearance as he campaigns for the Republican presidential nomination, Rudolph W. Giuliani cites a fusillade of statistics and facts to make his arguments about his successes in running New York City and the merits of his views.

title: The Capitols Rich Afterlife
description: Senator Trent Lotts sudden decision to retire from public office has Washingtons lobbying industry salivating at the prospect that the Mississippi lawmaker may join the millionaires row on K Street. Thats where more and more Congressional alumni have been hanging their backslappers shingle to lobby old buddies. Mr. Lotts planned departure  conveniently ahead of the new two-year wait before a retired senator can lobby  is shedding light on Capitol Hills quasi-aristocracy of ex-incumbents who never return home and stay close by to work politics from its more lucrative shadow world.

title: Sometimes a Big Gun Takes Time to Unlimber
description: On Surprise, her recent debut recording for Deutsche Grammophon, the Canadian soprano Measha Brueggergosman sings amusing works by Schoenberg, Satie and William Bolcom with such presence, power and humor that she almost seems to fly out of the speakers. So it was odd to hear her give comparatively pale performances of the same songs (along with Britten, Poulenc and Rorem works) at Zankel Hall on Wednesday evening.

title: China Explains Decision to Block U.S. Ships
description: BEIJING, Nov. 29  China denied permission for a United States aircraft carrier battle group and other American warships to visit Hong Kong last week because of the Bush administrations proposal to sell upgrades to Patriot antimissile batteries to Taiwan, Chinese state media said today.

title: Still No Way Out
description: There has been so much horrible news out of Iraq for so long that it is natural to want to celebrate better news. Sending another 30,000 American troops into Iraq has made life better: attacks are down, as are the number of American and Iraqi casualties. Some refugees are even venturing home. The news has cheered Americans and dampened Democrats enthusiasm for keeping up the pressure on Iraq policy. Unfortunately, it is just as important to look at what has not happened since President Bush announced his surge: Iraqs leaders are no closer to making the political deals that are the only hope for building a self-sustaining peace.

title: Food Banks, in a Squeeze, Tighten Belts
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., Nov. 26  Food banks around the country are reporting critical shortages that have forced them to ration supplies, distribute staples usually reserved for disaster relief and in some instances close.

title: Men Behaving Extremely, With True Believers Passion
description: The four men who relate their life stories in Protagonist, Jessica Yus enthralling documentary exploration of people with obsessive needs for control and self-mastery, are all disillusioned (and extremely articulate) true believers. When they were younger, they were certain they had found the Answer. One embraced terrorism, another crime, a third martial arts and the fourth missionary Christianity as ways of transcending painful, oppressive childhoods that left them with feelings of inadequacy and shame.

title: Splitting Up a Collection
description: SPLITTING UP

title: California: City Votes to Restrict Jets
description: The Santa Monica City Council has challenged the Federal Aviation Administration by voting unanimously to ban the fastest jets now flying into the citys single-runway airport. The new challenge comes in response to concerns among residents and local officials about the potential for aircraft to overrun Santa Monicas runway. Homes sit as close as 250 feet to landing and departing aircraft. The F.A.A., which signed an agreement with the city in 1984 to prevent Santa Monica from regulating jet traffic, has vowed to fight the ordinance.

title: From City to City, 20th-Century Art and Furniture
description: December promises to be a big month for 20th-century furniture and decorative arts at fairs, auctions, exhibitions and events around the country. There is even a floating art gallery involved.

title: China: U.S. Navy Snub Not a Misunderstanding
description: The Foreign Ministry said China withdrew permission for the United States aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk to visit Hong Kong last week because of the Bush administrations proposal to sell antimissile upgrades to Taiwan, and not as a result of a misunderstanding, as the White House characterized it earlier. The ministrys spokesman, Liu Jianchao, also said that President Bushs meeting with the Dalai Lama last month had also damaged ties between the countries.

title: Nobodys Home, and the Old House Is Ours Again
description: MAYBE its because we crave good apple pie. Or maybe its a desire for a bit of peace and quiet. Or maybe we thirst for nature. But whatever it is, once every couple of years, my mother, my father, my brother and I pile into one of our cars and drive east on Long Island on I-495 until we reach the last exit: the North Fork.

title: Fighting Off Darkness in a New Land of Oz
description: Nearly from the first glimpse, DG, a woman-child with pigtails and a soul-squelching job as a waitress in a rural nowhere, seems like someone who would be happier almost anywhere else. She has a sketch pad and some vague artistic ambition, slouchy trousers and a voice so flat you could lay a lounge chair on it. This town, that job, taking other peoples orders, DG tells her parents like an emo-style Stella Dallas, thats just passing time.

title: Queens: Man Resentenced in Wendys Killings
description: A man whose death sentence in the fatal shooting of five people at a Wendys restaurant in Flushing was set aside last month by the states highest court was resentenced yesterday to life in prison without parole, prosecutors said. The man, John B. Taylor, had been convicted of shooting seven employees at the restaurant on May 24, 2000, after forcing them to kneel at gunpoint inside a basement refrigerator. Prosecutors said Mr. Taylor shot the people to eliminate witnesses of a robbery; two survived. The Court of Appeals had vacated his death sentence in a divided opinion that found the state death penalty statute to be unconstitutional. Yesterday, Mr. Taylor was resentenced in State Supreme Court. His co-defendant, Craig Godineaux, had already been sentenced to life without parole. Neither will ever again see the light of day, Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, said in a statement.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Favre Also Has Separated Shoulder
description: Postgame, it was revealed that Brett Favre also has a separated left shoulder, along with the injury to his right elbow (a sprain that injured a nerve in his funny bone).

title: Is Romo the Next Favre, or Is Rodgers?
description: At 11-1, the Cowboys are riding high and Tony Romo has stepped into the role of the next Brett Favre. Call it a passing of the torch, of sorts, made even more poignant by the fact that the 38-year-old Favre was banged up by Dallas.

title: Cinema Series
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Museum at Eldridge Street
description: Images from the museum on the Lower East Side.

title: 'Mamma Mia' Returns
description: After a stagehands' strike that shut down the Winter Garden  Theatre for 19 days, the cast and crew returned to put "Mamma Mia" back  onstage.

title: Todays Photography Tip
description: Found here.

title: Nowhere To Sit: The Trent Lott Porch Story
description: From 236.com, the story of departing Senator Trent Lott, Katrina victim:

title: A New Debate on Female Circumcision
description: Should African women be allowed to engage in the practice sometimes called female circumcision? Are critics of this practice, who call it female genital mutilation, justified in trying to outlaw it, or are they guilty of ignorance and cultural imperialism?

title: Kudos to the Bush administration
description: Yes, you read that right  although I need to see more detail before giving a thumbs up. But as of this morning, it seems that Henry Paulson is being much more proactive on the housing mess than I expected:

title: Turbulence Ahead for American Eagle Spin-Off?
description: While investors cheered AMRs decision Wednesday to spin off American Eagle, Reuters said that the parent of American Airlines may have trouble actually completing the deal.

title: Candover Convinces Opponents to Deliver Stork
description: Candover Partners  announced Wednesday that it had sewn up a 76 percent stake in Dutch industrial group Stork, after enlisting former opponents of its bid to join an improved 1.5 billion euro ($2.2 billion) offer.

title: Navteq Takes a Hit on EU Scrutiny of Rivals Deal
description: Shares of digital mapping company Navteq nosedived Wednesday after the European Commission served notice that it would conduct an in-depth, stage-two investigation of the takeover of Navteqs biggest competitor, Tele Atlas of the Netherlands.

title: Alliance Data Denies That Blackstone Wants to Rejigger Deal
description: Alliance Data Systems, which manages credit cards for retailers, said it hasnt been approached by Blackstone Group to renegotiate the terms of its takeover.

title: Newmont Sell $1.3 Billion of Assets to Franco-Nevada
description: As Newmont Mining prepares to spin off Franco-Nevada in an initial public offering, the worlds No. 2 gold producer on Friday said it agreed to sell its royalty assets and other non-core investments to its subsidiary, in a deal worth about $1.3 billion.

title: Six Sins of Greenwashing  a Primer
description: Just a quick note. I found an excellent overview of what to look for in a product or service if youre concerned that its environmental attributes are being oversold.

title: America loses the wireless race  again
description: I have a T-Mobile cell phone, which uses GSM technology; it works all over the world  and in parts of New Jersey. One of the parts of New Jersey where it doesnt work happens to be my own home.

title: Millbrook Capital to Nominate Four for Brinks Board
description: Millbrook Capital, the activist hedge fund seeking a breakup or sale of the Brinks Company, is expected to announce its four nominees Friday for directors of the security company, The New York Times reported.

title: Clean Tech Investments Soar
description: Clean-technology investments by U.S. venture capital firms reached $2.6 billion in the first three quarters of 2007, the highest dollar volume ever by U.S. firms and a 46 percent increase over clean tech investments for all of 2006.

title: Florida Freezes Its Fund as Governments Pull Out
description: Seeking to stem a multibillion-dollar run on an investment pool for local governments, top Florida officials voted Thursday to suspend withdrawals from the fund, leaving some towns and school districts worrying about how they would pay their bills.

title: VCs Sample Gilt Groupe
description: Fashionistas jonesing for a high-end designer fix now have a discount online dealer-if they can score an invitation.

title: China Railway Said to Raise $2.5 Billion in Hong Kong I.P.O.
description: Hot on the heels of its $3 billion initial public offering in Shanghai last week, China Railway Group, the worlds third-largest construction company, raised more than 19.22 billion Hong Kong dollars ($2.5 billion), pricing a Hong Kong share sale at the top end, Bloomberg News reported.

title: 2 Hedge Funds Flail, Even Without Subprime
description: A pair of hedge funds that are getting battered by the choppy markets of the past few months are serving as a stark reminder that the pain inflicted on the once white-hot hedge-fund sector isnt only confined to those with subprime-bond exposure, the New York Post noted.

title: Israels InSightec Raises $30 Million
description: Israeli ultrasound technology company InSightec said on Thursday it had raised $30 million in a private funding round including General Electrics venture capital unit.

title: Fridays Links: Thoughts on Creativity
description: When Im stuck for ideas, I usually hit one of my two standbys  the shower or the streets. They say that standing under running water does something to stimulate creative thought. And a good walk, or any kind of exercise, often does the same thing. But these are pretty vanilla methods, and keeping in touch with creativity is far more complex. Heres two resources to get you thinking:

title: E*Trade: Before the Citadel Deal, a Parade of Suitors
description: Before E*Trade Financial agreed to a deal with the Citadel Investment Group, the hedge fund run by Kenneth C. Griffith, a parade of almost 40 other suitors had come calling.

title: Thain May Poach NYSE C.F.O., Report Says
description: John Thain doesnt start at Merrill Lynch until Monday, but hes already poised to make a key hire from his alma mater, NYSE Euronext, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: Fortis Plans $3.7 Billion Bond Sale to Fund ABN Deal
description: Fortis, part of the group that bought ABN Amro in Europes biggest-ever banking takeover, is raising 2.5 billion euros ($3.7 billion) by selling bonds convertible into shares to help pay for the purchase.

title: Has Lampert Cut Too Much at Sears?
description: Edward S. Lampert, the billionaire financier and chairman of Sears Holdings, is fond of saying that a company must be regularly pruned, like a tree or a wardrobe. But you cant cut your way to success, he warned investors in his annual letter this year.

title: Freddie Mac Banks $6 Billion in Offering
description: Freddie Mac, the nations second-biggest mortgage-finance company, successfully sold $6 billion of preferred stock to bolster capital amid a deepening housing slump.

title: Sprint Is Said to Reject Investment Offer
description: Sprint Nextel has rejected an offer from Providence Equity Partners and SK Telecom of South Korea to replace management and invest $5 billion in the company, according to The New York Times.

title: Snubbed in Scotland: Trumps Golf Megaresort
description: Hmm. Are we sure Bill Forsyth didnt script this news? It plays a lot like Local Hero: A flamboyant American billionaire accustomed to getting his own way cooks up a grandiose development scheme for a pristine stretch of the Scottish coast, and though the locals are sorley tempted by the money, they decide to preserve what they have and thwart the developer in the last reel.

title: Design Editors Notebook | Chic Shadows
description: Top: Bands of shadow and light were a surprising design detail. Above: The color-shifting James Turrell skyspace whose L.E.D.s remake the night landscape. (Jason Schmidt for The New York Times)

title: Deal Value Falls 71 Percent Fall in November, Report Finds
description: The value of announced U.S. mergers and acquisitions fell 71 percent in November to $58.1 billion when compared to the same month last year, Reuters reported, quoting a report by Dealogic, the research firm.

title: Flowers Said to Consider Revising Northern Rock Offer
description: J.C. Flowers is willing to revise its offer for ailing British bank Northern Rock and address two concerns the British government had with its initial proposal, Reuters reported citing an unnamed source.

title: Very | Abigail Breslin
description: (Don Ashby; Arnaldo Magnani/Getty Images.)

title: Whither Lars?
description: Before the showing of Sweeney at the Lincoln Square Loews, the Bagger met up with David Poland for some food at Ollies. Its a perfect pre-movie spot because they feed you in much the same way that geese are engorged in order to produce foie gras. A funnel is inserted and you are filled to the brim within a matter of minutes. Poland and the Bagger thought about doing a Lunch with David meets Carpetbagger video , but that seemed a little too meta, so we just ate and talked movies instead.

title: Diving Bell Taking Wing
description: Awards Daily has been taking the critical temperature and thinks The Diving Bell and the Butterfly is going to be bring a lot of heat to the awards season. The Bagger has not had the pleasure and has kept his eyes crossed while reading the reviews because he has heard the movie is full of surprises and wants to keep it that way.

title: Randstad Says It May Bid for Rival Vedior
description: Randstad may offer to buy Vedior, a combination that would create the worlds second-largest staffing company by sales. Vedior had a record gain.

title: Morgan Stanley Ousts Cruz; Is More Pain Ahead?
description: Could the ouster of Morgan Stanleys co-president Zoe Cruz signal that the bank is gearing up for more mortgage pain?

title: The Early Word: Dont Take Giulianis Word
description: Surely, part of Rudolph W. Giulianis appeal is his image as a passionate superhero who saved Metropolis from the brink of economic and social despair through a mix of brains and brawn. But a presidential candidate who throws statistics around as much as Mr. Giuliani does might want to make sure that those figures are accurate, writes Michael Cooper of the New York Times.

title: Galleries Hit the Lower East Side
description: Just east and south of the New Museum of Contemporary Art's Bowery site, some two dozen galleries are open for business.

title: There Will Be Blood. Did We Mention Blood?
description: Last night, one of the Oscar seasons biggest battleships pulled in for a New York preview. Sweeney Todd played to a very appreciative crowd, which applauded both Johnny Depps singing and his deft work with a straight razor. From where the Bagger sat, which was very close to the front, it seemed as if it had been filmed entirely on location in the Red Sea, but then he faints when a knee scab comes loose.

title: Broadway Emerges From 19-Day Slumber
description: The timing of the labor settlement on Broadway meant that 30 shows had fewer than 24 hours to ramp up for performances after a 19-day strike that cost the city an estimated $2 million a day in revenues.

title: Strikes, Strikes Everywhere: A Guide to Getting around Rome
description: As those of you in Rome certainly know, this has been a week of transport strikes: Since Wednesday, the taxi drivers have been out of service. Today the subways and busses are also down, from 8:30 am to 4:30 pm. Everything is expected to return to normal by Friday evening. But in the meantime, a primer for Romes frequent transit strikes:

title: A Uniform Solution?
Edwards Slams Bush
description: IOWA CITY, Iowa  Senator John Edwards often says he wants to avoid the bickering of Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama, even as he attacks their proposals.

title: Murtha Speaks Again
description: Friday morning pop quiz. Who said this yesterday?: I think the surge is working.

title: ABCs Sequel to Dancing: More Dancing
description: ABCs hit franchise Dancing With the Stars is the envy of the broadcast networks. The reality show routinely placed No. 1 on the weekly prime time ratings charts this fall, and the season finale averaged almost 25 million viewers on Tuesday night, when Helio Castroneves, a race car driver, beat out Melanie Brown of the Spice Girls and Marie Osmond to win.

title: A Death-By-Cell-Phone Story Falls Apart
description: Ever been so annoyed at some boor yakking too loud and too long on his cellphone that you find yourself wishing the accursed thing would just blow up in his hand? (Or have you ever had someone wish that on you?) Then consider this strange tale.

title: Why Is This Man Smiling?
description: He may not have won a board seat at Motorola, but Carl Icahn seems to have gotten a consolation prize. Some might even call it revenge.

title: Stray Questions for: Ben Fong-Torres
description: Ben Fong-Torress books include the essay collection Becoming Almost Famous: My Back Pages in Music, Writing and Life and a memoir called The Rice Room: Growing Up Chinese-American. His most recent book is The Doors by The Doors.

title: Eau de Chien? Yes, Fragrances for Dogs
description: If you want to spruce your dog up for the office, there are an ever-increasing number of grooming products to make your pet more palatable for the workplace, now including  dog perfume.

title: Strike News: Both Sides Dig In
description: Striking screenwriters on Thursday night dismissed a new set of proposals from producers as a massive rollback, and called on their members to continue their walkout with fresh resolve despite a plan to continue talks on Tuesday, Michael Cieply reports.

title: Ratings: Tila Tequila Closing In On SpongeBob SquarePants
description: A bisexual-themed dating reality show hosted by the Internet celebrity Tila Tequila has become the second most popular series on MTV, according to the latest Nielsen Media Research numbers.

title: Friday Kickoff: Is a Pro Coach Worth It?
description: Its not easy for an N.F.L. coach to succeed in college. John McClain of the Houston Chronicle details some of the high-profile coaches with professional experience who have flopped recently on campus.

title: Future Remains Bright for Oregons Dixon
description: One of the most gut-wrenching storylines of this college football season has been the downfall of Oregon quarterback Dennis Dixon. With one twist of a knee, he went from being a favorite for the Heisman Trophy and having his team on track for the national title to being out for the season with an uncertain football future. The reality is especially tough because Dixon risked further injury by playing with a torn anterior cruciate ligament.

title: Hawaii Focuses on the Task at Hand
description: While Hawaiis games are usually last-call fodder for folks on the East Coast, theyre really evening games in Honolulu. That gives the Hawaii team all day on Saturday to digest and analyze games around the country as they await kickoff.

title: Ex-Bear Stearns Representative Pleads Guilty to Insider Trading
description: A former registered representative at Bear Stearns pleaded guilty on Friday for his role in what authorities had called one of the most pervasive insider trading rings since the 1980s.

title: Behind the Scenes at a Beehive on Broadway
description: Reporters fanned out to theaters last night to observe the reopening of Broadway. Here are notes from Hairspray the Musical.

title: Best of the Best
description: FIFA annouced the finalists Friday for the World Player of the Year honor. Three men and three women will contend for the awards and, not surprisingly, half of them are Brazilian.

title: Clarence Thomass Case for Shutting Up
description: Aside from the occasional thrashing, Justice Clarence Thomas of the Supreme Court has mostly kept his thoughts during oral arguments to himself. Hes also kept his reasons for staying quiet to himself  after all, hes not called The Justice Nobody Knows for nothing.

title: Meet Coach Rod
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va.  College football fans across the United States about to get to know West Virginia Coach Rich Rodriguez a lot better. And boy, are they going to like him. Rodriguez could win a charm-off with just about any coach in America this side of Bobby Bowden. (If Ohio State goes to the national title game, Jim Tressel would be a six-touchdown underdog to win any of the news conferences.) Coach Rod, as hes know in these parts, has a folksy twang, uses the word aint liberally and isnt afraid to make a joke or two.

title: Obama and Bloombergs Breakfast Date
description: Just as developments in the real presidential race threaten to overshadow Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs status as the $1 billion question mark hovering over the contest, comes this: a showy breakfast meeting with Senator Barack Obama at a midtown coffee shop earlier today.

title: Page Two
description: The Baguette also caught up with Ellen Page, the diminutive star of Juno who won the award for breakthrough actor at the Gothams. We thought it might be good to check in on a girl we will be seeing a lot of in the next few months.

title: Indie Redux
description: There was a lot of debate at the Gothams the other night about the definition and application of the word independent, so the Baguette asked Sidney Lumet, the director of Before the Devil Knows Youre Dead and winner in the ensemble category, what he thinks qualifies. I dont think anythings truly independent anymore, he said.

title: 50 Sense
description: Ever wonder who the smartest 50 people in Hollywood are? The Bagger hasnt either, but he still read EWs list with a quickness. Judd Apatow topped the list, and its hard to argue with somebody who has cracked the code on making good movies that people actually pay money to see. But the Bagger visited Mr. Apatow a while back in his nothing-special Santa Monica office and he can say with certainty that Mr. Apatow is a little on the normal side to be on the top of any list of big cigars.

title: A Cameo Interview
description: The Reeler talks with Max von Sydow, who makes a brief appearance in The Diving Bell and the Butterfly as the father of Jean-Dominique Bauby, the Elle magazine editor who became locked in his own body and built a route back to the world. Mr. von Sydow said the reason he doesnt work much anymore is not his age  78  but because a lot of the scripts that come his way, um, suck.

title: When Stem Cell Research Gets Personal
description: The report last week that scientists had turned human skin cells into embryonic stem cells without having to make or destroy an embryo has a couple of heavy-hitter pundits with strong personal interests in such issues to square off. Even a scientist who cares not a whit about the morality of embryo destruction will adopt this technique because it is so simple and powerful, writes Charles Krauthammer, who has been confined to a wheelchair by a spinal cord injury for most of his adult life, in The Washington Post.

title: Clinton Campaign Calls Obama Health Care Ad Misleading
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons presidential campaign, which is now attacking Senator Barack Obama on a daily basis, this morning called on the Obama campaign to stop running a campaign television commercial in New Hampshire that asserts that his health insurance plan will cover all Americans.

title: Luxe In Translation | Hindi
description: T presents a series of essential foreign phrases. The first lesson is for weary travelers who find themselves in New Delhi, where the herbal oils used in even five-star ayurvedic massages can sometimes pack a wallop to rival a vindaloo.

title: On Comet! On Cupid! With Santa, on Banjo!
description: Video

description: Photographers jockey for space as Barack Obama and Michael R.  Bloomberg met at a Midtown diner this morning.(Video: WNBC-TV)

title: Facebook: What Would Google Do?
description: From its spare white layout to its audacious growth plans, a lot of Facebooks moves seem copied from Googles playbook. But as I look at the spurt of Facebook news this week, it leaves me wondering how Google would have handled the same situations.

title: An Air of Expectation
description: Tim Burton was jittery when the Baguette interviewed him recently but who could blame him? Hes got both a movie  Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street, and a baby  with Helena Bonham Carter  making an appearance in the world about the same time. Im a bit nervous about both I guess, Mr. Burton said.Ms. Carter co-stars in Sweeney as Mrs. Lovett, and Sacha Baron Cohen plays looney rival barber Signor Adolfo Pirelli. The Baguette asked Mr. Burton about casting non-singers in the title roles of the film.It gives the film, I think an extra layer of something that you dont necessarily get from the stage, which led the Baguette to ask about the casting of Mr. Cohen, who inhabited a similarly over-the-top persona as Borat.Sacha, hes great! Ill never forget it, he came in to audition and he had the book for Fiddler on the Roof and basically did pretty much the whole song book, Mr. Burton said. I knew he could do it. He has no fear.Mr. Burtons most palpable fears involved Stephen Sondheims reaction to his film. I was so nervous. I think I was more nervous showing it to him than anybody.Before they showed the movie to Mr. Sondheim he told the producers, You show him the movie. Ill be down at the pub down the street. Mr. Burton said he was relieved that Mr. Sondheim liked the film. He was extremely positive.As the Bagger mentioned, the movie has a rather crimson palette.We tried to use a bright color red, you know, because its Christmas.

title: Stealthy Virtues
description: Could it be that the best way to campaign for an Oscar is not to campaign? The Hollywood Reporter suggests that Focus Features has decided the best way to make sure Atonement gets a fair shake is to keep its pie-hole closed.

title: To Save the Polar Bears, Ride a Cub
description: Beyond being the quickest way to telegraph to fellow highway travelers that you enjoy macrobiotic salads and care about the environment, the Toyota Prius gets pretty good gas mileage. But its still not as good as the E.P.A. would have you believe.

title: Obama and Bloomberg Have Breakfast
description: Just as developments in the real presidential race threaten to overshadow Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs status as the $1 billion question mark hovering over the contest, comes this: a showy breakfast meeting with Senator Barack Obama at a Midtown coffee shop earlier today.

title: Through Two Rounds of the World Cup, a Big Upset and a Heartbreaking Loss
Please Explain
description: Paul and I are planning our next trip to Anna Maria. Were going to be there for an entire week, from Dec. 8 to 15, to make another round of decisions that can only really be done on site. For this trip weve rented a house. Also, some of our family  my brother and his wife, and my father and stepmother  will be joining us.

title: Weekly Pick Em: The Conference Title Games
description: So it comes down to this. Pete and Thayer are locked in a fierce competition to see who will end the season with the best record. Meanwhile, Im trailing far behind, sort of like Vanderbilt in the SEC. Oh well, I can always redeem myself during the bowl season. Or not. Still, this weekend promises to be another entertaining one, with plenty of games with national implications. Disagree with any of the picks? Feel free to let us know.

description: Are potential suitors burning up the phone lines at Sprint Nextel? At least one analyst doesnt think so, and investors seem to have their doubts as well.

title: East to Meet West
description: Sidney Crosbys Penguins will play Joe Thorntons Sharks next season. Guaranteed. The N.H.L. Board of Governors made that happen, voting Thursday to scale back the eight games of in-division contests to six, and ensuring that every team plays every other team in the league at least once.

title: Is the Exaflood Coming?
description: YouTube and its bit-hungry brethren of video, music and social-networking Web sites are surely consuming more of the Internets bandwidth. But are we facing a capacity crunch that will soon clog the global network, as it is overwhelmed by what some warn is a coming exaflood of demand?

title: Weekly Matchups: The Final Saturday
description: The last Saturday of the college football season is always filled with intrigue and this one is no different. Allow me to break this down for you and let you know what youre in for. Lets see, depending on how hard-core you are, you could peek in at the MAC Championship game at 11, but I imagine most of you will start with a look in at Army-Navy at noon. That one segues nicely into the A.C.C. title game at 1, which is about when you should be starting to hit your college football-viewing stride.

title: Ratings: Reruns Return and Reality Emerges
description: With the November sweeps period over, the reruns have returned, and along with them, ratings for the leading networks on Thursday, ABC and CBS, plummeted accordingly. NBC and Fox, meanwhile, failed to make up much of any ground.

description: Early risers in the Western Hemisphere on Sunday will be able to watch the draw for next summers European Championships live on ESPN across a number of its media platforms.

title: WNBC Takes Chance on Liquor Ads
description: Almost six years after NBC ended an experiment to bring the first liquor commercials onto national broadcast network television, the flagship station it owns, WNBC-TV in New York, has started running such spots, Stuart Elliott reports.

Paired up with fellow-rookie Eric Wright, the Browns may be well set at cornerback for years to come.

description: Be it a work of fashion, art or home design, in an era of hyper-vigilant P.R., a designers inspirations arent nearly as fun  or accurate  as guessing at them. Here, in The Moments The Style Equation column, we use a rudimentary calculation to reduce a new design object to the sum of its parts. First up, the new Stella McCartney ruck sack.

title: Mets Trade Milledge to Nationals
description: The news: Omar Minaya & Co. pulled off an interesting trade today, acquiring catcher Brian Schneider and outfielder Ryan Church from Washington in exchange for Lastings Milledge. Minaya is familiar with both players from his days as the Expos GM, trading for Church in 2004.

description: Despite E*Trade Financials proclamation that its $2.55 billion deal with Citadel Investment Group should ease fears about its financial health, it appears few are listening.

Previous sets of answers from Dr. Corrigan were posted on Wednesday and Thursday.

I asked why he thought lots of users would want to have information about their purchases sent to their Facebook friends through the companys new system called Beacon.

title: D.N.C. Fall Meeting Ends on Difficult Note
description: VIENNA, Va.  Worry and disappointment weighed heavy in the ballroom of the Sheraton Premiere hotel during the afternoon session of the Democratic National Committee fall meeting after Chairman Howard Dean announced that Hillary Rodham Clinton had cancelled her speech because of the hostage situation at her campaign office in Rochester, N.H.

title: Clinton Office Standoff Ends
description: 6:53 p.m. Less than an hour after the standoff ended, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton emerged from her home in Washington to make a statement and answer a few questions about the situation.

title: Wheres the Party?
Q & A: David Downton
description: I first met David Downton maybe five years ago at a showing of his drawings in Paris. His subject was Erin OConnor. You might say David, who is English, has an obsession with Erins long neck and lines. Well, she was meant for charcoal. Shortly after that meeting, I asked him to sketch a Dior couture dress in the studio, for a story about the making of a collection. Our link then and now was our admiration for the work of Joe Eula, and a fascination with the man. I got to know Joe well and in the last years of his life we worked together on a number of illustrated articles for the Times, including one about the denizens of the back track at Belmont. This past January, at the Dior show, David told me he was planning to bring out a magazine of fashion illustration and asked if Id write something about Joe. Issue #1 of Pourquoi Pas? has drawings by Rene Gruau, Eula, Richard Gray, Jason Brooks, with illustrations by David of Amanda Harlech, Jade Parfitt, and Carmen Dell Orefice. Among the writers contributing are Sarah Mower, Tony Glenville and Tim Blanks. The 72-page magazine is on heavy stock, costs about $40, and is available at pqpmagazine.com. David and I chatted by phone a few days ago.

title: Kefi on the Move
description: The casual Greek restaurant Kefi, a big hit on West 79th Street, wont stay there too long. In a telephone conversation I had today with its chef-owner, Michael Psilakis, he told me that he is definitely  no question about it  moving the restaurant into a much bigger space next year. He guessed that this would happen sometime around the middle of the year.

description: The most important economic statistic this week is one that appears to be months old. It is the revision of the governments estimate of wage and salary income in the second quarter.
